headline: TARP Bailout to Cost Less Than Once Anticipated
text: WASHINGTON  Even as voters rage and candidates put up ads against government bailouts, the reviled mother of them all  the $700 billion lifeline to banks, insurance and auto companies  will expire after Sunday at a fraction of that cost, and could conceivably earn taxpayers a profit.

headline: Owner Killed After Dog Leashes Are Tangled
text: The dispute began early Thursday over two dogs, a miniature pinscher named Rocco and a Shih Tzu, Bugsy, one tied too closely to the other outside a bar in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn.

headline: Standoff in Ecuador Ends With Leader’s Rescue
text: CARACAS, Venezuela  Ecuadorean soldiers stormed a police hospital Thursday night in Quito where President Rafael Correa was held by rebellious elements of the police forces, and rescued him amid an exchange of gunfire in an effort to end a tense standoff between Mr. Correa and hundreds of protesting police officers and military personnel.

headline: 50 Years Later, a Slide Still Confounds
text: The play  a pivotal moment in Game 7 of the 1960 World Series  demanded expert analysis.

headline: Mastering Martial Arts
text: Wilson Yip’s “Ip Man,” a biopic with a distant relationship to the actual life of the Chinese martial arts master of the title (whose students included Bruce Lee), is a proletarian kung fu movie. First seen living the bourgeois good life in southern China in the 1930s, Ip (Donnie Yen) achieves heroic status only after war forces him to resort to manual labor and leads him to teach a factory’s workers how to defend themselves against bandits.

headline: At Yahoo, Top U.S. Executive Is Latest to Leave
text: Yahoo’s top executive for the United States market is leaving the company along with other senior employees, adding to the management exodus at the Web portal.

headline: Intertwining Love and Obsession
text: Do they have date movies in China? Probably, and “Hot Summer Days,” an enjoyable concoction of loosely intertwined stories of love and obsession, is just right for that purpose. The film, by Tony Chan and Wing Shya, is intricate without being taxing and does just what you want a date movie to do: generate high hopes about the exhilarating, sometimes painful adventure that is love.

headline: John Boehner on Congressional Reform
text: An excerpt from a speech that the House Minority Leader gave at the American Enterprise Institute on the subject of congressional reform.

headline: Three Men Behaving (Really) Badly
text: A tired mash-up of every men-behaving-badly sitcom ever to grace a third-tier television network, “Speed-Dating” tries to coax laughs from characters so dated even Eddie Murphy would balk.

headline: A Tax Break for Replacing Bad Drywall
text: The Internal Revenue Service said Thursday that it would allow taxpayers with defective drywall in their houses to deduct the cost of repairs and replacement of damaged appliances.

headline: Before a Suicide, Hints in Online Musings
text: The young man writing on the gay chat site was torn: he had discovered that his college roommate had spied on him from another room with a webcam as he kissed a male friend. Should he complain to the school? Would officials assign him someone worse? Or would he simply risk angering the roommate?

headline: Cautious Stock Positions May Be Overdone
text: The annual investment updates from America’s great university endowments add to evidence that investors have fallen out of love with public equities. After a decade of zero returns, this is understandable. But with stocks cheap and bonds stretched, investors may rue this underweight position.

headline: An Homage to Slasher-Movie History
text: Picking up exactly where its 2007 predecessor left off, “Hatchet II,” Adam Green’s latest homage to slasher-movie history, returns us to the Louisiana marshlands and the murderous vendetta of the swamp-dwelling mutant Victor Crowley (Kane Hodder).

headline: Dollar Thrifty Shareholders Vote Against Hertz Bid, Leaving Avis Standing
text: Shareholders of the Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group rejected on Thursday a $1.46 billion takeover offer from Hertz Global Holdings, which then followed through on its promise to give up on the acquisition if its bid was not approved.

headline: Anderson Cooper Will Host a Daytime Talk Show
text: Starting next fall, the television anchor Anderson Cooper will divide his time between his hard-nosed nightly newscast on CNN and a light-hearted daytime talk show on local television stations.

headline: Ryan Enlists Another Raven to Help the Jets
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  In the world according to defensive lineman Trevor Pryce, certain truths are so obvious they remain unsaid. One such statement, Pryce revealed on Thursday, is “water is good for you.”

headline: Questions on Ex-Housekeeper Emerge for a Candidate
text: LOS ANGELES  In many ways, it had the makings of the kind of classic late-campaign political dust-up that happens so regularly in high-profile California campaigns: the celebrity lawyer, the illegal immigrant, a welter of conflicting allegations and conspiracy charges, a candidate willing to take a lie-detector test and the scene of reporters clustered in a swanky lawyer’s office overlooking the Hollywood Hills. News conferences were streamed live on TMZ.com, the scandal-chasing Hollywood Web site that has become a force in politics and celebrity in this town.

headline: A Candidate Tugs Unabashedly on the Heartstrings
text: MIAMI — Marco Rubio’s latest television ad features soaring music and tributes in Spanish to what he describes in speeches as the “go-getter” ethos that defines his family and the United States.

headline: Ireland, Hoping to Calm Investors, Takes Over a 2nd Troubled Bank
text: LONDON  The Irish government said on Thursday that it expected to inject billions more euros into two of the largest banks in the country, underscoring the extent to which they continued to jeopardize Ireland’s economic condition.

headline: World Series Game 3 Gets Earlier Start
text: Game 3 of the World Series will start at 6:57 p.m. Eastern, in an attempt to boost viewership that Saturday night among young fans watching on Fox.

headline: Making Math Lessons as Easy as 1, Pause, 2, Pause ...
text: FRANKLIN LAKES, N.J.  By the time they get to kindergarten, children in this well-to-do suburb already know their numbers, so their teachers worried that a new math program was too easy when it covered just 1 and 2  for a whole week.

headline: Foreclosures Slow as Document Flaws Emerge
text: The foreclosure machinery that has forced millions of Americans out of their homes is beginning to seize up as some lenders and their lawyers are accused of cutting corners in their pursuit of rapid home repossessions.

headline: The Elizabeth Warren Fallacy
text: Lest anyone forget, the full title of the landmark financial reform legislation that President Obama signed into law on July 21 is the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act. While Wall Street certainly needs some reform, do we really need more consumer protection?

headline: In New York, Standing by Men, Not Governing Beside Them
text: An honored political tradition was upheld the other day when Rick A. Lazio offered himself for a judgeship that he neither wants nor has a snowball’s chance in Singapore of winning. His wife stood beside him as he announced his plans.

headline: As N.C.A.A. Gets Tough, Coaches Take Notice
text: SOUTHBOROUGH, Mass.  Last week, dozens of college coaches from elite programs like Kansas, Duke and Texas rolled into this small town.

headline: Son of Dead Sea Scrolls Expert Is Convicted
text: The son of a prominent professor at the University of Chicago was convicted on Thursday of impersonating a New York University professor and other scholars who disagreed with his father’s theories on the origin of the Dead Sea Scrolls.

headline: NASA Gets New Orders That Bypass the Moon
text: NASA, best known as the agency that put the first man on the moon, is about to end its moon program for the foreseeable future.

headline: Patents Ending, Eli Lilly Chases New Drugs
text: INDIANAPOLIS  John C. Lechleiter walks a mile to work every morning to think about the day ahead. He walks home in the evening, he says, “to try to forget about it.”

headline: G.O.P. Stays on Upswing in Senate Forecast
text: Republican chances of taking over the Senate have improved again in this week’s forecast. They are now 22 percent — up from 18 percent last week and 15 percent two weeks ago. Republican chances are now approaching the point where they stood before the Delaware primary, when they had peaked at 26 percent before Christine O’Donnell’s victory.

headline: Hindus and Muslims to Share Holy Site
text: An Indian court ruled Thursday that a disputed holy site in Ayodhya, India, be divided between Hindus and Muslims.

headline: Insurer Cuts Health Plans as New Law Takes Hold
text: The Principal Financial Group announced on Thursday that it planned to stop selling health insurance, another sign of upheaval emerging among insurers as the new federal health law starts to take effect.

headline: Affirmative Action for the Rich, Part II
text: We’ve been having a spirited discussion on The Choice all week on Richard D. Kahlenberg’s book “Affirmative Action for the Rich,” which examines legacy admissions and advocates dismantling such practices. Mr. Kahlenberg, the book’s editor, weighs in on the subject on the Op-Ed Page of today’s Times, specifically on the ethics and legality of legacy preferences, as my colleague Rebecca R. Ruiz describes below. — Jacques Steinberg

headline: Magazine Association Renames Itself
text: THE trade association for the consumer magazine industry is joining other organizations in media and marketing in rebranding itself to better reflect the realities of competing for consumer eyeballs and advertising dollars in the 21st century.

headline: Filling an Aide’s Shoes With Very Different Feet
text: WASHINGTON  Pete Rouse is the anti-Rahm.

headline: It’s the Big Leagues Now, Rahm.
text: CHICAGO — For the rest of the country, Rahm Emanuel’s departure from the White House will probably be viewed as an announcement that he is moving on, heading home to run the City of Chicago. Case closed. But here — in a city bulging with candidates to replace Mayor Richard M. Daley — Mr. Emanuel’s decision to run for mayor was received as anything but a guarantee that he will glide into the job.

headline: Magazine Media Minute
text: Magazine Media Minute, an initiative to promote the value of magazines from the Association of Magazine Media. The videos will appear in a channel on YouTube.

headline: The Times Names Editor for Magazine
text: The New York Times has named the executive editor of Bloomberg Businessweek, Hugo Lindgren, as the next editor of The New York Times Magazine.

headline: Novartis Settles Off-Label Marketing Case Over 6 Drugs for $422.5 Million
text: The Swiss drug giant Novartis is paying $422.5 million to settle criminal and civil investigations into the marketing of the antiseizure medicine Trileptal and five other drugs, federal officials said on Thursday.

headline: Pepsi Refresh Contestant Claims Rules Were Broken
text: A group battling childhood cancer has filed a complaint against Pepsi, contending that its popular charity fund-raising contest, Pepsi Refresh, has been infiltrated by organizations with a political agenda.

headline: Knicks Practice in City That Made Coach’s Career
text: MILAN  Mike D’Antoni owes his fame, his family and his career to this city. This is where he became a star point guard and a decorated coach and met his wife, Laurel. It all could have changed with one impulsive decision.

headline: Lottery Numbers
For Some Germans, Unity Is Still Work in Progress
text: ERFURT, Germany  The air here used to stink from the low-grade coal people burned for heat. That is easy to forget 20 years after East and West reunited and well more than a trillion dollars has been spent to prop up and rebuild the dilapidated region that was the German Democratic Republic.

headline: A.I.G. Chief Says Repayment Plan Shows Firm’s Strength
text: The American International Group‘s plan to eventually repay its government-financed bailout is meant to show how far the insurer has come since its near-failure two years ago, the company’s chief executive said on Thursday.

headline: Ex-Dean Accused of Using Students as Servants
text: A former administrator at St. John’s University accused of embezzling about $1 million from the college in Queens has now been charged with far more lurid crimes: forcing students to clean, cook and act as her personal servants to keep their scholarships.

headline: Mixing Justice and Politics
text: To the Editor:

headline: Morneau Hopes to Return if Twins Reach A.L.C.S.
text: MINNEAPOLIS  In an attempt to return for the postseason, Minnesota Twins first baseman Justin Morneau  out since July 7 with a concussion  took early batting practice at Target Field on Thursday, his first on-field swings in more than a month.

headline: Dispute Over U.N. Report Evokes Rwandan Déjà Vu
text: When drafts of a United Nations study recently surfaced accusing Rwandan forces of committing atrocities against Hutu refugees in Congo in the 1990s  crimes that could constitute acts of genocide  the Rwandan government protested vociferously. It even threatened to withdraw its peacekeepers from Sudan and elsewhere if the report was published.

headline: Parcells May Be in the Market for a New Job
Memorable 10/1/75 Event
text: SHE walks in beauty, like the nightOf cloudless climes and starry skies;And all that ‘s best of dark and brightMeet in her aspect and her eyes— Byron

headline: U.N. Says Global Employment Needs 5 Years to Rebound
text: UNITED NATIONS  It will take five more years before employment around the world rebounds to the point it was before the financial crisis, two years longer than previously predicted, the International Labor Organization said in its annual jobs report on Thursday.

headline: Group Awaits Contact by City in Abuse Case
text: Nearly a month after a 4-year-old girl who weighed just 18 pounds was found dead in her family’s Brooklyn apartment, New York City’s child welfare agency has yet to contact the nonprofit group it briefly contracted to monitor the girl’s case, a group official said Thursday.

headline: Stoking a Fiery Passion for Art
text: The debating never stops for the title characters of “The Pitmen Painters,” Lee Hall’s feisty adult education class — I mean history play — about a group of aesthetically adventurous miners in Northern England. These are among the questions posed, and answered and considered and fought over, many times. (By all means, feel free to take out a pencil and jot down your own responses):

headline: A Case for the Classics, Chapter by Chapter
text: A.R. Gurney resurrects the culture clash over dead white males in his latest play, “Office Hours,” a wispy but congenial comedy structured as a series of tutorials tied to classical literature’s greatest hits. The play, which opened on Thursday night at the Flea Theater in a production directed by Jim Simpson, makes a gentle plea for the enduring worth of Homer, Dante, Shakespeare and the rest of the dear, derided DWMs as writers whose works illuminate everlasting problems of human life, even the lives of disgruntled feminists and deranged veterans of the Vietnam War.

headline: Paladino and Anger: How Much Is Too Much?
text: Over the course of Carl P. Paladino’s improbable journey from Buffalo business executive to Republican nominee for governor of New York, his anger  at politicians, at taxes, at Manhattan traffic  has defined and sustained him, driving his challenge to the Albany powers-that-be and drawing beneath his banner New Yorkers who share his outrage.

headline: Wood Back in Playoffs as a Different Pitcher in a New Town
text: TORONTO  Any baseball fan worth his or her Cracker Jack can recite the essentials from Game 6 of the 2003 National League Championship Series  Mark Prior shone, Steve Bartman intervened, Alex Gonzalez erred, Cubs lost, Marlins won. But what about from Game 7? Over time, those details may blur. So consider this a quick refresher: Kerry Wood hit a two-run homer. And gave up seven runs in five and two-thirds innings.

headline: Blue Haiti
text: LOOKING out the window as the plane descended, I saw that Haiti had changed color. The familiar earthy brown tones of the mountains surrounding Port-au-Prince were no longer visible; instead, everything I could see was deep blue  the color of the thousands of tarpaulins covering the landscape.

headline: A Rush to Legislate, and to Maneuver
text: WASHINGTON  It was a wild finish on Capitol Hill just after midnight Thursday as lawmakers approved a stopgap spending measure, authorized NASA space programs and, for the first time in several years, managed to adopt the annual intelligence policy bill. Then, they raced home to preserve their own jobs.

headline: Paladino and Columnist: A Couple of Teddy Bears
text: The fiery confrontation between the Republican candidate for governor, Carl P. Paladino, and the New York Post columnist Fredric U. Dicker transfixed YouTube viewers on Thursday, with the video of the altercation being watched more than 20,000 times.

headline: Taking On China
text: Serious people were appalled by Wednesday’s vote in the House of Representatives, where a huge bipartisan majority approved legislation, sponsored by Representative Sander Levin, that would potentially pave the way for sanctions against China over its currency policy. As a substantive matter, the bill was very mild; nonetheless, there were dire warnings of trade war and global economic disruption. Better, said respectable opinion, to pursue quiet diplomacy.

headline: ‘I Want to Know Why You Sent Your Goons After My Daughter’
text: Carl P. Paladino, the Republican nominee for governor, and Fredric U. Dicker, a political editor and reporter for The New York Post, got into a loud argument on Wednesday over claims of infidelity that Mr. Paladino made about his Democratic opponent, Andrew M. Cuomo. The exchange got so heated that Mr. Paladino’s campaign manager, Michael R. Caputo, stepped in between the two. Following are excerpts from a video recording of the encounter, at a hotel in Bolton Landing, N.Y.

headline: Dickey Has Fine Season At Plate, Too
text: Unless R. A. Dickey makes a surprise pinch-hitting appearance for the Mets over the final weekend of the season, he will end his year with a batting average almost 145 points below his career average. But that is fine with Dickey, considering he had only five at-bats (with two singles) in four previous seasons in the majors.

headline: Rifts Show at Hearing on For-Profit Colleges
text: Senator John McCain did not spend long on Thursday at a committee hearing in Washington about for-profit colleges.

headline: With Standards Tightened, Far Fewer New York City Schools Receive a Grade of ‘A’
text: The number of New York City public schools earning an A on the city’s A-to-F school report cards has plunged, according to results released on Thursday, as schools began to feel the impact of the state’s decision to make its standardized English and math exams tougher to pass.

headline: Ricketts Joins the Big Leagues With Earmarks Crusade
text: J. Joseph Ricketts, the Ameritrade founder and an owner of the Chicago Cubs, is moving into the political big leagues.

headline: Tribulations of a Gay Priest
text: A bleak prison drama from the English team of Darren Flaxstone and Christian Martin, “Release” recounts the tribulations of a gay priest who has been incarcerated for what we are primed to believe is pedophilia.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: The Austerity Caucus
text: Silicon Valley, Calif.

headline: A Message for China
text: China and President Obama have a lot to think about after the House voted, overwhelmingly, on Wednesday to give the Obama administration expanded authority to impose tariffs on nearly all Chinese imports.

headline: All They Need Is a Miracle
text: I watched most of the San Diego Padres’ game on television Thursday. I had to. In a weird way, I felt like I owed it to them.

headline: Autocomplete the Candidates
text: Begin typing into a Google search box and you will quickly see a list of suggested searches. Google describes this feature, known as autocomplete, as “a reflection of the search activity of all Web users.” For example, typing the name of a Senate candidate usually reveals “for senate” or “wiki” as the top item in the list. But not always. Below, the first suggestions that appeared this week for some candidates.

headline: At Hearing, a Dispute Over Banking Provision in Reform Law
text: WASHINGTON  The unity of regulators who have to put the Dodd-Frank financial reform law into effect was put to the test at a Congressional hearing Thursday as squabbling emerged over a provision affecting lenders.

headline: If He Can’t Take the Heat
text: Carl Paladino, New York’s Republican candidate for governor, likes to portray himself as the political tough guy, the one, as he declared, who can “take a baseball bat to Albany.” Now it appears as though the man who so enjoys dishing it out can’t even take a tough grilling from an irritating reporter.

headline: Limits Emerge for a New Bureau Without a Director
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is starting to set up the new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, but relief for consumers befuddled by the complex disclosures that accompany credit cards, auto loans and mortgages will not come about right away.

headline: City Hall Opens Its Doors to Dance
text: Since being rebuilt in 1915, San Francisco City Hall has been the site of many dramatic scenes.

headline: Shots From the Underground
text: A strange hybrid of personal journey, half-baked documentary and cleverly executed tease, “S&Man” (pronounced “Sandman”) gets up close and personal with three of the more extreme makers of underground horror and fetish films. Only two appear as themselves, but you’ll have to wait for the end credits to learn which; suffice to say that the actor portraying the third was unsettling enough to make me wonder why his character — if he exists at all — was still at large.

headline: No Defense
text: In Boston last week, Judge William Young ordered the Justice Department to pay $5,000 each to the families of Debra Davis and Deborah Hussey. He said that the department’s lawyers had bullied and maligned the families. This is only the latest humiliation from the F.B.I.’s continuous effort to cover up the crimes of two favored informants, James “Whitey” Bulger and Stephen “the Rifleman” Flemmi.

headline: San Francisco District Attorney Is Tireless in State Campaign
text: LOS ANGELES  The lively gospel singing had barely died down at the First African Methodist Episcopal Church on Sunday when the 800-strong congregation welcomed to the pulpit Kamala D. Harris.

headline: In the Habitable Zone
text: A planet orbiting a star causes a slight disturbance in the star’s rotation, the effect of the gravitational tug between the star and the planet. Astronomers have been studying the wobbling of stars for a couple of decades, in hopes of finding an exoplanet  a planet beyond our solar system  that might offer the possibility of sustaining human life. Now, after 11 years of searching with specialized instruments in Chile and Hawaii, a team of American astronomers has announced in the Astrophysical Journal that it has found the first likely candidate.

headline: The Afghan Election, as Seen by Karzai’s Brother
text: To the Editor:

headline: Candidate in Oakland Bucks Tide on Measure
text: Greg Harland, a retired businessman, acknowledged he was nervous before last week’s debate for Oakland mayoral hopefuls.

headline: Former A.T.F. Directors and Agents Oppose Gun Bill
text: To the Editor:

headline: Where Manual Labor Is the Price of Academic Excellence
text: Scott James is a columnist for The Bay Citizen.

headline: A Webcam in a Dorm Room, and a Life Cut Short
text: To the Editor:

headline: Learning From Brockton High School
text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: Obama Back Hauling Campaign Cash
text: Another day, another million dollars or maybe two. Back from a three-day campaign swing, President Obama continued his electioneering on Thursday night with a pair of Democratic National Committee fundraisers in Washington.

headline: A Romance of Mistaken Identity
text: Somewhere, there’s a sparkling gay romance waiting to conquer the mainstream. Alas, “Is It Just Me?,” for all its good intentions, isn’t it. Though the film, competently acted and shot on bare financial means, laudably upends perceptions of the gay dating scene, disdaining nightclub hedonism for committed relationships, it fails to ignite.

headline: Residents Worry About Post-Daley Budgets and Public Services
text: As Mayor Richard M. Daley prepares to leave office, some of his most loyal supporters are upset about the financial troubles he will leave behind and worried that the city services they have come to expect are in rapid decline.

headline: Debt Weighs Heavily on Burris, Friends Say
text: The bill is about to come due on Roland W. Burris’s short stint as a United States senator, and close friends and advisers say that the debt he has racked up in legal bills and other expenses is taking a toll on him personally.

headline: As Cubs Ponder, Quade Just Keeps Being Real
text: The modest office at Wrigley Field doesn’t look lived in, doesn’t bear the personal stamp of its occupant, whose stay might be temporary. But it’s a comfortable upgrade from the cramped quarters he shared with six fellow coaches down the hall.

headline: Looking for a Leader, and Finding Stereotypes Instead
text: James Warren us a columnist for the Chicago News  Cooperative

headline: Pregame Huddle: Stanford Makes Its Mark
text: The Stanford-Oregon game has turned into one of the marquee matchups this weekend, but the top billing still belongs to Alabama-Florida.

headline: The BP-Spill Baby-Turtle Brigade
text: Loggerhead nesting season started this year, as usual, in May. Across the northeastern coast of the Gulf of Mexico, female sea turtles began plodding out of the water and up the beach, each burying a clutch of a hundred or more leathery eggs beneath the sand. The eggs incubate for about 60 days. Then a throng of tiny black loggerhead hatchlings, each only about two inches long, frantically boils out of the ground, all paddling clumsily with their outsize, winglike flippers. They scuttle down the beach en masse, capitalizing on a one-time frenzy of energy to rush into the water and push past the breakers into offshore currents. Once they make it there — if they make it there — they typically find their way onto mats of seaweed called sargassum. The hatchlings will drift passively around the ocean on this sargassum for the first several years of their lives, like children inner-tubing in a swimming pool. It’s a life raft from which, conveniently, they can also pluck snacks. Many turtles wind up gliding around the Florida peninsula and floating as far out as the Azores during a developmental stage biologists call “the lost years.”

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,292 American service members who have died as part of the Afghan war and related operations. It recently confirmed the death of the following American:

headline: It’s All About a Dishonest Day’s Work
text: IN “The Asphalt Jungle,” a 1950 noir by John Huston that is credited with creating the template for the heist film, a duplicitous lawyer observes that “crime is only a left-handed form of human endeavor.” The idea of crime as a line of work — hardly an honest one, but a job all the same, requiring an investment of skill and labor — is central to this most process-oriented of cinematic genres.

headline: Word of the Day | compelling
text: compelling •\kəm-ˈpe-liN\• adjective

headline: Alien Nation
text: “There have been as many plagues as wars in history,” notes the central character in Albert Camus’s novel “The Plague,” “yet always plagues and wars take people equally by surprise.” The surprise is in the epidemic’s egalitarian choice of victims, in the unraveling of civic order and in the discovery that a just God may not be so just after all. This is why an epidemic makes such a great backdrop for a novel.

headline: Manhattan Real Estate Market Seems to Stabilize, With Prices Up and Sales Volume Down
text: After two years of unpredictable sales trends, the Manhattan real estate market seems to have settled into a more typical and seasonal pattern, with prices rising slightly and sales volume dipping in the recent summer months, third-quarter market reports to be released on Friday indicate.

headline: Fiat Denies Reports It May Sell Ferrari
text: Fiat has its owns means if it decides to seek a majority stake of Chrysler, and has no intention of selling its Ferrari unit to raise funds, the chief executive said Thursday, David Jolly writes in The New York Times.

headline: Wall Street Slips at End of an Upbeat Quarter
text: Shares fell Thursday on Wall Street, but the broader market ended the third quarter with its strongest three-month performance in a year, Christine Hauser writes in The New York Times.

headline: Science Knows Best
text: Sam Harris heads the youth wing of the New Atheists. “The End of Faith,” his blistering take-no-­prisoners attack on the irrationality of religions, found him many fans and, not surprisingly, a great body of detractors. In “Letter to a Christian Nation,” a follow-up prompted by the responses of Christians unhappy with his first book, he set out, he said, “to demolish the intellectual and moral pretensions of Christianity in its most committed forms,” and so acquired, no doubt, more friends and more enemies. Certainly both books have had a wide and animated readership.

headline: Police Officers Strike in Ecuador
text: President Rafael Correa of Ecuador was caught in an angry scrum of officers who were protesting a new law that would reduce their benefits and slow salary increases.

headline: Lost and Found
text: When Janet Elder was under­going a biopsy, she kept her emotions in check and her mind sharp. “I wasn’t scared,” she reports in her memoir, “Huck,” which improbably entwines the story of her breast cancer with an account of a missing family pet. Elder, a senior editor at The New York Times, handles a frightening subject — the impact of a potentially lethal illness on a family — gently enough that some parents might deem the book appropriate reading material for older children.

headline: The Gods Get Their Bridge at ‘Rheingold’
text: The rainbow bridge appeared!

headline: Sibling Rivalry
text: Michael Cunningham’s latest novel, “By Nightfall,” begins with an animal sacrifice: a horse pulling a tourist carriage has been hit by a car on Broadway. For New Yorkers in a hurry, this bloody spilled death is just the cause of another jag on their day’s journey. But for Peter Harris, caught in the blocked traffic, marooned in the stopped hour where life can’t move forward, the dead animal is a symbol of the losses, accidents, misdirections and mistakes of his 43 years. He has just turned 44.

headline: Hidden Tigers
text: In the early 1990s, when Sony was still digesting Columbia Pictures and Japan was seen as an economic threat to the United States, I was urged by my father to learn to bow and wear a kimono, because we were all going to be working for Japanese companies one day. The cultural artifact of the moment was Michael Crichton’s borderline racist novel “Rising Sun,” which became a film starring Sean Connery and warned of Japanese corporate imperialism and the menace it posed to our way of life.

headline: TARP Bailout to Cost Less Than Once Anticipated
text: Even as voters rage and candidates put up ads against government bailouts, the reviled mother of them all — the $700 billion lifeline to banks, insurance and auto companies — will expire after Sunday at a fraction of that cost, and could conceivably earn taxpayers a profit, Jackie Calmes writes in The New York Times.

headline: Prairie Fires
text: If you take an exit off a Midwestern highway and drive through a square-gridded prairie town, you might think there’s nothing much going on, nothing to see but the 7-Eleven and the high school, nothing to do but gas up, get biscuits and gravy at the diner and move on. But in her new novel, “Bound,” set mostly in Wichita, Kan., Antonya Nelson compels you to linger, makes you take in the shimmer of the long gray highway beside the strip malls, the promise and punishment of the steely blue sky. This America is her stage, and its characters are her people. Raised in Wichita, Nelson carries regional secrets in her internal map — the nameless back roads and hidden lakes a stranger wouldn’t even know to look for.

headline: Uganda: A Threat to Pull Peacekeepers
text: The Ugandan government delivered a veiled threat to the United Nations about withdrawing peacekeepers from Somalia because it is furious about a report on Congo that accuses Ugandan troops of war crimes. In a letter made public on Thursday, the Foreign Ministry wrote, “Such sinister tactics undermine Uganda’s resolve to continue contributing to, and participating in, various regional and international peacekeeping operations.” Uganda provides several thousand peacekeepers to Somalia. Rwanda had also threatened to withdraw peacekeepers because of its displeasure over the report, which is to be published Friday. The document blames various armed groups, including the Ugandan and Rwandan armies, for hundreds of massacres in the Democratic Republic of Congo.

headline: Hyperlinked
text: Early in Daniel Kehlmann’s internationally best-selling 2005 historical novel, “Measuring the World,” Alexander von Humboldt, the German scientist who rose to prominence as an explorer and geographer at the dawn of the 19th century, is talking to an aged professor who, the rumor goes, may be working on a novel: “Writing a novel, said Humboldt, seemed to him the perfect way to capture the most fleeting essence of the present for the future.”

headline: China: Building Blocks for Climate Pact
text: China’s lead negotiator for climate change has said that countries do not expect to reach a binding climate treaty this year, and climate officials will instead focus on trying to narrow their differences ahead of year-end climate talks in Cancún, Mexico. The negotiator, Xie Zhenhua, said that talks starting on Oct. 4 in Tianjin will pave the way for the meeting in Mexico, according to a report on Thursday in China Daily. He said at a news conference on Wednesday that if the meetings went well, the nations could agree on a legally binding treaty next year in South Africa.

headline: News Quiz | October 1, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: United Arab Emirates: Police Chief Accuses Israeli Spy Agency of Threats
text: The Dubai chief of police said he had received death threats from the Israeli spy agency Mossad because of his role in publicizing the details of the assassination of a senior Hamas figure this year, an Emirati newspaper reported Thursday. The police chief, Dahi Khalfan al-Tamim, told Al Etihad, a state-owned daily newspaper, that he had received the first threat two days after he made public videotape of the suspects believed to have killed the Hamas official, Mahmoud al-Mabhouh, in a Dubai hotel on Jan. 20. The police chief publicly accused Mossad in February of carrying out the killing. “Protect your back if you are still talking,” one message said. The second threat was delivered by phone to one of Mr. Khalfan’s relatives, the newspaper said.

headline: Ysrael Seinuk, 78; Made Tall, Sleek Buildings Possible
text: Ysrael Seinuk, a structural engineer who made it possible for many of New York City’s tallest new buildings to withstand wind, gravity and even earthquakes, died on Sept. 14 in Manhattan. He was 78 and lived in Forest Hills, Queens.

headline: Three Irritable Siblings, Ready to Pounce
text: In “Ritter, Dene, Voss,” the Thomas Bernhard play making its New York debut at La MaMa, one character voices what sounds like a Bernhardian credo: “I hate the theater,” he says. “There is nothing I find more odious.”

headline: Joe Mantell Is Dead at 94; Played Sidekick in ‘Marty’
text: Joe Mantell, a character actor who, nearly 20 years apart, delivered two of movie history’s more memorable lines, one to Ernest Borgnine and one to Jack Nicholson, died on Wednesday in Tarzana, Calif. He was 94 and lived in Encino, Calif.

headline: Foreclosures Slow as Document Flaws Emerge
text: The foreclosure machinery that has forced millions of Americans out of their homes is beginning to seize up as some lenders and their lawyers are accused of cutting corners in their pursuit of rapid home repossessions.

headline: Former SAP Chief to Lead Hewlett-Packard
text: Hewlett-Packard‘s board chose equal parts pragmatism, aggressiveness and surprise with its hiring of Léo Apotheker as the company’s new chief executive, Ashlee Vance writes in The New York Times.

headline: At Hearing, a Dispute Over Banking Provision in Reform Law
text: The unity of regulators who have to put the Dodd-Frank financial reform law into effect was put to the test at a Congressional hearing Thursday as squabbling emerged over a provision affecting lenders.

headline: Limits Emerge for a New Bureau Without a Director
text: The Obama administration is starting to set up the new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, but relief for consumers befuddled by the complex disclosures that accompany credit cards, auto loans and mortgages will not come about right away.

headline: What Health Tips Have Worked for You?
text: In a widely e-mailed “Really?” column from the Science Times this week, Anahad O’Connor reports on a Mayo Clinic study that shows that gargling with salt water can help ease winter colds. Have you ever done this? Did it work for you? What health tips can you share? For instance, do you have a working strategy to lessen the annoyance of the flu, mosquito bites, acne or headaches? Do you have some tips for preventing illness through healthy diet, exercise or stress reduction? Share your advice below.

headline: Brushes With Greatness
text: The Samurai Shopper is a master in the civil arts of social encounters, a mannerly person and a lively guest, trading effortless bons mots with newcomers, outsiders, friends and frenemies. But at some point during such festivities, an awkward situation arises. I enter my host’s bathroom for a quick freshening of hands or to minister to an urgent function. There is nothing to do but look around the bathroom, noting fixtures, shower curtains, rugs. Some décor is predictably matchy-matchy; some objects are pleasantly marked by habit and custom. The pictures on the wall prompt idle curiosity: what mysterious forces lurk behind this vapid still life or that totemic oddity? And then it happens — that unwanted glimpse into personal space.

headline: Ireland Takes Over a 2nd Troubled Bank
text: The Irish government said on Thursday that it expected to inject billions more euros into two of the largest banks in the country, underscoring the extent to which they continued to jeopardize Ireland’s economic condition.

headline: Gates and Buffett Say Charity Meeting a Success
text: After a night of wining and dining 50 of China’s richest people in the name of promoting philanthropy, Warren E. Buffett and Bill Gates told a horde of journalists on Thursday that the biggest difference between eating with Chinese tycoons and Western ones was the food.

headline: Studio Behind Facebook Movie Woos Techies

headline: 20th-Century Portraits at the New York Public Library
text: Correction Appended| There are about a half a million images in the photography collection  on the third floor of the main branch of the New York Public Library on Fifth Avenue. The collection’s curator, Stephen Pinson, spent a year searching through those photographs for 20th-century portraits, and now there is a handsome exhibition, “Recollection ,” in the library’s Print and Stokes Galleries. On display are portraits from more than 90 photographers of the 20th century, including Richard Avedon, Diane Arbus, Duane Michals, Henri Cartier-Bresson, August Sander and William Wegman.

headline: We
text: Theodore Rockwell, who served as technical director for the U.S. Navy’s nuclear-propulsion program in the 1950s and ’60s, shared a telling anecdote about his onetime boss, the famously irascible Adm. Hyman G. Rickover. “One time he caught me using the editorial we, as in ‘we will get back to you by. . . .’ ” Rockwell recalled in his memoir, “The Rickover Effect.” “He explained brusquely that only three types of individual were entitled to such usage: ‘The head of a sovereign state, a schizophrenic and a pregnant woman. Which are you, Rockwell?’ ”

headline: Boom for Maneuvers?
text: Buyouts are expected to return to heady pre-crisis levels and reach a frequency not seen since the height of the credit boom, Michael Queen, chief executive of 3i, told The Financial Times.

headline: Unicredit Names Ghizzoni to Replace Profumo
text: The board of Unicredit, the largest Italian bank, on Thursday chose Federico Ghizzoni to succeed Alassandro Profumo, the chief executive who resigned last week after a dispute with the executive board.

headline: Clearwire Resignations Spark Chatter
text: Three top executives of Sprint Nextel resigned from the board of its Clearwire venture, stoking speculation it would pave the way for a wholesale deal or equity stake sale to T-Mobile USA, Reuters reported.

headline: After Disappointing I.P.O., Elster Shares Rise
text: Elster Group shares rose 6 percent in their market debut Thursday, after raising less than expected in its initial public offering, The Associated Press reported.

headline: New Chief for A.I.G.’s Nan Shan Stokes Sale Talk

headline: BHP Poised to Challenge Potash Suit
text: BHP Billiton said Friday that it expected to file a challenge to Potash Corporation of Saskachewan’s lawsuit trying to block its $39 billion hostile offer.

headline: Portugal’s Leader Moves to Satisfy ‘Unfair’ Markets
text: Financial markets have been “very unfair” to Portugal, failing to recognize its previous deficit-cutting achievements and pressing the country to adopt more stringent economic measures than the government wanted, Prime Minister José Sócrates said Thursday, Raphael Minder writes in The New York Times.

headline: The Most Accurate Fantasy Experts … After 3 Weeks
text: David Kim is the co-founder of FantasyPros, a site that rates the accuracy of fantasy experts and provides tools that aggregate and organize expert advice. You can follow FantasyPros on Twitter.

headline: Changing the Malpractice System
text: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

headline: Paris’s Grand Palais Goes Clubbing
text: The Grand Palais in Paris is perhaps best known for hosting extravagant events like the recent Biennale des Antiquaires antique fair. On Saturday, Oct. 9, however, it will (literally) vibrate to a completely different rhythm, as the second edition of Nuit Electro transforms the glass and iron cathedral of Belle Époque architecture into a vast, pulsating dance floor.

headline: Koreas Agree to Resume Reunions
text: SEOUL, South Korea  In a sign of a possible easing of tensions between North and South Korea, the two countries agreed on Friday to hold a series of reunions of families separated by the Korean War, with 100 families from each side to be reunited at the Diamond Mountain resort in the North from Oct. 30 to Nov. 5.

headline: Borders Approves Warrants for C.E.O.
text: Borders Group‘s chief executive, Bennett LeBow, cemented his control over the bookstore chain after shareholders approved a move to issue Mr. LeBow warrants that could give him a stake of as much as 35 percent in the company, Publishers Weekly reported.

headline: European Finance Ministers Meet to Settle Bank Taxes
text: European Union finance ministers met on Friday in a fresh attempt to agree on a common approach to taxing banks for the cost of crises, although documents prepared by aides for the meeting showed agreement was unlikely, Reuters reported.

headline: Tessco Rebuffs Discovery’s Buyout Offer
text: Tessco Technologies, which makes products used to build wireless systems, said Thursday that its board unanimously rejected a buyout proposal from the Discovery Group, The Associated Press reported.

headline: For Hedge Funds, Bigger Remains Better
text: Bigger actually may be better — at least when it comes to hedge funds.

headline: Granta Names Best Young Novelists Writing in Spanish
text: Through its periodic lists of the best young novelists, the British literary magazine Granta has built a reputation for spotting and promoting emerging talents long before they become widely known. A 1983 list of British writers included Martin Amis, Julian Barnes, William Boyd, Ian McEwan, Salman Rushdie, and Graham Swift, while a similar inventory of American writers in 1996 drew attention to Sherman Alexie, Madison Smartt Bell, Edwidge Danticat, Jonathan Franzen and Lorrie Moore.

headline: More Deals to Come for Scotiabank
text: Bank of Nova Scotia‘s two recent acquisitions suggest that the bank, Canada’s third largest, is starting to make good on its pledge to find strategic growth opportunities, and more deals are likely to follow soon, Reuters reports.

text: President Obama has once again complained to lawmakers about the slow pace of judicial confirmations, calling the blocking of his nominations “a dramatic shift from past practice that could cause a crisis in the judiciary.”

text: Updated | 9:16 a.m. The more you follow professional cycling, the more you wish you’d gone to medical school first. That’s because the apparent sophistication with which some professional riders dope to gain an advantage, and the complicated ways in which their blood and urine are now tested, seem to lead many discussions of the sport away from tactics and training and into the realms of science and pharmacology.

Rarely would a parking garage feature among these complex’s biggest talking points, but not all garages are built to the specifications required by the Cube, a 450,000 square-foot site in Birmingham, hemmed in by a canal and surrounding businesses.

headline: Rahm Moments (Rated PG)
text: As he departs the White House for Chicago, Rahm Emanuel is an even bigger character than he was when he arrived. Mr. Emanuel, called simply “Rahm” around town, was already known as the short, profane, exercise-obsessed former lawmaker with a tendency to explode and then apologize and then explode again. But during his nearly 20 months as President Obama’s chief of staff, he also became the implementer of a new Democratic agenda and the protective mother hen for those who slaved for him in the White House. And of course he left a trail of “Rahm moments,” memorable encounters with coworkers, lawmakers, lobbyists or adversaries. Here are some of our favorites:

headline: Vain Glorious | Dangene, the Clear Winner
text: When you’re in your early 20s, it’s a little disconcerting to look in the mirror and see an impending case of pimples. Stress, perhaps? Allergies? The wrong face wash? Unlikely, says Dangene, the acclaimed bicoastal skin expert. Although Dangene is best known in Hollywood circles for her anti-aging “tour de face,” her real passion and biggest professional triumph is acne eradication. Ready to get rid of my own trouble spots once and for all, I enlisted in the facialist’s three-week blemish boot camp.

headline: Splendor in the Grass
text: The San Francisco Patient and Resource Center, or Sparc, is not your average pot club. There’s no peephole or scary-looking security guy, no skunky couches or blackened windows. Instead, a collegiate ‘‘community liaison’’ stands by the door answering questions from passers-by and checking membership cards and paperwork. (There’s no fee to join, but you need a doctor’s recommendation to enter.) And with its minimalist oak tables and benches, and jazz on the stereo, Sparc could easily be mistaken for a Japanese teahouse. Welcome to the medical marijuana dispensary of the future.

headline: Graphic Book Best Sellers: Stranger in a Strange Time
text: “The Exile: An Outlander Graphic Novel” is No. 1 on our hardcover list. It is the first graphic novel by Diana Gabaldon, who is no stranger to best-seller lists. Her novel “An Echo in the Bone,” the seventh installment in the Outlander series, made its debut at No. 2 on the hardcover fiction list of The New York Times Book Review last October and spent five weeks on the list; a trade paperback edition of the novel also made the list in July. The graphic novel “Exile” starts at the beginning of the Outlander mythos, telling the story of Claire Randall, a World War II-era nurse is transported back in time to the side of Jamie Fraser, a kilt-wearing Scotsman in the 18th century.

headline: Off the Menu: Mehtaphor
text: Did your mother tell you “no dessert first?” Jehangir Mehta is one of those chefs who ignored that rule, started making his name in pastry departments at Jean Georges, Aix and Compass, among others, and then sidled into savories with his first restaurant, Graffiti. Mehtaphor, opening on Oct. 7, is larger, with several dining areas and an inventive menu: beef tartare with guacamole sorbet, shaved foie gras with raspberry compote, an Indian burger, and cod in banana leaf with green chutney. The chef has often given classes for children, which he will reprise for the holiday season. And at Mehtaphor, he will also offer a menu of snacks for children after school: Duane Street Hotel, 130 Duane Street (Church Street), (212) 542-9440.

headline: Ecuador Police Chief Resigns After Uprising
text: CARACAS, Venezuela  Ecuador’s police chief resigned on Friday, a day after an uprising by police officers who held President Rafael Correa captive for more than 10 hours. Soldiers patrolled the streets of Quito, the capital, and other cities, enforcing a state of emergency.

headline: Friday Reading: Manhattan Real Estate Stabilizes
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Labor Dispute Digs ‘The Hobbit’ Into a Deeper Hole
text: A dispute between Peter Jackson, the executive producer of a film adaptation of “The Hobbit,” and actors’ guilds in Australia and New Zealand continued to bog down that film’s long-delayed production as Mr. Jackson warned again that he may move the project from New Zealand.

headline: A Down Goes Brown Preview: the Western Conference
text: As we count down to the start of the 2010-11 N.H.L. regular season, Down Goes Brown is back to continue his preview of the league. In the first part of this two-part series, we took a look at the Eastern Conference. Today, it’s on to Western Conference, where we’ll learn about Patrick Kane’s off-season training program, how the Wild will handle the loss of Derek Boogard, and whether the Ducks can rebound from the devastating loss of Scott Niedermayer’s beard.

text: Fashion shows tend to cover every contingency, so it’s not unusual to see leather and dark colors in the spring collections. But, this season, I bet we’ve seen more leather motorcycle jackets than bikinis. (In fact, where are those bathing suits and caftans?)

headline: Document Outlines Independent Group’s Plans to Help Democrats
text: A still-nascent independent group, which is readying itself to become the main conduit for large, unrestricted donations supporting Democratic House candidates, will concentrate its efforts on select competitive districts to build a “firewall” that it hopes will preserve the party’s majority, according to a confidential document outlining the organization’s plans.

headline: Parroting Brad DeLong
text: Brad DeLong references the old line about economists being nothing but parrots who squawk “supply and demand! supply and demand!”, then argues that they seem to have forgotten even that.

text: JENNY CRAIG, Richard Simmons, Oprah in her doughnut-denying prime  none can match Lotus Cars in a Biggest Loser contest.

headline: That’s Mr. Danza to You: Tony Danza Goes Back to School for His Reality Show
text: Even if you never tuned in to “Taxi” and didn’t care to know “Who’s the Boss?,” it’s hard not to feel bad for Tony Danza in the first episode of his new A&E reality series, “Teach: Tony Danza,” in which he leaves Hollywood to become a 10th-grade English instructor at Northeast High School in Philadelphia. In the debut installment, which will be shown Friday and which Alessandra Stanley reviews here, Mr. Danza is buffeted by strict administrators, outsmarted by his own students and – in a confessional scene that has dogged him throughout the promotion of the series – he breaks down and cries to the camera. (It’s O.K., Mr. Danza, you’re still the boss to us.)

headline: 2010 Lotus Evora
text: The Evora starts at under $75,000, but looks and handles like a six-figure supercar.

headline: A BMW on the Trans-Atlantic Plan
text: THE easy way to take delivery of my 2011 BMW 128i would have been to make a 45-minute train ride from my home in Queens to the dealership in Huntington, on Long Island. I chose the not-so-easy way: Queens to Huntington, via Munich.

headline: Complaint Box | Pushy Drivers
text: I am waiting, more or less patiently, in the right lane of the southbound Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive, crawling toward the exit for the Brooklyn Bridge. A maroonish blur zooms by on my left, and I take a deep breath, already guessing what I’ll see: the car, at the last possible minute, slows down and nudges into the line, right up by the exit.

headline: Timeless | Page Turner
text: In 1966, the furniture company Stendig commissioned Massimo Vignelli to design a promotional calendar. The result, a 3-foot-by-4-foot black-and-white grid of numbers and letters, was snapped up by the Museum of Modern Art for its permanent collection before a single calendar was printed. And it has been in print ever since, becoming at one point a fixture in the office of architects like Richard Meier, whose books and Web site are also designed by the legendary Vignelli. ‘‘I wouldn’t do anything without Massimo,’’ Meier insisted. ‘‘We both resolve ideas with a grid.’’ For Vignelli — who, with his wife and partner in Vignelli Associates, Lella, is also known for designs like New York City’s 1972 subway map and stacked plastic dinnerware for Heller, and who co-designed the just-opened Vignelli Center for Design Studies at the Rochester Institute of Technology — the calendar is an exercise in white space (or black; random pages of the calendars are reverse-printed). ‘‘For us, the space outside the type is more important than the type itself,’’ he said. Vignelli also designed a smaller version of the calendar, which he wishes were still in production. ‘‘Some people don’t have room for the large one,’’ he explained. But no matter: even if Vignelli doesn’t receive royalties for it, he’s happy that the big calendar is still in print. ‘‘It’s nice to see how fresh it still looks.’’ Go to unicahome.com.

headline: Happy Fiscal New Year!
text: A new day, a new fiscal year for the federal government. Len Burman suggests a new presidential address to honor the occasion:

headline: Rain Snarls Ryder Cup, Soaking American Team
text: NEWPORT, Wales  Once the rain stopped falling, after a 24-hour downpour that would have drowned most golf events, putts started falling at Celtic Manor and the 38th Ryder Cup sprang to life on Friday  before taking the rest of the night off for some well-earned rest.

headline: On Our Radar: Politics and the Drilling Ban
text: The Obama administration’s top offshore drilling regulator pushes back against pressure from Senator Mary Landrieu of Louisiana, who has placed a hold on Obama’s nominee to head the Office of Management and Budget until the deepwater drilling ban in the gulf is lifted. “There’s no chance that we’ll lift it sooner because of political pressure of any sort,” Michael R. Bromwich, director of the Interior Department’s Bureau of Ocean Energy Management, Regulation and Enforcement, says. “The only way we’ll lift the moratorium sooner is if we’re comfortable and confident there has been progress on a number of issues.” [The Hill]

headline: Crash Avoidance in Ireland, if the Passenger Catches His Drift
text: WE were 30 minutes outside Dublin, fresh off the plane and racing toward Ireland’s western coast, our two young children asleep behind us, when my wife and I developed our Verbal Collision Avoidance System.

headline: A Prison-Library Reunion
text: You know you’re not doing well when a prisoner regards you with pity. When a man in an oversize prison uniform — a man who could narrate the gruesome entirety of his life through the scars on his body — gives you the once-over and says: “You O.K., pal? You don’t look too good,” you know you’re in trouble.

headline: Branding Operation
text: So you’re about to have surgery. You’re probably nervous. But the medical staff seems calm and competent, and that’s reassuring, because you’re counting on them to make pretty serious decisions. You glance over at a nurse, and you notice the tag on her scrubs. “Grey’s Anatomy,” it says.

headline: Rahm Emanuel Gets a Send-Off, and a Sendup
text: Close to three dozen top White House aides gave Rahm Emanuel, the chief of staff, a standing ovation — and a dead fish — as he concluded his final 8:30 meeting in the Roosevelt Room Friday morning.

headline: Is Michelle Rhee’s Revolution Over?
text: Around the country, supporters of education reform — or at least of the test-scores-driven, tenure-busting, results-rewarding sort of reform epitomized by organizations like Teach for America and championed by Education Secretary Arne Duncan — gave a collective gasp of dismay last month when voters in a number of districts handed primary defeats to candidates closely associated with just this type of reform. In New York, three state-senate candidates who ran on pro-charter-school platforms each failed to garner more than 30 percent of the vote. In Washington, voters overwhelmingly rejected Mayor Adrian Fenty in favor of the City Council chairman, Vincent Gray, as the Democratic candidate in this year’s mayoral election. The Fenty defeat worried many people particularly because he was inextricably linked with his crusading, nationally celebrated schools chancellor, Michelle Rhee.

headline: If the Conversation Starts With ‘Witches’ …
text: What does it say about the midterm elections when Larry King asks an open-ended question — “What’s going to happen in November?” — and one of the first words out of a guest’s mouth is “witches”?

headline: Home Ground
text: A look at the work of the artist Wayne Thiebaud.

headline: A Tricky Medicare Enrollment Season
text: The new health care law has made Medicare enrollment season particularly complicated this year, reports Walecia Konrad in today’s Patient Money column.

headline: Now Reciting | ‘Oil Kills Poets Spill’
text: “Mulberry goes badly with marble,” the artist Stefan Bondell says, explaining an empty plot of land in the New York Marble Cemetery that once held a large mulberry tree until it was removed because its roots were interfering with the marble crypts below. It was around this very spot that Bondell staged a poetry reading last May. The evening was a wild success, drawing nearly 200 people to watch poets like Rene Ricard read in front of one of Bondell’s works, a 20-foot-by-20-foot painting titled “Pax Americana,” which was also the event’s theme.

headline: Accord Paves Way for Re-election of Iraq Premier
text: BAGHDAD  Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq appeared almost assured of a second term in office on Friday after securing the support of an anti-American Shiite Islamic movement whose return to political power could profoundly complicate relations with the United States.

headline: Coming Full Circle After a Pause
text: FOR once, the choreographer Ralph Lemon is not choosing his words carefully. A quizzical grin flashes across his handsome face. Then a nervous giggle. And finally a sigh. Mr. Lemon normally keeps his private life hidden behind a diaphanous veil  his work slyly alludes to what may or may not be true  but he is saying more over lunch than he would like to in the case of his new “How Can You Stay in the House All Day and Not Go Anywhere?”

headline: Taming Ives With Head, Heart and Humor
text: “THE more you dig into a piece of Ives, the more pleasure you get from it,” the pianist Jeremy Denk said recently, sitting at a piano in a rehearsal space at the Juilliard School. “It’s like solving a puzzle.”

And when the Bronx Zoo opened the competition to online voting, it all but guaranteed the end result: ladies and gentlemen, say hello to Justin Beaver.

headline: Drive and Determination of Zuckerberg and Gekko
text: THE great virtue of Facebook  as articulated early in “The Social Network” by Mark Zuckerberg, the Harvard student who was one of that site’s founders  is that it is “exclusive.” This may sound counterintuitive, given that one of the seductions of Facebook in the real world is that it is open to everyone. Far from exclusive, the network seems to have the potential to become universal.

headline: ‘Love Never Dies’ Will Not Come to Broadway This Spring

headline: Letter: Achieving Techno-Literacy
text: I am a physics professor at a technological university, learning how best to incorporate computers into teaching over the past 18 years. Many colleagues originally saw this approach as a panacea for solving the problems of higher education. Instead, the solution is to use computers to enhance and extend the experience that only a good, student-oriented faculty member can provide. As Kevin Kelly wrote about what he saw with his own son, education works best when teacher and student both learn together, whether it is the subject matter itself or the technology that allows the subject to be studied in new ways.

headline: New Models Help Sales for Automakers
text: DETROIT  Automakers reported solid if unspectacular sales in September, as manufacturers with the freshest products drew the most attention from American consumers.

headline: N.H.L. Players Prefer Quebec City for a New Team
text: ¶ Quebec City is the place N.H.L. players would most like to see added to the league, according to an informal poll of 90 N.H.L.’ers conducted by The Hockey News. La vieille capitale received 33 votes, followed by Winnipeg with 18, Las Vegas with 12, Hamilton with 11 and Seattle with 5. The Quebec provincial government has said it will bankroll up to 45 percent of the cost of a new rink in Quebec City in an effort to attract an N.H.L. team to replace the Nordiques, who left for Colorado in 1995, but Prime Minister Stephen Harper has said the federal government will not contribute financing.¶ Jaroslav Halak stops 30 shots for St. Louis in the Blues’ 4-1 exhibition win over Chicago, his first victory since his heroic playoff run with the Canadiens last spring.

headline: China’s Mandatory Vacation, With a Catch
text: BEIJING  Who doesn’t love a weeklong obligatory vacation? In China, where an estimated 200 million people on Friday began elbowing their way onto trains, buses and highways for the National Day holiday, the answer is not so simple.

headline: Letters: Does the Digital Classroom Enfeeble the Mind?
text: In Jaron Lanier’s great essay, he answers the title question when he writes, “The trick is being ambidextrous, holding one hand to the heart while counting on the digits of the other.” We have led a double life since the beginning, and there’s no reason we should be stymied by the latest technologies. Realizing we have always been dual can let us integrate whatever is thrown our way. The religious make room for God and Caesar; the spiritual reconcile mind and soul; education tempers sciences with humanities; psychology and philosophy relate inner and outer; and mundane obligations do not foreclose pursuit of the possible. The heart and the head can synchronize for full development of the human.

headline: Letter: Cooking With Dexter
text: Pete Wells’s resentment of the usual format of recipes may be misplaced. Rather than an order to mise en place, an ingredient list at the start may be viewed as a convenient shopping guide and a checklist to ensure that diners are comfortable eating all of the dish’s components. Noting that some ingredients must be chopped or otherwise prepared is not necessarily a command to do so, but rather an aid in accurate measurement. Once the cook knows that he has everything he needs to make the dish, he can decide what should (or may) be prepared in advance, and what steps can be taken while others are in progress. Cooking is an art as much as a science, so recipes should be a starting point for exploration and enjoyment; they are not meant to annoy or intimidate, but rather to encourage and inspire.

headline: And the Band Played on at Carnegie Hall
text: Go to concerts long enough, and you’ll see it all (if not hear it all).

headline: Letter: Drill, Baby, Drill
text: Virginia Heffernan’s Medium column demonstrates the benefits of mastery learning — a hallmark of the Kumon program. While there is no single way to learn, we firmly believe that children gain a strong foundation in the basics through practice. Our focus is on helping children develop the skills, motivation and self-confidence to become lifelong independent learners. We believe that once mastery is achieved, children can use their knowledge to explore their curiosity, ask questions, ponder solutions and truly enjoy the process of thinking. After-school enrichment programs, like Kumon, coupled with effective teachers and supportive parents are the ideal combination to help prepare students for the global marketplace and enable them to contribute to the betterment of our society.

headline: I Hate Everything!
text: “Everyone is essentially either sad, angry or afraid,” Mike, my best friend, said. We were sitting on the linoleum floor in my college dorm room. It was 1990. It was 3:45 in the morning. We were down to brass tacks.

headline: Back to the Future: The N.H.L.’s Blogger Guidelines
text: The N.H.L. stirred up no small amount of controversy among online media when a draft of guidelines for providing media credentials to bloggers was leaked in August. The measures, which could have barred access to the visitors’ locker room to bloggers who did not work for a “national news-gathering agency” and kept them away from mainstream reporters in the press box, pitted some blog friendly teams against more traditional franchises and produced heated objections from the free-spirited blogging community.

headline: Insuring an Ex-Employee
text: A family member, who owns a small business, and his sole employee took out life-insurance policies on each other. The employee left the business about 10 years ago, but my relative still keeps up the insurance on him, something the ex-employee does not know. I think this is unethical; my relative thinks I am “hard-nosed and narrow-minded.” You? M.T., KIRKLAND, WASH.

headline: When Lawyers Can Peek at Facebook
text: Could the legal world be moving toward a new set of Miranda warnings: “Anything you say, do — or post on Facebook — can be used against you in a court of law”?

headline: Carmakers’ Definitions of Coupe Evolve and Vary
text: PARIS — The word “coupe” is French in origin, from the verb “to cut,” and is often used in automotive parlance to describe a sedan that has been cut down from four doors to two. These days, in the auto industry, the word “coupe” has been corrupted; it is difficult to tell what it means anymore.

headline: Letter: Questions for Arne Duncan
text: It is unfortunate that Deborah Solomon chose to characterize online education as a “horrible” alternative to the traditional classroom in her interview with the secretary of education. Solomon shortchanges online education by suggesting that online students are learning from a machine instead of “a beloved high-school teacher.” Solomon should do her homework: online education connects students with highly qualified, experienced teachers — human beings who become beloved to their online students through message boards, chats, e-mails, videos, Skype and more. The machine is simply a conduit for human interaction. In fact, the 2010 online teacher of the year, Teresa Dove of the Florida Virtual School, credits the online environment with allowing more interaction and feedback to her students, noting that, “You might be separated geographically, but spending that one-on-one time with the kids is the biggest asset for an online instructor.”

headline: New Sketch of a Madcap’s Mad Life

headline: Salazar Warns Against Co-Opting of Science

The Obama administration, the new president promised, would be guided by vigorous and open scientific debate in decisions on biomedical research, climate change, endangered species and other technical endeavors.

headline: Now Online | T’s Fall Design Issue
text: The fall issue of T Design looks at different visions of domestic bliss. We look back at Design Research, the revered godfather of modern design stores. Pilar Viladas visits an airy, open house in Italy by the superstar designer Patricia Urquiola for Patrizia Moroso, the creative director of the cutting-edge furniture company Moroso, while Nicolai Ouroussoff considers a very different dwelling: a seven-sided house in Southern California, by the Los Angeles architect Michael Maltzan for the artists Lari Pittman and Roy Dowell, which spirals around an intimate courtyard, looking inward rather than out. Our Profile in Style focuses on Barnaba Fornasetti, the scion of a legendary design family who has made his own kind of magic. Alexandra Lange spends time with Renate Müller, the German designer of meticulously crafted, whimsical therapeutic toys, and Judith Nasatir peers into the exquisite world of Federico de Vera, the gimlet-eyed proprietor of one of New York’s most magical design shops. On an entirely different note, Jaime Gross takes a peek at a San Francisco medical marijuana dispensary that is as elegantly designed as any fashion store—bringing an often taboo subject out of the shadows. And the endpage features a calendar, by the graphic-design legend Massimo Vignelli, that is still timely after 44 years.

headline: Easy Pieces

A crisp white shirt with a perfectly conceived collar (not straight, not quite a Peter Pan), ribbed cable-knit sweaters without the waist-expanding bulk, and the only suit you’ll need all season (slim, two-button in charcoal wool) are the ingredients to a seamless fall wardrobe. Wear the pieces individually or layered on top of one another to get the maximum out of a minimalist look. With prices ranging from $20 to $230, it’s doubtful the clothes will be in store much past next Thursday’s release date.

headline: Artifacts | Trisha Brown, Off the Wall
text: At 5 p.m. on Wednesday, a camera-phone-wielding crowd gathered at the corner of Madison Avenue and 75th Street as a man on the roof of the Whitney Museum prepared to go off it. “Oh, my God,” gasped a passerby as the man, the dancer and choreographer Stephen Petronio, achieved liftoff. He let his body fall forward until it was perpendicular to the pavement, and then held perfectly still, looking down at the street and perhaps into his soul as well. After a few moments of awed silence, he began an absurdly casual stroll down the sheer 97-foot granite cliff of the Whitney’s side wall, rappelling in slow-motion and pausing, now and then, to let his seemingly weightless feet regain the wall before proceeding to the bottom, where he was greeted with an ovation.

headline: Booming Car Sales in China May Bypass Diesels
text: PARIS

headline: Trying to Echo Childhood’s Rhythms
text: A NEW mother, who is also a television critic, is inevitably asked whether she will permit her child to share her public pleasure. Friends and strangers have posed this question to me repeatedly since my son was born a year ago, and I have yet to formulate a position. I understand how addictive the medium is, but refusing it (as the American Academy of Pediatrics recommends for children under age 2) feels too sanctimonious  and unrealistic. A baby getting increasingly mobile does not sit still during a changing of clothes unless, according to studies conducted in my living room, he’s put in front of a TV for a minute or two  whether it’s “iCarly” or Harry Reid on “Morning Joe.” And fathers who love sports tend to feel that ESPN does not count as actual television. There may be toddlers who, though they have never watched a single second of “Dora the Explorer,” could hand you a nacho and talk third-down conversions.

headline: Defendant Ignited Fire, Cheshire Prosecutor Tells Jury
text: NEW HAVEN  A prosecutor at the trial of one of the two men accused of invading a home and murdering a woman and her two daughters contended on Friday for the first time that it was the defendant, Steven J. Hayes, who ignited the fire that killed the girls.

headline: A Piece of Her Heart on a 40th Anniversary
text: IN the late summer of 1968, Big Brother and the Holding Company had nearly finished recording “Cheap Thrills” when Janis Joplin, the band’s singer, slipped the drummer Dave Getz a set of lyrics she’d handwritten to accompany a piano riff he had been practicing. The song, “Can’t Be the Only One,” with words by Joplin and music by Mr. Getz, was something of a parting gift. Within days, Joplin gathered her band mates in a room at the Chelsea Hotel and announced that she was going solo.

headline: Lamborghini Sesto Elemento Showcases Lightweight Carbon Fiber
text: PARIS — It’s fitting that the Lamborghini Sesto Elemento made its debut in Paris. The seemingly deconstructed sports car looks like the city’s Centre Georges Pompidou on wheels, every working part is open and exposed to the world. Rumored to be the replacement for the current Murciélago supercar, the Sesto Elemento (Sixth Element) is actually a showcase of the Italian sports car company’s use of lightweight carbon fiber.

headline: Audi Quattro Concept Channels Nostalgia for the Classic Sport Quattro
text: PARIS — For Audi fans in the 1980s, the original Sport Quattro was more fun than Pac-Man and better looking than the highest shoulder pads. Inspired by the German automaker’s successful rallying program -– and the need to manufacture a street-legal version to homologate the car for racing -– the Sport Quattro was an instant classic, though only 224 were ever built.

headline: The Smith to Open a Branch in Midtown
text: Jeffrey Lefcourt and Glenn Harris, who own Jane on West Houston Street and The Smith on Third Avenue in the East Village, will be entering the uptown restaurant mix. They plan to open a big branch of The Smith in the spring at 956 Second Avenue (51st Street), with 10,000 square feet of space over two floors and a zinc bar that stretches for 100 feet. It’s an unusual turnaround for the Manhattan real estate scene because it replaces a Rite-Aid drugstore; usually drug stores and banks have replaced restaurants. “We have been looking for so long to find the right place to open a branch of The Smith in Midtown so we’re very excited,” Mr. Lefcourt said.

text: Driving rain and gusty winds battered the already wet East Coast before dawn on Friday morning.

headline: Now Showing | Driss Ouadahi
text: “Densité,” an exhibition of paintings by Driss Ouadahi, opens today at Hosfelt Gallery New York. Ouadahi grew up in Algeria and studied architecture before enrolling at the Kunstakademie Düsseldorf, in the German city that is now his home. His subject matter is the built environment of urban alienation: underground passageways, chain-link fencing, the sterile Modernist high-rise buildings that are home to so many immigrants in European cities. Ouadahi’s almost pretty color palette makes his screen-like, gridded high-rise facades seem seductive, until you realize that beyond them is a barren, depopulated landscape. His precisely rendered, claustrophobic tiled passages would make Kafka break out in a sweat, and his delicate depictions of chain link cover the canvas to its edges, suggesting a net that leaves no way out. The exhibition continues through Nov. 13. 531 West 36th Street; (212) 563-5454.

headline: ‘Humpbacked’ Porsche Looks Good From Driver’s Seat
text: PARIS — A Porsche sporting a “whale tail” rear spoiler used to be the height of automotive coolness. Originally designed to increase engine cooling and provide extra rear down-force for the 911 Turbo, the unique feature quickly became an over-used cosmetic addition to nearly every spec of 911. Perhaps Porsche is trying to resurrect this cetacean theme, via the distinctly “humpbacked” shape of the new 911 Speedster shown at the Paris Auto Show.

headline: Items for the Table That Are Truly Museum Pieces
text: Do you have dinnerware designed by Roy Lichtenstein, Keith Haring and James Rosenquist, and glassware by Sol Lewitt in your cupboard? The Museum of Arts and Design does in an exhibit called Eat Drink Art Design. In addition to the big name pieces, there is simple, beautifully crafted rustic Japanese stoneware alongside equally elegant disposable white Japanese dishes made from bamboo and sugar cane pulp. Scores of plates designed by Peter Ting and produced by Royal Crown Derby in England make up a display called Constellation Manhattan. A surreal silver Melting Teapot by Myra Mimlitsch-Gray is one of the rare, highly impractical pieces on view.Eat Drink Art Design is on the third floor of the Museum of Arts and Design at Columbus Circle through March 27, Tuesdays through Sundays 11 a.m. to 6 p.m., except Thursdays when it stays open until 9 p.m. The disposable Japanese Wasara plates are sold in the museum shop, six for $15.

headline: What Does Change Look Like? Making Documentaries About School

headline: Asked & Answered | Olivier Zahm
text: In 1992 Olivier Zahm printed the first issue of Purple Prose, a Parisian literary art zine that over the years has evolved into Purple Fashion Magazine. As founder and editor of the biannual publication, Zahm has remained faithful to Purple’s mission to foster emerging artists, fashion insiders and sexual creativity. At 47, Zahm is unfazed by his reputation as a louche lady-killer and promotes “alternative love lifestyles” (translation: open relationships). Nor is he averse to playing against type as witnessed by his recent sharing (some would say oversharing) of his heartbreak over being dumped by the model Natacha Ramsay on on his unapologetically pervy blog, purple-diary. The Moment caught up with Zahm in his New York office to chew the fat about downtown New York culture, fashion, art and sex.
