text: The Lanvin spring show was held this evening in a former transportation depot about 20 minutes from the center of Paris, but with Friday traffic and rain and other shows backing up, Lanvin’s start was delayed more than an hour. I went into the backstage, more like a bunker with long tables and mirrors, and Pat McGrath and her makeup artists were working on the models. It was 5:40 p.m. I said hello to Franca Sozzani, who was also killing time, and then I went in search of Alber Elbaz. Since there was a good sense of show panic, I got past the security guard at the dressing room entrance without any difficulty, and I heard Mr. Elbaz before I actually saw him.

headline: Weekly Pick ‘Em: Sorting Things Out
text: This Saturday was circled on the schedule by many college football fans at the beginning of the season, with Alabama against Florida and Oklahoma versus Texas looming as two of the year’s marquee games. But a funny thing happened in September. A few things, actually. Florida, while undefeated, has looked a little sluggish in the first few weeks of the post-Tim Tebow era; Texas appeared lethargic in losing to a seemingly unimposing U.C.L.A. team in Austin last week; and Stanford has developed into a top-10 team behind an explosive offense led by quarterback Andrew Luck. All that means that Stanford at Oregon has become perhaps the most intriguing game of the weekend, with the Cardinal traveling to the always raucous atmosphere of Autzen Stadium to try to prove that they belong in the top tier of the Pac-10. As for Florida, every team in college football wishes they could struggle as well as the Gators. Still, Alabama has been No. 1 since the season’s start and the return of Mark Ingram two weeks ago has made a terrific running game that much more formidable. These teams have been the class of the Southeastern Conference for several years and there is always a chance for an epic game when they play each other.

headline: Shotgun Justice Served With a Strut
text: “Justice” isn’t a word you often hear at concerts. At benefit shows, maybe, or at a Public Enemy or Yoko Ono performance. But that word has a depth of meaning that most musicians would probably like to skip altogether.

headline: ‘Hobbit’ Deal Close to Complete
text: The Times’s Media Decoder blog reports that Warner Brothers and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer are on the verge of an agreement that would allow the director Peter Jackson to begin shooting a two-part version of J. R. R. Tolkien’s “The Hobbit” early next year. The studios have wrestled with their dual ownership of the project over the last year but a financial deal should be in place over the next several days, according to several people who have been involved in the bargaining. Still pending: a labor dispute that has led Mr. Jackson and the studios to say publicly that they would consider moving the films out of New Zealand. People involved with the films said Friday that they expected a resolution to the union dispute imminently. Read more on Media Decoder…

headline: One Man’s Fascination With Miley, Real and Not
text: Neal Medlyn loves a good pop idol, and if she happens to be going through an identity crisis, all the better. In the case of “... Her’s a Queen,” performed at Dance Theater Workshop in 2009, Mr. Medlyn took inspiration from Britney Spears. On Wednesday night he completed his self-described opus with “Brave New Girl” at the Chocolate Factory, spotlighting a mouthful: the fictional Hannah Montana and Miley Stewart and the real Miley Cyrus.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Oct. 1
text: More Photographs

headline: Open Fashion Channel
text: Something about the shape of the horn combs in the models’ hair at Rick Owens suggested they might be available for radio signals. Now transmitting … come in, Karlie …

headline: Life and Death, Stat
text: THOMAS HAZAZ wanted out. Lying on a gurney, his chest covered with heart sensors, Mr. Hazaz was trying to cajole doctors in the emergency room at Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn to unplug him. In less than 24 hours, he needed to be in a tuxedo, walking his youngest daughter down the aisle in a Staten Island banquet hall. Mr. Hazaz, 52, a bartender at Embers, a steakhouse in Bay Ridge, kept saying that the pain in his elbows was nothing but overexertion from lifting heavy stuff at work. The professionals, though, suspected a heart attack.

headline: ‘Dad’ Lifts CBS Ratings
text: In its second outing on CBS, “$#*! My Dad Says,” the William Shatner comedy based on the popular Twitter feed, proved its strong premiere ratings were not an anomaly, as 10.4 million viewers tuned in to the sitcom on Thursday, according to Nielsen’s estimates. CBS’s crime shows delivered the night’s largest audiences, with “CSI” earning 13.3 million viewers at 9 p.m., and “The Mentalist” drawing 14.6 million at 10. The network also kicked off the night on a high note, attracting 13 million for “The Big Bang Theory” at 8, no doubt helping to increase the audience for Mr. Shatner’s new comedy at 8:30. “$#*! My Dad Says” outperformed all other programming in the 8 o’clock hour, including Fox’s “Bones” (9.6 million), ABC’s disappointing “My Generation” (3.9 million) and NBC’s comedies “Community” (4.5 million) and “30 Rock” (5.7 million). ABC ranked second for the night, earning solid results for its medical dramas “Grey’s Anatomy” (12.2 million) and “Private Practice” (8 million). Fox was third and NBC fourth, struggling at 10 with “The Apprentice” (3.7 million).

headline: The Week in Pictures for Oct. 1
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the campaign for governor, the American Muslim Day Parade, storm damage and a strike by dockworkers.

headline: Alaska Democrat Seeks Stevens Mantle
text: In Alaska, the G.O.P. and the Tea Party are strong. But the most durable political brand just might be Uncle Ted.

headline: Texas Pharmacies Sue CVS Caremark
text: A group of Texas pharmacies has filed a lawsuit against CVS Caremark, the nation’s largest pharmacy health care provider, saying it violates racketeering and privacy laws.

headline: Following Tradition With Three Solid Blows
text: A major part of the job for any music director of the New York Philharmonic is to tend to its traditions as the oldest symphony orchestra in America. And since Gustav Mahler held the job for a brief but formative period from 1909 until his death in 1911, the Philharmonic’s Mahler tradition is a special case, as Alan Gilbert, the current boss, seems well aware.

headline: A Digital Update on the One-Man Band
text: AFTER some 120 logistically grueling, technologically challenging and emotionally exhilarating concerts on his Orchestrion Tour, the famed guitarist and budding robotics whiz Pat Metheny was still trying to explain in plain language just what he was up to with his latest and most unusual venture.

headline: Big Hairy Feet, Now in 3-D?
text: So “The Hobbit” will be in 3-D. That is a measure of how much the movie world has changed in the last year or so. In the dimly remembered recesses of, oh, 2009, people involved with the two-movie version of the J. R. R. Tolkien book, then to be directed by Guillermo del Toro, insisted that 2-D screen technology was just right for a pair of movies that were viewed as being a little more intimate than their sweeping precursors in the “Lord of the Rings” trilogy. Then came “Avatar,” “Alice in Wonderland,” and even the much-maligned “Clash of the Titans” — one film after another proving that viewers would pay a premium for 3-D, as long as the underlying movie wasn’t an utter bust.

headline: Gesundheits as Chekhov and Vaudeville Collide
text: “The Sneeze,” the sketch from which a collection of eight stories and playlets by Chekhov takes its title, evokes classic silent comedy from the schools of Buster Keaton through to Mr. Bean. It involves Mr. and Mrs. Senior Government Official (Bradford Cover and Rachel Botchan) watching a performance of Tchaikovsky’s “Swan Lake,” with a low-level counterpart and his wife (Chris Mixon and Lee Stark) seated directly behind them. The offending outburst causes a ticklish pantomime of flying nasal debris, mortification, apology, insult, umbrage and political death, before it crescendos to cardiac arrest. The vignette earns laughs as physical comedy and as a swipe at a rigidly hierarchical society.

headline: ‘Letters to Answer, and Logs to Split’
text: At Pete Seeger’s 90th birthday celebration last year at Madison Square Garden, Bruce Springsteen called him America’s granddad, but with “a steely toughness that belies that grandfatherly facade.” Now 91, he has just written a new song addressing the Gulf oil spill and, in July, released a new album, “Tomorrow’s Children,” on Appleseed Recordings.

headline: Tech Deals Percolate, but There’s No M.&A. Boom
text: While there have been a number of notable technology deals recently, the sector is hardly experiencing a boom in mergers and acquisitions. The total value of technology deals in the third quarter fell 26 percent from second quarter. Still, the M.&A. market was stronger than in the depressed third quarter of 2009, when the economy was emerging from one of the worst recessions on record.

headline: A Mortgage Promotion, in Detail
text: An advertisement for an adjustable-rate mortgage being offered by ING makes some questionable claims about how the rates will change over time.

headline: In Mortgage Ad, Two Wrongs Don’t Make a Right
text: One of the most important lessons of the mortgage collapse is that potential borrowers need clear explanations of exactly what kind of commitment they are making.

headline: As the World Turned for Women in 1905
text: Esther is 35 and worries that she’ll never marry. Mrs. Van Buren worries that she can’t have children. Mayme, a prostitute, claims not to worry about anything anymore but still holds out faint hope for true love.

headline: Musharraf, Vowing Return, Announces New Party
text: LONDON  Pakistan’s former military ruler, Pervez Musharraf, used a meeting on Friday in one of London’s most historic political clubs to announce the creation of a new political party, the All Pakistan Muslim League, and to renew his pledge to return to Pakistan from a self-imposed exile here before national elections scheduled for 2013.

headline: Sometimes a Little of This and Some More of That Add Up to a Lot
text: Seven years ago, when City Center’s Fall for Dance festival was born, the idea of programming disparate companies in a single evening was new and bubbly. Now, depending on the show, the experience has flattened out, as if there were a seven-year itch. Effort is lauded above all else, and the last thing you expect is a glimpse into a fresh choreographic world.

headline: No Mozart, but Plenty of Whimsy
text: Quiz for balletomanes: A pretty heroine is in love with an impoverished but handsome village lad. A wealthy, bumbling suitor arrives, and the heroine’s parents chase away their daughter’s charming love interest, obsequiously fawning over the wealthy prospect. After some amusingly depicted obstacles, true love naturally prevails, and the love-struck pair is happy ever after by the final pas de deux.

headline: Sarkozy to Propose New Bond With Russia
text: PARIS  President Nicolas Sarkozy of France plans to propose a new security and economic relationship between Europe and Russia when he meets with President Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia and Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany this month in Deauville, senior French officials said Friday.

headline: ING Direct’s Statement on Its Mortgage Advertising
text: In this weekend’s Your Money column, I take a close look at a mortgage solicitation from ING Direct that fell short, in my opinion, of the kind of disclosure that would make the terms crystal clear.

headline: Not Exactly Your Top 40 ‘Reunited’
text: The Jazz Passengers wrapped up their first set at the Jazz Standard on Wednesday night with “Reunited,” a No. 1 hit for Peaches & Herb in 1979. Some liberties were taken, of course. The song, in its original form, is a lush disco ballad, sticky-sweet enough to spread on a biscuit. Here it began music-box prickly, with plucked violin and mallet-dampened vibraphone. The saxophonist Roy Nathanson recited a few thoughts about the passage of time and then sidled into the first verse:

headline: Tom Hanks Uses Web to Plot the Future
text: When Tom Hanks imagines the future, you might think he sees a desk strewn with Oscars, Emmys and the scripts for a dozen more World War II projects. But the far-flung earth that Mr. Hanks will present in a new Internet-based animated series called “Electric City” will be a more complicated one and yet  not surprisingly, given its creator  an optimistic one.

headline: A Musical Home With Three Sides
text: Chick Corea has adopted an array of instrumental formats over the years, from solo piano to full orchestra, occasionally plunging into projects like the Five Peace Band, a fusion extravaganza that traveled the globe last year. His most reliable vehicle, though, has been the acoustic trio. It’s in this arrangement  piano, bass and drums  that Mr. Corea seems most at ease, free to dig furrows into a standard repertory or put novel twists on rhythm and form.

headline: Just Jeff Daniels and His Guitar
text: THE actor Jeff Daniels has temporarily checked out of what he calls “the ambition hotel.”

headline: Granta’s List of Rising Literary Stars Spotlights Spanish-Language Authors
text: Through its periodic lists of the best young novelists, the British literary magazine Granta has built a reputation for spotting and promoting emerging talents long before they become widely known. A 1983 list of British writers included Martin Amis, Julian Barnes, Kasuo Ishiguro, William Boyd, Ian McEwan, Salman Rushdie and Graham Swift, while its similar inventory of American writers in 1996 drew attention to Sherman Alexie, Madison Smartt Bell, Edwidge Danticat, Jonathan Franzen and Lorrie Moore.

headline: When the Star Wattage Is High but Movies Shine
text: IN the Hamptons, a certain amount of star wattage is endemic, but when the 18th Annual Hamptons International Film Festival starts on Thursday, the celebrity presence on the east end of Long Island will be even more concentrated than usual. Alec Baldwin, Isabella Rossellini, Bruce Weber, Joel and Ethan Coen, Julian Schnabel and many others are expected to attend the festival, which will include more than 100 films in a number of competitive and noncompetitive categories.

headline: Waiting for the Show at Nina Ricci
text: Models spend a lot of time backstage, sometimes in white robes. They rehearse, even though the runways seldom vary. Our photographer Valerio Mezzanotti captured the wait at Nina Ricci on Thursday night, where the room was draped in pink silk. He also caught newcomer Lindsey Wixson.

headline: Pelosi to Shake Money Trees for Democrats
text: For Republican candidates, the House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, is a favorite target these days — the San Francisco liberal and leader of the Democratic incumbents that the insurgent, resurgent G.O.P. challengers want to oust. But as vilified as she may be at times, Ms. Pelosi is planning an aggressive itinerary to raise money for individual Democratic candidates and for her party as whole in the closing weeks of the campaign.

headline: The Right Kind of Disclosures for Mortgage Applicants
text: In this weekend’s Your Money column, I take a close look at an ING Direct mortgage promotion that turned up in the mailbox at Bucks headquarters in Brooklyn. Turns out the company broke one Federal Reserve rule related to adjustable rate mortgage disclosures and didn’t meet my own common sense/raised eyebrow standard over all.

headline: Leading a Singleton Gives Partner a Welcome Ruff
text: The Friday Swiss Teams at the Long Island Fall Regional in Smithtown, N.Y., eight days ago was won by the husband and wife Stephen Lucas and Lesley Decker Lucas of Woodbury, N.Y., and by Kelley Hwang and Glenn Robbins of Manhattan.

headline: Tip of the Week: Getting the Most From a Mac’s Dictionary
text: To see the Dictionary program that comes with Mac OS X 10.5 and 10.6 display definitions, press the command key and the space bar and then type a word into the Spotlight search bar; you can also open the program from the Applications folder. But like its paper counterpart (the New Oxford American Dictionary), the Dictionary program does much more than word definitions, even without an Internet connection.

headline: Recalling the Glory Days of Reader’s Digest
text: Chappaqua, N.Y.

headline: Marvelous Invention of Movie Make-Believe
text: What is a movie star? It may be more appropriate to phrase the question in the past tense, as an acknowledgment that the old breed is dying out and also as a valedictory tribute to one of its finest specimens. Because whatever the definition — a great performer; a larger-than-life personality; a sex symbol — the picture next to the dictionary entry might as well be of Tony Curtis in his prime, with his blue eyes, full lips and lush head of hair.

headline: At Edge of Whitney, Touching the Void
text: As Stephen Petronio leaned out face-forward horizontally into space on Thursday afternoon, only his feet touching the edge of the roof at the Whitney Museum of American Art, the crowd below gave a stifled gasp. Mr. Petronio was about to begin his short and hair-raising re-enactment of Trisha Brown’s 1970 “Man Walking Down the Side of a Building,” and it was a scary, exhilarating sight.

headline: Lanvin Says Take Your Pick; Dior Joins the Navy
text: Paris

headline: Wuhl, Former On-Screen Sports Agent, Gets Sports Radio Show
text: Robert Wuhl, the comic actor who played a sports agent on HBO’s “Arliss,” will be taking a real job in the business starting in January, when he will host a three-hour sports talk radio show for Westwood One on weekdays from 3 p.m. to 6 p.m.

headline: Photos of Survival in an Emergency Room
text: Ashley Gilbertson has taken photographs in emergency rooms throughout the world, including in Iraq and Afghanistan. But what he saw during the week he spent in the Maimonides Medical Center emergency room in Brooklyn shocked him.

headline: CNN Fires Sanchez After Critique of Stewart
text: Rick Sanchez, a daytime anchor at CNN, was fired on Friday, a day after telling a radio interviewer that Jon Stewart was a bigot and that “everybody that runs CNN is a lot like Stewart.”

headline: Their Lotus Can’t Take Root on a Yoga Mat
text: FOR yogis, few accessories are as ubiquitous as the yoga mat  that precious strip of padding that serves as a cushion, a territory marker and even a rolled-up status symbol, conveying one’s membership in the yoga tribe.

headline: Women of the Brooklyn Y.W.C.A.
text: About 200 women live at the Brooklyn Y.W.C.A. Some are there temporarily, while others have made it a permanent home. Four residents tell their stories.

headline: At the Y, ‘They Take Care of Each Other’
text: VALERIE BERGER was nearly 60 but had never had her own place. She split her time between her mother’s house and her boyfriend’s apartment, both in Park Slope, Brooklyn. Then her boyfriend died of a surgery-related infection at age 70, a few years after her mother did. Unable to afford much else, Ms. Berger moved in April 2009 into the Y.W.C.A. in Brooklyn, where she pays $625 a month — including utilities — for her 8-foot-by-12-foot room (a phone, with voicemail, costs $15 extra).

headline: Two Weeks, and Two Canceled Shows
text: The second week of the fall television season brought two casualties: Fox’s “Lone Star” and ABC’s “My Generation.”

headline: Syrian Actress Tests Boundaries Again
text: DAMASCUS, Syria

headline: Soggy Questions About October Dates
text: NEWPORT, Wales  Ryder Cups have been played later than this one, but the early October dates in Wales were causing ample debate in the aftermath of a soggy opening day, in which not one match came close to completion.

headline: Ana Meier and Daniel Creighton
text: WHEN she was a child, Ana Meier once announced to her family that she wanted to paint her bedroom pink, a radical idea in her household.

headline: The Wedding of Ana Meier and Daniel Creighton
text: On Sept. 25, the couple were married at the home of her father, architect Richard Meier, in East Hampton, NY.

headline: Tracking an Athlete’s Moves, Hollywood Style
text: Orthopedic surgeons at Massachusetts General Hospital are using motion-capture technology to try to improve athletes’ performance or prevent injuries.

headline: House Forecast: As October Dawns, November’s Math Still Strong for G.O.P.
text: Our House forecasting model continues to show Republicans as having about a two-in-three chance — 67 percent — of taking over the House on Nov. 2, similar to the forecast in recent weeks.

headline: Settlements Stymie U.S. Envoy’s Mideast Effort
text: JERUSALEM  The Obama administration’s Middle East envoy left Jerusalem empty-handed on Friday after intensive efforts to save Palestinian-Israeli peace talks that have run aground on Israel’s decision to allow a freeze on West Bank Jewish settlement construction to expire.

headline: For a Plus-Size Show, a Slimmer Backdrop
text: You can’t resist the upbeat charms of “Hairspray” at Paper Mill Playhouse, where the cheerful musical about a big-haired girl with outsize dreams is being happily replicated on a somewhat smaller scale than the 2002 Broadway hit that ran for more than six years. Though the scenery is slimmed-down, this fast-paced crowd-pleaser packs every ounce of its original whirlwind appeal.

headline: Jet-Lagged, but Eager to Shop
text: One of the glitzy, fine-dining restaurants that brought the flash of Las Vegas to a formerly bereft stretch of western Chelsea about five years ago, Morimoto still packs in a mix of celebrities, downtown creative types, tourists and international businesspeople. It has an eye-popping white-on-white décor — including an illuminated wall made of 17,500 water bottles — and an over-the-top genre-busting menu from Masaharu Morimoto, one of the stars of “Iron Chef America,” on the Food Network. But the restaurant, on 10th Avenue between 15th and 16th Streets, also manages a casual ease, which on Tuesday drew in a regular customer indulging in the $120 omakase menu at the sushi bar; co-workers sharing cocktails and snacks in the subterranean lounge; and a neighbor entertaining his parents visiting from Fulda, a small town in Germany.

headline: Ukraine: Court Gives President Some of Parliament’s Power
text: President Viktor F. Yanukovich’s control over the government grew on Friday when the constitutional court handed him some of Parliament’s powers. The court overturned changes in the government’s structure, adopted in 2004, that had split authority between the president and Parliament. Mr. Yanukovich, above, who took office this year, praised the decision, saying that he hoped to go even further by holding a referendum on a new Constitution. But his opponents said he had rigged the court and was trying to create an authoritarian system. Mr. Yanukovich’s allies control Parliament, and he has a loyal prime minister. But if opposition parties make gains in new elections, it will be harder for them to block his agenda.

headline: Excerpts From the Ethnic Press
text: Immigrant news organizations, like their mainstream cousins, have been closely tracking local political campaigns. In the following excerpts, El Diario La Prensa celebrates Francisco Moya’s victory in the Democratic primary for a Queens Assembly seat, while a Pakistani Web site and the Polish daily Nowy Dziennik report on apathy and feelings of marginalization. KIRK SEMPLE

headline: Russian Party Gains in Latvia Amid Economic Bust
text: RIGA, Latvia  When Latvians wrested their country from the Soviet Union two decades ago, their first thought, it seemed, was escape. Unable to physically uproot the country from its tiny plot next to Russia, they sought to integrate as deeply as possible with the West, eventually joining the European Union and NATO while spurning their former colonial masters and marginalizing the Russians who remained here.

headline: Will TARP Turn  to Gold?
text: “It wasn’t fair, but it was necessary.”  That comment about the Troubled Asset Relief Program, from Treasury Secretary Tim Geithner in April, seemed about the best that anyone would ever say of it. But with the program officially coming to an end on Sunday, some folks are pushing a different description: profitable.

headline: For a Newsman and His Town, the End of an Era
text: Ogdensburg, N.Y.

headline: My, for a Young Killer, You’re Cute as a Button
text: The evil-child movie has been with us at least as long as “The Bad Seed” (1956, gloriously funny) and “Village of the Damned” (1960, effectively chilling), and “Case 39” adds little to the diminutive-demon genre. Radiating a distinctly retro vibe, this throwaway thriller from the German director Christian Alvart tosses a bone to Renée Zellweger, who chews it to a nub as Emily Jenkins, a harried social worker.

headline: Burgers With Attitude
text: Smashburger, the Denver-based franchise that recently opened its second and third restaurants in New Jersey, cooks its burgers as the name suggests: squashing a hunk of ground Angus beef with a metal hand press while it is grilled and seared.

headline: South Korea: Looking to Germany for Lessons on Reunification
text: Germany and South Korea agreed to set up an expert group to examine how the German reunification model might be applied to the Korean Peninsula, the German Interior Ministry said Friday. A memorandum of understanding signed by Christoph Bergner, Germany’s deputy interior minister, and Kim Chun-sig, South Korea’s deputy minister in charge of reunification affairs, said Seoul would get access to historic and government documents on Germany’s 1990 reunification. “We are willing to share our insight and experience gathered with regard to the resolution of the German question, the economic reconstruction of eastern Germany and the development of the new federal states,” Mr. Bergner said.

headline: A Bit of Vietnamese, a Lot of Thai
text: IT was 8-ish on a Saturday night, the crowd was spilling out the door of Bamboo Leaf, and my heart sank. We didn’t have a reservation, but I had assumed Bradley Beach would be deserted after Labor Day.

headline: Israeli Soul Food
text: Westchester’s food scene has grown more diverse and interesting in recent years, and there is no need to travel to the city for most culinary fixes. But one exception has remained for much of the county: Middle Eastern street food.

headline: Crowds Fault Police Actions in Stuttgart
text: BERLIN — Tens of thousands of protesters flooded the streets of Stuttgart in southwestern Germany on Friday chanting “Shame on you,” one day after the police used pepper spray, water cannons and tear gas to disperse crowds that had gathered to save centuries-old trees from being cut down, German news agencies reported.

headline: Sprawling Menu and a Space to Match
text: VILLAGE Social Kitchen and Bar has opened in the space that was Woody’s on Main, and before that Luna (and before that a Ford dealership, the spacious dimensions of which remain pretty much intact).

headline: Michelle Martin and Justin Esgar
text: Michelle Hope Martin and Justin Taylor Esgar were married Saturday evening in East Meadow, N.Y. Rabbi Ronald L. Androphy performed the ceremony at the East Meadow Jewish Center.

headline: Rosanna Lam and R. Tom Boonyasai
text: Rosanna Lam and Rungtum Tom Boonyasai were married Saturday morning at the Lighthouse at Chelsea Piers in New York. Stuart B. Chernoff, a minister of the Spiritual Humanist Church, officiated.

headline: Lexi Dauber and Scott Rudolph
text: Lexi Dauber and Scott Evan Rudolph were married Saturday evening at Cedar Hill Golf and Country Club in Livingston, N.J. Rabbi Matthew D. Gewirtz officiated.

headline: Lisa Troyano, Patrick Ascolese
text: Lisa Marie Troyano and Patrick Alan Ascolese were married Saturday in Newport, R.I. The Rev. Kris von Maluski, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Joseph Parish Church.

headline: Jessie Podell, Ryan Pressman
text: Jessie Podell, a daughter of Adina Podell and Dan Podell of Caldwell, N.J., is to be married Sunday afternoon in Glen Ridge, N.J., to Ryan Pressman, a son of Ronni Pressman and Fred Pressman of Bloomfield, N.J. Rabbi Garry Loeb is to officiate at the Women’s Club of Glen Ridge, with Cantor Joel Caplan taking part in the ceremony.

headline: Purva Bedi and David Stoler
text: Purva Bedi and David Andrew Stoler are to be married Sunday at Bridgewaters, an event space in Manhattan. Jerusha Klemperer, who was ordained by the Church of Spiritual Humanism, is to officiate. She will say some Jewish prayers, and Pandit Krishna Pratap Dixit, a Hindu priest, is to also take part in the ceremony.

headline: Elena Stewart, Patrick Turevon
text: Elena Frances Stewart and First Lt. Patrick Veikko Turevon were married Saturday at St. Dominic’s Church in Oyster Bay, N.Y. The Rev. Gregory A. Schenden, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Jordana Horn, Jon Gordon
text: Jordana Horn and Jon Andrew Gordon are to be married Sunday morning at Congregation B’nai Jeshurun in New York. Rabbi Michael S. Friedman is to perform the ceremony, with Rabbi Azriel C. Fellner taking part.

headline: Michele Wiles, James McCullough
text: Michele Lee Wiles and James Renwick McCullough were married Saturday at Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York. The Rev. Dr. Fred R. Anderson, the pastor of the church, performed the ceremony.

headline: Jennifer Brown and Gust Hookanson
text: Jennifer Lucile Brown and Gust Jeremy Hookanson were married Saturday at the Watermark, a bar and lounge in Asbury Park, N.J. The Rev. Jeffery T. Bassett, a minister of the Living Water Ministries, officiated.

headline: Erika Hoops, Alexander Gorodetsky
text: Erika Elisabeth Hoops, the daughter of Maureen L. Hoops and Daniel J. Hoops of Dallas, was married Saturday morning to Alexander Gorodetsky, the son of Tatyana Gorodetsky and Leon Gorodetsky of New York. The Rev. William J. Bergen performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

headline: Officials in Contador Case Proceed at Deliberate Pace
text: More than two months after Alberto Contador failed a drug test at the Tour de France, officials from the International Cycling Union are clearly taking their time to investigate the matter before determining whether Contador should be charged with an antidoping violation.

headline: David Olsen and Leonard Flood
text: David Carlton Olsen and Leonard Joseph Flood were married Saturday at Christ Episcopal Church in Swansea, Mass. The Rev. Dr. Richard E. Bardusch performed the ceremony.

headline: Lisa Leigh, Kurt Abrahamson
text: Elizabeth Leigh and Kurt Gunner Abrahamson were married Saturday in a house in Calistoga, Calif., rented for the occasion. William Ericson, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

headline: Daisy Sindelar, Grant Podelco
text: Daisy Sindelar and Grant Podelco were married Saturday afternoon at Blackwater Falls Lodge in Blackwater Falls State Park in Davis, W.Va. Murphy Birdsall, a minister with the Universal Brotherhood Movement and a maternal aunt of the bride, led the ceremony, which incorporated Slavic elements, including folk songs and proverbs.

headline: Emily Schnure, Eric Bratten
text: Emily Joanne Schnure and Eric Douglas Bratten were married Friday evening at the Church of the Blessed Sacrament in New York. Msgr. Robert B. O’Connor, the church’s pastor, performed the ceremony.

headline: Elizabeth Howie and Clifford Dank
text: Elizabeth Wu Howie and Clifford Harris Dank were married Saturday at Chandler Hovey Park in Marblehead, Mass. The Rev. George Westerberg, an Episcopal priest, officiated, and Garrett R. Smith, a leader of Congregation Sar Shalom in Newton, Mass., took part.

headline: Diana Benton, Jason Schechter
text: Diana Jarvis Benton and Jason Henry Schechter were married Saturday evening at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. Rabbi Jessica Zimmerman officiated.

headline: Samantha Salvant, Richard Aviles
text: Samantha S. Salvant and Richard A. Aviles were married Saturday in Manhattan. The Rev. Jose Humphreys, a minister with the Evangelical Covenant Church, officiated at Turtle Pond in Central Park.

headline: Lyssa Sorkin, Benjamin Jacobs
text: Dr. Lyssa Yve Sorkin and Dr. Benjamin Harrison Jacobs were married Saturday evening at Cold Spring Country Club in Huntington, N.Y. Cantor Martha T. Novick officiated.

headline: Jessie Podell, Ryan Pressman
text: Jessie Podell, a daughter of Adina Podell and Dan Podell of Caldwell, N.J., is to be married Sunday afternoon in Glen Ridge, N.J., to Ryan Pressman, a son of Ronni Pressman and Fred Pressman of Bloomfield, N.J.

headline: Leah Altman, Zack Smith
text: Leah Kate Altman, the daughter of Phyllis Kaplan Altman and Jeffrey N. Altman of New York, was married Saturday evening to Zack David Smith, a son of Maxine Smith and Gary Smith of Los Angeles. Rabbi Steven Z. Leder officiated at the Ojai Valley Inn and Spa in Ojai, Calif.

headline: Danielle Rudich, Matthew Wosnitzer
text: Dr. Danielle Sylvie Rudich and Dr. Matthew Scott Wosnitzer are to be married Sunday at the Glen Island Harbour Club in New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbi David J. Small is to officiate.

headline: Jennifer Pan, Jared Chung
text: Jennifer Jie Pan, the daughter of Xiangping Liu and Youfang Pan of Carmel, Ind., is to be married Sunday evening to Jared Alexander Chung, the son of Eva Bruné of New York and Robert Chung of Berkeley, Calif. Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel is to officiate at the Bryant Park Grill in New York.

headline: Catherine Pullins, Scott Miles
text: Catherine McGuire Pullins and Scott Christopher Miles were married Saturday at the First Congregational Church on Nantucket in Massachusetts. The Rev. Dr. Gary W. Klingsporn, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony.

headline: Erin Reynolds, Daniel Kelsh
text: Erin Marie Reynolds and Daniel William Andrew Kelsh were married Saturday by the Rev. Michael F. Ford at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Monica in Manhattan.

headline: Christie Gestal, Amy Gross

Gestal of New Canaan, Conn., was joined in a commitment ceremony Saturday to Amy Leigh Gross, the daughter of Joan M. Gross and Alan D. Gross of Shaker Heights, Ohio. Lisa Dion, a work colleague of Ms. Gestal’s, led the couple in affirming their partnership at the Lodge and Spa at Cordillera, a resort in Edwards, Colo.

headline: Tony Maida, Anthony Volpe

Brown of Los Altos, Calif. The Rev. Michael O. Shirley performed the ceremony at Emmanuel Episcopal Church in Manchester-by-the-Sea, Mass.

Johnson and Mr. Bailey Sr., both of Brooklyn. The Rev. Matthew U. McKie, a Pentecostal minister, officiated at a nondenominational Christian ceremony at the Helen Mills Event Space and Theater in Manhattan.

Belson of Gates Mills, Ohio, was married there Saturday to Patrick William Devers, a son of Susan Beck Devers and Kevin P. Devers of South Euclid, Ohio. The bride’s mother, who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated at the Chagrin Valley Hunt Club.

Rueger, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Francis Xavier Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn.

O’Connor, the church’s pastor, performed the ceremony, with the Rev. Stuart E. Clark, a minister of the Reformed Church of America, taking part.

headline: Ashley Donnenfeld, Christopher Shackelton
text: Ashley Dawn Donnenfeld and Christopher Scott Shackelton were married Saturday evening at the Metropolitan Club in New York. Rabbi Richard H. Berman officiated.

text: Bank of America, the country’s largest mortgage lender by assets, said on Friday that it was reviewing documents in all foreclosure cases now in court to evaluate if there were errors.

text: Rick Sanchez, a daytime anchor at CNN, was fired on Friday, a day after telling a radio interviewer that Jon Stewart was a bigot and that “everybody that runs CNN is a lot like Stewart.”

Alexandre Jr. of Bedminster, N.J., was married Saturday evening to Denis Reed Dwyer, the son of Judy R. Dwyer and Denis J. Dwyer of Southampton, N.Y. The Rev. Mathew Fenlon, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Luke’s Episcopal Church in Gladstone, N.J.

headline: Oregon Turns Practice Into Nonstop Sprint With Precision as Goal

headline: After Paladino’s Claim Against Cuomo, a Father-to-Daughters Talk
text: Andrew M. Cuomo said Friday that he could deal with the unsubstantiated — and, later, clumsily retracted — claims made by his rival in the race for governor, Carl P. Paladino, that Mr. Cuomo had been unfaithful to his wife.

headline: Judge Delays Detainee’s Trial Over Issue of Witness
text: A federal judge in Manhattan has postponed the first civilian trial of a former detainee at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, until Wednesday.

headline: California Tightens Oversight of CT Scans
text: California’s governor has signed tough new legislation tightening oversight of diagnostic CT scans, largely in response to the overdosing of hundreds of patients who underwent brain scans for stroke in 2008 and 2009.

headline: California Reduces Its Penalty for Marijuana
text: SAN FRANCISCO  A month before California voters decide the fate of a ballot initiative that would legalize marijuana, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger has signed a bill that essentially puts those caught possessing small amounts of the drug on the same level as those caught speeding on the freeway.

headline: Official to Face Hearing Over Blog Attacks
text: An assistant attorney general in Michigan has taken a personal leave of absence and may be disciplined for his online attacks on a gay campus leader at the University of Michigan.

headline: Atlanta Hats? Seattle Socks? Macy’s Goes Local
text: ATLANTA  Long before it was renamed Macy’s, the department store of choice here was Rich’s. Opening just after the Civil War, it drew generations of Atlantans with its coconut cake and the Pink Pig, a Christmastime children’s train.

headline: Mexico Seeks to Unify Police to Fight Drugs
text: SANTIAGO, Mexico  The Mexican government is preparing a plan to radically alter the nation’s police forces, hoping not only to instill a trust the public has never had in them but also to choke off a critical source of manpower for organized crime.

headline: Deal Near for ‘Hobbit’ Films in 3-D
text: LOS ANGELES  “The Hobbit” is almost out of movie jail.

headline: Chandler, a Swingman, Remains a Constant on a Knicks Team That Is Always Evolving
text: MILAN  They traded his mentors and his friends, the veterans who guided him and the pranksters who kept him laughing. For two straight years, they traded nearly everyone, until one day Wilson Chandler looked up and found a roster of near strangers staring back at him, a dizzy survivor of The Great Knicks Purge.

text: The already complex calculus on reverse mortgages is about to change.

headline: A Show About Iraqi Refugees, to an Audience That Can Relate
text: Tholfikar Altaie, a 28-year-old Iraqi refugee who lives with his family in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, does not always know how to begin explaining to friends in New York the life he left behind in Baghdad. Their curiosity is as vast as the gaps in their knowledge.

headline: Legal Debate Swirls Over Charges in a Student’s Suicide
text: Dozens of Rutgers University students wore black on Friday to remember Tyler Clementi, a freshman who killed himself after his roommate, according to prosecutors, secretly streamed over the Internet his intimate encounter with another man.

headline: The Political Wild Card
text: WILMINGTON  Before she was a Tea Party cause célèbre, liberal laughingstock and perhaps the embodiment of a can-you-top-this-for-bizarre political season, Christine O’Donnell grew up in a “Brady Bunch” household of six kids (three Democrats, three Republicans), two parents (one of each) and an appreciation for the dramatic, the eccentric and the media spotlight.

headline: Saturday: Producer of Hits
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — We get only one themeless crossword this week, and it’s a fun one by Barry C. Silk. I found it easier than average for this constructor but with plenty of terrific answers.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Too Funny for Words
text: Washington

headline: Cuomo Way Ahead of Paladino in Cash, for Now
text: Andrew M. Cuomo will enter the final month of the race for governor of New York with $19 million on hand, according to figures his campaign released on Friday night, far more than the $209,406 his Republican opponent, Carl P. Paladino, reported having.

headline: From Picassos to Sarcophagi, Guided by Phone Apps
text: Walk into a crowded museum, and what do you see? People with cameras or cellphones snapping pictures of people looking at objects. The artwork, document or fossil is a tourist site; the photograph is our souvenir. And the looking  for which museums were created  becomes a memory before it has even begun.

headline: Judge Backs 2004 Arrest of Protesters
text: A federal judge has upheld the arrest of two protesters who refused to leave a sidewalk across from Madison Square Garden during the Republican National Convention in 2004.

headline: Wright’s Recovery Has an Air of Whiff
text: After a year’s sabbatical, David Wright’s power numbers have returned to him like an old lost cat. His home runs and runs batted in are back to normal levels after a season in which he managed a career-low 10 home runs. His total bases have not lagged far behind.

headline: The Campaign Disconnect
text: One in five American kids was living in poverty in 2009. Across the country, once solidly middle-class families are lining up at food pantries and soup kitchens for groceries or a hot meal. In New York City, a startling indicator of the continuing economic stress is the rise in the number of homes that don’t have kitchens.

headline: White House Ponders Post-Election Outlook
text: WASHINGTON  Now that President Obama has put the drama of Rahm Emanuel’s departure as chief of staff behind him, his White House is preparing for a very different relationship with Congress after the midterm elections, when Republicans are expected to gain strength and more top advisers are likely to call it quits.

headline: With Another $1 Million Donation, Murdoch Expands His Political Sphere
text: Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation is playing a larger and more directly partisan role in this year’s elections than it is known to have played in any previous American campaign.

headline: The Terrible Election Race Race
text: Which state is having the most appalling campaign season?

headline: What’s Dumb, Really?
text: Big-city liberals and their blogging buddies love to paint Tea Partiers as yokels with incoherent candidates and language-mauling signs. (Some have even dubbed their misspellings and grammatical gaffes “Teabonics.”) On some level, this may be true. But there is also a certain hypocrisy to these taunts.

headline: New Leadership for Mets Seems Near
text: After the Mets agonized for weeks about whether to retain their manager and general manager, word leaked Friday that Jerry Manuel would not be asked back as manager and that Omar Minaya would lose his role as the top baseball decision-maker, as has been expected.

headline: Mr. Cuomo’s Record
text: New Yorkers elected Andrew Cuomo as the state attorney general in 2006 by a large margin, but even then they were not certain what they were getting.

headline: In California Bid, Whitman Spends Record but Struggles
text: LOS ANGELES  Meg Whitman, the Republican candidate for governor in California, passed a milestone the other day, investing $119 million of her own money into her campaign, breaking a record held by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York.

headline: Maher Airs More Comments by O’Donnell
text: Week Three of the Christine O’Donnell comic hostage crisis: As promised, Bill Maher pressed on with his Friday night embarrassment-by-installment campaign. He’s trying, and failing so far, to goad Delaware’s Republican/Tea Party candidate for Senate into appearing on his current HBO show, “Real Time,” by airing wacky comments from her appearances on his old ABC show, “Politically Incorrect.”

headline: Yankees Are Hoping for Clarity With Solid Pitching
text: BOSTON  A few Yankees were sitting on a couch in the visiting clubhouse at Fenway Park Friday afternoon when a voice from the television started predicting their downfall. What happens if C. C. Sabathia stumbles in Game 1 of the playoffs? Or if the Yankees don’t win their division? Watch out for the Twins. Forget about Title No. 28. On it went.

headline: Closer Look at Rift Between Humanists Reveals Deeper Divisions
text: AMHERST, N.Y.  You can tell something about a man by what he names his dog. At Paul Kurtz’s house, I was greeted in his driveway by a pug puppy named John Dewey. The dog’s predecessors, I learned, included Voltaire and Bentham.

headline: Back to the Past
text: President Obama’s call for sweeping changes in the space program got mugged by lobbyists and pork-minded legislators. An authorization bill for NASA  the National Aeronautics and Space Administration  that cleared Congress will leave the agency mired in past technologies.

text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: G.E.’s Latest Maneuver
text: After decades of legal maneuvering, the General Electric Company finally agreed in 2006 to clean up the industrial pollutants it dumped in the Hudson River from the 1940s to the ’70s. The consent decree with the Environmental Protection Agency required the company to dredge the river free of toxic sediment.

headline: Bloggingheads: Talk to the Taliban?
text: Steven Walt, left, of Harvard University and Peter Bergen of the New America Foundation debate negotiating with the Taliban.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,294 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It recently confirmed the deaths of the following Americans:

headline: Louisiana: Admiral Ends Role
text: Thad W. Allen, the retired Coast Guard admiral leading the federal response to the BP oil spill, stepped down as planned on Friday, transferring oversight duties to Rear Adm. Paul Zukunft. Admiral Allen, left, has been a familiar face on television and a target of criticism and praise for the federal government’s actions. He made significant changes in the response command structure, a reorganization that was broadly welcomed by residents and local officials. “At a time when he could have enjoyed a well-deserved retirement from the United States Coast Guard, Admiral Allen stepped up to the plate and served his country when his skills and experience were urgently needed,” President Obama said in a statement.

headline: The Torturous Trials of the Idle Juror
text: The rocky shores of a cold lake. Soot-smudged medieval faces, twisted into grimaces. And then, from yonder trees, a desperate-looking villager being shoved to water’s edge, where he is bound at hand and foot and thrown in the water.

headline: ‘Waiting for Superman’ and the Education Debate
text: Take along a handkerchief if you plan to see the new education documentary “Waiting for Superman.” Steve Barr, a tough-minded charter school developer, told me on Friday that he had already seen the film four times and still can’t get through it without sobbing.

headline: Joseph Sobran, Writer Whom Buckley Mentored, Dies at 64
text: Joseph Sobran, a hard-hitting conservative writer and moralist whose outspoken antipathy to Israel and what he saw as the undue influence of a Jewish lobby on American foreign policy led to his removal as a senior editor of National Review in 1993, died on Thursday in Fairfax, Va. He was 64 and lived in Burke, Va.

headline: With Victory, Zenyatta Would Carry Perfect Mark Into Breeders’ Cup
text: Last year at this time, Rachel Alexandra and Zenyatta stood atop the thoroughbred racing world and had penetrated the consciousness of casual sports fans. Rachel Alexandra was undefeated in eight races, had beaten the boys three times and had graced the pages of Vogue.

headline: Pact Ends California Budget Impasse
text: SACRAMENTO  Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger and top lawmakers agreed to a compromise to close a $19.1 billion deficit and give California a budget, ending the state’s record three-month impasse with a vote expected next week on the spending plan, according to legislative leaders.

headline: Stephen J. Cannell, Prolific TV Writer, Dies at 69
text: Stephen J. Cannell, one of television’s most prolific writers and series creators, whose work encompassed the “The Rockford Files” and “Wiseguy” to “The A-Team” and “The Greatest American Hero,” died Thursday at his home in Pasadena, Calif. He was 69.

headline: Nonprofit Group Wins Pepsi Contest
text: A nonprofit group that complained that Pepsi had allowed organizations with political agendas to participate in its online giving contest, Pepsi Refresh, won one of the two $250,000 prizes. The group, Arms Wide Open Childhood Cancer Foundation, raises money for alternative therapies and treatments for children with neuroblastoma. The group contended that 16 contestant-groups that were members of the Progressive Slate were political groups tied to the Democratic party and thus violated contest rules. Pepsi disagreed, saying the groups were not advocating for a particular candidate or issue. Eight of those groups won $50,000 prizes.

headline: Satyam Says It Received Notice From S.E.C.
text: Satyam Computer Services, which is embroiled in India’s biggest corporate fraud investigation, disclosed that it received a so-called Wells Notice from the United States Securities and Exchange Commission in September 2009. The disclosure indicated that the agency’s enforcement division would recommend the filing of a civil suit against Satyam related to financial irregularities by the company’s chairman earlier in 2009. The S.E.C. has not yet decided whether to file a suit, Satyam said.

headline: Dozens Die in Indonesian Train Crash
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia  At least 36 people were killed and dozens severely injured in a high speed collision between two intercity trains in Indonesia’s Central Java province early Saturday. The cause was likely human error, officials said.

headline: Barry Who? Giants on the Verge of a Division Title
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Using young pitching, a breakout catcher and a lineup peppered with veteran castoffs, the San Francisco Giants have put themselves on the doorstep of winning the National League West, needing just one victory over the weekend to clinch the division. And for the first time since George Bush  the first one  was president, they have done it without Barry Bonds.

headline: Examining Mantle’s Running Play From 1960
text: After writing about the discovery of a pristine kinescope of Game 7 of the 1960 World Series between the Yankees and the Pirates in Bing Crosby’s old wine cellar, Richard Sandomir followed up Friday with an analysis of a critical base-running play in the game’s ninth inning.

headline: Haider Ackermann: Broken Hearts
text: Even if there had been no “Love Me Tender” at Haider Ackermann’s superb show Saturday morning, the clothes would have still delivered a rare emotional charge. The collection, paced slowly, opened with black motorcycle leather reduced to halters and vests, and a pair of black suede trousers, low and tight, with a billowy silk fold at the waist band, as though the lining had been pulled.

headline: Being a Rex Ryan ‘Guy.’  Trevor Pryce Explains.
text: Why do players love to play for Rex Ryan?

headline: G.M. Said to Scale Back I.P.O. Expectations
text: General Motors has reduced the expected size of its initial public offering from $12 billion to $8 billion, as the automaker faces difficult market conditions, The Financial Times reported.

headline: For Porsche, Taking Delivery at the Factory Is an Event
text: For those new-car buyers inclined to travel and to undertake a bit of adventure, the option of a European delivery makes sense — and might even save a bit of money.

headline: Trailing Early, Europe Seizes the Momentum
text: NEWPORT, Wales  The Ryder Cup began producing winners and losers on Saturday, and with the backlog of matches from Friday’s rain-interrupted session, there was a surplus of both at Celtic Manor Resort.

text: So, why did Tim Geithner feel the need to declare,

headline: Why Credit Cards?
text: In my Times column this week, I wrote about what I consider a breakthrough: the Square reader, which snaps into a smartphone or iPod Touch or iPad and lets you take credit-card payments. Yes, you, a non-corporate individual.

headline: How The Other Half Thinks
text: Ezra Klein has written in, asking for a post laying out the difference between the more or less Keynesian model Brad DeLong and I work with and the models others have been using – and how their predictions differ. It’s a good request, although the truth is that the other side in this debate doesn’t necessarily agree on a single model, or even use models at all. Still, I think it is possible to describe the general views of the other guys — and to see how off their predictions have been.

headline: Model-Morphosis | Lanvin
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of Paris Fashion Week. Here, the model Martha Streck from Women Model Management before (right) and after (left) makeup by Pat McGrath and hair by Guido Palau. (Drag the orange bar right to reveal the full transformation.)

headline: Urban Forager | Fungus on the Lawn? Let’s Eat!
text: At the recent annual foray of the Northeast Mycological Federation near New Paltz, N.Y., some amateur mycologists expressed surprise when they learned that we had great mushrooms of our own in New York City.

text: The model Melodie Monrose of Wilhelmina Model Management gets reinvented five times.

text: The Spring/Summer 2011 collection from Lanvin at Paris Fashion Week.

text: When Chris Bonanno’s sister learned she had breast cancer two years ago, he was desperate to do something to help.

headline: The Saturday Word: Rally Back
text: Activists are gathering on the Washington Mall today for a rally they hope will provide an antidote to several conservative, Tea Party-inspired, demonstrations held in that same spot, including one organized by Glenn Beck in August.

headline: Struggling Woods Sends Shivers Rippling Through a Sport’s Universe
text: In 1993, the basketball world gasped when Michael Jordan retired so he could try his hand at baseball. Suddenly, the sport that he elevated to new heights had to find a new icon and marketing engine. The replacement, it turned out, was Jordan himself, who returned to the N.B.A. two years later.

headline: Split Decisions
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — We haven’t seen a George Bredehorn “Split Decisions” puzzle in a while. If you’re new to these, read the instructions carefully. If the going is slow, take a break and come back to it later. It’s an acquired skill, but it’s one that helps with solving crosswords as well. Speed solvers often talk about how they get at least as much information from the letters already in the grid as they do from the clues.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Maison Martin Margiela
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Alexandra Catiere.

headline: Palestinian Leaders Urge End to Talks With Israel
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank — The Palestinian leadership said Saturday that four-week-old direct talks with Israel should be suspended if Jewish settlement construction resumed in the West Bank. It called on the international community to pressure Israel to stop the building but withheld a final decision on the talks until an Arab League meeting on Friday.

headline: U.S. Leading in Clubhouse but Trailing on the Course
text: NEWPORT, Wales  At its best, the Ryder Cup can build like a symphony, with complex themes and interdependent rhythms that unfold over the course of three days, a crescendo toward the 12 singles matches, always played  until maybe this rainy week  on Sunday.

headline: A Stark Change of Scenery Re-energizes a Top Recruit
text: EL RENO, Okla.  In Nurideen Lindsey’s West Philadelphia neighborhood, he walked past the haunting reminders of violence every day. Teddy bears, candles and murals etched into sidewalks marked the sites of young lives lost.

headline: Claims to BP Fund Attract Scrutiny
text: Kenneth R. Feinberg spent part of his summer barnstorming towns near the Gulf of Mexico, urging people who felt they had suffered financial hardship because of the oil spill to apply for a share of the $20 billion BP fund he was overseeing. The point of the fund was to pay claims rather than litigate them in court.

headline: House Majority Still Uncertain, Republicans Say
text: WASHINGTON  Republicans carry substantial advantages as they move into the final month of the fall campaign, but the resilience of vulnerable Democrats is complicating Republican efforts to lock down enough seats to capture the House and take control of the unsettled electoral battleground.

headline: Vick Is the Talk of McNabb’s Town
text: PHILADELPHIA  The long, winding corridor leading to the Eagles’ locker room features the sort of décor professional sports franchises currently favor: glossy action photographs, framed newspaper clippings, heavy plaques and awards extolling the confetti-dotted moments in team history.

headline: Postscript to Crosby’s Wine Cellar Treasure
text: The discovery of a copy of the broadcast of Game 7 of the 1960 World Series in Bing Crosby’s former wine cellar led some readers to raise an interesting question: if Major League Baseball owns the copyright to World Series broadcasts, why did it have to pay the Crosby estate for the rights to televise the game on the MLB Network in December and release a DVD?

headline: Scorecard | Lanvin Wins!
text: Come away, come away! John Galliano’s Bali sky-H’ai costume drama on the third day of Paris Fashion Week had Scorecard flashing back to Lincoln Center — though not to the minimalist whiteout of a few weeks ago, but a bit further back. When it comes to a romantic wardrobe for contemporary power dressing, however, Alber Elbaz’s multivalent play on the complex theater of the female persona had critics thinking there are — thankfully — quite a few things you can name that ain’t anything like a dame.

headline: Supreme Court Term Offers Hot Issues and Future Hints
text: WASHINGTON  The new Supreme Court term, which begins Monday, includes cases on some of the most contested issues of the day, including protests at military funerals, illegal immigration, support for religious schools, violent video games, DNA evidence and prosecutorial misconduct.

headline: Brazilian Leader’s Protégée Likely to Prevail in Election
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Though Dilma Rousseff is a political novice and lacks the charisma of her former boss, President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, voters appear likely to make her the first woman to be president of Brazil in Sunday’s election.

headline: Injury Shouldn’t Hurt M.V.P. Bid
text: The idea that Josh Hamilton’s injury should keep him from winning the American League Most Valuable Player award ignores powerful precedents.

headline: Are Giants Ready to Follow a Leader?
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Inside the Giants’ practice facility, there is a linebacker so brazen he once walked into an offensive team meeting to criticize them and became so fiery his teammates could barely understand him when he yelled at them during practices. His name is Jessie Armstead.

headline: Outgrowing Dream, Keller Fulfills Vision
text: At a wine bar last month in Lower Manhattan, Jets tight end Dustin Keller opted for the food sampler. Variety had won again.

headline: Bin Laden Resurfaces in Recordings
text: It was an odd call for compassion from a terrorist who has proudly claimed responsibility for mass murder and who Western intelligence agencies say is still active in plotting terrorist attacks.

headline: Against Alabama, Pressure Is on Quarterbacks
text: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. — One play in January’s national championship game between Alabama and Texas that should have caught the eye of Florida quarterback John Brantley, who was sure to watch film this week to get ready to play the top-ranked Crimson Tide on Saturday night.

headline: Sniffing .300, Hitters Hunker Down on Last Chances
text: Before his last plate appearance of the 2007 season, with the postseason looming and his catcher’s body disintegrating like a ’72 Impala, Victor Martinez came to the plate and noticed the scoreboard taunting him.

headline: Premier Works to Build Broader Coalition in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD  Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki reached across sectarian lines on Saturday to appeal to Sunnis to broaden support for his re-election bid, even as a rival coalition representing most Sunnis declared that it would not accept his nomination and refused to join a coalition government led by him.

headline: The Shot That Carried All the Way to the Pyrenees
text: From his home run on Oct. 3, 1951, to his death on Aug. 16 at age 86, Bobby Thomson lived 21,502 days and, in that time, heard as many stories of where people were when he won the National League pennant for the New York Giants against the Brooklyn Dodgers at the Polo Grounds. He enjoyed them. He came to know through them that he had struck at just the right moment, that a confluence of technology, geography, history and the particulars of a game had made his homer historic. Though maddeningly diffident, he came to understand that like Neil Armstrong and Lee Harvey Oswald, he had provided a collective experience.

headline: Company Stops Insuring Titles in Chase Foreclosures
text: A major title insurance company has stopped insuring homes foreclosed by JPMorgan Chase, another sign that the controversy over the legal practices of the big lenders is starting to influence the housing market.

headline: Happy Leading Cubs, if Only for Now
text: The modest office at Wrigley Field does not look lived in, does not bear the personal stamp of its occupant, whose stay might be temporary. But it is a comfortable upgrade from the cramped quarters he shared with six fellow coaches down the hall.

headline: Liberal Groups Rally, Challenging Tea Party
text: WASHINGTON  Tens of thousands of union members, environmentalists and peace activists rallied at the Lincoln Memorial on Saturday, seeking to carry on the message of jobs and justice that the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. trumpeted at a rally at the same site 47 years ago.

headline: Michigan State’s Dantonio Is Hospitalized With Blood Clot
text: EAST LANSING, Mich. — Michigan State Coach Mark Dantonio has been hospitalized with a blood clot and will miss Saturday’s game with No. 9 Wisconsin.

headline: U.S. Drone Attacks Kill 17 Militants in Pakistan
text: Two attacks by United States drones killed 17 militants and wounded three in northern Pakistan on Saturday, a Pakistani intelligence official said, after recent NATO helicopter strikes raised tensions with Pakistan, a country that is crucial to Washington’s war effort in Afghanistan.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: The Very Useful Idiocy of Christine O’Donnell
text: ALL it took was some 30,000 Republican primary voters in a tiny state to turn Christine O’Donnell into the brightest all-American media meteor since Balloon Boy. For embattled liberals, not to mention the axis of Comedy Central, “Saturday Night Live” and Bill Maher, she’s been pure comic gold for weeks: a bottomless trove of baldfaced lies, radical views and sheer wackiness. True, other American politicians have dismissed evolution as a myth. Some may even have denied joining a coven. But history will always remember her for taking a fearless stand against masturbation, the one national pastime with more fans than baseball.

headline: From ‘Avatar’ Playbook, Athletes Use 3-D Imaging
text: In the endless quest for athletic advantage, a handful of major league baseball teams are engaged in an elaborate, largely clandestine race to master an advanced imaging technology that some baseball officials think could influence the way athletes of all ages train, perform and recover from injuries.

headline: Third Party Rising
text: A friend in the U.S. military sent me an e-mail last week with a quote from the historian Lewis Mumford’s book, “The Condition of Man,” about the development of civilization. Mumford was describing Rome’s decline: “Everyone aimed at security: no one accepted responsibility. What was plainly lacking, long before the barbarian invasions had done their work, long before economic dislocations became serious, was an inner go. Rome’s life was now an imitation of life: a mere holding on. Security was the watchword  as if life knew any other stability than through constant change, or any form of security except through a constant willingness to take risks.”

headline: At Risk From the Womb
text: Some people think we’re shaped primarily by genes. Others believe that the environment we grow up in is most important. But now evidence is mounting that a third factor is also critical: our uterine environment before we’re even born.

headline: On the Foreclosure Front
text: The housing mess got a lot messier last week as JPMorgan Chase halted 56,000 foreclosures amid doubts that it had correctly followed laws on the foreclosure process. The announcement came soon after GMAC Mortgage suspended an undisclosed number of foreclosures to gain time to review its legal procedures. There may be more suspensions to come.

headline: Diplomatic Knicks, Settled in Milan, Get Ready to Play
text: MILAN  After 24 hours in Italy, Patrick Ewing Jr. sent up an electronic flare.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Lanvin
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: Found in Translation
text: AS the author of “Las Horas,” “Die Stunden” and “De Uren”  ostensibly the Spanish, German and Dutch translations of my book “The Hours," but actually unique works in their own right  I’ve come to understand that all literature is a product of translation. That is, translation is not merely a job assigned to a translator expert in a foreign language, but a long, complex and even profound series of transformations that involve the writer and reader as well. “Translation” as a human act is, like so many human acts, a far more complicated proposition than it may initially seem to be.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Oct. 3
text: Sunday’s political talk shows come with a midterm twist, featuring a debate between Senate candidates in Kentucky and plenty of election chatter.

headline: Side Effects May Include Lawsuits
text: FOR decades, antipsychotic drugs were a niche product. Today, they’re the top-selling class of pharmaceuticals in America, generating annual revenue of about $14.6 billion and surpassing sales of even blockbusters like heart-protective statins.

headline: Mini to Take On Ford Fiesta in World Rally
text: PARIS — Almost lost in the hoopla around the Mini brand’s introduction of two oh-so-cute electric scooters at the Paris Motor Show on Thursday was the introduction of the hairy-chested, meat-eating Mini WRC Concept rally car.

headline: Mark Zuckerberg’s Most Valuable Friend

headline: Lotus CityCar: Lost in the Paris Hoopla
text: PARIS — Much was made at the Paris Motor Show’s press days last week of the five new models coming in the next five years from Lotus, the heretofore diminutive British carmaker. But lost in all the hoopla around the mass introductions, there was, in fact, a sixth Lotus model on display: The CityCar Concept.

headline: Count on Sequels to TARP
text: THE government is pulling a sheet over TARP, the Troubled Asset Relief Program created during the panic of 2008 to bail out the nation’s financial institutions. With the program’s expiration on Sunday, we can expect to hear lots of claims from the folks at the Treasury that it was a great success.

headline: As Games Begin, India Hopes to Save Its Pride
text: NEW DELHI  When India won its bid for the 2010 Commonwealth Games seven years ago, the event instantly became an emblem of national prestige. But as the country prepares to open the games on Sunday evening, an opportunity to burnish its global image has instead become a national embarrassment.

headline: Iran Says It Arrested Computer Worm Suspects
text: TEHRAN  Iran has arrested an unspecified number of “nuclear spies” in connection with a damaging worm that has infected computers in its nuclear program, the intelligence minister, Heydar Moslehi, said Saturday.

headline: British Nukes vs. British Troops
text: The pledge by Britain’s coalition government to drastically slash spending is bad economics and bad public policy. Budget tightening is needed, but not this much, this fast or this way. The cuts to be announced this month will put recovery at risk, unfairly squeeze poorer Britons, and make it hard for government departments to work. That includes defense  targeted for a 10 to 20 percent reduction over the next five years.

headline: Mr. Bloomberg, Mr. Murdoch, Mr. Colbert
text: It is too late to make a difference this year, but Congress, or at least one subcommittee, finally heard a thoughtful discussion about immigration. Mayor Michael Bloomberg of New York and Rupert Murdoch, head of the News Corporation  both billionaires  told the immigration subcommittee of the House Judiciary Committee that rational and well-regulated immigration is an economic necessity.

headline: Playing With Fire
text: Rearing a child is already a journey through self-doubt and guilt, and now here comes Gever Tulley to say we’re doing it wrong, and that what we really need to do is hand our young ones power tools and let them lick nine-volt batteries.

If we are to break out of this downward spiral, we first need to understand the problem, then deal with it on a huge scale.

headline: Can I Change Places?
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Daniel A. Finan gives us a collection of theme answers with Strabismus. That’s the medical term, more or less, for “wandering I,” and I’s wander all over today’s theme answers. My favorite is DON’T TOUCH THAT DALI for “Admonishment at a Surrealist museum.”

headline: Scholarly Work, Without All the Footnotes

headline: New Labour Leader Heads Back to Britain’s Center
text: LONDON  Out of power for barely five months, Britain’s Labour Party set an ambitious goal as it concluded its annual conference last week: fulfilling the pledge of Ed Miliband, the party’s new, 40-year-old leader, an intellectual leftist strongly favored by Britain’s powerful labor unions, to make the governing coalition of Conservatives and Liberal Democrats led by Prime Minister David Cameron “a one-term government.”

headline: Smugglers of Drugs Burrow on Border
text: NOGALES, Ariz.  Drone aircraft patrol the United States-Mexico border from the skies. Fast boats look out for smugglers at sea. And tens of thousands of Border Patrol agents use trucks, horses, all-terrain vehicles and bicycles to stop unauthorized crossers on land.

text: CRETE, Neb.  Nebraska may appear to be an unlikely setting for swelling anti-immigrant sentiment.

headline: Correction Officer Is Wounded in a Police Shooting
text: An off-duty New York City correction officer was shot in the arm early Saturday after he ignored orders to drop a loaded 9-millimeter pistol that he had pointed at a group of plainclothes police officers in the Bronx, the authorities said.

headline: Hopefuls for Calif. Governor Debate
text: FRESNO, Calif.  With accusations about an illegal Mexican housekeeper dogging her campaign, the Republican candidate for governor of California, Meg Whitman, angrily blamed her Democratic challenger, Jerry Brown, for her political problems on Saturday, adding a dose of emotion to a tight race.

headline: Lessons in a Large Family
text: I’M one of 10 children in my family. My mother, a nurse, was always busy around the house or taking care of a new baby. As the second-oldest child and the oldest girl, I became a surrogate parent to many of my siblings.

headline: Wright Puts Three-Run Exclamation Point on Mets’ Victory
text: In one of the more eventful meaningless games of the season, the Mets clobbered the Washington Nationals, 7-2, behind an emphatic and emotional home run by David Wright on Saturday.

headline: Female Marines in Marja
text: Full-time "female engagement teams'" deploy alongside all-male infantry patrols in Helmand Province to try to win over rural Afghan women, who are culturally off-limits to outside men.

headline: For Nevada Casinos, Threats in California
text: LINCOLN, Calif.  The Thunder Valley casino, outside Sacramento, has all the trappings of a modern gambling resort: endless rows of slot machines, a high-end spa offering gold-leaf facials and the type of performers  Tony Bennett, Peter Cetera  for whom casinos were seemingly invented.

headline: Drug Makers Accused of Ignoring Price Law
text: WASHINGTON  Drug manufacturers often flout a federal law that requires them to provide the government with pricing data needed to calculate discounts on medications prescribed for poor people under Medicaid, federal investigators say in a new report.

headline: A Battle Against Prescription Drugs Causes Pain
text: Roland Lorenz has surgical screws in his back and neck and a pin in his upper leg, and when his pain reared up one recent weekend, he knew he needed something strong. He had just been to a pain clinic, where the doctor ordered an increase in his dosage of Percocet, a narcotic.

headline: Stretch | The Jocks Throw Down Their Mats
text: As I tilted my body into a triangle pose last week and stole a glance at those behind me at Jivamukti Yoga Center in Union Square, I noticed a lot of guys in the room. Not quite half the class, but close.

headline: A Protest March or an Invasion?
text: POLITICIANS and journalists feared and mocked them. The police boosted their ranks by 200 to control them. Their leaders were hustled off to jail, on a charge that, 116 years later, seems not only anti-American but preposterous: unlawfully stepping on the grass outside the United States Capitol.

headline: Of Glamour and ‘Glee’
text: Saturday night marked the midpoint of Paris Fashion Week with yet another round of parties, including an event to introduce a collaboration between Karl Lagerfeld and Hogan and a dinner at La Société for Glamour magazine, not to mention a citywide celebration called Nuit Blanche, during which museums and restaurants stay open all night and half of Paris seems to be on the streets.

headline: Trafficking in the Southwest Goes Underground
text: As enforcement efforts have increased and border barriers have been built, tunneling has gained in popularity, with Nogales becoming the capital.

headline: Measuring Success by Mission, Not Profit
text: IN May, I moved from a corporate job to nonprofit work. I had been a vice president at a large financial services firm in New York, analyzing risks and recommending investments in tax-exempt portfolios. I specialized in bonds issued by state and local governments; public and private schools, colleges and universities; and other nonprofit organizations. Before that, I was a credit analyst at a bond insurance company.

headline: A Code for Chaos
text: IN June, a Belarus-based computer security firm identified a new computer malware program, Stuxnet, which was repeatedly crashing the computers of one of its clients. Then, last month, a German security researcher suggested that the program’s real target might be the Iranian nuclear program — and that clues in the coding suggested that Israel was the creator. Since then, there has been growing alarm about the worm, as its target and sophistication have become more apparent. The code has appeared in many countries, notably China, India, Indonesia and Iran. It appears designed to attack a certain type of Siemens industrial control computer, used widely to manage oil pipelines, electrical power grids and many kinds of nuclear plants. The question is: Just how dangerous has this worm and cyberwarfare become?

headline: Las Vegas Faces Its Deepest Slide Since the 1940s
text: LAS VEGAS — There are many cities across the country that are beginning to see the first glimpses of the end of the recession.

headline: How Arthur Penn Undid Tony Curtis

headline: Next Mets Executive Could Break Familiar Pattern
text: In 2002, when Major League Baseball owned the Montreal Expos, Commissioner Bud Selig asked Fred Wilpon, the Mets’ principal owner, if he could appoint Omar Minaya as the general manager of the Expos. Wilpon said yes, with one stipulation. He wanted the right to take Minaya back one day.

headline: First Look Inside the Proposed Islamic Center
text: Visitors to the upper floors of the Muslim community center planned for near ground zero would walk through lofty spaces  for art exhibitions, for contemplation and prayer, for programs on interreligious dialogue, for a 9/11 memorial  as sunlight streams through irregularly shaped windows between white crisscrossing beams.

headline: U.S. Issues Terrorism Alert for Travel to Europe
text: The U.S. State Department issued an alert on Sunday urging Americans traveling to Europe to be vigilant about possible terrorist attacks in a statement that specifically cites the potential involvement of Al Qaida. The British government, meanwhile, raised the threat of terrorism to "high" from "general" for Britons in France and Germany.

headline: Ruling Coalition Wins Latvia Vote
text: RIGA, Latvia  Latvians appeared to have re-elected the governing coalition by a wide margin in parliamentary elections on Saturday, according to preliminary results, suggesting a broad public approval of the government’s handling of the financial crisis.

headline: Arrest Made in Nigeria Bombings
text: DAKAR, Senegal  A day after car bombs ripped through Nigeria’s independence day celebrations in the capital, Abuja, killing at least 12 people, a former senior leader of the militant group that claimed responsibility has been arrested, Nigerian officials said Saturday.

headline: Buy My Stuff — and Theirs, Too
text: J CREW launched an advertising campaign in September, featuring splashy print ads and a photograph of a well-dressed young man on its Web site, sitting atop a ladder. Surrounding him was an assortment of items: umbrellas, medicine balls, a retro-looking trailer, a slab of raw meat.
