headline: Stage Is Set (Again) for a Blue-Chip Revival
text: EVER since big blue-chip domestic stocks fell out of favor in early 2000, many market strategists have regularly been predicting their imminent return to glory.

headline: Blame Falls Short at Belmont; Zenyatta Remains Undefeated
text: This was not how the Jockey Club Gold Cup was supposed to turn out, and the railbirds along Belmont Park’s breezeway were letting jockey Garrett Gomez have it in all sorts of colorful and unprintable ways. He had just finished second aboard Blame, a colt who had won his last five races and who many felt was the best male horse in the United States.

headline: The Wealth of an Intellect
text: MEASURED by fame and lasting influence, there is no other book on economics that comes close to “The Wealth of Nations” by Adam Smith. Many aspects of this book, first published in 1776, have become cornerstones of neoclassical economics: the organizing power of self-interest, the “invisible hand” of free markets and the crucial role of the division of labor are just three examples.

headline: Dantonio Maintains Presence, Even While in Hospital
text: EAST LANSING, Mich. — Two weeks after having a mild heart attack following an overtime victory over Notre Dame, Michigan State Coach Mark Dantonio coached the Spartans’ game against No. 11 Wisconsin on Saturday from a local hospital instead of the stadium.

headline: White House Plans Job Training Partnership
text: As part of efforts to address record-high levels of long-term unemployment, President Obama plans to announce a new national public-private partnership on Monday to help retrain workers for jobs that are in demand.

headline: Yanks Split 2 Games With Red Sox
text: BOSTON  The first 161 games were not enough. The American League East title will come down to the final day of the regular season, when the Yankees will send out an exhausted team to play its third game in 24 hours. Maximizing the drama from a captivating season-long race, the Yankees, after splitting a doubleheader with the Red Sox, enter Sunday tied atop the division with the Tampa Bay Rays.

headline: Ukrainian Star Puts On a Dominant Display at the Olympiad
text: Every chess game is between just two people, but players can be organized into teams in which individual results are added up in a combined score.

headline: Bautista Shortens His Swing and Sends More Balls a Longer Distance
text: MINNEAPOLIS  The change in Jose Bautista from a free-swinging easy out into the leading home run hitter in the major leagues began in the middle of last season, in the weight room at Rogers Centre in Toronto. But not in the way you might think.

headline: Bullying, Suicide, Punishment
text: TYLER CLEMENTI may have died from exposure in cyberspace. His roommate and another student, according to police, viewed Mr. Clementi’s intimate encounter with another man on a Webcam and streamed it onto the Internet. Mr. Clementi, an 18-year-old violinist in his freshman year at Rutgers University, jumped off of the George Washington Bridge, and now the two face serious criminal charges, including invasion of privacy.

headline: Franzen’s Message to Fans: That Is a Rough Draft
text: OOPS. Jonathan Franzen’s new novel, “Freedom,” has been hailed by critics as “brilliant” and “a masterpiece.” But the version released in Britain last week is not quite all that, British newspapers report. Mr. Franzen told an audience at a reading in London that a draft version of his book had been published by mistake. How could this happen? The wrong computer file had been opened and copied, he said, rather than the one containing the final proof. He asked fans not to read the novel until the correct version is published this week.

headline: What Steve Jobs Learned in the Wilderness
text: THE saga of Steven P. Jobs is so well known that it has entered the nation’s mythology: he’s the prodigal who returned to Apple in 1997, righted a listing ship and built it into one of the most valuable companies in the world.

headline: Your Comments on our Pre-Natal Origins
text: My Sunday column looks at some fascinating research at the intersection of science and sociology. Essentially it argues that the pre-natal experience is particularly important because the brain and physiology are then coming together in ways that will shape a person for decades to come — and that all this has implications for fighting poverty.

headline: Fighting Words
text: Carl P. Paladino, the Republican nominee for govenor of New York, and Fredric U. Dicker, a political editor and reporter for The New York Post, got into a loud argument last week over claims of infidelity that Mr. Paladino made about his Democratic opponent, Andrew M. Cuomo.

headline: Prime Number
text: Married couples 18 and older made up 52 percent of the population last year. made up 52 percent of the population last year, according to the Census Bureau, the lowest proportion since the began collecting data more than 100 years ago. The long-term decline in marriage accelerated during the recession — married couples made up 57 percent of the population in 2000, for instance — with people postponing marriage and choosing to live together instead. “People are unsure about their job security, and a lot of people lost their jobs,” said Mark Mather of the Population Reference Bureau, a private research group that analyzes census figures. “Getting married is obviously a big step and if you’re not comfortable about your future, it makes sense that you’d postpone a big decision like this.”

headline: We Got a Mention! Now Let’s Panic
text: EARLY in the summer, Nick LaCava and his two partners got something most entrepreneurs wish for, and if these three had it to do over, they would wish for it again. But they say they might be more careful — and prepared.

headline: A Proposed Itinerary for Candidate Emanuel
text: James Warren is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: House Music, Bred in Chicago, Comes Out
text: Chicago, which is widely considered the birthplace of house music 30 years ago, is again exerting its influence, as the semi-underground genre enjoys its coming-out party.

headline: Rep. Quigley, Still in His First Term, Looks at the Mayoral Race, and Sees Possibilities
text: There is something about the seat in the Fifth Congressional District. Maybe it feels like a throne when you sit in it.

headline: A Death Sparks a Demand for Care
text: A few weeks shy of his 19th birthday, Damian Turner, a charismatic youth advocate and aspiring musician, was gunned down in a drive-by shooting on Aug. 15  four blocks from one of the best hospitals in the world, the University of Chicago Medical Center in Hyde Park.

headline: Picking Up the Pieces, San Bruno Residents Take Stock and Mind the Tourists
text: One sunny afternoon last week, a self-described disaster artist set up a canvas and easel in front of Jerry Guernsey’s San Bruno home.

headline: Health Cost Major Issue in Proposition B Debate
text: Cathy Helton, a secretary with the San Francisco Rent Board, a city agency, said she had never before been a political activist. But now she is, outraged that the Proposition B ballot initiative would force city employees to contribute far more toward their health-benefit costs.

headline: Local Intelligence | Pho
text: Bay Area eaters are eagerly gulping down Vietnamese noodle soup, or pho, typically made with beef or chicken broth. Turtle Tower in the Little Saigon neighborhood is one of San Francisco’s dozens of pho restaurants. Stephen Pham, the owner, came from Hanoi 20 years ago to what he calls “the land of opportunity.”

headline: Vows: Jen & Gust
text: Jen Brown met Gust Hookanson at her local watering hole where Gust was tending the bar. She was initially skeptical, but when she finally decided to take a leap of faith, love blossomed.

headline: For Female Marines, Tea Comes With Bullets
text: MARJA, Afghanistan  They expected tea, not firefights.

headline: This Time, Cink Ensures He Won’t Be Overlooked
text: NEWPORT, Wales  Overlooked by his captain during the opening ceremony, Stewart Cink looked increasingly indispensable on the Ryder Cup’s busiest day, rolling in timely putts from near and far on the soft greens and finding a way, with ample support from his rookie partner, Matt Kuchar, to get the better of one of Europe’s most potent pairs Saturday.

headline: Georges Charpak, Physics Nobel Winner, Dies at 86
text: Georges Charpak, who won the 1992 Nobel Prize in Physics for inventing a device to sift through the billions of hurtling subatomic particles liberated by collisions in atom smashers, opening the way for discoveries on the nature of matter, died on Wednesday in Paris. He was 86.

headline: Georgi A. Arbatov, a Bridge Between Cold War Superpowers, Is Dead at 87
text: MOSCOW  Georgi A. Arbatov, who was the senior “Amerikanist” in the Soviet Communist Party in the final decades of the cold war and served as the Kremlin’s voice for a generation of television viewers in the United States, died here on Friday. He was 87.

headline: Art Gilmore, the Voice of Coming Attractions, Dies at 98
text: Art Gilmore, whose disembodied voice, introducing television shows and narrating hundreds (if not thousands) of movie trailers, was a trademark of Hollywood’s self-salesmanship from the 1940s through the 1960s, died Sept. 25 in Irvine, Calif. He was 98.

headline: Anti-Angle Ads
text: A nursing union is out with four spots attacking Sharron Angle in the Nevada Senate race.

headline: Routing Florida, Alabama Looks Like a Champion
text: TUSCALOOSA, Ala.  Alabama apparently does not want any thoughtful dialogue on the national championship race. The Crimson Tide wants to end the discussion on half of the national championship matchup in January and make itself the plain choice for the title game against any of a half-dozen challengers who all look like underdogs.

headline: Buddy Morrow , Trombonist and Bandleader, Dies at 91
text: At 91, Buddy Morrow had to be helped onstage to lead the Tommy Dorsey Orchestra in Ormond Beach, Fla., on Sept. 24, but once the music started, his energy never wavered. He even played the trombone solo on “Night Train,” which had sold more than a million copies for him in 1952.

headline: It Comes Down to the Final Day, Maybe Beyond
text: Entering the final day of the regular season, none of the playoff matchups have been set. Wins by and the Yankees on Saturday ensured that the American League East winner and the A.L. wild card would be determined Sunday. But the situation in the National League is more complicated: two playoff spots are left, and three teams have the chance to claim them. San Francisco needed to win only one game this weekend to clinch the N.L. West, but the Giants to the Padres, cutting their lead in the division to one. The Padres’ two wins, combined with , resulted in a tie in the N.L. wild-card standings. Here is a look at how Sunday could play out, with the Braves playing the Phillies at 1:35 p.m. Eastern and the Giants hosting the Padres at 4:05 p.m. Eastern:

headline: Nurses Union Plans Ad Against Angle
text: The largest union of registered nurses in the country will begin a $200,000 advertising campaign on Monday aimed at defeating Sharron Angle, the Republican challenger to Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the majority leader.

headline: Oregon on Top of Pac-10, With Sky the Limit
text: EUGENE, Ore.  When Larry Scott took over as the commissioner of the Pacific-10 Conference in July 2009, he knew his league had a perception problem. He sensed one of his biggest challenges would be to convince people that the Pac-10 should be considered more than, as he put it, “U.S.C. plus nine.”

headline: Red Bulls Clinch a Playoff Spot
text: The Red Bulls clinched a berth in the M.L.S. playoffs Saturday night when they beat the Kansas City Wizards, 1-0, then picked up a bonus prize at almost the same moment when Columbus’s scoreless tie with San Jose allowed the Red Bulls to move into first place in the Eastern Conference.

text: The day in photos from the college football field.

headline: Italy’s Museums Stay Up After Hours
text: Tuesday nights in Italy just got more interesting. Through Dec. 28, museums and cultural destinations across the country will be open after hours (7 to 11 p.m.), and  free, on the last Tuesday of each month. The initiative, called “Martedi in Arte,” is sponsored by the Ministry of Cultural Heritage and Activities and is aimed at promoting museums and other cultural institutions, and at offering affordable alternatives during a period of economic crisis.

headline: Reverse Mortgage Rules to Change
text: Several big changes are coming to the Federal Housing Administration’s reverse mortgage program.

headline: Q&A With Andy Van Slyke
text: Andy Van Slyke, a former major league outfielder, once joked that a movie made about him would be named “The Summer of 4-to-3.” But first comes his first novel, “The Curse,” written with the St. Louis sportswriter Rob Rains, in which the Cubs are churning toward their first World Series since 1945 before fate intervenes. So much for suspension of disbelief. In Van Slyke’s version of Chicago tragedy, the charter plane carrying the first-place Cubs crashes, killing the entire organization except for two players. The team is a patchwork of players from other teams who soldier on together, while the crash becomes a backdrop whodunit. Clue: it isn’t Steve Bartman.

headline: How to Filter Your Facebook Chat List
text: One of my most frequent reader questions is, “Can I use Facebook Chat without specific people seeing that I am online? I don’t want those people to bother me.” I answered this question last year, but Facebook has recently changed its chat interface to allow more selective filtering. Still, there are details to which you should pay attention, lest you accidentally reveal yourself to the very people from whom you’re trying to hide.

headline: Jimmy Johnson, Survivor
text: Jimmy Johnson was voted off “Survivor” last week. (No word on whether his hairstyle made it out of Nicaragua.)

headline: With One Day Left, Europe Surges at Ryder Cup
text: NEWPORT, Wales — Colin Montgomerie, the European Ryder Cup captain, wanted passion, and he got it. He wanted momentum, and he got that, too. He wanted a tie going into the singles matches with the United States, and he got much, much more on Sunday.

headline: The Uncanny Accuracy of Polling Averages*, Part III: This Time, It’s Different?
text: This is the third installment of a five-part series on the accuracy of polls and polling averages.

headline: Will Blindside Hit Spare Cammalleri Discipline?
text: From The Montreal Gazette’s Habs Inside/Out blog, this post includes items on the Rangers Derek Boogaard, “Hockey Night in Canada” telecasts and other items from around the N.H.L.

headline: Celine: Laying the Foundation
text: The plywood that lined the floors and risers at Tennis Club de Paris this afternoon suggested that Phoebe Philo was still working on the fundamentals at Celine. Or, it could have served as a suitable backdrop for her rustic ponchos in knotty cream yarns or caftan tops in either heavy cotton twill or shirting cotton.

headline: Frail Casualties in the War on Drugs
text: This morning The Times reports on delays in obtaining painkillers experienced by nursing home patients.

headline: Model-Morphosis | Jean Paul Gaultier
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of Paris Fashion Week. Here, the model Lindsey Wixson from Marilyn Model Management before (left) and after (right) makeup by Stephane Marais and hair by Guido Palau. (Drag the orange bar left to reveal the full transformation.)

headline: You Can Feel Right at Home Here
text: Laura Shirk-Charles stopped by her next-door neighbor’s home for dinner the other night in Prospect-Lefferts Gardens in Brooklyn. She ordered salmon sliders right off the menu. To go.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Junya Watanabe
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Kava Gorna.

headline: Nurses Enter the Nevada Fray
text: The largest union of registered nurses in the country will begin a $200,000 advertising campaign Monday aimed at defeating Sharron Angle, the Republican challenger to Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, in Nevada, with union leaders describing this race as their top priority in this year’s mid-term elections.

headline: Getting Tough on China
text: The modest recent rise in the Chinese renminbi stopped last week. The renminbi is now up 1.7 percent versus the dollar since August and up 2.1 percent since the start of the year.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Sonia Rykiel
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Kava Gorna.

headline: Frustrations Aside, Indians Bask in Opening of Games
text: NEW DELHI  In sharp contrast to the run-up to the Commonwealth Games, the opening ceremony started on time Sunday night and appeared to be meticulously planned, with a throbbing musical number that included hundreds of intricately costumed drummers, the world’s largest helium balloon and enormous dancing puppets.

headline: And He’s Off
text: 8:17 a.m. | Updated The former chief of staff posted a video Sunday in which he promises to spend the next several weeks listening to the people of Chicago as he prepares to run. Here it is:

headline: Live Analysis: Jets Beat Bills, 38-14
text: ORCHARD PARK, N.Y. — The Jets slammed an emphatic exclamation point on the first quarter of their season Sunday. They did not beat or best Buffalo, so much as they battered the Bills into an early submission.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Jean Paul Gaultier
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: The Music Was Wagner’s; The Stamina Was Levine’s
text: BOSTON  When James Levine gave the downbeat to the Act I Prelude from “Die Meistersinger von Nürnberg”  the first work on the Wagner program with which he opened his seventh season as music director of the Boston Symphony Orchestra at Symphony Hall here on Saturday evening  it was with a grand, sweeping gesture that a conductor with serious back problems is unlikely to make without a grimace. And lest there be any doubt that he was up to the task, Mr. Levine continued to use the large, picturesque gestures that were once an important part of his interpretive arsenal but that have given way in recent seasons to more compact, sometimes almost microscopic movements in the style of Fritz Reiner, as he has tried to conduct while managing pain from a number of injuries and illnesses.

headline: Yankees Go Down to the Wire
text: BOSTON — With 70 minutes to go before the first pitch, the Yankees did not have their lineup set. Joe Girardi had to check with his players before determining who would play behind Dustin Moseley. Robinson Cano, Brett Gardner and Curtis Granderson played all 20 innings in the field Saturday, and Mark Teixeira and Alex Rodriguez played both games, too, though each was a designated hitter for one game.

headline: Vagueness of Alert Leaves Travelers Frustrated
text: The State Department travel alert issued on Sunday in response to reports of a threat by Al Qaeda was anything but precise.

headline: Executive Director of Queens Theater Resigns
text: Jeffrey Rosenstock, the founding executive director of Queens Theater in the Park, is stepping down after 21 years, the theater has announced.

headline: Kentucky Senate Candidates Debate
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — During Sunday morning’s debate between the two candidates vying to be the next senator from Kentucky, there was a revealing exchange reminiscent of a pivotal moment in the Massachusetts senate race earlier this year.

headline: Sunday Word: Whose Thumping?
text: The Obama administration and its former chief of staff, Rahm Emanuel, are preparing for their first week apart as Republicans and Democrats spar over how bad of a thumping the president’s party will take in November.

headline: 'Mrs. Warren's Profession'
text: Sally Hawkins, left, and Cherry Jones in a scene from the Broadway revival of Shaw's play, at the American Airlines Theater. (Video courtesy of the Roundabout Theater)

headline: 'El Gato Con Botas (Puss in Boots)'
text: A scene from the co-production between the Gotham Chamber Opera and the Tectonic Theater Project. (Video courtesy of the New Victory Theater)

headline: Monday’s Singles Pairings for Ryder Cup
text: Heavy rains overnight forced the final session of the Ryder Cup to Monday for the first time. After the completion of fourball and foursome matches Sunday, Europe leads the United States, 9 1/2 to 6 1/2. Here are the singles pairings for Monday’s session (all times Eastern):

headline: Oregon Jumps Boise State in Polls
text: Congratulations to those of you who had “five weeks” in the pool for when Boise State would get jumped in the polls.

headline: New Leaders for Disney’s Interactive Media Group
text: The Walt Disney Company shook up its underperforming Internet and gaming division on Sunday, effectively splitting the unit in two and tapping two  outsiders to lead the businesses.

headline: Media Decoder: New Leaders for Disney’s Interactive Media Group
text: The Walt Disney Company shook up its underperforming Internet and gaming division on Sunday, effectively splitting the unit in two and tapping two outsiders to lead the businesses.

headline: A Camera’s Lens Isn’t Its Most Important Part
text: Photographers are notoriously cranky and opinionated online. Even they’ll admit that. I wonder why that is?

headline: Commonwealth Games Begin
text: A crowd of about 60,000 packed Jawaharlal Nehru Stadium in central Delhi for the opening ceremony for the Commonwealth Games.

headline: Ethnic Wins in Bosnia May Cause Deeper Splits
text: PRAGUE  Fifteen years after the ethnic war in Bosnia ended, an outspoken nationalist Bosnian Serb leader was expected to triumph in elections there on Sunday, reinforcing ethnic divisions and threatening to rip apart the fragile country, according to political leaders and analysts.

headline: ‘Saturday Night Live’ Takes On Rahm Emanuel
text: The “SNL” version of Rahm Emanuel had the “SNL” version of Pete Rousereconsidering the White House chief of staff post on Saturday night.

headline: Israeli Soldiers Convicted of Using Boy as Shield
text: JERUSALEM  An Israeli military court convicted two soldiers on Sunday of using a 9-year-old Palestinian boy as a human shield by forcing him to check bags for explosives in Israel’s 2008-9 Gaza war.

headline: Stumbling to Wild Card, Yankees Turn Focus to Twins
text: BOSTON  When the Yankees emerged bleary-eyed from the dugout at Fenway Park before their game Sunday against the Red Sox, the Green Monster greeted them with an impish jab: the old hand-operated scoreboard listed TAMPA BAY above NEW YORK in the American League East standings, the handiwork of a cheeky stadium worker. A few hours later, Fenway’s tenants sealed the Yankees’ fate.

headline: Hegel on Wall Street
text: As of today, the Troubled Asset Relief Program, known as TARP, the emergency bailouts born in the financial panic of 2008, is no more. Done. Finished. Kaput.

headline: More States Allowing Guns in Bars
text: NASHVILLE  Happy-hour beers were going for $5 at Past Perfect, a cavernous bar just off this city’s strip of honky-tonks and tourist shops when Adam Ringenberg walked in with a loaded 9-millimeter pistol in the front pocket of his gray slacks.

headline: In No-Trump, Playing to Keep the Long Suit Off the Lead
text: PHILADELPHIA — The biggest world bridge championships are held every four years. The 13th tournament opened here on Friday evening. The highlights were an e-mailed message from President Obama, whose grandparents were avid players, and an amusing speech by Mayor Michael A. Nutter of Philadelphia.

headline: Pop Second-Guessing Itself, Building Up and Coming Apart
text: Menomena tears holes in its songs. One moment, the whole band is bearing down on a fast, burly riff, or filling out a stately melody with classical-piano filigree and echoing guitar; the next, there’s just a vocal, a drumbeat and perhaps a few bass notes skulking down below. On Friday night at Webster Hall, Menomena (pronounced “men-AH-men-uh”), from Portland, Ore., constructed and disassembled its music as if it wanted fans to be as analytical as the band itself: to hear the mechanisms within the songs, to recognize the decisions made within every arrangement.

headline: Getting the Grand Tour, and a Performance, Too
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Even though the San Francisco Ballet starts its season in December (with “The Nutcracker”), the fall dance scene in the Bay Area is already busy. At the Yerba Buena Arts Center there is a three-day conference on different genres of Indian dance. The Smuin Ballet is performing a world premiere by the much-talked-about Trey McIntyre. In Berkeley the Mark Morris Dance Group is offering a triple bill.

headline: From Wily House Cat to Lord of the Manor
text: Critiques of the 17th-century French fairy tale “Puss in Boots” have ranged from appreciations of the wily cat’s ingenuity and imagination to condemnations of the insinuation that trickery is a valid route to success.

headline: Behind That Humble Pitchfork, a Complex Artist
text: The cover of R. Tripp Evans’s “Grant Wood: A Life” does not depict “American Gothic,” the painting for which Wood is best known. Instead it features a lush green landscape, replete with rolling hillside and curving country road. On that road is a truck colored so prettily, picturesquely red that it suggests a freshly painted barn. There is a naïve-looking simplicity to the way this image has been rendered.

headline: Two Stars, Two Assertive Drummers
text: The trumpeter Terence Blanchard and the saxophonist Branford Marsalis, in back-to-back sets at Rose Theater on Friday, played what sounded like new music.

headline: New CDs
text: TOBY KEITH

headline: Day of a Strike Dawns for Detroit Musicians
text: The Detroit Symphony Orchestra has weathered decades of strikes, deficits, criticism over its racial makeup, mediocre concert homes, cuts in state aid and canceled tours.

headline: Obama Makes Campaign Ad Debut
text: Along with their daily dose of pigskin, New Orleans Saints fans received a midgame shot of President Barack Obama, when the first general election campaign commercial featuring the president aired on behalf of Louisiana state Rep. Cedric Richmond during the Saints-Carolina Panthers game Sunday.

headline: Madison Avenue ‘Plays Ball’ With Fox
text: In another sign of how eager advertisers are these days to sponsor live sports on television, Fox is reporting strong demand for commercials to appear during its postseason baseball coverage.

headline: Monday: Like a Dire Situation
text: I thought this was a cool theme, interesting and different. For the constructor, it has the added advantage of automatically creating symmetrical theme entries.

headline: Roman Projections
text: In his column today, Tom Friedman quotes Lewis Mumford on the decline of Rome, and applies it to ourselves. It’s a common trope, and I don’t have any problem with Tom using it. But I do think we should be aware that the Roman Empire was a very different kind of society from anything existing in the modern world, and that when someone draws morals from Rome’s decline, the reality of Rome almost never comes into the thing.

headline: Smart Selections at an Eclectic Film Festival
text: The hard hats have begun laying tile, but much remains to be done inside the new addition to the Film Society of Lincoln Center that is set to open next spring. Tucked under a recently opened restaurant, the Elinor Bunin Munroe Film Center rests smack in the middle of the south side of West 65th Street, giving film unaccustomed visibility on this performing arts campus. The Film Society’s administrative offices and the Walter Reade Theater will remain across the street and upstairs, the theater’s presence signaled by a forlorn black banner that, as you walk east, is partly obscured by a parking-garage sign.

headline: When a Man’s Castle Is Actually a Tiny Pod
text: A play that comes with a gimmick attached always raises a red flag. Are they giving away beer or passing out festive hats at the door to try to distract you from the fact that the play itself isn’t very good?

headline: Returning to Realism and Revisiting a Tragedy
text: Traditionalists alarmed by the Metropolitan Opera’s forays into the digital age can seek solace in Otto Schenk’s ultraconventional 1989 production of Verdi’s “Rigoletto,” which returned to the house on Wednesday evening.

headline: A Zaha Hadid Museum Wins RIBA Stirling Prize
text: MAXII, the National Museum of the XXI Century Arts in Rome, designed by Zaha Hadid Architects, based in London, has won the RIBA Stirling Prize, one of Britain’s top honors in architecture, BBC News reported. Ms.  Hadid, the Iraqi-born designer and the firm’s founding partner, began work on the $200 million MAXXI, as it is called, above, more than a decade ago. She was awarded the Pritzker Architecture Prize in 2004 and recently designed the Aquatics Center for the 2012 London Olympics. The annual Stirling Prize also carries a cash award, of about $31,000.

headline: A Solid Opening Weekend for ‘The Social Network’
text: “The Social Network” from Sony Pictures Entertainment opened to a strong but not stratospheric $23 million in weekend ticket sales at North American theaters. That result, while easily enough for No. 1, put the film, directed by David Fincher from a script by Aaron Sorkin, on par with recent releases like “The Town,” which opened with significantly less attention from the news media. “Even though it didn’t break any records, ‘The Social Network’ is going to maintain healthy receipts in the weeks to come,” said Phil Contrino, editor of BoxOffice.com. “The Social Network,” which received positive reviews but a slightly less rapturous response in audience exit polls, is considered an early Oscar favorite. “Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga’Hoole” (Warner Brothers) was second with $10.9 million for a new total of $30 million. “Wall Street: Money Never Sleeps” (20th Century Fox) was third with $10.1 million for a total of $35.9 million. “The Town” (Warner) was fourth with $10 million, bringing its total to $64.3 million. “Easy A” (Sony) rounded out the Top 5 with $7 million ($42.4 million total).

headline: Illness Slows New Leader of Chicago Symphony
text: Riccardo Muti, who took over as music director of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra with much fanfare this season, suddenly pulled out of a gala concert on Saturday night because of stomach pains, an orchestra spokeswoman said. Mr. Muti rehearsed the orchestra in the morning and went to the Symphony Center for the concert — called the Symphony Ball and sponsored by the orchestra’s Women’s Board — when he decided he could not go on, the spokeswoman said. The orchestra went ahead without him without a conductor, performing the Beethoven Violin Concerto with the soloist Anne-Sophie Mutter and substituting Mozart’s Symphony No. 34 (which it had recently played) instead of the other works on the program, Rossini’s “William Tell” overture and Liszt’s symphonic poem “Les Préludes.”

headline: Science Foundation Backs Climate-Change Play
text: The National Science Foundation has awarded a $700,000 grant to the Civilians, a New York theater company, to finance the production of a show about climate change. “The Great Immensity,” with a book by Steven Cosson (“This Beautiful City”) and music and lyrics by Michael Friedman (“Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson”), tells the story of Polly, a photojournalist who disappears while working in the rain forests of Panama. The grant is a rare gift to an arts organization from the foundation, a federal agency that pays for science, engineering and mathematics research and education. The company says it plans to spend the money on the development and evaluation of the show, as well as on a tour and educational programs, including post-show panel discussions with experts in related scientific fields. No performance dates have been announced.

headline: Two Weeks, Two Shows Canceled by the Networks
text: The second week of the fall television season brought two casualties: Fox’s “Lone Star” and ABC’s “My Generation.” ABC said on Friday night that it had canceled “My Generation,” a documentary-style drama about young people 10 years out of high school. The show had drawn a relatively meager 3.9 million viewers to its second episode on Thursday. The network did not immediately announce how it would fill the 8 p.m. Thursday time slot. But it did indicate that it hoped to broadcast the remaining six episodes, perhaps on the Internet. “My Generation” was the second new network show to be canceled. Fox took the Texas soap opera “Lone Star” off its schedule on Tuesday, one day after its second episode drew 3.2 million viewers, despite efforts by its creator to drum up interest. Fox has scheduled the returning drama “Lie to Me” in its place.

headline: Comic Strips Think Pink
text: In honor of Breast Cancer Awareness Month, King Features Syndicate has put together a “Cartoonists Care” newspaper strip event for Sunday. More than 50 cartoonists, including those behind “Zits,” “Dennis the Menace” “Blondie,” left, and “Family Circus,” will participate and turn their strips pink to increase awareness about the disease. Each strip will include a pink ribbon. Three female cartoonists  Sandra Bell-Lundy (“Between Friends”), Hilary Price (“Rhymes With Orange”) and Anne Gibbons (“Six Chix”)  have also created themed strips. All the strips will be posted Sunday on comicsgopink.com, along with an easy way to donate to a breast cancer charity.

headline: Back in Milan, Gallinari Finds His Voice and His Stroke
text: MILAN  The final burst of emotion had nothing to do with sentiment or surroundings or the pulse of the crowd. Danilo Gallinari’s parting gesture Sunday was pure competitive zeal  a timely 3-pointer, a triumphant fist pump, a shout.

headline: Attention, 49ers! Roddy White Doesn’t Give Up
text: Roddy White had seven catches for 104 yards in the Falcons’ 16-14 victory over the 49ers on Sunday, but neither his statistics nor the result were unusual.

headline: Migrant ‘Villages’ Within a City Ignite Debate
text: BEIJING  The community is walled and gated, an enclosure of rows of crowded low-rise homes and shops, where people live under the gaze of surveillance cameras and apart from the city. The police patrol around the clock, and security guards stop unfamiliar faces to check identification papers. In the morning, only one gate is open, through which parents head off to work and children go to school. At night, the gate is locked, preventing street loiterers from trespassing.

headline: Maury Allen, Sportswriter and Prolific Author, Dies at 78
text: Maury Allen, a longtime sportswriter for The New York Post who may have set a record of his own for the number of books on sports he turned out 38  died Sunday at his home in Cedar Grove, N.J. He was 78.

headline: Twins Manager’s Wife Plays Favorites
text: MINNEAPOLIS — Sunday morning in his Target Field office, Minnesota Twins Manager Ron Gardenhire said it didn’t matter to him whether his team faced the Yankees or the Rays in the American League division series. But that opinion wasn’t unanimous in the Gardenhire household.

headline: Firefighters in Queens Won’t Rush to All Calls
text: A million times a year, fire trucks are driven into the streets of New York City, usually at breakneck speeds with lights and sirens blaring. The rush is often critical: Firefighters converge on fires, douse the flames and save lives.

headline: Film Version of Zuckerberg Divides Generations
text: At what point does ambition, a cornerstone of American commerce, morph into something darker and less celebrated? Over the weekend, people who saw “The Social Network,” the movie about Facebook and its principal creator, Mark Zuckerberg, were left to ponder that question on the sidewalk.

headline: Live Analysis: Giants 17, Bears 3
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — It had been a week of soul-searching for the Giants. Their former players questioned the direction of the team and there did not seem to be a unified voice emerging from within the locker room.

headline: Runoff Will Decide the Presidency of Brazil
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil  Dilma Rousseff was leading late Sunday in her bid to be Brazil’s first female president, but election officials said she had failed to come up with enough votes to avoid a second round.

headline: Chicago Symphony’s New Leader Cancels Concerts After Illness
text: The Chicago Symphony Orchestra’s lovefest with its new music director, Riccardo Muti, came to a sudden halt on Sunday, when the maestro canceled two weeks of concerts to seek treatment in Milan for what the orchestra called “extreme gastric distress.”

headline: U.S. Military Apologizes for Civilian Deaths in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  In the wake of charges from Afghan officials that civilians were killed in two attacks over the weekend, the American military apologized for one episode in which a child was killed and two other children wounded and said it was investigating the deaths of several civilians in the other episode.

headline: In San Francisco, N.L. Pennant Race Ends With a Victory Lap
text: SAN FRANCISCO  A thick layer of fog hung over San Francisco early Sunday, and with it the lingering doubts about whether the Giants could finally put away the San Diego Padres and win their way into the playoffs.

headline: 2 Brothers Await Broad Use of Medical E-Records
text: There is no silver bullet for reforming America’s health care system, but medical experts have long agreed that digital patient records and electronic prescribing can help improve care and curb costs.

headline: Verizon Wireless to Pay Millions in Refunds
text: WASHINGTON  Verizon Wireless said on Sunday that it would pay up to $90 million in refunds to 15 million cellphone customers who were wrongly charged for data sessions or Internet use, one of the largest customer refunds by a telecommunications company.

headline: Suicides Put Light on Pressures of Gay Teenagers
text: FRESNO, Calif.  When Seth Walsh was in the sixth grade, he turned to his mother one day and told her he had something to say.

headline: Security in a Lawless Congo
text: In late July, hundreds of armed men gang-raped at least 200 women in Luvungi -- an embarrassment for United Nations peacekeepers who seem to be failing at their most basic task: protecting civilians.

headline: Cuomo, Candidate and De Facto Campaign Manager
text: Andrew M. Cuomo was driving his staff crazy.

headline: Lehman Omnipresent in Nomura’s Push Into U.S.
text: The discreet sign by the door does not say Lehman Brothers. But step inside: a bit of Lehman lives on here in Manhattan.

headline: Call to the Bullpen Crackles With a Last Laugh
text: After all the dreary lassitude of this season, Jerry Manuel found a way to change the mood in sad-sack Flushing.

headline: Health Care’s Lost Weekend
text: Doctors, like most people, don’t love to work weekends, and they probably don’t enjoy being evaluated against their peers. But their industry can no longer afford to protect them from the inevitable. Imagine a drugstore open only five days a week, or a television network that didn’t measure its ratings. Improving the quality of health care and reducing its cost will require that doctors make many changes  but working weekends and consenting to quality management are two clear ones.

headline: When Home Has No Place to Park
text: LOS ANGELES  Every day, Diane Butler and her husband park their two hand-painted R.V.’s in a lot at the edge of Venice Beach here, alongside dozens of other rickety, rusted campers from the 1970s and ’80s. During the day, she sells her artwork on the boardwalk. When the parking lot closes at sunset, she and the other R.V.-dwellers drive a quarter-mile inland to find somewhere on the street to park for the night.

headline: Where the Greats of Cricket Are Honored: A Humble Hall Atop a Restaurant
text: HARTFORD

headline: The Mets’ Season Ends, but the Intrigue Continues
text: An item in a Connecticut newspaper on Sunday said that Jeff Wilpon, Bobby Valentine, Omar Minaya and Wally Backman were seen dining recently at a restaurant in Norwalk called Quattro Pazzi, igniting speculation about the Mets’ future plans until the report was roundly dismissed.

headline: More Countries Adopt China’s Tactics on Currency
text: WASHINGTON  As the Obama administration escalates its battle with Chinese leaders over the artificially low value of China’s currency, a growing number of countries are retreating from some free-market rules that have guided international trade in recent decades and have started playing by Chinese rules.

headline: With Texas Not Ranked, Streaks End
text: Longtime observers of the Associated Press top 25 might have done a double-take on Sunday: for the first time since Oct. 15, 2000, Texas was not ranked.

headline: As Wild Card, Yankees Need Right History to Repeat Itself
text: BOSTON

headline: Fear and Favor
text: A note to Tea Party activists: This is not the movie you think it is. You probably imagine that you’re starring in “The Birth of a Nation,” but you’re actually just extras in a remake of “Citizen Kane.”

headline: No Stopping Movie View of Mark Zuckerberg
text: Millions of the moviegoers who made “The Social Network” the top box-office draw of the weekend saw an unflattering portrayal of Mark Zuckerberg, the co-founder and chief executive of Facebook.

headline: With High Expectations, Jets Skip the Celebration
text: ORCHARD PARK, N.Y.  The Jets trudged deceptively into the visitors’ locker room at Ralph Wilson Stadium, absent smiles, fist pumps, or any of the usual signs of celebration. Their body language suggested they expected this result.

headline: A Silicon Valley Investor’s Take on a Post-Facebook World
text: In “The Social Network,” the new movie that tells a fictional version of the founding of Facebook, Silicon Valley is getting the Hollywood treatment  and it’s about time. It captures a world where big money, oversize egos and raw feelings collide as entrepreneurs compete to create the next big thing. Meanwhile, the established system of investing in start-ups is being turned upside down.

headline: Eagles Look Lost After Vick Is Injured
text: PHILADELPHIA  Michael Vick gingerly pulled on his blue button-down shirt Sunday night, wincing as he tried to extend his right arm through the sleeve.

headline: Election Season Puts Politicians in the Pews
text: Eleven months out of the year, the parishioners of New York City can safely attend Sunday services with no reasonable fear of interlopers, television cameras or quizzical members of the press.

headline: As Maliki Clings to Power, Iraq’s Fissures Deepen
text: BAGHDAD  When Nuri Kamal al-Maliki began his bid for re-election as prime minister  exactly a year ago on Saturday  he pledged to unite a population splintered and suspicious after years of war. He has not, and while he is hardly alone in blame, the consequences could haunt Iraq for years to come.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Debate Over Meaning of Standoff in Ecuador
text: QUITO, Ecuador  The clock had struck 9 p.m. last Thursday. President Rafael Correa had been holed up on the third floor of the police hospital here for more than 10 hours after being assaulted by a clutch of rebellious police officers. Dozens still lurked near the entrance, quarreling with security forces that had arrived to free the president.

headline: Casinos Now See Online Gambling as a Better Bet
text: Many of the country’s largest casinos, long opposed to gambling games like poker on the Internet, are now having second thoughts.

headline: Iran Lifts Ban on Director, Saying He Issued an Apology
text: TEHRAN  Cultural officials have lifted a ban on film production by Asghar Farhadi, an award-winning director, that was imposed after he made public remarks supporting opposition filmmakers last month.

headline: Imam’s Wife Tells of Death Threats
text: One of the people behind the proposal to build a Muslim community center in Lower Manhattan said on Sunday that death threats had been made against her and her husband.

headline: Case of Accused Soldiers May Be Worst of 2 Wars
text: WASHINGTON  Over the last nine years, as the Army has cycled hundreds of thousands of soldiers through combat duty in Afghanistan and Iraq, it has also court-martialed 34 on murder or manslaughter charges in the killings of civilians in those conflict zones. Twenty-two were convicted, and 12 acquitted.

headline: Westwood Has Europe on a Roll From the Start
text: NEWPORT, Wales  It was not a glorious Ryder Cup Sunday for all the Europeans at Celtic Manor Resort.

headline: Race Is on to Claim, ‘We’re No. 2!’
text: EUGENE, Ore. — Nearly 2,500 miles from the psychedelic blend of yellows and greens that provided the backdrop for Oregon’s rout of Stanford here on Saturday, top-ranked Alabama put forth a more traditional performance in a blowout of Florida.

headline: Flawed Paperwork Aggravates a Foreclosure Crisis
text: As some of the nation’s largest lenders have conceded that their foreclosure procedures might have been improperly handled, lawsuits have revealed myriad missteps in crucial documents.

headline: First Monday
text: The Supreme Court enjoys all but free rein in selecting which cases to review. From the end of one term in the summer until the start of the next, on the first Monday in October, the work of the court is to sift through thousands of petitions from parties that lost in one of the federal appeals courts or highest state courts and are eager for the justices to reverse their fate.

headline: With a Squeegee and a Smile, a Relic of an Unruly Past Wipes On
text: Spotting a squeegee man used to elicit a grumble and a lot of useless waving-off gesticulation by the driver. Now a sighting of this rare species sparks a little charge, the way any New York City rarity  a faux Checker cab or a seltzer man  might.

headline: ’Tis No Pity She’s a C.E.O.
text: The delightful surprise of the generally less-than-delightful “Mrs. Warren’s Profession,” which opened on Sunday night at the American Airlines Theater, is that Cherry Jones, in the title role, does not nearly glow. She glitters.

headline: Rangers Make Roster Fit, but Forwards Are a Puzzle

headline: Who’s In?
text: As the global economic balance shifts, the United States and other of the post-World War II powers say they’re ready to make room. The Group of 8 rich countries ceded to the Group of 20, where the interests of Germany and France must vie with those of India. Despite that, the maneuvering before this week’s meetings of the International Monetary Fund suggest that the big players may not be as ready as they claim.

headline: Tape Has Angle Assailing Republicans
text: Sharron Angle, the Republican candidate for Senate from Nevada, faces a number of obstacles in her attempt to defeat Senator Harry Reid, the majority leader and perhaps the top target of Republicans this year. High among them is the fact that the November ballot includes an official Tea Party candidate, Scott Ashjian, who clearly threatens to draw votes away from Ms. Angle in what is shaping up to be a very tight race with Mr. Reid. (This despite the fact that Ms. Angle has the support of much of the national Tea Party).

You might expect the hordes to be hostile, their anger stoked by the return of a polarizing player who committed the mortal sin of not winning a championship. But Eagles fans are anything but predictable.

headline: Behind the Scenes at a Bomb-Plot Trial
text: Poems that the defendant wrote in prison tracked the genre’s well-worn themes: injustice, isolation and regret. In neat script on lined paper, the poems, by David Williams IV, were written between December 2009 and August 2010, as Mr. Williams and three other men awaited trial on charges that they had left what they thought were real bombs outside of two Bronx synagogues and had planned to shoot down military cargo planes.

headline: The Public Trust

Much is leased out, some to energy and mining companies, but mostly to ranchers for grazing cattle and sheep. The bureau is supposed to find a balance between the public interest and the interest of the leaseholders  upholding the public interest whenever conflicts arise.

headline: Sizing Up a Cheeseburger’s Caloric Heft
text: When people make numerical estimates, they are notoriously subject to the distorting influence of “anchors”: numbers previously observed that linger in the mind and drag up or down the later estimate. A new study describes a related but opposite effect: when the anchor is in a very different category, it can drive the target estimate away, rather than pulling it closer.

headline: Accusation Upsets a Province

The bold cover headline on the issue of Oct. 4 was no more subtle: “Quebec: The Most Corrupt Province.”

headline: More Countries Adopt China’s Tactics on Currency

Sanger and Michael Wines write in The New York Times.

headline: Gerald S. Lesser, Shaper of ‘Sesame Street,’ Dies at 84

Lesser, a Harvard psychologist who as the longtime chief adviser to “Sesame Street” poured the pedagogy into the show, helping ensure from the start that the new, experimental venture in education by television would be both enjoyable and instructive, died on Sept. 23 in Burlington, Mass. He was 84 and lived in Lexington, Mass.

headline: On Start-Ups, Angels and the Real Mark Zuckerberg

It captures a world where big money, oversize egos and raw feelings collide as entrepreneurs compete to create the next big thing. Meanwhile, the established system of investing in start-ups is being turned upside down.

headline: Wild Things
text: Big cats need plenty of room to roam, and so must designers. They can’t be fenced off, or have their creative habitat divided, as Tanzania proposes to do with a controversial highway through the Serengeti National Park. Riccardo Tisci’s fashion show for Givenchy on Sunday night might seem a world away from a serious concern in Africa, but the choice of leopard print got me thinking.

headline: A Family Album: American Soldiers at War
text: Tim Hetherington‘s “Infidel” (Chris Boot Ltd., 2010) is more of a family album than a traditional photojournalism book. There are of course powerful images of life for a platoon in the Korengal valley in Afghanistan that Hetherington and Sebastian Junger documented in the film “Restrepo.” But there are also thorough catalogs of the soldiers’ tattoos, their official Army ID photos and the magazine centerfolds in their barracks, and remarkably revealing interviews with seven of the soldiers. The book stands on its own, separate from the movie.

headline: VimpelCom in Merger Talks With Egyptian Tycoon

headline: Paris Celebrates Kertész, an Adopted Artist

The exhibition of his work at the Jeu de Paume (1, Place de la Concorde; 33-1-47-03-12-50; jeudepaume.org), which runs through Feb. 6, embraces all three eras, calling itself the first “proper retrospective” of his work in Europe.

Do you know about this case, and the Phoebe Prince case earlier this year? How tough should the punishment be for those who cyberbullied these students? Why? headline: Paris: Some Lemons
text: Stella McCartney’s super-trim, no-nonsense collection could be seen as a response to the boxy, over-layered clothes we’ve been served in the past day. I refer to the tent shapes at Céline and the leopard-and-chiffon layers at Givenchy, a moment of fashion gluttony in Paris. Ms. McCartney took a more healthful, fresh-air approach today. Her pantsuits, worn with fine buttoned-up polo shirts, were well-tailored, trim but easy, with somewhat high-waist trousers and a pale pastel palette of rose, pistachio, blue and lavender. She showed two or three colors in combination, and it worked. The clothes are a natural follow-up to fall’s classically slim trousers and crewnecks, and the shoe is now a low-heeled sandal with a single buckled strap at the front and an ankle strap.

headline: Panel Says Japanese Power Broker Should Face Charges
