Howard Johnson of New York. The Rev. Mark Santucci, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Mark’s Episcopal Church in Mystic.

headline: Goal Looms for U.N.: Ending ‘Energy Poverty’
text: The United Nations Millennium Development Goals were adopted in 2000 as a commitment to improve health and education as well as end poverty in less fortunate parts of the globe. The eight goals include targets like universal childhood education, reducing infant mortality and ensuring environmental sustainability.

headline: Figure Skating a Most Dangerous Game, Laraque Finds
text: ¶ The recently retired N.H.L. enforcer Georges Laraque requires 12 stitches to his forehead — not from a fight, but because his partner in CBC’s “Battle of the Blades” accidentally cut him with her figure skate. Laraque’s injury occurs on Saturday during a rehearsal for Sunday’s premiere of the competition portion of the figure-skating contest show, as he and his partner, Anabelle Langlois, practice a maneuver called the Chainsaw. The 97-pound Langlois, swinging from the 275-pound Laraque’s neck, loses her balance and starts to fall headfirst. As Laraque reaches to break her fall, her skate blade slices his forehead.

headline: Two Men Shot Dead in S.U.V. Near Gramercy Park
text: Updated 3:02 p.m. | Two men who had been sought by the police as potential murder witnesses were shot and killed as they sat in a parked sports utility vehicle in the Flatiron district early Monday morning, the police said.

headline: Early Word: Supreme Court Back in Session
text: The Supreme Court reconvenes today, but don’t blink if you want to catch a glimpse of its newest member, Justice Elena Kagan. She has recused herself from 25 of the 51 cases the court has accepted so far this term because she argued the cases during her 14-month tenure as solicitor general. The Times’s Adam Liptak will have the first look at the session later today.

headline: New Zealand’s Prime Minister Weighs In on ‘Hobbit’ Dispute
text: John Key, the prime minister of New Zealand, has become the latest and arguably the most influential person this side of the wizard Gandalf to seek a resolution in a labor dispute that has hobbled a planned two-film adaptation there of “The Hobbit” by J. R. R. Tolkien.

headline: Monday Reading: Making Doctors Work Weekends
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: McDowell Seals Ryder Cup for Europe
text: NEWPORT, Wales  Moments after Graeme McDowell won the final Ryder Cup point on the 17th green on Monday, something that looked like a Celtic Mardi Gras parade broke out in the Usk Valley. Singing, laughing pockets of elation spread out across the greensward, up the slope next to the 18th green, and in front of the Twenty Ten clubhouse, and in the 18th fairway at Celtic Manor.

headline: Jersey Sure
text: This weekend, co-vocabularists have generously shared descriptive toponyms.

headline: Sexual Violence in Eastern Congo
text: An epidemic of rape and sexual violence is attacking the women of South Kivu Province, Congo.

headline: Berlusconi’s Jewish Joke Falls Flat
text: Updated | 11:54 a.m. On Sunday, the Vatican’s official newspaper, L’Osservatore Romano, denounced Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi of Italy for telling a “deplorable” joke about Jews and the Holocaust.

headline: How ‘Difficult’ Parents Look From the Counselor’s Side of the Desk
text: 1:35 p.m. | Updated See below for a comment from Karen Felton, one of the high school counselors quoted in this post.

headline: This Week’s Health Industry News
text: This will be a big month for drug approval decisions by the Food and Drug Administration. The agency faces deadlines for decisions on several drugs.

headline: Deliberations Begin in Connecticut Murder Case
text: NEW HAVEN  After hearing weeks of often gruesome testimony, and with more than 200 pieces of trial exhibits to sift through, jurors on Monday began deliberating the charges against a parolee accused in a home invasion in Cheshire, Conn., that left a mother and her two daughters dead.

headline: Fungus From the Parks
text: Over on City Room, Ava Chin has a post on edible mushrooms in New York City, including chicken mushrooms, oyster mushrooms and giant puffballs.

headline: To Sell Apartments, Furnishing Is No Afterthought
text: It wasn’t just the swinging chair, strung from the ceiling, that was distracting. When apartment hunters stepped into the third-floor studio for sale at 650 Avenue of the Americas, they found a white leather circular bed with red pillows and a hanging L.E.D. lamp with colors shifting from green to blue. Some said it reminded them of the film “2001: A Space Odyssey.”

headline: Photos of the Moment | Céline
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Kava Gorna.

headline: Stuyvesant Town Foreclosure Auction Postponed
text: The planned foreclosure sale of the sprawling Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village complexes was suddenly postponed Monday morning, shortly before the 80-acre, 11,226-unit development was to be sold in the eighth-floor rotunda of the Federal Courthouse downtown.

headline: A ‘Pretty Edgy’ Climate Campaign
text: 4:15 p.m. | Updated Hey, in an entertainment universe where a blood-soaked psychopath can be a hero and flesh-munching zombies can be hilarious (to me, too), what’s a few exploding schoolchildren?

headline: ‘Running Wilde’ Races for an Audience
text: SANDS POINT, N.Y.  Lunching in the dining room of a Gatsbyesque country club where his Fox comedy “Running Wilde” was filming on a rainy Friday, Will Arnett was making the best of his opulent settings. He took alternating bites of the chocolate chip pie and carrot cake on his plate, and he joked that he had been transported to work that morning by “a driver who takes me to a helicopter that flies me to Boston, and then I take a ferry from there.”

headline: Actor’s Injury Attributed to Misfiring of Prop Pistol
text: The Donmar Warehouse in London said on Monday that it would resume performances of Stephen Sondheim‘s “Passion” on Thursday after an actor in the production was injured by a prop gun during a performance on Saturday. David Birrell, who is playing Colonel Ricci in the Donmar production of the musical, was injured during Saturday’s matinee performance and taken by ambulance to a nearby hospital, The Guardian reported.

headline: I.V.F. Takes the (Nobel) Prize
text: Motherlode sends its congratulations to Robert G. Edwards, who won the Nobel Prize for Medicine this morning. He is, figuratively, the father of the technology that, literally, has allowed four million babies to be born over the past three decades.

headline: Jimmie Johnson Takes Over Sprint Cup Lead
text: With a second-place finish at the Price Chopper 400 in Kansas City, Kan., Jimmie Johnson is back on top of the Sprint Cup standings. So what else is new?

headline: Robert Green Earns England Recall and Davies Gets His First Nod
text: Two days after he was victimized for a goal by Clint Dempsey in West Ham’s Premier League match against Fulham, goalkeeper Robert Green was recalled to the England squad for the first time since gifting a howler of a goal to Dempsey in the 2010 World Cup.

headline: The Netherlands Drops de Jong
text: The hard-tackling midfielder Nigel de Jong was dropped Monday from the Dutch national team for two Euro 2012 qualifiers (against Moldova and Sweden) by Coach Bert van Marwijk after his tackle resulted in an opposing player breaking his leg in an English Premier League game over the weekend.

headline: The Filter Adds New Places to the List of Great Coffee Bars in New York
text: Today I’m updating the Filter’s recommendations about New York coffee for The Scoop, the Times’s guide to New York for iPhone and iPad users, even though the coffee app was launched just last month. In fact, I will update the Filter at least once every month. New York’s coffee scene is growing and changing every week – the Scoop should help you stay on top of it.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Stella McCartney
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Alexandra Catiere.

headline: Integrity at Issue in Connecticut Senate Debate
text: HARTFORD  Richard Blumenthal and Linda E. McMahon questioned each other’s truthfulness and qualifications to serve in the United States Senate Monday in a televised debate marked by tart exchanges and obvious iciness between them.

headline: A Note On Currency Wars
text: I’ve seen a number of people — most recently, Yglesias — suggesting that mutual attempts by major economies to depreciate their currencies could be really helpful right now. The intuition seems clear: it gets countries printing money; and there’s also the historical argument by Eichengreen that competitive devaluation in the 1930s was actually quite helpful.

headline: ‘Dexter’ Watch: Back to Bloody Business
text: Anyone who thought that last week’s episode of “Dexter” was short on momentum and long on setup must have felt appeased by Sunday night’s hour, yes? Things are picking up and seem to be off to a strong start.

headline: Ask an Elder Law Attorney: Altering the Power of Attorney
text: Q.

headline: Law Firms Orrick and Akin Gump End Merger Talks
text: The big law firm Orrick, Herrington & Sutcliffe has seen its share of merger discussions fizzle out in recent years. Add its talks with Akin Gump Strauss Hauer & Feld to the list.

headline: Toyota Says 65% of Recall Repairs Are Completed
text: DETROIT  Toyota said on Monday that the rate of complaints about sudden acceleration had fallen 80 percent since April and that dealers had repaired 3.7 million of the six million vehicles in the United States covered by its two biggest recalls.

headline: Better to See an Apartment Furnished or Empty?
text: It wasn’t that long ago that real estate brokers could easily sell apartments with bare walls and little or no furniture. In the frothy years of 2006 and 2007, apartment buyers were supposed to picture where their fine art collections and antiques would fit (this was when New Yorkers, of course, could afford art collections).

headline: Sauber’s Bright New Mexican Driver, and Sponsor
text: The Sauber team  survived  after the German car manufacturer BMW pulled out of the team and the sport over the winter. But the car has run this season practically entirely white, with hardly any sponsors, aside from a couple of races with Burger King.  Today, the Swiss-based team announced that next season it would be running with sponsorship backing from Telmex, the Mexican telecommunications company, and it will be racing with a Mexican driver as well.

headline: Sauber’s Bright New Mexican Driver, and Sponsor
text: The Sauber team  survived  after the German car manufacturer BMW pulled out of the team and the sport over the winter. But the car has run this season practically entirely white, with hardly any sponsors, aside from a couple of races with Burger King.  Today, the Swiss-based team announced that next season it would be running with sponsorship backing from Telmex, the Mexican telecommunications company, and it will be racing with a Mexican driver as well.

headline: What We’re Reading: Cheap Gas and Obesity
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: The Uncanny Accuracy of Polling Averages*, Part IV: Are the Polls Getting Worse?
text: This is the fourth article in a series on the accuracy of polls and polling averages. In the first two installments, we demonstrated that polls have been extremely accurate at forecasting the winners of governors’ and Senate races in recent years — much more so than you might expect based on intuition alone.

headline: On Our Radar: White House Climate Battles
text: A detailed analysis of the collapse of recent climate legislation in the Senate finds that missteps and limited enthusiasm by the Obama White House helped doom the effort. [The New Yorker]

headline: Runway Beauty | Guido Palau Sets Hair Trends
text: Guido Palau has had a busy month so far. Those pin-straight hair extensions last week at Cavalli? His. The Jazz Age Marcel wave at Prada last week? Also his. The soft knots at the nape of necks at Nina Ricci, where he made references to both the Edwardians and the 1970s? You get the idea.

headline: Monday Matchup, Patriots at Dolphins
text: Patriots at Dolphins

headline: An Ailing Muti Leaves Chicago for Treatment
text: The Chicago Symphony Orchestra’s love fest with its new music director, Riccardo Muti, has come to a sudden halt because of Mr. Muti’s illness. He canceled his appearances with the orchestra halfway through his one-month fall stint with it so he could fly to Milan on Monday to seek treatment for what the orchestra called “extreme gastric distress.” Mr. Muti suffered stomach pains over the weekend and canceled a Saturday-evening gala performance at the last minute — the orchestra played with no conductor — and decided on Sunday to consult with his own doctors in Milan.

headline: A Gulag Family Reunion
text: Sometimes, the spartan lines of a caption can’t begin to tell the story behind the picture they describe. A striking example is the photograph we published in this weekend’s issue with Serge Schmemann’s review of “The Victims Return: Survivors of the Gulag After Stalin,” by Stephen F. Cohen.

headline: A Gulag Family Reunion
text: Sometimes, the spartan lines of a caption can’t begin to tell the story behind the picture they describe. A striking example is the photograph we published in this weekend’s issue with Serge Schmemann’s review of “The Victims Return: Survivors of the Gulag After Stalin,” by Stephen F. Cohen.

headline: Want an ‘Arrested Development’ Movie? You’d Better Watch ‘Running Wilde.’
text: During a recent visit to the set of his new series, “Running Wilde,” we weren’t necessarily going to ask Mitchell Hurwitz, the creator of the cult comedy “Arrested Development,” about the long, long awaited possibility of an “Arrested Development” movie, figuring it comes up in every interview Mr. Hurwitz gives, and besides, he probably has more pressing concerns right now.

headline: Mets Make Dismissals Official
text: Over the past 13 seasons, the Yankees have been a model of stability and success with one general manager, two field managers and four championships to their name. Across town, the Mets have struggled to keep up, cycling through three general managers and four managers in little over half that time.

headline: ‘Nemesis’
text: 1: Equatorial Newark

headline: Newark, 1944, When Polio Disrupted the Playground
text: Philip Roth’s latest protagonist is not one of his self-conscious writer-heroes, like Nathan Zuckerman or Peter Tarnopol, who spend their lives turning sentences around and contemplating the equation between life and art. No, he’s a simple Newark gym teacher who in the summer of 1944 is supervising the neighborhood playground, watching the boys play ball and the girls jump rope. In Mr. Roth’s new novel, “Nemesis,” it’s the summer when a polio epidemic sweeps through the city, spreading anxiety and suspicion.

headline: Billie Joe Armstrong Adds New Number to ‘American Idiot’
text: The Broadway musical “American Idiot” received a healthy shot in the arm last week as Billie Joe Armstrong, the frontman and lead guitarist for the rock band Green Day, performed in the devilish role of the heroin dealer St. Jimmy for a regular complement of eight performances. A rock opera set to more than 20 Green Day songs, “American Idiot” grossed $1,092,334 for the week, according to the producers — a significant improvement over the show’s weekly average gross of $740,000 since opening on April 20 at the St. James Theater. The maximum possible gross for that week of performances would have been about $1.3 million.

headline: Fees to Avoid
text: Have you called 411 recently? If so, you just racked up a needless directory assistance fee. Instead, you could have used free services.

headline: Arsonists Damage a Mosque in the West Bank
text: JERUSALEM  Arsonists suspected of being radical Israeli settlers damaged part of a Palestinian mosque early on Monday in a village near the West Bank city of Hebron, setting fire to rugs and copies of the Koran and scrawling the word “revenge” in Hebrew on a wall, police officials and witnesses said.

headline: Brennan Book, Many Years in Making
text: WASHINGTON

headline: In Sharp Change, Britain Will Reduce Child Benefits for the Middle Class
text: LONDON — The British government said Monday that it would no longer pay a universal child subsidy to wealthier families, opening a campaign that may end up transforming Britain’s welfare system by reducing benefits to the middle and upper classes.

headline: A Daughter Relocates 2,500 Miles Away, and a Mother Flies Home, Alone
text: A few weeks ago, I dropped my younger daughter, Emma, at college to start her freshman year. We hugged long and deeply. “It’s really happening? Now?”

headline: Photos of the Moment | John Galliano
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: Google TV Announces Its Programming Partners, but the Top Networks Are Absent
text: Google announced on Monday its first content partners for Google TV, its effort to marry two mediums  the Internet and television. But the announcement underscored the difficulties companies face as they try to work their way into the living room.

headline: Video Series: Small Business and the Recession
text: Nearly a year after the Federal Reserve Bank of New York deemed the recession over, many small-business owners are still waiting for real signs of recovery. In this video, part of a series of articles and videos that have followed several small businesses in New York City since 2008, one gets a glimpse of how unevenly the economic rebound is playing out across the city and various industries. A bicycle manufacturer in Queens has adapted to changing markets and come out a leaner, more diversified company. Meanwhile, a butcher in the Bronx recently closed shop because of outstanding debt.

headline: Cisco Executive Is Named Chief of Skype, as New Owners Build a Leadership Team
text: Skype, the popular Internet video and telephone service, has hired a top official at the networking giant Cisco Systems as its chief executive, Skype said Monday.

headline: Considering Some Things Mysterious
text: With so many putting so much on self-promotional, self-debasing display (e.g. the Naked Cowboy’s presidential run, etc.), it can be easy to lose track of all the things that still remain shrouded in the city, its hidden treasures and sub rosa machinations.

headline: Disposophobia
text: A sesquipedalian term for “hoarding.”

headline: Skype Picks New C.E.O. Ahead of I.P.O.
text: 1:04 p.m. | Updated

headline: The Claim: A Soap-and-Water Rinse Gets Produce Cleanest
text: THE FACTS The prospect of ingesting pesticides and other contaminants can make supermarket produce seem less than appetizing. Buying organic lowers the risk, but is no guarantee against food-borne pathogens.

headline: Even Benefits Don’t Tempt Us to Vegetables
text: “Eat your vegetables.”

headline: Scorecard | Haider Ackermann Wins!
text: How to go from still slightly under the radar critical darling to supernova? If Milan taught designers showing on the fourth day of Paris Fashion Week anything, it’s to break out the Pantone book. Then — at least if you combine your electric blue and saffron with starchitectural volumes — you’ll take the emotive level of reviews Haider and higher still. Because Scorecard knows critics didn’t really get Loewe.

headline: In Concert, U2 Spins a New ‘Spider-Man’ Song
text: Speaking of rock stars with Broadway ambitions: at a concert Sunday night in Coimbra, Portugal, U2 added a new song to its set list called “Boy Falls From the Sky.” If that title makes your spider-sense – or maybe just your memory neurons – tingle, that’s because it is one of the tracks that Bono and the Edge created for the coming Broadway musical “Spider-Man, Turn Off the Dark.” Reeve Carney, who will play Spidey and his alter ego, Peter Parker, in the musical, played the song last month in an appearance on “Good Morning America”; now you can hear how it sounds when it’s performed by its composers.

headline: TimesCast | October 4, 2010
text: Graham Bowley and David Gillen on why cash-rich companies still aren't hiring, the value of vague terror warnings for travelers and a look back at the discovery of insulin.

headline: VW Design Chief Collaborates With Leica
text: Walter de’Silva, the head of design for the Volkswagen group, known for his elegant designs for Audi and, before that for Alfa Romeo, has designed a camera for Leica.

headline: 11 Arrests in Alabama Bingo Investigation
text: Last spring, reports of a federal corruption inquiry began trickling through the Alabama Legislature as its members argued fiercely over a bill to allow some form of gambling in the state. Several legislators received subpoenas, others acknowledged wearing recording devices and still others said they had received surprise visits from F.B.I. agents.

headline: Vick’s Injury Clarifies and Complicates Things
text: In the Philadelphia locker room, the quarterbacks are clustered in one corner, but how long they stay that way is one of the Eagles’ most pressing questions. That became painfully obvious when Michael Vick, who had energized the team in two games as the starter, bruised his ribs in the first quarter of Sunday’s loss to the Washington Redskins and never returned.

headline: As ’55 Turns 55, a Dodger Celebrates
text: For people of a certain age who lived in Brooklyn more than half a century ago, Oct. 4 is a day that will live in infinity.

headline: The Morning Skate: N.H.L. in Europe, Hockey Night in Canada in the U.S.
text: Once again this season for the fourth straight year, some N.H.L. teams are opening in Europe, with six teams — Carolina, Minnesota, Boston, San Jose, Columbus and Phoenix — beginning their schedule overseas. The first game on the regular season schedule (this Thursday at noon Easter) features the Hurricanes and the Wild from Helsinki.

headline: In Connecticut, New Ad Attacks Blumenthal’s Vietnam Claim
text: Hours before their debate on Monday night, the Republican candidate for Senate in Connecticut, Linda McMahon, released a video showing her opponent, Richard Blumenthal, suggesting that he served in the Vietnam War, though he did not.

headline: The Job Is Open. Who Should Run the Mets?
text: Monday is the 55th anniversary of the Brooklyn Dodgers’ 1955 World Series victory over the Yankees, a moment that Dave Anderson has duly noted in a Sports of The Times column. That day was clearly a big moment in the life of Fred Wilpon, the Mets’ principal owner, who grew up in Brooklyn as an avid Dodgers fan and high school teammate of Sandy Koufax, and who, of course, modeled Citi Field after Ebbets Field, which is now long gone.

headline: Chloé’s Silent Spring
text: On days when there are shows in the tent in the Tuileries garden, you expect to cross the hard, pebbled ground, wedge your way through the rigid crowd of onlookers and standing-ticket holders, and see something quite different once the show starts. Today, however, at Chloé, the models looked older and more world-wise this time. With their buns and ballet flats, in their streamlined coat dresses and plain white cotton dresses, they looked like young ladies who study dance or music. That is, they looked like an ideal.

headline: Sanofi’s Chief: Genzyme, Give Us a Number
text: In announcing that Sanofi-Aventis was taking its $18.5 billion bid for Genzyme directly to shareholders, Sanofi’s chief executive wants one thing.

headline: For Desserts Without Gluten, Crumbles Take the Cake
text: Lately I’ve been thinking about desserts and all the after-dinner delights that my gluten-intolerant friends are missing.

headline: Japan Recycles Minerals From Used Electronics
Peach or Nectarine and Blueberry Crumble With Quinoa-Oat Topping
text: Peaches or nectarines and blueberries make a beautiful color combination and a nice package of nutrients. The peaches contain vitamin C, vitamin A, vitamin K, beta-carotene and potassium, while the blueberries have anthocyanins, compounds that some scientists believe may have antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties.

headline: Airline Defends Dancing Flight Attendants
text: Proceeding on the assumption that five million YouTube viewers can’t be wrong, Cebu Pacific, the largest airline in the Philippines, has rejected criticism of its plan to have flight attendants perform dance routines while instructing passengers in safety procedures.

headline: Sara Lee Rises on Report of Rebuffed K.K.R. Approach
text: Shareholders pushed up Sara Lee‘s stock price on Monday, on a report by The New York Post that the consumer goods giant had dismissed a takeover proposal by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts. By early afternoon, Sara Lee shares were still up about 8.5 percent at $14.57.

headline: Franzen’s British Publisher Apologizes for Printing Errors
text: In a case of “Freedom” meets “The Corrections,” Jonathan Franzen‘s British publisher has apologized for a printing error that left dozens of spelling and punctuation mistakes in the first edition of his new novel.

headline: It’s Wisconsin Cheese, So Cook With It
text: The cheese heads from Wisconsin are trying new ways to give the average dairy shopper a head for its cheeses.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Q: (Reader)

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
text: Alexander Interactive, New York, formed a unit, Canopy, to specialize in Web design for e-commerce businesses. David Wertheimer, director for strategy at Alexander Interactive, becomes chief executive at Canopy.

headline: "Favorite Foods with Chef Michael Symon"
text: Chef Michael Symon prepares pan-roasted shrimp with Wisconsin Parmesan, one of his first signature dishes at his restaurant Lola.

headline: East Village Squatters Lose a Leader
text: Throughout much of the 1980s and ’90s, a certain segment of the East Village appeared to be in nearly perpetual rebellion. There were the squatters who took over abandoned city-owned buildings. There were the gardeners who reclaimed trash-strewn lots. And there were the anarchists and artists who declared rhetorical war on developers while holding roving protests and sometimes skirmishing with the police.

headline: STEM Education Has Little to Do With Flowers
text: If you want to talk about bolstering science and math education in this country, I’ll gladly break out my virtual pompoms and go rah. Who wouldn’t? Our nation’s economy, global allure and future tense all depend on the strength of its scientific spine.

headline: Where Is the Female Steve Jobs?
text: For American women, the days of overt “Mad Men”-style discrimination are largely gone. Women outnumber men at universities, have career options beyond the secretarial pool, and are (slowly) narrowing the pay gap with their male peers. So why has this half of the population failed to reach critical mass in leadership roles across industries? She Owns It explored the topic here, and author Gloria Feldt answers the question in her new book, No Excuses: 9 Ways Women Can Change the Way We Think About Power and Leadership. Ms. Feldt, the former president and chief executive of Planned Parenthood, recently spoke with me about why women’s progress is stalled, her hope that a female Steve Jobs will soon emerge and the dangers of being a stay-at-home mom. A condensed version of the conversation follows.

headline: Model-Morphosis | John Galliano
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of Paris Fashion Week. Here, the model Arizona Muse from Next Model Management before (left) and after (right) makeup by Pat McGrath and hair by Julien d’Ys. (Drag the orange bar left to reveal the full transformation.)

headline: Fremantle Buys Majority Stake in @radical.media
text: FremantleMedia has bought a majority stake in @radical.media, an innovator in the growing field of branded entertainment — the business of incorporating brands and products into the plots of entertainment content like movies, TV shows and video games. FremantleMedia is the production arm of the RTL Group unit of the media giant Bertelsmann.

headline: Metropolitan Museum of Art, 11:28 A.M.
text: Art handlers installed “Palm Tree/Seascape,” a new work by the conceptual artist John Baldessari.

headline: Popping Up in London’s Dining Scene
text: For the city’s emerging cooks, pop-up restaurants are part recital and part art happening, a chance to dazzle an adventurous audience.

headline: What Sanofi Needs to Win Genzyme
text: Sanofi-Aventis’s hostile bid for Genzyme could be the start of a long fight between the French drug maker and its biotechnology target.

headline: Hazards: Rabies Alert for Travelers to Africa and Asia
text: Public health officials have issued a rabies warning to American travelers after a 42-year-old psychiatrist from Virginia died from exposure to a rabid dog while he was jogging in India.

headline: With Media in Tow, Emanuel Embarks on ‘Listening Tour’
text: CHICAGO – Rahm Emanuel, the former White House chief of staff who wishes to be mayor, said he wanted to know what Chicagoans were worrying about. And halfway through Monday — the first day of what he is calling his “Tell It Like It Is” tour – Mr. Emanuel had certainly heard his share of worries.

headline: U.S. Reaches Deal in Credit-Card Antitrust Suit
text: Consumers may see more discounts for using cash instead of a credit card under a tentative deal announced Monday by the Justice Department and the credit card companies Visa and MasterCard.

headline: Aiming to Learn as We Do, a Machine Teaches Itself
text: Give a computer a task that can be crisply defined  win at chess, predict the weather  and the machine bests humans nearly every time. Yet when problems are nuanced or ambiguous, or require combining varied sources of information, computers are no match for human intelligence.

headline: The Highest Property Tax Burdens in America
text: The typical resident of Westchester County in New York pays more in property taxes  than the typical resident of any other major American county, according to a new analysis of Census data from the Tax Foundation.

headline: Why Indiscretions Appear Youthful
text: She had every reason to start stealing, or so it seemed at the time. A young daughter at home. Sickly, dependent in-laws. No savings or decent income. She and her husband could barely make the rent, and here she was working at a large department store that was raking in the cash. Who would miss a few items here and there, a jacket, some cosmetics?

headline: Re-See | Bodkin
text: New York Fashion Week may be long gone, but for all of those not on the Europe circuit, that means taking a closer look at the collections in the labels’ showrooms, an appointment better known as “re-see.” On one such recent visit with Eviana Hartman, the designer behind the eco-conscious label Bodkin, T was thrilled to find that Hartman, now in her fourth season, is expanding into swimwear. “I was heading to Mal País, Costa Rica, for my first surf trip,” says Hartman of her decision to dive into new territory. “I couldn’t quite find a bathing suit that was me.” Her decision was sealed when she stumbled upon a pile of dead-stock gray and mint heather fabric in a Los Angeles warehouse. For now, the swimwear line features only two styles — the two-piece “Bodkini” and the one-piece twister suit (twisting and knotting is also featured throughout the lively spring/summer clothing collection) — but Hartman is optimistic that it will make a splash with her loyal fan base. “If the Bodkin girl isn’t already a surfer,” she says, “she probably wants to be.”

headline: Rediscovering the First Miracle Drug
text: Every few months some miracle drug or other is rolled out with bells and confetti, but only once or twice in a generation does the real thing come along.

headline: How to Stop Rogue Automatic Payments
text: Many of us have at least part of our financial lives on autopilot. Maybe Netflix and your gym automatically bill your credit card each month. Or perhaps you’ve authorized your credit cards and cable company to pull money directly from your checking account.

headline: Phone Carriers Sign On to Bring Service to Subways
text: Cellphone service in the subways: it’s coming. Eventually. To a few stations. As long as, you know, all goes as planned.

headline: Measles Vaccine, 1960
text: The first scientific description of measles dates from the ninth century, and the disease was first mentioned in The New-York Daily Times on Oct. 14, 1851, when the newspaper was not yet one month old.

headline: New Show by ‘Stomp’ Creators Is Canceled
text: The national tour of “Pandemonium: The Lost and Found Orchestra,” the latest show from the composers Luke Cresswell and Steve McNicholas, the creators of “Stomp,” has been canceled after fewer than three weeks of performances.

headline: Taking Revenge on ‘Borat,’ Amorous Donkey and All
text: ALMATY, Kazakhstan  Sitting before some editing banks on the second floor of a nightclub here, a Kazakh director named Erkin Rakishev described the weighty task ahead: defending the honor of all Kazakhs by wreaking revenge on the odious movie “Borat.”

headline: UPS Expands Its Hybrid Truck Fleet
text: UPS announced Thursday that it has ordered 130 new diesel hybrid electric delivery trucks to complement its existing fleet of 250 of the vehicles, which are made in two sizes by Freightliner with hybrid drive systems from the Eaton Corporation.

headline: In Any Case: Conducting a Mock Trial
text: Overview | What are the main components of a court proceeding? How can holding a mock trial provide insights into curricular material? In this lesson, students learn the key terms associated with the United States court system, then engage with core texts and subjects through the mock trial process.

headline: Critics' Picks: Howards End
text: A. O. Scott reviews James Ivory and Ismail Merchant's adaptation of E.M. Forster's novel starring Emma Thompson and Anthony Hopkins.

headline: Numberplay: Calculus for the Second Grader
text: 7:40 p.m. | (Updated: Errors Corrected.) Today I want to share with you something that I discovered for myself in my first year of college. It uses math that’s so simple that a second grader can do it, and yet it can let you figure out things that you might expect to require calculus. This technique deserves to be better known than it is, so I’m doing the first thing that publicists do: giving it a catchy name. “Calculus for the Second Grader” is only a small exaggeration. Let me show you …

headline: Cellphone Operator Moves to Expand Beyond Russia
text: MOSCOW  For years, Russian companies have said they have the cash and the ambition to expand well beyond the former Soviet Union.

headline: A Sustainable-Food Employment Agency
text: A new Web site for finding jobs in the food business — at the likes of Brooklyn Larder, not Burger King — has launched, goodfoodjobs.com. A national Craiglist for the sustainable set, the site aims to connect job seekers with such diverse employers as Blue Hill at Stone Barns, the Momofuku Restaurant Group, the Monterey Bay Aquarium, and individual farmers.

headline: Hazards of Flying: Low Fuel. Ice. Deer.
text: I’M a nervous wreck when I fly commercial, which is strange since I’m a pilot. I know intellectually that flying is a very safe mode of transportation. Whatever. When I’m not the pilot, my life is in someone else’s hands.

headline: A Specious Species? (3 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Explorers’ Best Friends (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Cheap and Effective (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: In First Marine Census, a Plenitude of Wonders
text: After a decade of research and more than 540 ocean expeditions, scientists presented the world with the first-ever census of marine life on Monday. The census involved the work of 670 institutions and 2,700 researchers and made direct observation of 120,000 marine species, including some 6,000 newly discovered species.

headline: Critics’ Picks: ‘Howards End’
text: In this week’s Critics’ Pick, A. O. Scott looks back at Ismail Merchant and James Ivory‘s 1992 adaptation of the E. M. Forster novel “Howards End.” The film stars Emma Thompson and Anthony Hopkins and explores class struggles and relationships in Edwardian England. Among the features Mr. Scott praises are the “lovely period clothing, gorgeous cinematography, lavish and historically-appropriate production design and scrupulous fidelity to the literary source.”

headline: Now Serving | The Taquerias of Colonia Narvarte
text: Mexico City is a well-documented hotbed of contradictions: wealth side by side with poverty, globalization nuzzling indigenous tradition, beheadings alongside leisurely afternoons in lush parks sucking jicama pops. In a city that contains 2,000 official colonias (neighborhoods), even intrepid visitors who come to explore end up sticking to one safe corner of this metropolis. A short taxi ride from the trendy Condesa/Roma area is the colonia Narvarte, a charming middle-class neighborhood where Che Guevara lived while plotting the overthrow of the Batista dictatorship with Fidel Castro. The area is known for its wide avenues with palm-lined camellones (traffic islands) and a somewhat old-fashioned atmosphere, and it also happens to house some of the city’s greatest taquerias. Here’s where to go.

headline: Shift at the Top of Twitter as a Founder Steps Aside
text: Evan Williams, the co-founder and chief executive of Twitter, is stepping down to lead product strategy at the company, Twitter announced on Monday. Dick Costolo, the chief operating officer, will succeed Mr. Williams.

headline: Climate Group Regrets Shock Film Tactic (So Does Sony)
text: 6:04 p.m. | Updated There are much more important things to focus on than an utterly misconceived mini movie blowing up kids to recruit carbon cutters, so it’s welcome that Eugenie Harvey, the director of the 10:10 UK group that commissioned the film, has moved toward closure by issuing a real apology (text below). The rather reluctant regrets note posted on Friday essentially encouraged YouTube visitors to copy and disseminate it by saying, “We won’t be making any attempt to censor or remove other versions currently in circulation on the internet.”

headline: Ford to Introduce Focus With an ‘Amazing Race’ of Sorts
text: DEARBORN, Mich. – Ford announced Monday that it would create a real-time interactive event called Focus Rally: America to help introduce the 2012 Focus compact car, which was scheduled for dealer showrooms early next year.

headline: Answers About World War II in New York, Part III
text: Richard Goldstein, an author and historian of the Second World War who was our guest expert on City Room last week, provided the following third and final batch of answers to  readers’ questions about all aspects of New York and the war. You can find previous installments in this Q & A here.

headline: With Tagline, MSNBC Embraces a Political Identity
text: MSNBC, once the also-ran but now the No. 2 cable news channel, has a new tagline that embraces its progressive political identity.

headline: Congressional Republicans Start 20-State Ad Blitz
text: Over the weekend, the National Republican Congressional Committee began releasing 27 spots in 20 states, many of which aim to portray Democrats as part of the Washington establishment and link them to the House speaker, Nancy Pelosi of California.

headline: Toiling to Save a Threatened Frog
text: SEQUOIA AND KINGS CANYON NATIONAL PARKS, Calif.  From the summit of Bishop Pass in the Sierra Nevada, elevation 11,972 feet, all you can see are miles of granite peaks against the sky. There is no traffic and no pollution. The natural world seems pure and unspoiled.

headline: Accusation Upsets a Province
text: The editors of Maclean’s, the venerable weekly Canadian magazine, have made provocative covers something of a specialty. But none of their earlier efforts produced quite the same response as an image of Bonhomme Carnaval, the snowman mascot of Quebec’s winter festival, jauntily carrying a briefcase overflowing with cash. The bold cover headline on the issue dated Oct. 4 was no more subtle: “Quebec: The Most Corrupt Province.”

headline: ‘Daily Show’ Correspondent to Marry Iraq War Veteran
text: John Oliver, British comedian of “The Daily Show” fame, announced that he’s engaged to Kate Norley, an Army medic who spent time in Iraq. The couple met in 2008 at the Republican National Convention.

headline: Analyst’s Street-Level View of Citi
text: It is going to take more than a two-hour meeting with Citigroup executives to make a believer out of the financial analyst Michael Mayo, left.

headline: Sundance Institute Announces Foreign Venture
text: Sundance is going abroad. As part of an effort to foster crosscultural understanding through cinema, the Sundance Institute said on Monday that it would work with a smattering of other nonprofit arts groups to present 10 independent films in New York and at American embassies and other locations overseas. The program, called Film Forward: Advancing Cultural Dialogue, will consist of five American and five international pictures. (Sundance did not announce any titles but likely candidates are films the organization has heralded in the past, like “Winter’s Bone,” about an Ozark woman’s quest to find her drug-dealing father.)

headline: Boozer to Miss 2 Months After Tripping Over Gym Bag
text: Once again, Mom was right: clean up your things before you trip on them.

headline: Criticism Flies After State Eases Ban on Art Sales
text: When the New York State Board of Regents met last month to consider making permanent a set of temporary regulations that bar the sale of artwork by museums to cover expenses, approval was widely considered a fait accompli.

headline: Ex-Members of Congress Call for Civility
text: Over 100 former members of Congress – many of whom won their own races by pointing out defects in their opponents– have written to all members of Congress as well as House and Senate candidates, imploring them to reject excessive partisanship as they enter the home stretch of this highly contentious political season.

headline: Readers Find No Consensus on Line-Cutting
text: From Sunday brunch to Shakespeare in the Park, lines are a ubiquitous, frustrating but largely tolerated part of New York life. (This is perhaps why we have our own way of talking about it: “on line” to the rest of the country’s “in line.”) Lines are also generally treated as sacrosanct: any effort to cut and head directly to the front is usually met with fiercely righteous wrath from all those who have sacrificed the better part of their day for some scarce, coveted item or experience.

headline: H.I.V.: National Institutes of Health Licenses Its Patent on a New Drug for AIDS
text: In a move that gave official American backing to the controversial idea of a “patent pool,” the National Institutes of Health last week became the first entity to license its patent on a new AIDS drug to an entity loosely affiliated with the World Health Organization.

headline: Feingold Ad Says He Fought Insurers
text: In a season when many Democrats are running away from the president’s health care bill — a plan some Republicans having been attacking as “Obama care” — Senator Russ Feingold of Wisconsin just cut a campaign ad aligning himself with that very topic.

headline: Notes From the Underground | CocoRosie
text: When Bianca and Sierra Casady, the sister act known as CocoRosie, recently performed at the Music Hall of Williamsburg, it was a amid an atmosphere of gypsy celebration complete with miscellaneous congratulatory balloons, a massive video projection, several classical musicians, a French beatbox star and a table full of noise-making children’s toys. The duo mostly performed songs from their recent album, “Grey Oceans,” but were joined intermittently by the performance artist Kembra Pfahler and the poet Rebecca Wright. Brought back to the stage by thunderous applause and the stamping of feet, the Casadys gleefully treated the audience to not one but two encore sets before embarking on the rest of their tour of the United States.

headline: Airplane Air Is No Riskier Than Other Enclosed Spaces, Study Says
text: Thousands of flights to Mexico were canceled last year in response to the outbreak of the H1N1 virus there. And the SARS scare in 2003 prompted airports and airlines to adopt emergency measures, among them screening passengers for high fevers as they boarded.

headline: The Joker in the Deck: Birth of a Supervillain
text: In comic books, origin stories often involve chance meetings, freak accidents or personal tragedies. Not many of them start on a tennis court in the Poconos. But that is where the career of Jerry Robinson, 88, the man who created the villainous Joker, began.

headline: Sweet, Ecstatic, Petulant and in Control
text: Plenty of times on Thursday night it was unclear where Ellie Goulding’s squeal stopped and the synthesizers backing her began. At the Hiro Ballroom for her first New York show, she was crowded tightly onstage, flanked by banks of chilly keyboards. But she is no simple machine. A young British singer with a scrappy but pretty voice, she makes music that’s a happy car crash of signifiers: part electro-pop, part soul, part blues, part indie rock, part folk. In Britain in the past five years, young female singers  in acts like La Roux, Duffy, Florence and the Machine, and more  have been toying with these styles individually, painting them with shimmering gloss. Ms. Goulding plays all of their games, and well.

headline: Debaters Step Into High-Risk Spotlight
text: The Takeway With Michael D. Shear

headline: Dance in Review
text: AITANA CORDERO

headline: Leafy Carpets of Laughter, Hints of Wartime and a Quirky Coltrane Score
text: Putting together the Fall for Dance festival’s five programs can’t be easy. There has to be a mix of dance styles, of well-known and unknown names, of length and pace, difficulty and ease. Sometimes it just doesn’t work out very well. On Saturday at City Center, the third program seemed ingratiatingly audience-appealing and thin in comparison with some of the vibrant juxtapositions of work that Fall for Dance has presented in the past.

headline: Saved, Before Alcoholics Anonymous
text: Of all the old war horses of the American theater, few have been more durable than “The Drunkard,” W. H. Smith’s cautionary tale on the evils of John Barleycorn. The original 1844 staging in Boston was for a temperance crusade and was deadly serious; a 1933 production in Los Angeles was played strictly for laughs and ran more than 20 years. An engaging revival by the Metropolitan Playhouse falls somewhere in between and makes a good case for the piece’s being more than a quaint theatrical curio.

headline: Catch, Treat, Release
text: Vance Vredenburg, a biology professor at San Francisco State University, is trying to save the Sierra Nevada yellow-legged frog from a deadly fungal disease that has been devastating amphibian populations around the world. In Tuesday’s Science Times, Erica Rex reports on Dr. Vredenburg’s efforts to inoculate wild frogs with an experimental bacteria treatment in Dusy Basin, in Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks.

headline: Training Flights for Bees
text: Q. How are bees able to find their way back to the hive after foraging for pollen?

headline: An Unlikely Tony Kushner World Premiere, Courtesy of NYU
text: Virtually every playwright has an unfinished or unresolved script tucked in a drawer somewhere. For Tony Kushner, that play was “Henry Box Brown,” a one act written in the early 1990s while he was finishing his epic “Angels in America,” whose two parts went on to win back-to-back Tony Awards for best play in 1993 and 1994.

headline: Rajaratnam Takes Stand at Hearing
text: 7:05 p.m. | Updated Almost a year to the day after agents from the Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested him on insider-trading charges, the hedge fund manager Raj Rajaratnam took the witness stand at a pretrial hearing in federal district court on Monday, raised his right hand and swore to the tell the truth, the whole truth and nothing but the truth.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Somalia, Brussels and Cambodia.

headline: Blue Whales With Pearly Whites, Once Upon a Time
text: Blue whales are enormous, magnificent creatures. The largest mammals known to have existed, they can grow to be more than 100 feet in length and weigh more than 100 tons, and they don’t even have teeth.

headline: Neanderthals’ Big Loss in Battle of the Elements
text: Homo sapiens may not have pushed Neanderthals to extinction, as some scientists have hypothesized; it may have been the weather that did them in.

headline: Dinosaurs Loom Larger After a Study of Limbs
text: As if dinosaurs, some of them anyway, weren’t big enough, a new study reports that the skeletons we see in museums should be as much as a foot taller than they are now. Dinosaurs, paleontologists write in the journal PLoS One, had thick pieces of cartilage between their joints that increased their height.

headline: Potash Deal Report Predicts Loss for Province
text: OTTAWA  The province of Saskatchewan could be hit by substantial revenue losses from a takeover of the Potash Corporation, according to an independent study released by the government on Monday.

headline: West 82nd Street, 9:15 A.M.
text: Caption contest! Write your own in the space below.

headline: From Heaps of Junk, a Melodious Clang
text: A tall, trim man in chinos and a green checked shirt strode quickly past broken car carcasses, Dumpsters and chunks of unidentified metal.

headline: Piece’s Twists and Turns Are Literal and Figurative
text: SAN FRANCISCO  I don’t hail “Oh, Inverted World,” a premiere by the choreographer Trey McIntyre for the Smuin Ballet, as any kind of masterpiece, and I don’t hail Mr. McIntyre as a genius. But this dance confirms the sense that he is now an important individual voice in ballet choreography. Having seen it once, I wish I could see it again soon, simply to come to terms with the surprises it springs in phrasing and structure.

headline: Photo Replay: Oct. 4
text: A view of the day in sports, with the Ryder Cup ending in Wales and the Commonwealth Games continuing in New Delhi.

headline: Behavior: Losing Fat, as Easily as Closing Your Eyes
text: Trying to get rid of that extra fat? Sleep in.

headline: Giles Deacon Joins Emanuel Ungaro
text: Suzy Menkes talks to Giles Deacon about his decision to become the fashion designer for the struggling French fashion house Emanuel Ungaro.

headline: Neurofeedback Gains Popularity and Lab Attention
text: You sit in a chair, facing a computer screen, while a clinician sticks electrodes to your scalp with a viscous goop that takes days to wash out of your hair. Wires from the sensors connect to a computer programmed to respond to your brain’s activity.

headline: In Different Hands, an Assortment of Moods
text: The blazing surge to the end of Dvorak’s “New World” Symphony at Carnegie Hall on Sunday afternoon was unusually satisfying. Here, as in the whole program, which also offered Brahms’s “Tragic Overture” and Schumann’s Cello Concerto, the Vienna Philharmonic was fully in its element after an unusual series of concerts. And encouraged by the young conducting dynamo Gustavo Dudamel, the orchestra played with a kind of gusto that few others can match, those patented string tremolos threatening to spark fire.

headline: Send In the Clowns — and the Truth Squad
text: Bozo-gate, anyone?

headline: Awareness: Killer of 200,000 Americans, Hardly Noticed
text: Sepsis causes more than 200,000 deaths in the United States each year, yet Americans know little about it: most people questioned online for a new study said they had never heard the term.

headline: For NBC, Football Delivers Sunday Night
text: “Undercover Boss,” “60 Minutes” and the season premiere of “CSI: Miami” lifted CBS to second place in the ratings on Sunday night, trailing only NBC and “Sunday Night Football.” According to Nielsen’s estimates, CBS’s new installment of “Undercover Boss,” featuring Kim Schaefer, the chief executive of Great Wolf Resorts, earned the largest nonfootball audience on Sunday with 13.1 million viewers, eking out a victory in the 9 p.m. time slot, ahead of ABC’s “Desperate Housewives” (13 million). CBS began the night in solid fashion as well with “60 Minutes” at 7 (12.5 million), followed by “The Amazing Race” at 8 (10.7 million), while the network’s ninth-season debut of “CSI: Miami” drew 11.8 million at 10. Although final ratings were not expected until Tuesday, preliminary overnight estimates for NBC’s “Sunday Night Football” were higher than those of last week’s game, which drew 18.2 million. Fox and ABC finished in a virtual tie for third place.

headline: In Illness, Old Dream Is Realized
text: When I was a boy, I ached to be a scientist. I was the kind of kid who needed to know why and how — right now! — not to mention who, what, where and when.

headline: Rail Service Expansion Imperiled at State Level
text: Republicans running for governor in a handful of states could block, or significantly delay, one of President Obama’s signature initiatives: his plan to expand the passenger rail system and to develop the nation’s first bullet-train service.

headline: Detroit Musicians Picket Music Center
text: About 60 musicians, many in black concert dress and bolstered by the music of a horn quartet, took to the picket lines outside the Max M. Fisher Music Center in Detroit on Monday as the members of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra went on strike. The picketing players (above, with Karl Pituch on French horn) were to have begun rehearsing for the new season’s first concert. They struck in a dispute with management over the extent of wage cuts and changes sought in work rules at the financially troubled orchestra. The last orchestra strike in Detroit was in 1987.

headline: How to Collect Your Verizon Refund
text: If you suspect that you are one of the estimated 15 million Verizon customers to receive credit due to erroneous data charges, you may wonder what you have to do to collect.

headline: Augmented Reality: From Baseball Cards to Books
text: In a world of multiple, multi-media diversions, how do you engage kids and keep them reading anything longer than a few lines of a text message? Simon and Schuster, along with the well-known children’s author and illustrator Tony DiTerlizzi, hope they’ve found at least a partial answer.

headline: Chilean Miners’ Rescue May Happen Within Weeks, President Says
text: SANTIAGO, Chile  The 33 miners trapped nearly half a mile underground in northern Chile may be rescued by Oct. 17, weeks before the government’s original predictions, President Sebastián Piñera announced in a nationally broadcast radio interview Monday.

headline: Rinsing Your Vegetables
text: In today’s “Really?” column, Anahad O’Connor explores the options for rinsing pesticide residue off vegetables.

headline: Reinventing the Suitcase by Adding the Wheel
text: MANY thousands of years ago, there were two important inventions, the wheel and the sack. As a traveler, I can’t help wondering why it took so long to put rollers on that sack to create wheeled luggage.

headline: Sanofi Bid for Genzyme Turns Hostile, and No Sweeter
text: Sanofi-Aventis of France took its $18.5 billion takeover bid for Genzyme hostile on Monday, going directly to Genzyme’s shareholders in an effort to advance deal negotiations.

headline: Teens Are Smarter About Condoms Than Adults Are
text: Teenagers are more responsible about using condoms than adults are, a new study shows.

headline: Verizon Comes Clean
text: Last November, I started up one of my patented Pogue Fights for the Consumer campaigns on my blog. I noted that Verizon Wireless was charging $2 a pop every time customers accidentally pressed the up-arrow key on their flip phones — the keystroke that comes hard-wired to mean “take me to the Web.”

headline: Obama Debates Advisers on Tax Cuts
text: President Obama gathered his outside economics advisers at the White House on Monday to talk job training and education but wound up debating the merits of increasing taxes on the wealthy in the middle of a volatile economy.

headline: Six New Books for Wine and Spirits Lovers
text: THEY say the book industry is dying, but obviously they must have ignored the piles of new wine and spirits books accumulating on my desk. The business has indeed changed, though. Of the six new-ish books I want to recommend here, two of them are not available in stores, or even at Amazon.com. Self-publishing has moved well beyond vanity works, and now includes some excellent books on wine.

headline: Potash Deal Could Be Costly for Canadian Province
text: The province of Saskatchewan could be hit by substantial revenue losses from a takeover of the Potash Corporation, according to an independent study released by the Canadian government on Monday, The New York Times’s Ian Austen reports from Ottawa.

headline: Weight Classes Aim to Balance Races
text: At 245 pounds and 6 feet 3 inches, Jeffrey West knows he looks more like a football player than a runner. But that hasn’t stopped him from competing in nine marathons in the past three years.

headline: Synthes to Divest a Subsidiary in Plea Deal Over Spinal Surgeries
text: Synthes, the American subsidiary of a global maker of medical devices, was ordered to divest one of its subsidiaries, Norian, on Monday in what was labeled an unprecedented plea agreement with federal prosecutors.

headline: For Giants, a Victory but Not Consistency
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  For the Giants’ offense, each week has been a process of self-discovery. The picture is not very clear at the quarter pole of the regular season.

headline: Climate Video Gets a Thumbs Down From Critics
text: Barely one minute into a short video by 10:10, a British climate advocacy group, two porcelain-skinned middle schoolers named Phillip and Tracy are deliberately blown up by their teacher. Their blood and body parts then scatter across their mates and the classroom in a crimson deluge.

headline: ‘Superman’ Movie Series is Up, Up and Away With a New Director
text: For his next movie, Zack Snyder will once again take to the skies – not with owls, but with one of the most recognizable and enduring heroes in comic books: Superman.

headline: The Making of 'Kraft'
text: Lou Mannarino, an audio engineer, finds local sounds in the scrap metal he is using to create instruments for the Magnus Lindberg symphony, "Kraft," for the New York Philharmonic.

headline: In Sign of Discord, Iran Blocks Web Sites of Some Clerics
text: TEHRAN, Iran  The web sites of two senior clerics have been blocked by government censors, a possible sign of a hardening political divide at the highest level of Iran’s religious establishment.

headline: Arizona and Its Accidental Governors
text: Arizona has a history of its governors departing early, some out of ambition and others in disgrace. A ballot initiative pushed by an civic group would try to bring order to the chaos of accidental Arizona governors.

headline: Apple Challenges Big Award Over Patents
text: Apple is challenging a jury verdict that could force it to pay as much as $625.5 million to a company founded by David Gelernter, a Yale computer science professor, for infringing three patents related to how files are displayed on the iPod, the iPhone and Macintosh computers.

headline: Christine O'Donnell's Political Ad
text: Christine O'Donnell, the Republican candidate for the Senate race in Delaware, released her first political ad.

headline: Little Ways the M.T.A. Can Ease Riders’ Pain
text: Barring miracles, and they are in short supply right now, the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority will vote in a couple of days to raise mass-transit fares. Combined with recent reductions in service, the increases are sure to send New Yorkers straight to the upper reaches of the unhappiness scale.

headline: O’Donnell Ad Confronts Reports on Her Past
text: Christine O’Donnell wants you, the voter, to know that she is not a witch.

headline: Greening the Armed Forces
text: The American military, facing increasing insurgent attacks on fuel supply convoys in Pakistan and Afghanistan, is pushing aggressively to develop, test and deploy renewable technologies to decrease its dependence on fossil fuels.

headline: 2 E-Books Cost More Than Amazon Hardcovers
text: Readers of e-books may not be able to turn paper pages, lend their copies to friends or file them away on living room bookshelves. But they do have the comfort of knowing that they paid less for them than for hardcovers.

headline: Odds Against Third-Party Bid Not as Long as They Seem
text: Thomas Friedman’s Sunday column, in which he predicted the emergence of a “serious third party candidate in 2012, with a serious political movement behind him or her,” is attracting a lot of comment — and criticism — in different parts of the blogosphere.

headline: A Marine Life Encyclopedia
text: The first ever census of marine life catalogs nearly 120,000 species, including remarkable creatures like the Christmas tree worm, a hairy crab and several newly discovered species.

headline: New Rule for Goalies Short and Tall
text: An N.H.L. rule change in the works for more than two years may do little to stem the long-term decline in scoring, but it will put goaltenders on a level playing field.

headline: Toshiba to Offer 3-D TV That Does Not Require Special Glasses
text: CHIBA, Japan  Toshiba, the Japanese electronics maker, said Monday that it would be the first on the market with a TV that displayed images in 3-D without requiring viewers to use special glasses.

headline: Coroner Calls for Changes in Luge Training
text: The coroner of British Columbia has ruled that the death of a Georgian luge athlete in a training run before the Vancouver Games was accidental, but he called on the International Luge Federation to do more to prepare athletes to race on unfamiliar tracks and before major competitions.

headline: 2 Swiss Banks Facing Higher Capital Standards
text: A Swiss government panel proposed rules on Monday that would require the nation’s two big banks, UBS and Credit Suisse, to hold more capital in reserve than their international competitors.

headline: Removing Blocks to City Bailouts
text: President Gerald Ford refused to help New York in 1975, a rejection immortalized in the headline “drop dead.”

headline: Rushes of Excitement, Sometimes Deserved
text: Paris

headline: It’s a Tough League for Quarterbacks, as the Giants Proved
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

headline: Their Feet May Be Stars in Japan
text: Paris

headline: Dealbreaker Sales Talks: A Hot Market for Blogs
text: TechCrunch has done it. PaidContent already did it. Now, it appears Dealbreaker is close to the doing the same.

headline: Relatives Tell of Civilians Killed by U.S. Soldiers
text: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  It was difficult enough for the people of western Kandahar Province. They are beleaguered both by the Taliban, who control the roads, demand taxes and execute anyone suspected of disloyalty, and by the American military, who often show little regard for people and whose demands that locals stand up to the insurgents seem unreasonable.

headline: Power Still Off at Twins’ New Home
text: MINNEAPOLIS  Not much ruffles the aw-shucks manner of Joe Mauer, the Minnesota Twins’ All-Star catcher and last year’s American League most valuable player. One subject, however, makes him uncomfortable: how poorly balls travel at Target Field, the Twins’ new open-air stadium.

headline: Turnovers Help Patriots Top Dolphins
text: Chad Henne threw for nearly twice as many yards as Tom Brady. Twice as many touchdowns and 10 more completions, too.

headline: In Haiti, Rising Call for Displaced to Go Away
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  As tent camps go, the one on the 28-acre Church of God property overlooking the Valley of Bourdon is almost bucolic, with hundreds of canvas-draped shelters under leafy shade trees and a cohesiveness among residents. But panic is building there.

headline: Dolores Wilson, Met Soprano, Dies at 82
text: Dolores Wilson, a Metropolitan Opera soprano of the 1950s who later sang in Broadway musicals, died on Sept. 28 in Englewood, N.J. She was 82 and lived in Englewood.

headline: After Growth, Fortunes Turn for Monsanto
text: As recently as late December, Monsanto was named “company of the year” by Forbes magazine. Last week, the company earned a different accolade from Jim Cramer, the television stock market commentator. “This may be the worst stock of 2010,” he proclaimed.

headline: Paris Accessories: Low Down
text: An eyebrow pencil might be the best accessory for spring, to judge from the makeup at Chloé and Stella McCartney on Monday. The Paris spring shows have given a different direction to accessories than what we saw in Milan. The news here is the flat shoe or low-heeled sandal, often with a metallic element, like the mirrored ankle pieces on Giambattista Valli’s low-heeled shoes, which had leopard print or solid color toes.

headline: Iraqi Festival Falls Prey to the Forces of Democracy
text: BAGHDAD  Saddam Hussein used to hold the Babylon Festival at the end of Iraq’s sweltering summers on the site of the ancient ruins of Hammurabi and Nebuchadnezzar, an hour’s drive south of the capital. It was agitprop, an annual expression of megalomania and, until the last one in fall 2002, with war already in the air, a forum for railing against the United States.

headline: Wilpons First Need to Replace Mind-Set
text: The next day was hanging day the sky was overcast and black  Bob Dylan, “Lily, Rosemary and the Jack of Hearts.”

headline: Afghan Election Official Is Held, Police Say
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  After a raft of complaints about fraud in the parliamentary elections in Khost Province, the provincial police arrested the provincial head of the Independent Election Commission on Monday, police officials said.

headline: Play-Doh? Calculus? At the Manhattan Free School, Anything Goes

headline: Literary Criticism Comes to the Movies

None, that is, until “Howl,” the new movie about Allen Ginsberg starring James Franco, which is not only about literary criticism but is the performance of literary criticism, an extended “explication de texte.”

But while international stars like Thierry Henry, Carlos Tévez and Nemanja Vidic have announced or hinted at retirement from their national teams, the American defender Steve Cherundolo is playing on with the United States and his Hannover 96 club in the Bundesliga.

Complaining of job losses, politicians in the gulf and many in industry are demanding that it be lifted now. Senator Mary Landrieu, a Louisiana Democrat, is threatening to block President Obama’s nominee for budget director unless drilling is allowed to resume quickly.

headline: An Illegal Search, by GPS
text: In a landmark 1967 case, the Supreme Court ruled that evidence from a wiretap on a phone booth was obtained unconstitutionally. Despite the public nature of a phone booth, the tap violated the defendant’s privacy under the Fourth Amendment. “Wherever a man may be,” the court explained, “he is entitled to know that he will remain free from unreasonable searches and seizures.”

headline: Confusion Over Secure Communities

Suspects’ names and fingerprints will be run not just through criminal databases but compared against immigration records, too, through a program that is being steadily and rapidly rolled out across the country.

headline: Televisa to Buy Stake in Univision

headline: Wayne Winterrowd
text: Wayne Winterrowd once told me, in an e-mail, that he thought of me when autumn brought pig-killing time around. I was grateful for the thought. And if I ever find myself covering rosebushes with evergreen boughs  while wearing crampons  I will certainly think of Wayne, who reported doing just that a couple of years ago. Like many gardeners around the world, I will be mourning Wayne for a good long time. He died on Sept. 17, age 68, at home in Vermont where he lived with his spouse and co-author, Joe Eck.

headline: California: State Furloughs Are Legal, Court Rules
text: In a blow to state worker unions, the State Supreme Court ruled Monday that mandatory furloughs of state employees were legal. In 2009, faced with a $40 billion shortfall in the budget through mid-2010, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger put in place three days a month of mandatory, unpaid furlough for some 200,000 state workers. Employee unions quickly filed multiple lawsuits contending that the governor did not have authority to issue involuntary furloughs. On Monday, the state’s highest court unanimously upheld the governor’s legal right to furlough workers through June 30 of this year, saying that the State Legislature had approved such cost-saving measures in last year’s budget legislation. The ruling comes as legislators and the governor say they have reached an agreement on a budget that is three months’ overdue, the longest budget impasse in the state’s history. Until details of the deal are released, which is expected to be Wednesday, it is unclear if this year’s budget will permit state worker furloughs to continue.

headline: Yves Saint Laurent Assembles a ‘New Tribe’
text: No, in all likelihood he would do a “real” Saint Laurent collection, since a major exhibition was held this year in Paris and other designers were influenced. (See the full collection.)The Yves Saint Laurent show was held last evening in several rooms at the grand-looking home that once belonged to Salomon de Rothschild, on the Rue Berryer. The address, near the Etoile and some of the top Michelin restaurants in Paris, indicated that Stefano Pilati’s collection would be a tribute to the master of chic, with the necessary tingle of eroticism. Mr. Pilati would not be showing puzzling things like white cotton dresses scattered with strawberry appliqués, as he did a year ago. Nor would the clothes look as solemn as last season.

headline: El Greco’s ‘Toledo’ on View in Madrid
text: For El Greco, Toledo, Spain, had an almost mystical significance. After the artist left his native Crete in the early 1570s and passed through Italy, the town provided him with a home, a place where his astoundingly original manner of painting was appreciated and an environment where his intellectual ambitions could be realized. The artist expressed his relationship with the town in his “View and Plan of Toledo,” a magnificent late work that normally calls the El Greco Museum in Toledo home. The piece is now on display, through Feb. 27, at the Prado  Museum in Madrid.

headline: Indonesian President Postpones Netherlands Trip

headline: ‘Likely Voter’ Gap Favors G.O.P. by 6 Points; Gallup’s Model Sees It Bigger
text: Democratic poll-watchers were having a pretty good Monday. Rasmussen Reports had shown Republicans with a relatively small 3-point advantage on the generic ballot — the narrowest advantage that Rasmussen has shown for Republicans in about a year. Meanwhile, two polls in a pivotal Senate race, Connecticut, showed the Democrat Richard Blumenthal with a solid lead there. Perhaps there was something to all the talk about a Democratic rebound in the polls, which has been in fashion lately.

headline: Spot On
text: After the stunning Chanel show this morning, I stopped by the new H&M flagship designed by Jean Nouvel on the Champs Elysées. Almost everything in the windows was covered with leopard spots – on jackets, blouses and pants. Editors have been wearing leopard prints all week. At the Chloé show on Monday, you could see Carine Roitfeld, the editor of French Vogue, in a spotted jacket, standing next to Anna Dello Russo in a leopard print minidress covered with fringe, next to Virginie Mouzat of Le Figaro in a white blouse flocked with leopard spots. If leopard prints are already going mainstream this fall, it makes you wonder if this trend will still have legs for spring, even though designers like Riccardo Tisci of Givenchy are betting on it.

headline: A Lavazza I.P.O. or Buyout? Don’t Count on Either

After all, the military has huge purchasing power, enough to create genuine markets.
