The bank’s announcement that it would unwind those bets, and its botched execution, has put the trader on the hook for $7 billion he did not actually lose. But who is so silly as to expect justice from a court of law? (From Dealbreaker via @alea_)

headline: Wall Street Extends Its Rally as S.&P. Rises 2.1%
text: Stock markets continued a robust rally Wednesday in Asia, a day after the market in the United States turned in one of its best performances in months.

headline: Buzzword Patrol
text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

headline: Buzzword Patrol
text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

headline: Dueling Marches and a New Talk Show
text: How’s this for alternate realities? Fox’s Glenn Beck on Monday gave his version of events surrounding last Saturday’s One Nation rally in Washington, D.C., where an array of groups promoted progressive causes.

headline: Ambitious, Donald? ‘Absolutely’ Trumps ‘Certainly Not’
text: The Donald just offered a perfect tutorial in how a developer-mogul-turned-celebrity-television-host can effectively manipulate the political press to gain maximum exposure.

headline: How Would You Improve the Subway?
text: In my column in Tuesday’s paper, I wrote about how the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority is expected on Thursday to approve mass-transit fare increases. Piled on top of recent service cuts, these increases are certain to make New Yorkers unhappy, even angry.

headline: Franzen’s Glasses Pilfered by Ruffians (or Possibly Hooligans)
text: Goodness! In a grievous insult to trans-Atlantic fraternity, the American man of letters Jonathan Franzen was calamitously accosted at a party in London on Monday night, in an incident in which his spectacles were stolen straight off the end of his nose, The Bookseller.com reported. Mr. Franzen, the author of such novel-length entertainments as “The Corrections,” was being celebrated for the British publication of his latest fictional monograph, “Freedom,” at the Serpentine Gallery when, around 8 p.m., two interlopers entered the event. One of the malefactors plucked Mr. Franzen’s glasses from his face and absconded, while the second handed the author a note before he also fled. According to The Bookseller, the note read: “$100,000 – Your glasses are yours again!”

headline: Jon Stewart Reacts to Rick Sanchez’s Firing
text: Last Thursday, the CNN anchor Rick Sanchez called Jon Stewart a “bigot” and, shortly after Mr. Stewart’s Judaism was invoked, remarked that “everybody that runs CNN is a lot like Stewart.” On Friday, Mr. Sanchez was fired. And on Monday, Mr. Stewart took to his “Daily Show” to react, sister blog The Caucus notes.

headline: The Case Against Chinese Revaluation
text: 8:56 p.m. | Updated with additional Derek Scissors comment

headline: ‘Population Billionaires’ Face Tough Choices
text: Joseph Chamie, a longtime analyst of population and immigration trends, has a new piece on the Globalist Web site, “The Battle of the Billionaires: China Vs. India,” that provides a useful, and sobering, overview of choices facing the world’s population giants.

headline: N.F.L. Breakout Players and Key Statistics After 4 Weeks
text: Chase Stuart contributes to the Pro-Football-Reference.com blog and to Footballguys.com.

headline: So Where Does Dollar Thrifty Go From Here?
text: 12:24 p.m. | Updated  A rare turn of events took place last week. Shareholders of the Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group overwhelmingly voted against a takeover bid by Hertz Global Holdings, a day after the Avis Budget Group added a modest last-minute sweetener to its competing higher offer for the company. The vote sets up an interesting series of future events as Avis continues to put forth its bid and Hertz goes off to the corner for some time alone.

headline: Why Some Polling Places Were Tardy on Primary Day
text: New Yorkers who want to know why they had trouble voting at their local school on Primary Day may find the e-mail reproduced here educational.

headline: The Early Word: Community College Summit
text: President Obama is scheduled to appear Tuesday at a White House summit on community colleges, along with Jill Biden, the vice president’s wife. Also on the president’s schedule are an East Room reception for the foreign diplomatic corps and a speech at Fortune magazine’s conference on powerful women. Warren Buffett, Michelle Rhee (the  schools chancellor in Washington) and Elizabeth Warren (who is helping to get the new federal consumer protection bureau up and running) are also scheduled to speak at the event.

headline: Bolivian President’s Knee Meets Opponent’s Groin
text: During a soccer match between teams of political rivals in Bolivia, the country’s president, Evo Morales, was caught on tape delivering a swift knee to an opponent’s groin in retaliation for a hard foul.

headline: The Takeaway: Elections and Debates
text: Click to Listen

headline: Next Call of Duty Game Will Be in 3-D
text: Activision, the big video game publisher, announced on Tuesday that Call of Duty: Black Ops, the highly anticipated combat game scheduled to be released Nov. 9, will be available in 3-D.

headline: The President and the MTV Crowd
text: The youth-oriented cable channel MTV and five of its sister channels will simulcast a town-hall-style meeting with President Obama on Thursday, Oct. 14.

headline: Three Siblings, and a Family Filled With Odious Things
text: In “Ritter, Dene, Voss,” the Thomas Bernhard play making its New York debut at La MaMa, one character voices what sounds like a Bernhardian credo: “I hate the theater,” he says. “There is nothing I find more odious.”

headline: Subway Work Disrupts Businesses
text: What we’re reading this morning:

headline: It’s Not About Me, Pelosi Says
text: The speaker of the House, Nancy Pelosi of California, stuck to a script of motherly wisdom and feminine strength for the attendees at a conference of powerful women being held by Fortune magazine.

headline: Paladino Gets No Easy Pass on Fox
text: An appearance on “The O’Reilly Factor” might have seemed like a slam-dunk for a candidate like Carl P. Paladino, who has made attacking the Democratic establishment a centerpiece of his bid to be New York’s next governor.

headline: In Nick of Time, N.H.L. Reaches Deal With Officials
text: ¶ A potential labor stoppage is averted on the brink of opening night as the N.H.L. and the N.H.L. Officials’ Association reach a tentative deal on a new collective bargaining agreement Monday evening. The league’s 39 referees and 35 linesmen had been working exhibition games without a contract, which expired on Aug. 31. The tentative four-year agreement, which assures that league arbiters will work Thursday’s season openers, must still be approved by the officials’ union and the N.H.L. board of governors. Both sides declined comment until the contract is ratified.

headline: Grey Marriages
text: When a French citizen is “duped” into marriage by a foreigner looking to secure residency.(Mariages Gris)

headline: Watchdog Groups Ask I.R.S. to Investigate Crossroads GPS
text: Two campaign finance watchdog organizations released a letter to the Internal Revenue Service today, requesting that it investigate whether a nonprofit advocacy group tied to Karl Rove was violating federal tax laws with its involvement in this year’s midterm elections.

headline: White House Going Solar — Again
text: The White House, which only last month rebuffed a proposal by activists to reinstall one of former President Carter’s solar panels atop the executive mansion, plans to announce Tuesday that it will be adopting solar power after all.

headline: Kravis Gives $100 Million to Columbia B-School
text: 8:08 p.m. | Updated Henry R. Kravis, the billionaire private equity executive, has pledged $100 million to Columbia Business School, the largest gift in the school’s history and the biggest donation he has ever made.

headline: Casting Elegant Shadows in Chanel’s Garden
text: Anyone who has seen the Resnais film “Last Year at Marienbad” (1961) will recognize the source for Karl Lagerfeld’s black-and-white garden at the Chanel show today. Some 2,800 people saw the show, at the Grand Palais, a gorgeous display of pale colors and filmy black dresses against a white pebbled ground and black terraces. The garden extended in three directions, with a fountain in the center, and a full orchestra set up at the end of one allee.

headline: Tuesday Reading: The Wrong Way to Fight a Cold
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: How Will Your Team Do? Take the Quiz
text: If you’ve ever taken one of those multiple-choice quizzes in a magazine, you know three things are true: They’re simple, they’re fun, and their results are unfailingly 100 percent accurate.

headline: At Brooklyn High School Named for Murrow, the Television Studios Are Dark
text: Frankie Fidilio was collecting scrap metal for money in Brooklyn when the gleam of iron behind a school caught his eye. There were teetering stacks of old televisions, obsolete video transfer machines and clunky cassette recorders. Even a 250-pound stationary studio camera like something out of a museum.

headline: Life in Prison for Would-Be Times Square Bomber
text: Updated, 11:49 a.m. | Faisal Shahzad, who pleaded guilty to trying to blow up a sport utility vehicle carrying a homemade bomb in May in Times Square, thick with Saturday visitors, was sentenced on Tuesday morning to spend the rest of his life in prison. Remaining defiant, and smirking as the sentence was read, he told the court: “Brace yourselves, because the war with Muslims has just begun.”

headline: Kanye West Names His New Album
text: Kanye West has given fans some extended (and sometimes unsettling) glimpses inside his psyche lately, from his decadent Dalí-esque video for “Power” to the pristine troupe of ballet dancers that surrounded him during his recent performances on “Saturday Night Live.” So it’s only fitting that the title of his next album should reflect the summation of his alternately playful and twisted soul: the record will be titled “My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy,” Mr. West wrote Tuesday morning on his Twitter account, and will be released on Nov. 22. Mr. West said the first song on the album would be “Dark Fantasy,” a track produced by RZA along with No I.D. and Mr. West, and the next single to be released would be the song “All of the Lights.” Mr. West also shared a small image that appeared to be a frame from a video for his song “Runaway,” but without our gemological microscope it was hard to say for certain.

headline: For Paladino, a Cool Reception on Fox
text: An appearance on “The O’Reilly Factor” might have seemed like a slam-dunk for a candidate like Carl P. Paladino, who has made attacking the Democratic establishment a centerpiece of his bid to be New York’s next governor. But the Republican received a far cooler reception than expected on the Fox News program on Monday night. Read about the interview on City Room.

headline: Natural History Museum in Los Angeles Opens Up Car Collection
text: One of Los Angeles’s great tourist attractions, along with the marks of stars in the sidewalk of Hollywood Boulevard, is the display of bones of sloths and saber-tooth tigers taken from the La Brea Tar Pits and displayed at the Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County.

headline: In Governors’ Races, Some Hope for Democrats
text: Gov. Jack Markell of Delaware, chairman of the Democratic Governors Association, said Tuesday that a $1 million contribution from Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation to help elect Republican governors had turned into “a galvanizing moment” for Democrats.

headline: Gluten-Free Crumble Recipes
text: This week’s Recipes for Health column by Martha Rose Shulman has several gluten-free crumble recipes, including Berry-Rose Crumble, Plum and Fig Crumble With Quinoa-Oat Topping, Peach or Nectarine and Blueberry Crumble With Quinoa-Oat Topping, Pear Ginger Crumble and Apple Crumble. In lieu of flour she uses flour made from quinoa — easy to do in a spice grinder — and gluten-free oats.

headline: Nathan Lane May Play ‘The Nance’
text: What’s next for Nathan Lane, after his Broadway run in “The Addams Family” ends in the spring? Mr. Lane is considering Douglas Carter Beane’s new play, “The Nance,” about a performer who played the role of the nance in burlesque shows in the early-20th century.

headline: White House Ends ‘Deliberative Process’ On Solar
text: 12:08 p.m. | Updated It’s hard to believe that someone as forceful and politically savvy as President Obama would prompt tears from environment-minded college students one month by letting his administration rebuff their call for solar panels on the White House roof, then proceed with such a plan a few weeks later, but such are the mysteries of modern politics.

headline: An Update on Vanavevhu
text: Around the same time Nick first wrote about Abel and his orphaned family in Zimbabwe, “On the Ground” highlighted two organizations at work in the area: World Bicycle Relief (which ultimately started a bicycle distribution and training program in Abel’s community), and Vanavevhu, an organization that takes care of and trains child head of households to build self-sustaining businesses. Below is an update from John Rex-Waller, a board member of Vanavevhu:

headline: $100 Million for Columbia Business School From Kravis
text: Henry R. Kravis, dealmaker-king and Columbia Business School alumnus, has blessed his alma mater with a $100 million pledge, the biggest gift in the business school’s history. The money will go toward construction of several buildings at the business school’s planned satellite campus in Harlem, including, of course, the Henry R. Kravis Building. Read the whole article on Dealbook.

headline: After Afghanistan: Risk-Averse
text: WHITE SALMON, Washington — Upon returning from our tour in Afghanistan, the leadership of our brigade decided to provide its soldiers with a series of adventure team-building exercises. My platoon was assigned to a whitewater rafting trip.

headline: Jealously Looking at a List of College Courses
text: Blogger’s Note: For those who may only be discovering Mom U this fall, Ms. Gerszberg reintroduces the series at the end of this post. –Jacques Steinberg

headline: Notes From Paris
text: When the fashion horde hits Paris, the words “click to buy” become both fantastical and urgent. No longer do you want to sit back contemplating the winds of change or indexing the trends. After a month of observing spring 2011, you feel compelled to live it. What’s in the stores? So this season. You dream happily and hopelessly of shopping the runway.

headline: New Gehry Tower Prepares for Renters
text: FOR years, New York developers have been trying to maximize the value of residential properties by hiring celebrity architects. At Philip Johnson’s Urban Glass House, Richard Meier’s Perry Street apartments and Jean Nouvel’s 100 11th Avenue, the architects were chosen in part to raise condominium prices.

headline: The Defense Spending Debate
text: In a pre-emptive shot across certain Tea Partier bows, Arthur Brooks, Ed Feulner and Bill Kristol make the case that any program of fiscal austerity should ring-fence (that’s British budget-ese for “don’t even think about cutting”) defense spending — because our military is already overstretched, our defense outlays are dwarfed by entitlement spending, and anyway, “it is unrealistic to imagine a return to long-term prosperity if we face instability around the globe because of a hollowed-out U.S. military lacking the size and strength to defend American interests around the world.”

headline: Omar Minaya: Misunderstood Goat?
text: So the Omar Minaya era comes to an end. That so much money was spent to such undistinguished ends suggests much culpability, from the Wilpons to Minaya. But Minaya’s tenure as general manager of the Mets was not nearly the disaster portrayed by bloodhounds of press and fandom.

headline: Fleeing Lead Paint
text: The kit that tests for lead can be found in almost any hardware store. In a guest post, the San Francisco writer Amy Ettinger explains why she and her husband, Dan White, wish they had bought one when they first moved in.

headline: Caustic Sludge Floods Several Hungarian Towns
text: PRAGUE  The Hungarian government declared a state of emergency in several towns on Tuesday, a day after a reservoir at an alumina refining plant in Ajka burst its banks, unleashing a flood of caustic red sludge that killed at least four people and injured more than 120, government officials said.

headline: Investors to Protest A.C.S.-Hochtief Deal
text: Two minority shareholder associations said Tuesday in Madrid that they would challenge the $3.5 billion takeover offer that the Spanish builder Actividades de Construcción y Servicios is set to make for its German counterpart, Hochtief.

headline: France Arrests 12 in Antiterrorism Raids
text: PARIS  The French police arrested 12 people in two separate raids in southern France on Tuesday in what the Interior Ministry said was part of a campaign against terrorism.

headline: What We’re Reading: Ig Nobel Prizes
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Yves Saint Laurent
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Kava Gorna.

headline: Patrick Kennedy Memoir to Tell of Addiction
text: Patrick J. Kennedy, a member of Congress and son of Senator Edward M. Kennedy, will detail his struggles with alcoholism, drug addiction and depression in a memoir to be released in the fall of 2011, the publisher said on Tuesday. Mr. Kennedy, 43, is writing the book with Mary Ann Akers, a former gossip columnist for The Washington Post and Roll Call.

headline: Rove’s Groups Spend Millions on Senate Ads
text: Karl Rove is making another big investment in the 2010 midterm elections.

headline: On Our Radar: Floodwaters Persist in Pakistan
text: In low-lying Sehwan, Pakistan, home of the country’s largest Sufi shrine, floodwaters from this summer’s devastating storms are draining slowly, or not at all. Malnutrition and illness are rife, and on the city’s outskirts, roving bandits loot abandoned villages, which remain completely surrounded by water. “Two months on, and the water is still surging,” a correspondent reports. [The Guardian]

headline: Muscles, Accusations and No French in Albany
text: If Carl P. Paladino had a tough time with Bill O’Reilly on Fox News, he didn’t do much better on the radio.

headline: Solar Will Return to White House Roof
text: After appearing to pooh-pooh White House solar panels a few weeks ago, the Obama administration intends to make use of all that sunlight after all, my colleague John Broder reports.

headline: Latino Vote Turnout Likely to Lag, Poll Says
text: PHOENIX  Arizona’s immigration law has prompted denunciations, demonstrations, boycotts and a federal lawsuit. But it may not bring the protest vote that many Democrats had hoped would stem a Republican onslaught in races across the country.

headline: Iran Denies Malware Connection to Nuclear Delay
text: TEHRAN  Iranian officials say a “small leak” was the cause of the latest setback to starting up its first nuclear power plant, and that the delay has nothing to do with a malicious computer worm that has infected industrial plants across the country.

headline: Burnett Missing From Playoff Rotation, So Far
text: 1:23 p.m. | Updated with release of playoff roster

headline: LudoBites Goes to the Valley
text: LudoBites, the Los Angeles pop-up restaurant, is totally going to the San Fernando Valley.

headline: U.S. Military Pushing Green Energy
text: As our colleague Elisabeth Rosenthal writes in the Green blog, the United States military is aggressively moving to decrease its reliance on fossil fuels by deploying renewable energy technology in battle.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Chloe
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: A Firebird No Longer in Toe Shoes
text: Stephanie Dabney has lived in Apt. 31C, high above 57th Street just off 10th Avenue, for more than a decade. It’s a one-bedroom with parquet floors, a small love seat tucked away at the far end of the living room, two small tables and three chairs.

headline: A Red Sludge Tsunami
text: As our colleagues pursue the red sludge avalanche in Hungary, we’re reading up on the bauxite-refining process that produces the mud. Here’s more from an engineering company.

headline: Lakers Aren’t Exactly Refreshed After Off-Season
text: The Los Angeles Lakers did not sprint to their repeat title last season as much as exhaust themselves at the finish line.

headline: Battle for Control of Pistons Nears an End
text: Hard-luck Detroit may appear to be an unlikely place for a bidding war. Yet a surprisingly lively battle is under way for control of the Pistons, a storied N.B.A. franchise also mired in tough times.

headline: Rays Run and Walk but Don’t Always Hit
text: Don Larsen’s perfect game in the 1956 World Series remains the only no-hitter in postseason history. If there will ever be another, it could come now against the Tampa Bay Rays.

headline: Convictions on 16 Counts in Triple-Murder Case
text: NEW HAVEN  A former parolee with a long history as a petty criminal was convicted of capital crimes on Tuesday for his part in a nighttime home invasion in Cheshire, Conn., three years ago that left a woman and her two daughters dead. The jury deliberated less than one full day.

headline: Pasta and Clams
text: As long as we’re discussing pasta and tomatoes this week, I thought I’d share these rather stunning pictures of one of my favorites: pasta with clam sauce, Manhattan style — which means, with tomatoes. In this case, fresh tomatoes.

headline: The IMF on Fiscal Austerity
text: Chapter 3 of the IMF’s new World Economic Outlook is online; it examines the economics of fiscal austerity. It won’t make the austerians happy.

headline: Giants-Braves Series to Show Off Pitching Staffs
text: Not too long ago, the Atlanta Braves and the San Francisco Giants were regulars on the October stage. The teams made 20 combined playoff appearances from 1987 to 2005, winning seven pennants.

headline: As 103-Year-Old Dies, Her Reading Circle Mourns
text: When Elizabeth Goodyear died late last month, at 103, a handful of friends, all more than two generations younger, sat vigil. They toasted her over dark chocolate, the elixir Ms. Goodyear had savored daily since she was 3 years old, and Champagne, a more recent favorite.

headline: TimesCast | October 5, 2010
text: A look at the growing pains of green energy technology and a report from Islamabad on a series of attacks on NATO fuel supply trucks in Pakistan.

headline: Germany Halts Demolition of Train Station
text: BERLIN  Hoping to cool down what has become a growing political problem and national embarrassment for Germany’s top leadership, officials said on Tuesday they would not cut down any more trees or demolish the remaining wing of a century-old train station, at least for now.

headline: Gardenhire and Twins Search for Solution to Yankees Puzzle
text: Ron Gardenhire played five seasons in the majors, all with the Mets from 1981 through 1985. Late in the 1986 season, he was told he would soon be called up as an extra infielder, to be eligible for the playoffs.

headline: Scorecard | Céline Wins!
text: How to succeed in Scorecard without really trying? Even if your chicly understated minimalism previously carried the day in your New York debut last season, we’d still advise against pulling a Zac Posen and taking your show on the road to Paris. Or if sample delay necessitates that you simply must present there, and on the fifth day opposite Céline, understand that you may generate less that overweening enthusiasm amongst the Philophiles.

headline: A Chef as Poet, Rock Star and Chemistry Professor
text: For a book that celebrates a break with traditional cooking, Colman Andrews’s new biography of the avant-garde Spanish chef Ferran Adrià lays on the cream sauce with a heavy hand.

headline: Despite a 15-year absence from the postseason, the Reds have World Series experience.
text: Dusty Baker was thinking big when he gathered his Cincinnati Reds for spring training in Goodyear, Ariz., in February. Never mind that the Reds had gone a decade since their last winning season. If a player, executive or staffer had a World Series ring, Baker told them, bring it to camp to display for the rest of the team.

headline: Breaking Down the Division Series
text: The American and National leagues divisional series will begin Wednesday at 1:37 p.m. ET when the Tampa Bay Rays host the Texas Rangers. Tyler Kepner writes that if a pitcher is ever going to repeat Don Larsen’s feat of pitching a perfect game in the postseason, it just might be against the Rays. “They led the American League in victories, with 96, yet they are prone to severe short-term offensive outages,” Kepner writes. For Kepner’s analysis of all four divisional series, click on the matchups below. Share your analysis of the baseball playoffs  here.

headline: The Chapter 11 Challenge to Delaware
text: Stephen J. Lubben writes about bankruptcy and debt issues for DealBook.

headline: Sludge Flood Kills Four in Hungary
text: Hungarian officials are calling the rupture of a red sludge reservoir an ecological disaster.

headline: What the Justice Department’s Credit Card Suit Means for You
text: If you’re a little confused about how or if your life will change thanks to the Justice Department’s payment card announcement on Monday, you’re not alone. So let’s review what we know and engage in some mild speculation.

headline: Off the Menu: A New Chef at Boqueria
text: Marc Vidal, a native of Barcelona who grew up in a restaurant family, is the new executive chef at Yann de Rochefort’s Boqueria restaurants in Chelsea and SoHo. It took Mr. de Rochefort months to find a replacement for the former chef, Seamus Mullen, who left for health reasons and to work on a book.

headline: Yankees Announce Playoff Roster
text: The Yankees announced their playoff roster for their American League division series with the Minnesota Twins on Tuesday. Game 1, at Target Field, is scheduled for Wednesday at 8:37 p.m., Eastern time.

headline: Angiomax May Get Patent Extension
text: It took more than nine years of lobbying and litigating, but a New Jersey drug maker seems to have finally reversed a billion-dollar blunder.

headline: A Soaked Roy Halladay Soaks It All In
text: PHILADELPHIA – The driving rain and mist have obscured the Center City skyline in the distance beyond the outfield at Citizens Bank Park. The red championship flags for 1980 and 2008 — plus five blue ones for N.L. titles – point stiffly to right field. The tarp covers the field for the scheduled workouts for the Philadelphia Phillies and the Cincinnati Reds.

headline: At Private Schools, a Hunt for New Leaders
text: Good news in a city where the joblessness rate hovers around 9 percent: There are job openings and new hires starting seemingly everywhere, that is, in the rarified employment sector of Manhattan private school administration.

headline: New Federal Auto Safety Rating System Takes Effect
text: On Tuesday morning, the federal government revealed details of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration’s new 5-Star Safety Rating System and released new ratings for some of the most popular 2011 model-year vehicles. Of the 33 vehicles tested, only two received an overall rating of five stars, which is the best: the BMW 5 Series (4-door and rear-wheel-drive models) and the Hyundai Sonata built after July 2, 2010.

headline: ‘Sister Act’ Gets a Broadway Home
text: Deloris Van Cartier, the aspiring disco star turned murder witness turned woman of the cloth, now has a New York home to hide out in: the musical adaptation of “Sister Act,” the 1992 Whoopi Goldberg comedy, will come to the Broadway Theater this spring, press representatives for the show said on Tuesday. The musical, which has a score by Alan Menken, lyrics by Glenn Slater and a book by Cheri and Bill Steinkellner, will be directed by Jerry Zaks, a consultant on the Broadway incarnation of “The Addams Family.” It is to begin previews on March 24 with an opening night set for April 20. No casting was immediately announced for the show’s Broadway run; a West End version of “Sister Act” starring Patina Miller as Deloris opened at the London Palladium in June 2009.

headline: Model-Morphosis | Giambattista Valli
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of Paris Fashion Week. Here, the model Melissa Tammerijn from New York Model Management before (left) and after (right) makeup by Val Garland and hair by Orlando Pita. (Drag the orange bar left to reveal the full transformation.)

headline: Israeli Army Investigates Video of Soldier and Prisoner
text: JERUSALEM  The Israeli Army opened a criminal investigation on Tuesday into an Internet video showing one of its male soldiers dancing suggestively next to a blindfolded, handcuffed Palestinian woman being held prisoner.

headline: Urban Mining
text: Recycling consumer e-waste to collect precious elements.

headline: New Books on Wine
text: I ordinarily write about the fall season’s new wine books closer to the holidays, but this year the books are so good, and have accumulated so quickly, that I hit the subject a little early.

headline: Smart Water Meters Catch On in Iowa
text: While some California cities move to ban smart electricity meters over fears about their impact on human health, residents of Dubuque, Iowa, are embracing smart water meters.

headline: John Jay College, 10:38 A.M.
text: Former Mayor Edward I. Koch, now a self-proclaimed crusader for change in Albany, took to the lectern at John Jay College of Criminal Justice on Tuesday morning to endorse Andrew M. Cuomo for governor.

headline: Longtime Washington Post Writer Heads to The Daily Beast
text: Howard Kurtz, a three-decade veteran of The Washington Post who came to embody insider Washington media reporting with his weekly column and CNN television show, is leaving The Post for Tina Brown‘s news and commentary Web site, The Daily Beast.

headline: Sun Co-Founder Uses Capitalism to Help Poor
text: MUMBAI, India  Vinod Khosla, the billionaire venture capitalist and co-founder of Sun Microsystems, was already among the world’s richest men when he invested a few years ago in SKS Microfinance, a lender to poor women in India.

headline: Now Screening | Yves Saint Laurent
text: The Spring/Summer 2011 collection from Yves Saint Laurent at Paris Fashion Week.

headline: Now Screening | Yves Saint Laurent
text: The Spring/Summer 2011 collection from Yves Saint Laurent at Paris Fashion Week.

headline: Trumka Likes Obama’s Jobs Message
text: President Obama took until mid-August to settle on a pro-jobs message that is working effectively to help Democratic candidates push back against Republican challenges in the mid-term elections, according to Richard Trumka, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.

headline: An Endless Cycle of Failed Diets
text: “Hmmm,” my doctor said.

headline: Patrick Kennedy Memoir to Tell of Addiction and Depression
text: Representative Patrick J. Kennedy, son of the late Senator Edward M. Kennedy, will detail his struggles with alcoholism, drug addiction and depression in a memoir to be released in the fall of 2011, the publisher said on Tuesday. Read more about the memoir, including its release date, on ArtsBeat.

headline: Quote Unquote | Switch and Bait
text: –Chloe Sevigny reveals her style tricks to The Guardian. So that’s why she wears those orthopedic socks.

headline: Anti-Islam Film Shown at Hate Speech Trial of Dutch Politician
text: Updated | Wednesday | 7:51 a.m. A court in Amsterdam watched a short film that attacks the Koran on Wednesday, as the trial of Geert Wilders, a powerful anti-immigrant politician charged with inciting hatred of Muslims, resumed.

headline: Justin Morneau Won’t Return This Season
text: MINNEAPOLIS — The Minnesota Twins never expected first baseman Justin Morneau to play in the American League division series. But last Thursday, after taking batting practice on the field, Morneau, who has not played since sustaining a concussion on July 7, said that he hoped to be back for the A.L. Championship Series if the Twins advanced.

headline: The iPhone Has a Real Fight on Its Hands
text: Back in March, I wrote about the increasingly personal fight between Steven P. Jobs, the Apple chief executive, and Eric E. Schmidt, his Google counterpart. In it, I quoted Mr. Jobs saying: “Make no mistake: Google wants to kill the iPhone. We won’t let them.”

headline: New ‘Punk’d’ Is Planned, or Is That a Prank?
text: Ashton Kutcher is planning to revive the hidden-camera reality show “Punk’d” for MTV, potentially with the singer Justin Bieber as the host behind the pranks, New York magazine and Deadline.com reported on Tuesday, citing anonymous sources. The premiere date is unknown.

headline: Andy Harman’s Big Leather Cheeseburger
text: Andy Harman’s first installations were fun houses that he set up in the basement his childhood home — he would pull the neighborhood kids through the creepy space on a sled. Fast forward a decade plus, and Harman, who got his M.F.A. in sculpture at Yale, is an established production and set designer working with renowned photographers like Terry Richardson, Roe Etheridge and Ellen von Unwerth. Recently, his career working with props and sets led him to reinvestigate sculpture via furniture design, resulting in a new kind of fun house.

headline: Abandoning a Bid to Create an Urban Village
text: For three years, a group of New Yorkers had hoped to create a new type of housing that would turn apartment living into a more communal experience. But after failing to convert three Brooklyn sites into the community of their dreams, the group recently disbanded, admitting to being defeated by the city’s uncertain and difficult real estate market.

headline: ‘A Troubling Trend': Discussing Bullying and Antigay Attitudes
text: Overview | What is the societal climate for antigay bullying in schools and a recent rash of related student suicides? What, if anything, can be done to make schools safer and more inclusive? In this lesson, students examine and discuss responses to the recent suicides that have occurred amid antigay bullying and complete an optional campaign to foster safety and acceptance at their own school.

headline: The Fight Over Wind Power in Vinalhaven
text: A small group of island residents are fighting three wind turbines built on the island of Vinalhaven off the coast of Maine.

headline: The Morning Skate: Puck Pundits Make Predictions
text: It’s preview time in the N.H.L. when many of those who watch the league for a living dispense their wisdom before the first puck is dropped. Not everyone has released their thoughts on the coming season; TSN for example, won’t telecast its preview show until Wednesday.

headline: New York Public Library Will Name Anthony W. Marx as New President
text: At a time when the digital revolution has thrown the mission of libraries into question, the New York Public Library is planning to name Anthony W. Marx, the current president of Amherst College, a native New Yorker and a passionate advocate of public education, as its new president. He replaces Paul LeClerc, who announced his plan to step down in November 2009.

headline: For Those Near, the Miserable Hum of Clean Energy
text: VINALHAVEN, Me. — Like nearly all of the residents on this island in Penobscot Bay, Art Lindgren and his wife, Cheryl, celebrated the arrival of three giant wind turbines late last year. That was before they were turned on.

headline: Gordon Ramsay Apologizes With Salted-Caramel Truffles
text: We’ve all stayed in hotels where service can sometimes go awry, but any hotel worth its salt usually sends up a gesture of remorse. This usually takes the form of flowers or wine, possibly loyalty-program points. But if you’re fortunate enough to have them mess up at the London NYC, the apology will be the most delicious salted-caramel truffles you will ever have in your life.

headline: Part of the Pit Crew
text: The Frugal Traveler tests his skills at the Nascar Hall of Fame in Charlotte, N.C.

headline: Newly Re-elected Chess Federation President Takes Your Questions
text: Kirsan Ilyumzhinov, the president of the World Chess Federation, who was re-elected last week after a contentious campaign, will answer readers’ questions.

headline: Seamen’s Institute to Sell Its Building and Leave Manhattan
text: In the early years of the Seamen’s Church Institute, sailors arriving from the Atlantic would congregate for prayer in floating chapel barges anchored in Lower Manhattan. The institute replaced the chapels with a pair of hotels on South and State Streets, where in 1913 seamen paid 25 cents for a room.

headline: Beyond the Landmarks: Finding Culture in Europe
text: TRAVELING to Europe has been a bit daunting this year. First there was the cloud of volcanic ash that stranded millions. Then came shockingly high airfares. And now the State Department has issued a stomach-churningly vague travel alert that advises Americans going to Europe to “take every precaution to be aware of their surroundings.”

headline: Readers’ Recipes: The Potluck
text: A selection of dishes to share.

headline: Snacklash: Junking a Virtuous Bag
text: In early 2009 Frito-Lay introduced its first-ever biodegradable snack chip bag for its SunChips brand. In a compost pile, the company proclaimed, the plant-based bag would decompose in just 14 weeks.

headline: Putting Diapers on a Toilet-Trained Child
text: A reader, who we will call Daughter-in-Law, has a problem. She and her husband work full time, and their 3.5-year-old son is cared for by his grandmothers. DIL’s mother cares for the boy three to four days a week, and her mother-in-law cares for him the other day or two. Her mother-in-law is highly educated but she speaks very little English, and her son serves as translator between DIL and his mother.

headline: Google Goggles Now Available for the iPhone
text: Google announced today that its visual-search tool, Google Goggles, was coming to the iPhone, to be in place today.

headline: Dismal Scientists
text: Ezra Klein has a good summary of what went down at the Newseum this morning.

text: Sunday, Sept. 26

text: A view of the day in sports, with some N.H.L. and N.B.A. teams playing preseason games overseas.

text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Alexandra Catiere.

headline: Marc Forgione
text: IN the imaginary New York of first novels and romantic comedies, there is often a restaurant like Marc Forgione, a brick-walled neighborhood spot glittering with candlelight and the promise of a third date going well.

headline: Taliban Leader Captured; Tied to Reporter’s Abduction
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  A Taliban leader in northern Afghanistan believed to have been involved in the kidnapping of a New York Times reporter as well as the intimidation of the local population was captured on Tuesday in Takhar Province.

headline: Blackstone’s Rise: Discipline With a Splash
text: You’ve likely seen the news that Henry Kravis has donated $100 million to Columbia Business School. That matches the amount that Mr. Kravis’s rival buyout baron, Stephen Schwarzman, gave to the New York Public Library a few years back. If these eye-popping donations have you asking yourself, “Just how in the world do these guys make so much money?,” DealBook has a book for you.

headline: Netanyahu Examines Offer on Settlement Freeze
text: JERUSALEM — As the Palestinians consider withdrawing from peace talks with Israel unless a freeze on Jewish settlement building in the West Bank is extended, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is engaged in his own calculations about whether accepting an American offer aimed at prolonging the freeze would destroy his political coalition.

headline: Post Says Farewell to Kurtz
text: The editors of The Washington Post sent out the following note to the staff, wishing the veteran reporter and columnist Howard Kurtz farewell:

headline: Top 5 Green Cars at the Paris Auto Show
text: More than 100 electric vehicles, hybrid electrics and vehicles sporting future-forward, environmentally friendly technologies are on display at this month’s sprawling Paris auto show. It is a veritable feast for the green car enthusiast.

headline: N.F.L. to Feingold: Ad is No Good
text: Turns out the flag was on Senator Russ Feingold’s campaign.

headline: Longoria and Hamilton Say They Are Healthy Enough
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. – Tampa Bay third baseman Evan Longoria is not just a piece of the team’s puzzle. He is a piece of Jenga.

headline: The Caucus Click: Denver
text: An image from inside of the the campaign headquarters of the Democratic incumbent senator, Michael Bennet, shows the final countdown before the midterm elections.

headline: Broadway Raises Money for Senator Gillibrand
text: It may not be “Hairspray” producer Margo Lion dialing for dollars on behalf of Barack Obama, as she did with zeal during the presidential election in 2008, but a roster of Broadway elites is showing partisan colors by supporting a “Broadway for Kirsten” re-election fund-raiser for New York’s junior Democratic senator, Kirsten Gillibrand, on Monday at the home of Scott Sanders, the lead producer of “The Color Purple,” and Brad Lamm.

headline: How Financial Innovation Helps the Poor
text: We have written before about the debate on whether financial innovation benefits or exploits the poor. (Even Russell Simmons weighed in.) Those who believe financial innovation necessarily hurts poor people may want to take a look at this perspective from Brazil, courtesy of NPR’s “Planet Money”:

headline: The Community Oven
text: A 30-plus-hour cooking party in the backyard of a Napa home.

headline: A Little More ‘Night Music’
text: Send in the cash. Bernadette Peters and Elaine Stritch, giving acclaimed performances in the Broadway musical “A Little Night Music” since replacing Catherine Zeta-Jones and Angela Lansbury in July, have agreed to remain with the show through the holiday season, the producers announced on Tuesday.

headline: Back to an Ensemble After Solo Work, Offering a Mind-Meld With Partners
text: The saxophonist David S. Ware is a force-of-nature improviser, the sort of musician whose output invites overblown comparisons to gales and eruptions, or deep-focus seismic events. Vulnerability is an afterthought to any receptive experience of his music.

headline: Dusting Off the Real Dragonetti Concerto
text: The works of the Venetian composer Domenico Dragonetti have largely fallen into obscurity. He is primarily (and erroneously) known for the “Dragonetti Concerto,” now thought to have been written by Edouard Nanny, and (rightly) for the Dragonetti bow. But during his lifetime (1763-1846), Dragonetti achieved considerable renown for his virtuoso skills as a double bass player, his compositions and his eccentricities, said to include carrying around a life-size doll.

headline: Despite Peace, Some in Ulster Want War
text: In a phone call to The Derry Journal, a newspaper in Northern Ireland, dissident paramilitaries from a group that calls itself the Real I.R.A. claimed responsibility on Tuesday for a car bomb that damaged an Ulster Bank branch in the early hours of the morning.

headline: Lackluster Ratings for CNN’s ‘Parker Spitzer’
text: The new CNN entry “Parker Spitzer” may not be the answer to that network’s chronic ratings problems in prime time – at least from the evidence of its first night on the air.

headline: Readers Tell of More Second Avenue Subway Woes
text: Celentha Finfer, a 75-year-old retired reading teacher, described how she fell trying to cross the street near the Second Avenue subway construction site after her foot became stuck in the large cracks between blocks that are used as a roadway covering.

text: It was a government bailout that only the Treasury could love.

headline: Slow-Cooked Goat Shoulder Moorish Style
text: This recipe adapts beautifully to lamb shoulder.

text: In the noirish world of the animator Bill Plympton’s “Idiots and Angels,” cars are miniature tanks with tiny windows and enormous haunches from which plumes of exhaust snake like tornado funnels.

headline: Harissa
text: 2 ounces dried red chili, such as Nora or Ancho, stemmed and seeded

headline: In Holocaust, Medicine’s Twisted Rationales
text: Robert Jay Lifton, the venerable psychiatrist and author, deserves a better documentary than “Robert Jay Lifton: Nazi Doctors,” a lazy piece of filmmaking that consists of little more than letting him talk for almost an hour and a half about one of his better-known books.

headline: Gehry Building Prepares for Potential Tenants
text: The wiggly-looking Frank Gehry apartment tower on Spruce Street near the Brooklyn Bridge — the tallest residential building in the city at 867 feet — is getting ready for renters. With more than 600 different apartment layouts, potential tenants may want to see dozens of units before selecting one to live in, which could be fun for the rental agents for the owner Forest City Ratner who plan to begin showing the building early next year. Read more in Real Estate.

headline: Cuba Journal: Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra in Havana
text: Over the next few days, Victoria Burnett will be reporting for ArtsBeat on Jazz at Lincoln Center’s visit to Cuba.

headline: Guilty Plea in Super Bowl Ticket Reselling
text: Sports Business Journal reported Tuesday that a marketing agent who has longstanding ties to the N.F.L. pleaded guilty in June to federal charges in a case involving allegations that he conspired with others to resell Super Bowl tickets that he bought from people who had obtained them at face value.

headline: Goat Sugo

headline: The Write Stuff | Sustainable Stationery
text: In the age of “The Social Network” and Evites, it’s nice to see that a new crop of eco-conscious letterpress houses are bringing a fresh approach to an antique practice. “For me, Facebook and e-mail are great ways to keep in touch, but there is something really special about getting a card or letter in the mail,” says Lehua Chong, whose New York City-based company Hour of Nine creates organic cards with funky motifs inspired by the streets of Manhattan. Made from ever-abundant bamboo, the cards are free of chlorine and pesticides, and using them just might mean that your friends won’t be able to R.S.V.P. to your next party via a status update.

headline: Builders Move Beyond McMansions in New Jersey
text: Faced with the prospect that New Jersey’s buildable open space could be gone by midcentury, developers are turning to projects that tap into existing infrastructure, use vacant buildings and emphasize the vertical over the horizontal.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Hungary, Pakistan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Afghanistan, Russia and Kazakhstan.

headline: Top 5 Freshest Designs From the Paris Auto Show
text: This year’s Paris auto show, which is open to the public until Oct. 17, showcases the design freedom that comes from working with micro-turbines, electric motors and ultra-lightweight materials.

headline: Why One Businessman Pledges Allegiance to the G.O.P.
text: Craig Fritsche’s building supply company has not made any money in the last two years, and it may not make any money this year. But that has not tempered his outrage at the prospect of seeing tax breaks for the wealthy expire. In fact, Mr. Fritsche is so furious that he has gone on television to denounce the Obama administration’s plan to extend the Bush tax cuts for all but top brackets, and he offered his premises as host to the Republican legislators who unveiled their Pledge to America a week ago Thursday.

headline: King-Size Markdown, Where Queen No Longer Stands Guard
text: THE 40-acre estate of the fabled hotel queen Leona Helmsley, in Greenwich, Conn., has a colorful history and was hard to sell, lingering on the market for 829 days, with giant price reductions along the way. But it finally sold last week, for $35 million, $20 million less than the last asking price, according to property records.

headline: An App Aspires to Be the Finder of Lost Pets
text: HomeAgain, a company makes microchip ID devices for pets and supports a pet rescue network, has released a free iPhone app to help volunteers reunite lost pets with their owners.

text: 12 ounces lean goat tenderloin (lamb or beef can be substituted)

text: Carl Richards, a certified financial planner, regularly publishes new sketches at BehaviorGap.com that try to simplify complex money decisions.

text: 10 ounces amaranth greens (or spinach); washed and coarse stems discarded

headline: Bolivian President’s Knee Meets Opponent’s Groin
text: During a soccer match between teams of political rivals in Bolivia, the country’s president, Evo Morales, was caught on tape delivering a swift knee to an opponent’s groin in retaliation for a hard foul.

headline: Dukkah
text: 2 tablespoons pistachios, toasted

headline: Catching Choreographers in the Act: Two Creations for a Percussive Beat
text: The stage was smaller, the program more compact and the imported stars of a lower stature. But, judging by Sunday afternoon’s show at the Guggenheim Museum’s Works & Process series, the Morphoses formula has remained intact since the departure last winter of its founder, Christopher Wheeldon: bring in guest dancers and choreographers, find a high-profile collaborator and throw in fancy recorded footage of the rehearsal process, all to showcase (and maybe demystify) contemporary ballet.

headline: Green-Tomato Chutney
text: 1 pound green tomatoes, chopped

headline: Saving Old Scores From Pop’s Dustbin
text: “Michael Feinstein’s American Songbook” isn’t a typical rerun of the same old clips looking back on the music of the prerock era with a misty-eyed nostalgia. This three-part PBS series, beginning on Wednesday and produced and directed by Amber Edwards, is a quirky, thoughtful mélange of history and biography that celebrates Mr. Feinstein’s passion for collecting what many would consider cultural detritus.

headline: New in EA’s FIFA 11 Game: Career Mode, ‘Dad Pad’ and More
text: Confession: I have never played the EA Sports’ FIFA series of video games. I hear my son Jesse is pretty good, but that is what he says. Now, there may be hope for us “mature” players in the new FIFA 11 game from EA Sports that was released on Sept. 28 in the United States, and is now available in 18 languages and 51 countries.

headline: A Town House in Antwerp
text: An 1895 four-story house in a suburb of Antwerp, Belgium, is on the market for 649,000 euros.

headline: House Hunting in ... Belgium
text: A FOUR-BEDROOM HISTORIC HOUSE IN ANTWERP

headline: Bruno Mars in Ascension
text: When history books address the pop seismology of the early 21st century, a chapter will have to be set aside for a discussion of the Sheraton Waikiki in the late 1980s. That’s where Bruno Mars, then just a few years old, performed as part of a tourist-trap family band, singing doo-wop, Elvis and more. He even made a cameo as a baby Elvis in the 1992 film “Honeymoon in Vegas,” appearing as a bouffant-haired tyke in a blue jumpsuit, with a fierce hip shake.

headline: Home From Afghanistan, Now Fighting to Join the N.Y.P.D.
text: Two combat tours in Afghanistan placed Army Sgt. Osvaldo Hernandez under frequent attack by the Taliban and tested his judgment and courage daily. His next challenge awaits him at home, as Sergeant Hernandez, a 28-year-old Queens native, renews his battle to join the New York Police Department, which has barred him because of a felony conviction.

headline: Clothes Fit for Woman or Beast
text: AS part of a recent arts festival, a little bicycle no taller than my knee has been chain-locked to a park gate near my house for the last week. An uncredited artist has crocheted over every contour — pedals, wheels, frame, handlebars — encasing the tiny bike entirely in a custom-potholder shroud of mismatched acrylic yarns.

headline: Helmsley Estate Sells for $35 Million
text: As reported in the Big Deal column of the Real Estate section on Tuesday, the 40-acre Greenwich, Conn., estate of the late hotel magnate Leona Helmsley has sold for $35 million. The 21,987-square foot mansion, owned by Ms. Helmsley and her husband, Harry, was at the center of a high-profile tax evasion case against the couple in the late 1980s. Read the full article.

headline: MCC Theater Plots Revenge for ‘Carrie’
text: Hide the pigs, cancel the prom and dust off your anecdotes about one of Broadway’s most notorious flops. The musical “Carrie” is looking for sweet revenge on the New York stage.

headline: A Shifting Oscar Race Heats Up
text: LOS ANGELES  Now it begins.

headline: The Stage Is Big, and Lagerfeld Fills It
text: Paris

headline: Retailers Go With Discounts for Halloween
text: FOR Halloween, what are consumers telling Madison Avenue they consider creepy and kooky, mysterious and spooky, and altogether ooky? High prices.

headline: Chairity | The Pink Wishbone Project
text: Breast cancer research is an undeniably worthy endeavor, but the container-loads of pink objects that have been sold to help pay for it aren’t always what you’d call high design. Which is why the arrival of the Pink Wishbone Project is welcome news. Thanks to Suite New York, a Manhattan furniture showroom, Hans Wegner’s famous Wishbone Chair, made in Denmark by Carl Hansen & Son, will be available in pink for the next year, with 20 percent of its sales going to the Breast Cancer Research Foundation. And to draw attention to the program, Barneys New York will exhibit chairs that were customized by 20 leading women designers. (A kickoff cocktail party takes place on Thursday evening at Barneys.)

headline: Ambassadors Left Out in the Cold, Literally
text: Note to the White House: If you’re going to wine and dine diplomats from other countries, you have to actually let them in.

headline: Urban Beat for Poetry Festival
text: Count Philip Roth, Allen Ginsberg and Amiri Baraka among the native sons of Newark, a place more often associated with urban woes than with distinguished wordsmiths. But from Thursday through Sunday, the backdrop for the Geraldine R. Dodge Poetry Festival will be the downtown Newark arts district, the first urban setting for this celebration, the largest poetry event in North America. That choice for the 13th festival underlines the hope  helped also by the recent $100 million pledged to Newark schools by the Facebook co-founder Mark Zuckerberg  that the city is on the upswing. It also bows to the idea that poetry can flow from the rhythms of the streets as well as from more sedate settings.

headline: A Family’s Influence
text: Dozens of President Hamid Karzai’s relatives and friends, many of whom used to live in the United States, have returned home to take on powerful positions in government and business, allowing the family to shape policy and benefit financially. Only a few family members remain in the United States.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening

headline: Once Skeptical, New York Chefs Embrace Michelin
text: IN 2005, when Michelin announced that it would begin publishing guides to New York restaurants, the city looked askance at this foreign interloper. The company’s stars were coveted in Europe, but New Yorkers already lived by their own red guide, Zagat, based on user surveys. Online reviewers were proliferating. Who needed another opinion?

headline: Spaghetti Tacos: Silly Enough for Young Eaters
text: IT started as a gag: spaghetti tacos.

headline: Bab al Yemen
text: IT is a rare dish that transports you to not only another place, but also another time. Such is Bab al Yemen’s aseed ($13), which dates to the 10th century.

headline: An Exhibition of Tableware as Art
text: Do you have dinnerware designed by Roy Lichtenstein (above), Keith Haring and James Rosenquist, and glassware by Sol LeWitt in your cupboard? The Museum of Arts and Design does. And it’s in an exhibition called “Eat Drink Art Design.” In addition to the big-name pieces, there is simple, beautifully crafted rustic Japanese stoneware alongside equally elegant disposable white Japanese dishes made of bamboo and sugar cane pulp. Scores of plates designed by Peter Ting and made by Royal Crown Derby in England make up a display called Constellation Manhattan. A surreal silver Melting Teapot by Myra Mimlitsch-Gray is one of the rare, highly impractical pieces on view.

headline: One Culture’s Ratatouille Is Another’s Fill-in-the-Blank
text: WHEN Julia Child introduced it to Americans back in the 1960s, ratatouille was pretty exotic. But it caught on so completely that, for many people, that’s where the eggplant repertory begins and ends.

headline: Valley Shepherd Opens a Cheese Shop in SoHo
text: Cheeses from Valley Shepherd Creamery in Long Valley, N.J., are in 15 Greenmarkets in New York. But Eran Wajswol (above) and his wife, Debra Van Sickle, the owners, don’t run the stands from November to April. So when the chance came to rent a little storefront that would allow for year-round sales, Mr. Wajswol grabbed it. “How many farmer-owned stores are there in New York?” he asked.

headline: An Italian Pasta Factory, Next to the Farm
text: The days when many Italian pasta manufacturers grew their own wheat are long gone. But Massimo Mancini has started reviving the tradition. The results, which are delighting some well-known chefs, are also available for home cooks.

headline: Your Abdominals May Need a Touch-Up
text: SIX-PACK abs, the rippled midsections that grace models in Men’s Health covers and Calvin Klein ads, are beyond the reach of many men, but that doesn’t stop them from trying. From 2000 to 2009, the number of men in the United States undergoing abdominoplasty (tummy tucks) more than doubled, to 4,670, according to the American Society of Plastic Surgeons.

headline: Nevada Tea Party Chairman Quits
text: The head of the Nevada Tea Party resigned Tuesday after its candidate for Senate leaked a recording of Sharron Angle – the Republican running to replace Senator Harry Reid, the leader of the Democratic majority — in which she complained about Republican leaders and confessed that she does not know if she can win.

headline: Allergan Settles Botox Case With Plea Agreement
text: Updated: As part of a sentencing hearing on Tuesday, federal prosecutors provided new details about efforts by Allergan, the maker of Botox, to market and sell the drug for medical uses not approved by the Food and Drug Administration.

headline: The Story Is ‘Dancing’
text: The story-telling night of “Dancing With the Stars” led the television ratings race on Monday as 20.1 million viewers tuned in to ABC for that show’s latest two-hour installment, according to Nielsen’s estimates. ABC led the night even though its 10 p.m. crime show “Castle” (11.9 million) finished in a virtual tie with CBS’s “Hawaii Five-0” (12 million). CBS was second over all, attracting large audiences for its comedies “Two and a Half Men” (14.2 million) and “Mike & Molly” (12.3 million) in the 9 p.m. hour. Fox was third largely because of the 10.5 million who watched “House” at 8. NBC was fourth.

headline: Health Care’s Uneven Road to a New Era
text: Consider what it would be like to have a health insurance plan that capped annual benefits at $2,000. For any medical care costing more than that, you would have to pay out of pocket.

headline: Sarah Burton’s First Collection for McQueen
text: Before the Alexander McQueen show tonight, Sarah Burton said her main objective with the collection — her first since taking over as creative director — was to impart a strong sense of craft. She also used the word “tender” to describe the general feeling of the collection, which was based on a decaying nature. The narrow tailcoats and low-rise trousers certainly follow the McQueen silhouette. The prints and ribbon embroideries were consistent with the style of the last few years. Some of the more sculptural shapes recall his sense of theatre. And Ms. Burton used materials and references associated with him, like feathers, designs that appear to have partially disintegrated, and the hand-painted leather butterflies that clustered on dresses.

headline: Tradition Returns to N.H.L. Jerseys
text: After years of trying to appeal to elusive audiences, the National Hockey League finds that what fans like most are designs rooted deep in hockey’s history.

headline: Shahzad Gets Life Term for Times Square Bombing Attempt
text: The defendant came to Federal District Court in Manhattan on Tuesday ready to ladle out several minutes of anti-American justification for his act of terrorism in Times Square. But the judge, Miriam Goldman Cedarbaum, best known of late for presiding over Martha Stewart’s trial, came ready, too.

headline: Halladay Savoring First Taste of Playoffs
text: PHILADELPHIA  The driving rain and mist obscured the Center City skyline in the distance beyond the outfield at Citizens Bank Park. The red championship flags for 1980 and 2008  and five blue ones for National League titles  pointed stiffly to right field. The tarp covered the field for the scheduled workouts for the Philadelphia Phillies and the Cincinnati Reds.

headline: Media Writer at The Post Is Headed to a Web Site
text: Howard Kurtz, a three-decade veteran of The Washington Post who came to embody insider Washington media reporting with his weekly column and CNN television show, is leaving The Post for Tina Brown’s news and commentary Web site, The Daily Beast.

headline: In Fact and Song, Fiendish Yankees
text: MINNEAPOLIS  Until Tuesday, the Minnesota Twins shortstop J. J. Hardy had never heard of “Damn Yankees,” the hit Broadway musical from 1955 that was made into a movie starring Tab Hunter and Gwen Verdon. But an explanation of the story, and how it applied to the Twins’ American League division series with the Yankees, intrigued Hardy, who was born 27 years after the show opened.

headline: Idled NATO Supply Trucks in Pakistan Are Attacked Again
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — As trucks carrying supplies for NATO troops in Afghanistan were stalled at the Pakistani border for the sixth day Tuesday, Pakistani truck owners complained that the government failed to protect for the convoys, leaving them vulnerable to attacks from militants and criminals.

headline: Karzai’s Kin Use Ties to Gain Power in Afghanistan

headline: Vichy Leader Said to Widen Anti-Jewish Law
text: PARIS  Far from the enfeebled and senile general manipulated by his peers, as the French have long viewed him, Marshal Philippe Pétain was an unapologetic anti-Semite, said Serge Klarsfeld, one of France’s leading Holocaust experts.

headline: 8 Longshoremen Charged With Smuggling Cocaine
text: Eight dockworkers at ports in New York and New Jersey helped smuggle millions of dollars worth of cocaine that was eventually sold on the streets of New York City, federal prosecutors said on Tuesday.

headline: U.S., Impatient Over China’s Progress on Currency, Looks to I.M.F. for Help
text: WASHINGTON  The United States is increasingly looking to the International Monetary Fund to hold countries like China accountable for “rebalancing” the global economy, a Treasury Department official said Tuesday.

headline: Buffaslug Among Cartoonish Logos to Go Extinct
text: The Buffaslug is gone, and no one is sad to see it go.

headline: For Paladino, a Softer Edge, if Only Briefly
text: This was the week that Carl P. Paladino was to become not a man of anger but a man of ideas, of action and, yes, of amiability.

headline: The Crucial Role of Insurance Mandates
text: The threat by McDonald’s to discontinue its health-insurance coverage is one recent aftershock of the health care overhaul, as my column this week discusses. In the end, McDonald’s seems unlikely to follow through on that threat. But another part of the new law will lead to real changes: the requirement that insurers offer coverage to all children, including those with pre-existing illnesses.

headline: Global Fight Against AIDS Falters as Pledges Fail to Reach Goal of $13 Billion
text: In another signal that the global battle against AIDS is falling apart for lack of money, the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria failed on Tuesday to reach even its lowest “austerity level” fund-raising target of $13 billion  the amount it had said it needed just to keep putting patients on treatment at current rates.

headline: Hazing Accusations Against a Sorority
text: In two separate hazing cases at universities this year, members of Sigma Gamma Rho, an African-American sorority, have been charged with beating their pledges with wooden paddles.

headline: For a Republican’s Sake, a 3rd-Party Rival Quits
text: Republicans improved their prospects for picking up a House of Representatives seat in the northernmost region of New York State after a third-party candidate with strong conservative backing abruptly withdrew from the race on Tuesday.

headline: Challenge to Background Checks Falters
text: WASHINGTON  Scientists at a California research facility appeared likely to lose their challenge to background checks required by a Bush administration antiterrorism initiative, judging from the justices’ questions on Tuesday during arguments at the Supreme Court.

headline: Voters Face Decisions on a Mix of Issues
text: The nation’s job woes may be the determining factor in which party controls Congress, but voters across the country will also have the chance to weigh in directly  through ballot initiatives  on some of the other contentious issues that have made cameo turns in the spotlight this year.

headline: Zuckerberg: Non-Evil Non-Genius?
text: Is Mark Zuckerberg a bad person? Did he, as the movie “The Social Network” suggests, steal the idea for Facebook from two of his fellow undergraduates at Harvard?

headline: Back Stories for 2010 Milestones
text: Elena Gustines has put together for Bats an outstanding compilation of the memorable plays and milestones, of the 2010 season. Here are some back-stories to her assemblage:

headline: Foreclosure Furor Rises; Many Call for a Freeze
text: The uproar over bad conduct by mortgage lenders intensified Tuesday, as lawmakers in Washington requested a federal investigation and the attorney general in Texas joined a chorus of state law enforcement figures calling for freezes on all foreclosures.

text: The Mets have begun what they say will be a methodical process to identify and hire a new general manager — and then a manager.

headline: Chinese Civilian Boats Roil Disputed Waters
text: BEIJING  The diplomatic discord set off by Japan’s recent detention of a Chinese fishing trawler captain points to what foreign military officials say is a growing source of friction along China’s borders: civilian vessels plying disputed waters  and sometimes acting as proxies for the Chinese Navy.

headline: Stem Cells in Court, Scientists Fear for Careers
text: Rushing to work at Cincinnati Children’s Hospital Medical Center one recent morning, Jason Spence, 33, grabbed a moment during breakfast to type “stem cells” into Google and click for the last 24 hours of news. It is a routine he has performed daily in the six weeks since a Federal District Court ruling put the future of his research in jeopardy.

headline: Bailout Loss Estimated at $29 Billion
text: The Treasury Department expects to lose $29 billion on the federal bailouts stemming from the financial crisis, with most of the losses in its housing finance program and the auto rescue.

headline: Heat-Knicks to Be First N.B.A. Game Broadcast in 3-D
text: The game between the Miami Heat and the Knicksat Madison Square Garden on Dec. 17 will be broadcast on ESPN’s 3-D network, making it the first N.B.A. game broadcast in 3-D, according to N.B.A. and ESPN officials. The network will show eight regular-season games in 3-D during the 2010-2011 season, and another six in the playoffs.

headline: Solar Power Plants to Rise on U.S. Land
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Proposals for the first large solar power plants ever built on federal lands won final approval on Tuesday from Interior Secretary Ken Salazar, reflecting the Obama administration’s resolve to promote renewable energy in the face of Congressional inaction.

headline: Obama and a Room of Powerful Women
text: When the polls are bad, the polls are bad. But let’s face it, President Obama never had a chance in this contest. Still, he showed up for the victory celebration anyway, honoring, among others, the woman he beat for the presidency, Hillary Rodham Clinton, now his secretary of state.

headline: Sidney J. Weinberg Jr., Former Goldman Executive, Dies at 87
text: Sidney J. Weinberg Jr., a senior director of Goldman Sachs and a member of the family dynasty that had played a central role at the investment banking firm since 1907, died Monday at his home in Marion, Mass. Mr. Weinberg, who was also a significant philanthropist, was 87.

headline: Televisa Invests $1.2 Billion for a Stake in Univision
text: Univision, the leading Spanish-language television network in the United States, will retain the rights to popular telenovelas produced by the Mexican television giant Grupo Televisa for another 15 years.

headline: Man Bites Dog: Yankees Are Underdogs
text: MINNEAPOLIS – The David and Goliath analogy is one of the more tired clichés in sports. But when Alex Rodriguez used it Tuesday night, he managed to add a surprising twist.

headline: Nigerian Government Searches for Culprits Behind Bombings
text: DAKAR, Senegal  Aftershocks from last week’s deadly blasts in the Nigerian capital, Abuja, continued to reverberate on Tuesday as the shaken government pressed its search for the culprits.

headline: Indonesia: Fearing Arrest, President Delays a Trip to the Netherlands
text: President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono delayed a state visit to the Netherlands on Tuesday after three Dutch citizens supporting indigenous Indonesian separatists known as Moluccans filed a claim demanding that he be arrested on Dutch soil for human rights abuses. The claim was widely seen as a publicity stunt in the Netherlands because the visiting president would have been protected by diplomatic immunity. The Indonesian government has been accused of abusing human rights in suppressing Moluccans, who live in Maluku Province in eastern Indonesia. Ninety political prisoners have been sentenced or are awaiting trial for separatism, with some serving sentences as long as 20 years, said Andreas Harsono, Indonesia consultant for Human Rights Watch.

headline: Thailand: Arms-Smuggling Suspect Is a Step Closer to U.S. Extradition
text: A Thai court on Tuesday dismissed a second set of charges, money laundering and wire fraud, against Viktor Bout, the Russian businessman accused of running arms-trafficking networks across the world, removing another obstacle to his extradition to the United States. Washington had expected Mr. Bout’s rapid extradition, but the case has spurred a tug of war with Moscow, which does not want him to go on trial in the United States, most likely because he is thought to know much about Russia’s restructured intelligence system.

headline: Democratic Republic of Congo: Arrest of Rebel Leader in Hundreds of Rapes
text: Lt. Col. Sadoke Kokunda Mayele, the chief of staff of the Congolese rebel group Mai Mai Cheka, was arrested by United Nations peacekeepers on Tuesday and accused of coordinating a series of attacks between July 30 and Aug. 2 in which 303 civilians were raped in 13 villages in Walikale, according to Leo Salmeron, spokesman for the United Nations peacekeeping operations in North Kivu Province.

headline: Iran: Spying Charges Dropped Against British Embassy Worker
text: An appeals court dropped spying charges against Hossein Rassam, an Iranian employee of the British Embassy in Tehran who had been sentenced last year to four years in prison after protests broke out over the country’s disputed elections, the man’s lawyer told Agence-France Presse on Monday. The lawyer said that because Mr. Rassam “had no previous record and held no managerial posts,” his sentence was suspended on the condition that he not work for foreign embassies or have ties to political groups for five years. The embassy had called the sentence “an attack against the entire diplomatic community in Iran.”

headline: Spain: DNA Tests Shatter One Man’s Dream of Nobility
text: DNA tests have shown that José Collado, an orphaned trumpeter from Marbella who has been fighting a 10-year legal battle to be recognized as the rightful heir to the de Larios family fortune, is not the son of the fourth Marquis de Larios, Mr. Collado’s lawyer, José Ortiz, said Tuesday.

headline: New York Missed or Ignored Signs on Girl Who Died
text: A 4-year-old Brooklyn girl who weighed 18 pounds when she died in September appears to have gone months without a visit from child welfare workers assigned to monitor her well-being, despite indications that she could be at risk, New York’s child welfare agency revealed on Tuesday.

headline: Breakout Players of the First Quarter of the Season
text: After the first four weeks of the N.F.L season, it’s time to reorient ourselves from what we thought we knew to what actually happened on the field. Here’s a look at some of the surprising players and key statistics.

headline: Fate of Missing Balloonists Clouds Joy at U.S. Festival
text: ALBUQUERQUE  Two accomplished balloonists from the United States recently set out from Bristol, England, with hopes of winning the world’s most prestigious balloon competition. Four days later, they vanished over the Adriatic Sea in stormy weather. No signs of the pilots or their balloon have turned up, and the Italian Coast Guard has called off its search efforts.

headline: Florida Lawmaker Is a Proud Firebrand

headline: Wednesday: Basslike
text: Although I spent a couple of high school summers working on a cattle farm in New Jersey (I handled the haying chores, collecting the bales, getting them to the barn and stacking them to the rafters), I never dabbled in the fine art of COW TIPPING. Instead of researching the subject, and offering a suburban slicker’s take on it, perhaps someone here can enlighten us as to this “Mischevious rural pastime.”

headline: Risks and Advantages in U.S. Effort in Mideast
text: WASHINGTON  When President Obama reopened face-to-face talks between the Israelis and Palestinians last month, he pledged that his administration would hold their hands but warned, “The United States cannot impose an agreement, and we cannot want it more than the parties themselves.”

headline: A Sunny Urban Vision of Traveling Underground
text: They don’t come much more cheery than “In Transit,” the optimism-oozing, a cappella musical that opened on Tuesday night at the 59E59 Street Theaters. Though the show is set mostly on grimy subways and populated by beleaguered characters, rarely a minute goes by onstage without a twinkling eye or a toothy smile. It’s a testament to the company’s pluck that you’ll smile widely too, even as your inner cynic tells you that it’s all being laid on a bit thick.

headline: Archdiocese to Release List of Schools It May Close
text: By early November, the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York plans to release a list of parochial schools that may have to close as part of its plan to cut deficits and resuscitate its faltering grade-school system, church officials said Tuesday.

headline: In Hartford, Fiery Exchanges in a Debate for Governor
text: HARTFORD  Displaying an aggressive style befitting his previous life as a Brooklyn prosecutor, Dannel P. Malloy, the Democratic nominee for governor of Connecticut, relentlessly attacked his Republican opponent, Thomas C. Foley, in a debate on Tuesday night over his work in private business and his positions on education, government and other crucial issues.

headline: Obama Strains to Get Liberals Back Into Fold Ahead of Vote
text: WASHINGTON  With four weeks until Congressional elections that will shape the remainder of his term, President Obama is increasingly focused on generating enthusiasm within the base that helped put him in the White House two years ago, from college students to African-Americans.

headline: Clean and Open American Elections
text: For at least 44 years, it has been illegal for foreign corporations, countries and individuals to make political contributions in the United States for any election, either directly or indirectly. It is even against the law to solicit such contributions. But in this Wild West year of political money, that longstanding ban is being set aside. The United States Chamber of Commerce  one of the biggest advertisers in midterm races around the country  is actively soliciting foreign money, and government enforcers seem to be doing nothing to stop it.

headline: Verizon Wireless Says Oops
text: The big phone companies have been campaigning to convince Congress that attempts by the Federal Communications Commission to regulate Internet access like it regulates phones are a costly intrusion that will slow online investment and hamstring progress. And then  oops!  one of the big phone companies reminds us why they should not be allowed to discipline themselves.
