text: In January 2008, soon after the venerable Tribune Company was sold for $8.2 billion, Randy Michaels, a new top executive, ran into several other senior colleagues at the InterContinental Hotel next to the Tribune Tower in Chicago.

headline: Amherst President Is Expected to Lead New York Public Library
text: At a time when the digital revolution has cast the traditional mission of libraries into question, the New York Public Library is expected to name Anthony W. Marx, the president of Amherst College, as its new president on Wednesday. He would replace Paul LeClerc, who is to retire next year.

headline: Civil Justice, Military Injustice
text: Supporters of the tribunals at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, who insist military justice, not the federal courts, is the best way to deal with terrorists, should pay close attention to Tuesday’s events in a United States District Court in Manhattan. Faisal Shahzad was sentenced to life imprisonment, five months and four days after he tried to blow up his car in Times Square.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Yankees Use 3-Pitcher Rotation for Playoffs
text: MINNEAPOLIS  Assembling a 25-man roster for a postseason series is sort of like raiding the supermarket before an approaching snowstorm. You stock up on the staples, but also some cookie dough, a jar of pickles and two boxes of saltines. You might not eat them, but you might be glad they are there  just in case.

headline: Cleaner Cars
text: President Obama announced last year the first big increase in fuel economy standards in three decades, plus a new requirement reducing tailpipe emissions of carbon dioxide, the main greenhouse gas.

headline: Reds’ Flamethrower Seems to Be Pushing Limits of Pitching
text: PHILADELPHIA  Jamie Moyer unzipped a small bag at his locker in the Philadelphia Phillies clubhouse on Tuesday. Tucked among the personal notebooks and photographs, he found a weathered envelope, torn on the side. It held a copy of his original scouting report from 1984.

headline: Making Pit Stops in Charlotte
text: I know that Nascar is awesome in the same way I know that cricket and Tolstoy novels and contemporary dance are awesome. I personally can’t see the appeal, but enough reasonable people disagree with me that I believe in their awesomeness.

headline: Credit for the Recovery
text: EVERY time the United States suffers a recession, trendspotters hasten to identify signs of frugality, extol the rediscovery of thrift and find evidence that Americans are finally (finally!) kicking their demon debt habit. We crack open history books to locate the anti-debt impulse in pre-revolutionary America and troll through quotation collections for ammunition. I’ve been around long enough to go through this exercise twice  first in the early 1990s and then in 2001 after the dot-com bust. Here we go again.

headline: A Plot Twist at Univision
text: The private equity owners of Univision have scripted a twist worthy of a telenovela.

headline: Georgia: Man Sues to Stay in Theater
text: A man who lives in one of Atlanta’s famous cultural landmarks, the Fox Theater, is suing his landlords for the right to remain there. The theater’s board of directors voted in August to change a housing contract for the man, Joe Patten, 83, citing his “deteriorating health.” He lives in a rent-free apartment as a reward for his role in saving the building from demolition in the 1970s. In a statement, the theater promised that Mr. Patten could stay in the apartment “as long as he is able,” but not necessarily for life, as the original contract guaranteed.

headline: Le Bernardin Gets a 29 in Zagat
text: There is a rarity in the 2011 Zagat New York City Restaurants guide: a restaurant that scored an unconditional 29 for food. The happy recipient of that rating, which had not been bestowed since the original Bouley got it in 1996, is Le Bernardin, a restaurant that has been at or near the top of the rankings since it opened nearly a quarter century ago.

headline: Phys Ed: Free the Free Radicals
text: We’re all used to hearing that everything we once thought was good for us is not. But even within that framework, the latest science about antioxidants, free radicals and exercise is telling. As many of us have heard, free radicals are molecules created by the breakdown of oxygen during metabolism. Each of us constantly creates free radicals simply by living and breathing. But these molecules are highly reactive and capricious, sometimes attacking other cells and damaging tissue. Wilding free radicals have been linked with a number of diseases and with aging. Exercise, because it requires increased oxygen consumption, also increases the production of free radicals. So, many experts began urging the fitness-minded to pop large doses of antioxidant vitamin supplements, like vitamins C and E, to counteract the presumed damaging effects of the free radicals. Food alone would not supply sufficient levels of the necessary antioxidants, it was thought. The exercising body needed help from vitamins.

headline: Dim Outlook for Holiday Jobs
text: As the economy sputters, prospects are dimming for unemployed workers who were banking on a seasonal retail job to carry them through the holidays.

text: impassive •\(ˌ)im-ˈpa-siv\• adjective

headline: Timeless: Babe Ruth’s Uniform Number
text: On June 13, 1948, the 25th anniversary of the opening of Yankee Stadium, Babe Ruth stood alone at home plate acknowledging the cheers of thousands in a ceremony retiring his number. Nat Fein, a photographer for The New York Herald-Tribune, took a big chance. He didn’t line up with the other photographers along the first-base line or alongside the Life magazine photographer Ralph Morse, who took the shot from somewhere near the pitcher’s mound. Instead, he stood behind Ruth, capturing the stadium and teammates in the same frame. He said of that day: “The Number 3 was the thing I was interested in. I felt the only way to tell the story of Babe retiring was from the back.”

headline: Norman Wisdom, Funnyman, Dies at 95
text: Norman Wisdom, one of Britain’s best-loved cinematic clowns, who also earned a Tony nomination on Broadway, died on Monday on the Isle of Man. He was 95 and had continued performing until he was 90.

headline: Andy Albeck Is Dead at 89; Headed United Artists
text: Andy Albeck, a movie executive whose three turbulent years as president and chief executive of United Artists included the release of both “Raging Bull,” the Martin Scorsese boxing drama that is often cited as one of Hollywood’s finest achievements, and “Heaven’s Gate,” the extravagant western directed by Michael Cimino that was one of its most celebrated flops, died on Sept. 29 in Manhattan. He was 89.

headline: U.S. Apologizes as Attacks in Pakistan Continue
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Dozens of tanker trucks carrying fuel to Afghanistan for NATO troops were torched near Quetta in western Pakistan on Wednesday, the third major attack on supplies since Pakistan closed a border crossing to Afghanistan a week ago and the first at the only checkpoint that remained open.

text: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  Assailants fired on a vehicle carrying five British diplomats on Wednesday morning in the Yemeni capital, Sana, and one of the officials was slightly wounded. It was the second attack against British personnel in Yemen since April.

headline: How Would You Do in a ‘Free School’?
text: At the Manhattan Free School, students “do not receive grades, take tests or have to do anything, really, that they do not feel like doing.” Teachers there believe that students learn best when they direct their own education, so though there are classes, students can play video games all day if they like. Would you want to attend a school like this? If not, why not? If so, what do you think you would do with your time? Do you agree that you learn best when you direct your own education? Why or why not?

Weinberg Jr., a senior director of Goldman Sachs and a member of the family dynasty that had played a central role at the investment banking firm since 1907, died Monday at his home in Marion, Mass. headline: Morning Take-Out
text: –Globalization: It’s bad for you. What’s more, when a recession does hit, the recovery becomes slower as globalization increases.”

headline: Monetary Versus Fiscal
text: Karl Smith has his own version of the models people are using to think about this crisis. I don’t have much disagreement, except that I would group the various non-Keynesian models together as all various attempts to see this as a supply problem: the mishmash mismatch theory is basically a particular form of real business cycle theory, with a particular form of real shock, and recalculation, as far as I understand it, can generate unemployment only via mismatch, so it’s a subset of a subset. And I see all of these views as refuted by actual experience with interest rates and inflation.

headline: Businesses Seek Clarity on Climate Goals
text: In the run-up to the Cancún climate change conference that opens late next month in Mexico, a sizable group of business leaders are fighting to make their voices heard. But this time, it is not to argue that a low-carbon economy is bad for business, they say. The opposite, in fact.

headline: ‘Glee': You’ve Got to Have Faith (Unless You Don’t Want To)
text: This blog got into unexpectedly hot water last week with its unqualified enthusiasm for the “Britney/Brittany” episode of “Glee,” and it’s with some reluctance we have to say that this week’s installment was not one of our all-time favorites. (Your mileage may vary, of course.) The premise was promising and, for network television, potentially provocative: Finn’s discovery of what he believes is the face of Jesus on a grilled cheese sandwich leads to an exploration of his faith and the religious beliefs of his glee-choir colleagues.

headline: The 36-Hour Dinner Party
text: HERE’S THE CONCEIT: Build a single wood fire and, over the course of 30-plus hours, use it to roast, braise, bake, simmer and grill as many different dishes as possible — for lunch, dinner, breakfast and lunch again. The main ingredients: one whole goat from the McCormack Ranch in Rio Vista, Calif.; several crates of seasonal produce (and a case of olive oil) from Hudson Ranch in Napa; a basket of morels and porcini gathered near Mount Shasta; an assortment of spices from Boulettes Larder in San Francisco; and a couple of cases of wine from Kermit Lynch in Berkeley. The setting: a shady backyard in Napa (but picture suburban subdivision, not vineyard estate), where a big country table stretches out beneath the canopy of a mulberry tree. The cast: three accomplished Bay Area chefs (Mike and Jenny Emanuel — whose kitchen and backyard we’ve commandeered for the weekend — and Melissa Fernandez), one gifted baker (Chad Robertson), one jack of all culinary trades (Anthony Tassinello) and two amateurs (me and my 17-year-old son, Isaac). The guests: all of the above, plus a rotating crew of spouses, children, friends and neighbors. The fire: almond, oak and mulberry logs burning in a cob oven that Mike Emanuel built with the help of some friends in 2006. A cob, or earth, oven is a primitive, domed cooking device that can be made from layers of mud, clay, straw, stucco, even manure; the earthy mixture, the cob, can endure much higher heat, and hold it much longer, than an indoor oven can. Emanuel’s incarnation, which he built “to bring together family and friends for extended feasts,” stands 5 feet tall with a 30-inch hearth and looks like a cartoon character: a visitor from a planet of chubby, eyeless, big-mouthed monsters.

headline: Understanding and Misunderstanding the ‘Enthusiasm Gap’
text: I was an early adopter of the term “enthusiasm gap” in the context of this year’s elections, having first applied it in August 2009 — a summer of town-hall protests and Tea Party rallies — to describe polling numbers for Democrats in Virginia and New Jersey, which were to vote for governor that year. Those polls suggested that there had been a significant shift in the electorate from the one that gave Democrats their majorities in 2006 and 2008.

headline: New York Philharmonic Adds Concert After Foreign Cancellation
text: The New York Philharmonic will add a concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Oct. 19 to plug a hole caused by the cancellation of a visit to the Republic of Georgia. The orchestra and its music director, Alan Gilbert, will tack on another performance of the program being presented Oct. 14-16, which consists of Brahms’s Symphony No. 4 and Violin Concerto (with Pinchas Zukerman as soloist), and Webern’s Passacaglia (Op. 1). Brahms’s “Academic Festival Overture” will replace the Webern work in the Oct. 19 concert. The visit to Georgia was to have been the first stop on a European tour but was canceled by Georgia’s government because of what it called money problems.

headline: Keeping Score: Rays Score Runs With Their Eyes and Feet
text: As the Rangers and Rays series gets under way on Wednesday, you should not be surprised if a Rangers pitcher throws a low-hit gem at some point during the series. The Rays had five games this season when the opposing pitching staffs allowed one or no hits. This includes the May 9 perfect game by the A’s Dallas Braden and the June 25 no-hitter by the Diamondbacks’ Edwin Jackson. Add in the three one-hitters thrown at the Rays by Cleveland, Toronto and Boston, and the Rays had the most low-hit games in a single season since 1920 with five.

headline: Paris Picks | The Marais Invasion
text: For a long time now, the Haut Marais has attracted indie boutiques and avant-garde designers. More and more, they’re foreign-born. The American modernist Jack Henry made his home at 25, rue Charlot, which is just down the street from Plagg, Barbara Kurdziel’s shop devoted to Scandinavian fashion, which is just down the street from the Korean designer Moon Young Hee’s whimsical atelier. And just around the corner on rue Vieille du Temple, the New York design collective Surface to Air opened its new flagship featuring edgy-urbane men’s and women’s fashion. Foreign flair is suddenly everywhere, and for a city that’s infamous for resisting change, it’s a welcome infusion.

headline: When a College Visits Your High School

headline: Letters: Kafka’s Last Trial
text: Elif Batuman does a magnificent job of guiding us through the labyrinthine world of Kafka’s literary estate (or what remains of it among the papers of his longtime executor and friend Max Brod) and the highly contentious, occasionally absurd battle to win possession over it. As someone who has conducted research both at the National Library of Israel and at the German Literature Archive in Marbach — the two institutions vying to gain possession of Brod’s papers — I can see certain advantages in each. Yet to my mind one key difference, the critical edge that Marbach holds over Jerusalem, is not so much the state-of-the-art research facility that Marbach is, but rather that its holdings include under one roof the manuscripts of the greatest modern writers and poets of the German language, Jew and gentile alike. It would seem, given Kafka’s universal appeal and his ardent international following among readers and scholars, that this is the most prudent choice.

headline: Letters: The Great Connecticut-Country-Club Crackup

headline: On Our Radar: Brazil’s Green Candidate Gets 20%

The result was a “green tsunami,” declared the O Dia newspaper in Rio de Janeiro, where Ms. Silva garnered 32 percent of the vote. “Marina Silva’s face will not be on the ballot on Oct. 31, but her electoral ghost will decide the second round,” the newspaper says. [The Guardian]

headline: Diva Franco
text: Is there anything James Franco can’t do? The multihyphenate’s multihyphenate, whose latest offerings include a starring turn as Allen Ginsberg in the movie “Howl” and “Palo Alto” (Scribner), a collection of short stories being released on Oct. 19, appears in drag on the cover of the fall issue of Candy magazine. Billed as “the world’s first transversal style magazine,” the ambisexual publication plays limbo with the markers of gender and high-fashion and is the brainchild of Luis Venegas, the Madrid-based publisher of the cult magazines Fanzine 137 and Electric Youth. In addition to Mr. Franco’s fashion shoot with the photographer Terry Richardson, the new issue of Candy features a photo spread of Mr. Venegas impersonating Vogue editor in chief, Anna Wintour. Divino!

headline: Shifting Tides in Governors’ Races: Brown Now 3-to-1 Favorite

Last week, Mr. Brown was a 60 percent favorite, and two weeks ago, he was the underdog in the race.

headline: Report Slams Administration for Underestimating Gulf Spill

headline: Rocking Crew

The second video teaches us the tools of the trade in a modern-day style guide that captures the antics of the lead singer, Blair Van Nort, and the drummer, Erik Ratensperger, as they walk us through the differences between the lean silhouette of the perennially popular Ludlow suit and the more traditionally proportioned Aldridge style. “We were looking for a way to bring the suits to life,” says Jack O’Connor, men’s style director for J. Crew, “and what cooler way than on the Rassle performing outside the Liquor Store in the suits.” Even cooler, there is a link to download the band’s latest EP for free.

headline: Falling Incomes, Fine Dining and ‘People on Foot’

So far at least, this has not happened, despite the recession. Even the squeegee men have not returned, though there are a few like David Morales in East Harlem who never stopped plying their  trade.

headline: Scorecard | Yves Saint Laurent Wins!
text: It makes sense that YSL’s return to its masculin-féminin thing would score as we near the end of our four-week international fashion appreciation tour, because Scorecard is hard pressed to name more than a handful of shows this season that weren’t, for better or for worse, an homage to the man who first gave women the pants to wear, Monsieur Saint Laurent. But if Stella McCartney didn’t want to cast such a long glance back, she might just have looked to Stefano Pilati’s spring 2010 collection — because we know the current designer for the house learned then that garden-variety prints don’t get you the win.

headline: Introducing Dashboard: This Week in Small Business
text: Since 1994, I’ve been running my own small business (it’s a consulting firm that helps clients with customer relationship management). In the early years, the best way to get information was by reading a few self-help business books and visiting a couple of Web sites once in a while. Now it seems as if there are a million Web sites and books and experts all trying to tell me how to succeed. And another million bloggers and pundits interpreting the daily political, economic and cultural news and events that affect my company.

text: Fill in the blanks in the first several paragraphs of a Business section article about Halloween bargains. Use your own words and phrases, or click “read more” to choose from a scrambled list of the words or phrases that were removed.

headline: A Warm and Cozy Show Set for Park Avenue Armory
text: The Park Avenue Armory, as the venue for the Winter Antiques Show, has seen its share of American quilts. But it has never seen an extravaganza quite like what the American Folk Art Museum will bring to the 55,000-square-foot Drill Hall from March 25 to 30. The museum will present an exhibition of more than 650 red and white American quilts, owned by the New York collector Joanna Rose. In announcing the exhibition, which will be free to the public, the museum’s executive director, Maria Ann Conelli, described it as an effort to reach new audiences. Ms. Rose and her husband, Daniel, are covering the costs of the presentation and also donating 50 quilts to the museum.

headline: Yankees Change, but Postseason Focus Doesn’t
text: Minneapolis

headline: British Leader Vows End to ‘Heavy-Handed State’
text: BIRMINGHAM, England  As the government prepares to drastically scale back its operations with steep across-the-board budget cuts, Prime Minister David Cameron on Wednesday used the occasion of the annual Conservative Party conference here to make an earnest, impassioned call for a fundamental change in the relationship between the state and the people.

headline: Finding Team Success With a Little Less Strain
text: I am willing to bet that every retiring youth coach utters prayers of thanks for experiencing the last of three things: the “am I going in?” screamfests, the losses to the team coached by a Bobby Knight disciple and, finally, the questions from parents about why their child played 30 seconds fewer than another player.

headline: Graphic Content | Milton Glaser, Still Questioning
text: At 81, Milton Glaser is still creating significant design at full capacity, which is demonstrated in the exhibition “In Search of the Miraculous or One Thing Leads to Another,” on view through Nov. 24 at the AIGA National Design Center in New York. Glaser told me that the show is his last hurrah, but I don’t believe him.

headline: One on One: Caterina Fake, Flickr and Hunch
text: Caterina Fake is a co-founder of the photo sharing Web site Flickr, which was sold to Yahoo in early 2005. Since then, Ms. Fake has guided a number of Web products, including Etsy, the online marketplace for crafts and vintage products, Dailybooth, which lets users publish daily  photographs of themselves, and Hunch, which finds products and places that a user’s online friends like  and then predicts what else the user might like.

headline: Stiff Back Sidelines Placido Polanco
text: PHILADELPHIA – The Phillies have won Game 1 in each of their last six postseason series. But if they’re going to do it again on Wednesday against the Reds, they’ll have to manage without third baseman Placido Polanco.

headline: Justices Take Up Funeral-Protest Case
text: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court heard arguments on Wednesday in a highly charged case involving protesters objecting to homosexuality who picketed a military funeral.

headline: Denial and Speculation Follow Woodward’s Hint of a Clinton-Biden Swap
text: 2:23 p.m. | Updated In response to the White House’s pushback against his idea that Hillary Rodham Clinton and Joseph R. Biden Jr. might exchange places, Bob Woodward said this afternoon that the idea of a Biden-Clinton swap is “on the table” in the sense that “any legitimate vote-getting strategy is always on the table in politics.”

headline: Looking Back and Looking Ahead: Week 5 in Fantasy Football
text: Chet Gresham blogs about fantasy football at Razzball. You can follow him on Twitter @Chetrazzball.

headline: Geolocation Services: Find a Smartphone, Find a Customer
text: CHAMIN MILLS has found a new way to give customers a poke.

headline: Hungarian Towns Begin Cleanup of Nightmarish Red Sludge
text: KOLONTAR, Hungary  Just before he raced for refuge in the attic of his family’s home here on Monday at lunchtime, Krisztian Holczer called his mother at her job at a school near here.

headline: Green Beret Is Awarded Medal of Honor Posthumously
text: President Obama on Wednesday awarded the Medal of Honor posthumously to a Green Beret who gave his life to save more than a dozen American and Afghan soldiers in a battle with insurgents in Afghanistan last year. It was the latest in a series of such White House ceremonies at a time of debate about the war.

headline: Childish Food
text: Readers, like Di Liu of Chicago, who photographed the dish at the right, are submitting pictures and stories of unusual dishes their children have had them cook — like spaghetti tacos. “My brother invented this when he was 8. It is bread, slathered with Prego, and finally topped with Goldfish crackers.” The Dining section will display a slide show of selections later this week.

headline: Have You Tried Foursquare?
text: In a small-business guide we just published, Kermit Pattison explains, step by step, how to get started with location-based marketing. The guide focuses primarily on Foursquare, the most prominent of the services, but there are many others. Below is a quick rundown of the alternatives. Have you tried any of them? What has your experience been?

headline: Senator Jim DeMint and Morality
text: I’m stunned by what Senator Jim DeMint says about moral requirements for teachers. Not only is he against gay teachers, but also against single women who sleep with their boyfriends. Not clear what he thinks of those boyfriends having sex before marriage, but they don’t seem to alarm him so much. Here’s how he was quoted in the Spartanburg, S.C., newspaper:

headline: Runways, Then Shop Doorways
text: PARIS

headline: Guy Deutscher Responds
text: Guy Deutscher provides a statement below, in response to my Oct. 3 column Scholarly Work, Without All the Footnotes.

headline: Trains With Dedicated Tracks Top Subway Rankings
text: Looking for the best subway lines in the city? Find the one that has a track all to itself.

headline: The Science of Conception: Studying Fertility and I.V.F.
text: Overview | How does conception work, and what are the major issues related to fertility? What are some of the medical advances that help infertile women conceive? In this lesson, students investigate and create storyboards for animations that explain the process of conception, the issue of infertility and the uses and risks of fertility treatments. They also consider the awarding of the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine to a pioneer in the development of in vitro fertilization, along with the ethical implications of the treatment.

headline: A New Version of Windows Live Essentials
text: Last week, Microsoft released a new version of its Windows Live Essentials application suite, which has been in a public beta test for months.

headline: A Fund Manager’s Message Beyond the ‘Pinata’
text: Anthony Scaramucci, the hedge fund manager of SkyBridge Capital, made headlines last month when he asked President Obama on television when he was going to “stop whacking Wall Street like a piñata.”

headline: West Virginia Sues U.S. Over Mining Restrictions
text: The state of West Virginia sued two federal agencies on Wednesday, seeking to reverse the stricter controls on mountaintop coal mining adopted in 2009 by the Obama administration.

headline: Now Open | Raphael Young
text: “It’s a real pépite d’or, this boutique,” the shoe designer Raphael Young explains, likening his new store in the First Arrondisement in Paris to a gold nugget. Indeed, Young struck gold with this prime spot on rue Jean-Jacques Rousseau. “It’s big but well-proportioned,” he says. “There are rooms on the lower level where we’ve set up my atelier for special orders, our offices, a small lounge and my studio. It’s perfect!”

headline: Footprint Fossils Offer Earliest Evidence of Dinosaurs’ Ancestors
text: The earliest known relatives of dinosaurs were the size of a house cat, walked on four legs and left footprints in the quarries in Poland.

headline: Cuba Journal: A Taste of Duke Ellington, Dizzy Gillespie and More
text: Over the next few days, Victoria Burnett will be reporting for ArtsBeat on Jazz at Lincoln Center’s visit to Cuba.

headline: 133 Charged in Puerto Rico Graft Inquiry
text: WASHINGTON  In what officials described as the largest investigation into police corruption in the history of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Justice Department on Wednesday announced the indictments of 89 police officers and 44 other people in Puerto Rico on drug trafficking charges.

headline: When Sleep Apnea Masquerades as Dementia
text: The woman who came to see Dr. Ronald Petersen, an Alzheimer’s specialist at the Mayo Clinic, was only in her 60s but complained that she was having trouble concentrating. “Her attention was waning,” Dr. Petersen recalled. “She couldn’t follow a television program or stay focused during a conversation.”

headline: A Soigné Kothari Boutique Opens on Madison Avenue
text: SARI-DRAPING tutorials and tea service are among the perks offered by Soigné Kothari at her new Madison Avenue boutique, Soigne K at 717 Madison Avenue (at 63rd Street); (212) 486-2890;

headline: Issey Miyake Offers a New Bag in a New Space
text: ISSEY MIYAKE is in the details of the new Bao Bao collection (pictured, $615), which builds on his popular Bilbao style. The bag doesn’t arrive until November, but already there is a waiting list. It will be sold at the recently renovated Pleats Please at 128 Wooster Street (at Prince Street); (212) 226-3600; isseymiyake.com.

headline: Scouting Report
text: POP UP

headline: Epaulet Opens a Pop-Up Focusing on Collaborations
text: EPAULET in Brooklyn has opened a pop-up shop on the Lower East Side featuring new collaborations at 151 Orchard Street (at Stanton Street); (212) 477-1018; epauletshop.com. A party will be held tonight, from 7 to 9:30, to introduce the slim-fitting Gitman Vintage for Epaulet shirts (pictured, Loden, Ultraviolet Tartan, $165). Coming: a shawl-collar hand-knit cardigan made in a seven-person workshop on Prince Edward Island ($325); Thorogood No. 685 Boot, handcrafted in Merrill, Wis. ($245); Epaulet & Staple special-edition rivet chinos made with brushed cotton twill from Japan ($165). The store will close Oct. 30.

headline: Just 30 Pieces of Glamour
text: JANE MAYLE, who closed her influential NoLIta boutique in 2009, has a 30-piece capsule collection at Sigerson Morrison Laboratory Boutique at 19 East 71st Street (Madison Avenue); (212) 734-2100; sigersonmorrison.com. The collection will be available until Oct. 14 and includes wool coats in textures like soft twills and tweeds, wool bouclé and coarse twill ($765 to $875); whimsical print silk dresses ($545 to $645), and bags ($295 to $725).

headline: How (Not) to Treat a Stay-at-Home-Dad
text: Matt Villano, a freelance writer and stay-at-home dad in Healdsburg, Calif., is getting used to being the only father in the room. He understands that there will always be mothers who will ignore him, as they cluster together on the other end of the playground. In fact, as he writes in a guest post today, he would prefer to be ignored — particularly if the alternative is way too much attention. (Of course, a no-big-deal middle ground would be nice.)

headline: Quote Unquote | Punk’d
text: –Steve Albini, the pioneer of punk, tells it like it is to GQ.  At least that’s one musician we can count on not to start a clothing line anytime soon.

headline: Class Struggle and Fabergé’s Imagination Played Out on a Board
text: In the fall of 1977, George Dean, a Detroit doctor and chess set collector, received a call from a man with a thick Russian accent offering to sell a set made by the legendary jeweler Peter Carl Fabergé. Dr. Dean knew that Fabergé had made a set in 1905, but the one offered for sale was supposedly made in 1915.

headline: Big Issues, Small Answers
text: From the Montreal Gazette’s Habs Inside/Out blog:

headline: Aroldis Chapman and the Risk of the Fleeting Flamethrower
text: PHILADELPHIA -– You don’t run much risk of injury by walking down the street. If you run, your risk rises a little. On a bike, it’s greater. On a motorcycle or a race car, it’s greater still. It only makes sense: the faster you’re going, the greater your risk of getting hurt. It’s true for a rotating shoulder, too.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Hungary and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Hungary, Somalia and Mexico.

headline: Cisco Rolls Out Umi Home Videoconferencing System
text: So, there’s kind of clunky but blissfully free PC video chat on Skype and any number of other Web services. And now there’s superhigh-quality chat over your TV from Cisco for $898.88, for a year of service.

headline: It’s a Celebration, So Let’s Squeeze In a Ferris Wheel
text: How do you get to the Park Avenue Armory?

headline: A Soft Spot for Public Lands
text: John D. Leshy, a former Interior Department solicitor, likes to say, “There’s no square yard of public land that somebody doesn’t love.”

headline: Why Holiday Retail Sales Matter
text: Stephanie Clifford and I have an article in today’s paper about the outlook for holiday sales and holiday retail hiring, which is grim (especially when you consider that retailers are entering the season with very lean sales forces).

headline: A Twin, a Ranger and, Most of All, a Senator
text: The Minnesota Twins and the Texas Rangers are in the American League playoffs together for the first time. In a general sense, each is bound to two failed Washington Senators franchises. More precisely, their ties go through a man in Huntsville, Ala.

headline: Clean Living in the Henhouse
text: NORTH MANCHESTER, Ind.  The stuff doesn’t even smell that bad.

headline: Egg Farms Fight Contamination
text: Egg farms in northern Indiana show that much is being done in the egg industry to fight salmonella.

headline: Mysterious Renminbi Proposals
text: As Chinese officials make increasingly frantic and bizarre statements — other emerging markets have experienced huge currency appreciations, so how is it that having China move modestly in the same direction would be a “disaster for the world”? — there seems to be a growing consensus that pressure must be placed on China. But how?

headline: Case Study | Will the Real Mai Tai Please Stand Up?
text: In the past, I’ve had a fairly stock cocktailian’s response to the concept of tiki and its representative drinks, those kitschy, oversweetened, unnaturally colored mash-ups of various “tropical” liquors and juices with too many ingredients and too much enforced silliness. Whenever I was asked to produce a mai tai or a planter’s punch, I would follow protocol and dump a number of rums and mixers together — some pineapple, right? And some O.J., sure, and don’t leave out the coconut. …

headline: Cranking it Down a Notch
text: Sometimes — often — an aim of cooking is to maximize flavor, a pretty easy notion to grasp if not always to execute. But another, more elusive, concept is optimizing flavor. This can mean holding back just when your first instinct is to let ’er rip. Here’s an example.

headline: Video Shows Torrents of Sludge in Hungary
text: As my colleague Elisabeth Rosenthal reports, Hungarians are struggling to prevent 185 million gallons of sludge that flooded out of an industrial reservoir on Monday — residue from the production of aluminum — from reaching the Danube.

headline: The Market Believes in QE2
text: For the moment at least. Optimism about Fed action has led both to falling long-term interest rates:

headline: Whitman and Fiorina Won’t Appear With Palin and Steele
text: LOS ANGELES – It’s shaping up as two of the more star-studded Republican events of the fall: Sarah Palin, the former governor of Alaska, and Michael Steele, the head of the Republican National Committee, appearing on the same stage – first in Orange County and the following week in Orlando – at what is being billed as “final path to victory” rallies, intended to raise campaign funds and build enthusiasm among conservatives as Election Day approaches.

headline: Halladay: First Postseason No-Hitter since Don Larsen
text: Roy Halladay threw a masterpiece, and he made it look easy. In his first career postseason start, Halladay threw the first playoff no-hitter since Don Larsen’s perfect game in 1956. Halladay cruised: 104 pitches, 79 strikes, and only three three-ball counts.

headline: God and the Details
text: Via Alan Jacobs, I see that the Immanent Frame has gathered a symposium of religion scholars to discuss the recent Pew Forum findings on American religious literacy — or religious illiteracy, more aptly — which I discussed a little bit in this space. Jacobs flags these comments, from Calvin College’s James K.A. Smith:

headline: Memo Hints at Name Change for MSNBC.com
text: NBC Universal and Microsoft, the parents of MSNBC.com, are holding high-level talks about a name change, something that could be a risky endeavor for the third most popular news Web site in the United States.

headline: New Protections for an Ancient, Ailing Fish
text: The Atlantic sturgeon, an armored, ancient, kayak-size denizen of eastern rivers and coasts, is still ailing despite strict fishing limits, so federal officials on Tuesday proposed giving it protection under the Endangered Species Act. The plan, after a period of public comment, would give endangered or threatened status to five populations of the species grew out of a petition last year by the Natural Resources Defense Council.

headline: Health Care at McDonald’s (Cont.)
text: Aaron Carroll of Indiana University School of Medicine expands on why he thinks the insurance exchanges to be established by the new health care law will give many McDonald’s workers better care for less money:

headline: Workers Not Saving Enough to Get 401(k) Match
text: It’s free money, yet a large percentage of Americans are increasingly leaving it on the table.

headline: Ambac Drops $6.1 Billion in Claims Against Lehman
text: Lehman Brothers said the Ambac Assurance Corporation had agreed to withdraw claims worth more than $6.1 billion against the company as part of a global settlement of a dispute over derivatives, Reuters reports.

headline: The 10 Things to Talk About This Weekend
text: 1. Nobel Prize for Literature announced Thursday, October 7. Philip Roth spends day eyeing telephone, vacuuming.

headline: In Bilbao, It’s Not Just the Museum
text: BETWEEN its Norman Foster subway system, Santiago Calatrava bridge and, of course, Frank Gehry’s magnificent Guggenheim Museum, washed like a titanium-clad shipwreck on the once gritty shores of the Nervión river, Bilbao has undergone a dramatic transformation over the last 15 years.

headline: Bilbao’s New Restaurant Scene
text: Bilbao, Spain is beginning to steal some thunder from nearby San Sebastián.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Hungary and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Hungary, Somalia and France.

headline: Federal Government to Add 100 Electric Cars
text: Last October, President Obama issued an executive order calling on government agencies to reduce their greenhouse gas emissions. Low-hanging fruit for carbon reduction is in the transportation fleet, particularly zero-emission, battery-electric cars, but there aren’t many on the market, and very few federal agencies have acquired them.

headline: Don Hill’s
text: IN a town where hot spots can have the life span of fireflies, the resuscitation of 19-year old Don Hill’s seems an evolutionary marvel. Sure, the drag-punk party Squeezbox faded in 2001, and the still-sizzling Misshapes departed in 2007. But last month the dingy club got a reprieve, thanks to Paul Sevigny and Nur Khan, the nightlife gurus who made their name with the Beatrice Inn. Their formula — no bottle service, a draconian door policy, an illicit air — hasn’t faltered yet.

headline: For ‘Parker Spitzer,’ a Better Second Outing
text: After its rocky start, the pressure was already on CNN’s new prime-time hour “Parker Spitzer.” It had nowhere to go but up — and up it went.

headline: Lee Reprises Role as Postseason Ace for Rangers
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  The Rangers traded for Cliff Lee in July for games in October. And on Wednesday, Lee delivered the type of performance that he displayed a year ago in leading the Phillies to the World Series.

headline: Cold-Case Trial: Two Opposites on Same Side, Facing Down a Killer
text: Last year Michael Connelly took his readers on a slow boat to China. He wrote “Nine Dragons,” a disappointingly flat and gimmicky story featuring his long-suffering Los Angeles police detective, Harry Bosch. Harry’s usual stomping ground is the depraved underbelly of Los Angeles, but “Nine Dragons” sent him on a touristy detour to Hong Kong. It also used one of the detective novel’s cheapest tricks, the kidnapping of someone near and dear to the hero (in this case his schoolgirl daughter) to generate suspense.

headline: Scientists and Soldiers Solve a Bee Mystery
text: DENVER  It has been one of the great murder mysteries of the garden: what is killing off the honeybees?

headline: Continental Sets Date to Start Charging for Food
text: Continental, the last major carrier to offer free meals to its passengers, will start charging most of its domestic economy passengers for food on Oct. 12. First- and business-class passengers will still eat free, as will passengers on many international flights (all intercontinental routes and some others), and on domestic flights of more than six and a half hours.

headline: Model-Morphosis | Hermès
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of Paris Fashion Week. Here, the model Aline Weber from Elite Model Management before (left) and after (right) makeup by Tom Pecheux and hair by Odile Gilbert. (Drag the orange bar left to reveal the full transformation.)

headline: Recipe Redux: The Community Cookbook
text: Six years ago, I decided to write a cookbook that would gather the best New York Times recipes ever. I was sure it was a great idea, because the paper — which began publishing recipes in the 1850s— has been one of the leading voices in the evolution of American food. But it turned out to be a terrible idea logistically, because The Times has published tens of thousands of recipes. So I turned to the paper’s readers — you! — a group of people I barely knew, for help, placing a small author’s query in the Dining section, soliciting readers’ “most stained recipes” from The Times.

headline: 1967: Veal Chops Beau Séjour
text: Lotti Morris from Bennington, Vt., wrote:

headline: Film Producer on a Roll, With Fingers Crossed
text: LOS ANGELES  Young movie producers are a dime a dozen in Hollywood. Sometimes they find a hit movie before they fade back into obscurity. If they’re lucky, they might land two.

headline: The (Mostly Financial) Stars Come Out for ‘Inside Job’
text: A passel of financial stars came to Lincoln Center in Manhattan for a screening of “Inside Job,” the documentary about the origins and consequences of the financial crisis.

headline: West Virginia Sues Over Mountaintop Mining Limits
text: West Virginia says it is filing a lawsuit against two federal agencies that seeks to reverse the stricter controls on mountain-top coal mining adopted in 2009 by the Obama administration.

headline: 'Gatz'
text: More photos from the production at the Public Theater.

headline: Heroes Welcome
text: SO a dog walks into a bar. Honestly, no joke. The dog is a German shepherd and he’s not just any dog, he’s a hero. He’s a shelter dog saved from a pound as a puppy and destined for euthanasia until some alert human spotted a spark in him — some cleverness, some drive — and set in motion a series of events that led to him becoming a search-and-rescue animal. Now he is one of those dogs you sometimes see in the news, snout to the rubble in the wreckage of disasters in Haiti, Sri Lanka, Pakistan, at ground zero.

headline: Miu Miu: Dancing With the Stars
text: The Paris spring shows closed on quite a high as exhausted, sniffling, shuffling editors and buyers saw the collections of Louis Vuitton, Hermès and Miu Miu. On a raised runway, Marc Jacobs seemed to pitch Louis Vuitton to the affluent Asian consumer, or at least acknowledge the considerable influence that China and other Asian countries have on fashion and luxury retailing. Virtually every look seemed dipped in electric-bright colors — fuchsia, red, jade, purple, orange — and then rolled in glitter. The models, their hair smoothed into tight rolls with a flip over one eye, sometimes walked three or four abreast on the catwalk, like shows in the past — and maybe in the future. The clothes, which included a black and white gown with the silhouette of a panda’s head, were tempting for their New World sheen. Mr. Jacobs made his campy point without overdoing it.

headline: Trouble Over a Gelada Baby
text: Friday, Oct. 1

headline: A Printer, Several Computers, Wireless Network. Mix.
text: What do you get when you mix four computers, two operating systems, one printer and a wireless home network? If you are lucky, a convenient way to share the printer among all computers.

headline: Could Liverpool Ownership Squabble Trip Up Reds?
text: The news that the New England Sports Ventures, owner of the Boston Red Sox, agreed to buy the Liverpool Football Club appears to be the penultimate chapter in an intriguing sports-business story that started long before Tom Hicks and George Gillett Jr. went looking for a buyer in April.

headline: A Steadicam for Your iPhone
text: There are few things more foreboding, more memorable, than those ominous Steadicam tracking shots of little Danny Torrance riding his Big Wheel down the long halls of the Overlook Hotel in Stanley Kubrick’s “The Shining.” The way the camera glides smoothly behind him as he pedals his way to freaky twin girls and blood-drenched elevator doors is one of the most enduring shots in all of moviemaking.

headline: From Japan, a Reminder That We Are Dust, and to Dust We Return
text: Butoh, the dance form that developed in Japan in the late 1950s, was at first an approach to, or a philosophy about, movement, rather than a particular style. At early performances audiences were shocked by its dark expressionism, its emphasis on the grotesque, the shaven-headed dancers, white-painted bodies and contorted, eerily slow positions. Today that aesthetic is familiar and beloved, and Butoh’s dreamlike images and pared-down presentation has had a significant effect on Western dance.

headline: The Very Familiar New Jersey of Snooki’s Grandparents
text: Maybe Susan DiLallo and Stephen Weiner just like a challenge. When they wrote the musical comedy “Once Upon a Time in New Jersey” (Ms. DiLallo, book and lyrics; Mr. Weiner music), they started off with a double handicap: they set it not only in a shopworn time period, the 1950s, but also in a shopworn place, New Jersey.

headline: Scorecard | Alexander McQueen Wins!
text: There was a bittersweet symphony in the air on the penultimate day of Paris Fashion Week, and not just on the sound system at the Grand Palais. Which was probably as good foreshadowing as any that on this rather momentous day of untimely debuts, returns to Marienbad, 40th-anniversary retrospectives and sweet reconciliations, Scorecard notes that for the first time ever no designer missed the cut — but a very talented right-hand woman took flight.

headline: Fledgling Musicians Spread Their Wings
text: The annual Carnegie Hall performances by the young musicians from the Sphinx Organization are always illuminating, not only because they are the fruits of an inspiring program, but also because the performances are invariably energetic and finely burnished. Sphinx, which is based in Detroit and was started in 1996 by Aaron P. Dworkin, a violinist, is dedicated to getting black and Hispanic students involved in classical music, mainly by training them to play and compose but also through music history courses that help produce informed listeners.

headline: Israeli Group Set to Play in Bayreuth
text: The Israel Chamber Orchestra plans to play a concert next summer in Bayreuth, Germany, the city most associated with Richard Wagner, whose music is taboo in the Jewish state because of its embrace by Hitler and because of the composer’s noted anti-Semitism.

headline: The Caucus Click: New Orleans
text: The Bible of Reverend Bobby Cromier rested next to a poster for Cedric Richmond, the Democratic nominee for Louisiana’s Second District.

headline: Live Analysis: Yankees Win Game 1, 6-4
text: The Yankees beat the Minnesota Twins, 6-4, in Game 1 of their American League division series at Target Field in Minneapolis.

headline: Spring, Fashion’s Operatic Season
text: PARIS

headline: The Porter Will Kindly Show You to Your Doom
text: Arriving just in time for haunted house season is “Hotel Savoy,” a site-specific theater piece by Dominic Huber presented by P.S. 122 in association with the Goethe-Institut on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, smack opposite the Metropolitan Museum. Inspired by the Austrian writer Joseph Roth’s 1924 novel of the same name, the work is essentially a solo performance with a few minor supporting characters. The soloist — surprise! — is you.

headline: N.R.C.C. Moves to Secure Million-Dollar Loan
text: A bank loan is not always the mark of trouble. At the end of a political race, it can be a sign of opportunity.

headline: With Dresser, G.E.’s Just Getting Started
text: 6:00 p.m. | Updated General Electric executives have said for months that they would start spending the billions of dollars in cash that the company has been accumulating. That time, it seems, has now come.

headline: TV’s Future Has Arrived (Almost)
text: Americans used to gather in front of their TV sets on, say, Thursday at 8 p.m. and tune in to Channel 3. The upside: the whole country had a common cultural bond.

headline: Crazy Juice, ‘Made with Real DeMint’
text: Are you “crazy” about political advertisements this election cycle? Then check out this new video, released on Wednesday by the campaign of Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid of Nevada and uploaded to his YouTube channel. Our favorite line: “Made with real DeMint,” an allusion to Senator Jim DeMint, the South Carolina Republican who has endorsed Mr. Reid’s Republican opponent, Sharron Angle, a former Nevada assemblywoman. In two words: Crazy Juice. But watch and see for yourself.

headline: Guarded Pals in a Critical TV Rivalry
text: “Welcome to 8,” read the Twitter message from Dan Harmon, an executive producer of “Community,” to Bill Prady, his counterpart on “The Big Bang Theory.”

headline: Newly Discovered Ted Hughes Poem Is Read on British Television
text: The poet Ted Hughes has always been somewhat overshadowed by his estranged wife Sylvia Plath, whose 1963 suicide at 30 continues to fascinate. That pattern continues even after his death with the discovery of a previously unknown poem he wrote about the night of Plath’s suicide. A version of the poem was read on the evening newscast in Britain Wednesday night by Jonathan Pryce, The Guardian of London reported.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Louis Vuitton
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Kava Gorna.

headline: Drug Arrest for Man Involved in Fatal Game in 1994
text: In 1994, a 12-year-old boy named Ronald Herron was playing cops-and-robbers in the Gowanus Houses in Brooklyn when a 13-year-old friend carrying a toy rifle was fatally shot on a staircase by a police officer.

headline: Bleaching Hits Caribbean Corals
text: Widespread coral bleaching caused by abnormally high sea temperatures is hitting reefs throughout the Caribbean, according to reports from field researchers in the region. It’s just the latest development in what is shaping to be one of the worst years on record for the world’s coral reefs.

headline: Emanuel vs. Bloomberg: Facebook Faceoff
text: Who’s got more Facebook friends, Rahm Emanuel or Michael R. Bloomberg?

headline: A Maverick Conjures Up Some Favorite Madmen
text: The organist Cameron Carpenter began his late-night concert at Le Poisson Rouge on Tuesday in his preferred manner, mingling with the crowd beforehand and dressed in atypical organist fashion: a bowler hat, black velvet trousers, blue socks, bow tie and a white shirt with glitter on the shoulders.

headline: Facebook Now Lets You Take Your Data With You
text: Facebook did something bold today. The world’s largest social network now lets members download all the information they’ve ever uploaded into Facebook — their Wall, photos, videos, friends, messages, events and notes — into a Zip file that can be browsed, for example, to see every photo ever uploaded from your account.

headline: Recovering Changes From Microsoft Word
Lightens My Sadness, She Livens My Days
text: Time warps, time lines and time signatures: as John Pizzarelli crooned Irving Berlin’s “Count Your Blessings” with the tenderness of a father lulling a sleepless child, the voice of his wife and musical partner, Jessica Molaskey, slipped in behind him to sing Jonathan Larson’s “Seasons of Love,” from the musical “Rent.”

headline: F.T.C. Accuses Tax Relief Company of Empty Promises
text: WASHINGTON  Who wouldn’t like to settle with the Internal Revenue Service for pennies on the dollar?

headline: Shedding Some Light on ‘Darkness’
text: A lot of motives might have been at play in “The Promise: The Making of ‘Darkness on the Edge of Town’ ”: nostalgia, vanity, a desire for documentation or benediction. One thing that’s undoubtedly on display, though, is bravery.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: A Computer That Could Drive a Car
text: Researchers at Yale and New York University have developed a supercomputer based on the human visual system. On this week’s Tech Talk podcast from The New York Times, Bettina Edelstein speaks with Eugenio Culurciello, an associate professor of electrical engineering at Yale who has helped create this supercomputer. He says it could someday allow a car to drive itself. Embedded on a single chip, the system runs more than 100 billion operations a second using only a few watts, which Mr. Culurciello says is less power than a cellphone uses. Other potential applications, he says, include motion monitors in assisted living facilities that could summon help should an elderly person fall and all-around vision for soldiers in the battlefield.

headline: As Yankees’ Most Valuable Repairman, Long Revives Struggling Hitters
text: MINNEAPOLIS  The University of Arizona baseball team in 1989 was flush with major league talent. Trevor Hoffman started at shortstop. J.T. Snow patrolled first base. The Wildcats’ ace was Scott Erickson. But the leader of the team was a 5-foot-7 center fielder named Kevin Long, whom everyone gravitated toward.

headline: Mixed Pairs Title Decided, And Fantoni Is Back on Top
text: PHILADELPHIA  The winners of the World Mixed Pairs here on Monday were Donna Compton of Dallas and Fulvio Fantoni from Italy. They nearly failed to qualify for the final three sessions, needing a near-top on the last board to get in. But with no carryover, they played consistently, having session scores of 56.34, 58.34 and 58.45 percent.

headline: Specter to Campaign for Sestak
text: Senator Arlen Specter, Democrat of Pennsylvania, is expected to appear on Monday alongside the man who defeated him in the party’s primary, Representative Joe Sestak.

headline: Shopping With Katie Lydon
text: The British-born interior designer searched for trays, some pretty, others rough-edged.

headline: L.A. Design Store Eccola Grows as it Moves
text: In the six years since Kathleen White Almanza and her husband, Maurizio, opened the first Eccola, a Los Angeles store specializing in midcentury modern furnishings from Italy, they’ve moved twice, expanding and remodeling each time. “We have an affinity for gutting,” said Ms. Almanza, a former set decorator. The newest incarnation is a 4,500-square-foot space in a 1916 garage on Beverly Boulevard. “We took it down to what it was, which was pretty glorious: old cement floors, gorgeous brick walls and huge windows,” she said. “We added eight skylights.”

headline: Standard 41 Introduces a Line of ‘Taibles’ and Seating
text: Taible is a new line of tables and seating from Andrew Raible, of Standard 41, a “midcentury influenced furniture design” company in Brooklyn “with a 21st-century environmental approach,” founded in 2006. “I grew up having dinner at a table my father designed and built,” said Mr. Raible, a sixth-generation woodworker. “I love the idea of tables and the community they create. Hopefully, they stimulate conversation.” The first three pieces are the All Y’all dining table with 24-karat gold corners (inspired by a talk with a Dallas interior designer who wanted “bigger tables with more bling”); the Il Palio walnut side table; and the Train to Dijon table (above, with matching chair and bench), which tilts 12 degrees and looks as if it might topple over. “I wouldn’t mind if people smiled at the design,” he said.

headline: New From Dempsey & Carroll, Stationery by John Derian
text: Fans of John Derian’s Old World patterns on découpaged dishes and paperweights can now share the designer’s graphics with friends. Working with Dempsey & Carroll, the stationery company, Mr. Derian has selected six designs from his archives and his current collection to decorate a line of cards and envelopes.

headline: In Texas, an Artist Plans to Rotate a House 180 Degrees
text: Sometime later this month, Mary Ellen Carroll, a conceptual artist who has been lecturing for the last few years at Rice University’s school of architecture, will oversee the 180-degree rotation of a small one-story house in the Houston suburb of Sharpstown, a once-prosperous postwar planned community that has suffered economic reversals. The project, “prototype 180,” will be streamed live on the Web.

headline: A Student’s New Screen Evokes Waves and Gains Acclaim
text: The wavelike shape of the Phenomena screen may call to mind water, but Sang Hoon Kim, the designer, said his inspiration was actually the way that light moves over time. “I wanted to bring that phenomenon into the home,” he said, by creating undulating ribs that would reflect light at many different angles.

headline: Trays
text: KATIE LYDON, a British-born interior designer living in New York, likes to have a lot of trays around the house  and not just for entertaining.

headline: Sales at Mxyplyzyk, Elegant Setting and BoConcept
text: The Elegant Setting, a tabletop and gift store in Southampton, N.Y., is having a fall clearance to Oct. 30, with most items up to 50 percent off (frames in leather, mother-of-pearl and silver, originally $60 to $235, are $30 to $120; and glass and crystal vases, formerly $80 to $300, are $40 to $150); 31 Main Street (Walnut Street), Southampton, N.Y., (631) 283-4747 or theelegantsetting.com.

headline: A Seed Library for Heirloom Plants Thrives in the Hudson Valley
text: AS a child, Peg Lotvin used to watch her father, Hank, head out into his garden every fall on a mission. After setting aside part of the bean harvest for his neighbor Flossy, who was reputed to make the best baked beans in all of Ghent, in New York’s Hudson Valley, he would select the largest, heartiest beans from the crop and put them up to plant the next year.

headline: What Did They Ever Do to This Guy? Creator of Weezer Breakup Campaign Explains Himself
text: Why would anyone try to raise $10 million for the sole purpose of persuading Weezer to break up? In a telephone interview on Wednesday evening, James Burns, the architect of the Web-based fund-raising drive covered earlier on ArtsBeat, explained the motivation for what he admitted was a “silly” campaign.

headline: A London Home Makes the Most of an Odd-Shaped Plot
text: An architect with a talent for maximizing space and a limited budget created his own northeast London home.

headline: In London, a Big Idea Fit for a Tiny Lot
text: London

headline: A Log Home in Chapel Hill
text: The sculptor Patrick Dougherty says his first artwork was his house in North Carolina, handmade from old barn timber, fallen trees and rocks that he dug from the ground.

headline: Building With Sticks and Stones
text: CHAPEL HILL, N.C.

headline: Israel Braces for Ahmadinejad Stone-Throwing
text: Hezbollah’s television station, Al Manar TV, reports that Iranian President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad hopes to find time during a visit to Lebanon next week to throw a rock at Israel.

headline: Women on the Verge of a Big Broadway Gamble
text: IN the world according to “Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown,” the new Broadway musical about love and abandonment in 1980s Madrid, the gazpacho is laced with Valium, the boyfriends are cads and terrorists, and theater royalty, Patti LuPone, is in full diva glory. Playing a jilted wife fresh from 19 years in an insane asylum, Ms. LuPone glowed in platinum blonde curls and oversize jewels at a recent rehearsal  a wigged-out kinswoman of her Tony Award-winning characters in “Evita” and “Gypsy.” And her opening lines in the show’s first number, appropriately titled “My Crazy Heart,” set the tenor of the show to come.

headline: Today Show | College Recruiting
text: New York Times reporter Jacques Steinberg and Grinnell College's Dean of Admissions, Seth Allen, discuss recruiting tours by college admissions officers on the Today Show.

headline: Stricter Labeling for Green Products
text: Manufacturers will face stricter rules on how to advertise products that claim to be eco-friendly under a proposal from the Federal Trade Commission, our colleague Tanzina Vega reports.

headline: Rolfing, Excruciatingly Helpful
text: A FORMER dancer of 14 years, Anna Zahn is in touch with her body. To gain more flexibility, and to counteract some of the strain from dancing, she has tried a number of remedies: Reiki, acupuncture, yoga.

headline: 'Time Stands Still'
text: Laura Linney and Brian D'Arcy James in an excerpt from the Broadway play. (Video courtesy of the Manhattan Theater Club)

headline: 2 Stars for a Brooklyn Grocery Kitchen
text: It may not have the opulence of Adour Alain Ducasse or the pedigree of L’Atelier de Joël Robuchon. But the Chef’s Table at Brooklyn Fare  an 18-seat bar and open kitchen inside a Boerum Hill grocery store  has something neither of those places has: two stars from the new Michelin Guide to New York, making it that book’s highest-rated restaurant outside Manhattan.

headline: Washington’s Fresh Coat of Greasepaint
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Soldier Killed Saving Comrades Is Awarded the Medal of Honor
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama awarded the Medal of Honor posthumously on Wednesday to a Green Beret who died to save his fellow soldiers in a pitched battle with insurgents in Afghanistan last year, the latest in a series of such tributes at a time of domestic debate about the war.

headline: The Spoils of Happiness
text: In 1974, Robert Nozick, a precocious young philosopher at Harvard, scooped “The Matrix”:

headline: Inside Old Hickory’s Curio Cabinet
text: WHEN the set designer Donyale Werle began work on the Broadway production of the musical “Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson,” a hybrid of emo-rock concert and anachronistic history lesson about America’s controversial seventh president, she decided it should be performed in a mash-up environment that matched the genre-bending vision of the show’s writer and director, Alex Timbers, and its composer, Michael Friedman.

headline: Steered Into the Kitchen, Thanks to Mom
text: William Patrick Harrison was cooking scrambled eggs with freshly snipped home-grown chives by age 8, though at that stage of his culinary education his mother supervised his use of scissors. Two degrees from the Culinary Institute of America later, Mr. Harrison, 23, totes his own self-sharpened knives to his job as a line cook at the River Café in Brooklyn. He lives with his parents in Glendale, Queens.

headline: As Paladino Spends on Campaign, He Often Earns, Too
text: If Carl P. Paladino comes up short in his run for governor against Andrew M. Cuomo, he will not have thrown his money away. At least not all of it.

headline: Galleon Wiretap Application Under Scrutiny
text: By PETER LATTMAN

headline: Father and Son Found Guilty of Tax Evasion
text: A federal jury in Florida convicted a father and son on Wednesday of hiding a $33 million hotel sale from federal tax authorities while living a lavish lifestyle.

headline: For Cyclists in Tuscany, Winning Isn’t the Point
text: GAIOLE IN CHIANTI, Italy  On the first Sunday of October, almost 3,500 cyclists took to the hills of central Tuscany, riding vintage bicycles, wearing woolen knits and old-fashioned goggles and eating bread and prosciutto.

headline: Drug Maker From China Pleads Guilty
text: GeneScience Pharmaceutical, a Chinese company, and its chief executive pleaded guilty on Wednesday to federal charges of illegally distributing human growth hormone in the United States, capping a three-year investigation.

headline: In New Realm, In Command
text: PHILADELPHIA  During each half inning when he was not pitching on Wednesday, Roy Halladay sat alone in the tunnel behind the Phillies’ dugout and watched his teammates bat on a television monitor. And each time he walked past the pitching coach Rich Dubee, who could see as well as anyone the brilliance that was unfolding on the mound when Halladay was on it, Dubee provided the same insight and tactical suggestions.

headline: Web Site to Offer Health Advice, Some of It From Marketers
text: THE expression “sharing is caring” was coined long before the Internet and social media like Facebook and Twitter made it easier for information, opinions and advertising to be shared among multitudes.

headline: Rampant Fraud Threat to China’s Brisk Ascent
text: BEIJING — No one disputes Zhang Wuben’s talents as a salesman. Through television shows, DVDs and a best-selling book, he convinced millions of people that raw eggplant and immense quantities of mung beans could cure lupus, diabetes, depression and cancer.

headline: Paying Homage to Japan’s Raw Edges
text: “THE eye adjusts,” as fashion people say, a truism routinely exploited in defense of styles so extreme that they often affront conventional tastes. It took some adjusting indeed to digest and assimilate the groundbreaking trends spawned in Japan in the early 1980s  a period of fashion revolt that ushered in radical innovations like breastplates and street-sweeping skirts.

headline: Unusual Opposition to a Favorite for Nobel
text: BEIJING — With just a day until the Nobel Peace Prize is awarded, the usual whirl of speculation over the winner is in full force, with many human rights advocates contending that an imprisoned Chinese dissident, Liu Xiaobo, has emerged as the favorite.

headline: Cathy Horyn's Paris Fashion Week Report
text: Cathy Horyn discusses many of the standout spring 2011 collections.

headline: Brutality in Congo: Who Can Stop It?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Literature’s Path, From Writer to Reader
text: To the Editor:

headline: Ex-Variety Critic McCarthy Lands at Hollywood Reporter
text: LOS ANGELES — Todd McCarthy, fired as Variety’s chief film critic seven months ago, has landed — again. Shortly after losing his longstanding job with Variety in a round of cost-cutting last March, Mr. McCarthy joined the IndieWire network of blogs with his newly formed Web site, Todd McCarthy’s Deep Focus. But Mr. McCarthy is now jumping to the revamped Hollywood Reporter, to join a team being assembled by its new editorial director, Janice Min.

headline: MSNBC.com May Change Its Name
text: NBC Universal and Microsoft, the parents of msnbc.com, are holding high-level talks about changing its name, an unusual and potentially risky endeavor for the third most popular news Web site in the United States.

headline: Stronger Hezbollah Emboldened for Fights Ahead
text: AITA AL SHAAB, Lebanon  It was from this shrub-ringed border town that Hezbollah instigated its war with Israel in 2006, and supporters of the militant Shiite movement sound almost disappointed that they have not fought since.

headline: Beauty Spots
text: YOU LOOK HAPPY For those fed up with cocoa butter, there is this news: Swiss Skin Repair, a company founded by Beatrice De Borg, the former Swiss model, and Dr. Howard T. Bellin, a plastic surgeon, has a new Scar and Stretch Mark Body Cream featuring extract of edelweiss (left), which the company claims will enhance absorption and provide an impressive filling effect. The cream, which is $165, can be found at swissskinrepair.com.

headline: A Punch to the Breadbasket as Nebraska Begins a Farewell
text: MANHATTAN, Kan.  The Nebraska Cornhuskers have been making the two-and-a-half-hour trek due south here for nearly a century. Generations of players have looked out the bus windows at the browns and golds of the tabletop plains. They watched Beatrice, Neb., give way to Marysville, Kan., before finally arriving at the home of one their oldest rivals, the Kansas State Wildcats.

headline: Bloggingheads: Machines vs. Migrants
text: Sister Simone Campbell, left, of NETWORK and Mark Krikorian of the Center for Immigration Studies debate migrant farm labor.

headline: Christie’s Silence Spurs Worry for Train Tunnel
text: In his first several months as New Jersey’s governor, Chris Christie made it clear that he intended to cut the state’s budget in ways that might surprise and upset some residents. But one big project  a train tunnel to Manhattan projected to cost $8.7 billion  appeared safe.

headline: Bear Hunt Training, Minus the Bear
text: TRAVELERS REST, S.C.  Later this month, camouflage-clad hunters and packs of dogs will set off across the densely forested foothills and rushing creeks here in western South Carolina for an age-old rite of fall: bear-hunting season.

headline: Teachers Make Mark on Midterms
text: The two most powerful teachers’ unions are putting millions behind Democratic candidates around the country even though their members have railed against President Obama’s education policies.

headline: Gay Teenagers’ Suicides, and a Call for Legislation
text: To the Editor:

headline: New York Is Yours for the Taking
text: Would you like to break into my apartment right now?

headline: Lottery Numbers
‘Torture’ for Giants Becomes Triumph
text: SAN FRANCISCO  As the San Francisco Giants crept toward a playoff berth, signs held aloft by fans would appear at their ballpark with a command: end the torture.

headline: Election Day Foretold
text: You won! What a nice run of the House, with a big enough Republican cushion to free the more pumped-up partisans to hold investigations of Obama’s birth certificate. Let them throw steak scraps at the base, while the rest of you restore Wall Street, the insurance industry and Karl Rove to their rightful places in power.

headline: At Yale, Anger Over Tactics Used in Raid of Off-Campus Party
text: NEW HAVEN  It was well after midnight, and the invitation-only party for Yale University undergraduates was reaching a peak. In the upscale nightclub Elevate, not far from campus, more than 100 students in semiformal attire were on the dance floor as Journey’s “Don’t Stop Believing” pulsed over the sound system. In a throwback to childhood, a buffet table held platters of chicken nuggets and French fries.

headline: Women in Management
text: To the Editor:

headline: Facebook Lets Users Interact in Small Groups
text: PALO ALTO, Calif.  Facebook is trying to become a bit more like the real world.

headline: Run for a Seat Thought Safe Turns Into a Battle
text: CHARLESTON, W.Va. — Gov. Joe Manchin III, the Democratic candidate for the Senate here, could barely contain his frustration during an interview at the Capitol.

headline: Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn, 6:50 P.M.
text: Pancho the tire-shop dog, ever vigilant.

headline: Better Than Perfect? No-Hitter in Playoff Debut
text: PHILADELPHIA  In a glass case at Citizens Bank Park is a bronze cast of Roy Halladay’s right hand. It holds an official baseball, stamped with a hologram, commemorating his perfect game this May.

headline: Fiscal Woes Deepening for Cities, Report Says
text: The nation’s cities are in their worst fiscal shape in at least a quarter of a century and have probably not yet hit the bottom of their slide, according to a report released on Wednesday.

headline: Waivers Aim at Talk of Dropping Health Coverage
text: As Obama administration officials put into place the first major wave of changes under the health care legislation, they have tried to defuse stiffening resistance  from companies like McDonald’s and some insurers  by granting dozens of waivers to maintain even minimal coverage far below the new law’s standards.

headline: Runners and Rallies Will Not Share Toilets
text: WASHINGTON  The Marine Corps Marathon here bills itself as “the people’s marathon.” As the largest marathon in the world that does not offer prize money, it expects a field of 30,000 runners for this year’s race, on Oct. 31.

headline: Democrats in Tight Races Put Focus on Abortion Rights
text: DENVER  Republicans have won points with many voters by promising a conservative overhaul of taxes and spending, but Democrats are working hard in the closing weeks of the campaign to convince voters that a conservative social agenda is waiting in the wings, too, should Republicans be elected in large numbers.

headline: Stem Cell Research
text: To the Editor:

headline: Playoffs Replay: Oct. 6
text: A look at the day in sports, which was dominated by the baseball playoffs, which in turn were dominated by a pair of starting pitchers.

headline: Whiplash Can Follow a Car Crash or a Wedding Announcement
text: Teaneck, N.J.

headline: Port Oversight Again an Issue After Charges of Smuggling
text: Workers at the bustling New York-New Jersey port  including the eight longshoreman who were arrested Tuesday on cocaine-smuggling charges  are licensed by an obscure agency that is supposed to ensure that only people of good character find work there.

headline: Opening Night: A Walk on the Beach
text: A minister, a publisher and a pundit walked into a bar. That’s no joke. That’s opening night at Southfork Kitchen, a night that was neither the rousing climax of a year’s work nor the punch line to a funny story. Opening night was, I kid you not, as smooth as mackerel skin. No drama, no calamities, no fireworks. It went as planned.

headline: U.S. Tries to Calm Pakistan Over Airstrike
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration scrambled to halt a sharp deterioration in its troubled relationship with Pakistan on Wednesday, offering Pakistani officials multiple apologies for a helicopter strike on a border post that killed three Pakistani soldiers last week.

headline: With Higher Fares Ahead, M.T.A. May Spare Drivers
text: Barring a last-minute miracle, the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority will vote on Thursday to raise fares for the region’s subway, bus, and commuter-rail passengers. The biggest burden will be placed on 30-day unlimited MetroCard users, who will be asked to pay $104 a month, up from $89, a 17 percent increase.

headline: Missing Woman Found Dead in Vehicle Near Police Building
text: The body of a pregnant woman who had been missing for more than a week was found in the Bronx on Tuesday night in a vehicle parked outside a building used by the New York Police Department.

headline: The Seat Not Taken
text: AT least twice a week I ride Amtrak’s high-speed Acela train from my home in New York City to my teaching job in Providence, R.I. The route passes through a region of the country populated by, statistics tell us, a significant segment of its most educated, affluent, sophisticated and enlightened citizens.

headline: A Weekend in Rome
text: After years of hitting snooze, this ancient city might just be waking up.

headline: 36 Hours in Rome
text: ROME is the city that oversleeps. Unlike other European cultural capitals, this glorious jumble of history and art changes slowly. But lately, Rome has welcomed some new sparkle. A futuristic museum in the historic center has added color to the city’s architectural scene. Around town young chefs are experimenting with local ingredients to create new tastes. Even old palazzos have been given makeovers. After years of hitting snooze, this ancient city might just be waking up.

headline: Portis May Miss Six Weeks, Leaving Redskins Thin in Backfield
text: Clinton Portis, Washington’s two-time Pro Bowl running back, will be out at least a month with a groin injury, putting his future in doubt once again.

headline: Thursday: Coming Unclued
text: If it’s a Thursday and it’s a Blindauer, odds are it’s tricky. It certainly was today.

headline: Before Auction, Lennon Has Brush With the F.B.I.
text: John Lennon has been dead for 30 years, but the Federal Bureau of Investigation is still on the case.

headline: Escaped Predator? What Else Is New?
text: A big cat is actually on the prowl in “Tigers Be Still,” an endearing new play by Kim Rosenstock, but nobody’s paying much attention to this alarming problem. A fiercer foe is the grief clawing at the hearts of all the characters, whose afflictions come in many stripes, from debilitating illness to a mother’s death to a father’s abandonment. The possibility of being eaten by a wild animal might be greeted with indifference, if not actually welcomed, by the benumbed, bewildered and bedridden characters in this quirk-addicted but heartfelt comedy.

headline: Borne Back Ceaselessly Into the Past
text: The most compelling love affair being conducted on a New York stage this season isn’t between a man and woman. (Or a man and a man, a woman and a woman or a boy and a horse.) It is between a man and a book.

headline: Devils’ Roster Is Thin
text: To squeeze under the N.H.L.’s salary cap, the Devils will take a 20-man roster, the league minimum, into their regular-season opener Friday at home against the Dallas Stars. The league approved the Devils’ roster, which does not include defensemen Bryce Salvador, who was placed on long-term injured reserve with a concussion, and Anssi Salmela, who had knee surgery and was designated as an injured nonroster player.

headline: Heat’s Wade Recovering
text: The Miami Heat star guard Dwyane Wade’s right hamstring remains sore, and he says he’s undergoing treatment to try to get back on the court as soon as possible.

headline: A Room With a View (of Art) for the Night
text: CHEAP pod hotels, homey B & Bs, chic design-forward dens and modern business chains all provide shelter to their respective demographics. But a new batch of hotels in Europe appeals to a high-minded psychographic, doling out the keys to local culture related to literature, art, theater or history — both in their designs and in their locations. Whether it is Stalin-era art and architecture, Portuguese music, Turkish history, Parisian literature or the London stage, if you’re bound for Europe for culture, check-in at one of these newcomers affords instant access.

headline: A Finnish City Prepares for the Limelight
text: “LIFE ON A LEAF,” a whimsical yellow house that sits in a wooded park at the edge of Turku in southern Finland, is a lopsided construction with a bright red, blue and green roof and a leaf-shaped floor plan. Inside, it’s even wackier: curved walls, windows in the shape of teardrops, and a catwalk with a tiny video screen embedded in the floor that shows an endless loop of antlike commuters rushing through Grand Central Terminal in New York.

headline: Joining the Locals In Paris’s East
text: In the 20th Arrondissement of Paris, the action for residents is off Rue de Ménilmontant.

headline: Real Estate Collapse Spells Havoc in Dubai
text: DUBAI  On a sultry June evening in 2007, more than 100 people camped out at the offices of Emaar, a prestigious Dubai property developer, to ensure that they would land a coveted spot in a gleaming new skyscraper scheduled to open this year near the Burj Khalifa, the world’s tallest building.

headline: Strategies Clear in Florida Senate Debate
text: The three men competing to be Florida’s next United States senator all said the same thing, over and over, in their debate tonight: “I’m the only candidate at this table who…”

headline: Bright Spots for N.H.L. As the Season Opens
