text: The N.H.L. season opens Thursday on the heels of an electrifying Olympic tournament, the continuing rise of charismatic young stars and a third straight postseason dominated by teams from hockey-steeped American cities. There will be challenges, but rather than symptoms of a league’s struggles, they seem to be signs of growing strength.

headline: Passionate Fight Over Obama’s Former Seat
text: VILLA PARK, Ill.  The prospect of seizing the United States Senate seat here, the one that once belonged to President Obama, is so delicious to Republicans that a party leader found himself dreaming aloud in this Chicago suburb one recent afternoon.

headline: Beyond the Usual Stanley Cup Contenders
text: When it comes to Stanley Cup favorites, there are always the usual suspects. After all, the Blackhawks still have Jonathan Toews, Patrick Kane, Duncan Keith and Marian Hossa; the Penguins’ Sidney Crosby and Evgeni Malkin may skate on the same line; and the Capitals’ Nicklas Backstrom and Mike Green can still pump in the few shots Alex Ovechkin doesn’t take. And who would dismiss the Red Wings’ Henrik Zetterberg and Pavel Datsyuk?

headline: Motorola Sues Apple Over 18 Patents
text: A Motorola unit filed three lawsuits and a trade complaint against Apple, contending the maker of the iPad computer tablet and iPhone mobile phone is infringing 18 of its patents.

headline: Revis vs. Moss: Round 2 Is Monday Night
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  For the most part, the Jets reacted with a shrug Wednesday to the trade that sent Randy Moss to Minnesota. They had plans to play the Vikings anyway on Monday night.

headline: Ex-Diplomat Who Advised Kurds Gets Millions in Oil Deal
text: A British court has awarded between $55 million and $75 million to Peter W. Galbraith, the former United States diplomat who advised the Kurds during the negotiations on Iraq’s Constitution, and a Yemeni investor for their stake in a widely criticized oil deal involving Iraq’s rich northern fields, the oil company ordered to pay the award said Wednesday.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,302 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: New York Asks to Bar Use of Food Stamps to Buy Sodas
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg sought federal permission on Wednesday to bar New York City’s 1.7 million recipients of food stamps from using them to buy soda or other sugared drinks.

headline: Republicans See a Political Motive in I.R.S. Audits
text: WASHINGTON  With growing scrutiny of the role of tax-exempt groups in political campaigns, Congressional Republicans are pushing back against Democrats by warning about the possible misuse of the Internal Revenue Service to audit conservative groups.

headline: Eyes Are on Stoudemire as Knicks Conclude Tour
text: PARIS  Amar’e Stoudemire left the Palais Omnisports late Wednesday in a suit, shirt, tie, scarf and knit cap, which was one suit, shirt, tie, scarf and knit cap more than he was wearing when he set the sports world abuzz.

headline: Sherman J. Maisel, Former Fed Governor, Dies at 92
text: Sherman J. Maisel, an economist and former Federal Reserve governor whose research on housing markets shaped decades of federal policy on mortgages, died on Sept. 29 in San Francisco. He was 92.

headline: Ad for Attorney General Echoes an Old Opponent
text: Introduce yourself. Question your opponent. Borrow from a former opponent turned supporter: Eric T. Schneiderman, the Democratic nominee for attorney general, did all three in the space of 30 seconds on Wednesday.

headline: Deportations From U.S. Hit a Record High
text: Immigration authorities deported a record 392,862 immigrants over the last year, Homeland Security Secretary Janet Napolitano said Wednesday.

headline: Coal Plant Would Get New Controls
text: The Environmental Protection Agency signaled on Wednesday that it would require a New Mexico power plant, one of the largest coal-fired ones in the nation, to install $717 million in pollution controls to curb emissions that spread haze over the Four Corners region of the Southwest, home to national parks like Mesa Verde.

headline: Agency Acts to Ease Delay of Pills for Elderly
text: The Drug Enforcement Administration has issued a new guideline intended to help ease the delay some nursing home residents face in receiving certain painkillers and anti-anxiety medications.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Shareholders Applaud G.E.’s Shopping Spree
text: General Electric’s shareholders seem curiously overjoyed to see the conglomerate back in shopping mode. The company added $4.2 billion to G.E.’s market cap on Wednesday, when it spent $3 billion on an energy infrastructure business, confirmed its interest in a British maker of oil pipes and snapped up some of Citigroup’s more questionable loans. It is a shift from years on the defensive, selling assets. But the celebration looks overdone.

headline: Trifecta of Torment
text: We journalists tend to cover politics the way we cover sports:

headline: Connecticut on the Ropes
text: HARTFORD

headline: Lamentable Speech
text: To the American Nazi Party, Hustler Magazine, and other odious figures in Supreme Court history, add the Rev. Fred Phelps Sr. and the members of the Westboro Baptist Church in Topeka, Kan. Their antigay protests at the funeral of a soldier slain in Iraq were deeply repugnant but protected by the First Amendment.

headline: Haiti: U.S. Adds $120 Million in Aid
text: Six months after the Haiti Recovery Fund was established to help the earthquake-shattered country, the United States announced Wednesday that it had signed an agreement to contribute $120 million to the fund. The long-awaited American contribution will nearly double the assets of the fund, which is only one source of reconstruction financing. Although the United States spent more than $1 billion in humanitarian aid to Haiti after the earthquake, it has been slow to honor its pledge to the recovery fund as well as its overall promise of $1.15 billion in reconstruction money. Announcing the contribution at the third meeting of Haiti’s reconstruction commission, Cheryl Mills, chief of staff to Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton, said that the United States preferred that 75 percent go toward rubble removal and housing repairs.

headline: They Need to Talk
text: Peace talks between Israelis and Palestinians are in danger of unraveling unless Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, show more political courage and sense.

headline: Retrenchment, by the Numbers
text: “No more stimulus” has become the destructive mantra of conservative politicians here and across Europe. Britain has vowed to cut the budget of most government departments by 25 percent to 40 percent over the next four years. Germany’s government has adopted its own slash-and-burn austerity plan.

headline: Why Firemen Let That House Burn Down
text: No amount of political ranting about limits to government could douse the flames for a homeowner in rural Tennessee who forgot to pay his annual surcharge for fire department protection. Gene Cranick watched his house burn down in Obion County after firefighters from the nearby town of South Fulton arrived. They declined to turn their hoses on because his $75 fee for county residents had not been paid.

headline: Senegal’s Changing Urban Landscape
text: Updated | Dec. 13, 10:30 a.m.

headline: No Food Stamps for Sodas
text: SINCE its introduction in 1964, America’s food stamp program has helped millions of struggling Americans put food on their tables in difficult times. During the recent economic downturn, the number of people in New York City receiving this assistance has grown more than 35 percent.

headline: Word of the Day | rummage
text: rummage •\ˈrə-mij\• verb and noun

headline: Expensive Questions on Giants’ Roster
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The Giants will not be required to announce their roster for the division series against the Braves until 1 p.m. Eastern on Thursday. But one of the big questions in recent days is whether the Giants’ three highest-paid players will be on it.

headline: G.E.: A Buyer Once More
text: General Electric marked its return to the takeover track with its first major deals since the start of the financial crisis, with G.E. executives suggesting that more are likely to follow in the coming months, Reuters writes.

headline: Nets Show the Way From M.S.G. to Newark
text: Terrence Williams stood outside Madison Square Garden on Wednesday, in the heart of Knicks territory, an act the Nets hope their fans will soon follow on their way to Newark.

headline: Smaller Firms Could Have Taken on Soured Assets
text: The Treasury Department‘s program to soak up soured mortgage assets may have unnecessarily excluded smaller, well-qualified fund managers to the detriment of taxpayers, a U.S. bailout watchdog said on Thursday, Reuters reports.

headline: Yankees Take Game 1 of A.L. Division
text: The Yankees overcame the Twins’ early lead in Game 1 of the American League division series to win, 6-4.

headline: With Rally, Yankees Prevail Once Again
text: MINNEAPOLIS  Fans rushed through the right-field gates at Target Field when they opened Wednesday evening, the new ballpark radiant and glistening for its playoff debut. It was a symbol of a new era  the move to an open-air palace from a dome, to a pitcher-friendly stadium from a hitters’ haven  and that, at least, was the Minnesota Twins’ hope entering another series against their postseason nemesis.

headline: World Bank and I.M.F. at Odds Over Hot Money
text: Emerging economies should consider steps to contain fund flows that could cause currency rallies and asset bubbles, the World Bank chief was quoted as saying, but the International Monetary Fund called such actions “undesirable,” Reuters reports.

headline: News Quiz | October 7, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Real Estate Collapse Spells Havoc in Dubai
text: On a sultry June evening in 2007, more than 100 people camped out at the offices of Emaar, a prestigious Dubai property developer, to ensure that they would land a coveted spot in a gleaming new skyscraper scheduled to open this year near the Burj Khalifa, the world’s tallest building, Liz Alderman writes in The New York Times.

headline: Payment to End Wells Fargo Inquiry
text: Wells Fargo is paying $24 million to end an investigation by eight states into whether lenders acquired by the bank gave risky mortgages to consumers without disclosing their perils, The Associated Press reports.

headline: Test Yourself | English, Oct. 7, 2010
text: Test your vocabulary skills with today’s question, created by Danielle Hoagland and Judith McCaffrey at Grammarlogues from the Times article “For the Unemployed Over 50, Fears of Never Working Again.”

headline: Stephen Pace, Painter and Abstract Expressionist, Is Dead at 91
text: Stephen Pace, whose exuberant style applied Abstract Expressionist scale and directness to figurative painting, died on Sept. 23 in an assisted-living center in  New Harmony, Ind. He was 91 and until two years ago had divided his time between homes in Manhattan and Stonington, Me.

headline: Fitch Downgrades Ireland
text: Ireland got an unwelcome jolt Wednesday as Fitch Ratings cut its sovereign credit rating to the lowest level of any of the major agencies, citing the heavy burden of bailing out the country’s banking sector, David Jolly writes in The New York Times.

headline: Vale Said Set to Invest $20 Billion Next Year
text: Vale, the Brazilian mining company that is the world’s largest producer of iron ore, will invest at least $20 billion in 2011, a source close to the company said on Wednesday, Reuters reports.

headline: Madoff Clan Denies Role and Seeks Dismissal
text: Nearly two years after the revelation of Bernard L. Madoff’s vast investment fraud, family members who were executives at his firm insist they had nothing to do with it, asking a judge on Wednesday to halt a bid to sue them for nearly $200 million, Reuters reports.

headline: Daily Lexeme: Boozeroo
text: Today’s word, in association with the voluminous Oxford English Dictionary, is

headline: Pasta + Tacos = Delicious?
text: WHO originated the spaghetti taco, and on WHAT television show?

headline: After Loss, Twins Mull Their Yankee Curse
text: MINNEAPOLIS  Michael Cuddyer thought the ball would land foul. But as the Minnesota Twins first baseman watched Mark Teixeira’s high fly ball hug the right field line, descend, and finally fall into the seats just inside the foul pole, he tried not to think what most of the agonized Twins fans at Target Field were thinking.

headline: Deutsche Publishes Postbank Tender
text: Deutsche Bank published the terms of its tender offer for Postbank on its Web site on Thursday, saying the 25 euro per share bid would expire on November 4.

headline: Novelis Seeks to Buy BP Stake in Venture
text: Novelis, a unit of the Indian aluminum maker Hindalco Industries, is in talks to buy BP out of its 60 percent stake in their United States joint venture, Logan Aluminum, for $600 million, the business newspaper Mint reported on Thursday.

headline: Can Money Buy You Happiness?
text: A Bucks blog post ponders a recent study from Princeton University that found that people reported an increase in happiness as their incomes rose to $75,000 a year. “Then, the impact of rising income on happiness levels off,” the post says. What do you think of this finding? How much money do you think you would need a year to be happy? Do you think more money would make you more happy? If so, then how, as the blog post asks, do you explain the fact that “there are plenty of people who seem to have very little money and lots of happiness”?

headline: Gates Foundation Backs ABC News Project
text: From Bill Carter at Media Decoder:

headline: Eventbrite Books More Cash
text: From Jenna Wortham at Bits:

headline: Goldman Sachs and the Economy
text: Peter Boone is chairman of the charity Effective Intervention and a research associate at the Center for Economic Performance at the London School of Economics. He is also a principal in Salute Capital Management Ltd. Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is the co-author of “13 Bankers.”

headline: France Gives Ground on European Union Fund Rules
text: France backed away from its total opposition to a vital part of the European Union’s proposed rules for hedge funds and private-equity funds, making a Europe-wide set of laws for the institutions more likely, The Financial Times reports.

headline: Site in Hungary Was Listed as Risky
text: BUDAPEST  The storage pond filled with caustic alumina-processing waste that burst and inundated several Hungarian villages this week was on a 2006 watch list of more than 150 industrial sites that were at risk for accidents that could contaminate the Danube River, according to an environmental group.

headline: Whitney’s Foresight Falters After Citi Prediction
text: Meredith Whitney, the bank analyst who jumped to celebrity from obscurity by correctly predicting Citigroup’s dividend cut, is having less success divining stock market winners and losers, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: Former Jefferies Fund Manager Convicted of Fraud
text: A former hedge fund manager in New York has been convicted on federal charges that he participated in a $7 million insider-trading fraud, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Betfair I.P.O. Values Company at Up to $2.3 Billion
text: Betfair, the world’s biggest Internet betting exchange, set an indicative price range for its initial public offering of between £11 and £14, valuing the company at almost £1.5 billion ($2.3 billion) at the top end, The Telegraph reported.

headline: Blackstone Stands by Its Dynegy Bid
text: A Blackstone Group executive tamped down expectations of a higher bid for Dynegy, saying that its $4.7 billion bid for the power producer was a “full and fair” price, not to mention a steep premium, Reuters reported.

headline: Time May Be Genzyme’s Best Defense
text: Time may be Genzyme’s best defense against a $18.5 billion hostile takeover bid from Sanofi-Aventis, after Genzyme shed protections that could have helped deflect an unwanted suitor, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: CNO’s White Elephant, ‘Le Chateau,’ Finds Buyer
text: “Le Chateau Renaissance” is a seven-bedroom mansion in Indiana. As well as the bedrooms, the property has nine fireplaces, two swimming pools, a walk-in closet big enough to live in, and now, a new owner.

headline: Newsweek’s Price Tag: $1
text: So just how much did Sidney Harman pay for Newsweek? The bargain-basement price of $1.

headline: When Colorful Fashions Reigned at Wimbledon
text: With the U.S. Open behind them, tennis fans can still find something to satisfy their appetites until Grand Slam season starts again. On the grounds of Wimbledon (Church Road, Wimbledon; 44-208-946-6131; wimbledon.org) a year-round museum is devoted to the joys and history of the sport — and one of their current exhibits showcases Ted Tinling, the popular and controversial designer of tennis dresses for most of the top female players, including Billie Jean King and Margaret Court.

headline: Renault Sells $4.2 Billion Volvo Stake
text: Renault, the French carmaker, said Wednesday that it was selling more than 300 million shares of the Swedish truckmaker Volvo AB to institutional investors to raise more than 3 billion euros, or $4.2 billion, with plans to use the money to reduce its debt by divesting the nearly 15 percent stake in the company.

headline: Revisiting Jets’ Timid Play Against Ravens
text: The Jets’ opening loss to the Ravens might as well have been four years ago, not four weeks ago.

headline: Charting Mark Sanchez’s Progress
text: A common trait among most highly drafted quarterbacks who go on to have success is a  jump in production from their rookie years  to their second years.

headline: The Almanac as Early iPhone
text: Today’s idea: The Old Farmer’s Almanac deserves new respect as the “iPhone of early America,” a scholar argues.

headline: WaMu Bank Bondholders Settle for $335 Million
text: A group of Washington Mutual creditors have signed on to a settlement that pushes the bank’s reorganization plan a step closer to approval, The Associated Press reported.

headline: K.K.R. Biggest Spender on Deals for Past 5 Years
text: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company has committed more money to buy companies over the past five years than any other private-equity firm in the world, according to data compiled by Bloomberg News.

headline: Warburg to Invest $150 Million in National Penn
text: Warburg Pincus, the private-equity firm, will invest $150 million in National Penn Bancshares for a 16.4 percent stake in the company, an operator of banks in Pennsylvania and elsewhere, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Permira Takes Stake in Medical Device Maker
text: Permira is taking a majority stake in Creganna-Tactx Medical, an Irish medical device maker, in the British private-equity firm’s first health care deal in a decade.

headline: Statoil Seeks $850 Million From Fuel and Retail I.P.O.
text: Statoil, Norway’s largest oil and gas company, aims to raise 3.84 billion kroner to 4.92 billion kroner ($850 million) by selling shares in its gas station and transport fuel unit, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: European Central Banks Hold Rates Steady
text: The European Central Bank signaled Thursday that it would stick to its policy of gradually removing extraordinary economic stimulus measures, even as other monetary authorities appeared to be moving in the opposite direction.

headline: 3 Newspaper Groups Back Ongo, a News Start-Up
text: Ongo, an online news venture based in Silicon Valley, has nabbed $12 million in financing from three of the country’s largest newspaper groups.

headline: Flood of Campaign Cash Becomes the Issue
text: In January, during his first State of the Union address, President Obama predicted that a U.S. Supreme Court decision would “open the floodgates” of money into campaigns. He warned against elections that are “bankrolled” by powerful interests.

headline: New LED Display to Give New York Taxis Ads More Pop
text: The latest upgrade to the glowing signs atop New York City taxi cabs, which have been strutting their advertising stuff for more than 30 years, borrows technology from the latest flat-panel television sets. They will be lighted by LED.

headline: Key Matchups: Euro 2012 Qualifiers
text: The outstanding matchups in Euro 2012 qualifiers on Friday and Saturday, with home teams listed first:

headline: Lehman Push Is Said to Lack Legal Grounding
text: As Lehman Brothers‘ bankruptcy estate battles Barclays Capital over the deal that handed over much of the fallen investment bank to its British rival, a Bloomberg News columnist sees a few fundamental flaws in Lehman’s case.

headline: Eola Property Trust Plans $675 Million I.P.O.
text: Eola Property Trust is seeking to raise as much as $675 million in an initial public offering, the company said Wednesday.

headline: Was Belichick Right to Trade Moss?
text: Don Banks of Sports Illustrated has it right. Everyone has an opinion on the Randy Moss trade — and feel free to share yours in the comments section — but it would be interesting to know what one person in particular is thinking.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: –Wall Street’s gender gap, and its hormonal explanation: “You put on a trade, you get it right, you make a big win, your testosterone levels go up, you get more confident, you want more risk and this thing feeds on itself.”

headline: Paladino to Broadcast Message Across State
text: Carl P. Paladino, the Republican candidate for governor, has quietly purchased several minutes of television time to broadcast a synchronized message across the state on Thursday, his campaign said.

headline: Mario Vargas Llosa Wins Nobel Literature Prize
text: Mario Vargas Llosa, the Peruvian writer and author of novels including “The Time of the Hero,” “The Green House” and “Conversation in the Cathedral,” won the 2010 Nobel Prize in Literature on Thursday. In its citation, the Swedish Academy hailed Mr. Vargas Llosa, 74, “for his cartography of structures of power and his trenchant images of the individual’s resistance, revolt and defeat.”

headline: Week 5 N.F.L. Game Probabilities, and Home Field’s Value
text: My prediction model factors in home-field advantage, but it’s not as simple as adding a 7 percentage advantage for the home team’s probability.

headline: Vargas Llosa Takes Nobel in Literature
text: The Peruvian writer Mario Vargas Llosa, whose deeply political work vividly examines the perils of power and corruption in Latin America, won the 2010 Nobel Prize in Literature on Thursday.

headline: Man Group Jumps on Bid Speculation
text: Man Group, the hedge-fund manager buying GLG Partners, rose the most in more than four months amid speculation that an unidentified United States bank may make an offer for the firm, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: It Isn’t Just China’s Currency
text: The fourth post in our renminbi series comes from Clyde Prestowitz, a former Reagan administration official who runs the Economic Strategy Institute.

headline: Hevesi Pleads Guilty in Pension Case
text: Former State Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi, once considered a leading voice on corporate governance and ethics, stood before a judge on Thursday and calmly explained how he took part in a sprawling corruption scheme involving New York State’s $125 billion pension fund while serving as its sole trustee.

headline: Europe Weighs Limits on Bankers’ Pay
text: European Union authorities are set to clamp down on compensation in the finance sector as delegates from the union’s 27 member states meet in London to write up new rules to limit bonuses, The Financial Times reports.

headline: Night Watch: Talk of Witches and an Apology
text: Prepping for his Wednesday night appearance on CBS’s “Late Show With David Letterman,” the White House senior adviser David Axelrod probably knew that there would be a joke about the presidential seal falling off a lectern on Monday while President Obama was speaking.

headline: September Sales Topped Forecasts for U.S. Retailers
text: Back-to-school sales that were stronger than expected have retailers cautiously hoping consumers are back and gearing up for a robust holiday shopping season.

headline: Hevesi Pleads Guilty to Felony
text: 12:52 p.m. | Updated Former State Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi pleaded guilty on Thursday to steering millions of dollars in state pension money to an investment firm in return for kickbacks that included travel and other expenses, and campaign funds, The New York Times’s William Rashbaum and Danny Hakim reported.

headline: Who Owns A.I.G. (a Continuing Story)
text: The federal government’s exit plan from the American International Group involves one of the largest corporate reorganizations in history. It contemplates the conversion and sale of $49.1 billion in the government’s preferred share ownership interests, the $15.5 billion sale of A.I.G.’s Alico subsidiary to MetLife, the approximately $15 billion initial public offering of the company’s American International Assurance subsidiary and the repayment of a $20 billion loan to the Federal Reserve.

headline: Tunnel Of Idiocy
text: Many reports that Chris Christie is about to scuttle the second rail tunnel under the Hudson. If so, it’s arguably the worst policy decision ever made by the government of New Jersey — and that’s saying a lot.

headline: It’s All in the Game: A Monopoly Tribute to ‘The Wire’
text: A week ago it seemed as if the television producer David Simon had reached the pinnacle of his achievements when he was named the winner of a MacArthur Foundation “genius grant.” But a British comedy publication has given him perhaps a higher honor by creating a Monopoly board inspired by his HBO series “The Wire.”

headline: Food Stamps Won’t Buy Sodas, if the City Has Its Way
text: Happy M.T.A. fare increase day. Here’s what we’re reading this drizzly, windy morning:

headline: Hello Again: A Field Guide to Parents’ Weekend
text: Blogger’s Note: Periodically on The Choice, we look past the college search to the college experience itself. No matter how old (or young) their children, I suspect many parents will relate to this essay. –Jacques Steinberg

headline: The Mom-Bomb
text: The effect of motherhood on the pay of female managers.Writing for Fox 5 Money, Melanie Alnwick observed, “there’s a new word in Washington to describe women’s pay” – the mom-bomb:

headline: Poetry Pairing | October 7, 2010
text: In our weekly “Poetry Pairing” series, we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poem’s themes. Each poem is introduced briefly by Ted Kooser, a former United States poet laureate.

headline: Thai Leader Defends Crackdown as Way to Ensure Stability
text: BRUSSELS  Prime Minister Abhisit Vejjajiva of Thailand acknowledged that a continuing crackdown against the opposition might have led to possible human rights abuses in his country, but he insisted that the emergency policies were necessary to ensure stability.

headline: M.T.A. Approves Transit Fare Increases
text: Updated, 11:31 a.m. | The board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority voted 12 to 2 this morning to approve a package of fare increases for its subways, buses and commuter railroads, the third time in three years that New Yorkers face a stiff rise in the cost of getting around.

headline: Folksy Ad Not So Folksy After All
text: 2:25 p.m. | Updated Kevin McLaughlin, a spokesman for Mr. Raese’s campaign, emailed the following statement this afternoon: “The ad is ridiculous and I am happy to say that no one with the Raese campaign had anything to do with it. As a matter of fact, we asked that it be taken down long before it went public. But this race isn’t about TV ads, it’s about the future of West Virginia. Joe Manchin is desperate to avoid talking about the issues because he knows when we do that West Virginians overwhelmingly don’t want him in Washington rubber stamping President Obama’s radical agenda.”

headline: For Comics Fans, City Leaps Off the Page
text: EVERYONE knows that the Comic-Con International in San Diego is like a nerds-are-cool Woodstock, where freak flags are waved proudly and Hollywood sweats to build buzz for its releases. But New York is the birthplace of comic books, and the New York Comic Con, at just five years old, has become a respectable contender as the “it” place for a pop-culture celebration.

headline: For One Bookmaker, All Bets Are Off for British Literary Prize
text: Had you been inclined to wager on the winner of the 2010 Nobel Prize in Literature based on the odds set by Ladbrokes, the British bookmaking chain, you might have put your money on the Swedish poet Tomas Transtromer, the Syrian poet Adonis, the Kenyan novelist Ngugi wa Thiong’o or the South Korean poet Ko Un. And you would have come home with a big fat goose egg when the Peruvian novelist Mario Vargas Llosa (who was given 25-1 odds by Ladbrokes) was named the winner on Thursday morning.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Alexander McQueen
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: Thursday Reading: Start of Fees for Food on Continental Flights
text: A variety of consumer-focused stories appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: The Early Word: Money Matters
text: From the global economy to the world of politics, money is driving the conversation in Washington this Thursday.

headline: In Fierce Opposition to a Muslim Center, Echoes of an Old Fight
text: Many New Yorkers were suspicious of the newcomers’ plans to build a house of worship in Manhattan. Some feared the project was being underwritten by foreigners. Others said the strangers’ beliefs were incompatible with democratic principles.

headline: Maldives President Installs Solar Roof
text: President Mohamed Nasheed of Maldives, a sun-baked nation of 1,200 low islands south of India, donned jeans and a hard hat earlier today and helped install 48 donated solar photovoltaic panels on the roof of his official residence in the crowded capital, Male (the photo below, taken by Mohamed Ali, is from the government Flickr.com photo stream). Just last year Nasheed donned scuba gear for an underwater cabinet meeting ahead of climate talks in Copenhagen.

headline: Keeping Score: The Parallel Paths of Halladay and Lee
text: Neil Paine is an analyst at Baseball-Reference.com, an online baseball encyclopedia of players, teams and box scores in the major and minor leagues.

headline: On Our Radar: Virginia’s Second Subpoena on Climate Research
text: Virginia’s attorney general, an outspoken climate change skeptic, continues his investigation of the former University of Virginia climate researcher Michael Mann, issuing a second civil subpoena demanding documents related to a state-funded grant application, which he contends was marred by fraud. A previous subpoena had been rejected by a state judge, who concluded that Attorney General Ken T. Cuccinelli had failed to provide any justification for suspecting that fraud had been committed. [Washington Post]

headline: Woman Falls Eight Stories on Staten Island
text: Updated, 1:05 p.m. | A young woman fell from an eighth-floor window of a public housing building on Staten Island, fire officials said. We erroneously reported that she had died, but fire officials say she is in serious condition with multiple fractures and broken bones. The full extent of her injuries was not immediately known. Police officials say the woman is 19, but they have not released her identity.

headline: Turku: A European Capital of Culture
text: Turku is Finland’s fifth-largest city, but it is one of its most inviting.

headline: Popcast: Nellie McKay and Bruno Mars
text: This week on Popcast, The Times’s music podcast, Nellie McKay plays two songs on the ukulele from her new album, “Home Sweet Mobile Home” (Verve). (We are proud to note that this is our third ukulele performance on Popcast. Last year we had a session by Arms, the group led by Todd Goldstein of Harlem Shakes, and in May we had a visit from the otherworldly-voiced Jonsi of Sigur Ros.)

headline: Ayrton Senna Movie to Open in Japan
text: The documentary on the life and career of Ayrton Senna, the great Brazilian Formula One racecar driver, will have a special screening in Suzuka, Japan, on Thursday, as teams prepare for the Grand Prix of Japan, according to The Globe and Mail. The film opens in theaters across Japan on Friday.

headline: Keeping It Kosher
text: “IS HE COMING BACK?” Clara Santos Perez was peering out the windows and across the street, where an imposing man in black stood, his face turned in her direction.

headline: Giving the Honeybee Its Due
text: Insects are not the warmest and fuzziest members of the animal kingdom. Your average mosquito, not to mention bedbugs or lice, just can’t compete in the sweepstakes of human affection with a soulful dog, its head nuzzled in your lap, or the anciently wise demeanor of the average house cat.

headline: Cuba Journal: Jazz at Lincoln Center Players Dance to Students’ Beat
text: Over the next few days, Victoria Burnett will be reporting for ArtsBeat on Jazz at Lincoln Center’s visit to Cuba.

headline: Montreal Chef Is Coming to Fedora
text: A second veteran of Martin Picard’s quirky Montreal restaurant Au Pied de Cochon is coming to New York. Medhi Brunet-Benkritly, who worked for four years there, and at Toqué before that, will be the chef at Fedora, the venerable Greenwich Village bistro that Gabriel Stulman, an owner of Joseph Leonard, and his partners bought and are renovating, to open in November.

headline: Woman Arrested in Colorado After Destroying Artwork
text: A Montana woman was arrested Wednesday at a Colorado museum after she destroyed an artwork that some observers say depicts Jesus engaged in a sex act. The Denver Post reported that Kathleen Folden of Kalispell, Mont., was taken into police custody after she entered the Loveland Museum/Gallery in Loveland, Colo., and destroyed a work called “The Misadventures of Romantic Cannibals,” a lithograph by Enrique Chagoya. The police told The Post that Ms. Folden had used a crowbar or similar tool to break the plexiglass in front of the work and then tore it up. She has been charged with criminal mischief, a felony punishable by a fine of up to $2,000.

headline: Next on ‘The Gelada Bachelorette’
text: Saturday, Oct. 2

headline: Readers’ Potluck Dishes
text: A few weeks ago, we asked you to submit recipes and photos of your go-to potluck dishes. We received more than 350 entries, which came from around the world and varied from Shanghainese style belly pork to triple chocolate pecan bites. It was really tough to narrow it down to our top 20, not to mention the five we selected as “editors’ picks,” but after much debating, testing and tasting, we managed to make the call.

headline: The D.E.A. Changes a Policy on Painkillers
text: Following a report in The Times that nursing home residents were being forced to go without necessary painkillers, the federal Drug Enforcement Agency on Wednesday issued new rules designed to expedite the dispensing of these drugs in long-term care facilities. Read the full article, and share your thoughts in the comments section.

headline: Photo of the Week
text: A man plays a violin in downtown São Paulo, Brazil.

headline: What You Can Get Free
text: What do passport photographs, workouts and e-books have in common? You can easily get all three at no cost, according to Kiplinger.com, which recently released its fourth annual list of 33 quality freebies.

headline: Personal Income Drops in New York Region
text: Driven by declines on Wall Street, total personal income earned by residents of metropolitan New York fell last in 2009 for the first time in 40 years — by 4.1 percent — according to the latest data from the government’s Bureau of Economic Analysis.

headline: New Study Names Honda as the Greenest Automaker
text: Honda has the greenest vehicles in the United States, with Toyota and Hyundai tying for second place, according to a study released on Thursday by the Union of Concerned Scientists, a nonprofit advocacy group.

headline: Corruption in Afghanistan: An Aid Worker’s Experience
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — I was talking to a friend about the challenges of working in an environment of endemic corruption, and I remarked that it “takes so many forms here,” causing his eyes momentarily to roll back into his head.

headline: After 25 Years, Johnson to Leave ‘Page Six’
text: Richard Johnson, who has edited The New York Post’s Page Six gossip column for nearly 25 years, is leaving the New York tabloid for a job in Los Angeles.

headline: Modified Corn Aids Nearby Farmers, and Vice Versa
text: A long-term study of corn production in the Midwest has found that the widespread use of varieties engineered with a bacterial gene that kills insect pests has had big benefits in adjacent fields of conventional corn — cutting infestations there and boosting farmers’ income by billions of dollars. The paper, “Areawide Suppression of European Corn Borer with Bt Maize Reaps Savings to Non-Bt Maize Growers,” is being published in the Oct. 8 edition of the journal Science.

headline: Theater Talkback: From Seat to Stage
text: “To be sure,” begins a frantically comforting passage in a press release for “Hotel Savoy,” the new show from P.S. 122 at the Goethe-Institut, “this is not a performance predicated on traditional audience participation. There is no pressure for visitors to perform, there is no stage to be thrust upon.”

headline: Indonesian Military Joins a Local Terrorism Fight
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Indonesia has sent its military to fight local militants for the first time in nearly a decade to send a “strong message” to the insurgents, who are shifting from suicide bombings to armed attacks on the government, the country’s antiterrorism chief said Thursday.

headline: An Aftermarket GPS, Sony-Style
text: Not every driver likes the suction-cup aesthetic of aftermarket GPS systems. And for those who have space in their dashboard, Sony has two new models that combine audio features with full-service navigational abilities.

headline: Is Arenas Seeing the End With Wizards?
text: The Wizards All-Star guard Gilbert Arenas is known for his interesting statements. They can range from funny to odd, and never fail to get a reaction.

headline: Hot Lips
text: François Nars’s makeup can be described as dramatic, but his limited-edition Bento Box lipstick set takes the concept literally. Inspired by a porcelain pot of lip stain used for kabuki actors that Nars found in Japan 10 years ago, the set of two cups of hand-poured color comes in a handsome wooden box with a wisteria-handled lip brush. “I’ve always been fascinated with the concept of kabuki makeup,” Nars says. “It’s about symbolism and using color to create drama.” The lipstick application is as seductive as its presentation. “You dip the brush into the cup, around the perimeter, to pick up product, and simply paint,” he says. “It’s a beautiful process.” Unless you want to look like a Japanese theater character, however, Nars recommends using a little restraint: “It’s highly pigmented, so I suggest starting out light and building for desired intensity. It seems intimidating, but the texture is creamy and light and will move easily.” The set will be available for $125 beginning November 1 at Saks Fifth Avenue and Barneys New York, or go to narscosmetics.com/bento to pre-order.

headline: Euro Clashes and Friendlies Offer Compelling Soccer Plot Lines
text: The international furlough means the world’s top leagues will go dark this weekend while their best players don the jerseys of their national teams. Most of the compelling games will be played in Europe, where teams will continue the Euro 2012 qualifying campaign. (Rob Hughes suggests these games to watch.) Elsewhere, teams will play friendly matches, including the Americans’ Oct. 9 exhibition against Poland and their Oct. 12 match with Colombia.

headline: Finally, a Chance to Dress Up Again
text: WE all age, and that includes drag queens, even with their limitless tools of illusion. So it was on Saturday night when Joey Arias, the gender-bending chanteuse who swanned across downtown during the 1990s, celebrated his birthday with fellow disco demimondes.

headline: Don’t Look Back, Brooklyn; Houston Is Gaining on You
text: It would still be the fourth largest city in America, but for how much longer?

headline: U.S. Believes Arab States Won’t Scuttle Mideast Talks
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration believes it has persuaded Arab states not to scuttle the fledgling Middle East peace negotiations, officials said Thursday, despite the Israeli government’s refusal to freeze Jewish settlements and a vow by the Palestinians to walk away if Israel did not.

headline: Scene City: Happy Birthday, Joey Arias
text: On a recent Saturday night, Joey Arias, the gender-bending chanteuse who swanned across downtown during the 1990s, celebrated his birthday with fellow disco demimondes.

headline: Nearly 5 Jobless Workers Per Opening in August
text: There were slightly fewer than five unemployed people for every job opening in August, according to a Labor Department report. The ratio was largely unchanged from July but below its highs from last fall.

headline: Numerology Meets Filmmaking in ‘One Day on Earth’ Project
text: What will you be doing on 10-10-10? The organizers of One Day on Earth don’t care what the answer is as long as you videotape yourself doing it.

headline: Who Maimed the Economy, and How
text: As I was watching “Inside Job,” Charles Ferguson’s meticulous and infuriating documentary about the causes and consequences of the financial crisis of 2008, an odd, archaic sentence kept popping into my head. The words come from the second chapter of “The Scarlet Letter” and are spoken in frustration and disgust by an old Puritan woman who watches Hester Prynne, publicly disgraced but without any sign of remorse, making her way from Salem’s prison to a scaffold in its market square. She “has brought shame upon us all,” the anonymous woman remarks. “Is there not law for it?”

headline: What We’re Reading: Drug Testing for the Unemployed
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: Gloves Off in Colorado House Race
text: The advertising battle is heating up in Colorado’s Fourth District, where Representative Betsy Markey is locked in a fierce battle in her bid for a second term.

headline: Timescast | October 7, 2010
text: Caustic mudslide in Hungary, why the Supreme Court may be deadlocked and a look at the new old Rome.

headline: Which Pitcher Would You Rather Have, Lee or Halladay?
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Yes, the Rays and Rangers saw it, too.Roy Halladay’s no-hitter for the Phillies against the Reds may have come in the National League playoffs, but Halladay spent 12 years pitching in the American League. Plenty of Rays and Rangers have struggled to get hits off of him, too, over the years.

headline: Forecast Sees Drug-Sales Growth Overseas
text: The global drug market will grow  5 to 7 percent in 2011, to $880 billion, as higher spending in nations like China, Brazil and India makes up for slow growth and patent losses in the United States, according to a forecast released Wednesday by IMS Health, an industry data company.

headline: Time Dwindles for 3M’s Offer for Cogent
text: The 3M Company’s tender offer for Cogent expires Thursday at midnight. It is going to be a nail-biter.

headline: The Morning Skate: 30 Teams Worth of Questions
text: All around the world, the puck drops on the 93rd N.H.L. regular season today, a premiere that stretches across nine time zones.

headline: Medical Student Distress and the Risk of Doctor Suicide
text: Several years ago, I learned that a physician in a town not too far from where I was practicing had committed suicide. Neither I nor my hospital colleagues knew him, but according to the story we heard, he was the father of young children, was respected by doctors and patients alike and had struggled privately with mental illness since medical school.

headline: When Doctors Get Depressed
text: In today’s Doctor and Patient column, Dr. Pauline Chen discusses the alarmingly high rates of depression and suicide among doctors.

headline: Sharp Jabs as Rivals for Senate Debate Again
text: NORWALK, Conn.  The Republican candidate, Linda E. McMahon, and her Democratic opponent, Richard Blumenthal, traded harsh attacks on Thursday in a debate that underscored the increasingly combative tone of the Senate race in Connecticut.

headline: Now Reading | Handcrafted Modern
text: Of all the houses that designers create, their own are often the most interesting, since they tend to be the most revealing. Leslie Williamson, a San Francisco photographer, assumed that this was true of Modernist designers, too, but had a hard time finding books on the subject. Thus, “Handcrafted Modern: At Home With Midcentury Designers” (Rizzoli) was born. An intimate look at 13 houses and one apartment (that of the furniture designer Vladimir Kagan), Williamson’s book visits the homes of masters of studio furniture like Wharton Esherick, George Nakashima and J.B. Blunk; industrial designers like Russel Wright, Charles and Ray Eames, and Irving Harper; and the architects Walter Gropius and Albert Frey.

headline: Four French Horn Players Take On Lady Gaga, Queen and More
text: The publicity photos make them look like either the Four Hornswomen of the Apocalypse or neon-colored aerobics instructors. They go by the stage names Freedom Barbie, Velvet Barbie, Jungle Barbie and Attila the Horn. They play arrangements of songs by Lady Gaga, Michael Jackson, Queen and other pop acts.

headline: A Horse Overhead
text: An interactive look at the set of the Broadway musical “Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson.”

headline: Honda Is Greenest, Study Suggests
text: Our friends at the Wheels blog report that Honda has the greenest vehicles in the United States, according to a study released on Thursday by the Union of Concerned Scientists. The automaker barely edged out Toyota and Hyundai, which tied for second place. The results were based on the fleets’ impact on global warming.

headline: A Moderate Voice Is Silenced in Pakistan
text: A spokesman for the Taliban in Pakistan’s Swat Valley claimed responsibility this week for the murder of an outspoken critic of the Islamist militants, Dr. Mohammad Farooq Khan, a religious scholar and educator who was gunned down along with his assistant on Saturday.

headline: Waiting for Luggage With Vargas Llosa
text: QUITO, Ecuador — Flying above the Andes allows time for many things: typing away on a laptop, dozing off or daydreaming as one gazes below at the jagged peaks that run up and down South America’s spine. But on one such flight in 2008, I had trouble concentrating on any of them.

headline: Drafting a College List in a Tough Economy
text: A few weeks into senior year, anxious students start asking, “Am I applying to enough colleges?”

headline: Vocabulinks
text: An occasional assemblage of notable vocabulary and linguistic debate from around the Web.

headline: Creative Accounting in California
text: Why worry about budget deficits when you can merely assume they won’t exist?:

headline: Christie Halts Train Tunnel, Citing Its Cost
text: The largest public transit project in the nation, a commuter train tunnel under the Hudson River to Manhattan, was halted on Thursday by Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey because, he said, the state could not afford its share of the project’s rising cost.

headline: Poetry on Film: Interpreting ‘Howl’ in the 21st Century
text: Overview | How can poetry both reflect and transcend the era in which it is written? How can looking at a poem from multiple perspectives illuminate its meaning? In this lesson, students consider a film about Allen Ginsberg’s “Howl,” study the poem and express their ideas about poetry, their generation and life in writing and on film.

headline: The Search for an Internet Business Continues
text: It’s been one year since my brother-in-law, Dan, began his search to buy the perfect Internet business. In those 12 months, he has reviewed hundreds of listings, made inquiries on about 50 and submitted six offers. None of them  resulted in a deal.

headline: Thelonious Monk, Created Wry Jazz Melodies and New Harmonies
text: Thelonious Monk, the pianist and composer whose wry, angular melodies and unusual harmonic progressions are among the most striking contributions to the jazz repertory, died yesterday in Englewood Hospital in New Jersey at the age of 64. He had suffered a stroke on Feb. 5.

headline: Agnew Quits Vice Presidency And Admits Tax Evasion In '67; Nixon Consults On Successor
text: Washington, Oct, 10--Spiro T. Agnew resigned as Vice President of the United States today under an agreement with the Department of Justice to admit evasion of Federal income taxes and avoid imprisonment.

headline: Maldives Leader Gets a Solar Roof
text: The president of Maldives, an island nation that is deeply concerned about global warming and rising seas, has had 48 donated solar panels installed on his roof, Andy Revkin reports at his Dot Earth blog. The point was to lend support to global efforts to rein in greenhouse gases from fossil fuel emissions through steps like embracing solar energy.

headline: Mrs. Roosevelt, First Lady 12 Years, Often Called 'World's Most Admired Woman'
text: Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt was more involved in the minds and hearts and aspirations of people than any other First Lady in history. By the end of her life she was one of the most esteemed women in the world.

headline: Astronauts Carry Out Early Maneuvers on 163-Orbit Journey
text: Cape Kennedy, Fla., Oct. 11--Three American astronauts rocketed into orbit today for the first manned test flight of the Apollo spacecraft, which may some day fly men to the moon.

headline: Verizon Expects a Lot More Devices for Its Old Network
text: By now, the rumors of a Verizon iPhone are as common (and tired) as Lindsay Lohan’s repeated stints in jail. But as the latest round of speculation blazes through the Web, one detail doesn’t seem to add up. Why would Verizon unveil a sleek new Apple device running on its aging 3G network?

headline: American Ballet Theater to Visit Moscow
text: First Cuba, now Russia. American Ballet Theater has added Moscow to its touring itinerary for the 2010-11 season, the company announced Thursday. The March engagement, part of the Mstislav Rostropovich Week Festival, will include the premiere of a new work by Benjamin Millepied commissioned by the festival. American Ballet Theater last performed in Moscow in 1960. That was also the last time it appeared onstage in Havana, where the company will be returning next month.

headline: Elmer Sperry Dies; Famous Inventor
text: Elmer A. Sperry, inventor, died yesterday morning at St. John's Hospital, Brooklyn, from complications which set in after he had recovered from an operation for gallstones six weeks ago. He was in his seventieth year.

headline: ROBERT E. LEE.
text: Richmond, Oct. 13--Richmond presents today a scene of mourning hardly witnessed in this generation. The stores and public buildings are all closed. The bells in all parts of the city are tolling. On many doors are pictures and photographs of Gen. Lee, draped in crape, with evergreen. The citizens are standing in groups on the principal thoroughfares and talking in subdued tones of the sad event. The feeling that he ought to be buried here, at the State's expense, is universal, and the Legislature, in making this request of his family, reiterated the public desire. The City Council met this afternoon, at the call of the Mayor. Gov. Walker sent the following Message to the General Assembly:

headline: Milan in Bloom
text: For an international style capital, home to A-list designers who set the trends and dominate the news, Milan gets no respect. The fashion pack descends four times a year and complains about the weather, the traffic. They shop, pillaging the stores on Via Montenapoleone, and then they leave, in a hurry to get to Paris. Even the Italians dislike Milan. Or rather, the Italians in particular dislike it. Any native of Rome or Florence or Bologna will tell you that all people do there is work work work, that it’s gray, industrial, unwelcoming, without a soul. I’ve heard nicer things about Cleveland.

headline: Making a Movie Into a Musical
text: Bartlett Sher, the director of "Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown," talks about turning Pedro Almodovar's movie into a musical.

headline: Lenny Bruce, Uninhibited Comic, Found Dead in Hollywood Home
text: Hollywood, Aug. 3 (AP)--Lenny Bruce, the controversial nightclub comedian whose acts were sprinkled with four-letter words and pungent social satire, died tonight in his home on Hollywood Boulevard. He was 40 years old.

headline: BIGGEST PACIFIC AIR FLEET BOMBS RABAUL; WRECKS 177 PLANES, 123 SHIPS IN SURPRISE; BADOGLIO, DECLARING WAR, RALLIES ITALY
text: Algiers, Oct. 13--Italy declared war on Nazi Germany, her former Axis partner, at 3 P.M. today, Greenwich time [11 A.M. in New York].

text: Apple and Roku approach Internet television from very different perspectives. The products from both companies have shortcomings.

headline: Dwight David Eisenhower: A Leader in War and Peace
text: Military leadership of the victorious Allied forces in Western Europe during World War II invested Dwight David Eisenhower with an immense popularity, almost amounting to devotion, that twice elected him President of the United States. His enormous political success was largely personal, for he was not basically a politician dealing in partisan issues and party maneuvers. What he possessed was a superb talent for gaining the respect and affection of the voters as the man suited to guide the nation through cold war confrontations with Soviet power around the world and to lead the country to domestic prosperity.

headline:
Martin
Luther King Wins The Nobel Prize for Peace
text: Oslo, Norway, Oct. 14--The Nobel Peace prize for 1964 was awarded today to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

headline: Khrushchev Ousted From Top Posts; Brezhnev Gets Chief Party Position And Kosygin Is Named New Premier
text: Moscow, Friday, Oct. 16--Premier Khrushchev has been deprived of political power in the Soviet Union.

text: Weimar, Aug. 25.--Prof. Friedrich Wilhelm Nietzsche, the philosopher, died here today of apoplexy.

headline: Losing a Father
text: When Meera Oliva last wrote for Motherlode, she shared thoughts about her son, Elan. The boy was born with a cleft lip, and, several days before the surgery, Oliva described how she would miss his imperfect smile, even though she knew the repair was necessary and the timing was right. (Elan’s doing wonderfully, she reports, with “ just the slightest scar to show where his cleft once was, and we love his new smile just as much as we loved the old one, which we do still miss from time to time.”)

headline: Jeb Bush Heads to Harvard

headline: Fall Maintenance
text: Despite the recent tropical rainfall events and microcells that have uprooted 100-year-old oaks in the Northeast, the early fall weather has generally been friendly to local beehives. The weather has been hot, and fall flowers, like goldenrod, have thrived. As I strolled through the Brooklyn Botanic Gardens the other day, scouting with a colleague to prepare for a coming school field trip, I was jealous that local Brooklyn beekeepers had it so good, as hundreds, if not thousands, of honeybees mingled with native pollinators on lush native flora in the park.

headline: President Falls Far Short of Expectations, Poll Says
text: A CBS News poll out today suggests widespread disappointment with President Obama, as two-thirds of Americans say he has been an average or poor president, far below their expectations.

headline: Sufi Shrine in Pakistan Is Hit by a Lethal Double Bombing

text: The two largest components of consumers’ budgets — housing and transportation — fell in 2009, according to the Labor Department’s latest Consumers Expenditures survey.

headline: Abandon All Hope

headline: While Europe Scrimps, European Union Spends
text: BRUSSELS — In Greece, taxes are up and so is the age of retirement. In Spain, civil servants have taken pay cuts. In Britain, spending on welfare, the military and education could be chopped by a quarter.

headline: Ignoring Boundaries and Borrowing Freely
text: Back in 1985, when the Museum of Modern Art inaugurated its New Photography series, appropriation was very much in vogue. Richard Prince, Sherrie Levine and other “re-photographers” delighted and outraged viewers with their canny absorptions of other artists’ work. So it’s fitting that “New Photography 2010,” which marks the 25th anniversary of the series, is all about “post-appropriative practice.”

text: We haven’t written as much about Illinois as some other Senate contests — but it may be taking on an increasingly important role as some other races that had once looked to be competitive, like Connecticut and Missouri, now show a clearer advantage for one or another party.

text: –Karolina Kurkova was surprised to discover what the contestants on America’s Next Top Model ate. And we are surprised that none of them ever become top models?

text: The usual suspects on the comment board are, inevitably, arguing that rail transit should pay for itself. The obvious response is that road transit doesn’t; why should only public transit have to self-finance, when private vehicles generally drive on free roads built and maintained out of taxes?

headline: Canelés: The New Madeleine?
text: Thanks to its fame as a literary device, the tiny madeleine has an outsize reputation. But France has as many varieties of pastries as it has cheeses (though, to our knowledge, no one has ever linked them to a resistance to being governed). Two of them, the canelé, a custardy confection with a caramelized crust from Bordeaux, and the financier, an almond-flour tea cake that was first sold in the area around La Bourse (traders prized them as a convenient snack, hence the name), are favorite afternoon treats with the French.

headline: A Video For Chris Christie

headline: The Return of the Disturbing Mushroom
text: As our Urban Forager, Ava Chin, reminds us, this is high season for mushrooms in the Northeast. And few are faring better this fall than the Disturbing Mushroom of Lincoln Place, a fungus growing in an empty street-tree pit in Park Slope, Brooklyn.

headline: Devils Have Put Together a Formidable Top Line
text: NEWARK  Three players stand out at any Devils practice, and not because they are the only ones wearing white jerseys. Two of them, Ilya Kovalchuk and Zach Parise, are wings who have become renowned as prodigious scorers.

headline: First Couple Are Ohio Bound
text: Democrats in Cleveland will get a political twofer later this month: a joint campaign appearance by President Obama and his wife, Michelle.The first couple will visit the city on Oct. 17 to stump for Ohio Gov. Ted Strickland, who is in a tough race for re-election against John R. Kasich, a former Republican congressman. On Monday, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. was in Youngstown headlining a rally and fundraiser for the Democratic governor.

headline: A Craftsman’s Biography, Carved Into His Furniture
text: John Shearer eked out a living as a furniture maker in Maryland and Virginia from about 1790 to 1820. That is pretty much all scholars know about him, except that he probably was a Scottish immigrant; he inscribed furniture with references to Edinburgh; and he misspelled slogans proclaiming his loyalty to the British crown.

headline: Money Guaranteed, but a Spot on Giants’ Roster Is Not
text: SAN FRANCISCO – If the Giants needed another reminder that the $126 million, seven-year contract they lavished on Barry Zito was not a very good investment, they got one Thursday when he was left off the 25-man roster for San Francisco’s National League division series with the Atlanta Braves. Game 1 is Thursday night.

headline: The Botox Special
text: Allergan, the maker of Botox, agreed last month to pay $600 million to settle criminal and civil charges that it had illegally marketed the drug for medical uses — like headaches and pain– not approved by the Food and Drug Administration.

headline: G.M.’s Wage-Cutting Deal Clears Way for a Small Car

headline: Obama Calls for Voters to Outweigh Outside Money

headline: What a Microsoft-Adobe Merger Might Look Like
text: Thanks to our colleague Nick Bilton at Bits, we now know that the chief executives of Microsoft and Adobe Systems met recently to discuss, among other possibilities, a potential merger of the two tech giants.

headline: DC Comics to Lower Prices
text: Fans of DC Comics will have reason to celebrate in January. The company, a division of Warner Brothers Entertainment and Time Warner, announced plans to lower the price of all standard 32-page continuing comic book titles to $2.99 from $3.99.

headline: In Relief, Yankees Bullpen Lines Up Just Right
text: MINNEAPOLIS – As he so often has in the past, Mariano Rivera recorded the most important out in the Yankees’ Game 1 victory Wednesday night. Getting Denard Span to ground out with two on and two out in the eighth inning improved the Yankees’ win probability by 13 percent, according to baseball-reference.com, to 92 percent over all. Their second most important out came from someone whose brightest career postseason moment also came against the Twins in last year’s American League division series. Derek Jeter started calling Dave Robertson “Houdini” last year after he escaped a bases-loaded, no-out jam in the 11th inning of Game 2. This time, Robertson was asked to get only one out, but what an out it was, striking out Jim Thome and thwarting a two-on, two-out rally in the seventh. Robertson threw three straight curve balls to Thome. The second dropped over the plate for a called second strike. The third bounced in front of the plate and drew a feeble swing. “That was a beautiful sequence,” Alex Rodriguez said. “He came with the fastball then threw him three nasty breaking balls.” Omitting a second left-handed reliever was a calculated risk by Joe Girardi, who, with left-handed starters set to pitch in four of five games, figured that Boone Logan would be sufficient to navigate through Joe Mauer, Thome and Jason Kubel. To start the seventh, Girardi went with Logan, who got two outs but gave way to Robertson after Mauer singled. The Yankees had seven more outs to get, but the bullpen was set up almost perfectly. Kerry Wood matched up well with the bottom of the Twins’ order, which had right-handed hitters in three of four slots, and the Yankees never have to worry about matchups when Rivera came in. Every one is in Rivera’s favor. If a save situation arises again Thursday, Girardi will obviously turn to Rivera again, though he was uncertain whether he would ask him to pitch multiple innings for a second straight night. Rivera’s struggles last month began on Sept. 11, when he surrendered two ninth-inning runs in Texas, the night after working two innings, and Girardi said he was cognizant of a possible link. “I would prefer not to do it tonight, but I said that last night,” Girardi said.

headline: Letters: Scholarly Work
text: My assistant and I go through all the letters sent to the Public Editor. Starting this week, we will post selected letters responding to my columns, beginning with the group below. This week’s letters are in response to my most recent column, Scholarly Work, Without All the Footnotes.

headline: Inside 'Marwencol'
text: The photography of Mark Hogancamp, the subject of the documentary "Marwencol."

headline: When Utilities Charge for Credit Card Payments
text: Like many Bucks readers, I don’t give many service providers the privilege of siphoning money directly from my checking account. Several companies automatically charge my credit card each month, but only a sacred few — a student lender and an insurer – are allowed to pull money directly.

headline: The Man Who Repairs Time
text: When Marcel Zalaznick goes on vacation, a once-a-year event, he hangs a sign outside his watch-repair store on 30th Avenue that says, “Gone fishing.” Mr. Zalaznick, 59, is the proprietor and the sole employee of Grand Jewelers, a type of small business that feels like a rarity these days. It has been in the same spot in Queens for a long time, it turns a (modest) profit, and it is unaffected by the whims of the commercial real estate market because its owner is also its landlord.

headline: The Edit | Wait and See Boutique
text: Once a design consultant for Etro and Missoni and the creator of her own high-end knitwear line, Uberta Zambeletti personifies both Milan’s scrappy entrepreneurial side and its affinity for bourgeois, slightly bohemian luxe. Now she is channeling her finely edited high-low sensibility at Wait and See, the boutique she just opened in a former convent near the Duomo. ‘‘Milan is so full of brands, but it’s either cute little dresses or Balenciaga, with no in-between,’’ she says. ‘‘You should be able to get a great, affordable dress without having to go to Zara.’’ Wait and See carries jeans, sparkly platform shoes, organic potpourri and evening wear, with prices ranging from about $3 to $1,300. Among Zambeletti’s favorites: Sandrina Fasoli’s cocktail dresses, Owen Barry’s sheepskin coats, Isaac Reina’s leather and silicone handbags and the American label Hazel Brown’s soft leather pants. ‘‘Everything has a bit of an edge to it,’’ she says, ‘‘but nothing is too extreme.’’ Via Santa Marta 14; 011-39-02-7208-0195; waitandsee.it.

headline: Was Halladay’s Gem The Greatest Philly Sports Moment Ever? Mike Schmidt Says So
text: PHILADELPHIA – Somewhere in an old cardboard box, I have a VHS cassette from 1986 called “The Greatest Moments in Philadelphia Sports History.” I was 11 years old then, living in the Philadelphia area, and there was no doubt what would be the No. 1 moment: Tug McGraw striking out Willie Wilson to win the 1980 World Series.

headline: Grim And Grimmer
text: EPI has the video of Tuesday’s discussion on fiscal policy.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Pakistan, Afghanistan, and Kashmir.

headline: Rangers’ Tim Kennedy Finds Salary Cap an Unforgiving Opponent
text: BUFFALO  The small room where you order and pick up your pies at Imperial Pizza on the south side of this city is a shrine to the two N.H.L. players the neighborhood has produced.

headline: A Demand for Action on PCBs in Schools
text: Members of Congress and a state assemblywoman from New York City, the United Federation of Teachers and other groups have announced a plan to tackle the problem of polychlorinated biphenyls, or PCBs, in the city’s public schools. They asked the federal Environmental Protection Agency on Thursday in a letter to step in immediately and conduct thorough testing of the schools and establish firm guidelines. The letter was signed by all 13 members of New York City’s House delegation.

headline: The Caucus Click: Levittown, Pa.
text: In Levittown, Pa., a man shouts at two demonstrators as they videotape a campaign appearance by former Representative Michael G. Fitzpatrick.

headline: Grazing in Dark Woods of the Human Soul
text: Death and grief and spiritual renewal, the brutality of war and the moral responsibility of those who bear witness to it: mighty themes are chewed over exhaustively in “The Deer House,” a dance-theater work from Jan Lauwers and the Brussels-based Needcompany. The piece is making its American premiere as part of the Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

headline: House Tour: Woodstock, N.Y.
text: HOW MUCH $335,000. Taxes: $3,069.

headline: Over-the-Top Style Meets Some Good-Hearted Sense
text: As Lainie Kazan recounted her life at Feinstein’s at Loews Regency on Wednesday evening, it was as though the turning point in her career in the mid-1960s happened only last week. That was when she was an understudy for Barbra Streisand in “Funny Girl” and waited more than a year to step into the role of Fanny Brice. As she recalled, the day came, the press was invited, and Ms. Streisand appeared at the last minute.

headline: PNC Said to Be Latest Lender to Suspend Foreclosed Sales
text: The PNC Financial Services Group has suspended sales of foreclosed homes for 30 days, according to a title insurer that received the memo from the bank, becoming the fourth major lender to impose a moratorium.

headline: Picturing a Mind-Blowing World Made of Drugs
text: Is cosmic consciousness for real? I mean, if you have a religious vision, do you perceive a truly existing, transcendental dimension that is hidden from everyday awareness? Or is mystic revelation the illusory product of unusual neurochemical activity in your brain?

headline: Broad Call for Faster Action on School PCBs
text: A coalition of elected officials and unions called on Thursday for faster action from the city and federal government to monitor and, if necessary, remove hazardous chemicals known as PCBs from as many as 700 city schools, calling the problem a “serious health threat.”

headline: Russian Students Strip for Putin’s Birthday
text: Two groups of female Russian journalism students have produced dueling calendars to mark Prime Minister Vladimir Putin’s 58th birthday on Thursday.

headline: App Smart Extra: Checking the Score
text: This week’s App Smart column looks at applications for youth sports coaches who want to improve the performance of their team. A new app will help parents and other spectators track the games themselves.

headline: Putting Faith in Speed and Sinew
text: Diane Lane might be the two-legged star of “Secretariat,” a gauzy, gooey, turf-pounding, Bible-thumping tribute to the celebrated 1970s thoroughbred from the wonderful weird world of Disney. But the bigger and truer stars of this enjoyable, sometimes accidentally entertaining movie are the five horses that take turns playing Secretariat — one was used for running, another posed for the cameras — along with the memory of that original breathtaking beauty. This was a champion whose races thrilled the usual society swells and off-track gamblers along with a larger public swept up by the story of the big red horse who could and did.

headline: Pairing Up to Tango, in Every Combination
text: When Anton Gazenbeek talks about dancing tango, his words suggest that he’s referring to more than just fancy footwork.

headline: Game 2 Analysis: Yankees 5, Twins 2
text: Andy Pettitte pitched seven strong innings as the Yankees beat the Minnesota Twins, 5-2, on Thursday night in Game 2 of their American League division series.

headline: Best School Day Ever: Johnny Depp Comes to Class
text: Which member of the “Pirates of the Caribbean” team is so super-nice that he took a break from making the latest movie to appear in person at a  school in the London borough of Greenwich to meet a student who had written him a fan letter? The cinematographer Dariusz Wolski? The boom microphone operator Jeffrey A. Humphreys? How about its A-list megastar Johnny Depp, who, BBC News reports, came in character as Jack Sparrow himself?

text: Classical

headline: Genzyme Again Rejects Sanofi’s Bid
text: By MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

headline: Rock-Paper-Scissors: You vs. the Computer
text: Test your strategy against the computer in this rock-paper-scissors game illustrating basic artificial intelligence.

headline: Jazz Listings
text: Jazz

headline: A Fifth Avenue Enigma
text: MARTHA STEWART owns an apartment in the building. And you could easily run into other notables in the elevator or the lobby. You could buy an apartment on the sixth floor, with about 4,800 square feet of space, overlooking Central Park at 72nd Street, from people who have hung a Warhol in their maid’s room, and where Halle Berry and Cindy Crawford were once frequent cocktail party guests.
