text: Pop

headline: Dance Listings
text: Dance

headline: First Buyers of Nissan Leaf Get a Trunkful of Perks
text: Tax credits, rebate checks, personalized home visits, government giveaways  even customer service calls from top corporate executives.

headline: S.E.C. Calls TV Cop a Real-Life Crook
text: Three decades ago, the actor Larry Wilcox played Officer Jon Baker on the popular television show “CHiPs.”  But more recently, he has been on the other side of the law — at least according to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Pakistan, Afghanistan, and Kashmir.

headline: Rediscovering an Earthy Master
text: “Man, Myth, and Sensual Pleasures: Jan Gossart’s Renaissance” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art is a big deal. It is the first survey in this country devoted to the supple, mercurial, groundbreaking art of Gossart (1478-1532), the perennially underestimated Flemish master also known as Mabuse.

headline: Week 5 Fantasy Football Matchups
text: The brothers Sablich are here to help with fantasy football analysis for Week 5. They also answered reader questions earlier in the week. Read their answers below and follow them on Twitter for more advice leading up to game time on Sunday.

headline: Mario Vargas Llosa Speaks About the Nobel Prize, Literature and More
text: Mario Vargas Llosa thought a semester teaching at Princeton would give him some time off from the attention he attracts in Lima and Madrid. But his sojourn turned very public this morning when the Swedish Academy announced he had won the Nobel Prize in Literature.

headline: The Man Who Repairs Time
text: When Marcel Zalaznick goes on vacation, a once-a-year event, he hangs a sign outside his watch-repair store on 30th Avenue that says, “Gone fishing.” Mr. Zalaznick, 59, is the proprietor and the sole employee of Grand Jewelers, a type of small business that feels like a rarity these days. It has been in the same spot in Queens for a long time, it turns a (modest) profit, and it is unaffected by the whims of the commercial real estate market because its owner is also its landlord.

headline: Art and News, Intersecting in the Digital Age
text: After steady assault from Twitter, Facebook and Blogger Nation, we have come to this: “The Last Newspaper.” Or so the title of the New Museum’s big fall show seems to tell us. In reality the situation isn’t quite that dire. All of us partial to news in hard copy (not to mention those of us who have indoor pets) can relax, kind of, for the moment.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings
text: Art

headline: Grand Jewelers
text: Times have changed since Marcel Zalaznick graduated from watchmaking school in 1973, but timepieces still need repair.

headline: Movie and Film Series Listings
text: Movies

headline: From a Mysterious Mansion to a Ralph Lauren Store
text: THE super-luxe new Ralph Lauren palazzo, at the southwest corner of Madison Avenue and 72nd Street, is scheduled to open in mid-October. But across the street, hidden for months behind a veil of netting, is the old store, a limestone mansion with a mournful past, built in 1898 by an heiress who never lived in it.

headline: Children’s Events
text: For Children

headline: Electric Cars, Packed With Middle-Class Benefits
text: In Friday’s Times, Bill Vlasic reports on the perks of being an electric car pioneer.

headline: The Urban County Fair
text: A tour of Oakland’s Eat Real Festival.

headline: Food Groups
text: The D.I.Y. movement has never tasted (or looked) better.

headline: Spare Times
text: Around Town

headline: Rediscovering the Natural Side of the Bronx
text: ON a recent sunny Saturday in the Bronx, a handful of women taking a tour of the borough paused to gawk while a guide pointed out a pothole.

headline: Scorecard | Miu Miu Wins!
text: Oh, hey there, Marc Jacobs. One hundred forty-six shows and 1,309 reviews (23 days, that is) since Scorecard last checked in with your maybe-the-wrong-side-of-pastiche for your signature line, you spelled it out for critics with the Sontag citations in the show notes for your disco heaven redux at Vuitton that you are no Elie Saab fame monster — but a New York Intellectual. Too bad, then, that a designer rocking banana earrings since Milan had to come along with slyly subversive starlet wear for the Twi generation seated front row at Miu Miu. This is the way that Paris Fashion Week ends: not with a bang but with a giggle.

headline: Now, PNC Is Said to Halt Foreclosed Sales
text: The PNC Financial Services Group has suspended sales of foreclosed homes for 30 days, according to a title insurer that received the memo from the bank, becoming the fourth major lender to impose a moratorium, David Streitfeld of The New York Times reports.

headline: How to Record Phone Calls With Google Voice
text: Have you ever wished you could replay a phone call after it’s over? Google’s free call-handing service, Google Voice, will record calls as MP3 audio files for free, with a few caveats.

headline: Nice Daguerreotype!
text: At age 37, I find myself unexpectedly single again. So I joined Match.com, where I’ve chatted with a lot of pretty women  many of whom turn out to be far less pretty (and much older) than their online pictures make them out to be. Is this normal? Is there an etiquette for asking how recent somebody’s online pictures are? Jason, N.Y.C.

headline: Mets’ Rodriguez Looks for Plea Agreement
text: A lawyer for Mets closer Francisco Rodriguez and the Queens district attorney’s office are negotiating a plea agreement that could spare Rodriguez prison time, both sides said Thursday after a court hearing.

headline: A Storyteller Enthralled by the Power of Art
text: At first glance, Mario Vargas Llosa’s novels seem like a one-man miscellany of subjects and styles: There are harrowing narratives based on historical events like Rafael Trujillo’s tyrannical rule over the Dominican Republic (“The Feast of the Goat”) and a 19th-century religious uprising in the backlands of Brazil (“The War of the End of the World”).

headline: More Superheroes From Stan Lee
text: Stan Lee has long proved his superhuman ability to churn out comic characters. But this is starting to get a little nuts. On Thursday came word that Mr. Lee, 88, has agreed to create 30 superheroes for the National Hockey League, one for each team. On Friday, he will announce the creation of another character: Airwalker, a member of a C.I.A. group that tackles the world’s deadliest killers with the aid of miniature rocket packs developed by his scientist brother. The Airwalker comic, which will arrive in traditional and digital form in the first quarter of next year, is from Stan Lee Comics, A Squared Entertainment and Archie Comics. The three are also behind Stan Lee’s 7, a series Mr. Lee announced in July.

headline: Obama Plans to Veto Foreclosure Bill
text: White House officials said Thursday that President Obama would not sign a little-noted measure that suddenly gained attention amid questions about some big lenders’ slipshod bookkeeping on home foreclosures, Jackie Calmes of The New York Times reports from Washington.

headline: A Coming-of-Age Tale, Set Among the Sad
text: For a movie set in a psychiatric hospital, “It’s Kind of a Funny Story,” Anna Boden and Ryan Fleck’s adaptation of the novel by Ned Vizzini, is disarmingly gentle, sweet and whimsical. The New York mental institution where most of the action takes place is hardly the allegorical hellhole of “One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest.” It is overseen not by a tyrannical Nurse Ratched, but by the wise and patient Dr. Minerva, played with a benevolent glow by Viola Davis. Instead of Grand Guignol visions of madness, there is a mood of shuffling, whispery melancholy. This hospital, Argeron, feels like an oasis where the sad can congregate in safety and do their best to make one another laugh.

headline: Goal of the Year?
text: A gem of a goal. There is no other way to describe Matthew Burrows’s crazy-sick back heel that gave Glentoran F.C. a 1-0 win against visiting Portadown on Tuesday, taking Glentoran to the top of the standings in Northern Ireland.

headline: Master Chefs at a Miser’s Price and More
text: What is a hero? For some, it’s a graffiti artist who turns tags into sculptures. For others, it’s a chef who dares to cook with real butter. For misers, it’s both, and more, at heroically low prices.

headline: Ads Call Colbert’s House Testimony No Laughing Matter
text: As Stephen Colbert prepares for his triumphant return to Washington for his “Rally to Keep Fear Alive” on Oct. 30, the political right is using his last appearance in the capital to try to keep Democratic incumbents from returning after Nov. 2.

headline: Futuristic Face-Off Caps a Four-Part Program
text: Four companies. Four dances. In a new Fall for Dance program, which one will fall first? On Wednesday night, we waited until the bitter end.

headline: Sell Yourself, Rahm. Surely, You Already Know the City.
text: After the second day of Rahmapalooza, the candidate’s blog offered this update:

headline: Staring Down Death And Lust With a Sly Eye
text: A smart aleck lurks within many a rock primitivist, insisting on the difference between simple and simple-minded. That’s the situation with the Vaselines, the regrouped Scottish band that headlined Webster Hall on Wednesday night after releasing its second album, “Sex With an X” (Sub Pop), in the course of 23 years.

headline: G.M. to Build Small Cars in Lake Orion Plant
text: 9:41 a.m. | Updated

headline: Blackhawks Enter Dismal Sports Landscape
text: Like fidgety children on a car trip, the youthful Blackhawks were “are we there yet?” restless Sunday for much of the exhibition finale against the St. Louis Blues at the oddly sedate United Center.

headline: On His Own, Finding His Range Again
text: No one wants El DeBarge to fail. Not his family. Not his fans. Not even the enablers he turned to during the darker parts of the last two decades, when he struggled with addiction to a range of substances, from heroin to crack.

headline: Finding Love Over Dirty Diapers and Sippy Cups
text: It’s enough to say that the bland romantic comedy “Life as We Know It,” in which there is not a single deviation from formula, is well made for its corporate type. One sign that the movie, directed by Greg Berlanti from a screenplay by Ian Deitchman and Kristin Rusk Robinson, has its unimaginative head on straight is that its lead characters actually have jobs that the film explores in some depth.

headline: Party Hopping | Divide and Conquer
text: It’s a hoary old chestnut, but New York truly is the city that never sleeps — at least not while there is an opening in town. Last night, T’s fashion department split up and hit the streets. The Garment District showroom of Loden Dager, the American men’s-wear clothing label, threw a friends and family shopping event. In SoHo, Uniqlo celebrated the launch of the +J collection, designed by Jil Sander, by allowing guests to pre-shop without the public frenzy. Nearby, the Romanian footwear import Musette hosted fashionable feet at the opening of its first Stateside store. And across town at the Earnest Sewn boutique in the Meatpacking District, David Yurman feted his son Evan’s latest men’s jewelry collection. Yurman the Younger’s offerings included a line of sterling silver bracelets with intricate wave carvings and identification tags with classic onyx inlays. “The inspiration was Japanese prints and ornaments,” he said. “I wanted to bring craftsmanship to modern times with antiquated, traditional techniques. I feel like that is something that is lacking.”

headline: M.G.M. Outlines Its Bankruptcy Plan
text: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, the beleaguered film studio, introduced on Thursday a bankruptcy plan under which it would hand over control to its lenders, a group comprised mainly of hedge funds.

headline: Charter Education Expanding in Chicago
text: From a windowless basement office on Chicago’s West Side, Greg White is trying to answer public education’s $2 million-dollar question: What is the top priority for a school in Chicago’s cash-strapped district?

headline: Brighton Beach Reality Show to Become Reality
text: The Russians are coming to reality TV. “Brighton Beach,” an in-depth exploration of the personal dramas of Russian-Americans in Brooklyn whose gestation we documented in March, has been picked up by the Lifetime network.

headline: ‘Man, Myth, and Sensual Pleasures’
text: Images from a new exhibition of works by Jan Gossart, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: As Daley’s Tenure Nears End, Aldermen Seek New Opportunities
text: Mayor Richard M. Daley’s decision not to seek re-election next year raises the prospect of a major shift in the balance of power in City Hall.

headline: Offense Disappears, and the Rays, Down Two Games, May Soon Follow
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  The Tampa Bay Rays finished the regular season with the American League’s best record, but their hitting statistics made their success look like a magic trick. The Rays’ .247 batting average was the worst for a playoff team in nearly 30 years, and they struck out 1,292 times, more than any playoff team in history.

headline: M.G.M. Looks to File for Bankruptcy Protection
text: LOS ANGELES — The next chapter for Hollywood’s storied film studio Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer: Chapter 11, if the company has its way.

headline: House Democrat Voices First ‘No Vote’ for Pelosi
text: Representative Bobby Bright, a conservative Alabama Democrat in a tough fight for re-election, became the first incumbent member of his party to say definitively that he would not support Nancy Pelosi for speaker next year if the Democrats retain control of the House. His statement illustrated the lengths some Democratic lawmakers are going to distance themselves from the speaker, who has been cast by Republicans as the embodiment of excessive liberalism.

headline: Family Opened Up the Door to John and Yoko
text: Scott James is a columnist for The Bay Citizen.

headline: I.M.F. Chief Steps Into Dispute Over China’s Currency Policy
text: WASHINGTON  The head of the International Monetary Fund urged China on Thursday to allow its currency to rise in value, an attempt to keep a contentious issue between the United States and China from broadening into a bitter international dispute.

headline: Lennon’s Teenage Years: Rocking and Roiling
text: At its most obvious, the title of “Nowhere Boy,” a prettily photographed melodrama about a tumultuous period in John Lennon’s adolescence, is a reference to his song “Nowhere Man.” Included in the Beatles’ 1965 album “Rubber Soul,” the masterwork that pointed to new horizons (“This was the departure record,” Ringo Starr said), it has lyrics worthy of Samuel Beckett (“He’s a real nowhere man/Sitting in his nowhere land”) and a strong melancholic undertow. The song is often seen as autobiographical and, somewhat repellently, its title has been used to describe both Lennon and his killer, Mark David Chapman.

headline: Glory and Misery on the Way to Stardom
text: Acceptance speeches are definitely a lot better to give than to receive. But Patti LuPone’s 60 seconds of glory at the Tonys after her win for “Gypsy” constituted one of the highlights of that year’s telecast. Cradling the twirling medallion, she began with a sly joke. “It’s such a wonderful gift to be an actor who makes her living working on the Broadway stage,” she said, “and then every 30 years or so, pick up one of these.”

headline: Lovely in Twin Cities, With Usual Fall
text: Minneapolis

headline: Mark Zuckerberg at the Movies
text: On Wednesday night, Mark Zuckerberg invited some 400 people to watch a movie. No, not that movie. This was Mark Zuckerberg the philanthropist, not Mark Zuckerberg the Facebook chief executive. And in line with his philanthropic giving in support of education reform, the movie was “Waiting for Superman,” a poignant documentary about America’s failing public schools.

headline: Rangel, Waters Ethics Trials Set
text: The chairwoman of the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct has scheduled hearings for next month in the separate cases of Representatives Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of New York, and Maxine Waters, Democrat of California, who have been accused of ethics violations.

headline: Tackling Redistricting With Money and Zeal
text: Charles T. Munger Jr., wearing a smooth herringbone blazer and a bow tie, sat in a downtown Palo Alto office one recent morning and discussed his decision to give $7 million to support Proposition 20, a ballot initiative that would wrest Congressional redistricting powers from legislators and hand that control to a citizens panel.

headline: Video: Title Contender Outlook
text: Will any team stand in the way of No. 1 Alabama? And can Boise State get back into the national title conversation? Reporter Pete Thamel gives The Quad’s Paul Myerberg a well-deserved break in this week’s edition of the Pregame Huddle.

headline: Showcases for Locally Made Documentaries
text: When Chris Metzler decided to make the change from narrative filmmaking to documentary in 1999, friends advised him to move to San Francisco to find a like-minded community.

headline: Upright Parole Officer With a Target on His Back
text: Edward Norton looks good behind bars. In “Stone,” a brooding, low-key intrigue, Mr. Norton wears cornrows and tattoos, and much as he did in his screen debut, “Primal Fear,” keeps his performance in check. He plays the title character in the new movie, an arsonist turned inmate who’s grown weary of waiting to be released. As far as Stone can tell, or as far as the movie initially suggests, the only thing standing between him and the outside world is an unsmiling parole officer, Jack Mabry (Robert De Niro), who, when he’s not shuffling papers, listens — in his car and at home — to Christian talk radio.

headline: More Sex, Please, We’re British Rustics
text: “Tamara Drewe,” directed by Stephen Frears and written by Moira Buffini, plants its cheeky flag at the crossroads of sex farce, pastoral and high literary polish. The spot of territory it claims, which could only be in England, is a picturesque rural village populated by recognizable types, not all of them traditional rustics.

headline: Judge Rules Health Law Is Constitutional
text: A federal judge in Michigan on Thursday dismissed one of more than 15 legal challenges to the new health care law, becoming the first to rule that the law is constitutional.

headline: Political Points: Guilt-Trips and Midterm Losses
text: Click to Listen

headline: Philadelphia Inquirer Editor Out as New Owners Take Control
text: The Philadelphia Inquirer has been through a lot in the last few years: bankruptcy, two new owners and layoffs, just to name some of it.

headline: Here’s the Pub, Church and Field for Public Sex
text: PUTTENHAM, England — There was the man they called “Bob the Builder,” who wore only a hard hat. There was the naked sunbather who remarked, “Nice day for it, isn’t it?” to a woman taking a walk. And there was the moment, Jules Perkins said, when the dizzying array of sexual forces that have somehow descended on her blameless Surrey village came together all at once, like a scene from a one-size-fits-all X-rated film.

headline: Contract Lengths and Guarantees May Be N.B.A.’s Targets
text: PARIS  It took two years of furious roster shuffling and careful bookkeeping for the Knicks to land a star player and create the chance for a rebirth. Their endeavor provides some hints about where the N.B.A. might be heading in its labor negotiations.

headline: Richardson Shapes New Mexico Race
text: ALBUQUERQUE  Although Gov. Bill Richardson’s name is being sullied on the airwaves and in campaign debates up and down this border state, Susana Martinez, the Republican candidate to replace him, is not  technically at least  running against him.

headline: Death by Chicken Tikka, in Service of Romance
text: Four gastronomic murders (a chicken-tikka kebab in the neck, suffocation by naan) have hit Southall, an Indian neighborhood in London, and the hunky cop Raj Murthy (Sendhil Ramamurthy, from “Heroes”) is sent undercover to investigate. The perpetrator is Mrs. Sethi (the venerable Shabana Azmi), a widow whose passionate defense of her full-figured daughter, Roopi (Goldy Notay), has taken a homicidal turn. Mrs. Sethi, you see, feels she cannot join her husband in death until she has married off Roopi, whom the victims made the mistake of mistreating.

headline: G.O.P. Senate Odds Improve for Third Consecutive Week
text: Democrats are on the verge of locking up several Senate races in the Northeast, including one in Connecticut that some analysts had considered a toss-up. But Republicans have gained ground overall in this week’s Senate forecast by virtue of improved polling in Nevada and West Virginia. Their odds of taking over the Senate on Nov. 2 have now improved to 24 percent — up from 22 percent last week and 15 percent three weeks ago, according to the FiveThirtyEight forecast model.

headline: Hevesi Successor Cleared in Inquiry
text: Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo’s office said Thursday that it had cleared the current state comptroller, Thomas P. DiNapoli, in its pension investigation.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,306 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: Sex on the Run? No, We Parked
text: TEN years ago I worked briefly as a production accountant on a television show called “Welcome to New York,” a sitcom starring Jim Gaffigan as a TV weatherman and Christine Baranski as his city-slicker boss.

headline: Addressing Your Cat’s ... Ahem ... Solid Waste
text: BECAUSE consumers know perfectly well what function cat litter serves, brands have not been compelled to spell out what Fluffy does in the litter box, and instead dwell on what the products do: reduce odor. Now, however, Arm & Hammer, which makes Multi-Cat and Super Scoop cat litters, is introducing a new variety, Double Duty, and to highlight its unique selling point, the brand decided there was no room for euphemism.

headline: Model Town as Safe Haven
text: Four years in the making, “Marwencol” emerges as a number of things: an absorbing portrait of an outsider artist; a fascinating journey from near-death to active life; a meditation on the brain’s ability to forge new pathways when old ones have been destroyed. Woven together by Jeff Malmberg — if not seamlessly, then with illuminating patience — these disparate strands honor an individual as unique as the miniature universe on which he depends.

headline: Afghans Linked to the Taliban Guard U.S. Bases
text: WASHINGTON  Afghan private security forces with ties to the Taliban, criminal networks and Iranian intelligence have been hired to guard American military bases in Afghanistan, exposing United States soldiers to surprise attack and confounding the fight against insurgents, according to a Senate investigation.

headline: The Closing Flourish Is the Campy Kind
text: Paris

headline: Visiting New York, Seeking Vengeance
text: Several varieties of creepy run through “As Good as Dead,” a gruesomely alluring tale of long-simmering revenge, but the guy you especially don’t want showing up at your door is Frank Whaley.

headline: Mexican Leader Pushes Police Overhaul
text: MEXICO CITY  Mexico’s sweeping plan to revamp the nation’s local police departments, a bid to deter corruption and infiltration by drug trafficking organizations, moved forward this week when President Felipe Calderón made a formal proposal to Congress.

headline: A Normal Flu Season Unfolds
text: Flu activity in the Southern Hemisphere, where the flu season is ending, has been “typical,” the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said Thursday. All three types of flu that normally circulate are present, although the H1N1 “swine flu” strain that caused last year’s pandemic has replaced the seasonal H1N1 strain that circulated before 2009. The seasonal flu shots now available in the United States are a good match for all three, and the agency urged shots for everyone over 6 months old, and particularly for pregnant women, young children, health care workers, parents of infants and people with conditions like asthma, diabetes and heart disease.

headline: Washington: Court-Martial Recommended in Afghan Killings
text: An Army investigating officer has recommended court-martial proceedings for Specialist Jeremy N. Morlock, one of five American soldiers accused of killing three Afghan civilians this year. Specialist Morlock and other soldiers have said in sworn statements that the killings were staged to look like combat deaths. Lawyers for Specialist Morlock have argued that he was heavily medicated with prescription drugs at the time of the killings and the statements. The recommendation for court-martial follows an investigative hearing last week. A final decision on whether to refer him to court-martial will be made by the commander of the Stryker brigade in which the soldiers serve. The other soldiers await investigative hearings.

headline: Junk Bonds Are Back on Top
text: Jim Casey remembers the fast times when Michael R. Milken ruled Wall Street as the billionaire king of junk bonds.

headline: A Study in Middle East Nonviolence
text: American audiences watching the documentary “Budrus,” about a pioneering effort in nonviolent protest by Palestinians in the West Bank, will find many of the images familiar. The marching, the chanting, the nerve-racking encounters between protesters and jumpy, heavily armed young policemen and soldiers: it’s “Eyes on the Prize” with olive trees.

headline: Outside Court, a Failure to Be Fearful
text: Not one, not two, but three terrorism cases weaved their way simultaneously this week through the federal courthouse in Lower Manhattan. You can make that four cases if you go back two weeks to include a Pakistani woman, Aafia Siddiqui, who received a super-long prison sentence for trying to kill Americans in Afghanistan.

headline: S.&P. Says Cost to Care for Elderly Will Spiral
text: Credit analysts at Standard & Poor’s said on Thursday that the cost of caring for the world’s aging populations would be “on an explosive path” and could swamp the budgets of many countries in the next 40 years unless governments accelerated belt-tightening efforts that are already proving highly unpopular.

headline: Picture Books No Longer a Staple for Children
text: Picture books are so unpopular these days at the Children’s Book Shop in Brookline, Mass., that employees there are used to placing new copies on the shelves, watching them languish and then returning them to the publisher.

headline: Mets Move Forward With G.M. Search
text: PHILADELPHIA — The Mets will begin interviewing candidates to be their next general manager early next week.

headline: The Editor of Page Six Is Departing After 25 Years
text: New York gossip will never be the same.

headline: Rumors Are Gone; Now the Hornets’ Test Begins
text: WESTWEGO, La.  Chris Paul played pickup games in Miami, Las Vegas, Washington and cities in between this summer, testing his surgically repaired knee and resting his concerns.

headline: Preparing for Sightlessness
text: In “Going Blind,” a documentary pegged to his own glaucoma, Joseph Lovett seems largely interested in convincing himself that losing his sight won’t be so bad. That leaves the film feeling less like a hard look at the fears and challenges of being visually impaired and more like a cheerleading exercise.

headline: Poor Prospects for New Climate Meeting
text: WASHINGTON  With wounds still raw from the chaotic United Nations climate conference in Copenhagen last December, negotiators are making final preparations for next month’s meeting in Cancún, Mexico, in a surly mood and with little hope for progress.

headline: Postseason Begins; So Do Calls for Replay
text: MINNEAPOLIS  Day 1 of the postseason began with a disputed call in the first inning of the first division series game at Tampa Bay, and it ended with another in the last inning of the last game at Target Field. Symmetry, in this case, was not good.

headline: Make Wall Street Risk It All
text: Two years after the near collapse of capitalism, we certainly have our fill of financial reforms. The 2,200-page Dodd-Frank Act, which President Obama signed this summer, creates an Orwellian alphabet soup of new agencies, oversight boards and offices intended to protect us from ourselves.

headline: Phillies’ Ruiz Quietly Built Toward Perfection
text: PHILADELPHIA  The clubhouse is not a place for reflection. Players live in the moment, preparing for the next game. They have little interest in taking stock of their achievements. Usually.

headline: An Exploitation Film, Remade
text: A title like “I Spit on Your Grave” has a lot to live up to, even had it not belonged to one of the classics of exploitation cinema: Meir Zarchi’s sickening — and visually horrendous — 1978 rampage, originally titled “Day of the Woman.” Mr. Zarchi returns as an executive producer for Steven R. Monroe’s remake, which may be one reason that Stuart Morse’s screenplay takes few liberties with the story. Those he does take, however, are a significant improvement.

headline: California Lawmakers Pass Overdue Budget
text: LOS ANGELES — Faced with huge budget deficits and a stubbornly sour economy, California lawmakers Friday approved a $126 billion state budget — 100 days late — including a $3.5 billion cut to the beleaguered public school system. It was a deadline-breaking record that served as a reminder of the problems that have paralyzed California government as it struggles through one of the grimmest fiscal crises in its history.

headline: Favre and Sanchez Meet at a Hectic Intersection
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Before Brett Favre, the Jets practiced in an outdated facility on Long Island, played in a stadium named for another team and worked for a reclusive owner, all in the large shadow of the Giants.

headline: Paladino Tries to Reset His Campaign for Governor
text: Seeking a reset of his faltering campaign for governor, Carl P. Paladino bought a three-minute advertisement on local television stations in Buffalo on Thursday to try to persuade New Yorkers that he is a serious candidate for governor, despite recent flare-ups and angry outbursts.

headline: Chicago Democrats Come Out for Obama — Except for One
text: CHICAGO — There were a lot of heavy-hitting Chicago Democrats at the Drake Hotel on Thursday night for a fund-raiser attended by President Obama.

headline: Some in G.O.P. Find Soft Spot for Bill Clinton
text: WASHINGTON  Many Republicans with a deep animus for President Obama find their hearts aflutter with the memory of a former leader. He was a compassionate conservative, a guy who cared about free trade, a man who reached across the aisle.

headline: Plan to Ban Food Stamps for Sodas Has Hurdles
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg may face legal and political hurdles in carrying out his ambitious plan to bar food-stamp recipients from using their benefits to buy sugar-sweetened drinks, food policy experts said Thursday.

headline: Old Brooklyn Advice for Reds: Fuhgeddaboudit
text: PHILADELPHIA  There are no training manuals on how to recover from a no-hitter in the postseason. Only scant evidence exists because only once before has a team had to rebound from one.

headline: They Unpaved Paradise
text: City limits, property lines and state borders appear clear and inviolable on a map. But things are trickier on the ground, and even more so on the water, where such neatly drawn lines are bypassed by flooding rivers or wandering runoff. Water, particularly in ever-shifting wetlands, meanders between civilization and wilderness, reminding us that both are conduits in a larger circulatory system.

headline: The Beagle Vanishes
text: This is the fourth in a series.

headline: A Fishing Paradise Gains a Deadly Reputation
text: HOUSTON  For decades, Falcon Lake was known primarily as an anglers’ paradise, a tranquil reservoir straddling the border with Mexico where a clever fisherman could catch enormous largemouth bass. These days, however, the lake is developing a reputation for something else: piracy.

headline: Flawed Foreclosure Documents Thwart Home Sales
text: OCALA, Fla.  Amanda Ducksworth was supposed to move in to her new home this week, a three-bedroom steal here in central Florida with a horse farm across the road. Instead, she is camped out with her 7-year-old son at her boss’s house.

headline: Who Will Rescue America’s Schools?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Playoff Photo Replay: Oct. 7
text: The Texas Rangers beat the Tampa Bay Rays, 6-0, to take a 2-0 lead in their American League division series.

headline: Science Fiction for the Great Recession
text: “Jim” is two or maybe three movies in one. There’s an angry downsizing drama, a sort of “Falling Down” for the derivatives age, that overlaps with a cautionary tale about modern medicine and genetic engineering, and these connect in a hazy way to a dystopian science-fiction fantasy set on a future earth populated by clones. What they all share is a reliance on cliché and a limited visual imagination that is aggravated, in the science-fiction segments, by the film’s minuscule budget.

headline: Dealing With China
text: To the Editor:

headline: Christie Helped Lose Grant for Schools, Ex-Official Says
text: Before rejecting a compromise with teachers that would have won New Jersey a $400 million federal education grant, Gov. Chris Christie’s main objection was that it would appear that he had given in to the teachers’ union, a former education commissioner testified on Thursday.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Phillips Talbot, U.S. Envoy in Cold War, Dies at 95
text: Phillips Talbot, an American diplomat who helped mediate crises in South Asia and the Middle East during the cold war, died on Oct. 1 at his home in Manhattan. He was 95.

headline: Ghailani Case Ruling Spurs Debate on Trial’s Value
text: When a federal judge barred prosecutors on Wednesday from using a crucial witness in the first civilian trial of a former Guantánamo terrorism detainee, the ruling  widely perceived as a major setback for the government  contained an unusual observation.

headline: The Ex-Con and the Priest
text: Moon-faced, mannish and with the shoulders of a hod carrier, Leila (Kaarina Hazard) is not your average movie heroine. Mysteriously pardoned after serving 12 years of a life sentence (for what, we can initially only imagine), Leila grudgingly accepts a position as personal assistant to Father Jacob (Heikki Nousiainen), a blind priest holed up in a rundown rural rectory.

headline: Expanding Control, Taliban Refresh Stamp on Afghan Justice
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  A Taliban court had already scheduled the sentencing of a young Afghan aid worker named Attiqullah, when NATO forces raided the Taliban prison where he was being held in mid-August.

headline: ‘Texas Two-Step’ Helps Yankees’ Series Bid
text: MINNEAPOLIS — On his first day with the Yankees after 11 seasons as a leading man with Houston, Lance Berkman ambled into the visiting dugout at Tropicana Field in July and made a promise. In his Texas twang, Berkman said that he was not looking to “crow like a rooster” or anything. He just wanted to fit in.

headline: An Inevitable Slide for Americans’ Standard of Living
Cuomo and Paladino to Debate at Hofstra, With 5 Other Candidates
text: Andrew M. Cuomo and Carl P. Paladino will debate after all  but they won’t be alone.

headline: Prosecutors Will Examine City’s Role in Girl’s Death
text: The Brooklyn district attorney’s office has opened a rare and wide-ranging criminal investigation into the actions of the city and outside health and social service providers responsible for the well-being of Marchella Pierce, the 4-year-old girl who weighed 18 pounds when she died last month.

headline: MGM Is Rallying Support for a Reorganization
text: LOS ANGELES  The next chapter for Hollywood’s venerable film studio Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer: Chapter 11, if the company has its way.

headline: Loose Connections That Lead to Horror
text: “Red White & Blue,” the latest feature from the British director Simon Rumley, builds a triptych of character studies into an engrossing — and profoundly distressing — tale of random connection and specific revenge.

headline: Knicks Form Quick Bond; Results May Take Longer
text: PARIS  It was 6:45 a.m. Thursday when the line began forming inside the luxury hotel on Rue de Castiglione. The Knicks were just another party of bleary-eyed travelers, waiting to reconcile room charges and begin the long journey home.

headline: Months After Cutbacks, M.T.A. Approves Higher Fares
text: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority approved a package of fare increases on Thursday for its subways, buses and commuter railroads, the third time in three years that New Yorkers will face a sharp rise in the cost of getting around.

headline: Lee and Halladay Are Linked by More Than a Trade
text: Cliff Lee and Roy Halladay will always be linked through the Philadelphia Phillies, who essentially swapped one ace for the other last December. But their connection goes deeper than that, especially in light of their stellar performances on Wednesday.

headline: To Cut Costs, Islanders Consider Radio Deal With Hofstra
text: Radio and television broadcasts are the lifeblood of any sports team, a way to reach fans who cannot get to the stadium or arena.

headline: Making Congress All It Can Be
text: The attraction of reading what a sitting Supreme Court justice has to say about interpreting the Constitution is undoubtedly what has turned Justice Stephen G. Breyer’s new book, “Making Our Democracy Work,” into a surprise best seller. Commentators and reviewers have also emphasized the Constitution-related passages in the book, particularly Justice Breyer’s cogent analysis of why “originalism” falls short and why the interpretive goal should be to engage with the framers’ deepest values rather replicate their 18th-century frame of reference. His point, as the book’s title suggests, is for judges to make their way through the mists of history to a Constitution that works today.

headline: Canada: Ex-Commander of Air Base to Plead Guilty to Dozens of Charges
text: The former commander of Canada’s largest air force base will plead guilty to the murder of two women, two sexual assaults, two charges of unlawful confinement and 82 counts of breaking and entering, mainly involving thefts of women’s lingerie, his lawyer told a civilian court in Belleville, Ont., on Thursday. Col. Russell Williams, above, who occasionally piloted Canadian government flights carrying the prime minister and other dignitaries, is accused of carrying out the killings in a village near Canadian Forces Base Trenton, which provides logistical support for Canada’s military mission in Afghanistan. Many of the break-ins occurred in Ottawa, where Colonel Williams also lived. The Ottawa Citizen reported that about 500 pieces of women’s undergarments were seized from his townhouse there.

headline: France: Full-Face Veil Ban Approved
text: France’s top legal authority, the Constitutional Council, on Thursday approved a law banning full-face veils in public. The council said that the law was constitutional, but that it could not be applied in public places of worship because of the freedom of religion. The decision is the last hurdle for the ban, which has been criticized as stigmatizing Muslim women and violating individual freedom. The law, which will take force next year, sets fines for women who cover their faces in public and criminal penalties for those who force women to wear the full veil. The law is expected to be challenged in the European Court of Justice for violating European human rights law.

headline: The Ability to Push for Candidates, Not Just Issues
text: The Supreme Court’s landmark ruling in Citizens United has absorbed the bulk of the attention when it comes to recent changes on the campaign finance landscape.

headline: Money Talks Louder Than Ever in Midterms
text: The dominant story line of this year’s midterm elections is increasingly becoming the torrents of money, much of it anonymous, gushing into House and Senate races across the country.

headline: Popular Gift for Paladino: Bats to Fight Corruption
text: BUFFALO  Carl P. Paladino often speaks of clobbering the ineffective state government in Albany with a baseball bat. Now, he may actually be able to do so.

headline: Boy, 4, Is Killed by a Bus in Brooklyn
text: A 4-year-old boy was killed and his mother was badly injured Thursday evening when they were hit by a bus in Brooklyn after the boy darted into the street, the police said.

headline: Milka Planinc, Former Yugoslav Premier, Dies at 85
text: PRAGUE  Milka Planinc, the prime minister of the former Yugoslavia in the early 1980s and its first female premier, died Thursday in Zagreb. She was 85.

headline: Jets’ Jenkins Will Try to Return From Third A.C.L. Tear
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — I’ve been meeting once a week with Kris Jenkins since he tore his anterior cruciate ligament for a third time, against Baltimore in Week 1. On Thursday, inside an interview room at the Jets’ facility, Jenkins ate chicken wings and smiled as he announced: “I’ve made a decision. I’m coming back. I have to. You know why? It’s my choice. I choose to. I don’t need any more money. I don’t need anyone’s approval. I still want to leave my mark.”

headline: South Africa: Leader’s Approval Falls
text: Battered by a strike by public employees that crippled hospitals and schools and the perception that his 28-year-old son was using political connections to get rich, President Jacob Zuma’s approval rating among urban adults plunged to a new low of 42 percent, according to 2,000 face-to-face interviews conducted last month in seven cities by TNS Research Surveys. The poll has a margin of sampling error of about plus or minus 2 percentage points. The result suggests that the glow from the successful World Cup this summer has already worn off for Mr. Zuma, in office since May 2009.

headline: Duke Winces as a Private Joke Slips Out of Control
text: DURHAM, N.C. — For nearly two weeks, many here on the Duke University campus had been aware of a certain senior “thesis” that a recent graduate wrote, apparently as a private joke, about her sexual exploits with 13 student-athletes.

headline: Friday: The Great Pretender
text: Today’s puzzle was a smorgasbord of surprises and cleverness, with snippets of information thrown in from many walks of life. I’d categorize it as a “What was your favorite clue?” type of puzzle. In my case, top honors goes to “What can give you a heads-up?” for COIN TOSS.

headline: Wounds of War Run Deeper Than Ever
text: That a good play can sometimes make you feel bad is fairly obvious. If you make it to the sanguinary close of one of Shakespeare’s tragedies with nary an inward wince, for example, something is definitely amiss. It was about halfway through my latest visit to Donald Margulies’s “Time Stands Still,” which reopened on Broadway on Thursday night at the Cort Theater, after a summer hiatus, that my inward wincing became pretty unbearable.

headline: Ethics Head Sets Dates for Hearings
text: The chairwoman of the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct has scheduled hearings for next month in the separate cases of Representatives Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of New York, and Maxine Waters, Democrat of California, who have been accused of ethics violations.

headline: Examining an Activist’s Death
text: “Rachel,” Simone Bitton’s fascinating if uneven documentary about Rachel Corrie, the activist killed in Gaza in 2003, shares a goal with “My Name Is Rachel Corrie,” the controversial Off Broadway play from 2006. Both lionize this 23-year-old protester from Olympia, Wash., who was crushed under a mound of dirt pushed by an Israeli bulldozer clearing a Palestinian area.

headline: Holiday on Monday Columbus Day
text: NEW YORK

headline: Democrats Defend Mass. Seat Once Deemed Safe
text: In a post-Scott-Brown world – where tea parties and pickup trucks can win the hearts of those thought to be the country’s most liberal voters – Massachusetts is no longer a Democratic safe haven.

headline: A Love Triangle Without the Bollywood
text: “Bombay Summer” sounds like a Bollywood film, but the only singing or dancing takes place on battered LPs (good) or in a cocaine-infested nightclub (bad). Written and directed by Joseph Mathew-Varghese, who is based in New York, it’s the rare film set in India that speaks the melancholy language of the international art house.

headline: Bloggingheads: Hidden Puppet Masters
text: Todd Gitlin of Columbia University and David Weigel of Slate discuss conspiratorial thinking in American politics.

headline: Pakistani Army Chief Orders Video Inquiry
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The chief of the Pakistani Army said Friday that he had ordered an inquiry into an Internet video that shows men in Pakistani military uniforms executing six young men in civilian clothes.

headline: ‘The Last Newspaper’
text: Images from an exhibition at the New Museum.

headline: Using a Workout to Rest Up
text: AS a six-day-a-week exerciser who favors high-intensity workouts, I consider the seventh day enough rest. But it turns out that moving even more might be a smarter way to let my muscles recover and help me to push myself harder in the gym.

headline: The Experiments in Guatemala
text: A medical historian’s discovery that American researchers in the 1940s deliberately infected hundreds of people in Guatemala with syphilis or gonorrhea has provoked outrage in both countries. President Obama and Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton rightly apologized to President Álvaro Colom of Guatemala. More will be needed to make amends, beginning with a planned investigation of this appalling breach of medical ethics.

headline: The Chamber of Commerce
text: To the Editor:

headline: Recusals and the Court
text: Justice Elena Kagan’s seat was empty when the second case of the new term of the Supreme Court was called for oral argument on Monday. Because of her previous job as President Obama’s solicitor general, she has, so far, recused herself from 25 of 51 cases accepted.

headline: New York’s Pension Scandal
text: Alan Hevesi, the former comptroller, has provided the best argument to stop giving one person the power to invest New York State’s $125 billion pension fund.

headline: The Facebook Searchers
text: In 1952, two-thirds of Harvard applicants were admitted. The average verbal SAT score for incoming freshmen was 583. If your father went to Harvard, you had a 90 percent chance of getting in.

headline: The End of the Tunnel
text: The Erie Canal. Hoover Dam. The Interstate Highway System. Visionary public projects are part of the American tradition, and have been a major driver of our economic development.

headline: Hard Truths on the Spill
text: In May, President Obama asked a blue-ribbon commission to determine the causes of the BP oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, find out “what worked and didn’t” in the government’s response and identify ways to make drilling safer. He asked for frank talk, and he’s getting it.

headline: Game 2 Replay: Yankees 5, Twins 2
text: An impressive game from Lance Berkman and Andy Pettitte brought the New York Yankees to 2-0 against the Minnesota Twins.

headline: Quarterback Dazzles for Cornhuskers
text: MANHATTAN, Kan.  From Ogallala to Alliance and from Omaha to Norfolk, Nebraskans are starting to utter the name of Taylor Martinez alongside some of the most potent and beloved of Cornhusker quarterbacks. Turner Gill. Tommie Frazier. Eric Crouch.

headline: Tributes to a Young Suicide Victim at a Hometown Forum
text: RIDGEWOOD, N.J.  After all the anti-bullying pleas, the celebrity testimonials and the huge gatherings at Rutgers, an event to honor Tyler Clementi’s life and reflect on the meaning of his death was held in his hometown on Thursday night in an old stone church.

headline: Cuddyer and Twins Struggle for Answers
text: MINNEAPOLIS — When reporters entered the Twins’ clubhouse after their 5-2 loss to the Yankees on Thursday night, first baseman Michael Cuddyer stood at his locker, prepared for the onslaught of difficult questions.

headline: Guard Held in Sexual Attack on Transgender Inmate
text: A New York City correction officer was arrested and charged on Thursday with forcing a transgender inmate to engage in a sex act with him at a Manhattan jail.

headline: Roy Ward Baker, Prolific British Filmmaker, Dies at 93
text: Roy Ward Baker, an undersung British filmmaker who directed “A Night to Remember,” a vivid black-and-white rendering of the sinking of the Titanic revered by history and movie buffs alike, died on Tuesday in London. He was 93.

headline: Money in the Midterms
text: Following a Supreme Court ruling and other decisions, politically linked groups feel empowered to make direct appeals for or against electoral candidates.

headline: With Lincecum Pitching, a Lead Feels Insurmountable
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Tim Lincecum climbed atop a small stage Wednesday and sat down to answer questions from the news media, moments after Roy Halladay finished off his no-hitter in Philadelphia.

headline: After Betfair, Moneybookers I.P.O. Planned
text: Investcorp, the Bahrain-based investment bank, plans to float Moneybookers, the fast-growing European online payment firm it tried to sell last year, four people familiar with the matter told Reuters on Thursday.

text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: HSBC Told to Increase Money-Laundering Controls
text: HSBC North America Holdings has been ordered to improve its compliance with money-laundering laws, federal regulators said Thursday, The Associated Press reports.

text: Jim Casey remembers the fast times when Michael R. Milken ruled Wall Street as the billionaire king of junk bonds, Nelson D. Schwartz writes in The New York Times.

headline: New U.S. Options Exchange Is Planned
text: The International Securities Exchange is planning to start  a second exchange for trading American stock options, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing a person familiar with the situation.

text: The Treasury Department on Friday announced a $1.5 billion lending initiative to promote small businesses at the state level, Reuters reports.

text: Test your knowledge of history with today’s question, about the Oct. 8, 1982, ban on all labor organizations in this Eastern-bloc country.

headline: U.A.E. Says BlackBerry Dispute Is Resolved
text: The United Arab Emirates backed off a threat to cut crucial services on BlackBerry smart phones Friday, just days before the ban on the device made by Research in Motion was set to take effect, The Associated Press reports.

headline: A Dinner to Please the Persnickety Parent
text: This week readers want different ways to celebrate birthdays. As always, send your restaurant questions to dinejournal@nytimes.com or Twitter.com/samsifton.

headline: Spare Times: For Children
text: Rose Center 10th Anniversary Celebration

headline: To What Writer Would You Award a Prize?
text: This week, the Nobel Prize in Literature was awarded to the Peruvian writer Mario Vargas Llosa. If you were in charge of giving a prize to a writer, what would the prize be for and to whom would you give it? Pretend that you could give it to any writer you like for any reason at all. For instance, you might choose to give a prize for “best characters” to a favorite children’s book writer, or you might give an award for “best play-by-play” to a sportswriter, or “most realistic dialogue” to a writer of young-adult books. Whom would you like to honor? Why?

headline: Norris: How Did This Pass?
text: From Floyd Norris’s blog:

headline: SocGen Open to Solution on Kerviel Fine
text: Société Générale‘s chief of communications, Caroline Guillaumin, told French radio on Thursday that making Jérôme Kerviel, whose 50 billion euros in rogue trades led the bank to take huge losses in 2008, pay the 4.9 billion euro fine decided Tuesday by a French court was “out of the question.”

headline: F.D.I.C. Is Said to Plan New Liquidation Rules
text: The federal banking regulator is expected to propose new rules for seizing and dismantling large financial firms on the verge of collapse, Reuters said, citing a report in The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Potash Scoffs at BHP, While Sinochem Waits
text: The chief executive of the Potash Corporation went on the offensive against its unwanted suitor on Thursday, confidently describing BHP Billiton‘s $130-a-share hostile bid as “non-starter” even though a competing offer has yet to emerge.

headline: Vodafone Buys Two Expense Management Firms
text: Vodafone is spending $9.7 million to buy two firms specializing in managing telecom expenses, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Nobel Peace Prize Given to Jailed Chinese Dissident
text: BEIJING — Liu Xiaobo, an impassioned literary critic, political essayist and democracy advocate repeatedly jailed by the Chinese government for his activism, has won the 2010 Nobel Peace Prize in recognition of “his long and non-violent struggle for fundamental human rights in China.”

headline: Plane-Crashing Money Manager Gets 10 Years
text: A judge Thursday ignored pleas for leniency from an Indiana money manager who conned friends into investing in a fund that didn’t exist and tried to fake his death by parachuting out of a plane and crashing it when the scheme started to fall apart, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Philadelphia Paper Shake-Up on Eve of Court Sale
text: The editor of The Philadelphia Inquirer has stepped down on the eve of a bankruptcy court’s $139 million sale of the newspaper company to creditors, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Actelion Is Said to Explore Potential Sale
text: Actelion, a Swiss biotech drug maker, has formed a special board committee to explore a potential sale of the company, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing unnamed sources.

headline: Ahmad Bradshaw Misses Another Practice
text: When Ahmad Bradshaw missed practice on Wednesday because of a sore ankle, he played down the seriousness of the injury. But there are new questions about his status for Sunday’s game against the Houston Texans after he sat out again on Thursday. “He’s a little better,” Coach Tom Coughlin said. “I think we’ll get him tomorrow.”

headline: When Flemish and French Art Met
text: Following up its exhibition of Flemish painting last year, the Musée Jacquemart-André in Paris has opened a new show that highlights the cross-fertilization of Flemish and French art.

headline: The Uncertainties of Pay-for-Performance
text: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

headline: ‘Making an Amends’
text: Meg e-mails: “I am a member of a 12-step program in which the eighth and ninth steps refer to ‘making amends.’ When people share their experience with these steps, they often talk about ‘making an amends’ as if it were a combination of singular and plural. I find this so annoying that I may need to make amends for interrupting people to correct their grammar. But perhaps I am in error. Could you please advise as to the correctness of ‘making an amends’?"

headline: U.S. Chamber Threatens to Challenge Overhaul
text: The United States Chamber of Commerce is mounting a new legal attack on the Obama administration’s regulatory policies just weeks ahead of Congressional elections, telling voters that Democrat-driven regulation is hurting the economic recovery.

headline: Asian I.P.O.’s Reflect Growth and Liquidity
text: Initial public offerings from the logistics unit of the Singapore wealth fund G.I.C. and a Philippine budget airline drew strong demand from investors, underscoring how Asia’s robust economic growth and rising currencies are acting as a magnet for capital, Reuters reported.

headline: Favre Says He Hopes Jets Fans Appreciated His Effort
text: Eagles fans once jeered Santa Claus, so Brett Favre probably wouldn’t be surprised if some equally intense fans booed him Monday night at New Meadowlands Stadium.

headline: Iceland Banks May Forgive $2 Billion in Debts
text: Iceland’s banks may come under pressure to forgive about $2 billion in mortgage debt after protests this week prompted the government to consider proposals from the island’s homeowner protection group, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Carlyle Betting Patience Will Pay Off in India
text: The Carlyle Group is betting that patience will be rewarded in an Indian market where global players have had to content themselves almost exclusively with deals for minority stakes, Reuters reported.

headline: Is Gold Rally Due for Correction? Ask Gartman

headline: Nobel Prize Is Seen as Rebuke to China
text: BEIJING — Few nations today stand as more of a challenge to the democratic model of governance than China, where an 89-year-old Communist Party has managed to quash political movements while creating a roaring, quasi-market economy and enforcing a veneer of social stability.

headline: I.L.F.C. Pays Back $2 Billion in Debt
text: The International Lease Finance Corporation, the jet-leasing unit of the bailed-out insurer American International Group, said Thursday that it had paid back $2 billion in loans, which it needed during the financial crisis of 2008.

headline: Reviewer Spotlight: Miguel Syjuco
text: Miguel Syjuco, the author of the novel “Ilustrado,” makes his debut in the Book Review this weekend with his review of “How to Read the Air,” Dinaw Mengestu’s second novel. Both of these writers use the immigrant experience to explore themes of family and homeland, politics and identity. In an e-mail conversation, I recently asked Syjuco about his own writing, and the questions and subjects currently driving his work.

In an e-mail conversation, I recently asked Syjuco about his own writing, and the questions and subjects currently driving his work.

headline: How Do Democrats Make a Final Economic Pitch?
text: 12:43 p.m. | Updated The release of the jobs report Friday morning sparked a fresh round of rhetoric as both parties attempt to spin the numbers to their advantage in the three weeks left before election day.

headline: Wall Street Tailor Looks West
text: Mitchells stores , a Connecticut clothier to hedge funds and corporate chiefs, prospered with Wall Street until the financial crisis battered sales. Now, the group sees its California counterpart as the path to growth, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: Complaint Box | Twin Discrimination
text: When you’re outnumbered, you learn to up your game — fast. I had twins almost three years ago and decided to stay home with them. I needed to play zone defense if I was ever going to get out of the house.

headline: Week 5 N.F.L. Matchups
text: Chiefs (3-0) at Colts (2-2)Sunday, 1:00 p.m.Line: Colts by 7 1/2Peyton Manning could take the field with the cast of “Modern Family” and still produce a 12-win season. At least that’s the perception. Indianapolis has lost two divisional games and all of its experienced safeties are injured, but there has been little hand-wringing about the team’s playoff chances. So what if the rookie Brandon King and the off-the-street free agent DaJuan Morgan have replaced Bob Sanders and Melvin Bullitt in the secondary? As long as Julie Bowen and Eric Stonestreet aren’t covering deep zones in the cover-2 and Manning isn’t scaring those cute kids with his noisy audibles, everything will be just fine.

headline: Afghan Governor Is Killed in Blast at Mosque
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  In an audacious attack, insurgents assassinated the governor of Kunduz Province on Friday by bombing the mosque where he attended the weekly Friday Prayer, according to Afghan officials.

headline: Abu Dhabi Fund Hedges Barclays Stake

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Return to Oz
text: The collected edition of “The Marvelous Land of Oz,” the comic-book version of the L. Frank Baum novel, touches down at No. 5 on the New York Times hardcover list this week. The book is a sequel to “The Wonderful Wizard of Oz,” by the writer Eric Shanower and the artist Skottie Young, which made its debut at No. 9 on the graphic novel hardcover list in September 2009.

headline: Q. & A. With Bernie Williams
text: Bernie Williams, a four-time World Series winner with the Yankees, is now a guitarist with another nine-man team, a jazz band. Informally known as Bernie Williams and the All-Star Band, the group will appear on Oct. 23 at the Lafayette Theater in Suffern, N.Y. Williams, 42, is also a spokesman for the Priceless NYC Reserved by MasterCard, a program that offers items like Yankees playoff tickets to cardholders.

headline: More Taxes in Finance, European Commission Says
text: The European Commission has spelled out its vision for taxing the financial sector, saying it would help fund development, fight against climate change and better combat the global economic crisis.

headline: U.A.E. Halts Plan to Ban BlackBerry
text: HONG KONG — The United Arab Emirates, one of several countries that have threatened to suspend services for the Blackberry smartphones this year, on Friday backed away from a ban that was to have come into effect on Monday, after reaching an agreement with the popular messaging devices’ manufacturer, Research In Motion.

headline: Rio Tinto Is Said to Be Interested in Potash Sector
text: The mining company Rio Tinto is interested in possible bolt-on acquisitions in a range of sectors, including potash, an executive said on Thursday, Reuters reported.

headline: Big Union Wins Vote Against a Rival in California
text: The Service Employees International Union decisively defeated a rival union that was seeking to persuade 43,000 employees who worked for Kaiser Permanente in California to switch unions, the National Labor Relations Board announced Thursday night.

text: –The chief technology officer of AOL, Alexander Gounares, says the company may add more online media to its stable, after buying TechCrunch last month.

headline: Buffett Says Rivals ‘Don’t Know the Business’

headline: An ‘Every Village,’ Awash in Misery
text: Often the damaging environmental effects of industry don’t feel real to faraway consumers. The carbon dioxide that spews into the air from power plants is invisible even to those who are close at hand. When the Deepwater Horizon oil spill disaster began last spring, few could see the impact a mile under water, conveyed only belatedly by cameras when BP decided to release the footage.

headline: Faith in Fed Pushes Dow Past 11,000

headline: ‘The Office’ Butchers ‘Sweeney Todd’ (in a Good Way)
text: Happy 80th birthday, Stephen Sondheim! The gifts you’ve been receiving for the occasion this year keep getting better and better: a Broadway revue of your unparalleled body of work; a new series of Kennedy Center grants established in your honor; a Broadway theater with your name on the marquee. And if you were watching television on Thursday night and not working on a crossword puzzle, maybe you got to see a network sitcom make mincemeat of one of your best-known works. (You’re still a national treasure, anyway.)

headline: Public Jobs Drop Amid Slowdown in Private Hiring
text: In the one-two punch long feared by many economists, hiring by businesses has slowed while government jobs are disappearing at a record pace.

text: Updated | 4:32 p.m. On Friday, Liu Xiaobo, a Chinese dissident currently serving an 11-year term in jail, was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize, as my colleagues Andrew Jacobs and Jonathan Ansfield report from Beijing.

headline: Move Over, Carbon, Humans Are Jolting Nitrogen, Too
text: Humans have appropriated much of the planet’s nitrogen cycle, with big environmental consequences.

headline: Excerpts From Vargas Llosa’s Books
text: “Two related themes” Michiko Kakutani writes, “thread their way through all the novels of Mr. Vargas Llosa, who won the Nobel literature prize Thursday. These themes are a fascination with the human craving for freedom (be it political, social or creative) and the liberation conferred by art and imagination.”

headline: Brown Campaign Apologizes to Whitman Over Slur
text: The Los Angeles Times released a recording on Thursday night of a voice-mail message left by Jerry Brown, the Democratic candidate for governor in California, in which an unidentified person apparently can be heard suggesting that his opponent, the Republican Meg Whitman, is “a whore.”

headline: Sanofi Disputes Genzyme’s Account of Deal Meeting
text: The battle between Sanofi-Aventis and Genzyme is quickly becoming a war of words.

headline: Looking Back, Even More Jobs Lost
text: Joshua Shapiro of MFR Incorporated points out that today’s jobs report also contained revisions for the March 2009-March 2010 period. Those revisions show that the job market was in even worse shape than previously thought.

headline: The Cow-munity
text: A FEW YEARS AGO, two teachers at a prep school called the Albuquerque Academy discovered their mutual appreciation for local food. And in New Mexico, beef is about as local as it comes. So Sarah Councell, who teaches experiential education, and Casey Citrin, the chairwoman of the English department, decided to share a steer. They didn’t really know each other. They just wanted local beef for a good price and a steady supply of it. They looked online and found the Ranney Ranch, run by a family that has been raising Angus cattle on 18,000 acres since 1968. The animals are small, maybe 600 pounds, and are sent to slaughter the day they stop weaning. It makes for exceptionally lean but tender beef.

headline: A Maine Island Becomes a Seafood Magnet
text: One woman has put the fisherman of Deer Isle, Me., on the culinary map with her seafood supplying business.

headline: The Catch
text: THOUGH WE HAD agreed to meet at 9 a.m., Ingrid Bengis-Palei woke me at 7, shouting from the bottom of the stairs leading to the apartment where I was staying above her barn on Deer Isle, Me. She had orders for 600 oysters, a third of which had to be overnighted to Beverly Hills to Bouchon, owned by Thomas Keller, one of the two dozen high-end chefs who buy oysters, crab, clams, scallops, mussels and lobsters from Ingrid Bengis Seafood. Those oysters had to be acquired, iced, packed and shipped by 3:30 that July afternoon, and she wanted to leave plenty of time. “The easy part is when it’s a beautiful day and everybody does what they’re supposed to do,” said Bengis-­Palei, dressed in a yellow slicker to ward off the drumming rain, as she sped in her Subaru station wagon over the island’s narrow, wet roads. “But usually a crisis of one kind or another comes up.”

headline: On This Farm There Was Animosity
text: I don’t care if it’s good for you, because to me kale has always been a four-letter vegetable. We seemed to have a lifetime supply this summer courtesy of the local community-supported agriculture farm. When Ira, my spouse, told me he signed us up for $575 last spring, I balked at the cost. Did it really make sense? Our little Long Island weekend town already has a farm stand and a grocer with local produce.

headline: Growing Together
text: When I began writing about American farmers and food artisans for this magazine’s Field Report column two years ago, I set out to learn the story behind the people whose ingredients were driving chefs to create great dishes. Little did I know it would become a column about communities — of producers, of customers, of eaters and enthusiasts.

headline: A Mealtime Manifesto
text: Although known as an environmental activist, you take up a less divisive cause in your new book, “The Family Dinner,” a cross between a cookbook and a parenting manifesto.  I’ve got two teenage girls and have found parenting unbelievably challenging. At one point I said to myself, I have to get some happy family moments. And so I zeroed in on family dinner as the perfect time to accomplish that.

headline: Shared Tastes
text: For some, the old cliché that you are what you eat has taken on increasingly complex implications: food choices can be a stand-in for social, ideological, even political identity and beliefs. Eaters can form communities of a sort, and businesses are built catering to them. Surely this has contributed to the interest in “incubator” programs designed to give new opportunities to aspiring food entrepreneurs. The concept has all the foodie do-gooder trimmings, often involving local cooks making cuisine linked to their immigrant backgrounds.

headline: Paying for a Prisoner’s Food
text: As a desk sergeant in a suburban police department, I’m responsible for seeing that prisoners are fed. When a prisoner’s religion prohibited him from eating our standard meal, an officer found an acceptable meal at a local restaurant, to be paid for by taking up a collection among the precinct crew. When we explained the situation to the restaurant staff, they refused payment, saying it was their religious duty to help a fellow practitioner. Could we ethically accept this donation? A. G., LONG ISLAND

headline: Summer of ’44
text: I wrote Roth off. Back in my early 20s, in a fit of literary conscientiousness, I undertook to sample his work. At the point when my nose could wrinkle no further in distaste, I was struck by a relieving epiphany — “Oh: these are for boys” — upon which I resumed my reading life unburdened by any expectation of venturing deeper into Rothiana.

headline: Pie + Design = Change
text: ON A SUN-SPLASHED afternoon in August, blueberry pies and peach pies cooled on wire racks inside PieLab, a white brick cafe with floor-to-ceiling windows on Main Street in Greensboro, Ala. Behind a counter made of planks salvaged from abandoned sharecropper shacks, two young women slid pie tins into a double oven stack. At trestle tables, beneath industrial pendant lights, four young men, on lunch break from their G.E.D. classes, dug into slices of taco pie and made weekend plans.

headline: Hope in a Pie
text: Graphic designers are trying to revive an impoverished county in Greensboro, Ala., with an all-butter crust.

headline: Gimme a Z! Gimme an L! Gimme a B!
text: One of the truly frustrating aspects of economic discussion since the crisis began has been the consistent unwillingness and/or inability of many of my colleagues to wrap their minds around the fact that short-term interest rates are up against the zero lower bound — and that therefore (a) normal monetary policy isn’t available (b) comparisons with fiscal policy when monetary policy was available tell you little.

headline: Donilon to Replace Jones as National Security Adviser
text: President Obama will announce on Friday that Gen. James Jones, the national security adviser, is resigning and will be replaced by his deputy, Thomas E. Donilon, senior administration officials said.

text: Turning into a game elements of one’s electronic life – from to-do lists to blogs.
