headline: Border Songs
text: In 2007, Dinaw Mengestu made a forceful debut with “The Beautiful Things That Heaven Bears.” It was an indelible novel about African immigrants in Washington, D.C., struggling to find a place in an America whose idealized promises succumb to everyday realities. Mengestu’s skillful sensitivity turned observations from his life into a broader narrative, earning him deserved accolades.

headline: Up Front: Miguel Syjuco
text: Like the Ethiopian-American writer Dinaw Mengestu, whose second novel, “How to Read the Air,” he reviews in this issue, Miguel Syjuco — a Filipino living in Montreal — is a novelist who has used the immigrant’s perspective to explore themes of family and homeland, politics and identity.

headline: Accounting for Taste
text: You never know when someone online might go into raptures over Chinese soup dumplings. In real life I’ve been buttonholed plenty of times by soup-dumpling rhapsodizers. I should have expected to find hymns to dumplings on the Web too. Restaurant-obsessed people seize on slim pretexts to go on at length about where to get soup dumplings, where the soup dumplings are much better than that other place you had them, how you have to consume them on spoons using complex protocols to avoid squirting and scalding and, finally, how you must behold soup dumplings for an hour of awestruck contemplation and then stuff a mattress with them and sleep on a bed of them for a year or you will never get the full effect of the sexy incredibleness that is the soup dumpling.

headline: 36 Hours in Rome
text: Rachel Donadio, The New York Times's Rome bureau chief, spends a weekend exploring some of the avant-garde cultural and culinary attractions of the ancient capital.

headline: Spurs Downsizing Their Roster
text: To the average sports fan, an N.B.A. team seems steeped in money. The players make millions, fly on a private plane and stay at luxury hotels, and the team’s big arena charges big bucks for parking, tickets and food.

headline: MacKenzie Hires Senior Executive From Altman
text: MacKenzie Partners, one of the big proxy solicitor firms, said Thursday that it had hired Paul Schulman from the Altman Group as a senior vice president.

headline: A Canvas You Can Paint With Cash
text: THE road to cheap automotive thrills is pockmarked with caveats and compromises. Manufacturers seeking customers for budget-performance cars will mate an eager engine to a laterally stiff chassis, only to imbue the surrounding sheet metal with the charisma of a gym locker. In other cases, a deceptively stout steering wheel might engage the rack and pinion with all the exuberance of a limp handshake.

headline: Comparing Recessions: Job Recovery
text: Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics. Chart by Amanda Cox. Horizontal axis shows months. Vertical axis shows the ratio of that month’s nonfarm payrolls to the nonfarm payrolls at the start of recession. Note: Because employment is a lagging indicator, the dates for these employment trends are not exactly synchronized with National Bureau of Economic Research’s official business cycle dates.

headline: Sanchez Apologizes for ‘Offensive’ Comments
text: The fired CNN anchor Rick Sanchez said he “screwed up” last week when he called Jon Stewart a “bigot” and made comments that some viewed as anti-Semitic.

headline: The Beat Generation and the Tea Party
text: The counterculture of the late 1950s and early 1960s appears to be everywhere these days. A major exhibition of Allen Ginsberg’s photography just closed at the National Gallery in Washington. A superb book, by the historian Sean Wilentz, about Ginsberg’s dear friend and sometime influence Bob Dylan recently made the best-seller list. “Howl,” a film about Ginsberg and the Beats, opened last month. And everywhere around us, the streets and airwaves hum with attacks on government authority, celebrations of radical individualism, inflammatory rhetoric, political theatrics.

headline: Friday Reading: Some Potluck Dish Ideas
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: The Last U.N. Climate Extravaganza?
text: In an article in Friday’s paper, Elisabeth Rosenthal and I describe the bad mood and poor prospects pervading the run-up to the next big United Nations climate change conference, which opens at the end of November in Cancún, Mexico.

headline: 2011 Scion tC
text: Scion has long hitched its cheap-speed ambitions on the tC.

headline: Japan Gets the Best of Argentina’s A-Team
text: Rafael Nadal, the No. 1 tennis player in the world, sped through his quarterfinal match at the Japan Open to make it to Saitama to watch his friend, Lionel Messi, and Argentina take on Japan in an international friendly. But while Nadal easily dispatched Dmitry Tursunov ( 6-4, 6-1), Messi and Co. lost, 1-0, the Blue Samurai.

headline: Former ‘Dora the Explorer’ Star Speaks Up and Sues Nickelodeon
text: What are some things you can find in a courtroom? You can see judges, you can see gavels, you can see bailiffs, and you might soon see Caitlin Sanchez, a 14-year-old former star of the animated series “Dora the Explorer,” who is is suing Nickelodeon, MTV Networks and Viacom, saying she is owed millions of dollars for her work on the show.

headline: Concerns on No-Fault Divorce, and a Conviction Stands
text: While no-fault divorce was signed into law in New York this summer with great fanfare, the bill included numerous unheralded provisions that have left many divorce lawyers uneasy.

headline: What the Dog Saw
text: Murder takes a capital “M” when it appears in most novels, bossing the story around in myriad ways. The guiding principle is that murder (even manslaughter) will out, and the dire secret of the crime will squirm noisily around, leaving clues until its circumstances are discovered. We see a murder in a novel, and then we watch and wait until the layers of plot are revealed through a satisfying, often surprising, set of procedures that make us appreciate how clever the detectives (official and unofficial) can be. But while someone is killed right up front in Scott Spencer’s 10th novel, “Man in the Woods,” the murder doesn’t operate as a motor for the action; instead, it glows like something toxic in the daily lives of the characters. It’s as much a question as an act: What if you killed a stranger who had few ties to the world — a person no one might miss?

headline: Chinese Dissident Awarded Nobel Peace Prize
text: Liu Xiaobo, 54, is the first Chinese citizen to win the Peace Prize and one of three people to have received it while incarcerated.

headline: Lost in America
text: Immersed in factual nuance, exacting about sequence and presentation, the historian never steps to the side in his work to register amazement at circumstance, never says, “Look!” For this we have the other arts, fiction front and center, though it doesn’t quite do for the novelist to make such a bald declaration either. Rather, he aims to recreate a world so the reader is quietly overtaken by it.

headline: Art and Action
text: The biggest surprise about Milan’s galleries is how few Italian artists show there. Scattered about town or gathered in a few clusters, they wield enough international clout to make up for the time it takes to travel between them. Most ambitious is the Naples-based Lia Rumma’s new temple to minimalist cool at Via Stilicone, 19. One of the largest commercial galleries in Europe, it opened last May and has attracted a fashionable clientele. Its triple-height space, designed by CLS Architetti, easily accommodates anything the artists on its blue-chip roster (Marina Abramovic, Andreas Gursky, Anselm Kiefer, Ettore Spalleti, Vanessa Beecroft) can think up.

headline: Frozen in Time, a Palace Worthy of the Packard
text: DAYTON, Ohio

headline: Keeping Score: Did Lincecum Pitch Better Than Halladay?
text: 2:56 p.m. | Updated

headline: Anatomy of an Uprising
text: Trying to describe the ideas of the Tea Party movement is a bit like a blind man trying to describe the elephant. The movement, like the elephant, exists. But no one, not even the Tea Partiers themselves, can seem to get hands around the whole of it. Jonathan Raban, who attended the first National Tea Party Convention and wrote about it in The New York Review of Books, was struck by how little agreement there was among “members” as they talked about their griev­ances and aspirations. And yet the Tea Party uprising is the most visible and energized political phenomenon of the last year. Whether it will remain a viable movement remains to be seen, but it shows no sign yet of running out of steam.

headline: Government Helps to Insure Children, Even Above the Poverty Line
text: THE last few years have not been easy for Dean McCrea.

headline: Tenement Long Outlasts Fight Against Skyscraper
text: A lonely little red building sits on a short block a stone’s throw away from Lincoln Center. Five stories tall, crisscrossed by fire escapes, it looks as if it escaped from the Lower East Side. Skyscraping apartment towers loom over it like bullies ganging up on an old lady. A parking garage and a flyspeck of green space surround it like a moat.

headline: Health Insurance for Children
text: In today’s Patient Money column, Lesley Alderman writes about the various ways parents can find health coverage for their children, even if they think they can’t afford it.

headline: Halloween Judgments
text: Ellen Seidman, an editor at Redbook, wrote an essay in the October issue that she thought was about flexibility and compromise. Instead she has found herself in a conversation that is about something else entirely.

headline: The Early Word: 9.6 Percent
text: The country’s jobless rate held at 9.6 percent in September, the Labor Department said Friday in its last jobs report before Election Day.

headline: Faces in the Crowd
text: Heather Sellers owns all the ingredients for a tough-childhood memoir: the schizophrenic mother, the alcoholic, cross-dressing father. But this is not a memoir in the sliced and bleeding vein of “Running With Scissors.” Nor is it, despite Sellers’s timbre of forgiveness and love, a “Glass Castle” clone. “You Don’t Look Like Anyone I Know” does not read like any memoir you know, largely because of a condition you may not know and certainly can’t say: prosopagnosia.

headline: Punk Days
text: One night in 1985, a teenage Kristin Hersh got inspired to pick up her guitar and compose a tune for her punk band, Throwing Muses. “So I wrote a dumb little song about smack freaks, unemployment and holocausts,” she remembers in her memoir, “Rat Girl.” “It was only a minute long ’cause I got bored, but it was funny.” The song, “Hate My Way,” rants about the aforementioned topics as well as God (it’s all his fault), her father (no, it’s his fault), school (to blame), society (totally to blame) and wanting to die (although she doesn’t want to want to die). And that was the band’s pop song.

headline: Tesla Recalling 439 Roadsters for Fire Hazard
text: Tesla Motors is recalling 439 of its electric sports cars because of a possible fire hazard involving the 12-volt electrical system, according to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: First U.S. Open Tennis Stadium Will Not Be Sold
text: Members of the West Side Tennis Club in the Forest Hills Gardens enclave of Queens, voted Thursday night not to sell the storied stadium where the first United States Open tournaments were played. Now the club, which has operated in the red for years, will have to figure out what to do with the place.

headline: The Other Side of the Water
text: The figure of the Haitian living abroad is one that evokes bitter comedy and, often, envy among Haitians living in Haiti. Haitian Haitians can quickly spot someone from what is called the diaspora visiting Port-au-Prince. A Haitian friend once told me that the big difference, aside from a visible discrepancy in wealth, is that someone from lòt bò dlo (or the other side of the water, which means “abroad” in Haitian Creole) walks with purpose and studied intent, as if he or she has a destination in mind at every moment. Island Haitians can find such goal-oriented behavior strange, unreal, even ridiculous, since the poverty of life in Haiti means that goals are often unachievable.

headline: Largest U.S. Bank Halts Foreclosures in All States
text: Bank of America, the nation’s largest bank, said Friday that it was extending its suspension of foreclosures to all 50 states.

headline: Predicting the 2010-11 N.H.L. Season
text: Any so-called expert can make vague predictions about the most obvious aspects of the new hockey season. In fact, playing it safe has become an annual tradition for hockey pundits.

headline: America’s Packard Museum
text: What began as the city’s premier Packard dealership is now a center for all things Packard.

headline: The Inconstant Gardener
text: Jason Elliot’s first novel may be the ideal thriller for the age of “C.S.I.” Forget Bondian femmes fatales and Bournian superassassins, and prepare to learn a great deal about steganographic code-making, the differences in the safety catches of various Soviet-era firearms and which side of a car to fling yourself out of should you come under roadside attack. It’s safe to say that “The Network” is the first spy thriller in which the climactic action scene is decided in large part on the basis of whose vehicle has superior gear differentials. And yet, it’s a lot of fun, this mix of spy chic and übergeek.

headline: Celebrating A Gift From Bali: Delicious Confusion
text: NO longer quite the inaccessible Shangri-La of antique travelogue, Bali remains, for artists of all kinds and seekers of a spiritual bent, an isle of pristine enchantments. To musicians with or without the cosmic baggage, the fascination lies in the intricately layered pulse and shimmer of the gamelan, the indigenous form of orchestral ensemble, dominated by percussion and associated for centuries with Balinese ritual and devotion.

headline: Mirror, Mirror
text: Just because something happened to you doesn’t make it interesting. Anyone who has suffered through an overly indulgent blog post or cocktail-­party anecdote is familiar with this thought, which also roughly captures the risk of first-person fiction. And that’s what makes “Vida,” Patricia Engel’s under­stated first collection of stories, so arresting: Engel never strays from the even-keeled perspective of Sabina, the daughter of Colombian immigrants, an unambitious young woman from New Jersey to whom nothing truly horrible or truly wonderful happens. But by the end of her book, Engel has, with apparent ease, entirely overcome her reader’s skepticism.

headline: Lotus Designer Shows Up With a 6-Pack
text: DANATO COCO seems to have been busy since he became design director for Group Lotus in January. Most designers would be happy to be credited with two or three cars in their careers, but he delivered six new designs last week at the Paris Motor Show. Not since Chanel has a designer named Coco had so many new models at once on the runways of Paris.

headline: S.B.A. Lending Catches Up With Demand — for Now
text: That did not take long.

headline: Grim News for Those Out of Job Market
text: Amid the grim news about local government losses and feeble private sector growth, today’s jobs report shows that those who aren’t even counted in the official unemployment rate fared uniformly worse in September.

headline: All the Swans At This Lake Are Male
text: LONDON

headline: Finding Brahms in Schoenberg
text: “BRAHMS THE PROGRESSIVE” is the title of an insightful essay that Schoenberg first presented as a radio talk in 1933 in honor of the Brahms centenary. At the time to speak of Brahms as a progressive was counterintuitive. Brahms was a Romantic of course. But if anything, he was regarded as the Classicist among his generation of German Romantic composers.

headline: Making Sense of Complex Controls
text: LOOK inside the 2011 Ford Fiesta and you will see dashboard controls that have been modeled after the keypad of a cellphone. In some ways, that makes perfect sense: Ford’s market research suggested that young buyers were more attached to their mobile phones than to their means of mobility.

headline: Arvo Pärt’s Fourth Symphony
text: ARVO PäRT: SYMPHONY NO. 4,

headline: Bedeviled
text: “May you be in heaven a half-hour before the Devil knows you’re dead.” This familiar Irish toast implies that it’s possible to stay a step ahead of Satan. Not so in Patrick McCabe’s new novel, “The Stray Sod Country,” where a host of malignant spirits haunt and taunt the residents of an Irish hamlet called Cullymore.

headline: Songs for the Feet, And Even the Heart
text: DJ Nate

headline: For ‘Housewives,’ Wallflowers Need Not Apply
text: AFTER five incarnations of “The Real Housewives” series, it’s safe to say that Andy Cohen knows his way around women. As senior vice president for original programming and development for Bravo and the host of the cable network’s self-referential “Watch What Happens Live,” he helps to stir the pot, overseeing the catfights, the marital meltdowns and even the fisticuffs that have become de rigueur among the ladies who lunch and feud in Orange County, New York City, Atlanta, New Jersey and Washington.

headline: Protectionism by China Is Biggest Since World War II
text: C. Fred Bergsten — the director of the Peterson Institute for International Economics and one of the most prominent proponents of pushing China to revalue its currency — wraps up our discussion of the renminbi for this week. We’ll continue next week. Here’s Mr. Bergsten:

headline: Getting to Five
text: The story of this book is really two stories, and only one of them is about Supreme Court Justice William J. Brennan Jr. As Seth Stern and Stephen Wermiel explain in an authors’ note, Brennan first agreed to cooperate on a biography with Wermiel, then the Supreme Court correspondent for The Wall Street Journal, in 1986. Brennan granted more than 60 recorded interviews in chambers and gave Wermiel access to tens of thousands of pages of records, including case files, correspondence and the coveted case histories his clerks had prepared each term. Wermiel completed part of the book before Brennan’s death in 1997, then, as he explains, put the project aside. He came under criticism, most notably from Jeffrey Toobin of The New Yorker, for his unparalleled access to documents closed to other researchers and for “what little he has managed to make of it.” That was in 2004. In 2006, Wermiel brought Stern, of Congressional Quarterly, to the project and, their note continues, it was Stern who reorganized the vast amounts of material and drafted most of the chapters.

headline: In Baghdad, It’s Business as Unusual
text: BAGHDAD — Overlooking a conspicuously unfit-for-purpose road stands a modern women’s boutique, its spotless marble tile flooring a contrast to the good for nothing graveled highway. As soon as irritable customers pass through the sparkling double-glass doors they leave the outside squalor behind, and their mood instantly changes.

headline: Liu Xiaobo and Chinese Democracy
text: Congratulations to Liu Xiaobo for winning the Nobel Peace Prize – and to the Nobel committee for giving it to him. China has countless dissidents and people pushing for democracy, of course, but there’s a reason Liu rose to the top in Nobel estimations. He has combined relentless courage and persistence in pushing for democracy over 21 years with a broad vision of democracy, all tethered to moderation and willingness to work with Communist Party leaders.

headline: If Walls Could Talk
text: Many adults have a fantasy that if they could go back to college — now that the desire to party, drink and sleep around has faded to a burnished memory — they’d get so much more out of it. The publishing industry often reflects this wish. Every season brings offerings that are right at home on anyone’s continuing-ed syllabus: innovative, original ways to study world history through lenses trained on the minutiae of salt or cod, earthworms or spices, tea or telephones. Now, finally, for those of us who wrestled with Rocks for Jocks, pined amid Physics for Poets and schlepped through college on 101s of any and every subject — the beloved survey courses — here’s that most popular professor, Bill Bryson, with a fascinating new book, “At Home: A Short History of Private Life.”

headline: Cake Man Raven Is Shut Down
text: Cake Man Raven, the celebrated and well-connected Brooklyn baker who has blanketed much of the city in red velvet cake from his shop in Fort Greene, was shut down by the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene this week for sanitary violations that it said included the presence of flies, lack of a hand-washing station near the food preparation area and toilet room, and the supervisor of operations’ lack of a food protection certificate.

headline: The Convert
text: The years since the end of the cold war divide into two very different ages. The first, the 1990s, was dominated by the rise of free markets and free trade across the globe. The second, since 9/11, has been defined by terrorism, counterterrorism, war and Islamic radicalism. Bill Clinton is the symbol of the first decade and George W. Bush of the second. Tony Blair is the only major political figure to span both eras, beginning his political life in the corridors of Davos and ending it in the mud flats of Basra. He tells both tales in his engrossing memoir, “A Journey,” but they never fuse into one larger story.

headline: Week 6 College Football Matchups
text: What did I learn last week? Well, I learned that Alabama is much better than Florida. I learned that Oregon cannot be stopped on offense. I also learned that in college football it’s not always the games that are circled on your calendar that end up providing the most drama. Case in point, last week’s LSU/Tennessee game and the Michigan/Indiana game. Those two games went down to the wire in thrilling fashion, but the marquee games provided little late game intrigue.

headline: Cahill Files Lawsuit Against Former Aides
text: 5:54 p.m. | Updated  First Timothy Cahill’s top aides quit his campaign, followed by his running mate, Paul Loscocco, who proclaimed that Mr. Cahill, an independent candidate in the Massachusetts governor’s race, had no shot at winning. In another twist of the knife, Mr. Loscocco promptly endorsed Charles Baker Jr., the Republican.

headline: Man-Eater
text: The large and malevolent tiger at the center of this nonfiction hunting tale bears a striking resemblance to its fictional seafaring predecessors: the white whale and the movie-star shark (both of which, by the way, are said to have been inspired by real creatures).

headline: Pumping Up the Self-Control in the Age of Temptations
text: I HAVE a cold and a headache, and I just want to go to bed. But knowing that my editor is relying on me (and I’m relying on my next paycheck), I muster my willpower to stay at my computer and finish the column.

headline: Altering the Capital’s Skyline
text: A look at Bing Thom’s renovation of the Arena Stage theater complex in Washington.

headline: On Our Radar: More Safety Violations for Massey Coal
text: A surprise inspection uncovers major safety violations at another Massey Energy Company coal mine in West Virginia. Last year an explosion at a Massey coal mine in the state killed 29 workers. The latest violations, discovered on Sept. 28, could have caused a similar explosion, officials say. “This is a reflection of the problem that we have in this mining industry with some who, regardless of what you do, ignore the mine law,” said Joe Main, the director of the federal Mine Safety and Health Administration. “There is absolutely no justification to be operating a mine in this condition.” [The Associated Press]

headline: The Rosenbergs Revisited
text: Walter and Miriam ­Schneir were aboard a train crossing a 15,000-foot peak in the Andes in 1959 when a fellow passenger, a Peruvian Franciscan friar, paused and asked whether they were Catholic.

headline: Long After Death, Lennon Remains an Inspiration
text: John Lennon would have turned 70 on Saturday, and the anniversary has occasioned a flood of events and releases to commemorate the songwriter and his work. In a way, Lennon’s stature  the reason for the celebrations  makes some of them seem beside the point. Since he was murdered outside the Dakota, 30 years ago in December, Lennon has remained a powerful presence in the culture, both for his songwriting and performances as a Beatle and for his post-Beatles life as a peace crusader, born-again feminist and alternately strident and affecting solo artist. Do we really need to be reminded about John Lennon?

headline: Widow of ‘Last Lecture’ Professor Will Write a Memoir
text: “The Last Lecture” will not be the final chapter in the story of Randy Pausch, the computer science professor at Carnegie Mellon University who turned his ruminations on life and his own impending death into a wildly popular oration and that best-selling book.

headline: Crisp Fall Desserts (Without the Gluten)
text: Crumbles are an easy way to turn simple fruit into a decadent, crispy dessert. And for the growing number of diners who can’t tolerate the gluten in wheat, it’s easy to make crumbles that are gluten free without sacrificing taste, writes Martha Rose Shulman in this week’s Recipes for Health.

headline: Health Department Shuts Cake Man Raven
text: The Local reports that the health department shut down Cake Man Raven Confectionery for a variety of violations, including a failure to have a hand washing facility near the food preparation area and toilet room, and not having a food protection certificate for its supervisor of operations. Raven — Raven Patrick De’Sean Dennis III, a celebrity favorite — has also been accused of cheating his workers on pay.

headline: Death March
text: In his second novel, Mark T. Mustian appears to confront an enormous subject: the Turkish deportation of Armenians during World War I, when hundreds of thousands died amid a hellish march into Syria — an expulsion that has, outside Turkey, often been labeled as genocide. But in truth, Mustian, a writer and lawyer from Tallahassee, Fla., who is himself distantly of Armenian heritage, tells a story that probes a timeless array of life’s general adversities: the tricks of memory that enable us to carry on with our daily existence; the brash decisions and subsequent regrets of the young; the ever present need for forgiveness; the way a single event can be subject to many interpretations. Mustian embodies the intractability of these difficulties in the image of an Armenian girl with mismatched eyes, “the light eye questioning, the dark eye confirming.” She sees the past and the present, the good and the bad, our side and theirs. Her mystery is life’s mystery.

headline: Religious Persuasion
text: At first glance, the authors of “American Grace” would seem to suffer from very bad timing. Between the completion of their manuscript and its publication, the dispute over the Islamic center in Lower Manhattan erupted, followed by the ­Koran-burning controversy, and somewhere along the way a New York cabdriver was stabbed, apparently for being a Muslim. All this gives a quaint air to their declaration, in the book’s first chapter, that “America peacefully combines a high degree of religious devotion with tremendous religious diversity.” And it seems to render moot one of their main goals: to illuminate the source of this inter­faith ­tolerance.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: ORIGINS: How the Nine Months Before Birth Shape the Rest of Our Lives,  by Annie Murphy Paul (Free Press, $26.) Paul’s balanced, common-sense study of the emerging field of fetal origins research is structured around her own pregnancy.

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE UNNAMED,  by Joshua Ferris (Reagan Arthur/Back Bay/Little, Brown, $13.99.) The hero of Ferris’s second novel can’t stop walking — for miles and miles, away from his work at a high-powered law firm, away from his loving wife and troubled daughter. No doctor or psychiatrist has been able to diagnose his “ walking thing,” which becomes progressively worse. “What does it mean?” our reviewer, Jay McInerney, asked. “Tim’s affliction might be a metaphor for addiction, for careerism.” But he found fault with Ferris’s descriptions of the hero’s misadventures: “not bad writing, but . . . not good storytelling.”

headline: Blucher! Neighhhh!
text: Oh, dear. Brad DeLong is right: the CBPP transcript (pdf) of Jan Hatzius, Marty Feldstein, and yours truly being gloomy does keep calling Marty “Feldman” instead.

headline: Inside the List
text: SLAM BOOKS: “Obama’s Wars,” Bob Woodward’s fly-on-the-wall account of Barack Obama’s decision to send 30,000 more troops to Afghanistan, hits the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 1 — the 16th consecutive book by Woodward to make the list in hardcover. Woodward depicts the administration as “deeply divided and riven with suspicions” (as Michiko Kakutani of The New York Times put it in a recent review), but that’s a compliment compared with the portrayals of Obama in the rest of this week’s political best sellers, including Dinesh D’Souza’s “Roots of Obama’s Rage” (anti-American zealot), David Limbaugh’s “Crimes Against Liberty” (socialist evil genius) and Bill O’Reilly’s “Pinheads and Patriots” (pinhead). If the Democrats tank in the midterms, however, Obama may be able to take comfort in another new title, “------ Finish First,” Tucker Max’s follow-up to his surprise smash, “I Hope They Serve Beer in Hell.”

headline: Silent Pictures
text: Long before graphic novels earned a dedicated section in bookstores — indeed, before the term “graphic novel” was even coined — the American wood engraver and illustrator Lynd Ward (1905-85) created six enduring examples of the form. Ward was one of only a handful of artists in the world who bucked literary convention by eliminating all words but the title from standard narrative works. His novels often contained more than 100 ­pages, with one image per right-hand page. The pictures, influenced by German Expressionism, were dark and melodramatic, as though taken directly from an early film noir storyboard. Ward’s thematically related sequences and cinematic pacing bridged the divide between mass comics and the more rarefied illustrated book. Now this groundbreaking work, originally published between 1929 and 1937, has been collected in “Six Novels in Woodcuts,” the first graphic fiction from the Library of America.

headline: Someone on the Line
text: On Friday afternoon, the federal Administration on Aging unveils its new, improved elder care locator. The major change: anyone who dials the toll-free number, (800) 677-1116, from 9 a.m. to 8 p.m. Eastern time on weekdays should get an actual human on the line, ready to answer questions about government services and refer seniors and caregivers to local agencies that can help.

headline: New York City Ballet | ‘Plainspoken’
text: A calm, gentle breeze seemed to permeate its way onto the stage last evening at the New York City Ballet Fall Gala. And members of high society seemed all the more pleased to leave their winter coats at home in place of a stunning assortment of gowns as they made their way into Lincoln Center’s David H. Koch Theater. The spotlight was on the principal dancer Benjamin Millepied’s world premiere of “Plainspoken,” set to music by the Pulitzer Prize-winning composer David Lang, with costumes by Karen Young.

headline: Bill Ackman, Meet Howard Hughes
text: It’s been a busy day for the hedge fund manager William A. Ackman. Along with disclosing his 16.5 percent stake in J.C. Penney, Mr. Ackman has revived the ghost of Howard Hughes.

headline: Weekend Competition: Better Book Titles
text: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to suggest more realistic titles for already published books.

headline: Reid Receives Two G.O.P. Endorsements
text: 5:11 p.m. | Updated Harry Reid can now boast a second Republican feather in his cap, of sorts. Less than 24-hours after earning the endorsement of Bill Raggio, a highly influential Republican and Nevada state senator, the Senate majority leader on Friday  landed the support of Dema Guinn, the wife of the former governor who died unexpectedly this year.

headline: Timescast | October 8, 2010
text: Jobs report portends long slog to economic recovery, the media await the surfacing of 33 Chilean miners and reader questions about the all electric Nissan Leaf answered.

headline: His Latest Trick? Staying Sober
text: REGRETS, Steve-O’s had a few. Not among them: holding a lit firework in his derriere, attaching a leech to his eyeball, inserting a hook through his cheek and swimming with sharks, or any of the other stunts he performed as part of the “Jackass” cast.

headline: The Crowd Around the Gold Counter
text: Gold evokes emotions from investors like few other investable assets. Whether it is increasing or decreasing in value, people usually have an interest in it beyond its intrinsic value as an investment.

headline: U.S. Calls for Withdrawal of United Nations Prize Financed by a West African Dictator
text: PARIS  The United States has put forward a resolution at the board meeting of the United Nations’ main cultural and education organization calling for the withdrawal of a lavish prize offered by an African dictator and the return of the money, European diplomats said Friday.

headline: Raisins Give Hope to Afghan Farmers
text: KABUL — Raisin Producer Cooperative Center No. 2 stands alone astride the highway in Parwan Province, an hour north of Kabul. Inside the clay-colored building with a cheery yellow gate, a group of Afghan raisin farmers sits cross-legged on the tan carpet, talking about the past — and the future.

headline: White Plains, 10:35 A.M.
text: Andrew M. Cuomo, the Democratic candidate for governor, accepted the endorsement of Planned Parenthood Advocates of New York at a rally on the steps of the Westchester County Center.

headline: Afghan Raisins for Export
text: Raisins grown in Parwan Province, Afghanistan, will once again land on food shelves in Britain thanks to an unusual alliance among Afghan farmers, a U.S. aid organization, and a British food producer.

headline: Two Ejections and a Renewal of the Replay Debate
text: Bud Selig, the commissioner of Major League Baseball, has said he is open to future discussions about expanding the use of replays to review umpire’s calls.

headline: Ex-Bank Chief Pleads Guilty to TARP Fraud
text: A former New York bank president, whom prosecutors accused of trying to steal millions from the government’s $700 billion banking bailout program, pleaded guilty on Friday to fraud, embezzlement and bribery.

headline: The Tensions of the Championship Showdown
text: The first two practice sessions of the Japanese Grand Prix were particularly interesting on Friday against the backdrop of the four-race run to the drivers’ championship title that has just begun.

headline: The Tensions of the Championship Showdown
text: The first two practice sessions of the Japanese Grand Prix were particularly interesting on Friday against the backdrop of the four-race run to the drivers’ championship title that has just begun.

headline: From Stuyvesant High to Nascar Combine
text: To the average New York City helicopter parent, Julia Landauer’s scholastic trajectory would be the stuff of daydreams. Last spring, she graduated from Stuyvesant High School. This summer, she reported to Stanford University, where she is fashioning her own undergraduate concentration within the Management Science and Engineering department.

headline: A Night for a Rhapsodic Violin And an Old Brake Drum
text: On Thursday night, right behind my regular seat at Avery Fisher Hall for the New York Philharmonic, there was an ominous shiny steel tank labeled “Refrigerated Liquid Nitrogen.” Two full rows of seats behind mine had been removed to accommodate this (presumably empty) tank, a makeshift percussion instrument for the Philharmonic’s performance of Magnus Lindberg’s “Kraft,” in its New York premiere, conducted by Alan Gilbert.

headline: Manufacturing’s Brief Rebound
text: The brief spring for manufacturing could be over.

headline: Photo Journalism
text: ‘‘Photography is relevant because it sits at the axis of true, false and fake,’’ said Massimo Torrigiani, the Milan-based publisher and editor-at-large behind the year-old magazine Fantom. The English-language quarterly, which is edited by Cay Sophie Rabinowitz and Selva Barni, explores ‘‘the uses and abuses’’ of photography — artistic, commercial, scientific, etc. — with essays, interviews between photographers and picks from curators and gallery owners. Fantom is riding two trends that Torrigiani finds exciting: the return of intellectual debate in the art world and the emergence of cool independent magazines in Milan like Apartamento and Mousse. And, of course, it makes debate look great.

headline: Arthur Penn, a Director Attuned to His Country
text: “BONNIE AND CLYDE” was the movie on everyone’s lips after Arthur Penn’s death on Sept. 28 at 88, but there was more to his legacy than this exuberant 1967 gangster joy ride that shook up critics and audiences alike. It was the movie of its tumultuous moment, jolting in its violence and vitality. Critics were appalled or blissed out, and wrote about it and wrote about it until it became a veritable fetish. In time it became something other than a great film, something beyond a sexually bold, violent cinematic exorcism of the generational divide. It also became the first shot in New Hollywood’s war against Geezer Hollywood.

headline: Preview: Alabama at South Carolina
text: Penn State, Arkansas and Florida showed how the football can be moved against Alabama’s defense in the middle of the field. There are pass plays to be made behind linebackers and in front of safeties.

headline: A Sweeping Tale of a Terrorist and His Time
text: EVERYTHING about “Carlos,” the new film from the French director Olivier Assayas, is large and ambitious, from its length — about five and a half hours — to its subject matter: the rise and fall of the international terrorist known as Carlos the Jackal. But that’s not how things started.

headline: Al Pacino to Take On Phil Spector in HBO Movie
text: LOS ANGELES — It’s not quite a monster movie, but it has some of the same elements: an outsize character, a mysterious death, plenty of metaphor for mankind’s destruction. And lots and lots of excessively teased hair.

headline: Boehringer Stops Work on a ‘Female Viagra’
text: The German drug maker Boehringer Ingelheim announced Friday that it had stopped work on a pill for low libido in women, the latest setback in the controversial efforts to produce a “female Viagra.”

headline: The Latest Rush to Gold
text: Gold was trading at more than $1,300 an ounce on Friday, after a steady march upward over the past year. As Paul Sullivan writes in his Wealth Matters column this week, the rise in gold prices is once again inspiring sharply divided opinions. Is this the next bubble that is destined for a painful collapse? Or has the precious metal found a permanent — even expanded — place in portfolios?

headline: Civilian Replaces General in Key Foreign Policy Job
text: WASHINGTON  In speeding the replacement of the national security adviser, Gen. James L. Jones, with his deputy, a foreign policy aide with deep political experience, President Obama has given civilian and political advisers a bigger voice in the hard choices of the coming months, including how quickly to withdraw American troops from Afghanistan.

headline: Bank of America Halts Foreclosure Sales
text: Bank of America, the country’s largest bank, said Friday that it was halting all foreclosure proceedings and sales of foreclosed homes indefinitely, David Streitfeld of The New York Times reports.

headline: Tracking Campaign Money: A Guide
text: Court rulings and rule changes this year loosened some restrictions on campaign support and spending. Here’s how.

headline: Student Crossword | World Explorers
text: Complete our Student Crossword to see what you know about famous explorers and expeditions. You can find the answers here.

headline: Resources | World Explorers
text: To commemorate the observation of Columbus Day, we’ve collected Learning Network lessons and features on explorers and exploration, along with related resources from The Times and around the Web.

headline: Seven Arrested in Bronx in Antigay Attacks
text: 11:21 a.m. | Updated  Click here for the final, fuller version of this article that appeared in the newspaper.

headline: A New Sifty Fifty!
text: Well, not an entirely new one. As fall swings into gear, I have updated my list of favorite New York restaurants on The Scoop, the Times’s iPhone guide to New York, in order to bring a few new favorites into the light. (Some old ones, too.) Accordingly, a number of restaurants have fallen off the list. Will they ever be back? Probably! Or not. Or both. As Kanye West says over on the Twitter machine (where you can follow him  or me), “#ITSAPROCESS.”

headline: Next ‘Harry Potter’ Movie Will Not Be in 3-D
text: Visual-effects artists may be wizards in their own right, but they won’t have enough magic to present the next installment of the “Harry Potter” movie franchise in 3-D after all. On Friday, Warner Brothers Pictures said that “Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1,” the first of two films adapted from the final novel in J. K. Rowling‘s best-selling Harry Potter series, will be released in 2-D and in Imax theaters, but will not be shown in 3-D.

headline: Schoolboys Meet Again, With More on the Line
text: SAN FRANCISCO  There were times when Jason Heyward, the Braves’ young slugger, stepped to the plate Thursday night and was serenaded with chants of “Posey’s better.”

headline: Did ‘Whale Wars’ Leader Sink Boat for Publicity?
text: News reports are probing whether Paul Watson, who has turned a longstanding anti-whaling campaign into popular television entertainment with “Whale Wars,” ordered the intentional sinking of a million-dollar protest boat after it was damaged in a collision with a Japanese vessel early this year. 2:49 p.m. | Update  Watson posted a comment on Dot Earth Friday night offering a detailed defense.]

headline: Arab League Offers Reprieve on Mideast Talks
text: JERUSALEM  Arab League ministers meeting in Libya walked a diplomatic tightrope on Friday, issuing a statement that put the Israeli-Palestinian peace process on notice but also giving American brokers another month to resolve an impasse over Israeli settlement construction and restart the talks.

headline: Another Dimension of Idiocy
text: “JACKASS 3D,” which arrives in theaters on Friday, marks the improbable 10th anniversary of the MTV phenomenon, part fraternity hazing ritual and part extreme sports stunt. Those who loathe “Jackass” — which brought the world beer enemas and urine snow cones and thrust its merry band of dolts into reptile lairs and shark-infested waters — have called it disgusting and irresponsible: an incitement to copycat idiocy, if not a sign of the end of Western civilization. Fans of the franchise, which began as a television series (from 2000 to 2002) and spawned two earlier features (“Jackass the Movie” in 2002 and “Jackass Number Two” in 2006), counter that it is comic anarchy at its freest, as cathartically funny as it is monumentally stupid.

headline: Quote Unquote | Skirting Disaster
text: –Kanye West explains why he put his clothing line on hold. Apparently something good came out of Lindsay’s failed stint as a fashion designer.

headline: On DVD, ‘Essential Bugs Bunny Collection’
text: CERTAIN cultural phrases become so embedded in our subconscious that they will interrupt our own final rites. Maybe you hear whispers of Dickinson when sandwiched in a packed subway. (“I’m nobody! Who are you?/Are you nobody, too?”) Maybe a jolt of Shakespearean bravado sounds in your head as you join the line at Dunkin’ Donuts (“We few, we happy few, we band of brothers.”) Or maybe, like me, you stare into the morning mirror to be greeted with:

headline: Arts & Leisure Preview: ‘Women on the Verge,’ Dan Barry on Bugs Bunny and More
text: Wisdom, insights and observations from this weekend’s Arts & Leisure section. (Click on links for complete articles.)

headline: Flying Fewer Planes, Airlines Find Stability
text: VICTORVILLE, Calif.  For the first time since their industry was deregulated in the late 1970s, airlines in the United States have managed to hold the line on the number of planes they fly.

headline: Week in Pictures, Oct. 8
text: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region.

headline: A Gehry Sculpture for Rent
text: With its undulating walls of stainless steel, the new 8 Spruce Street tower designed by Frank Gehry will have over 600 apartment layouts.

headline: From Texas, Harvard Captain Finds His Way
text: BOSTON  Collin Zych, a senior free safety at Harvard, wakes up on a typical autumn Sunday feeling the aftershocks of most of the hits he made in the game the day before. He carries bumps and bruises, and his shoulders tend to ache.

headline: Nairobi Nights
text: Until the Tribe opened in Nairobi two years ago, boutique hotels were almost unknown to the Kenyan capital, where accommodations tend to be more shabby than chic. Travelers dubbed the high-tech, 137-room lodge serving the diplomatic community in the parklike Gigiri suburb “the Soho House of Nairobi.” That was partly because Mark Somen, its general manager, is a former director of that New York club. A Kenyan native and a believer in deluxe creature comforts like flat-screen TVs, organic food and fine linens, he gave the Tribe the look and feel of a hip resort and turned the stylish bar and lobby into a thriving nightspot.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Making Sense of the Tea Party
text: This week: Kate Zernike discusses Tea Party politics; Sam Roberts talks about new findings in the Rosenberg spy case; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has bestseller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

headline: Ex-Head of Park Avenue Bank Pleads Guilty to Fraud
text: The former chief executive of the Park Avenue Bank on Friday became the first person to be convicted of trying to defraud the federal bank bailout program after pleading guilty to numerous criminal charges, including securities fraud, bribery and embezzlement.

headline: Lessons From Female Owners Around the World
text: The number of businesses owned by women is growing worldwide. And while many of these ventures — particularly those in developing countries — face hurdles that are unimaginable in the United States, they also experience some universal challenges. This is evident in the stories of female owners from countries as geographically, politically and socially diverse as Afghanistan and Mexico.

headline: Allie Compton and Chris Ryan
text: HIS life is a fast-moving swirl of punk rock stagecraft, two-wheeled protests, film projects and occasional bits of street theater.

headline: Silver (Yawn) Is the Most Popular Car Color, Again
text: Car paint comes in wide range of colors, from Denim to Cognac to Wicked (i.e., green), but that marketing creativity isn’t matched by customer preferences — which, according to a new report, remain silver, black and white.

headline: Low Back Sprain Sidelines Nets’ Troy Murphy
text: The Nets announced Friday that Troy Murphy would be sidelined indefinitely after a magnetic resonance imaging examination confirmed that he had sustained a low back sprain. The development heightens the Nets’ need for Derrick Favors, the third overall pick in the draft, to acclimate quickly to the N.B.A.

headline: Cuba Journal: A Mixing of Styles in Havana
text: What happens when you put some great American jazz musicians onstage with the biggest names in Afro-Cuban music?

headline: ‘CHiPs’ Actor’s Journey in the Land of Penny Stocks
text: 5:34 p.m. | Updated  Larry Wilcox became famous for playing Officer Jon Baker on the hit television series “CHiPs” decades ago. But what about his most recent role — as the president and chief executive of a California company called the UC Hub Group?

headline: The Playground Gets Even Tougher
text: SCARLETT made for a good target. The daughter of a Williamsburg artist, she wore funky clothing to her East Village school, had a mild learning disability and was generally timid and insecure. Lila, the resident “mean girl” in Scarlett’s kindergarten class, started in immediately.

headline: The Morning Skate: Young Oilers Debut Promises Fun Season
text: Who before the season was willing to take the Edmonton Oilers seriously? Not too many come to mind. TSN, for example, ranked them last in their preseason rankings of N.H.L. clubs. Hockey Night in Canada was a bit more charitable

headline: Coping With an Unfinished Life
text: SOUTH PASADENA, Calif.

headline: Now Trading | Manly Goods
text: With its hunting-cabin vibe, its selection of rugged men’s wear and its hodgepodge selection of duck-related artworks (paintings, lampshades, knickknacks), walking into Palmer Trading Company is like stepping back in time — with the settings on the time machine switched to “manly” and “Americana.” Or maybe it’s more like visiting your hermit great-uncle who digs hunting.

headline: Alderson to Interview for Mets’ General Manager Job
text: Sandy Alderson, the longtime baseball official, said in a telephone interview on Friday that he is scheduled to meet with the Mets  owner Jeff Wilpon in New York next week to discuss the team’s general manager vacancy.

headline: Philip Roth’s Literary Javelin
text: Longtime readers of the Book Review may recall George Plimpton’s classic 1992 essay “The Smaller the Ball, the Better the Book,” which held that when it comes to sports literature, there is an inverse relation between the size of the thing people are trying to hit and how much fun it is to read about it.

headline: Philip Roth’s Literary Javelin
text: Longtime readers of the Book Review may recall George Plimpton’s classic 1992 essay “The Smaller the Ball, the Better the Book,” which held that when it comes to sports literature, there is an inverse relation between the size of the thing people are trying to hit and how much fun it is to read about it.

headline: North Koreans ‘Have the Honor of Serving’ Leader’s Son, Senior Official Says
text: In an interview with Associated Press Television News on Friday, a senior North Korean official seemed to confirm that Kim Jong-un, the youngest son of the country’s “dear leader,” Kim Jong-il, will eventually succeed his father.

headline: Carbon-Cutting ‘Party’ Set for Sunday
text: Some prominent climate scientists, like James Hansen of NASA, think the safe threshold for carbon dioxide in the atmosphere is no higher than 350 parts per million. Beyond this point, they say, we risk severe climatic consequences: melting ice caps and glaciers, rising seas, and a sharp increase in heat waves, droughts, crop failures and extreme weather events.

headline: Handbags at Dawn
text: The pre-release of four styles from the Mulberry for Target line sold out within minutes on GiltGroupe.com in August, proving the public’s desire for the English luxury house’s leather goods. Now, the stellar collaboration is having its official introduction, in Target stores and on target.com, today. Priced from $14.99 for the mobile-phone-friendly Mini Messenger to $49.99 for large satchels and totes, the collection features 18 pieces available in leather and denim, including a winning pink leopard print. Says Emma Hill, Mulberry’s creative director, “Leopards are king this season.”

headline: Origins of Human Rights
text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: Coffee, TV or Wi-Fi?
text: The politicians have it all wrong. We are not addicted to foreign oil. We are addicted to Wi-Fi, the wireless networking technology that holds our youth in its wavy grip.

headline: A Complicated Woman
text: To the Editor:

headline: Toys Without Borders
text: And to think that Betsy Wetsy shares the same phylum as Kaori the Nurse. Both are dolls, of course, but Kaori is a limited-edition designer toy meant for grown-ups who can afford four figures for a “cuddly” five-inch work of art. The scope of these plastic critters, which range from the abstract to the downright lewd (see Cathy Cowgirl, the heifer with big teats), is wonderfully surveyed in “I Am Plastic, Too” (Abrams, $45), by Paul Budnitz, the designer and collector behind the art-toy company Kidrobot. What began in 1996 with some handmade toys by two Chinese artists in Hong Kong has now spread west with collectors lining up for hours to buy the latest releases. Globalism strikes again!

headline: Plenty of Ideas for Making the Subway Better
text: With New Yorkers being asked once again to pay more for less transit service, the NYC columnist, Clyde Haberman, asked readers to suggest low-cost ways for the perpetually cash-starved Metropolitan Transportation Authority to make taking the subway a more pleasant experience.

headline: Tapping ‘The Power’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Based on a True Story
text: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Ten, Ten, Ten,’ the Pitchmen Say, 10 Times Over
text: Marketers are always looking for ways to latch onto big events and other things that get consumers talking, the better to stand out amid the clutter. Such efforts to borrow interest seem to be increasing in this age of social media, as people make marketing moves — like the new logo redesign for Gap — the subjects of posts, comments and chats.

headline: Living in Borough Park, Brooklyn
text: In Borough Park, Brooklyn, religious tradition and ritual touch nearly every aspect of neighborhood life.

headline: In New York, a Rivalry Shifts Into High Gear
text: FOUR years ago, three women opened a candlelit cycling studio called SoulCycle in the back of a lobby on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, charging $27 a class. At the time, stationary cycling was a ho-hum staple of traditional gyms, and this place had no showers, and no room to maneuver in its cramped hallway. What self-respecting Manhattanite would pay a premium to pedal 45 minutes to nowhere?

headline: Abbott Labs Withdraws Meridia From the Market
text: The diet drug Meridia is being withdrawn from the market because it can increase the risk of heart attacks and strokes.

headline: Reds Have to Deal With Another Roy
text: PHILADELPHIA – The Cincinnati Reds will soon be back on the field for Game 2 of the National League division series, which could be the best way for them to put the memory of Roy Halladay’s no-hitter in Game 1 behind them. But the Reds still have to deal with Roy.

headline: On the Street | In Paris at Chanel
text: Guests attending the spring 2011 Chanel show in Paris wore nothing else but, well, Chanel.

headline: 3M Gains 52% of Cogent’s Stock
text: The 3M Company said on Friday that it had received 52 percent of Cogent‘s shares in its tender offer for the fingerprint identification company, despite opposition from some shareholders who thought 3M should make a higher bid than $10.50 a share.

headline: Outflanked on Right, Coulter Seeks New Image
text: “I WROTE a new speech for the gays and I don’t have it memorized yet!” said Ann Coulter, as she ducked into a hallway in the Union Square apartment of the venture capitalist Peter Thiel on a recent Saturday night, flicking a half-empty packet of Habitrol gum between her fingers. She was there to speak at Homocon 2010, a party for the one-year anniversary of GOProud, the Washington-based advocacy group for gay conservatives.

headline: Here’s Looking at Bogie, Kid
text: A NEW boxed set from Warner Home Video, “Humphrey Bogart: The Essential Collection,” reminds us of how many movies Bogart made, and how few of them actually feature “Bogie,” that wincing, faded idealist who remains one of the most popular and resonant figures in American movies.

headline: Weekend Fare
text: Celebrity chefs are crowding Manhattan this weekend for the New York City Wine and Food Festival, which runs through Sunday. Most of the dinners, wine and food tastings, cooking demonstrations and hands-on classes take place in the meatpacking district. Many popular events are sold out, but there are still tickets available, $10 to $275. The proceeds benefit Share Our Strength and the Food Bank For New York City.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Israel and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Israel, Afghanistan and Russia.

headline: Dancing With the Council
text: Councilwoman Letitia James hasn't danced for 20 years. But she's putting on her dancing shoes, and gearing up for competition, along with other community and business leaders.

headline: Is Gossip Good for You?
text: THE GIST Gossiping can be beneficial.

headline: Now Queen of the Firing Range
text: ON a recent morning at the Four Seasons Hotel in Midtown Manhattan, Helen Mirren sat in a plush old armchair and poured herself a latte from a silver pot resting on a silver tray. Wearing a fine-knit salmon-colored cardigan and with her head held high and knees pressed together primly, Ms. Mirren seemed the embodiment of regal, a word so frequently attached to her that she has grown to dislike it. Upon further inspection, though, certain complicating details emerged. Black pencil ringed her eyes punkishly. Glinting, oversize zippers sawed diagonally up the sides of her skirt, trimmings a touch more dominatrix than dame. And that jagged black abstraction just below her left thumb? A tattoo she got years ago after more than a few drinks.

headline: Now Showing | Tony Cox “White Trash Mystic”
text: That an exhibition called “White Trash Mystic” is opening in a pop-up gallery space in the new luxury-condominium building at 211 Elizabeth Street (where the actor Gabriel Byrne reportedly coughed up more than $3 million for a two-bedroom) is either ironic or, well, just plain trashy. But for the show’s artist, the former professional skateboarder Tony Cox, the liminal space between the city’s high-end art scene and the culture that some people disparagingly call “white trash” is a rewarding creative zone.

headline: Game 2 Final: Phillies 7, Reds 4
text: The Reds committed the fewest errors in the National League during the regular season, but they committed four of them – including two on one play – as the Phillies beat them, 7-4, to take a two-game lead in the best-of-five playoff series.

headline: Of a Certain Age, With Vitality and Style
text: ON THE SCREEN At first glance, Advanced Style looks like an ordinary street-fashion photo blog. The mostly vertical images of pedestrians in dapper suits and fanciful skirts mingle with short descriptions of the clothing and back stories about the wearers.

headline: Chinese Leader Denies Using Mineral Exports for Political Ends
text: BEIJING  Prime Minister Wen Jiabao of China has told European political and business leaders that China has not imposed any bans on exports of industrial minerals for political purposes, and that it does not intend to stop exports in the future, according to a report on Friday in China Daily.

text: Photographs from Israel, Afghanistan and Russia.

text: The planned rail tunnel under the Hudson River may not be quite dead yet.

text: Graham Bowley, a DealBook colleague, reports:

headline: Anti-Incumbent Fervor Skips Tennessee District
text: MANCHESTER, Tenn.  Amid the rolling hills of Tennessee’s Fourth Congressional District, which wraps around the state’s rural middle like a cigar band, it is difficult to find a lot of enthusiasm for the Obama administration. The residents of the district  farmers, factory workers, small business owners  are abidingly conservative.

headline: Housekeeping
text: For new commenters: no obscenities, this is the Times. Also, to prevent trolls from hijacking the discussion, I have a length limit — trying to get it automated, but pending that, a quick and dirty rule of about 3 inches on my screen. So if you wonder why your comment didn’t make it, that’s why.

headline: Death Reclaims His Fractured Psyche
text: In 2005, the entertaining terror-in-the-skies thriller “Red Eye” indicated that Wes Craven still had his horror mojo, a decade or two or three after “Scream,” “A Nightmare on Elm Street” and “The Hills Have Eyes.”

headline: Gay Harassment and the Struggle for Inclusion
text: Weeks before she had any reason to know the name Tyler Clementi, the Rev. Audrey M. Connor was planning a celebratory day of worship at her church in Lynchburg, Va. It would take place this Sunday, the eve of a gay-rights event called National Coming Out Day. There would be prayers, songs and testimonies by three congregants who had successfully emerged from the closet.

headline: Don’t Put on Lead the Defender Who’ll Find the Unwanted Shift
text: PHILADELPHIA  The knockout stages of the women’s McConnell Cup and the open Rosenblum Cup have begun here.

headline: It’s Got a Good Beat and You Can Sign Bills to It
text: What music does President Obama have playing in the background when he’s “sweet-talking” the First Lady? We found out Friday, as singer-songwriter Stevie Wonder joined Mr. Obama for a bill signing in the East Room of the White House.

headline: We Made It Ourselves | Scream Sorbet
text: Sorbet may have its charms, but, let’s be clear, it’s no ice cream. That’s one stigma with which the dairy-free, (usually) fruity substance has been marked. According to Noah Goldner, one of three principles behind Scream Sorbet, there’s another issue: “There’s a surprisingly large percentage of the population that clearly doesn’t know there’s a difference, sort of the same way a lot of people don’t know where Florida is.”

headline: This Time Around, Something Citified
text: AFTER the younger of her two children left for college a year ago, “I was empty-nesting like crazy,” Kathi Homenick said. She was eager to leave her two-story detached wood frame house on a lovely, leafy street in Bayside, Queens. With the kids gone, there was no reason to stay in a neighborhood that seemed way too suburban.

headline: A Long Winter Awaits Some Sellers
text: THE five-bedroom four-bath farm ranch on more than 2.5 acres that Margaret Trautmann owns in Upper Brookville has been on the market for nine months. Originally listed at $1.695 million, the 51-year-old slate-roofed house has since had its price cut by $100,000.

headline: James D. Stanton
text: Mr. Stanton, 58, is the president of the World-Wide Holdings Corporation, which was started by his father, Frank, and Victor Elmaleh, who serves as the chairman.

headline: Borough Park, Brooklyn
text: IN late September, during the final days of the weeklong holiday of Sukkot, young boys in white shirts and black hats could often be seen lining the streets of Borough Park, a large neighborhood in southwest Brooklyn. Standing behind folding card tables arrayed with long, thin willow branches to be waved in synagogue, they called out in Yiddish, hoping to attract customers from among the crowds of shoppers who exited, bags in hand, the kosher markets of 13th Avenue.

headline: Preventing Credit Score Dings
text: IF you’re looking to refinance or buy a home, potential lenders and mortgage brokers will be checking your credit scores. And if those scores are being verified, chances are they are going down.

headline: The Dollar Made Them Do It
text: IN boom times and bust, international buyers play an integral role in the Manhattan residential marketplace, stabilizing prices in lean years and driving demand when the market is ascendant. They make up an estimated 10 to 15 percent of all sales in the city almost every year, brokers say.

headline: A Fair-Housing Inquiry in Darien
text: THE United States Department of Justice is investigating the Fairfield County town of Darien for possible violations of the Fair Housing Act.

headline: Wall-to-Wall Memories, Built-In Baby Sitter
text: STANDING in front of a small brick apartment house on Netherland Avenue in the South Riverdale section of the Bronx, Matt Bergin can trace the lives of nearly every member of his family.

headline: Building Good Will and More
text: TIMES being tough for New Jersey real estate, the news is mostly hard to take; but this concerns some news that isn’t.

headline: Have You Heard the One About Mayor Bloomberg?
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has charmed New Yorkers, or tried to, with his borscht-belt brand of humor, peppering news conferences with cranky wisecracks and Catskills-worthy puns. Now he is taking his act to a national audience.

headline: Dear FloFab: My Friends Brought Bacon Double Cheeseburgers Into My Kosher Home
text: Each week, Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.

headline: Out of the DVR and Onto the Stage
text: The nearly three-hour “So You Think You Can Dance” live tour came to Radio City Music Hall on Thursday night, greeted by screaming, merchandise-bedecked multitudes. They had come to see winners and finalists from the last seven seasons of that reality television competition; these young dance celebrities, having vanquished a slew of opponents and genres, are now enjoying their victory lap.

headline: Print Publishers Give Marketers More Ways to Reach Men
text: Among the reasons that the nontraditional media are thriving is that men are big fans of going online to watch video and read sports and news articles. Still, the appeal of print as a medium remains, as evidenced by start-ups of magazines aimed at men.

headline: Apple Plans to Offer iPhone on Verizon
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Facing intense competition from phone makers wedded to Google’s Android software, Steven P. Jobs, Apple’s chief executive, finally plans to make the iPhone available on Verizon Wireless, the largest wireless carrier in the United States.

headline: G.E. Keeps Shopping for Energy Assets
text: General Electric’s recent multibillion-dollar acquisition spree may just be getting started. The conglomerate’s GE Energy Financial Services unit has recently been taking a hard look at several energy companies that operate in the Gulf of Mexico, aiming to possibly acquire some or all of their assets, according to two people briefed on the matter.

headline: Ryan Seacrest Backs New Cable Effort
text: Ryan Seacrest, the host of “American Idol” and co-host of “E! News,” is backing a proposed entertainment cable channel with AEG, the events promoter, and CAA, the talent agency.

headline: Setting Life and Loss to Song, and Seeking a Stamp of Approval
text: “There are 30 shows in the New York Musical Theater Festival, so you have a one in 30 chance you came to the right show,” said David Rossmer, addressing the audience at the start of “V-Day,” which he and Steve Rosen wrote and perform.

headline: Serving Up Style and Atmosphere
text: OPEN only since June, Moderne Barn has swiftly acquired a reputation for outstanding contemporary design. The Livanos family of restaurateurs has always decorated its restaurants with style, and this newest addition to its string — including City Limits Diner in White Plains, Burger Deluxe in Wayne, N.J., and Oceana, Molyvos and Abboccato in Manhattan — is no exception. The Barn is a seductive place.

headline: Student Says He Found an FBI Tracking Device on His Car
text: A 20-year-old college student in California says that during a visit to his mechanic for a routine oil change, the mechanic found a suspicious wire sticking out at the right rear of his car. The garage owner pulled on it, and detached a GPS transmitter that had been attached to the chassis with a magnet. According to Wired.com, the student, Yasir Afifi, who attends Mission College in Santa Clara, recognized it as a GPS tracking device and posted photos of it on the Reddit site.

headline: How Flin Flon Explains the World: Kevin Lowe Tries to Save a River
text: Canada seems lost in a political tailspin: a deadlocked minority government, a largely ineffective opposition, a ruling party — Stephen Harper’s Tories — struggling to pass legislation that is usually controversial to begin with.

headline: Boehner Campaigns in Ohio, Evoking Twisted Sister a Bit
text: You’ve heard Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio, the House Republican leader, wants to be speaker. Did you also know that he is running for re-election?

headline: The Week in Pictures for Oct. 8
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include political campaigning in New York and Connecticut, a memorial service for firefighters, and New York’s oldest Roman Catholic church.

headline: Chic in Review | Rachel Zoe’s New Project
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Southern Barbecue, Up North
text: Mama’s Southern Style B.B.Q. II, in the Vauxhall section of Union is a hidden hole-in-the-wall that attracts a steady clientele with its combination of Carolina-style barbecue and other Southern staples like fried chicken. Christopher Finnick and his wife, Nakeya, are the owners, with family members helping out.

headline: Infused With the Taste of Orange-Yellow
text: MONTCLAIR’S thriving restaurant scene offers tastes of nearly every region of the world in six square miles. But South America has been woefully underrepresented. In May, with the opening of Costanera, the town finally got what places like Kearny and Paterson, catering to their clusters of immigrants, have long enjoyed in abundance: authentic Peruvian cuisine, with its distinctive flavors.

headline: The Caucus Click: Philadelphia
text: Outside the restaurant where Pat Toomey, the Republican candidate for Senate, received the endorsement of Luis G. Fortuño, the governor of Puerto Rico.

headline: Battle of the East End Reds
text: Long Island’s increasingly vocal merlot vs. cabernet franc debate  which should be considered the region’s signature red?  came to mind recently when I tasted wines made by Osprey’s Dominion, in Peconic.

headline: A Smokehouse Outpost in a Shopping Center
text: LONG ISLAND has never been barbecue territory, but in the past few years it has experienced a miniboom of barbecue places. Among them is Dixie’s Smokehouse in Kings Park, which has had good word of mouth since it opened in July 2009.

headline: Coffee, Tea and a Goddess
text: The teapot silhouette on a peach-colored inset just outside Bartleby’s Cafe seems incongruous for a place that prides itself on freshly roasted, hand-ground coffee. Yet Bartleby’s, which opened in 1999, is as much a fine teahouse as it is a coffee shop.

headline: Sebold Takes Job as a Book Editor
text: Alice Sebold, the author of “The Lovely Bones,” has taken a part-time job as editor of Tonga Books, a new imprint of Europa Editions, a small New York-based publishing house. The new imprint is to publish three or four novels a year, with an emphasis on titles that are dark, cutting-edge or otherwise outside the publishing mainstream. “Sympathetic characters rock,” a news release said, “but we dig” the nasty ones as well. “Tonga cannot pony up the big bucks,” the release also said. “All advances will be in the four figures.” Ms. Sebold, who has never been a book editor, said in a telephone interview that she was still a little stunned that she had agreed to the proposal from Sandro Ferri and his wife, Sandra, the founders and owners of Europa. She added that she hoped to attract first novelists as well as veteran writers who are having trouble getting published these days because their books don’t sell “a gazillion copies.” The initial Tonga book, scheduled for the fall of 2011, is “You Deserve Nothing,” a first novel by Alexander Maksik, who is currently studying at the Iowa Writers’ Workshop.

headline: What’s The Spell For Making a Film 3-D?
text: Although Warner Brothers announced early this year that the final two “Harry Potter” films would be released in 3-D, the first of them will not. In a statement on Friday Warner Brothers said it had decided to release “Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1” on Nov. 19 in 2-D for both conventional and Imax theaters. “Despite everyone’s best efforts, we were unable to convert the film in its entirety and meet the highest standards of quality,” Warner said in a statement. This year Warner was criticized by fans, media types and industry executives for releasing “Clash of the Titans” in a 3-D version that did not measure up to the expectations of some. The final installment in the Potter series, “Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2,” will be released on July 15, 2011, in both 2-D and 3-D, Warner said.

headline: Flavors of the Mideast and North Africa
text: AT first glance, it seems that Bespoke, formerly owned by the New Haven restaurant mavens Arturo and Suzette Franco-Comacho, has changed little. The new proprietors, Lauren Kendzierski and her father, John Kendzierski, have wisely retained the Franco-Comachos’ elegant décor, including that incredible onyx fireplace that still dominates the mezzanine. Even the steel-gray menu jackets are the same, though they have begun to look worn around the edges.

headline: ‘Secretariat’ Horses Learn Hollywood’s Ways
text: It’s not easy being an innocent young horse in Hollywood. Just ask the five creatures who collectively played the title character in “Secretariat.” To film that drama, which arrived in theaters on Friday, Walt Disney Studios used a group of horses. One was better for close-ups. One was better for racing sequences. You get the idea. But none of them made it into the credits of the film. And while Disney divulged the names of two of the horses to reporters  Trolley Boy, a 6-year-old from Kentucky, and Longshot Max, a 7-year-old from Oklahoma  the studio refused to identify the other three. A case of equine inequality? Disney didn’t put any of the horses in the credits, a studio spokeswoman explained, in the interest of time. It had been decided that the scroll could last only 4 minutes 30 seconds and there wasn’t room for them. It sounds as if some horses needed better agents. As for the three mystery horses, the somewhat fuzzy explanation involves control. While a professional animal trainer, Rusty Hendrickson, has custody of Trolley Boy and Longshot Max, the other three  used primarily as racing doubles  were sold after filming. Disney, thinking only of the animals, perhaps, did not want the new owners to be able to exploit the horses’ potential celebrity for personal gain.

headline: Mind Over Other Matter
text: “The Mentalist” earned the most viewers in prime time on Thursday night as 14.3 million tuned in to that crime show, according to Nielsen’s estimates. The CBS series easily outperformed its 10 p.m. competitors, “Private Practice” (8 million) on ABC and “The Apprentice” on NBC, which attracted a disappointing audience of just 3.8 million viewers. CBS led the night over all, with ABC placing second and Fox third, garnering 9.1 million viewers for “Bones” at 8 but only 5.2 million for “Fringe” at 9. NBC lagged behind in fourth place.

headline: ‘Character Assassins’ Explores the Wages of Criticism
text: Maybe it’s just because of the dapper characters in old movies like “All About Eve,” but theater critics  fictional ones, at least  sometimes seem to belong to another era.

headline: Bam! Pow! A Loud Young Rapper Rekindles Rap’s Old Fighting Spirit
text: The beats and the lyrics matter on “Flockaveli,” the debut album by the Atlanta rapper Waka Flocka Flame, but everything important about this album is captured in the ad-libbed vocal interjections sprinkled throughout, which approximate the fight captions of old “Batman” episodes: “Bam!” “Pow!” “Whap!” “Boom!” “Oof!”

headline: Tales of Motherhood, With a Rock Beat
text: Five disparate housewives, bonding in their long-suppressed desires to be rock stars, form a band soon to become famous as MoM. Eight years later, the women return to the high school gym where they first performed to sing about their subsequent highs, lows and wife-mother-superstar throes in “MoM A Rock Concert Musical.”

headline: Israelis vs. Palestinians: The 90-Minute Version
text: The journalist Lawrence Wright possesses a knack for clarifying complicated problems. Obviously this comes in handy in his regular line of work, but it is just as useful in his secondary vocation, as a public raconteur trying to elucidate thorny topical issues from the unlikely pulpit of an Off Broadway stage.

headline: More Serves and Volleys In Adams Photo Dispute
text: Rick Norsigian, the man who says he found the “lost negatives” of the landscape photographer Ansel Adams, fought back on Friday against those who have suggested that at least some of the images may have been created by an unheralded photographer, Earl Brooks.

headline: TD Ameritrade Waives Trading Fees on 101 E.T.F.’s

headline: From Girlhood Trials to Onstage Triumph
text: WHEN Elaine Del Valle was a little girl, in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn in the 1980s, she lived in an apartment that required only one key to open the front door. headline: Teacher and Student(s), in a Comedy of Manners
text: To be an American etiquette teacher in 1967, when hippies and the Summer of Love reigned, was probably a thankless job. To be a 9-year-old boy forced to take an etiquette class that year must have seemed like a fate worse than violent death. “Mrs. Mannerly,” Jeffrey Hatcher’s gentle two-actor comedy now playing at Penguin Rep, sympathizes with both sides of the situation.

headline: In the Attic With Anne Frank
text: So that’s where it happened.

headline: Reverend Billy’s Revelation: A Role for Money
text: Two weeks ago Reverend Billy, the performance artist and activist best known as the leader of the Church of Stop Shopping, was plying his trade, public proselytizing. He and 15 members of the church’s choir traveled from New York to Washington to stage a protest as part of Appalachia Rising, a campaign to end mountaintop-removal coal mining. They gathered around a mound of symbolic dirt in the lobby of a bank that they say finances mountaintop removal, shouted “Hallelujah!” and sang folk songs. Reverend Billy was arrested for what his wife and performance partner, Savitri D, guessed was the 50th time.

headline: Still a Lot to Mine From Ella’s Life
text: If “Ella,” the Long Wharf Theater’s first production of the season, has a message about Ella Fitzgerald, it is that she was terribly unattractive and a horrible mother. Whether true or not, these attributes are treated as givens in this show. So maybe the producers should have a makeup artist drab down their star, Tina Fabrique, or recast the role.

headline: In Illinois, Questions About Trust Are Front and Center
text: The Senate contest in Illinois has been in a stalemate for months, with questions of trust about both candidates hovering in the background.
