headline: Classic Scones
text: Mark Bittman bakes traditional English scones, which are light, flaky and barely sweet at all.

headline: Applying Broad Strokes to a Time of War
text: The great American art critic Clement Greenberg once described kitsch as a “debased and academicized” version of “genuine culture,” offering familiar images that demand little of the viewer. Norman Rockwell and Ilya Repin, a late 19th-century Russian realist, were Greenberg’s primary examples.

headline: California Budget Wins Approval
text: LOS ANGELES  After an all-night session of legislative wrangling, the California Legislature on Friday morning approved a nearly $126 billion budget that imposes a new round of cuts on the state’s public school system, but includes changes in the public employee pension system and California’s budget process that officials said could help avoid another budget crisis.

headline: What Do Women (or Men) Want? A Gala’s Question
text: If I were an examiner instead of a critic, Benjamin Millepied might well be my favorite living ballet choreographer. I’d bring lots of other dance makers (some of them much more famous) to see his work and say, “Look how much he knows about spatial and temporal structure, and about groupings! Look how each piece stretches him in an impressively new direction! Look how chic, how now, his every work is, but always in a different way! Note how his men don’t endlessly manipulate their women!” I’d give him prizes galore.

headline: Nightclub Tradition Gets a Jolt Of Youth
text: Stately grandeur and youthful intensity: the annual New York Cabaret Convention at the Rose Theater has never lacked for great ladies and refined gentlemen. But as for youth (performers under 50), it has always struggled to forge a credible connection between a nightclub tradition nearly done in by rock ’n’ roll and television and the idea of a future. This year was different. All it takes to demonstrate that somehow or other the tradition goes on is a couple of exceptional rising talents. And at the convention’s opening-night gala on Thursday, two singers  T. Oliver Reid and Amanda King  leapt out from the pack.

headline: An Unseen Evil Still Ensnaring Countless Souls
text: CINCINNATI  Peer through a circular hole into one of the displays in the permanent exhibition “Invisible: Slavery Today,” opening on Saturday at the National Underground Railroad Freedom Center here, and you see a tawdry room the size of a closet. On the floor a stained mattress is scrawled with the words: “At sixteen, her new ‘life’ had begun.” The irony stings. Around the portal’s opening, a seemingly handwritten account tells of Margo’s abusive father, the promises of escape offered by Lenny and her delivery into sexual slavery.

headline: Weekly Pick ‘Em: The Grind
text: Last Saturday brought a wealth of marquee matchups, including Florida-Alabama, Stanford-Oregon and Texas-Oklahoma. At first glance, this weekend doesn’t look as glitzy. But that’s only because teams are now into the grind of conference play, where each week brings a familiar opponent and the chance to be lulled into complacency. Alabama has one of the more absurd conference schedules in recent memory, with South Carolina the first of six SEC opponents that will be coming off a bye week when they face the Tide. That will make the Tide’s road through the league that much more difficult. Florida will try to bounce back from being handled easily by Alabama when it faces Louisiana State in the Swamp. The Tigers, through a combination of good defense and horrendous clock management, are 5-0 but being treated like they are underachievers. A win against the Gators could give them some credibility. Elsewhere in Florida, Florida State and Miami will play the latest installment of a rivalry that was one of the best in college football over the last quarter century. While that rivalry has lost some of its luster, Michigan-Michigan State has gained some glitz thanks to the outsize performance of Denard Robinson this season. Coach Mark Dantonio is expected to return to the Spartans after missing two games after having a mild heart attack. In the Pac-10, Stanford is coming off a loss to Oregon and Southern California is hoping to prove that it still deserves to be considered one of the conference’s top teams. There is plenty to be excited about now that conference play has started in earnest and the history and familiarity between teams always makes prognosticating that much more difficult. As always, if you agree, disagree or simply find the picks laughable, feel free to let us know.

headline: A Very Proper Scone
text: MOST scones in this country are overly sweet and loaded up with some ridiculous combination of raisins, apples, cherries, chocolate chips, almonds, ginger and perhaps a few other ingredients. Traditional English scones are actually barely sweet, though they’re usually eaten with sweet jam and clotted cream, which is not easy to find here. In general they’re lighter, flakier and tastier than what you buy. And they’re easy to make.

headline: Air Products Wins Round in Battle With Airgas
text: Despite some last-minute chatter in arbitrage circles that Airgas had turned the corner and a very good presentation by Ted Mirvis of Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz, Air Products and Chemicals won an important decision in Delaware Chancery Court late Friday in its takeover quest for Airgas. Chancellor William B. Chandler III ruled that a new corporate bylaw that would move up the Airgas annual shareholders meeting to January was valid under Delaware law.

headline: Roosevelt Island’s Flying Buses to Return Soon
text: In the company of 109 other daredevils, you’d step into a giant glass bubble. As the bubble is suspended, somewhat unconvincingly, from a length of wire, you’d all be pulled up off the ground and out away from solid land. Higher, farther, higher, farther — until you were dangling 230 feet above the East River.

headline: Top-Rated Place to Eat Is Home
text: Tim and Nina Zagat, co-founders and co-chairmen of the Zagat Survey, don’t cook much during the week. When you spend your days expanding and perfecting your empire of restaurant and leisure guides — like the 2011 Zagat Survey, released on Wednesday — it would be wrong to whip up some pasta at home instead of heading out to, say,  the Mark Restaurant by Jean Georges. That changes on weekends, which Mr. and Mrs. Zagat (pronounced zuh-GAHT) spend at their country home in Millerton, N.Y. On Sundays, Mrs. Zagat, 68, makes soups and jams, and when there are guests — often their two grown sons and daughter-in-law — she prepares lavish breakfasts. Mr. Zagat, 70, enjoys them.

headline: An Optimistic Seller of Disaster Plans
text: NO, Catherine Hooper did not live through Hurricane Katrina, and while she did see the second plane hit the World Trade Center, she viewed it from the treadmill at her gym, where she was watching television. But Ms. Hooper, a 5-foot-1, 99.6-pound disaster-preparedness entrepreneur in a Christian Dior dress, has had some riveting firsthand experience.

headline: When the City Defined Who’s Who
text: ETHAN MORDDEN mulled titling his latest social and cultural history “From Mrs. Astor to Truman Capote, or the Rise of New Yorkism in American Life.” Instead, he settled on a more generic (and inviting) title with a more specific subtitle: “The Guest List: How Manhattan Defined American Sophistication  From the Algonquin Round Table to Truman Capote’s Ball” (St. Martin’s Press, $29.99).

headline: What the Squirrels Know: Acorns for Dinner
text: THE assault began in early September. That’s when my 60-year-old mother, an avid gardener, began laying mulch under the shrubs at her home in Westchester. She had her shovel in hand when  thunk!  a white oak fired its first shot. For the next several weeks, the century-old tree would rain acorns on her head like a Newtonian nightmare.

headline: ‘The Tiger’
text: Prologue

headline: Chronicle of a Changing City
text: THE NEW YORK UNIVERSITY QUIDDITCH TEAM started Monday, with a surprising turnout of 95 students. To those who somehow slept through the Harry Potter craze, quidditch is that fantastical sport played by wizards and witches on flying broomsticks. But there is an earthly game known as Muggle Quidditch, adapted for a grassy field, in which players use volleyballs, basketballs and dodge balls instead of quaffles. “We didn’t really get any big bruisers  they were mostly nerds,” said the club’s founder, Sarah Landis, 20, a sophomore from New Jersey. “A lot of them have never played sports before.” Ms. Landis said the players hoped to persuade the university to bestow official team or “competing club” status by doing well next month in the fourth annual Quidditch World Cup, in Manhattan.

headline: Vows in the Park? Expect Joggers
text: THE wedding of Leila El-Azem and Samuel Butt in Fort Tryon Park had an international guest list of 136  college friends from the Midwest; uncles from Paris and London; family friends from Geneva. But there were many other witnesses, as well: women of a certain age who turn out every weekend to watch nuptials in the park; a 29-year-old bride planning to exchange vows in the same spot this Sunday ; and Alexis Guichardo, who took his own wedding photos in the park 30 years ago and said he just loved the “whole ritual of weddings.”

text: Jeff Genyk had his jaw-dropping Denard Robinson moment long before everybody else.

headline: Ruling Limits State’s Power in School Suspensions
text: In a ruling that puts new restraints on get-tough “zero tolerance” discipline, the North Carolina Supreme Court ruled Friday that schools must provide strong reasons for denying alternative schooling or tutoring to students after they are suspended for misbehavior.

headline: A Real Scone
text: A real scone is not yet another form of cake; it’s closer to a biscuit, though a tad sweeter and richer, designed to be eaten (in England at least) with jam and something creamy. Check out this week’s Minimalist column for more.

headline: William M. Birenbaum, College Leader, Dies at 87
text: William M. Birenbaum, a nationally known university administrator who helped rescue Antioch College from looming insolvency during his tenure as president there in the 1970s and ’80s, died on Monday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 87 and also had a home in Wellfleet, Mass.

text: Engineers have nearly completed a rescue shaft.

headline: N.F.L. Is Reviewing Claims About Favre and Jets
text: The N.F.L. has begun reviewing allegations made in an article published by the Web site Deadspin.com that Brett Favre sent graphic photos and suggestive messages to a sideline personality, Jenn Sterger, while both Favre and Sterger were employed by the Jets.

headline: A Double Standard at H.P.
text: And so it came to pass that on the 55th day — 55 days, that is, after firing its chief executive, Mark V. Hurd, for playing footsie with a consultant and fudging his expense accounts — the board of directors at Hewlett-Packard proudly announced it had found a new man to lead the company out of the wilderness.

headline: Voting Test Falls Victim to Hackers
text: Hackers infiltrated the District of Columbia’s online voting system last week. They changed all votes for mayor to Master Control Pro and elected HAL 9000 the council chairman. The blaring University of Michigan fight song played whenever a new ballot was successfully cast.

headline: UConn Punishes Itself, Not Calhoun
text: The University of Connecticut responded on Friday to the N.C.A.A.’s findings of major violations in its men’s basketball program, admitting its transgressions, imposing penalties, but at the same time going out of its way to separate the Hall of Fame coach Jim Calhoun from involvement in the recruiting scandal.

headline: Obamacare Passes Its First Test
text: Are you one of the 46 million Americans without health insurance? Well, you may not have that, uh, luxury for much longer. “A federal judge in Michigan on Thursday dismissed one of more than 15 legal challenges to the new health care law, becoming the first to rule that the law is constitutional,” reports The Times’s Kevin Sack. “The central question, which may ultimately fall to the Supreme Court, is whether the Commerce Clause of the Constitution gives Congress the authority to require citizens to obtain a commercial product, namely health insurance. Starting in 2014, the law will require most Americans to obtain health insurance …”

headline: Regulators Seek Curbs for Bank Bonuses in Europe
text: LONDON  Bankers should not receive more than half of their bonuses in cash and as much as 60 percent of the payment should be deferred depending on their position at the bank, according to European draft guidelines published Friday.

headline: China Central Bank’s Chief Backs Gradual Rise in Currency
text: WASHINGTON  The head of China’s central bank said Friday that he favored letting the Chinese currency rise in value, but only gradually, as exchange-rate tensions overshadowed an international meeting of finance ministers and central bankers.

headline: Robinson Runs, and Michigan Holds Its Breath
text: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — Publicly, Denard Robinson’s coaches and teammates are confident that Robinson, Michigan’s sophomore quarterback, is rugged enough to take the pounding defenses dish out each Saturday. They admire his ability to ignore lingering pain in his left knee.

headline: In Somalia, Signs of Discord Appear in a Militant Group
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia  The movement of Islamist fighters out of towns in southern and central Somalia in recent days, along with comments by government officials and insurgents, suggests that rifts have developed within the leadership of the country’s most powerful militant organization, the Shabab.

headline: After Foreclosure, a Focus on Title Insurance
text: When home buyers and people refinancing their mortgages first see the itemized estimate for all the closing costs and fees, the largest number is often for title insurance.

headline: Title Insurance: Share Your Experiences
text: So now we finally know what this title insurance stuff is for.

headline: Projected Republican Gains Approach 50 House Seats
text: It has become fashionable to speak of a Democratic comeback, but we’re not really seeing one in our forecasting models. Certainly there are some individual races — particularly on the East and West Coasts, as well as some gubernatorial contests outside these regions — that look better for Democrats than they did a few weeks ago. But we’re showing Republicans gaining ground where they need to gain it to maintain decent chances of taking over the Senate. We also show improvement for them in the House forecast this week.

headline: Past Equestrian Scandals Lead to Clearer Drug Rules
text: LEXINGTON, Ky.  Armed with harsher penalties and more investigative muscle, equestrian officials and drug stewards are keeping a close eye on the horses competing here at the World Equestrian Games after incidents at the past two Summer Olympics resulted in the disqualification of eight competitors.

headline: Topic of Foreign Money in U.S. Races Hits Hustings
text: WASHINGTON  Ever since he raised the issue in his State of the Union speech nearly nine months ago  prompting head-shaking by Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. of the Supreme Court  President Obama has been warning about the danger of foreign money creeping into elections as a result of the court’s landmark campaign finance ruling.

headline: Killing of Doctor Part of Taliban War on Educated
text: MARDAN, Pakistan — Farooq Khan, doctor to the poor, scholar of Islam and friend of America, represented everything the Islamist extremists hated.

headline: Campaign Gaffes Highlight 2 Jerry Browns
text: SAN FRANCISCO  On Wednesday night, at a party held for young San Francisco Democrats, Jerry Brown took the microphone and gave the kind of stirring, if somewhat eccentric, speech that has defined his 40 years in politics.

headline: Yanks’ Secret Versus Twins? Take a Trip to the Bullpen
text: Delve into the Yankees’ recent playoff history with the Minnesota Twins, and a distinct pattern emerges: each game has its own rhythm and flow, and yet it ends the same way as every other.

headline: Shares in Micron Rise After It Posts a Profit
text: Micron Technology, the computer chip maker, rose 7 percent Friday after it reported a 90 percent increase in fourth-quarter sales. The company reported its first annual profit in four years after the markets closed on Thursday. Micron said net income was 32 cents a share, after a loss of $100 million, or 12 cents, a year earlier. The company said sales in the period, which ended Sept. 2, almost doubled to $2.49 billion. Stock in Micron, which is based in Boise, Idaho, rose 48 cents, to $7.59 a share.

headline: Tenant Accused of Cheating Subletters in Public Housing
text: The Craigslist posting was no different from dozens of others: Someone was renting out a room in the hipster haven of Williamsburg, Brooklyn, for $400 a month, utilities included. The listing noted the hardwood floors and “quiet peaceful area.” The price to move in was $800 cash, a month’s rent plus a security deposit.

headline: Arizona Is a Haven for Refugees
text: PHOENIX  Here in Arizona, illegal immigrants get the boot. But refugees get the welcome mat.

headline: Umpires and Players Will Meet
text: Players and umpires have scheduled a meeting for Dec. 3 to discuss complaints about umpiring, baseball officials said.

headline: Twins Starter Has Been There Before
text: It all happened so fast. In one breath, Brian Duensing remembered hustling to the bullpen at the Metrodome in the 10th inning of the Minnesota Twins’ divisional tie-breaker game with Detroit last October in case he had to pitch in relief.

headline: Activism of Thomas’s Wife Could Raise Judicial Issues
text: RICHMOND, Va.  As one of the keynote speakers here Friday at a state convention billed as the largest Tea Party event ever, Virginia Thomas gave the throng of more than 2,000 activists a full-throated call to arms for conservative principles.

headline: Lured Into a Trap, Then Tortured for Being Gay
text: He was told there was a party at a brick house on Osborne Place, a quiet block set on a steep hill in the Bronx. He showed up last Sunday night as instructed, with plenty of cans of malt liquor. What he walked into was not a party at all, but a night of torture — he was sodomized, burned and whipped.

text: From The Montreal Gazette’s Habs Inside/Out blog:

headline: In Bomb Case, Turmoil Over What Jurors Saw
text: The trial of four men accused of trying to bomb synagogues in the Bronx and shoot down military transport planes was thrown into turmoil on Friday after the judge learned that evidence the jurors were not supposed to consider ended up in the jury room.

headline: The Titan and the Pfc.
text: Eddie Fisher dead at 82.

headline: 10/10/10: They Love Just Thinking About It
text: Sunday is the big day for saying “I do.”

headline: With Drilling Near End, Chile Rescue Enters Risky Phase
text: SAN JOSÉ MINE, Chile  After more than two months living nearly half a mile underground, the 33 miners trapped below this scorching desert could be just a few short days from emerging into what will seem like a blinding sun.

headline: Don’t Try Terrorists, Lock Them Up

headline: Christine O’Donnell: The Girl Next Door
text: Christine O’Donnell’s crusade to convince voters she’s just like them continues.

headline: A Day Off to Regroup? Not for the Twins
text: In 1986, the heavily favored Mets lost the first two games of the World Series at home. The Red Sox shut them out in the first game and beat them, 9-3, the next day.

headline: Outraged, and Outrageous
text: PAMELA GELLER’S apartment, in the fashion of the blogosphere, doubles as her office. It is a modern full-floor unit in a high-rise on the East Side of Manhattan that could belong to a socialite or the editor of a lifestyle magazine. There is ample light and a tasteful lack of clutter. The kitchen appliances are made of brushed steel; the countertops are slate. In the earth-toned living room hangs a painting, in vibrant colors, of a woman in a swimsuit.

headline: Saturday: Quads
text: Crosswords with full-width stacks can sometimes be a little easier to solve, but that wasn’t the case for me today. I finally got everything (well, the No. 48 square remained blank), but it took a fair amount of hopping around and piecing together to get there.

headline: Democratic Republic of Congo: Trial of Warlord Must Continue
text: In the latest twist in the case against the Congolese warlord Thomas Lubanga, appeals judges at the International Criminal Court in The Hague ruled on Friday that Mr. Lubanga could not be released and that his war crimes trial, halted in July by a lower court ruling, must continue. The trial has been bogged down in disputes between the prosecutors and the bench. The lower court had ruled that Mr. Lubanga could not get a fair trial because the prosecution was refusing to hand over information to the defense, but the appeals judges called that too “drastic” a measure. Mr. Lubanga, an ethnic Hema, had pleaded not guilty to charges of enlisting and conscripting children under 15 to his Union of Congolese Patriots to kill members of the rival Lendu tribe in Congo’s 1998-2003 war.

headline: Bloggingheads: What if Obama Fails?
text: John McWhorter, left, of The New Republic and Glenn Loury of Brown University debate the impact of Barack Obama's presidency on African-Americans.

headline: Phillies Take 2-0 Series Lead Over the Reds
text: PHILADELPHIA  In Game 1 of this division series, Citizens Bank Park was the stage for one of the playoffs’ finest pitching performances, a no-hitter by Roy Halladay that was within one pitch of being a perfect game. Game 2 devolved into one of the playoffs’ sloppiest games, a ragged affair that bore no resemblance to the near perfection on display two days earlier.

headline: U.N. Delegation Presses Sudan to Allow a Referendum and Avert a New Civil War
text: WASHINGTON  After languishing as what many experts worried was the world’s most neglected foreign-policy problem, Sudan is now in the spotlight: a high-level delegation from the United Nations Security Council arrived in the capital, Khartoum, on Friday, to press the government not to disrupt a coming referendum that is considered likely to result in partition.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Mr. Paladino and the System
text: Carl Paladino, the Republican nominee for governor of New York, portrays himself as a business-hardened outsider who would reform Albany’s corrupt and bloated bureaucracy and drive out the pay-to-play special interests. “I’m just a regular guy from Buffalo,” he says.

headline: Pickets at a Funeral: Testing the Limits of Freedom
text: To the Editor:

headline: Awful, Awfuler, Awfulest
text: I recently wrote a column on the pressing question of which state is having the most terrible election this year. Nevada won. Immediately, there were outcries from voters who believed their state had been unfairly overlooked on the dreadfulness meter.

headline: Why Is the Seat Next to Me Empty?
text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: High Cost of Crime
text: When times get hard and talk turns to spending and budgets, there is one area that gets short shrift: the cost of crime and our enormous criminal justice system. For instance, how much do you think a single murder costs society? According to researchers at Iowa State University, it is a whopping $17.25 million.

headline: Liu Xiaobo
text: China warned the Norwegian Nobel Committee not to honor the democracy activist Liu Xiaobo. The committee didn’t listen. On Friday, Mr. Liu  who is locked in jail on an 11-year sentence for spurious subversion charges  became the first Chinese to win the Peace Prize.

headline: Policy at Its Worst
text: We can go to war in Iraq and Afghanistan, and threaten to blow Iran off the face of the planet. We can conduct a nonstop campaign of drone and helicopter attacks in Pakistan and run a network of secret prisons around the world. We are the mightiest nation mankind has ever seen.

headline: The September Report
text: There was no good news in the September employment report. The economy lost another 95,000 jobs last month, as a modest gain in private-sector jobs was swamped by big losses in government jobs.

headline: A Mets Candidate Used to Authority
text: Of the various general manager candidates on the Mets’ list, Sandy Alderson stands apart.

headline: Optimism for Offense as Rangers Start Anew
text: BUFFALO  The Rangers open their 85th season on Saturday with an intriguing four lines. But it would be a mistake to think those combinations will stay intact for long, given how frequently Coach John Tortorella juggles lines, and with the expected return of Chris Drury and Vinny Prospal from the injury list this month.

headline: U.S. and South Korea Reaffirm Ties
text: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates and his South Korean counterpart on Friday reaffirmed the close partnership of the two nations, even as they warned of potential instability as North Korea moves opaquely toward a transition of power atop its dictatorial government.

headline: ‘It Gets Better’ Starting Now for Gay Youth
text: Whenever Daniel Derraugh, who is 12 and gay, gets depressed about life, he thinks ahead. Way ahead. “I think about my retirement plans,” said Daniel, who lives in Wallingford, Conn. “When I’m retired from being famous and I move somewhere in California, somewhere warm and sunny, like Malibu near the beach.” He smiled, thinking about a brilliant future spent reflecting on past glories.

headline: U.N. Weighs How to Answer a Knock on Earth’s Door
text: UNITED NATIONS  There is no United Nations special envoy for space aliens, let’s get that straight from the outset, nor even an official designated to pick up the phone should one call.

headline: Finding the Funny Amid the Sacred and the Professed
text: Can you say the word “breast” in a sermon? If so, how often?

headline: U.S. Team, Drawing on the Recent Past, Looks Ahead
text: Bob Bradley has a new contract and a new mission, but Bradley, the United States national team coach, is caught in a strange sort of limbo.

headline: Challenge to Immigration Law Is Upheld
text: A Federal District Court judge ruled Friday that one of the main lawsuits seeking to overturn Arizona’s new immigration law could go forward, despite efforts by Gov. Jan Brewer and several sheriffs to have the suit thrown out. But the judge, Susan R. Bolton, dismissed some portions of the suit, filed by the National Immigration Law Center and other advocacy groups, including their claim that the law would restrict immigrants’ rights to travel and to use a foreign language.

headline: Albertina Walker, Soulful Gospel Singer, Dies at 81
text: Albertina Walker, a gospel singer with a lush contralto voice whose group, the Caravans, recorded a string of hits in the 1950s and 1960s and nourished the careers of such greats as the Rev. James Cleveland, Inez Andrews and Pastor Shirley Caesar, died on Friday in Chicago. She was 81.

headline: Marshall Flaum, Documentary Filmmaker, Dies at 85
text: Marshall Flaum, an award-winning documentary filmmaker whose movies over a 55-year career examined show business, nature and historical subjects, died Oct. 1 in Los Angeles. He was 85.

headline: A Shoemaker That Walks but Never Runs
text: Sant’Elpidio a Mare, Italy

headline: Tod's: A Shoemaker That Walks but Never Runs
text: Tod’s, the luxury Italian shoemaker, has become a multibillion-dollar multinational, but its operations still ooze with Old World tradition.

headline: William Norton, Writer Wilder Than His Movies, Is Dead at 85
text: William Norton, a Hollywood screenwriter whose own life story would stretch the credibility of most screenplays, died Oct. 1 in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 85.

headline: Corrections
text: NATIONAL

headline: ‘Whale Wars’ Leader Responds on Boat Sinking
text: [June 2, 11:52 p.m. | Updated  I interviewed Paul Watson on the eve of the opening segment in the new season of “Whale Wars.” The video below is part one.]

headline: After 15 Years, Wait Is Over for Mike Sweeney
text: PHILADELPHIA – Mike Sweeney waited longer than any other active player, when measured by service time, to appear in the postseason. He finally stepped onto the stage Friday night in the seventh inning of Game 2 of the Phillies’ division series, and before him was the hardest throwing pitcher he has ever seen: Aroldis Chapman of the Cincinnati Reds.

headline: A Long Wait for a Clean Creek
text: In 1881, New York’s special committee on Effluvium Nuisances reported that “intolerable stenches” were coming from the area known as Newtown Creek. On its banks were mills and offal rendering shops, oil refineries and fertilizer factories. Over the years, industry thrived in the area, leaving tons of toxic residues.

headline: Jocketty Could See Minaya Working With Alderson
text: PHILADELPHIA – When Omar Minaya was fired by the Mets on Monday, he said he would consider coming back in the right circumstances, but it would be hard to imagine what those circumstances might be. Perhaps they would include working with a highly respected baseball statesman like Sandy Alderson.

headline: N.L.D.S. Photo Replay: Oct. 8
text: Photos from the National League divisional playoff series.

headline: Paladino Serenades a Former Target
text: HOLLEY, N.Y.  It was not so long ago that Carl P. Paladino, the Republican nominee for governor, was comparing the chairman of the state’s Republican Party, Edward F. Cox, to Pontius Pilate. But on Thursday night, Mr. Paladino led Mr. Cox’s 64th birthday serenade.

headline: France: Sarkozy and Pope Meet Over French Actions Against Roma
text: President Nicolas Sarkozy met Pope Benedict XVI in the Vatican on Friday after some senior church officials, including local bishops, criticized France’s dismantling of illegal migrant camps and its deportation of Roma migrants from Romania and Bulgaria who had overstayed their permitted time in France. Mr. Sarkozy requested the meeting with the pope, who had personally appealed for the acceptance of “legitimate human diversity.” The half-hour meeting focused on international issues and the “ethical and social dimensions of economic problems,” according to the Vatican. Mr. Sarkozy then visited a chapel where Cardinal Jean-Louis Tauran said a “prayer for France,” which included an appeal “for the welcome of the persecuted and immigrants.”

headline: Late Home Run Boosts Braves to Win Over Giants
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Back in another lifetime Rick Ankiel authored one of the more bizarre chapters in playoff history when he stood on the pitcher’s mound and threw pitch after pitch that seemed to hit everything but the catcher’s glove.

headline: Holiday on Monday: Columbus Day
text: NEW YORK

headline: Why the N.F.L. Is Investigating Brett Favre
text: No woman has put her name behind claims of sexual harassment by Brett Favre. We have to start there, and with a presumption of innocence. But accusations that Favre sent suggestive messages and photos to the Jets sideline personality Jenn Sterger in 2008 are well past the whispering stage and seem likely to become a major distraction. The N.F.L. is investigating.

headline: The Mortgage Morass
text: After the Asian financial crisis of 1997-1998, it was often said that a key barrier to recovery was the uncertain state of property rights: so much debt had been run up during the boom, and there had been so many defaults in the bust, that it was no longer clear who owned anything. Plus, these countries lacked clear legal procedures, and in general suffered from insufficient rule of law. All this was said, of course, in a tone of superiority: we Americans had solved such problems.

headline: Drill Reaches Miners in Chile, but Risks Remain
text: SAN JOSÉ MINE, Chile — It was a moment of euphoria.

headline: Rodriguez Reflects on Coaches and Health
text: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — One week after having his return temporarily postponed by a blood clot in his leg, Michigan State Coach Mark Dantonio is expected to resume his duties for Saturday’s game between No. 18 Michigan and No. 17 Michigan State (both 5-0, 1-0 Big Ten).

headline: Video: State of the Pac-10
text: How far will U.S.C. fall? Is Oregon for real? In a special bonus edition of the Pregame Huddle, Pete Thamel breaks down the Pac-10 heading into this weekend’s games.

headline: The People of Levittown, Pa.
text: A look at some of the people Representative Patrick Murphy spoke to in a door-to-door political campaign.

headline: Door-to-Door in Levittown
text: LEVITTOWN, Pa.

headline: Allies in War, but the Goals Clash
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Saturday Word: Education, Jobs and Palin
text: Just over three weeks before voters go to the polls, President Obama warned that if Republicans had their way, they would cut education spending, imperiling the future of the American economy. In his weekly address, Mr. Obama acknowledged the massive national debt, but said cutting education is not the way to save, pledging — as he has for a number of weeks — to continue his investments in public schools, community colleges and student loans.

headline: On Guadalcanal, Studying Evolution
text: Three short hours from the cosmopolitan city of Brisbane, Australia, and a world away, I have arrived in the Solomon Islands. Stepping from the crisp tubular world of jet travel into the familiar thickness of tropical air, I descend the gangway into a place that once echoed with the thunder and stench of the Battle of Guadalcanal, a place first visited by American Museum of Natural History biologists nearly a century ago during an expedition that really did change the world, and a place still alive in a timeless blend of biological and cultural wonder that inspired my career as a biologist.

headline: Laugh Lines
text: JAY LENO

headline: Whiskey, Wine and Moonshine, Born in the County of Kings
text: “To Grandpa Tom.”

headline: A Musical Trip to Middle Earth
text: The low brasses growled as a hideous legion of Orcs marched through the dim light. Noble trumpet lines soared to accompany the heroes galloping across the countryside. Ethereal choral vowels floated by as men and at least one elf died slow-motion deaths in battle.

headline: Grown-Up, but Still Irresponsible
text: THEY have sex with friends, acquaintances and people they’re casually dating. Many have never been tested for H.I.V. or any other sexually transmitted disease, but they rarely use condoms. Who are they?

headline: Shuttle Campaigning, Iraqi-Style
text: BAGHDAD

headline: Less Demand for Dominicans as M.L.B. Scrutiny Increases
text: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic  New rules aimed at curtailing steroid use and age fraud among baseball prospects in the Dominican Republic have reduced the number of elite Dominican teenage players being signed to contracts by Major League Baseball teams and the size of their signing bonuses.

headline: Moss Trade Shows Perils of Patriots’ Way
text: Pro football is still buzzing over the blockbuster trade that sent Randy Moss, one of the best receivers in history, to Minnesota from New England.

headline: Pakistan Will Reopen Route to Supplies for NATO
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Pakistan announced Saturday that it was immediately reopening its main border crossing with Afghanistan and that it would allow NATO to resume shipping supplies through it after a 10-day blockade left hundreds of fuel tankers and other trucks open to attacks from militants.

headline: S.B.A. Makes Small Businesses Bigger (the Easy Way)
text: The enlarging of small business has begun.

headline: Leaving the Pictures Behind
text: Picture books are failing. Publishers, it was reported last week, have cut down on the number of new titles, and sales are suffering.

headline: Prime Number
text: 11.7: THE AMOUNT, IN BILLIONS OF DOLLARS, pledged by 40 countries over the next three years to pay for treatments for millions of AIDS patients around the world. The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria had hoped to raise $20 billion to catch up with the growing epidemic, and needed at least $13 billion to continue putting patients on treatment at current levels. An estimated 33 million people are infected worldwide, a number that grows by a million people a year after adding new infections and subtracting deaths.

headline: Acrostic: Eight Letters
text: Is an acrostic a literary work? Not in the usual sense, but it is a creation that requires many editorial choices. First is picking an interesting quote. Second is in the choice of vocabulary for the answers. Third, and most obvious, are the clues.

headline: For the Nets, First Brooklyn and Then the World
text: The Nets might be an odd choice to be the N.B.A.’s ambassador overseas. With 12 wins last season, they are often a forgotten team even in New Jersey, where they fail to sell out their home games and live in the shadow of the cosmopolitan Knicks.

headline: Not Exactly Rock ’n’ Roll...
text: PHIL COLLINS’S COLLECTION OF MOTOWN CLASSICS wasn’t the only nostalgia act on the pop charts last week in Britain, The Guardian reports. A legend of a different sort  Winston Churchill  claimed the No. 4 spot with “Reach for the Skies,” an album that sets recordings of two of the wartime prime minister’s most famous speeches to music by the Central Band of the Royal Air Force. Who’s buying all those albums? Members of Churchill’s original fan club are now in their dotage, so gems like “The Finest Hour” and “The Few” must be inspiring a younger generation.

headline: No Windup, Then the Pitch
text: ROY HALLADAY, A RIGHT-HANDER for the Philadelphia Phillies, pitched a no-hitter last week, beating the Cincinnati Reds 4-0 in Game 1 of their division playoff series. It was only the second no-hitter in postseason history since Don Larsen’s perfect game for the Yankees in the 1956 World Series.

headline: Trouble in the Hive
text: Human beings and honeybees go way back, probably to some unrecorded, fateful day thousands of years ago when a forager stumbled upon some golden goo in the woods, stuck a finger in to taste, and realized that the bears were on to something good.

headline: Farnsworth and Ankiel Cap Tough Journeys
text: SAN FRANCISCO — In the waning hours before the July 31 trading deadline, Kyle Farnsworth and Rick Ankiel were in a hot tub in the Kansas City trainer’s room discussing whether they would be dealt from the floundering Royals.

headline: Johnny Edgecombe, British Scandal Figure, Dies at 77
text: Around lunchtime on Dec. 14, 1962, Johnny Edgecombe, a small-time hustler and jazz promoter angry at being jilted, fired six or seven shots at the London apartment where Christine Keeler, his former girlfriend and a sometime prostitute, was staying.

headline: Putting Foot to the Ball Can Often Be a Test of Will
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Becky Dodge speaks with her 23-year-old son, Matt, once a day. He often calls on his drive to or from work, sometimes to vent frustrations about his new job. Other days, she has stayed up until 1 a.m. waiting to hear from him.

headline: Charting a Path Between Hope and Fear
text: THE financial markets have seemed on the verge of something big for months, with investors divided about whether the breakthrough would be a result of something good or something bad.

headline: Sold on Pork Bellies (and Other Commodities)
text: IN 2005, K. Geert Rouwenhorst and Gary B. Gorton, now finance professors at Yale, published a paper about the investment benefits of an asset class that was then the province of specialists: commodities. Contrary to the prevailing conventional wisdom, the researchers suggested that pork bellies, coffee and crude oil had a place in individual portfolios alongside stocks, bonds and cash.

headline: Fighting Words
text: On Thursday, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey halted construction of the largest public transit project in the nation, a multibillion-dollar commuter train tunnel under the Hudson River to Manhattan. The governor said the state could not afford its share of rising costs for the tunnel, known as Access to the Region’s Core. A day later, after an outcry, Mr. Christie agreed to a two-week review of the project.

headline: Rescue Tunnel Reaches Miners
text: Chilean rescuers finished drilling an escape shaft for 33 miners trapped underground after a cave-in over two months ago.

headline: DNA Testing of Prospects Continues Under New Rules
text: After it was revealed last year that investigators for Major League Baseball were using DNA testing on teenage prospects and their parents to verify the players’ ages to combat identity fraud, genetic experts roundly criticized the practice and raised questions about its legality.

headline: New Test, Introduced Without Warning, Could Give Antidoping Officials an Edge
text: Antidoping scientists who conducted the drug testing at this summer’s Tour de France used their best weapon: the element of surprise.

headline: A Stimulus Plan, Disguised as Censorship
text: I’VE been thinking a lot lately about “Operation Dark Heart.”

headline: Is the Time Now Right for Payout Funds?
text: IT seemed an idea whose time had arrived: mutual funds specifically designed to transform the nest-egg accumulations of the first baby-boom wave into a stream of retirement income.

headline: A Fearless Prediction by Yanks’ Cano
text: The ninth-inning double play that drained the faith from the Target Field crowd Thursday night was scored 6-4-3, as routine as one gets. But far from Minneapolis, in a home on the north side of Newark, the mere television image of Robinson Cano stepping on second base and firing across his body to first immediately unleashed the sweetest of childhood memories.

headline: Hungary’s Premier Warns of New Spill of Caustic Sludge
text: Hungarian officials on Saturday ordered the evacuation of a village in the shadow of the industrial reservoir that spilled caustic red sludge into the surrounding countryside last Monday, after discovering that cracks in the reservoir’s northern wall had widened overnight, raising the possibility of a second spill.

headline: Blazing Three Trails to Red-Hot Sectors
text: PRECIOUS-METAL and emerging-market stock funds have been generating more interest than Lady Gaga’s get-ups. New investor money has been pouring into both fund types. And little wonder: they provided double-digit returns through the first nine months of this year, while many other fund categories had small to middling gains.

headline: Funds’ Tax Bills Are Looking Light
text: THE fourth quarter means eating Thanksgiving turkey, shopping for Christmas gifts and, in the world of mutual funds, perhaps getting a tax bill. Securities laws require that mutual fund managers pass on to their investors nearly all of the realized capital gains they accumulated during the year. Most funds do so in November and December.

headline: Mercedes Recalls 85,000 Recent Cars for Steering Problem
text: Mercedes-Benz is recalling 85,000 of its 2010 and 2011 models because a steering problem could make the vehicles difficult to control.

headline: For the Chiefs, Three Wins Are Little More Than a Good Start
text: When Todd Haley was growing up in Pittsburgh, the son of one of the men most responsible for building the Steelers dynasties of the 1970s and 1980s, he used to ride to home games in the back seat of Tom Moore’s car, trying to stay quiet so he would not annoy the reticent Moore, a longtime N.F.L. assistant.

headline: When Troubled Assets Are the Attraction
text: TROUBLED assets and mutual funds are terms that aren’t often yoked together, at least not in marketing campaigns. Yet three new closed-end mutual funds have made investing in such assets a selling point.

headline: For Top College Teams, a Marathon on Skates
text: With little fanfare, except possibly in outposts like Grand Forks, N.D.; Madison, Wis.; and Sault Ste. Marie, Mich., the N.C.A.A. Division I men’s college hockey season is concluding its first full weekend of play. Technically, games began Oct. 2, the first official day of practice, when Mercyhurst tied Michigan, 4-4.

headline: Filling Buckets, Avoiding Debt
text: THE financial planner Raymond J. Lucia boasts in “The Buckets of Money Retirement Solution” (Wiley, $24.95) that he has helped “thousands of people invest more than $2 billion” by showing them how to use the method of the book’s title.

headline: Drill Reaches Chile's Trapped Miners
text: A drill breaks through and reaches 33 miners trapped for more than two months.  NBC's Kerry Sanders reports.

headline: A Big-Picture Way to Run a Portfolio
text: THERE may be something to that adage about the devil being in the details. The strong interest in world allocation funds suggests that investors think so, anyway  or maybe that they just think details are devilishly difficult for money managers to get right.

headline: Rain Delays Qualifying in Japan
text: The last time qualifying was canceled on Saturday and set for Sunday morning because of bad weather was at Suzuka in 2004. Back then. a typhoon made it impossible to drive on one of the toughest tracks in the series — actually, I seem to recall that by the time of qualifying the sun had started to come out and they might just have been able to run. But the circuit was practically empty of people as we had been advised long before that it would not be possible to race, the typhoon would hit.

headline: Rain Delays Qualifying in Japan
text: The last time qualifying was canceled on Saturday and set for Sunday morning because of bad weather was at Suzuka in 2004. Back then. a typhoon made it impossible to drive on one of the toughest tracks in the series — actually, I seem to recall that by the time of qualifying the sun had started to come out and they might just have been able to run. But the circuit was practically empty of people as we had been advised long before that it would not be possible to race, the typhoon would hit.

headline: Kidnapped Scottish Aid Worker in Afghanistan Is Killed During Rescue Raid

headline: An X-Ray of Dysfunction
text: I still find it amazing that with all the climate, security, health and financial interests America has in reducing its dependence on oil, our Congress could not work out an energy bill over the past two years  especially when China, Japan and the European Union are all hurdling ahead on clean-tech. The fact that we failed to pass an energy bill  cap-and-trade, a carbon tax, efficiency standards, I don’t care which  is actually a reflection of a broader U.S. power failure. It is the failure of our political system to unite, even in a crisis, to produce the policy responses America needs to thrive in the 21st century. As the Wall Street Journal columnist Gerald Seib once noted: “America and its political leaders, after two decades of failing to come together to solve big problems, seem to have lost faith in their ability to do so. A political system that expects failure doesn’t try very hard to produce anything else.”

headline: Facebook Politicians Are Not Your Friends
text: “THE Social Network,” you’re understandably sick of hearing, is a brilliant movie about the Harvard upstart Mark Zuckerberg and the messy birth of his fabulous start-up, Facebook, circa 2004. From the noisy debate over its harsh portrait of Zuckerberg, you’d think it’s a documentary. It’s not. Its genre is historical fiction  with a sardonic undertow. The director David Fincher and the screenwriter Aaron Sorkin are after bigger ironies than the riddle of Zuckerberg, a disconnected geek destined to spawn a virtual community of 500 million “friends.” You leave the movie with the sinking feeling that the democratic utopia breathlessly promised by Facebook and its Web brethren is already gone with the wind.

Its margin of error is about ±30 seats — meaning that a gain of as few as 17 seats, or as many as 78, is entirely possible — and there is a small chance of even larger or smaller gains.

headline: French Unemployment
text: OK, that’s weird. I just taped This Week, which included an interview with Christine Lagarde, the French finance minister. In her defense of austerity, she asserted that unemployment in France is down from 9.6 to 9.3. But I looked it up on Eurostat (pdf), which has French unemployment in August at 10.1, up from 9.6 a year ago.

headline: The Elusive Youth Vote
text: President Obama will continue his attempts to engage younger voters this week, holding a rally with a musical guest, the Roots, in Philadelphia on Sunday and a town-hall-style meeting on MTV on Thursday. Younger voters were among the Democrats’ strongest supporters in 2008, and they have the highest approval ratings of the president. But in the last two midterm elections, only one in four people under age 30 voted, about half the rate for recent presidential elections. And, according to a poll by the Pew Research Center in September, young Democrats are currently even less engaged than they were in 2006.
