headline: Rays Earn Another Home Game and Matchup With Lee
text: ARLINGTON, Tex.  If Cliff Lee could characterize himself, he said on Sunday, he would use the words extremely competitive. Evan Longoria, the star third baseman for the Tampa Bay Rays, called him a warrior.

headline: Sampler of Classical and Contemporary
text: The final Fall for Dance program was a reminder of how good this festival at City Center can be at offering a wide, unpredictable range of dance in satisfyingly textured combinations. Two of the four works on Friday were ballet, danced by large-scale companies, yet neither was a gala-style or predictable example of that genre. And the two contemporary pieces that bookended the classical offerings suggested both the differences between European and American sensibilities and the enormous range of individual choreographic styles.

headline: Fall for Dance
text: Photographs of performances by Tero Saarinen, Dresden SemperOper Ballett and others.

headline: Israeli Cabinet Approves Citizenship Amendment
text: JERUSALEM  The Israeli cabinet on Sunday approved a contentious draft amendment to the country’s citizenship law that calls for non-Jews seeking to become citizens to pledge loyalty to Israel as a Jewish and a democratic state.

headline: ‘Social Network’ Stays No. 1
text: Smart beat sentimental at the weekend box office, albeit by a slim margin. “The Social Network,” right, the drama about the founding of Facebook, from David Fincher and Aaron Sorkin, repeated as the No. 1 movie in North America. “The Social Network” (Sony Pictures Entertainment) sold an estimated $15.5 million for a new total of $46.1 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles ticketing statistics. Close behind with about $14.6 million was the romantic comedy “Life as We Know It,” starring Katherine Heigl and Josh Duhamel. Although critically panned, “Life as We Know It” (Warner Brothers) received an A-minus score from audiences in exit polls. “Secretariat” (Walt Disney Studios) pulled up in third place with about $12.6 million. The studio now must hope that older moviegoers, usually reluctant to come out on opening weekend, will heed the film’s upbeat reviews in the weeks ahead. “Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga’Hoole“ (Warner Brothers) clung to life in fourth place with $7 million for a new total of $39.4 million. Wes Craven’s “My Soul to Take“ (a Universal Pictures release of a Rogue production) disappointed with fifth place and $6.9 million.

headline: End May Have Arrived for Braves’ Wagner
text: ATLANTA — Closer Billy Wagner, the latest injured Atlanta Braves, may have pitched his last game in the major leagues. Wagner, 39, strained his left oblique muscle in Friday night’s dramatic 5-4 win over the San Francisco Giants in the National League division series and has been put on the disabled list.

headline: In Defense of Naïve Reading
text: Remember the culture wars (or the ’80s, for that matter)? “The Closing of the American Mind,” “Cultural Literacy,” “Prof Scam” “Tenured Radicals”? Whatever happened to all that? It occasionally resurfaces, of course. There was the Alan Sokal/Social Text affair in 1996, and there are occasional flaps about winners of bad writing awards and so forth, but the national attention on universities and their mission and place in our larger culture has certainly shifted.

headline: In Life’s Latest Chapter, Feeling Free Again
text: LONDON  Last year, when she was 91, the editor and writer Diana Athill moved from her beloved apartment into an “old person’s home,” as she calls it. It was the most painful decision she had ever made, and it might have been a terrible diminishment, the reduction of a long, full life into something small enough to fit into a tiny room off a communal corridor.

headline: In Havana, Jam Sessions With a Master Trumpeter
text: HAVANA  Wynton Marsalis pulled a young Cuban trumpeter aside as he left the Mella Theater here on Wednesday after a Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra concert. The band was here for a residency that ended over the weekend, and Mr. Marsalis had seen 17-year-old Kalí Rodríguez play a few nights earlier at an official reception for the American musicians.

headline: When the Artists Voted for the Politics of Order
text: Boilerplate is safe box office, and we’ve gotten our share lately. So it’s great that the Guggenheim Museum is giving us the opposite in its major fall exhibition, “Chaos and Classicism: Art in France, Italy, and Germany, 1918-1936.”

headline: Reveling in the Rapid Fires, Then the Retreats, of Flamenco
text: Passion and intensity are words often associated with flamenco. The form’s great musicians and dancers bring a certain heat to the stage, a burning austerity often characterized as authenticity.

headline: Those Perpetual Bedfellows, Religion and Politics
text: When I was in college, the conventional wisdom held that outside of religious colleges, professors of theology tended to be nonreligious people. We had no evidence, but it was a notion that appealed to undergraduate contrarianism.

headline: Holiday on Monday: Columbus Day
text: NEW YORK

headline: ‘Deadliest Catch’ Reels in Three of Its Stars
text: Just in time for the start of the king-crab fishing season, three stars of the Discovery Channel’s “Deadliest Catch” have rescinded their threat to quit that reality show. The captains Sig Hansen and Andy and Johnathan Hillstrand, left, said at the end of September that they could not be on the show anymore, apparently because of Discovery’s decision to sue the Hillstrands for allegedly refusing to finish a special show called “Hillstranded.” But the men were still under a separate contract for “Deadliest Catch,” and on Friday they said in a statement: “We’re happy we worked everything out with Discovery. A deal’s a deal.” Discovery declined to say whether the lawsuit had been dropped.

headline: Chinese Treasures Boost Asian-Art Auctions
text: Sotheby’s in Hong Kong made record sales at its biannual Asian auctions last week, bringing in $400 million in sales of Asian art, jewelry and wine, Reuters reported. The auctions can serve as an indicator of the health of Chinese and Asian art markets, and this year’s sales exceeded those of 2009. The high numbers were attributed to sales of Chinese imperial treasures from private collections. A vase from the Qianlong period, above, which sold for $32.5 million, including fees to Sotheby’s, was the highest price ever paid for a Chinese porcelain piece at auction. An imperial white jade Qing Dynasty seal broke the record for white jade at just under $16 million.

headline: Monday: Shifting Crust
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — How do constructors come up with puzzle themes? You might be able to guess where this one came from. The constructor Robert Fisher makes his New York Times debut today and I have some notes from him. Further down, there’s an important announcement about how we will be distributing electronic crosswords from now on.

headline: Brits Off Broadway to Start Seventh Season
text: This fall’s Brits Off Broadway festival will include a play by Edna O’Brien, below, starring the Academy Award nominee Brenda Blethyn (“Secrets and Lies”), a one-man show about the life and work of Peter Sellers, and the latest work by 83-year-old writer Peter Nichols (“A Day in the Death of Joe Egg”), the organizers at 59E59 Theaters will announce Monday. The seventh annual festival, scheduled from Nov. 3 to Jan. 2, will begin with the Welsh company Clwyd Theatr Cymru’s production of Hywel John‘s dark fable “Pieces.” Next up will be “Personal Enemy,” a so-called lost play by John Osborne and Anthony Creighton; it was written and performed in the 1950s, but copies disappeared soon afterward and were discovered only in 2008, according to 59E59 Theaters. Mr. Nichols’s play “Lingua Franca” is centered on the character Steven Flowers from his earlier work “Privates on Parade,” while Carl Caulfield‘s show “Being Sellers” will look at the famed actor of “Lolita” and the early “Pink Panther” movies. Among the other productions will be Ms. O’Brien’s play “Haunted,” about an elderly man and the two women (one played by Ms. Blethyn) who meant the most to him. Information about all of the productions and performance dates is at britsoffbroadway.com.

headline: Shubert Grants Grow Despite Recession
text: The Shubert Foundation’s grants to arts organizations have increased to $18.2 million this year, up from $17.6 million in 2009, according to a report being released by the foundation this week. Grants ranging from $5,000 to $275,000 have been given to around 450 companies nationally by the nonprofit organization. Theater companies in 42 states received most of the money, around $13 million, while dance companies received $2.5 million. The remainder was distributed to other performing arts groups, professional theater training programs and charitable agencies. In New York, Lincoln Center Theater was one of the top beneficiaries, receiving $275,000, along with American Ballet Theater ($200,000) and Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater ($155,000). Smaller companies like Elevator Repair Service were awarded around $5,000.

headline: Footnotes
text: Michelle Williams has been cast as Marilyn Monroe in “My Week With Marilyn,” a film about Monroe’s time working with Laurence Olivier in London in 1956 on the set of “The Prince and the Showgirl,” Reuters reported. Kenneth Branagh will play Olivier. ... The British rocker Billy Idol has promised quite a bit of rebel yelling in a memoir he is writing about his musical career, The Associated Press reported. Touchstone, a division of Simon & Schuster, announced that it would publish “Dancing With Myself” in late 2011 or early 2012. ... In addition to traveling through time, the cast of the BBC sci-fi show “Doctor Who,” seen on BBC America, will be traveling to the United States. The channel announced on Sunday that it would film part of the Season 6 opener, set in the United States in the late 1960s, in Utah in November. The first block of the new season will be shown next spring.

headline: Wife Detained After Visiting Nobel Winner
text: BEIJING  The wife of this year’s Nobel Peace Prize winner, Liu Xiaobo, was allowed to meet with her husband on Sunday at the prison in northeastern China where he is serving an 11-year sentence, but she was then escorted back to Beijing and placed under house arrest, a human rights group said.

headline: The World This Week
text: A discussion of convicted former trader Jerome Kerviel; Washington's accusation that China has deliberately undervalued the Yuan; Europe's terror alert and; Desmond Tutu's announced retirement.

headline: Putin’s Party Wins in Russia’s Local Elections
text: NOVOSIBIRSK, Russia  Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin’s ruling party triumphed easily in regional elections here in Siberia and elsewhere in Russia on Sunday, demonstrating that its standing has not suffered, despite several challenging months for the government.

headline: Obama Ratchets Up Tone Against G.O.P.
text: PHILADELPHIA — With his party facing losses in next month’s election, President Obama pressed his argument Sunday that the opposition is trying to steal the election with secret special-interest money, possibly including money from foreign companies.

headline: Brooklyn Stars Put On Their Dancing Shoes
text: Kym Hampton leaned against the wall of Studio D at Mark Morris Dance Center in Fort Greene last Friday evening and let out a whoop.

headline: Convincing Win Over Texans Gives Giants a Boost
text: HOUSTON  It has been exactly a year since the Giants avoided the peculiar vertigo that has marked their recent history. Up and down they have gone, the offense surging while the defense collapsed last year, the offense sputtering while the defense rebounded this season, the offense and defense even occasionally falling apart all at once  as happened against Indianapolis three weeks ago.

headline: Game 3 Final: Phillies 2, Reds 0
text: Cole Hamels pitched a shutout, and Chase Utley hit a solo home run as the Phillies beat the Reds, 2-0, to sweep their National League division series.

headline: Bloomberg Plans a Data Service on the Business of Government
text: Ambition and confidence have never been in short supply at Bloomberg L.P.

headline: A Vanishing Journalistic Divide
text: If you were going to pick an epicenter for mainstream media, The Washington Post’s Howard Kurtz would not be a bad place to land. With his running scorecard on Beltway journalists, his interviews of other scorekeepers on his “Reliable Sources” show on CNN, and his ceaseless fascination with network news, Mr. Kurtz embodied the folkways of the traditional press.

headline: Paladino Laces Speech With Antigay Remarks
text: The Republican candidate for governor, Carl P. Paladino, told a gathering in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, on Sunday that children should not be “brainwashed” into thinking that homosexuality was acceptable, and criticized his opponent, Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo, for marching in a gay pride parade earlier this year.

headline: After Building an Audience, Twitter Turns to Ads
text: Twitter at last looks serious about making money.

headline: Hoping to Stir a Revival of Basketball in Russia
text: MOSCOW  The Nets dropped into Moscow on Sunday for a one-day visit meant to raise their profile in the home country of their new owner, the Russian billionaire Mikhail D. Prokhorov.

headline: After Election, Coalition Seems Likely in Kyrgyz Parliament
text: BISHKEK, Kyrgyzstan  Supporters of the government that took power after an uprising in April appeared to be on the way to winning seats in a new Parliament, but were likely to be compelled to form a coalition with at least some figures from the previous government, according to preliminary results from an election in Kyrgyzstan on Sunday.

headline: New Web Code Draws Concern Over Privacy Risks
text: Worries over Internet privacy have spurred lawsuits, conspiracy theories and consumer anxiety as marketers and others invent new ways to track computer users on the Internet. But the alarmists have not seen anything yet.

headline: Code of Silence After a Brawl in the Suburbs
text: SCARSDALE, N.Y.

headline: Documentary Film Company Takes On Fiorina
text: Brave New Films, the documentary film company behind a series of damaging anti-McCain viral videos in the 2008 presidential campaign, has put its sights on Carly Fiorina, the Republican candidate for Senate in California.

headline: U.S. Presses Iraqi Leaders to Broaden Coalition
text: WASHINGTON  Faced with a shifting political landscape in Iraq after months of impasse, the Obama administration has intensified pressure on the country’s political leaders to form a broad coalition government that, while unwieldy, would marginalize a fiercely anti-American party now poised to wield more influence than ever.

headline: CBS Is a Network on a Roll
text: Three weeks into a new television season, the usual carnage is becoming apparent, with new shows collapsing and crises appearing all over network prime-time schedules.

headline: Giants Take Advantage of a Brave’s Miscues
text: ATLANTA — Braves infielder Brooks Conrad, who has spent most of his professional career in the minor leagues, won a game for Atlanta in May by hitting a grand slam in the bottom of the ninth inning.

headline: A Children’s Channel Retools
text: WITH imports of European cartoons, a smattering of Hasbro ads and a rerun of the movie “Garfield,” Hasbro and Discovery Communications unveiled a new television brand for children on Sunday, called The Hub.

headline: Rolling Out Speedier Bus System, to Glitches and Grumbles
text: It has been hailed as the next generation of New York City public transport: a European-style rapid-transit bus system that operates in exclusive traffic lanes and requires passengers to buy tickets from sidewalk kiosks so trips will not be delayed by a single rider struggling for exact change.

headline: Transcripts on ’73 War, Now Public, Grip Israel
text: JERUSALEM  For many Israelis, the 1973 Arab-Israeli war was their single most terrifying moment, when a woefully unprepared nation, deluded into believing that its neighbors regarded it as impregnable, suffered a devastating attack and struggled back to victory at enormous cost with last-minute American help.

headline: Nevada’s Runaway Offense
text: The University of Nevada entered the top 25 for the first time in more than a half-century this season, features a fringe Heisman Trophy candidate in the dynamic quarterback Colin Kaepernick, and has a late-season game with Boise State that could affect the national title race.

headline: On New York School Tests, Warning Signs Ignored
text: When New York State made its standardized English and math tests tougher to pass this year, causing proficiency rates to plummet, it said it was relying on a new analysis showing that the tests had become too easy and that score inflation was rampant.

headline: Sluggish Economy Curtails Prospects for Building Nuclear Reactors
text: WASHINGTON  Just a few years ago, the economic prognosis for new nuclear reactors looked bright. The prospect of growing electricity demand, probable caps on carbon-dioxide emissions and government loan guarantees prompted companies to tell the Nuclear Regulatory Commission that they wanted to build 28 new reactors.

headline: Floating at the Edge of a Dream
text: DETROIT  The stellar record of the amateur boxer Erick De Leon, who is undefeated in this country for three years in his weight class, should make fighting for the United States in the 2012 Olympics a natural next step. Instead, De Leon’s biggest fight is not in the ring, but with the United States immigration system.

headline: Rift Endangers Power-Sharing Deal in Zimbabwe
text: JOHANNESBURG  After months of putting an optimistic face on his power-sharing deal with Zimbabwe’s autocratic president, Robert Mugabe, Prime Minister Morgan Tsvangirai erupted last week with frustration at Mr. Mugabe and the country’s troubled progress toward democracy.

headline: Film Society of Lincoln Center Names a New Theater
text: The largest of the Film Society of Lincoln Center’s two new theaters will be named the Francesca Beale Theater in honor of a recent gift, the society said. The society planned to make the announcement on Sunday night, after a screening of Clint Eastwood’s “Hereafter” on the closing night of the New York Film Festival. The naming gift  the amount was not disclosed  helps the society complete the private phase of a $41 million capital campaign for its new Elinor Bunin Munroe Film Center, scheduled to open next spring. The society, which has raised $37 million so far, will now start a public campaign to raise an additional $4 million. The new film center will add two theaters to the existing Walter Reade Theater, along with a new amphitheater and a cafe.

headline: Fears of More Red Sludge in Hungary
text: DEVECSER, Hungary — In this small agricultural town, nestled along the front line of the environmental catastrophe shaking this proud central European nation, Otto Kovacs, like many residents, said he was determined not to join the growing ranks of the “sludge refugees.”

headline: Iranian Officials Warn of Unrest Tied to Subsidy Cuts
text: TEHRAN  After suppressing the political protests that followed last year’s disputed presidential election, Iran’s security forces are now on the alert for a new kind of domestic threat  strikes and civil unrest provoked by planned cuts in fuel subsidies.

headline: Cincinnati Is a Party as the Reds Get Ready
text: CINCINNATI  A sunny, warm Sunday turned into a daylong festival in the Queen City, with all three major sports stadiums along the banks of the Ohio River in use and drawing big crowds.

headline: Finding Your Way Through the Mall or the Airport, With a Cellphone Map
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Mobile phone maps have guided people through streets and alleys around the globe. But when those people step into a sprawling building, they can get lost.

headline: Easy for Yanks, but Tricky Choices on Pitching
text: The Yankees have won four straight postseason series without using a fourth starter, and as they prepare for the American League Championship Series it is natural to ask: will they try to make it five? That is one of the leading questions Manager Joe Girardi and his staff will be debating in the coming days as they await the winner of the Rangers-Rays division series.

headline: Carnival Air Fills Chilean Camp as Miners’ Rescue Nears
text: SAN JOSÉ MINE, Chile  Clowns dance and pass out caramels. The wives and girlfriends of the 33 trapped miners are picking out sexy lingerie and getting their hair and nails done to receive their men. And relatives of the miners trapped nearly half a mile underground for more than two months have learned a new phrase  “motor home”  from their hundreds of new journalist friends.

headline: Taming the City of God
text: Years of hatred and mistrust are thawing in some of Rio’s most violent slums.

headline: In New York Governor Race, Two Italian Identities
text: Strategy sessions have been held at a restaurant called Sinatra’s. “Sopranos”-style gold chains have shown up in campaign advertisements. Ethnic-tinged terms, like “goumada,” and wisecracks about Sicilian grudges have been bandied about. And television news crews from Italy have descended on the candidates.

headline: Guns in Bars: A Debate Over Safety
text: To the Editor:

headline: Tomlinson Countering Doubts With Yard After Yard
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  On the eve of training camp, the first night of the second act of his Hall of Fame career, LaDainian Tomlinson was summoned by a knock to the door. There stood his new Jets coach, Rex Ryan, who presented a thick stack of paper as a housewarming gift.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Currency Rift With China Exposes Shifting Clout
text: WASHINGTON  At a private dinner on Friday at the Canadian Embassy, finance officials from seven world economic powers focused on the most vexing international economic problem facing the Obama administration.

headline: In Pennsylvania, Anger Fuels a Race for Senate
text: BROOMALL, Pa.  The voters of Pennsylvania are angry at Washington. And Pat Toomey, the Republican nominee for United States Senate, is glad to stoke the fury.

headline: The Shore Is Alive With the Sound of Turbines
text: To the Editor:

headline: Felton Finding His Fit With Stoudemire
text: Of all the hellos the Knicks have said this preseason in familiarizing themselves with one another, one of the most important new relationships on the team originated nearly a decade ago. As high school players, forward Amar’e Stoudemire and point guard Raymond Felton occasionally crossed A.A.U. and summer-camp paths, sometimes playing together.

headline: Drugs in Nursing Homes
text: To the Editor:

headline: Inside City of God
text: Officials in Rio de Janeiro have deployed new “peace police” units to the slum as part of an ambitious plan to wrest control of the city’s slums, or favelas, from drug gangs.

headline: In Rough Slum, Brazil’s Police Try Soft Touch
text: RIO DE JANEIRO  Leonardo Bento longed for vengeance after a policeman killed his brother five years ago. So when he heard that the new “peace police” force in the City of God slum was offering free karate classes, Mr. Bento signed up, hoping he would at least get to beat up the karate instructor.

headline: Packers Are Trending Downward
text: To say that the Packers are hurting is an understatement. Green Bay, which entered Sunday’s game against the Redskins with injury concerns at running back, safety and linebacker, can now add tight end and — most troubling — quarterback to that list.

headline: From Wedding Halls to Horse Tracks, a Special Date
text: October 10, 2010  10/10/10  came and went largely unmarked in New York, unless you were getting married or placing a bet.

headline: An Expanded Reading List for the Tea Party
text: To the Editor:

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
text: Accounts

headline: Provocative Image of Christ Sets Off a Debate Punctuated With a Crowbar
text: LOVELAND, Colo.  For once, the quaint museum on Lincoln Avenue was all quiet. A sign inside was the only indication of the recent trouble.

headline: Despite Army Efforts, Soldier Suicides Continue
text: FORT HOOD, Tex.  At 3:30 a.m. on a Saturday in August, Specialist Armando G. Aguilar Jr. found himself at the end of his short life. He was standing, drunk and weepy, in the parking lot of a Valero station outside Waco, Tex. He had jumped out of his moving pickup. There was a police officer talking to him in frantic tones. Specialist Aguilar held a pistol pointed at his head.

headline: In Higher Education, a Focus on Technology
text: The education gap facing the nation’s work force is evident in the numbers. Most new jobs will require more than a high school education, yet fewer than half of Americans under 30 have a postsecondary degree of any kind. Recent state budget cuts, education experts agree, promise to make closing that gap even more difficult.

headline: From Tea Party Advocates, Anger at the Federal Reserve
text: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve, having weathered criticism of its regulatory failings and interest rate decisions in the years before the financial crisis, is facing a new source of anger: the Tea Party movement.

headline: ‘The Sound of Music,’ the Blu-ray Treatment
text: LOS ANGELES  When in doubt, roll out the von Trapps.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: Bond markets will be closed on Monday in observance of Columbus Day. The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes the regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills on Tuesday and an auction of four-week bills on Wednesday.

headline: Illinois Senate Debate Focuses on Integrity of Candidates
text: Questions about personal integrity dominated a televised debate on Sunday between the two candidates running for the Illinois Senate seat that was vacated by President Obama.

headline: Corrections
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,309 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American on Sunday:

headline: Baseball Replay, Oct. 10
text: A look at three division series games Sunday, between the Tampa Bay Rays and the Texas Rangers; the San Francisco Giants and the Atlanta Braves; and the Cincinnati Reds and the Philadelphia Phillies.

headline: Giants Replay: Oct. 10
text: Plenty of passing and a powerful defense carried the Giants to a 34-10 victory over the Texans.

headline: Democrats Vie for Votes, and Their Party’s Largess
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio — Embattled Democratic lawmakers must fight this week to impress two audiences: voters, and party leaders back in Washington now deciding where to invest for the campaign homestretch.

headline: William C. Patrick III, Expert on Germ Warfare, Dies at 84
text: William C. Patrick III made enough germs to kill everyone on earth many times over. Then, after putting aside those living weapons, he worked for nearly four decades to build defenses against them, to better protect the United States from biological attack.

headline: Degrees of Debt
text: Denver

headline: Hey, Small Spender
text: Here’s the narrative you hear everywhere: President Obama has presided over a huge expansion of government, but unemployment has remained high. And this proves that government spending can’t create jobs.

headline: Grading School Choice
text: In this fall’s must-see documentary, “Waiting for ‘Superman,’ ” Davis Guggenheim offers a critique of America’s public school bureaucracy that’s manipulative, simplistic and more than a little bit utopian.

headline: Unpublished Stieg Larsson Book Is Confirmed
text: Remember that mysterious, unpublished, unconfirmed manuscript of the fourth book in Stieg Larsson’s best-selling “Millennium” series? It’s actually the fifth book.

headline: Two Words: Wasteful and Ineffective
text: New York State will spend an extraordinary $170 million this year on 21 juvenile facilities. The system has more than 2,000 employees to oversee fewer than 700 children.

headline: Balkans, Past and Future
text: Bosnia, Serbia and Kosovo have come a long way since the 1990s. Serbia is no longer a rogue aggressor. Bosnia is no longer a killing field. And Kosovo, once a terrorized province of Serbia, is now an independent state. Washington and, in particular, former President Bill Clinton deserve a large share of the credit.

headline: Hamels Dashes Hopes as Phillies Sweep Reds
text: CINCINNATI  The banner was draped over the railing of the upper deck in left field, its red block letters crystallizing the hopes of towel-waving Cincinnati Reds fans who jammed Great American Ball Park in record numbers for Game 3 of the National League division series. It read, “We Still Believe.”

headline: A Station Defects From PBS
text: The financial strains on public television came into stark view on Friday when KCET-TV, Los Angeles’s main public station, said it would leave PBS on Jan. 1 and become the nation’s largest independent station.

headline: Whose Advantage?
text: Some of the private health plans that participate in Medicare will be dropping out next year, but don’t blame health care reform. Most are unwilling to meet the sensible requirements of a 2008 law that they do more to earn the federal subsidies that have fueled their rapid growth.

headline: What’s Your Timeline?
text: My grandmother was born 100 years ago in the city of Pachuca, an hour’s drive north of Mexico City. She died more than 10 years ago. But last week, as Mexico became one of the few countries ever to sell “century bonds,” I couldn’t help picturing her as a baby, swathed in cloth diapers, a turbulent century set to roll out before her.

headline: Freed Journalist Laura Ling Will Host ‘E! Investigates’
text: Laura Ling, who was detained in North Korea with a colleague from Current TV last year, is restarting her television career at a channel much closer to home — E!, the entertainment channel.

headline: TPG’s Headache in Russia
text: The public travails in Russia of David Bonderman’s buyout fund, TPG, are enough to scare other private equity firms away from the country. TPG is in a nasty, even violent, battle for control of the St. Petersburg hypermarket chain Lenta. For a $110 million investment, it might seem a case study in why Russia is too much trouble. But even so, the risks might be worth it.

headline: Bronx Attacker’s Ultimatum: Be Hit With a Bat, or a Pipe
text: After he had been punched, kicked and stripped of his clothes and jewelry, the 17-year-old man was given a choice: the bat or the pipe.

headline: Metropolitan Diary
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: Solomon Burke, Influential Soul Singer, Dies at 70
text: Solomon Burke, a singer whose smooth, powerful articulation and mingling of sacred and profane themes helped define soul music in the early 1960s, died on Sunday at Schiphol Airport in Amsterdam. He was 70 and lived in Los Angeles.

headline: Should Brooks Conrad Have Been in the Game in the Ninth Inning?
text: Braves Manager Bobby Cox is retiring after this season, and nothing that happens in this National League division series between Atlanta and San Francisco is going to change Cox’s standing as one of the great managers in baseball history.

headline: Short Attention Spans for Web Videos
text: After watching an online video for a full minute, 44.1 percent of viewers will have clicked away, according to Visible Measures. But an outsize slice of that loss occurs in the first 10 seconds, during which 19.4 percent of a video’s audience defects.

headline: News Quiz | October 11, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: S.B.A. Makes Small Businesses Bigger
text: From Robb Mandelbaum at You’re the Boss:

headline: Kramnik Wins Again, Carlsen Loses Again in Bilbao Final
text: After two rounds, Vladimir Kramnik leads the tournament while Viswanathan Anand, the world champion, is in second after beating Magnus Carlsen, who has lost both his games.

headline: Chinese Pharma Set to Raise $741 Million
text: Sihuan Pharmaceutical Holdings Group, China’s largest cardio-cerebral vascular drugmaker, seeks to raise up to $741 million through its Hong Kong initial public offering, according to a term sheet seen by Reuters on Monday.

headline: White House Aide Doubts Need to Halt Foreclosures
text: A top White House adviser questioned the need on Sunday for a blanket halt to home foreclosures, even as pressure grows on the Obama administration to do something about growing evidence that banks have used inaccurate documents to evict homeowners, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Ryan Seacrest Backs New Cable Effort

text: Today’s word, in association with the inestimable Oxford English Dictionary, is

headline: AIA’s $21 Billion I.P.O. Said to Meet Huge Demand
text: American International Group has received strong demand for the mega I.P.O. of its Asian life insurance business, AIA Group, with the offer covered more than five times in the first week, sources with direct knowledge of the matter told Reuters.

headline: Morgenson: It’s Not Nice to Mess With J.R.
text: From Gretchen Morgenson’s latest column:

headline: Blow the Whistle. Then Worry and Wait…

text: Janchor Partners Pan Asian Fund, run by the former Asia leader of the Children’s Investment Fund Management UK, returned 21 percent after fees in the first nine months of the year, according to an e-mail sent to investors and seen by Bloomberg News.

headline: Microsoft Deal in Europe Barely Affects Browser Market

headline: Cnooc in $2.2 Billion Deal With Chesapeake Energy
text: Cnooc, one of the largest Chinese state-run oil companies, has agreed to buy a third of Chesapeake Energy’s oil and gas assets in a south Texas shale deposit for $1.1 billion, in a deal that will ultimately be worth double that amount. It is the largest Chinese purchase of United States energy assets ever and the latest in a string of similar deals by Beijing around the world.

headline: Britain Opens Public Inquest Into 2005 London Terrorist Attacks

headline: This Blog’s Final Post
text: A note to readers: This post is the last for the Idea of the Day blog, started by the editors of the Week in Review more than two years ago as a place to highlight the most interesting current writing on the Web. The blog’s end is a result of limited resources in a medium where any number of worthy projects are possible, and where new priorities continually emerge. Thanks to all our readers and commenters, and regrets.

headline: This Week in Small Business: Bankruptcies, Waivers and iPads
text: MAYBE I SHOULD HIRE SOMEONE. Intuit’s small-business employment index for September shows slowing job growth, reporting that “for small businesses with fewer than 20 employees, only 27,000 new jobs were created.” Compensation also declined. “It’s a disappointing number, but it’s not unexpected,” Joel Prakken, chairman of Macroeconomic Advisors, told CNBC. “G.D.P. growth has slowed to below the growth rate of productivity, and it’s inevitable that you’d have this deceleration in jobs.” The overall unemployment rate stayed close to 10 percent. Even the American Jobs Creation Act of 2004 made little impact according to research by Mitchell Petersen, a professor of finance at the Kellogg School of Management. Anyone out there hiring?

headline: On Our Radar: Turtle Egg Rescue Pays Off
text: A monumental effort to relocate vast numbers of sea turtle eggs from oil-threatened beaches along the Gulf of Mexico to Florida’s Atlantic coast appears to have paid off, scientists said, with nearly 15,000 hatchlings released into the Atlantic since July. Survival rates were virtually identical to those in the wild, but some uncertainty remains over whether the newly hatched turtles will eventually return to their native beaches. [Nature]

headline: Getting Away From It All: The Iraq You Don’t Often See
text: HABBANIYA, IRAQ — Over the weekend, Iraqis escaped from the bombs, checkpoints and assassinations around them by coming to Habbaniya Tourist Village, a holiday site 50 miles west of Baghdad, near Falluja. Habbaniya was built in the era of Saddam Hussein, whose 1982 official tourist guidebook boasted that it was at the time “the largest tourist village of the kind in the Middle East.”

Do I believe them? I do, even if facing Cliff Lee in the playoffs sounds as appealing as taking a bath with piranhas.

headline: Notes From the Underground | All Tomorrow’s Parties
text: When I checked in at the press desk for All Tomorrow’s Parties, I was given the following directive: “The rule at ATP is, there are no rules — just don’t caught.” So when Iggy Pop took to the stage on opening night, so did I. I scaled a wall of speakers 20 feet high and dangled by one arm as I snapped away. And mysteriously, I did not get thrown out.All Tomorrow’s Parties is the ultimate insider’s festival. Created in England in 1999, it exists without corporate sponsorship or mainstream headliners, playing host to a slew of avant-garde noise music, indie rock and underground hip-hop acts. An annual event in the States since 2008, it is the rebel yell of alternative concert programming, democratically housing the bands in the same hotel as the fans and turning its nose up at industry money.

headline: Planned Adam Lambert Concert in Malaysia Draws Protest
text: A fundamentalist Muslim party in Malaysia is demanding the cancellation of a concert by the pop-rock star Adam Lambert planned for Thursday, saying the singer and his show will promote “gay culture,” Reuters reported. Mr. Lambert, an “American Idol” runner-up who is openly gay, and who is scheduled to perform at the Putra Indoor Stadium in Bukit Jalil, near Kuala Lumpur, has met with opposition from the Pan Malaysian Islamic Party, which is that nation’s second-largest political party. Nasrudin Hasan, a youth leader for the party, was quoted by Reuters as saying that Mr. Lambert’s shows “are outrageous, with lewd dancing and a gay performance that includes kissing male dancers,” which is “not good for people in our country.” The party, which has previously protested shows by artists like Beyoncé, Rihanna and Mariah Carey, also said it would send “many of its members and supporters” to proselytize at the concert if it went forward. A representative for Malaysia’s arts, culture and heritage department said Mr. Lambert had agreed to abide by performance guidelines, which include not removing his clothing and maintaining a distance of about 25 feet between his stage and the audience.

headline: Red Bull Takes Charge in Japanese Grand Prix
text: For the second straight year, Sebastian Vettel made winning the Japanese Grand Prix look easy. The Red Bull Racing driver started on pole — ahead of his teammate, Mark Webber — and stayed in front wire to wire for his third win of the season. More importantly, Vettel jumped from fourth to second in the championship, with only three races remaining.

headline: When Apartment Hunters Heed Their Noses
text: This week’s installment of my column, The Appraisal, explores the delicate topic of smells in apartments. Yes, the reporting involved determining some of the worst smells found in New York homes (cats, smoke, Subway sandwiches) and how much they influence sales and leases. And we’re not just talking about a few clichéd household odors: At one West Side condo tower, the lobby is overwhelmed by the, um, aroma pouring in from a neighboring truffle store.

headline: House of the Rising Son: Site of Bob Dylan’s Bar Mitzvah for Sale
text: How many Hebrew school classes must one boy take before you can call him a man? The answer, my friends, may be contained within an unusual piece of Bob Dylan memorabilia that has been posted for sale on Craigslist: the building that was once the synagogue where the singer-songwriter had his bar mitzvah. The Duluth News Tribune reported that the structure at 2320 West Second Street in Hibbing, Minn., which was formerly the Agudath Achim Synagogue where the young Robert Zimmerman was first called to read the Torah in 1954, was put on sale a few months ago by its owners. (They have since turned to Dylan fan sites and the news media in hopes of finding a buyer.)

But fresh variations on “Swan Lake” — Aronofsky’s included — have companies like New York City Ballet and American Ballet Theater anticipating a grande jeté in attendance this spring.

headline: That’s So 19th Century: Demi Moore Rethinks Her Art Collection
text: The manner in which the 19th-century artist William Bouguereau depicted women — with a combination of “gentleness, serenity and strength’’ — as Demi Moore put it, is what drew the actress to his work. So in 1995, when “Frère et Soeur,’’ an 1887 canvas of a young girl carrying her baby brother, came up for sale at a Christie’s auction in New York, she bought it for $178,500. It wasn’t all she purchased at that sale. Ms. Moore also snapped up a painting by the Belgian artist Alfred Stevens, from 1883, called “Mère et Ses Enfants,’’ for $200,500.

headline: Rushdie Writing Memoir About Years in Hiding
text: Salman Rushdie is writing a memoir that will recount his years in hiding after the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini ordered Muslims to kill him because of what he called blasphemy in Mr. Rushdie’s novel “The Satanic Verses,” according to Reuters. “I’m beginning to write this memoir,” Mr. Rushdie told the news agency. “So far I feel that I’m right: I’m not getting churned up and upset, I’m just writing it and I’m feeling quite pleased to be writing it.” Mr. Rushdie, 63, has frequently spoken of the death sentence, issued in 1989 as a fatwa, an Islamic religious ruling, but has devoted most of his time since then to writing fiction: in recent years, “The Enchantress of Florence” and “Shalimar the Clown.” His children’s book “Luka and the Fire of Life” will be published next month. The memoir could be completed by the end of 2011.

text: How did “The Simpsons” manage to track down Banksy, the pseudonymous British artist, and get him to create the powerful opening-credit sequence from Sunday’s episode, which seems to reveal the torturous sweatshop responsible for the show’s creation? And how, after all that mockery, have the producers behind that Fox animated series been able to retain their jobs? Al Jean, an executive producer and the longtime show runner of “The Simpsons,” pulled back another layer of the curtain and explained the stunt to ArtsBeat on Monday afternoon.

Mr. Kelly becomes managing director of the San Francisco office, succeeding Lynn Rundell, who left, the agency said, to pursue other interests; Mr. Kelly had been executive vice president and managing director at the San Francisco office of G2, part of the Grey Group unit of WPP.

headline: Parity: Trying to Muddle Through Equally
text: Three weeks ago, the Houston Texans were the darlings of the A.F.C. at 2-0, a striving team that had finally toppled the entrenched Indianapolis Colts in what seemed an inevitable rise to the playoffs. By Sunday, the Texans were 3-2, dragged back into the purgatory where bleary-eyed coaches wonder where the good times went. They played so poorly in a bludgeoning by the Giants that Coach Gary Kubiak announced, “I don’t think there was anything we did good.”

text: Vimeo aims to make Hollywood – and its pesky rules and constrictions – irrelevant, and judging by the winners of the online video-sharing site’s first awards contest, it’s doing a credible job.

headline: A Fine Italian Hand
text: “Wait,” Maurizio Cattelan says in his low, conspiratorial, Italian-accented voice. ‘‘I have something for you.’’ It’s a warm July evening, and I am walking along the Hudson with the art world’s most famous prankster, so I feel a double twinge of apprehension and curiosity when he reaches into the cotton bag at his side. Out comes a strange object: a life-size orange hand from which all the fingers except the erect middle one have been broken off. Obscene, goofy and eye-catching, the one-fingered hand looks like a cross between a gag-store novelty and a sex toy. To anyone else, it might well be a joke. To Cattelan, it’s something entirely serious: a prototype for his next sculpture, which is to say, his next test of the public’s equanimity. Cattelan passes the hand to me, and we continue strolling, talking about his plans. This being New York, pedestrians and joggers studiously avoid glancing at us, two men contemplating a rude, inexplicable object.

headline: ‘Dexter’ Watch: Suspicions Are Growing
text: Let’s just say you are a vigilante serial killer and single parent who keeps odd hours and also has a day job, what are you looking for in a nanny? Sunday night’s episode of “Dexter” had as one of its many subplots Dexter’s search for a proper caregiver to help him with baby Harrison. With Deb’s assistance he found one pretty quickly — more quickly than today’s average helicopter mom, but let’s not quibble with details. (No, let’s keep quibbling: what are the chances of finding a nanny that quickly and one who seems to be Irish, in the middle of Miami?)

That means that A. J. Burnett, whose poor performance in the regular season cost him a potential start in the division series against Minnesota, will start Game 4.

You’ll be happy to know that someone stuck with a huge waterfront mansion in Grand Cayman plans to auction it on Nov. 3, the day after the election. Previously listed at $19.8 million, the promise is that it will be sold to the high bidder, without reserve.

text: Nate Silver appeared in the first installment of The Caucus, a TimesCast segment offering daily insight into what’s shaping the midterm elections. Nate spoke with The Times’s Megan Liberman on the latest in the West Virginia Senate race, and how the results of this surprisingly competitive contest could affect the make-up of the Senate.

headline: Russia Asks Schwarzenegger to Help in a Tough Task
text: SKOLKOVO, Russia  Perhaps frustrated by what at times can seem like his own one-man effort to bring his unwieldy country into the 21st century, President Dmitri A. Medvedev on Monday turned to a seasoned fighter of government bureaucracy and other dark forces.

headline: Disney Revs Up ‘Tron’ Promotional Campaign
text: Borrowing a marketing ploy from 20th Century Fox and “Avatar,” the Walt Disney Company said it would preview more than 20 minutes of its forthcoming “Tron: Legacy” free at Imax theaters around the world. Fox and Imax created this model by showing about 15 minutes of “Avatar” a few months before that movie’s release. The “Tron” promotional screenings will take place Oct. 28 as stand-alone events. Tickets will be distributed on a first-come basis starting Tuesday; information on how to get one can be found at facebook.com/tron. Disney is pushing the science-fiction themed “Tron: Legacy,” which opens Dec. 17, with everything in its marketing arsenal, including a huge array of related merchandise (rolling out in stores this month) and a continuing nighttime street party at one of its California theme parks.

headline: The Dwindling Options for Airgas
text: The legal victory won by Air Products and Chemicals on Friday evening in its battle with Airgas was accompanied by some last-minute drama in Delaware Chancery Court. Earlier that Friday, Chancellor William B. Chandler III had made some remarks that arguably could have been interpreted as supporting Airgas’s claims. Some arbitragers certainly interpreted it as such. Airgas’s stock subsequently fell about a dollar a share.

headline: When a Dog’s Dish Seems Half Empty
text: Dogs can be worried and pessimistic just like people, researchers report in a new study in Current Biology. And they aren’t talking about basset hounds: those dogs just look as if they expect the worst.

headline: Fashion Week Finale | Accessories Report
text: It’s time to bid your Fashion Week farewells and au revoirs as the shows come to a close. Designers may enjoy a moment of satisfied rest, but editors are busier than ever. This season’s collections ditch the pointy-toe kitten heels and full housewife skirts. (And weren’t we all a bit exhausted of the ’50s!) Instead, they offer everything from the polished refinement of a sleek Row suit and Audrey-like crimson ballet flats to Prada and Balenciaga’s ’90s homage to grunge, with Dr. Martens-esque footwear.

headline: Joints Key to Bats’ Complicated Flight
text: The scientific order for bats, Chiroptera, appropriately translates to “hand wing.” And like human hands, bat wings are fleshy and have myriad joints. In contrast, bird wings have only a few joints, and those of winged insects contain a single joint.

text: WASHINGTON  Federal Reserve officials “have no choice” but to try to “contain future bubbles and credit binges” and limit their damage to the economy, the central bank’s vice chairwoman said on Monday, detailing the Fed’s newly broadened mandate to promote financial stability.

text: The two economists call their paper “Mental Retirement,” and their argument has intrigued behavioral researchers. Data from the United States, England and 11 other European countries suggest that the earlier people retire, the more quickly their memories decline.

The university, which has longstanding financial difficulties, is seeking to share ownership of the collection with the Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art in Bentonville, Ark.

headline: Understanding ‘Ba Ba Ba’ as a Key to Development
text: As a pediatrician, I always ask about babble. “Is the baby making sounds?” I ask the parent of a 4-month-old, a 6-month-old, a 9-month-old. The answer is rarely no. But if it is, it’s important to try to find out what’s going on.

headline: Now Viewing | Buildings on Film
text: Architecture film buffs, take note: the Architecture and Design Film Festival opens Thursday evening at Tribeca Cinemas and runs through Oct. 17. The first of its kind in the United States, the festival (for which T is a media partner) was founded by Kyle Bergman, who produced the play “The Glass House,” about the human dramas behind Mies van der Rohe’s Farnsworth House and Philip Johnson’s Glass House. After the opening night — at which Makoto Yabuki’s short film “White Box” will be shown with Olga Spátová’s “Eye Over Prague,” a documentary on Jan Kaplicky’s ill-fated design for the National Library in Prague — the festival will present a variety of feature-length, short and documentary films. Among them are “Citizen Architect: Samuel Mockbee and the Spirit of the Rural Studio;” “Contemporary Days,” Murray Grigor’s film on the postwar British design pioneers Robin and Lucienne Day; “Studio Gang Architects: Aqua Tower,” about the cutting-edge Chicago apartment tower designed by Jeanne Gang; and “Saving Lieb House,” Jim Venturi’s account of his and the architect Frederic Schwartz’s successful efforts to rescue a 1969 house designed by Venturi’s parents, Robert Venturi and Denise Scott Brown. Panel discussions will feature speakers like Paul Goldberger, the architecture critic for The New Yorker; James Sanders, the architect, filmmaker and author of “Celluloid Skyline”; and Cameron Sinclair, the co-founder of Architecture for Humanity.

headline: What China Seeks in Chesapeake Shale Deal
text: China’s $2.2 billion investment in the Texas oil patch may be small, but the deal with Chesapeake Energy involves a potential transfer of technology and intellectual knowledge to Beijing that some people in Washington may find uncomfortable, and that unease could trip up the deal.

headline: The Calm Before the Brain Injury Was Discovered

headline: Child Abuse Investigations Didn’t Reduce Risk, a Study Finds

headline: Africa: $130 Million From United States to Train Doctors in a Dozen Countries
text: The United States will donate $130 million to African medical schools to improve medical education on the continent, the Obama administration announced last week. The donations, to be made over five years, will go to about 30 medical schools and teaching hospitals in a dozen countries, and to about 20 American medical schools that have agreed to collaborate with them.

headline: A Demon Blogger Profiled Again, and Pee-Wee Takes Manhattan
text: The trouble with profiles of blog moguls who mostly write about the media is that there isn’t really much of an audience for them. The insiders, who might be expected to be interested, already know all about the subject’s peccadilloes, while outsiders could be fairly said to not care a wink.

headline: Moonlighting as a Conjurer of Chemicals
text: Sir Isaac Newton was a towering genius in the history of science, he knew he was a genius, and he didn’t like wasting his time. Born on Dec. 25, 1642, the great English physicist and mathematician rarely socialized or traveled far from home. He didn’t play sports or a musical instrument, gamble at whist or gambol on a horse. He dismissed poetry as “a kind of ingenious nonsense,” and the one time he attended an opera he fled at the third act. Newton was unmarried, had no known romantic liaisons and may well have died, at the age of 85, with his virginity intact. “I never knew him to take any recreation or pastime,” said his assistant, Humphrey Newton, “thinking all hours lost that were not spent on his studies.”

headline: Letters: Being Glenn Beck
text: Beck is at the apex of a couple of iconic American inventions: self-victimization and hyperhucksterism. In Mark Leibovich’s article, Beck claims that he needs to live behind a six-foot wall but doesn’t acknowledge the connection between his hateful words and his (perhaps real) vulnerability. We can perhaps forgive his contradictions — if not his venality — because his life-as-vaudeville-show is part of a long tradition in America: he’s laughing all the way to the bank.

headline: At Lani Kai, the Taste, and Scent, of the Tropics
text: Are there any orchids or bromeliads left in the city, now that Julie Reiner and her partners have fully decked out Lani Kai, their new Hawaiian-style cocktail lounge? This taste of the tropics, which has replaced Tailor, offers an extensive drink list, from classics like planter’s punch and the mai tai, to an array of aromatic inventions, including Hawaiian iced tea spiked with orange vodka, South Maui sangria with white wine and litchi juice, and the Lone Palm, combining gin with melon, ginger and basil.

But he has also been nourishing his inner rock star, playing electric violin in his own band.

headline: Is Chemo Brain Really Cancer Brain?
text: Much has been written about “chemo brain,” the foggy thinking and forgetfulness that afflicts many cancer patients after treatment. Now, new research suggests the cognitive problems associated with chemotherapy may also be caused by other types of treatment or even the disease itself.

headline: Movement to Fill Every Corner of a Space
text: As you enter the Center for Performance Research auditorium (in Williamsburg, Brooklyn) for the performance of Anne Zuerner’s “near the far,” four dancers are seated against a wall, with the audience (most on a slightly raised dais) facing them. Later, however, the dance moves around to the area on the audience’s left, and people choose whether to adjust their seats or watch the dance over a shoulder. Finally, the performance enters a third zone, and the audience adjusts seats again.

headline: A Stand-Up Comedian Walks Into Some Sketches
text: Nick Swardson wields comedy like a blunt instrument: the harder he swings, the funnier he is. The high point of the first episode of “Nick Swardson’s Pretend Time,” a new series beginning on Tuesday night on Comedy Central, is a sketch not everyone will want to watch. Mr. Swardson plays a doughy corporate human-resources manager giving a sexual harassment seminar to the employees of a Mexican donkey show. A performance is in progress behind him.

text: Police officials and bomb squad officers continued their investigation late into the afternoon of the package of C-4 explosive recovered in New York City Marble Cemetery in the East Village. Read the latest updates.

text: Megan Liberman and I talked about the horse-race aspects of West Virginia in today’s TimesCast: suffice it to say that, from an electoral perspective, it’s as important a state as any in terms of Democrats’ ability to hold the Senate.

headline: We Three Things | The ATL
text: Atlanta can seem like mainstream city, a hub better known for its airport, housewives and Coca-Cola headquarters. But at its power core are deep-rooted music and art scenes that exert an illuminating influence over the rest of the country’s cultural landscape.The Dust-to-Digital founder Lance Ledbetter is a musical defibrillator. He scours the country hunting down lost, nonprofessional and obscure American folk, bluegrass, gospel and jazz music, which he rereleases accompanied by lush illustrated books — box sets full of raw cotton and the enthusiast’s true love.

headline: In California, Pot Is Now an Art Patron

But one art foundation taking shape on 120 acres in the high oak chaparral of Sonoma County has different kinds of worries these days: spider mites, bud rot and the occasional low-flying surveillance visit from the local Sheriff’s Office.

headline: Honoring a Jazz Pianist and Mentor (Without Using a Single Jazz Piano)
text: Jaki Byard was a jazz pianist of rumbling mastery, quick humor and sprawling erudition, never as prominent as he should have been, though he was hardly unheralded in his time. Since his death in 1999, his legacy has been burnished by some posthumous live recordings and, no less effectively, by the continuing testimony of his students, several generations of whom he mentored in music schools across the Northeast.

headline: Bodies Like Statues, Beginning to Move and Then Set Free

Cecilia Bengolea and François Chaignaud posed that question over the weekend at Danspace Project in “Sylphides” (on Thursday and Friday nights) and “Pâquerette” (on Saturday afternoon). Like the collaborators, both pieces are as audacious as they are important.

headline: Betting on Becoming a Grandmaster

headline: A Quartet Mixes It Up With Younger Voices
text: Before Friday night the Kronos Quartet had never played at Le Poisson Rouge, the Bleecker Street nightclub that has served as an epicenter for adventurous music ever since it opened just over two years ago. But Friday’s concert, the first of two that the quartet presented at the club over the weekend, felt more like a homecoming. Sold out well in advance, both events were crammed to capacity with friends and fans.

headline: On Campaign Trail, Biden Comes Home
text: SCRANTON, Pa. – As he campaigns for Democrats around the country, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. likes to say that the “the longest walk up a short flight of stairs’’ that a man can take is the one to tell the kids he has lost his job. Invariably, Mr. Biden follows up by recounting how own father took just such a walk when the family lived in this hardscrabble town.

headline: Remembering Marcel Lapierre, A Beaujolais Trailblazer

headline: Preclearing Customs, a Prized Advantage
text: THERE are significant benefits to the United States Customs and Border Protection preclearance program, which allows passengers bound for the United States to clear customs at one of about 15 airports mostly in Canada and Ireland. The biggest benefit is that a passenger can pass through customs quickly and arrive in the United States without having to stand in one of those long, dreary lines at, say, Kennedy International Airport.

headline: For Democrats, Even ‘Safe’ Seats Are Shaky
text: ST. CLAIRSVILLE, Ohio  Republicans are expanding the battle for the House into districts that Democrats had once considered relatively safe, while Democrats began a strategy of triage on Monday to fortify candidates who they believe stand the best chance of survival.

headline: Political Math: What Percentage Equals Lockstep?
text: In numerous races across the country this year, Republican hopefuls have been hammering incumbent Democrats in Congress for voting in lockstep with Representative Nancy Pelosi of California, the House speaker, more than 90 percent of the time.

headline: Critics' Picks: 'Walkabout'
text: A.O. Scott looks back at Nicolas Roeg's film about the persistent dream of innocence.

headline: When 50 Percent Off Just Won’t Do
text: WHEN it comes to wooing wary shoppers, many retailers are playing the percentages.

headline: Oracle and I.B.M. Agree to Java Pact
text: Millions of software developers uneasily held their collective breath when Oracle bought Sun Microsystems earlier this year. The deal handed Oracle the role as the corporate steward of Java software technology, initially developed by Sun in 1995.

headline: Europe May Ease Jet Carbon Fees
text: BRUSSELS  The transportation chief of the European Union said Monday that airlines based in the United States could receive an exemption, at least in part, from European carbon regulations if Washington moved to reduce greenhouse gas emissions at home.

headline: Testing the Limits of Loose Money
text: Sound monetary policy begins at home. The prime goal of the Federal Reserve is to nurture a healthy national economy. But it would be naïve to ignore the influence that Fed policy has on markets around the globe. And at present the Fed risks blowing global bubbles, with potentially damaging effects.

headline: 2nd Teamsters Candidate to Challenge Hoffa in 2011
text: Sandy Pope, president of a Teamsters local in New York City and one of the most prominent women in the union, announced on Monday that she would challenge James P. Hoffa for the presidency.

headline: Live Analysis: Jets 29, Vikings 20, Final
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The story lines before the Minnesota Vikings’ trip here on Monday night dominated the headlines in New York and attracted national attention. But all of it overshadowed something: that the Jets continue to hum along.

headline: Ohio Attorney General Fights Against Wall Street
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio  Back East, at the corner of Broad and Wall Streets, the view is swell. The Dow is soaring, and bankers look pleased.

headline: KKR Strikes Pipeline Deal
text: A partner at Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company recently told us that the firm had a number of deals in the pipeline. Little did we know that one of those deals was a pipeline.

headline: Cromartie Stands in for Revis in Rematch
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Randy Moss and Darrelle Revis have crafted a personal rivalry that transcends the colors on their uniforms. Whether Moss is in New England or Minnesota, Revis seems to relish the opportunity to cover him.

headline: Back in San Jose, and Now Back in the Playoffs
text: Only one playoff berth in Major League Soccer remains to be claimed after the Seattle Sounders and the San Jose Earthquakes clinched spots last weekend.

headline: A Mistake the Police Won’t Forgive
text: A week ago, Sgt. Osvaldo Hernandez ended his second tour of Army duty in Afghanistan, a tough seven-month stretch, and immediately hit life’s reset button.

headline: 9th Suspect Is Arrested in Attacks in the Bronx
text: The ninth suspect accused of beating and torturing three Bronx men in antigay attacks was taken into custody on Monday afternoon, the authorities said.

headline: Arizona Rethinking Open Range Laws
text: PHOENIX — They have startled the residents of Ahwatukee, a bedroom community in southern Phoenix. They have tramped on lawns and damaged vehicles in Rio Rancho, a neighborhood of tract homes outside Albuquerque. A Border Patrol agent lost his life crashing into one of them near the Mexican border in Texas.

headline: Agendas of Paladino and Rabbi Meld
text: Carl P. Paladino’s introduction to the world of conservative Jewish politics began with an unsolicited early-morning phone call three weeks ago to his campaign manager, Michael R. Caputo.

headline: N.F.L. Is Compelled to React
text: Deadspin’s mission is to be everything the mainstream news media are not: snarky, mean spirited and unbound by more rigorous principles of old-line journalism. In that spirit of online mayhem, the sports blog last Thursday posted photographs of what it purports to be Brett Favre’s genitals, shots that it said he sent while still the Jets’ quarterback to Jenn Sterger, a former game-day host for the team. So far, the story has been viewed 1.9 million times.

headline: Knicks May Try Rookie Center On First Team
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — The directives that CoachMike D’Antoni offered Timofey Mozgov, the Knicks’ rookie center from Russia, are simple, with little room to be lost in translation.

headline: Maurice Allais, Nobel Winner, Dies at 99
text: Maurice Allais, who won the Nobel in economic science in 1988 for his influential insights into markets, risk, interest rates and myriad other economic phenomena, died Saturday at his home near Paris. He was 99.

headline: Los Angeles TV Station Severs Ties With PBS
text: LOS ANGELES  Tim Muskatell was weaned on KCET, Los Angeles’ flagship PBS station, where he tuned in for landmark programs like “Sesame Street.” Now 41 years old and without a cable subscription, he said he still relied on KCET for documentaries and shows like the “Masterpiece” series.

headline: For Favre, It’s Finally the Point of No Return
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

headline: A Foreclosure Tightrope for Democrats
text: WASHINGTON  The swelling outcry over fast-and-loose foreclosures has thrust the Obama administration back into the uncomfortable position of sheltering the banking industry from the demands of an angry public.

headline: Russia Is Seeking to Build Europe’s Nuclear Plants
text: MOSCOW  The Russian nuclear industry has profited handsomely from building reactors in developing countries, including India, China and Iran. Now it is testing the prospect of becoming a major supplier to the European Union, too.

headline: Unrepentant, Paladino Calls Gay Parades ‘Disgusting’
text: Despite an uproar over his remarks about gays, Carl P. Paladino appeared on national television on Monday and expressed revulsion at gay pride parades.

headline: Female Factor
text: Katrin Bennhold reports on the advancement of French women helped by state social policies.  But despite the high levels of education and employment, the glass ceiling remains.

headline: Carla Cohen, Owner of Washington Bookstore, Dies at 74
text: Carla Cohen, whose independent bookstore, Politics and Prose, sat at the nexus of Washington’s literary and political scenes and became a requisite stop for authors passing through town, died Monday at her home in Washington. She was 74.

headline: Worrying Over China and Food
text: Are the Chinese coming?

headline: Starting Over: Burnett Rejoins Yanks’ Rotation
text: The Yankees have made the playoffs 49 times, but there is a simple reason that 27 flags ring the top of Yankee Stadium: nothing less than winning the World Series is acceptable.

headline: For Pena, Rebirth Is All in the Timing
text: ARLINGTON, Tex.

headline: The True Mission of ‘Crisis Pregnancy Centers’
text: Imagine a young woman riding the subway, consumed by her thoughts: she is pregnant, considering abortion, but unsure of where to turn. She looks up midcommute and notices a sign with three bold words, one beneath the other: “Free abortion alternatives.” At the bottom of the sign are several phone numbers that will lead her to any one of 12 E.M.C. FrontLine Pregnancy Centers around New York City.

headline: The Crisis of the Humanities Officially Arrives
text: In a response to last week’s column on “Howl,” the movie about Allen Ginsberg’s famous poem, Charlie from Binghamton asked, “What happened to public investment in the humanities and the belief that the humanities enhanced our culture, our society, our humanity?” And he speculated that it “will be a sad, sad day if and when we allow the humanities to collapse.”

headline: Inspectors in Rearview as Food Trucks Rule Road
text: LOS ANGELES  This is the place where food trucks really first took to the streets, catering to fanatical customers who relished  along with the food  the renegade and slightly outlaw nature of the whole business.

headline: Scotland Not Afraid of a ‘Stooshie’ With Critics or Spain
text: Oct. 12, 5:22 p.m. |Spain 3, Scotland 2

headline: Giants’ Rally Ousts Braves and Ends Cox’s Career
text: ATLANTA  Bobby Cox bit his lip, trying to stifle any tears that wanted to drip out. He was forced to change the subject to keep from becoming too emotional in his last news conference as the Atlanta manager.

headline: Races Range From Odd to More So
text: WASHINGTON  Revelations that Rich Iott, a Republican Congressional candidate from Ohio, once whiled away time dressing up as a Nazi have not been fortunate for his candidacy. He has been abandoned by a prominent member of his party, castigated by critics and may well be doomed as a politician.

headline: A Soprano Hailed as ‘La Stupenda’
text: Joan Sutherland, a soprano known for her vocal charisma and for singing the title role in “Lucia di Lammermoor,” died at 83.

headline: New Yorkers’ Anger at Politicians Doesn’t Fuel a Surge in Voter Registration
text: Despite professed outrage over dysfunctional politicians, few unregistered New Yorkers have been motivated enough to register to vote in November, according to election officials.

headline: Lottery Numbers
‘Outlaw’ Canceled by NBC
text: The NBC drama “Outlaw” became the third show of the new television season to be canceled. The network announced Monday that the program would be moved from Friday to Saturday night for the remaining four episodes that have been produced.

headline: This Year’s Giants Aren’t Afraid to Work a Little Overtime
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  In the rhythm of life in the N.F.L., there are certain abiding truths. Most games are on Sunday and players are off on Tuesday.

headline: Relying on Pitching, Phillies Save Big Celebration
text: CINCINNATI  Off to the side, safely away from the gathering mess in the middle of the Philadelphia Phillies’ clubhouse  empty Champagne bottles, spent corks, twisted wire and ice cubes  pitcher Roy Halladay savored the first playoff championship celebration of his 13-year career.

headline: Two Draws, One a Marathon, Preserve Status Quo at Bilbao Masters
text: Vladimir Kramnik leads at the half-way point, with Viswanathan Anand, the world champion, in second.

headline: Offering Donors Secrecy, and Going on Attack
text: The American Future Fund, a conservative organization based in Iowa, has been one of the more active players in this fall’s campaigns, spending millions of dollars on ads attacking Democrats across the country. It has not hesitated to take credit for its attacks, issuing press releases with headlines like “AFF Launches TV Ads in 13 States Targeting Liberal Politicians.”

headline: Explosives Abandoned In Cemetery Are Mystery
text: The New York City Marble Cemetery has long had an air of mystery. Practically hidden between apartment buildings and brownstones, the leafy urban pocket was once the resting place of President James Monroe. A fire long ago destroyed records showing some of its other early inhabitants. The cemetery’s Web site welcomes amateur genealogists to help fill in the blanks.

headline: For G.M., Mets Ponder Another Team’s Assistant
text: When the Mets interview Rick Hahn on Tuesday for their general manager opening, he will have one distinct advantage over other candidates. Hahn, the assistant general manager of the Chicago White Sox, attended the University of Michigan, the beloved alma mater of Fred Wilpon, the Mets’ principal owner. That should prove beneficial.

headline: Tuesday: Something in Common
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — We first met José Chardiet, who is 16, at his debut puzzle on July 6 (Across Lite, Solution, blog). This time we have a much more ambitious theme that takes us through the months of the year in order. Take a look at the starred answers because they’re nicely done — symmetrically distributed, and each three-letter abbreviation is at the start of the longer answer. “Roundabout, for one” is a good clue for JUNCTION and the problem of starting a word with SEP that doesn’t look like SEPTEMBER is nicely solved with the “Cosmetics chain” SEPHORA.

headline: Sham Candidacy Is Charged in House Race
text: CINNAMINSON, N.J.  Adam Haraburda grinned at the sight of the local celebrity running for Congress, happy for a chance to stop and chat with the candidate. But that did not mean he had decided how to vote.

headline: In China, a Village’s Silk Goes Out of Fashion
text: The name Jili used to be synonymous with silk in China. Now the village’s homespun fortunes are fading as young people leave for the cities.

headline: Silk Craft Fades in Village That Clothed Emperors
text: JILI, China  There was a time when clean water, mulberry trees and tiny, squirming, milky-white larvae made this village one of the most famous in all of China.

headline: Two Arrested While Interviewing Condemned Iranian’s Son
text: TEHRAN  Iran’s chief prosecutor said Monday that the police had arrested two foreigners masquerading as journalists who were caught in midinterview with the son of a woman convicted of adultery and murder and sentenced to death by stoning.

headline: Mine Saga in Chile Captivates Bolivians
text: SAN JOSÉ MINE, Chile — Impoverished in his Bolivian homeland and desperate for a job, Carlos Mamani had been working at the mine here in Chile’s barren northern desert for just five days — before disaster struck.

headline: Marcel Lapierre, Beaujolais Producer, Is Dead at 60
text: Marcel Lapierre, a Beaujolais grower and producer who played a leading role in rejuvenating the diminished reputation of the region’s wines, died Sunday in Lyon, France. He was 60.

headline: China: Prominent Doctor Sentenced in Attacks on Critics
text: A prominent doctor was sentenced to five and a half months in jail for orchestrating a revenge attack on two writers who had accused him of fraud, state media reported on Monday. According to the police, Dr. Xiao Chuanguo, a urologist from Wuhan, confessed to paying four men a total of $15,000 to assault Fang Xuanchang, a science writer, and Fang Shimin, a blogger whose Web site is dedicated to exposing academic and scientific fraud. They had written critically about a nerve-rerouting procedure Dr. Xiao pioneered and practiced on hundreds of patients with incontinence. The attacks were carried out with pepper spray, a hammer and an iron rod; both victims have recovered. During a closed-door trial on Sunday, the four attackers received terms ranging from one and a half months to five and a half months, according to the official Xinhua news service, which said Dr. Xiao would appeal his sentence.

headline: Closing the Case on the Cole
text: TEN years ago, Qaeda terrorists blew a hole in the side of the Navy destroyer Cole in Yemen, killing 17 sailors. Yet the attack’s mastermind still hasn’t been prosecuted, and many of the men tried and imprisoned for the bombing are again free.

headline: At Synod With Mideast Bishops, Pope Condemns Terror Ideologies
text: Pope Benedict XVI opened a two-week synod of Catholic bishops from the Middle East on Monday by condemning terrorist ideologies carried out in “God’s name.” In off-the-cuff remarks to the bishops and other religious leaders who convened for the synod, the pope said that these acts of violence have “nothing to do with God and instead everything to do with false gods that must be exposed.” The aim of the synod, which ends Oct. 24, is to discuss problems faced by Christians living in the Middle East, where the Catholic Church’s members have been dwindling because of war, and economic and social conflict. It also hopes to foster better communication between the Catholic churches there and Rome, as well as improve interreligious dialogue with Muslims and Jews.

headline: Turkey: Members of Judicial Board Resign in a Power Struggle
text: Seven of the 12 members of the Senior Board of Judges and Prosecutors resigned on Monday amid a power struggle between the staunchly secular judiciary and the religiously conservative government in Turkey. The board chairman said members were frustrated at not being allowed to perform their duties since the government proposed a referendum calling for major structural changes to the board, which is in charge of appointing and dismissing magistrates. The referendum passed a month ago. A Justice Ministry statement denied the claims and said the resignations were an effort to influence the election of new board members.

headline: Hail and Heavy Rain Batter Parts of Region
text: Weeks after a severe storm tore through parts of New York, another blast of foul weather visited the city, with hail falling in some neighborhoods, curtailing subway service and delaying the Jets-Vikings football game.

headline: Inquiry in Fatal Hit-and-Run Looks at Firefighter’s S.U.V.
text: A Brooklyn firefighter has been placed on administrative duties while the police investigate whether his sport utility vehicle was involved in a fatal hit-and-run accident early Sunday, a Fire Department spokesman said on Monday.

headline: The First Marty McFly
text: In this clip from the “Back to the Future” 25th Anniversary DVD collection, Robert Zemeckis, Steven Spielberg and Bob Gale discuss why they replaced the actor Eric Stoltz as Marty McFly.

headline: Offshore Wind Power Line Wins Backing
text: WASHINGTON  Google and a New York financial firm have each agreed to invest heavily in a proposed $5 billion transmission backbone for future offshore wind farms along the Atlantic Seaboard that could ultimately transform the region’s electrical map.
