text: ominous •\ˈä-mə-nəs\• adjective

headline: The Paralysis of the State
text: Sometimes a local issue perfectly illuminates a larger national problem. Such is the case with the opposition of the New Jersey governor, Chris Christie, to construction of a new tunnel between his state and New York.

headline: ‘So Utterly Inhumane’
text: You have to believe that somebody really had it in for the Scott sisters, Jamie and Gladys. They have always insisted that they had nothing to do with a robbery that occurred near the small town of Forest, Miss., on Christmas Eve in 1993. It was not the kind of crime to cause a stir. No one was hurt and perhaps $11 was taken.

headline: The Latest Crisis
text: Another crisis is roiling American-Pakistani relations after NATO helicopters mistakenly fired on a border post and killed Pakistani soldiers last month. Islamabad then closed a major supply line for NATO troops in Afghanistan; last week, extremists torched fuel trucks waiting at the border crossing. A new White House report said that Pakistan’s Army is refusing to go after Taliban groups targeting American forces.

headline: Politically Crude
text: Carl Paladino’s bigoted remarks about gay people were bad enough by themselves  another dip in his low-road campaign for governor of New York. But when you consider his timing, they were shockingly irresponsible.

headline: Justice Thomas and His Wife
text: Virginia Thomas, the wife of Justice Clarence Thomas of the Supreme Court, is the founder and chief executive of Liberty Central, a nonprofit organization set up to “restore the greatness of America,” in part by opposing the leftist “tyranny” of President Obama and Democrats in Congress. Its first contributions of $500,000 and $50,000 came from undisclosed donors. The size of those gifts, their anonymity and their importance to the organization raise a serious issue of ethics for Justice Thomas.

headline: A Nobel Prize for Peter Diamond
text: It has been a big year for Peter Diamond, 70, the renowned professor of economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. In April, Mr. Diamond was nominated by President Obama to serve on the seven-member board of governors of the Federal Reserve. On Monday, he became one of three recipients of this year’s Nobel in economic science.

headline: Baseball Replay: Oct. 11
text: The San Francisco Giants edged the Atlanta Braves 3-2 to clinch the National League Division Series 3-1.

headline: Bloggingheads: Christians and Gay Rights
text: Sarah Posner, left, of Religion Dispatches and Robert Jones of the Public Religion Research Institute discuss changing public opinion of gay rights.

headline: Jets Replay: Week 5
text: Images from the Jets’ game against Brett Favre and the Minnesota Vikings at New Meadowlands Stadium.

headline: Defense Seeks Mistrial in Synagogue Bomb Case
text: Lawyers for four men charged in a plot to bomb Bronx synagogues and shoot down military planes asked the judge in the case on Monday to declare a mistrial because jurors were allowed to see evidence that was not admitted during the trial.

headline: News Quiz | October 12, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Test Yourself | English, Oct. 12, 2010
text: Test your reading comprehension skills with today’s question, created by Danielle Hoagland and Judith McCaffrey at Grammarlogues from the Times article “Doctor’s Orders: Eat Well to Be Well.”

headline: Sorkin: Worrying Over China and Food
text: The prospect that a group backed by China may make a takeover offer for the Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan that rivals a $38.6 billion hostile bid from BHP Billiton has Washington lawmakers, Canadian regulators and Wall Street bankers talking, The New York Times’s Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his latest DealBook column.

headline: Jets Win Fourth Straight, Spoiling Favre’s Return
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Jets and Minnesota Vikings endured two lightning delays before the first snap on Monday night and finished the strangest of slugfests early Tuesday morning. In between, Brett Favre made history, Randy Moss made his Vikings’ debut and Darrelle Revis made his return to the Jets defense.

headline: In Hungary, Mogul Finds Fertile Area for Software
text: On a whim, Michael Simon sprinted off to Hungary after finishing business school in St. Louis. Twenty years later, he has carved out an unusual niche as perhaps Hungary’s most successful software entrepreneur, Ashlee Vance reports in The New York Times.

headline: Analysis: A Foreclosure Tightrope for Democrats
text: The swelling outcry over fast-and-loose foreclosures has thrust the Obama administration back into the uncomfortable position of sheltering the banking industry from the demands of an angry public, Binyamin Appelbaum writes in The New York Times.

text: C. J. Chivers, a Times correspondent and frequent contributor to At War, often from his embeds in Afghanistan, has written a book, “The Gun,” that is being released on Oct. 12. He will be answering readers’ questions over the next several days. Please submit your questions below in the comments box.  UPDATE: Follow the Q&A here.

headline: Citi Cuts Foreclosure Work With Investigated Firm
text: Citigroup said it stopped steering foreclosure work to a Florida law firm whose court filings to support home seizures were under investigation by the state’s attorney general, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: A Disputed Nobel Peace Prize
text: WHO is Liu Xiaobo?

headline: French Strikes Disrupt Air and Rail Travel
text: PARIS  In the latest expression of discontent over government austerity moves across Europe, French transport and energy workers, teachers and civil servants took to the streets on Tuesday to protest plans to reform the country’s pension system  the third such strike here in just over a month.

headline: Japanese Company to Buy iPhone Game Developer
text: DeNA, the Japanese social gaming giant, said Tuesday that it would acquire Ngmoco, a Silicon Valley iPhone game developer, for $400 million — one of the largest deals ever involving an iPhone application developer and another sign that the iPhone is fast becoming the hottest gaming device on the market.

headline: The Ghetto, the Nazis and One Small Boy
text: They are photographs that crystallize moments of our shared history: the exuberance and relief of victory captured by an American sailor bending over to plant a kiss on a woman in a white dress in the swirl of Times Square on Aug. 14, 1945; the horror of savage weapons seen on the anguished face of a 9-year-old Vietnamese girl fleeing down a road after a napalm attack; the terror produced by a monstrous tyranny as a child with a newsboy’s cap raises his arms in surrender during a roundup of Warsaw Jews.

headline: France Hits Back at U.S. on Hedge Fund Rules
text: The French economy minister, Christine Lagarde, rebuffed United States criticism that demands for tough new European Union rules on hedge funds were protectionist but she also extended an olive branch, signaling she was ready to compromise, Reuters reported.

headline: How Do Your Parents Teach You to Behave?
text: Two recent Times articles suggest that some behavior of concern to schools – bullying among elementary-school children and lack of responsibility-taking among high school students – is, at least partly, driven by parents. Have you witnessed students who are apparently emboldened by their parents to mistreat others or flout rules? What do your parents teach you about how to treat your peers and act at school?

headline: Is Diageo Rooting for Ackman Against Fortune?
text: From Reuters Breakingviews:

headline: Is Wall Street on Track for Record Pay?
text: 7:46 a.m. | Updated Total Wall Street compensation is on pace to reach $144 billion for 2010, a record for the second consecutive year, a study by The Wall Street Journal finds .

headline: Liverpool Court Battle Starts as New Bid Looms
text: The legal battle to force Tom Hicks and George Gillett Jr. to sell Liverpool F.C. to New England Sports Ventures, which also owns the Boston Red Sox and is run by the hedge fund manager John W. Henry, reaches London’s High Court on Tuesday, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Petronas Chemicals Plans $4 Billion I.P.O.
text: Petronas Chemicals is looking to raise as much as $4 billion (£2.5 billion) in a Malaysian initial public offering, exceeding earlier estimates of over $2 billion as it hopes to tap strong global investor demand for Asian stocks, Reuters reported.

headline: California Selects Buyer for 11 State Properties
text: California announced Monday it was selling 24 government office buildings — including the Ronald Reagan State Building in Los Angeles and the San Francisco Civic Center — to a group of private investors for $2.3 billion.

headline: BlackRock Still Bullish on India and China
text: BlackRock, the world’s biggest asset manager, expects many countries to impose capital controls on “hot money,” predicting the foreign fund flows to Asia that have pushed up regional currencies to continue for the next six months.

headline: Ukraine Bus Driver Pulls Into Train Path, Killing 41
text: MOSCOW  Ignoring flashing lights, a warning siren and the terrified screams of passengers, the driver of a commuter bus in central Ukraine pulled into the path of an oncoming train on Tuesday, Ukrainian officials said, causing a crash that killed at least 41 people, including 3 children, and left at least 10 people in critical condition.

headline: Calpers Cuts Ties With Adviser Hit by ‘Pay to Play’
text: 1:19 p.m. | Updated

headline: A New ‘Asylum’ for Prague Cyclists
text: Cracked cobblestones, hurried drivers and a dearth of bike lanes make cycling in the center of Prague a perilous affair. The self-proclaimed bike activist Martin Kontra wants this to change.

headline: The Spousal Safety Net
text: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts Amherst.

headline: Bonus Time May Not Come Early for Wall St. Banks
text: Large Wall Street banks are unlikely to accelerate bonus payouts, even if doling out bonuses in December would cut the tax bills of employees, Reuters said, citing compensation experts.

headline: Rival Bidders Join to Buy Sea Island for $212 Million
text: Competing bidders ended up banding together Monday to negotiate a deal to jointly buy the Sea Island Company for $212.4 million at an auction intended to settle the Georgia luxury resort operator’s bankruptcy case, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Lions Gate Said to Propose Merger With MGM
text: Lions Gate Entertainment has made a merger proposal to bankrupt film studio Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, The Los Angeles Times reported, citing people close to the matter.  Carl C. Icahn, a major backer of Lions Gate, was previously reported to be urging such a move.

headline: EDF Said Prepared to Back Constellation Sale
text: Electricite de France, the largest shareholder in Constellation Energy Group, would support the sale of the company as relations between the partners sour, Bloomberg News reported, citing a person with knowledge of the matter.

headline: Punch Taverns to Sell 1,300 Pubs
text: Punch Taverns, a British operator of more than 6,700 pubs, said it would accelerate plans to dispose of weaker outlets and focus on food, news that pushed its shares down the most since May, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Obama Message in Flux as Election Day Nears
text: With three weeks left until Election Day, President Obama holds the Democratic Party’s biggest political weapon: the White House megaphone.

headline: What Exactly Is a ‘Coachable’ Entrepreneur?
text: Previously, Catherine Mott, an angel investor, stressed the importance of investing in “coachable” entrepreneurs who surround themselves with solid management teams. As chief executive and founder of BlueTree Allied Angels in Wexford, Pa., Ms. Mott says she knows one when she sees one. But during a recent conversation, I asked her to try to specify what she looks for when investing in start-ups. A condensed version of our conversation follows.

headline: Apology and Interception for Favre
text: A decisive late-game interception almost seemed like a Brett Favre cliche, but the second half of Vikings-Jets and the off-the-field happenings did not lack spice. Let’s go to the links:

headline: Investors Pour $11 Billion into Hedge Funds in Aug.
text: Hedge funds received net deposits in August of $11.3 billion, the largest since February, as investors increased their appetite for risk, Bloomberg News reported, citing data from TrimTabs Investment Research and BarclayHedge.

headline: Icahn’s Stock Buy Suggests Battle for Dynegy
text: Hedge fund filings show that investors like Carl C. Icahn and Douglas A. Hirsch are betting on Blackstone upping its $4.7 billion bid for Dynegy, and may put up a fight if it resists.

headline: Are Activist Investors Primed for a Rebound?
text: Is it comeback time for activist investors?

headline: Cairn Chairman Admonishes India on Vedanta Deal
text: Cairn Energy chairman, Bill Gammell, has said that the way the India government deals with the proposed $9.6 billion sale of his company’s Indian energy business to Vedanta will be a key pointer for future foreign investment in the country, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Harbin Chief and Baring Team Up on Buyout Bid
text: The chief executive of Harbin Electric and Baring Private Equity Asia Group have teamed up to table a buyout bid that values the Chinese producer of electric motors at $752.2 million.

headline: An Undersea Trench for Wind Power?
text: In Tuesday’s paper, I write about a proposal for a 350-mile undersea cable system that would carry energy from numerous Atlantic wind farms back to shore. It presents some interesting technical twists.

headline: Private Equity-Backed I.P.O.’s Hit Slow Down
text: Bankers who hoped for a rush of private equity-backed initial public offerings this year may have to rein in their expectations.

headline: Jets Are Good, but Super Bowl Good?

headline: The ‘Back to the Future’ That Might Have Been
text: The “Back to the Future” films have given us glimpses of times and places that could have been, from a comical 2015 populated with flying cars and hovering skateboards to an alternate 1955 where Michael J. Fox invented rock ‘n’ roll. But how might history have turned out if the first “Back to the Future” movie had starred Eric Stoltz, as its filmmakers originally planned? In this clip from the “Back to the Future” 25th Anniversary DVD collection, the director Robert Zemeckis, his co-screenwriter, Bob Gale, and executive producer Steven Spielberg discuss how they made the heavy if cinematically momentous decision to replace Mr. Stoltz with Mr. Fox, and show early footage that was shot with Mr. Stoltz in the role of Marty McFly.

headline: U.S. and China Soften Tone Over Disputed Seas
text: HANOI, Vietnam  The United States and China sought to defuse tensions over disputed territorial seas on Tuesday, with Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates urging nations to honor historic rights of free transit through international waters and his Chinese counterpart saying the region had nothing to fear from Beijing’s armed forces.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: –From Slate’s review of The Social Network: Aaron “Sorkin explains that the filmmakers went to great pains to discern what “kind of beer [Facebook‘s founder, Mark Zuckerberg] was drinking on a Tuesday night in October seven years ago.” In reality, the name of the beer —Beck’s — can be uncovered with a simple Google search. Sorkin’s sincerity is harder to locate.”

headline: Varvatos Said to Seek Buyers
text: John Varvatos, the hip menswear label currently owned by the VF Corporation, is in talks with potential buyers about taking over the company and helping pay off its debt, The New York Post reported Tuesday, citing unnamed sources.

headline: In Greece, Repayment Talk Drives Bonds
text: LONDON  With its austerity program well under way, Greece held a successful bond sale on Tuesday amid a growing debate about whether the country should be given more time to repay the international bailout loans that saved it from bankruptcy.

headline: Payard Chef to Take Over Benoit
text: Philippe Bertineau, who had been the executive chef at Payard Patisserie and Bistro, which closed in 2009, and had more recently been at Balthazar, will take over the kitchen at Benoit, Alain Ducasse’s restaurant in Midtown, a branch of a venerable Paris bistro. He will start on Oct. 25, replacing Pierre Schaedelin, who was the chef and a partner, and who will be pursuing other ventures. Mr. Bertineau plans to revise Benoit’s menu, adding dishes like an upside-down cheese souffle and crispy pig’s trotters.

headline: No Twin Discrimination, but No Special Treatment, Either
text: By multiplying every daily parenting difficulty by two, raising twins can be a tough business. So it was with a feeling of adding insult to injury that Susannah Meadows wrote about her dispiriting experience with “twin discrimination” at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden in last week’s Complaint Box.

headline: TriBeCa Bar Will Have Its Own Iceworks
text: Weather Up, Kathryn Weatherup’s latest eponymously named cocktail bar — set to open at 159 Duane Street in TriBeCa in early November — is one saloon that will never have to send out for ice.

headline: Play Inspired by Beckett Heading to His Turf
text: It’s perhaps fitting for a play inspired by Samuel Beckett that a) its life seems to just go on and on and b) it will soon be performed in Dublin, where Beckett was born. “Krapp, 39,” the solo show written and performed by Michael Laurence that was presented in the New York International Fringe Festival in 2008 and Off Broadway for a critically lauded extended run in 2009 will be staged in Dublin and London this fall.

headline: Beijing Calls Nobel Insult To People Of China
text: BEIJING  The Chinese government continued its vilification campaign against the awarding of the Nobel Peace Prize to a jailed dissident, Liu Xiaobo, by canceling another meeting with Norwegian officials and denouncing the award as an affront to the Chinese people and a ploy to try to change the country’s political system.

headline: Urban Fervor: ’30 Rock’ Shares Details of Its Live Episode
text: What can we tell you about Thursday’s episode of “30 Rock”? Not much more than what NBC has been saying since the summer: for the first time, the show will tap into the “Saturday Night Live” experience of its creator and star, Tina Fey, and co-stars like Alec Baldwin and Tracy Morgan, and will be performed live at the show’s namesake headquarters in Manhattan (instead of being filmed at its familiar studios in Long Island City). What can Robert Carlock tell you about the live episode? Probably a whole lot more since he’s an executive producer and show runner of “30 Rock,” not to mention an “SNL” veteran himself.

headline: At Home in the World
text: When did Italian design take over the world? Suddenly, it’s everywhere: in hotels from Milan (of course) to Tokyo; in shops, restaurants and airport lounges; and even at The New York Times, where cutting-edge Italian furniture can be found throughout the building. At a time in which design has become more international than ever — provocateurs from the Netherlands, Japan and Brazil are just a few of the players who’ve shared the field in the last decade — Italy’s reach is global.

headline: Singapore Billionaire Makes Rival Bid for Liverpool

headline: From Brooklyn to the Stratosphere
text: The Science section has a profile this morning of Luke Geissbühler, the cinematographer from Park Slope and mastermind of the archly named Brooklyn Space Program who launched a weather balloon attached to a video camera from a park near Newburgh, N.Y. The balloon reached an altitude of 100,000 feet and took some amazing NASA-like footage before tumbling back to earth. Read the article in Science.

headline: Justices Turn Down Appeal Over Speech Ejections

headline: Trapped 68 Days, First Chilean Miners Taste Freedom

Glenn Close, who has three Tony Awards (“Sunset Boulevard”) and three Emmys (“Damages”) to her name, will play Dr. Emma Brookner, the physician in a wheelchair who anticipates the AIDS epidemic and encourages the central character, Ned Weeks (to be played by Joe Mantello), to warn others of the disease.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘Walkabout’
text: A.O. Scott explores how life in the modern world can sometimes make us long for simpler times with this week’s Critics’ Pick, “Walkabout.” This Nicholas Roeg film tells the story of a teenage girl and her brother who are abandoned by their father in the middle of the Australian desert. They are befriended and saved by a young Aborigine. Mr. Scott is captivated by the film’s visual beauty, but beyond that he says “Roeg uses the camera; wide shots, close-ups, colors and textures; to create a sense of unmediated perception as if we were seeing the world for the very first time.” Have you seen “Walkabout?” Please share your thoughts.

headline: Jerry Seinfeld and Colin Quinn Prepare for Broadway, Trade Quips, Yada Yada Yada
text: You didn’t think Jerry Seinfeld‘s directorial debut would just quietly tiptoe its way onto Broadway, did you? On Tuesday afternoon, he and Colin Quinn, the star and writer of “Colin Quinn Long Story Short,” which Mr. Seinfeld is directing for its coming run at the Helen Hayes Theater, convened at the Snapple Theater Center in Midtown Manhattan, ostensibly to offer a preview of the show to journalists but primarily to crack jokes about the production and each other. The give-and-take between Mr. Quinn and Mr. Seinfeld, conducted on the stage where “The Fantasticks” is performed, was moderated by Anderson Cooper, the CNN and CBS news personality, who proved pretty adept with the one-liners himself.

headline: The Fabric of Her Life | Louise Bourgeois at Hauser & Wirth
text: Louise Bourgeois was reportedly a notorious hoarder. The artist, who died this year at the age of 98, accumulated all manner of tablecloths, napkins, clothing and bed linens — a lifetime’s worth of material, really — which she began to cut up and reassemble into “drawings” in the mid-1990s. Her Collyer Brothers tendencies aside, Bourgeois no doubt found precarious comfort in the nest of this critical mass; she grew up surrounded by textiles in her parents’ tapestry restoration workshop, and the act of sewing, she said, was her attempt to keep things together and make them whole. In this context, the more than 70 pieces in “Louise Bourgeois: The Fabric Works,” an exhibition that aptly christens Hauser & Wirth‘s new space on Savile Row in London, are as poignant as they are vibrant. But taken purely at face value, these pieces make one lament the fact that Bourgeois never moonlighted as a textile designer.

headline: More Retail Buyout Chatter: Is OfficeMax Next?

headline: Pairings: Short Ribs in Broth With Squash and Shiitakes
text: It was definitely autumn. We were to be guests at a dinner party, the first of the season, at which the hostess set the table indoors. I would bring the main course for eight to accompany several bottles of zinfandels from Sonoma.

headline: Zinfandel Steps Back From the Abyss
text: SAD to say, I don’t drink much zinfandel these days. That wasn’t always the case. When I first awakened to the joys of wine back in the 1980s, I was excited about zinfandel. All right, I was excited about any wine, but zinfandel in particular intrigued me. It was full of gorgeous fruit, yet rarely too tannic or too sweet. The grape was singular, grown almost nowhere but in California. It was pure pleasure, and I remember enjoying many wonderful bottles with friends.

Diners were tucking into yellowfin tuna ribbons or gently smoked squab, talking cheerfully as staff members padded silently through the elegant, carpeted room.

Among those employees whose sentences were announced Tuesday was Mohsen Shaalan, a deputy culture minister who heads the fine arts division of the ministry.

headline: New Tool to Test Home Listings
text: ZipRealty, a nationwide residential real estate brokerage, recently released a new tool on its Web site aimed at helping potential home sellers decide whether to put their home on the market.

headline: More Power, Less Fuel? It Can Be Done With Gas
text: FOR now, the internal combustion engine is holding its own.

headline: A Tarnished Anniversary for the Suburban
text: An anniversary can be such a fabulous thing, although there is always the concern that something will tarnish it. And that brings us to the 75th anniversary of the Chevrolet Suburban.

headline: Organic, Slow or Local: Exploring Food-Based Communities
text: Overview | How do communities and beliefs shape how and what people eat? And conversely, how do food values and preferences help people find and create communities? In this lesson, students examine communities that come together around shared beliefs about food and food production, and then construct their own philosophy of food.

headline: Honoring Sutherland Via Satellite Radio
text: The Metropolitan Opera is honoring Joan Sutherland, who died on Sunday, with a full day of broadcasts of her recordings. The live recordings, taken from the Met’s archives of its radio transmissions, can be heard this coming Sunday on the house’s Sirius XM channel. They will range from a “Lucia di Lammermoor” of 1961 to a “Trovatore” of 1987, and include performances of “La Sonnambula,” “Norma,” “I Puritani” and “Esclarmonde.” The Met also said it was dedicating its performance of “Les Contes d’Hoffmann” Tuesday night to the soprano.

headline: Where Are the N.R.A.’s Ads? Everywhere.
text: All this talk of newfangled outside groups receiving money from anonymous donors has overshadowed some of the more traditional players. But one of them, the National Rifle Association, is coming in big.

headline: D’Antoni Adjusts Knicks’ Game-Day Schedule
text: The Knicks will probably not win an N.B.A. championship this season, but at least they can dream about it, without an alarm clock disrupting their R.E.M. cycles.

headline: Chamber of Commerce Vows to ‘Ramp Up’ Political Activity
text: The president of the U.S. Chamber of Commerce vowed Tuesday to “ramp up” his group’s political activity in the face of what he called a “smear campaign” by the White House aimed at stemming Democratic losses in the midterm elections.

headline: Muti’s Ailment Said to Be Caused by Exhaustion and Stress
text: Exhaustion and stress were behind the stomach pains that caused Riccardo Muti to cancel two weeks of concerts at the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, the orchestra said on Tuesday. Mr. Muti, who is in his first season as the orchestra’s music director, flew to Italy on Oct. 4 to consult with his doctors in Milan and undergo tests.

headline: Silicon Valley’s Solar Innovators Retool to Catch Up to China
text: FREMONT, Calif.  A few years ago, Silicon Valley start-ups like Solyndra, Nanosolar and MiaSolé dreamed of transforming the economics of solar power by reinventing the technology used to make solar panels and deeply cutting the cost of production.

headline: Hail Got Our Attention, but It Could Have Been Worse
text: Grapes. Gumballs. Molars and rabbit droppings. But thankfully, not pumpkins.

headline: A Winning Formula for Nascar
text: BOB LATFORD was a genial public relations man with a battered, bulging briefcase, a love for auto racing and the ability to crunch numbers with only the aid of a ballpoint pen and a stack of bar napkins  or so the famous story goes.

headline: Nice Supercar. Now Eat My Dust.
text: ULTRA high-powered sports cars  supercars  are considered by many to be the highest expressions of vehicular performance. Schoolboys, young and otherwise, dream of Ferrari Enzos, Porsche Carrera GTs, Lamborghini Gallardos, Ford GTs and Corvette ZR1s.

headline: Ellen’s Lemon Basil Salad Dressing
text: Ellen Greenblatt, a friend who lives in Berkeley, Calif., shared this recipe with me. Toss a green salad with this dressing, and no additional herbs will be necessary. It is perfect for chicken salad or drizzled over a cooked chicken breast; use it over shrimp, salmon or sliced tomatoes.

headline: Ruthless Czar, Haunted by Doubts
text: It would not have been surprising if the director Stephen Wadsworth had said “No, thanks” when the Metropolitan Opera contacted him in July to rescue the company’s new production of Mussorgsky’s “Boris Godunov.” This was to have been the Met debut of the renowned German director Peter Stein. The concept and designs had long been settled on, and the sets and costumes were nearly completed when, three months ago, in a huff that seemed from all reports unwarranted, Mr. Stein quit, citing frustration with bureaucratic complications regarding his visa.

headline: Chile Mine Rescue Operation Complete
text: After more than two excruciating months, the rescue of the 33 Chilean miners trapped in a collapsed mine is complete.

headline: Detroit Refueled
text: IT wasn’t long ago that American consumers were wondering whether Detroit’s troubled auto companies would survive, much less prosper again.

headline: Phillies Beat Yankees, in Ticket Price

headline: The Morning Skate: Early Days, Many Controversies
text: The N.H.L. season is not yet a week old, but controversy is in midseason form. If you think there’s as much to cry about as cheer about so far, well, you’ve got company. The Panthers, for example, felt victimized in their season opener Sunday against the Oilers when Shawn Horcoff looked to perhaps kick the winning goal in with his right skate (at about 1:25 in the video below, and sorry for the   commercial) …

headline: Dodd Backs Warren for Consumer Bureau, but…
text: Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut and one of the architects of the Dodd-Frank financial regulatory law, said Tuesday that the White House was likely to nominate a director for the new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau in the coming days, but he was doubtful that a nominee would be confirmed before the new Congress takes over in January.

headline: Provençal Tomato and Basil Soup
text: I learned to make this soup years ago when I lived in France. If there are no fresh tomatoes at hand, use canned. The soup is delicious and silky if you thicken it with tapioca.

text: This past weekend, the N.F.L. swirled pink into their sweat bands and quarterback hats, shoes and jerseys to raise awareness of breast cancer.

headline: The Samurai Shopper | My Favorite Nose
text: Enthusiasts, gasbags and connoisseurs roam the cultural landscape with foghorns, advocating this, decrying that. We stay alert, in case profoundity happens. But yammering happens, too, and tempts us with clichés like de gustibus non est disputandum. There’s no accounting for taste, and taste depends on a variety of factors. One man’s pork belly is another man’s tempeh.

headline: Making the Dream Trip a Reality
text: IT’S a dream anyone with a passport fantasizes about once in a while: ditching everything to travel the world for a year, or at least long enough to forget about office life.

headline: Why Don’t Republicans Believe in Climate Change?
text: Ron Brownstein and Bill McKibben both have pieces up lamenting the ascendancy of climate change skepticism in the Republican Party. While McKibben ponders the intellectual roots of this phenomenon (a subject I touched on, as he notes, in a column earlier this year), Brownstein points out that the G.O.P. is an outlier among the developed world’s right-of-center parties:

headline: Anatomy of a Roach Attack
text: It is among the worst nightmares of diners and restaurateurs: a roach on the table. When it happens, there are screams. And so there were at Jean Georges on Monday night. But then a finely honed roach-removal-and-memory-erasing plan went into effect. Free Champagne was involved. City Room pal Sam Sifton, over at Diner’s Journal, recounts the incident in all its creepy, crawly detail. Go read it.

headline: Defendant in Court for Hearing at Ft. Hood
text: FORT HOOD, Tex.  Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan returned Tuesday to Fort Hood in a wheelchair and combat fatigues for a pretrial hearing 11 months after he opened fire in a base processing center, killing 13 people and wounding 32 more.

headline: Latest Updates on the Rescue of the Chilean Miners
text: On Tuesday and Wednesday, The Lede provided updates in real time on the final stage of the rescue of 33 Chilean miners whose entrapment in a collapsed mine shaft ended after 69 days. The live coverage included a video feed from the mine (now concluded) and reports from our colleagues Simon Romero and Alexei Barrionuevo, who were at the San José mine, near the Chilean city of Copiapó, along with family members of the miners and more than 1,400 journalists. To follow the rescue as it unfolded, read up the page below.

headline: Schwarzenegger Endorses Crist
text: Modern love is expressed via Twitter, and so it was that California’s governor, Arnold Schwarzenegger, tweeted his affection for Florida’s governor and embattled Senate candidate, Charlie Crist, while in London.

headline: At Stadium, but Far From Roar of Crowd
text: Everybody likes to go behind the scenes. About half the fun of being a journalist is having somebody open a door and give you a story or a fact.

headline: Explosives Found in Cemetery Are Many Years Old
text: The C-4 explosives recovered in an East Village cemetery over the weekend were made more than a dozen years ago, initial police tests show.

headline: Howard Jacobson Wins Booker Prize
text: The Manchester-born author Howard Jacobson won the Man Booker Prize, Britain’s most prestigious literary award, on Tuesday night for “The Finkler Question,” a witty novel about a friendship between a radio producer and a philosopher and the questions of religion it brings. Mr. Jacobson, 68, beat out “C,” by Tom McCarthy, widely considered the favorite to win. The Man Booker Prize is given every year to a novel by an author in Britain, Ireland or the Commonwealth nations.

headline: SarahPAC Spreads Its Wealth
text: Sarah Palin’s political action committee raised more than $1.2 million during the last three months, giving her the freedom to spread her wealth to like-minded candidates.

headline: Obama’s Haste On Resumed Offshore Drilling
text: In the face of America’s oil addiction two things seem to fade fast — the wallet shock of $4-a-gallon gasoline and the political impact of an oil spill, once it’s stanched.

headline: In Ethiopia, a System Built to Go the Distance
text: When Haile Gebrselassie, the world-record holder from Ethiopia, competes in the New York City Marathon on Nov. 7, he will be both a star and a growing anachronism.

headline: What to Do About Phantom Charges on Your Phone Bill
text: The news of Verizon’s “phantom charges” and pending consumer payout has sent smart consumers to pore over their phone bills. But before your blood pressure peaks, be aware that one apparent phantom charge is harmless and carries no cost, though another, which appears to be a scam, shouldn’t be ignored.

headline: Who’s the Unnamed and Frustrated Wall St. Chief?
text: It doesn’t take an in-depth investigation to figure out that many top Wall Street executives aren’t too pleased with the Obama administration. But who’d be so bold as to venture their opinion semi-publicly?

headline: Young Patriots
text: Like a latter-day John Hughes, Hedi Slimane is smitten with American adolescence. Since moving to Los Angeles after stepping down as the influential designer of Dior Homme, Slimane has exalted an idealized version of youth in his myriad photography and art projects. In “I Love U.S.A.,” a new video shot exclusively for the fashion e-commerce site thecorner.com, Slimane turns his lens on two teenagers he discovered at the Coachella rock festival. The premise of the improvised storyline is undeniably abstruse — the star-crossed lovers are a confused cheerleader and her cello-playing paramour, who wears a wolf mask — but as tender as any lingering shot of Molly Ringwald’s face.

headline: 'La Bete'
text: Mark Rylance, David Hyde Pierce and Stephen Ouimette in an excerpt from the Broadway revival of David Hirson's play. (Video courtesy of the production)

headline: Attention, Ladies: After Heartbreak Can Come Redemption
text: Mary J Blige lives to sing about obstacles overcome, so maybe she was just setting herself one more obstacle with the way she built her set at Radio City Music Hall on Monday night.

headline: Fame to Affect Adjustments for Miners
text: The ordinary miners are long gone, left behind in another lifetime.

headline: A Wall of Coverage Planned for Mine Rescue
text: Cable news networks in the United States are on standby for the mine rescue in Chile that has captured the world’s attention, and some say they will provide wall-to-wall coverage when the rescues are under way.

headline: The Broadway That’s Forever Buoyant
text: Exclamations of adoration regularly erupted at Friday’s opening-night performance of Marilyn Maye’s new show, “Her Own Kind of Broadway,” at the packed Metropolitan Room. Ms. Maye, who at 82 personifies a hardy, upbeat show-business trouper, swung Broadway standards in a dark, honeyed voice untouched by the years; she even shimmied and executed a single high kick precisely timed to a drumbeat.

headline: Evolving Movements That Flow Through Time and Into Infinity
text: The premise of Russell Dumas’s “dance for the time being,” performed at the Baryshnikov Arts Center on Sunday, is that it is not the finite, finished artwork that we, as audiences, are accustomed to seeing (or at least think that we’re seeing). Not that “dance” is anything but polished and accomplished. Its smoothly unfolding flow of movement holds no improvisation or uncertainty.

headline: Casting an Opponent as ‘The Taxman’
text: Chris Coons is… The Taxman.

headline: Baroque Style’s Evolution Is Traced Across Europe
text: Last year the Juilliard School had some listeners puzzling over the name of its new resident period-instrument ensemble, JuilliArd415, which plays on the A in Juilliard and the fact that a common Baroque tuning put the pitch of an A at 415 cycles per second rather than at the higher, modern pitch, 440.

text: Chase Stuart contributes to the Pro-Football-Reference.com blog and to Footballguys.com.

headline: After Paladino’s Remarks, a Barrage of Comments
text: Earlier this week, Carl P. Paladino, the Republican candidate for New York governor, defended comments he had made criticizing homosexuality, including some in which he said the city’s gay pride parade was not a place for children — he said the parade featured participants “grinding at each other and doing these gyrations,” something he called “disgusting.”

headline: Amazon Introduces a Format for Shorter E-Books
text: E-readers and smartphones have brought big changes to the publishing industry, but Amazon.com is aiming to bring some more with a new format for shorter and cheaper e-books.

text: Jay-Z is looking for an encore.

headline: Japanese Game Maker on a Buying Spree
text: TOKYO  DeNA, a Japanese social game company, said on Tuesday that it would acquire Ngmoco, a Silicon Valley iPhone game developer, for $400 million  one of the largest deals involving an iPhone software company and another sign that Apple’s products are fast becoming the hottest mobile game devices on the market.

headline: The Necessity of Conservation, and of Eating Ripe, Green Bananas
text: The capital city of the Solomon Islands, Honiara, really ticks to a different clock. For all its hustle and bustle, rattling trucks, scampering feet, laughter and clamor, Honiara is on Solomon time. As hard as you may try to keep a tight schedule, time in the Solomons tends to open up and swallow itself.

headline: George Clooney at the White House
text: Rarely has the power of a celebrity to draw attention to an issue exerted such a pull as on Tuesday, when White House reporters called an end to the daily briefing by press secretary Robert Gibbs to catch the actor George Clooney as he left a meeting with President Obama about the crisis in Sudan.

headline: Interstellar
text: The Theory of Interstellar Trade has now been published, 32 years late.

headline: Plan B Turns Out to Be Fastest Path for Rescue
text: In the days immediately after the discovery that 33 workers trapped at the San José Mine were alive, Chilean officials cautioned that it might take up to four months to reach them with a rescue hole.

headline: From Waitress to Brother’s Savior, Then Hollywood Hero
text: BRISTOL, R.I.  Betty Anne Waters still greets her lunch customers here as they tuck into pints of Guinness and Reuben sandwiches at Aidan’s, a pub hard by the harbor in this small, boat-building town.

headline: Blackface and Bigotry, Finely Tuned
text: NO star actors. (Check.) A complex cast of characters. (Check.) A plot based on a low moment in American history. (Check.) Songs that satirize racism, anti-Semitism, and execution by electric chair. (Check.) And all told by resurrecting one of theater’s most controversial storytelling devices, the minstrel show. (Check.)

headline: Europe Considers a Curb on Deepwater Drilling
text: LONDON  As the United States lifted its moratorium on deepwater oil drilling Tuesday, the European Commission was on the verge of proposing a curb on drilling in extreme conditions until an inquiry into the causes of the fatal explosion at a BP rig in the Gulf of Mexico was completed.

headline: Pushing the Spotlight Away From Herself
text: UNLIKE most playwrights, who get to hide in the back of the theater on opening night  if not in a bar around the corner  Lisa Kron has spent most of her career performing in her own plays, which have frequently been autobiographical, including “2.5 Minute Ride,” about her father, and “Well,” about her perpetually unwell but nonetheless redoubtable mother, which had a Broadway run in 2006.

headline: ‘Memphis’ Box Office Surpasses $1 Million Mark
text: Ever since winning the Tony Award for best musical in June, “Memphis” has been rising in box-office rankings of Broadway, and last week the show passed a milestone: “Memphis” grossed more than $1 million for the standard eight performances for the first time since previews began on Sept. 23, 2009.

headline: A Multitasking Nun in Medieval Germany
text: “Vision,” Margarethe von Trotta’s sympathetic imagining of the life of the 12th-century Benedictine nun Hildegard von Bingen, opens with a prologue that establishes a contemporary secular distance from the film’s devotional medieval ethos. The members of a millennialist sect anticipating their last night on earth prostrate themselves in an abbey overnight only to awaken in the bright morning sun to discover that the world hasn’t ended.

headline: A Final Rescue Phase
text: For the remaining trapped miners, a short trip to the surface is at hand.

headline: Xiao Ye
text: EIGHT in the evening at Xiao Ye, Eddie Huang’s new restaurant on Orchard Street on the Lower East Side, and hip-hop was bouncing off the black-painted walls of the long, narrow dining room. Young men and women ate dumplings and slurped noodles, drank Taiwanese beer. They talked smack about football and architecture, smartphones and music.

headline: How to Keep Facebook Groups From Taking Over Your Life
text: Last week, Facebook added a feature that seems years overdue: Members can now create small, private groups of friends.

headline: C.D.C. Girds for Climate Change
text: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention have announced their first-ever direct grants to states and cities to study the potential effects of climate change in the United States.

headline: Off the Menu
text: BAR BASQUE This sprawling restaurant in the Eventi Hotel, including an area with a roof that can roll back in Costa Brava weather, takes its Spanish food seriously. The executive chef, Yuhi Fujinaga (right), worked at Eighty One, Alain Ducasse and Lespinasse and, more to the point, in Spain. The à la carte menu emphasizes the Basque country but touches on other regions. Prix-fixe dinners will be prepared by guest chefs from Spain, starting with Daniel Garcia from Bilbao, from Thursday to Oct. 30. (Opens Thursday): 839 Avenue of the Americas (29th Street), (646) 600-7150.

headline: About as High Tech as a Pizza Stone Can Get
text: There’s a great deal to like about the Emile Henry ceramic pizza stone from France. It can hold a 12- to 14-inch pizza in the oven, on a grill or on a stove top. It is glazed to make removing the pizza easy and, with its handles, can go to the table (on a trivet). All that is without discussing the designer colors: fig, black, red and olive. The technology is said to leave a certain porosity in the material so dough moisture is absorbed, making for a crisper crust. At 425 degrees in the oven, the crust browns nicely without overcooking the topping. The stone even doubles as a plancha on the grill, withstanding up to about 700 degrees. The maker says the pizza can be cut directly on it without damaging the surface. With some hesitation, I tried it. Not a scratch.

headline: A Vegas Wedding for China and Mexico, Under the Chef José Andrés
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Fiber Meets Flavor in New Whole-Grain Pastas
text: I’VE made several concessions at my table in the name of good health, and most of them are positive. I like brown rice nearly as much as white, and a crusty whole-grain boule even more than most pale baguettes. Quinoa and millet have happily entered my dinner rotation, and whole-grain polenta is a sweet, corny delight.

headline: Tri Tip Grill
text: 30 Rockefeller Plaza (49th Street), Concourse Level, (212) 664-1003, tritipgrill.com.

headline: Pico de Gallo

headline: Jeffrey’s Grocery Lets You Sit and Eat
text: Restaurants with little market areas continue to proliferate. The latest, Jeffrey’s Grocery, opened by Gabriel Stulman and his partners, is serious and well stocked, with a little restaurant attached. It could almost be a movie set in its nostalgic perfection, were it not for the merchandise on display. Who had pink carrots in the old days? Purple potatoes? Bunches of lovage? Fat, round golden zucchini? The goods are from local farms, notably from Brooklyn Grange in Queens, and Cato Corner Farm in Colchester, Conn., which also supplies cheeses and veal. Free-range eggs come by the half-dozen in mixed colors. The shelves hold a well-edited selection of staples and condiments, including decidedly unlocal but delicious chocolate bars from Montreal. Some prepared foods  from the kitchen that supplies the raw bar, salads and sandwiches for the informal dining area beyond the retail store  are also sold. Who’s Jeffrey? It’s Mr. Stulman’s father. (The name of Mr. Stulman’s restaurant, Joseph Leonard, comes from his grandfathers.)

headline: San Matteo Pizza and Espresso Bar
text: 1739 Second Avenue (90th Street), (212) 426-6943.

headline: Fair Café Liqueur Has Elegant Coffee Flavor
text: Fair Café liqueur is not syrupy, like some others, but has an elegant, balanced flavor. The drink is distilled in the Cognac region of France, with coffee from a farmers’ cooperative near Chiapas in southern Mexico and Fair Trade sugar from Malawi. It’s good on its own after dinner, especially with some chocolates to nibble, and it can deepen the flavor of dark rum in a cocktail. Or soak raisins in it for garnishing coffee ice cream.

headline: Ties to Galleon Founder Tarnish a Legacy
text: Be careful who your friends and business associates are — especially if one of them is Raj Rajaratnam.

headline: How to Make the Grim Appear Artfully Beautiful
text: Jay Rosenblatt makes friendly art films. Their subject matter may be grim — suicide, grief, violence, murderous dictators — but his constructions of found footage and appropriated narration are inviting and accessible. Hence they turn up in mainstream environments like the Sundance Film Festival, Film Forum and Cinemax (where they’re called shorts or documentaries, “art” and “experimental” being words a programmer would rather not hear).

headline: Dancing With the Stars? Not if There’s Dancing in the End Zone
text: Football has become the blunt instrument of television ratings, pounding everything around it into mush. That point was proved again Monday night when an especially strong “Monday Night Football” game on cable’s ESPN, between the Jets and the Vikings (led by the scandal-tinged Brett Favre), dominated even the strongest night of network television.

headline: At Google, Mayer Takes a New Job
text: Marissa Mayer, who has been Google’s vice president of search products and user experience, has a new job — overseeing geographic and local services, the company announced Tuesday.

headline: Left Behind
text: A growing number of photographers are using their craft to document the hidden side of the foreclosure crisis.

headline: Perfect Dancing
text: Jennifer Grey (with Derek Hough, above), on Monday earned the first perfect 10’s  for her tango  from the judges this season on “Dancing With the Stars,” as that ABC reality series topped another night in the ratings with 19.8 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. The show lifted the network to first place over all. CBS ranked second, earning its best ratings in the hour at 9 for “Two and a Half Men” (13.2 million) and “Mike & Molly” (10.8 million). Fox was third, with “Lie to Me” (5.5 million), at 9. NBC placed fourth, earning its best results in that same hour with “The Event” (6.5 million).

headline: BP and Arco Stations to Get Electric Fast Chargers
text: The charging company ECOtality, which on Monday announced a plan to put chargers into 12 Best Buy stores on the West Coast, has a new partner: the oil company BP.

headline: The Obama Car Joke Gets Souped Up

headline: Howard Jacobson Wins Man Booker Prize for ‘The Finkler Question’
text: Howard Jacobson won the Man Booker Prize, Britain’s most prestigious literary award, on Tuesday night for “The Finkler Question,” a comic novel about friendship, wisdom and anti-Semitism.

headline: N.F.L. Backs Program for Ex-Players in Need
text: Almost exactly one year since Gay Culverhouse sat before a Congressional committee and blistered the N.F.L.’s treatment of its retired players, the league announced Tuesday that it would support her Players’ Outreach Program to help identify and assist former players in need.

headline: Hit in Face by Puck, Playing It Safe for Now
text: Ian Laperriere, the pugnacious 36-year-old forward for the Philadelphia Flyers, said this week that he would not play again until he felt better. Considering that Laperriere is the type of player who has often used his face to block slap shots, that is a big sacrifice.

headline: The Caucus Click: Huntersville, N.C.

headline: Top Architects Transform M.I.T.’s Campus

headline: Judge Orders U.S. Military to Stop ‘Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell’
text: A federal judge on Tuesday ordered the United States military to stop enforcing the “don’t ask, don’t tell” law that prohibits openly gay men and women from serving.

headline: M.I.T.’s Makeover for the 21st Century
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Not so long ago, the campus of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology was a hodgepodge of bunkerlike academic buildings, converted World War I-era factories, parking lots and even an occasional Quonset hut. But a 10-year development plan, nearly complete at a cost of $1.4 billion, has set a new mood  avant-garde  with 10 buildings by architects like Frank Gehry, Steven Holl and Fumihiko Maki, as well as a revamped streetscape.

headline: All 33 Miners Rescued
text: After a long and successful rescue operation, all of the miners and emergency workers have been removed from the mine.

headline: Arrest Expands Suspect Pool in Bronx Attacks
text: A 10th suspect has been arrested in an antigay attack that unfolded over two days in an unoccupied apartment in the Bronx, officials said on Tuesday.

headline: A Climate Proposal Beyond Cap and Trade
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Modest Gains for Democrats in Gubernatorial Forecast
text: Although we’ve been skeptical about the notion that the overall political environment has improved by any discernible margin for Democrats, there are some exceptions in gubernatorial elections around the country. In recent weeks, Democrats have moved into the lead in the gubernatorial race in California, while closing their deficits in other states where they once trailed badly. Likewise, while there were relatively few shifts in this week’s gubernatorial polls, the exceptions generally benefited Democrats.

headline: How to Spend on Clean-Energy Research
text: 11:51 a.m. | Updated with link to proposal from three institutes.

headline: North Korea: Leader’s Eldest Son Faults Power Transfer to Brother
text: The eldest son of the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-il, told Japanese television on Tuesday that he opposed the recently announced generational transfer of power to his younger half-brother. In a rare sign of discord within the secretive North Korean ruling family, Kim Jong-nam, 39, told TV Asahi that he is “against third-generational succession.” However, he also said there might have been unspecified internal factors that made the succession of his brother Kim Jong-un necessary. Once the presumed heir, Kim Jong-nam apparently fell out of favor after he was detained while trying to enter Japan on a false passport to visit Tokyo Disneyland. He now lives in China and Macao, where he gives interviews, but only for a hefty fee.

headline: Rising Corn Prices Bring Fears of an Upswing in Food Costs
text: First it was heat and drought in Russia. Then it was heat and too much rain in parts of the American Corn Belt. Extreme weather this year has sent grain prices soaring, jolting commodities markets and setting off fears of tight supplies that could eventually hit consumers’ wallets.

headline: How Marriage Survives
text: Washington

headline: Canada: Airline Dispute Causes Eviction From Arab Air Base
text: A dispute over airline landing rights has led to Canada’s eviction from an air base in the United Arab Emirates that is an important logistical hub for its military mission in Afghanistan, the Canadian defense minister, Peter MacKay, said Monday. Emirates officials said that continuing the lease was contingent on allowing Emirates Airline and Etihad Airways more than the current three flights each per week. Air Canada opposes additional flights, fearing the two airlines will use them to compete with Canadian air service to Asia, Europe or elsewhere in the Middle East.

headline: U.S. and Vietnam Build Ties With an Eye on China
text: HANOI, Vietnam  A visit to Vietnam this week by Robert M. Gates, the United States defense secretary, is just the latest step in a bilateral relationship that is at its warmest since diplomatic ties were established 15 years ago.

headline: Arrests of 2 Germans in Iran Take on Political Overtones
text: BERLIN  Germany and Iran faced off Tuesday over the case of two Germans arrested in Iran over the weekend while interviewing the son of a woman whose sentence to death by stoning raised an international uproar.

headline: At the Brooklyn Botanic Garden: Twins, Come On In!
text: To the Editor:

headline: Germany, Unscathed, Is in Eye of Terrorism Scare
text: HAMBURG, Germany  This wealthy port city advertises its bustling canals and bridges and its towering 19th-century churches to draw visitors from around the world.

headline: A Green Product, Laying Claim to the Yellow, Red and Orange
text: WHEN it comes to sponsorships, brands tend to attach their names to sporting events and arts festivals, but Marcal Small Steps, the paper products brand, has taken the unusual step of laying claim to a seasonal phenomenon, declaring itself the Official Sponsor of Fall Foliage.

headline: Sony Unveils the First Google TV
text: A new line of Sony televisions introduced Tuesday allows people to use the Internet while watching their favorite shows – minus the set-top box that competing systems require. And they will be the first TV’s on the market to run Google TV, Google’s new operating system for Internet-connected televisions.

headline: All Eyes (Especially the Yanks’) Are on Cliff Lee
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.

headline: The Troubled Tribune

headline: Knicks Will Now Be Excused From Meal
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  The Knicks probably will not win a championship this season, but at least they can dream about it, without an alarm clock disrupting their REM cycles.

headline: Paladino Apologizes for Remarks About Gays
text: BUFFALO  Carl P. Paladino, the Republican nominee for governor of New York, apologized on Tuesday for delivering comments that offended gay people, even as his campaign manager provoked a new controversy by calling the Democratic nominee, Andrew M. Cuomo, “oily.”

headline: U.S. Sues To Ensure Military Votes Are Counted
text: WASHINGTON  The Civil Rights Division of the Justice Department sued New York State on Tuesday to guarantee that state election officials take extra steps to count absentee ballots cast by military service members and other overseas voters in the Nov. 2 election.

headline: In West Bank, Peace Symbol Now Signifies Struggle
text: TURMUS AYA, West Bank  Palestinians from villages like this one in the West Bank governorate of Ramallah still remember when the olive harvest was a joyous occasion, with whole families out for days in the fall sunshine, gathering the year’s crop and picnicking under the trees.

headline: Military Base Likely Source of Explosives at a Cemetery
text: The mysterious military-grade explosives that were found in an East Village cemetery over the weekend are more than a dozen years old and were most likely stolen from a military base, the police said Tuesday.

headline: Civilian Cargo Plane Crashes in Mountains East of Kabul
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  A civilian cargo plane trying to land at Kabul’s international airport crashed into the nearby mountains Tuesday night, and Afghan and NATO officials said they feared that there were no survivors among the eight people aboard.

headline: Recipes for Pasta Dishes and Sauces
text: From The Times, more than three dozen ways to adorn your pasta.

headline: A Long Road Ahead in Regaining Lost Jobs
text: At the current pace of job growth, it will take years to recover all the jobs lost since Dec. 2007.

headline: Across the U.S., Long Recovery Looks Like Recession
text: This is not what a recovery is supposed to look like.

headline: Transgender Woman Sues L.P.G.A. Over Policy
text: A transgender woman filed a federal lawsuit Tuesday against the L.P.G.A., arguing that its requirement that competitors be “female at birth” violates California civil rights law.

headline: Reactions to ‘Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell’
text: A federal judge has ordered the United States military to stop enforcing the “don’t ask, don’t tell” law that prohibits openly gay and bisexual soldiers from serving, as reported by John Schwartz in The New York Times. Below, gay serving and former service members give their reactions:

headline: N.Y. Faces $200 Billion in Retiree Health Costs
text: The cities, counties and authorities of New York have promised more than $200 billion worth of health benefits to their retirees while setting aside almost nothing, putting the public work force on a collision course with the taxpayers who are expected to foot the bill.

headline: Uphill in Wisconsin
text: When it came to the actual details of governing, Senator Russ Feingold, a Democrat of Wisconsin, trounced his Republican challenger, Ron Johnson, in a debate in Wausau, Wis., on Monday night. He knew that the new health care law will not reduce Medicare spending but will slow its staggering rate of growth. He knew that a vast majority of small businesses would not pay higher taxes if rates went up on the wealthy and that global warming isn’t caused by sunspots. He knew that without the 2009 stimulus there would be at least 1.5 million fewer people with jobs.

headline: New York’s Debate Gap
text: As things now stand, Andrew Cuomo, the Democratic nominee for governor of New York, and Carl Paladino, his Republican opponent, will participate in just a single debate before next month’s election. Well not exactly a debate. More like a group news conference.

headline: The Jets’ Understudies Grabbed the Spotlight
text: The final blow in the Jets’ latest victory came from two players who reside near the bottom of the roster and exemplify the depth crucial to the team’s four-game win streak.

headline: First-Round Victory on Health Reform
text: The first federal court decision on the constitutionality of the new health care reform law upheld its validity and dealt a well-deserved setback to opponents who are trying to overturn it. We can only hope that judges presiding over 15 or more other legal challenges follow the lead of this first major ruling.

headline: Vice President Tries to Energize Democrats
text: PITTSBURGH  Joseph R. Biden Jr., unyielding optimist, Democratic cheerleader and vice president of the United States, wants Americans to know that the midterm elections will not be a Republican rout. And after Democrats win in 2010, Mr. Biden says, he will be on the ticket with President Obama in 2012  all that buzz about Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton replacing him notwithstanding.

headline: A Conditional Go-Ahead
text: The Obama administration’s decision to lift its moratorium on deep-water oil drilling in the Gulf of Mexico came with a vital condition: Each company and each rig must first demonstrate that it can contain a blowout and meet a host of other essential new safety regulations.

headline: Questions Linger on Recruit’s Eligibility
text: Three days before official practice begins, Kentucky’s national title hopes could hinge on the freshman center Enes Kanter, a star recruit from Turkey whose eligibility remains in question.

headline: Nike to Replace Reebok as N.F.L.’s Licensed-Apparel Maker
text: The N.F.L. said Tuesday that Nike would become the league’s exclusive maker of licensed on-field apparel including uniforms, clothing worn on the sidelines and fan gear. Nike replaces Reebok, whose agreement is expiring.

headline: Robert Tishman, Real Estate Developer, Dies at 94
text: Robert V. Tishman, a real estate developer whose companies  bearing the family name since the 19th century  etched their mark on the skylines of cities around the nation, including construction of the World Trade Center, died Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 94.

headline: Game 7 of 1960 World Series Will Air
text: MLB Network has set Dec. 15 as the day it will televise the recently discovered broadcast of Game 7 of the 1960 World Series, which was won by the Pirates on Bill Mazeroski’s game-winning home run against the Yankees’ Ralph Terry.

headline: Trial of Man Once Held at Guantánamo Opens
text: In the first civilian trial of a former Guantánamo detainee, the word Guantánamo was not uttered in front of the jury as the case began on Tuesday in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

headline: Judge Denies Bid for Mistrial in Synagogue Bomb Case
text: A federal judge on Tuesday denied requests for a mistrial from four men charged with plotting to bomb Bronx synagogues and ordered jurors to continue their deliberations.

headline: Humanity Is Drawn to Scene of Rescue
text: SAN JOSÉ MINE, Chile  In the unlikely community that has coalesced here in recent weeks, a television crew discussed coverage in Mandarin. A Roman Catholic priest lamented how money corrupted the human spirit. A clown named Rolly pondered the meaning of sacrifice in the Atacama desert, arguably one of the driest places on Earth.

headline: State Is Likely to Ease a Rule on Extra Help for Students
text: The New York State Board of Regents is set to excuse school districts from a requirement to provide extra help to all students who fail the state’s standardized exams, a number that grew by hundreds of thousands after the state made the exams tougher to pass this year.

headline: Intel Tries Anonymity, for a Change
text: An average laptop contains about 1,800 components, but only one garners much brand awareness from typical consumers: the chip made by Intel.

headline: E.M.T. Accused of Failing to Help Pregnant Woman Is Arraigned in Her Death
text: An emergency medical technician accused of not helping a pregnant woman who collapsed and later died was arraigned in Brooklyn Criminal Court on Tuesday on a misdemeanor charge of official misconduct.

headline: Picturing the Crisis
text: One of the ways we remember an economic crisis is through images. Think of the Great Depression, told through the black-and-white portraits of men in bread lines, or wearing placards that beg for work; of a Wall Street suit hocking his car to pay for food; of Hoovervilles.

headline: Rival Bid for Liverpool
text: The marriage of the Boston Red Sox and Liverpool F.C. may be delayed. A week after the owner of the Red Sox, New England Sports Ventures, bid for the storied but financially troubled English soccer team, a rival offer has emerged. Peter Lim, a billionaire from Singapore, has offered £320 million, or about $509 million, £20 million more than New England Sports Ventures. Lim said he would buy the team using his own money, which would erase the team’s debts. More at nytimes.com/sports.

headline: Mantle Biography Delves Into Traumas and Myths
text: Jane Leavy, Mickey Mantle’s new biographer, admits her bias: she loved him as she grew up in Roslyn, N.Y., on Long Island, and always took his side when she debated her father over who was better: Mantle or Willie Mays. “Facts, statistics, nothing mattered,” she said. “Mickey was my guy.”

headline: At Obama Forum, Friends Not Fireworks
text: Even President Obama called one of the questions a “softball” but the same could be said of the other queries he got on Tuesday night at a town-hall-style meeting streamed over the Internet to mobilize supporters nationwide for the elections three weeks away.

headline: Photo Replay: Oct. 12
text: A view of the day in sports, including cold water and soccer fireworks.

headline: Burnett Is Hoping to Regain His Postseason Magic
text: Game 2 of the 2009 World Series was a seminal moment in the long and winding career of Allan James Burnett, an I-told-you-so of a seven-inning performance that featured his curveball at its most dazzling, his fastball at its most lethal. His tempo was quick, his mind blank. His confidence reached the upper deck of Yankee Stadium.

headline: Tribune Executive Sends Explicit E-mail, Then Apologizes
text: File this under managerial don’ts.

headline: Musicals Born on Broadway Cause Jitters
text: Broadway may keep theater fans on the edge of their seats this season: four major musicals are opening without any out-of-town tryouts or earlier runs where kinks are usually ironed out, giving audiences a rare chance to see a show jell  or not  from night to night.

headline: Stand Against Earmarks Grows Lonely as Home State Sees a Need
text: MOUNT PLEASANT, S.C.  Mike Murphree is as sympathetic as anyone to Senator Jim DeMint and his crusade against earmarks, those pet projects financed by Congress, usually out of the public eye. Mr. Murphree is chairman of the Charleston Tea Party and sees earmarks as a root cause of overspending and political corruption.

headline: GMAC Mortgage Expands Review of Its Foreclosures
text: Amid growing inquiries by law enforcement into dubious paperwork by home lenders, one of the nation’s largest, GMAC Mortgage, said Tuesday that it was expanding its review of foreclosures to all 50 states.

headline: For North Dakota Cattle, a One-Way Trip to Asia
text: More than a hundred cows boarded a plane in North Dakota on Tuesday with a one-way ticket to Kazakhstan.

headline: Build ’Em and They’ll Come
text: Kishore Mahbubani, the dean of the Lee Kuan Yew School of Public Policy at the National University of Singapore, is over for tea and I am telling him about what I consider to be the most exciting, moon-shot-quality, high-aspiration initiative proposed by President Obama that no one has heard of. It’s a plan to set up eight innovation hubs to solve the eight biggest energy problems in the world. But I explain that the program has not been fully funded yet because Congress, concerned about every dime we spend these days, is reluctant to appropriate the full $25 million for each center, let alone for all eight at once, so only three are moving ahead. But Kishore interrupts me midsentence.

headline: Wednesday: You Are Here
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Earworm alert! That Glen Campbell song at 57 Across does tend to get stuck in one’s cranium. It’s a gentle ballad about a really big football player who hunkers down near a football, waits for it to be snapped, and then bangs as hard as he can into the nearest player wearing different-colored clothes. Or, at least that’s the clever conceit of this Wednesday crossword by Alan Arbesfeld. Other theme answers are about other linemen — a CENTER on a spree, a hostile and antagonistic END, and a GUARD for a soccer legend.

headline: From Mamet, a Backstage Bouquet
text: The words delicate and David Mamet seldom appear in close proximity. Mr. Mamet, after all, is widely regarded as the macho man of American theater, a two-fisted dispenser of high-testosterone dialogue and ugly truths. As a playwright, he has never been a doily maker.

text: It was business as usual on Restaurant Row in Manhattan on Tuesday night as the theater crowd nibbled on entrees and clinked glasses. But inside Pomaire, a Chilean restaurant on West 46th Street, toasts had an altogether different meaning as patrons gathered, transfixed by the evening’s main attraction: the daring effort to rescue 33 men trapped inside a mine in northern Chile.

headline: After 28 Years, a Congressman on the Ropes
text: FORT MILL, S.C. — Representative John M. Spratt Jr., a Democrat who has managed to be elected and re-elected in this increasingly red district since 1982, climbed slowly to the podium at a Democratic Party fish fry on Monday night. A couple of hundred party loyalists had finished their Calabash fried shrimp and rose to give him a standing ovation.

headline: California: 11 State Buildings Are Sold to Shore Up Budget
text: A Texas investment company will buy 11 state buildings to help close a $19 billion budget deficit, California officials said Monday. The company, California First L.L.C., will pay about $2.33 billion for structures including the San Francisco Civic Center, the Ronald Reagan State Building in Los Angeles and five buildings in Sacramento, producing “desperately needed revenues,” said Ron Diedrich, acting director of the Department of General Services. The state will lease the buildings for 20 years, during which time it can buy them back.

headline: Ups and Downs of Foreign Capital
text: Hot money (money in pursuit of short-term gains) is the bugbear of policy makers in many developing economies. Ask Brazil or, indeed, Thailand, which just imposed a 15 percent withholding tax on interest and capital gains earned by foreign investors on Thai bonds. One worry is that booming currencies will become uncompetitive; another is that easy-come, easy-go money will make economies vulnerable to booms and busts.

headline: In Puerto Rico, a Rental Car as a Bed and a Closed Cafe for Lunch
text: Failure was overdue. Four months of near nonstop traveling had gone amazingly well. Cheap lodging appeared from thin air, restaurant recommendations from strangers yielded culinary gems, buses and planes ran on time.

text: WASHINGTON  Michelle A. Rhee, the Washington schools chancellor whose confrontations with the teachers’ union made her a polarizing symbol in school reform battles nationwide, is stepping down, a city official said.

headline: Vaccine Case Before Justices Turns on the Language of a Law

text: SAN FRANCISCO  With the stakes  and tempers  running high, Meg Whitman and Jerry Brown clashed on issues both substantive and scandalous in the final debate of the hard-fought and closely watched California governor’s race on Tuesday night.

headline: Inside the West Wing
text: Behind the scenes with President Barack Obama.

headline: Education of a President
text: On a busy afternoon in the West Wing late last month, President Barack Obama seemed relaxed and unhurried as he sat down in a newly reupholstered brown leather chair in the Oval Office. He had just returned from the East Room, where he signed the Small Business Jobs Act of 2010 ­— using eight pens so he could give away as many as possible. The act will be his administration’s last piece of significant economic legislation before voters deliver their verdict on his first two years in office. For all intents and purposes, the first chapter of Obama’s presidency has ended. On Election Day, the next chapter will begin.

headline: Robert Goodnough, Painter Who Eluded Categories, Dies at 92
text: Robert Goodnough, a painter whose stylistic evolution from vibrant, Cubist-inspired abstractions to Color Field canvases made him one of the least definable members of the second-generation Abstract Expressionists, died on Oct. 2 in White Plains. He was 92 and lived in Thornwood, N.Y.

headline: F.C.C. Wants to Stop Cellphone ‘Bill Shock’
text: WASHINGTON  The Federal Communications Commission will propose rules on Thursday requiring mobile phone companies to alert customers by voice or text message when they are have reached monthly usage limits and are about to incur extra charges, the commission’s chairman said Tuesday.

headline: Phys Ed: Do Marathons Hurt Your Knees?
text: About this time every year, with the fall marathon season at its zenith, racers in training begin to hear the refrain, ‘‘You are going to ruin your knees.’’ The idea that distance running inexorably leads to arthritis is deeply entrenched, despite the publication of a number of recent studies (detailed in a Phys Ed column last year) that have found otherwise. In one representative experiment, the knees of experienced marathoners, with multiple races behind them, were scanned with magnetic resonance imaging technology, and then scanned again 10 years later. The runners’ knees were and remained robust throughout that time, with few significant cartilage abnormalities. The only truly unhealthy knee in the study belonged to a former marathoner, who had quit the sport. In the years since he stopped running, his joint had deteriorated badly.

text: SKS Microfinance, which recently became the first Indian microlender to sell shares in the stock market, should be enjoying a honeymoon right now, Vikas Bajaj reports in The New York Times.

text: PORT HOPE, CANADA — The tidy, meticulously restored 1840s brick house of Lee Caswell and Blaise Gaetz here in this town about an hour east of Toronto was once a neighborhood eyesore.

text: Wall Street wants Google‘s new products and initiatives to start paying off, as its accelerating spending spree nibbles away at margins and alarms investors, Reuters reported.

headline: Timeless: Warm Cats, Cold City
text: Carl T. Gossett Jr.’s name appeared in agate-type letters as credit lines beneath his photographs in The New York Times for nearly 40 years. He covered the Nuremberg war-crime trials in the late 1940s and the 1956 uprising in Hungary. In 1964, he took an exhilarating picture of ecstatic teens reacting to the arrival of the Beatles in New York City.

text: Wall Street is more worried about high unemployment than the makeup of Congress or the Federal Reserve’s next move, according to views from the market ahead of next month’s election, Reuters reports.
