headline: Paris Art Show Gives ‘Buzz’ a New Meaning
text: The FIAC contemporary art fair at the Grand Palais is now one of the biggest such events in the world — about 80,000 visitors are expected this year. Visitors looking to avoid the crowds, but retain the buzz of “now” art, can try a satellite show at the flagship perfume store of the Guerlain chain, on the Champs Elysées, just down the road from FIAC.

headline: Large States Show the Way, Continued
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.California and other states with large populations are legal innovators of sorts, as I explained last week. In order to make all of those laws, big states need to have a different kind of legislator.

headline: Nothing for Certain in Vimpelcom’s Orascom Buy
text: Vimpelcom‘s $6.6 billion bid to buy Orascom, a Russian telecom group, from the Egyptian tycoon Naguib Sawiris is by no means a done deal, the chief executive of Telenor, one of Orascom’s main shareholders, was quoted as saying, Reuters reported.

headline: Chinese and U.S. Education Companies to Merge
text: The online education companies Eleutian Technology and Idapted said on Wednesday that they would merge, bringing together the American and Chinese companies in the fast-growing $100 billion market for online English instruction, Reuters reported.

headline: Can Ackman Break Up Fortune?
text: From Reuters Breakingviews:

headline: Buffett Issues Bearish Warning on Euro
text: Warren Buffett, who last month called himself “a huge bull” on the United States, said the euro faces “a real challenge” after the currency posted its biggest quarterly gain in eight years, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: Facebook Adds 3 New Security Features
text: Facebook on Tuesday announced three new security features that could help you defeat account hijackers.

headline: News Corp’s BSkyB Bid Said to Slow Over Antitrust
text: The delay of Rupert Murdoch‘s News Corporation in notifying the European Union about a planned takeover of British Sky Broadcasting, Britain’s biggest pay-TV operator, suggests it is seeking to avoid a British government challenge, lawyers say, according to Bloomberg News.

headline: Judge Backs Liverpool Sale Over Owners’ Protest
text: Liverpool, the English Premier League team, inched closer to a sale on Wednesday when a British High Court judge ruled against its unpopular American owners, Tom Hicks and George Gillett, and backed the club’s board and its right to negotiate a deal, Reuters reports.

headline: Bondholders of Irish Nationwide Unite
text: Bondholders of Irish Nationwide are looking to unite in defiance of the losses they may be forced to take as the Irish government pushes ahead with its restructuring of the mortgage lender, The Financial Times reports.

headline: JPMorgan Chase Agrees to Tribune Debt Deal
text: The Tribune Company said Tuesday that it reached agreement with more parties to its bankruptcy as it attemps to bring its publishing and broadcasting business out of Chapter 11, Reuters reports.

headline: For Samuelson, It’s One Finish Line After the Next
text: Joan Benoit Samuelson is a goal oriented woman. The 53-year-old mother and Olympic gold medalist set out to run a sub-three-hour marathon and, like she has done with so many other feats, accomplished it last Saturday when she completed the Chicago Marathon in 2:47.50. As Jere Longman reported, it was the fastest time for a woman age 52 and older, but was short of the 2:46 she needed to qualify for the Olympic trials.

headline: Hedge Funds Have a Strong September
text: Hedge funds chalked up their strongest gains in 16 months in September, helped by climbing stock prices around the world, Reuters said, citing data from Singapore-based fund tracker Eurekahedge.

headline: Rethinking What Your Mother Told You
text: There are some things your mother told you that may have served you well in everyday life — and that I hear from business owners all the time. But not everything mothers say makes for sound advice when running a business. Here are some common sayings that seem reasonable but may be worth reconsidering.

headline: JPMorgan Chase Profit Rises as Loan Provisions Fall
text: JPMorgan Chase kicked off what was expected to be a mixed quarterly earnings season for big banks on Wednesday with a 23 percent increase in third-quarter income.

headline: Voting by Mail in Washington State May Confound Pollsters
text: Washington State plays a pivotal role in the battle for the Senate this year, since the Republicans’ path of least resistance runs right through it. Were Republicans to win the three contests that can be described as tossups — in Illinois, Nevada and West Virginia — and avoid surprises in other states like Colorado and Kentucky in which the polling is still fairly close, then a victory by Dino Rossi in Washington would give them their 51st senator.

headline: Agent’s Confessions Indict College Football

headline: Iran’s Leader Cements Ties on State Visit to Lebanon
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon  President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran arrived here on Wednesday morning and was given an ecstatic welcome by supporters of Hezbollah, the militant Shiite movement his country backs.

headline: Improved Earnings Help Buoy Wall Street
text: Upbeat results across three bellwether sectors reassured investors about the economy and drove stocks higher on Wednesday.

headline: Showdown on Bluefin Tuna
text: In advance of an annual meeting of bluefin tuna fishing nations next month in Paris, scientists and environmental groups are sharply questioning the validity of scientific data being used to set catch levels for the fish, which remains highly coveted as sushi but is increasingly threatened by commercial overfishing.

headline: Judge Rules Against Attempt to Bar Liverpool Sale
text: LONDON  The group that runs the Boston Red Sox moved one step closer Wednesday to taking over ownership of Liverpool F.C.

headline: The Early Word: Michelle Obama on Campaign Trail
text: Michelle Obama joins the midterm campaign trail Wednesday on behalf of several Democratic candidates. Sheryl Gay Stolberg explains that from now until Election Day, Mrs. Obama “will make the case that the election will have consequences for working families.”

headline: Buffett Pressured by Kravis Over Debt Swap
text: Warren Buffett and Henry Kravis are clashing over the debt restructuring of Energy Future Holdings, a firm backed by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company and one in which Mr. Buffett holds $2 billion in bonds, The New York Post reported.

headline: An Ugly Return to Fan Violence in Europe
text: London

headline: Clinton Reaches Out to Kosovo’s Serbs
text: GRACANICA, Kosovo  Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton sought to soothe Kosovo’s Serbian population on Wednesday, assuring religious and political leaders that the United States would look out for the Serbs’ rights even though it had thrown the full force of American backing behind the Kosovo Albanians who declared independence from Serbia two years ago.

headline: Midterms Are a Test for Obama’s Ground Game
text: There’s a reason that President Obama decided to broadcast his meeting with college students on the Internet on Tuesday night, taking sympathetic questions by way of Facebook and Skype and Twitter. (About the only hip thing the president didn’t try was to break out the Guitar Hero and start playing “Revolution.”) The midterm campaign has now entered its final phase, and Mr. Obama is focusing his attention on the younger voters and volunteers he inspired in 2008.

headline: Face Time | The Thunderbolt by MB&F
text: It’s billed as an horological machine, not a watch. In any case, the Thunderbolt, a tribute to aeronautics, is the newest creation in a series of highly complicated timepieces from the five-year-old Geneva-based company MB&F, founded by Maximillian Büsser, a veteran of the Swiss haute watch world. The Thunderbolt’s twin pods, which house a power reserve and hour/minute indicators, was inspired by the 1970s-era A-10 aircraft’s two cylindrical jet reactors. More than 200 hours are required to carve, finish and polish the block of titanium and solid sapphire crystal into these sleek “engines.” With dials perpendicular to the wearer’s wrist, it makes for the perfect pilot’s watch — or, for those ground-bound, an on-time driver.

headline: From Half a World Away, Chileans Watch Rescue
text: What we’re reading this sunny but cool October morning on which the Chilean miners have tasted fresh air for the first time in months:

headline: ‘Glee': It Takes Two (or Sometimes Just One)
text: We have to imagine that Tuesday was a tough day for Eric Stoltz. If he happened to do a Google search of his name or go pretty much anywhere on the Internet, he probably ran straight into that footage from the five short weeks he spent as the star of “Back to the Future,” with narration from Steven Spielberg and Robert Zemeckis explaining why Mr. Stoltz had to be replaced on the film because it “wasn’t getting the laughs.”

headline: Stars in Finance and Media Come Out for Rattner
text: Scores of boldfaced names made their way to the Seagram Building on Park Avenue Tuesday night to celebrate Steven Rattner and the publication of “Overhaul” (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt), his account of the Obama administration’s restructuring of the auto industry.

headline: Poorism
text: The intersection of tourism and poverty.[Poor + (tour)ism]

headline: Trying to Chart the Long Road Back
text: Perhaps it should come as no surprise that after enduring the most brutal recession since the Great Depression, the United States economy has emerged with a pronounced limp.

headline: Limited Edition Chevy Camaro Convertible at Neiman Marcus
text: Nestled in the pages of the Neiman Marcus Christmas Book, the over-the-top extravaganza of price-is-no-object presents, between a $17,500 Leica M9 and a $4,500 electric tricycle is the Chevrolet Camaro Convertible. The car does not hit showrooms until February, but the eager consumer may order one of 100 limited edition Neiman Marcus versions for $75,000 next week (for delivery next spring).

headline: Arts Become Latest Luxuries Monaco Offers
text: MONACO  A new opera and a couple of new exhibitions in spanking new museums have opened here in recent days, evidence of Monaco’s latest bid for cultural prestige. The opera was mostly a private venture, but the museums belong to the principality, where lately Princess Caroline, a longtime champion of culture, has settled again and is making the arts a priority. Even the Oceanographic Museum, one of Europe’s treasures and closest to the naturalist Prince Albert’s heart, dipped its foot in the water this summer with a show mixing some of Damien Hirst’s pickled animals and gigantic dot and spin paintings among the stupendous antique displays of nautical equipment and undersea creatures.

headline: Night Watch: Poll Numbers and Campaign Financing
text: Cable news on Tuesday night was mostly swallowed up by the first rescues of the miners in Chile, and the political headlines that remained were largely about poll numbers and campaign-finance figures.

headline: That Was No Lady, That Was My Wife
text: There are several ways to look at Jeff Koons’s so-called sex pictures from nearly 20 years ago, a series known more formally as “Made in Heaven Paintings,” which is currently ensconced in the town-house gallery of Luxembourg & Dayan on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. All are equally interesting and, in different ways, aesthetically unfulfilling.

headline: Wednesday Reading: Marriage Rates and the Recession
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that can hit your wallet.

headline: Tribune Memo Lands With a Thud at Headquarters
text: The memo on Monday from Lee Abrams, the chief innovation officer at The Tribune Company, began innocently enough:

headline: Lockheed to Sell Enterprise Integration Unit
text: Lockheed Martin announced on Wednesday that it had agreed to sell its enterprise integration group to the private-equity firm Veritas Capital for $815 million in cash.

headline: Floccinaucinihilipilificationism: A Word as Big as the Man
text: He advised four presidents, twice served as a United States ambassador and had a tenured chair at Harvard, all before becoming a four-term senator from New York.

headline: A Hero or Just a Parent?
text: During the discussion here last week about the challenges of parenting a disabled child (“Is It Harder to Have a Child with Down Syndrome?”), I heard from Stacie Lewis. An American living in London, Lewis has an 18-month-old daughter named May, who has severe brain damage, caused by lack of oxygen at birth.

headline: Paris Exhibition Honors Némirovsky
text: PARIS — The Memorial of the Shoah on Wednesday unveiled a vast exhibition in tribute to the French Jewish writer Irène Némirovsky, a rare collection including a series of letters she sent months before her arrest and deportation to Auschwitz and an original audio recording of an interview she gave in 1939.

headline: Kennedy Center to Honor Anniversary of John F. Kennedy’s Inauguration
text: On the 50th anniversary of President John F. Kennedy’s inauguration on Jan. 20, the Kennedy Center in Washington will honor him with a star-studded concert, kicking off three weeks of related performances and events. Diane Sawyer and Mike Nichols will co-host the concert, which will include appearances by Julie Andrews, Harolyn Blackwell, Herbie Hancock, Yo-Yo Ma, the Manzari Brothers, Terrence McNally, Lorne Michaels and Brian Stokes Mitchell. American Ballet Theater will perform “The Dying Swan,” and Christoph Eschenbach will conduct the National Symphony Orchestra in the world premiere of a composition by Peter Lieberson that features narration, drawn from Kennedy’s speeches and writings, to be spoken by Morgan Freeman.

headline: Ciao, Amore
text: Cesare Rimini is a lucky man. He used to drive a Ferrari but sold it because Italian laws wouldn’t let him drive fast enough. These days his hobby is wine. He makes it, but not for sale, just to give lucky friends. “One bottle of his wine costs more than a bottle of Dom Pérignon,” says his daughter, Alessandra, with a laugh.

headline: Show Us Your City: Neil’s Historic, Artistic Philadelphia
text: A few weeks ago, we asked readers to give us the local point of view by submitting a short travel video that shows why their city, town or neighborhood is amazing. Well, the Show Us Your City submissions have started to roll in. First up, Neil Nandi shares his love of history and art by visiting some of Philadelphia’s best attractions.

headline: 36 Hours in Santa Monica, Calif.
text: WHEN Angelenos think of the perfect beach town, they think of Santa Monica. Venice (to the south) has its countercultural charms, and Malibu (up north) is celebrity central, but only Santa Monica feels homey. Residents enjoy cultural institutions, athletic facilities, and stores and restaurants of the highest order. Now, there’s even more. In August, Santa Monica Place, a sprawling indoor-outdoor mall a few blocks from the beach, reopened, with offerings both high (Louis Vuitton and Tiffany) and low (a food court with priceless sunset-over-the-ocean views).

headline: A Weekend in Santa Monica, Calif.
text: When Angelenos think of the perfect beach town, they think of Santa Monica.

headline: Amazon Awakening
text: ILLUMINATED by a single candle, the shaman’s weathered face appeared kindly, like that of a sympathetic doctor, with painted red marks also suggesting a calm, fierce authority — both qualities that I would rely on during the dark and uncertain hours ahead. He sat on a wooden stool carved into a tortoise, and wore turquoise beads around his neck and a crown of crimson feathers. A table beside him displayed the modest tools of the ceremony: a fan of leaves, jungle tobacco, a gourd bowl and a clear plastic soda bottle containing an opaque, brown liquid.

headline: Into the Amazonian Rain Forest
text: A local tribe has been using tourism as a means to preserve and protect its way of life.

headline: Overnight in Anderson Valley, Calif.
text: Cradled between ridges of coastal redwoods and inland oaks are grapevine-draped hills.

headline: California Farmland, Known for Its Drinks
text: EVEN before the first sip of wine, I was drunk on the smell of baked earth and California bay leaves. It was August and the air was hot and dry, and specked with tiny white butterflies. The hills were shrouded in straw, with green vineyards creeping up their sides. The scene was intoxicating.

headline: A Desert Blooms Along China’s Silk Road
text: AS the sun began its long descent late one afternoon in the Taklamakan Desert in the Xinjiang region of northwestern China, my traveling companions and I mounted a train of camels and wondered aloud if we would ever emerge from the dunes that stretched to the horizon. The last sign we had seen before leaving the lonely strip of asphalt was not encouraging: “Entering the desert,” the faded Chinese characters said, “please be careful.”

headline: Along Xinjiang’s Ancient Route
text: Much of this remote province remains a world apart from China.

headline: Austrian Vineyards Are All in the Family
text: ON a July afternoon, lunch at the Denk Family vineyard’s heuriger — one of a number of hilltop village wine gardens in the Wachau Valley of Austria, about 50 miles west of Vienna — was served family style under a walnut tree overlooking the valley. My group had been cycling and sipping our way through local vineyards all morning; we were famished, and we were tipsy. We filled our plates with grilled meats and cold salads and washed everything down with more wine from the Denk vineyard.

headline: Northwest Hotels Go Eco-Plus
text: THE Oxford Hotel is just three blocks from Drake Park in Bend, Ore., a popular gathering spot where couples and families picnic and teenagers lazily hand-paddle down the Deschutes River on air mattresses. But it’s mattresses of another sort that are notable at the hotel. They are all-natural  no polyester or off-gassing here  and are purchased from a supplier less than three miles away.

headline: Where Restaurants Plead Their Case
text: New York’s restaurants sprawl across a vast territory, from the pristine precincts of the multicourse tasting menu to the gritty backwaters of the takeout joint. But there is one grim corner where they all come together: the health department tribunal, a little-publicized court system that metes out penalties for violations of the city sanitary code.

headline: Lazard Hires Cazenove Ex-Chief
text: 2:42 p.m. | Updated Lazard said on Wednesday that it has hired Naguib Kheraj, the former chief executive of JPMorgan Cazenove, as a deputy chairman and a senior member of its financial advisory team.

headline: Former N.B.A. Star Selling at Trump Place
text: The former N.B.A. all-star center Dikembe Mutombo, who has invested millions in philanthropic causes in his native country, Congo, is selling his $4.5 million apartment at Trump Place. It is being listed by Heather E. Stein of Brown Harris Stevens.

headline: Case Involving Former Curator Marion True Ends
text: ROME — The court case against Marion True, the former curator of antiquities at the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles, ended abruptly on Wednesday, after a court in Rome ruled that the statute of limitations had run out on allegations that she had received stolen goods from Italy and conspired to deal in looted Italian artifacts.

headline: Nominees for National Book Awards Announced
text: 12:09 p.m. | Updated

headline: How to Protect Data After Laptop Theft
text: My trip to Beijing a couple of weeks ago was going fine until the cab driver dropped us off at the airport. He took our luggage out of the trunk and then got back in the car and drove away — with my laptop and a bag full of fabric still in the front seat, where the hotel bellman had placed them.

text: Marc Bousquet, who blogs for The Chronicle of Higher Education, worries in his latest post that the harsh federal spotlight currently illuminating the excesses of for-profit colleges is missing similar problems at nonprofit institutions.

headline: Friendly Officers, Gambling Birds and Future Gods of Guitar

Indeed, as a video the group posted on Monday attests, police officers used to help clear the way for Critical Mass rides back in May 1999. On bikes!

headline: Hungarian Arrested in Sludge Spill Is Freed
text: BUDAPEST  The managing director of the company linked to Hungary’s red sludge disaster was released from custody without charge, his lawyer said Wednesday, citing a lack of sufficient evidence.

headline: All 50 States Start Inquiry Into Foreclosures
text: As the nation’s attorneys general announced a joint investigation into flawed paperwork filed to support home foreclosures, federal housing regulators urged lenders Wednesday to vet their foreclosure procedures and fix them.

headline: Eyes on the Prize | Design That Does Good
text: Design isn’t only about the latest cutting-edge chair or yet another must-have coffee maker. As demonstrated by the winners of two different design awards, it can sometimes make a fundamental difference in the quality of people’s lives — and can even make the difference between life and death. Just look at Longreach, the winner of the 2010 James Dyson Award. The compact, easy-to-handle buoyancy deployment system, which was designed by Samuel Adeloju, shoots an emergency buoyancy aid up to 500 feet out to sea — which could prevent some of the 150 deaths that occur each year in the United States alone when swimmers are swept out to sea by currents or riptides.

headline: Research First, Cap and Trade Next

headline: Nascar No. 37 Car Will Race With Andy Griffith Paint Scheme
text: Dave Blaney is not in contention for the Nascar Sprint Cup, but his stock car will probably get a lot of attention Saturday night during a race at the Charlotte Motor Speedway. Mr. Blaney’s car will carry a paint scheme designed to evoke memories of one of the most legendary Fords to roam the North Carolina countryside, at least on television.

headline: Goodbye, New York. Thanks for Breaking My Heart.
text: Two years ago, Christopher Solomon moved to New York City from the Pacific Northwest and wrote about it in the City Weekly section of The New York Times. Things didn’t quite work out as he had hoped.

headline: Fee Dispute Could Disrupt Fox Programming
text: Cablevision customers in the New York metropolitan area may lose access to Fox programming this weekend if the cable company cannot come to new terms with News Corporation, the owner of Fox.

headline: Penney Hires Goldman for Defense Against Ackman
text: J.C. Penney has hired Goldman Sachs as an adviser as the retailer braces for a possible battle from the hedge fund manager William A. Ackman, Women’s Wear Daily reports.

headline: Vietnam Smackdown
text: Richard Blumenthal has said repeatedly that he misspoke about his service in the Vietnam war, but Linda McMahon isn’t about to let him — or any of Connecticut’s voters — forget it.

headline: Plotting the Course of Alzheimer’s
text: Many Web sites offer help for stressed caregivers in general and information on Alzheimer’s disease in particular (the Alzheimer’s Association site is particularly comprehensive). But they don’t fully harness the Web’s interactivity to provide specific, tailored advice regarding Alzheimer’s — recommendations that necessarily change as patients’ behaviors and symptoms shift.

headline: Manny Harris Has Impressed the Cavaliers
text: There are many cautionary tales of college stars who left early to pursue fame and a big payday in the N.B.A. When things do not work out and there is no fairy tale ending, critics are left to wonder what could have been if the player had stayed in school.

headline: The Rising Incidence of Thyroid Cancer
text: It’s easy to crunch the numbers on thyroid cancer and assume it is a disease fast on the rise. Incidence has more than doubled since the early 1970s, and for women, it is the cancer with the fastest-growing number of new cases.

headline: TimesCast | October 13, 2010
text: The Chilean rescue goes viral; President Obama on his first two years in office and Favre scandal moves from fringe to mainstream media.

headline: China Cheers Rescue Halfway Around the World
text: SHANGHAI — In a country where mining tragedies are common, there was jubilation Wednesday at a rescue operation that was attempting to lift 33 miners to safety after a lengthy ordeal in Chile. And there was a sense that China was not just sympathetic but had contributed something.

headline: As China Advances, Solar Start-Ups Strategize
text: In an article in The New York Times on Wednesday, I wrote about how high-tech Silicon Valley solar companies are retooling their strategies to compete with low-cost Chinese manufacturers.

headline: What to Ask About Thyroid Cancer
text: Confronting a new diagnosis can be frightening — and because research changes so often, confusing. Here are some questions you may not think to ask your doctor, along with notes on why they’re important.

headline: When Procreation Is a Matter of Real Estate
text: The choice to have sex has everything to do with location, at least for tiny freshwater creatures called rotifers.

headline: Why a Pantry?
text: Daily, it seems, I find myself preaching the benefits of a well-stocked pantry, and of cooking a pot of beans and a pot of grains once a week or so. Here’s a good example of why.

headline: Selected Studies: Thyroid Cancer
text: Government agencies, universities and corporations frequently enroll patients in studies designed to test the effectiveness of new drugs, procedures and medical devices. Participants may benefit by gaining access to experimental therapies, and they make an important contribution to scientific research. For more information, please visit ClinicalTrials.gov, a service of the National Institutes of Health.

headline: Hot Wax
text: Barbour, the U.K.-based outerwear company and holder of the warrant to supply “waterproof and protective clothing” to England’s royal family, has created a limited-edition collection of boots with the New England-based shoemaker Rockport. The signature rain-resistant waxed cotton used in Barbour’s weatherproof jackets has been hand-stitched to rough, textured leathers in three styles of boots that incorporate the advanced technology in walking comfort for which Rockport is known. Though a bit rugged for most workplaces, they’re a perfect match for the tweed pants and suits now hitting stores for the coming winter — and will most certainly weather any storm, be it in a peat bog or a concrete canyon.

headline: When Will It End?
text: Campaign-weary Americans may believe they’ll finally know on Nov. 2 whether Republicans or Democrats will control the next Congress, but it is possible that things may not be that simple.

headline: The Many Faces of Thyroid Cancer
text: Dr. Steven Sherman is the medical director of the endocrine center and chairman of the department of endocrine, neoplasia and hormonal disorders at the University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center in Houston. Here are the five things he thinks everyone should know about the disease.

headline: Q&A With C.J. Chivers About “The Gun”
text: C.J. Chivers is answering your questions about his book, “The Gun.” The most recent questions and answers appear at the top of this post.

headline: Will the Real Producer Please Stand Out
text: LOS ANGELES — Think of it as a Good Housekeeping Seal of Approval for the calfskin loafers set.

headline: Finding Clarity in Ambiguity
text: Matt Eich, a freelance photographer based in Norfolk, Va., is a founding member of Luceo Images. Mr. Eich, who was born in 1986, focuses on the sense of identity found within communities. This year, he was named one of PDN‘s 30 emerging photographers to watch. He has also received awards from Pictures of the Year International. His conversation with Amanda Rivkin has been condensed.

headline: Indie Video Arcade Pops Up in Midtown
text: “There’s not a lot of free-spirited stuff going on in Midtown,” Todd Patrick, the music promoter better known as Todd P, said the other day in the Showpaper 42nd Street Gallery, his new pop-up gallery near Grand Central Terminal. Eager young volunteers were hanging puppets in the window while two installation artists playing a fencing-themed video game exchanged articulate insults. “So it’s nice to provide a place like this for people to come and hang out,” he said.

headline: 18 Iran Guards Killed by Blast at Their Base
text: TEHRAN  An explosion on Tuesday at an Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps base in a remote area of southwestern Iran killed 18 members of the powerful military organization and wounded 14 more, Iranian state news media reported on Wednesday.

headline: How Is Technology Changing Your Classroom?
text: Teachers!

headline: NATO Helping Afghan-Taliban Talks
text: BRUSSELS  NATO forces are facilitating efforts by the Afghan government to seek a reconciliation deal with insurgents, including a pledge to guarantee safe passage for Taliban leaders who have attended initial peace talks in Kabul, a senior NATO official said Wednesday.

headline: Quote Unquote | Would You Like Fries With That?
text: –The super model Lara Stone traces her career trajectory for Vogue UK. Um, like we believe her.

headline: The Rescue on TV: Elation and Elvis
text: It was compared to a moon shot, to the airliner’s emergency landing on the Hudson and even to the World Cup, but for viewers awaiting the rescue of 33 Chilean miners, the vigil of Tuesday night and Wednesday was more like a difficult delivery: a long, tense and at times tedious labor, followed by the sudden, surprising whoosh of life.

headline: Kebede Teases, but Tough Marathon Double Is Not in His Plans
text: Tsegaye Kebede of Ethiopia teased marathon manics Sunday after his second-place finish at the Chicago Marathon when he did not immediately discredit claims that he might run the New York City Marathon on Nov. 7. Kebede trails Samuel Wanjiru by 10 points in the race for the 2009-10 World Marathon Majors title and would have to finish at least in second place in the final race of the series in New York to win the top prize of $500,000.

headline: Buddymoon
text: A honeymoon taken with friends, or two platonic friends vacationing together.

headline: Documentaries (in Name Only) of Every Stripe
text: “ALL I want is the truth. Just gimme some truth!” John Lennon sang. Lennon, who would have turned 70 last weekend, is the subject of Michael Epstein’s new documentary, “LENNONYC,” shown at the recently concluded New York Film Festival and slated for broadcast on PBS next month. Mr. Epstein’s film is part of a surge of documentaries, some shown on television, some released in theaters, that try to answer Lennon’s plea while demonstrating just how tricky the pursuit of cinematic truth can be.

headline: Ask an Expert About Thyroid Cancer
text: Oct. 21, 2010 2:49 p.m. | Updated Thanks for all your questions. See Dr. Tuttle’s first set of responses in “Toxins, Genes and Thyroid Cancer.”

headline: U.S. Moves Against Illegal Fishing
text: A new federal rule will allow the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration to bar entry at American ports to any foreign fishing vessel that has been listed as having taken part in illegal, unreported or unregulated fishing. The rule takes effect in two weeks.

headline: A Bit More Ethanol in the Gas Tank
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration made a gesture of support for the ethanol industry on Wednesday, with a declaration by the Environmental Protection Agency that gasoline retailers can sell fuel blends containing up to 15 percent ethanol for use in late-model cars.

headline: 44 Charged in Huge Medicare Fraud Scheme
text: An Armenian-American crime syndicate stole the identities of doctors and thousands of patients and used them and more than a hundred spurious clinics in 25 states to bill Medicare for more than $100 million for treatments no doctor ever performed and no patient ever received, the federal authorities announced on Wednesday.

headline: In Chicago, Village Life in a Big City
text: Over the years, Andersonville, a neighborhood that sits far north on the Chicago city map, has retained its mom-and-pop charms.

headline: Gran Turismo 5 Is Delayed Again
text: The announcement from Sony on Wednesday morning has a familiar whiff: Gran Turismo 5 delayed.

headline: Berlin Tie Guy
text: It may be 11 in the morning on a Saturday in Berlin’s rough-around-the edges district of Kreuzberg, but Jan-Henrik Scheper-Stuke is decked out in an eye-catching yellow bow tie. A matching silk pocket square tucked into his natty blazer shimmers as he flips on the light switch in the Edsor Kronen factory’s showroom. Spinning on his heels, Scheper-Stuke, who is 28, does a little Fred Astaire-style backward kick, then turns back around, brandishing a swath of purple and gold Italian silk. Then he jumps, with practiced agility, right up onto the sample table. “See?” he says, holding a rich, lime-green paisley up to one of the sworls in an antique wool fabric hanging behind glass on the wall. “For this print, this was the inspiration.”

headline: The Caucus
text: The Times's Michael D. Shear and Peter Baker discuss Mr. Baker's Times Magazine piece on the first two years of the Obama presidency.

headline: R.F.K. Jr. Endorses Crist’s Senate Campaign
text: DEERFIELD BEACH, Fla. — Robert F. Kennedy Jr. told a bagel-noshing crowd of Florida voters here today that Marco Rubio, the Republican candidate for Senate, was a Tea Party “crackpot,” “a radical,” and a “sock puppet” who speaks for a “corporate plutocracy threatening to crush our democracy.”

headline: Emerging From Escape Shaft, a Pageant of Spirit
text: Victor Zamora held his pregnant wife, Jessica, in a tender, extended embrace. The moment  after his 69 days of dark separation, and in the penetrating glare of the sun and the world’s attention  was theirs alone.

headline: White House Meeting for Black Journalists Doesn’t Stay Off-The-Record for Long
text: The White House is usually quite good at keeping a muzzle on the media after one of its off-the-record sessions with President Obama and senior members of his administration.

headline: ‘Morning Joe’ Team Is Working on a Prime Time Show
text: Joe Scarborough and Mika Brzezinski of the cable news channel MSNBC’s “Morning Joe” are helping to develop a prime time show, “Young Turks,” for the flagship NBC network. Mr. Scarborough and Ms. Brzezinski are consulting producers on the potential show, Variety reported Wednesday. An MSNBC spokesman confirmed their involvement.

headline: Tribune Suspends Lee Abrams for Memo
text: After sending out a memo containing some questionable links, Lee Abrams has been suspended from his job as chief innovation officer for The Tribune Company. The memo follows:

headline: A Grand Homecoming and a Questioned Suspension
text: From The Montreal Gazette’s Habs Inside/Out, this blog post discusses the Lightning’s visit to Montreal, where the Tampa Bay stars Vinny Lecavalier, Martin St. Louis and Simon Gagne and their new coach, Guy Boucher, have roots, and the two-game suspension handed down by the N.H.L. to the Blackhawks’ Niklas Hjalmarsson for his hit from behind on the Sabres’ Jason Pominville.

headline: Swiss Wine Center Offers Tastes and More
text: Long known for its precision watches, delicious chocolates and soaring mountains, Switzerland also produces an array of white and red wines, although few are exported to the United States. One of the main wine regions is Lavaux, marked by terraced vineyards that hug the slopes overlooking Lake Geneva. (The vineyards, which date to the 11th century, are a designated Unesco World Heritage site.) So it should come as no surprise that a tasting room, multimedia center and shop called Vinorama, which opened in mid-May in the town of Rivaz, is now giving visitors access to the flavors of the area’s grapes.

headline: A Transgender Voice
text: Jamie Clayton, a student in the Act Out class for gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender students, talks about her life as a transgender woman. (Video courtesy of Brad Calcaterra)

headline: Michelle Obama Hits Campaign Trail With Soft-Sell Message
text: MILWAUKEE  Michelle Obama burst back onto the campaign trail Wednesday with a highly personal, soft-sell appeal intended to prod Democratic voters  especially women  to set aside whatever disappointment they may have in her husband and go to the polls to “finish what we’ve started.”

headline: Tasting Whole Wheat Pasta
text: While Melissa Clark was researching her article on whole wheat pasta, she had Anna Klinger, chef and a co-owner of Al di Là in Park Slope, Brooklyn; and Emma Hearst, chef and a co-owner of Sorella on the Lower East Side, taste some of the pastas in her kitchen in Brooklyn. I was there too.

headline: TimesCast: Education of a President
text: The Times’s Michael D. Shear and Peter Baker discuss Mr. Baker’s recent interview with President Obama for a Times Magazine article on the first two years of the Obama presidency.

headline: On Our Radar: A Solar Jobs Census
text: A “solar jobs census” tallied 93,000 solar power industry jobs in the United States as of August, and it projects industry job growth of 26 percent in 2011. Roughly half of solar employers planned to add employees next year, compared with just 2 percent for the private industry economywide. The report, which surveyed 2,300 solar companies, was partly financed by solar power industry groups and conducted in partnership with Cornell. [Portfolio.com]

headline: Clash of the Titan: Spielberg Movies Will Duel
text: So it’s Spielberg vs. Spielberg for the holidays in 2011. On a morning conference call Stacey Snider, the DreamWorks chief executive, told reporters on Wednesday that “War Horse,” directed by Mr. Spielberg, was being moved by DreamWorks and Disney to a release date of Dec. 28, 2011. That puts it on track for a release just five days after Paramount Pictures is scheduled to release “The Adventures of Tintin: Secret of the Unicorn,” also directed by Mr. Spielberg. A Paramount spokeswoman did not immediately respond to an email seeking comment on the move.

headline: Reader Idea | Science Literacy and the Study of Clouds

text: This week, Peter Meehan concludes his epic Grass Fed postings on René Redzepi of Noma in Copenhagen. For last week’s, click here.

text: When the Giants’ Tim Lincecum and the Phillies’ Roy Halladay take the mound in the opener of the National League Championship Series on Saturday night, the matchup of aces will take its place among the best in postseason history.

headline: Perez Hilton Vows to End Celebrity Insults
text: Perez Hilton, one of the Web’s best-known gossip bloggers, says he will stop attacking celebrities and scrawling insults on photos of their faces.

text: Among investors who make their investment decisions without the help of an investment adviser, those who invest with Vanguard were most satisfied with their firm, according to a recently released study by J.D. Power and Associates.

headline: Cap and Trade: The Buck Stops Where?
text: At the Economix blog, our colleague David Leonhardt examines differing perspectives on how much blame should be apportioned to President Obama and his staff for the failure to pass climate legislation this year. He also sizes up the prospects of passing legislation promoting clean energy research, which some see as a prerequisite for any cap and trade bill.

headline: Stanford Loses Bid to Make Insurer Pay Legal Fees
text: Lloyd’s of London, the insurer, will not be on the hook for paying for the legal defense of the jailed Texas financier R. Allen Stanford after all.

text: Three young men in the Gaza Strip hope to escape the extreme poverty of the area by dedicating themselves to parkour, the acrobatic sport with French roots.

headline: Turning Business Owners Into Stars of Their Own Stories
text: ONCE upon a time in Chicago, there lived a man named Abe. He owned a neighborhood pharmacy, Polin Drugs, and worked behind the counter. His father and two sons lent a hand. When people could not afford doctors during the Great Depression, they scraped by on Abe’s free advice. He kept the doors open until midnight. He knew his customers by name.

headline: A Surge in Ratings as First Miners Appeared
text: More than 10 million people were watching CNN, Fox News and MSNBC as the first of 33 miners was rescued in Chile on Tuesday night, the beginning of the end of a two-month ordeal for the men trapped underground.

headline: Making Movies With Laptops and Ingenuity
text: GARETH EDWARDS knew the power of the green screen, the blank matte used by special-effects artists to create computer-generated imagery. But he rejected it for his new science-fiction movie, “Monsters.” He learned from experience: A special-effects engineer with a background in television, Mr. Edwards once constructed a massive green screen to manufacture battles digitally in the hourlong BBC movie “Attila the Hun,” which he also directed. The vast crew needed, though, quickly overwhelmed him.

headline: G.M. and Utilities Want to Install 5,300 Electric Chargers in Michigan
text: DETROIT — While Michigan’s history is inseparably linked to the gasoline engine, General Motors said on Tuesday that more than 5,300 home and workplace electric-vehicle charging stations would be installed in the state to meet the demands of an emerging fleet of plug-in hybrid and electric vehicles.

headline: Whitacre Sees $20-$25 Share Price in G.M.’s I.P.O.
text: Edward E. Whitacre Jr. the chairman of General Motors, said Wednesday that the automaker’s shares were likely to be priced at $20 to $25 in G.M.’s initial public offering in November.

headline: My Mom Is on Facebook
text: We’ve talked about how parents might handle things when their children want to join Facebook.

headline: Field Report: Market Share
text: In New York City, the push to eat locally can go only so far, allowing diners the occasional gotcha moment at restaurants that promote their sourcing. When I tasted the smooth, rich polenta at Roberta’s, a restaurant in Brooklyn that grows vegetables out back, I was sure I’d caught them. “Anson Mills, right?” I asked the chef, Carlo Mirarchi, name-checking the South Carolina gristmill of choice. He’d got me: “Cayuga Pure Organics, upstate.” O.K. . . . Did the staff forager at Print, an upscale locavore restaurant, find the nutty freekeh (roasted green wheat berries, a Middle Eastern specialty) that anchors its vegetable plate at Kalustyan’s, across town? Cayuga Pure Organics again. The heirloom beans at Gramercy Tavern? Exactly.

headline: Douglas Sirk Without Tears
text: THE director Douglas Sirk has become identified almost exclusively with the lushly produced, emotionally extravagant and flamboyantly hued melodramas he made near the end of his Hollywood career, movies like “All That Heaven Allows” (1955), “Written on the Wind” (1956) and “Imitation of Life” (1959).

headline: Chicken With Freekeh
text: 1 medium chicken (about 3 pounds)

headline: Spelt Sablés
text: 1 cup (4.5 ounces) unbleached all-purpose flour

headline: Eastwood Breaks Another Mold
text: ALMOST every fall lately, it seems, Clint Eastwood drops a little surprise on the moviegoing public: an unheralded, modestly budgeted film about a subject that hardly seems to fit the Eastwood mold. In 2004 there was “Million Dollar Baby,” about a female boxer; in 2008 there was “Gran Torino,” about a bigoted Korean War vet, played by Mr. Eastwood himself, who forms an unlikely, heartwarming friendship with a young Hmong boy. His latest film, “Hereafter,” which opened Friday in New York and will be released nationwide a week later, ventures into supernatural territory, which is about the last place you’d expect to find Mr. Eastwood. “Hereafter” concerns itself with just what the title suggests: what we can look forward to after we die.

headline: A Head Full of His Dreams
text: Antwerp

headline: India a Hit for Foreign Investors
text: MUMBAI, India  Two years ago, when the crisis on Wall Street reached its pinnacle, the high-flying Indian stock market fell with a thud as foreign investors took nearly $5 billion out of the country.

headline: Asked & Answered: Danny Clinch, Rock Photographer
text: Judging by the company he keeps, the rock photographer Danny Clinch has led a supremely charmed life: he started his career working for the shutterbug legends Mary Ellen Mark, Annie Leibovitz and Steven Meisel, before setting off on his own. Since then, he has shot his way through a good portion of the popular music pantheon, including Bob Dylan, Bruce Springsteen, Run-DMC, Tupac Shakur, Radiohead and Johnny Cash. The Moment recently caught up with photographer, harmonica player and filmmaker fresh off his latest assignment —a shoot for Dewar’s scotch. Starting on Thursday, Oct. 14, Clinch’s photos can be seen at the Morrison Hotel Gallery in SoHo as part of the exhibition “From Darkness to a Dream: The Images of Bruce Springsteen.”

headline: Finding Traces of Cinema in a Real-Life Rescue
text: Kirk Douglas starred as a former big-time New York City newspaper reporter in possibly the greatest man-stuck-in-hole-while-media-watches movie of all time, Billy Wilder’s “Ace in the Hole,” which came out in 1951. On Wednesday, like many of us, he watched as Chilean miners emerged from the earth one by one. City Room gave him a call and asked if it brought back memories.

headline: In a Page Six Reign, Stars and Scars
text: FEW newspaper columns survey the city’s cultural skyline as panoramically as Page Six, The New York Post’s marquee gossip page, which reports equally on the goings-on in downtown dive bars, corporate boardrooms and uptown penthouses.

headline: Is Samsung’s Galaxy Tab a Worthy Rival?
text: The first time I laid my eyes on my shiny new iPad, I was smitten.

headline: Surviving on the Front Lines
text: At the New York Times Small Business Summit, two business owners discussed networking, hiring and firing, and the role of luck.

headline: To Hone Message, White House Revives the ‘Gaggle’
text: As he came to the end of his morning session with reporters, Robert Gibbs, the White House press secretary, was asked about Karl Rove’s charge that the president has an “enemies list.” Mr. Gibbs scoffed and said it was unfounded.

headline: Sharing Online, but With More Than 140 Characters
text: The singer and guitarist John Mayer, whose prolific posts on Twitter drew nearly four million followers, shocked fans in mid-September by closing his account.

headline: Can Paul Rabil Make Lacrosse Sexy?
text: PAUL RABIL, “the LeBron James of lacrosse” to loyal fans, was shooting. He can fire the ball at up to 111 miles an hour, faster than a slap shot in hockey and only slightly slower than an archer’s hurtling arrow. But this time the shot missed, hitting the top goal post and ricocheting out toward the stands. A little girl in the line of fire screamed in an accelerating crescendo, “I don’t want to get hit, I don’t want to get killed!” The ball sailed harmlessly overhead. Calming down she asked, “Who shot that?”

headline: Witnesses Recount Horror at Ft. Hood
text: FORT HOOD, Tex.  The first few of dozens of witnesses to the 2009 massacre on this sprawling Army base gave chilling testimony on Wednesday in a pretrial hearing for Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan, who is charged in the attack.

headline: Every Finger Tells a Story
text: THREE years ago, Sharmadean Reid, a London nail salon owner, was watching the American Music Awards when she saw Beyoncé Knowles with a manicure that made her nails look as if they’d been plated with gold. “I paused the television,” she said. “I was like, ‘What is on her nails?’ Gimme now.”

headline: Work Wear Rebuilt for Idle Time
text: WHEN spies see each other across a room, do they flinch? Do they regard each other with quiet admiration, respecting their attempts at subterfuge?

headline: Huddy, Rap Promoter, Dies in Car Crash
text: Andre Hudson — also known as Huddy or Huddy 6 —a local celebrity on the Harlem rap scene who was a confidant to some of the biggest names to come out of the neighborhood, including the late Big L, Cam’ron and Jim Jones, was killed in a traffic accident on the George Washington Bridge early Wednesday.

headline: When Comic Books and Catwalks Collide
text: “Who are you wearing?” That overly familiar red-carpet question took on a bizarre resonance last weekend at Comic Con, a New York City convention for rabid devotees of comic books and graphic novels, film animation and video games.

headline: Too Long At the Fair
text: Jack Shafer has some fun mocking the perennial journalistic lament that this or that star athlete has stayed in the game too long, that he should have gone out on top when he had the chance, that he’s embarrassing himself, etc. Here’s Shafer’s rebuttal:

headline: In Rescue, from One Tight Situation to Another
text: SAN JOSÉ MINE, Chile — Some of the miners rescued here said they were touched by God. Others said they were pondering new careers, like Victor Segovia, who is writing a book about the ordeal. Yonni Barrios, 50, the electrician who was tasked with keeping health updates on the 33 men during their time underground, emerged with a bit more sizzle.

headline: Portable Art, Data Not Included
text: MOST of us think of them as cheap, utilitarian doodads that are about as aesthetically striking as thumb tacks and binder clips. But a new breed of flash drives  those matchbox-size storage devices that plug into your computer’s USB port  is challenging that no-frills image.

headline: The Mine Rescue: H. Sapiens at Its Best
text: The combination of endurance, audacity, innovation and courage on display at the mine head in the Atacama Desert of Chile over the last two months — and particularly the last few days — is humanity at its absolute best.

headline: Signing Up as an Organ Donor, the Easy Way
text: Last September in this newspaper, the economist Richard H. Thaler wrote an article calling on Steven P. Jobs of Apple to create an app that would enable people to quickly register to donate organs. Mr. Jobs didn’t answer the call, but Raymond Cheung, an independent app developer, did.

headline: Local Efforts to Help the Earth
text: EVEN as some saw The Unbearable Heaviness Of Being this summer as evidence that the globe is indeed warming, the attempt to live greener still engenders some dispute. An 82-year-old woman behind the effort to ban the sale of bottled water in Concord, Mass., plans to keep up the fight, despite challenges from the bottled water industry and the state’s attorney general. Raleigh, N.C., is a candidate for the Nice Try award, after a measure to outlaw garbage disposals there was repealed, preserving every citizen’s right to add even more gunk to the municipal water system.

headline: What Henry (Could Have) Heard: Night at the Frick
text: The passion of the industrialist Henry Clay Frick for the visual arts is well documented, his legacy preserved in the Frick Collection on Fifth Avenue. Less well known is his patronage and love of classical music, explored during a program called “A Gilded Age Evening in New York” in the museum’s music room on Tuesday.

headline: Financier Is Said to Accept a Ban in Pension Case
text: Steven Rattner, who oversaw the Obama administration’s overhaul of the auto industry, for months resisted a settlement with regulators over his role in New York pension fund kickbacks because he did not want to be banned from the securities industry.

headline: Truthiness
text: Around 4 p.m. on Oct. 17, 2005, Stephen Colbert was searching for a word. Not just any word, but one that would fit the blowhard persona that he was presenting that night on the premiere episode of Comedy Central’s “Colbert Report.” He once described his faux-pundit character as a “well-intentioned, poorly informed, high-status idiot,” and the word he was looking for had to be sublimely idiotic.

headline: Rattner Said to Settle S.E.C. Charges in Pension Case
text: Steven Rattner, the former car czar, has agreed to a settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission over kickback claims involving the New York State pension fund, The New York Times reported on Wednesday.

headline: Chasing a Fast-Fashion Knockoff
text: IT happens every season: the knockoff that sends me scrambling; the capsule collection that leads me on a treasure hunt, online and off; the bargain that I’m willing to fly overseas for. Logic has nothing to do with it.

headline: Melding Incongruities, as Only Those With a History Can
text: The guitarist John Abercrombie takes a measured, self-possessed approach to improvisation, so much so that it’s easy to underestimate the considerable chance taking in his playing. During the late set at Birdland on Tuesday night he played seated, using his thumb rather than a pick, and with only the rarest applications of pedal distortion. His demeanor was workmanlike, engrossed and inward turning, even as his solos flowed far and wide, moving forward in graceful and often unpredictable ways.

headline: A Romeo Who Struts, A Juliet Who Glitters
text: Charles Dutoit’s position as chief conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra was always meant to be an interim job, a way for both the ensemble and Mr. Dutoit to capitalize on their longstanding relationship while the management searched for a music director to succeed Christoph Eschenbach.

headline: Just Give Me Your Tired, Your Poor and Their Money
text: If the aim of black comedy is to get under the audience’s skin by gouging inappropriate humor out of uncomfortable situations, then the savagery of “Microcrisis” is impressive indeed.

headline: Neglected Gadgets on Stage
text: Ordinarily, this column is about electronics, or software, or tech culture.

headline: Sworn Statements Ordered in Massachusetts Case
text: More drama in the Massachusetts governor’s race: A judge on Wednesday ordered three former aides to Tim Cahill, the independent candidate, to submit sworn statements on whether they shared campaign secrets with Mr. Cahill’s Republican opponent.

headline: Primped and Pampered Princesses of La-La Land
text: Homogenized landscapes no longer shock. Americans have become used to retail sprawl, those swaths of stores — T. J. Maxx, Starbucks, the Gap, Bed Bath & Beyond — that sprout up all over without local roots or regard for regional differences.

headline: Rome Trial of Ex-Getty Curator Ends
text: ROME  The case against Marion True, the former curator of antiquities at the J.Paul Getty Museum, ended abruptly on Wednesday, after a court here ruled that the statute of limitations on her alleged crimes  receiving artifacts stolen from Italy and conspiring to deal in them  had expired.

headline: Life Choreographs Art
text: FEW may associate the word “innovation” with the American Ballet Theater, a company that is synonymous with “The Nutcracker,” a work it has performed year in and year out. But on Tuesday night at the Rose Hall at Lincoln Center, dance stars, fashion luminaries and bright lights in the city’s social stratosphere came out to celebrate the company’s wild side: four works by young ballet dancers who had won a competition to choreograph their own pieces.

headline: Old-School Electronica to Trip the Mind, Tickle the Eye and Sway the Body
text: Melancholy turns plush in the music of Kruder & Dorfmeister, the self-effacing Austrian electronica duo that performed at the Best Buy (formerly Nokia) Theater on Tuesday night, their first New York City appearance in nine years. The set moved chronologically through what their M.C., Earl Zinger, promised as their past, present and future. Their mission hasn’t changed; as Mr. Zinger sang, it was to make “your mind unravel and your body feel motion.”But the tempos have picked up.

text: POP-UP

headline: A Rescue Mirrors the Movies
text: A Wednesday article about Chilean miners being rescued from the San José Mine in some ways mirrored the dilemma that Kirk Douglas’s character faced in the 1951 film “Ace in the Hole.” City Room spoke to Mr. Douglas about the rescue. More from City Room.

headline: The Caucus Click: Outside Castle Rock, Colo.
text: Alongside Highway I-25, elections big and small are trying to attract voters’ attention.

headline: A Whale of a Journey, Captured in Photos
text: If you cruise the Web you can find long-lost friends, high school sweethearts and ... far-traveling humpback whales.

headline: Theater Talkback: When Page Meets Stage
text: Nobody goes to the theater to read. In our time at least, reading is usually a private, passive activity, experienced as an individual internal dialogue with a writer’s words. But a recent visit to “Gatz,” Elevator Repair Service’s word-for-word adaptation of F. Scott Fitzgerald’s “Great Gatsby” at the Public Theater, set me to thinking anew about shows that meld the experiences of the reader and the theatergoer.

headline: Love and Pain Relief
text: Love really can be a drug, according to new research that shows feelings of intense love can relieve pain.

headline: Video Highlights: Life on the Front Lines
text: At the recent New York Times Small Business Summit, two contributors to this blog, Jay Goltz and Paul Downs, took part in a panel discussion about life on the front lines of small business.

headline: Legal Tug of War Over Calder Sculpture
text: A huge motorized sculpture in Chicago by Alexander Calder, which has greeted and loomed over visitors to the tallest building in the country for 36 years, is at the center of a lawsuit that may put its future location in question. The owners of the 110-story Willis Tower, formerly the Sears Tower, want to keep the sculpture, “The Universe,” in the lobby, and are asking a Cook County Circuit Court judge to block the building’s former owner, Sears, Roebuck & Company, from buying it. The two sides disagreed about whether a 1994 option agreement that would allow Sears to purchase the art for half its appraised value was still valid in July, when Sears notified the current owners, 233 S. Wacker LLC, of its intent to buy. (The original agreement includes a clause terminating the option to buy upon the sale or transfer of the legal title to the tower property.) “The Universe” is 33 feet tall, 55 feet wide and weighs about 16,000 pounds; the plaintiffs’ lawyer, George B. Collins, said it would cost around $250,000 to move the sculpture. But “we don’t plan to move it,” Mr. Collins said. “We plan to win the case.” Kim Freely, a spokeswoman for Sears, declined to comment.

headline: Trade Officials Ponder China’s Rare Earth Stance
text: BEIJING  As a three-week-long Chinese suspension in exports of crucial minerals to Japan continues, American and Japanese trade officials have been considering whether to file cases against China at the World Trade Organization.

headline: Clash Of the Titan: Spielberg Films Will Duel
text: So it’s Spielberg versus Spielberg for the holidays in 2011. Stacey Snider, the DreamWorks chief executive, said in a conference call that “War Horse,” directed by Steven Spielberg, was being moved by DreamWorks and Disney to a release date of Dec. 28, 2011. That puts it on track for a release just five days after Paramount Pictures plans to release “The Adventures of Tintin: Secret of the Unicorn,” also directed by Mr. Spielberg. A Paramount spokeswoman did not immediately respond to an e-mail seeking comment. Asked about the potential collision, Ms. Snider said, “We think there’s room for a couple of holiday films during that season.” “War Horse” had been scheduled for release in August 2011, and the move pushes that movie into the film awards season but will leave Mr. Spielberg in a bit of a bind as he presumably works to promote both films.

headline: After Losing the Trick, Winning the Battle
text: PHILADELPHIA  At the world championships here on Monday, the Senior Teams was won by Garey Hayden and Reese Milner from the United States and Paul Hackett, Gunnar Hallberg and John Holland from England. In the 48-board final they defeated Victor Markowicz and Victor Melman from the United States, Julian Klukowski and Jerzy Russyan from Poland, Roald Ramer from the Netherlands and Shalom Zeligman from Israel by 72 international match points. The three English representatives won last year’s World Senior Teams in São Paulo, Brazil, defeating Markowicz, Klukowski and Russyan in that final.

headline: When iPhoto Meets Kindle

headline: Pass-Happy Broncos Are Actually Quite Unhappy
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. – The Denver Broncos have one of the most productive passing offenses in the N.F.L., and perhaps the most surprising. They have thrown for a 333-yard average this season, second best in a league that values passing more than ever.

headline: Group Seeks Food Label That Highlights Harmful Nutrients

headline: Earth Is Parched Where Syrian Farms Thrived
text: AR RAQQAH, Syria  The farmlands spreading north and east of this Euphrates River town were once the breadbasket of the region, a vast expanse of golden wheat fields and bucolic sheep herds.

headline: High Court Weighs Death Row Inmate’s DNA Query
text: WASHINGTON  In the course of an hourlong argument at the Supreme Court on Wednesday about a death row inmate’s quest to test DNA evidence, the justices asked neither of the questions that people without legal training might have thought crucial: Why won’t Texas prosecutors consent to the testing? And could the results show that the inmate, Henry W. Skinner, is innocent of the triple murder that sent him to death row?

headline: Cat People Are People, Too

headline: The Tools You Really Need to Maintain Your Home

headline: Edward Fields Updates Designs From Its Archives
text: Wavelength I, one of 11 new rugs from Edward Fields Carpet Makers based on designs from its archives, is an update of a pattern created in the 1970s. “It was part of a category of free-form designs — strong colors and big-scale motifs,” said Yasmina Kossmann, the design director. “They were done in wool, a high-cut pile, like a shag. It was the era of really heavy, comfortable rugs.”

headline: A Comedy Writer on Her New Career Making Mosaics
text: Sybil Sage, a veteran television comedy writer (for “The Mary Tyler Moore Show,” “Maude,” “Alice” and other gems from the written age), had been making objects with pique assiette — a French mosaic technique using broken plates — for years as a hobby, whacking china into shards to put on frames, vases and furniture for friends like Gene Wilder, Teri Garr, Lily Tomlin and Larry Merchant. She and her husband, Martin, who is also a comedy writer, had retired from television some years ago, and Ms. Sage said life was chugging along happily until 2008, when their savings were wiped out.

headline: An Austin Architect Turns Builder to Get a House Done
text: Austin, Tex.

headline: New Lamps From David Weeks
text: It has been eight years since David Weeks designed his first lighting collection for Ralph Pucci, but with this one — his fifth — he has finally hit his stride, he said. “There are four different directions,” Mr. Weeks said, “and they feel well conceived and less forced this time around. My progression is at a slow pace, so it makes sense it would take this long.”

headline: A New Monograph on Muji
text: Muji, the Japanese manufacturer, is known for the artful modesty of its products. In fact, the company has earned a cultish following for housewares so spare and generic they turn anonymity into a high aesthetic.

headline: Dwell Studio Opens a Shop at ABC Carpet & Home
text: Dwell Studio, the home accessories and furniture manufacturer, is opening its first shop, in the bedding department at ABC Carpet & Home, on Oct. 19.

headline: Stretch Pants, Vertically Speaking
text: IF you are looking for a fresh fashion muse, or a way to fritter away a few minutes on YouTube before your 10:30, you can kill two birds with one stone named Shelley Hack. Sure, there are clips of the ginger-haired actress in her most famous role, as the Boston-bred Tiffany Welles on “Charlie’s Angels,” but thanks to YouTube, her greatest achievement can now be appreciated: her glamorous ads for Charlie, the 1970s Revlon fragrance. Ms. Hack was breeziness incarnate, and demonstrated once and for all the fine art of wearing wide-leg pants. And given the return of the style this fall, most inspirationally on the Chloé runway, the ads should be required viewing, not merely to savor that Charlie je ne sais quoi, or to get the jingle, sung by Bobby Short, stuck irrevocably in your head, but to get the look down. Herewith, some tips.

headline: Ann Patchett’s Nashville Home
text: The pink brick house on a tree-lined street is a calm home base for the novelist.

headline: A Novelist’s Prime Nesting Place in Nashville
text: WHEN I was growing up, the joke in my family was that we moved every time the vacuum cleaner bag was full. We hoped that discontent could be cured by the packing and unpacking of boxes and so we tried it often. The most consistent home of my childhood belonged to the Wilsons, distant cousins by marriage, who let me stay with them for long stretches while other family members traveled. It was from their snug house that I rode my bike the two blocks over to Whitland Avenue, where I live now.

headline: The Annual Kips Bay Decorator Show House
text: After a six-month delay, the show house opened Thursday on the Upper East Side.

headline: Almost a No Go, the Kips Bay Decorator Show House Opens
text: IN New York City, real estate isn’t personal, it’s all business: in a face-off between a children’s charity and a record-breaking deal in a down market, whom would you put your money on? Last March, the Kips Bay Boys & Girls Club took it on the chin, when the property where its organizers had planned to hold their annual decorator show house the next month was sold.

headline: Vague, Opaque and Ambiguous: Israel’s Hush-Hush Nuclear Policy
text: In 1986 a former technician in the Dimona nuclear reactor in Israel revealed to The Sunday Times of London everything he knew about Israel’s clandestine nuclear weapons program. It caused a worldwide sensation, with experts estimating Israel’s arsenal at more than 100 atom bombs.

There was no entourage, no adoring fans  just a half-finished milkshake and the remains of a plate of Philly cheese steak egg rolls.

headline: Roberta Freymann Is All Over the Map by Design

headline: Sales at Blu Dot and More
text: King’s Road Home, the home furnishings company, is closing its SoHo shop and having a sale, with discounts of up to 75 percent on all items, through Nov. 15 (the Bobby dining table, originally $4,485, is $3,060; the Suar wood scoop bench, regularly $2,500, is $1,250; the Casa Modern NY coffee table, originally $2,100, is $525); 42 Wooster Street (Grand Street), (212) 941-5011, kingsroadhome.com.

headline: Another Democrat Says No to Pelosi

headline: From 10,000 Meters to 26.2 Miles in New York
text: PHILADELPHIA  Shalane Flanagan has yet to run a marathon, but she has already felt the electric energy that envelops race morning. Flanagan rose before dawn along with the runners of the 2009 Boston Marathon to make sure she could ride in the press truck that is driven ahead of the leaders. She embraced the runners’ nervous anticipation.

headline: Shunned for the Senate, Martha Coakley Hits the Massachusetts Trail Anew
text: WEYMOUTH, Mass.  It is enough to give any Massachusetts voter a throbbing sense of déjà-vu: Martha Coakley back on the campaign trail, extending her hand with her trademark clipped, “Nice to see you.”

headline: EMC Takes a Big-Data Swipe at Oracle, H.P. and I.B.M.

headline: Washington Chancellor’s Departure Isn’t Expected to Slow Public School Change
text: With Michelle Rhee’s decision to resign Wednesday as the Washington schools chancellor, the movement to shake up the nation’s public schools is losing perhaps its most visible leader.

headline: An End to Israel’s Invisibility
text: NEARLY 63 years after the United Nations recognized the right of the Jewish people to independence in their homeland  and more than 62 years since Israel’s creation  the Palestinians are still denying the Jewish nature of the state. “Israel can name itself whatever it wants,” said the Palestinian Authority president, Mahmoud Abbas, while, according to the newspaper Haaretz, his chief negotiator, Saeb Erekat, said that the Palestinian Authority will never recognize Israel as the Jewish state. Back in 1948, opposition to the legitimacy of a Jewish state ignited a war. Today it threatens peace.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Privacy and HTML 5
text: The language that’s the backbone of the Web is changing, and its latest version, HTML 5, is already being used to create new ways of experiencing online content. But HTML 5 is also raising privacy issues. On this week’s Tech Talk podcast for The New York Times, Bettina Edelstein talks to Tanzina Vega, a media reporter for The Times who has examined the implications of this new technology. Ms. Vega says that while HTML 5 offers benefits, like being able to use Web apps like e-mail when you’re offline, it can also collect personal data that it stores on computer hard drives, including Web-browsing histories, blog text, photos and messages. And deleting HTML 5’s so-called local storage can be tricky.

headline: Time to Forget Yanks-Rangers Season Series
text: When the Yankees swept a three-game series from Texas in mid-April, the Rangers started two pitchers, Scott Feldman and Rich Harden, who are not on their playoff roster, and another, C. J. Wilson, who lost when his defense collapsed behind him. Josh Hamilton, a leading candidate for most valuable player, left New York hitting .220.

headline: Israeli Minister Exposes Rift With Netanyahu
text: JERUSALEM  This week, Foreign Minister Avigdor Lieberman of Israel gave a dinner for the foreign ministers of France and Spain, who were here urging a West Bank settlement freeze to improve the chance for peace with the Palestinians. When the meal was over, Mr. Lieberman spoke.

text: Defying grim predictions about how they would fare after two months trapped underground, many of the Chilean miners came bounding out of their rescue capsule on Wednesday as pictures of energy and health, able not only to walk, but, in one case, to leap around, hug everyone in sight and lead cheers.

text: The flurry of managerial openings in the major leagues has made Bobby Valentine a busy man, with the Milwaukee Brewers the latest team to show interest.

Bloomberg has been busy this election season endorsing candidates from both parties all over the country, including Harry Reid, the Nevada Democrat and Senate majority leader, and Lincoln Chafee, the former Republican senator now running as an independent for governor of Rhode Island.

headline: Global Warning
text: ON Oct. 3, the State Department issued a travel advisory to Americans about potential terrorist attacks in Europe. The same day, Britain issued a travel advisory based on the threat of terrorist attacks in France and Germany. Shortly afterward, the French government alerted its citizens to an increased risk of a terrorist attack in Britain.

headline: For Reid, No Shaking Tea Party Challenger

When that didn’t seem to work, he thought he could pull out this election with a scorched-earth campaign aimed at his Republican opponent, Sharron Angle, a Tea Party candidate with a rich history of unorthodox statements and politically unpopular positions.

headline: Dithering on ‘Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell’

headline: Princeton’s Jordan Culbreath Regains Health and Form
text: PRINCETON, N.J.  It would have been completely understandable if Princeton running back Jordan Culbreath, brimming with potential off the field, had decided never to play football again. A mechanical and aerospace engineering major, he, along with a friend, invented a cold-water treatment tub with a refrigeration and filtration system that has saved Princeton thousands of dollars on ice.

headline: G.O.P. Accelerates, but Speed Bumps Remain
text: WASHINGTON  Democrats virtually conceding House races. House Republicans sensing real chances for victory in contests that seemed far out of reach only weeks ago. Third-party groups putting millions of dollars behind Republican contenders, eliminating one last big Democratic advantage.

headline: Glimpse at Jurors in Ex-Guantánamo Detainee’s Trial
text: They include a handyman from the Bronx, a registered nurse from Manhattan and a 22-year-old restaurant worker in Westchester County who is attending college. This week, they joined nine other people as members of the jury in the first civilian trial of a former detainee at the military prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.

text: Did he ever return?No he never returnedAnd his fate is still unlearn’dHe may ride forever’neath the streets of BostonHe’s the man who never returned.

Jacobs Theater, where it opened on Wednesday night.

headline: George W. Bush Is Back in the Rangers’ Front Row
text: George W. Bush does not appear to be a luxury suite type of guy.
