text: Chet Gresham blogs about fantasy football at Razzball. You can follow him on Twitter @Chetrazzball.

headline: The Next Bubble
text: It seems premature to start worrying about the next financial crisis. Yet amid the current gloom, Wall Street is snapping up assets of the “emerging economies” that are growing faster and offer higher, more consistent returns. Financial regulators and policy makers in these countries need to pay close attention.

headline: French General Mixes Formula for a Bit of Afghan Calm
text: FORWARD OPERATING BASE TORA, Afghanistan  Just east of Kabul lies a stark mountain moonscape that for centuries was home to gunmen who preyed on travelers and harassed invaders in the narrow mountain passes. As recently as last year, ambushes of NATO troops were not uncommon.

headline: U.S. Aids Taliban to Attend Talks on Making Peace
text: The U.S. effort to support preliminary talks with the Karzai government might reflect pessimism that the buildup of American forces will defeat the Taliban.

headline: Sportscasting Fixture Files Age-Discrimination Lawsuit
text: Sal Marchiano, a decades-long fixture in New York sportscasting, filed suit Wednesday in Manhattan federal court accusing Betty Ellen Berlamino, the former general manager of WPIX-TV/Channel 11, of age discrimination when she did not renew his contract in 2008.

headline: For Senator and Governor in Connecticut
text: The bitter contest to replace retiring Senator Christopher Dodd pits the charm-free, experienced public servant against the splashy business executive. Connecticut voters should pick experience.

headline: U.S. to Let Insurers Raise Fees for Sick Children
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration, aiming to encourage health insurance companies to offer child-only policies, said Wednesday that they could charge higher premiums for coverage of children with serious medical problems, if state law allowed it.

headline: As the iPhone Goes ...
text: Apple isn’t commenting on reports that it will release a new iPhone for use on Verizon Wireless’s network next year. We find the prospect of a non-AT&T iPhone tantalizing. Could it mean that wireless service providers will finally have to accept real competition?

headline: Inquiry Into Assemblyman Prompts Halt to Suit
text: Citing a federal investigation of Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez, a state judge on Wednesday suspended a Brooklyn community group’s lawsuit against New York City over a planned low-income housing development involving Mr. Lopez’s sprawling social-service organization.

headline: For the Rich, It’s Always Special Arrangements
text: Paul B. Martinez fell in love with carnations 52 years ago. He was 13, a poor kid growing up in East Harlem, where his Puerto Rican-born father ran a bodega with his uncle. When a guy named Nick, who owned the combination hot dog stand/flower shop next door, needed a delivery boy, Mr. Martinez took the job: 50 cents per trip, mostly carnations and gladioluses destined for neighborhood funeral homes. Now 65, he is a designer and manager at Flowers by Philip on Madison Avenue, owned by Philip Mercedes. He lives in Yorkville with his wife, Puma.

headline: Mets Turn to Boston in Search for a G.M.
text: Of the three executives the Mets have interviewed for their vacant general manager’s position, two played key roles for the Red Sox during their recent World Series championships, and they received glowing recommendations Wednesday from Boston’s general manager, Theo Epstein.

headline: Producers Guild Pushes for Clearer Film Credits
text: LOS ANGELES  Think of it as a Good Housekeeping Seal of Approval for the calfskin loafers set. The Producers Guild of America is quietly pressing the major film studios to begin including a new “producer’s mark”  comprising the lower-case letters “p.g.a.”  behind the names of some people who are granted a coveted “produced by” credit on theatrical films, guild officials confirmed on Wednesday.

headline: N.C.A.A. Is Investigating Baylor Men’s Program
text: LA PORTE, Ind.  Kevin Kunst, the athletic director at La Lumiere School, said on Wednesday that the N.C.A.A. is engaged in a wide investigation of the Baylor University’s men’s basketball program that includes its recruitment of Hanner Perea, a forward from Colombia who is widely considered one of the best 25 high school juniors in the country.

headline: Unexpected Turns for Suit Over ‘Don’t Ask’ Rule
text: The timing could not have been worse. Just as the Log Cabin Republicans’ lawsuit challenging “don’t ask, don’t tell” was finally racing out of judicial limbo in 2009, the group was in disarray.

headline: Awaiting the Next Step on Policy on Gay Service
text: Each side of the controversy over the “don’t ask, don’t tell” law that restricts openly gay men and women from serving in the military waited on Wednesday for the Obama administration to reveal its next move in court.

headline: Democratic Polling Improves in Key Senate Races, Lengthening G.O.P. Takeover Odds
text: After having lost ground in the Senate forecast for three consecutive weeks, Democrats have demonstrated improved polling in several key matchups over the past week, dimming Republican hopes for taking over the chamber.

headline: Stoudemire Makes Good First Impression
text: The introduction was a tad understated, at least by Amar’e Stoudemire’s standards. He did not dislodge the rim from the backboard or block a shot into the expensive seats or ruin anyone’s self-esteem. There will be many chances for that later, when the games count.

headline: Vazquez’s Final Pitch in Pinstripes?
text: In front of 50,287 empty seats, Javier Vazquez climbed the mound at Yankee Stadium on Wednesday for what could have been his final time in pinstripes. There were no farewell ceremonies or video montages to commemorate the occasion, just a few simulated innings intended more to preserve the hitters’ timing than to keep his arm fresh.

headline: Ben Quayle Faulted by Opponent in Debate
text: Jon Hulburd, a Democrat running for Arizona’s Third Congressional District, tried to draw blood in what was his first, and likely last, debate with Republican Ben Quayle, son of the former vice president, on Wednesday night.

headline: A Casualty Both of War and the Spanish Economy
text: MOLLET DE VALLÈS, Spain  Belly Meneses Díaz and John Felipe Romero Moreno have a special shelf in their living room. It holds a Spanish flag, war medals and a polished wooden box with the ashes of their youngest son. He was 21 when he was killed in northern Afghanistan earlier this year.

headline: Canada Declares BPA, a Chemical in Plastics, to Be Toxic
text: OTTAWA — The government of Canada formally declared bisphenol A, a chemical widely used to create clear, hard plastics, as well as food can liners, to be a toxic substance on Wednesday.

headline: At Polo Store, the Feel of a Mansion to Bolster a Brand
text: “Big cities have international people,” Ralph Lauren said. “Tourists come wanting to buy souvenirs.”

headline: Besides Hungarian Sludge, Potential Troubles Lurk
text: BUDAPEST — As the death toll from the Hungarian sludge disaster reached nine on Wednesday, environmentalists warned of other potentially lethal accidents across a region dotted with poorly maintained industrial facilities.

headline: Bloggingheads: Not-So-Free Checking
text: Tim Fernholz, left, of The American Prospect and Katherine Mangu-Ward of Reason debate new rules about overdraft fees.

headline: Five Public Colleges in Georgia Ban Illegal-Immigrant Students
text: ATLANTA — Education officials in Georgia voted Wednesday to bar illegal immigrants from attending the state’s five most selective public colleges, a decision that immigrant rights groups threatened to challenge in court.

headline: Mexican Investigator of American’s Killing Is Beheaded
text: HOUSTON  An investigation into a reported shooting of an American on a border reservoir took a bizarre turn this week when the Mexican police chief overseeing the search was murdered and his head was left in a suitcase outside a military base, the Zapata County Sheriff’s Office said.

text: The day in sports photographs.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,313 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: Tribune Executive Suspended for a Memo Found Offensive
text: The Tribune Company on Wednesday suspended an executive who sent out a companywide memo with links to Web parodies featuring obscene language.

headline: David F. Musto, Expert on Drug Control, Dies at 74
text: Dr. David F. Musto, an expert on drug-control policy who wrote an important history of drug use in the United States and government efforts to control it and served as a government adviser on drug policy during the Carter administration, died Friday in Shanghai. He was 74 and lived in New Haven.

headline: John Huchra Dies at 61; Maps Altered Ideas on Universe
text: John Huchra, a man who loved telescopes and whose pioneering maps of a bubbly universe challenged notions of how the galaxies were born, died on Friday at his home in Lexington, Mass. He was 61.

headline: Cablevision Subscribers Facing Loss of Fox Shows
text: Cablevision customers may want to make backup plans for watching this Sunday’s Giants football game.

headline: Osteoporosis Drugs May Be Linked to Fractures
text: Certain drugs used to treat the bone-thinning disorder osteoporosis may increase the risk of a rare type of break in the hip or thighbone, the Food and Drug Administration said on Wednesday. The drugs, in a class called bisphosphonates, are Fosamax, Fosamax Plus D, Actonel, Actonel with Calcium, Boniva, Atelvia, and Reclast (and their generic products). The types of break account for less than 1 percent of all hip and thigh fractures, and it is not certain that the drugs are to blame, but many people with these injuries have been taking the drugs. Warnings will be added to the drug labels. Patients are advised not to stop the drugs without consulting their doctors, and to tell a doctor if they develops hip or thigh pain while taking the medicines.

headline: Microsoft’s Bing Gets a Social Lift From Facebook

headline: Exports of Chinese Goods Continued to Surge in September

headline: Raising Capital and Using It Well

The bank’s own valuation, long at a premium to peers, is looking distinctly high.

headline: As Populations Age, a Chance for Younger Nations
text: YOU MAY KNOW that the world’s population is aging — that the number of older people is expanding faster than the number of young — but you probably don’t realize how fast this is happening. Right now, the world is evenly divided between those under 28 and those over 28. By midcentury, the median age will have risen to 40. Demographers also use another measure, in addition to median age, to determine whether populations are aging: “elder share.” If the share, or proportion, of people over 60 (or sometimes 65) is growing, the population is aging. By that yardstick too, the world is quickly becoming older. Pick any age cohort above the median age of 28 and you’ll find its share of the global population rising faster than that of any segment below the median. By 2018, 65-year-olds, for example, will outnumber those under 5 — a historic first. In 2050, developed countries are on track to have half as many people under 15 as they do over 60. In short, the age mix of the world is turning upside down and at unprecedented rates.

headline: And Then There’s Mrs. B
text: Call me naïve. Some years ago — never mind how long precisely — having no literary project on the boards, I thought I would open a small fish joint in this watery end of the world. Little did I imagine the sheer volume of human beings with whom I would come into contact on a daily, no, hourly basis. All manner of humans: professional, half-formed and holy humans; newbies and wannabes; multilingual, minimally trained, overqualified, fried, rehabbing, should-be-rehabbing humans; ambitious people, passionate people and degenerate people. They surround you like the ocean. You could drown in them. They keep you afloat. They are exhausting.

headline: Mr. Strummy-Strum Tries a Synth Sound

He can see the party boats and barges float by, joined occasionally by groups of kayakers. And he can see the workers at the Con Edison power plant across from his building. It looks like the set of an old sci-fi movie and emits, he says, a high, crinkly buzzing sound. “Many a day has gone by where I’ve done nothing but just watch,” he said. He keeps a pair of binoculars on the windowsill, but doesn’t really use them to spy.

headline: Saloni Milano NYC
text: Milan’s annual design week, Salone Internazionale del Mobile, turns 50 next April. As part of the global run-up to the festivities, New York will host ‘‘I Saloni Milano in New York,’’ a six-week program starting Nov. 29 that will bring a taste of the design world’s reigning extravaganza to Manhattan. It’s a mini-Salone, in which 20 Italian furniture showrooms (including B&B Italia, Flos and Poltrona Frau) will host ‘‘Italian Christmas’’ exhibitions; the director Peter Greenaway’s Milan-centric video installation, ‘‘Leonardo’s Last Supper: A Vision’’ (above), which was seen at the Salone in 2008, will take over the Park Avenue Armory; and the theater visionary Robert Wilson will create video portraits of Roberto Bolle, who dances at La Scala, interacting with an assortment of iconic design objects (Nov. 30 through Dec. 18 at Center 548). Design has always been close to Wilson’s heart. ‘‘When I was 8 years old,’’ he says, ‘‘in the middle of the night I took all the plates and glasses out of the kitchen closet and put them back in the shelves in a designed order.’’ Perfetto.

headline: Younger Than That Now: Revisiting Bob Dylan’s ‘Witmark Demos’ in Film

headline: City Ballet Arrived Early, With Revelations
text: NEW YORK CITY BALLET’S first fall season at Lincoln Center has come and gone, along with talking dancers and conductors. (We, and they, survived.) Until this year, when New York City Opera ceded the time slot, audiences had to wait until late November and “The Nutcracker” to see the company, and City Ballet often toured abroad at this time. It was invigorating to have its performances as part of the general cultural rush of the fall, and the season, which ended last Sunday, was intriguing in ways both usual  the charting of dancers’ progress, debuts in roles, new work  and, in at least one case, unexpected.

headline: Forget the Downturn; Punish the Lazybones
text: IN the new ABC series “No Ordinary Family’‘ an affluent couple, Jim and Stephanie Powell (Michael Chiklis and Julie Benz), living with their teenage children in Modernist splendor in Los Angeles, struggle with the pressures of careerism. Stephanie is a research scientist who works 80-hour weeks and answers to barracudas. She’s the kind of person who, with the best of intentions, will plan to meet you for dinner at 8, call at 8:10 to say that she’s running late and then realize at 10:15 that she won’t be able to make it until possibly the next leap year. She rarely has time to talk to her husband and doesn’t realize that her son has learning difficulties. All of this is presented as a problem in need of a solution.

headline: On Our Radar: Skepticism on Carbon Offsets
text: Skepticism runs high on the Clean Development Mechanism, a carbon offset program created by the Kyoto Protocol. The program allows companies in industrialized countries to earn carbon credits by sponsoring greenhouse gas reduction projects in developing countries. Large numbers of credits have been given for the construction of hydroelectric dams in China, however, which experts call an abuse of the system. [The International Herald Tribune]

headline: Reporting From the Women’s Forum
text: This week I travel to Deauville, France, to attend the sixth Women’s Forum for the Economy and Society, an annual meeting that brings together influential women — and men — from around the world. Described as “Davos for Women,” the forum was founded by French entrepreneur Aude de Thuin, who saw a need to give voice to the other half of the population after she failed to receive an invitation to the predominantly male gathering in the Swiss Alps. The 2010 forum will focus on change in politics, the economy, the environment, global health, and the steps necessary to enable progress in all by facilitating full participation by women.

headline: Municipal Bonds
text: I moved to Milan in 1949, when my parents left Piacenza to take advantage of the opportunities for work and advancement that Milan offered after the war. In spite of the depth of the attachment that I feel to the city in which I have built my career, I am always aware that Milan does have its shortcomings and that it lies at times in thrall to a prevailing mood of melancholy, which has perhaps altered its character and diminished its sense of optimism, its capacity to think big and retain the confidence to accomplish its ambitions. As the Italian capital of financial activity and the world capital of fashion, design and opera, Milan derives its unique strength, I believe, from its capacity to promote a continuous flow of creative ideas and harness them into successful commercial ventures. I love this city most when its sense of discipline is evident, expressed through its citizens’ work ethic and ability to plan on a large scale. I also love its rational approach — one driven by passion and generosity. (It’s no coincidence that Milan is the center of the nation’s charitable sector.) I hope that the optimism and the characteristic determination of the Milanese will provide a much-needed stimulus to the public sector, because the greater one’s love for a city, the more one expects from it. From this perspective, Expo 2015 could be the turning point, the opportunity to boost Milan’s prestige and provide the perfect arena to reassert our claim to greatness.

headline: When to Push Through the Pain Is a Difficult Question
text: Training for a marathon is a delicate balancing act for athletes who must push themselves beyond certain limits, but know when to listen to their bodies. Injuries, small and large, can derail the efforts of amateur runners or some of the best in the marathon business. This week, the two-time champion Martin Lel of Kenya and his compatriot Robert Cheruiyot announced they would pull out of New York because of injuries. Lel, who won New York in 2003 and 2007, has a leg injury. Cheruiyot, the four-time Boston Marathon champion who finished second in New York last year, has a groin-muscle injury.

headline: Fasten Your Seat Belts and Embrace the City
text: I don’t think the woman who flashed us the other night on West 57th Street by lifting up her shirt was in the cast of the new bus ride/city tour/improv show/New York experience called “The Ride.” But I’m only guessing, because one business-suited passerby on 42nd Street was so intoxicated by the Broadway melodies being broadcast by our passing bus that he dropped his briefcase and leapt into a vaudeville tap-dance routine right out of a 1930s musical. And a late-night deliveryman on East 43rd Street was so caught up by the passing tour’s blaring hip-hop soundtrack that he spun and flipped into a virtuosic break-dance routine.

headline: Restaurant Review: The Corson Building in Seattle
text: You can learn a lot about what sort of restaurant the Corson Building is by taking a trip around its Web site. And there are prominent references to the food writer Angelo Pellegrini, whose philosophy, Corson’s co-owner and chef Matthew Dillon said, was about “taking the gourmet out of it, and just having dinner.”

headline: Now Showing | Linder Sterling’s Fashion Turn
text: Anyone who smears raw steak on themselves in public — a gesture of both feral sexuality and absurdity — owes a debt to the Liverpool-born feminist punk artist Linder Sterling. Linder’s “menstrual jewelry” (made from absorbent cotton and red nail polish) turned tampons into pretty punk-feminist totems. Her arresting collages from the ’70s give girly pop teeth. (See her cover for the Buzzcock’s “Orgasm Addict.”) And her ethereal wailing, crying and laughter as a member of the British punk band Ludus were the expression of her interest in ritual, religious ecstasy and the torment from her art.

text: Oh, it’s a sad day in techland.

headline: Pfizer Accused of Lack of Disclosure
text: Previously unpublished data from Pfizer shows its antidepressant drug reboxetine is “ineffective and potentially harmful,” according to a German research group’s report Wednesday, triggering another round of debate about how much information should be publicly disclosed.

headline: Beard Awards Will Not Distinguish Between Online and Print Journalism
text: Do you write about food online or in print, for a magazine or a newspaper? It no longer matters to the James Beard Foundation.

headline: Going Beyond Cliché: How to Write a Great College Essay
text: Overview | What makes a college essay “work”? How can writers reveal themselves through writing? In this lesson, students explore sample college essays and then consider advice about what separates a great essay from a mediocre or ineffective one as well as essay-writing tips. Finally, they write essays based on the piece of advice that resonated with them.

headline: What We’re Reading: The Burger King Kids
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: Could Main Street Break a Bank?
text: If you spot copies of an adult magazine being passed around bank offices this month, it may not be what you think.

headline: Fewer People Choose Cobra Subsidy Option
text: Is the cost of health insurance so out of reach that even when the federal government helps out, many people still can’t afford coverage? According to a new analysis by the Employee Benefits Research Institute, the answer may be yes.

headline: O’Reilly Comments Lead to Walk Off at ‘The View’
text: An interview with the Fox News host Bill O’Reilly on the ABC daytime show “The View” turned heated on Thursday morning, prompting the show’s co-hosts Whoopi Goldberg and Joy Behar to walk off the set for a short time.

headline: Chefs Show Their Kitchen Battle Scars
text: Thirteen chefs share stories of kitchen cooking accidents and culinary scars in the latest issue of The New York Times Magazine. It’s an entertaining glimpse into the fast-paced, intense and even abusive world of culinary excellence. But some of the lessons also are relevant to home cooks. Among the culinary cautions offered by the chefs:

headline: Where the Crisis Has Wreaked the Most Damage
text: As my colleagues Michael Powell and Motoko Rich detailed recently, the financial crisis has caused longer-term pain that is expected to last well beyond the confines of the financial panic itself. It has wrought a sort of economic reset, slowing down growth for years to come.

headline: World’s Fittest Gold Bug: Mr. T
text: I pity the fool who misses this most excellent Bloomberg Television interview:

headline: Chinese Fans Greet an Older, Slower Yao With Same Gusto
text: It was the welcome normally reserved for a rock star: screaming fans, waving arms, and a surge of excitement.

headline: An Odd Couple: Yahoo and Goldman
text: Yahoo, which is reportedly the target — or not — of a potential takeover by AOL and private-equity firms, has been holding meetings with its bankers to prepare itself in the event it receives an offer, people close to the company said.

headline: Book Shelf | DC Comics Turns 75
text: They say you should not judge a book by its cover, but maybe no one told the folks at DC Comics or Quirk Books, who have teamed up for “DC Comics: The 75th Anniversary Poster Book.” Inside are 100 covers from the DC archives from three-quarters of a century. The slide show contains some of our favorites from the $40 book.

headline: Pogue’s Posts: Farewell, GOOG-411
text: It’s a sad day in techland, writes David Pogue on his blog.

headline: Torn Between 2 Phones, Again: Android vs. Windows Phone 7
text: Earlier this year readers who were unhappy with Apple’s closed app ecosystem and frustrated with AT&T’s spasmodic service asked via e-mail and Twitter if the Android platform could be a real competitor to the iPhone. In a blog post I compared Google’s Nexus One phone running the Android operating system to the venerable Apple iPhone.

headline: Running for a Cause: Commitment Challenge
text: For four years, I talked about running the New York City Marathon. But each year I ended up curbside, coffee cup in hand, watching waves of people push themselves to the finish. I would leave the race and say to friends, “I’d really like to run the marathon while I live in New York.”

headline: For Every Rescued Miner in Chile, Hundreds Far Less Lucky
text: Skip this post if you prefer to bask in the happy ending that played out on your TV screen all day on Wednesday as 33 miners in Chile stumbled out of a tiny hole in the ground.

headline: TimesCast | October 14, 2010
text: Ahmadinejad visits Lebanon; Delaware Senate candidates face off and talk of the next Pavarotti.

headline: 66 Years Later, a Bronze Star
text: For more than 50 years, George Vujnovich was a mild-mannered salesman working away at his small business in Queens and living a quiet life on a quiet block in Jackson Heights. He never spoke, even to his closest friends, about his secret role organizing one of the greatest rescue missions of World War II.

headline: Mozilla Taps SAP Executive as New Chief
text: Mozilla, the maker of the open-source Firefox Web browser, said Thursday that it would appoint Gary Kovacs, a veteran software executive, as its new chief executive. The appointment ends a nearly six-month search that began after John Lilly, who has been Mozilla’s chief executive for the last three years, announced that he would leave to join Greylock Partners, a venture capital firm.

headline: Q&A: Where to Go Near Tuscany for Christmas
text: Based on the enticing Travel section article “Tuscany Without the Crowds” (March 7, 2010), my husband and I are planning a week in the Val d’Orcia after Christmas. The problem is: we fly into Milan the week before and don’t know where to go over Christmas (we will be in Milan for several days at the end of the trip). We’ve never been to Venice. Any ideas?

headline: British Judge Refuses to Throw Out Suit Accusing Rowling of Plagiarism
text: J. K. Rowling, the author of the Harry Potter books, still cannot make a years-old plagiarism charge disappear. A lawsuit in a British court accusing Ms. Rowling of partly copying a 1987 book, “The Adventures of Willy the Wizard,” by Adrian Jacobs, may go to trial now that a judge has turned down an application by Ms. Rowling’s lawyers to dismiss the case, according to Reuters.

headline: Chilean Miner to Be Invited to New York Marathon
text: A variety of windfalls — perhaps including book and movie deals and trips to Greece and Graceland— may be on the way for the 33 miners who emerged after being trapped for more than two months beneath the Chilean desert. But already, less than 24 hours after the completion of the globally televised and celebrated rescue, one miner has attracted a singular solicitation: an invitation to the New York City Marathon.

headline: Grand Jury to Look Into City Role in Brooklyn Girl’s Death
text: The Brooklyn district attorney’s office impaneled a special grand jury today to look into the death of 4-year-old Marchella Pierce and subpoenaed records from the city’s Administration for Children’s Services as well as from a city contractor and a hospital that had roles in her care, the office said.

headline: Securing Your Laptop Before It Gets Stolen
text: If your laptop happens to be stolen, as mine recently was, it can be a big hassle to protect your data after the fact. That’s why it’s important to know how to secure your laptop before it’s gone.

headline: Week 6 N.F.L. Game Probabilities
text: Just as predicted this past off-season, New York is home to the best defense in the N.F.L. But it doesn’t belong to the Jets.

headline: Afghanistan: The Problems With Partnering
text: PASHMUL, Afghanistan – From inside the outpost, the sounds of a gunfight were unmistakable. First the clatter of assault rifles and machine guns, then the sound of rocket-propelled grenades exploding a few hundred yards away. Finally, the report of an 82mm recoilless rifle firing off one big shell, then another, then a third.

headline: Steve Fossett’s Land Speed Racer Is Up for Sale
text: Steve Fossett, the millionaire businessman and adventurer perhaps best known for circumnavigating the world nonstop in a hot air balloon, was preparing to break the absolute land speed record — 763 miles per hour — when he died. He was declared dead after the single-engine plane he was piloting disappeared over the east-central mountains of California in September 2007. (The plane and Mr. Fossett’s remains were later discovered near Mammoth Lakes, Calif.)

headline: Artifacts | Frieze-Dried London
text: Art people have their rituals, especially when it comes to international trade shows. The moment they hit a host town – say, London, where the eighth annual Frieze Art fair opened to V.I.P.’s yesterday – they adopt a pattern of social behavior calculated to produce a buzz. Galleries, museums and auctions houses do their best to whet everyone’s appetite for spending money with openings and parties, and visiting dealers, collectors and curators try to be first to spot art that will make the world feel fresh and new.

headline: Punch, the Drink of Dickens, Redeemed
text: Ask David Wondrich how he became so fascinated with punch — as in the liquid curse of many a holiday party, ladled out in portions too stinting to dull the pain of forced conversation and obligatory merriment — and suddenly you’re in England. In the middle of the 19th century. At Charles Dickens’s house.

headline: Third-Quarter G.D.P. Forecast Revised Down
text: Speaking of slow growth, Macroeconomic Advisers, a respected forecasting firm, has just downgraded its estimate for third-quarter annual output growth to a measly 1.2 percent.

headline: Derek Jacobi, Alan Rickman, Geoffrey Rush To Take BAM Stage in the Spring
text: The Brooklyn Academy of Music has organized a particularly theater-heavy line-up for its spring 2011 season, including a Donmar Warehouse production of “King Lear” starring Derek Jacobi; the Abbey Theater’s staging of Ibsen’s “John Gabriel Borkman,” with Alan Rickman and Fiona Shaw; and an Australian mounting of Gogol’s “Diary of a Madman” starring Geoffrey Rush.

headline: Police Shoot Bank Robbery Suspect Near Penn Station
text: Updated, 5:47 p.m. | One day after being released from federal prison, a 69-year-old man was shot and wounded by a police officer after trying to hold up a bank branch steps from Penn Station on Thursday afternoon, police officials said.

headline: Just When He Thought His Suffering Was Over, an Invitation to More
text: After running underground for two months to preserve his sanity and his body as he awaited rescue along with 32 other miners in the Chilean desert, Edison Peña may have earned himself a unique reward: a seat at the New York City Marathon or, if he desires, an entry.

headline: Reader Rejoinders
text: An occasional assemblage of overheard or underappreciated words – generously emailed by co-vocabularists.

headline: ArtsBeat: O’Reilly Comments Lead to Walkout at ‘The View’
text: Dave Itzkoff reports that an interview with the Fox News host Bill O’Reilly on the ABC daytime show “The View” turned heated on Thursday morning, prompting the show’s co-hosts Whoopi Goldberg and Joy Behar to walk off the set for a short time.

headline: The Doctor Is In (but Shouldn’t Be)
text: One winter toward the end of my training, I came down with a cold. At first, the constant coughing and runny nose made me miserable; then they became tiring. To decrease the chances of spreading my germs, I had to tie on a mask every time I came into contact with patients, wash my hands so frequently my skin became raw and wipe down the phone receivers with alcohol when I answered a page. Unable to scratch, wipe or blow in the operating room without contaminating my hands, I learned that for a surgeon with a runny nose, there are no palatable options for the uncontrollable nasal effluvium; I had to wear two masks every time I scrubbed up for a case.

headline: Why Doctors Should Take Sick Days
text: As many as 80 percent of physicians continue to work when they are sick, even though they would have excused patients in the same condition, writes Dr. Pauine Chen in this week’s Doctor and Patient column.

headline: O’Neal: Not Playing, Still Talking
text: Shaquille O’Neal still commands the room, even at age 38, even in street clothes, even on nights when he never leaves the bench.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Lebanon and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Lebanon, Afghanistan and Greece.

headline: Screen Test: Margareth Madè
text: The Italian actress on working with Sophia Loren, her role in "Baaria" by Giuseppe Tornatore and what she loves about Milan.

headline: Striking Detroit Musicians’ Concert to Be Televised
text: The striking musicians of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra have won a small propaganda coup. A local television station, WADL-TV38, has decided to broadcast one of their concerts, a program on Oct. 24 at a church in the affluent Detroit suburb of Bloomfield Hills, Mich. The musicians went on strike on Oct. 4 over wage and benefit cuts and work rule changes at the financially troubled orchestra. They have been playing concerts on their own, to earn publicity and money to support the strike, a common practice in such disputes. The program features Vivaldi’s “Four Seasons” and Brahms Symphony No. 2, conducted by Joseph Silverstein.

headline: The Caucus
text: The Times's Megan Liberman and Frank Bruni discuss how the two Delaware Senate candidates, Chris Coons and Christine O'Donnell, during their debate on Wednesday night, embodied the difficulties each of their political parties is facing this election cycle.

headline: India Declares Commonwealth Games a Success
text: NEW DELHI  The Commonwealth Games, which opened 12 days ago with the world bracing for the worst, managed to conclude on Thursday without any of the predicted embarrassment or disaster. Stadiums did not collapse. Terrorists did not strike. Fears of disease went mostly unrealized. And the closing ceremony was a stirring success.

headline: Electric Youth
text: For its first collaboration with the watchmakers TKO Orlogi, Henri Bendel is turning back the clock to the ’90s slap band craze. Like those fun bracelets of yore, the watch’s interchangeable straps come in a range of neon colors. At only $50 a pop, the watches are a wallet-friendly alternative to Balenciaga’s eye-catching timepieces on the runway for spring.

headline: Bypassed Cellphones: Biased Polls?
text: On Wednesday, Pew Research issued a study suggesting that the failure to include cellphones in a survey sample — and most pollsters don’t include them — may bias the results against Democrats. Pew has addressed this subject a number of times before, and in their view, the problem seems to be worsening. Indeed, this is about what you might expect, since the fraction of voters who rely on cellphones is steadily increasing: about 25 percent of the adult population now has no landline phone installed at all.

headline: TimesCast: The Debate for Delaware Senate
text: The Times’s Megan Liberman and Frank Bruni discussed the debate Wednesday night between the two candidates for Delaware’s Senate seat, Chris Coons and Christine O’Donnell.

headline: The Young Guns of Finance
text: DealBook loves lists, and Fortune magazine gives us a scrumptious one today with its “40 Under 40″ ranking of business’s hottest rising stars. (This reporter has about one month until his 40th birthday — and, alas, has never made this illustrious list — so our exuberance is somewhat muted this year.)

headline: We Are Not Alone
text: Here’s what’s happening on the U.F.O. front Thursday afternoon, a day after silver objects hovered briefly in the skies over western Manhattan.

headline: And Now, a Grand Prix in Russia
text: The rumors were rife at the Japanese Grand Prix that Formula One was about to announce a deal to race in Russia.

headline: And Now, a Grand Prix in Russia
text: The rumors were rife at the Japanese Grand Prix that Formula One was about to announce a deal to race in Russia.

headline: Rescue May Redeem a Troubled Past for Chilean City
text: COPIAPÓ, Chile — Though the vuvuzelas have quieted down, this desert city is still basking in the daring rescue of the 33 men trapped deep in a copper and gold mine nearby for more than two months. And for some, the triumph was a striking contrast to another set of events here in Copiapó — also involving its miners — from a much darker time in Chile’s history.

headline: Pazzo Palazzo
text: The Italian designer Mauro Orietti-Carella believes in combining the old and the new. Several years back, he brought fresh life to Zagliani, a venerable but musty manufacturer of crocodile bags, by applying techniques he perfected in his former life in medical school, where he studied skin reconstruction — injecting the material with silicone and resin so that its stiffness gave way to a buttery softness. (The company is preparing to open its first stand-alone store, on Madison Avenue.)

headline: The Morning Skate: Early Turnarounds Mark First Week
text: It’s still early in this N.H.L. season but it’s impossible to ignore the turnarounds and successes of last year’s non-playoff teams so far. They have combined for 19 wins, while losing 12 in regulation and two after regulation, which is 40 of a possible 66 points. Meanwhile, last year’s playoff teams have won 22, lost 18 in regulation and nine after regulation, getting only 53 of a possible 98 points.

headline: Actors’ Equity Association Names Mary McColl New Executive Director
text: Actors’ Equity Association, the union of more than 49,000 theater actors and stage managers, announced on Thursday that Mary McColl would become its new executive director in January 2011. In that role Ms. McColl, currently the executive director of the Cowles Center for Dance and the Performing Arts in Minneapolis, will oversee the collective bargaining process for more than 30 national and regional contracts and act as the union’s representative with other labor groups and government officials. Before her position in Minneapolis, Ms. McColl was the director of labor relations for the Broadway League, the trade association of theater owners and producers. She succeeds Carol Waaser, who has served as acting executive director since November 2009, and who plans to retire next year after 26 years on the staff of Actors’ Equity.

headline: Andy Rooney's Fall Cleaning
text: David Pogue looks at a wireless speaker for bicycle handle bars, a desk frame for an iPhone, a projector, a PrintStik, a case for an iPad and stickers for wires.

headline: Judge Overrules Terror Suspect’s Request on Evidence
text: DETROIT — Overruling the wishes of a Nigerian man accused of trying to use explosives in his underwear to blow up a transcontinental airliner over Detroit last Christmas, a federal judge on Thursday ordered that the man’s standby lawyer receive documents related to the prosecution’s case. The defendant, Umar Farouk Abdulmutallab, also waived his right to a speedy trial.

headline: How to Bargain at Marketplaces
text: As part of my business school’s program, my classmates and I recently went to China. On our trip home, many of us were carrying or wearing much fancier accessories than we had gone with. Think Rolex watches, Louis Vuitton bags and Gucci sunglasses — all knockoffs, of course.

headline: Are You Sure You Don’t Want to Retire?
text: Thank goodness for Dashboard, Gene Marks’s new blog channel here at “You’re the Boss.” If not for his efforts to mine the information superhighway for the rest of us, I would have missed a recent Gallup poll declaring that nearly half of small-business owners may never retire.

headline: Democrats Press Attack on Secret Money
text: National Democratic officials have decided that their attacks on undisclosed  corporate money are working, and they have decided to intensify the argument in the final days of the midterm campaign.

headline: Real-Life Design: Erecting Solutions to Social Problems
text: Architecture is rediscovering its social conscience. That’s the message behind “Small Scale, Big Change: New Architectures of Social Engagement,” an exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art.

headline: ‘Small Scale, Big Change’
text: Photographs of a new exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art.

headline: Behind the Growing Number of Tender Offers
text: The tender offer is definitely back. According to Factset Mergermetrics, tender offers were used in 22.95 percent of friendly public deals in 2010. This compares with only 7.59 percent of such deals in 2006. The tender offer has not seen such heights since the 1980s.

headline: From Darkness and Mine Dust to Sea and Sand
text: ATHENS  Beyond the hugs they’ve received from their president and the celebrity treatment they’ve gotten from media around the world, the 33 miners rescued this week have been offered something they might desperately need after more than two months of confinement underground: a vacation.

headline: New Climate Fight, Same as the Old One?
text: The decade-long effort to pass comprehensive climate legislation framed around a declining cap and trading for carbon dioxide emissions died an ignominious death. Now new proposals focused on a substantial ramp-up of investments in energy innovation are percolating — and instantly being attacked. Keith Kloor has nicely woven together links to relevant coverage and commentary in a riff titled “The Post Partisan Power Play.”

headline: Europe Walks a Fine Line on Regulation of Cloning
text: BRUSSELS — European Union regulators are getting ready to propose rules on cloned livestock that would be stronger than those in the United States with regard to actual clones, but would seek to avoid trade tensions by allowing imports of food produced from their offspring as well as imports of semen and embryos from clones for breeding.

headline: Dumpster Dips
text: Trash containers have been turned into swimming pools in Brooklyn.

headline: Theater Listings: Oct. 15 — 21
text: Theater

headline: Mine Coverage Taxes BBC News Budget
text: This is the reality of the television news business: when an unexpected event eats into the annual news-gathering budget, at some point there will have to be cutbacks elsewhere.

headline: Photo of the Week
text: Two lovers are seen at sunrise on La Promenade des Anglais in Nice, France.

headline: Favorite Spaces
text: Why will.i.am, Annie Leonard, Todd Oldham and other homebodies love their houses.

headline: Chart: Gucci Mane’s ‘The Appeal’
text: The mush-mouthed Atlanta rapper Gucci Mane is back with his third studio album, “The Appeal: Georgia’s Most Wanted,” which features guests like Bun B, Nicki Minaj and Estelle. The artist Andrew Kuo dissects it, track by track.

headline: Biden: I’ll Be Obama’s Running Mate in 2012
text: Is President Obama already thinking about his 2012 re-election campaign?

headline: F.D.A. Admits Error, Will Revoke Approval for Knee Patch
text: The Times’s Gardiner Harris writes in an article posted this afternoon that the Food and Drug Administration announced that it would rescind approval for Menaflex, a patch for knee injuries, and acknowledged that had erred. The account notes that approval was granted in 2008 after the agency was pressured by four New Jersey congressmen and its own commissioner.

headline: Republicans Eat Crow on ‘Hicky’ Ad
text: Talk about having to eat crow.

headline: Le Music Subsidy
text: Last year we wrote about how France was subsidizing the ailing newspaper industry. Now it appears the French government has opened its coffers to another sector whose business model has been pummeled by the digital age: the music industry.

headline: Rita Hayworth, Movie Legend, Dies
text: Rita Hayworth, the legendary Hollywood beauty who rose to international fame in the 1940's and 1950's, died Thursday night, of Alzheimer's disease, in her Central Park West apartment in Manhattan. She was 68 years old.

headline: CAPONE CONVICTED OF DODGING TAXES; MAY GET 17 YEARS
text: Chicago, Oct. 17-- Al Capone was found guilty here tonight on five of the twenty-three counts contained in the two indictments brought against him by the Federal Government for income tax evasion from 1924 to 1929.

headline: 2 Black Power Advocates Ousted From Olympics
text: Mexico City, Oct. 18--The United States Olympic Committee suspended Tommie Smith and John Carlos today for having used last Wednesday's victory ceremony for the 200- meter dash at the Olympic Games as the vehicle for a black power demonstration.

headline: Pierre Trudeau Is Dead at 80; Dashing Fighter for Canada
text: Pierre Elliott Trudeau, the long-serving prime minister of Canada who successfully defended his vision of federalism and a unified nation against the aroused forces of Quebec separatism, died yesterday in Montreal. He was 80.

headline: Yankees-Rangers in Perspective
text: Rangers have a History …

headline: Neighborhood Joint | Central Art Supply
text: An East Village store has been a destination for creative spirits in need of paper, pencils, paint and brushes since 1905.

headline: One Store, Five Floors, 6,000 Papers
text: “PAPER is upstairs.”

headline: Shot in the Right Thigh. At Bellevue.
text: This is a raw feed from police reporters Al Baker and Karen Zraick on the shooting near Pennsylvania Station. It was sent to James Barron, who will incorporate it along with witness accounts and other reporting into his developing City Room post and story for Friday’s newspaper. It is paraphrased from statements by Paul J. Browne, the main police spokesman.

headline: Opera's Next Tenor?
text: The 33-year-old tenor Vittorio Grigolo is making his debut at the Metropolitan Opera in “La Bohème.”

headline: How Close Is Cheap Clean Energy?
text: Tyler Cowen continues the discussion about the next steps for climate policy:

headline: Tavern on the Green Visitors Center Opens
text: The former Tavern on the Green will reopen to the public on Friday, reincarnated as a $2.5-million visitor center, food court and retail shop, temporarily replacing the once-glittering landmark restaurant in Central Park, which shuttered on New Year’s Day.

headline: Ristretto | Coffee With Tim Wendelboe
text: Last year, Tim Wendelboe, a former World Barista Champion (2004) and World Tasting Champion (2005) whose eponymous coffee shop and roaster in Oslo has become a destination for coffee pilgrims on the order of Lourdes or Fallingwater, wrote a book on coffee. It was released in English this summer as “Coffee With Tim Wendelboe.” The slim volume is the most complete portrait of this moment in coffee to date.

headline: Yahoo Sale Speculation Loses Steam
text: The buzz Thursday morning was all about reports that AOL and buyout firms might cobble together a complicated bid for Yahoo.

headline: Plaintiffs’ Bar Unhappy With Tip Process
text: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — Got a beef against your broker? Regulators have made it easy for investors to come forward: Call one of their fraud hot lines and tell your story. The Securities and Exchange Commission may even give you cash if your tip pans out.

headline: Living Rooms With a View
text: What is it like to live in a townhouse designed by Mies van der Rohe?

headline: Judge Delays Resumption of Guantánamo Trial
text: WASHINGTON  A military judge on Thursday decided to delay the resumption of the first trial before a military commission under the Obama administration, giving government officials and defense lawyers more time to work on a potential plea deal.

headline: Cue the Exterminators: Bedbugs at Lincoln Center
text: Bedbugs have made their debut at Lincoln Center. The pests were sighted in the dressing room of the David H. Koch Theater, the New York City Opera confirmed on Wednesday, and at the Metropolitan Opera. City Opera, whose fall season opens Oct. 27, shares the theater with the New York City Ballet, whose season ended on Sunday. The outbreak was reported online on Wednesday by The New York Observer, which quoted from an Oct. 8 e-mail from Mark Heiser, the theater’s managing director, who said treatment was under way. “Please understand that this is an epidemic,” Mr. Heiser wrote. “Any signs of bedbug activity should not be considered a sign of an untidy house.” The pests were also found at the Metropolitan Opera. “Bedbugs were discovered in some isolated locations but not in any public areas,” a spokesman for the Met said in a statement, adding that the areas were being treated and monitored.

headline: Dear FloFab: How Do I Tell the Chef ‘This Needs Salt’?
text: Each week, Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.

headline: Sponsors Also Star in School Makeover Reality Show
text: NBC’s new Friday night show “School Pride” tries to tap the out-with-the-bums, everything’s-broken mentality currently at large in the country and apply it to the popular home-makeover genre. In doing so it becomes a microcosm of both the good side (authentic, if totally random, charity) and the bad side (stunning superficiality, rampant commercialism) of this particular corner of reality television.

headline: 52 Percent of Americans Flunk Climate 101
text: A new study by researchers at Yale University suggests that Americans’ knowledge of climate science is limited and scattershot, with some understanding of basic issues like the contribution of fossil fuels to global warming and some singular misconceptions as well.

headline: Free Music, Documentaries and Vampire Bites
text: With lyrics like “We would have never met, without the Internet” and “I left my wife and only child for a girl at the Renaissance fair,” Ethan Lipton and His Orchestra tell tales of quirky, modern romance. On Saturday Mr. Lipton, joined by Eben Levy on guitar, Ian Riggs on stand-up bass and Vito Dieterle on saxophone, will be crooning for the hapless lovers of Park Slope, Brooklyn, in the back room of the bar Barbès, beginning at 8 p.m. Seating is limited, so arrive early, or stop by any other night of the week to hear a lineup that can range from Americana to Gypsy brass. (376 Ninth Street, at Sixth Avenue, Park Slope, Brooklyn; 347-422-0248, barbesbrooklyn.com; $10 suggested donation.)

headline: Google’s Income Rises 32%, Topping Forecast
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Google has spent the last few months arguing to anyone who will listen that its new advertising businesses  including ads with images and video and on cellphones  will fuel its next phase of growth. On Thursday, the company finally gave some numbers to support the claim.

headline: Comedy With a Bang
text: Robert Schwentke, the director of the action comedy "RED," discusses his use of guns and weaponry in the film.

headline: Where’s That Bus? Check Your iPhone
text: A new experiment by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority allows riders on the M16 and M34 bus routes to check the real-time location of buses on the Web or a mobile device.

headline: Rising Cost of Kimchi Alarms Koreans
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Even in the middle of a loud and bustling outdoor market, her voice drops to a whisper when she agrees to reveal the two secret ingredients that make her kimchi so popular with her customers.

headline: Camaraderie on Ice
text: OUTSIDE it was fall, but inside, winter had already arrived. Huddled in the stands on a recent Friday night, a small group of fans yelled enthusiastically for the NY Lions hockey team. One of dozens of teams in the adult coed league run by Sky Rink at Chelsea Piers, the Lions are also one of five that belong to the New York City Gay Hockey Association. On the ice a spirited match against a straight team called TBD was under way.

headline: A Theater Is Shuttered and The Shows Won’t Go On
text: The Theaters at 45 Bleecker Street, one of New York’s diminishing number of commercial Off Broadway spaces, has closed indefinitely due to litigation between the theater producers and their landlord, the 45 Bleecker theater manager said in an interview on Thursday. Performances have been canceled for Thursday night, including for the two new Off Broadway productions running there, “The Deep Throat Sex Scandal” and “Perfect Harmony.”

headline: Who Ya Callin’ Gramps, Junior?
text: If you are in the mood to revisit some of the bad movies of last summer — there was no shortage — then “RED” may be just the ticket. You might even say that this movie, directed by Robert Schwentke and based on the comic books created by Warren Ellis and Cully Hamner, represents a do-over, a moderately successful attempt to restore the entertainment potential of two much-abused genres.

headline: Wallowing in Grief Over Maman
text: Roland Barthes  the French literary critic, theorist and philosopher  died an absurd death. In 1980 he was hit by a laundry van in Paris, while walking home from a lunch given by François Mitterrand, the future president of France, and died a few weeks later. He was 64 and as dashing as he’d been at half that age.

headline: Environmentalists Join Mountaintop Fray
text: Environmental groups from Appalachia moved Thursday to join the federal government in fighting an industry lawsuit that would weaken oversight of mountaintop coal mining.

headline: BMW and Mercedes-Benz to Add Mounts for iPad
text: DVD monitors are just so passé. Mercedes-Benz and BMW have just announced devices — cradles, so to speak — that will house Apple iPads, allow them to swivel and even charge them via a dock connector.

headline: Brahms for the Schumanns
text: Brahms set the agenda for the first concert of the Collegiate Chorale’s 69th season, presented at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night. Yet almost perversely, at least from a historical perspective, the lure was a pair of Wagnerians: the mezzo-soprano Stephanie Blythe, who played a resplendent Fricka in the Metropolitan Opera’s much-ballyhooed new staging of “Das Rheingold,” and the bass-baritone Eric Owens, whose dramatically shaded, unusually sympathetic Alberich in the same production stole the show.

headline: On the East Side, Cooking Without Gas
text: To the clatter, pedestrian obstacle course and store closings created by the Second Avenue subway project, add one more affliction for more than 100 families living on the East Side: no gas.

headline: House Tour: Barrytown, N.Y.
text: WHAT Three-bedroom Greek Revival house

headline: Jets’ Revis Making Trip to Denver and May Play
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. – On Thursday, there were positive developments concerning the left hamstring of the injured Jets cornerback Darrelle Revis. That does not mean that Revis will play Sunday at Denver, but the possibility is now higher than earlier this week.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Lebanon and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Lebanon, Afghanistan and Greece.

headline: China’s Elite Feel Winds of Change, but Endure
text: BEIJING  For China’s small band of liberal intellectuals, this is the springtime of hope. Six days ago, one of their own, the writer and dissident Liu Xiaobo, was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize. On Monday, a score of Communist Party elders and scholars issued a scalding public attack on the government’s censorship regime. Since mid-August, Prime Minister Wen Jiabao has endorsed political reform on at least seven occasions, including on CNN and at the United Nations.

headline: Rare Books About New York
text: DO you think it’s too early for holiday shopping for New York-related books? Hardly! Indeed, you may be too late.

headline: Rescue Bolsters Ratings for CNN and Fox News
text: The viewership for Fox News and CNN more than doubled Wednesday night as the final miner was rescued in Chile.

headline: Quote Unquote | Siren Call
text: –Joan Collins bemoans the lack of screen sirens today to Vogue UK. Poor Joan Collins, she doesn’t know that Rosie Huntington-Whitely was cast in the next Transformers film.

headline: Scenes From the Frieze
text: Images from the art fair in London.

headline: Stressing Out Over an ‘Urban Spa’
text: THE concept was a model for future development: a nationally known spa paired with an urban luxury condominium that would give residents all the elements of a pampered vacation right in their own buildings. But since plans were unveiled in 2006 for Miraval Living, a residential tower and spa that would have been just such an urban sanctuary on the Upper East Side, the project has stumbled.

headline: Somali-American Is Named Prime Minister of Somalia
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia  The Somali president on Thursday named a Somali-American to succeed the prime minister whose resignation last month brought the weak transitional government to a standstill.

headline: The Days, Nights and Years of the Jackal: The Tale of a Terrorist
text: About 15 minutes into “Carlos,” Olivier Assayas’s excited, exciting, epic dramatization about the international terrorism brand known as Carlos the Jackal, the title character takes a long, loving, vainglorious look in the mirror at his naked body. It’s 1974 and after a bungled assassination attempt and an ineffectual bombing, Carlos has just headed down the flamboyant career path — riddled with bodies, rutted by explosions and festooned with publicity — that will inspire pulp fictions, detailed biographies, hyperventilated conspiracy theories and lasting myths. As he luxuriates in his own image, you see how Carlos saw himself: the terrorist as pinup.

headline: Rockefellers Selling Co-op for $6.5 Million
text: MICHAEL S. AND TARA ROCKEFELLER, the power society couple, are selling their four-bedroom apartment at 34 Gramercy Park, one of Manhattan’s oldest co-ops, for $6.5 million.

headline: Sidney Weinberg Jr. and the End of an Era
text: Sidney J. Weinberg Jr. retired as a general partner from Goldman Sachs in 1988, but almost every week afterward until his death, he came into the office. He would meet with staff to give advice about Goldman’s culture and values, hoping to leave a little of the firm’s past in the present.

headline: Philadelphia Orchestra’s Principal Clarinetist to Perform With the Philharmonic
text: Could Philadelphia’s loss be New York’s gain?

headline: Philadelphia Orchestra’s Principal Clarinetist to Perform With the Philharmonic
text: Could Philadelphia’s loss be New York’s gain?

headline: On ‘Mad Men’ the Thrills Are All in the Office
text: Risky behavior is the organizing principle of “Mad Men,” an immorality play built around those bad habits of the 1960s that we now try to abjure: drinking, smoking, promiscuity, and racial and sexual prejudice.

headline: Saudi Prince Makes Offer for Trump World Tower Penthouse
text: THE Yankee shortstop Derek Jeter’s digs at Trump World Tower, with over 5,400 square feet of space and now on the market for $20 million, may be fit for a king. But a Saudi prince looking into buying a condominium in that building, near the United Nations, felt that the floor  described as being on the 88th but actually on the 70th  wasn’t high enough.

headline: Plug-In Cars Pose Riddle for E.P.A.
text: DETROIT  About two months before two new plug-in cars go on sale in the United States, the federal government is struggling with how to rate the fuel economy of mass-market plug-in vehicles.

headline: A Museum Exhibition Assembled on the Fly
Lending Is Up, but Demand Is Lacking
text: Corporate lending by banks is rising. Finally.

headline: Big Fish and Fresh Cash at London Fair
text: LONDON  The contradictions of the art world, as well as of the current economic moment, were in full view as the Frieze Art Fair began here in Regent’s Park on Wednesday. Despite what some called a more thoughtful, less flashy mood than during the boom years, a Damien Hirst fish-in-formaldehyde installation brought $5.6 million, according to his London gallery.

headline: A Hike Into the Mystic, or Just a Walk in the Woods?
text: KENT, N.Y.

headline: For Democrats, the Outlook Gets Better in the Senate and Worse in the House
text: The New York Times has changed its rating of Connecticut’s Senate race from tossup to leaning Democratic, finding that Attorney General Richard Blumenthal has somewhat solidified his position against businesswoman Linda McMahon, the Republican candidate and former wrestling impresario.

headline: With a Round to Go, Kramnik Retains Lead of Bilbao Masters
text: Vladimir Kramnik drew with Viswanathan Anand, the world champion, while Magnus Carlsen finally won a game.

headline: Obama Seeks Stay on Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell Ruling
text: WASHINGTON — Saying it would appeal a ruling striking down the law that bans gay men and lesbians from serving openly in the United States military, the Obama administration on Thursday asked the federal judge who issued the ruling for an emergency stay of her decision.

headline: Shahn Art Collection and Home Are for Sale
text: The artist Ben Shahn and his second wife, Bernarda Bryson Shahn, spent much of their lives in a government-built cinderblock house. In 1939 the couple moved to Roosevelt, N.J., southeast of Princeton, where a federal relief program had created Modernist subdivisions. The Shahns surrounded themselves with lively collections: Indian illuminated manuscripts, ancient classical statues and 20th-century works by their friends, including the artists Robert Rauschenberg and Jacob Lawrence and the woodworker George Nakashima.

headline: App Smart Extra: Patient Journal App
text: Apps highlighted in this week’s App Smart column are tailored to medical altruists who might like to help save another person’s life.

headline: The Dead Have Messages for the Land of the Living
text: The afterlife is not necessarily where you would expect to find Clint Eastwood, who at 80 shows no signs of tiring out or settling down. His latest film, “Hereafter,” is at once recognizably his — in tone and atmosphere — and a startling departure from his previous work.

headline: Spanish Draftsmanship That Leaps Off the Page
text: In between Velázquez and Picasso there was Goya, and then there was everyone else. That’s exactly the way the Frick Collection has sensibly chosen to organize its thrilling exhibition “The Spanish Manner: Drawings From Ribera to Goya.”

headline: Before the Rebellion, Playful Pop Art Novelty
text: Why have there been no great female Pop artists? That’s the question posed by Sid Sachs at the start of his catalog essay for “Seductive Subversion: Women Pop Artists, 1958-1968,” a revelatory time capsule of an exhibition that he has organized at the Brooklyn Museum. He is paraphrasing the title of Linda Nochlin’s monument of feminist art history, “Why Have There Been No Great Women Artists?”

headline: Heated Debate at Hearing on Smoking Ban in Parks
text: A New York City Council public hearing on a proposed smoking ban in city parks evolved into an hours-long, occasionally raucous showdown Thursday afternoon, touching on issues such as civil liberties, public health, big government and litter.

headline: Still Traveling
text: Back on this side of the Pacific, but still not in a position to post.

headline: Push to End Job Barriers Rattles Greece and Economy
text: ATHENS — Antonios Avgerinos, 59, a retired army pharmacist, always wanted his own pharmacy here. And why not? Greek law ensures that pharmacists get a 35 percent profit on all drugs sold, even over-the-counter medications.

text: Pop

headline: Second Sestak Comeback Is Unlikely
text: There’s been some excitement this week about Pennsylvania, where two internal polls commissioned by Democrats show a tight Senate race. One of the polls actually puts their candidate, Joe Sestak, ahead by 3 points; the other has him 1 point behind Pat Toomey. Further contributing to the buzz is the disclosure that Republicans are upping their ad buys in the state. On the other hand, Rasmussen Reports provides for a buzzkill of sorts, having released a poll this morning showing Mr. Toomey 10 points ahead — the largest advantage that Rasmussen has given him all year.

headline: Challenging Health Care Law, Suit Advances
text: In a foreboding ruling for the Obama administration, a federal judge in Florida decreed Thursday that a legal challenge to the new health care law by officials from 20 states could move forward and warned that he would have to be persuaded that its keystone provision  a requirement that most Americans obtain insurance  is constitutional.

text: Democrats have tried many ways to capture the attention of distracted voters before Election Day.

text: The closing ceremony of India’s Commonwealth Games, which opened 12 days ago with the world bracing for the worst, was a success.

headline: Wall Street: 60 Goats and a Soft Shoe
text: If only the hotshot bankers who drove the global economy off a cliff had been playing with marbles instead of credit default swaps. Or merely trading tangible things, like shoes and loaves of bread and gallons of cider. The world might look a whole lot different today.

headline: Film Riches, Cleaned Up for Posterity
text: Movies may seem a more permanent medium than ephemeral art forms like theater and dance. But films are fragile things that often exist only fleetingly in their definitive state.

headline: Students Aim for Success With a New View of Vocational School
text: Buzzing with excitement, 72 11th graders sat in the auditorium of Austin Polytechnical Academy recently, waiting to board buses that would take them to the International Manufacturing Technology Show at McCormick Place, the largest show of its kind in the United States.

text: President Obama was put on the defensive on issues from the economy and Washington partisanship to gay rights and race relations during a televised town hall-style forum on Thursday that captured the disillusionment taking root among younger voters who were a significant force in his election.

text: Dispatches from the campaign bedlam:

headline: Week 6 in Fantasy Football: Matchups and Q. and A.
text: The brothers Sablich are here to help with fantasy football analysis for Week 6. They also answered reader questions earlier in the week. Read their answers below and follow them on Twitter for more advice leading up to game time on Sunday.

headline: What Should I Do at CMJ?
text: Another year, another 1,200 bands looking for a breakthrough at the CMJ Music Marathon, which opens in New York on Tuesday.

headline: Awaiting a Second Chance for a Dugout View
text: Bob Brenly has sometimes wondered if the sparkle from the ring he won for managing the Arizona Diamondbacks to the 2001 World Series title has faded into irrelevance.
