headline: House Democrats Plan Ad Spending
text: House Democrats, who need every advantage they can get in the midterm elections, say they will have about $10 million more than their Republican counterparts to spend on television advertising in the final three weeks before Election Day.

headline: The Caucus Click: Washington
text: At an intersection in the Chinatown neighborhood of Washington, D.C., where Vince Gray is the Democratic candidate for the upcoming mayoral race.

headline: Beirut Festival Pulled Film to Spare Ahmadinejad’s Feelings
text: As my colleague Robert Worth reports, a two-day visit to Lebanon by Iran’s president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, seems to have passed off without major incident — or minor stone-throwing — but the presence of Iran’s best-known Holocaust-denying, 9/11-truther did have an impact on Beirut’s film lovers.

headline: Her Brother’s Keeper, No Matter the Cost
text: For a while “Conviction,” based on the true story of a New England woman’s long struggle to win freedom for her imprisoned brother, feels as if it just might escape the stifling conventions of the crusader-for-justice melodrama. The film, directed by Tony Goldwyn from a script by Pamela Gray, starts in a chronological scramble: the lives of the characters have been shattered, and the filmmakers are sorting through the shards, offering us painful glimpses of adult anxiety and childhood pain.

headline: F.D.A. Vows to Revoke Approval of Device
text: WASHINGTON  The Food and Drug Administration said Thursday that it would rescind the approval of a patch for injured knees that it granted in error in 2008 after being unduly pressured by four New Jersey congressmen and its own commissioner.

headline: Murphy Embraces Health Care in Ad
text: Even the Democrats who supported President Barack Obama’s health care legislation last March aren’t exactly making the bill the center-piece of their re-election campaigns. Everyone, that is, except Rep. Scott Murphy of New York.

headline: Knicks Trying to Figure Out Their Rotation
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Mike D’Antoni is highly familiar with Amar’e Stoudemire’s offensive prowess and, as if to give a subtle reminder, Stoudemire scored 30 points on a thrifty 13 field goals in his first game as a Knick at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Trying to Sniff Out a Rat Hiding in a Toxic World
text: The cramped, mildewed atmosphere of Ben Wheatley’s deadpan crime comedy, “Down Terrace,” is so claustrophobic you can understand why its hapless characters are continually bickering. The grainy movie, filmed with a handheld camera, soaks up the fetid world of a criminal clan in which two of the members, Bill (Robert Hill) and his son, Karl (Robin Hill), played by a real father and son, were ratted out to the police by one of their own.

headline: Controversy Over Mascots at Ole Miss
text: Colonel Reb, meet your replacement.

headline: The Dark Art of Drawing Political Lines
text: “Gerrymandering” is an illustrated civics lesson that strains to make its complicated, shadowy subject — electoral redistricting — a political hot topic. Written and directed by Jeff Reichert and outfitted with a pounding soundtrack and flashy graphics, it examines the legal chicanery by which electoral districts are modified for political purposes. The word (with a hard g) was coined in 1812 after the governor of Massachusetts, Elbridge Gerry (pronounced Gary), signed a bill redistricting the state to his own advantage. One district was described as having the shape of a salamander; hence the term.

headline: How Wall Street Hid Its Mortgage Mess
text: The conventional wisdom has it that the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission — the bipartisan group of wise men and women charged with uncovering what caused our recent economic meltdown and telling us what should be done to prevent a recurrence — is woefully out-of-touch and out-of-date. A Times article last month suggested that “an exodus of senior employees” from the commission and “internal disagreements” among those remaining could hamper efforts to produce a meaningful and useful report, which is due to be published in December.

headline: Clubs Urge Locals to Come Hear the Music Play
text: An otherwise inconspicuous air duct at the back of the Fairmont Hotel’s ornate Venetian Room harbors an important piece of local cultural history. There, the names of Ella Fitzgerald, Nat King Cole, Tina Turner and other great vocal artists who performed in the club were etched  reportedly by a hotel technician  onto the surface of the ventilation conduit.

headline: After Police Shooting, a Focus on How Mentally Ill Are Handled
text: On the morning of Sept. 26, a San Francisco police officer responded to a complaint about loud music at a residential hotel for seniors and the mentally ill in the Tenderloin District. The officer accompanied the hotel manager to Room 708.

headline: Fehr, Nominee to Lead Union, Meets With Rangers
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Donald Fehr, nominated to be executive director of the N.H.L. Players Association, was at the Rangers’ practice rink Thursday to meet with players.

headline: Proving Poverty Could Be Problematic at Area Food Pantries
text: Scott James is a columnist for The Bay Citizen

headline: Hearts Full of Sorrow
text: Admirers of Nicole Krauss’s novel “The History of Love” (and they are many, and I am one) will want to know the answer to this question: How much does her new novel, “Great House,” resemble its predecessor? The good news is: very much indeed. And the good news is also: not so very much.

headline: In Benicia, Emissions Measure Is Personal
text: In most of California, the arguments over Proposition 23, which would suspend the state’s landmark global-warming law, are dominated by theoretical claims about the measure’s potential effect on jobs and the environment.

headline: Maximum Gross Outs in Sleazy, Queasy Stunts
text: It just might be that America’s favorite jackasses, having played around with sharks in their last big-screen effort (“Jackass Number Two” of course), have this time actually jumped one, and in 3-D no less. As aficionados of their previous feature-length compilations of gags and giggles have come to know, there is a certain, sometimes inexplicable, queasy pleasure to be had from watching Johnny Knoxville, Chris Pontius and the rest of these MTV-sponsored merry buffoons wreak semi-havoc on one another, themselves and an occasional rattled and confused onlookers (the two-legged variety, especially). But alas there are only so many times you can slurp from the same fetid well, or at least make like Krakatoa and blow.

headline: Marketers Trade Tales About Getting to Know Facebook and Twitter
text: ORLANDO, Fla.

headline: After a Death, Friendships and Secrets
text: It’s a puzzle why you can’t see the face of the woman who bustles through the opening of “Nora’s Will,” her hands front and center — setting a table, locking away paper — while her features remain out of sight. By the time you finally see that face in full, its eyes are closed because Nora is now literally on ice, awaiting the burial that gives this slight, sentimental movie its narrative shape and clumsy comedy. That she’s also a mystery meant to be solved helps explain why the director Mariana Chenillo keeps her carefully under wraps.

headline: Post-Recalls, a New Way to Clean the Greens
text: The produce industry  rocked by several major recalls in recent years linked to outbreaks of salmonella, E. coli and other bacteria  has been searching for a better way to wash the lettuce, spinach and other greens it bags and sells in grocery stores and to restaurants.

headline: Verizon Wireless Is to Sell Apple iPads
text: Apple said Thursday that Verizon Wireless would begin selling the iPad at its stores on Oct. 28.

headline: Wordless and Lost, a Young Couple Flee
text: How do you know you’re looking at a pretty good piece of filmmaking? When the director and actors can make you care about the central characters even though they exchange almost no dialogue. And when the movie holds your interest even though you lack the cultural reference points that show it off to best advantage.

headline: Growing Interest, Despite Questions, in Jon Stewart’s Rally
text: Though no one is quite sure what it is going to be yet, the Rally to Restore Sanity, organized by the comedian Jon Stewart and set for Oct. 30 on the National Mall in Washington, is drawing widespread national attention.

headline: New Attitude Has Jacobs Running Hard
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Brandon Jacobs walked around the Giants’ locker room Thursday wearing slippers, sweat pants and a smile. He looked like a man at home.

headline: A Heated Debate
text: Photos from the debate between Representative Loretta Sanchez and Van Tran for the 47th Congressional District in Orange County, Calif.

headline: Medtronic to Settle Lawsuits Over Devices Tied to Deaths
text: Medtronic, the maker of heart devices, agreed to pay $268 million to settle lawsuits over claims that fractured wires in a line of its cardiac defibrillators caused at least 13 deaths.

headline: Vietnam Human Rights Play Role in House Race
text: SANTA ANA, Calif.  The flagging economy came up, of course. So did the high unemployment rate. But it is not every Congressional debate that turns on the question of how to improve human rights in Vietnam.

headline: Recognizing Israel as a Jewish State
text: To the Editor:

headline: Giants Beat Phillies’ Big Three
text: There was a time in Philadelphia — O.K., maybe for only a few months in 1982 — when the term “H2O” referred to the most successful album of the local pop duo Hall and Oates. Now, it is the unmistakable nickname of the most celebrated pitching threesome in baseball: the two H’s and an O of the Phillies — Roy Halladay, Cole Hamels and Roy Oswalt.

headline: Phillies Fans Refuse to Let Rain Ruin a Rally
text: PHILADELPHIA  This is the best of times for Philadelphia sports fans.

headline: Colorado Candidate’s Brother Lies Low
text: TRINIDAD, Colo.  The Salazar family name has been a leading political brand in Colorado for years. It has also been shorthand for a big-thought Democratic Party strategy of carrying the West that the Salazar brothers, John and Ken, helped invent and articulate as shoulder-to-shoulder voices of deep-country Colorado, where they grew up and where John still runs the family potato farm. The Salazar formula: rural and urban coalitions around centrist, libertarian-tinged politics, mixing support for gun rights with an ability to look natural in a cowboy hat.

headline: Milestones: John A. Boehner
text: The life and political career of Representative John A. Boehner, an Ohio Republican and soon-to-be House speaker.

headline: Boehner’s Path to Power Began in Small-Town Ohio
text: READING, Ohio  John A. Boehner, the House Republican leader, laments that the America he grew up in has been “snuffed out” by Democrats. Yet Mr. Boehner’s hometown seems virtually untouched by the decades that have passed since he lugged kegs of beer around his father’s bar, tossed a Friday night football and frightened a driving instructor by burning rubber in a GTO.

headline: Romance in Brazil’s Wild West
text: “Carmo, Hit the Road,” a picaresque romance set (and filmed) in Brazil’s wild west on the borders of Paraguay and Bolivia, rambles through some beautiful jungle-and-river landscapes without really going anywhere. It’s not a memorable ride, but there’s enough rueful humor, tropical sensuality and borrowed style along the way to make it pleasant.

headline: Mistake in Second Avenue Subway Work Cuts Gas Off
text: To the clatter, pedestrian obstacle course and store closings created by the Second Avenue subway project, add one more affliction for more than 100 families living on the East Side: no gas.

headline: Mortgage Mess May Cost Big Banks Billions
text: One billion dollars? Six billion? Ten billion? More?

headline: Where Tea Party Candidates Are Running
text: An examination by The Times identified Tea Party candidates in 129 House races and 9 Senate races.

headline: In Waterfront Hearings, Accounts of a Union’s Kickbacks and a Mafia Tie
text: Edward Aulisi was a dockworker  at least in theory. According to law enforcement officials, Mr. Aulisi, whose father led a longshoremen’s union local, knew of the local’s kickback payments to organized crime, and he was in contact with a Mafia captain who was a fugitive from justice.

headline: The Whitney Trims Its East Side Holdings
text: Cementing its decision to shift its focus from the Upper East Side to the meatpacking district, the Whitney Museum of American Art on Thursday sold the six brownstones next to its signature Marcel Breuer building on Madison Avenue as well as two town houses around the corner on 74th Street.

headline: Tales of an Imaginary City
text: “Urville” requires some explanation, which the film itself, by the German director Angela Christlieb (“Cinemania”), does not provide.

headline: Tea Party Set to Win Enough Races for Wide Influence
text: Enough Tea Party-supported candidates are running strongly in competitive and Republican-leaning Congressional races that the movement stands a good chance of establishing a sizable caucus to push its agenda in the House and the Senate, according to a New York Times analysis.

headline: Accountability Behind the Plate
text: The Umpire in the Sky

headline: Mother Nature Decoded
text: This is the fifth in a series.

headline: Living With Mies
text: A few blocks east of Detroit’s downtown, just across Interstate 375, sits Lafayette Park, an enclave of single- and two-story modernist townhouses set amid a forest of locust trees. Like hundreds of developments nationwide, they were the result of postwar urban renewal; unlike almost all of them, it had a trio of world-class designers behind it: Ludwig Hilbersheimer as urban planner, Alfred Caldwell as landscape designer and Mies van der Rohe as architect.

headline: Obama on Defensive at Forum
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama was put on the defensive on issues including the economy, gay rights and race relations during a televised town-hall-style forum on Thursday that captured the disillusionment taking root among younger voters who were a significant force in his election.

headline: U.S. Uses Attacks to Nudge Taliban Toward a Deal
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Airstrikes on Taliban insurgents have risen sharply here over the past four months, the latest piece in what appears to be a coordinated effort by American commanders to bleed the insurgency and pressure its leaders to negotiate an end to the war.

headline: The Mortgage Morass
text: American officials used to lecture other countries about their economic failings and tell them that they needed to emulate the U.S. model. The Asian financial crisis of the late 1990s, in particular, led to a lot of self-satisfied moralizing. Thus, in 2000, Lawrence Summers, then the Treasury secretary, declared that the keys to avoiding financial crisis were “well-capitalized and supervised banks, effective corporate governance and bankruptcy codes, and credible means of contract enforcement.” By implication, these were things the Asians lacked but we had.

headline: From a Maine House, a National Foreclosure Freeze
text: DENMARK, Me. — The house that set off the national furor over faulty foreclosures is blue-gray and weathered. The porch is piled with furniture and knickknacks awaiting the next yard sale. In the driveway is a busted pickup truck. No one who lives there is going anywhere anytime soon.

headline: Judge Says Key Figure in Embassies Bombing Case Isn’t Credible
text: A key witness who was to testify in the first civilian trial of a former Guantánamo detainee was accused by the judge on Thursday of making false statements about why he decided to cooperate with authorities.

headline: Francoeur Misses His Friends but Is Happy in the Playoffs
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. – Six weeks after the trade that liberated him from a sinking ship in Queens, Texas Rangers outfielder Jeff Francoeur still keeps in touch with his friends on the Mets. He called the former manager Jerry Manuel on Wednesday, and he said he heard from David Wright, Mike Pelfrey and the hitting coach Howard Johnson, among others, during the Rangers’ American League division series.

headline: 3 Harvard Researchers Retract a Claim on the Aging of Stem Cells
text: Harvard researchers have retracted a far-reaching claim they made in January that the aging of stem cells might be reversible.

headline: The Foreclosure Crises
text: Attorneys general in all 50 states have pledged a coordinated investigation into chaotic foreclosure practices by some of the nation’s largest banks. The Department of Justice is also looking into what happened, while some lawmakers are now calling for a nationwide moratorium on all foreclosures until the legal questions are settled. The Obama administration is insisting such a broad delay would hurt the economy.

headline: Need a Lawyer? Good Luck
text: Across the country, programs that provide legal representation in civil cases to low-income Americans are so cash-strapped that they are turning away numbers of people. Hard-pressed Americans fighting foreclosure or seeking protection from domestic violence or access to medical care or unemployment benefits must often navigate the judicial system on their own or give up.

headline: Taking a Vote on Union Construction
text: SAN DIEGO  California’s go-go construction industry came crashing to earth when the housing bubble burst. Ever since, union leaders and nonunion contractors have fought hammer and tongs for a bigger share of the shrunken business, much of which is public sector construction.

headline: Rewards for Miners Rescued in Chile
text: SAN JOSÉ MINE, Chile  The lucky ones now have more than $10,000 in the bank and a free vacation in Greece awaiting them. But for the moment, many of the family members of the 33 miners trapped under the hard volcanic rock here for more than two months seemed content to remain at Camp Hope on Thursday, tending to their tents and sweeping away the desert dust from their makeshift dining tables.

headline: Seeking Vengeance in High Heels
text: The problem with reviewing a movie called “Ticked-Off Trannies With Knives” is that you’re required to admit publicly that you have actually watched a movie called “Ticked-Off Trannies With Knives.” That’s the kind of damning tidbit that could be stumbled upon and misinterpreted by some future background-checker — a potential employer, for instance, or a vetting body for Nobel Prize nominees. Not to mention the personal implications. My mother could read this review, for gosh sakes.

headline: N.B.A. Cracks Down on Whining About Foul Calls

He then looked around in curiosity after hearing the whistle again. In a circumstance that could repeat itself all season, the official, Steve Javie, had assessed Pierce with a technical foul for his demonstrativeness.

headline: Would You Run?

He worked at the State Department, the World Bank and the law firm of Baker & McKenzie before becoming counsel to the House committee on foreign affairs. He has served for the past decade as a congressman from the northern suburbs of Chicago.

headline: Waging a Campaign of Apology

Paladino, the self-styled tough guy with a baseball bat, has turned into a serially apologizing cream puff, retreating from aggressively held positions more often than almost anyone since Napoleon hightailed it out of Moscow in 1812. text: WASHINGTON  A federal jury found two young Pennsylvania men guilty of a hate crime on Thursday in the 2008 beating death of a Mexican immigrant. The verdict was welcomed by Hispanic organizations, which saw the trial as a national test case for the treatment of Latinos.

headline: Protecting School Reform in D.C.

headline: Joyous Rescue

headline: Selma Al-Radi, Restored Historic Madrasa, Dies at 71

Then, with his daughter by his side, he would ride into the hills above town, to behold his vast edifice ablaze with light.

headline: Tajikistan: Fighters Agree to Amnesty
text: The leader of an armed group in Tajikistan has told supporters that he agreed with the government to lay down arms in exchange for an amnesty, Russia’s Interfax news agency reported Thursday, assuaging fears that fighting in a remote mountain valley might destabilize the Central Asian nation that borders Afghanistan. The authorities had accused Mirzokhudzha Akhmadov of organizing an attack on a military column on Sept. 19 that killed at least 23 soldiers in the Rasht Valley east of the capital, Dushanbe. The valley was a stronghold of antigovernment forces in the civil war in Tajikistan from 1992 until 1997, and remains largely outside central government control today.

headline: Rwanda: Opposition Leader Is Arrested
text: The Rwandan opposition leader Victoire Ingabire, left, was arrested over accusations that she is linked to rebel activities, the police said. Thursday’s arrest was the result of an investigation into Peter Uwumuremyi, a former commander of the rebel Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda, the police spokesman, Eric Kayiranga, said by telephone. Mr. Uwumuremyi was arrested Wednesday on charges of buying and distributing arms and ammunition to a group associated with Ms. Ingabire’s party, the spokesman said. Ms. Ingabire returned to Rwanda in January after being in exile for 16 years. She was arrested in April over accusations that she associated with a terrorist group and propagated genocide ideology, and she was freed on bail. She said her party had been blocked from registering candidates in August’s presidential election, which was won by the incumbent Paul Kagame.

headline: China: Plans to Build 30 Sea Vessels
text: China is building 30 sea vessels for maritime law enforcement over the next five years, adding to an expanding fleet of boats under civilian authorities that operates occasionally in disputed territorial waters, according to an article in People’s Daily. The article quoted Li Lixin, director of the South China Sea Branch of State Oceanic Administration of China, as saying that China did not have enough vessels to enforce the law in its vast territorial waters. Japan has more than 100 such vessels at a weight class of more than 3,000 tons, while China does not have even half that, Mr. Li said.

headline: Now Showing | Iron Men 2
text: On an unassuming side street in Paolo Sarpi, Milan’s burgeoning Chinatown, Mirko Pancaldi and Davide Grosso are flying the flag for design’s future being in the past. Since 2001, the pair, who collaborate under the G | Lab name, have been drawing attention for their delicately ornate furniture and lighting fixtures made from discarded aged wood and laser-cut iron. ‘‘We are known for breathing new life into traditional materials and forms,’’ Pancaldi says in the G | Lab showroom, which occasionally doubles as a workshop for average Giovannis wanting to learn time-held wood-turning and ironwork techniques. ‘‘All of our designs refer back to 18th-century French and Italian furniture traditions, and to patterns and shapes found in nature.’’ And so a slab of industrial iron becomes a filigreed room divider that is as intricate as it is commanding, and a hunk of maple found in an abandoned sawmill has a second life as a Baroque cabinet. Is this work, which often has Oriental accents, a function of the showroom’s location or the result of travels to Asia? ‘‘I’ve never been to Asia,’’ enthuses the usually taciturn Pancaldi. ‘‘Only the Asia of my imagination.’’

headline: Memories of Vargas Llosa
text: When word came last week that the Peruvian novelist Mario Vargas Llosa had won the Nobel Prize in Literature, it brought me back to a small, sun-splashed office with centuries-old books lining pine shelves and a papier mâché pencil holder, the words “Happy Father’s Day” scribbled on it, sitting on the desk. That was my father’s office in our home in the suburbs of Syracuse, and it was there that my father, hunched over an old cassette player for weeks and months, became Vargas Llosa’s accidental autobiographer.

headline: The Sound of Spirit
text: Emigrating from the Soviet Union to the West in January 1980 with his wife, Nora, and their two small sons, the Estonian composer Arvo Pärt was stopped by border police at the Brest railroad station for a luggage search. “We had only seven suitcases, full of my scores, records and tapes,” he recalled recently. “They said, ‘Let’s listen.’ It was a big station. No one else was there. We took my record player and played ‘Cantus.’ It was like liturgy. Then they played another record, ‘Missa Syllabica.’ They were so friendly to us. I think it is the first time in the history of the Soviet Union that the police are friendly.” He was joking, but not entirely. Later, when I asked Nora about that strange scene at the border, she said, “I saw the power of music to transform people.”

headline: Live, Twice, From New York, It’s ’30 Rock’
text: One thing that can certainly be said about Thursday’s live episode of “30 Rock” is that it occurred. It was a stunt, one that NBC has tried with previous shows like “Will & Grace” and “ER,” and while the live “30 Rock” may not have been life-altering television (these days, what is?), it wasn’t the 10-car pile-up that some of its creators seemed to be masochistically wishing for, either. Even if it didn’t advance the show’s meta-narrative, and even if the laughter of the live studio audience was occasionally jarring, it had a certain frantic energy, like, say, the first half-hour of a decent “Saturday Night Live.”

headline: I Am Lovely
text: Margareth Madè has had two roles to date, one in an epic by the director of “Cinema Paradiso” and the other playing Sophia Loren. Not bad for a Sicilian girl who felt like E.T. until she moved to Milan to model. Growing up, she gorged herself on Nonna’s pasta as well as on old Hollywood films — “Wilder, Hitchcock, Cukor,” Madè says dreamily. When she goes home, her mother still tells her, “Mangia! Mangia! You are too skinny!” Madè says this is what she loves about Italy: “This affection, the presence of your roots. Knowing where we come from allows us to move forward.”

headline: Inflation Looks Tame, and Shoppers Take Heart
text: The economy continued to show little sign of inflation as consumer prices eased marginally in September, while consumers provided a glimmer of hope for the retail sector, government reports said on Friday.

headline: Sharing a Table, and Much More
text: My friend Ellen works in an internist’s office where she encounters a procession of older widows. She hears them fret about the high costs and general aggravation of maintaining and paying taxes on the big old houses they still live in. She also hears them confide that it’s lonely to occupy these once-bustling spaces alone. And she wonders why they can’t find some way to live together.

headline: Complaint Box | Meetings Bring Out the Worst
text: When I was a 19-year-old college sophomore, I went to my first grown-up meeting. I was working several hours a week for a political science professor, and any escape from collating scholarly papers about demographic voting trends seemed exotic and terribly adult.

headline: Israel Plan to Build Clouds Peace Talks
text: JERUSALEM  Israel ended an unofficial construction freeze in Jewish neighborhoods in East Jerusalem on Friday, announcing plans to build 238 housing units. The move comes as hard-won peace talks are stalled over the question of whether Israel will extend its broader construction moratorium in the West Bank.

headline: Chinese Dissidents Sign Letter Supporting Nobel Winner
text: China’s spate of public agitation for political reform continued Friday, as more than 100 Chinese intellectuals and dissidents signed and posted an online letter asking that the Nobel Peace Prize winner Liu Xiaobo be released from prison and that government security officers stop harassing his wife, Liu Xia. In line with Charter 08, the pro-democracy manifesto that Mr. Liu co-authored and which led to his imprisonment, signers of the new letter also asked that government leaders “make good on their oft-repeated promise to reform the political system.”

headline: Paladino as Hugger, Not Fighter
text: What we’re reading this morning: a Staten Island man arrested in Tel Aviv in the killing of his parents, and news from the campaign trail and New York’s courtrooms.

headline: Laptop Thigh
text: Rash caused by the heat from a laptop.In an article titled “‘Laptop thigh’ skin rash warning,” the BBC reported that heat generated by laptops can cause a rash, particularly when the computers are placed on bare skin for hours at a time:

headline: Regulation Footwear | Stubbs & Wootton
text: Handcrafted in Europe and unconsciously self-conscious, Stubbs & Wootton slippers have attained a cultlike following among the nouveau preppy set. Not surprisingly, when Lisa Birnbach was working on “True Prep: It’s a Whole New Old World,” a recent digital-era update of “The Official Preppy Handbook,” she had Stubbs & Wootton create a pair of gray flannel shoes ($425) to be featured inside. If you needed any more proof of the company being synonymous with entitled glamour, the embroidered English setter that appears on the shoes’ vamp also snagged the book’s cover.

headline: The Early Word: Delaware-Bound
text: President Obama and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. have been doing a fair bit of campaigning in this midterm campaign — and on Friday, they get to do it together.

headline: U.S. Stocks Mixed on Fed Signal and Retail Sales
text: Stocks were mixed Friday as investors weighed encouraging retail news and signs of new Fed measures to bolster the economy against the impact of the tangled foreclosure process on the nation’s banks.

headline: Man Sought in Parents’ Deaths Is Caught in Israel
text: An international manhunt ended Friday when a man being sought for questioning in the fatal stabbings of his parents in their Staten Island home was captured in Israel, the New York City police said.

headline: Graphic Books Best-Sellers: Vampire 2.0
text: “American Vampire,” another series about those bloodsucking monsters of the night, has landed at No. 1 on the hardcover list. The collected edition contains the first five issues of the monthly series and features two narratives. The main story, about a woman named Pearl who is turned into a vampire in the 1920s, is written by Scott Snyder, the creator of the series. The back-up story, written by Stephen King, is about Skinner Sweet, the first of a new breed of vampires born in the days of America’s Wild West. The series is illustrated by Rafael Albuquerque.

headline: Foreclosure Crisis Trips Up a SPAC
text: The foreclosure crisis has an unusual capital markets twist. A law firm at the center of the controversy in Florida, the Law Offices of David J. Stern, sold its foreclosure-servicing business to a special purpose acquisition company, or SPAC, the Chardan 2008 China Acquisition Corporation, less than a year ago. The newly formed company is called DJSP Enterprises.

headline: Middlebury Dean Says SAT or ACT Score Is ‘Seldom a Deal Breaker’
text: Mr. Clagett is dean of admissions of Middlebury College.

headline: Sorting Myth From Fact as Volt Makes Its Debut
text: LAST week, General Motors began its press introduction for the 2011 Chevrolet Volt, which is scheduled to be in dealerships next month. The program included detailed engineering and marketing presentations, and journalists drove the cars about 200 miles on Michigan roads.

headline: The Caucus: Oprah Supports Jon Stewart Rally
text: Saying “I think we need a little bit more sanity in the world,” Oprah Winfrey endorsed Jon Stewart’s coming rally by offering to send every member of his studio audience on Thursday night to Washington, The Caucus notes.

headline: Inside the List
text: LIBRARY SCIENCE: In “A Short History of Nearly Everything” (2003), which spent a whopping 76 weeks on the hardcover and paperback best-seller lists, Bill Bryson provided witty CliffsNotes on a panoply of natural phenomena, from supernovas to slime molds. With “At Home,” new at No. 6 on the hardcover nonfiction list, he aims to write a history of domestic life without leaving the house — in his case, an 1851 rectory in a quiet English village. Bryson wanders his rooms musing on subjects like the evolution of fish knives and the modernization of toilets, stopping in the library to marvel briefly at the revolution brought about by cheap books. When Thomas Jefferson’s father died in 1757, Bryson writes, “he left a library of 42 books, and that was regarded as pretty impressive. A library of 400 books — the number that John Harvard left at his death — was considered so colossal that they named Harvard College after him. Over the course of his life, Harvard had acquired books at the rate of about 12 a year. Jefferson, over the course of his life, bought books at the rate of about 12 a month.”

headline: The Italian Jobber
text: Federico Marchetti likes to compare himself to Caronte, the boatman who leads Dante into the underworld. He’s joking — sort of. Since June 2000, when he founded Yoox.com, the online merchant of discounted high-end clothes and accessories, Marchetti has been helping fashion labels navigate the Internet’s murky waters.

headline: Read My Book? Tour My House
text: This past summer, I sat in Norman Mailer’s living room in Provincetown, Mass., as the sun beat on the windows looking out to the bay, listening to Mailer’s literary executor and longtime friend, J. Michael Lennon, tell stories about “Norm,” his wives and his writing habits. I was there as a writing fellow at the Norman Mailer Center, which is what the brick house on Commercial Street has become, and our group, Lennon told us, was going to have a special opportunity to tour the house, including Mailer’s attic study, which has been “preserved in amber.” Mailer was in the middle of writing a book when he died, and after his death nothing was touched. The plan is to have the room “stay that way forever, ” Lennon said.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: NEMESIS,  by Philip Roth (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $26.) Set mostly in Newark in 1944 and suffused with tenderness, Roth’s novel tells the story of a military reject, a young phys ed teacher, who turns a polio outbreak into his own patriotic battleground.

headline: Final Movement
text: Is there any genre convention John Lawton hasn’t boldly disregarded, often to brilliant effect? While ostensibly grounded in post-World War II London, his elegant police procedurals featuring Inspector Frederick Troy of Scotland Yard succeed in traversing fluid timelines. His characters have solid fictional substance, even as they routinely interact with real-life figures to insinuate themselves into critical events in history. And although Inspector Troy observes the basic investigative procedures, Lawton is quick to discard them when he wants to expand his crime narratives into international espionage thrillers.

headline: Paperback Row
text: COWBOYS FULL: The Story of Poker,  by James McManus (Picador, $18.) McManus, whose splendid earlier book “Positively Fifth Street” described his improbable rise to the final table in the World Series of Poker in 2000, here offers a lively account of poker’s past and present. It is, he says, a particularly American game, combining “Puritan values — self-control, diligence, the steady accumulation of savings . . . with what might be called the open-market cowboy’s desire to get very rich very quickly.” McManus “writes with verve and knowledge,” our reviewer, Robert Pinsky, said, and the book is “entertaining, informative and genial.”

headline: 3G Gets Nearly 94% of Burger King Shares
text: 3G Capital said on Friday that nearly 94 percent of the common shares of Burger King have been tendered into its $3.26 billion offer for the fast-food chain.

headline: Jolie Defends Film After Permit Is Cancelled in Bosnia
text: Angelina Jolie said she hopes audiences will wait to see her coming film about a romance set against the Bosnian war before drawing any conclusions about it, Reuters reported.

headline: Never Grow Old
text: An attempt to publish the inventory of Mickey Mantle iconography began in February 2009 and will continue well into next year. From Mickey Mantle vanity license plates to Mickey Mantle postcards to Mickey Mantle bobblehead dolls to Mickey Mantle postcards depicting him holding Mickey Mantle bobblehead dolls, the cataloged, photographed and priced relics will ultimately exceed 2,000, and will have filled 200 ­pages in the memorabilia industry’s weekly Sports Collectors Digest. Included in the reckoning are at least 30 full-scale Mickey Mantle biographies, half a dozen of which carry the Mantle imprimatur as author, co-­author or frontman.

headline: Up Front: Keith Olbermann
text: Well into his 20s, Keith Olbermann was an “insatiable” Yankees fan.

text: TESTED 2010 Buick LaCrosse CX

headline: Hey, Candidates, Time to ‘Man Up’
text: It’s official. The bipartisan phrase of the week, hands down, is “man up.”

headline: Questions About the Chevrolet Volt
text: Earlier this week, Paul Stenquist wrote about some of the questions raised since General Motors officially unveiled the production version of the Chevrolet Volt:

headline: Q. and A. With Tyler Kepner
text: With the league championship series about to begin, Tyler Kepner, The Times’s national baseball writer, will answer readers’ questions today. The American League starts things off tonight when the Yankees return to Texas. Three times in the late 1990’s the Yankees defeated the Rangers in division series, but this year, Kepner wrote, “the Rangers have a weapon that may be unbeatable: Cliff Lee, a left-handed ace the Yankees covet and cannot seem to beat.”

headline: Friday Reading: The Biggest Potential Tax Policy Mistakes
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Brooklyn Housing Market Is Rebounding
text: The Brooklyn housing market is on the rebound, according to a report being released Friday. Average sales prices during the third quarter increased by more than 7 percent over both the second quarter and last year’s third quarter, though they remain well below peak levels. And apartments were selling about a third faster than they were at the same time last year. Read more on the housing recovery in the Real Estate section.

headline: Looking Ahead to Open Enrollment
text: In this week’s Patient Money column, Walecia Konrad explains what this year’s open enrollment period means to consumers.

headline: The Professor Goes to Washington
text: Sometime in the late 1980s, I had lunch with Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan. The drug war was a hot topic of conversation, and at the start of the lunch I asked him how he thought it was going. To answer the question fully, he said, would require a little historical background.

headline: Harvard Colleagues Clash Over F.D.A.
text: In a very public war of words, two Harvard colleagues have been debating the effectiveness of the Food and Drug Administration following publication of a new book, “Reputation and Power: Organizational Image and Pharmaceutical Regulation at the F.D.A.,” by Daniel Carpenter, a professor at the university.

headline: A Grisly Murder Trial, in 140-Character Bits
text: NEW HAVEN  Dr. William A. Petit Jr., whose wife and daughters were killed by two intruders in Cheshire, Conn., took the witness stand. It was one of the most expectantly intense moments of the three-week trial of one of two defendants in the case. Every seat in the courtroom was taken.

headline: Obama Lesson: ‘Shovel Ready’ Not So Ready
text: Even before President Obama entered the White House, he and his allies successfully used the allure of “shovel ready” infrastructure projects to help sell his $787 billion stimulus legislation to a resistant Congress and a wary public.

headline: Exchange Student on the Honor Roll
text: WHEN a bankrupt General Motors realized it had to downsize its money pit of a house, tossing away Pontiac, Saturn, Saab and Hummer the way parents give away their children’s old toys, it surprised some people by keeping Buick.

headline: Borough Skirmishes
text: Alfredo Batista, the 19-year-old drug-dealing hero of Matt Burgess’s scorching first novel, “Dogfight, a Love Story,” is about to have the most nail-biting weekend of his life. It’s June 2002, and in the next 24 hours, Alfredo’s older brother, Tariq, released from prison, will arrive at his family’s apartment in Queens, where Alfredo lives with Isabel, who was Tariq’s girlfriend when he was incarcerated, but who is now seven months pregnant with Alfredo’s child.

headline: Despite Protests, Adam Lambert Calls for ‘Love’ at Malaysian Concert
text: A concert performed by Adam Lambert drew fans as well as protesters in Malaysia, but the singer kept his word that he would follow the restrictions placed on the show, The Associated Press reported.

headline: The Case of the Demon Mirror
text: ACURA steering racks that squeal and BMWs that emit strange noises or show signs of demonic possession are among the subjects of the latest technical service bulletins from automakers.

headline: An ‘A’ for Jean George
text: The pendulum has swung for Jean Georges, the four-star restaurant in the Trump International that was the subject of an embarrassing  (if popular!) post on Diner’s Journal earlier this week, after a wandering cockroach was spotted in the dining room.

headline: Winking at the Apocalypse
text: When I realized (after I’d agreed to write this review) that Fay Weldon’s latest novel, her 29th, is set in a totalitarian England after the fatal crash of capitalism, I considered looking to see if I still had any refills left for my old Wellbutrin prescription. Generally, I keep away from fiction or movies about the end of the world, even if it’s just about the end of the world “as we know it.” (I avoid stories set in prison for the same reason: guaranteed nightmares, often involving ferrets, a small cage and me.) In this case, however, I needn’t have worried. Despite a surfeit of the genre’s requisite trappings (food rationing, secret police, universal surveillance, dopey government acronyms), “Chalcot Crescent” might be the least depressing — certainly it’s the most cheerful — dystopian fiction I’ve ever come across, thanks to Weldon’s slashing wit and her refusal to suffer fools gladly, no matter how despotic. Even in a world without reliable electricity or real coffee, life worth living goes bumbling on. This is not quite “1984” with baggy pants, big shoes and a seltzer bottle, but close.

headline: Living Down the Past
text: It cannot always be easy to be a German. How does one deal with a recent national history drenched in so much innocent blood? How does a German writer find the right tone to describe it, without escaping into mawkish self-flagellation or nervous apologetics? Whether Bernhard Schlink, a lawyer as well as a novelist, found the right tone in “The Reader,” his best-selling 1995 novel about the love affair between an illiterate war criminal and an adolescent boy, is open to question. But the combination of erotic allure and earnest moral soul-searching, about sex, growing up and the German past, made the book a worldwide hit.

headline: 2011 Buick LaCrosse
text: The LaCrosse is a positive step in the effort to broaden Buick’s appeal.

headline: Mock Canadian Attack Ad of the Year
text: As Americans argue about the influence political attack ads made with secret special-interest money might be having on the upcoming midterm elections, a shadowy group in Canada has taken credit for trying to sway voters in a tight mayoral race in Winnipeg.

headline: ‘One Shining Moment’ Might Need Some Polishing
text: Preparation for the N.C.A.A. basketball season begins in earnest on Friday as most men’s Division One teams hit the practice floor for the first time.

headline: On the Origins of Island Life
text: Tuesday, Oct. 12

headline: Before He Was Experienced
text: In 1967, a music critic called Jimi Hendrix’s music “robust” and “hellish” in the same review, which is like describing God as “outstanding” and “divine.” “Robust” just doesn’t cut it — that adjective might apply to a Sousa march, but not to such sulphurous anthems as “Manic Depression” and “Foxy Lady.”

headline: U.S. to Investigate China’s Clean Energy Aid
text: The economic tension between the United States and China escalated on Friday, as the Obama administration pledged to investigate Beijing’s subsidies to its growing clean energy industries while delaying a politically volatile report on the Chinese currency.

headline: Seeing Things | Transformative Travels
text: The impact of global movement on local environments is examined in an exhibition that opens next week at the Canadian Centre for Architecture in Montreal. “Journeys: How Traveling Fruit, Ideas and Buildings Rearrange our Environment,” which is on view through March 13, 2011, tells 15 stories about migration and displacement, each associated with a specific place and time.

headline: A Personal Look at Mario Vargas Llosa
text: Over on the Book Review’s Paper Cuts blog, Eric Lichtblau, a reporter in The Times’s Washington bureau, writes of his family’s personal ties to Mario Vargas Llosa, who was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature last week.

headline: Path to Dissent
text: “So what’s happened to our Jews?” the agronomist Koryako asks his neighbors, grinning slyly. “Children, old men — I haven’t glimpsed a Jew all day. It’s as if they’d never existed. And only yesterday they were all coming back from the market with 12-kilo baskets!”

headline: 2011 Buick Regal
text: The new Regal might be the best-looking sedan from any American automaker.

headline: Under God . . . or Not
text: Today’s conservatives often describe themselves as strict constructionists, seeking the “original meaning” of the nation’s founding texts. In the case of the Pledge of Allegiance, a much ­fetishized if not legally binding document, this approach is unlikely to yield the desired political result. As Jeffrey Owen Jones and Peter Meyer note, the original author of the pledge was a former Christian Socialist minister who hoped to redeem the United States from its class and ethnic antagonisms. Interpretations of its meaning have been growing more conservative, not more liberal, ever since.

headline: When the Beat Came in a Box
text: In December 2001, while on assignment in Tokyo, the photographer Lyle Owerko came across a funky old boombox at an outdoor market. He was struck by its bulk and intrigued by its link to a vanished New York of break dancing and graffiti, and as soon as he returned home to New York he began scouring flea markets and eBay for more of them.

headline: A Physicist’s Climate Complaints
text: Almost 20 years ago, Harold Lewis, a respected physicist who had advised the government and the Pentagon on matters ranging from nuclear winter to missile defense, included his assessment of climate change from the buildup of human-generated greenhouse gases in a book on technological risk:

headline: Orpheus Chamber Orchestra Announces Winners of Commissioning Program
text: The Orpheus Chamber Orchestra, which takes the populist view that musical interpretations can be shaped by the ensemble rather than by a conductor, has expanded on that concept in a commissioning program, Project 440. The orchestra’s goal was to commission four composers to help celebrate its 40th anniversary. Intent on getting its audience involved, it joined forces with WQXR, the classical radio station, which opened the process to its listeners.

headline: The News From Shanghai
text: In the first four decades of the People’s Republic, Shanghai existed in a strange limbo, a kind of ghostly half-life. No longer the jeweled sewer of decadence and corruption it had once been — a city of opium smokers and courtesans, millionaires and beggars, the high elegance of the Bund and the conspiratorial darkness of the foreign concessions — it lingered on under Communism as an industrial center, a vital source of taxable wealth, but symbolically something of an embarrassment, its foreignness a stain that couldn’t be washed away. Then, after Deng Xiao­ping liberalized its economy in 1991, Shanghai roared back to life and regained its place as a financial and cultural hub, a symbol of China’s dizzying emergence on the world stage.

headline: Sweetleaf Coffee Expands
text: Sweetleaf  is entering a new weight category. The Long Island City, Queens, coffee spot tripled in size after taking over the storefront next door and adding a pour over bar (where coffee will be brewed by the cup), and single origin espresso – right now it’s Stumptown Coffee Roaster’s Ethiopian Mordecofe.

headline: Five-Link Friday: Twitter Police and a 404 Not Found
text: So the U.F.O. was probably a bunch of balloons freed from a Westchester wedding, or maybe from the feting in Times Square of a Spanish street, or both. Well, it was fun while it lasted, but never fear, we have plenty of uninvited guests appearing out of the blue all over the city, and they are real.

headline: The Life She Fled
text: Travel back to another era, to another sensibility, to an age when fantasy and nightmare mingled in the air with the scent of lime blossom, when survival would soon come to depend on the capacity for selective forgetting. With her enthralling, richly imagined and remorseless novel, “The Blindness of the Heart,” Julia Franck, born in 1970 in East Germany but raised in the West, emerges on the literary stage with a work reminiscent of some grand regional forebears. Winner of the 2007 German Book Prize, her novel brings together the haunting folk echoes of Dinesen’s “Winter’s Tales,” the visual immediacy of Isherwood’s “Goodbye to Berlin,” the narrative cohesion of Mann’s “Buddenbrooks.”

headline: What We’re Reading: PermaBear-Speak
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: Able to Take the Mound in a Single Bound
text: If you haven’t already, now is the perfect time to note how baseball’s Supermen have changed. Once, in the last millennium, they had forearms the size of Volkswagens (with accompanying sketchy pharmaceutical histories) and everyone talked about the long ball and whether the parks were too small and how much Babe Ruth would so surely approve. But heading into the league championship series this weekend, any comparisons to Ruth will have to mention that he was also a pitcher and the only comparison involving a Volkswagen is whether the Yankees’ C.C. Sabathia would fit in one.

headline: Afghan War Is Off the Voters’ Radar
text: Polling suggests that the war in Afghanistan is barely a blip on voters’ radars as the midterm elections approach, according to a report in The New York Times by Dalia Sussman and Megan Thee-Brenan.

headline: New Ratmansky and Wheeldon Works Highlight American Ballet Theater’s Spring Season
text: Alexei Ratmansky and Christopher Wheeldon continue their reign as the most in-demand choreographers in the ballet world this spring at American Ballet Theater. Two new works by the choreographers, as well as the premiere of a revival of Antony Tudor’s 1967 “Shadowplay,” are among the highlights of the company’s spring season, which runs May 16 to July 9 at the Metropolitan Opera House.

headline: Egghead
text: David Susskind was an egotist, a womanizer, an intellectual, a charmer, a producer of high-minded television dramas and a talk-show pioneer. Now he is a giant roar from the past.

headline: A Life Between
text: As of 2005, the United States had a black, female secretary of state, and yet black America has largely observed this more than celebrated it. There is a tacit sense “out there” that Condoleezza Rice isn’t black in the “real” way, as we might put it. Not “with” us, perhaps.

headline: Responding to Reader Comments
text: It’s great to get the comments to my introductory post. Like pretty much all working human beings — and unlike our computers and gadgets, unless there’s a new iPhone app I’ve missed — I appreciate appreciation, so thanks much for the welcoming notes. I do, however, try to pay special attention to criticisms, concerns and requests, in the hopes that they can lead me to do at least an incrementally better job. To prove I’m paying attention, let me respond to a few of those.

headline: Everything Turns to Fire
text: The opening sentence of Amelia Gray’s “Museum of the Weird” — “One morning, I woke to discover I had given birth overnight” — could serve as a metaphor for the creation of a certain type of story. While many stories come into being through intense ­authorial diligence and cogitation, others spring into existence in an instant, discharging themselves onto the page almost by magic.

headline: Actual Families on Virtual Pages
text: The humorous video I linked to earlier this week, about a fictional app that defends a child’s Facebook profile from his mother, led to two very serious e-mails from readers struggling with the role of their actual family in their virtual life.

headline: Chile y Todo el Mundo: Connecting the Chilean Miners Story With Universal Themes
text: Overview | Why did the rescue of 33 miners in Chile captivate the world? What universal themes are found in their story? In this lesson, students create a multimedia project that addresses curricular themes related to the will to survive and the ability to see ourselves in the struggles of others.

headline: The Fashion Cycle | Linus Bikes
text: Long before gas-guzzling Western capitals did something of a backpedal by implementing safer bike lanes and investing in bike-for-hire schemes, Adam McDermott and Chad Kushner, the South African founders of Linus Bikes, spent years traveling bicycle-centric cities in Europe and Asia. “We loved the simple, utilitarian bikes we’d find in other countries,” McDermott says, “and wished there was a similar urban bike-as-transportation culture back home.” Inspired by the elegant but basic designs of French city bikes of the ’50s and ’60s, Linus achieves the aesthetic of a modern vintage cycle: straight, clean lines, monochromatic colors and no excessive logos. Its new bicycle carryalls — crafted from wax canvas, oilskin leather and solid brass hardware that is designed to age nicely — are saddle bags you want.

headline: Weekend Competition: Please Do Not Make Eye Contact with the Robots
text: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to invent warning signs from the future.

headline: BMW Drivers Are the Angriest in Britain, Says Survey
text: If you’re a BMW driver — now, don’t get mad at this — you are the angriest motorist on the road, at least in Britain.

headline: Pressing My Nose to the Glass in China
text: For the past week I’ve been in Beijing, my first trip to China. Except for the city’s famous traffic jams, the city is nothing like I had expected. And what did I expect of this remarkable, sprawling, fast-changing city? Today — Friday in Beijing — I had lunch with Angelica Cheung, the editor in chief of Vogue China, at the China Grill on the 66th floor of the Park Hyatt, and since I arrived at the restaurant a few minutes early, I took a moment to press my nose to the windows. The sprawl of new buildings — skyscrapers, hotels, apartment blocks — is almost unfathomable and seemingly endless.

headline: iRead
text: In Lane Smith’s new book, called, simply, “It’s a Book,” a mouse, a jackass and a monkey — all drawn with the kind of early-’60s geometric-minded stylization that requires a gentle reminder of which animal is which on the title page — discover a new thing. Flat and rectangular, with a hard cover and a soft, yielding inside, it baffles the jackass, while the behatted monkey tries patiently to explain its curious technology. “Do you blog with it?” the jackass says. “No, it’s a book,” the monkey explains. This only makes the donkey’s exasperation keener: Where’s the mouse? Does it need a password? Can you make the characters fight? Can it text, tweet, toot? No, none of that, the monkey explains, and then Monkey hands the book to Jackass, who takes it worriedly, like a nut too hard to crack.

headline: Early Fiction by Wes Anderson, Owen Wilson and Colum McCann
text: Perhaps the only place we expected to see Colum McCann side by side with Wes Anderson and Owen Wilson is at a Barnes & Noble where someone misfiled a paperback copy of “Let the Great World Spin” between DVDs of “Bottle Rocket” and “The Royal Tenenbaums.”

headline: New Jersey Arts Center Sets Real Estate Venture
text: Performing arts centers typically present performances, not develop real estate.

headline: How the West Was Won
text: Tarnation! Seems like a mule’s age since we’ve had a hero of American folklore worth wasting song and spit over, someone big enough to wear the boots of Paul Bunyan, Pecos Bill and John Henry, a giant who cuts canyons with his plow and seeds lakes with his tears.

headline: Miners No Longer Forced to Order In
text: Among the grateful bear hugs and kisses the world didn’t see on television after the Chilean miners emerged to life on the surface this week were those given to their chef. For more than a month, Edmundo Ramírez and a staff of 12 had sent five meals a day nearly half a mile underground to them.

headline: TimesCast | October 15, 2010
text: What makes a true Tea Party candidate; buying a foreclosed home and a look at end credits of documentaries.

headline: Miners Begin to Speak, Though Sparingly, of Ordeal
text: A first-hand account of how the 33 miners survived their emotional, physical and psychological trials while trapped for 69 days a half-mile under the Chilean desert has yet to emerge.

headline: Taking Basil Beyond Pesto
text: In this week’s Recipes for Health, Martha Rose Shulman takes basil beyond pesto, offering fresh new ways to use the popular herb.

headline: You Know You’re a Milan Insider When . . .

headline: Happy Birthday to Us

headline: Tate Modern Closes Access to ‘Sunflower Seeds’
text: When an installation by the Chinese conceptual artist Ai Weiwei opened on Tuesday at Turbine Hall, the cavernous entrance space of the Tate Modern in London, visitors were encouraged to touch and even walk on the 100 million hand-crafted porcelain sunflower seeds that gave the piece its name. But on Thursday this kind of intimate interaction stopped. Officials at the museum closed off access to “Sunflower Seeds,” and is now only allowing visitors to see it from a walkway above the hall.

headline: Red Sox Owner Takes Over Liverpool Soccer Club
text: Long-suffering Liverpool F.C. fans clamoring for change can rejoice: the English soccer team officially has a new owner, the investor group that also owns the Boston Red Sox.

headline: Georgia Shifts Leaders’ Powers, but Some See a Political Ploy
text: TBILISI, Georgia  The Georgian Parliament gave final approval on Friday to constitutional amendments reducing the powers of the president and strengthening the role of the prime minister after presidential elections in 2013.

headline: Aging: Longer Life Expectancy Seen for Hispanics
text: Scientists call it the “Hispanic paradox”: despite high rates of poverty and relatively low rates of health insurance, Hispanics in the United States tend to outlive African-Americans and non-Hispanic whites.

headline: Flanagan to Face Her Fears on the Streets of New York
text: As a first-time marathoner, Shalane Flanagan will confront a flurry of unknown factors at the New York City Marathon on Nov. 7. Her seven years as a professional track and field athlete running a variety of distances from the 1,500 meters to 10,000 on synthetic track surfaces will provide minimal comfort on the blacktopped roads of an urban marathon. Winning a bronze medal in the 10,000 at the 2008 Beijing Olympics has done little to ease her concerns.

It detailed the unorthodox – and according to some, toxic – management style of top executive Randy Michaels and his crew, who were transplanted from careers in the wacky world of radio to the helm of a tradition-proud news organization known for its serious mien.

text: In only the second elimination of a disease in history, rinderpest  a virus that used to kill cattle by the millions, leading to famine and death among humans  has been declared wiped off the face of the earth.

headline: North Korea Threatens to Attack if South Resumes Propaganda
text: SEOUL, South Korea  In the first aggressive threat by North Korea since a new leadership hierarchy was announced last month, the North vowed to attack South Korea if the South resumed a propaganda war along their border, the North’s official Korean Central News Agency said Friday.

But several Queens officials have written to the Environmental Protection Agency to make sure the agency doesn’t play favorites.

headline: Orientation
text: To the Editor:

headline: Back to the Circus
text: It began in 2008, that improbably toxic year: an endless search for almost-jobs; the completion of an expensively worthless degree; a lying, cheating girlfriend; a crashed stock portfolio (bought with money from the Brooklyn home I flipped as a successful subprime borrower). I had to get away. I flew to Los Angeles, bought a motorcycle and rode for weeks as far as Seattle, only to be summoned overnight back to L.A., where my deaf aunt was dying of the leukemia she had managed for 23 years. According to her friends, she was dying because she quit her medical treatments after a Gypsy psychic convinced her that the doctors were lying to her.

headline: Little Brother Is Watching
text: In George Orwell’s “1984,” that novel of totalitarian politics whose great mistake was to emphasize the villainy of society’s masters while playing down the mischief of the masses, the goal of communications technology was brutal and direct: to ensure the dominance of the state. The sinister “telescreens” placed in people’s homes spewed propaganda and conducted surveillance, keeping the population passive and the leadership firmly in control. In the face of constant monitoring, all people could do was sterilize their behavior, conceal their thoughts and carry on like model citizens.

headline: Reality Lags the Football Dream at Rutgers
text: PISCATAWAY, N.J.  No one can blame Greg Schiano for believing he can build Rutgers into a national football power. When he arrived 10 years ago, the Scarlet Knights had appeared in a single postseason bowl game in 135 years of competition. This year, Rutgers is seeking its sixth consecutive bowl invitation.

headline: The Queen
text: In your new biography of Cleopatra, you take issue with historians who have attributed her achievements to her looks and implied that she slept her way to the top. For reasons I am sure you can explain to me, it has always been preferable to attribute a woman’s success to her beauty rather than brains. We seem convinced that men strategize while women scheme. Men are authoritative while women are shrill.

headline: E-Readers’ Collective
text: Any piece of writing that’s for sale lives and dies by display copy — titles, subtitles, cover lines, jacket copy, blurbs, headlines, captions, pull quotes. Display copy frames most literary production, high and low, and instructs readers in how to interpret it.

headline: Rough Patches
text: “Hey, big guy,” Dr. Wolffe Nadoolman called out in a friendly voice, “why don’t you come help me and your mom figure out where this rash of yours is coming from?” The gangly 4-year-old boy clambered into the chair and sat down expectantly. The skin on his face was fair and unblemished. But according to his mother, it wasn’t clear a week ago.

headline: The Anesthesiologist’s Game
text: I am an anesthesiologist. A few of my patients are children undergoing their first surgery — understandably nervous, sometimes in tears. Medications can calm them; developing a rapport with them also helps. One way I do that is to propose a contest. If they can pop the “balloon” (the bag an anesthetized patient uses to breathe), they will win a fabulous prize — a pony, a puppy, a motorcycle. This task is effectively impossible (but their deep breathing puts them to sleep faster). Some nurses complain that children in the recovery room are very disappointed when told they did not win a prize. Should I suspend the contest? MARK ISAAC, MANSFIELD, OHIO

headline: Week in Pictures, Oct. 15
text: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region.

headline: The Elusive Small-House Utopia
text: Every year, in conjunction with a big trade show, the magazine Builder creates something it calls its “concept home.” The house is an exhibition on a theme — the 2004 edition, for example, was called the Ultimate Family Home — but also a commercial venture. Attendees of the International Builders’ Show can walk through a model, and when the show is over, the concept is quite literally put to a test when the finished house is offered up for sale on the open market. During the last decade’s real estate boom, the annual demonstration kept up with the times: designs abounded with baronial features like colonnades, cathedral ceilings and observation towers, and they sometimes topped 6,000 square feet. But then the crash came, wiping out credit lines and shaking the industry’s confidence. For this year’s show, Boyce Thompson, the editorial director of Builder, wanted a look more attuned to curtailed appetites, so he came up with a concept that he called a Home for the New Economy.

headline: The Traditionalist
text: IN A BLUSTERY ECONOMIC climate, with waves of populist resentment thundering outside the thickest paneled doors, what do rich people want in a home? Is it their wish to be exposed in glass-and-steel boxes? Will they opt for precarious-seeming triumphs of cantilevered engineering? Or are they, perhaps, looking for something else? Last winter, I went on a fact-finding mission to 15 Central Park West. The project is the most successful high-end Manhattan residential development in recent memory, having gone to contract on all of its 202 units for approximately $2 billion, before its doors opened in late 2007. My guides were Robert A. M. Stern, whose New York-based architecture firm designed the building, and William Lie Zeckendorf, who developed it with his brother, Arthur. Both Zeckendorfs live there. So do Lloyd Blankfein, the chief executive of Goldman Sachs (alongside many of his generals; Goldman Sachs helped finance the venture); Sanford Weill, the former Citigroup chairman; and a smattering of bold-faced names (Denzel Washington, Sting).

headline: Ask the Contractor
text: I’m considering radiant heat for my bathroom. How does it work, and is it a good idea?DISALVO: You can only add radiant heat if you intend to renovate your bathroom or at least replace the floor. Once you have the floor up, however, radiant-heat systems are easy to install. You have them on a thermostat, and they heat up and heat the floor, which is very comfortable. The downside is that it takes several hours for the floor to warm up, but once it does it eliminates the need for a radiator. WIENER: There are two kinds of systems. The water system uses plastic tubing with warm water. The electrical uses mats of electrical coils. Water is mostly not allowed in apartment buildings because of the potential for leaks. Both systems are good. DARDICK: I haven’t done a master bathroom in the last three years that did not have a heated floor. Everybody loves them. I don’t know anyone who doesn’t like them. But if you live in a cold-weather climate, a heated floor may not be the entire solution for heating a whole room.

headline: Keeping Score: Rangers’ Hitters Are Out of Order
text: It’s impressive that the Texas Rangers knocked off the team with the best record in the American League for their first postseason series win in team history. It’s even more impressive that they did so with a batting order that defies reason. If Ron Washington is serious about winning the pennant, he should read up on the latest research into lineup construction and give his order a makeover.

headline: While England Moves Toward 2018, U.S. Focused on 2022
text: Americans will have to wait at least 12 more years to see a World Cup final game at home. The USA Bid Committee said Friday that it had withdrawn from trying to secure the 2018 World Cup and would instead focus on trying to win the 2022 event.

headline: When the ‘Dust Blossom’ Clears in Kandahar
text: ZHARI, Afghanistan — I yelled to my men, ordering them to get down and take cover and orient their weapons eastward, halting our joint patrol with the Afghan National Army. A sniper had been terrorizing our small outpost in the middle of the Zhari district in Kandahar for three weeks. This menace had created a phantom persona, like the Ghost of Christmas Past who had followed us to the deserts of Afghanistan.

headline: Robbing the Cradle Sitter
text: I have two little boys and a nanny who takes care of them twice a week. It took me months to find her. A neighbor asked for her number to see if she might baby-sit occasionally. I gave it to her because our nanny was always looking for more hours. Now, the neighbor has called to say she’s gotten a job and has offered our nanny a full-time position. Our nanny is better off, but I can’t help feeling betrayed by the neighbor. Could she have handled this better? M. D.

Shortly before the clashes started, a Western aid worker was kidnapped from the same area.

headline: City to Get Federal Disaster Money for Tornadoes
text: Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island were declared federal disaster areas for the purposes of tornado cleanup, the governor’s office announced Thursday night. That means the federal government will pick up three-quarters of the tab for emergency response, debris removal and repairs to public property resulting from last month’s destructive storm — about $22 million out of an estimated $27 million. The federal government has not yet acted on Gov. David A. Paterson’s request for individual relief for homeowners, renters and businesses.

headline: Letters: Kafka’s Last Trial
text: It simply won’t do for Elif Batuman to epitomize Kafka’s working life as “working in an insurance agency” (Sept. 26). That office was as fruitful a source of Kafka’s work an any literary or Freudian critic can conjure. In his 14 years as a lawyer, he worked first in Prague for Il Assicurazioni Generali (a Jewish-founded insurance company based in Trieste that featured a menorah in its lobby), the insurer for Workers Compensation in Austria-Hungary before World War I. Before and after the war, he toiled in the same field for the Workers Accident Insurance Institute, the government agency administering benefits for work injuries (no occupational diseases then). Kafka’s projection of what Max Weber called the “iron cage of bureaucracy” was literally lifted from the admittedly boring and unsatisfying work at the compensation agency. “The Castle” and “The Trial” are rife with examples, like the official of “The Castle” who assures the land surveyor that the confusion in question can be “proved from the official papers.” The response: “The papers will not be found.”

headline: Tacos and Dumplings: Coming Soon to a Park Near You?

headline: Self-Pity in the White House
text: Up to a point, Peter Baker’s excellent Times Magazine piece on the mood in the Obama White House inspires a certain amount of sympathy for this administration. When Baker’s sources complain that their boss is being unfairly maligned by foes and friends (or “frenemies,” perhaps) alike, they have a point: The most strident criticisms of the Obama presidency have almost all been at least somewhat unfair, whether it’s conservatives calling the president a socialist and a radical (when actually he’s just a very conventional liberal), left-wingers claiming that he’s a sell-out and a crypto-conservative (when actually he’s accomplished more for the left than any president since L.B.J.), or D.C. insiders dismissing his political skills and salesmanship (hey, you try being a political salesman when the unemployment rate is 9.5 percent!). I’m no great admirer of Barack Obama’s policies, but some of the discontent swirling around the White House at the moment is the usual cult-of-the-presidency nonsense, in which the occupant of the Oval Office is held responsible for forces and events beyond his control, and everyone pretends that the world would be perfect if he weren’t so incompetent, so cowardly, or so evil.

headline: Week 7 College Football Matchups
text: The college football season is a grind. The clear goal for the top teams is to stay undefeated and that means you have to bring your best game every week. Alabama showed us last week that the top teams can’t afford to come out flat. The Tide traveled to face a tough South Carolina team that had a great day and now it no longer controls its own destiny. This week Ohio State, which took over the top spot, goes on the road to Madison for one of the toughest games on its schedule. Auburn hosts Arkansas with the goal of remaining unbeaten headed into next week’s game against L.S.U. (Would love to see both teams undefeated for that one.) Meanwhile, unbeaten Nebraska looks for some revenge as it hosts Texas in a rematch of last year’s Big 12 championship game. Even some of the lower ranked unbeatens like Michigan State and Missouri have challenging games. Every week we learn a little bit more. This Sunday the B.C.S. rankings come out and the debate gets ratcheted up a notch. Things are happening people. Every Saturday is important.

headline: Weekend Fare

There will be stands set up by restaurants, food trucks and vendors at Hester and Essex Streets between 10 a.m. and 6 p.m., rain or shine. Some of those supposed to be on hand are: Purple Yam, Cheeky Sandwiches, Mile End Delicatessen, Pies ‘n’ Thighs, Luke’s Lobster, Cascabel Taqueria, AnChoi, Kickstand Coffee, Kelvin Natural Slush Company and Mexicue.

headline: Artifacts | The Frieze Art Fair: Salvage Instinct
text: Trend-spotters at the Frieze Art Fair this week had an easy time finding the next big thing: the artist as clutter queen. During a V.I.P. preview attended by Keith Richards as well as the mega-collectors Dasha Zhukova, Steven Cohen and Charles Saatchi, I saw so much junk repurposed as found-object sculpture that I actually mistook a pair of fire extinguishers for an artwork. But when I reached the stand of Berlin’s Contemporary Fine Art, and a friend blurted a telltale alert – “What the hell is that!” – I knew we were onto something big.
