text: Photographs from Switzerland, Afghanistan, Germany and Washington.

headline: Scrutinizing the Elite, Whether They Like It or Not
text: THE rich are sitting firmly in the public cross hairs, especially as the economy continues to stumble. Reports that Wall Street bonuses will again be high, and the debate in Congress over tax increases for the wealthy, just add to the outrage.

headline: Princeton Endowment Posts a 14.7% Return
text: At a time when many of the nation’s largest endowments have generated returns below 12 percent, Princeton University said on Friday that its endowment had returned 14.7 percent last year, bringing its total to $14.4 billion.

headline: E.P.A. Official Seeks to Block West Virginia Mine
text: WASHINGTON  A top federal regulator has recommended revoking the permit for one of the nation’s largest planned mountaintop removal mining projects, saying it would be devastating to miles of West Virginia streams and the plant and animal life they support.

headline: Grading College Athletes
text: The stereotypes are (partly) true: College athletes do worse in school than their non-athlete counterparts.

headline: Death of a Fulton Fish Market Fixture
text: THE fish men see her still, their Annie, in the hide-and-seek shadows of South Street. She’s telling her dirty jokes and doing anything for a buck: hustling newspapers, untaxed cigarettes, favors, those pairs of irregular socks she’d buy cheap on Canal. She’s submitting to the elements, calling out “Yoo-hoo” to the snow and the rain and her boys.

headline: First Pregnancies Are the Best?
text: When Marcella Gate was pregnant the first time, she remembers saying things like :

headline: Can Happy Meal Meme Stand Up to the Scientific Method?
text: McDonald’s has been taking a bit of a beating lately, what with the photographer Sally Davies’s “Happy Meal Project” going viral this week. Each day for 137 days, she took a photo of the same hamburger and fries from a Happy Meal. Unnervingly, neither item rotted or even grew a feather of mold.

headline: Liverpool Sale to Red Sox Owner Finalized
text: The battle for ownership of Liverpool F. C. ended Friday with the sale of the club to New England Sports Ventures, the owners of the Boston Red Sox, for about $480 million.

headline: And The Winner Is…
text: Design Miami has named the German designer Konstantin Grcic as its Designer of the Year for 2010. In this video by TheCrane.tv, which is exclusive to T, Grcic talks about how and why he designs–and shows us an object he just had to have.

headline: Avoid Foreclosure Market Until the Dust Settles
text: Are you out of your mind to even consider buying a foreclosed property right now?

headline: In NASA Image, a Submerged Pakistan
text: New satellite images from NASA show the extraordinary scope of the continuing disaster in Pakistan, where thousands of square miles of land remain submerged two months after the country was hit by catastrophic flooding.

headline: Coyotes Update, Gainey Talks Team and Buffalo’s Woes
text: From The Montreal Gazette’s Habs Inside/Out blog:

headline: Despite Image, Union Leader Backs School Change
text: In “Waiting for Superman,” the new education documentary, the union leader Randi Weingarten is portrayed, in the words of Variety, as “a foaming satanic beast.”

headline: E.P.A. Seeks to Revoke Mining Permit
text: The Environmental Protection Agency has announced that it plans to revoke a permit granted under the Bush administration for a vast mountaintop mining operation in West Virginia, saying it would bury streams and extinguish wildlife.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Swiss Alps and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Switzerland, Afghanistan, Germany and Washington.

headline: Share Your Foreclosure Purchase War Stories
text: In this weekend’s Your Money column, I offer up some tips for people who just can’t resist a bargain and are determined to shop around for a good deal on a foreclosed home.

headline: Obama Fills In G.O.P.’s Blanks
text: WASHINGTON  In speech after speech lately, President Obama has vowed to oppose a Republican proposal “to cut education by 20 percent,” a reduction that would “eliminate 200,000 children from Head Start programs” and “reduce financial aid for eight million college students.”

headline: At Bronx Science, a Nobel Homecoming
text: David Politzer donned a pair of safety goggles Friday morning and smiled as two soccer-playing robots whizzed around the floor of a classroom at the Bronx High School of Science.

headline: From Boys to Men
text: HAS anyone seen the Dior man? You know the one, that scrawny rocker dude with a chicken chest, a size 36 suit and a face that seems to be sprouting its first crop of peach fuzz.

headline: Toddlers’ Favorite Toy: The iPhone
text: THE bedroom door opened and a light went on, signaling an end to nap time. The toddler, tousle-haired and sleepy-eyed, clambered to a wobbly stand in his crib. He smiled, reached out to his father, and uttered what is fast becoming the cry of his generation: “iPhone!”

headline: Hey, That’s Me Up on That Screen
text: THE opening scenes of “The Social Network,” in which Mark Zuckerberg’s character embarks on a manic marathon coding session with his friends, rang eerily true to 23-year-old Jared Hecht. That’s because he lived through it  although not at Harvard and not in 2003.

headline: Fox Stations Go Dark as Dispute With Cablevision Escalates
text: There have been new developments since this blog post was last revised. Here is the latest update on the Cablevision-Fox dispute.

headline: A Skeptical Take on Gawker’s Sale Prospects
text: This fall has apparently been the season of pieces on Nick Denton, and The New Yorker has now contributed not one, but two pieces on Mr. Denton, the Gawker Media impresario.

headline: For a Child, God’s Back Story
text: NOT long ago, Eden, one of my 5-year-old twin daughters, bounded into my lap at bedtime and asked me if I would read her a book, “Bagels From Benny.” I had never seen this book before, nor had my wife. (I learned later it was a gift from her grandmother.) In the story, written by Aubrey Davis, Benny adores his grandfather’s bagels so much he wants to thank God for them. He takes a bag of bagels to the synagogue, places them in the ark, and asks God to taste his bounty.

headline: No Nuts? No Problem
text: When Janet Antico found out that her daughter, Arabella, had a severe peanut and tree nut allergy about 12 years ago, she did what many parents of children with food allergies do: she started obsessively reading labels.

headline: A Menu That Changes as the Garden Grows
text: DAYS, even weeks after visits to A Toute Heure, I’m still smiling. I’m enamored of its small, sweet dining room, its earnest staff and its carefully sourced food. A Toute Heure — which translates to “anytime” — is a good restaurant that spikes to very good, with optimism on the plate and in the dining room.

headline: A Tale of Two Remotes
text: Remote controllers for home electronics, be they weighty or featherweight, thick or thin, backlit by tiny bulbs or glow-in-the-dark buttons, have one bottom-line reason to live: functionality.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Oct. 15
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: Gifts for the Broken-Hearted
text: THE Obama volunteer coordinator assigned to find me a canvassing partner walked me toward a busload of elderly people. She must have noticed my dismay, because suddenly she veered left toward a smaller group of mostly male twentysomethings from Brooklyn. The day began looking up.

headline: Queens Wants Consideration in Creek Cleanup
text: Queens is fighting to make sure it gets its share of Superfund attention for Newtown Creek, whose effluent-laden waters lap the shores of both Queens and Brooklyn. Several Queens leaders assert that the federal Environmental Protection Agency has primarily focused on the Brooklyn side of Newtown Creek in studies and sampling of the waterway. “That has to change,” the officials wrote. “Time after time, Queens has simply been forgotten — literally omitted from the studies, the documentation and the E.P.A.’s attention.” Read about the Battle of Newtown Creek on the Green blog.

headline: Red Hook Community Farm Tries to Recover From Hail Storm
text: In less than 10 minutes on Monday evening, a storm swept through Brooklyn and unleashed nickel-sized hail, leaving the Red Hook Community Farm’s fields in tatters.

headline: Jimi Hendrix Before He Was Jimi Hendrix
text: Photographs of the rock ’n’ roll legend’s early days.

headline: Many Different Sounds In a Wide-Ranging Week
text: If you want to understand the ways that a modern orchestra must be all things to all people if it hopes to maintain a devoted audience, look at the New York Philharmonic’s schedule for the week just ended.

headline: Jimi Hendrix, Innocence and Experience
text: I suppose I always imagined that Jimi Hendrix sprang directly from the head of a particularly freaky hippie Zeus, but Steven Roby and Brad Schreiber set me straight. Their book, “Becoming Jimi Hendrix: From Southern Crossroads to Psychedelic London, the Untold Story of a Musical Genius” — reviewed in this Sunday’s issue by David Kirby — mostly ignores Hendrix’s days as a superstar to trace his improbable rhythm-and-blues rise, on the road with groups like Hank Ballard’s Midnighters, the Bonnevilles, Curtis Knight and the Squires, the Isley Brothers and the Tams. Hendrix got fired a lot. “He couldn’t play the music right,” a fellow guitarist explained.

headline: Jimi Hendrix, Innocence and Experience
text: I suppose I always imagined that Jimi Hendrix sprang directly from the head of a particularly freaky hippie Zeus, but Steven Roby and Brad Schreiber set me straight. Their book, “Becoming Jimi Hendrix: From Southern Crossroads to Psychedelic London, the Untold Story of a Musical Genius” — reviewed in this Sunday’s issue by David Kirby — mostly ignores Hendrix’s days as a superstar to trace his improbable rhythm-and-blues rise, on the road with groups like Hank Ballard’s Midnighters, the Bonnevilles, Curtis Knight and the Squires, the Isley Brothers and the Tams. Hendrix got fired a lot. “He couldn’t play the music right,” a fellow guitarist explained.

headline: The Lobbyist
text: What your Milan hotel says about you.

headline: Studying the Rich
text: The wealthy have become both a source of fascination and derision in America. But they have rarely been the subject of academic debate across various disciplines.

headline: Gary L. Malin
text: Mr. Malin, 42, is the president of Citi Habitats, a division of the Corcoran Group and one of the largest residential rental brokers in New York City. The company opened for business in 1994 and was acquired by NRT, Corcoran’s parent, 10 years later.

headline: Double Squeeze Helps Win a World Team Title
text: PHILADELPHIA  The Rosenblum Cup was won here on Wednesday evening by John Diamond, Brian Platnick, Fred Gitelman, Brad Moss, Eric Greco and Geoff Hampson. They defeated Nick Nickell, Ralph Katz, Bob Hamman, Zia Mahmood, Jeff Meckstroth and Eric Rodwell by 121 international match points to 78.

headline: Weekly Pick ‘Em: A New No. 1
text: There is a new No. 1 this week. And no, I’m not talking about our race for the Quad’s top prognosticator. Despite a brutal 1-4 performance last weekend, Paul Myerberg still holds a slim, one-game advantage over Pete Thamel. The real new No. 1 is Ohio State, which faces its first true road test tomorrow night at Wisconsin. Camp Randall is always an intimidating atmosphere, but the Buckeyes hope Terrelle Pryor and a tough defense will be enough to overcome the Badgers’ stout running game. Auburn is one of the last two undefeated teams in the Southeastern Conference (Louisiana State is the other), but the Tigers looked shaky in beating Kentucky last week. They face a stiff challenge from Arkansas on Saturday. Nebraska knows what it feels like to fall from the heights of the Big 12, so the Cornhuskers could have some empathy for struggling Texas if they choose to. They probably won’t though. Michigan is trying to bounce back from a loss to Michigan State, but is running right into an Iowa squad that would like to fight it out with Ohio State for Big Ten supremacy. Meanwhile, in the Pac-10, Oregon State is quietly looking to assert itself as one of the conference’s top teams. It beat Arizona last week and will try to knock off a Washington squad that has already defeated Southern California. There is plenty to watch this week and much to predict. As always, if you agree, disagree or merely find our picks laughable, feel free to let us know.

headline: Considering Existence From the Proper Angle
text: MONTCLAIR, N.J.  That Carolyn Carlson spent time dancing with the shape-shifting, technology-minded choreographer Alwin Nikolais is immediately apparent in her “Double Vision,” which had its American premiere on Thursday night in Montclair State University’s Peak Performances series. It is clear, too, that Ms. Carlson, an American, has spent the last four decades in Europe, and chiefly France (where she has had a substantial career).

headline: The Deal on Buying a Used Phone in 2010
text: In the car industry, the preferred term for “used” is “certified pre-owned.” It would appear the term is becoming popular in the phone industry as well. Here’s the lay of the land.

headline: Persistent Sunny Spells With an Occasional Cloud
text: The Avett Brothers have not, to my knowledge, made a children’s album. They should. Not because their music  reductively, a string-band hijacking of pop-punk, or vice versa  carries enough boisterous cheer for an iPod commercial. Not because the ruckus of their live show is harmless merriment, even when they’re asserting otherwise. Those things are true enough, but the bigger factor is the emotional landscape of their songs, an unwalled garden of wonderment and confusion. Judged by preadolescent standards, those songs are pretty deep.

headline: A Novelist’s Voice, Both Exotic and Midwestern
text: Early in Dinaw Mengestu’s new novel, “How to Read the Air,” the main character, a troubled young Ethiopian-American named Jonas Woldemariam, goes to a job interview, only to be asked, “Where’s that accent of yours from?” by a prospective boss baffled by his seemingly alien provenance. “Peoria,” Jonas replies, puzzling his interviewer even further.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Oct. 15
text: More Photographs

headline: College Cost Calculator
text: An interactive tool to estimate the future cost of higher education.

headline: Surgical Errors Continue Despite Protocols
text: Despite a requirement that hospitals abide by a standard set of procedures to prevent surgical mistakes like operating on the wrong patient or the wrong body part, such errors continue to occur far too often, researchers are reporting.

headline: Murdoch Defends News Corp.’s Political Donations
text: The News Corporation chairman Rupert Murdoch said on Friday morning that his company’s $1 million donations to the United States Chamber of Commerce and the Republican Governors Association “were unusual” but that “they were in the interests of our shareholders and the country.”

headline: Sunday Preview
text: @import url("http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/css/multimedia/bundles/SlidingGallery.css");

headline: Breathing Room
text: New York’s small squares offer serenity, light and space.

headline: Boozman Outraises Lincoln in Arkansas
text: Representative John Boozman outpaced Senator Blanche Lincoln in fund-raising last quarter for the the first time in his bid to unseat her, according to campaign finance reports filed Friday with the Federal Election Commission.

headline: New York’s Tiny Squares Offer Breathing Room
text: ABINGDON SQUARE PARK, a 0.222-acre triangle of greenery in the West Village, is not a place that requires much time for exploration. A lap of its curving byways, around a manicured garden island, takes just a minute or two. Indeed, most everyone there on a recent sunny Saturday was partaking in the square’s main day-to-day activity: sitting on benches.

headline: Bedbug Rider Looms in Real Estate Deals
text: Our colleague Vivian S. Toy reports that disclosure clauses involving bedbug infestation, a growing problem in New York City, are making their way into co-op and condo sales contracts.

headline: The Nest Is Empty No More
text: MONDAY through Friday, Lisa Buck, director of a nonprofit group called the Bridge Fund of Westchester, works to keep people who have lost a job from also losing the roof over their head. Especially in economic times like these, her desk in White Plains is stacked high with case files.

headline: What Will Apple Reveal Next Week?
text: When Apple makes an announcement about a coming press event it can sometimes feel like the National Hurricane Center has identified a new hurricane.

headline: A Housing Market Divided
text: IT seems that the story of what is happening in the real estate market has very nearly become a tale of two states: northern New Jersey and southern New Jersey.

headline: Rolling Back the Power Meter
text: Hicksville

headline: A Failed Bank Robber’s Lifetime of Run-Ins With the Law
text: His nickname, on his rap sheet, is “Johnny Shades.”

headline: For Sale: A Medal Worth More Than Gold
text: The news was jarring and slightly unbelievable. Tommie Smith, the former Olympic champion, was auctioning his gold medal.

headline: U.S. Will Enforce Marijuana Laws, State Vote Aside
text: LOS ANGELES  The Department of Justice says it intends to prosecute marijuana laws in California aggressively even if state voters approve an initiative on the Nov. 2 ballot to legalize the drug.

headline: Chic in Review | Tom Brady’s Bad Hair Day
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Why Are You Voting? Tell Us in Video
text: What issue is driving you to vote this year?

headline: Quick 'Preserved' Lemons
text: Mark Bittman demonstrates an easy method for getting the taste of Moroccan preserved lemons without weeks of waiting.

headline: Echoes of Olde England
text: FOR those who envision Queens as stamped by cookie cutter  block after block of almost indistinguishable homes, like mood wallpaper for the ’70s TV show “All in the Family”  Auburndale might come as a surprise.

headline: On the Street | At Ease
text: A number of women in Paris were noticeably intent on putting together a practical solution to modern dress.

headline: Art of Upheaval, and Cross-Pollination
text: Faith Ringgold, who turned 80 this year, is best known for the story quilts that she began making in the 1980s. But her paintings on canvas from the 1960s are also rather extraordinary. So it’s surprising that a comprehensive exhibition of these works is happening for the first time, with “American People, Black Light: Faith Ringgold’s Paintings of the 1960s,” at the Neuberger Museum of Art in Purchase.

headline: Roles Reconsidered
text: New Haven

headline: For 15 Years, Cuisine That Comes With a View
text: FIFTEEN years after it opened, Splash Restaurant and Bar, always a treat, has gotten even better. The restaurant is situated on the grounds of the Inn at Longshore, the town-owned, open-to-the-public country club in Westport, and has a deck that overlooks Long Island Sound.

headline: Yogurt Your Way
text: The hot pink and lime green signs at 16 Handles, a new frozen yogurt cafe in Jericho, N.Y., lend a cheerful energy to the space. They also serve a purpose: to give directions to customers as they move through the stations at this serve-yourself shop.

headline: Seafood Specialties With Global Perspective
text: THE space that is home to Long Fin Seafood Restaurant on Hempstead Turnpike in East Meadow has been one of those places where restaurants come and go at a rapid clip. It was Louis & Marxx in 2007, followed by Ruby’s Famous B. B. Q. Joint, which closed in January, and then Ristorante Besi, which closed in July.

headline: Moved by Music of the Tropics, A Composer Moves to Them
text: No one who has ever thrilled to the radiant shimmer and throb of a fine Balinese gamelan could have trouble understanding the composer Evan Ziporyn’s longtime preoccupation with finding ways to integrate elements of that magical tradition into his own music. “A House in Bali,” a two-act opera that opened at the Howard Gilman Opera House on Thursday night, is among Mr. Ziporyn’s most ambitious efforts at bridging Eastern and Western styles.

headline: Small Place, Big Menu
text: The narrow storefront of Lubins-N-Links, a quality fast-food carry-out spot, is easy to miss. Just inside the door, the waiting area in front of the counter is marginally larger than an old-fashioned phone booth. But the menu is gigantic.

headline: River Views and Boat Parking
text: THE COVE, the restaurant that took over the old Crystal Bay space on the Hudson River in Peekskill, has a lot going for it. The owners, Tom and Melissa Radocaj, have renovated with an eye toward the water, opening up the views with a wall of windows. There is a marina that makes parking your boat as easy as parking a car and a large deck for comfortable outdoor eating. And the prices — with most appetizers around $7 or $8 and entrees as low as $14 or $16 — are welcome in these tough economic times.

headline: Finding Wine Amid Marshes
text: Contrary to the idealized concept of a winery set among rolling hills of volcanic substrate, Saltwater Farm Vineyard is on flat land surrounded by a briny tidal inlet. And unlike the chateau-style production plants of Napa, Sonoma and the Loire Valley, Saltwater holds its tastings in a converted airport hangar, with a grass landing strip nearby.

headline: The Killer Is Hot, The Hero Hotheaded
text: At first perusal, a drama about a tormented-but-brilliant cop whose ethics code doesn’t require cleaning up as much as fumigation would seem like an old, familiar destination. You have made the journey here before, particularly if you got on board “The Shield” for its seven seasons. And yet, when the cop is played by Idris Elba (Stringer Bell of “The Wire”) and his mind-meld is happening with a murderer who looks like a gangster’s moll, quotes Bertrand Russell and sounds like Judi Dench, the stamp on your passport starts to look decidedly novel.

headline: Capturing Morocco in Its Sunny Pickle
text: PRESERVED lemons, a staple of Moroccan cooking, are pickles, and terrific ones. Made using the entire lemon  skin and all  they’re cured in their own juices, along with salt and sugar. Like most relishes, the recipe varies from cook to cook, so you might find garlic, shallot, bay leaves, coriander seeds, chili flakes or cinnamon sticks in a given batch.

headline: Quick ‘Preserved’ Lemons
text: Time: At least 3 hours, largely unattended

headline: A Second Disease Vanquished
text: Quietly, almost under the radar, a United Nations organization announced this week that another disease — the first after smallpox — had been eliminated from the face of the earth.

headline: Unlocking the True Flavor of Mackerel
text: MACKEREL escabèche is one of those dishes I have always preferred to admire from afar. It’s traditionally prepared by pickling the fillets in vinegar, but I’ve never quite cottoned to its biting flavor. To me, it overwhelms the delicacy of a good fresh piece of fish.

headline: Challenging the Wii’s Supremacy
text: Slicing and thrusting through the air to control a virtual sword. Flicking your wrist to roll a digital bowling ball. Striking an imaginary golf ball down a tree-lined fairway.

headline: Botox for Migraines Is Approved
text: The Food and Drug Administration has approved the use of Allergan’s Botox to treat chronic migraines, a little more than a month after the company agreed to pay $600 million to settle criminal and civil allegations that it had illegally marketed the drug for unapproved uses — including headache and pain — for years. Related Article

headline: Perky Becomes Poignant
text: If you happened to see “Circle Mirror Transformation” in New York last fall and then heard about the cast that would be doing it at the George Street Playhouse this month, Sandy Duncan might be the last person you would think of to play the teacher. As hard as she tries, this is one actress who just can’t shake her bright-eyed, giggly-girl persona. But she turns out to be quite good.

headline: A Fast Route to Preserved Lemon
text: Preserved lemons take minutes to make, but they take weeks to cure. There is, however, a compromise, a way to enjoy something pretty close to the authentic preserved lemon experience in much less time. These quick “preserved” lemons are wonderful with fish and amazing with stews.

headline: Bowling, Golfing and Shooting With the Sony Move
text: Move, Sony’s recently released add-on for its PlayStation 3 video game system, is the company’s expensive attempt to compete against Nintendo’s wildly successful Wii. Like the Wii, Move allows consumers to simply swing a small electronic wand in the air to control game action on a television screen, like a character swinging a sword, throwing a flying disc or hitting a tennis ball. Such technology has made the Wii the most popular of the current game systems because it allows players to avoid having to master the use of more than a dozen buttons, sticks and triggers on a modern console game controller. Meanwhile, the PS3 has languished in third place behind both the Wii and Microsoft’s Xbox 360.

headline: Modern Décor With African Touches
text: Claude Grunitzky lives in a luxury high-rise at 15 Broad Street, Philippe Starck’s conversion of a structure that included the fabled House of Morgan.

headline: Domestic Luxury, Artfully Accented
text: CLAUDE GRUNITZKY  jet-setter, media entrepreneur and all-around cool person  did not always live in the shadow of a 1,900-piece Louis XV crystal chandelier that once hung in the House of Morgan. Or just an elevator ride from a 5,000-square-foot roof garden complete with fountain and working fireplace. Or steps from both the New York Stock Exchange and Federal Hall, the site on which George Washington took the oath of office as the first president of the United States.

headline: Frank and Personal Don’t Rule Out Commercial
text: Soul jazz has been a nearly lifelong fascination for the saxophonist David Sanborn: a cause and a catalyst, if not always the center of his craft. Mr. Sanborn is best known for his long reign in the changeable realm of instrumental pop, and his related output as a session man. But with his two latest albums, both on Decca, he has fixated on the legacy of his first and most formative saxophone hero, Hank Crawford, who died last year.

headline: CardStar’s Vision Problem
text: Progress is usually a good thing, but it’s spoiling a very nice free iPhone app.

headline: Seven Winning Visions of a Suburbia Reborn
text: IT’S just another day at a Long Island train station, where a trickle of off-peak commuters board the largely empty cars while the rest of the train is loaded with freight — mail, packages from small businesses, recyclables, you name it.

headline: Lost in Their Own Worlds, Yet Performing Together
text: When a dancer is hurt and pulls out of a show before the premiere, there’s no way of knowing how that presence might have shaped the final product. Such an unfortunate incident occurred with “I Am Saying Goodnight,” presented by the group Amanda Loulaki and Short Mean Lady on Wednesday evening at Performance Space 122. Rebecca Brooks, a long-limbed dancer both articulate and soulful, was forced to withdraw after an injury, yet it’s doubtful that her absence was the only reason “I Am Saying Goodnight” left the audience in the dark.

headline: Rescuing Young Women From Traffickers’ Hands
text: CONSTANTA, Romania

headline: Grappling With Grief, And Then With Bodies
text: I suppose you could call Ralph Lemon an interdisciplinary artist. But somehow the term seems flat and cumbersome in describing his output, which at this point feels more like a continuing set of questions and proposals than a series of distinct pieces. He is building a body of work in the truest sense, reaching for a poetics at once complex and simple and constructing a container to receive, if only for scattered moments, things that can’t be kept.

headline: Americans Need a Pick-Me-Up
text: Americans’ levels of well-being have been falling for the last four months, according to the Gallup-Healthways Well-Being Index.

headline: Help for an Autistic Son Means Trouble for a Marriage
text: A young couple, struggling to secure the most beneficial education for their autistic 4-year-old son, disagrees on what’s best for him. The separate paths the spouses explore eventually threaten their marriage in “Love and Communication,” a new drama by James J. Christy.

headline: Growing Older With Less Empathy
text: There wasn’t much provision for growing up in emo, the sensitive-guy punk-pop that emerged in the mid-1990s. That’s one reason that bands like Jimmy Eat World  a pioneer of emo’s earnest, churning confessionals and self-help manifestoes  hate the term. It doesn’t promise any second act once adolescent angst and self-absorption start to wear thin.

headline: Dylan, Channeled by Billie Holiday
text: For the jazz singer Paula West, the American songbook, from Irving Berlin through Bob Dylan, is a banquet from which she selects favorite dishes and stirs in her own secret ingredients to make them her own. Those added flavors include a sly sense of mischief that can quicken the pulse of a Berlin song like “The Best Things Happen While You’re Dancing” or turn Cole Porter’s “I’m in Love Again,” into a delirious explosion of joy.

headline: New Theater for Luna Stage
text: Luna Stage Theater Company moved into its new building in West Orange in July, but relocating has not been as easy as unpacking boxes of props and costumes.

headline: Real Estate Q & A
text: From Rent-Controlled to Market-Rate

headline: Who’s the Best Free-Agent Signing in Yankees History?
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. – The following question was posed by Marc Carig of The Star-Ledger of Newark in the beat reporters’ interview session with Joe Girardi: Is C.C. Sabathia the best free-agent signing in the history of the Yankees? Girardi acknowledged the impact Sabathia has made in his two seasons – 40 regular-season victories, four more in the postseason, a World Series title – but, ever the diplomat, passed the question along to General Manager Brian Cashman, who was sitting on a couch nearby.

headline: Sacrifice and Devotion in the Indian Tradition
text: Every autumn, many Indian women observe Karwa Chauth, a daylong fast on behalf of their husbands’ prosperity.

headline: A.L.C.S. Game 1 Final: Yankees 6, Rangers 5
text: The Yankees scored one run in the seventh inning and five runs in the eighth to overcome a 5-0 deficit and beat the Texas Rangers, 6-5, on Friday night in Game 1 of the American League Championship Series in Arlington, Tex.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Oct. 15
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a cemetery in the East Village where explosives were found, photos from the campaign trail and a self-anointed saint.

headline: A Night for Pagans Brings Out the Sexy
text: The Celts saw the end of October as a moment when spirits could slip from their world into ours. To ward off unwelcome visitors, wary mortals built bonfires, slaughtered livestock and donned scary masks. Those rituals, says the historian Nicholas Rogers, gave rise to the holiday now known as Halloween.

headline: No Rest for a Long-Distance Runner
text: Her days of running marathons are over: her knees made that decision for her. But Mary Wittenberg, who entered and won her first race after a happy hour dare while attending college in Buffalo, still plans her life around the sport. As president of the New York Road Runners Club, which she has led since 2005, she is directing the New York City Marathon, to be held Nov. 7. Ms. Wittenberg, 48, lives on the Upper East Side with her husband, Derek, a banker, and their two sons, Alex, 9, and Cary, 8. ROBIN FINN

headline: For Some Immigrants, Voting Is a Criminal Act
text: The way Joseph E. Joseph tells it, he was just doing his civic duty.

headline: Top-Notch Drinks, and the Latest Gossip
text: THE prototypical destination lobby in a city now cluttered with them, Forty Four at the Royalton Hotel — called 44 when it opened in 1988, not long after New Yorkers first flocked to see Gordon Gekko wax fondly of greed — has emerged from yet another renovation that brings it closer to its nightclub roots.

headline: In Truman Homes, Reflections of a City
text: INDEPENDENCE, Mo.  Harry S. Truman once proclaimed that returning to this small city where he began his unlikely political ascent allowed him to forget he was president of the United States. That would be impossible today  his name and bespectacled image have become so omnipresent here that were he to make his ritual morning stroll through downtown he might conclude that his status is less favorite son than only son.

headline: When Pangs of Love Are All Too Real
text: Love hurts — sometimes literally — and it’s no mistake that, as the idiom goes, we fall into it (and sometimes land on our faces). The following poems about pratfalls leading to, or resulting from, a romantic encounter were found last week in the Missed Connections section of newyork.craigslist.org. They are printed verbatim, with only line and stanza breaks added; the titles are the subject headings. ALAN FEUER

headline: How Official Is Official?
text: Not every agency is on the same wavelength regarding the avenue north of Central Park that is named for the former Harlem representative.

headline: Russia Plans Nuclear Plant in Venezuela
text: MOSCOW  President Dmitri A. Medvedev said Friday that Russia planned to build the first nuclear power plant in Venezuela, and that the United States should not object because Russia’s intentions were “absolutely pure and open.”

headline: Bloggingheads: Friends Who Torture
text: Daniel Drezner, left, of Foreign Policy and Eli Lake of The Washington Times debate U.S. allies who torture suspected terrorists.

headline: Atheists Debate How Pushy to Be
text: LOS ANGELES — Energized by a recent Pew Research Center poll showing that atheists are more educated about religion than religious people, 370 atheists, humanists and other skeptics packed a ballroom at the Millennium Biltmore Hotel last weekend to debate the future of their movement.

headline: Suspended Executive Resigns at Tribune
text: Lee Abrams, the Tribune Company executive who was suspended this week for sending out a companywide memo with sexual content, resigned on Friday, the company said in a statement.

headline: Capturing the Facebook Obsession
text: Ben Mezrich is the kind of nonfiction writer we used to call a hype artist. He takes relatively mundane subjects  counting cards in Vegas, derivatives trading, the New York Mercantile Exchange  and turns them into high-octane page-turners, replete with sex, skullduggery and plot twists worthy of James Patterson.

headline: Biotech Company Gains on Prostate Cancer Trial
text: Molecular Insight Pharmaceuticals, a biotechnology development company, reported positive results from a clinical trial of a treatment that detects prostate cancer, setting off a 65 percent gain in its share price. The company released the results of the early stage trial of the treatment, called Trofex, after the market closed Thursday. On Friday, shares of Molecular Insight, which is based in Cambridge, Mass., rose 50 cents, to $1.27. The news came a week after Nasdaq told Molecular Insight that it was in danger of being delisted because the company’s stock had remained below $1 a share for 30 consecutive business days. Also on Friday, the company said it had reached an agreement to extend a waiver with bondholders to allow debt restructuring negotiations to continue until next Friday.

headline: Rum Battle in Caribbean Leaves Tax Hangover
text: Rum and politics have made a fiery mix since America’s earliest days, when a young politician named George Washington won election to the House of Burgesses in colonial Virginia with the help of spiked punch at the polls.

headline: Long Battle by Foes of Campaign Finance Rules Shifts Landscape
text: WASHINGTON  It was Thanksgiving break of 1998 at Capital University Law School in Ohio, and Senator Mitch McConnell was on the phone for Prof. Bradley Smith.

headline: In Mumbai, Adviser to Obama Extols India’s Economic Model
text: MUMBAI  First, there was the pro-free-market development model known as the Washington consensus. Then came the Beijing consensus, which is used to describe China’s state-led, export-powered growth.

headline: Foreclosure Mess Draws in the Lawyers Who Handled Them
text: With the rash of foreclosures across the country in recent years, many lawyers have specialized in the lucrative business of handling cases for banks and loan servicers. And now that flaws are being acknowledged by big lenders in the processing of foreclosures, some of these lawyers are finding themselves in the cross hairs of investigators  and scorned by their former clients.

headline: Setting a New Standard for a Long-Beleaguered Franchise
text: Philadelphia

headline: Johnson Seems Unbeatable as Chase Nears the Midpoint
text: CONCORD, N.C.  Concession speeches have yet to be delivered in the 2010 Chase for the Sprint Cup, but an air of inevitability is beginning to hover over the Nascar garage. It is Jimmie Johnson’s title to win. Again.

headline: Larry Siegfried, Guard Who Won 5 Titles With Celtics, Is Dead at 71
text: Larry Siegfried, a stalwart guard on the great Boston Celtic teams of the 1960s, died Thursday in Cleveland. He was 71 and lived in Perrysville, Ohio.

headline: Cable Dispute Could Leave Millions of Fans in the Dark
text: The much-anticipated matchup between the Phillies’ Roy Halladay and the Giants’ Tim Lincecum in Game 1 of the National League Championship Series Saturday at 7:57 p.m. Eastern may not be seen by Cablevision’s 3 million customers in the New York metropolitan area.

headline: Botox Shots Approved for Migraine
text: The Food and Drug Administration on Friday approved Botox, the anti-wrinkle shot from Allergan, as a treatment to prevent chronic migraines, a little more than a month after the company agreed to pay $600 million to settle allegations that it had illegally marketed the drug for unapproved uses like headaches for years.

headline: Another Paladino’s Views
text: BUFFALO — Cathy Paladino says she barely recognizes the Carl Paladino she hears about these days: fiery, volatile and seemingly unable to speak without offending.

headline: While Azubuike Heals, D’Antoni Fiddles
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — After lunging, hopping and backpedaling, Kelenna Azubuike stopped, grabbed a ball, dribbled a few times and gazed pensively across the room.

headline: At Hearing on Fort Hood Attack, Few Clues
text: FORT HOOD, Tex.  Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan, with a blanket draped over his shoulders and a watch cap pulled low over his dark eyes, listened impassively in recent days as several survivors of his murderous rampage a year ago rose and pointed to him as the gunman who had shot them.

headline: 5 Officers Face Charges in Fudging of Statistics
text: A New York City police commander and four officers are facing internal charges based on a fellow officer’s allegations that crime complaints in the 81st Precinct in Brooklyn were manipulated, the Police Department said.

headline: Exhibit on Hitler and the Germans
text: An exhibit offers a view of a Germany that was ripe for Nazi populism.

headline: Hitler Exhibition Explores a Wider Circle of Guilt
text: BERLIN — As artifacts go, they are mere trinkets — an old purse, playing cards, a lantern. Even the display that caused the crowds to stop and stare is a simple embroidered tapestry, stitched by village women.

headline: Obama and Biden Stump for Delaware Candidate
text: WILMINGTON, Del. — Chris Coons, the Democratic Senate candidate in Delaware, is far ahead in state polls, yet both President Obama and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. were here on Friday to give him a hand and to keep attention on his rival, Christine O’Donnell, as a symbol of Tea Party Republican candidates across the country.

headline: Universities in Britain Brace for Cuts in Subsidies
text: LONDON — For months, Britain’s universities have warned in apocalyptic terms about the devastating cuts they face as part of the government’s grand plan to reduce public-sector costs. Now, with the government poised next week to announce its spending plans, their worst fears seem about to come true.

headline: The World Bank’s Palm Oil Mistake
text: Lagos, Nigeria

headline: Period Music, Played With Freewheeling Touches
text: The English Concert’s performance at Weill Recital Hall on Wednesday evening had plenty to recommend it, not least Rachel Podger’s magnificent violin playing in a pair of Vivaldi Concertos, and intensely dramatic accounts of Monteverdi and Handel vocal works with the mezzo-soprano Alice Coote.

headline: After an Enlightenment, a Return to Texas
text: ARLINGTON, Tex.

headline: Don’t Mix Chili and Politics, South Dakota Official Says
text: In addition to arguing over health care and gun rights, Congressional candidates in South Dakota are engaged in a food fight. Democrats who served chili at campaign rallies on reservations in South Dakota this week got a chilly reception from state Republicans and the state attorney general, who warned party leaders not to offer food for votes.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,321 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: U.S. Shuts Banks in Midwest
text: Lenders in Missouri and Kansas were shut by regulators on Friday, bringing the total bank failures in the nation this year to 132.

headline: Mets Interview Dodgers Assistant for G.M. Job
text: PHILADELPHIA — The Mets interviewed Logan White, the Dodgers’ assistant general manager, for their vacant G.M. position Friday, but Sandy Alderson remained the heavy favorite to get the job.

headline: Attacks Fly at New York Debate for Senate Candidates
text: Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand of New York and the Republican seeking to unseat her, Joseph J. DioGuardi, questioned each other’s integrity in a debate on Friday filled with sharp exchanges.

headline: Postseason Duels of Pitching Aces Can Go Awry
text: PHILADELPHIA  Dave Righetti, the San Francisco Giants’ pitching coach, knows what baseball fans are expecting in Game 1 of the National League Championship Series on Saturday. Tim Lincecum and Roy Halladay are scheduled to face each other in the most highly anticipated matchup of aces in years, and if their first appearances in the postseason last week are an indication, it could be something to behold.

headline: In Iran, Future of University Is in Flux
text: TEHRAN  The future of Iran’s largest academic institution is in question after the supreme leader stepped into a tug of war this week between President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad and his rival Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, who was instrumental in vastly expanding and improving the university.

headline: After Summer Together, Helping Set Columbia Apart
text: Alex Gross, a linebacker for Columbia, shared an apartment over the summer with Sean Brackett, a quarterback. Brackett had just finished his freshman year and, as Gross explains it, freshmen typically go home for the summer. But Brackett is no typical player.

headline: Sudan’s Threatened Peace Deal
text: Time is running out on efforts to avert another civil war in Sudan. A United States-backed deal in 2005 ended two decades of fighting between the Arab Muslim north and the largely Christian south that killed two million people. That deal is now in danger of unraveling if two referendums set for early January do not go forward.

headline: For New York Comptroller, Attorney General
text: Harry Wilson

headline: Rangers Add Left-Handers to Combat Yankees
text: ARLINGTON, Tex.  The Yankees have one left-hander, Boone Logan, in their seven-man bullpen. The Rangers, after making two revealing changes to their 25-man roster Friday, now have four in theirs. They added Michael Kirkman and Clay Rapada to join Derek Holland and Darren Oliver, giving Manager Ron Washington additional options to combat Robinson Cano, Brett Gardner and Curtis Granderson.

headline: Accused G.I.’s Were Isolated From Officers
text: WASHINGTON  Soldiers in an American Army platoon accused of murdering Afghan civilians for sport say they took orders from a ringleader who collected body parts as war trophies, were threatened with death if they spoke up and smoked hashish on their base almost daily.

headline: Obama, Hitting the Trail, Still Looks for Ways to Make His Message Stick
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama is preparing to wage the final weeks of the midterm campaign with a theme he has been hammering for months  a plea that voters not embrace the Republican policies of the past. But the specifics of his closing argument remain in flux as the White House searches for a way to frame the message that connects with voters.

headline: Saturday: Expressions of Affection
text: Yet one smile more, departing, distant sun!One mellow smile through the soft vapory air,Ere, o’er the frozen earth, the loud winds run,Or snows are sifted o’er the meadows bare.

headline: The Future of the Global Fund
text: Even in the midst of an economic downturn, the United States and other donors have increased their pledges to a global fund that is fighting three of the world’s most devastating infectious diseases. Unfortunately, the money will not be nearly enough to meet the rising health needs in developing countries.

headline: Tough Lessons in a Free Press
text: Mayor Philip Amicone of Yonkers has just received what looks like a very expensive lesson in basic Constitutional rights.

headline: France: Pension-Reform Protests Continue Amid Fuel Shortage Fears
text: Protests and industrial action against planned pension reforms in France continued for a fourth day Friday as fears about fuel supplies intensified. Production at the country’s 12 crude refineries remained stalled by striking workers, according to union officials. There were also concerns about a possible shortage of jet fuel at the main Paris airports after news reports had quoted Trapil, a supply company, as saying that pipelines carrying jet fuel to the airports had stopped operating because of industrial action. Trapil did not respond to calls for comment.MATTHEW SALTMARSH

headline: Uganda: Drought and Famine Forecast by Parliament for 2011
text: More than half of Uganda’s 31 million people face severe food shortages by February 2011 because of an expected drought, Parliament said in a statement on Friday, citing the minister for disaster preparedness, Tarsis Kabwegyere. The current rains, the statement said, will be followed by an “unusual period of drought and severe water shortage” that will spread famine and kill livestock in many parts of East Africa.

headline: Zimbabwe: Robert Mugabe Seeks Elections and Vote on Constitution
text: President Robert Mugabe wants a referendum on a new constitution early next year and new elections by mid-2011, the state-owned Herald newspaper reported Friday. His rival in a power-sharing deal, Prime Minister Morgan Tsvangirai, has said that elections should be held only if there are safeguards to prevent the state-sponsored attacks on his supporters that led to widespread torture, beatings and murder in 2008 elections. Civic groups say that political intimidation of Mr. Tsvangirai’s party members has marred the process of creating a new constitution.

headline: Richard Morefield, Held Hostage in Iran, Dies at 81
text: As throngs of Islamist militants surged into the American Embassy in Tehran on Nov. 4, 1979, Richard Morefield, the United States consul general to Iran, told colleagues around him to flee the compound.

headline: Are the Democrats the True Extremists?
text: It’s the duty (and, O.K., the bliss) of an opinion journalist to demonstrate that the Beltway’s conventional wisdom has far fewer garments than it supposes. But on one count — that the progressives are at the moment far more marginalized by their Democratic president and Congressional leadership than are the Tea Party enthusiasts by the Republican powers-that-be — it’s been hard to show contention. After all, the president who insisted that the day of his inauguration would be “the moment when we ended a war,” who confidently said that “we are going to close Guantanamo”, who promised to repeal the military’s don’t-ask-don’t-tell policy has shown, through deed if not word, that he’s not exactly a hostage to the far left. Nor has the Democratic leadership: Senate majority leader Harry Reid is an apostate on a woman’s alleged right to choose — “abortions should be legal only when the pregnancy resulted from incest or rape, or when the life of the woman is endangered” — and Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi isn’t exactly beloved.

headline: The Mississippi Pardons
text: Gov. Haley Barbour of Mississippi has to decide whether to show mercy to two sisters, Jamie and Gladys Scott, who are each serving double consecutive life sentences in state prison for a robbery in which no one was injured and only $11 was taken.

headline: Bronx Neighbors Protest Planned Residences for Homeless
text: Even with the rumble of elevated trains overhead, Doreen Smith, a Jamaican immigrant, has worked hard for 17 years to maintain the cachet of her Beautopia hair salon in the modest neighborhood of Wakefield, about as far north as you can go in the Bronx without stepping into Westchester.

In this case, the Democrats’ appeal is to black voters, the most unwavering portion of President Obama’s base, and the message is simple: The president is under attack, and black voters must mobilize to protect him.

headline: When the Tormentors Live Just Outside Your Front Door
text: William Cruz, a shy homebody who moved to the Bronx in 2006, always kept his private life just that  private, for reasons of self-protection. “I hear the news, about gay people getting stabbed, beat up,” Mr. Cruz, now 47, said. “You never know. It could be things like that that happen to you, you could bump into the wrong person.”

headline: Rangers Fall, but Real Loss Comes in 2 Injuries
text: There were silver linings to the Rangers’ wild 4-3 overtime loss in their home opener at Madison Square Garden on Friday night. But the clouds they lined were huge, dark and ominous.

headline: General Johnson, Singer and Writer of Hit R&B Songs, Dies at 69
text: General Johnson, who provided the distinctive lead vocal for the Chairmen of the Board’s 1970 Top 10 hit, “Give Me Just a Little More Time,” and went on to become a successful rhythm-and-blues songwriter, died Wednesday in suburban Atlanta. He was 69 and lived in East Point, Ga.

headline: Simon MacCorkindale, Dashing British Actor, Dies at 58
text: Simon MacCorkindale, the dashing British actor who turned heads in the star-studded 1978 film “Death on the Nile” and went on to play villains and charming Englishmen on numerous television shows in Britain and the United States, died on Thursday in London. He was 58.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Israelis Hold Son Sought in S.I. Deaths

headline: A Nobel Laureate Returns Home to Bronx Science
text: David Politzer donned a pair of safety goggles Friday morning and smiled as two soccer-playing robots whizzed around the floor of a classroom at the Bronx High School of Science.

headline: Eugene O'Neill Dies of Pneumonia; Playwright, 65, Won Nobel Prize
text: Boston, Nov. 27--Eugene O'Neill, noted American playwright whose prolific talents had brought to him both Nobel and Pulitzer Prizes, died today of bronchial pneumonia. His age was 65.

headline: China Tests Atomic Bomb, Asks Summit Talk On Ban; Johnson Minimizes Peril
text: Hong Kong, Oct. 16--Communist China announced tonight that it had exploded its first atom bomb. Peking pledged that it would never be the first to use nuclear weapons in the future.

headline: Yankees Rewrite Script With Outburst in Eighth
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — The Rangers still have never won a home playoff game, a truth their fans may find difficult to comprehend had they not suffered Friday night through one of the most torturous innings in the franchise’s 39 seasons in Texas. A crowd that pulsed with excitement fell silent in the eighth, when the Yankees crushed the Rangers’ visions of a superlative start to their inaugural American League Championship Series by pummeling five Texas pitchers in a five-run rally.

headline: Bill Clinton Campaigns for Jerry Brown
text: For those wounds that time will not heal, there is always the salve of the campaign trail.

headline: Republican Governors Association Raises $31 Million With Notable Contributions
text: A number of eye-popping contributions showed up in Friday’s quarterly filing by the Republican Governors Association with the Internal Revenue Service, part of a $31 million haul over a three-month period.

headline: Senate Dollar Sweepstakes
text: As Senate candidates revved up general election campaigns and raised money for the stretch run, there were some winners and losers apparent in the quarterly fund-raising reports due Friday.

headline: Taking Times Square By the Horns
text: In Times Square Friday afternoon, 10 bulls bucked beneath their riders as part of the Professional Bull Riders’ Road to Las Vegas competition. Crowds in cowboy hats gathered at the temporary arena that sprang up on Broadway between 42nd and 43rd streets. Some craned their necks to watch from the street, while others looked down from the skyscrapers around.

headline: Jets Prepare for the Air in Denver
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. – The Jets stretched and warmed up on Friday morning to Joe Walsh’s “Rocky Mountain Way” blaring over the loudspeakers at the team’s practice facility. The altitude in Denver is known to play strange tricks with the ball, from Steve O’Neal’s 98-yard punt in 1969 to the home runs that fly out of Coors Field. But it isn’t the ball soaring through the mile-high air that has the Jets being cautious; it is merely getting a chance to breathe.

headline: Classic Ad: Buick Riviera
text: Sure, this ad for the 1964 Buick Riviera may claim that only a man can understand such a “great and rare machine.” But if there’s anything we’ve learned from the fellas at Sterling Cooper Draper Pryce, it’s that casual sexism was par for the Madison Avenue course in the ’60s.

headline: Consensus Points to 50-Seat G.O.P. Gain in House, but May Understate Uncertainty
text: FiveThirtyEight’s projection for the U.S. House shows little change from last week. Republicans are given a 73 percent chance of taking over the House, up incrementally from 72 percent last week. During an average simulation run, Republicans finished with 227 seats, up from 226 last week; this would suggest a net gain of 48 seats from the 179 they hold currently.

text: Brian Jones is a studio analyst for CBS College Sports Network. He can also be seen every Tuesday night during the season as part of “The Tony Barnhart Show” at 9 p.m. and “Inside College Football” at 10.

headline: Presidential Contenders to Get a Head Start on White House Transition
text: President Obama signed a bill Friday that he hopes won’t be really necessary until at least 2016.

headline: The Nipponization of Ben Bernanke
text: I’m with Brad DeLong on Bernanke’s speech: given Bernanke’s diagnosis of our problems, what he said about the policy response was astonishingly diffident:

headline: The Boehnerization of Barack Obama
text: Why has stimulus become a dirty word? Many reasons, I guess: an inadequate plan combined with a wildly overoptimistic forecast was more or less guaranteed to create the impression of a failed program. But it’s also true that the president himself has had a deeply self-destructive tendency to echo his opponents’ arguments. My original invisible bond vigilantes post was inspired, in part, by Obama’s decision to go on Fox News and declare that we needed to cut the deficit to avoid a double dip. Then, in July, he repeated almost verbatim John Boehner’s justly mocked claim that since the private sector is tightening its belt, the government should do the same.

text: Here:

headline: Benoît Mandelbrot, Novel Mathematician, Dies at 85
text: Benoît B. Mandelbrot, a maverick mathematician who developed the field of fractal geometry and applied it to physics, biology, finance and many other fields, died on Thursday in Cambridge, Mass. He was 85.

headline: Saturday Word: Up to Boston
text: President Obama travels to Boston on Saturday afternoon to lend his support to Gov. Deval Patrick of Massachusetts, who is facing a tough battle for re-election. Then, he’ll speak at a Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee event at a private home west of the city.

headline: Marzieh, Iranian Singer and Voice of Dissent, Dies at 86
text: Marzieh, the great diva of Persian traditional song, who was silenced after the Islamic Revolution in 1979 but who re-emerged years later outside Iran as a singer and a highly public supporter of the resistance, died on Wednesday in Paris. She was 86 and had defected to France in 1994.

headline: In Mangold, Jets Have Connoisseur at Center
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The large man entered the small California winery in early October 2008. Nick Mangold wore blond hair past his shoulders and a scraggly beard. He stood 6 feet 4 inches, weighed more 300 pounds and looked, as one teammate said recently, as if he ran a biker gang.

headline: Long Live the Mascot, Uga VIII
text: ATHENS, Ga.  Sonny Seiler stepped into the Uga Suite, Room 301, and turned past the framed jersey fit for a particular barrel-chested white English bulldog. The walls were filled with photographs of the various University of Georgiamascots that Seiler has owned and anointed since 1956, the seven dogs that Seiler deemed fit to be an Uga.

headline: Toronto’s M.L.S. Team Is Testing Patience of Its Fans
text: TORONTO  In a sports bar one recent night, the bartender was giving away collectible beer glasses bearing the Toronto F.C. logo and motto, “All for One.” For some, those words are hard to swallow right now.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Numbers Are a Weak Spot in the B.C.S. Standings
text: The Bowl Championship Series will release its first standings of the year on Sunday. One-third of the formula that will eventually determine the matchup for college football’s national championship game comes from a compendium of six computerized ranking systems that deal in mathematical minutiae. The nerds did not just crash the jocks’ party. They were invited.

headline: 21 Are Killed in Explosion at China Mine
text: SHANGHAI  A coal mine explosion in central China early Saturday killed 26 workers and trapped 11 others underground, China’s state-run news media said.

headline: Kick Returns Facing Weakened Resistance
text: Stefan Logan was about 30 yards into his kickoff return last Sunday when he knew he would score a touchdown. A member of the St. Louis Rams’ coverage team had briefly grabbed Logan and turned him, but when Logan brought his head up, he still saw the Rams’ end zone in front of him.

headline: Lawmakers Sow Disillusion in Indonesia
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Indonesia’s House of Representatives barely passed any laws in the first year of its current term, placing critical pending legislation on matters related to national security, welfare and natural resources on the back burner. Still, lawmakers recently managed to squeeze in trips to South Africa, Japan and South Korea for what they said were fact-finding missions to research a bill on this country’s Boy Scouts.

headline: Versatile and Creative, Giants Limber Up for Race to the Quarterback
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  When Justin Tuck was named a Giants captain last month, a fellow defensive lineman placed a small figurine bearing his likeness in the unit’s meeting room. It started as a cute way to poke fun at Tuck. Then the team lost back-to-back games in September, and something needed to change.

headline: Microsoft Moves to Help Nonprofits Avoid Piracy-Linked Crackdowns
text: MOSCOW — Microsoft is vastly expanding its efforts to prevent governments from using software piracy inquiries as a pretext to suppress dissent. It plans to provide free software licenses to more than 500,000 advocacy groups, independent media outlets and other nonprofit organizations in 12 countries with tightly controlled governments, including Russia and China.

headline: For the Nets, a Journey Toward Becoming a Global Brand Has Just Begun
text: BEIJING — Brett Yormark is talking about the incredible global marketing potential of the New Jersey Nets, a concept — New Jersey, the Nets and global marketing potential — that might seem unlikely until you hear his pitch, and remember that two years from now, they will probably be the New York Nets.

headline: Using Technology to Find Flaws
text: Computerized analysis helps locate delivery problems that might be missed by coaches and trainers. Eight high-speed cameras surround the mound and track the motion.

headline: Diagramless and Numberplay Challenge
text: Discussion of the diagramless crossword with a bonus challenge for the Numberplay set

headline: Mystery of Lost M.P.H.: Pitchers Weren’t Hurt, Their Fastballs Were
text: Major League Baseball officials and fans are thrilled when they see radar gun readings flashing triple digits on stadium scoreboards. But for every one who threw a pitch 100 miles per hour or faster this season, other healthy, hard-throwing pitchers caused scouts to bang their radar guns and check their batteries.

headline: The Giants’ Panda, Loved, but Benched
text: A look around AT&T Park says all one needs to know about Giants fans and their feelings toward Pablo Sandoval. There, adorning the heads of the San Francisco faithful, sits a mix of orange fright wigs, faux Brian Wilson beards and long, would-be Tim Lincecum tresses.

headline: ‘Rashomon’ in East Jerusalem
text: Updated | Sunday | 2:02 p.m. According to an online preview, an episode of “60 Minutes” that will air on Sunday includes a report on the escalating conflict in the East Jerusalem neighborhood of Silwan, where 70 Jewish families have settled among about 55,000 Palestinians.

headline: For Some Embattled Democrats, a Campaign Against Their Leader
text: PERRY, Ga.  As if embattled Congressional Democrats did not have enough on their hands, some are opening up a new front in their fight to save their seats  against Nancy Pelosi, the speaker of the House and a leader of their own party.

headline: A Kind of Hunt That Even Deer Can Get Behind
text: LAND BETWEEN THE LAKES, Ky.  The deer hunters returned to the tournament checkpoint tired and hungry, their camouflage clothing soaked with sweat. All were empty-handed  no big bucks for bragging rights, no fat does for venison. But that was the plan all along.

headline: U.S. Had Warnings on Plotter of Mumbai Attack
text: American officials received warnings from two wives of David Headley, who scouted for the Mumbai attacks that killed 163 people, that he was planning such an attack.

headline: Questionable Calls to the Bullpen for Texas
text: One of Rangers Manager Ron Washington’s deviations from mathematically optimal baseball strategy — putting batters that are nowhere near his best atop his lineup — wound up working out Friday night, as both the leadoff man Elvis Andrus and the second-place hitter Michael Young reached base twice in Game 1 of their American League Championship Series against the Yankees. Another questionable strategic move, however — his choice of relief pitchers — did not go so well.

headline: When Drugs Cause Problems They Are Supposed to Prevent
text: In the past month, the Food and Drug Administration has concluded that in some cases two types of drugs that were supposed to be preventing serious medical problems were, in fact, causing them.

headline: Top American Runner Leaves the Pain Behind
text: ALBUQUERQUE  The morning sky was as clean and blue as a gas flame. Thin clouds hung like a fleecy collar over the Sandia Mountains, as if to warm against the lingering chill, as Dathan Ritzenhein set out for his run on feet that were famously fast and brittle.

headline: Critical Assault by Allies Begins Near Kandahar
text: KANDAHAR AIRFIELD, Afghanistan  Hundreds of Afghan and American troops on Saturday made an air assault into the horn of Panjwai, a wide area that has served as the main base for the Taliban threatening Kandahar city, Maj. Gen. Nick Carter, the commander of coalition forces in southern Afghanistan, said.

headline: Iranian Official Calls for Trial of U.S. Hikers
text: TEHRAN — Iran’s intelligence minister on Friday insisted that two United States hikers who remain in custody more than a year after their capture near the Iraqi border must be tried in an Iranian court.

headline: Lincoln in Lonely Race in Arkansas
text: RUSSELLVILLE, Ark.  Senator Blanche Lincoln, the incumbent Democrat  a double-whammy of a handicap this year  was hanging around the Pope County Courthouse here, looking for someone, anyone, to talk to.

headline: Roethlisberger Returns to Offense That May Rely on Him Less
text: Long before Milledgeville, Ga., became the center of the Pittsburgh Steelers’ off-season universe, the team had begun the move to a more run-based offense. Within days after the Steelers failed to make the playoffs as the defending Super Bowl champions last season, the team president Art Rooney II talked to Coach Mike Tomlin about reverting to a style that looked more like the Steelers teams of the 1970s and less like the pass-happy version that had emerged in recent years.

headline: Laugh Lines
text: JAY LENO

headline: Louis Henkin, Leader in Field of Human Rights Law, Dies at 92
text: Louis Henkin, a legal scholar often credited with creating the field of human rights law and the author of classic works on constitutional law and the legal aspects of foreign policy, died Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 92.

headline: Fighting Words
text: Senator Harry Reid, the majority leader, and Sharron Angle, the Nevada Republican running with Tea Party support for his Senate seat, squared off in a debate last week. What emerged was a vivid contrast in philosophy over the role of government in health care and other areas.

headline: In Cable TV Fights, Consumers Wait to See Who Blinks
text: A few minutes into the early hours of Saturday, when three million Cablevision customers in the New York area were blocked from watching Fox because of a contract dispute, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission issued a statement expressing disappointment with both Cablevision and the owner of Fox, the News Corporation.

headline: Prime Number
text: 5,300: The number of home and workplace electric-charging stations that General Motors and two of Michigan’s major utilities will install around the state to meet the demands of an emerging fleet of plug-in hybrid and electric vehicles.

headline: Second Basemen Joined by Time and Miscues
text: If Braves second baseman Brooks Conrad felt any apprehension each time a ball came his way last Sunday  uh-oh, please don’t hit it to me  it was perfectly understandable, Mike Andrews said.

headline: The Key Was B Flat; the Beer Wasn’t
text: Anyone popping in for a quick beer at the Happy Dog bar in Cleveland on Wednesday night and expecting the usual fare — polka, country or indie rock — would have been surprised.

headline: Sis, Boom, Bah (Humbug): Cheer Squads Have No Place in the N.F.L.
text: On Sunday, the Giants host the Detroit Lions in a game between teams headed in opposite directions. The Giants are 3-2, the Lions, in the midst of another losing season, are 1-4.

headline: Carp Invasion May Prompt Changes to Waterways
text: The battle over closing Chicago-area outlets into Lake Michigan is not only about preventing Asian carp from decimating the $7 billion Great Lakes fishing industry, experts said. It has also prompted efforts to re-engineer a century-old waterway system that Joel Brammeier, president of the Alliance for the Great Lakes, has compared to “having left Michigan Avenue a dirt road while we built up a modern city around it.”

headline: Yankees Prepared All Season for Their Game 1 Comeback vs. Rangers
text: ARLINGTON, Tex.  For the four Yankees who remain from Manager Joe Torre’s first world championship team in 1996, the details of many of their comeback postseason victories have dissolved so much over the years that even reminders do little to jog memories.

headline: Return of the Secret Donors
text: To old political hands, wise to the ways of candidates and money, 1972 was a watershed year. Richard M. Nixon’s re-election campaign was awash in cash, secretly donated by corporations and individuals.

headline: Gates Weighs Afghanistan and Leaks
text: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said in a private letter over the summer that while the release of 75,000 classified documents about the war in Afghanistan by the Web site WikiLeaks endangered the lives of Afghans helping the United States, the disclosures did not reveal any significant national intelligence secrets.

headline: Splendor in the Grass
text: The San Francisco Patient and Resource Center, or Sparc, is not your average pot club. There’s no peephole or scary-looking security guy, no skunky couches or blackened windows. Instead, a collegiate “community liaison” stands by the door answering questions from passers-by and checking membership cards and paperwork. (There’s no fee to join, but you need a doctor’s recommendation to enter.) And with its minimalist oak tables and benches, and jazz on the stereo, Sparc could easily be mistaken for a Japanese teahouse. Welcome to the medical marijuana dispensary of the future.

headline: The Chilean Mine Rescue, Hollywood Version
text: Life has been pleasant to Nando Parrado since he survived a 1972 plane crash along with his rugby team on an Andes mountaintop. He became an author and a successful television producer in Uruguay. Ethan Hawke played him in a movie. And he still attends an annual reunion with the 15 others whose tortuous survival story was depicted in the 1993 film “Alive.”

headline: Off the Shelf to Keep Yankees in the Game
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — The Yankees did not need Joba Chamberlain or Dustin Moseley to sweep the division series. Without them, they may not have won Game 1 of the American League Championship Series.

headline: A.L.C.S. Game 2 Final: Rangers 7, Yankees 2
text: The Yankees did not get a quality performance from their starting pitcher for the second straight game, and lost, 7-2, to the Texas Rangers on Saturday in Game 2 of the American League Championship Series in Arlington, Tex.

headline: In Afghanistan, the Exit Plan Starts With ‘If’
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — After nine years of war, the endgame here has finally begun.

headline: Kramnik Wins Bilbao Final Masters

headline: The X Factor of Economics: People
text: Economists — they certainly are a contentious bunch.

headline: Unlikely Allies in Food Stamp Debate
text: Seventeen years ago, Ann Landers got a letter from “Upset in Texas,” a checker at a grocery store, complaining about customers on food stamps. One woman bought a “fancy birthday cake” for $17. Another bought a “luxury” bag of shrimp for $32.12, and so forth. “Can’t something be done about the freeloaders who are costing us taxpayers millions?” Upset complained.

headline: Your Comments on “Tea in Kabul”
text: My Sunday column, “Tea in Kabul,” offers a few vignettes to explain why I think we’re pursuing the wrong strategy in Afghanistan. Granted, any reader knows that I’ve been critical for some time, warning since 2004 that we were losing ground in southern Afghanistan to the Taliban and strongly against the “surge” that led President Obama last year to triple our troop presence in Afghanistan. So fair warning that my reporting in Afghanistan may not have been entirely neutral. It confirmed my beliefs — humans always tend to find evidence to back up their preexisting ideas.

headline: The Many Faces of You
text: The other day, Facebook suggested that I make a new friend: myself.

headline: Magic by Numbers
text: Cambridge, Mass.

headline: The Fed’s Next Move
text: The economy isn’t recovering fast enough. So what can the Federal Reserve do now? With short-term interest rates near zero, Ben Bernanke, the Fed’s chairman, said on Friday that he would have to use “nonconventional” tools to spur growth.

headline: And a Pricier Renminbi
text: The Federal Reserve has yet to act, but officials in Europe and Russia are already complaining about the prospect of a much weaker dollar. More Fed intervention could ultimately do the global economy good  especially if it gets China to stop cheapening its currency and squeezing out the rest of the world’s exports.

headline: Don’t Stay the ‘Don’t Ask’ Ruling
text: The Obama administration has conjured up some inflated fears to justify its decision to appeal an injunction that brought a screeching halt to investigations and discharges of gay men and women serving in the military.

headline: Running Against Food Stamps
text: Jobless and hungry, Anthony Jedvabny stood in a charity grocery line in Philadelphia, shocked at how far he’d fallen from his well-paying career as a music producer. “I never imagined this,” he said, inching along North Sixth Street in a grateful crowd at a food center run by Philabundance. “I’m down to basic survival,” said Mr. Jedvabny — a starkly human statistic in the news that Philadelphia’s poverty rate has hit 25 percent, worst among the 10 largest cities in the nation.

headline: How Countrywide Covered the Cracks
text: ON June 27, 2006, Countrywide Financial, the nation’s largest mortgage lender, was about to close its books on a record-breaking six-month run. The housing market was on fire and Countrywide’s earnings were soaring. Despite all the euphoria inside the company, some executives noticed that Angelo R. Mozilo, the company’s brash and imperious chief executive, seemed subdued.

headline: Tea in Kabul

headline: In Afghan South, U.S. Faces Frustrated Residents
text: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  As American troops mount a critical operation this weekend in the campaign to regain control in Kandahar, they face not only the Taliban but also a frustrated and disillusioned population whose land has been devastated by five years of fighting.

headline: Sunnis in Iraq Allied With U.S. Rejoin Rebels
text: BAQUBA, Iraq  Members of United States-allied Awakening Councils have quit or been dismissed from their positions in significant numbers in recent months, prey to an intensive recruitment campaign by the Sunni insurgency, according to government officials, current and former members of the Awakening and insurgents.

headline: Japan Goes From Dynamic to Disheartened
text: OSAKA, Japan  Like many members of Japan’s middle class, Masato Y. enjoyed a level of affluence two decades ago that was the envy of the world. Masato, a small-business owner, bought a $500,000 condominium, vacationed in Hawaii and drove a late-model Mercedes.

headline: How to Erase the Lost Decade?
text: IT’S been a rough decade for the stock market  even when considering its recent rally. But frustrated investors can at least fall back on a comforting thought: that the market will eventually “revert to the mean,” or snap back to its historical average returns.

headline: Here Comes a Turnover Storm
text: LAYOFFS, cutbacks and stress inflicted on employees in the economic downturn have left many of them discontented and disengaged. As this pent-up frustration is released, the impact on businesses, their work forces and their customers will be pronounced. A turnover storm is looming, and most businesses are ill prepared for it.

text: MUMBAI, India

headline: The Non-Surge In Government Spending, Continued
text: A bit more on how government spending has not, contrary to what you hear everywhere, surged under Obama. Let me offer a calculation that will, I hope, make things a bit clearer. (Cue the usual suspects shouting that I’m lying).

headline: Barbara Billingsley, TV’s June Cleaver, Dies at 94
text: Barbara Billingsley, who as June Cleaver on the television series “Leave It to Beaver” personified a Hollywood postwar family ideal of the ever-sweet, ever-helpful suburban stay-at-home mom, died Saturday. She was 94.

text: Every once in a while it seems necessary to explain why, when considering monetary policy, we need to focus on inflation measures that exclude volatile prices like food and energy. So, read this.

headline: Don’t Lose That Start-Up State of Mind
text: This interview with Jenny Ming, president and C.E.O. of Charlotte Russe, a clothing chain, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant. Ms. Ming is a former president of Old Navy.

headline: After Service, Veteran Deaths Surge
text: In the six years after Reuben Paul Santos returned to Daly City from a combat tour in Iraq, he battled depression with poetry, violent video games and, finally, psychiatric treatment. His struggle ended last October, when he hung himself from a stairwell. He was 27.

headline: Going Long Liberty in China
text: There has been a lot of buzz lately about investors “shorting” China’s overheated real estate market, basically betting that it will go down. I say that’s peanuts. There is a much more interesting shorting opportunity in China today. It is truly “The Big Short,” and that is betting that China can’t continue to grow at this pace indefinitely by only permitting its people to have economic liberty without political liberty. I’m sure Goldman Sachs would write you a credit default swap on that, and the Chinese Communist Party would take the other side. Are you game? It seems that the Nobel Prize Committee is. I’d be, too.

headline: Income Inequality: Too Big to Ignore
text: PEOPLE often remember the past with exaggerated fondness. Sometimes, however, important aspects of life really were better in the old days.

headline: Times Link to Its Own Course Is a Lesson
