headline: Barbara Billingsley, Who Played June Cleaver (and Later Spoke Jive), Is Dead
text: Barbara Billingsley, television’s June Cleaver, died Saturday morning at her home in Santa Monica, Calif. She was 94. In Ms. Billingsley’s obituary, posted on The Times’s Web site, Michael Pollak writes:

headline: Sunday: Figure of Speech
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Patrick Blindauer seems incapable of constructing a normal crossword these days. Remember his most recent puzzle with something on the side? (Across Lite, Solution, blog.) Before that, he collaborated with Andrea Carla Michaels on an even more extreme mind-bender that our poor guest blogger Adam Langer had to tackle. (Across Lite, Solution , blog.) If you’re completely stuck today, here’s a huge clue. It’s a rebus puzzle. Some squares contain a symbol instead of a letter. The title of the puzzle will help you here. Come back when you’ve figured it out.

headline: Bus Drivers Take Appeal to Riders
text: Clarceen Caldwell, a retired Muni driver, approached Jesus Romero Jr. to try to convince him to vote against a November ballot measure that takes aim at the pay of San Francisco’s bus drivers.

headline: World Marathon Majors Offers Extra Incentive to Runners
text: True to its name, the World Marathon Majors offers the grandest financial prize for the top global marathoners. Since it started in 2006, male and female winners each claim $500,000 in a points series that comprises the top five competitive marathons as well as the world championship and Olympic marathon in two-year cycles. Samuel Wanjiru of Kenya secured the 2009-10 men’s series Sunday when he won the Chicago Marathon. Liliya Shobukhova won in Chicago on Sunday and clinched the women’s title.

headline: Digital Maps Don’t Always Tell the Whole Story
text: Thanks to Google Earth and MapQuest and GPS and all the other digital mapping products, an image of where we are, or where we are headed, is always just a click away. These geographical services are so omnipresent, in fact, it would be easy to assume that there’s nothing left to map.

headline: From Palaces to Hotels
text: I WAS born in Udaipur in Rajasthan in 1944, three years before India achieved independence. Udaipur was founded in 1559 by my forefather Udai Singh.

headline: King of Beers, and a Slippery Throne
text: MANY Americans barely noticed two years ago when InBev of Belgium took over Anheuser-Busch, the maker of Budweiser, for $52 billion. But the deal transformed an industry and represented the failure of a proud but parochial American family dynasty to stave off a foreign threat, says Julie MacIntosh, author of “Dethroning the King: The Hostile Takeover of Anheuser-Busch, an American Icon” (Wiley, $27.95).

headline: The Pulse | A Strong Endorsement, But Not a Replacement
text: Toni Preckwinkle said this week that she would not ask Mayor Richard M. Daley to appoint State Representative Will Burns, Democrat of Chicago, to replace her as Fourth Ward alderman if she is elected president of the Cook County Board of Commissioners.

headline: In Massachusetts, Obama Stumps
text: BOSTON  President Obama sought to rally Massachusetts Democrats to help re-elect Gov. Deval Patrick, his close friend and political ally, whose 2006 campaign of “hope” and “change” presaged Mr. Obama’s two years later, but who is struggling against voter anger in a weak economy.

headline: In Mexico, Scenes From Life in a Drug War
text: Incidences of drug-related violence in Mexico and on the border continue to make news. We tend to hear about the crimes that touch American lives — like the reported killing of a man riding a Jet Ski on the Rio Grande. What we don’t hear as much about is how drugs and violence shape the everyday lives of Mexicans. So here are dispatches from four writers on how drug trafficking has changed their parts of the country. They were translated by Kristina Cordero from the Spanish.

headline: In Fervor for Voting, Retirees Hold a Key
text: FORT COLLINS, Colo.  In an election year of hype and hyperbole, one fact resonates across all contests and candidates: in midterm elections, many people tune out and stay home, but older voters vote. It is a deeply rutted pattern in American history that could swing race after race.

headline: Playing All the Angles
text: LAS VEGAS

headline: Stars Get Lessons in Life Out of the Bike Lane
text: Flying on my bicycle down the dotted line between lanes on Park Avenue, I had a decision to make. I could follow Dave Jordan as he rode between rows of slow-moving traffic. That would mean bobbing and ducking around rear view mirrors that jutted out from vans like reflective baseball gloves to catch any passing helmeted head. Or I could slow down and go with the flow of traffic.

headline: Polls Show Voters Are Focused on Domestic Issues, Not War
text: It has been going on for nine years and counting. Nearly 100,000 American troops are currently deployed for it. More than 1,300 American service members have lost their lives in it. And the United States has spent over $300 billion on it. Yet polling suggests that the war in Afghanistan is barely a blip on voters’ radar as the midterm elections approach.

headline: Come-From-Behind Victory in a Game Riddled With Errors
text: The chess world has so many colorful characters and interesting back stories, it is possible to forget that the biggest dramas occur at the board. The final round at the Continental Class Championships in Arlington, Va., which ended on Monday, provided that reminder.

headline: The Rage Won’t End on Election Day
text: CARL Paladino began his New York gubernatorial campaign by bragging he’d “clean out Albany with a baseball bat.” When an ally likened his main Albany target, the (Jewish) leader of the State Assembly, to “an antichrist or Hitler,” he enthusiastically endorsed the slur. We also learned of Paladino’s repertory of gag e-mails  among them a pornographic picture of a woman having sex with a horse and a photo of an African tribal ritual captioned “Obama Inauguration Rehearsal.” How blind we were not to recognize that his victory in a Republican primary under the proud Tea Party banner was inevitable.

headline: Much Ado Over ... Notarization?
text: WASHINGTON  In some circles, President Obama’s veto of an obscure bill this month has proved more controversial than the legislation itself. The White House called it a “pocket veto.” Some constitutional experts beg to differ.

headline: Script Looks the Same, but Rangers Don’t Flinch
text: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Ron Washington’s job title is somewhat deceptive. He is the manager of the Texas Rangers, but, at his essence, he is also a teacher  a beloved one, at that  and instruction is a responsibility that he takes very seriously. His latest teaching moment arrived shortly after 11 p.m. Friday, minutes after presiding over one of the most excruciating losses in franchise history. In the Rangers’ clubhouse, Washington addressed his team.

headline: Nina Singh, Kiran Pratap

Ricardo Fajardo, a Roman Catholic priest and a cousin of the bride, taking part.

The gist of the conversation was this, according to O’Day: How did all of us manage to stink on the same night?

With those command performances as the backdrop, expectations were high coming into Game 1 of the National League Championship Series. But the two aces, Roy Halladay and Tim Lincecum, wound up falling a little short in their encore presentations.

headline: Rooney Benched Before Tie
text: The Manchester United star Wayne Rooney was dropped from the team’s starting lineup without explanation and played only the last 20 minutes of a 2-2 draw with West Bromwich Albion in a home game in the Premier League. Rooney was left on the bench days after directly contradicting Manager Alex Ferguson by denying that he had missed games because he had been struggling with an ankle injury. Rooney played 90 minutes for England in a 0-0 draw against Montenegro on Tuesday.

text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Although the preliminary results of the Sept. 18 parliamentary elections, expected to be announced Sunday, were postponed, interviews with Afghan and Western officials indicate that fraud was pervasive and that nearly 25 percent of the votes are likely to be thrown out.

headline: Oregon Is No. 1 for the First Time
text: Oregon is ranked No. 1 in the Associated Press Top 25 for the first time. The Ducks received 39 first-place votes and moved up from No. 2 after Ohio State’s 31-18 loss to Wisconsin.

headline: Morals Without God?
text: I was born in Den Bosch, the city after which Hieronymus Bosch named himself. [1] This obviously does not make me an expert on the Dutch painter, but having grown up with his statue on the market square, I have always been fond of his imagery, his symbolism, and how it relates to humanity’s place in the universe. This remains relevant today since Bosch depicts a society under a waning influence of God.

headline: New York Job Offer for Philadelphia Orchestra’s Principal Clarinetist
text: The New York Philharmonic took a step closer to filling a key position this weekend, offering its vacant principal clarinet job to Ricardo Morales, who holds the post at the Philadelphia Orchestra.

headline: The Pace Years: When One Gallery Is Not Enough
text: Fifty years ago one of the 800-pound gorillas of today’s New York gallery world was born. Now with four locations in Manhattan and one in Beijing, the Pace Gallery has real estate and a roster of blue chip artists that are eclipsed only by Gagosian Gallery’s global empire, which in addition to three locations in New York, has satellites in Beverly Hills, London, Rome and Athens.

headline: The Pace Gallery Looks Back
text: Highlights from the exhibition, at three locations, marking the mega-gallery’s 50th anniversary.

headline: At the Broadway Cabaret Festival, Kooks and Cutups
text: An incandescent kook, a swinging cool guy, a gregarious cutup, a neurotic sob sister and two tough ladies: the performers in “Broadway Melody Makers,” Friday’s opening-night show of the three-day Broadway Cabaret Festival at Town Hall, made up a reasonable cross section of personality types you might find at a showbiz after party. The program  created, written, and hosted by Scott Siegel  was devoted to mostly familiar songs, by mostly American songwriters, mostly from the theater, sung by Broadway performers. Conspicuously absent among the composers were Jerome Kern and George Gershwin.

headline: Left-Field Hip-Hop, Coherently Disjointed
text: Before the members of Shabazz Palaces took the stage on Friday night, they huddled off to one side, strapping on ornate black masklike headpieces and making sure they were perfectly vertical, towering several inches above the tops of their heads.

headline: Monday: Officials Behind Batters
text: Since blogging for Wordplay, I’ve never had a chance to talk about a Lynn Lempel puzzle. I finally do and, as usual, it’s very nice. She’s one of the best Monday constructors around — a master I’d have to say (since calling her a mistress doesn’t sound quite right).

headline: Prince’s Fate, Entwined With Desire
text: The choreographer and director Matthew Bourne has said that as a child he found swans frightening, so it’s only fitting that in his theatrical mind they are as well  wild, menacing creatures, quicker on land than you might expect and poised to attack. They tip the scale more toward power than pretty; they’re also played by men.

headline: The Met Makes Way for New Bohèmians
text: Saturday was a night of multiple debuts at the Metropolitan Opera when Franco Zeffirelli’s popular production of Puccini’s “Bohème” returned to the repertory. Three of the main characters, as well as the conductor, Roberto Rizzi Brignoli, were all appearing for the first time. But the focus of attention was on the fast-rising Italian tenor Vittorio Grigolo, making his Met debut as Rodolfo.

headline: A Revolutionary of Arabic Verse
text: ANN ARBOR, Mich.  Every year around this time the name of the Syrian poet Adonis pops up in newspapers and in betting shops. Adonis (pronounced ah-doh-NEES), a pseudonym adopted by Ali Ahmad Said Esber in his teens as an attention getter, is a perennial favorite to win the Nobel Prize in Literature. This year Ladbrokes, the British bookmaking firm, had his chances at 8-1, which made him seem a surer bet than the eventual winner, Mario Vargas Llosa, a 25-1 long shot. Why Adonis appeals to the oddsmakers, presumably, is that he’s a poet, and poets have been under-represented among Nobelists lately; that he writes in Arabic, the language of only one Nobel winner, Naguib Mahfouz; and that as is the case with so many recent winners, most Americans have never heard of him.

headline: Handel’s Old Testament Dramas Revived in New York
text: A particular delight of the New York classical music season at its teeming height is the way seemingly unrelated events intersect to produce a spontaneous minifestival, or at least a theme. It happened last week on consecutive evenings, when two of the city’s finest professional church choirs presented contrasting Handel oratorios touching on more or less parallel Old Testament subjects.

headline: A French Thinker Who Crossed Continents and Cultures
text: Patrick Wilcken first interviewed the celebrated French anthropologist Claude Lévi-Strauss in 2005. For Mr. Wilcken an audience with the great man must have been a daunting occasion: Mr. Wilcken had a biography in the works, and his subject was then well into his 90s. (He died in 2009, just short of his 101st birthday.) And even at that late date Mr. Wilcken wanted Lévi-Strauss to address some of the fundamental issues raised by his work.

headline: Numerous Titles Are Awarded at World Championships
text: PHILADELPHIA — One world championship was decided here on Friday, and seven more titles were determined on Saturday afternoon.

headline: A Linguist at a Loss for Words Regarding Love
text: Looking to brush up your Esperanto? Make sure to grab a ticket for “The Language Archive,” a new play by Julia Cho that offers theatergoers a rare chance to acquire a phrase or two of that little-used international tongue.

headline: Why Have Deficits Exploded?
text: For all those commenters saying that we must have had a surge in government spending — I mean, look at the deficit! — a simple picture:

headline: ‘Jackass 3D’ Leads Weekend Box-Office Sales
text: Never underestimate the power of sophomoric humor at the American multiplex. “Jackass 3D,” left, produced for $20 million by Paramount Pictures, surpassed expectations to sell an estimated $50 million at the weekend box office. As the third installment in the franchise, this picture was helped by premium-priced 3-D tickets. But it also benefited from an enormous promotional effort by MTV, Paramount’s corporate sibling and the home of the “Jackass” television series. “Jackass: The Movie,” made in 2002 for $5 million, opened to about $28 million (after adjusting for inflation). “Jackass Number Two,” made for $12 million 2006, opened to an adjusted $31.4 million. Finishing second this weekend was the sharply more expensive “RED,” with John Malkovich, an adaptation of an obscure graphic novel. Summit Entertainment spent about $60 million to make “RED,” which took in about $22.5 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office statistics. “The Social Network” (Sony Pictures Entertainment) ranked third in its third weekend, selling about $11 million for a new total of $63 million. “Secretariat” (Walt Disney Studios) was fourth with $9.5 million ($27.5 million total). The romantic comedy “Life as We Know It” (Warner Brothers) was fifth with $9.2 million ($28.9 million total).

headline: Orpheus Announces Commission Winners
text: The Orpheus Chamber Orchestra, which takes the populist view that musical interpretations can be shaped by the ensemble rather than by a conductor, has expanded on that concept in a commissioning program, Project 440. The orchestra’s goal was to commission four composers to help celebrate its 40th anniversary. Intent on getting its audience involved, it joined forces with WQXR, the New York classical radio station, which opened the process to its listeners. Orpheus and WQXR assembled a panel of more than 30 performers, composers and music executives, who nominated 60 composers. Listeners were invited to peruse the composers’ biographies, to listen to music clips on WQXR’s Web site, wqxr.org, and to comment. The selection committee, taking listener comments into account, chose 30 semifinalists whose music was streamed for 24 hours on Q2, WQXR’s Internet station. That marathon yielded 12 finalists, and 4 winners were announced at Orpheus’s first New York concert of the season, on Thursday at Carnegie Hall. They are Alex Mincek, a New York composer; Clint Needham, who recently completed his doctorate at Indiana University; Andrew Norman of California; and Cynthia Lee Wong, who completed studies at Juilliard. At the concert Orpheus also introduced its new executive director, Ayden Adler. Ms. Adler, a former French horn player in the Rochester Philharmonic, joins the ensemble from the Philadelphia Orchestra, where she was director of education and community partnerships.

headline: Roethlisberger Shakes Off Rust in Return
text: PITTSBURGH  There was a time last spring, perhaps a few weeks, when a segment of Pittsburgh Steelers fans wanted Ben Roethlisberger traded, their disgust over Roethlisberger’s troubling behavior with a woman in a Georgia bar seemingly tainting forever the relationship between a two-time Super Bowl winner and one of the most devoted fan bases in the N.F.L.

headline: A Spaceflight Attempt’s Almost-Instant Documentary
text: Few people are better self-promoters than Richard Branson, the tycoon and entrepreneur behind Virgin Records, Virgin Mobile and now Virgin Galactic. So, not surprisingly, he sees the value in having a television documentary series closely follow his company’s efforts at commercial spaceflight.

headline: Amid Cacophony and Rapture, a Plaintive Quality Prevails
text: Extremes of human nature, dire and exalted, are the subjects of Bradford Cox’s songs for his band Deerhunter; and extremes of sound, consonant and bristling, are his vehicle. At Webster Hall on Friday night he sang, in a high voice that often stayed strangely serene, about murder, revelation, love, nightmares, memories, annihilation and regeneration. Playing guitar, he led Deerhunter through songs that used just a few rudimentary chords each but rode those structures toward cacophony and rapture.

headline: A Washington Senator Fights to Keep Her Seat
text: EVERETT, Wash.  Never mind Nevada. If you are among the party power brokers and political fortunetellers obsessed with America’s most elusive elected position, Senate seat No. 51, head to Washington  the real one.

text: James E. Fuchs, who developed a new way to heave the shot to compensate for a leg injury and used the technique to set world records and dominate shot-putting over two remarkable seasons, died in Manhattan on Oct. 8. He was 82.

text: BERLIN — It has been many years since a German film student had a feature-length movie shown in the competition at the prestigious Berlinale International Film Festival, a distinction that can launch a career. That is what Burhan Qurbani is enjoying at the moment, with his film “Shahada.”

headline: Groups Push Legal Limits in Advertising
text: A recent television commercial sponsored by an Iowa-based nonprofit group, American Future Fund, attacking Representative Bobby Bright, an Alabama Democrat, could hardly have been more explicit in its closing: “On Election Day,” the narrator said, “take the right path. Vote against Bobby Bright.”

headline: Louis F. Bantle, Chief of U.S. Tobacco, Dies at 81

headline: Mission Is Control as Rangers’ Lee Limits Walks

headline: Obamas Rally for Democrats in Final Push
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama is seeking to rally anxious Democrats for the final two weeks of the midterm election campaign, traveling to the heart of the electoral battleground to urge them not to be discouraged  “Don’t let them tell you that change isn’t possible”  even as resurgent Republicans continued to expand their sights with the help of deep-pocketed allies.

headline: Lincecum Holds Steady and Laughs Off the Whistling

headline: Citi’s Uneasy Deal With EMI
text: Citigroup has the most to lose from its showdown over EMI, the British music company. Barring an 11th-hour settlement, the bank is scheduled to start defending itself in court on Monday against allegations that it tricked Terra Firma, the private equity firm led by Guy Hands, into buying EMI for £4.2 billion ($6.7 billion) in 2007. The only way Citi can avoid the confrontation is to agree to restructure the £3 billion it lent Terra Firma to finance the deal.

The Supreme Court allowed unlimited campaign spending by corporations and unions but didn’t require the folks picking up the tab to stand behind their words.

headline: Death, DNA and the Supreme Court

headline: Brazil: No Green Party Endorsement in Runoff

Ms. Silva’s decision “benefits Dilma Rousseff because an endorsement of Serra was expected,” said David Fleischer, a political analyst at the University of Brasilia.

And no one fills that role better than Matthew Weiner, who created the show, oversees its production and would probably cater it if he had the time, and who is kind of like a walking Wikipedia of “Mad Men” (with a much higher rate of accuracy).

So the Phillies found another way to keep Ross, the hottest hitter in the playoffs, from beating them: they outslugged him.

headline: This Week in Small Business: Taxes, Bankers, the Windows Phone

Now that we’ve ended combat operations in Iraq, President Obama is being accused of declaring war on the Chamber of Commerce.  A new scorecard from a small-business group suggests that Republicans are more business-friendly than Democrats. An analysis of polls by the FiveThirtyEight blog finds there’s a 72 percent chance that Republicans will take over the House. Small-business advocate Jim Blasingame discusses ways our political leadership can encourage economic recovery. Unhappiness with the current administration is creating a business backlash, even in the president’s home state.

headline: Obama Takes Science Push to ‘Mythbusters’

headline: The Unbearable Slowness of Understanding
text: OK, I’m about to be unfair. But this article about how the Fed is gradually coming to realize that low inflation and a liquidity trap might be a problem fills me with despair.

headline: We’re Not China
text: In various comments and other places I keep seeing people compare European complaints about the weak dollar to American complaints about the undervalued renminbi. It’s a false equivalence, which should be obvious if you think about the basics of the situation.

headline: From a Klingon Armory to a Defendant’s Cache
text: When federal agents raided a home in central New Jersey on Wednesday, they discovered nothing short of a private armory, with pistols and rifles hidden throughout its 25-plus rooms. But they found something else — something, it would become clear later, that should give earthlings pause.

headline: Chinese Promotion Puts Official on Track for Presidency
text: BEIJING  Xi Jinping, China’s vice president, was named to an important military position on Monday, continuing his elevation to the top echelons of China’s leadership and reconfirming that the Communist Party had selected him as the successor to President Hu Jintao.

headline: Kanye West’s Film Debut Is Coming (But His Album Art Will Have to Wait)
text: Sometimes Kanye West gets what he wants and sometimes he doesn’t: while a new film he has written and directed will soon make its television debut, the cover art he proposed for his new album will not be hitting stores any time soon. We’ll just have to assume he’s O.K. with that.

headline: Sadly, the Scary Hits in N.F.L. Keep Coming
text: Today seems like a perfect day to stop and appreciate your job. For a moment, set aside everything that might stink about it and think: at least at no point today will the Steelers’ James Harrison or the Falcons’ Dunta Robinson launch himself full-speed and helmet-first at your head and threaten to turn your brain into something resembling Cream of Wheat.

headline: Numberplay: The Puzzle Gourmet
text: Today and next week we have a couple of puzzles selected by a puzzle gourmet. They have a delicious and surprising quality that the very best puzzles — or dishes — have. What’s more, they are beautifully connected with puzzles recently presented on Numberplay. Therefore they belong to a rare category that Hollywood rarely masters: the perfect sequel or second course.

headline: A Ceremonial Start for Moynihan Station
text: Gov. David A. Paterson is planning to swing a sledgehammer at a faux brick wall erected on Monday afternoon at the James A. Farley Post Office in a groundbreaking ceremony for Moynihan Station.

headline: More on iPhones and Toddlers
text: Several of you have asked for a chance to weigh in on the article in the Styles section this weekend about toddlers and iPhones. It has become “the most effective tool in human history to mollify a fussy toddler,” writes Hillary Stout, “much to the delight of parents reveling in their newfound freedom to have a conversation in a restaurant or roam the supermarket aisles in peace.”

headline: Keeping Score: How the Yankees Can Beat Cliff Lee
text: In July, the Yankees thought they had a deal to acquire a second bona fide ace behind C.C. Sabathia in Cliff Lee. Instead, the Mariners sent the southpaw to Texas. Now, Lee is not only not pitching for New York, but he will also face them in Game 3 of the American League Championship Series on Monday night. As dominant as Lee has been since 2008, he has been even tougher against the Yankees: between the regular season and the playoffs, he has compiled a 2.62 earned run average against them in 58 1/3 innings, compared with a 2.88 E.R.A. against all other opponents.

headline: Facebook Acknowledges Privacy Issue With Applications
text: Facebook said on Monday that it was talking to application developers about how they handled some personal data, after a report said some applications had been improperly sharing the data with advertisers and Web tracking companies.

headline: Pfizer Makes Move Into Biologic Drugs
text: Making a new move into the fledgling market for generic biotech drugs, pharmaceutical giant Pfizer has acquired worldwide rights to sell human insulin and insulin analogs being developed by Biocon, one of India’s largest biotech companies.

headline: Mariinsky Takes Mahler to Russia
text: For generations now, a common argument goes, national styles of music making have been losing their distinctiveness to a global musical melting pot. International standards and tastes increasingly trump national heritage and culture.

headline: Now Reading | The Finest Rooms
text: Thomas Jayne, the New York decorator, has always brought both a scholarly knowledge of design history and a quirky sense of the modern to his work, creating rooms that bridge the old and the new. And even though there is none of Jayne’s own work in his new book, “The Finest Rooms in America” (The Monacelli Press), his sensibility is evident in his choice of what the book’s subtitle calls “fifty influential interiors from the 18th century to the present.” (Full disclosure: I am mentioned in the book’s acknowledgments, along with a number of other magazine editors, but was not involved in the book.) Any conversation with Jayne on the subject of decorating invariably touches on his passion for great interiors of the past, and indeed, nearly half the rooms in this book are historic, although Jayne includes 20th-century interiors — like the living room of Frank Lloyd Wright’s Hollyhock House and that of Charles and Ray Eames’s house — in this category, along with 18th-century spaces like the Tea Room at Monticello or the Large Dining Room at Mount Vernon. But seeing his broad-ranging eye at work is part of the pleasure of reading Jayne’s book. His selection of contemporary rooms won’t please every decorator — particularly given the book’s somewhat loaded title, an homage to the famous 1964 volume “The Finest Rooms by America’s Great Decorators,” which included interiors by now-departed greats like Rose Cumming, Sister Parish and Billy Baldwin — but it is as catholic as his tastes. So you’ll find the more-is-more drawing room of the jewelry designer Kenneth Jay Lane and Robert Couturier’s classically inspired dining room sharing the book’s pages with an elegantly spare living room by David Kleinberg and an edgy studio by Christopher Coleman. While many of the rooms are fairly grand in scale and furnishings, it is one of the smallest that that makes your heart beat faster: Albert Hadley’s Manhattan intimate sitting room, an object lesson in understated chic, which Jayne rightly saves for last.

headline: Roadside Bomb Kills Baghdad Official
text: BAGHDAD  A roadside bomb during the Monday morning rush killed a member of Baghdad’s Provincial Council, the local governing body. The explosion, which wounded eight people, is the latest in a stream of small attacks aimed at the police and government officials.

headline: The Claim: After Being Broken, Bones Can Become Even Stronger.
text: THE FACTS Just like muscle, human bone grows and strengthens under pressure, and weakens when barely put to use.

headline: Jimmie Johnson Pads Nascar Sprint Cup Lead
text: As the Nascar Sprint Cup season winds down, it doesn’t matter so much who wins or loses the individual races anymore. The series has turned into the Jimmie Johnson watch. And Johnson, who has won the last four Sprint Cup championships, continues to pull away from the rest of the pack. At Charlotte Motor Speedway in North Carolina on Saturday night, he finished third to push his overall lead in the series to 41 points.

headline: The Battle to Recover From Lost Advances
text: Three years ago, Gary Barnett started writing checks to brokers who found him buyers for one of the glassy condominium towers he was building on the Upper East Side. The brokers cashed the checks, some in the hundreds of thousands of dollars, and paid taxes on them. Then they did what they wanted with the money: put it in savings accounts, paid off mortgages or simply spent it on what any person with spare cash would spend money on, like Christian Louboutins, French manicures, even frozen yogurt.

headline: Questioning the Results of Medical Research
text: This week The Atlantic wonders if we should all be more skeptical of medical research. The magazine focuses on Dr. John Ioannidis, a Greek researcher who has spent his career “challenging his peers by exposing their bad science.”

headline: Edison's Electric Light
text: There was no lack of enthusiasm or of confidence about Mr. Edison as he greeted the Times reporter who entered his laboratory at Menlo Park, N. J., yesterday. The inventor, a short, thick-set man, with grimy hands, led the way through his workshop, and willingly explained the distinctive features of what he and many others look upon as an apparatus which will soon cause gas-light to be a thing of the past. The lamp which Mr. Edison regards as a crowning triumph is a model of simplicity and economy. In the lamp the light is emitted by a horseshoe of carbonized paper about two and a half inches long and the width of a thread. This horseshoe is in a glass globe, from which the air has been as thoroughly exhausted as science is able to do. So good a vacuum is produced that it is estimated that at the utmost no more than a one-millionth part of the air remains. The operation of pumping lasts one hour and a quarter. At the ends of the carbon horseshoe are two platinum clamps, from which platinum wires run outwardly through a small glass tube contained within a larger one leading out of the glass globe. The small tube contains air. Within it the platinum wires are met by two copper wires connecting with the conductors of the electricity. The air is left in the small tube, because otherwise the copper wires would be fused by the electric current. The carbonized paper is capable of being made incandescent by a current of electricity, and while it allows the current to pass over it, its resistance to the heat is strong enough to prevent it from fusing.

headline: Hope Opera | Fabrizio Ferri’s ‘Anima’
text: Fabrizio Ferri is at it again. The renowned fashion photographer, architect, clothing designer and musician has composed an opera, “Anima,” which will be performed on Tuesday in Naples at the Teatro di San Carlo (Europe’s oldest opera house, dating from 1737). Ferri was initially contacted by Rosanna Purchia, the theater’s newly appointed “sovrintendente,” to create evocative imagery for the coming season’s performances. For the theater’s first ever promotional campaign Ferri shot dance students from the Teatro’s school in the volcanic surroundings of Mt. Vesuvius, above. Ferri, who had also been working for almost a decade writing, orchestrating and recording the score for a musical film, happened to play a selection of songs for Purchia, who convinced him to turn his film-to-be into an opera for the newly revived theater. “Anima,” which means “soul,” tells the story of North African immigrants who left their homelands behind for a better life in Europe. “The music envelops the people like the sea,” Ferri says, “sometimes soothing, like a mother or father, and sometimes angry and dangerous.” An 80-person choir, a 50-person children’s choir and an 80-piece orchestra will be joined by some gifted friends of Ferri: the trumpeter Chris Botti, who also contributed recordings for the original score; Andrea Griminelli, a world-famous flautist; and Gil Goldstein, an orchestrator. (A surprise appearance by Sting, a longtime friend, is also anticipated.) Ferri credits the creation of this extraordinary event to Purchia and to “the power of this theater, in a moment of crisis, to have the guts and strength to create the necessary energy so artists come to Naples to play this music, to raise their eyelids, to look ahead.”

headline: Coping With Economic Uncertainty
text: I started writing for this blog some 10 months ago — a time when just about everyone, including me, was trying to sort out what was going on in the economy. In the months since then, I’ve shared many stories with you about how open-book management has helped propel SRC Holdings through at least three recessions and has set us up to take advantage of the recovery. That’s also why I’ve written several times about our manufacturing facility in Lexington, Ky. — the plant we purchased not long before I started this blog. I chose to share the stories from Lexington because I thought it would help illustrate what happens when a traditionally run company opens its books.

headline: Mistrial for Schizophrenic in Killing of Psychologist

text: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department sued Blue Cross Blue Shield of Michigan on Monday, asserting that the company, the state’s dominant health insurer, had violated antitrust laws and secured a huge competitive advantage by forcing hospitals to charge higher prices to Blue Cross’s rivals.

headline: The Playoffs Through a Times Photographer’s Lens
text: While a batter who gets three hits in every 10 at-bats is considered to be a great success, James Estrin writes on the Lens blog, “for a sports photographer covering a playoff or the World Series, getting a good shot three times out of 10 spells failure.” He adds, “Chang W. Lee, a staff photographer for The New York Times, aspires to a 1.000 average.”

headline: Now Reading | W.W.D. at 100
text: The truth is that Women’s Wear Daily, at least in the beginning, was written for men. Not just any men, but “important men in all departments of women’s wear” who are “scattered everywhere over the earth’s surface and lose track of events and happenings.” (Sounds like your typical fashionisto.) These words appeared in the first issue of Women’s Wear (the “Daily” came later), from June 1910, in a mission statement titled “Our Excuse for Being.” The defensive pose actually makes some sense: it’s not easy to prove, as W.W.D. has, that you can write about an essentially frivolous enterprise without indulging in frivolity. This year marks the end of Patrick McCarthy’s reign over the newspaper but also its 100th anniversary. In celebration of that second, happier occasion, the paper has just unveiled “W.W.D.: 100 Years | 100 Designers” (Fairchild, $65), about its own history and the designers who have animated its pages for a century. The best part of the book are the reprints of old issues: sketches of Paul Poiret’s costumes for a Parisian revue; news of the D-Day landings competing for front-page space next to a report on handbag pricing; and a cover story on the 1999 John F. Kennedy Jr. plane crash that mourned as much for Carolyn Bessette — the former Calvin Klein saleswoman, style icon and fashion publicist — as for John Jr.

headline: Canada Poised for 2011 Withdrawal From Afghanistan

headline: What Recent Deals May Say About M.&A.’s Future
text: 3:28 p.m. | Updated Where is the market for mergers and acquisitions going? After a summer of prominent deal announcements and increased M.&A. activity, investment bankers are speculating that the market will grow 15 percent to 30 percent in the next year. Bankers tend to talk their book, but this time it looks like the market is likely to support a modest upswing, albeit one not as big as the bankers hope for.

headline: Lake Mead Hits Record Low Level
text: Sometime between 11 and noon on Sunday, the water level in Lake Mead, the massive reservoir whose water fills the taps of millions of people across the Southwest, fell lower than it ever has since it was filled 75 years ago.

text: MOGADISHU, Somalia  The struggling transitional government and its allies have undertaken a limited offensive against radical Islamist insurgents, attacking their positions in several places over the past few days, Somali officials and witnesses said Monday.

headline: Change in Law Sharpens Ads
text: Nonprofit groups are now able to use corporate money to run ads explicitly urging votes for or against candidates. Previously, they had been mostly limited to so-called “issue ads”, which stopped short of directly calling for candidates to be elected or defeated. Some groups have aggressively taken advantage of this ruling (which could raise legal questions) while others have refrained. A look at ad spending from some of those groups and the portion spent on express advocacy.

headline: Defendant Talks With F.B.I Informer
text: James Cromitie talks with Shahed Hussain, an F.B.I informer, about possible bombing targets. Prosecutors said the tape showed Mr. Cromitie was "pre-disposed" to commit a terrorist attack.

headline: A Chess Player With a Swelled Head
text: It’s not exactly a surprise that some chess players have big egos, but the guy who was recently photographed playing chess in Washington Square Park in Manhattan really had a swelled head. According to Brian Dube, the creator of New York Daily Photo, the blog on which the photo appeared, the player had only mediocre skills.

headline: Now Showing | Mike Ballard’s Coat Tales

headline: 100 Candles on Her Next Cake, and Three R’s to Get Her There
text: Esther Tuttle is nearing the end of the 10th decade of a remarkably productive and adventurous life. If all continues to go as well as it has to date, next July 1 she will join the rapidly growing clan of centenarians, whose numbers in the United States have increased to 96,548 in 2009 from 38,300 in 1990, according to the Census Bureau.

headline: Living to 100 and Beyond
text: Want to know what it’s like to live to be 100? Be sure to check out our new multimedia feature “Secrets of the Centenarians.” You’ll see pictures and listen to eight centenarians tell their stories of life in three digits.

headline: Stone Power

headline: Predicting the Vote: Analyzing Election Data
text: Overview | What do polling numbers and other statistics reveal about races for political office? How can we use data and quantitative tools to analyze and understand elections? In this lesson, students apply both quantitative and qualitative reasoning skills to profile a current election. Using polling and demographic data, they synthesize data, statistics and representations to investigate the mathematics of elections.

The coming Lexmark Genesis is unmistakably a printer, albeit a handsome one, but it has impressive new technology under the hood: a digital camera that can scan documents and photos in a whizzy three seconds.

headline: Is There an Effective Climate ‘Narrative’?
text: Keith Kloor, the journalist and Collide-a-Scape blogger, e-mailed me this morning asking if I agreed with his post noting an apparent “narrative vacuum” on energy and climate. He built his piece around a riff on the need for serious research on geo-engineering by Dana Milbank at the Washington Post. I sent this reply (e-mail shorthand is cleaned up a bit):

headline: Parody Trips Up Chevron Ad Campaign
text: A lampoon of Chevron’s “We agree” advertising campaign seems to mock the ads’ emphasis on the oil company’s community-mindedness, our friends at the Media Decoder blog report. Chevron is not amused.

headline: The Phillies’ Optimal Lineup
text: ESPN.com’s Rob Neyer recently wrote that by flip-flopping Plácido Polanco and Chase Utley in the second and third spots in the lineup, Phillies Manager Charlie Manuel had come up with the “perfect lineup.” There’s no doubt that the switch is a huge improvement.

headline: What to Tell Children About God
text: Bruce Feiler ponders God for a living. After all, he has written four books on the subject. And yet, as he wrote in an essay in The Times’s Styles section yesterday, he was thrown when his 5-year-old-daughter asked her first question:

headline: Now Sparkling | Ralph Lauren’s Fine Jewelry
text: After two years of construction, Ralph Lauren’s 22,000-square-foot, four-story women’s flagship is finally open, but the brightest sparkle perhaps comes from the 600-square-foot watch and fine jewelry salon on the ground floor. The simultaneous introduction of six fine jewelry collections exclusive to the store represents a new direction for the company, which plans to expand distribution next year in select markets. Standouts include the Equestrian stirrup pendants, the Signature Diamonds and Classic tennis bracelet and necklace, and a jaw-dropping Monogram necklace with akoya pearls and rose gold with diamond monogram (and a hefty $145,900 price tag to boot).

headline: Building Ranks of Young  Voters, and Poll Workers
text: With two weeks left before Election Day, City University officials are hoping to mobilize New Yorkers who typically have been among the least likely people to vote: college-age young adults.

headline: Mount Airy Lives On, But in Name Only
text: Anyone who watched late-night programming in the 1980s will be familiar with the Mount Airy Lodge. ”All you need to bring is your love for everything,” went the jingle of one of the Pocono resort’s famous commercials. After a heyday in the ’60s and ’70s, though, the resort had fallen into disrepair by the late ’90s, and it finally closed in 2001.

headline: Disney to Go It Alone With Superheroes
text: Paramount’s deal to distribute Marvel’s superhero films will end two years early.

headline: Lute Fanciers Meet 3 Stars From the Past
text: The lutenist Paul O’Dette has lately been fascinated by the music of Marco dall’Aquila, an Italian lutenist-composer who was born around 1480, worked mostly in Venice and died in 1544. Though he is barely known today, dall’Aquila had a stellar reputation in his lifetime. He was listed among the great musicians of his day in a 1519 poem by Filippo Oriolo, and nearly two decades later, another author, Francesco Marcolini, wrote rhapsodically of the sound produced by dall’Aquila and two lutenists who are more familiar now, Alberto Ripa da Mantova and Francesco da Milano.

headline: DreamWorks Theatricals Plans a Touring ‘Madagascar’ Show
text: DreamWorks Theatricals, which made its first attempt to transform a movie property into a Broadway show in 2008 with “Shrek the Musical,” is now teaming up with Broadway Across America for DreamWorks’s first live family touring show based on its “Madagascar” film series, the two companies announced on Monday.

headline: Prescription Drug Use Soared in Past Decade
text: If you are taking a prescription medicine and you are older than 60, it is probably a cholesterol-lowering drug. If you are 20 to 59, it is more likely to be an antidepressant.

headline: Light and Color in an Undulating Cloud
text: In assuming the role of music director at the American Composers Orchestra, the conductor George Manahan inherits an institution whose stature and primacy are not what they were. A chamber orchestra in all but name, the ensemble has not fielded a full symphonic complement since 2007.

headline: Top Canadian Commander Pleads Guilty to Murders
text: BELLEVILLE, Ontario  In April, Canadians reacted with shock after a top Canadian military commander, who frequently piloted planes for top political figures and dignitaries, including Queen Elizabeth II, was charged with rape, murder and an extensive campaign of perverse home break-ins.

headline: On Our Radar: Nascar to Use Biofuel Blend
text: Starting next season, Nascar will use a 15 percent ethanol blend from Sunoco for its three national touring series. A Nascar executive says the use of American ethanol “creates jobs in the United States, helps foster energy independence and continues the greening of our sport.” [The Des Moines Register]

headline: Video: A New East Window on Eldridge Street
text: Earlier this month the Museum at Eldridge Street unveiled a new stained-glass window designed by the artist Kiki Smith and the architect Deborah Gans for its 1887 synagogue, which re-opened in 2007 after a 20-year restoration. The filmmaker Jenny Carchman documented the installation of the window from start to finish for a short piece titled “The East Window.” Julie Bloom spoke to her about the film, watching Ms. Smith and Ms. Gans at work and the always-changing Lower East Side. Below is the finished film, along with edited excerpts from the interview.

headline: Period Works, Played With Freewheeling Touches
text: The English Concert’s performance at Weill Recital Hall on Wednesday evening had plenty to recommend it, not least Rachel Podger’s magnificent violin playing in a pair of Vivaldi Concertos, and intensely dramatic accounts of Monteverdi and Handel vocal works with the mezzo-soprano Alice Coote.

headline: Bringing in Family to Combat Anorexia
text: At their first family therapy session, Rina Ranalli and her husband tried to coax their anorexic 13-year-old daughter to eat a bagel with cream cheese. What followed was a protracted negotiation.

headline: The Night My Liver Started Running My Life
text: I first met my liver the night it tried to kill me.

headline: Freddy’s Pan Will Bang No More for Yankees
text: Freddy Schuman, who with one eye, one tooth and several old frying pans and spoons turned his love of the New York Yankees into a full-time occupation as the team’s unofficial mascot, becoming one of the wackiest and unlikeliest cheerleaders of a baseball empire not known for wackiness, died Sunday afternoon at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 85.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Philippines and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from the Philippines, Afghanistan and France.

headline: Family Therapy for Eating Disorders
text: Parents often feel helpless in their efforts to cure a child of an eating disorder. Now new research shows a family-based therapy program may be the solution. The method, reports Roni Rabin in today’s Science Times, is not only more effective than adolescent-focused individual therapy but keeps working even after the treatment ends.

headline: Killings in Nigeria Are Linked to Islamic Sect
text: MAIDUGURI, Nigeria  A rash of mysterious killings by gun-wielding motorcycle assassins of policemen, politicians and others in this city near the desert has led authorities to declare that a radical Islamic sect thought to have been crushed by Nigerian troops last year has been revived.

headline: Yoko, Before ‘Oh Yoko!’  (and Other Origin Stories)
text: The art-world documentarian Chiara Clemente set her sights on seven creative personalities, whom she has profiled in miniature for “Beginnings,” a new film series debuting Tuesday at sundancechannel.com. All of the subjects — from Yoko Ono (the profile of her is embedded above) to the Blue Hill chef Dan Barber — hit the big time in New York, and in going back to their beginnings, Clemente reminds us that none of us — O.K., very few of us — fall off of the truck an instant star. Carmen de Lavallade returns to the 92nd Street Y, site of the 79-year-old dancer’s first performance in the city. The photographer Mario Sorrenti shows off his mother’s art studio, where, as a young vandal, he’d crash after long nights spent spraying graffiti. And the designer Carolina Herrera recalls her first meeting with Diana Vreeland, in which she explained her desire to go into fabric design. “But how boring that is!” Vreeland told her. “Why don’t you just do a little collection?”

headline: How to Push Past the Pain, as the Champions Do
text: My son, Stefan, was running in a half marathon in Philadelphia last month when he heard someone coming up behind him, breathing hard.

headline: Harrah’s Files Plan to Sell Shares
text: Harrah’s Entertainment, the biggest casino operator in the world, disclosed on Monday that it planned to sell some $575 million worth of shares in an initial public offering.

headline: Gov. Christie Expresses Concern Over Cable Dispute
text: New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie weighed in Monday on the increasingly bitter cable television dispute that prevented three million homes in New Jersey and New York from seeing both the Giants football game and the second game of the National League baseball playoffs on Sunday.

headline: The Sting of Salt Air, Old Loves and Honey Bees
text: Matthew Zapruder’s new book of poems is called “Come On All You Ghosts,” a title that could be slapped on almost any collection of poetry. Many of our finest poems are infested with ghosts — just ask Edgar Allan Poe or Emily Dickinson.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘L’Avventura’
text: How can people who have so much feel so empty and so lost? A. O. Scott poses that question with this week’s Critics’ Pick, “L’Avventura.” Directed by Michelangelo Antonioni, the film follows a group of wealthy young Romans on a day trip to a volcanic island. During the trip, one of the women vanishes, but the film’s characters seem to pay her disappearance little concern. The film was booed at Cannes when it had its premiere there 50 years ago, yet was also awarded a prize by the jury. It has been debated among cinephiles ever since. Have you seen “L’Avventura?” Please share your thoughts.

headline: Pushing Past Pain to Improve Performance
text: How do elite athletes find the motivation to push past the pain and take their bodies to the limit? That’s an issue explored in today’s entertaining Personal Best column by Gina Kolata. She writes:

headline: Largest Bank Will Resume Foreclosure Push in 23 States
text: Bank of America announced on Monday that it would resume home foreclosures in nearly two dozen states, despite the running controversy over how banks handled tens of thousands of cases of homeowners facing eviction.

headline: Sanctions Are Ending For Museum
text: When the National Academy Museum sold two important Hudson River School paintings in 2008 to pay its bills, the Association of Art Museum Directors came down hard with sanctions, making the academy a pariah in the museum world and a symbol for the evils of deaccessioning.

headline: Complaint Box Recap: Meetings, and Those Who Hate Them
text: It’s a pain known to almost every person who has ever held a job: the intense boredom of a useless meeting.

headline: A Superstar Puts One of His Early Influences Back in the Spotlight
text: Early last year Leon Russell was at his home outside Nashville when his telephone rang. It was Elton John, calling from a safari vacation somewhere in Africa.

headline: A Look at Lee’s Walks, the Intentional Ones
text: My article in Monday’s Times about Cliff Lee and his remarkable control had plenty of minutiae, but I was not able to get into something  intriguing. Two of Lee’s 18 walks this season were intentional.

headline: Underwater Homes, Then vs. Now
text: Why the housing market is still a mess, in two maps:

headline: Reliving Schubert’s Classic Tussle With Death
text: Many composers, Stravinsky notably among them, have been inspired by earlier styles and works, which they weave through a contemporary prism. Daniel Kellogg is a current example, reimagining the scores of others in his works.

headline: Two Minutes For Booking: Sports Illustrated’s The Hockey Book
text: Michael Farber had to laugh. Sports Illustrated’s lead hockey writer, who is likely the most erudite of the all those chronicling the game today, had just seen an ad for Sports Illustrated’s new large-format “The Hockey Book,” which listed some of the best-known contributors. The ad listed Farber above the Nobel Prize winning author William Faulkner, whose 1955 Sports Illustrated essay “An Innocent At Rinkside” is included in the book.

headline: South Africa: Condoms Star in a Sex Film With a Message
text: With three goals in mind  to score a political point, to convey a safe-sex message and to make money  a South African producer has made that nation’s first all-black pornographic movie.

headline: Questioning the Guilt of an Executed Father
text: “Frontline” begins its 29th season in a relatively low-key manner. Rather than hot-button topics like the election season, the economy or the financial prospects of the Chilean miners, it looks at the 2004 execution of a Texas man convicted of killing his three children by setting fire to his home.

headline: Sales and Profit Surge for Apple, but Its Margins Slip
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Strong sales of iPads, iPhones and even Mac computers produced record revenue and profit for Apple in its fourth quarter.

headline: In ‘Mad Men,’ She Would Have Been Peggy
text: Before she co-founded the National Women’s Political Caucus, before she wrote “How to Make It in a Man’s World,” and before she had three children, Letty Cottin Pogrebin was Peggy.

headline: Google Car Home GPS App Gets Upgrade
text: With new improvements to a phone app called Car Home, Google is enticing drivers to say, “Goodbye Garmin, uh-uh, TomTom, and get lost, Magellan.”

headline: Bank of America Plans to Resume Foreclosures
text: Curtailing a moratorium sooner than expected, Bank of America announced Monday that it would resume foreclosures by next week in 23 states where court approval was needed to go ahead, The New York Times reports.

headline: I.B.M. Posts 12% Rise in Profit
text: I.B.M. said Monday its third-quarter profit rose by 12 percent as its revenue increased modestly, adding to the evidence that corporate customers are beginning to spend again on computer technology.

headline: Healthy Jets and Happy Ryan Head Into Bye Week
text: Jets Coach Rex Ryan said Monday that he sent his team off into its bye week with hearty congratulations for its 5-1 start, which he said accomplished most of the team goals for the first part of the season. “But I think this team can improve in a lot of areas, and that is what’s so exciting,” Ryan said.

headline: Michelle Obama and Stock Market Fashion
text: In the Economix blog, our colleague Catherine Rampell writes that Michelle Obama’s public fashion choices can boost the stock price of the companies making her clothes: “That is the conclusion of an analysis by David Yermack, of the Stern School of Business at New York University, published by The Harvard Business Review. Ms. Obama wears an outfit, and in (oftentimes correct) anticipation that her get-up will become the latest New Thing, the company that makes those clothes gets a healthy boost in its stock price.”

headline: N.F.L. May Suspend Players for Harsh Hits
text: The N.F.L. will probably impose harsh penalties this week, possibly suspensions, on players involved in damaging hits to the head that left several with concussions and neck injuries on Sunday, Ray Anderson, the league’s executive vice president for football operations, said Monday.

headline: Indie Scene’s Uncomplicated Side
text: A couple of months ago Cults took the stage at the Knitting Factory as if they’d stepped out of a particularly smoky van in the mid-1960s. Their hair was long and stringy. The singer Madeline Follin wore a flowy, shapeless black Elvira dress and did a lot of swaying. She looked a little stern  mad, even  but enchanting. Cults are essentially a two-member band  Ms. Follin and Brian Oblivion, who sings and plays guitar  though during this show they swelled to six, making for a sound far bigger than the group needs. What it needs is basic: the singing of Ms. Follin, seductive and sweet; the chipper xylophone countermelodies that run through many of its songs; and strutting bass lines that recall the swing of 50 years ago. There are other parts to the band’s songs, of which there are currently just a few, but in a short period of time Cults have refined their style, gotten it down cold, made it elegant.

headline: Can a Good Stock Market Help Democrats?
text: The midterm election season has featured a very strong stock market. Since the end of June, the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index is up 14.9 percent.

headline: Proposed Law Could Limit Interstate Wine Shipping
text: SEATTLE

headline: At Tate Modern, Seeds of Discontent by the Ton
text: LONDON  Last Wednesday I had a close encounter with “Sunflower Seeds,” the Chinese artist Ai Weiwei’s oceanic new installation piece in the cavernous Turbine Hall at the Tate Modern here. The work consists of roughly 100 million hand-painted porcelain sunflower seeds covering a vast expanse of floor to the depth of about four inches, and visitors were invited to wade right in. The black-and-white seeds crunched delightfully underfoot, and the whole thing resembled an indoor pebble beach, with people strolling about and then plunking down to sit or recline. One young man had buried himself.

headline: Alderson Coming Back to Finish First Interview
text: Sandy Alderson was scheduled to return to Citi Field on Thursday to complete the first round of his interview process for the Mets’ vacant general manager position, but the team said the meeting was not part of the second round of interviews, in which select candidates will meet with Fred Wilpon, the principal owner, and Saul Katz, the team president.

headline: Artifacts | Fair Trade-Off: Frieze Week in London
text: When Frieze week in London ended yesterday, a collector from New York asked what I liked best about the art fair. There were many reasons to like being there this year, but what stood out in my mind were two exhibitions I saw outside the fair. The Serpentine Gallery hit it out of the park (Hyde Park, that is) with its Klara Liden retrospective, the most affecting show I saw in five days of nonstop art viewing. The other great experience was Christian Marclay’s new 24-hour video, “The Clock,” at White Cube in Mayfair.

headline: A Solid-State Drive for the Road
text: Combine the advances in capacity for solid-state drives with the increases in data transfer speed afforded by the new U.S.B. 3.0 platform, and the result looks something like Iomega’s black slab.

headline: More for ‘The Event,’ ‘Outsourced’ and ‘Law & Order: L.A.’
text: NBC has stepped up to back three of its new programs with full-season orders.

headline: Robin Williams May Play ‘Bengal Tiger’ on Broadway
text: “Bengal Tiger at the Baghdad Zoo,” an Iraq War play by Rajiv Joseph that had an acclaimed production in Los Angeles, may come to Broadway in the spring with Robin Williams in the title role.

headline: In Studying Haiti, a New Angle on an Earthquake’s Intensity
text: When the magnitude 7.0 earthquake struck the Haitian capital, Port-au-Prince, last January, the enormous destruction and loss of life were attributed largely to two factors: the proximity of the city to the fault that caused the shaking, and shoddy construction that allowed thousands of buildings to easily crumble.

headline: Waking in the Clouds to a Chorus of Birds
text: Friday, Oct. 15

headline: You Can Photograph That Federal Building
text: The right of photographers to stand in a public place and take pictures of federal buildings has been upheld by a legal settlement reached in New York.

headline: Tackling the Last of Beethoven’s Sonatas
text: The character of many of Beethoven’s 32 piano sonatas can be evoked by titles like “Tempest” and “Appassionata” or by their witty, brilliant or jovial elements. But the final three sonatas, composed when he was completely deaf, resist easy categorizations.

headline: News Editor Detained by Security Guards for Alaska Senate Candidate
text: 6:06 p.m. | Updated The tumultuous Alaska Senate race thrust itself into the national spotlight again over the weekend, when private security guards hired by Joe Miller, the Republican nominee, handcuffed and detained the editor of an online news site at a campaign event in Anchorage on Sunday.

headline: Booker Prize Winner’s Jewish Question
text: LONDON  A funny thing happened when Howard Jacobson won the Man Booker Prize last Tuesday. Instead of the traditional audience reaction  euphoria from the winner’s entourage, anemic clapping underpinned by envy and bitterness from everyone else  the announcement, over dinner at the Guildhall here, was greeted by loud, sustained applause. A smattering of people who were not even related to Mr. Jacobson stood and cheered.

headline: Not So Sudden Aspen Decline
text: Researchers say that sudden aspen decline, or SAD, appears to have stabilized.

headline: Freud on Madison Avenue, Where Biology Appears as Destiny
text: Sunday night’s season finale of “Mad Men” was so full of the unexpectedly bizarre that it seemed to belong to the world of dreams. Did Don Draper, the emotionally disabled advertising executive, actually cast aside his age-appropriate psychologist girlfriend, Faye Miller, and impulsively ask Megan, his beautiful young secretary of the easy manner and French Canadian heritage, to marry him? If you are a certain kind of “Mad Men” obsessive, like many readers posting comments on nytimes.com, you lost a good deal of your Monday evaluating this question.

headline: Killer of Aspen Slows, but Worries About a Beloved Tree Remain
text: GUNNISON, Colo.  Aspen trees, with their quivering, delicate foliage and the warm glow of color they spread across the high country of the Rocky Mountains this time of year, have an emotional appeal that their stolid, prickly evergreen cousins do not.

headline: A.L.C.S.: Game 3 Preview
text: Jay Schreiber, assistant sports editor of The Times previews Game 3 of the A.L.C.S. match-up between Cliff Lee and Andy Pettitte.

headline: Ray Ozzie, Cloud Advocate, Floats Away From Microsoft
text: 4:16 p.m. | Updated  Added more details about Mr. Ozzie’s exit.

headline: The Caucus Click: Reno, Nev.
text: Members of the Tea Party movement held a rally in Reno, Nev. on Monday to show their support for conservative candidates.

headline: The Eternal Question: Football or Baseball?
text: Viewers largely favored football on Sunday over the baseball playoffs on Fox, choosing to watch NBC’s coverage of the Indianapolis Colts and Washington Redskins game. Although final ratings were not expected to be available until Tuesday, Nielsen’s preliminary overnight estimates for “Sunday Night Football” were up compared with the same night a year ago, when 18.2 million viewers tuned in. Fox, in third place, earned what appeared to be an average audience closer to 8 million for its coverage of Game 2 of baseball’s National League Championship Series between the San Francisco Giants and the Philadelphia Phillies. Fox got a boost in the 7 p.m. hour from an overrun of its afternoon football broadcast. CBS was second on the night behind NBC, garnering 12.9 million viewers at 7 for “60 Minutes” and 12.2 million at 9 for “Undercover Boss.” ABC was fourth.

headline: ‘Dexter’ Watch: Warring Impulses
text: “Dexter” has always been a series that gains more and more momentum as the season progresses, and this one is no exception. Sunday’s episode set off a psychologically intriguing battle between Dexter and the tortured young woman whom Fowler had been holding captive. It is a wise move on the writers’ part because it puts Dexter’s warring impulses of ruthlessness and protectionism in direct, high relief. He wants to save and take care of this bloodied young woman, but of course he can’t just let her out the door and off to Miami General because she has witnessed him murdering her tormentor. He is forced to treat her like one of his victims, injecting her with sedatives and locking her up.

headline: Seatmate, the Problem Wasn’t the Tequila ...
text: I PROBABLY have one of the world’s most enjoyable jobs. I travel around the country talking about tequila.

headline: A U.S.B. Charging Adapter for the iPad
text: If you have a lot of gadgets, you probably have to use a U.S.B. hub to keep all your devices plugged in. The problem is that some devices either won’t won’t charge on a hub.

headline: Live-Blogging the Debate for Governor
text: Good evening, loyal readers, and welcome to one of the most anticipated moments of political theater in recent New York history. Seven — count ’em, seven! — candidates for governor of New York are set to meet face-to-face on Monday at Hofstra University on Long Island for the first and only scheduled debate of this year’s race for governor, and the potential for shock, revelation and self-immolation are high.

headline: Many Views on Recovery; Shared Hate for ‘Glocal’
text: HERE is a look at some of the highlights, lowlights and sidelights from the 100th anniversary conference of the Association of National Advertisers, which a record 1,600 people attended from Wednesday through Saturday in Orlando, Fla.

headline: Hotels Take ‘Locally Grown’ a Logical Step Beyond
text: David Garcelon, a chef, says he enjoys checking on the little alpine strawberries, Malabar spinach, mojito mint and several varieties of wine grapes in his small garden. But he is not out in his backyard; he’s on the 14th-floor roof of the Fairmont Royal York in Toronto, where the view is of the steel, glass and concrete of nearby skyscrapers.

headline: Times in Deal to Expand Texas Report
text: The New York Times announced Monday that it had entered into another local news collaboration, this one with The Texas Tribune, a nonprofit news organization.

headline:
Melvin Lane Powers Is Dead at 68;
Cleared of Murder With Lover-Aunt
text: Candy and Mel. She, the stylishly coifed Houston socialite with the little-girl voice. He, her nephew, half her age and movie-star handsome. In the mid-1960s, Candace Mossler and Melvin Lane Powers may have been the nation’s most notorious couple.

headline: Agents Deported by U.S. Are Honored in Moscow
text: MOSCOW  Russian sleeper agents, arrested in the United States this summer and deported to Russia as part of a prisoner exchange, received top government honors from President Dmitri A. Medvedev on Monday.

headline: Mildred Jefferson, 84, Anti-Abortion Activist, Is Dead
text: Dr. Mildred Jefferson, a prominent, outspoken opponent of abortion and the first black woman to graduate from Harvard Medical School, died Friday at her home in Cambridge, Mass. She was 84.

headline: Patricia Herzog, 88, a Lawyer Who Changed Marital Law, Dies
text: It was an advertisement on a matchbook cover that inspired Patricia Herzog’s legal career and, eventually, led to a significant change in California marital law  allowing one divorcing spouse to be reimbursed for having helped the other obtain an advanced degree.

headline: Names of the Dead

headline: Even More On The Origins of the Deficit
text: I’ve thought of another way to present the data on GDP, spending by all levels of government, and taxes. Let’s look at trends in GDP, spending, and revenues over two periods — one designed to capture “normal” growth, the other the economic crisis.

headline: The Homeowner Wins, Without a Lawyer
text: In a column on Tuesday, I discuss legal arguments regarding whether MERS — Mortgage Electronic Registration Systems — has violated state real estate laws, and note a couple of cases where rulings have gone against it.

text: Is one media company big enough for Barry Diller, Tina Brown and Sidney Harman?

headline: H&R Block May Not Provide Loans
text: H&R Block, the tax-preparation firm, said Monday it might not be able to provide refund loans next year because of a dispute with HSBC Holdings.

headline: Rivals Not the Only Ones Delighted to See the Nets
text: NEWARK  Take a sports team with the worst record and worst attendance in its league. Move it to a new town with a rough reputation. Make it clear in advance that the franchise will stay just a couple of years before relocating again.

headline: Defendant Unfit For Trial In Killing of Psychologist
text: The trial of a 42-year-old man charged with hacking to death an Upper East Side psychologist ended Monday before it had even started when a judge declared a mistrial because two court-appointed psychiatrists found the man mentally unfit to stand trial.

headline: A Spray of DNA to Keep the Robbers Away
