headline: Citi’s Good News Proves Reassuring
text: Vikram Pandit, chief executive of Citigroup, has snatched some of Jamie Dimon’s market momentum. Mr. Dimon, who runs JPMorgan Chase, has lately been setting a comforting tone for the sector’s earnings. But growing foreclosure-related fears overshadowed his bank’s latest decent results. Now, his counterpart at Citigroup seems to be the one reassuring investors.

headline: Advising President Karzai
text: To the Editor:

headline: Reuters Writer Resigns Over Ethics Policy Breach
text: Reuters Breakingviews, the financial news and analysis Web site, disclosed on Monday that one journalist had resigned and two others were under internal review after failing to disclose financial interests in companies they covered.

headline: Lessons in a Life Well Lived
text: If you are fortunate enough to live to 92, you are also unfortunate enough to have few people left from your formative years. Funerals for people in their 90s tend to be sparsely attended affairs, with but a sprinkling of contemporaries and maybe some friends of the children and grandchildren on hand for moral support.

headline: N.F.L. Agrees to Help Ex-Players Who Have A.L.S.
text: The N.F.L. and the players union announced Monday that they would expand qualifications for the 88 Plan, which since 2007 has assisted former players with medical expenses related to dementia, to include amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or Lou Gehrig’s disease.

headline: Seau Is Injured in Crash Only Hours After Arrest
text: The former N.F.L. star linebacker Junior Seau crashed his sport utility vehicle down a steep slope early Monday near Carlsbad, Calif., sustaining minor injuries less than nine hours after he was arrested on suspicion of domestic violence.

headline: Sacrifice, for Fiscal Sanity
text: To the Editor:

headline: Crisis of the Humanities  II
text: The outpouring of passionate, learned and thoughtful comments in response to my column about the demise of French, Italian, Russian, classics and theater at SUNY Albany is a testimony to the hold the idea of the humanities has on so many in our society. The respondents make a number of points, but two are made repeatedly: (1) The humanities not only pay for themselves but help fund the sciences and (2) I dismiss traditional justifications of the humanities — the transmission of the best that has been thought and said, the humanities enhance society, and so on; you could recite them in your sleep — but I myself either have nothing to offer or end by offering a weak version of what I have dismissed.

headline: Rethinking School Reform
text: To the Editor:

headline: Favre’s Time in the League Begins to Feel Borrowed
text: Brett Favre was not clutching his elbow when he was frantically waving that the Dallas Cowboys’ loopy end-of-game lateral fest should not count. That was progress. How much longer Favre will be smiling and celebrating, though, is a question that may be answered this week.

headline: Jobs Says Apple’s Approach Is Better Than Google’s
text: On Monday, I wrote an article about the competition between the iPhone from Apple and smartphones running the Android operating system from Google. The article discussed some of the advantages and disadvantages of Apple’s vertically integrated and closed approach and Android’s more open strategy. It concluded by quoting experts and analysts saying that while Android, and perhaps other systems, are likely to do well, Apple has little reason to worry.

headline: Rutgers Player’s Road to Recovery Has Been Walked
text: When Adam Taliaferro sustained a career-ending spinal cord injury while playing for Penn State in 2000, doctors feared he would not walk again. A year later, he led the Nittany Lions onto the field, jogging in short bursts out of the tunnel.

headline: In Kansas, Climate Skeptics Embrace Cleaner Energy
text: SALINA, Kan.  Residents of this deeply conservative city do not put much stock in scientific predictions of climate change.

headline: Pooling Resources, Two Newsrooms Merge
text: The nonprofit investigative journalism world continues to expand with the announcement on Tuesday that the Center for Public Integrity will absorb the Huffington Post Investigative Fund, a nonprofit journalism arm of The Huffington Post. The move would bring the total headcount at the center to more than 50 employees, making it one of the largest nonprofit investigative newsrooms in the country.

headline: John Force Out to Prove Drag Racers Can Win After 60
text: MOHNTON, Pa.  It was late, and John Force was working out after spending most of the day traveling from California to Pennsylvania for yet another National Hot Rod Association event. In the old days, he would have found another spot at the hotel to relax.

headline: Slugger Who Just Won’t Stop
text: WOODSIDE, Calif.  Willie McCovey is not bothered by the people who are already writing the Giants’ obituary in the wake of their 6-1 loss to the Philadelphia Phillies in Game 2 of the National League Championship Series. Instead, three decades after retiring as one of the Giants’ most beloved players, McCovey continues to set an example on how to quell the doubters.

headline: Facebook Vows to Fix a Flaw in Data Privacy
text: SAN FRANCISCO  When you sign up for Facebook, you enter into a bargain. You share personal information with the site, and Facebook agrees to obey your wishes when it comes to who can see what you post.

headline: Negotiations Fall Apart for Telecom Deal in Mexico
text: MEXICO CITY  When the American company NII Holdings agreed in February to join forces with the giant media company Grupo Televisa to invest in the wireless communications market in Mexico, the partnership appeared to have the financial and political strength to shake up the Mexican mobile market.

headline: Health Care and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance
text: Welcome to Fixes.

headline: Paamco Founders Statement on Judge’s Ruling
text: The hedge-fund investment firm Pacific Alternative Asset Management Company has long portrayed itself as being owned and run by women. But S. Donald Sussman, a financier who has stood behind the firm for years, has challenged that assertion, claiming in a lawsuit that he was due a 40 percent ownership stake. A federal judge ruled in his favor in August and said the firm’s arrangement with Mr. Sussman “may have been designed to mislead.” Here is an e-mailed statement from the firm’s parent company, Paamco Founders, taking issue with some conclusions made by the judge in his ruling.

headline: A Hedge Fund Controlled by Women, So It Claimed
text: Jane Buchan is a rarity in the big-money boys’ club of hedge funds.

headline: From Obama, the Tax Cut Nobody Heard Of
text: HUNTERSVILLE, N.C.  What if a president cut Americans’ income taxes by $116 billion and nobody noticed?

headline: Democrats Are at Odds on Relevance of Keynes
text: WASHINGTON  A rift has emerged within the Democratic Party between liberal economists, who generally view the 2009 stimulus package as a success and say that Keynesian economics should remain the heart of the party’s economic policy, and elected officials, who in growing numbers have shunned affiliation with the $787 billion effort and are expressing doubts about the effectiveness of fiscal intervention.

headline: I.B.M. Rides Global Focus on Services to Deliver a 12% Increase in Profit
text: The leading high-technology industrial companies like Intel, General Electric and I.B.M., which have reported quarterly results in the last several days, are seen by analysts and economists as bellwethers of the economy, because their chips, equipment and services are used in so many industries.

headline: Zambia: Two Chinese Managers Arrested in Mine Shooting
text: Two Chinese citizens  managers at a Chinese-owned Collum Mine  were arrested on Monday and accused of shooting 12 miners who were protesting wages and working conditions at the mine, about 200 miles south of Lusaka, the capital, on Friday. A district commissioner said the managers were charged with attempted murder, according to Agence France-Presse. Two miners were transferred to a hospital.

headline: Israel: Benjamin Netanyahu Warns of Risks to Aircraft Flying Near Gaza
text: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Monday that Israeli aircraft had “a tough time flying near Gaza because there are antiaircraft missiles there.” His first public comments about the missiles came in a speech to Likud Party lawmakers about the need for appropriate security arrangements as part of any peace deal with the Palestinians. Without them, he said, aircraft at Israel’s international airport near Tel Aviv could be at risk. Israeli officials have pointed for some time to what they say is a buildup of advanced weapons, including antiaircraft missiles, in Gaza, which is governed by the militant group Hamas.

headline: Germany: After Merkel’s Comments,president Makes Trip to Turkey
text: On the heels of Chancellor Angela Merkel’s comments about the failure of multiculturalism in Germany, President Christian Wulff traveled to Ankara, Turkey, on Monday for the first official visit in 10 years by a German president. Mr. Wulff, left  who has a history of reaching out to Germany’s four million Muslims, most of whom are Turkish  will address Turkey’s Parliament, where he is expected to focus on economic, cultural and religious issues. He also will visit Islamic sites and will hold talks with the Turkish official in charge of religious affairs. On Saturday, Mrs. Merkel told the annual meeting of young Christian Democrats that multiculturalism in Germany had “utterly failed.”

headline: Democrats Remain Favored to Retain Senate
text: With only 15 days to go until the election, we’re going to be upping the frequency of our forecast updates somewhat.

headline: Half-Dozen N.Y. Races May Help G.O.P. Win House
text: RYE BROOK, N.Y.  New York has turned into a major battleground over the future of the House of Representatives, with Democrats forced to defend at least a half-dozen Congressional seats from unexpectedly strong Republican challenges.

headline: Many Questions on Killing of Pace Student by Police
text: It was the homecoming game, and a reunion of sorts for two childhood friends on the opposing teams. Danroy Henry Jr. was a junior defensive back for the home team, Pace University, in Pleasantville, N.Y. Everyone called him D.J.

headline: Campaign Offers Help to Gay Youths
text: “Middle school was the worst,” Calvin Stowell says in a YouTube video he uploaded on Oct. 1.

headline: James E. Fuchs, Innovator in the Shot-Put, Dies at 82
text: James E. Fuchs, who developed a new way to heave the shot to compensate for a leg injury and used the technique to set world records and dominate shot-putting over two remarkable seasons, died in Manhattan on Oct. 8. He was 82.

headline: Familiar Debate: Use an Ace on Short Rest Or a Besieged Starter
text: On the eve of a pressure-packed Game 4, the manager of the Yankees again answered questions about his beleaguered starter. He trusted him enough to give him the ball for a critical postseason start. No matter how poorly he had pitched, the manager was not changing his mind: Kenny Rogers was going to start.

headline: Meeting Pakistanis, U.S. Will Try to Fix Relations
text: WASHINGTON  As Pakistani civilian and military leaders arrive here this week for high-level meetings, the Obama administration will begin trying to mend a relationship badly damaged by the American military’s tough new stance in the region.

headline: Sorkin: Felix Rohatyn Looks Back, and Sighs
text: In his DealBook column, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes about a conversation with Felix Rohatyn, the veteran investment banker who helped save New York City from bankruptcy in the 1970s, advised RJR Nabisco on its sale to Kohlberg Kravis Roberts in the 1980s and sold Columbia Pictures to Sony in the 1990s.

headline: To Lower Violence, Escalate the Penalty
text: The violence in the N.F.L. continues. Week after week, season after season, we see debilitating injuries from crushing tackles and brain-rattling hits.

headline: As Yankees Grit Teeth, A Ranger Just Smiles
text: Those tracking the angst over whether A. J. Burnett should start Game 4 of the American League Championship Series for the Yankees may be surprised to learn that there is another starting pitcher in the game.

headline: Freddy Sez, the Yankees’ Pan-Banging Mascot, Dies at 85
text: Freddy Schuman, who with one eye, one tooth and several old frying pans and spoons turned his love of the New York Yankees into a full-time occupation as the team’s unofficial mascot, becoming one of the wackiest and unlikeliest cheerleaders of a baseball empire not known for wackiness, died Sunday afternoon at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 85 years old.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Officials Push to Bolster Law on Wiretapping
text: WASHINGTON  Law enforcement and counterterrorism officials, citing lapses in compliance with surveillance orders, are pushing to overhaul a federal law that requires phone and broadband carriers to ensure that their networks can be wiretapped, federal officials say.

headline: California’s Crystal Cathedral Files for Bankruptcy
text: Crystal Cathedral, the landmark megachurch in Orange County, Calif., where the “Hour of Power” is taped, filed for bankruptcy protection, church officials announced Monday.

headline: Ruling on Health Law Is Due by End of Year
text: RICHMOND, Va.  A federal judge said Monday that he would rule by the end of the year on the constitutionality of the new health care law, as lawyers for the Obama administration and the Commonwealth of Virginia debated whether the entire 2,700-page act should be invalidated if a key provision is struck down.

headline: Religion Moves to Forefront in Kentucky
text: It’s fair to say things are getting increasingly hot in Kentucky’s Senate contest.

headline: Angle’s Edge in War Chest Evaporates
text: Sharron Angle, the Tea Party-backed candidate hoping to take down Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, shocked many in the political world last week when she announced she had raised a remarkable $14 million during the third quarter.

headline: O’Reilly Embraces Role, Because It Puts Her on Field
text: At one time, Heather O’Reilly was the goal-scoring ingénue of the United States women’s soccer program.

headline: Tuesday: Crossword Face-Off
text: We’ve got a double dose of Fred Piscop today — his Tuesday puzzle and another used for a contest with the New York Islanders (below).

headline: Building a Clean-Energy Movement in the Heartland
text: Global warming has few believers in a deeply conservative region of Kansas, so a nonprofit group avoided the issue and instead invoked patriotism, thrift, job creation and religion to persuade residents to save energy.

headline: Phillies in No Rush to Discuss Short Rest
text: SAN FRANCISCO  All through the Yankees’ postseason run, fans have fretted over A. J. Burnett, and whether he would actually make a start. For the Philadelphia Phillies, the right-hander Joe Blanton plays the part of Burnett. He may start Game 4 on Wednesday, or he may not.

headline: Checking the Statements in the Debate
text: With seven candidates crammed on a stage, the format for the debate on Monday night among those running for governor of New York was hardly ideal for the kind of thrusting and parrying on issues that is usually the hallmark of such encounters. Still, there were enough moments in the 90-minute debate for Carl P. Paladino, the Republican nominee, and Andrew M. Cuomo, the Democratic nominee, to make many claims  including some that were either exaggerations or deserving of additional explanation.

headline: Binghamton Avoids Major Sanctions
text: Binghamton University acknowledged Monday that its men’s basketball program had made mistakes but said that the N.C.A.A.’s investigation had been closed with no major violations found.

headline: Albany Governor Debate Verges on Farce
text: The moderators’ questions were frequently ignored. The candidates barely looked at one another. One wore black gloves and spoke of himself repeatedly in the third person. And Andrew M. Cuomo, the Democratic candidate and the race’s front-runner, at times struggled to suppress laughter.

headline: Time to Talk to the Taliban
text: SPECULATION is growing both inside and outside Afghanistan that the government in Kabul is about to open reconciliation talks with the Taliban. Indeed, Taliban leaders, however hesitantly, are beginning to look at alternatives to fighting. They no doubt realize that a military victory is as remote and as hard to define for them as it appears to be for President Hamid Karzai and his NATO allies.

headline: Good News and Bad for St. John’s
text: The long-term future of the St. John’s program received a glimmer of hope Monday, but the immediate future of this year’s team took a dark turn. The Red Storm got its fourth commitment from a top-100 recruit when Dom Pointer, a forward from Michigan, chose St. John’s.

headline: Poll Shows Big Leads for Gillibrand and Schumer
text: Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand holds a significant lead over her Republican opponent, Joseph J. DioGuardi, in New York’s United States Senate race, according to a New York Times poll.

headline: Corrections

headline: U.S. Agrees to Uphold Right to Photograph Near Its Buildings
text: It is O.K. to take photos while standing in public spaces near federal buildings, after all. In a settlement with the New York Civil Liberties Union reached Monday, the federal government agreed to instruct its employees in writing of the “public’s general right to photograph the exterior of federal courthouses from publicly accessible spaces” and to remind them that “there are currently no general security regulations prohibiting exterior photography by individuals from publicly accessible spaces, absent a written local rule, regulation or order.”

headline: Don’t Follow the Money
text: Over the past few months, there’s been a torrent of commentary about political donations and campaign spending. This lavish coverage is based on the premise that campaign spending has an important influence on elections.

headline: China Plans to Reduce Its Exports of Minerals
text: HONG KONG — The Chinese government plans a further reduction, of up to 30 percent, next year in its quotas for exports of rare earth minerals, in an attempt to conserve dwindling reserves of the materials, the official newspaper China Daily said Tuesday.

headline: Bike Riders in New York Win Settlement
text: The city agreed on Monday to pay nearly $1 million to participants in the monthly Critical Mass bicycle rides who claimed they had been wrongly detained and arrested by police officers.

headline: That Sinking Feeling
text: Barack Obama seems to think he’s done a pretty terrific job as president, but maybe he hasn’t trumpeted his accomplishments effectively enough.

headline: A.L.C.S. Game 3 Final: Rangers 8, Yankees 0
text: For the Yankees Monday night, Andy Pettitte was great and the bullpen was dreadful. But the way Cliff Lee pitched for the Rangers, it probably didn’t matter that the Yankees’ bullpen imploded by giving up six runs in the ninth inning.

headline: Tough Road for Tea Party in Democratic Delaware
text: NEWARK, Del. — An unexpected win by a Tea Party candidate here has given Democrats hope of winning a seat that Republicans were once confident they could count in their column.

headline: Links to Obama at Play in Race in Illinois
text: WINNETKA, Ill.  When Dan Seals, a Democratic candidate for Congress, attended an event for President Obama in Chicago a few months ago, someone suggested that if he stepped into the cordoned-off streets, the crowd might mistake him for the president.

headline: Newcomer’s Money and Ads Grab Attention in California
text: RANCHO CORDOVA, Calif.  A year ago, Representative Dan Lungren said he had no idea who Dr. Ami Bera was, and he is pretty certain some of his constituents in California’s Third District are still confused.

headline: Democrats’ Grip on the South Continues to Slip
text: JONESBORO, Ark. — The Southern white Democrat, long on the endangered list, is at risk of being pushed one step closer to extinction.

headline: The Court’s Pre-emption Test
text: In the Supreme Court last week, oral arguments in a case called Bruesewitz v. Wyeth turned on the meaning of the word “unavoidable,” but the real issue was something much bigger. The case is about whether the family of a girl, who they said was badly injured by a vaccine, can sue the manufacturer in a state court. Or are they barred by a 24-year-old federal law that blocks this sort of lawsuit if “the injury or death resulted from side effects that were unavoidable?”

headline: Tribune Is Said to Seek Chief’s Resignation
text: The board of directors of the Tribune Company is expected to ask Tuesday for the resignation of Randy Michaels, the controversial chief executive of the company, according to a person directly involved in the matter.

headline: France, the Unions and Fiscal Reality
text: France has been rocked by strikes and protest marches over President Nicolas Sarkozy’s plans to raise the legal retirement age from 60 to 62. Social Security reform is a difficult issue everywhere, and the brash and increasingly unpopular Mr. Sarkozy has not made much of an effort to woo union support. Yet raising France’s retirement age is an urgent necessity.

headline: Since Big Branch
text: Nine American miners have been killed in eight little-noted accidents since April, when an explosion in rural West Virginia left 29 dead. Lawmakers, claiming to be scandalized by the failures in safety enforcement, vowed sweeping reforms. That’s all they’ve done.

headline: Hickory Rain
text: It’s well before light, and I’m listening to the rain, watching every now and then the flicker of headlights coming down the hill. I no longer have custody of Ethel the border terrier, so I’m up early on my own.

headline: The Southern Democrat
text: From Virginia to Florida and South Carolina to Texas, nearly two dozen Democratic seats are susceptible to a potential Republican surge in Congressional races on Election Day.

headline: Yankees Put Up a Big Number, but Put It in the Wrong Column
text: The most startling moment of Cliff Lee’s masterful and unprecedented performance in Game 3 of the American League Championship Series happened in the fourth inning. Lee, who had retired the game’s first 11 batters, walked Mark Teixeira on a full count  his first walk in 20 postseason innings this season.

headline: Against Lee, Yankees Swing and Miss, Again
text: In a detailed look at Cliff Lee’s regular season, a few numbers jump out. The seven complete games. Eighteen walks. A full workload of 212 1/3 innings. So does this nugget: He gave up eight runs to light-hitting San Diego, and eight more in a start against Baltimore.

headline: With Gift, Harvard to Study Institutional Corruption
text: In this age of great corporate scandals, business schools have understandably ratcheted up their focus on corporate ethics in recent years.  But what about when people generally follow the rules — and bad things still happen?

headline: California: Judge Signals She’ll Let Ruling on Military Policy Stand
text: A federal district judge in California said Monday that she is inclined to deny the government’s request to allow the Pentagon to enforce its “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy on gay and bisexual members of the military while her injunction against it is being appealed. “My tentative ruling is to deny the application for a stay,” Judge Virginia A. Phillips said at a hearing on the government’s request, according to Reuters. She is expected to issue a ruling to that effect on Tuesday. The Obama administration has defended the law, arguing that change should come from Congress, not the courts; last week the Department of Justice gave notice that if the request for a stay was denied or not resolved by Monday at noon, it intended to appeal to the Ninth Circuit “to allow the orderly litigation of the stay request before that court.”

headline: A.L.C.S. Game 3 Replay, Oct. 18
text: A look at Game 3 of the American League Championship Series between the Yankees and the Texas Rangers at Yankee Stadium.

headline: Nevada: Lake Mead Dips to a Low
text: The water level in Lake Mead, the massive reservoir that fills the taps of millions of people across the Southwest, has reached a record low, the federal Bureau of Reclamation says. Even as thunderstorms dropped rain on the Las Vegas area, Lake Mead’s level dropped to 1,083.18 feet above sea level just before noon on Sunday, and fell farther, to 1,083.09 feet, by Monday morning. Lake Mead is still eight feet above the level at which rationing could go into effect in Nevada and Arizona, and well above the levels at which Hoover Dam’s hydroelectric output might be seriously jeopardized. But Barry Nelson, a senior policy analyst for the Natural Resources Defense Council, said: “This strikes me as such an amazing moment. It’s three-quarters of a century since they filled it, and at the three-quarter-century mark, the world has changed.”

headline: Bloggingheads: Christians & Gay Suicide
text: Emily Bazelon, left, of Slate and Ann Althouse of the University of Wisconsin Law School debate the sources of recent suicides by gay teens.

headline: At the Mayo Clinic: The Orthopedist and Hockey Parent
text: ROCHESTER, Minn.–Dr. Michael J. Stuart, one of the organizers of this week’s conference on head injuries at the Mayo Clinic (the Ice Hockey Summit: Action on Concussion, the conference is officially called) has impeccable credentials to be among those in charge of such an important gathering of medical researchers and hockey officials. He is a professor of orthopedics and co-director of sports medicine at the Mayo Clinic, as well as chief medical officer of USA Hockey and team doctor for the 2010 men’s Olympic team.

headline: On Post-Marathon Monday, Please, Just Say Congratulations

headline: How Cliff Lee’s Start Compares in Postseason History
text: After Cliff Lee silenced the Yankees in an eight-inning, 13-strikeout masterpiece Monday night, Curtis Granderson was asked whether he had ever been part of a better-pitched game. Nothing specific came to mind, but Granderson said a few other performances trumped Lee’s. Maybe so, but let’s take a look at just how dominant Lee was on Monday. With the help of Baseball-reference.com, I tried putting Lee’s outing in context in postseason history.

headline: Do You Support or Oppose the Death Penalty?
text: A trial in which a man was convicted in a triple murder case has just entered the penalty phase. Jurors are deliberating between two sentences: life in prison without parole and and the death penalty. Do you support or oppose the use of the death penalty? Why?

headline: CME Group Begins Clearing Interest Rate Swaps
text: The CME Group has begun providing clearing to the $400 trillion market for interest rate swaps, the largest of the opaque markets for which lawmakers are requiring more transparency.

text: Silicon Valley financiers got the Hollywood treatment in “Social Network,” the new film about Facebook, but the courtship between the technology and entertainment hubs has heated up with venture capital deal values in Los Angeles nearly doubling this year, Reuters reports.

headline: Reviewing Penalties in Jets-Broncos Game

headline: Where to Find an Autumn Seafood Special in Hong Kong
text: It’s autumn in Hong Kong, and that means peak season for a quintessentially Chinese delicacy: the hairy crab. As fall arrives, the crabs plump up, and restaurants stock them in huge numbers. Those cooking at home can buy live crabs, the little bundles bound up with bamboo strips, from specialty stores and even street vendors.

headline: Investors Cautious on Enel Green Power I.P.O.
