headline: Candover Expected to Drop Parques Reunidos Sale
text: Candover is close to canceling its plans to sell or make an offering of Parques Reunidos, the Spanish theme-park operator, after a string of disappointing bids from rival private equity firms, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Former Goldman Trader Said to Raise $1 Billion
text: Pierre-Henri Flamand, the former London-based head of Goldman Sachs‘s principal strategies group, has raised more than $1 billion in capital and commitments for his new hedge fund, Edoma Capital, MarketWatch reported, citing a person with knowledge of the matter.

headline: Seven Steps to Managing Your Online Reputation
text: A camera-store salesman recently steered me away from the compact, ultrahigh-tech camera I thought I wanted. Smaller is fine, he told me, but only if it fits in your pocket — any bigger will end up hanging from your shoulder anyway, so what’s the advantage? And don’t buy based on fancy features, he added; the differences between comparable models rarely result in better pictures for amateurs. The one feature you’ll really appreciate, he said, is how the camera feels in your hand.

headline: Private Equity Group Starts Fund in Iraq
text: MerchantBridge, a global private equity group, has started an equity fund in Iraq and plans to close a deal in Saudi Arabia worth up to $100 million in early 2011, its chief operating officer has said.

headline: Blacks Leisure of Britain in Takeover Talks
text: Blacks Leisure, the British outdoor goods retailer, said on Tuesday that it was in takeover talks — reportedly with two or more private equity firms — and its shares climbed more than 25 percent.

headline: Bank of America Reports $7.3 Billion Loss, Citing Charges
text: Bank of America, the nation’s biggest bank, announced Tuesday that operating profit rebounded in the third quarter, helped by improved credit conditions among consumers and businesses.

headline: For Goldman, a Problem of Trust?
text: Goldman Sachs, it appears, may have a slight trust problem.

headline: BofA Posts $7.3 Billion Loss on One-Time Charge
text: 7:35 a.m. | Updated The New York Times’s Nelson D. Schwartz has more on Bank of America’s third-quarter earnings.

headline: China Fund Said to Plan Office in Hong Kong
text: The China Investment Corporation is opening a Hong Kong office, the fund’s first ever business operation outside of mainland China, Reuters reported, citing people with direct knowledge of the matter.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: –Following Angelo R. Mozilo’s settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission, David Weidner wrote for MarketWatch that “regulators can look back on a decade where the biggest crook they outed and put behind bars was Martha Stewart.”

headline: Where Do You Draw the Line on Head Hunting in the N.F.L.?
text: Before the 2009 season, the N.F.L. put in new rules to protect defenseless receivers from head shots, then they expanded protections before this season. (Not that it guaranteed anything, given the hits by Brandon Meriweather on Todd Heap, Dunta Robinson on DeSean Jackson and James Harrison on Mohamed Massaquoi during Week 6.)

headline: Tea Parties, Independents and Conservative Reform
text: In yesterday’s column, I suggested that the Tea Party message — in its anti-spending, anti-deficit form, at least, rather than its “repeal the 17th amendment” manifestation — has a stronger resonance with swing voters and independents that some of the other, bygone irruptions of right-wing populism (the Liberty League, the John Birchers, etc.) to which the Tea Partiers are frequently compared. David Frum took issue with this argument, citing Jonathan Rauch’s recent piece on the changing composition of independent voters to argue that many of the “independents” tilting Republican this election cycle are really just right-wing voters who were disillusioned with the G.O.P., rather than the kind of middle-of-the-roaders that the party needs to rebuild a durable majority. Here’s Frum, summarizing Rauch:

headline: New York Times Co. Posts $4.3 Million Loss
text: The New York Times Company on Tuesday reported a $4.3 million net loss for the third quarter as advertising and circulation revenue declined, and charges at The Boston Globe weighed on the bottom line. That result, which translates into a loss of about 3 cents a share, was an improvement from the period a year ago, when losses were 25 cents a share.

headline: A Cheaper Route to Solar Cells
text: A company that secured a Department of Energy grant to pursue a breakthrough idea in the manufacture of solar cells plans to announce on Tuesday that it has raised $20 million to commercialize its technique, which it says will reduce the price of solar panels by 40 percent.

headline: Parallel Problems
text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

headline: Parallel Problems
text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

headline: The Next Great Schism: Faith of Cartoon Character Is Debated
text: Nobody tell the Reverend Lovejoy, but Homer Simpson, the patriarch of the animated clan on Fox’s “The Simpsons,” is Catholic — at least, according to the official newspaper of the Vatican, Reuters reported. In an essay published over the weekend in the newspaper, L’Osservatore Romano, Luca M. Possati writes: “Few people know it, and he does everything to hide it. But it’s true: Homer J. Simpson is Catholic.” As proof the essay cites a Jesuit priest’s study of the 2005 “Simpsons” episode “The Father, the Son and the Holy Guest Star,” in which Bart attends a Catholic school and Homer tries out the practice of confession. The study concludes that “The Simpsons” is “among the few TV programs for kids in which Christian faith, religion and questions about God are recurrent themes.” (Never mind that Homer has said he is a follower of “that religion with all the well-meaning rules that don’t work out in real life,” which he explains to mean Christianity.)

headline: Bring Your Questions on the Foreclosure Crisis
text: 12:10 p.m., Oct. 21 | Updated  Mr. Lawler’s responses to reader questions are posted here and here.

headline: James Cameron on ‘Avatar,’ ‘Titanic,’ Cleopatra and the Future of 3-D
text: Nearly a year after his movie “Avatar” broke box-office records and opened up a floodgate of big-budget 3-D features, James Cameron is still very much immersed in his budding science-fiction franchise and the medium of 3-D filmmaking. On Nov. 16 20th Century Fox Home Entertainment will release a special extended collector’s edition of “Avatar” on DVD and Blu-ray, including a longer cut of the film and nearly an hour of deleted scenes, among other bonus features.

headline: Shares End Sharply Lower on Wall Street
text: Stocks fell sharply on Wall Street on Tuesday and the dollar rose after a surprise interest rate increase by China’s central bank suggested that growth in the world’s second largest economy after the United States could slow.

headline: Video of Chechnya Attack Aftermath
text: As my colleague Michael Schwirtz reports, a deadly attack on the Chechen Parliament in Grozny on Tuesday showed that the capital city of a region where separatist rebels have been quelled is still not entirely safe for local authorities loyal to Russia.

headline: Strikes Force Travelers to Weave a Tangled Web Through Paris
text: PARIS  International travelers passing through Paris faced disruptions on Tuesday because of strikes by public transport workers and air traffic controllers. But airlines said they were striving to maintain most, if not all, of their international flights to and from the French capital.

headline: Outsiders Steal Show at Debate
text: What we’re reading about this morning.

headline: Traffic Stopping | Freeway Eyewear
text: “Sunglasses are symbolic of life in Los Angeles,” says the California native and first-time eyewear designer Alex Israel. His collection, aptly called Freeway, includes five styles named after Route 1, Interstate 15, and the 10, 110 and 405 freeways. Each model was designed “to literally represent the landscape,” Israel says. “Like, the 405 freeway covers territory from San Diego to Brentwood; the shape of the frame is a classic Kurt Cobain meets Jackie Kennedy. I envision the glasses on San Diego punk kids and Brentwood moms.” If you can’t beat the traffic, stop it. Grab a pair of modestly cool sunglasses from Freeway out of the glove compartment and have all eyes on you.Freeway Eyewear is available at Gagosian Shop, Barneys and Maxfield.

headline: Tough Transit in Paris
text: Business travelers and tourists moving through Paris are used to the occasional and unexpected work stoppage interfering with their visits. But today’s demonstrations and strikes are especially widespread, affecting all kinds of transportation in the city — and even tourists on foot, who might encounter police barricades and marchers blocking their path to well-known sights. Nicola Clark at The International Herald Tribune in Paris is keeping an eye on French travel activity.

headline: The Early Word: 14 Days to Go
text: With two weeks left until Election Day, where are Democrats on the defensive as Republicans make a push to take over the House?

headline: China Raises Rates
text: As if to illustrate my point about the non-equivalence of the United States and China: China raises interest rates.

headline: Night Watch: New York’s Debate
text: The Web was ablaze Monday night with reactions to the New York gubernatorial debate, which was alternately called a seven-ring circus and an “SNL” parody waiting to happen.

headline: Treasury to Sell More Citigroup Shares
text: The great government clearance sale of financial stocks continues.

headline: American Speech: Hotel Slang (1939)
text: by William Stewart Cornyn

headline: All Is Not Lost for Texans, or  Cowboys
text: The Cowboys aren’t just any 1-4 team. Their statistics suggest they’re capable of making a run to the playoffs. And the Texans might have had a watershed moment against Kansas City.

headline: The Ultimate Formula One Slot-Car Track
text: Subsumed by the Nascar juggernaut, Formula One barely registers on the radar of most American motorsport fans, lending wheel-to-open-wheel racing a dose of underground cachet. It is so underground, in fact, that one Michigan man channeled his love of Formula One into a veritable basement fight club.

headline: Musical Chairs: Morgan Eyes Goldman’s Old Building
text: In its quest to consolidate its Manhattan office space, could Morgan Stanley choose its archrival’s old headquarters?

headline: Horrors! Adrien Brody Sues to Stop Release of Dario Argento Film
text: He didn’t stand in the way of “The Village” or “Predators,” but Adrien Brody doesn’t want anyone to see a new horror movie he stars in and which is slated to be released Tuesday on DVD. Mr. Brody, the Academy Award-winning star of “The Pianist,” has filed suit against the makers of “Giallo,” an Italian horror movie directed by Dario Argento, whose past films include “Suspiria,” The Hollywood Reporter said.

headline: Tuesday Reading: The Latest on the Foreclosure Crisis
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Rooney Latest United Star to Split With Ferguson
text: In 2004, Wayne Rooney made his Manchester United debut against a Turkish team at Old Trafford in the Champions League and scored a scintillating hat trick, an audacious sign of things to come. Now, six years later, Rooney will sit out the team’s Champions League group match against another Turkish team, Bursaspor, on Wednesday, and said he wants to leave the club where he has starred for six seasons.

headline: Monserrate Indicted on Federal Corruption Charges
text: Former State Senator Hiram Monserrate, who was expelled from office earlier this year and whose conduct was held up as an example of Albany’s dysfunction, was indicted on Tuesday on federal charges that accuse him of using workers at a Queens nonprofit group he financed to aid in his Senate campaign.

headline: Jeter Vaguely Recalls Yanks Coming Back Before
text: In their glorious run in the past generation, the Yankees have come back from crushing losses and jolting injuries, but rarely have they suffered both on the same night.

headline: Moktada, Moktada, Moktada
text: BAGHDAD — Iraq’s parliament has met for only 17 minutes since national elections in March, but that doesn’t mean changes aren’t afoot in the great hall of government.

headline: Asked & Answered | Leong Leong
text: The first collaborative project by the architects Chris and Dominic Leong’s was a tree fort with their father in the backyard of their childhood home. Nowadays, using slightly more advanced forms of sticks and stones, the brothers behind the New York-based design firm Leong Leong are doing projects with the likes of Opening Ceremony and Phillip Lim.

headline: Ariel Sharon Is Subject of Sculpture in Israeli Exhibition
text: A life-size sculpture of Ariel Sharon, the former Israeli prime minister who suffered a debilitating stroke in 2006, will be put on display in a gallery in Tel Aviv, BBC News reported. The sculpture, by the Israeli artist Noam Braslavsky, depicts Mr. Sharon in a hospital bed with his eyes open and his chest rising up and down as the work appears to breathe. Mr. Sharon, who never regained consciousness after his stroke, remains hospitalized in Tel Aviv.

headline: A Ghost Town in China
text: In Ordos, China, there is just one thing largely missing in the city’s new and extravagant central district: people.

headline: A Gray Market in Real Estate
text: ORDOS, China  As the real estate action in Kangbashi New Area reached a fevered pitch last year, banks that are controlled by the national government, concerned about overbuilding, began restricting loans to property developers here.

headline: Chinese City Has Many Buildings, but Few People
text: ORDOS, China  By many measures, this resource-rich city in northern China is a fabulous success.

headline: Caregiving Without Siblings
text: In some ways, Regina Milgram-Bossong acknowledges, she has it easy. Her parents live nearby in central New Jersey. Despite the usual run of late-life health problems — her father, 84, is diabetic and has had a hip replacement; her mother survived ovarian cancer and last year underwent heart valve surgery — they’re still managing well in the house where Ms. Milgram-Bossong grew up.

headline: After Sweat Lodge Deaths, Fewer Tourists With Spiritual Needs
text: SEDONA, Ariz.  There is negative energy in the air here, which the channelers, mystics, healers, psychics and other New Age practitioners of Sedona are grappling to identify and snuff out. It has to do with the recent dearth of visitors to this spiritual oasis in search of enlightenment.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Video: Starbucks of the Future – USA TodayStarbucks, in its evolve-or-die mode, is targeting dinner. Actual food on actual china. Cheeses. Cured meats. Beer. Wine. (Everything roasted to within an inch of its life?) – Glenn Collins

headline: At the Mayo Clinic: The N.H.L. vs. the N.F.L.
text: ROCHESTER, Minn. — For those who follow hockey closely but not the National Football League, the news that the N.F.L. is “considering” suspensions after a series of severely injurious helmet-to-helmet hits is astonishing — and highlights the comparatively progressive stance of the N.H.L. in its longstanding policy of levying suspensions for dangerous plays. The three-game suspension of Shane Doan of Phoenix, handed down Monday, for his egregious sideswipe of Anaheim’s Dan Sexton is an example of the N.H.L.’s policy in practice — in particular its new rule against blindside hits to the head, for which this suspension is the stiffest so far:

headline: China Raises Rates, Jolting World Markets
text: BEIJING — A surprise announcement by China’s central bank that it would raise interest rates for the first time in nearly three years jolted world financial markets Tuesday, as investors worried that China, the world’s second-largest economy after the United States, could slow and crimp the global recovery.

headline: A Question of Appearances: Obama Will Bypass Sikh Temple on Visit to India
text: NEW DELHI  The Golden Temple, a sprawling and serene complex of gleaming gold and polished marble that is the spiritual center of the Sikh religion, is one of India’s most popular tourist attractions. Revered by Indians of all faiths, it is a cherished emblem of India’s religious diversity. So it was no surprise when the gold-plated marvel was promoted as the likely third stop on President Obama’s visit to India, scheduled for early November.

headline: Hearing the Voice of a 51-Year-Old Man in the Essay of a 17-Year-Old Girl
text: When I worked in admissions at Duke, I said a lot of things on the recruiting trail that weren’t exactly genuine: “Your combined SAT scores are in triple digits? Apply!” “We can’t get enough kids from northern New Jersey! Apply!” “You got a bunch of C’s in high school — at least you got a B in weight-lifting! Apply!”

headline: At the Mayo Clinic: N.H.L. Concussions, Blow by Blow
text: ROCHESTER, Minn. — Some remarkable statistics were presented in Tuesday’s morning session of the Mayo Clinic conference on concussion in hockey.

headline: Preparing Kids for the Unknown
text: There are many reasons not to start the push toward college before your child is even in preschool. You know most of them, but here’s one you might not have thought of: There is no point in pushing children, because by the time today’s toddlers turn 18, college — along with the book-based world for which college prepares you — will be an obsolete relic.

headline: Saudi Prince Convicted of Murder in London
text: Updated | 2:17 p.m. On Tuesday, a court in London found a 34-year-old Saudi prince guilty of murdering a man he described as his servant in a luxury hotel there in February, the BBC reports.

headline: On Our Radar: A Super Typhoon
text: Super Typhoon Megi heads toward China after making landfall in the Philippines. Winds peaked at 178 miles per hour, making Megi the most intense tropical storm of the season; the cyclone is expected to regain strength as it crosses the South China Sea. [NASA]

headline: Energy Action Amid Climate Discord
text: I encourage you to read “In Kansas, Climate Skeptics Embrace Cleaner Energy,” Leslie Kaufman’s excellent story on enthusiastic energy-saving initiatives in a community largely resistant to the “climate crisis.”

headline: Nature Called, and Paladino Answered
text: In a debate filled with bizarre moments, it was certainly among the strangest: Carl P. Paladino’s clumsy waltz offstage in the middle of the closing statements in search of a bathroom.

headline: A Photo-Sharing App With Bigger Aspirations
text: For many people, the iPhone camera — always in your pocket — is fast replacing digital cameras. And with the help of a bunch of applications, the pictures can look even better than typical photos.

headline: Weighing Secured Lenders’ Recent Setbacks
text: Stephen J. Lubben writes about bankruptcy and debt issues for DealBook.

headline: A Broadway Welcome to ‘Normal Heart’
text: Joe Mantello, Glenn Close, Michael Stuhlbarg and the rest of the cast of the Broadway reading of Larry Kramer’s “Normal Heart” drew a solid standing ovation after its performance on Monday night, which raised $150,000 for charity. But then the director Joel Grey stepped onto the stage half-tugging Mr. Kramer to come out for a bow, and a chorus of hosannas rose within the packed Walter Kerr Theater. Mr. Kramer hugged Mr. Grey, then Mr. Mantello, then took a step or two backward as if reeling from the adulation.

headline: The Ethics of Using Airport Outlets
text: With all the electronic devices we now carry when we travel, finding a good seat at the airport gate is often all about making sure to be near an electrical outlet, if you can find one. But finding an outlet and actually being able to use it can be different stories.

headline: The Readers Behind Bars Put Books to Many Uses
text: Avi Steinberg’s memoir, “Running the Books,” about his job as a prison librarian at “the Bay”  the Suffolk County House of Correction in South Bay near Boston  gets off to an obnoxious start.

headline: Letty, Groucho, Flirting and Sexism in the ’60s
text: At the home of Letty Cottin Pogrebin, once a “Mad Men”-era up-and-comer in the publishing field, now a renowned feminist, are several scrapbooks that could well have been the basis for several of the show’s plot lines. She shared them with me as we watched the final episode together Sunday night, which I wrote about in Tuesday’s Big City column.

headline: Fernandez Warming to Portland?
text: Rudy Fernandez hasn’t been shy in letting the Portland Trail Blazers and the world know he is unhappy and homesick.

headline: You’re the Boss: Seven Steps to Managing Your Online Reputation
text: The You’re the Boss blog, which is about running a small business, takes a look at how B&H, the online electronics store, manages its customer service department.

headline: Notes From the Underground | Geo Wyeth
text: Geo Wyeth took the stage at Cameo in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, last week, performing a set of heartfelt, otherworldly tunes, accompanied by his band Jive Grave. Although he stuck mostly to the guitar and a microphone in this particular show, Wyeth is known for his chops on the piano, the accordion and an array of other instruments. A native New Yorker, Wyeth can be seen performing at venues all over the city with his various acts.

headline: Doubting Homer Proclaimed a Catholic by Vatican Newspaper
text: As my colleague Dave Itzkoff reports on our Arts Beat blog, an author for the Vatican’s newspaper, L’Osservatore Romano, has been reading between the pixels of America’s most popular animated sitcom and come to the surprising conclusion that, “Few people know it, and he does everything to hide it, but it’s true: Homer J. Simpson is Catholic.”

headline: Keeping Score: What the Future May Hold for Giants’ and Phillies’ Pitchers
text: Starting pitching captured much attention going into the 2010 National League Championship Series, and with good reason: Philadelphia’s top three starters (Roy Halladay, Roy Oswalt and Cole Hamels) are all current or former Cy Young Award candidates, while San Francisco has three young hurlers (Tim Lincecum, Matt Cain and Jonathan Sanchez) who combined for 42 wins and a 3.22 earned run average this season.

headline: Your Health Benefits
text: As we head into the open enrollment season, we’re interested in hearing what you are finding as you review your company’s benefit packages.

headline: Ad Hits Reid for Living at the Ritz
text: If there was a political attack that could have been predicted, it has to be this one: national Republicans are hitting Senator Harry Reid, the majority leader from Nevada, for living at the Ritz-Carlton.

headline: 2012 Nissan GT-R to Have ‘Enhanced Performance’
text: Nissan announced on Monday that its ultra-performance GT-R sports coupe would be getting a makeover for the 2012 model year.

headline: Showdown in the Battle of Two Combat Games
text: Playing Medal of Honor, the new military combat game from Electronic Arts, I couldn’t stop thinking two things. First, E.A. is supposed to be better than this. And second, Activision and Call of Duty don’t have much to worry about.

headline: Cliff Lee’s All-Thesaurus Pitching Performance
text: As the sports journalism world tries to produce words worthy of Cliff Lee’s latest otherworldly pitching performance  which has the unlikely Texas Rangers tripping panic buttons all over the Yankee dynasty  it’s hard not to wonder what Lee could accomplish if his talents transcended baseball. Perhaps he could tackle the health care system. Or the tax code. Solving the strikes in France? The Fox-Cablevision dispute?

headline: Global Weirding: New York Non-Political Edition
text: The theme of the day is weird. As in: Jimmy McMillan weird. (He is certainly the favorite of the blogs. Mr. McMillan, a Vietnam vet, told the Daily Politics that his black gloves are worn as part of trauma he experienced with Agent Orange.)

headline: ‘Running the Books’
text: Chapter 1: The up & up and low low

headline: O’Donnell Questions Church-State Separation
text: Click to Listen: WDEL 1150

headline: Afghan Detainee Killed in Kandahar
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  An American soldier shot and killed an Afghan detainee in a district jail in Kandahar Province on Sunday, according to a statement from President Hamid Karzai that appeared to portray the shooting as unprovoked.

headline: ‘Mad Men’ Star Joins Same-Sex Marriage Effort
text: Roger Sterling, the character played by John Slattery on “Mad Men,” is no poster boy for marriage.

headline: Should There Be Rules for Using Airport Outlets?
text: Over on the Bucks blog, Jennifer Saranow Schultz writes about the complicated ethics of using electrical outlets in airports.

headline: Q&A: New York City on a Tight Budget
text: Q.

headline: Stop Us If You’ve Heard This N.H.L. Broadcast Before
text: Hockey fans love nothing more than to sit down in their most comfortable chairs and turn on a hockey game. But after awhile, have you ever felt like some of those broadcasts start to feel a little… familiar?

headline: TimesCast | October 19, 2010
text: France strikers protest government changes to pension plans; off-the-cuff campaign moments and a new restaurant tries to revitalize downtown Detroit.

headline: Boom Times, at Least in Finance
text: The Bureau of Labor Statistics is out with its quarterly report on employment and wages in counties  around the country. The data comes from unemployment insurance premium payments, which means it is thorough and not subject to the vagaries of restatement. It also means that it is old when released. The report today is for March of this year.

headline: Going on a Diet? Start Paying in Cash
text: Paying with credit or debit cards makes people more likely to make impulsive, unhealthy food purchases, according to a new study in The Journal of Consumer Research.

headline: At the Mayo Clinic: The Ex-N.H.L. Player With 9 Concussions
text: ROCHESTER, Minn. — Jim Johnson, a fit 48-year-old who played 13 years in the N.H.L. before retiring in 1998, admitted he was nervous as he listened to Ann McKee, address the Mayo Clinic concussion conference here on Tuesday morning. McKee is the Boston University researcher who has done groundbreaking work with the donated brains of former athletes.

headline: Garden Is the World’s Second-Busiest Arena
text: The health of the biggest arenas in and around New York City seems to be rising and falling along with the professional basketball and hockey teams that are their main tenants.

headline: Turning Pain Into Performance: Tricks of the Elite Runner
text: Among the qualities that set elite runners apart from those in the middle of the marathon pack is how effectively they manage the pain associated with running 26.2 miles.

headline: Heirloom Variety
text: Kerrilynn Pamer, the owner of the stylish downtown clothing shop Castor & Pollux, always has eventual heirlooms in the back of her mind. These weighty brass bracelets were cast from vintage versions that belonged to her Aunt Maggie, who passed away last March. “She always wore three of them — two thick and one thin,” Pamer says. “She had the most pitch-perfect style imaginable.” The bracelets are $172 (for the thin style) and $182 at Castor & Pollux, 238 West 10th Street, or go to castorandpolluxstore.com.

headline: Turning Asphalt Into Edible Education
text: When Celia Kaplinsky, a Brooklyn elementary school principal, visited a schoolyard garden project in Berkeley, Calif., a few years ago to see if it could work back home, something impressed her more than the lush rows of tomatoes and cucumbers.

headline: A Landlord Learns From His Son
text: In his father’s house are many rooms. Roberto Fata has put sensors in a lot of them: Water sensors that warn when toilets are backing up. Temperature sensors that showed “we were baking the tenants,” he said  the average living-room temperature in one building was 96 degrees in the winter of 2004, when he installed the first ones. Oil-tank sensors that provide the evidence when a delivery is 200 gallons short.

headline: Everyone’s a Designer
text: Mary makes honey — or the bees she keeps make honey — and when it’s too thick to pour, it’s the best honey of all. Her brother, Tom, is a big-time landscape architect whose credits are too voluminous and intimidating to list; just know that he has designed projects in New York, New Zealand, Jamaica and the Flight 93 memorial in Pennsylvania.

headline: Buying Food With Cash or Plastic
text: The Economix blog today offers an interesting lesson on economics and eating behavior. People who buy food with cash make better choices than people who pay with credit and debit cards.

headline: China Said to Widen Its Embargo of Minerals
text: HONG KONG — China, which has been blocking shipments of crucial minerals to Japan for the last month, has now quietly halted some shipments of those materials to the United States and Europe, three industry officials said this week.

headline: Dimon on Regulation: We Can Handle It
text: Few banking executives have been more vocal about the financial regulatory overhaul — and what should and shouldn’t be included — than Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase. And in an interview with Fortune’s Duff McDonald, the outspoken Mr. Dimon again emphasizes that his firm can manage Washington’s new rules for the financial industry.

headline: Weatherization Went Awry, Audit Shows
text: Money provided in the stimulus bill for making buildings more energy-efficient is finally starting to flow, the Department of Energy’s inspector general says. But in a report released Tuesday, his office says that in some cases it has been badly spent.

headline: JetBlue Flight Attendant Accepts Plea Deal
text: The former JetBlue flight attendant who famously slid down an emergency chute after broadcasting his frustrations over the public address system managed to sidestep jail time on Tuesday, agreeing to a plea deal that calls for him to attend counseling sessions regularly for at least a year.

headline: What We’re Reading: Beauty Ads Are Bad for Your Self-Esteem
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: Citi’s Parsons Has a Leather Jacket That ‘Works’
text: 4:25 p.m. | Updated Daily Intel caught up with Richard D. Parsons, Citigroup‘s chairman, on Monday night at the Jazz Foundation of America‘s annual loft party on Sunday. Among the topics of conversation: Mr. Parsons’ leather jacket, an item of clothing he loved — he’s worn it a lot — but didn’t want written about.

headline: Playoff Baseball by the Bay
text: SAN FRANCISCO – Baseball is filled with these timeless rituals, little bursts of flavor around the margins of the game. I suppose it is like this with other sports, too, that if you’re partial to golf or boxing or auto racing, you will find yourself smiling at just as many sidelights. But to me there is nothing like baseball at playoff time.

headline: For Carnegie Festival, What Would You Like to Hear? (But You Won’t Hear It)
text: Power to the listener! But not too much.

headline: In France, Protests Over Austerity Measures
text: Hundreds of thousands of people took to the streets of Paris and other cities on Tuesday ahead of a parliamentary vote on the country’s pension system.

headline: A Google-Apple Snipefest
text: Over the years, business battles between corporate titans have played out in several different media: through press releases and news articles, or through multimillion-dollar ad campaigns in newspapers and on TV. Arguments made in one medium were generally responded to in the same medium.

headline: The All-Cash Diet
text: Economix has a report on a new study which found that people who purchase their groceries with credit cards are more likely to buy cookies, cakes and pies (“vice items,” in the researcher’s parlance) than consumers who pay cash. The design of the study, in the Journal of Consumer Research, does not control for all variables, but the findings offer an intriguing suggestion that shoppers might be able to curtail calorie-laden impulse buys simply by carrying a fat bankroll (which, you will be thrilled to learn, you can assemble yourself with an elastic taken from a bunch of broccoli.)

headline: Tylenol Recalls Erode Johnson & Johnson Sales
text: Johnson & Johnson said on Tuesday that its third-quarter sales this year fell by 0.7 percent to $15 billion, largely due to recalls at its McNeil Consumer Healthcare unit.

headline: Now Baking | Haute Crumbs at Morini and Lincoln
text: In New York, two of the fall’s most discussed phenomena have been the openings of Lincoln and Osteria Morini; both restaurants take an almost obsessive approach to pared-down, classic Italian cuisine, and both are fronted by a well-promoted star chef with proven talent (Jonathan Benno and Michael White respectively).

headline: Guy Hands Takes Stand in Battle With Citigroup
text: Guy Hands, the charismatic British financier, took the witness stand on Tuesday before a packed federal courtroom in Lower Manhattan to pursue his fight with Citigroup. Mr. Hands’s private-equity firm, Terra Firma Capital Partners, has sued the bank over its failed buyout of the EMI Group, accusing Citigroup of lying to him about the presence of another bidder during the auction of the music company.

headline: Brooklyn Bridge, 11:25 A.M.
text: Hundreds of New Yorkers marched across the Brooklyn Bridge to Manhattan to attend a rally near City Hall organized by the immigrant advocacy group Make the Road New York. The group is urging the city Department of Corrections to stop cooperating with federal immigration authorities in roundups of immigrants.

headline: Emanuel: Support Democrats for House
text: Who says exploring a run for mayor of Chicago takes up all of someone’s time?

headline: I Am A Jelly Donut
text: On my way to Berlin and beyond. Posting will be erratic.

headline: Saab Reveals 9-4X Ahead of Los Angeles Debut
text: Saab has previewed its new 9-4X model ahead of its introduction at the Los Angeles Auto Show media preview days, beginning Nov. 17. The medium-size crossover is a legacy from General Motors, the Swedish company’s previous owner, to the new owner, Spyker. It gives dealers a much needed third item to display in their windows beside the 9-3X and the new 9-5 — and one with available 4-wheel drive. A 9-5 SportCombi or station wagon is also due later.

headline: Intel to Build New Chip Plant in Oregon, and Upgrade Others
text: The Intel Corporation said on Tuesday that it planned to invest $6 billion to $8 billion to upgrade manufacturing plants in the United States and build a new one in Oregon, adding as many as 1,000 new high-tech positions and thousands of construction jobs.

headline: Are AT&T and Verizon About to Square Off Over Pricing?
text: While Steven P. Jobs, Apple‘s chief executive,  and Andy Rubin, the vice president of engineering at Google, fire pot shots at one another over their rival cellphone  platforms, the wireless carriers are engaging in their own snipefest behind the scenes.

headline: The Morning Skate: Blackhawks, Bad Checks and Bag Skates
text: It’s time to look in on the Stanley Cup champions, who, despite a young roster and very talented core, may not fare any better than every champion that has failed to repeat since the Red Wings won the last back-to-back titles in 1997 and ’98.

headline: Junot Díaz’s ‘Run, Don’t Walk’ Books
text: Junot Díaz was here for an event at The Times last night, and in the course of the evening he rattled off the names of several authors and books that have greatly influenced his work — or simply flat-out floored him. Among them: “Family Installments: Memories of Growing Up Hispanic,” by Edward Rivera, a 1982 memoir “noisily brimming with life,” as Phillip Lopate described it in the Book Review; “Poison River” and “The Death of Speedy,” two collections of the Love & Rockets comics by Gilbert and Jaime Hernandez; “The Keepsake Storm,” a collection of poetry by Gina Franco; and “The Housekeeper and the Professor,” by the Japanese writer Yoko Ogawa, about a brilliant mathematician whose short-term memory is impaired after an accident, and who develops a close relationship with his caretaker and her 10-year-old son. (Dennis Overbye described it in the Book Review last year as “deceptively elegant,” “written in such lucid, unpretentious language that reading it is like looking into a deep pool of clear water.”)

headline: Junot Díaz’s ‘Run, Don’t Walk’ Books
text: Junot Díaz was here for an event at The Times last night, and in the course of the evening he rattled off the names of several authors and books that have greatly influenced his work — or simply flat-out floored him. Among them: “Family Installments: Memories of Growing Up Hispanic,” by Edward Rivera, a 1982 memoir “noisily brimming with life,” as Phillip Lopate described it in the Book Review; “Poison River” and “The Death of Speedy,” two collections of the Love & Rockets comics by Gilbert and Jaime Hernandez; “The Keepsake Storm,” a collection of poetry by Gina Franco; and “The Housekeeper and the Professor,” by the Japanese writer Yoko Ogawa, about a brilliant mathematician whose short-term memory is impaired after an accident, and who develops a close relationship with his caretaker and her 10-year-old son. (Dennis Overbye described it in the Book Review last year as “deceptively elegant,” “written in such lucid, unpretentious language that reading it is like looking into a deep pool of clear water.”)

headline: CMJ Music Marathon: What to Expect
text: The great majority of CMJ performers qualify as indie-rock, in subgenres as diverse as punk and math-rock, chamber-pop and chillwave, electro and singer-songwriter; there’s some collegiate-minded hip-hop, too.

headline: Flush With Cash, Will Apple Go Shopping?
text: Pulling in billions of dollars quarter after quarter, Apple has provided Silicon Valley with a seemingly endless guessing game about possible mergers and acquisitions — but one that has largely gone on up to now without the participation of Steven P. Jobs, Apple’s chief executive.

headline: Reader-Submitted Photos: New York City Marathon
text: New York Times readers share their photographs of Sunday’s race.

headline: Marathon of Surprises in New York
text: Derartu Tulu of Ethiopia edged the women's world record holder while Meb Keflezighi became the first American to win New York in 27 years.

headline: Rooney Wants Out at Manchester United
text: LONDON  Wayne Rooney, the Kobe Bryant of English soccer, has said he wants to quit the most famous team in the land, Manchester United, according to his manager.

headline: For McCain, Stimulus Money Questions
text: Senator John McCain found himself trying to recover — or at least explain away — a Recovery Act faux pas Tuesday on ABC’s “Good Morning America” with George Stephanopoulos.

headline: In Hiring Mike Quade, Cubs Pass Over Ryne Sandberg
text: SAN FRANCISCO – There is no way of knowing, right now, whether Chicago Cubs General Manager Jim Hendry made the right call Tuesday by hiring Mike Quade as manager. Quade, 53, paid his dues as a minor league manager for 17 seasons. The Cubs played hard for him this summer, going 24-13 after Lou Piniella resigned. He knows the Cubs, having spent four years as their third-base coach. He is personable and outgoing, and should handle the scrutiny well.

headline: Lockheed Cuts Profit Estimate for Year
text: Lockheed Martin on Tuesday cut its earnings forecast for 2010, and said delays in the award of Pentagon programs would hurt its sales growth and leave profits flat in 2011.

headline: Mosques Open Their Doors for a ‘Week of Dialogue’
text: Muslim organizations have kicked off a “week of dialogue” and mosque open houses across the United States, encouraging their members to invite neighbors and non-Muslim friends to attend Muslim prayers and question-and-answer sessions at mosques, and, in turn, to explore churches, synagogues and other houses of worship.

headline: Intermission, at Best, in Battle Over Foreclosures
text: Bank of America may be trying to bring down the curtain on the foreclosure furor, but there were numerous indications Tuesday that the problems would not move off-stage so quickly.

headline: The Fate of Interstate Wine Shipments
text: I sit comfortably in New York City, knowing that I can find just about any wine that interests me at one of our many excellent retail shops. On the rare occasion that they all fail me, I can quickly search stocks around the country using a convenient tool like wine-searcher.com. And, last week, some very good friends of mine were reveling: they had just received one of their twice-a-year deliveries from Garagiste, an unusual Internet wine retailer that makes it easy for people in 33 states and Washington to find the sort of esoteric wines that ordinary retail shops might not carry.

headline: E.D.F. and Constellation Step Up Nuclear Battle
text: The romance is over for Électricité de France and the Constellation Energy Group, partners in a nuclear power joint venture. Their very public squabble was ostensibly set off by Constellation’s withdrawal of its application to the Energy Department for a loan guarantee for the Calvert Cliffs 3 nuclear project in Maryland. E.D.F. publicly responded with a letter scolding Constellation and asserting its willingness both to proceed with the Calvert Cliffs project and buy out Constellation’s 50 percent interest in their UniStar joint venture, the corporation formed to develop Calvert Cliffs.

headline: Claiming Responsibility: Understanding the Rise and Popularity of Hitler
text: Overview | Did the German people elevate Hitler, or did Hitler victimize the Germans? How do historians formulate claims about complex historical events? In this lesson, students consider competing historical claims about responsibility for the rise of Adolf Hitler and then examine primary sources to generate and support their own historical claims. They also consider what the significance of these claims might be for contemporary society.

headline: The Pedometer Test: Americans Take Fewer Steps
text: Americans are thousands of steps behind other countries when it comes to daily physical activity, according to new research that used pedometers to measure movement.

headline: Pennsylvania Revisited
text: I’ve been fielding a lot of questions about the Public Policy Polling survey in Pennsylvania’s Senate race that gives Representative Joe Sestak, the Democrat, a 1-point lead over the Republican Pat Toomey.

headline: Keeping Tabs on Tax Changes
text: Economists recently discussed on the Freakonomics blog what they think the biggest tax mistake of this year might be.

headline: Murder Trial Puts Death Penalty in Spotlight in Connecticut Campaigns
text: If Dannel P. Malloy’s gubernatorial campaign had the authority to set Connecticut’s court calendar, it probably would have scheduled the state’s most sensational murder trial for some other time. Like after Election Day.

headline: Britain Announces Severe Military Cutbacks
text: LONDON  In a bid to streamline its armed forces and help reduce its daunting levels of national debt, the British government on Tuesday announced plans to cut its military personnel by 10 percent, scrap 40 percent of the army’s artillery and tanks, withdraw all of its troops from Germany within 10 years, and cut 25,000 civilian jobs in its Defense Ministry.

headline: Wealthfront Loses the Sound Effects
text: 10:03 a.m. | Updated Correcting how much Wealthfront managers outperformed the S&P index.

headline: Answering Readers’ Questions About the Chevrolet Volt
text: As driving impressions and technical details of the 2011 Chevrolet Volt emerged from last week’s press introduction in Michigan, Wheels invited its readers to add their own questions to the topics covered in the FAQ article published last weekend.

headline: Exploring Eataly
text: Inside the giant new Italian food hall in Manhattan.

headline: Eataly Offers Italy by the Ounce
text: NEW YORKERS understand full-contact grocery shopping.

headline: Pictures of the Day: France and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from France, Pakistan and Russia.

headline: Breast Cancer Seen as Riskier With Hormone
text: Hormone treatment after menopause, already known to increase the risk of breast cancer, also makes it more likely that the cancer will be advanced and deadly, a study finds.

headline: Eataly: Waiting for Supermarkets
text: Such are the vagaries of reviewing restaurants in a city still shaking off the terrors of recession: this week’s review isn’t really a review at all, but a notebook about a grocery store, Eataly, that opened recently next to Madison Square Park, in the Toy Building. (More photos are in a slide show, and check out the floor plan here.)

headline: The Caucus
text: Two off-the-cuff moments captured on video in Nevada and Kentucky show how intense the campaigns have become in the last days before the midterm elections.

headline: New York Fed Urges BofA to Buy Back Loans
text: A group of financial institutions demanding that Bank of America repurchase $47 billion worth of loans packaged by Countrywide Financial has an unusual new member: the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

headline: Cars.com Rejoins Super Bowl Lineup
text: The roster of Super Bowl advertisers has grown again with word on Tuesday that Cars.com, which advertised during the last three Super Bowls, will be a sponsor of Super Bowl XLV on Feb. 6, 2011.

headline: Student Accused of Slashing Cabby Is Freed on $500,000 Bail
text: Michael Enright, the film student charged with slashing a Muslim cabby in Midtown in August, was released on $500,000 bail Tuesday afternoon. The family of Mr. Enright, 21, secured the bond by putting up their house in Brewster, N.Y., and a certificate of deposit.

headline: Watching the French Protests on YouTube
text: During another day of nationwide unrest in France on Tuesday, scuffles were reported between rock-throwing students and riot police firing tear gas in Nanterre, on the outskirts of Paris.

headline: Mets and Francisco Rodriguez Resolve Contract Dispute
text: The Mets and Francisco Rodriguez resolved their contract dispute on Tuesday with Rodriguez admitting responsibility for his thumb injury and renouncing claims to lost salary, and the Mets agreeing not to convert his contract to nonguaranteed status.

headline: Pictures of the Day: France and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from France, Pakistan and Russia.

headline: Final: Giants 3, Phillies 0
text: Matt Cain pitched seven shutout innings and Cody Ross delivered yet another clutch hit as the Giants shut out the Phillies 3-0, taking a two game to one lead in the National League Championship series.

headline: TimesCast: Off-the-Cuff Moments
text: In the latest edition of TimesCast, Michael D. Shear takes a look at two recent off-the-cuff campaign moments this election year.

headline: Artful Books | The Island of Rota
text: Ted Muehling is known for designing objects, like jewelry, porcelain vases and crystal bowls, that are based on forms found in nature, like a lily pad, coral or a tortoise shell. His first foray into book design, a collaboration with the neurologist and writer Oliver Sacks and the photographer Abelardo Morell, is no exception. “The Island of Rota” is a mysterious and seductive book about the natural history of an island in Micronesia. Its text is taken from Sacks’s book “The Island of the Colorblind”; its rich, cliché-verre photographs of ferns and cycads (very early plant forms that grow on Rota) are by Morell; and the book itself, a highly textured, handmade, sensual object, was designed by Muehling.

headline: At the Mayo Clinic: Women’s Hockey, a Most Dangerous Game
text: ROCHESTER, Minn. — In terms of concussions, women’s ice hockey is the most dangerous N.C.A.A. sport.

headline: Shaken Baby Syndrome Debate Moves Offshore
text: Sometimes a healthy debate takes place at some distance from the point of origin of a Times news story or column. That was the case with “Anatomy of a Misdiagnosis” by Deborah Tuerkheimer, an Op-Ed piece published on Sept. 21.

headline: Indianapolis Symphony Names Music Director
text: The Indianapolis Symphony named a 28-year-old Pole, Krzysztof Urbanski, as its music director, starting in September. Mr. Urbanski, who succeeds Mario Venzago, graduated from the Chopin Music Academy in Warsaw just three years ago and was named chief conductor of the Trondheim Symphony Orchestra in Norway in 2009.

headline: The Bulls’ Rose Also Rises
text: If the road to N.B.A. superstardom were paved with All-Star votes and YouTube highlight reels alone, Derrick Rose would already be a player of legend. He would be the subject of folk songs, star in countless tall tales, and be immortalized in bronze alongside Michael Jordan outside Chicago’s United Center. Unfortunately for Rose, such are the spoils reserved for the game’s true elites, and while the young Bulls guard is among the brightest up-and-comers on today’s N.B.A. scene, Rose’s rise hasn’t quite mirrored the meteoric brilliance of, say, Kevin Durant.

headline: Cervelli to Catch Burnett in Game 4
text: With the Yankees trailing by 2-1 in their American League Championship Series against Texas, Joe Girardi will start a battery that has not played since Oct. 2. As he has for most of the season -– and each of his starts since Aug. 2 –- Francisco Cervelli will catch A.J. Burnett on Tuesday night.

headline: Bringing Business To Detroit
text: Melena Ryzik visits Detroit, where a young restaurateur is working to revitalize a section of the blighted city.

headline: Is Pure Altruism Possible?
text: Who could doubt the existence of altruism?

headline: Using Twitter to Predict Stock Market Swings
text: Forget Michelle Obama’s wardrobe. Here’s an even more deliciously unexpected stock market indicator: Twitter.

headline: Yahoo Profit Rises, but Revenue Is Flat
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Almost two years after Carol A. Bartz took over as chief executive of Yahoo, the turnaround of the country’s biggest Web portal is still clearly a work in progress.

headline: New Web Life for the Dead Sea Scrolls
text: JERUSALEM  The scribes who wrote the Dead Sea Scrolls could not have imagined their texts’ one day being Googled.

headline: Eye-Popping for Art’s Sake: An Advocate for 3-D Films
text: Nearly a year after his fantasy movie “Avatar” broke box office records and opened a floodgate of big-budget 3-D features, James Cameron is still very much immersed in his budding science-fiction franchise and 3-D filmmaking.

headline: New Lab Complexes Make the City Ready for a Biotech Future
text: An initiative to develop a bioscience industry in New York City is starting to take root with the construction of two commercial laboratory complexes, one on the East Side of Manhattan and the other at the Brooklyn Army Terminal in Sunset Park.

headline: Can EMC and Dell Kiss and Make Up?
text: EMC felt like a jilted lover when Dell made an unsuccessful run at 3Par, EMC’s rival in the data storage business.

headline: Landmarks Says No to a Guggenheim Food Stall
text: Foodies take note: The New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission on Tuesday voted to deny the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum’s application to install a food kiosk outside its entrance. The commission determined that the kiosk would disrupt the entryway and introduce a visual interruption to Frank Lloyd Wright’s museum.

headline: Microsoft Moves Office to the Cloud
text: It has been a busy year inside Microsoft: the company is getting ready to introduce an entirely new mobile platform and a new type of Xbox gaming interface that uses the human body instead of a traditional controller. Now it is offering a new kind of Microsoft Office suite, called Office 365, which is based in the cloud.

headline: Hunting for the Dawn of Writing, When Prehistory Became History
text: CHICAGO  One of the stars of the Oriental Institute’s new show, “Visible Language: Inventions of Writing in the Ancient Middle East and Beyond,” is a clay tablet that dates from around 3200 B.C. On it, written in cuneiform, the script language of ancient Sumer in Mesopotamia, is a list of professions, described in small, repetitive impressed characters that look more like wedge-shape footprints than what we recognize as writing.

headline: Sheepshead Bay, 2 p.m.
text: Who’s that waving from the balcony?

headline: Officer Failed to Warn C.I.A. Before Attack
text: WASHINGTON  Three weeks before a Jordanian double agent set off a bomb at a remote Central Intelligence Agency base in eastern Afghanistan last December, a C.I.A. officer in Jordan received warnings that the man might be working for Al Qaeda, according to an investigation into the deadly attack.

headline: Sales Decline, but Earnings Rise for Johnson & Johnson
text: A series of recalls of Tylenol and other popular brand-name medicines this year is largely to blame for a decline in third-quarter sales at Johnson & Johnson to $15 billion, a decrease of 0.7 percent, the company said on Tuesday.

headline: Sylvan Sounds, Meant to Be Seen
text: Can a concert be too beautiful for comfort? The question seemed pertinent for a long stretch of a rare local performance by Ryuichi Sakamoto in the Skirball Center for the Performing Arts at New York University on Monday night. Mr. Sakamoto, 58, is a figure whose renown encompasses a plethora of disparate activities. Apart from being a skillful keyboardist, he is a pop-culture hero in his native Japan, a composer of film scores and symphonic works, a record producer and entrepreneur, an actor and, most recently, an environmental activist.

headline: The Caucus Click: Plymouth, Mass.
text: Jeff Perry, the Republican candidate for the Massachusetts’s 10th District, held a coffee hour at the Plymouth Area Chamber of Commerce.

headline: Turkey’s Rapidly Rising Currency Has Downside
text: ISTANBUL  Day after day, the Turkish stock market has been setting records, lifted by a flood of foreign capital in search of higher yields in Turkey and other fast-growing emerging markets.

headline: A Date with Bruno Frisoni
text: Bruno Frisoni, the artistic director of Roger Vivier, has an important date in New York this week. He’s here to introduce his latest collection, the limited-edition Rendez-Vous. “I wanted this collection to be more affordable than couture and more accessible in terms of design,” says the designer, who played with a range of natural materials including wood, cord and horn. (Orders start in December and are limited to 10 per style.) New Yorkers will be the first to see the collection at a party tonight at Saks Fifth Avenue’s shoe mecca, 10022, hosted by Stephanie Winston Wolkoff, Lincoln Center’s director of fashion. But this week isn’t all business for Frisoni. He “loves the old charm and the shabby chic suites,” at the Carlyle Hotel and dining at the downtown bistro Da Silvano, “for the Italian-like atmosphere and sunny terrace.” Still, you never know when another bag or shoe idea will strike. His biggest inspiration, he says, “comes from the graphic lines of the city and the crisp skies.”

headline: 3 Midtown Projects and How They Grew (or Didn’t)
text: One of Manhattan’s newest skyscrapers is rising on a nondescript corner of the Avenue of the Americas and 32nd Street. In coming months, the building, once called Tower 111 and now tentatively renamed the Continental, will begin marketing its 338 rental units. Its developer is hoping that sweeping views of the Empire State Building, nine-foot ceilings and amenities that include an indoor swimming pool will draw renters to this mostly commercial stretch of the Garment District.

headline: Longing for the Lines That Had Us at Hello
text: LOS ANGELES  Have we heard the last (truly memorable) word from Hollywood?

headline: Where the Well-Heeled Dress Down
text: A RECENT article on ArtThreat.net examined the Internet mini-sensation of the graffiti artist Banksy’s animation intro for “The Simpsons.” In the clip, Banksy lampoons the outsourcing of Simpsons animation cels to South Korea by showing the characters being drawn by candlelight in damp underground sweatshops. ArtThreat quoted Naomi Klein’s Twitter feed:

headline: From the Garden to the Record Books, a Supersize Pumpkin
text: The largest pumpkin ever grown measures more than 15 feet around and is 4½ feet tall. It weighs 1,810½ pounds and contains enough flesh to make about 900 pies. On Friday, it left New Richmond, Wisc., in the back of a 2010 Dodge Ram pickup.

headline: Clarence Thomas’s Wife Asks Anita Hill for Apology
text: WASHINGTON — Nearly 20 years after Anita Hill accused Clarence Thomas of sexual harassment during his contentious Supreme Court confirmation hearings, Justice Thomas’s wife has called Ms. Hill, seeking an apology.

headline: An Ugly Duckling Gets Her Ginger Up Over Fitting In
text: It’s hard to imagine that the actress Julianne Moore was ever an ugly duckling. And she wasn’t, exactly: she was a freckleface strawberry.

headline: In Five Different Lives, Many Ties That Bind
text: It’s a small world, and for the disparate and troubled characters in “Interchange,” Ken Jaworowski’s engrossing new play at the WorkShop Theater Company, their universe will be reduced to one degree of separation before the evening is done.

headline: Lower Profit at Goldman Reflects Wall St. Slowdown
text: By SUSANNE CRAIG

headline: Secretive Republican Donors Are Planning Ahead
text: A secretive network of Republican donors is heading to the Palm Springs area for a long weekend in January, but it will not be to relax after a hard-fought election  it will be to plan for the next one.

headline: Sci-Fi Goosebumps and Aliens on a Mission
text: Lines were bungled. Light cues missed. The pacing wandered almost as much as the performances, which ranged from the wooden to the flamboyantly hammy. In other words, the stage version of Edward D. Wood Jr.’s “Plan 9 From Outer Space” is just about perfect.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Eating Local: Discuss

headline: A Taste of Detroit’s Future
text: The restaurateur Phil Cooley of Slows Bar-B-Q has brought the beginnings of a restaurant scene to the blighted city.

headline: Sunset’s Covers Through the Decades
text: Covers of the magazine over the years reveal much about how the West was fed.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening

headline: Botella’s Effective Wine Decanter
text: No decanter is simpler and more effective than this utilitarian model. It is like an elongated bottle standing more than 16 inches high, making for an impressive presentation on the table and allowing the wine to aerate as it travels downward, entering through its matching glass funnel.

headline: Totto Ramen and Hide-Chan Ramen
text: JAPAN is dotted with wonderfully workaday ramen shops, places that are especially compelling when the weather turns cold. The lunch crowd squeezes into a narrow space shrouded in steam pouring from soup bowls, stock brews on open flames beyond the counter, and beside it a man pulls fresh noodles. The only sounds come from the bubbling pots and the clatter of chopsticks and spoons in bowls. Outside, the air is cold and thin; inside, the soup is hot and rich. Lunch at these places is, at once, otherworldly and comforting.

headline: ‘The New Brooklyn Cookbook’
text: By calling it “The New Brooklyn Cookbook,” Brendan and Melissa Vaughan, husband and wife authors, clearly present a time frame: the last decade, give or take a couple of years. The cookbook opens with a nod to the “old” Brooklyn of Di Fara’s and Peter Luger, and then plunges right in with the place the Vaughans consider to be the game changer when it comes to Brooklyn food: Al di Là in Park Slope, which opened in 1998. This is a history of the contemporary food scene with 70 restaurant recipes, including cocktails, and even a home brewer’s version of Sixpoint Craft Ale’s American Brown Ale.

headline: In Chinatown, Cupcakes Frosted and Savory
text: If Michelin rated cupcake stores, Everything Frosted might qualify for an “exceptional, worth a special journey” for lovers of flavors like green tea, jasmine, red bean and black sesame. On tiny Mosco Street, it’s a tricky find, even by Chinatown standards. Instead of a storefront, it has just a hanging sign and a narrow flight of stairs up to a no-frills kitchen, office and counter where dozens of cupcakes with iced topknots are displayed.

headline: Detroit’s Renewal, Slow-Cooked
text: DETROIT

headline: The Original California Cuisine, Courtesy of Sunset Magazine
text: BEFORE Alice Waters picked her first Little Gem lettuce and Wolfgang Puck draped smoked salmon across a pizza, California cuisine meant something else.

headline: When That Smile Is Too Perfect
text: IN this age of advanced aesthetic enhancement, subtlety is prized. The discerning get just enough Botox to unfurrow their brows, lest they become expressionless clones. Women dissatisfied with their breast size may get a surgical boost, but few aim to be as conspicuously colossal as Heidi Montag. And now dental patients are pursuing perfectly imperfect teeth.

headline: Debit and Credit Cards and Diets
text: In a post on the Economix blog, Catherine Rampell writes about a new study that suggests paying with credit or debit cards makes people more likely to make impulsive food purchases.

headline: Homes for $1.1 Million
text: A six-bedroom house in Maine, a three-bedroom house in Pennsylvania and a two-bedroom condo in California.

headline: What You Get for ... $1.1 Million
text: BUCKS COUNTY, PA.

headline: At Harvard, the Kitchen as Lab
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

headline: Osmond Joy: Donny and Marie Bringing Christmas Show to Broadway
text: One of the quirkiest, kookiest clans in popular culture is headed to Broadway for the holiday season: not the Addams family, which is already firmly entrenched in the theater district, but the Osmond family. The sibling entertainers Donny and Marie Osmond, who between them have dozens of gold records — not to mention dozens of the most lustrous teeth in show business — are headed to the Marquis Theater for a 12-performance run in December, publicists for the show said on Tuesday. “Donny & Marie – A Broadway Christmas” will be the first time that Mr. Osmond, the teen heartthrob turned “Dancing With the Stars” champion, and Ms. Osmond, the performer and lone sister to eight Osmond brothers, have shared a Broadway stage together. Mr. Osmond previously played Gaston in the Broadway production of “Beauty and the Beast,” and Ms. Osmond played Anna in a Broadway revival of “The King and I” in 1997. The limited run is from Dec. 9 (Donny’s birthday!) through Dec. 19, and is produced by Greg Young, Jon B. Platt and Magic Arts & Entertainment in association with Eric Gardner and Greg Sperry.

headline: Taliban Elite, Aided by NATO, Join Talks for Afghan Peace
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Talks to end the war in Afghanistan involve extensive, face-to-face discussions with Taliban commanders from the highest levels of the group’s leadership, who are secretly leaving their sanctuaries in Pakistan with the help of NATO troops, officials here say.

headline: Matt Cain Pitches the Giants Past the Phillies
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Just about every time he had faced the Philadelphia Phillies, Matt Cain had been treated like a piñata.

headline: Internet Is a Weapon in Cable Fight
text: In disputes between television programmers and distributors, the new battleground is the Internet.

headline: Cablevision-News Corp. Fight Intensifies
text: The fight between Cablevision and the News Corporation — which has led to a blackout of the Fox network in 3.5 million homes in Long Island and New Jersey for four days running — does not appear to be getting less bitter. If anything, it is growing more heated.

headline: Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell: A Gay Marine Writes
text: The author is an active-duty Marine sergeant in his mid-20s. He enlisted in 2002, served two tours in Iraq, and is now back in the United States. He has asked that his name not be published.

headline: DealBook: Flush With Cash, Will Apple Go Shopping?
text: Thomas Kaplan over at the Dealbook blog raises the question of what’s on Apple‘s shopping list.

headline: Brandy Lifts ‘Dancing’
text: The actress and pop singer Brandy topped the scoreboard on Monday’s edition of “Dancing With the Stars” as the two-hour installment of that ABC reality show dominated the night’s prime-time ratings with 19.3 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. The competition easily led both the 8 and 9 o’clock hours for the network, while providing a boost at 10 to “Castle,” which won its time slot with 11.6 million viewers, outperforming CBS’s “Hawaii Five-0” (10.6 million) and NBC’s “Chase” (5.2 million). CBS earned second place for the night, posting strong results at 9 and 9:30 for its sitcoms “Two and a Half Men” (13.4 million) and “Mike & Molly” (11 million). Fox ranked third as “House” delivered a solid audience at 8 (9.5 million). NBC was fourth.

headline: NBC Extends 3 Shows
text: NBC is backing three of its new series with full-season orders. On Monday the network gave a vote of confidence to its most talked-about new drama, “The Event”; the comedy it added to its Thursday lineup, “Outsourced”; and the new edition of its long-running “Law & Order” franchise, “Law & Order: Los Angeles” Not one has emerged as a hit, and all have ratings that might be labeled marginal. But NBC has fewer successful shows than the other networks, and all three series have shown at least some promise.

headline: Russia Accepts Invitation to Attend NATO Summit Meeting

headline: Just Knock It Off
text: Some of Israel’s worst critics are fond of saying that Israel behaves like America’s spoiled child. I’ve always found that analogy excessive. Say what you want about Israel’s obstinacy at times, it remains the only country in the United Nations that another U.N. member, Iran, has openly expressed the hope that it be wiped off the map. And that same country, Iran, is trying to build a nuclear weapon. Israel is the only country I know of in the Middle East that has unilaterally withdrawn from territory conquered in war  in Lebanon and Gaza  only to be greeted with unprovoked rocket attacks in return. Indeed, if you want to talk about spoiled children, there is no group more spoiled by Iran and Syria than Hezbollah, the Lebanese Shiite militia. Hezbollah started a war against Israel in 2006 that brought death, injury and destruction to thousands of Lebanese  and Hezbollah’s punishment was to be rewarded with thousands more missiles and millions more dollars to do it again. These are stubborn facts.

headline: Privacy vs. Profits

headline: 1 in 5 Americans Have Close Ties Elsewhere
text: Nearly one in five Americans are either immigrants or were born in the United States to at least one parent from abroad, the Census Bureau said Tuesday. The second generation was more likely to be better educated and earn more and less likely to be living in poverty. “This suggests that the children of immigrants are continuing to assimilate over time as they have in past generations,” said Elizabeth M. Grieco, chief of the bureau’s Foreign-Born Population Branch. The bureau said that in 2009, 12 percent of the population, or 36.7 million people, were immigrants and that 11 percent, or 33 million, were the children of at least one immigrant parent. Among the foreign born, 29 percent had a bachelor’s degree and 31 percent earned more than $50,000. Among the second generation, 33 percent had a bachelor’s degree and 42 percent made more than $50,000.

headline: Texas: Jordanian Sentenced in Bomb Plot
text: A Jordanian man who tried to blow up a Dallas skyscraper during an F.B.I. sting was sentenced Tuesday to 24 years in prison by Judge Barbara M. G. Lynn of Federal District Court. The man, Hosam Maher Husein Smadi, 20, had overstayed a tourist visa, married an American woman and began dabbling in radical Islamic politics. In September 2009, undercover F.B.I. agents drew Mr. Smadi into a fake plot to blow up the 60-story Fountain Place building. Mr. Smadi drove a truck that he believed carried an explosive device into a garage under the building and activated the false bomb, according to court documents. Facing life in prison, Mr. Smadi agreed to plead guilty to attempted use of a weapon of mass destruction in exchange for a reduced sentence. Defense lawyers had argued that he suffered from depression and had received a diagnosis of schizophrenia.

headline: China: Dissident Is Under House Arrest
text: Yu Jie, a prominent Chinese dissident writer, said in a cellphone text message sent to friends on Tuesday afternoon that he had been put under house arrest in Beijing. His latest book is “China’s Best Actor: Wen Jiabao,” a collection of essays published in Hong Kong in August that criticized Prime Minister Wen Jiabao for talking about political reform without making moves toward reform. Mr. Yu said in his message that four security officers had been posted to his door, one in a police uniform and three in plain clothes, to keep him from leaving. He said his Internet service had been cut off.

headline: China: A Call for the Return of Antiques
text: The managers of the old Summer Palace in Beijing are urging the owners of any antiques that were originally in the palace during the Qing dynasty to return them to the Chinese government, China Daily reported Tuesday. For many Chinese, the palace, called Yuanmingyuan, is a symbol of imperial aggression by the West  it was looted in 1860 by British and French forces and burned to the ground. China Daily quoted a park official as saying that 1.5 million relics had been looted or lost from old palace grounds over the years. Another official, Qin Jing, said more than 100 relics were scattered across Beijing because their current owners had refused to return them. Relics from Yuanmingyuan have sold at international auctions for millions of dollars.

headline: Britain: Saudi Prince Guilty of Murder
text: A Saudi prince was convicted of murder on Tuesday for beating his servant to death last winter in a five-star hotel suite in London. Prince Saud Abdulaziz bin Nasser al Saud, 34, a grandson of King Fahd of Saudi Arabia, also bit and strangled his servant Bandar Abdulaziz, 32, in an assault at the Landmark Hotel in the early hours of Feb. 15, the Old Bailey criminal court was told. The two men had just returned from a Valentine’s Day celebration.

headline: Phys Ed: Do Women Sweat Differently Than Men?
text: Does a hard-working woman sweat like a man? That question, which has figured in many an antiperspirant commercial, has received surprisingly little scientific scrutiny. But a new study published this month in the journal Experimental Physiology provides persuasive evidence that women do sweat copiously during exercise. (Did anyone really believe they misted?) But fit women seem to sweat differently than unfit people of either sex, and quite differently than fit men, a fact that has implications for sports performance. It also may have some bearing on what it has meant, since prehistory, to be female.
