His tones are gentle, changing shapes quickly but never abruptly. Maybe two dozen people are watching, half of those paying attention.

headline: Report Faults Former BayernLB Managers in Failed Bank Deal
text: BayernLB, one of the German regional banks that got into the most trouble during the financial crisis, said a study it had commissioned found its former management team was liable for the disastrous decision to buy a controlling stake in Hypo Alpo Adria, an Austrian lender that had to be nationalized late last year.

headline: Greg Dulli Summons Old and New Fans Alike
text: Of all the acts playing the first night of this year’s CMJ, perhaps only Greg Dulli remembered what the festival was like in its early incarnations. Mr. Dulli is 45, more than twice the age of many of the young musicians hoping to use CMJ as a stepping stone to something great.

headline: At Santos, an Oddly Juxtaposed Showcase
text: A festival of this size can make for some strange bedfellows, but sometimes you don’t have to strain that hard to find the oddest juxtapositions. At Santos Party House on Tuesday was a showcase for the IAMSOUND record label. Headlining was MEN, the always-fun, queer-politics-focused electro-pop outfit.

headline: TARP More Profitable Than Treasury Bonds
text: The government’s bailout of financial firms through the Troubled Asset Relief Program provided taxpayers with higher returns than they could have made buying 30-year Treasury bonds — enough money to finance the Securities and Exchange Commission for the next two decades, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Wealthfront Loses the KaChing Sound Effects
text: From Verne Kopytoff at Bits:

headline: Seoul Arrests Alleged N. Korean Spy
text: SEOUL, South Korea  The South Korean authorities said Wednesday that they had arrested a North Korean spy who had been on a mission to assassinate the highest-ranking North Korean official ever to defect.

headline: Jupiter Assets Rise 12% in Third Quarter
text: Jupiter, the asset manager, posted a 12 percent rise in assets under management, to £22.2 billion ($35 billion), trumping analyst forecasts.

headline: LivingSocial Buys Urban Escapes
text: From VentureBeat:

headline: British Bank Plans Middle East Private Equity Deals
text: Standard Chartered Bank plans to close a $100 million private equity deal before the end of this year, its first in the Middle East, a senior executive of the bank said on Wednesday.

headline: G-20 to Weigh Ending Mandatory Debt Ratings
text: Financial regulators will recommend to the Group of 20 leading economies that they abolish, wherever possible, mandatory credit ratings for institutions or instruments accessing the public debt market, Mario Draghi, the Financial Stability Board chief, said on Wednesday.

headline: How I Became a Head-Hunting Defensive Back
text: A reader, Peter from Brooklyn, in joining the debate about where to draw the line on head hunting in the N.F.L., spoke from personal experience:

headline: Bloomsbury Festival Returns to London
text: Never say die. That should be the motto of the Bloomsbury Festival, which lost its funding after 2007, only to return this year, from Oct. 22 to 24, once again celebrating the London neighborhood’s historic past and remarkably vibrant present.

headline: Seeking to Revive European Subprime Market
text: Investec, the South African bank, is seeking to revive the market for subprime mortgage bonds in Europe three years after the securities were blamed for the worst financial crisis since the Great Depression, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: Under Spotlight, Goldman to Cut Compensation
text: Goldman Sachs will divide $3.8 billion among 35,400 employees in the third quarter, a pay pool reduced significantly from the period a year earlier, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Secretive G.O.P. Donors Are Planning Ahead
text: A secretive network of Republican donors, which includes chiefs from the hedge fund and private equity industries, media moguls and wealthy individuals, is heading to the Palm Springs area for a long weekend in January, but it will not be to relax after a hard-fought election — it will be to plan for the next one.

headline: Massey Energy’s Shares Jump on Report It May Sell Itself
text: Massey Energy, owner of the Upper Big Branch mine where a methane gas explosion killed 29 people in April, has seen its shares jump almost 5 percent after a report that the coal company was exploring a possible sale.

headline: Iraq Gas Auction Draws Meager Interest
text: Iraq is set to open three major natural gas fields to international companies on Wednesday, but lackluster turnout by potential bidders could stymie the country’s hopes of exploiting a commodity it sorely needs to rebuild, The Associated Press said.

headline: ShangPharma Falls 15% in Market Debut
text: ShangPharma‘s stock seesawed in its market debut, hitting the market above the company’s initial offering price of $15, but quickly diving to close down 15 percent.

headline: BlackRock Investors Look for 3rd-Quarter Spark
text: When BlackRock, the world’s largest money manager, posts third-quarter earnings on Wednesday, shareholders will be looking for an indication that  it is more than a tired behemoth.

headline: Campaigns Don’t Coordinate. Really.
text: It all looks so, well, coordinated.

headline: Pereira on a Safer N.F.L.: If You Don’t Like It, Don’t Watch It
text: After the N.F.L.’s heavy fines on Tuesday, many players said the league was turning the sport into flag football or two-hand touch. The former player Ross Tucker, writing for ESPN, said he was “enthralled” by the hits — while acknowledging long-term safety concerns — and added, “I don’t know that helmet-to-helmet contact can or should ever be completely legislated out of the game.”

headline: Should I Charge Less or Advertise More?
text: Many businesses these days are trying to figure out how to increase sales. Money is tight, and customers are holding on to their dollars more than ever. I just had an interesting meeting with my managers as we plan for next year.

headline: Deutsche Postbank Backs Takeover Offer
text: Deutsche Postbank, the German retail lender, recommended on Wednesday that its shareholders accept a takeover offer from Deutsche Bank, The Associated Press reported.

headline: S.E.C. Charges 2 Hedge Fund Managers With Fraud
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission has sued two hedge fund managers based in Georgia, claiming they had defrauded investors by overvaluing illiquid assets to hide losses and collect higher management fees, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: How Many of Cutler’s Sacks Are His Fault?
text: The Bears’ Jay Cutler is fourth in my passer ratings this season, but there’s one problem. He’s running for his life.

headline: New Weapon Against Invading Fish: The Pan
text: [Dec. 31, 6:04 p.m. | Updated  A postscript has been added below, including my plan to compile an online “Edible Invaders” cookbook. Post suggestions as a comment or e-mail to dotearth@nytimes.com!]

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: –Homer Simpson teaches economic externalities.

headline: Rubenstein Calls for More Varied Fee Structure
text: David M. Rubenstein, pictured, the co-founder of the Carlyle Group, and Jon Moulton, founder of Better Capital, put in their two cents on the debate over the private equity industry’s fee model of “two-and-twenty.”

headline: Mariner Sells Stake to Orix of Japan
text: Mariner Investment Group, a hedge fund with $12 billion under management, plans to sell a “significant” stake of its holding company to a unit of Orix of Japan to help it expand its asset management business, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: NetSpend Rises 18% in First Day of Trading
text: NetSpend Holdings, a provider of reloadable prepaid debit cards that delayed its initial public offering last week, jumped 18 percent in its first day of trading, after raising $204 million in its I.P.O., Bloomberg News reported.

headline: BlackRock Posts $551 Million Quarterly Profit
text: 9:49 a.m. | Updated BlackRock, the world’s largest money manager with $3.45 trillion worth of assets, announced on Wednesday a big increase in third-quarter profit, which reached $551 million.

headline: Britain Plans Deepest Cuts to Spending in 60 Years
text: LONDON  The British government on Wednesday unveiled the country’s steepest public spending cuts in more than 60 years, reducing costs in government departments by an average of 19 percent, sharply curtailing welfare benefits, raising the retirement age to 66 by 2020 and eliminating hundreds of thousands of public sector jobs in an effort to bring down the bloated budget deficit.

headline: A Day After China’s Jolt, Shares Bounce Back
text: Stocks on Wall Street regained ground on Wednesday as new earnings reports helped lift the mood of investors.

headline: Careful Approach Works for Wells Fargo, as Earnings Rise 7%
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Within weeks of scooping up the failed banking operations of Washington Mutual in late 2008, JPMorgan Chase began phasing out the WaMu brand, replacing signs on retail branches. WaMu accounts became Chase accounts. Just over a year later, the conversion was done, turning the WaMu name into a relic of the financial crisis.

headline: The Early Word: Stumping Out West
text: President Obama and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. are headed West on Wednesday to campaign for Democrats in Oregon, Washington State and Nevada.

headline: The Virtues of Streamlining the Classics
text: This week’s Minimalist column, about a (relatively) fast way to make preserved lemons, gives results that are quite frankly not the same as the traditional version, which sits for weeks. I would even guess that many people would prefer the more leisurely traditional version.

headline: The D.I.Y. Way
text: A look at the Kopila Valley Children’s Home, Maggie Doyne’s school in Nepal.

headline: D.I.Y. Foreign-Aid Revolution
text: Like so many highly trained young women these days, Elizabeth Scharpf has choices. She could be working in a Manhattan office tower with her Harvard Business School classmates, soaring through the ranks as a banker or business executive and aspiring to become a senator or a C.E.O. someday.

headline: A Shameless Ploy for the Attention of Kanye West
text: Not that it was ever easy getting hold of Kanye West, but since he signed up for a Twitter account the game has added a whole new level of challenge. Through Twitter posts, Mr. West has offered readers a nearly round-the-clock conduit to whatever is on his mind, whether it’s profound or ephemeral. But he’s also learned how to use the platform as a way of getting around the news media, talking to fans directly without the intermediation of inquisitive reporters or critics.

headline: How to Change the World
text: I have an essay in the New York Times Sunday Magazine about do-it-yourself foreign aid, but I know that it won’t fully answer the question that many readers will have: What can I do? Originally we had a sidebar addressing that question to go with the article, but it had to be cut for space reasons – and so I’ve found a home for it here on my blog.

headline: Ocean Spray and Disney Strike a Deal
text: Ocean Spray and the Disney parks and resorts unit of the Walt Disney Company are to announce on Wednesday morning a multiyear promotional and marketing partnership. Financial terms are not being disclosed.

headline: Monserrate Faces Corruption Charges
text: What we’re reading this morning:

headline: Cremista
text: Suggested name for one who makes ice cream while you wait.In The Los Angeles Times, C. Thi Nguyen described how ice cream is made at the West Hollywood store, Ice Pan. Having opted for strawberry, topped with Reese’s peanut butter cup, Nguyen explained how the “cremista” began by placing the mixture in a freezing cold, metal pan:

headline: This Donation Cycle Catches G.O.P. in the Upswing
text: Out in the districts where Democratic members of Congress are enduring an unrelenting avalanche of attack ads from well-financed conservative groups, some of the party’s strategists are now warning of a permanent change in the landscape.

headline: Microsoft and New York in Software Deal
text: New York City has put the squeeze on Microsoft, negotiating a bulk software purchase that should lower technology costs for the city and give government workers access to more modern applications.

headline: Airlines Find a Route to Profit
text: After struggling with huge losses in recent years, the airline industry is on track for a blowout quarter.

headline: Republicans and Medicare: A History
text: Updated 10 a.m., Oct. 21.

headline: Screaming Females, Salem, Yo La Tengo and More Scenes From CMJ
text: Images of some of the bands that performed the first night of the music marathon.

headline: Screaming Females, Yo La Tengo and More Scenes From CMJ
text: More Photographs

headline: N.F.L. Removes Photos of Illegal Hits
text: The N.F.L. moved quickly Wednesday morning to take responsibility for and remove from an outside Web site pictures for sale of the helmet-to-helmet hits by the Steelers’ James Harrison and the Patriots’ Brandon Meriweather. The hits, from Sunday’s games, drew fines for both players and were part of the impetus for the N.F.L.’s decision to ratchet up discipline for dangerous hits.

headline: Full Text of British Spending Review and Video From Parliament
text: As my colleagues Sarah Lyall and Alan Cowell report, the British government announced deep cuts in public spending on Wednesday, “sharply reducing welfare benefits, raising the retirement age earlier than planned and eliminating almost half a million public sector jobs over the next four years.”

headline: Trends in Rent, Monuments and Education
text: If elections were decided based on what words are hot right now on Twitter, then Jimmy McMillan would be a front-runner. On Wednesday, the phrase “Damn High” was still trending on the service, a development mostly connected to postings referencing the name of Mr. McMillan’s bombastic, rent-focused political party and only partly buttressed by the inclusion of some unrelated messages about marijuana, medical and otherwise.

headline: Actor Withdraws From Havel Play After Car Accident
text: Simon Jones, a co-artistic director of the Actors Company Theater, has withdrawn from a key role in the company’s coming production of Vaclav Havel‘s “Memorandum”  after being hurt in a car accident, the company said on Wednesday.

headline: Messing With J.R., the Postscript
text: Many people on Wall Street were surprised when an arbitration panel awarded Larry Hagman, who played the rapacious oil baron J.R. Ewing in the 1980s hit series “Dallas,” $11.6 million in a securities arbitration case against Citigroup.

headline: Leaders to Convene on Tiger Rescue
text: With just 3,200 tigers thought to remain in the wild, time is growing short to save the species. Poaching and habitat destruction continue to imperil the tiger, which has undergone an estimated 40 percent drop in its wild population over the last decade and is now perched on the brink of extinction throughout much of its range.

headline: Show Us Your City: Eduardo Cruises the Venice Canals
text: A few weeks ago, we asked readers to give us the local point of view by submitting a short travel video that shows why their city, town or neighborhood is amazing. This week, Eduardo Manilla shows us why he thinks Venice, Calif., is the best city on the west coast.

headline: Night Watch: O’Donnell and the Constitution
text: Christine O’Donnell faced fresh scrutiny on television Tuesday night for her apparent gaffe earlier in the day involving the First Amendment.

headline: The Scoop Buys New York Another Round
text: When the Times issued the first edition of its New York-focused iPhone app, The Scoop, Pete Wells shared about two dozen of his favorite bars in a list called the Top Shelf. But it’s a big, thirsty city, so another veteran bar hound, Steven Stern, was enlisted to double the number of recommendations. The full list and a map can be found online, or downloaded for free from the iTunes store; the newcomers are after the jump.

headline: Wednesday Reading: A Good Time to Buy an Island
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Sailing Into Oyster Season – The GuardianA cool video piece about oyster dredging in Falmouth, England, and the last boat to do so with sail. – Sam Sifton

headline: On the Lookout for New Champions League Stars
text: The day a former teenage phenom announced the most peculiar decision of his career, another English youngster asserted his claim for soccer stardom. Hours after Sir Alex Ferguson proclaimed befuddlement at Wayne Rooney’s decision to leave Manchester United, his rival at Arsenal, Arsene Wenger, hailed his own 18-year-old starlet, Jack Wilshere.

headline: In McCovey Cove, Bobbing for Giants Home Runs
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Below the Third Street bridge leading to AT&T Park, three Giants fans were “stern-gating” before Game 3 of the National League Championship Series.

headline: The Insider | Sara Rotman
text: The Insider is a recurring profile of emerging tastemakers in the fields of fashion, design, food, travel and the arts.

headline: N.A.A.C.P. Examines Race in the Tea Party Movement
text: The nation’s oldest and largest civil rights organization declared in a report released Wednesday that the Tea Party was “permeated with concerns about race,” an assessment that is likely to reignite a feud between the two groups.

headline: A Real Marathon Man Runs 10 a Year
text: Michael Wardian can comfortably be considered one of the most prodigious pavement pounders in the world. He has averaged at least 10 marathons each year since the mid-1990s, running most of them no slower than the mid-2:20 range. Yet Wardian has run the New York City Marathon only once, in 1998. He claims conflicts with other races have prevented him from running the race more often.

headline: Behind an Old Subway Wall, a Glimpse of an Even Older One
text: When people compare New York to Rome, the reference is not usually meant to be flattering. But our town shares at least one inspiring quality with the Eternal City. Just about anytime you knock an old wall down, there is an even older wall behind it.

headline: ‘Death of a Salesman’ Coming to Broadway With Philip Seymour Hoffman
text: The director Mike Nichols confirmed on Wednesday that he would mount a Broadway revival of “Death of a Salesman” next fall starring Philip Seymour Hoffman as Willy Loman and Linda Emond as Linda Loman.

headline: Grumbling From the Bronx
text: Yes, that is an ill wind blowing your way from the Bronx. You may even feel the ground rumbling a bit. Of course, that might have just been the crowd stampeding toward the subway even before the Texas Rangers put the finishing touches on their 10-3 drubbing of the Yankees on Tuesday night. The dynasty may be wobbling, but hey, the home fans weren’t sticking around to try to prop it up.

headline: Breast Feeding and Weight Loss
text: October is Breast Cancer Awareness Month, and studies show one way to reduce your risk of the disease is to breastfeed. There is also evidence that breastfeeding increases a child’s IQ, while boosting her immune system and lowering her lifetime risk of obesity.

headline: Ex-Newsweek Editor Jon Meacham Heads to Random House
text: Jon Meacham, the longtime Newsweek editor and Pulitzer Prize-winning author, has accepted a high-ranking editorial position at Random House, the publisher said on Wednesday.

headline: How the Gulf Spill Was Good for America
text: David Brancaccio, a longtime correspondent for public radio and television, has written a fascinating post on his new Economy 4.0 blog for the Marketplace radio show analyzing the economic impacts of the gulf oil spill six months after explosions killed 11 workers and unleashed the gusher in the seabed.

headline: Keeping Score: Does Long Rest Hurt a Pitcher?
text: The most hotly contested managerial decisions of the postseason often seem to center on starting pitchers, specifically, whether to start an ace on three days’ rest.

headline: Health Scares Sideline Two N.B.A. Coaches for a Bit
text: Players aren’t the only ones who can spend time on the disabled list.

headline: Two Americans Among New Cardinals
text: ROME  Pope Benedict XVI named 24 new cardinals on Wednesday, adding fresh blood to the institution that will one day elect his successor and raising the chances that more electors of the next pope will be Italian.

headline: Regrets? Yes. And Money Was the Root of Them All.
text: Earlier this week, Christine Haughney, who writes the weekly column The Appraisal, described efforts by developers to get back commissions they had paid to real estate agents for deals that later fell through. She asked readers to describe some financial decisions, or purchases, that they wish they could reverse. Some commenters took a very wide view of the question, to say the least. Here, only lightly edited, are our favorites:

headline: One Place Where Spitzer Isn’t Forgiven: Harvard Club
text: In his emergence from political disgrace, Eliot Spitzer has played multiple roles: political commentator, financial columnist, college professor and, most recently, CNN host.

headline: Without Teixeira, a Different Look for Yankees’ Lineup
text: Filling out his lineup card had been the easiest part of Joe Girardi’s day during the playoffs. He had a batting order against right-handed pitchers and a batting order against left-handed pitchers and rarely deviated from that. On Wednesday, with the Yankees facing elimination, he did.

headline: ‘Driving on the Rim’
An Author Still Writing His Way Through Big Sky Country
text: McLEOD, Mont.  Thomas McGuane, whose new novel, “Driving on the Rim,” comes out on Thursday, is the only member of the American Academy of Arts and Letters who is also in the National Cutting Horse Association Hall of Fame. Yet he claims not to be a real rancher. “All the ranchers I know have had back surgery, operations on their rotator cuffs,” he said recently. “They all have new knees. I’d like to think I belong to that breed, but I don’t.”

headline: Answers to Your Questions on the Foreclosure Crisis
text: Yesterday we asked you to submit questions for Thomas A. Lawler, a housing expert, about the foreclosure crisis. Mr. Lawler is a founder of Lawler Economic & Housing Consulting, and a former director and senior vice president at Fannie Mae. Below is his first batch of responses.

headline: Now Showing | ‘Jean-Michel Frank in Argentina’
text: The French designer Jean-Michel Frank lived a short life — he committed suicide in 1941, at the age of 46 — but his interior and furniture designs became among the most influential of his century, and they haven’t lost their power to astonish. A case in point is the exhibition “Jean-Michel Frank in Argentina,” which opens today (and runs through Nov. 19) at Gallery BAC in SoHo. The gallery — which was founded in 2001 by the architect Carlos Aparicio to sell 20th-century design of the elegant, pared-down style that Frank epitomized — is showing more than 30 objects in this exhibition, the first devoted to Frank’s work in, and influence on, Argentina in the 1930s and 1940s. (A catalog, with an essay by the gallery’s director, James Buresh, offers plentiful illustrations.)

headline: Defendant in Triple-Murder Case Is Called Suicidal
text: NEW HAVEN  The man convicted of killing a mother and her two daughters in a harrowing home invasion in Cheshire, Conn., has tried to commit suicide on numerous occasions since his arrest in 2007, jurors considering whether to impose the death penalty were told on Wednesday.

headline: A Father’s Acceptance: His Son Won’t Be Following His Ivy Footsteps
text: 2:48 p.m. | Updated After you’ve read Mr. Marcus’s essay, click here for a follow-up post featuring some of the most resonant reader responses.

headline: A Large Worldview From Small Details
text: Peter van Agtmael, 29, who is represented by Magnum Photos, spent the last four years documenting America at war. In 2006, his work from Iraq won second place in the general news category from World Press Photo. His book, “2nd Tour, Hope I Don’t Die,” was described on Lens (Nov. 3, 2009). His conversation with Amanda Rivkin has been edited and condensed.

headline: Putting a Value on Biodiversity
text: Forests, fisheries, coral reefs, bee colonies and other natural assets carry large and unappreciated economic benefits as well as contributing to the diversity of the planet’s plant and animal life, according to a new study from the United Nations Environment Program.

headline: A Passenger’s Airport Wish List
text: AIRLINES have taken a lot of heat over bad customer service, but as I was waiting for a flight at La Guardia Airport this summer, I realized that the stress of flying sometimes starts at the terminal curb.

headline: 2011 Hyundai Equus Priced at $58,900
text: Hyundai’s dive into the luxury sedan market moved a step closer to the showroom this week with the automaker announcing a base price of $58,900 for the 2011 Equus, its new flagship.

headline: Changing View of Retirement as We Know It
text: Is the traditional concept of retirement likely to become a casualty of the latest recession?

headline: Four Questions, Less Than Two Weeks Left
text: Gail Collins: David, this election season has worn me down. And as far as I can tell, the polls now show that every race is a tie. This happens a lot toward the end, but I can’t help wondering if this year the voters have decided they don’t want to reward anybody.

headline: Updates From Apple’s Mac-Focused Event
text: Steven P. Jobs, Apple’s chief executive, took the stage on Wednesday at the company’s headquarters in Cupertino, Calif., to talk about upgrades to the company’s iLife and Mac OS products, and to unveil two new MacBook Air models. Our live updates from the news media event, including color commentary from Sam Grobart, our personal tech editor, are below.

headline: Soros Donates $1 Million to Media Matters
text: Media Matters, the liberal activist group that wages a rhetorical war against Fox News Channel and others in the conservative press, will announce on Wednesday the receipt of a $1 million donation from the philanthropist George Soros.

headline: TimesCast | October 20, 2010
text: Football helmets and concussions; impact of Tribune Company troubles and following outside money in campaigns.

headline: Supreme Court in Britain Gives More Legal Force to Prenuptial Agreements
text: LONDON  A ruling by the Supreme Court here on Wednesday gave prenuptial agreements more weight in divorce cases, bringing British law closer in line with that in the United States.

headline: Saying Damage Is Done, Jackson Prepares to Move ‘The Hobbit’ Out of New Zealand
text: Peter Jackson said that preparations were under way to move the production of a two-film adaptation of “The Hobbit” from New Zealand to another country because of a labor dispute with actors’ unions in New Zealand and Australia, The Press of New Zealand reported.

headline: Is That an Austrian Accent I Hear?
text: Jerry Brown wants voters to hear an echo — an echo with an Austrian accent.

headline: ‘Hipster Highway’ Bus Connects D.C. and Brooklyn
text: With BoltBus, Megabus, and an array of Chinatown-to-Chinatown companies already operating, it might seem the market for discount New York-to-D.C. bus lines has reached capacity. But one upstart is betting there’s room for a new angle. The Know It Express, which debuts Friday, bypasses Manhattan and downtown Washington altogether, instead offering direct service from Washington’s trendy U Street to Brooklyn’s Atlantic Terminal, at the nexus of Fort Greene, Park Slope and Prospect Heights.

headline: Looking Back and Looking Ahead: Week 7 in Fantasy Football
text: Chet Gresham blogs about fantasy football at Razzball. You can follow him on Twitter @Chetrazzball.

headline: Business Technology Partners
text: A technology consulting and IT support company in New York City and Detroit had to deal with a downturn in the economy the loss of some important employees.

headline: Quote Unquote | The Old Razzle Dazzle
text: –Georgia May Jagger talks about stealing her dad’s clothes. But when your mom is Jerry Hall, why bother with Mick’s hand-me-downs?

headline: Saskatchewan Asks Canadian Government to Block BHP Bid for Potash
text: OTTAWA  Brad Wall, the premier of Saskatchewan, said on Wednesday that he wanted the federal government to block a $38.6 billion takeover by the Australian mining company BHP Billiton of Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan, the world’s largest fertilizer company.

headline: Rooney Says His Ambitions Outpace Man United’s
text: Wayne Rooney confirmed he wants to leave Manchester United, not because of the scrutiny over his personal life, or the fans, or tempting offers from exotic places, but because the club’s management won’t match his ambitions.

headline: Hands on the Stand: Replaying the EMI Deal
text: When Guy Hands acquired the music company EMI Group more than three years ago, the New York City venue he most likely envisioned himself in was Madison Square Garden, taking in a Coldplay concert in the front row or perhaps a Lady Antebellum show from a sky box.

headline: Dominique Young Unique Struts at CMJ
text: The rapper Dominique Young Unique, from Tampa, has what it takes to get noticed, in or out of CMJ. She’s young (still a teenager), svelte, career-minded, raunchy and aggressive. She rattles off rhymes at top speed in a high, cutting voice, punctuated now and then with a singsong hook; her producers rev up analog electro sounds and they looked excited onstage, playing synthesizers and percussion. MTV has steadily promoted her.

headline: What We’re Reading: The Economics of ‘Seinfeld’
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: Gubernatorial Forecast Update: Can Tancredo Win in Colorado?
text: We’re gearing up for a more rapid schedule of updates to our forecasting models. You can expect Senate and House updates later today. We’ll then update all three of our models — Senate, House, Governor — again on Friday, and then just about every day from next Monday through the election on Nov. 2.

headline: Police Records Detail Large Presence at Critical Mass Rides
text: Cyclists and advocates connected to the monthly rides known as Critical Mass have long charged the police with responding to the unsanctioned events with a display of force far out of proportion to the number of riders or their potential danger to the public.

headline: Zoolander  Is Bringing His Fashion Sense to the Web
text: Nearly a decade after Derek Zoolander set out to find if there was “more to life than being really, really, ridiculously good looking,” that obliviously self-centered male model is coming back – this time, as a cartoon character on the Internet.

headline: Centrovert
text: One who is slightly introvert and slightly extrovert and is thus ideally suited for mediation, negotiation and collaboration.

headline: Creating God in Your Parents’ Image
text: In response to the Motherlode post earlier this week about children and God, a number of you wrote to me recommending additional resources. Mentioned most often was the book “NurtureShock”, which looks at the science behind raising children. And one of those who wrote to suggest I direct my readers there was Ashley Merryman, one of the book’s authors.

headline: Roaming for Ramen
text: @import url("http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/css/multimedia/bundles/SlidingGallery.css");

headline: Eurofile | What’s Really Cooking in Paris?
text: Paris just may be the English-speaking world’s favorite non-English-speaking city, which explains why so many Paris lovers take a proprietary interest in the French capital. To wit, they desperately don’t want it to change, which explains why they often react to news that it has with real anguish, even indignation. And if this protectiveness applies to almost everything about the city, it’s often fiercest when it comes to eating there.

headline: U.S. Tries to Ease Wider Worries Over Foreclosures
text: WASHINGTON  Administration officials renewed efforts on Wednesday to ease concerns about the integrity of the foreclosure process, saying that no evidence had emerged so far of any problems that threatened the health of the financial system.

headline: After Bust, Using ’60s Law to Get Out of Condo Deals
text: In May 2008, a few months before the financial industry’s meltdown, the shipping executive Vasilis Bacolitsas signed up to buy a $3.4 million apartment at the Brompton, a luxury condominium tower being built on the Upper East Side.

headline: Pixar Removes Its First Female Director
text: Walt Disney Studios confirmed a report on the blog CartoonBrew.com that Brenda Chapman — heralded as the first woman to direct a Pixar film, the forthcoming “Brave” — had been replaced at the helm of that picture by Mark Andrews, the director of the 2005 Pixar short “One Man Band.”

headline: Gardner v. Markey(s) Takes an Unusual Turn
text: Cory Gardner’s latest campaign ad seems to have hit a bit off the mark — er, make that, off the Markey.

headline: Burglar Pays a Visit to Slater’s House
text: 8:01 p.m. | Updated  The Queens County district attorney’s office released a corrected statement Wednesday evening. It turns out the burglary happened last week; it was the arrest that occurred on Tuesday.

headline: Palestinians Shift Focus in Strategy for Statehood
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank  The Palestinian leadership, near despair about attaining a negotiated agreement with Israel on a two-state solution, is increasingly focusing on how to get international bodies and courts to declare a Palestinian state in the West Bank, Gaza and East Jerusalem.

headline: Keith Richards Has Memories to Burn
text: It is 3 p.m. Eastern Daylight Time in the New York office of Keith Richards’s manager, a place that might look ordinary if every wall and shelf were not crammed with some of the world’s most glorious rock ’n’ roll memorabilia. Mr. Richards has a 3 o’clock appointment. “Come on in, he’ll be here in a minute,” an assistant says — and here he comes in a minute, at 3:01. This from a man who once prided himself for operating on Keith Time, as in: the security staff ate the shepherd’s pie that Keith wanted in his dressing room? Then everyone in this packed stadium can bloody well wait. The Rolling Stones don’t play until another shepherd’s pie shows up.

headline: Europe Seen Avoiding Keynes’s Cure for Recession
text: LONDON  The British economist John Maynard Keynes may live on in popular legend as the world’s most influential economist. But in much of Europe, and most acutely here in the land of his birth, his view that deficit spending by governments is crucial to avoiding a long recession has lately been willfully ignored.

headline: Car and Anime Cultures Collide in Japanese Trend Called Itasha
text: @import url("http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/css/multimedia/bundles/SlidingGallery.css");

headline: The 10 Things to Talk About This Weekend
text: 1. Osama bin Laden is reportedly “living in relative comfort” in a house, not a cave. He got tired of stalactites and waiting for the cable guy to show up.

headline: Jon Meacham Taking a Job at Random House
text: Jon Meacham, the longtime Newsweek editor and Pulitzer Prize-winning author, has accepted a high-ranking editorial position at Random House, the publisher said on Wednesday. Read more on MediaDecoder.

headline: This Time, London’s Not Burning
text: Updated | 6:23 p.m. On Wednesday, as Britain’s government unveiled plans to slash public spending, eliminate nearly half a million jobs and raise the retirement age from 65 to 66, the British largely resisted the urge to follow the lead of their French neighbors and flood the streets in angry and sporadically violent protest at the austerity measures.

headline: Who Won the Debate? I Did!
text: Oh, for the good old days of postdebate spin rooms.

headline: Paladino’s Accidental Running Mate Is Also His Mop-Up Man
text: He was booed in Harlem once a crowd realized he was Carl P. Paladino’s running mate. He has regularly reassured audiences that Mr. Paladino was speaking only metaphorically and would not really bring a baseball bat to Albany. And he has tried, with limited success, to make peace with gay leaders stung by Mr. Paladino’s description of their parades as “disgusting.”

headline: Tzigan
text: S O much for the end of bottle service. That much-maligned affectation of the boom times still has its stranglehold on the city. At Tzigan, a shimmering lounge that opened last month in the meatpacking district, matters seem to be becoming worse. Not only can you order a bottle of tequila for $1,400 (that would be for the Don Julio Real), but now you can also pay $500 a month to store it in Baccarat crystal carafes stowed inside your own cherrywood locker.

headline: Iran Will Try American Hikers on Nov. 6, Their Lawyer Says
text: TEHRAN — Two American hikers held in Iranian custody for nearly 15 months as well as a companion released in September who is now back in the United States will be tried Nov. 6 on spying accusations, a lawyer for the three confirmed Wednesday.

headline: European Parliament Votes for 6 Percent Increase in Budget
text: BRUSSELS — Despite a mood of austerity across the Continent, the European Union’s directly elected Parliament voted on Wednesday to raise the bloc’s spending by about 6 percent — double the increase that national governments say they can afford.

headline: The Fountain of Youth? Examining Factors That Contribute to Longevity
text: Overview  | What happens to our bodies as we age? How do centenarians seem to escape some of the typical ailments associated with aging? In this lesson, students explore the science of aging. They predict their own longevity, assess their personal lifestyle habits in the context of longevity, and research the science of aging and longevity.

headline: We Could Not Possibly Be More Excited for the ‘Rocky Horror’ Episode of ‘Glee’
text: ‘Glee’ Does The ‘Time Warp’ @ Yahoo! Video

headline: Short and Sweet
text: Creative multitasking seems to run in the Spade company, well, in spades. Kate Spade New York’s president and creative director, Deborah Lloyd for one, is sporting the hat of publisher these days with the release of “She Is Quick and Curious and Playful and Strong,” a collection of short stories produced in conjunction with the Strand bookstore. Among the seven authors commissioned for the project is Laurie Baker, whose “Go in Peace, Not in Pieces” explores the youthful desire to surrender oneself to love. In the story, which is set in Swaziland, South Africa, the narrator and her companion spend a few days in the Malolotja Nature Reserve, home to a myriad of animals, including zebras, the inspiration for the book’s cover art. Baker, along with her fellow writers Bridie Clark, Hannah Seligson and Sara Vilkomerson, will give a reading at the Strand on Oct. 27 from 7 to 8. The complete boxed set is $35 at Kate Spade New York shops, the Strand and katespade.com.

headline: Having a Devil of a Time
text: From the Montreal Gazette Habs Inside/Out blog:

headline: Vance Steps Up Fight Against Corruption
text: Cyrus R. Vance Jr., the Manhattan district attorney, on Wednesday announced the formation of a unit that will focus on corruption by public officials, indicating a further step by his office to become more involved in cases that have mostly been the province of federal prosecutors.

headline: Economic Activity Is Expanding Modestly, the Federal Reserve Says
text: Economic activity in the United States has continued to expand at a modest pace, although some areas, including housing, construction and the labor market, remain weak, the Federal Reserve said on Wednesday.

headline: Group Texting Grows Up, With Features That Appeal to Adults
text: Group texting is an activity that, in the past, seemed largely confined to teenagers at sleepovers. But the applications are limitless for adults concerned with life’s important moments.

headline: Getting Your Product Onto Retail Shelves
text: Business owners with a product to sell often dream of winning shelf space in the Wal-Marts and Targets of the world. But these days, with the recovery dragging, it is a challenge to get shelf space in any store.

headline: Thomas Stacy to Retire From New York Philharmonic
text: Thomas Stacy has retired from the New York Philharmonic as its English horn player, having departed just weeks into the season. Mr. Stacy, who was with the orchestra for 38 years, appeared with it as a soloist more than 70 times and made numerous recordings and a name for himself as a leading proponent of the instrument.

headline: Happy World Statistics Day, and a Reading List
text: Hello fellow numbers nerds. It’s 10-20-2010, which means it’s the first official World Statistics Day.

headline: Obama Tries to Shore Up the Party Base With a Western Campaign Swing
text: PORTLAND, Ore.  President Obama began his four-day campaign swing on Wednesday to fortify a Democratic firewall on the West Coast, telling a crowded rally here to “defy the conventional wisdom just like you did in 2008,” when Oregon overwhelmingly backed him for president.

headline: Pictures of the Day: France and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from France, England and Spain.

headline: Province Chief Wants Canada to Block Potash Bid
text: Brad Wall, the premier of Saskatchewan, said Wednesday that he wanted the Canadian government to block a $38.6 billion takeover of Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan by the Australian mining company BHP Billiton, the world’s largest fertilizer company, The New York Times reports.

headline: Organizing Photos on an iPad
text: Troubleshooting printer problems, organizing photos for the iPad, and Facebook photo albums.

headline: How Did You Get Your Product on the Right Shelves?
text: We just published a small-business guide to getting retailers to carry your product. Written by Eilene Zimmerman, the guide offers the experiences of several business owners, including Jill Cartwright, founder of Go GaGa, who actually took a job with a retailer in an effort to place her line of ergonomic diaper bags.

headline: Bonds Is Still the King of the City
text: Just when you thought Barry Bonds had disappeared, there he was in San Francisco looking fit in his familiar No. 25 as he was showered with a kaleidoscope of emotions  mostly cheers on a beautiful day by the bay.

headline: Heeding a Call to Cross the River
text: A STIFF wind was blowing through Chelsea, driving the cold rain sideways. It was last Thursday, early evening, just after quitting time. Seven in the evening is hardly a decent hour for a must-attend party, let alone one held outdoors in a space sheltered, though barely, by the elevated train tracks of the High Line. Still, New York being New York, there were already people lining up by a half-shuttered riot gate, umbrellas blown inside-out, waiting to get in.

headline: V.C.U. Names Building for Martin Agency President
text: Mike Hughes, the president and co-chief creative officer at the Martin Agency in Richmond, Va., is to be honored on Oct. 27 when the Brandcenter at Virginia Commonwealth University names its new building Mike Hughes Hall.

headline: At the Mayo Clinic: Helmets Not an Answer, Conference Told
text: ROCHESTER, Minn. — Helmets are not the answer to reducing the high rates of concussion in hockey, but banning all checks to the head probably is. That’s what the Mayo Clinic conference on head trauma in the sport was told here Wednesday morning, as the second and final day of the meeting began.

headline: Leaving Kolombangara
text: We left Kolombangara on our first clear morning. By midday, gushing rain transformed the lower-elevation forests into torrents of braided streams that formed and reticulated as we wandered, obliterating all signs of our passage. What little there was of a trail was gone, turned streambed. So we just went down, followed water, became it in the steady downpour.

headline: How I Saved My Company: Business Technology Partners
text: If the recession wasn’t bad enough, Business Technology Partners — a technology consulting company with offices in New York and Detroit — was also hit by a “mutiny” of several employees who had been important to the firm’s small-business practice and who left to start a competing company.

headline: Oberhofer’s All Over  at CMJ
text: Oberhofer is making itself ubiquitous at CMJ: at least one set a day, usually more, with a final salvo of three on Saturday. Drop in on them at certain moments, and they might sound like a punk-pop band, putting a galloping beat behind lyrics like “You ask me what I want from you/But I can’t tell you” and oohing through power-pop choruses. But that impression doesn’t last.

headline: ‘How to Succeed’ Revival Summons John Larroquette
text: We have no objections, it pleases the court, and those are pretty much all the legalese references we can think of at the moment: John Larroquette, who won four consecutive Emmy Awards for his portrayal of the lascivious assistant district attorney Dan Fielding on the NBC sitcom “Night Court” (and a fifth such trophy for a guest stint on ABC’s legal drama “The Practice”) is bound for Broadway. He’ll be making his debut there in the revival of “How to Succeed in Business (Without Really Trying),” playing the wicket executive J. B. Biggley, publicists for the show said on Wednesday. He joins the show’s previously announced star, Daniel Radcliffe, who is playing the ambitious window-cleaner J. Pierrepont Finch. Rob Ashford is directing the revival of the Frank Loesser musical, which is to begin previews at the Al Hirschfeld Theater on Feb. 26 and open on March 27. We rest our case. (O.K., we thought of one more, so sue us.)

headline: The Caucus
text: With outside groups pouring millions of dollars into campaigns this election cycle, it's (almost) history repeating itself.

headline: As Injuries Rise, Scant Oversight of Helmet Safety
text: NORMAN, Okla.  Moments after her son finished practicing with his fifth-grade tackle football team, Beth Sparks examined his scuffed and battered helmet for what she admitted was the first time. She looked at the polycarbonate shell and felt the foam inside before noticing a small emblem on the back that read, “MEETS NOCSAE STANDARD.”

headline: Quote Unquote | Face Off
text: –Paulina Porizkova tells the NY Post what she thinks of Janice Dickinson’s plastic surgery. That statement is an insult to transvestites everywhere.

headline: The Making of a Political Viral Video
text: Sean Bielat, a first-time candidate, is running a long-shot candidacy against Representative Barney Frank in Massachusetts. He hopes his new ad will make him a viral superstar.

headline: Rival Gives Frank Some Unflattering New Steps
text: REVERE, Mass.  Representative Barney Frank was dancing around the issues  first doing a version of the Running Man, then the Sprinkler, then a disco boogie.

headline: Iraq Prime Minister Visits Egypt and Iran
text: BAGHDAD  In the fractious world of Iraqi politics, October has been a month of unlikely courtships.

headline: Lucasfilm’s Keeper of the Fans Is Leaving
text: A force behind the Force is leaving Lucasfilm. In an e-mail blast on Wednesday,  Stephen J. Sansweet said he planned to end his reign as director of content management and head of fan relations for Lucasfilm, the company behind the “Star Wars” franchise, next spring.

headline: Battling the Earbud Blues
text: Do you have trouble making iPod earbuds stay in your ears? Does the least bit of exercise make them fall out?

headline: Boeing Posts Profit and Raises Forecast
text: Buoyed by a rebound in commercial aircraft sales, the Boeing Company reported third-quarter earnings on Wednesday that beat analyst expectations and raised its profit forecast for the year.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Digi-Novels and Dating
text: New technologies have always brought new ways of telling stories. On this week’s New York Times Tech Talk podcast, J.D. Biersdorfer talks to Anthony Zuiker, the creator of the hit TV show “CSI: Crime Scene Investigation,” about his latest digi-novel, “Dark Prophecy.” What’s a digi-novel? As Mr. Zuiker explains, it’s “the best of publishing, motion picture and social communities all kind of meshed into one experience.” Every 25 pages, readers get a code they can take to a Web site, where they can watch a video segment that bridges the chapters. “Dark Prophecy,” a thriller, is the second book in Mr. Zuiker’s “Level 26″ series. He tells Ms. Biersdorfer that an iPad app with interactive features is expected next month.

headline: MSNBC Leans. Fox News Moves.
text: This month, the cable news channel MSNBC adopted a new tag line, “Lean forward.” It’s a statement, the channel says, that it wants to be the home for the ideas that will advance America. It’s being featured in a nationwide ad campaign.

headline: Beauty Spots
text: CREAM FOR A CAUSE Starting Nov. 1, Kiehl’s will sell a limited edition of its Creme de Corps holiday collection, packaged with artwork by Jeff Koons; another, smaller run of Mr. Koons’s packaging will be introduced a few weeks later in select stores. Prices start at $27, and all proceeds will benefit the Koons Family Institute, an initiative of the International Center for Missing and Exploited Children.

headline: Jewish Funhouse Mirror Is Alive and Not So Well
text: Howard Jacobson recently described himself to The New York Times as “an English writer who happens to know about Jews and would like to write like Jane Austen, with a little bit of Yiddish,” adding that he’d rather be called “the Jewish Jane Austen” than “the English Philip Roth.” In saying this, he only affirmed the impression that his characters may be autobiographical in their self-delusions.

headline: Same Old, Same Old
text: IT’S not exactly Poets’ Corner of Westminster Abbey, but the blond-wood shelves at BookCourt in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, do confer a certain prestige in this literary-minded neighborhood. So it was at a recent Wednesday event, when a small crowd was leaving a reading from a graphic novel about the Cuban revolution by Inverna Lockpez and Dean Haspiel, and passed a shelf filled with T-shirts printed with the names of famous writers: “Whitman,” “Poe,” “Vonnegut” ... “Ames.”

headline: Clip: 'Waste Land'
text: A scene from Lucy Walker's documentary "Waste Land," about the artist Vik Muniz and his "Pictures of Garbage" series.

headline: On This Night, Everyone’s a Singer
text: HUGH JACKMAN sings Elton John in the shower. Which song? “Candle in the Wind,” he said Monday night, although his children beg him to stop. “And they’re not very happy they didn’t get to come to the ball tonight,” his wife, Deborra-Lee Furness, added before she hummed a few bars of her own.

headline: Scene City: Showing Support
text: Celebrities gather at the Elton John AIDS Foundation’s ninth annual benefit at Cipriani Wall Street.

headline: Anatomy of a Traditional Football Helmet
text: The dense foams used in current football helmet designs perform well for the kind of impacts that can cause fatal injuries, but have been less successful at mitigating the increase of concussions in the sport.

headline: Investment Group Wants to Buy Boston Globe
text: The Boston Globe reports that a newly formed investment group wants to buy The Globe, along with Boston.com and the Worcester Telegram & Gazette from The New York Times Company.

headline: Audi Aims at After-Market With a Display at SEMA
text: Audi of America has discovered there is gold in after-sales accessories, and it is planning to mine significantly more of it. To that end, the company announced on Wednesday it would for the first time have an exhibit at the Specialty Equipment Market Association trade show in Las Vegas, from Nov. 2 to 5.

headline: Football Helmet Safety
text: The standard for football helmets has not changed meaningfully since it was written in 1973, despite a growing awareness of the dangers of concussions.

headline: Showing Homeland Security’s Softer Side
text: Since becoming director of the sprawling federal agency called United States Citizenship and Immigration Services last year, Alejandro Mayorkas has endeavored to make it a nicer, gentler organization.

headline: EBay’s 3rd-Quarter Income Rose 23%
text: SAN FRANCISCO  EBay’s efforts to revive its auction and retail operations showed limited success in the third quarter while its PayPal online payments service continued to flourish.

headline: Who Lives There: The Pyramid Atop Seattle’s Smith Tower
text: Petra Franklin Lahaie and her family inhabit what may be the most extraordinary apartment in the city.

headline: A Time of Darkness Illuminated Onstage
text: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Even many South Carolinians barely remember the night when two unarmed black college students and a high school senior were killed, and 28 others injured, after state troopers opened fire at a civil-rights demonstration on Feb. 8, 1968. It was the first incident of its kind on an American campus, but the news was swamped by the Tet Offensive a week earlier and the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. two months later.

headline: Distorting Everyday Actions, With Movements Awkward and Active
text: The motto behind the Belgian company Les Ballets C de la B reveals much: “This dance is for the world and the world is for everyone.” In the case of its recent production, “Out of Context  for Pina,” performed Tuesday evening at the Joyce Theater, the line is both trite and something of a stretch.

headline: Over All, Colleges Accept an Average of 2 of 3 Applicants
text: On The Choice, we try as often as we can — though probably not as much as we should — to remind applicants and their parents that there about 2,000 four-year colleges in this country, and that most accept a sizable majority of those who apply.

headline: Swimming in a Sea of Color-Shifting Sound
text: The vibraphonist Gary Burton’s new quartet has the same shape as an important one he led 43 years ago on the record “Duster”: vibes, guitar, bass, drums. He was 24 then and figuring out ways to make jazz an even bigger container of American sound than it already was: it could evoke Chet Atkins and the Byrds and Ornette Coleman and Count Basie and the Modern Jazz Quartet.

headline: The Folkways That Led to Dvorak and Bartok
text: Folk traditions heavily influenced 19th-century Central European composers like Dvorak and some of their 20th-century successors, most notably Bartok. This folk heritage was explored at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday evening in the first of two Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center programs organized by the pianist Jeremy Denk.

headline: Bright Vision
text: Stowing away sunglasses come fall is about as antiquated an idea as ruling out white after Labor Day. (When else would you wear Prada’s ivory vinyl peacoat?) The fact is, the world is in a “weather chaos,” if you haven’t heard, calling for all-climate protection, all-year-round.

headline: Obama to Visit Pakistan in 2011
text: President Obama announced on Wednesday that he will visit Pakistan next year for the first time since taking office as his administration tries to bolster rocky relations with perhaps its most important partner in the war against al Qaeda and its allies.

headline: TimesCast: Campaign Money and Voter Frustration
text: The Times’s Matt Bai and Michael D. Shear discuss how the flow of campaign money in this election cycle and others tends mostly to be a function of ideological fury and alienation.

headline: Pictures of the Day: France and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from France, England and Spain.

headline: Commission Order to Guggenheim: Hot Dogs, Hold the Kiosk
text: Word has it that Frank Lloyd Wright enjoyed a hot dog now and then, sometimes served with cheese and pickles at picnics he held on the sandstone bluff near his famous Wisconsin home, Taliesin.

headline: A Star Takes an Excursion Out of Her Comfort Zone
text: Mix a tablespoon each of opera, Texas swing, New York art song, country, and classic Broadway, and the tasty barbecue rub you come up with distills the vocal personality of Kelli O’Hara, who opened a two-week engagement at Feinstein’s at Loews Regency on Tuesday evening.

headline: Revisionist Fourth-Grade History: ‘Thousands’ of Black Confederate Soldiers
text: As Kevin Sieff reported in The Washington Post on Wednesday, historians are wondering how a fourth-grade textbook in Virginia was approved despite including the spurious claim that “Thousands of Southern blacks fought in the Confederate ranks, including two black battalions under the command of Stonewall Jackson.”

headline: Dressing the Part
text: Some women show curves while campaigning, but shapeless corporate uniforms hold the lead.

headline: They’re Young, Even if They Aren’t Beginners
text: The New York Festival of Song has pursued two specialties with particular vigor in the 22 years since the pianists Steven Blier and Michael Barrett founded it. One is thematic programming. The other is finding promising young singers likely to build successful careers.

headline: No Matter the Country, Boys Will Be Boys
text: The lines between traditional and experimental art are often sharply demarcated  or self-consciously combined  so that the present smartly comments on the past.

headline: The Fashion Conservatives
text: A WOMAN seeking political office in 2010 faces a fashion quandary. The choice, in simplest terms, comes down to this: to follow the lead of Sarah Palin or cast a style vote with Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: Graco Recalls Strollers on Strangulation Concerns
text: In the largest recall of strollers ever, Graco Children’s Products on Wednesday urged the owners of about two million older-model strollers to stop using them because of concerns about possible strangulation.

headline: Taylor Swift Is Angry, Darn It
text: FOR pure star-on-star revenge, “Dear John,” from the new Taylor Swift album, “Speak Now,” will be tough to beat. Six and a half minutes long and flagrantly provocative, it’s a deeply uncomfortable song, its protagonist anguished and violated. “Don’t you think I was too young to be messed with?” she asks. “The girl in the dress/Cried the whole way home.”

headline: An Autism Fund-Raiser That’s Built on Laughter
text: What’s the best way for a television network to raise money for autism, a serious condition that affects millions of Americans and their families?

headline: Quote of the Day: Bush on the $700 Billion Bailout
text: “It wasn’t that hard for me, just so you know. I made the decision to use your money to prevent the collapse from happening.”

headline: Catching a Flight, and a Show
text: When Taylor Swift sweeps through New York next week to promote her new album, “Speak Now” (Big Machine), her stops will include “Today,” “Late Show With David Letterman” and “Live! With Regis and Kelly”: all high-profile, major-media events that will be seen by millions of people.

headline: Footnote
text: Thomas Stacy has retired from the New York Philharmonic as its English horn player, departing just weeks into the season. Mr. Stacy, who was with the orchestra for 38 years, appeared with it as a soloist more than 70 times and made many recordings and a name for himself as a leading proponent of the instrument. Most orchestra players retire at the end of the season. Mr. Stacy, 72, said the timing was “a mutual thing.”

headline: Rare Vote Set on a Union in Fast Food
text: MINNEAPOLIS  The Jimmy John’s restaurants here are known for serving attitude with their sandwiches. Many of their young workers wear nose rings, beards and dreadlocks, and the shops sport mottoes like “The Customer Is Usually Right” and “Subs So Fast You’ll Freak.”

headline: A Newcomer to CMJ, All the Way From Australia
text: Circle Pit is an Australian group making their first venture to CMJ, thanks largely to a benefactor who paid for their flights from Sydney.

headline: TV Crime Pays Again
text: Crime shows on CBS dominated Tuesday night’s ratings, with “NCIS” leading the way with 19.1 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. Following that 8 o’clock procedural, CBS’s spinoff series “NCIS: Los Angeles” also eked out a victory at 9, garnering 16 million viewers while ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars” results episode was seen by 15.3 million. ABC placed second on the night over all, while NBC finished a distant third, earning an average of 7 million viewers for “The Biggest Loser” from 8 to 10. Fox was fourth with mostly reruns.

headline: Animation in Starts and Stops, Simplified
text: For Stuart Bury, Jeremy Casper and Isaiah Powers, the path to a student Academy Award for their stop-motion animation cost less than $1,000, although it did require four months of often constant filming in Mr. Powers’s basement.

headline: Scouting Report
text: OPENINGS

headline: Fair Isle Sweaters in the Spotlight
text: FAIR ISLE sweaters are moving from ski chalets to city chic. Rag & Bone’s interpretation (the grayling cropped sweater, left, $310) was a hit on the runway, appearing in numerous fall fashion magazines. A longer sweater is $355, and a cardigan is $395. For those just looking for an accent, the mittens, which come with a detachable string (pictured), are $140; a cap is $140; a scarf, $195. Rag & Bone stores, including 119 Mercer Street (Prince Street); (212) 219-2204, rag-bone.com.

headline: Lord & Taylor Unveils Its New Look
text: AFTER a yearlong renovation, Lord & Taylor has unveiled the new look of its flagship store on Fifth Avenue. Six floors, including the men’s (right), were reconfigured to expose windows hidden by storage rooms. The store also has a new home department, on the ninth floor, devoting much of the space to Ralph Lauren Home and Calvin Klein Home Collection. The first-floor beauty department received a major face-lift  whiter and brighter, with a 1,000-pound Swarovski Elements chandelier illuminating the sales floor. 424 Fifth Avenue (39th Street); (212) 391-3344; Lordandtaylor.com.

headline: A Clog for All Seasons
text: THE clogs of summer are morphing into winter staples worn with skirts and tights or heavy patterned socks. The Cynthia Vincent Wiley Wood Clog Bootie (above left, $325) is available at Bloomingdale’s stores and Bloomingdales.com. The Phillip Lim 3.1 Tom Tom Knotted Clog Bootie (above center, $695) is from the designer’s first full shoe line, available at the 3.1 Phillip Lim store, 115 Mercer Street (Prince Street); (212) 334-1160. Swedish Hasbeens, the source for all things clog, offers the High Heeled Jodhpur (above right, about $399) in colors from blue to bubblegum pink at Swedishhasbeens.com, Urbanoutfitters.com and select Urban Outfitters stores.

headline: Saving the World. Smelling Good, Too.
text: SHFT.COM, an eco-conscious Web site with a high-profile pedigree (the actor Adrian Grenier and the film producer Peter Glatzer are the founders), is presenting a pop-up gallery in New York in a tie-in with pureDKNY, a scent that is packaged in recyclable glass and features the eco-activist model Angela Lindvall in its ads.

headline: Smooth Work by the Kings of Pair Events
text: If you need pinch-hitters to win a pair event for you, pick Bobby Levin of Lake Ariel, Pa., and Steve Weinstein of Andes, N.Y. In May they won the Cavendish Invitational, and on Saturday they received the gold medals for the World Open Pairs in Philadelphia.

headline: The Misunderstanding of Momentum
text: Turn on the news or read through much of the analysis put out by some of our friends, and you’re likely to hear a lot of talk about “momentum”: the term is used about 60 times per day by major media outlets in conjunction with articles about polling.

headline: What Spitzer Could Learn from Boesky
text: Our colleagues Sewell Chan and Nicholas Confessore have a scoop that the Harvard Club rejected Eliot L. Spitzer‘s membership application.

headline: One Star, Two Films: An Awards Conundrum
text: LOS ANGELES  The Hollywood awards season, never a simple matter, is complicated this year by the delicate question of how Michael Douglas will figure into it.

headline: A Desperate Lifetime, a Caring Photographer
text: In February 1993, Darcy Padilla was photographing a team of doctors and social workers in San Francisco who cared for people with AIDS who were too sick to make it to a clinic. She envisioned the story as an updated urban version of W. Eugene Smith’s epic 1948 photo essay “Country Doctor.”

headline: Morgan Stanley Posts Quarterly Loss
text: 6:32 p.m. | Updated

headline: Mott Haven, the Bronx, 3:45 P.M.
text: Students at the Bronx Academy of Letters in Mott Haven wore purple ribbons, undershirts and accessories in support of their L.G.B.T.Q. classmates.

headline: Surprise: Most New Yorkers Say They Like the City
text: So much for the idea that New York City is home to cranky, crotchety, chronically unhappy people who are never, ever O.K. with anything. A new survey found that 84 percent are “satisfied” or “very satisfied” with the city as a place to live. Only 4 percent said they were not at all satisfied.

headline: N.L.C.S. Game 4: Giants 6, Phillies 5
text: Buster Posey had four hits, and Juan Uribe hit a game-winning sacrifice fly to give the Giants a 6-5 win in Game 4 of the National League Championship Series.

headline: From Jet to Jetset
text: An Ontario company refurbishes commercial jets, transforming them into luxurious personal aircraft.

headline: Trump Among Donors to Rove-Linked Group
text: It is becoming something of a monthly ritual, as campaign finance reports are filed with the Federal Election Commission, to gape at the kinds of outsize checks from wealthy donors flowing into the independent groups that are playing such a large role in the midterm elections this year.

headline: Battle Lines Forming in Clash Over Foreclosures
text: About a month after Washington Mutual Bank made a multimillion-dollar mortgage loan on a mountain home near Santa Barbara, Calif., a crucial piece of paperwork disappeared.

headline: Investor Group Plans Bid for Boston Globe
text: Will Aaron Kushner finally take The Boston Globe off The New York Times Company‘s hands?

headline: Newly Released Books
text: “You can learn a lot about society by the pop culture it embraces,” Nathan Rabin writes in an essay collection that pays more attention to bad movies than good. What do this month’s new releases tell us? Nazi doctors, serial killers and the great outdoors continue to scare us, mothers and daughters still have issues, and it takes a European novelist to blend the personal and the political.

headline: Growing in Size, Soaring in Price and in Demand
text: JUST based on the new luxury jets that were the hottest items at the National Business Aviation Association annual convention in Atlanta this week, it would be easy to overlook that the private jet business has been mired in a depression for two years.

headline: Bloggingheads: Social Conservatives?
text: Matt Welch, left, of Reason and Timothy Carney of The Washington Examiner debate whether Republicans will focus on social issues.

headline: Investors Seek Boston Globe
text: A Boston-area investment group has announced that it wants to buy The Boston Globe, along with Boston.com and The Worcester Telegram & Gazette in Massachusetts, from The New York Times Company.

headline: Jon Meacham, Former Newsweek Editor, Takes Job at Random House
text: Jon Meacham, the former Newsweek editor and Pulitzer Prize-winning author, has accepted a high-ranking editorial position at Random House, the publisher said on Wednesday.

headline: A Basket of Assets in One Investment
text: AS investment vehicles, exchange-traded funds seem like a perfect fit for retirement portfolios.

headline: For Legal Fees, It’s More of a Buyer’s Market
text: EVEN if you are never embroiled in a lawsuit, life events set off legal issues. Vast bodies of law affect milestones like buying or selling a home, being fired, starting a business, getting divorced and losing a loved one, for instance.

headline: Leave the Children the House, Without a Hefty Tax Bill
text: GIVE my house to my children while I’m still alive? You must be kidding!

headline: An Investment for the Experienced
text: DEPENDING on whom you talk to, structured products are either clever ways of hedging specific portfolio risks or another demon from Wall Street.

headline: 3 Schools of Thought on Wealth Management
text: AS portfolios tick up after the vast losses of two years ago, many investors remain wary. The latest whiz-bang product is more likely to inspire skepticism than desire. Promises of steady returns do not inspire confidence, either.
