text: IN 2003, Mark Kress was having money troubles.

headline: Treading Carefully in the Currency Bazaar
text: WHILE the long-term outlook for the dollar seems to be dismal these days, what about other currencies? And if you are interested in investing in currencies, how best to go about it?

headline: The Watchword on Taxes This Year Is Flexibility
text: IF even the savviest of taxpayers feel confused about what strategies to follow this quarter to whittle tax liabilities for this year and beyond, they can be forgiven.

headline: A Philanthropy Coach Talks About Wise Giving
text: “IT’S easy to give money away, but it’s hard to do it well,” says Lisa Philp, who says she often serves as a philanthropy coach. Formally, her title is global head of philanthropic services at J. P. Morgan Private Bank, where she heads a 10-member team that works with individuals and families, other advisers in the bank’s worldwide operations and with nonprofit organizations, all in an effort to treat charitable giving with the same care given investments.

headline: The Caucus Click: Washington
text: Demonstrators brought a giant banner with words from the United States Constitution to a rally protesting the Citizens United ruling.

headline: Big Hurdles in Canada for BHP’s Potash Bid
text: BHP Billiton’s hostile bid for the Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan has hit a regulatory snag that may derail the proposed $38.6 billion deal before shareholders have their say on the matter.

headline: App Store Will Increase Competition in Mac Software
text: Among Apple’s new product announcements on Wednesday, which included updates to the company‘s Mac OS X operating system and iLife suite, one product probably sent a chill down the spine of a few software companies: the new Mac App Store.

headline: Noem Won’t Commit to Boehner as Speaker
text: Kristi Noem, a Republican challenging Representative Stephanie Herseth Sandlin in South Dakota, told a local newspaper on Wednesday that she would not commit to supporting the House Republican leader, John A. Boehner of Ohio, to be the next speaker if Republicans win control.

headline: Who’s Sorry Now?
text: It’s Virginia Thomas, not Anita Hill, who is apologizing – for the public appearances she has been canceling since the news broke Tuesday that she recently asked Ms. Hill to apologize for accusing Ms. Thomas’s husband, Justice Clarence Thomas, of sexual harassment during his Senate confirmation battle nearly 20 years ago.

headline: A Wood-Fired Hot Tub for an Old-Style Soak
text: MARTY PICCO, a 51-year-old software developer in Santa Cruz, Calif., does not seem like a back-to-the-land type. He has an iPhone, an iPad, two MacBooks, two desktop computers, a digital single-lens reflex camera and a plasma television. But when he bought a hot tub, he went for the lowest-tech model around.

headline: A New De Vera Store, Tailored to the Upper East Side
text: When Federico de Vera opened his first New York shop on the corner of Howard and Crosby Streets in SoHo seven years ago, he was a pioneer of sorts — the neighborhood wasn’t the rarefied area of retail it has since become. On Friday, Mr. de Vera will open his second Manhattan store, on another off-the-beaten-track spot, on the Upper East Side. “We have a good client base uptown,” he said. “And the energy is more peaceful than SoHo.”

headline: ‘Tools for Living: A Sourcebook of Iconic Designs for the Home’
text: For those who aim to fill their homes with the best everyday designer objects, there is a new shopping bible. “Tools for Living: A Sourcebook of Iconic Designs for the Home” (Fiell Publishing; $59.95), a 768-page tome to be published next month, tries to identify the most thoughtful, functional, reliable and aesthetically pleasing examples of almost every type of household product, regardless of price. That includes furnishings like chairs and lamps, and utilitarian items like waste bins and toilet brushes.

headline: Sales on Alessi Products, Lighting and More
text: During the Stewart/Stand Fall Into Design sale, through Wednesday, some Alessi items are up to 50 percent off (the Blow Up mirror, originally $303, is $150; the E-Li-Li vase, regularly $330, is $115; and, pictured, the coffee press, originally $170, is $85, and the mugs, regularly $75 for a pair, are $36); 141A Front Street (Pearl Street), Brooklyn, (718) 875-1204, stewartstand.com.

headline: Nought Collective Rugs, for Those Who Worship Icons
text: Tracey Sawyer, a New York designer who owns the Nought Collective, a company specializing in area rugs, is “inspired by the symbols that great civilizations use as icons,” she said. In her new collection, Oh My Head, Ms. Sawyer focuses on nine of them, ranging from the familiar (like the smiley face and the Statue of Liberty) to the lesser known (like Haida, above, inspired by Native American totem poles).

headline: Gerald Slota’s Photos Paired With Neil LaBute’s Words
text: “Home.Sweet.Home,” a show of 18 images by the photographer Gerald Slota, with captions by the playwright Neil LaBute, opened last week at the Ricco/Maresca Gallery in Chelsea.

headline: Making a Home in a Pyramid, 462 Feet Above Seattle
text: SEATTLE

headline: A Tiny Penthouse Studio Dressed in Comic Book Colors
text: ENID WOODWARD’S toenails are painted blue, a color you don’t often see on a mature woman. The walls of her tiny Manhattan penthouse are even more unusual — a strong sky blue, with blocks of red.

headline: Donald Trump on His New Line of Crystal
text: Donald Trump isn’t afraid to put his name on things — at last count, he had more than a dozen licensees making products bearing his name, including steaks and eyewear. But unlike other high-profile types, who lend their names to things they never actually use, Mr. Trump seems to delight in surrounding himself with Trump products. On a recent morning, during an interview at his 26th-floor office in Trump Tower, Mr. Trump was wearing a Donald Trump dress shirt, a Donald Trump necktie and Donald Trump cuff links.

headline: A Home in 600 Square Feet
text: Enid Woodward’s Upper West Side penthouse studio, which opens onto a terrace of nearly equal size, is a study in how to live small.

headline: G.M. Estate to Provide Millions for Cleanup of Old Sites
text: DETROIT  The bankruptcy estate of General Motors will commit $773 million toward cleaning up old plant sites and other property abandoned by the automaker, under a deal reached Wednesday with the Obama administration and 14 states.

headline: The Tricks and Trials of Traveling While Fat
text: AS soon as I board an aircraft, the first thing I do is make a beeline for the flight attendant and begin a routine that has changed little in 20 years:

headline: For Morgan Stanley, a Bad Report but the Right Track
text: James Gorman, Morgan Stanley’s chief executive, took one on the nose in the third quarter. While his peers have largely beat analysts’ estimates, Mr. Gorman presided over results that not only missed the target but included an unexpected $91 million loss. In fact, the company had to rely on one-time items to avoid an even worse showing. After a decent first half of the year, it’s a setback.

headline: Cracked Lens Alters View, but Not Game 4 Outcome
text: When Brett Gardner’s broken bat sailed toward a TBS camera Tuesday night at Yankee Stadium, Steve Angel’s gaze through the viewfinder was fixed on Alex Rodriguez at third base.

headline: How Money Influences Elections
text: To the Editor:

headline: Pentagon Will Help Homeland Security Department Fight Domestic Cyberattacks
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration has adopted new procedures for using the Defense Department’s vast array of cyberwarfare capabilities in case of an attack on vital computer networks inside the United States, delicately navigating historic rules that restrict military action on American soil.

headline: Macy’s Gets Fast Fashion
text: ANY retailer on earth would just about die to create the kind of consumer craze that takes place when H & M introduces a discount designer collaboration (like the heavily touted one from Lanvin coming on Nov. 20). The high-low concept has worked well for Target, Gap and Uniqlo, but the latest store to delve into fast fashion is a bit unexpected in that it is the classically mainstream Macy’s.

headline: Shopping With Martin Brudnizki
text: A designer who has done several restaurant interiors shopped for dining chairs in SoHo.

headline: Dining Chairs
text: WHILE some might insist that a dining chair should conform to certain standards — if nothing else, the seat ought to be a certain height — Martin Brudnizki disagrees.

headline: Muslim Sect Sees Struggle Through Christian Lens
text: NAJRAN, Saudi Arabia  Among the ruins on the edge of this ancient oasis city are deep trenches littered with bones. That, local people say, is all that remains of one of the great atrocities of antiquity, when thousands of Christians were herded into pits here and burned to death by a Jewish tyrant after they refused to renounce their faith.

headline: Struggling Phillies Like Fastballs, but the Giants Aren’t Cooperating
text: SAN FRANCISCO  After the Phillies were held to just three hits by Giants starter Matt Cain and two relievers Tuesday, Philadelphia center fielder Shane Victorino said there would be no going back to the drawing board  or a psychiatrist’s couch  for the Phillies’ hitters.

headline: Fear and Loathing in Nevada
text: Sharron Angle did not show up at the huge Tea Party Express rally in Las Vegas on Tuesday night. She rarely makes public appearances anymore. But the event was almost entirely in support of her and the divisive, anti-immigrant platform she has promoted in her accelerating drive to replace Senator Harry Reid.

headline: Final: A.L.C.S. Game 5 – Yankees 7, Rangers 2
text: The Yankees will play again in 2010 after taking Game 5 of the American League Championship Series against the Texas Rangers on Wednesday.

headline: One-Note Tax Debate
text: Several tax cuts are slated to expire at the end of the year, which means that the lame-duck Congress will face several tough decisions come November. To hear campaigning lawmakers tell it, however, the only tax issue out there is whether to extend the Bush-era tax cuts for the rich. The debate and the work can’t end there.

headline: L.A.-Style Chorizo
text: Approximately 8 feet sausage casing, packed in salt (optional; see note)

headline: Cooking With Dexter: Not in My Backyard
text: The backyard-chicken movement may be a great thing for poultry fanatics, but for parents it’s a nightmare. A few years ago, it was easy enough to say, “Oh, honey, we’d love to have a pet chicken, but unfortunately you aren’t allowed to keep hens in Hamden, Conn. [or Evanston, Ill., or Madison, Wis., or Salem, Ore.].” No more. Egg-gathering activists in those communities successfully lobbied for legalization. Naturally you can try lying to your children, but if they are old enough and resourceful enough they will eventually navigate their way to the backyardchickens.com forum on local laws and ordinances, and the jig will be up.

headline: Apple Flips the Playbook, Putting Mobile Tech in PCs
text: CUPERTINO, Calif.  Over the last few years, Apple used technologies from its Macintosh computers to create the iPhone and the iPad, building a multibillion-dollar mobile computing business that now accounts for 60 percent of its revenue.

headline: Analyzing the New Mac Landscape
text: With Apple‘s announcement on Wednesday of a redesigned MacBook Air, people looking to buy a Mac now have a new option to consider.

headline: N.A.A.C.P. Report Raises Concerns About Racism Within Tea Party Groups
text: The nation’s oldest and largest civil rights organization released a report Wednesday declaring that the Tea Party is “permeated with concerns about race,” an assessment that is likely to reignite a feud between the two groups.

headline: Yankees Get Back on Winning Track
text: The meeting in the Yankees’ clubhouse after their loss in Game 4 was brief, a standard, brink-of-elimination pep talk. Mariano Rivera characterized Manager Joe Girardi’s message like this: “Win today  period.” No ultimatums attached. None were needed.

headline: Early Action Could Aid in Admission, Report Finds
text: It is a question on the minds of so many high school seniors at this time of year: How can you raise your chances of getting into your No. 1 college choice?

headline: United Nations Report Focuses on Global Lot of Women
text: UNITED NATIONS  American men who maintain they are doing more housework have a second source to back their claim  a United Nations report released Wednesday  although it would be premature to argue that the sexes had reached parity on domestic chores or nearly any other issue.

headline: To Promote PBS Film, an Invitation to Head South
text: THE filmmaker Stanley Nelson’s documentary “Freedom Riders” will not be shown on PBS until May 16, but the promotional campaign has already started.

headline: Regrets? Yes. And Money Was the Root of Them All.
text: This week, Christine Haughney, who writes the weekly column The Appraisal, described efforts by developers to get back commissions they had paid to real estate agents for deals that later fell through. She asked readers to describe some financial decisions, or purchases, that they wish they could reverse. Some took a wide view of the question, to say the least. Here are our favorites:

headline: President Will Travel To Pakistan Next Year
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama announced on Wednesday that he would visit Pakistan next year for the first time since taking office as his administration tries to bolster rocky relations with perhaps its most important partner in the war against Al Qaeda and its allies.

headline: An Outsider, or Merely Outlandish?
text: MOUNT KISCO, N.Y.

headline: How to Really End ‘Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell’
text: Washington

headline: Defenders Criticize N.F.L. For Helmet-to-Helmet Fines
text: The N.F.L. knew its crackdown on helmet-to-helmet hits would not quickly be embraced by defensive players who have long complained that rules protecting offenses make it difficult to do their jobs.

headline: Battered Landscape for a California Democrat
text: MANTECA, Calif.  When Jerry McNerney, a Democrat, was first elected to Congress in 2006, it was both an upset and, it seemed, a harbinger.

headline: Foreclosures Profit Some Equity Firms
text: With a surge in lawsuits against law firms specializing in foreclosures, a case in Mississippi is casting light on another aspect of the mortgage mess  the connection between Wall Street private equity firms and those law firms, often known as foreclosure mills.

headline: Afghan Election Commission Is Praised for Its Fairness, in Spite of Tainted Voting
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Despite rampant fraud in the parliamentary elections last month, whose preliminary results were announced Wednesday, the Afghan Independent Election Commission appears to have tried to do an honest job of counting the ballots, an effort that was lauded by the United Nations and even by some losing candidates.

headline: Court Keeps Military Gay Policy for Now
text: WASHINGTON  A federal appeals court on Wednesday temporarily stalled the landmark court decision allowing openly gay recruits to be accepted into the military.

headline: Malpractice Methodology
text: The health care legislation that Congress enacted earlier this year, contrary to much of today’s overheated rhetoric, does many things right. But it does almost nothing to reform medical malpractice laws. Lawmakers missed an important opportunity to shield from malpractice liability any doctors who followed evidence-based guidelines in treating their patients.

headline: A Pharmacist With Dreams of Independence
text: Maria Frangos, 25, imagined a future as a careerist in snazzy business suits, ensconced in her own office, until she took a college-level class in business management and despised it. Inspired by her older brother, a pharmacy intern, she changed course. Six years of college later, she is a licensed pharmacist holding down two jobs in Brooklyn: at the Starrett City CVS, part of the national chain; and at the Fifth Avenue branch of Neergaard Pharmacies, a Park Slope institution since 1888. She lives in Park Slope with her parents and her brother, Minas, 27, also a pharmacist.

headline: Photo Replay: Oct. 20
text: A view of the day in sports, from the beam to basketball to baseball.

headline: Dr. Greg and Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan

headline: Trade Spats Are Driving a Wedge in the G-20
text: WASHINGTON  Representatives of the Group of 20 economic powers, who managed to cooperate during the financial crisis two years ago, will confront festering disputes over trade and currency this weekend, and try to reconcile diverging approaches for how to deal with them.

headline: Climate Change Doubt Is Tea Party Article of Faith
text: JASPER, Ind. — At a candidate forum here last week, Representative Baron P. Hill, a threatened Democratic incumbent in a largely conservative southern Indiana district, was endeavoring to explain his unpopular vote for the House cap-and-trade energy bill.

headline: Despite Speculation, Dolan Is Not Named a Cardinal
text: Italian newspapers were among the first — back in March — to float the rumor that New York’s charismatic new archbishop, Timothy M. Dolan, was sure to be made a cardinal at the next big meeting of Roman Catholic prelates in Rome. The rumor sustained a robust life on its own, fed by Catholic news media and the eternal curiosity of many American Catholics about the nebulous world of Vatican power.

headline: G.O.P. Odds of House Majority Now 3-in-4
text: The latest FiveThirtyEight projection for the House of Representatives shows little overall change from our previous update, released this weekend, but the Republican position has improved slightly. They are now given a 75 percent chance of winning the House on Nov. 2, up from 73 percent previously. During an average simulation run, the Republicans finished with a total of 228 seats (up from 227): this would reflect a net gain of 49 seats from their current position.

headline: As Dollar’s Value Falls, Currency Conflicts Rise
text: Is this a currency war or what?

headline: The Fury Failure
text: Rage is not working out.

headline: Rejection by N.B.A. Gives New Shoes Even Greater Bounce
text: For the founders of a fledgling athletic-shoe company, there is only one thing better for business than having an N.B.A. star endorse your new shoes: have the league say the shoes will not be allowed on its courts at all.

headline: Union Plans to Try to Block Release of Teacher Ratings
text: The city’s teachers’ union said on Wednesday that it would request a restraining order to prevent education officials from releasing reports that rate thousands of city teachers based on how much progress students made on state standardized tests.

headline: G.O.P. Ad in Alaska Hits Obama
text: With Election Day less than two weeks away, negative political advertisements are popping up on television screens all across the country.

headline: Your Court in Action
text: “Let me correct some things that Mr. Frederick said that were not true.” That was as close as a Supreme Court lawyer comes to calling her adversary a liar. The speaker was Kathleen Sullivan, a formidable advocate and former dean of Stanford Law School, challenging David Frederick, just as impressive and well credentialed, at the court last week.

headline: Tidal Power: The Next Wave?
text: Over the next few years, we can expect to see huge advances in our ability to harness power from the ocean’s waves and tides, a new report from IHS Emerging Energy Research, a Cambridge, Mass., consulting firm, predicts.

headline: Ernest Gaines, Acclaimed Author at Home
text: Ernest J. Gaines, 77 is part of the fifth generation of his family to be born on a plantation in Oscar, La., where his ancestors were slaves.

headline: Writer Tends Land Where Ancestors Were Slaves
text: OSCAR, La.  His ancestors were slaves. They worked this flat plantation land just west of the snaking Mississippi, chopping sugar cane with their machetes. They and some of their descendants lived in the plantation’s “quarters.” And when they died, most were buried here in a small patch of earth, for blacks only.

headline: Thy Neighbor’s Duplex
text: Recently, when I was in Austin, Tex., I drove by a house with a helipad.

headline: John Roberts’s America
text: COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo. — I wish Chief Justice John Roberts could spend a day and a night in the Rocky Mountains experiencing what his activist Supreme Court majority has dumped on the American voter in 2010.

headline: Lee Looms Large for Yanks in Texas
text: Kerry Wood can tell us better than anyone how home field and the hottest pitchers do not necessarily make for the most secure safety net. He can tell us about the Cubs and the Marlins, himself and Mark Prior, Steve Bartman and the trapdoor a team can fall through just when it seems ready to take off for the stars.

headline: Coalition Forces Routing Taliban in Key Afghan Region
text: ARGHANDAB, Afghanistan  American and Afghan forces have been routing the Taliban in much of Kandahar Province in recent weeks, forcing many hardened fighters, faced with the buildup of American forces, to flee strongholds they have held for years, NATO commanders, local Afghan officials and residents of the region said.

headline: At Detainee’s Trial, Insider Gives Glimpse Into Al Qaeda
text: A former military trainer for Al Qaeda choked up when a prosecutor asked him on Wednesday why he quit the terrorist group in the mid-1990s.

headline: Lottery Numbers
L.S.U.’s Record Says 7-0; L.S.U.’s Fans Say, Lucky
text: BATON ROUGE, La.  There are fans here who want their 7-0 team to look more tidy. They want some polish, a little more shine. They do not know quite how to wrap their arms around this Louisiana State squad, especially its coach, Les Miles.

headline: Timetable Is Set for the Only Civil Trial in a 9/11 Death
text: Eight months from now, the family of Mark Bavis will get what they have wanted since he died on Sept. 11, 2001: their day in court.

headline: Our Culture, From Marilyn Monroe to Sarah Palin
text: To the Editor:

headline: Efforts to Prosecute Blackwater Are Collapsing
text: WASHINGTON  Nearly four years after the federal government began a string of investigations and criminal prosecutions against Blackwater Worldwide personnel accused of murder and other violent crimes in Iraq and Afghanistan, the cases are beginning to fall apart, burdened by a legal obstacle of the government’s own making.

headline: Talking to the Taliban: Some Questions to Ask
text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: Posey Helps Giants Win With Offense
text: SAN FRANCISCO

headline: In No Trouble, Schumer Opens Coffers to Party
text: With his re-election virtually assured against a little-known Republican challenger, Senator Charles E. Schumer of New York is using his campaign war chest to help other Democrats across the country running for the Senate get elected next month.

headline: Carlsen Takes Early Lead in Pearl Spring Tournament
text: As one of the strongest tournaments of the year begins, one of the participants is still dealing with the fallout from a feud with his own chess federation.

headline: ‘Rent Is Too Damn High,’ Set to Music
text: The synthesizer pulses with an urgency that fits the lyrics. The voice is at once smooth and aged, reminding the listener of Ted Hawkins playing for pocket change on Venice Beach, but shot through with a dash of Chuck D. The lyrics, meanwhile, are straight-up Woody Guthrie.

headline: Keady Brings His Aura to St. John’s
text: Steve Lavin, the new basketball coach at St. John’s, sat with three of his players on folding chairs on a dais inside Madison Square Garden on Wednesday and talked for 90 minutes about the coming season. The players were excited. Lavin was much more measured.

headline: Anthony Is Topic No. 1 As Trade Talks Percolate
text: PHILADELPHIA  Eight days before the start of the Amar’e Stoudemire era, the conversation was about Carmelo Anthony. It might be this way for a while.

headline: Police Discretion Is Issue in Injured Bystander’s Suit
text: After the gunfire ceased in Harlem one evening in 2005, it became clear that a 25-bullet fusillade by police officers had done more damage than intended.

headline: Bob Guccione, Penthouse Founder, Dies at 79
text: Bob Guccione, who founded Penthouse magazine in the 1960s and built a pornographic media empire that broke taboos, outraged the guardians of taste and made billions before drowning in a slough of bad investments and Internet competition, died Wednesday in Plano, Tex. He was 79.

headline: OTB Gets Relief
text: New York City Off-Track Betting Corporation, the bankrupt operator of 68 wagering locations across the city, will remain open after reaching a debt-forgiveness agreement with unsecured creditors. About $95 million owed by OTB, which in March was ruled eligible for Chapter 9 reorganization, will be resolved, according to a statement by New York Governor David Paterson. Creditors including Yonkers Racing Corporation and New York Racing Association will forgive about $65 million in exchange for some of OTB’s wagering operations and changes to state racing laws to help video-lottery terminal operators generate revenue.

headline: Paul S. Miller, Advocate for Disabled, Dies at 49
text: Paul Miller, a lawyer who was born with achondroplasia  dwarfism  overcame discrimination because of his disability and became a leader in the disability rights movement, died Tuesday at his home on Mercer Island, Wash. He was 49.

headline: Thursday: Dr. Squish
text: Dan Naddor died last December, but not before submitting three crosswords to The New York Times. The first two ran on March 21 and May 6. He stops by today for his final Times visit and, as Will Shortz says, “he goes out with a bang!”

headline: My Son, Not Myself
text: Dave Marcus went to Brown. Now he writes and lectures about the college admissions process, spreading the message that there’s no “best” school, just a good fit, and parents shouldn’t live their own dreams through their children, and that it all works out for the best in the end.

headline: Experts Review Canadian Commander’s Sadistic Crimes
text: OTTAWA — He had a privileged upbringing, a highly successful career and sadistic sexual urges that would qualify as extreme even by the morbid standards of serial killers.

headline: Tiles, Farms and the Dead Zone
text: Every year, usually beginning in late spring, an oxygen-depleted dead zone forms in the Gulf of Mexico at the Mississippi River’s mouth, killing off fish, shrimp and other marine life. By the time cooler weather restores life to the zone, the fishing industry has sustained substantial losses.

headline: Mistakes Catch Up to Rangers in Game 5
text: While the Texas Rangers are still in command of the American League Championship Series, Wednesday’s game at Yankee Stadium raised concerns for them, beyond the fact that the Yankees won, 7-2, to force Game 6 on Friday in Texas.

headline: F.B.I. Computer System Is Late and Over Budget, Report Says
text: A computer system for the Federal Bureau of Investigation known as Sentinel is $100 million over budget and two years behind schedule, said a report released Wednesday by the Justice Department’s inspector general. As of August, after spending about $405 million of the $451 million budgeted, only two of the four phases of the project had been completed, according to the report. Thomas J. Harrington, associate director of the F.B.I., said the report did not accurately reflect the bureau’s management of the project, relied on outdated cost estimates and failed to credit the bureau with taking steps to stay within budget.

headline: In the Series Undercard, Cano and Hamilton Are Slugging It Out
text: The cities are different, but the chants are the same. Josh Hamilton heard Rangers fans rhythmically shout “M.V.P.!” for him during the first two games of the American League Championship Series in Arlington, Tex. For the last three days in the Bronx, Yankee fans chanted the same for Robinson Cano.

headline: Facing Runoff in Brazil, Candidate Backed by President Stays Ahead of Her Rival
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — With less than two weeks until the deciding second round of Brazil’s presidential election, Dilma Rousseff, the chosen successor to President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, is staving off a late push from her rival candidate.

headline: White Knight Is Shaken by Dark Horse in Illinois
text: CHICAGO  Less than two years ago, when Patrick J. Quinn, a Democrat and the lieutenant governor of Illinois, was elevated to governor after a corruption scandal swirling around Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich, he was hailed as a welcome, desperately needed respite from what had come before.

headline: Hockey Urged to Ban All Blows to Head by Concussions Panel
text: ROCHESTER, Minn. — A conference on reducing concussions in hockey recommended prohibiting contact to the head at every level of the game, including the N.H.L., and banning body checking by 11- and 12-year-olds to reduce the high rate of concussions among youth players.

headline: Somalia: British Aid Worker is Released Unharmed
text: The British aid worker kidnapped last week by Somali gunmen was released unharmed on Wednesday, aid officials said, after extensive negotiations with clan elders. The aid worker, Frans Barnard, left, a consultant for Save the Children, was taken at gunpoint last Thursday from a guest house in Adado. Clan elders there persuaded the kidnappers to free Mr. Barnard, said Anna Ford, a Save the Children spokeswoman. She denied reports from Somali residents that a $100,000 ransom had been paid.

headline: A.L.C.S. Photo Replay: Oct. 20
text: A look at Game 5 of the American League Championship Series between the Yankees and the Rangers.

headline: Water Scarcity a Bond Risk, Study Warns
text: The municipal bonds that help finance a major portion of the nation’s water supply may be riskier than investors realize because their credit ratings do not adequately reflect the growing risks of water shortages and legal battles over water supplies, according to a new study.

headline: Q. & A. With the Rangers Owner Chuck Greenberg
text: Chuck Greenberg and Nolan Ryan were part of the group that acquired the Texas Rangers from Tom Hicks on Aug. 5 in a federal bankruptcy court auction. At the time, the team had a record of 63-45, good enough to be in first place in the American League West by eight and a half games. They beat Tampa Bay in five games to win the division series and were up 3-1 over the Yankees in the A.L.C.S. when Richard Sandomir talked to Greenberg by telephone before Game 5 of the series.

headline: China G.D.P. Grew 9.6% Despite Cooling Efforts
text: HONG KONG  The Chinese economy continued to expand at a rapid clip during the third quarter, demonstrating that government measures aimed at reining in growth have not choked off expansion.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Mayo Clinic Calls for Tougher Head-Checking Rule in N.H.L.
text: ROCHESTER, Minn. — The Mayo Clinic conference on concussions in hockey called for the N.H.L. to completely outlaw all contact with the head, proposing a rule that would go far beyond the N.H.L.’s current Rule 48 banning blindside hits to the head.

headline: NPR Fires Analyst Over Comments on Muslims
text: NPR has terminated its contract with Juan Williams, one of its senior news analysts, after he made comments about Muslims on the Fox News Channel.

headline: Grandmaster Plans to Play More Than 500 People at the Same Time
text: One of the feats that elite chess players can do that always seems to amaze people who do not play chess (or play it very little) is competing against many opponents at the same time. These simultaneous displays, or simuls, seem impressive, but as long as there are not too many participants (say more than 20 or 25) and none of them are too skilled, it is not all that difficult.

headline: Dr. Georges Mathé, Transplant Pioneer, Dies at 88
text: In the morning of the atomic age, there was optimism that the nuclear genie could heal as well as kill. By the mid-1950s, researchers had cured mice of leukemia by destroying diseased bone marrow with near-lethal doses of radiation, then rescuing them by transplanting healthy marrow.

headline: Word of the Day | assay
text: assay •\ˈa-ˌsa, a-ˈsa\• noun and verb

headline: Giants Push Phillies to the Brink
text: SAN FRANCISCO  All around AT&T Park, there are reminders of the great Giants sluggers. There is a statue out front of Willie Mays and a cove out back named for Willie McCovey. Even Barry Bonds made a rare appearance when he bounced out of the dugout to throw out the first pitch when the National League Championship Series returned here.

headline: China: Tibetan Students March To Protest Education Policies
text: More than 1,000 Tibetan students marched in peaceful rallies Tuesday in a town in Qinghai Province to protest Chinese education policies, according to reports from Tibetan advocacy groups Wednesday and photographs and video of the protests circulating on the Internet. The protests were in and around Tongren, known in Tibetan as Rebkong, on the edge of the Tibetan plateau. The town has one of the most prominent monasteries in the Tibetan world, and monks there have protested against Chinese policies in recent years. Some monks joined the student protesters, who shouted “equality of ethnic groups” and “freedom of language,” according to the International Campaign for Tibet.

headline: Equatorial Guinea: Unesco Expected to Hold Award in Abeyance
text: The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization is expected to vote in plenary session Thursday to continue to suspend the awarding of a prize underwritten by President Teodoro Obiang Neguema Mgasogo of Equatorial Guinea, European diplomats said on Wednesday. The United States and other Western countries won agreement from African members on a compromise that mandates the continuing suspension of the Unesco-Obiang prize, some $3 million, for research in the life sciences “until a consensus is reached” among members, which is unlikely to occur. Mr. Obiang is suspected of being highly corrupt, and most of Equatorial Guinea’s residents are extremely poor, despite the country’s oil wealth.

headline: Aid Groups’ Advice in Afghanistan
text: In connection with my Thursday column, I asked several NGO’s for their advice on how to work in insecure or Taliban areas. Their advice was remarkably consistent, all about consulting local people and getting buy-in from them. And of course that’s good advice whether it’s an aid organization in the South Bronx or in southern Afghanistan.

headline: Marijuana Bonfire Celebrates a Fragile Calm
text: TIJUANA, Mexico  It is now the city safe enough for an Al Gore speech.

headline: U.S. Tries to Ease Wider Worries Over Foreclosures
text: Administration officials renewed efforts on Wednesday to ease concerns about the integrity of the foreclosure process, saying that no evidence had emerged so far of any problems that threatened the health of the financial system, Binyamin Appelbaum reports for The New York Times.

headline: News Quiz | October 21, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Battle Lines Forming in Clash Over Foreclosures
text: About a month after Washington Mutual Bank made a multimillion-dollar mortgage loan on a mountain home near Santa Barbara, Calif., a crucial piece of paperwork disappeared, Gretchen Morgenson and Andrew Martin report in The New York Times.

headline: Foreclosures Profit Some Firms
text: With a surge in lawsuits against law firms specializing in foreclosures, a case in Mississippi is casting light on another aspect of the mortgage mess — the connection between Wall Street private equity firms and those law firms, often known as foreclosure mills, Barry Meier writes in The New York Times.

headline: Wells Fargo Reports Higher Earnings
text: Within weeks of scooping up the failed banking operations of Washington Mutual in late 2008, JPMorgan Chase began phasing out the WaMu brand, replacing signs on retail branches. WaMu accounts became Chase accounts. Just over a year later, the conversion was done, turning the WaMu name into a relic of the financial crisis, Eric Dash reports in The New York Times.

headline: Would You Trade Your Paper Books for Digital Versions?
text: Do you own an e-reader or read books on your phone? Have you ever used an electronic textbook? Studies show that while young people are interested in e-readers,  two-thirds of them do not want to give up traditional print books. What do you think? Should students be given a choice? What are the benefits and drawbacks of print books and textbooks? How do you think reading on an electronic device would change reading, studying and learning for you?

headline: Eisman’s FrontPoint Back on Its Own
text: Steve Eisman, the hedge fund manager who made millions by anticipating the housing market collapse long before anyone else did, is back on his own.

headline: Bair Says U.S. Bank Rules to Be Stricter Than Basel

headline: Japan’s NTT Data Is Reported to Buy Keane Inc.
text: NTT Data, an information technology company in Japan, plans to buy Boston-based Keane Inc., a computing services company, for more than 100 billion yen ($1.2 billion) as it looks to make a push into the world’s biggest I.T. market, the Nikkei business daily said on Thursday, according to Reuters.

headline: Credit Suisse Profit Down on Sluggish Trading
text: Swiss bank Credit Suisse‘s third-quarter net profit tumbled 74 percent and missed forecasts, as sluggish equities trading cut investment banking earnings in half from the previous quarter, Reuters reported.

headline: Time for Some New Stress Tests for Banks
text: Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is a co-author of “13 Bankers.”

headline: Conoco Chief Says Asset Sales May Top $10 Billion
text: ConocoPhillips may sell more assets than it initially planned as part of its two-year effort to raise cash and reduce debt, the company’s chief executive has told CNBC, according to Reuters.

headline: Swedbank Earnings Point to Baltic Turnaround
text: Shares of Swedbank, the largest bank in the Baltic countries, rose to their highest price in more than two years in Stockholm trading after reporting better-than-estimated earnings, helped by a profit rebound in the region, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: S.E.C. Set to Vote on Rattner Deal, Report Says
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission is to vote on Thursday on a settlement with Steven L. Rattner, the former head of the government’s auto task force, over his role in a pay-to-play scheme, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Piper Jaffray Profit Slips, Prompting Strategic Shift
text: Piper Jaffray, the broker and middle-market investment bank based in Minneapolis, has reported a $7.1 million profit for the third quarter, down nearly 24 percent from the period a year earlier and slightly below its second-quarter numbers.

headline: Bravo Brio Cooks Up $140 Million in I.P.O.
text: The Bravo Brio Restaurant Group , an Italian restaurant chain, raised $140 million selling shares at the low end of the price range for its initial public offering.

headline: Renoir’s Passion, on Display at the Prado
text: Passion is a concept constantly revisited in the work of Pierre-August Renoir. The popular Impressionist devoted his life to painting the female figure, nudes, landscapes, still lifes and flowers — all with a vibrancy matched by few. A master of form, light and color, he glorified bourgeois life, taking particular interest in feminine sensuality.

headline: TAL Education of China Soars 50% in Debut
text: Shares of TAL Education Group, a Chinese tutoring company, rose 50 percent in their market debut, after the firm’s initial public offering raised $120 million.

headline: Ecotricity of Britain Plans ‘EcoBond’ Offering
text: Ecotricity,  Britain’s largest independent green energy company, plans to raise up to £10 million ($15.7 million) through a four-year bond to help accelerate its plans to build renewable energy sources.

headline: Former Morgan Stanley Banker Lands at Cheyne
text: A former Morgan Stanley star banker, John Hyman, has landed at Cheyne Capital, the British hedge fund, Financial News reported.

headline: Avenue Capital Said to Plan Listed Credit Fund
text: The  Avenue Capital Group, the hedge fund run by Marc Lasry, plans to raise a fund to buy different types of credit by selling shares to the public, a first for the firm, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Pakistani Justices Resist Control
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The Supreme Court directed Parliament on Thursday to reconsider its efforts to amend the Constitution to claim greater power over higher-court appointments.

headline: Private Equity Invests a Record $40 Billion in 3rd Quarter
text: Private equity firms invested a record $40.1 billion of cash in the third quarter as global credit markets remained tight, Bloomberg News said, citing an industry report.

headline: Regulator of Fannie and Freddie Said to Hire Law Firm
text: The Federal Housing Finance Agency, overseer of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the crippled mortgage finance giants, has hired a law firm specializing in business litigation, signaling that the agency may be considering further legal steps to recover billions of dollars related to mortgage-backed securities purchased from Wall Street firms, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Hands Is Said to Have Most of His Fortune Tied to EMI
text: Guy Hands, the British financier, had two-thirds of his fortune sunk into the music group EMI before his firm’s buyout of the company ran into debt trouble.

headline: Somebody Stole My Idea!

I said that I sympathized with the urge to start and run more than one business, especially if you’d had a taste of success and understood the dynamics of getting a venture from concept to commercial viability.

headline: Russia to Sell 15% of Rosneft to Help Balance Budget
text: Russia plans to sell as much as 15 percent of Rosneft, its biggest oil producer, as the government seeks to raise 1.8 trillion rubles ($59 billion) in asset sales in the next five years to help balance the budget, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: N.Y. Pension Invests $300 Million in Blackstone Fund
text: The Blackstone Group‘s buyout funds continue to prove popular with New York State’s $124.8 billion pension plan, with the state pension investing a fresh $300 million in the private equity firm’s latest buyout fund, according to Comptroller Thomas P. DiNapoli.

headline: Carlyle Hunts Deals as Chief Predicts Industry Divide
text: The Carlyle Group is in talks to buy both an unidentified hedge fund and AlpInvest Partners, the Dutch private equity fund of funds, as Carlyle’s co-founder, David M. Rubenstein, pictured, predicts the buyout industry is facing a split between larger diversified firms and niche players, The Financial Times reported.

headline: 1.5 Million Toyotas Recalled for Brake and Fuel Pump Problems

headline: The Early Word: Women Out West
text: The Election Day outlook for Democrats remains dim, as President Obama, his administration and supporters search for the energy of 2008. Today, women are the focus.

text: Toyota is recalling 1.53 million vehicles worldwide, including 740,000 vehicles in the United States, that could leak brake fluid and cause stopping power to “gradually decline.”

headline: First Impressions From South Korea
text: I arrived today at the Yeongam circuit for the inaugural Korean Grand Prix. Let me start by admitting that this race was the one that I least wanted to attend this season, and I was not alone in that feeling. Many of the journalists who attend most of the races are not attending this one, and many others had said to me as well that it was the one they least wanted to attend. In fact, I am quickly coming to the conclusion that I am having a delightful time and that this could end up being a popular one – at least with the people within the Formula One circus.

headline: First Impressions From South Korea
text: I arrived today at the Yeongam circuit for the inaugural Korean Grand Prix. Let me start by admitting that this race was the one that I least wanted to attend this season, and I was not alone in that feeling. Many of the journalists who attend most of the races are not attending this one, and many others had said to me as well that it was the one they least wanted to attend. In fact, I am quickly coming to the conclusion that I am having a delightful time and that this could end up being a popular one – at least with the people within the Formula One circus.

headline: Americans Aren’t Saving Enough for Retirement, Study Finds
text: The typical middle-age American is saving far too little for retirement, and the Employee Benefit Research Institute has estimated the shortfall: an average of $47,732 per individual over the course of that person’s retirement.

headline: Wall Street Seesaws Through the Day, Closing Slightly Higher
text: Shares closed slightly higher on Thursday, after a day of seesawing despite corporate earnings reports that were generally upbeat.

headline: Rocking the Vote, in the 1820s and Now
text: NOT long before Andrew Jackson’s death in 1845, George P.A. Healy, the American portraitist, traveled south to Tennessee to paint Jackson and other statesmen  including Henry Clay of Kentucky, an implacable Jackson foe. Healy was expected at Ashland, Clay’s estate in Lexington, but overstayed his time at Jackson’s Hermitage in Nashville. When Healy finally made his appearance in Kentucky, Clay knew that Jackson had won yet again. Clay did not bother hiding his jealousy and resignation, remarking to Healy, “I see that you, like all who approached that man, were fascinated by him.”

headline: A Former Renegade Spirit Becomes a Headmistress
text: WHEN Gelsey Kirkland is not teaching a ballet class, you get the feeling that a gust of wind could scoop her up and blow her away.

headline: ‘A Quiet Place’ Of Dysfunction And Dystopia
text: AS the motorcade carrying the body of Leonard Bernstein passed through Brooklyn on its way to Green-Wood Cemetery 20 years ago, construction workers removed their yellow hard hats and called out, “Goodbye, Lenny!” It was a gesture of affection unthinkable for any other classical musician. In death, as in life, Bernstein was the exception: capable of anything and, almost, everything. One of the great conductors of the 20th century, he was also a composer, educator, television personality and political activist who at one point hobnobbed with the Black Panthers.

headline: Matters of Spirit In a World Of Hectic Clamor
text: “MANY if not all of the answers to one’s own life actually lie inside ourselves,” a smiling professional said during a recent private session in a tidy Upper West Side office. “I believe deeply in having access to, and spending time with, one’s interior life.”

headline: Career Zigzag, Changing Coasts And Galaxies
text: IN a contemporary nightmare on YouTube titled “Zachary Quinto Cannot Escape the Swarm of Fans,” a mob of unrelenting Klingons outside a Hollywood event crowd in on the unnerved Mr. Quinto, shoving cameras and photographs in his face, demanding autographs as he struggles to navigate the two blocks to his car.

Fried, a geriatrician, has sought to make the dramatic aging of the world’s population, and its myriad ramifications, one of the pillars of education for the 1,100 graduate students there.

headline: Food and Property Prices Drive China’s Concern Over Inflation
text: SHANGHAI  China’s roaring economy slowed in the third quarter, rising at an annual rate of 9.6 percent after the government took steps to prevent overheating, according to data released Thursday. But inflation last month hit its highest rate in nearly two years.

headline: On Our Radar: A Debate Challenge for Charles Koch
text: A senior at Cal State in Los Angeles who belongs to a student group on clean energy challenges Charles Koch, chief executive of Koch Industries, to a debate on Proposition 23, which would indefinitely suspend California’s climate change and clean energy law. headline: Report Criticizes Senators on Casino in Queens
text: State Senate leaders manipulated the choice of who would build New York City’s first casino, leaking information and showing favoritism to a troubled bidder that was donating to Democratic candidates and had ties to key political figures, the state inspector general said Thursday.

headline: Thursday Reading: The Latest Recalls
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Running for Charity Fuels a Boom in Marathoning

headline: Fired From NPR, Juan Williams Keeps Talking on Fox
text: 1:58 p.m. | Updated throughout  On the Fox News Channel Thursday morning, Juan Williams objected to NPR’s decision to fire him and stood by his statements earlier in the week about Muslims.

headline: Office for Mac Isn’t an Improvement
text: It’s a big month for Mac fans. Yesterday, Apple showed off a preview of the next Mac OS X version, called Lion (coming in summer 2011); a new MacBook Air laptop (faster, solid-state instead of a hard drive, available in 11- and 13-inch sizes); new versions of iMovie and iPhoto; and a Mac software store modeled after the iPhone app store. I’ll review ’em when I get ’em.

headline: Easing the Transition From Soldier to Civilian
text: When the fighting began in Afghanistan nearly nine years ago, it was almost unthinkable that the upper-echelons of the military would one day own up to the psychological damage of war. Post-traumatic stress disorder was seen as the vestige of long ago wars, its consequences buried under hundreds of years of stigma and shame.

headline: Notes From the Women’s Forum
text: Last week in Deauville, France, nearly 900 women from around the world gathered for the Women’s Forum for the Economy and Society. For me, the most rewarding aspect of the conference was the opportunity to meet female entrepreneurs from every corner of the globe. I was impressed by the ways in which their experiences often mirrored those of women who build companies in the United States.

headline: Your Comments on High-Octane Parents, and Their Blessedly Decaffeinated Children

headline: Canadian Colonel Is Given 2 Life Jail Terms
text: BELLEVILLE, Ontario — When Col. David Russell Williams pleaded guilty to two counts of first-degree murder on Monday, he was condemned under Canadian law to a sentence of life in prison without any chance of parole for 25 years.

headline: Answers to Your Questions on the Foreclosure Crisis, Part II
text: Earlier this week we asked you to  submit questions for Thomas A. Lawler, a housing expert, about the foreclosure crisis. Mr. Lawler is a founder of Lawler Economic & Housing Consulting, and a former director and senior vice president at Fannie Mae. We posted his first set of responses yesterday; here is another.

headline: Studio Kabul
text: At the age of 27, after 14 years of marriage, with seven children and a husband 30 years older than she was, a husband who was addicted to opium, who once deprived her of food because she gave birth to a girl and not a boy, who beat her when she took too long to conceive, who pulled out her hair and knocked out her teeth to make her too ugly to remarry, who beat her again when he couldn’t find money for opium because he had spent it on phone cards for the mobile to call his lovers — after 14 years, Abada had had enough. She cried, screamed, pulled out her hair, desperate to die. She put her littlest daughter outside the room where she cooked. She turned on the gas and waited for peace.

text: Behind-the-scenes images from Afghanistan’s first soap opera.

headline: Sondheim’s Rhymes and Reasons
text: What’s so great about “Finishing the Hat,” the new book on songwriting by Stephen Sondheim, is implicit in its title. This self-portrait of the artist as an obsessive lyricist is about a dynamic, unending process; it’s about finishing, not having finished. And the mental energy this process emanates is enough to give a reader a satisfying case of brain burn.

headline: Thai Flooding Is Called Worst in Decades

headline: Geek Chic | Luxe City Guides for iPhone
text: Not that a Luxe City Guide ever took up much space in your pocket — its slim profile was always its genius. But these days it’s always a cause for celebration when a traveler can dispense with paper altogether (however gorgeously laminated it may be) and bring all his intelligence with him on his smartphone. Our friends at Luxe have rolled out a wide collection of their snappy directories for iPhone, covering 20 cities in total, among them Los Angeles, Florence, Venice and Beijing. Now the hotels listings come with pictures; there are GPS-enabled maps and automatic updates; and the whole guide can be searched and personalized with itineraries based on your favorites. What remains from the dead-tree versions, of course, are the cheekily concise summations of a smart selection of accommodations, restaurants, shops, clubs and culture — along with sundry raves, grievances and anecdotes. If there’s one thing lacking, it’s that we might like to read more of what the Luxe founder Grant Thatcher and his team have to say about the three bistros we’re trying to decide between (seriously, Thatcher’s hilarious). In the Luddite version of the guide, each gets only a sentence. But now that we’re measuring in megabytes and not column inches, why not gas on a bit?

headline: RNC Raises $10M in September, But Cash is Low
text: The Republican National Committee raised close to $10 million in September but ended the month essentially under water financially, with only about $3.4 million in cash on hand but $4.6 million in debts and obligations. The struggling national party committee also took out a $2.5 million loan.

headline: The Games People Play: Twist the Brain, Stretch the Body

Even bookstore employees didn’t know.

headline: Losing Touch With the Patient
text: Several years ago I helped care for a man who had been hospitalized with a severe infection of the abdominal wall. When his primary doctors discovered that the bacteria responsible was resistant to most antibiotics, they quickly isolated him, moving him into a single room with a sign on the door proclaiming “Contact Precautions” and directing visitors to put on gloves, mask and gown before entering.

headline: Putting Barriers Between Doctor and Patient
text: Because of growing alarm about the spread of MRSA and other hardy “superbugs,” precautions like hand washing, physical isolation, gloves and masks have become a routine part of clinical life in hospitals. But despite their widespread use and acceptance, only a few studies have acknowledged that the rigidity and isolation inherent in such limitations may themselves lead to problems.

headline: Wick and Mortar
text: Cire Trudon, the cult candle maker that once dipped tapers for Marie Antoinette, has transformed the corner of Bond Street and the Bowery into a tiny version of Versailles’s Galerie des Glaces. The company’s first Stateside outpost, which opens this week on the lower-ground level of the old Bouwerie Lane Theater, is filled with antique mirrors and historical French moldings and hardware — the perfect surroundings for perfumed candles, pillars and room sprays that conjure waxed palace floors and Madame de Pompadour’s boudoir. Cire Trudon’s 36-year-old owner, Ramdane Touhami, a forward-thinking classicist if ever there was one, invites customers to linger in the space for as long as they like. “Choosing a scent for your home should be like choosing one for your body,” he says. “It takes time.”

headline: New Zealand Still in ‘Hobbit’ Picture, for Now
text: LOS ANGELES—The tussle between producers of two planned films based on “The Hobbit” and a New Zealand union is still going on, despite a move on Wednesday by the Screen Actors Guild and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists to lift a ban that had kept members from working on the films. As of Thursday morning, according to a person briefed on the matter, Warner’s New Line unit, which is supervising the production for Warner Brothers and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, was still considering a move to another country, in part because, in the studios’ view, the New Zealand actors, despite having withdrawn their call for an international union boycott, are continuing to insist that the “Hobbit” producers conduct discussions that would run afoul of New Zealand law. A team of Warner executives is expected to be in New Zealand by Tuesday, both to assess the situation and to consider plans for production elsewhere.

headline: Getting the Best Out of Vegetables
text: A while ago, just on the seam between summer and fall, I had a good dinner at a blessedly calm London restaurant called Gauthier. My first dish, after the initial sequence of snacky things, was a pair of olive-oil crisps with vegetables sandwiched between them. Kind of like a ratatouille, to give you some sense of the intensity of flavor. But this set of vegetables went beyond the usual summery Mediterranean standbys — eggplant, zucchini, peppers — to include things like carrots (which also grow in the summer, of course), all deeply flavorful both because they’d been carefully purchased and impeccably cooked. I’m guessing that each element of the mixture had been prepared separately – how else to account for eggplant and carrots that were both optimal?

headline: Mackerel: The Sustainable Fish
text: As I’ve become more aware of the urgent need to eat more sustainable seafood, I’ve been reaching for squid, clams, sardines, and especially mackerel whenever a fishy hunger strikes. Mackerel is a good fish that’s gotten a bad rap, something I wrote about in my column yesterday. Many cooks have sworn off it, saying it’s too heavy, too oily. And when it comes to the canned stuff, they’re right. But mackerel can be mild and buttery, especially when very fresh. But, more importantly to me, it’s the oiliness of mackerel that imparts its uniquely briny flavor. When cooked just so, mackerel is a fish you can love to serve as well as eat. And it’s also relatively inexpensive.  Check out these links from the Monterey Bay Aquarium and The Guardian about mackerel sustainability. Recipes:

headline: Reforming Medicare’s Payment System
text: In Wednesday’s paper, David Leonhardt wrote about a proposal by Peter Bach of Memorial-Sloan Kettering Cancer Center and Steven Pearson of Mass General to reform how Medicare paid for new treatments and technologies. Under the plan, they would be reimbursed in full for three years. If they hadn’t proven to be more effective than previous treatments and technologies after three years, however, they would be reimbursed at the (lower) rate of those previous technologies.

headline: (Name of City)’s Sports Fans Are the Best
text: In most cities, sports fans love their teams unequivocally. You applaud your pitcher, even after he gets rocked. You stay to the end of the game, even in a blowout. You’re eternally, irrationally optimistic. New York was once that way. It wasn’t that long ago when “Wait till next year” was an unofficial slogan of the Brooklyn Dodgers. But not anymore.

headline: Big Brother vs. Little Brother: Updating Orwell’s ‘1984’

How have concerns about privacy and freedom expressed in the novel been manifested in the contemporary world? In this lesson, students compare and contrast the world, people and technologies of “1984” with those of today and create a treatment for a modern film, print or stage adaptation that revolves around current technologies.

headline: New First Violinist for Juilliard String Quartet
text: The Juilliard String Quartet has named a new first violinist, only the fourth in its 64 years. He is Joseph Lin, 32, a Harvard University graduate who is a professor at Cornell University and an active soloist and chamber musician with a strong interest in Chinese culture. Mr. Lin will start with the quartet next year. He replaces Nick Eanet, who joined the quartet last season but had to withdraw for health reasons. Robert Mann, the founding first violinist, retired in 1997 and was succeeded by Joel Smirnoff, who was named president of the Cleveland Institute of Music in 2008.

headline: ‘I See a Makeover in Your Future’
text: Elle Muliarchyk has seen enough psychics to take their soothsaying with a pinch of sodium chloride. A model turned photographer, she believes that the clothes she has worn on the day of her readings have influenced the prognostications she has received. During the making of “Somnambuli,” Ms. Muliarchyk’s fashion video, shot exclusively for T, about the power of clothes to affect our destiny, the model Meghan Collison underwent a series of high-fashion transformations and had her fortune read by various New York clairvoyants. “The same psychic who told the model to clean up her act when she was dressed like a hippie,” Ms. Muliarchyk recalled, “saw Harvard in her future a few days later when she was dressed up like an Upper East Side lady.” Spooky, huh?

But by then he had already slipped through the cracks of art history. Or rather he had fallen into one of the deep trenches that divide that history into artificial islands with names like Pop and Minimalism.

headline: Yulianna Avdeeva Wins Chopin International Piano Competition
text: Yulianna Avdeeva, a 25-year-old Russian, won the top prize in the 16th Chopin International Piano Competition, officials in Warsaw announced on Wednesday. Second prizes were awarded to Lukas Geniusas of Russia and Lithuania and Ingolf Wunder of Austria. The event takes place every five years and is one of the most prestigious on the piano competition circuit. This year’s winner, Ms. Avdeeva, is scheduled to perform with the New York Philharmonic on Oct. 29 in Warsaw, where the orchestra will stop while on a European tour, and on Jan. 4 in New York.

headline: A Singer From Everywhere Arrives Here

But her music, with its roots on four continents, draws on such a wide range of influences, from jazz and flamenco to pop, soul and African polyrhythm, that it sometimes seems as if she is from everywhere at once and nowhere in particular.

headline: Those Greek Heroes, Sometimes Behaving Badly
text: The ancient Greeks did not require perfection of their heroes, only greatness. They would certainly recognize some of our heroic figures (trapped miners, soldiers, quick-thinking pilots), but not our shock at the personal conduct of others (sports stars, politicians). Greek heroes misbehaved frequently, and when they did  Achilles dragging Hector’s body behind his chariot, Odysseus boasting to the Cyclops Polyphemus  it was a matter to be settled between the hero and the gods.
