headline: ‘Auction Hunters’ and Other Buy-and-Sell TV
Tweaking Tradition, Even in Its Temple
text: If “John Baldessari: Pure Beauty” is any indication, the Metropolitan Museum of Art may finally be catching up to the 21st century. Granted, the museum has never met a century whose art it hasn’t embraced. But its relationship to the latest thing has often felt forced and out of it.

headline: ‘Bengal Tiger,’ With Robin Williams, Coming to Broadway in March
text: Confirmation arrived on Thursday that Robin Williams will indeed star next spring in a Broadway production of Rajiv Joseph’s play “Bengal Tiger at the Baghdad Zoo,” and from the horse’s – or is that tiger’s – mouth?

headline: 'John Baldessari: Pure Beauty'
text: Image from the exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: Where Everybody Knows Your Name, and Other Things About You, Too
text: There was a fascinating post over at the Gourmet Live site today, about restaurant hosts using the power of the Internet to identify those who come into their establishments. (Hat-tip to Eater  for, as they say, surfacing the material.)

headline: Cronkite’s Summer Home Under Contract
text: WALTER CRONKITE was a summer fixture in Edgartown on Martha’s Vineyard, often spotted taking the Clintons and other political bigwigs out sailing in his 60-foot yacht Wyntje. Now the summer home of Mr. Cronkite, the CBS news anchor known as “the most trusted man in America,” who died last year at the age of 92, has gone into contract, according to brokers on both sides of the deal.

headline: Calling Mr. Mom?
text: You could easily compile statistics to make the case that women — at least Western women — are already empowered. In the United States, we are 50 percent of the workplace (and 51.4 percent of managerial and professional jobs). We receive three college degrees for every two earned by men (along with 60 percent of all master’s degrees, about half of all law and medical degrees and 43 percent of M.B.A.’s). Working wives are coming close to bringing in nearly half the household income. Single, childless urban women under 30 actually earn 8 percent more than their male peers.

headline: A Wave of Indie Angst Hits South Asian Cinema
text: Bollywood, until recently the home of fine romances with no kisses, now takes smooching in stride. Did anyone expect the younger generation of South Asian filmmakers to stop there? How could they, growing up not only with Bollywood  itself only a portion of the Indian film business  but also with Hollywood, Hong Kong cinema, indies and all the global culture the Internet can deliver.

headline: TimesCast: The Senate Race in Pennsylvania
text: The Times’s Marcus Mabry and Megan Liberman discuss how the union vote in Pennsylvania could influence the outcome of the Senate race between Representative Joe Sestak, the Democratic candidate, and Pat Toomey, the former congressman and Republican candidate.

headline: Desserts, Literary Women and Broadway Babies
text: Get your week off to a good start. And I don’t mean with a big bowl of whole-grain oats and a jog. I’m talking about chocolate. Lots and lots of it. Which is what you’ll get on Sunday morning during the Chocolate Crazy Dessert Fest walking tour. Meet at Sweet Revenge, which claims the title of being New York’s “only beer, wine and cupcake bar,” for a dark chocolate cupcake. Then head to Jacques Torres, to pop a truffle before devouring a pain au chocolat from François Payard’s new bakery, FPB. Those misers not already in a sugar-induced coma can finish up with a scoop of handmade Argentine-style white chocolate ice cream from Cones. (11:30 a.m., 62 Carmine Street, at Bedford Street, Greenwich Village; 917-842-4319, walkingtoursmanhattan.com; $5 suggested donation for the Food Bank of New York City, plus the cost of your treats.)

headline: M.L.S.: There’s an App for That
text: In time for the playoffs, Major League Soccer (which launched a newly designed Web site at the start of the 2010 season, not without a few fits and starts), released on Thursday an application for users of iPhones and iPod Touch devices.

headline: BBC Journalist Destroys Protester’s Sign
text: As Matt Wells reports on the Guardian’s Web site, a senior reporter for the BBC snatched a sign from the hands of an antiwar protester on Wednesday night and destroyed it, moments after concluding a live television report on the government’s new austerity measures — which will cut the BBC’s budget.

headline: Calling Mr. Mom
text: This week’s New York Times Magazine is about women’s empowerment, and in an essay in that issue I argue that the empowerment of women, at least in the Western world, now depends on men. Not as in “men have to give their permission” but rather “men must be empowered too.”

headline: Storming Statehouses With Plans for Growth
text: MIAMI — Few issues have inspired as much voter anger this campaign season, or as many caustic campaign commercials, as the issue of jobs and how to put Americans back to work.

headline: A Life-Saving Journey to the Dark Side
text: “Inhale,” a shrill, feverish melodrama about illicit organ trafficking, stars Dermot Mulroney as Paul Stanton, a rising district attorney in Santa Fe, N.M., who is willing go to any lengths to secure two lungs for his ailing young daughter, Chloe (Mia Stallard). The girl is dying of a rare respiratory disease, and Paul’s search is a race against time that takes him across the Mexican border to Juárez.

headline: The Latest Sherlock Hears a ‘Who’
text: Benedict Cumberbatch — best known to Americans as the reprehensible houseguest in “Atonement” — is currently enjoying the privilege of playing two of British pop culture’s greatest heroes. He’s being paid for just one of them, though.

headline: The Caucus Click: Harrodsburg, Ky.
text: Louise Dean, a Democratic volunteer, at the Mercer County Democratic Headquarters in Harrodsburg, Ky.

headline: A Nook for Books, Underground
text: THEY call it the commuters’ secret, these denizens of the Terence Cardinal Cooke-Cathedral branch of the New York Public Library. It is located down a flight of stairs, just outside the turnstile entrance to the No. 6 train on the northwest corner of Lexington Avenue and 50th Street. The door is next to a MetroCard machine. There is no street-level sign announcing its existence.

headline: Renée Fleming Dropping Publicist
text: The soprano Renée Fleming is dropping her longtime publicist, Mary Lou Falcone, and assigning public relations duties to employees of her own office, the singer’s representatives said on Thursday. Ms. Falcone, one of the classical music industry’s main P.R. agents, said the parting — which becomes official at the end of the year — was entirely amicable. “It’s the conclusion of a very wonderful business relationship, which still remains in terms of friendship,” Ms. Falcone said. “It’s just simplifying her business situation by putting everything in house.” Ms. Fleming was in Germany for a performance and unavailable for comment, her representatives said.

headline: What We’re Reading: Bernie Madoff’s Slippers
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: Young Men Are Adrift; A Girlfriend Is Missing
text: Early in James M. Hausler’s morose psychological thriller, “Kalamity,” Stanley, the deranged baby-faced manager of an electronics and car parts store in Northern Virginia, vents his fear and loathing of the opposite sex to his best friend, Billy. “Women run everything: us, the world,” he fumes. The more even-tempered Billy, whose five-year relationship with Alice recently ended, is sympathetic. Still obsessed with Alice, he complains that he finds himself replaying their conversations in his head like an answering machine loop. His thoughts are so vivid that in several scenes Alice materializes beside him in his car.

headline: Children and Their ‘Thems’
text: Dario D’Ambrosi certainly makes “Bong Bong Bong Against the Wall, Ting Ting Ting in Our Heads,” his people-and-puppet fantasy about children with mental disabilities, interesting to look at. But considering that back home in Italy Mr. D’Ambrosi has for years been exploring theater by and about the mentally ill and disabled, the play shows a disappointing lack of insight.

headline: Institutional Investing, Along Central Park West
text: THE impassive neo-Classic facade of the New-York Historical Society at 77th Street and Central Park West, now covered by construction scaffolding, is an odd duck on a residential street. But the historical society, opened in 1910, is part of Central Park West’s shadow civic history, and the museums and similar structures now there predate almost all of its apartment houses.

headline: Central Park West's History, Institutions Included
text: Before the apartments moved in, Central Park West was home to more institutions like hospitals, theaters and societies.

headline: Eight City Ballet Dancers Headed to Cuba
text: Dancers from New York City Ballet will perform at the International Ballet Festival in Havana next month, it was announced on Thursday. For the trip, under the auspices of the New York-based Cuban Artists Fund, eight principal dancers are going: Jared Angle, Tyler Angle, Megan Fairchild, Joaquin De Luz, Abi Stafford, Tiler Peck, Teresa Reichlen and Andrew Veyette. The program includes George Balanchine’s “Tarantella”; pas de deux from his “Chaconne” and “Stars and Stripes”; and a concert version of “Who Cares.” The dancers will also perform Jerome Robbins’s “In the Night” and “Other Dances” and Christopher Wheeldon’s “Liturgy.” The performances will take place at the Teatro Mella on Nov. 1 and 2. American Ballet Theater is also performing at the festival.

headline: When Tea Party Tops Ticket, House Democrats Look to Scald
text: 5:52 p.m. | Updated

headline: A Can-Do Attitude for the Giants’ New Fullback
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Tight end Bear Pascoe has been the Giants’ resident cowboy, a cattle-roping Californian with a taste for country music and an appreciation for the wide-open space on his family’s ranch.

headline: On the Streets of Lisbon, Love, Romance and Desire
text: “The Portuguese Nun,” obliquely inspired by a book of 17th-century love letters of enigmatic authorship, is itself, among other things, a love letter to the city of Lisbon. The long, patient opening shot floats through battered, beautiful streets as a fado — the passionate music that is to this city what blues is to Memphis — plays underneath. Several later scenes take place on a hotel terrace with an appealing view of an old hillside neighborhood, and a climactic encounter takes place in a Baroque church. There is more music, moonlight dancing on the water, and much sun-bleached limestone.

headline: Longer Phone Power, and a Light Case, Too
text: Phone cases with built-in batteries are certainly a great way to keep your handset running during marathon phone sessions, if you don’t mind carrying around a brick-sized device.

headline: N.H.L. Has No Plans to Modify Rules on Hits to Head
text: Bill Daly, the N.H.L. deputy commissioner, said Thursday that the league is “comfortable with the steps we have already taken” to reduce concussions and had no plans to modify its new head-checking rule.

headline: Top Corporations Aid U.S. Chamber of Commerce Campaign
Full Vision of ‘Metropolis’ Includes Lang’s Vivid Wit
text: Fritz Lang’s “Metropolis,” surely one of the most intensely studied and widely imitated films of the silent era, grows more complex and mysterious as time goes on. This is partly because the movie has not been seen in the form its director intended since 1927. The German studio UFA cut Lang’s ambitious science-fiction allegory shortly after its initial domestic release, and the American version (distributed by Paramount) was trimmed by an hour and effectively rewritten, with title cards that altered Lang’s meaning. Over the years new material has been discovered, and fresh restorations have been offered, so that the further “Metropolis” recedes into history, the newer it becomes.

headline: Juan Williams Signs New Contract at Fox News
text: One day after being fired by NPR, Juan Williams’ other employer, Fox News, offered him a new and more lucrative contract, the Los Angeles Times reported.

headline: Tragic Love Tale of Spirits and Samurai
text: Pools of deepest black nearly engulf, with strange beauty and mystery, the characters in “Kuroneko,” a Japanese ghost story from 1968 about two avenging spirits and the brutal samurai they tick off. Shot in widescreen in stunning black-and-white 35 millimeter film and directed by Kaneto Shindo, “Kuroneko” had a brief run in New York in 1971 and doesn’t seem to have been back since. A Criterion DVD appears to be forthcoming, but for now a new print has been struck and is available for your delectation at Film Forum.

headline: Ask an Elite Runner
text: Did you ever want to ask an elite athlete about his or her training? The best foods to eat? What they think about during a race?

headline: A Long Year for Thomas O. Hicks
text: Few sports owners have had as rough a year as Thomas O. Hicks.

headline: Final: Phillies 4, Giants 2
text: The Phillies needed a team effort to stay alive in the National League Championship Series, and they got one. They manufactured three runs in the third inning and got a strong performance from their bullpen in a 4-2 win that narrowed the Giants’ series lead to three games to two.

headline: Office Depot Settles Fair-Disclosure Charges
text: It’s not often these days that the Securities and Exchange Commission charges companies with violating rules concerning fair disclosure of information.

headline: After Online Success, an “It Gets Better” Book
text: It has been one month since the creation of “It Gets Better,” the viral video campaign intended to speak directly to gay youths who are the subject of bullying and homophobia.

headline: 36 Hours in Asheville, N.C.
text: WHETHER it’s culture, the great outdoors or homegrown food and beer, Asheville takes its pleasures seriously. Playgrounds are equipped with rock-climbing walls. Bumper stickers exhort the locals to buy local. There’s even a fund-raising drive under way to erect a museum named for Bob Moog, the synthesizer pioneer, who lived in Asheville, that will trace the intersection of science and music. All this connoisseurship unfolds, to the benefit of the casual visitor, against the backdrop of the seriously beautiful Blue Ridge Mountains.

headline: A Weekend in Asheville, N.C.
text: Against the backdrop of the seriously beautiful Blue Ridge Mountains, Asheville takes its pleasures seriously.

headline: Sweat, Blood and Philosophy to the Rhythms of the Sweet Science
text: Pugilists and philosophers of all kinds converge in Frederick Wiseman’s mesmerizing documentary “Boxing Gym.” Owned by a tight knot of muscles named Richard Lord, a trainer with a rasp in his voice and a rattail hanging down his neck, the gym is in a former warehouse with no heat and no air-conditioning. There are no frills here, just men, women and children of assorted colors, means, grace, beauty and abilities meeting among the heavy bags and peeling posters, their fists and feet drumming different time signatures.

headline: Kindred Spirits, Young and Mature
text: T Bone Burnett didn’t perform much in the Speaking Clock Revue, the rootsy benefit concert at the Beacon Theater on Wednesday night. It featured musicians he has produced as well as kindred spirits: the duo of Elton John and Leon Russell, Gregg Allman, John Mellencamp, Elvis Costello, Jeff Bridges, Jim James of My Morning Jacket, Karen Elson and the bluegrass patriarch Ralph Stanley.

headline: Recalling a Collector of Bold Art and Life
text: “Here Rests Peggy,” a new work by Ivy Baldwin Dance, was drawn from several disparate sources: German Expressionist film, Peggy Guggenheim’s extravagant life and art collection, and, as the news release puts it, “the constant crashing of the Ligurian Sea,” which Ms. Baldwin encountered during a research fellowship in Bogliasco, Italy.

headline: City and Union Agree to Wait on Release of Teacher Data
text: In an agreement with the teachers’ union, the city Department of Education said Thursday it would delay releasing the internal performance reviews of some 12,000 teachers that rank them according to their students’ progress on standardized tests.

headline: 25 Years of Glass Eye Pix
text: Larry Fessenden, the filmmaker behind Glass Eye Pix, narrates a look at some of the company's films.

headline: Full Seasons Ordered for Five CBS Hits
text: CBS underscored the early success of its new batch of prime-time series by giving out full-season orders to all five of them on Thursday.

headline: Somnambuli | Elle Muliarchyk
text: A model transforms, with the help of high fashion, and gets her fortune read by various New York clairvoyants in Elle Muliarchyk's exclusive video for T.

headline: Hall Splits With Coach and Will Leave Mammoth
text: Ryan Hall, who set records as the fastest American-born marathoner before struggling this fall, has left his longtime coach, Terrence Mahon.

headline: Week 7 in Fantasy Football: Matchups and Q. and A.
text: The brothers Sablich are here to help with fantasy football analysis for Week 7. They also answered reader questions earlier in the week. Read their answers below and follow them on Twitter for more advice leading up to game time on Sunday.

headline: The Subway in Pictures
text: To mark the 106th birthday of the New York City subway system, a look at 10 decades of the subway.

headline: A Show Is All Cyber, Some of the Time
text: It may seem like a stroke of morbid journalistic humor that the New Museum’s “Free,” a show exploring the Internet as a public art space, coincides with another exhibition titled “The Last Newspaper.” On the third floor, artists are toiling in a makeshift newsroom; on the second, they’re dismantling the last traces of print culture.

headline: Why Can’t Middle-Aged Women Have Long Hair?
text: MY mother hates it. My sister worries about it. My agent thinks I’m hiding behind it. A concerned friend suggests that it undermines my professional credibility. But in the middle of my life, I’m happy with it. Which is saying a lot about anything happening to my 55-year-old body.

headline: 2010 Campaign Ads
text: Candidates around the country are running campaign ads criticizing Wall Street, and the city around it.

headline: A Nook for Books, Underground
text: This post is part of the first-ever themed issue of The Times’s Sunday Metropolitan section, which is devoted to New York’s subway system. Go to The Subway Issue »

headline: Profit Climbs 71% at American Express
text: The American Express Company said on Thursday that its third-quarter profit jumped 71 percent as cardholders spent more and the company wrote off fewer unpaid bills.

headline: Europe Tested as War Crimes Suspect Remains Free
text: BELGRADE — After 15 years on the run — sometimes in plain sight at soccer matches and weddings and sometimes deep in the fabric of this secretive city — Europe’s most wanted war-crimes suspect, Ratko Mladic, is being hidden by no more than a handful of loyalists, most probably in a neighborhood of Communist-era housing towers, according to investigators and some of his past associates.

headline: The Hunt for Ratko Mladic
text: Ratko Mladic led the armed forces of the Bosnian Serbs during the Balkan wars of the early 1990’s.

headline: City Will Crack Down on Scofflaw Cyclists
text: The New York Police Department plans to step up enforcement of bicycle safety in parts of the city that have seen a disproportionately higher rate of collisions involving bicyclists, city officials said Thursday.

headline: For Chevron, 2 Giant Gulf Drilling Ventures
text: Just nine days after the Obama Administration lifted the deepwater drilling moratorium, Chevron announced on Thursday that it was going forward with a $7.5 billion project to develop two giant deepwater fields in the gulf. The Jack and St. Malo fields hold in excess of 500 million barrels of recoverable hydrocarbons, the company said. That’s roughly equal to the world’s oil consumption in about five days — nothing to sneeze at.

headline: Q&A: Reintroducing Printer to PC
text: Q.

headline: Two Takes at NPR and Fox on Juan Williams
text: NPR’s decision on Wednesday to fire Juan Williams and Fox News Channel’s decision on Thursday to give him a new contract put into sharp relief the two forms of journalism that compete every day for Americans’ attention.

headline: In Lambertville, N.J., a Modern Classic for Sale
text: HOW MUCH $1.299 million. Taxes: $8,936.

headline: Salem, the Sound of Givenchy
text: Salem is infamous for its alienating approach to the independent music business. So it was a little surprising to see the trio — John Holland, Heather Marlatt and Jack Donoghue — dutifully play a short set for their label’s humdrum CMJ showcase on Tuesday night at Santo’s Party House. But thankfully, the band returned to dissonant form with Wednesday night’s absurdly exclusive, secretive, hard-to-find, smoke-filled basement show at Ramiken Crucible, a narrow basement gallery no one’s ever heard of that sits south of East Broadway, deep in the Lower East Side.

headline: Coming Out Illegal
text: Leslie, a history major at the University of California at Los Angeles and an aspiring marathon runner with three part-time jobs and plans for grad school, keeps a neatly folded dark blue T-shirt in her closet among her jeans and her U.C.L.A. Bruins sweatshirt. Like an intimate detail, she reveals it cautiously, wearing it to campus events but not on the streets of Orange County; to a rally with a group of friends, but not alone on a crosstown bus. A senior at U.C.L.A. and the only child of a single working mother, Leslie is brave but not reckless: in the wrong place under the wrong circumstances, the T-shirt’s two words across the chest — “I’m Undocumented” — are provocative enough to upend her life.

headline: Making Hospital Chapel Welcoming to All Faiths
text: Looking resplendent in red vestments, the Rev. John Jimenez conducted mass on Monday before about 20 congregants and reminded them the date was the Feast of St. Luke. “Luke is the patron saint of doctors,” he said, “so it has some special meaning here in the hospital.”

headline: Predators Gone, Small Fish Get Bolder
text: Little fish are cautious and timid around big, hungry fish, and rightly so. But when populations of predators like tuna and shark shrink because of human fishing, small prey are more adventurous, according to a coming study in The American Naturalist.

headline: Kleiner Perkins and Partners Create $250 Million ‘Social’ Fund
text: Hoping to capitalize on the popularity of social networking, the well-known venture capital firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers is teaming up with heavyweights of the social Web to create a $250 million fund to invest in social start-ups.

headline: New Faces Enter Fray in Accounting
text: As the great accounting fight of the past decade moves near to a conclusion that seems likely to satisfy no one, the cast of characters is suddenly changing. The two most important accounting bodies in the world will be under new leadership as they try to move on from bruising battles that have pitted them against banks, bank regulators and politicians.

headline: From Dangerous Home to Safe House
text: One day last spring , just a couple of weeks after I opened a safe house for victims of domestic violence in Glendale, Ariz., my cellphone rang. I was doing schoolwork with my kids at home. A young woman was on the other end of the line, and she was crying. “I need someone to come get me now,” she said. “If I go back home, I might not ever get out.”

headline: Left Wing Shudders as Its Presumed Leader Endures a String of Recent Setbacks
text: Three months ago, Aaron Peskin seemed poised to be the boss of this one-party town, following in the footsteps of former Mayor Willie L. Brown Jr., the strong-armed patronage king who was his political nemesis.

headline: The Hot New Sound on the Scene? Oh, Yes, It is the Clarinet
text: Since the end of the big band era, the clarinet has taken a backseat to its sexier woodwind cousin, the saxophone. But in the Bay Area, thanks to a fertile environment of classically trained clarinetists with experimental sensibilities, the oft-overlooked instrument is having a moment.

headline: ‘Minds’ Over Baseball
text: “Survivor” and “Criminal Minds” lifted CBS to No. 1 in the ratings on Wednesday night. According to Nielsen’s estimates, “Criminal Minds” was the most watched show with 14.3 million viewers. “Survivor: Nicaragua” drew 12 million viewers. Fox ranked second with Major League Baseball playoff coverage, drawing approximately eight million viewers. NBC edged placed third over all, though its new series “Undercovers” (5.9 million) struggled. As usual, ABC earned its best ratings with “Modern Family” (11.9 million).

headline: He’s a Big Man on a Mission
text: World Wrestling Entertainment continues its effort to meld violent sport with gooey, throwback family comedy in the claptrap road movie “Knucklehead.” In “Legendary,” released last month, the W. W. E. star John Cena played a wrestler; in “Knucklehead” the behemoth Paul Wight (billed as the Big Show) fights his way across the South to win enough money to save his orphanage — the one where, at 35, he still lives.

headline: The Ice Age
text: The award-winning fashion designer Richard Chai has partnered with Daniel Arsham and Alex Mustonen of the avant-design firm Snarkitecture to create an elaborately carved “ice” cavern for a new pop-up shop opening Thursday evening. Conceived by Boffo, an art and culture nonprofit group, and the architect/writer Spilios Gianakopoulos to promote visibility for designers and artists, the project — titled Building Fashion — consists of a series of five rotating installations in a space underneath the High Line (504 West 24th Street). The five participating fashion designers (Simon Spurr, Heather Huey, House of Waris, Richard Chai and Siki Im), none of whom has a freestanding store, were each given the opportunity to create a three-dimensional representation of his or her brand. Chai said he wanted to avoid “the straightforward clothes-on-a-rack retail space” in favor of creating “an environment, a feeling, more of an emotional experience.” The “cave,” which is hand carved from high-density Styrofoam, also allows for irregular crevices and crannies to display merchandise. The store will carry  Chai’s men’s and women’s collections and will be open to the public until Oct. 31 (noon to 6 p.m.), so head over there quickly before it “melts.”

headline: Album Sales Report
text: You hear a lot about digital music these days, but CDs  which make up the majority of album sales  still count for a lot. Two weeks ago Lil Wayne’s album “I Am Not a Human Being” (Cash Money/Universal Motown), which was first for sale only as a digital download, opened at No. 2 on the Billboard album chart, and in its second week  still digital-only  it fell to No. 16. But then it came out on CD, and so in its third week the album has shot to No. 1 with 125,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan. The album leads a number of high-charting new releases. Darius Rucker, the Hootie and the Blowfish frontman who has reinvented himself as a solo country singer, opened at No. 2 with 101,000 sales of “Charleston, SC 1966” (Capitol Nashville). Big Time Rush, the teen band and star of a Nickelodeon show, opened at No. 3 with 67,000 sales of “B.T.R.” (Nickelodeon/Columbia). And the Band Perry, a country trio of siblings, bowed at No. 4 with 53,000 sales of its self-titled debut, released by Republic Nashville. Eminem’s “Recovery” (Aftermath/Interscope) fell one spot to No. 5 with 50,000 sales, and Kenny Chesney’s album “Hemingway’s Whiskey” (BNA) is No. 6 in its third week out, with just less than 40,000.

headline: New Way to Help Chickens Cross to Other Side
text: Shoppers in the supermarket today can buy chicken free of nearly everything but adjectives. It comes free-range, cage-free, antibiotic-free, raised on vegetarian feed, organic, even air-chilled.

headline: Dolores Park Groups Are Upset Over Vendors
text: The San Francisco Recreation and Park Department did not expect its decision to permit two vendors inside the Mission District’s popular Dolores Park to raise many eyebrows.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,331 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: Amid Talk of Anthony, Knicks Prepare to Start
text: MONTREAL — The Knicks have moved on to their fourth country of the preseason, carrying rumors along with their luggage to each stop.

headline: The Myth of Consensus Politics
text: Two years after an election that seemed to portend a new era of comity, American politics has resumed what now appears to be its permanent condition of polarization, quite possibly worsened by widening rifts within the two major parties.

headline: Obama Talks With Steve Jobs
text: SAN FRANCISCO — President Obama met Thursday with Steve Jobs, the chief executive of Apple, the White House press secretary, Robert Gibbs, said.

headline: Wal-Mart to Add Nook to Inventory of E-Readers
text: Starting Sunday, there will be another front in the e-reader retail war.

headline: Pretty Women and Plenty of Cows
text: Who knows why “Milk and Money,” a daffy, enjoyable little film from 1996, never got much of a look the first time around. But it’s a treat to look at now, with some great older actors, a few younger ones who went on to bigger things and a script that has nothing on its mind but seeing how many incongruities it can string together.

headline: Goldman’s Proprietary Trading Desk to Join K.K.R.
text: Wall Street is holding a garage sale, and private equity firms are showing up to buy.

headline: The State of Liberalism
text: It’s a sign of how poorly liberals market themselves and their ideas that the word “liberal” is still in disrepute despite the election of the most genuinely liberal president that the political culture of this country will probably allow. “Progressive” is now the self-description of choice for liberals, though it’s musty and evasive. The basic equation remains: virtually all Republican politicians call themselves conservative; few Democratic politicians call themselves liberal. Even retired Classic Coke liberals like Walter F. Mondale are skittish about their creed. “I never signed up for any ideology,” he writes in his memoirs.

headline: Kansas Governor’s Race Seen Redefining G.O.P.
text: PAOLA, Kan. — This state has been painted, unwillingly at times, as a caricature of a certain brand of conservatism. It was here that the State Board of Education challenged the theory of evolution, that an abortion provider was fatally shot at his church, and that a writer set his polemic “What’s the Matter with Kansas?”

headline: Office Depot to Pay $1 Million to Settle S.E.C.’s Fair Disclosure Charge
text: WASHINGTON  Office Depot and two of its executives agreed on Thursday to settle Securities and Exchange Commission charges that they violated fair disclosure laws in a case in which some investors and analysts were alerted that the company would not meet earnings estimates for the second quarter of 2007.

headline: The State of Conservatism
text: Within the space of a week last summer, one judge in Arizona, ruling in a suit brought by the Obama administration, blocked a provision in a new state law permitting police officers to check the status of suspected illegal immigrants, while another blocked the implementation of a California referendum banning gay marriage. The two decisions imposed liberal policies that public opinion opposed. These things happen, of course. Congress had acted contrary to measurable public opinion when it passed health care reform in March. What made the two judicial rulings different was that both seemed to challenge the principle that it is the people who have the last word on how they are governed.

headline: New Bush Exhibit Opens Rift at S.M.U.
text: DALLAS — For the first two years, George W. Bush managed his return to private work in Texas as a quiet transition.

headline: Gay Conservative Group Attacks Congressional Democrats
text: Just as “The Real Housewives of D.C.” is drawing to a close, the nation is about to get “The Real Democrats of Washington, D.C.”

headline: For 7.8 Million Californians, an Earthquake Drill
text: SAN FRANCISCO  To the high-pitched whine of emergency sirens, Mayor Gavin Newsom of San Francisco crawled under a school desk with a group of fourth graders on Thursday.

headline: Average College Debt Rose to $24,000 in 2009
text: College seniors who graduated in 2009 had an average of $24,000 in student loan debt, up 6 percent from 2008, according to an annual report from the Project on Student Debt.

headline: Providing Equal Justice for the Poor
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Hairy Love Situation
text: Of the crop of gay-centered features from TLA Releasing at the Quad Cinema of late (“Is It Just Me?,” the musical “Fruit Fly”), the romantic dramedy “BearCity” certainly shows the most complexity. A group portrait in the West Village-Chelsea nexus, it covers a fair bit of emotional territory, although without amounting to much especially profound.

headline: The Home Video Rises to Museum Grade
text: Neither life nor art has been the same since the hand-held video camera became increasingly available in the 1970s. And they’ve been even less like themselves since YouTube came along in 2005, giving the world a continuously expanding bulletin board for moving images to which anyone can contribute just about anything. By now the YouTube video universe is, like the real one, large and complex beyond comprehension, and the repercussions for video art are equally hard to fathom.

headline: Gaza: Donated Vans Driven From Egypt
text: Hundreds of pro-Palestinian activists drove scores of donated vans into Gaza on Thursday after Egypt let them pass through. Kevin Ovenden of Viva Palestina, a group in London that sponsored the aid convoy, said at a news conference in Gaza that Middle East peace could be achieved only by including Hamas, the Islamist group that governs Gaza. The convoy of 140 vans started its journey last month in London. A ship picked up the convoy in Syria this week and docked in the Egyptian port of Al-Arish in the northern Sinai. Egypt is set to send the rest of the cargo to Gaza via ground crossings with Israel. Israel and Egypt have imposed an embargo on Gaza because of their dispute with Hamas, but international outcry, especially after the killings of nine activists in a Turkish flotilla last May, has caused some easing in the policy.

headline: White House Promotes Economic Efforts for Women
text: WASHINGTON  As one of its closing arguments before the midterm elections, the Obama administration is highlighting the impact its economic policies have had on women.

headline: Making Music With Comedy
text: If “Punching the Clown” seems more polished than the usual low-budget indie comedy — the jokes more finely honed, the timing better — that’s only as it should be. Henry Phillips (writer and star) and Gregori Viens (writer and director) have been working on this material for more than a decade. They have even made this movie already, as a documentary, in 1997.

headline: Where Are the Great Lines of Yesteryear?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Muslims Meet Punk
text: “The Taqwacores” aims for a provocative, anarchic cool by juxtaposing Islam and punk rock. But the storytelling is so muddled and the filmmaking so unpolished — and not in a good way — that mostly this movie is just unpleasant. It’s also not nearly as insightful as it thinks it is.

headline: Justice Thomas’s Wife, and the Call to Anita Hill
text: To the Editor:

headline: Veterans Reaching Out for Help Online
text: As Cpl. Ricoh Danielson of the Army and his buddies left an Oklahoma Wal-Mart with a 12-pack of Corona and a case of Keystone Ice for a Fourth of July celebration, they passed a Middle Eastern-looking man accompanied by a woman wearing a head scarf. Just then, someone ignited a firecracker.

headline: Campaign Spending and Election Outcomes
text: To the Editor:

headline: N.B.A. Eyes Drastic Cut in Payouts to Players
text: The N.B.A. wants to slash player income by at least $750 million annually  a stance that could trigger a lockout next summer.

headline: N.F.L.’s Policy on Helmet-to-Helmet Hits Makes Highlights Distasteful
text: For more than two decades, a recurring opening sequence on “Monday Night Football” featured an image of two helmets crashing into each other and exploding into smithereens.

headline: Stem Cell Research Skirts Hurdles, but Raises Ethics Issues, Too
text: In an academic-corporate partnership that may represent the future of stem cell research, Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago has teamed up with a biotech company to begin the first human trials of a therapy derived from embryonic stem cells.

headline: Communists in India Fight to Hold On to Mission
text: CALCUTTA  Lenin’s statue still rises near the center of the city, and portraits of Stalin and Marx still hang inside the biggest union hall. Anyone doubting the local political dominance  and cold war humor  of India’s Communists need only visit the street in front of the United States Consulate: It was long ago renamed for Ho Chi Minh.

headline: In the Twilight of a Noted Theologian’s Life, the Words Still Go Forth
text: James Warren is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative

headline: Republicans Find Cash Through New Group
text: Two Party System Inc., a recently formed group, has quietly raised hundreds of thousands of dollars from a small set of prominent Illinois businessmen and is spending the money largely to help Republican candidates for the General Assembly.

headline: A Campaign About Computer Security, Couched in Plain English
text: IN recent weeks, drivers on Route 7 near Minneapolis may have noticed something unusual: once a week, a painting crew has been hoisted up to repaint a section on the left side of a billboard, from green one week to red the next and finally to blue.

headline: Louisiana Builds Barriers Even as Oil Disperses
text: Three months after BP capped its runaway well in the Gulf of Mexico, the state of Louisiana is still building a chain of sand berms off its coast to block and capture oil even as federal officials and many scientists argue that the effort will prove pointless.

headline: States Affirm Tough Limits on Insurers’ Use of Dollars
text: WASHINGTON  State insurance commissioners on Thursday unanimously endorsed tough new standards that would require many health insurance companies to spend more of each premium dollar for the benefit of consumers.

headline: The Bank Wins ...
text: The Dodd-Frank financial reform law is supposed to correct the problems and abuses that led to the crisis. It could take years to implement. Meanwhile, Wall Street is still engaged in many of the same practices. That was abundantly clear in Louise Story’s article in The Times this week on securities lending, a multitrillion-dollar activity, both before the crash and today.

headline: Slow Markets, Slow Bonuses
A Favorite Villain in Election Ads: New York
text: A Georgia congressman is shown driving around New York in a convertible with the House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, soaking in cheers at a ticker-tape parade on Wall Street and then basking in the bright lights of Times Square.

headline: Sikhs Lament Obama Plan to Bypass India Temple
text: WASHINGTON  Sikhs in the United States expressed their frustration Thursday that President Obama would skip a tentatively planned visit to their holiest site in India, while advocacy groups called on the White House to reconsider.

headline: Demonize, Then Demoralize
text: This year’s crop of negative political ads is fresh and repellent and headed for the landfill on Nov. 3. At least they aim to motivate voters, however basely.

headline: The Shadow Knows
text: This is the sixth in a series.

headline: Elvis Andrus Leads Rangers’ Revolution of Savvy Over Slugging
text: ARLINGTON, Tex.  In Venezuela, some families like to break with tradition and give their children foreign-sounding first names of famous people who are not of Spanish heritage. At first glance, this might be an esoteric explanation for why the shortstop for the Texas Rangers, who was born in the central Venezuelan city of Maracay, is named Elvis Andrus.

headline: Harry Reid: Man Up? Me?
text: Man up? Please, says Harry Reid.

headline: Credit Cards Soon to Get a Makeover
text: The simple credit card is about to get a makeover.

headline: Buffalo’s Passion for Paladino Wanes
text: BUFFALO  On a patch of grass in West Seneca, a town just south of Buffalo, a yard sign announces in bold black and orange that this is “Carl Country.” The same sign sprouted like crabgrass on lawns all over the area after Carl P. Paladino, a wealthy Buffalo real estate developer, scored an unexpected and lopsided victory in the Sept. 14 primary to become the Republican nominee for governor.

headline: U.N. Doubts Fairness of Election in Myanmar
text: UNITED NATIONS  With just over two weeks until the first elections in Myanmar in 20 years, a United Nations envoy on Thursday questioned the fairness of the vote.

headline: Report Assails Haiti Officers in Prison Killings
text: After officers had quelled the prison uprising in Les Cayes, Haiti, in January, Jacklin Charles, an unarmed detainee, was killed by a bullet to the head as he stood beside a tree in the courtyard. Several witnesses said that the chief of the antiriot police pulled the trigger.

headline: Waging a Campaign of Her Own
text: SOUTH BEND, Ind.  When Notre Dame Coach Brian Kelly introduced his future wife to his father, she was spirited and fearless. She teased Paul Kelly about his awkward comb-over, which was met with stunned silence. Not long after, he shaved his head.

headline: Pakistani Troops Linked to Abuses Will Lose Aid
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration will withhold training and equipment for about a half-dozen Pakistani Army units that are believed to have killed unarmed prisoners and civilians during recent offensives against the Taliban, according to senior administration and Congressional officials.

headline: For Final, Pac-10 Decides Location Isn’t Everything
text: SAN FRANCISCO  The soon-to-be Pacific-12 Conference, somewhere on the fast track to challenging the Big Ten and the Southeastern Conference as a major player in college athletics, decided it was not quite ready to go full speed ahead.

headline: Afghanistan Today
text: Voters don’t seem to be paying much attention to the war in Afghanistan and President Obama certainly isn’t making it an issue. His administration is doubling down on the fight against the Taliban and showing mixed results. That may not sound like much, but even mixed results are an improvement over the utterly bleak situation of several months ago.

headline: Giants’ Scrappy Lineup Could Be Right Mix
text: SAN FRANCISCO

headline: Is That a Dagger I See?
text: We’ve been waiting a long time for technology to deliver us an alternative reality, like the future in H.G. Wells’s “Time Machine,” Neo’s Matrix, or the universe of code navigated by the “Neuromancer” hacker, Case. The future has arrived, finally — by the prosaic hand of our cellphones. Chances are it will soon be sponsored by laundry detergent or a fast-food chain.

headline: For Democrats, Aqueduct Report Complicates a Difficult Election Season
text: ALBANY  For many prominent Democratic campaigns across New York State, the release of the state inspector general’s searing Aqueduct Racetrack report on Thursday raised a dilemma.

headline: Gates ‘Don’t Ask’ Memo Limits Discharge Policy
text: WASHINGTON  In the growing legal confusion at the Pentagon over the “don’t ask, don’t tell” law, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates issued a directive on Thursday that appeared to be a near moratorium on discharges of openly gay service members.

headline: A Great Line, Taken Badly Out of Context
text: That public figures can be influenced by movies is an old story.

headline: New Role Added to UConn Star’s Résumé: Leader
text: The other day at basketball practice, Maya Moore cut one way, then changed her mind and reversed herself, leading to a turnover. Moore has done a lot of remarkable things in her career at Connecticut, but her coach, Geno Auriemma, was impressed with what she did next.

headline: Big Gifts to G.O.P. Groups Push Donor to New Level
text: WASHINGTON — When Bob Perry, a wealthy home builder from Texas, emerged six years ago as a prime financer of the Swift Boat Veterans attack ads against Senator John Kerry, the 2004 Democratic presidential nominee, the political strategist Karl Rove was there to vouch for Mr. Perry.

headline: Calling John Roberts
text: As 1997 wound down, Bill Clinton was in the White House, the Republicans controlled the Senate, and the Clinton administration’s judicial nominees were going nowhere. Nearly one in 10 federal judgeships was vacant, a total of 82 vacancies, 26 of which had gone unfilled for more than 18 months. In Democratic hands back in 1994, the Senate had confirmed 101 nominees. In 1997, under the Republicans, the number dropped to 36.

headline: Panel Is Facing Deadline on Immigrants’ Pardons
text: In May, as the federal government increased deportations and some states sought to tighten immigration enforcement, Gov. David A. Paterson caused a national stir by announcing a push in the opposite direction: a state effort to speed the granting of pardons to immigrants facing deportation for old or minor criminal convictions.

headline: Out to the Yankee Game, but Only for 4 Innings
text: A pair of prosperous businessmen, having rushed up from downtown Manhattan, settled into their box seats on Wednesday afternoon, two rows from the Yankee Stadium field.

headline: Italy: Clashes Erupt Over Waste Dumps
text: Hundreds of protesters set fire to garbage trucks and threw projectiles at the police on Thursday as a garbage crisis flared up near Naples. Tensions are running high in the towns of Terzigno and Boscoreale, outside Naples, where residents have clashed violently with the police in recent days, protesting the opening of waste dumping sites that they say are contaminating their towns. This week, officers used tear gas to disperse protesters and made six arrests, the police said. The crisis is seen as a referendum on Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, who has called resolving a similar garbage crisis near Naples in 2008 an important accomplishment of his government.

headline: Britain: Case of the Purloined Feline
text: A British court was the venue on Thursday for the arresting story of a lawmaker’s wife, her husband’s lover and the theft of a family kitten. Christine Hemming, 52, whose husband, John Hemming, is a Liberal Democrat member of Parliament for Birmingham, has been charged with stealing the tabby kitten from the home of Emily Cox, a researcher with whom Mr. Hemming fathered a child in 2005. Mr. Hemming, who describes his domestic situation as “unclear,” has posted an appeal for the kitten, named Beauty, which remains missing. “If anyone has seen this kitten, please contact me at the House of Commons,” he said.

headline: Lottery Numbers
An Inquiry Into the Breed of Paladino’s Pet, and a Sharp Response From His Campaign
text: It seemed like a harmless and responsible journalistic task meant to settle a question that had hung over the race for governor — at least in the pages of The New York Times.

headline: Campaign Donors Betting on a Big Step for Boehner
text: Cash is pouring into the coffers of Representative John A. Boehner this midterm election season as interest groups jockey for influence with the Republican leader who may be the next speaker of the House.

headline: British Fashion Victims
text: In the spring of 2010, fiscal austerity became fashionable. I use the term advisedly: the sudden consensus among Very Serious People that everyone must balance budgets now now now wasn’t based on any kind of careful analysis. It was more like a fad, something everyone professed to believe because that was what the in-crowd was saying.

headline: New Law Allows Homeowners to Recoup Legal Fees in Foreclosure Cases
text: A new state law signed in Albany this week will allow homeowners who win foreclosure proceedings to have the lender pay their lawyers’ fees.

headline: Friday: Racing Form Data
text: I kept wondering how the answer “Havens for folkies?” could be plural, given the last two letters I had — IE. That was a good reminder of how important shifting gears can be. Havens is also a singer’s name.

headline: On Further Review, the Coach Stands
text: Granted, the man has a lot to do. Like instilling professionalism, heart and fierce dedication in a frozen winter field full of young men. Like transforming a losing football team into a winning one in the span of a single season. And then leading that team to a series of history-making championships, including the first two Super Bowl titles.

headline: Top Official to Investigate Police Conduct
text: The New York City Police Department has assigned a ranking official to look into a wide array of allegations of misconduct, including charges that crime complaints were ignored or manipulated, in the 81st Precinct in Brooklyn, according to two law enforcement officials with knowledge of the investigation.

headline: Subway Preachers
text: Portraits of four underground preachers in the New York City subway.

headline: Speaking of God, as Souls Hurry By
text: The graffiti has been replaced by advertising. The tokens have been replaced by MetroCards. But the subway preachers are a constant. They were there before I was born and will likely be there after I die — unless, of course, their occasional prophecy of the exact date that the world will end turns out to be accurate.

headline: Yankees Can Draw Inspiration From Teams of Yore
text: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Since 1996, the dawn of a wildly successful era in pinstriped history defined by Derek Jeter’s steady presence at shortstop, the Yankees have played 30 postseason series. In only five of them have Jeter’s Yankees  21-8, with their current matchup with the Texas Rangers still to be decided  ever trailed by more than one game. Thus, as they try to battle back from being two games down in the American League Championship Series, they are in a somewhat unfamiliar position.

headline: Thomas’s Wife Is Off Memo List
text: Justice Clarence Thomas’s wife, Virginia, asked to have her name removed from a memorandum that called President Obama’s health care overhaul unconstitutional, as she distanced herself from an issue that may come before the Supreme Court.

headline: Corrections
text: NEW YORK

headline: Red Bulls Go From Worst to First
text: Dane Richards scored his fifth goal of the season in the first half and Joel Lindpere added an insurance score in second-half added time as the Red Bulls defeated the New England Revolution, 2-0, Thursday night in Harrison, N.J., and clinched first place in Major League Soccer’s Eastern Conference. The Red Bulls (15-9-6, 51 points) completed a worst-to-first season after winning only five games in 2009, when they finished in last place in the conference and had the fewest points (21) in the league. The Red Bulls will open the M.L.S. playoffs next week.

headline: No ‘Hangover’ for Mel Gibson
text: LOS ANGELES — Oops, never mind. Despite a flurry of reports that Mel Gibson was pointed toward a cameo appearance in “The Hangover Part II,” Warner Brothers and Legendary Pictures on Thursday joined the director Todd Phillips in a statement declaring that he was not. “I thought Mel would have been great in the movie and I had the full backing of Jeff Robinov and his team,” Mr. Phillips said in the statement, describing support from Mr. Robinov, a member of Warner’s office of the president.

headline: Democrats Try to Revive Female Voters’ Enthusiasm
text: SEATTLE  Women came out strong for Barack Obama in 2008. Now, with barely 10 days before the midterm elections that are looking increasingly perilous for his party, he is trying to win them back.

headline: Big Networks Block Web Shows From Google TV
text: In the latest sign that Google may struggle to transform television viewing with Google TV, its new service for Internet-connected TVs, three major broadcast networks and Hulu are blocking people from using the service to watch full-length TV shows on their Web sites.

headline: Iowa Keeps Opponents Thinking Pink
text: When the legendary Iowa coach Hayden Fry got to Iowa City, one of the first things he did was redecorate.

headline: Incursions Into CMJ Territory?
text: What are the boundaries of the CMJ Music Marathon? Is the event comprised of just the official showcases and panel discussions, for which you need a $495 identification badge? Or is it the whole official and unofficial shebang, with all the daytime shows and unsanctioned parties, whose sponsors may or may not mention “CMJ” in their announcements?

headline: The Flock Comedies
text: For most of television history, sitcoms have been about families. From “The Dick Van Dyke Show” to “All in the Family” to “The Cosby Show,” TV shows have generally featured husbands and wives, parents and kids.

headline: No Small Roles: ‘The Hobbit’ Announces Its First Cast Members
text: Wherever his “Hobbit” movies get made, Peter Jackson wants you to know he has a cast to appear in them.

headline: Photo Replay: Oct. 21, 2010
text: A view of the day in sports, from surfing in Munich to some Formula One house cleaning.

headline: Political Ads Attack the Other Guy’s Lavish Living
text: WASHINGTON  Living small is the new living large, at least when it comes to candidates running for election in November.

headline: 7-Day Disabled List Is Under Discussion
text: Major League Baseball is considering establishing a seven-day disabled list to help teams deal with players who have concussions, a league official said Thursday. The idea of the new, shorter D.L. will be examined by a committee started by M.L.B. to set protocols as part of a more comprehensive concussion policy.

headline: After Watching Berkman Tumble, Teixeira Sounds Off
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — As Lance Berkman took a not-so-graceful backward tumble in foul territory Wednesday, Mark Teixeira watched in the dugout and winced — and not because his tender right hamstring was acting up. The warning track around the Yankee Stadium grass had claimed a victim.

headline: Senate Forecast Update: Don’t Call It a Comeback?
text: It’s silly season for election watchers, that time of year where every uptick or downtick in the polls is assumed to have great meaning: the first tip-off to a last-minute comeback, or the first sign that a candidate who seemed to have his race locked up won’t be able to close the deal.

headline: Word of the Day | overwrought
text: overwrought •\ˈo-vər-ˈrȯt\• adjective

headline: A.I.G. Raises $17.8 Billion in Unit’s Stock Sale
text: HONG KONG — American International Group raised $17.8 billion by selling shares in its Asian life insurance unit — widely considered one of the insurer’s crown jewels — making another substantial contribution in its efforts to pay down the huge bailout it received from the U.S. government at the height of the global financial crisis.

headline: Phillies Foil Giants and Force Game 6
text: SAN FRANCISCO — When Chase Utley, late on a jittery night, leaped into the air, he realized he had left his feet too early and launched himself from the wrong spot. But when Utley, the Phillies’ second baseman, reached across his body, the baseball off the bat of Aubrey Huff — the one that seemed destined to land in right field and keep a rally alive — found a home in the far reaches of the webbing on Utley’s glove.

headline: Paterson Fires Top Conservation Official
text: The Paterson administration fired Alexander B. Grannis, the commissioner of the Department of Environmental Conservation, in a surprise move on Thursday, after a dispute over cuts to the department’s budget.

headline: Protectors Hinder Pursuit of Ratko Mladic
text: After 15 years on the run Europe’s most wanted war-crimes suspect, Ratko Mladic, is being hidden by no more than a handful of loyalists.

headline: Robert Katz, Who Wrote About Nazi Massacre in Italy, Dies at 77
text: Robert Katz, an author and screenwriter who incurred the wrath of the Vatican by accusing Pope Pius XII of failing to act to stave off a Nazi massacre of Italians in 1944, died Wednesday in Montevarchi, Italy, northeast of Siena. He was 77.

headline: Elizabeth L. Sturz, Salvaged Troubled Lives, Dies at 93
text: Elizabeth L. Sturz, who started and ran renowned programs to help troubled youths and people suffering from both mental illness and drug addiction  all to further her goal “to be of use”  died on Thursday in Manhattan. She was 93.

headline: Ari Up, a Founder of the Slits Punk Band, Dies at 48
text: Arianna Forster, who gained acclaim in the late 1970s as Ari Up, the singer of the exuberant and influential all-female punk-rock band the Slits, died on Wednesday in Los Angeles. She was 48.

headline: News Quiz | October 22, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Fannie and Freddie May Need Infusion
text: Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac‘s federal bailout may be winding down with relatively little additional cost to taxpayers so long as the economy continues to recover. But if the economy tips back into recession, the bailout could nearly double in size, according to new government projections announced on Thursday.

headline: Oligarchs Fight Over Nickel Company
text: In a battle of Russian oligarchs, shareholders voted on Thursday to retain the current board at Norilsk Nickel, thwarting an effort by a minority owner to gain more seats and oust the management, Andrew E. Kramer reports in The New York Times.

headline: Singapore Exchange Is Said to Mull ASX Merger
text: Singapore Exchange is in talks to combine with ASX, which runs the Australian stock exchange, a person with direct knowledge of the matter told Bloomberg News.

headline: French Senate Passes Pension Bill
text: PARIS  After nearly three weeks of debate and a series of national strikes, the French Senate voted Friday evening to pass President Nicolas Sarkozy’s bill to raise the minimum retirement age to 62 from 60 and the age for a full pension to 67 from 65.

headline: The Zombie Attack as Stress Test
text: THERE is a certain comforting familiarity to how a zombie-invasion movie is supposed to unfold. Civilization revels in unsuspectingly tenuous tranquillity; a virus or alien pathogen is unleashed; the dead rise from their graves; two hours of vivid acts of cannibalism and exposed human innards ensue.

headline: The Nice Guy Who Puts the Mean Into ‘Glee’
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Test Yourself | History, Oct. 22, 2010
text: Test your knowledge of history with today’s question about a confrontation during the Cold War.

headline: Terex Ready for an Equipment Deal
text: The top executive of Terex said on Thursday he was willing to use most of the $1.35 billion in cash on his company’s books to pay for the right acquisition in the heavy equipment business, Reuters reports.

headline: Do You Judge Political Candidates by Their Looks?
text: Does a candidate’s appearance affect his or her chances of being elected? As Election Day nears, candidates have ramped up their public appearances and placed their television commercials in heavy rotation. What messages do the candidates convey? Do you think that, consciously or unconsciously, you assess candidates for office by the way they look and dress?

headline: Saskatchewan Officially Opposes BHP Bid
text: Saskatchewan, the province where the Potash Corporation is based, on Thursday officially opposed the $39 billion takeover offer by the mining giant BHP Billiton, saying it “does not provide a ‘net benefit’ to the people of Saskatchewan and Canada.”

headline: Tip of the Week: Downloading Facebook Albums Easily
text: Facebook photo albums have become a great way to share picture collections with family and friends. If grabbing your favorite snaps one by one does not appeal to you, a Firefox add-in called FacePAD lets you quickly download entire Facebook photo albums to your computer with a couple clicks. The FacePAD add-on, tutorials and other information about using it with Firefox can be found here.

headline: Megadeals Absent in M.&A. Rebound
text: This year’s rebound in mergers and acquisitions has one conspicuously large absence, Bloomberg News notes: the megadeal.

headline: Bank of China Chief Calls for Overseas Expansion
text: The Bank of China chairman, Xiao Gang, said the financial sector in his country needed to make use of the international post-crisis environment to speed up its overseas growth, The Financial Times reported.

headline: ‘Mini-Madoff’ Sentenced to 14 Years in Prison
text: Arthur Nadel, a fund manager whose $168 million fraud was one of several that collapsed in the declining economy and left hundreds of investors without their money, was sentenced to 14 years in prison on Thursday, Reuters reported.

headline: Ericsson Cautious on Recovery Despite Profit
text: Ericsson, the biggest maker of telecom networking equipment, said on Friday that its profit had more than quadrupled in the third quarter after a year of cost-cutting. But it still gave a cautious prognosis for the industry’s recovery.

headline: Slow Markets, Slow Bonuses

headline: Health Care Accounting Is Challenging, Not Impossible
text: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

headline: Health Care Accounting Is Challenging, Not Impossible
text: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

headline: New Prague Pub Celebrates Czech Brews
text: The Czech Republic’s lagers are celebrated around the world and its citizens consume more beer per head than any other country. But thanks to a limited selection at most Prague pubs, visitors hoping to sample a range of Bohemian brews might have felt like they were missing something. A new pub, the Prague Beer Museum, aims to change that.

headline: N.F.L. Sends Safety Video, and Warning, to Its Teams
text: Ray Anderson, the N.F.L.’s executive vice president for football operations, told players they were “on notice” in a video explaining the boundaries of hits to the head area. The video was sent to all 32 teams, and it’s a good primer for fans.

headline: Raising Debt a Cheap Way to Drum Up Cash
text: From Reuters Breakingviews:

headline: Cnooc Is Said to Team Up for Kosmos Asset Deal
text: Cnooc of China and Ghana National Petroleum have bid $5 billion for Kosmos Energy’s assets in Ghana, a West African country, including its stake in the Jubilee field, a source close to the deal told Reuters on Friday.

headline: Ireland Drives New Bargain on Anglo Irish Debt
text: Anglo Irish, the nationalized Irish lender that blazed a trail in bad real estate loans during the country’s banking boom and crash, made an offer on Thursday to its junior debt holders to exchange about 1.6 billion euros in dated bonds in the bank for new, government-guaranteed bonds — at a steep loss.

headline: The Bank Wins…
text: From the Editorial Pages of The New York Times:

headline: Caterpillar to Buy Engine Maker From 3i
text: Caterpillar said Friday that it would buy MWM Holding, a German engine maker, from the British private-equity firm 3i for $810 million in cash.

headline: Bridgewater Wins Big on Bearish Bets
text: Bridgewater Associates, one of the largest hedge funds in the United States, looks like one of 2010’s winners, with a return of about 38 percent at its flagship fund after a string of bearish bets, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: A Long Year for Thomas O. Hicks
text: Few sports owners have had as rough a year as Thomas O. Hicks, Ken Belson and Richard Sandomir report in The New York Times.

headline: MGM Is Said to Dispute Savings From Lions Gate Deal
text: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer plans to make public a merger proposal from Lions Gate Entertainment to dispute the purported cost savings, The New York Post reported, citing an unnamed source.

We’ll wager this has at least as good a chance of going viral as Stephen Colbert and Steve Carell’s “Sully Song.”

headline: Video Shows ‘Stealth’ Nuclear Submarine Stuck in Scottish Mud
text: 3:57 p.m. Update: The BBC reports that tugboat crews successfully pulled the submarine to safety after waiting for the evening tide to come in. My colleague John Burns has more on the grounding of the submarine and the operation to free it from the silt.

headline: Weekly Pick ‘Em: Sorting It All Out
text: When Texas lost to U.C.L.A. earlier this season, it looked as if it might be a rough year for the Big 12. But then Oklahoma, Missouri and Oklahoma State kept on winning. Those three are still undefeated, but this is the weekend when the Big 12 promises to shake itself out. Texas knocked Nebraska from the ranks of the unbeaten last week. Will the Cornhuskers be able to bounce back from that loss and do the same to Oklahoma State? Oklahoma travels to Missouri as the No. 1 team in the Bowl Championship Series standings, and the Tigers would love to prove their legitimacy by knocking off the Sooners. Speaking of legitimacy, Texas Christian does not seem as if it will get a legitimate chance at the national title, even if it keeps dominating opponents. The Horned Frogs face Air Force, which had been ranked until a loss last week. In the SEC, Louisiana State and Auburn are undefeated and in the top 10, but both seem to be searching for respect. Many think it is simply luck that has kept Les Miles’s bunch undefeated, while Cam Newton has kept Auburn winning despite a woeful defense. In the Big Ten, Wisconsin is coming off a huge win over Ohio State. Now the Badgers travel to Iowa, where they hope the running back duo of John Clay and James White will continue their productivity. It’s a weekend where many teams will find out where they stand, and so will our prognosticators. As always, if you agree or disagree with the picks, or merely find them laughable, feel free to drop in a comment.

headline: Tibetans in China Protest Proposed Curbs on Their Language
text: BEIJING  Thousands of Tibetan students in western China have protested since Tuesday against proposals to curb or eliminate the use of the Tibetan language in local schools, according to reports from Tibet advocacy groups and photographs and video of the protests circulating on the Internet.

headline: Nations Agree on Need to Shrink Trade Imbalances

headline: Graphic Books Best-Sellers: What Is Manga?

Beyond that list, there is an increasing number of popular manga-style series – like “Odd Is On Our Side,” at No. 8 on the softcover list, based on the Dean Koontz character Odd Thomas – and the line of what is manga and what is manga-inspired sometimes gets blurry.

text: Sometimes CMJ can turn into an unlikely science experiment, allowing listeners to see their favorite bands dissected, its moving parts left out for all to see. On Thursday night, there were performances by the side projects of the two steady members of Vivian Girls, a band that, for all its charm and instinctual acumen, has not always seemed to have constituent parts to be broken into.

headline: Honda Is Recalling 470,000 Vehicles for Brake Fluid Problem
text: Honda is saying that 470,000 vehicles could be involved in its latest recall, for brake fluid leaks, reports The Detroit News. It is the same problem for which Toyota issued its latest recall, of 740,000 vehicles in the United States. Honda and Toyota use the same supplier, the Advics Company in Japan, for the parts.

Not many vehicles could handle those two assignments on the same drive, and the Cayenne was unquestionably a marvel of engineering. But to what end?

headline: A Familiar Brand, if No Longer for Motorcycles
text: AMONG those whose passions include vintage Japanese motorcycles, Bridgestone is a familiar name, usually as the brand of tires fitted to Hondas, Kawasakis, Suzukis and Yamahas from the 1960s. But keen enthusiasts, collectors and restorers know that Bridgestone the tire maker also produced motorcycles  innovative bikes that sold in small numbers when new, but are increasingly sought-after today.

text: THE ideal spot for a billboard advertising a new car is along a high-traffic road where lots of drivers poking along in grille-to-tailgate traffic have time to read it. Yet those same clogged thoroughfares would be the worst possible places to savor the performance features of a sporty sedan.

headline: Inside the List
text: BIEBER SCHNITZEL: Forget the midterm elections. Let’s talk about Justin Bieber (!), who, in “Justin Bieber. First Step 2 Forever: My Story,” overcomes childhood adversity and bad punctuation to land at No. 2 (!!) on the children’s hardcover chapter book list, presumably after a precision spin. (I’ll admit, the copy I read on the subway was concealed inside the dust jacket of the more age-appropriate Rick Springfield autobiography “Late, Late at Night,” new at No. 13 on the grown-up hardcover nonfiction list.)

headline: Slither Room
text: “A fisherman,” according to an old Russian proverb, “can spot another fisherman from far away.” This is true. And within the fishing clan there is a set of private yet shared moments that bond fishermen together in an almost spiritual communion. The explosion of spray and color when a big fish charges a topwater lure. The devastating ping of snapped line after that same fish makes a last desperate surge and claims its freedom.

headline: Criminal Mind
text: The stranger wore a white rabbit fur toque for its symbolism of purity. Inside his hobo sack he carried necessary accouterments of the wandering class and various weapons, including a knife and wooden clubs. Eventually, he adopted a dog and a pet magpie, and toted an accordion. The instrument he could not play well. The animals he clubbed to death as a horrified witness looked on. He was Joseph Vacher, a former soldier who roamed the French countryside from 1894 to 1897, killing more than twice as many people as Jack the Ripper, and the antagonist of Douglas Starr’s absorbing historical true-crime book, “The Killer of Little Shepherds.”

headline: In the Eyes of Others
text: Western societies got weird in the 19th century. I mean that not as an insult but as an acronym. The cultural psychologists Joe Henrich, Steve Heine and Ara Norenzayan recently showed that many psychological processes work differently in people raised in Western, educated, industrialized, rich and democratic (WEIRD) societies. The normal, or default, mode of human cognition, for example, is holistic, given to seeing relationships among elements, but people in WEIRD societies think more analytically. They see a world full of discrete objects, like balls on a billiard table, whose properties are best analyzed individually.

headline: Place of Last Resort
text: In his 1943 study of E. M. Forster, Lionel Trilling described “Howards End,” published in 1910, as a novel “about the rights of property, about a destroyed will-and-testament and rightful and wrongful heirs. It asks the question, ‘Who shall inherit England?’ ” A century later, the British novelist Rose Tremain has given us “Trespass,” a dark and unflinching novel that is also about rights of property, in this case to a former silkworm hatchery called the Mas Lunel, in the Cévennes region of France. The question, however, is not “Who shall inherit France?” It is “Shall France be inherited by its occupiers?”

headline: Just Win
text: “The Washington Huskies weren’t breaking new ground here.” “Here” is a college football program that sacrifices its players’ long-term well-being and its community’s dignity for the sake of winning; that looks the other way when stars are accused of violent crimes; that skirts ethics off the field while pursuing perfection on it. Which sounds bad, but in a boring way. What the investigative reporter Ken Armstrong and the higher-education correspondent Nick Perry have done, first in an award-winning Seattle Times series and now in “Scoreboard, Baby,” is lay out — in hard-boiled style and with the verve only real story­telling can supply — exactly whose lives were mangled in the course of the University of Washington’s historic 2000 season. Their idiosyncratic characters and plots ultimately indict a vast, impersonal system that has produced dozens of such teams. The Huskies didn’t break new ground here, but in so comprehensively detailing them, the authors did.

headline: Teen Spirit, Soured
text: Too often, our comfort zones are our tombstones. We settle into numbing patterns and that’s that — wake me when it’s over. Not so in the frenetic world of James Franco, whose ambition over the past few years has manifested almost as performance art: he’s been affiliated with multiple M.F.A. programs, in fiction, poetry and filmmaking; he’s angling to add “Dr.” to his name, having recently become a Ph.D. aspirant at some shabby school called Yale. Oh, and in case your particular comfort zone is a cave, he’s a pretty successful actor, too.

headline: Editors’ Choice

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE PRIVILEGES,  by Jonathan Dee (Random House, $15.) In this “contemporary morality tale,” as our reviewer, Roxana Robinson, called it — assuming you can write a morality tale about people without morals — a young golden couple marry, have children and become incredibly wealthy from insider trading. Dee’s “intelligent and ambitious book” proposes “that the family is essential to society, that we abandon it at our peril,” Robinson said. She praised the “elegance, vitality and complexity” of Dee’s writing.

headline: Don’t Landfill That Goose. Braise It.
text: The key to delicious Canada goose, Jackson Landers says, begins at the moment of death.

headline: Fabulous Dead People | Laura Ashley
text: People tend to think of Laura Ashley as being ironically fabulous; actually, she was genuinely fabulous. When Ashley introduced mix-and-match home furnishing fabrics in tiny florals in the ’60s, it was the shot heard ’round the world. Prints with reversible ground and motif colors became her signature. Some of them were twee, but they raked in millions. It’s a look the industry has been feeding off ever since.

headline: Key European Matchups: Serbian Grudges
text: The outstanding matchups in European league soccer this weekend:

headline: Halladay Earns Himself, and the Phillies, a Reprieve
text: If you feel some strange forces at work in these baseball playoffs, you are not alone. Just as both league championship series were speeding toward installing the plucky underdog in the World Series  much to the chagrin of television executives, the giant robot that calculates the Yankees’ payroll and Bud Selig’s cardiologist  the big-bucks teams fought back, at least for a game. Like the Yankees a day before, the Phillies fought off elimination, cueing the conspiracy theorists and prompting all those television executives to put the paper bags away.

headline: Off the Menu: Eolo and Tía Pol
text: Melissa Muller-Daka is serious about the cooking of her native Sicily. At Eolo she has devised a menu [pdf] as a showcase for dishes like maccu cu grancio (fava bean puree with ricotta, carb and wild fennel), tummala del gattopardo (a round of pastry filled with pasta and meatballs), pisci spada cu cus-cusu (swordfish with cous cous). She is in the kitchen and her husband, Tarek Daka, is running the little restaurant named for the Aeolus, god of winds of Greek mythology, in homage to Sicily in ancient times as Magna Graecia.

headline: Nonfiction Chronicle
text: THE MADE-UP SELF  Impersonation in the Personal Essay.  By Carl H. Klaus.  University of Iowa Press, paper, $19.95.

headline: Doubts Persist on Gulf Sand Barriers
text: In Friday’s paper I write about the construction of sand berms off the Louisiana coast, a project that began at the height of the oil spill and continues today, despite the rapid dilution of the remaining oil in the gulf.

headline: Suffolk Police and Immigrants Meet at the Volleyball Net
text: BRENTWOOD, N.Y.  The police officers poured out of sport utility vehicles that looked barely large enough to contain their brawny frames. Then the day laborers arrived, their narrow shoulders as spindly as the old bicycles they rode.

headline: Envisioning a Sustainable America
text: I’m attending a meeting at my new home, Pace University, exploring the need for an increased focus within the study and practice of law focused on sustainable development.
