headline: A Bertoia Sculpture Is Dismantled
text: A sculptural screen of 800 floating metal panels by the artist Harry Bertoia is being dismantled and moved from its home on the second floor of the Fifth Avenue building that is now owned by JPMorgan Chase. The 1954 building, which Gordon Bunshaft originally designed for Manufacturer’s Hanover Trust, is a landmark, but that designation protects only the exterior of the building, not the interior or Bertoia’s 70-foot-wide, 20-foot-high screen.

headline: From Bomb to Bust
text: There’s been lots of ink and oceans of pixels spilled on the question of whether the Internet has killed film criticism, but the very short answer is that serious (if unpaid) criticism has thrived on the Web. The problem is that it’s all too serious: you don’t have to strain your Google finger to find a knowledgeable enthusiast expending 8,000 words on Ozu or Leone. Locating someone who can write succinctly and intelligently on, say, the 1985 Christmasploitation extravaganza “Santa Claus: The Movie” is much harder.

headline: U.S. Offers Pakistan Army $2 Billion Aid Package
text: WASHINGTON  Even as the Obama administration moved to stop training and equipping Pakistani Army units that have killed civilians in the offensive against the Taliban, the United States said Friday that it planned increased aid for Pakistan’s military over the next five years.

headline: CHARTER BECOMES 'LAW OF NATIONS,' 29 RATIFYING IT
text: Washington, Oct. 24--The United Nations World Security Organization came into being when the Soviet Government in mid-afternoon deposited its instrument of ratification, the twenty-ninth necessary to bring this about, and James F. Byrnes, Secretary of State, then signed the protocol at 4:50 o'clock, Eastern standard time, formally attesting that the Charter of the United Nations has come into force.

headline: Bob Kane, 83, the Cartoonist Who Created 'Batman,' Is Dead
text: Bob Kane, the cartoonist who created Batman the Caped Crusader and his sidekick, Robin the Boy Wonder, died on Tuesday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 83 and lived in Los Angeles.

headline: Picasso: Protean and Prodigious, the Greatest Single Force in 70 Years of Art
text: There was Picasso the neoclassicist; Picasso the cubist; Picasso the surrealist; Picasso the modernist; Picasso the ceramist; Picasso the lithographer; Picasso the sculptor; Picasso the superb draftsman; Picasso the effervescent and exuberant; Picasso the saturnine and surly; Picasso the faithful and faithless lover; Picasso the cunning financial man; Picasso the publicity seeker; Picasso the smoldering Spaniard; Picasso the joker and performer of charades; Picasso the generous; Picasso the Scrooge; even Picasso the playwright.

headline: U.N. Awaits Peking Delegates; Taipei Clings To Affiliate Ties; Rogers Calls Ouster A Mistake
text: United Nations, N. Y., Oct. 26--A delegation representing Communist China, which was voted into the United Nations last night, is expected to arrive here this week to take its seat, diplomats close to the Chinese said today.

headline: Mahalia Jackson, Gospel Singer, And a Civil Rights Symbol, Dies
text: Mahalia Jackson, who rose from Deep South poverty to world renown as a passionate gospel singer, died of a heart seizure yesterday in Little Company of Mary Hospital in Evergreen Park, Ill., a Chicago suburb. She was 60 years old, and had been in poor health for several years.

headline:
THE JORDAN-ISRAEL ACCORD: THE OVERVIEW; ISRAEL AND JORDAN
SIGN A PEACE ACCORD
text: ARAVA CROSSING, Israel, Oct. 26 -- At this desert outpost along their border, desolate except for their hopes, Israel and Jordan signed a peace treaty today to put behind them 46 years of war, mistrust and fear for tomorrow.

headline: Her Poetry, Not Her Death, Is Her Triumph
text: Great Britain's Royal Shakespeare Company is bringing an evening of Sylvia Plath to the Brooklyn Academy. Her work, including "Three Women," the only verse play she ever wrote, is to be in repertory with Shakespeare's "Richard II" starting Tuesday. This is prestigious indeed. Why Plath and why now?

headline: Between Sisters
text: Danielle Evans’s whip-smart first story collection charts the liminal years between childhood and the condition dubiously known as being a grown-up. Told from a close distance, these stories lack the rich patina of hindsight, their pleasures coming instead from an immediacy and an engaging voice. They evoke the thrill of an all-night conversation with your hip, frank, funny college roommate.

headline: Ask an Expert About Gambling Addiction
text: As a growing number of states turn to gambling as a source of additional revenue, compulsive gambling is on the rise.

headline: The Queen of Crafts and the Willowy Miss M.

headline: Liberty's Great Statue
text: The statue of Liberty yesterday was seen through a mist darkly. Piercing winds blew around Bedlow's Island, and the numerous workmen, who were not in any way protected from the weather, worked uncomfortably. The speakers' stand, and that for the use of musicians above it, were in readiness yesterday. Planks were removed and a semblance of tidiness was given to the island. A big barge, which looked extremely dismal, with its legend in red characters, "Eat, drink, and be merry," stood at the Bedlow's Island dock to land visitors. It will be used for that purpose this afternoon.

headline: Dr. Jonas Salk, Whose Vaccine Turned Tide on Polio, Dies at 80
text: Dr. Jonas Salk, who in the 1950's developed the first successful vaccine against poliomyelitis, the viral illness that had gripped a fearful nation with images of children doomed to death or paralysis, died yesterday at Green Hospital in the La Jolla section of San Diego. He was 80.

headline: CNBC: An Interview With Harry Reid
text: John Harwood interviewed Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid of Nevada about his challenging race against Sharron Angle, his Republican candidate and Tea Party favorite.

headline: Justice Thomas’s Ex-Girlfriend Speaks Out
text: Just days after the wife of Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas left a surprise voice mail message for Anita Hill, Mr. Thomas’s former girlfriend is speaking out.

headline: Serving Up Vegetables With Eggs
text: Egg dishes can be a great way to serve up more vegetables at dinner time, explains Martha Rose Shulman in this week’s Recipes for Health.

headline: Ali Regains Title, Flooring Foreman
text: KINSHASA, Zaire, Wednesday, Oct. 30 -- Under an African moon in the darkness before dawn today, a bee battered a lion as Muhammad Ali registered an eighth-round knockout of George Foreman and regained the world heavyweight title at the age of 32 after a lapse of more than seven years.

headline: Fred W. Friendly, CBS Executive and Pioneer in TV News Coverage, Dies at 82
text: Fred W. Friendly, the former CBS News executive who was a towering figure in the evolution of news coverage on television, died Tuesday at his home in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. He was 82.

headline: When A Child Moves to Nepal
text: In The New York Times Magazine this weekend, Nick Kristof has a story examining what he calls “D.I.Y. Foreign Aid” — what he says is the emerging trend of individuals creating their own philanthropies and setting out to change one small part of the world.

headline: A New Resource for L.G.B.T. Seniors
text: We’ve written in The New Old Age on occasion about the particular challenges that gay men and lesbians face as they age: the financial inequities that result from federal and state governments declining to recognize same-sex marriages; the fears of discrimination in senior housing and programs; the frequent reliance, when family support is missing, on friends who are aging as well.

headline: Double-Fault
text: Everyone knows that pop culture is bonkers for brooding, romantic, dangerous types with underworld connections. I am speaking, of course, of vampires. But a long time ago, before Bella and Edward even started dating, there was another dark romantic hero who captured our imaginations. He was called a spy. He drank gin or whiskey, not blood. He was preferably English. Educated. And if he had to kill someone he did it like a gentleman, which is to say with a poisoned dart at the end of an umbrella.

headline: Bad Company
text: I am a “celebrity” — broadly speaking — spokesperson for a company I always loved. I shop there, enjoy its aesthetic and admire its charitable giving. But I’ve learned that its labor practices here and abroad are not so admirable, and I’m ashamed I took the job. May I use my Web site to promote organizations that oppose such practices — anti-sweatshop groups, for example? Would donating some of my spokesperson money to charity offset any harm I do? And most important, may I keep this job? NAME WITHHELD, CALIFORNIA

headline: Monetizing Motherhood
text: BlogHer ’10, a conference focused on women and the blogosphere, offered two days of panels and discussions at the New York Hilton this past August. One panel that drew a standing-room-only crowd was about Federal Trade Commission guidelines regarding online advertising disclosures. While other discussions, about activist bloggers, “Radical Blogging Moms” and social- or community-change blogs, may suggest more obvious ideas (or at least hopes) about online empowerment, the intense interest in what the F.T.C. rules might mean to certain bloggers is telling. Web empowerment isn’t always just about having your voice heard; it can also be about money.

headline: Childhood Attachments
text: It’s not hard to understand why an introspective writer like Myla Goldberg, who gravely examined a sensitive child’s yearning to be special in her first novel, “Bee Season,” might want to switch to a genre format to write a going-back-home narrative of adult self-­discovery. Within the conventional novel, it takes some tricky maneuvers to return a grown-up child to the family bosom. Traditional holidays and reunions still serve for short visits, although you’re probably sick to death of those predictable flare-ups over the Thanksgiving turkey. But extended stays demand something more dramatic in the way of a plot. While the death of an elderly parent or an ailing sibling works in theory, it shifts the attention away from the prodigal child. And that can be a real problem when the writer’s primary interest is in sending the protagonist back to revisit his or her younger self, not to fuss over funeral arrangements and be upstaged by the dearly departed.

headline: Party and Punishment
text: In April, after years of the online tabloids’ pushing photos of Lindsay Lohan looking undone in the back seats of limousines, Dr. Drew Pinsky, the TV addiction specialist, offered his opinion of Lohan to one of those Web sites.

headline: Making Bette Midler’s Costume
text: Martha Stewart and Bette Midler create Ms. Midler’s Hulaween ball costume during a recent taping of “The Martha Stewart Show.”

headline: A Glimpse Into the World of Shady Medical Billing
text: Gregory Vinarsky ran his business with a few ground rules.

headline: Let the Sun Shine In
text: When I started writing this article a little more than a month ago, I hadn’t yet had two bulging disks flare up, putting me in excruciating pain. I hadn’t yet had a neck epidural where, as I sat in a hospital gown designed for someone three times my size, the R.N. inserted the IV into the arm on the side that was in such distress. I hadn’t had to spend my half hour of recovery time in a Nightingale ward — those wards with rows of beds divided by the thinnest of sliding curtains that allow you to hear all the particulars of your neighbors’ condition and all the sounds of their discomfort. I hadn’t had to sit in a row of wheelchairs (no other seating was provided) while waiting to consult with the surgeon after the procedure.The procedure went fine and I’m slowly improving, but in my woozy post-op state I had ample time to think yet again about how the experience of health care could be so vastly improved.

headline: The Many Colors of Kenya’s Matatus
text: A couple of days ago, I wrote about Itasha, a recent car trend in Japan where enthusiasts cover their cars with characters from Japanese anime and video games, and comic book logos.

headline: Weekend Competition: Define Middle Class
text: This Weekend, Schott’s Vocab is soliciting definitions of middle class.

headline: The Donor
text: As the co-chairwoman of the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, whose $33 billion endowment makes it the largest private foundation in the world, you’ve focused your efforts on the health and welfare of women in developing countries.  Women and children. It’s been a passion of mine for a long time, but now you’re seeing the world do it.

headline: How to Cook a Canada Goose
text: Our pals at City Room have been talking with Jackson Landers, a hunting instructor and locavore activist based in Virginia, who is coming to Brooklyn next Saturday to teach New Yorkers how to cook Canada geese. The visit was prompted by the federal government’s disposal of some 400 Canada geese in Prospect Park, and subsequent comments about that act on the premises of the City Room blog. Mr. Landers will be cooking with another fellow with an interesting name, Leighton Edmondson, who has cooked at Jimmy’s No. 43, among other places.

headline: On the Mend
text: The narrator of Thomas McGuane’s new novel, “Driving on the Rim,” is a Montana doctor who was given the name Irving Berlin Pickett by his patriotic, evangelical mother, after the writer of “God Bless America.” Berl, as he’s known, describes himself as “irritable, hypercritical, obsessively orderly, claustrophobic, impatient, antisocial and agoraphobic, filled with objectless dread, pessimistic and fault-­finding.” All this might be true, but he’s also a good doctor, and he’s funny, sometimes with a sharp, sardonic wit and sometimes with a goofy self-deprecation. In the way of McGuane’s earlier American quasi ­heroes, he’s both competent and hapless, discovering, in his search for meaning, “that I was remarkably unformed for a man of my age and experience.”

headline: The Grass Is Really No Greener Next Door
text: CHICAGO — The backyard barbecue, that homey symbol of suburban togetherness, occasions conflagrations emotional and literal in the terrific new play “Detroit,” by Lisa D’Amour, at the Steppenwolf Theater here. This scary-funny comedy, set in a nameless housing tract possibly, but not necessarily, outside the city of the title, speaks to the fractious, frightened American moment more perceptively than any play I’ve seen on a New York stage.

headline: The Art of Social Change
text: In 1929, the Church of Scotland Mission, which had a long and successful history of missionary work among the Kikuyu in colonial Kenya, began a campaign to eradicate the practice of female circumcision. The results were hardly what church members hoped for. Large numbers of Kikuyu left the church, and Kenya’s leading anticolonial political organization mounted a vigorous attack on the church’s policies. Female circumcision became a nationalist issue, and a custom that might have gradually disappeared grew further entrenched. Nearly 40 percent of Kenyan women today are estimated to have undergone some form of it.

headline: An iPhone Artist Haunts the Subways
text: This post is part of the first-ever themed issue of The Times’s Sunday Metropolitan section, which is devoted to New York’s subway system. Go to The Subway Issue »

headline: An Uncompromising Woman
text: “Tell them to stop leaning on the fence!” Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, president of Liberia and the first woman ever elected head of state on the continent of Africa, ordered the leader of her security team. We were driving along one of the scarce paved avenues in her nation’s capital, Monrovia. With her convoy rode United Nations gunmen, part of a peacekeeping force of 10,000 charged with preventing a conflagration in the aftermath of 14 years of horrific civil war. The fighting ended in 2003, but outside the windows of Sirleaf’s S.U.V., the skeletons of abandoned buildings and the cries, at once thrilled and desperate, of the onlookers along the president’s route were signs of the country’s position near last on any list of how well the world’s nations are functioning.

headline: Bottle of Cristal, Please
text: A friend recently hosted a large dinner at an upscale restaurant. We were presented the regular menu, and the server advised us of some expensive specials as well. Most of us ordered moderately priced items off the menu, but some of our table mates ordered much pricier specials. Was that a boorish choice?

text: Senator Harry Reid, Democrat of Nevada and the majority leader, is battling the Republican challenger Sharron Angle in one of the most closely watched races of the 2010 campaign. Mr. Reid discussed his bid for a fifth term with John Harwood of The Times and CNBC at the Gritz Café in Las Vegas. Below is a condensed, edited version of their conversation.

headline: Pirate Latitudes
text: What’s up, you might ask, with the Sir David Lean-ish title? For 50 years, Elmore Leonard has specialized in hoodlums who ply their trade in tacky, unexotic locales: guys like Chili Palmer, the Miami loan shark whose moviemaking aspirations take him to ­B-list Hollywood in “Get Shorty” (1990), and Stick Stickley, the Detroit ex-con whose heisting aspirations take him to the gutter-ball precincts of Chili’s Miami in “Stick” (1983).

headline: Israeli Sets World Record by Playing 523 People Simultaneously
text: Alik Gershon, a 30-year-old Israeli grandmaster, set a world record on Thursday by playing 523 people simultaneously in Rabin Square in Tel Aviv.

headline: Lohan Is Sent Back to Rehab
text: A Los Angeles judge ordered Lindsay Lohan to remain in a drug rehabilitation program until Jan. 3 after Ms. Lohan violated the terms of her probation, CNN.com reported. Judge Elden S. Fox of Los Angeles County Superior Court, who made the ruling on Friday morning, had previously ordered Ms. Lohan, the star of “Mean Girls” and “Freaky Friday,” to be sent to jail in September and to be held without bail after she failed a drug test she had been ordered to take as a condition of her probation. But that decision was quickly overturned and Ms. Lohan, after being freed on $300,000 bail, checked into the Betty Ford Center. Ms. Lohan, who faced up to 30 days in jail for the violation, was ordered to return to the court on Feb. 25.

text: The government of Saskatchewan has waded into the middle of Potash‘s takeover battle, officially opposing BHP Billiton‘s $39 billion unsolicited bid.

headline: The Windows Phone 7 Review Roundup
text: For a while it seemed that the competition in the smartphone space was going to consist of an unfair fight between the Apple iPhone, Research in Motion’s BlackBerry and a few bedraggled stragglers. But over the last year, new products have made their way into the marketplace, including Google’s Android platform, and the competition has heated up.

headline: Chris Rock Takes On Broadway in ‘Hat’
text: The comedian Chris Rock will make his Broadway debut this spring in Stephen Adly Guirgis’ new play “The ________ With the Hat” (obscenity deleted) as an Alcoholics Anonymous sponsor working with a recovering addict (to be played by Bobby Cannavale) whose long-time love (Elizabeth Rodriguez) remains in the grip of drugs and alcohol.

headline: They Fetch, They Roll Over, They Aid Tumor Research
text: An operation commonly performed to remove brain tumors from the pituitary glands of humans is now available to dogs, thanks to a collaboration between a neurosurgeon and some veterinarians in Los Angeles. And that is turning out to be good for humans.

headline: The Pros and Cons of the Tutor Stampede
text: I’M well aware that many parents in my community assume that hiring tutors  whether to help their children with learning difficulties or to bump up already high scores  will be as much a part of the cost of school as backpacks and calculators.

headline: Timing Seems Right for Hall to Move On
text: When I first met Ryan Hall, in the spring of 2007, his coach Terrence Mahon was at his side, literally, running next to him as the two jogged from their Midtown Manhattan hotel into Central Park to begin a training run on the 2008 Olympic trials marathon course. About a month earlier, Hall ran the second-fastest debut for an American in the marathon at London in 2 hours 8 minutes 24 seconds. Suddenly, Hall had become a favorite to win the trials, to be held the following November in New York. In fact, he went on to win that race, propelling himself to the top of the thin list of world-class American male marathoners.

headline: Sony Reaches Out for Help with TVs
text: TOKYO – Sony has been a champion of networked televisions for years. These are the TVs that link seamlessly with other Sony gadgets, link to the Web and finally bridge the gap between PCs and the living room.

headline: The Catch
text: About 10 years ago, I was tending my used-book shop opposite Columbia University when a woman walked in, piled up every copy we had of “The Bonfire of the Vanities,” “The Catcher in the Rye,” “Portnoy’s Complaint,” “The Liars’ Club” and a dozen other representative titles by American authors. She asked if we had any more in the back, which we did. She cleaned us out and informed us that these books would be going to Russia, where they would give her Russian students a glimpse of life in America. (Hmm. Had to wonder what impression some of those would make.) Instead of producing the expected credit card, she proposed an unusual barter. “I own a seafood company in Maine,” she explained. “How would you like to get paid in lobster? I’ll phone in a credit in your name, and my staff will ship you lobsters.”

headline: Former President Bush to Appear on ‘Oprah’
text: Oprah Winfrey has scored the second television interview with former President George W. Bush as he embarks on a book tour.

headline: Week 8 College Football Matchups
text: One of my favorite (and most delicious) things to compare the college football season to is a pint of Guinness. It takes some time to settle. You think you’re ready for that first sip, but you’re not. Patience, things are still settling. You stare at it. Still settling. Sometimes (often when you are thirstiest) it feels like it will never be ready to drink. (Anyone else getting thirsty?) That’s how this season is going. It’s taking forever to settle. The picture is still hazy. Just when it seemed like we knew what was going on the No. 1 team started losing every week. Now it seems we know even less. Will Oklahoma be the third straight No. 1 to go down? Don’t sleep on Missouri and its nasty defense. Who will remain as the last unbeaten in the SEC after Auburn hosts L.S.U.? Will Cameron Newton’s stock continue to rise? Or will he pull a Taylor Martinez/Denard Robinson when he faces a tough L.S.U. defense? Can Iowa take control of the Big Ten? Can Nebraska bounce back? Let’s all get a pint of Guinness and wait to see what happens.

headline: Juan Williams Says NPR Was ‘Looking for a Reason’ to Fire Him
text: Two days after being fired by NPR, Juan Williams is, as the NPR media correspondent David Folkenflik put it, “now enjoying the full embrace of Fox News, which has given him a new three-year, $2 million contract and a guest slot, Friday night, as host of The O’Reilly Factor.”

headline: The Food Issue: Eating Together
text: It is a rare day that I sit down and read The New York Times Magazine cover to cover — a 2-year-old and a husband who steals the magazine for the crossword the moment it lands on our front step provide enough obstacles — but I saw Sunday’s cover and knew I needed it back once the crossword was wrestled into submission. Thank you so much; such beautifully written articles. I laughed, cried and stood in awe of the amazing things people are doing with food and creating community. When I finished, I passed the magazine back to my husband and said, “Read everything.”

headline: Recipe Redux
text: I admire the magazine’s food-themed issues, which encourage readers to look at food as not just an object of consumption but also as an opportunity to make an impact, for better or worse, through our conscious decisions. The Times regularly reminds us that our food choices not only affect our physical health but also shape our social, environmental, economic and cultural identities. I thus find it paradoxical that the magazine’s Food Issue features a recipe for veal. This issue advocates taking a more holistic perspective on eating and food, and Amanda Hesser’s Recipe Redux extols the impact of The Times’s “classic” recipes over the years. Yet by featuring a 1962 recipe for veal chops beau séjour, The Times fails to heed its own advice. The veal industry, which the ethicist Peter Singer calls “the most morally repugnant” of all “factory farming,” involves tethering calves in pens not wider than two feet so they are unable to stretch their legs from birth until slaughter, and deliberately feeding them a diet lacking in iron, so that their meat reaches a desired tenderness and complexion. Surely The Times can set a better example for its readers?

headline: Pie + Design = Change
text: John T. Edge makes clear the disconnect that followed Project M from Maine to Greensboro, Ala., and how the group’s original Pie Lab concept, though charming, shared the drive-by aspect that weakens so many American efforts to do good. I’m sure many of the Project M folks who went to Hale County were drawn by the myth-making of “Let Us Now Praise Famous Men,” which is a fine work of literature but not a sociology text and one which has been criticized by Hale County people since its release for its drive-by qualities. You get a sense of what discomfits them by a quick glance through the Walker Evans archive at photos of the Burroughs (really Gudger) family that have not become iconic — the ones in which they are smiling and dressed in their nicer clothes. It’s significant that one outsider depicted in Edge’s article who is still making a difference in Greensboro — Pam Dorr — made a life investment in the town by moving there and staying long enough to learn the nuances. This is something that rural people are likely to respect and relate to.

headline: Keeping It Kosher
text: As an orthodox Jew who (alas, too infrequently) dines out, I am horrified by Rabbi Levy’s demand, reported in Frank Bruni’s article on Basil Pizza & Wine Bar, for video feeds from OK- certified restaurants. If in fact Rabbi Levy is correct that kosher consumers will not eat in establishments where “inappropriate” behavior or dress is tolerated, then market forces will prevail and the restaurant will go out of business. Neither the restaurant owner nor the diners need Big Brother to determine whether patrons were “socializing for matrimonial purposes.”

headline: Kafka’s Last Trial
text: In using the ambivalent notion of “trial” in the title of her cover story (Sept. 26), Elif Batuman connects the title and contents of Kafka’s novel with the current (and past) legal procedures concerning Max Brod’s literary estate. She also associates one of Brod’s heirs, Eva Hoffe, who as a matter of fact is a key figure in this matter, with Kafka’s famous doorkeeper in “Before the Law.” She suggests that a number of important papers may be locked up in her “cat infested” flat in Tel Aviv. I do not believe that this is the case for two reasons. First, I am quite sure that the considerable number of bank safes held by the Hoffes give enough space to preserve the most important documents. Second, the Hoffe family occupied two apartments at 23 Spinoza Street. The one in which Eva’s mother, Esther Hoffe, lived on

headline: Animosity Farm
text: As one of the neighbors of the farm Bob Morris writes about in the Lives column, I hardly recognized the place he describes. I did, however, recognize the “handsome Ivy League educated” farmer with the “blue green eyes . . . bright as bachelor buttons.” I knew this was the organic farm right next door, one of two small farms we are fortunate to have in our community and one we want to encourage and nurture. The farmers and their staff of interns are more than competent at their jobs; they seem gifted. As Morris does mention, they do work terribly hard; the produce is beautiful and healthful.

headline: F.C.C. Calls for ‘Good Faith’ in Cable Dispute
text: 4:15 p.m. | Updated The Federal Communications Commission on Friday stepped up its pressure on Cablevision and News Corporation, signaling just how seriously the feud over retransmission payments is being taken in Washington.

headline: Nevada Jobless Rate Still at Record High
text: Nevada’s unemployment rate was 14.4 percent in August, the highest of all the American states. That figure also tied its rate in August as the highest ever recorded for the Silver State since the Labor Department began keeping track in 1976, according to a report released Friday.

headline: Now Booking | Romeo Hotel, Naples
text: Naples, Italy, has been hard at work lately distancing itself from its reputation as a city of lawlessness and litter. It has invested millions in restoration and transportation projects, not to mention improving its tourism infrastructure with the likes of the new Romeo Hotel.

headline: Client 9 and Other Interested Parties
text: CAN that really be Eliot Spitzer, the disgraced former governor of New York, smiling into the camera with his co-host, Kathleen Parker, on a new CNN talk show, or is it some kind of fever dream? Did that sordid call-girl scandal really happen?

headline: In Jail or on the Run, Karadzic and Mladic Could Still Win Bosnia’s War
text: As my colleagues Dan Bilefsky and Doreen Carvajal report, European countries have apparently reduced the pressure on Serbia’s government to arrest Ratko Mladic, the Bosnian Serb general still wanted on war crimes charges by an international tribunal in The Hague for his part in the massacre of 8,000 men and boys after forces under his command seized the Bosnian town of Srebrenica in 1995.

headline: Rounding Up the Usual Suspects: Interpreting Famous Quotations
text: Overview | What do we say about ourselves when we quote lines from movies or elsewhere? Why do famous quotes from movies, literature and history resonate with many people? In this lesson, students consider the power of their favorite movie lines and other famous quotes, then write essays interpreting and commenting on a selected quotation.

headline: The Reliable (Melodic) Drone of Suuns
text: Suuns, from Montreal (pronounced “Soons” and formerly called Zeroes), are drone scholars. They bear down on one chord, or just one repeated note, in all sorts of ways, as their lead singer, Ben Shemie, croons ominious thoughts in a high tenor with sociopathic gentleness: “Don’t you be yourself/you are someone else,” he intoned.

headline: G.M. Recalls 300,000 Chevrolet Impalas for Seat-Belt Problem
text: General Motors is recalling 303,000 2009-10 Chevrolet Impalas because the front seat belts could come loose in a crash. The recall comes more than a year after G.M. first learned of the problem.

headline: Come for the Highway. Stay for the View.
text: BOULDER CITY, Nev.  It is an engineering marvel and an acrophobe’s nightmare. And even in its first week, it is a tourist attraction.

headline: Cholera Outbreak Kills 150 in Haiti
text: A cholera outbreak in a rural area of northwestern Haiti has killed more than 150 people and overwhelmed local hospitals with thousands of the sick, the World Health Organization said Friday, increasing long-held fears of an epidemic that could spread to the encampments sheltering more than a million Haitians displaced by the January earthquake.

headline: U.S. Prevails in Trade Dispute With China
text: WASHINGTON  The United States claimed victory Friday in a trade dispute with China, after a World Trade Organization panel largely upheld tariffs that were imposed on an array of Chinese-made steel pipes, tires and other products during the Bush administration.

headline: Deadline Slips on an Oil Spill Report
text: The agencies conducting the main federal investigation into the BP Deepwater Horizon explosion and spill said Friday that they had asked for and been given extra time to complete their report.

headline: N.R.S.C. Opens $10 Million Line of Credit
text: The National Republican Senatorial Committee has taken out a $10 million line of credit less than two weeks before the midterm elections, an indication of the large number of competitive – and costly – states that both parties are battling over.

headline: Being Tony Curtis
text: In this portion of the January 15, 1970, interview with Dick Cavett, Tony Curtis discussed his films and his relationship with directors.

headline: She’s Leaving Home; Grab a Camera
text: DOUG BLOCK has made a film about his daughter Lucy’s final year of high school without a mention of SATs, SAT IIs, AP courses, tutors, college counselors, recommendations, essays or acceptance rates.

headline: Questions for Tony Curtis
text: In this portion of the January 15, 1970, interview with Dick Cavett, Tony Curtis took questions from the audience.

headline: Pregame Huddle: Contending or Pretending
text: Oklahoma is undefeated and a top of the B.C.S. standings, but are they better than Boise State?

headline: For the Record: N.H.L. Countdowns to Infamy
text: Hockey fans who like to keep an eye on the record book could be in for a treat this season. Several records have already fallen, and plenty of players will be closing in on historical achievements over the coming weeks and months.

headline: Beyond Bullets and Berets, Life in Wartime
text: “I’m a soldier, I’m not a martyr,” Carlos the Jackal announces in “Carlos,” Olivier Assayas’s fictionalization of the life and brutal times of the Marxist turned mercenary. Carlos delivers this line in 1975 during a re-creation of a heated exchange with the radical true believers with whom he has taken OPEC ministers hostage. It was one of the more spectacular operations in his career as a self-professed professional revolutionary, and he had carefully dressed for the part in a black beret and leather jacket meant to invoke Che Guevara, pop martyr supreme.

headline: Part 2: N.B.A.’s Defensive Movers and Shakers: Who Will Improve?
text: Previously, we wrote that Washington and Milwaukee are the top candidates to improve on offense this season, with Cleveland and Toronto prepared for a tumble. Now, it’s time to look at who’s headed up and who’s headed down on defense.

headline: Maternal Wisdom (5 Pounds’ Worth)
text: THE memo from the middle school came home in my daughter’s backpack on a Friday afternoon. “Next week your sixth-grade child will participate in a flour-sack baby exercise,” it said. All sixth graders were to report to school Monday with five-pound bags of flour dressed up as dolls, and carry them everywhere for the week. The idea was to teach them the responsibilities of teenage parenthood. “We encourage parental participation to make this exercise a success,” the note concluded.

headline: L.I.R.R. Plans Service Suspensions
text: When subway riders grouse about periodic weekend service disruptions, they may be wise to consider what the Long Island Rail Road is about to do.

headline: Underwriting a Child’s Business Poses Pitfalls for Parents
text: Several years ago, Nathan Deal and his wife invested $2 million to help their daughter and son-in-law open an outdoor sporting goods store. They eventually doubled down by guaranteeing bank debt worth $2 million more. The business failed in 2009, the children filed for bankruptcy and their elders are now scrambling to avoid the same fate.

headline: British Navy Seeks Inquiry After Nuclear Sub Runs Aground
text: LONDON  The Royal Navy hastened to assemble an official inquiry Friday evening to explore why Britain’s newest nuclear submarine, H.M.S. Astute, ran aground while undergoing sea trials off the coast of northwest Scotland on Friday morning and remained stuck on a bank of sand and shingle for nearly 10 hours before a tug pulled it free at nightfall. A spokesman for the Royal Navy said divers would be deployed at first light on Saturday to check concerns that the submarine’s rudder had been damaged.

headline: How to Get Unfriended on Facebook
text: THE GIST People are most likely to unfriend those who post mundane or inflammatory status updates.

headline: Hannelore Schmidt, 91, Wife of West German Chancellor, Dies
text: BERLIN  Hannelore Schmidt, a former schoolteacher and prominent conservationist who won the affection of Germans as the down-to-earth wife of Helmut Schmidt, the West German chancellor, died Thursday at her home in Hamburg. She was 91.

headline: Kortrijk Report | Design Without the Traffic Jams

headline: Trial of Synthetic Mesh in Pelvic Surgery Ends Early
text: To repair the uncomfortable and potentially dangerous condition called pelvic organ prolapse  a weakening of the muscles and ligaments that support organs like the bladder and uterus  more gynecological and urological surgeons have been turning to a synthetic mesh that shores up the vaginal wall.

headline: $200 Billion in Ads, Mr. Biden? That’s Real Money
text: Conservative groups have not dumped $200 billion in political ads on the heads of Democratic candidates.

text: Photographs from Kashmir, Haiti and Britain.

headline: ‘The False Friend’
text: Chapter 1

headline: Under London’s Railway Arches
text: A FEW years ago, if you were to take a late-night walk down the Gales Garden, a tiny alley of arches under the railway viaducts in the Bethnal Green area of London, you would have come across Studio 10. A sleazy after-hours club of dubious renown, it was a place where people “were allowed to express themselves in almost any way they liked,” as Jalle Rousku diplomatically put it.

headline: Video: Who Is Contending, Who Is Pretending?
text: Oklahoma is undefeated and atop the B.C.S. standings, but is it better than Boise State? And can Auburn keep winning despite its problems on defense? Connor Ennis and Paul Myerberg break it down on this week’s edition of the Pregame Huddle.

headline: 6.1 Million Tune In to ‘Jersey Shore’ Finale
text: As it did the first time around, MTV’s “Jersey Shore” ended its second season with more viewers than it started with.

headline: Indonesia Debates Possibility of Honor for Suharto
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia  To millions, Suharto, the military strongman who ruled Indonesia for 32 years, was a tyrant, a thief and a murderer.

headline: Hotel Review: Rafayel on the Left Bank, in London
text: BASICS

headline: Fight Breast Cancer? I’ll Drink to That
text: Each October, Madison Avenue not only thinks pink, it turns pink, as marketers seek to show how much they support the fight against breast cancer. Products are re-dressed in pink packaging, appliances are sold with pink tints, pink ribbons festoon apparel and some newspapers even tint their pages pink.

headline: LeBron James Shares Hateful Twitter Messages
text: Athletes have received nasty messages from fans since the day of the first sporting competition back in ancient Greece. Things have evolved from verbal taunts to written notes. Back in the day, athletes received hate snail mail.

headline: Mets Narrow General Manager Search
text: The Mets have narrowed their search for their next general manager, inviting two candidates — Josh Byrnes and Sandy Alderson — for a second round of interviews that will be conducted next week.

headline: The Gang That Couldn’t Bomb Straight
text: IN “Four Lions,” the first feature directed by the British comedian Chris Morris, a group of British Muslim fundamentalists hatch a plot to blow themselves up during the London Marathon. From this decidedly unfunny premise the film finds multiple occasions for laughter.

headline: Where Football Means Business
text: Saturday will be homecoming at Clarkson University in upstate New York, with part of the festivities including a football game against a team from Boston University.

headline: Arts & Leisure Preview: Keith Richards, Taylor Swift, ‘The Walking Dead’ and More
text: Wisdom, insights and observations from this weekend’s Arts & Leisure section. (Click on links for complete articles.)

headline: Weekend Fare
text: Pots of chili, consommé, chicken noodle soup and more will be simmering during the Smith Street Soup Festival in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, on Saturday. Admission is $5 a person or $10 a family. Local restaurants will sell four-ounce samples of soups from 1 to 4 p.m. on Smith Street between Carroll Street and Atlantic Avenue. Proceeds will go to benefit a new culinary arts program at the High School for International Studies on Baltic Street.

headline: The Devil Inside and the Demon in Disguise
text: The Exorcist

headline: Does Rooney Deal Undermine United’s Ability to Compete?
text: Wayne Rooney was upset that his club, Manchester United, didn’t want to win as much as he did. Despite Sir Alex Ferguson’s “genius,” his teammates’ talents and efforts, management wasn’t willing to spend lavishly on international stars to complement Rooney.

headline: This Old 'House'
text: A look inside “House,” a 1977 Japanese horror now releasing on DVD.

headline: Changing Definitions of ‘Green’ Alter Investment Strategies
text: Green investing has been getting a boost lately through a combination of increasing attention to climate change and low returns from traditional investments.

headline: She Keeps Bees — In the Footsteps of P.J. Harvey
text: Jessica Larrabee, the guitarist and singer in the Brooklyn duo She Keeps Bees, has a gift for opening lines. “Brick by brick, she’s gonna take you down,” she warned in one song. “Don’t follow me, honey, not the road you want to be on,” went another. The songs smolder and ignite from there, as her voice rears up and she strums blaring, increasingly frenetic chords on her electric guitar.

headline: Terra Madre Kicks Off in Turin
text: The Palasport Olimpico, built for the 2006 Winter Olympics in Turin, Italy, saw the opening ceremony of another sort of worldwide delegation on Thursday: Terra Madre 2010. Instead of athletes, there were farmers, fishermen and artisanal food producers, along with other sustainable food idealists (young and royalty alike) — from Pavlos Georgiadis, a student from Thrace, Greece, who helped create an edible garden at his university in Stuttgart, Germany, to Alice Waters.

headline: Countless
text: Should the word be used for things we can actually count?

headline: Pictures of the Day: Kashmir and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Kashmir, Haiti and Britain.

headline: Store Review: Ioli, in Madrid
text: Over the last few years, if you saw a Madrileña wearing a pair of fabulous shoes — a pair of genuine ruby slippers like Dorothy’s, say, only a touch more urban, styled as a flat or a d’Orsay pump, with red matte piping along the edge and a slightly more flattering rounded toe — the likely origin of the slippers in question was a bright turquoise shoe box of a shop on Calle Espiritu Santo in the Malasaña neighborhood. There, Cynthia Ioli, an Argentine transplant and former costume designer for theater and opera, is redefining what’s cool on the feet of Madrid’s men and women.

headline: In Papua New Guinea, Trek on a Trail of  War
text: WE entered the jungle of Papua New Guinea equipped for an intrepid voyage into the heart of darkness, hauling a tent and a week’s worth of couscous and instant noodles. The wide cart track we were following soon narrowed to a footpath that slithered muddily through the trees, and the canopy above our heads closed in, blocking the sun.

headline: Going to the Galápagos, and Trying to Limit the Footprint
text: WIND and waves tossed our inflatable dinghy as we circled Champion Islet, a craggy rock in the Pacific Ocean, in search of one of the world’s rarest birds. As the boatman steered the panga in and out of coves, our guide, Ernesto, made a call that was something between a chirp and a shhh. Ten of us intently scanned the arid islet, a last refuge for the Floreana mockingbird. This wasn’t just any bird  its ancestors had inspired Darwin’s thinking on the origin of species.

headline: Lost in Ireland
text: THE place was called Cronin’s Yard, and it was somewhere around here — it had to be. Off to my right, past the barbed-wire fences that bordered intense green pastures, rose the first russet foothills of Macgillycuddy’s Reeks, the highest mountain peaks in Ireland, swathed in a fog punctured in rare spots by the pale morning sun. In there — somewhere — was the Yard, supposedly the best starting point for hikers in the Reeks, and now, after four days of driving southwest from Dublin to County Kerry without a map, GPS or, really, any sense of Irish geography, I was so close. All I had to do was find it.

headline: Getting Lost in Ireland
text: Coming to Ireland to lose myself, over the course of a week, in a country I knew nothing about.

text: In this week’s Your Money column, I use the saga of a Georgia candidate for governor, Nathan Deal, to discuss when (or if) parents should ever invest in the business ventures of their adult children.

text: ON a recent Tuesday, the musician Esperanza Spalding was out searching for “mildly androgynous” vintage items to wear onstage.

headline: Your Commute, Your Life, Your Personal Subway Map
text: This post is part of the first-ever themed issue of The Times’s Sunday Metropolitan section, which is devoted to New York’s subway system. Go to the Subway Issue »Endlessley pored over, chronically criticized, instantly recognizable — the subway map is like the city’s wallpaper. (Or, say, shower curtain; many versions available for under $30.) In June, the 1979 design got its first overhaul in a decade, with Manhattan magnified, Staten Island shrunk, and a lighter taupe background and new gray outlines to make it more readable.

text: Microsoft, I.B.M., Cisco Systems and Citrix have some new, plucky competition when it comes to Web meeting software.

headline: Connecticut Home Builders Promote Energy Savings
text: BUILDERS are trying a bread-and-butter approach to promoting environmentally conscious construction, using previous buyers’ heating and cooling bills to persuade shoppers that buying new will save them money.

headline: Cyclist Fatally Doored in East Harlem
text: Updated, 10:53 p.m. | A 27-year-old cyclist in East Harlem was killed Friday morning when a driver in a parked car opened his door into him and knocked him into the path of a truck, the police said. The rider, Marcus Ewing of Manhattan Avenue, was heading east on East 120th Street just west of Third Avenue around 8 a.m. when he was struck.

headline: Echo and Delay — Too Much of a Good Thing
text: A stray thought: At this year’s CMJ, the new glockenspiel — that is, a nice sound in small doses that has become rampantly overused — is echo and delay effects on vocals. I’ve heard it all over the place, in chillwave, psychedelia, folktronica, hard rock and whatever genre — “witch house?” — Salem is claiming this week.

text: IT used to be that the only thing keeping Gary D. Warshauer up at night was the chatter of crickets and the howl of coyotes.

text: Pound Ridge, a 23-square-mile municipality in northeastern Westchester, is rich in open space.

headline: TimesCast: Donors Unveiled
text: The Times’s Jim Rutenberg and Megan Liberman examine recently revealed corporate donors to the United States Chamber of Commerce, which is spending more money on campaign ads than any non-party group this cycle.

headline: Plumb Beach, Brooklyn 3:14 P.M.
text: In 2006, a gay man named Michael J. Sandy was lured to a rest area off the Belt Parkway by three young men who tried to rob him and chased him onto the highway, where he was killed by a car. His attackers were convicted of hate crimes. On Friday, a park bench at the rest area was dedicated to Mr. Sandy’s memory.

headline: Subway Sketches
text: Eric Molinsky draws people riding New York's subway using the Sketchbook application for the iPhone.

headline: We Three Things | Interior Monologues
text: I find images of unpeopled interiors infinitely more satisfying than pictures of populated rooms. I love the way they appear to wait in quiet anticipation. This is probably why I never tire of looking through decades-old back issues of World of Interiors or Country Life. Empty rooms, especially other people’s, are like handwritten invitations, not to mention oblique self-portraits of the artists who make them.

headline: This Cleo Is No Baby on the Nile
text: Kate Mulgrew is knowing, sensual, slithery and, with her throaty Katharine Hepburn-after-three-vodkas voice, slightly bawdy. And it all adds up to Cleopatra.

headline: Redone Theater Fit for a Pharaoh
text: THEATERGOERS arriving at Hartford Stage this month to see “Antony and Cleopatra” will also get their first look at Phase 1 of the theater’s ambitious renovation. Before the performance on the night of Oct. 16, a friend and I were given a tour of the theater, and I was glad to see that all the planned improvements, which took four months and cost $4 million, had become a reality.

text: In his Wealth Matters column this week, Paul Sullivan writes about how “green” investing has been getting more attention, both because of increasing attention to climate change and because traditional investments have been generating low returns.

headline: The Defense Department’s Response
text: Following is the response to the WikiLeaks documents from Geoff Morrell, the Defense Department press secretary:

headline: The Iraq Archive: The Strands of a War
text: A huge trove of secret field reports from the battlegrounds of Iraq sheds new light on the war, including such fraught subjects as civilian deaths, detainee abuse and the involvement of Iran.

headline: Iran Seized U.S. Hikers in Iraq, U.S. Report Asserts
text: Iran has accused three American hikers of illegally crossing into Iranian territory in July 2009 and is still holding two of them in prison. But a classified American military report made public by WikiLeaks, which describes the chaotic day when the hikers were detained, asserts that the hikers were on the Iraqi side of the border when they were seized.

headline: A Grim Portrait of Civilian Deaths in Iraq
text: The reports in the archive disclosed by WikiLeaks offer an incomplete, yet startlingly graphic portrait of one of the most contentious issues in the Iraq war — how many Iraqi civilians have been killed and by whom.

headline: Detainees Fared Worse in Iraqi Hands, Logs Say
text: The public image of detainees in Iraq was defined by the photographs, now infamous, of American abuse at Abu Ghraib, like the hooded prisoner and the snarling attack dog. While the documents disclosed by WikiLeaks offer few glimpses of what was happening inside American detention facilities, they do contain indelible details of abuse carried out by Iraq’s army and police.

headline: What We’re Reading: Rainfall and Democracy
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: Leaked Reports Detail Iran’s Aid for Iraqi Militias
text: On Dec. 22, 2006, American military officials in Baghdad issued a secret warning: The Shiite militia commander who had orchestrated the kidnapping of officials from Iraq’s Ministry of Higher Education was now hatching plans to take American soldiers hostage.

headline: Letter: Getting to Turku, Finland
text: To the Editor: It might be a cliché, but when it comes to traveling to Turku, getting there is half the fun. Two ferry lines (Tallink Silja and Viking) run giant ships between Stockholm and Turku twice a day, passing through beautiful archipelagos on both ends. The ships are equipped with varieties of cabins, food, entertainment and shopping and are quite inexpensive.

headline: Letter: Sibelius in Turku, Finland
text: To the Editor: I just read Sunday’s article about Turku, “A Finnish City Prepares for the Limelight” (Oct. 10), and was saddened not to find mention of Jean Sibelius, Finland’s greatest composer. Rather curious, since the city is being promoted as a Capital of Culture. The Sibelius Museum (www.sibeliusmuseum.abo.fi) is a gem where 300 musical instruments are on display, concerts are given and memorabilia from Sibelius’s life would fascinate any music lover. Let’s not keep it a secret.

headline: With a Name Like Beach Fossils, Can Sunny Be Far Behind?
text: Put “Beach” in a band name, and the word “sunny” will inevitably appear in descriptions of the music. Especially if it’s true, as it is with Beach Fossils, from Brooklyn. They’re simply asking for it, with peppy, major-key songs and lyrics full of hopeful romance: “I let the time pass by/Soon I’ll be by your side.” The guitars mesh and cascade, splashed in surf-rock reverb, through picking patterns of stuttering notes and arpeggios, stratified like the 1980’s arrangements of New Order or the Cure, but much, well, sunnnier. New Order goes surfing?

headline: In American Custody
text: John Moore of Getty Images has visited American-run detention centers in Iraq, including Abu Ghraib and Camp Cropper; prisons for Taliban fighters in Afghanistan run by that country’s National Directorate of Security; the Pul-e-Charki prison outside Kabul; and, more recently, the Guantánamo Bay detention center. He is gathering these images in a longterm project, “Detained.” James Estrin and David Furst interviewed him by telephone in August. The transcript of their conversation has been edited.

headline: The War Logs: Newly Disclosed Iraq War Reports
text: The At War blog is following reaction to the release of classified American field reports from the Iraq War, which contain information about many episodes never made public in such detail. The New York Times had access to the documents and published a series of reports.

headline: Chic in Review | The Mobama Effect
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Democrats Back Third Parties to Siphon Votes
text: ORLANDO, Fla.  Seeking any advantage in their effort to retain control of Congress, Democrats are working behind the scenes in a number of tight races to bolster long-shot third-party candidates who have platforms at odds with the Democratic agenda but hold the promise of siphoning Republican votes.

headline: N.J. Governor to Evaluate Tunnel as Cost Estimates Rise
text: New Jersey’s governor, Chis Christie, has said he will spend the weekend contemplating whether to put a stop to the planned rail tunnel under the Hudson River. As he does so, he has some very big numbers to consider.

headline: Michaels Out at Tribune; Replaced by Council
text: The Tribune Company’s board today resolved what had been its preoccupation for at least a week: orchestrating the ouster of Randy Michaels, the chief executive whose boorish behavior and sexual antics became a dark sideshow to the bankrupt company’s financial struggles.

headline: A Search for Freedom in a Noisy, Wired World
text: One integral theme running through Trajal Harrell’s programming for his current Platform series, “certain difficulties, certain joy," has to do with pleasure  or with works that flutter ever so lightly around the idea that play doesn’t have to veer into stupidity. On Thursday night at Danspace Project, Mr. Harrell added a memorable addition to his growing pile of treasures: an old work shown in a new space.

headline: Editor at Embattled Literary Journal Will Stay
text: The University of Virginia has released its audit investigating workplace conditions at the Virginia Quarterly Review, the prizewinning literary journal it oversees, but nearly three months after the suicide of its managing editor, Kevin Morrissey, the journal is still on hold. Carol Wood, a spokeswoman for the university, said on Friday that Ted Genoways, the editor of VQR, had been invited to stay on as editor, and Mr. Genoways confirmed in an e-mail that “Yes, I will be remaining on as editor.”

headline: Once Cruel to Be Kind, Now Soft to Be True
text: Nick Lowe is feeding his audience some extremely fine new songs. His show on Wednesday at City Winery started with one of them, sung alone with acoustic guitar. Called “Stoplight Roses,” it uses cheap flowers at a smoggy crossroads as a stand-in for love’s promise, convenience and perishability. The feel was maudlin, but he knew it and played it down and impaled the audience with it.

headline: Surrendering to Muses, Poetry and Song Unite
text: The composer William Bolcom says he finds choosing poems for a song cycle an “arduous task,” as difficult as writing the music. With the help of Joyce Castle, the mezzo-soprano for whom he wrote this song cycle, “The Hawthorn Tree,” he eventually selected seven poems of contrasting character by American and English poets.

headline: For Sustainable Wood, a New and Unloved Standard
text: Next week select members of the United States Green Building Council will begin casting ballots on whether to overhaul how the organization awards sustainability credits for wood products.

headline: A Plush Voice Discovers Some Room to Be Frisky
text: There are no shortcuts to the kind of musical maturity that the jazz singer Jane Monheit displayed at Birdland on Wednesday evening. Although endowed with improvisatory skill and a voice of singular plushness, Ms. Monheit has often struggled to connect with the meanings of songs, letting the sheer beauty of her sound and her polished technique carry her performances. Like many young pop-jazz singers, she often seemed to be listening to herself and gauging her intonation instead of heeding the material.

headline: ‘South Park’ Apologizes for Lifted Material in ‘Inception’ Parody
text: 5:29 p.m. | Updated

headline: A Note From the Editors
text: Like a similar set of articles published in July about Afghanistan, the articles published today are based on thousands of United States military incident and intelligence reports from Iraq  records of engagements, mishaps, intelligence on enemy activity and other events. The New York Times, the British newspaper The Guardian, the German magazine Der Spiegel and the French newspaper Le Monde were given access to the material in June, on the condition that the contents not be made public until now.

headline: App Smart Extra: A Glympse of Your Friends
text: This week’s App Smart column partly focused on the group-texting app Fast Society, which earns points for its self-expiration feature. Start a group text and within a set amount of time the group disbands.

headline: Campy Ode to Film Noir and a Twist on Politics
text: Amanda McBroom is a gusher. By that, I don’t mean an obsequious well-wisher brimming with feigned enthusiasm, but a singer and songwriter who overflows with warmth and good humor, tempered with a hard, clear-eyed wisdom. Ms. McBroom, whose most famous song is “The Rose,” writes in a plain, broad-based pop-country-folk style that has a theatrical heft. The best of her lyrics, many of which address the inner lives of desperate housewives, go the quick of experience with a visionary acuity.

headline: Sfoglia and Its Founders Have Split
text: Ron Suhanosky and Colleen Marnell-Suhanosky, the couple who founded Sfoglia on Nantucket and its intimate offshoot on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, where customers tended to fill up on her delicious bread before the rest of the meal arrived, are no longer involved with either restaurant.

headline: Triathletes, 40-Somethings, Going for Youth
text: HE was 39 and thought he was in decent shape. But when Eric Goodman, an information technologist from Stamford, Conn., tried to run a mile on a treadmill, he could barely make it without feeling as if he were coughing up a lung.

headline: The Price of a ‘No-Cost’ Loan
text: HOME buyers concerned about high closing costs in this tight economy might be tempted by a type of loan that requires no cash outlay in exchange for paying a higher interest rate, especially because rates are already at historically low levels.

text: AFTER graduating from the Juilliard School, Monica Ohuchi Bunch practiced and taught on her upright piano. Two years ago, she upgraded to a Steinway Grand, Model B, nearly seven feet long.

headline: Steven D. Sladkus
text: Mr. Sladkus, 41, is a partner in the law firm Wolf Haldenstein Adler Freeman & Herz, which is based in New York. With a practice focusing on real estate, he represents co-ops and condominiums. His clients include the Cityspire Condominium in Midtown and the Parkchester North Condominium in the Bronx.

headline: An Area on the Brooklyn Waterfront, Growing in a Family Way
text: NEW YORKERS have been rediscovering a small neighborhood in Brooklyn called the Columbia Street Waterfront District — and so have the real estate developers.

headline: How a Tunnel Would Help New Jersey Home Values
text: WHAT is the real estate value of a one-seat train ride to Manhattan from a station close to one’s home in New Jersey? Leave it to statisticians to come up with a figure.

headline: Sometimes, Lucky Numbers Add Up to Apartment Sales
text: FOR some New Yorkers on the hunt for an apartment, the must-have item in the search is nothing as prosaic as a walk-in closet or a second bathroom. It is a number  a lucky number.

headline: Strapped: A Bumpy Year
text: JAY H. WALDER, the imposingly tall 51-year-old chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, pointed approvingly at the giant flat-screen television installed this month near an entrance to the Atlantic Avenue subway station in Downtown Brooklyn. The screen presented a real-time, color-coded guide to what was happening on every line in the system  the type of basic information, commonplace in European transit systems, that the authority has struggled for years to provide.

headline: ‘Paranormal Activity 2’: An Inside Look
text: Last year, “Paranormal Activity” proved itself to be “The Blair Witch Project” of its generation: a gritty, indie, ultra-low-budget horror picture that word-of-mouth powers into the box office stratosphere. “Paranormal” cost $10,000 to make and sold $193 million at the global box office.

headline: Tough Times No Deterrent for This Ball
text: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  Barbara Davis, dripping with dangerously large diamonds as only an 80-year-old society queen can, held court at the Polo Lounge here on a recent Monday afternoon. She touched on various topics  her friend Nancy Reagan has been struggling lately to find comfortable yet stylish shoes  but it was the Carousel of Hope Ball that Mrs. Davis most wanted to talk about.

headline: Can Winnipeg Support an N.H.L. Team?
text: From The Montreal Gazette’s Habs Inside/Out blog, this post discusses two newspaper surveys on whether fans and corporations would pay higher costs for N.H.L. hockey and the plight of the Ottawa Senators.

headline: Week in Culture Pictures, Oct. 22
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Oct. 22
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the groundbreaking of Moynihan Station, a visit by Justice Sonia Sotomayor of the Supreme Court to the Fordham Law Film Festival, and the rising cost of printed textbooks in a digital age.

headline: A Beach Bungalow With a Magnetic Pull
Among the Pads and Huddles, a Nudge Toward College
text: Tuesday night was busy and chilly on Gun Hill Road in the Bronx, even if most eyes and minds were focused a few miles south, where the Yankees were hosting a playoff game. Out of the darkness around 7:30, squeezing through the doors of crowded buses and descending the steps from an elevated train platform, about 40 football players walked one by one across uneven sidewalks lugging shoulder pads, cleats and brightly painted helmets.

headline: City Critic: Patrolling the City
text: Ariel Kaminer, The New York Times's City Critic, takes a ride on a new scooter that the New York Police Department will use to patrol the subway.

headline: All Games Are Decisive at Pearl Spring
text: Magnus Carlsen continues to lead, with Viswanathan Anand, the world champion, now in second.

headline: Chronicle of a Changing City
text: THE B AND Q SUBWAY STATIONS at Neck Road and Avenue U on the Brighton Line are to reopen on Monday after partial closings since mid-2008, and it is not hard to gauge how riders feel about it. Last week at the Avenue U station, a sign offering apologies for delays was defaced with a rebuttal: “Apology Not Accepted.”

headline: The Mating Game
text: ON a misty late morning the Tuesday after Labor Day, Patti Stanger, namesake star of the popular Bravo reality program “The Millionaire Matchmaker,” was standing in her Marina del Rey, Calif., office  a raw industrial space with red-painted walls and matching red chairs shaped like lips  preparing to douse one of her clients in the cold water of her now-notorious realism.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Oct. 22
text: More Photographs

headline: Abraham’s Progeny, and Their Texts
text: The sweep of the new exhibition at the New York Public Library — “Three Faiths: Judaism, Christianity, Islam” — is stunning. It stretches from a Bible found in a monastery in coastal Brittany that was sacked by the Vikings in the year 917, to a 1904 lithograph showing the original Temple Emanu-El on Fifth Avenue. It encompasses both an elaborately decorated book of 20th-century Coptic Christian readings and a modest 19th-century printing of the Gospels in the African language Grebo. There are Korans, with pages that shimmer with gold leaf and elegant calligraphy, and a 13th-century Pentateuch from Jerusalem, written in script used by Samaritans who traced their origins to the ancient Northern Kingdom of Israel.

headline: Anatomy of a Favorite Giants Play, 36/37 BOB
text: Andy Barall writes about pro football history for The Fifth Down. The Ahmad Bradshaw run is at the 40-second mark of the video at top.

headline: Sometimes, Money Can’t Buy You Votes

headline: What Change Could Look Like

headline: Don’t Spirits Ever Knock Anymore?
text: In a very nifty trick, “Paranormal Activity 2” turns out to be both prequel and sequel to its 2007 parent (released in 2009), sliding this new story into the timeline and events of the first with considerable agility. And though the original film’s budget (less than $15,000) has swelled to just under $3 million, the aesthetic and concept — rudimentary in every way — remain rigorously enforced.

headline: Where Does Adobe Go From Here?
text: It’s been a bit of a rough year for Adobe Systems.

headline: The Caucus Click: Fairbanks, Alaska
text: The Federation of Natives endorsed Senator Lisa Murkowski’s write-in campaign for re-election.

headline: At CMJ, Some Get Spotlight; Others Get Lost in the Haze
text: For the last few days, often well into the wee hours, the music writers for The New York Times have been all around town, checking out some of the 1,200 acts performing at this year’s CMJ Music Marathon, which ends on Saturday. Here’s a sampling of whom they’ve seen and heard, excerpted from items posted on the ArtsBeat blog (nytimes.com/artsbeat).

headline: Photo Diary | Lingerie New York
text: What did we learn last night? Among other things, that to compete on the catwalk with a poodle — especially one sporting a heavy metal hairdo — requires quite a lot of black latex. The latex was supplied by the Japanese lingerie designer Atsuko Kudo (a Lady Gaga favorite), who made her American runway debut as part of Lingerie New York, an event thrown at Cipriani’s by the Seven Bar Foundation, a nonprofit organization that has helped poor women in India, Mexico and Brazil start their own businesses. Yes, it was all for a good cause (some seats sold for $25,000 a pop), a fact that was alluded to if not entirely conveyed by the event’s tagline: “Empowering women on a g-string rather than a shoe-string.” The Belgian-based designer Carine Gilson also offered up her own fantasy twists on linge de corps, which Carine Roitfeld, the editor in chief of French Vogue, has described as “the most refined lingerie in the world.”

headline: Finding the Right Pace (and Support Crew) for a Marathon
text: Since becoming the head of the Mariinsky Theater in St. Petersburg, Russia, in 1988, Valery Gergiev has built the house orchestra into an important touring ensemble. Even so, playing six Mahler symphonies in five programs over eight days would test even orchestras that make a specialty of these still-daunting works.

headline: Profiling for a Seat
text: LIKE many liberal-minded New Yorkers, I find racial profiling abhorrent. But there is one place that I, like many liberal-minded New Yorkers, profile people all the time, and not only by race but also by age, ethnicity and sartorial choices: on the subway.

headline: Canadian Oil Company Fined for Duck Deaths
text: OTTAWA  Syncrude, the largest operator of oil sands projects in Canada, was ordered to pay $2.92 million on Friday for causing the deaths of 1,603 ducks.

headline: To Serve and Protect, Perched on 3 Wheels
text: You may have seen them zipping along underground, seeming quite determined and purposeful on their way from this point to that. Or perhaps you spotted them standing alone by a subway exit, like kids who want you to see but not play with their awesome new toy.

headline: The Diversity of Birds and Fishes

headline: Game 6 Analysis: Rangers 6, Yankees 1
text: The Texas Rangers scored four runs in the fifth inning to break a 1-1 tie and went on to beat the Yankees, 6-1, in Game 6 of the American League Championship Series on Friday night. The Rangers won the series, four games to two, and advanced to their first World Series. The franchise began play in 1961 as the Washington Senators.

headline: CBS Maintains No. 1 Spot
text: CBS extended its reign as the No. 1 network on Thursday, leading the night with its crime shows “CSI” (14.7 million ) and “The Mentalist” (14.2 million), according to Nielsen’s estimates. CBS’s sitcoms managed to stay strong despite competition from Major League Baseball coverage on Fox. Final audience figures for Game 5 between the Philadelphia Phillies and the San Francisco Giants were not immediately available. ABC was third with “Grey’s Anatomy” (10.8 million) while NBC ranked fourth, attracting modest ratings for its comedy lineup, including “The Office” (6.8 million).

headline: U.S. Drops Criminal Charges Against UBS
text: Federal prosecutors on Friday dropped criminal charges against UBS, saying that the Swiss bank had gotten out of the business of selling offshore private banking services that allowed wealthy Americans to avoid billions of dollars in taxes.

headline: Paris Review Editor Frees Menagerie of Wordsmiths
text: The first issue of The Paris Review under its new editor, Lorin Stein, hit newsstands recently, and it’s a thing of sober beauty. The issue doesn’t contain many surprises  there’s fiction from Sam Lipsyte, poetry from Frederick Seidel and work from other usual, if talented, suspects. But it’s a solid and auspicious start, worth having tucked under your arm for that 45-minute wait outside Eataly.

headline: From Texas, Talk of Toppling Government
text: The themes of antigovernment revolution have occasionally seeped into comments of Tea Party-backed candidates or their supporters this campaign season, and now a Republican House candidate in Texas has added his thoughts.

headline: Neiman Marcus to Open New Bargain Outlets
text: Neiman Marcus may be known as a place for Texas-size yearnings and price tags, but in a sign of the economic times for luxury retailers, the company is being drawn to a less haughty shopper.

headline: For CMJ, a Slice of Stumptown
text: Depending on the realtor, the New York outpost of Alex Calderwood’s Ace Hotel is either located in NoChe (short for North Chelsea) or NoMad (for North of Madison Square Park), but regular people just think of the area as a place to buy knockoff handbags. Inside the hotel it’s a different scene, like some dreamy Epcot Center version of the Pacific Northwest, especially on this Friday afternoon, when Colin Meloy, the frontman of the Portland-based Decemberists, began tuning up for a solo show, sponsored by KEXP, the great Seattle radio station that moved into the lobby of the hotel for three days during CMJ. “I’m so glad this pocket of Portland is here,” Meloy said of the hotel, which was founded in Seattle but is now headquartered in Stumptown. “Now I feel safe in New York.” His set — which was prefaced by 15 minutes of lovely droning gibberish from Nick Urata’s gypsy punk band DeVotchKa — began with a trio of appropriately transportative songs that Meloy called “Pacific Northwest folk.” Word. It was new stuff, from the band’s forthcoming album, which sounded like a welcome return to the moody lyricism of “Castaways and Cutouts,” the 2003 record that launched 1,000 indie-girl obsessions.

headline: Democrats Look to Clout of Unions as Vote Nears
text: SHARON, Pa.  Just up the hill from a huge, shuttered Westinghouse factory, three campaign foot soldiers from the United Steelworkers rang Ed Turosky’s doorbell to urge him to vote for the Democratic candidates for the House and Senate here.

headline: Preacher Sons Seek Their Father’s Voice, and Heart
text: On one of his periodic visits from New York to his father in Georgia, the Rev. David K. Brawley realized he was having trouble making out the older man’s words. For the previous four years, ever since cancer was found in his chest, Don Brawley Jr. had gone through periods when his voice weakened, when its baritone clenched into a hoarse rasp.

headline: For French Choreographer, a Night to Rattle the Audience

headline: Molding Sound to Behave Like a Solar Eclipse

headline: Beyond Ribbon-Cutting
text: When we started Fixes, we were hoping that interested readers would write in with their own ideas and experiences.  Anyone who read the comments on our debut column, “Health Care and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance,”  knows that this is exactly what happened.  Readers responded to our column on Riders for Health ─ an organization that maintains the motorcycles used by health care workers in rural Africa ─ with a variety of ideas for improving transportation on that continent.  They also proposed many intriguing fixes of their own ─ some of which we will look into for future columns.

headline: Navigating a Close Last Round to Win the Swiss Teams Title
text: The 13th World Bridge Series, held in Philadelphia this month, permitted transnational pairs and teams in all but the junior events. There were several such teams in the Mixed Swiss Teams, including the winners: Greg Hinze, Jo Ann Sprung, Connie Goldberg and Lynn and Dale Johannesen from the United States, and Daniel Lavee from Canada. (Hinze and the Johannesens were misidentified as Canadian in Monday’s column.)

headline: Days and Nights of a Thousand Screams
text: BELLEVILLE The State Scare Factory, 229 Main Street, is open on Sunday and from Wednesday until Halloween from 7 p.m. until midnight. Tickets: $18; $15 for children 12 and under. Tickets that allow front-of-the-line access cost $28. Not recommended for children under 10. For young ones, there is a matinee at 6 p.m. Friday and Saturday and from 2 to 6 p.m. Sundays. Tickets: $8. Information: statescare.com or (973) 450-1070.

headline: Tastes and Sounds of Poland
text: Walking along Nepperhan Avenue, you’re likely to hear the sounds of many cultures: the lilt of a Caribbean accent, the music of Mexico, Puerto Rican-accented Spanish. But step into the Polish Deli and you’re solidly in Eastern Europe.

headline: Tribune Chief Accepts Advice and Backs Out
text: The Tribune Company’s board resolved on Friday what had been its preoccupation for most of the week: sealing the fate of Randy Michaels, the controversial chief executive whose boorish behavior and cronyism became a dark sideshow to his bankrupt company’s financial struggles.

headline: Ricotta Cheese Gnocchi

headline: Fresh Bread, Made With Care
text: In the 14 months since Ross’ Bread opened, it has become something of a social hub in the Copps Hill Common shopping area in Ridgefield. That is less because of its large selection of excellent breads than the attentiveness with which almost everything else there is prepared and served.

headline: An Airy Respite from CMJ’s Subterranean Scene
text: Friday was another windy yet gorgeously sunny afternoon for CMJ, which made trolling through dank, loud subterranean clubs all day feel that much more unnatural. I don’t smoke, so my excuse for all the extra trips to the sidewalk was that the cell service is better out there. Well, it is!

headline: Ricotta Gnocchi Are Sticky and Lumpy (and Just Right)
text: YOU think you know what gnocchi are: small, fork-tine-indented potato dumplings served with pesto or tomato sauce. They’re starchy, thick and filling, and rarely made well enough at home to justify the work.

headline: A Bistro Without Frills, but With Refinement
text: BAR BOUCHON is so hot it sizzles. Named after the small neighborhood restaurants in Lyon, France, called “bouchons,” this tiny, very French bistro in Madison opened quietly two months ago, with Jean-Pierre Vuillermet of New Haven’s Union League Cafe as the executive chef. It is already so mobbed that I felt lucky to snag a 4:30 p.m. dinner reservation one recent Saturday.

headline: For First Time, Model Has G.O.P. Favored to Win 50-Plus House Seats
text: Republican chances of taking over the House are now up to 80 percent, according to the FiveThirtyEight forecast model; they had been 75 percent two days ago.

headline: At a Long Island Middle School, a Course in What Unites and Divides
text: JERICHO, N.Y.  Fifteen eighth graders at Jericho Middle School were considering a fictional case of stereotyping by hair color the other day, or how a boy came to be prejudiced against people with green hair, or “greenies.” From there, they extrapolated to the stereotypes in their own lives: dumb football players, Asian math whizzes, boring bankers.

headline: Big Problem for Banks: Due Process
text: Earlier this week, Bank of America, the nation’s largest consumer bank, reported its third-quarter earnings. It was a very good quarter; putting aside an accounting charge  a very large, $10.4 billion accounting charge, admittedly  the bank reported $3.1 billion in profits. It was the third consecutive quarter that Bank of America had earned more than $3 billion.

headline: In Congressional Races, Nonprofits Outspend National Parties
