headline: James F. Neal, Litigated Historic Cases, Dies at 81
text: James F. Neal, a lawyer who found success in nationally prominent cases on both sides of the legal battlefield, prosecuting Jimmy Hoffa and the Watergate conspirators and defending the Ford Pinto, the Exxon Valdez, the filmmaker John Landis, Elvis Presley’s doctor and Vice President Al Gore, died on Thursday in Nashville. He was 81.

headline: The Way We Treat Our Troops
text: You can only hope that the very preliminary peace efforts in Afghanistan bear fruit before long. But for evidence that the United States is letting its claim to greatness, and even common decency, slip through its fingers, all you need to do is look at the way we treat our own troops.

headline: Elections: Oshkosh Shrugged
text: “I’m in Sheboygan!” said Senator Russ Feingold over the phone. “It’s the bratwurst capital of the world!”

headline: Cuomo for Governor
text: It has been many years since New York State had a governor with the vision, judgment and authority that it needs now to turn Albany’s budget from obesity, to resist powerful interests, to plot a course out of an ethical netherworld in which state the government has become a national embarrassment. For the state’s fed-up voters, the choices are Andrew Cuomo, the Democratic state attorney general, and Carl Paladino, the Republican businessman from Buffalo.

headline: Rangers’ Molina Has 2 Shots at a Ring
text: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Among baseball players, only Bengie Molina could get this lucky.

headline: Britain’s Austerity Overdose
text: There is a time and a place for aggressive deficit reduction. Now is not the time, especially not in Britain. The deep spending cuts announced by Prime Minister David Cameron’s government will hobble public services, strain poor families’ budgets and weaken Britain’s influence abroad. They could suffocate a feeble recovery.

headline: Jimmying the Tax Code for Votes
text: Bare-knuckled political machines masquerading as nonprofit social advocacy organizations are romping through the tax code on the strength of their own avowals that their blind attack ads serve the public interest.

headline: End of One Scourge
text: It’s almost impossible for a modern American to imagine what an outbreak of rinderpest, a viral cattle disease, would have looked like. But when the disease was at its worst  in Britain in the mid-1860s and South Africa in the 1890s  the spectacle must have been horrifying. Rinderpest spreads rapidly and kills nearly every animals it infects.

headline: When Elite Starters Become Star Relievers
text: ARLINGTON, Tex.  On his walks to the bullpen, C. C. Sabathia is usually joined by a catcher and the Yankees’ pitching coach, Dave Eiland. But that could not happen Friday, because the Yankees’ game against Texas had already started.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Saturday: Circus Tent Raiser?
text: Happiness is knowing the answer to the first clue you look at in a Saturday crossword puzzle.

headline: Genzyme Investors Are Urged to Reject Sanofi Offer as Too Low
text: The biotechnology company Genzyme argued strenuously on Friday that it was worth far more than the $18.5 billion that the French drug maker Sanofi-Aventis was offering in a hostile bid.

headline: Knicks End Preseason as They Started It: Full of Questions

headline: Stern Says Eliminating Teams Could Be Part of Labor Discussion
text: As the N.B.A. and the players union turn up the rhetoric in labor negotiations, Commissioner David Stern acknowledged Friday that contraction could become part of the discussion.

headline: A Day Without a Train
text: For three decades, Gene Russianoff, the staff lawyer for the New York Public Interest Research Group’s Straphangers Campaign, has championed the rights of subway riders. Most days, he is one: He and his wife, Pauline Toole, the program director of the We Are New York Community Leadership Project, do not own a car. But on Sundays, Mr. Russianoff, 57, Ms. Toole, 54, and their daughters, Jennie, 14, and Natalie, 11, who all live in Park Slope, dash around Brooklyn on foot, by bus and, if they are late to a soccer game, by car service. “Taking the train on the weekend,” Mr. Russianoff said, “is like Russian roulette.”

headline: NPR’s Schiller Says Juan Williams Was Fired Because of Ethics Guidelines
text: The timing might not have been perfect. But firing Juan Williams was the right decision, the NPR chief executive, Vivian Schiller, said in an interview Friday.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,332 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

headline: Rangers Overpower Yankees to Gain Series Berth
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — The Yankees lavished $243.5 million on starting pitching two winters ago, and the splurge returned them to glory. It restored that fall ritual in New York, the championship parade, but it might have had an expiration date. The rotation started to splinter in the second half this year, and it toppled an overmatched playoff opponent in the first round, but it was no match for the Texas Rangers, who outpitched, outhit and outplayed the Yankees all the way to the World Series.

headline: Walking Hamilton Has Perks (Sometimes)
text: ARLINGTON, Tex.  It is always a calculated risk, especially given the identity of the batter following Josh Hamilton in the Texas lineup. But until the fifth inning on Friday night, the inherent danger of pitching around Hamilton to bring Vladimir Guerrero to the plate kept working in the Yankees’ favor in the American League Championship Series.

headline: U.S. Envoy in China Cites Progress on Climate Pact
text: BEIJING  The top American envoy on climate issues clung to the prospect of an international agreement to counter global warming, but reported no concrete breakthroughs after two days of closed-door negotiations with China.

headline: Start Time? What Start Time?
text: PHILADELPHIA – So many baseball players like to have a specific routine to prepare for a game, beginning with the time they arrive at the ballpark. But because of the flexible scheduling, the starting time of Game 6 of the National League Championship Series was unknown until the outcome of the Yankees-Rangers game was determined.

headline: Photo Replay: Oct. 22
text: A view of the day in sports from the balance beam to the roller speed skating track.

headline: Consuelo Crespi, Aristocrat of Fashion, Dies at 82
text: Consuelo Crespi, a New York girl turned Italian countess who helped shape postwar high fashion by modeling, editing Italian Vogue and, perhaps most important, wearing the chic new thing to exactly the right places, died on Monday in Manhattan.

headline: A.L.C.S. Replay: Oct. 22
text: A look at Game 6 of the American League Championship Series between the Yankees and the Rangers.

headline: 76 at 60, With 100 as a Goal

headline: Times Photographer Wounded by an Afghan Mine
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A New York Times photographer was severely wounded Saturday when he stepped on a mine while on patrol with American soldiers in southern Afghanistan.

headline: Joao Silva, Times Photographer, Is Wounded in Afghanistan – Updated
text: Joao Silva, a New York Times photographer, was severely wounded Saturday when he stepped on a mine while on patrol with American soldiers in southern Afghanistan. Mr. Silva, 44, was wounded in his legs while moving through an area near the town of Arghandab. He was evacuated from the scene and taken to Kandahar Air Field, the American and NATO base. Three American soldiers sustained concussions (this post had previously stated that none had been injured).

headline: How To Think About QE2 (Wonkish)
text: Still on the run, so no long posts. But with all the talk about further quantitative easing by the Fed — QE2, for quantitative easing, the sequel — I think it’s worth sharing one way of thinking about what’s on the table — and why you shouldn’t be too optimistic about its effects. This isn’t original, although I don’t know who deserves the credit.

headline: Q&A: Organizing Photos on an iPad
text: Q.

headline: Accidents, Happy and Not, at CMJ
text: With dozens of clubs hosting hundreds of bands on ludicrously tight schedules, it’s all but a guarantee that even the best laid CMJ plans will go awry. Last year, I’d planned a night around catching a set by the Korean-American Los Angeles party-rap group Far East Movement, but when I arrived at the venue at the appointed time, they were still two hours from going on. In the meantime, I waited through one terrible act, who shall remain nameless, and stumbled on another, Chiddy Bang, who turned out to be fantastic. I never saw Far East Movement except for in the crowd, wearing matching silvery jackets. They currently have the number one single in the country, “Like a G6.” At least I can say I was (almost) there way back when.

headline: Fabulous Qualifying at Fabulous, Festive Korean Grand Prix
text: I can only think of superlatives to describe this Korean Grand Prix for the moment. The qualifying session just ended with a sudden, huge change in the final seconds as Sebastian Vettel took the pole position on his final lap, Mark Webber moved into second on his final lap seconds later and Fernando Alonso dropped from virtual pole to third place.

headline: Fabulous Qualifying at Fabulous, Festive Korean Grand Prix
text: I can only think of superlatives to describe this Korean Grand Prix for the moment. The qualifying session just ended with a sudden, huge change in the final seconds as Sebastian Vettel took the pole position on his final lap, Mark Webber moved into second on his final lap seconds later and Fernando Alonso dropped from virtual pole to third place.

headline: At Rival Music Fest, It’s Deradoorian vs. the Bowling Pins
text: What’s scribbled in Angel Deradoorian’s notebook? It was the first thing she looked at when she came on stage Friday night at Brooklyn Bowl, where she was playing as part of the #Offline festival, organized by the music website Pitchfork as CMJ counterprogramming/piggybacking.

headline: Weekend Word: One Week to Go

headline: The Worst Economist in the World
text: A thought: it has occurred to me that we could use an economics equivalent of Keith Olbermann’s “Worst Person in the World” award. KO does not, of course, mean that the person he goes after on any given night really is the worst person in the world; he just uses the title to highlight some especially awful action or statement.

headline: G-20 Vows to Avoid a Currency War
text: Moving to shore up the “fragile and uneven” recovery, officials from the world’s 20 biggest economies promised Saturday to refrain from weakening their currencies, agreeing to let the markets exert more influence in setting foreign exchange rates.

headline: Governor Forecast Update: Chafee’s Chances Wax; Whitman’s Wane
text: Here are the candidates for governor who find themselves in a materially stronger position from earlier this week.

headline: Groups Rally Behind Grannis

headline: Use of Contractors Added to War’s Chaos in Iraq
text: The first shots sailed past Iraqi police officers at a checkpoint. They took off in three squad cars, their lights flashing.

headline: Mix of Trust and Despair Helped Turn Tide in Iraq
text: The Iraq war archive, taken as a whole with its details of incidents small and large, offers a cautionary postscript for the current military strategy in Afghanistan.

headline: Acrostic: In Search of Nines
text: Two weeks ago, the acrostic consisted entirely of eight-letter words. Did you notice today’s was all eights again, this time mixing in some two-word phrases? The authors (and a few guests) have more to say about this in the notes below.

headline: Bloggers’ Stylings in Hardwood Heaven
text: Baseball has its numbers and football has its hard hits, but basketball, more than those sports, has style. And no one has done more to try to capture that than the collection of bloggers known as  FreeDarko.

headline: Tensions High Along Kurdish-Arab Line
text: The new trove of documents released by WikiLeaks portrays the long history of tensions between Kurds and Arabs in the north of Iraq and reveals the fears of some American units about what might happen after American troops leave the country by the end of 2011.

headline: WikiLeaks Founder on the Run, Trailed by Notoriety
text: LONDON — Julian Assange moves like a hunted man. In a noisy Ethiopian restaurant in London’s rundown Paddington district, he pitches his voice barely above a whisper to foil the Western intelligence agencies he fears.

headline: U.N. Compound Attacked in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  At least two bombers dressed in burqas and another driving a car attacked the United Nations compound in the comparatively peaceful western city of Herat just before noon on Saturday, but no one working in the compound was injured, Afghan police officials said.

headline: Fighting Words
text: After weeks of debate and national strikes, the French Senate voted Friday to raise the minimum retirement age to 62 from 60 and the age for a full pension to 67 from 65. The vote all but seals passage of the measure; violent protests continued.

headline: Laugh Lines
text: JIMMY KIMMEL

headline: Prime Number
text: 11: The percentage decline in private donations to the nation's biggest charities last year — the steepest one-year drop in 20 years, according to Philanthropy 400, an annual survey by The Chronicle of Philanthropy. Six of the 10 largest private charities reported a decrease, including the United Way (No. 1 ), the Salvation Army (No. 2), the American Cancer Society (No. 7), and the Y (No. 10). The survey reflected the sluggish economic recovery; contributions are not expected to rebound by the end of 2010.

headline: Taste, Up in the Air
text: Airline passengers can stop blaming the chef for the bland food. According to The Independent, a British newspaper, scientists at the University of Manchester investigating how sound affects taste found that subjecting diners to loud noise decreased their sensitivity to sugar and salt. Scientists speculate that a plane’s roaring engines distract or stress passengers enough to dull their palates. But pleasant music sparked diners’ tastebuds, a finding that airlines, most of which are now charging for meals, might want to heed.

headline: Game-Saver of ’69 Mets, Ryan Is Back in the Series
text: ARLINGTON, Tex.  As a pitcher and a Texan, Nolan Ryan always had fire in his belly. Now, as the 63-year-old president of the Texas Rangers, Ryan has an ample belly to go with it.

headline: N.F.L. Crackdown Tests Limits of Mayhem
text: When the enormous video screens at New Meadowlands Stadium showed a replay of two players smashing into each other and crumpling to the ground last Sunday, the fans boomed “Oh!” in unison, marveling at the impact that sent Atlanta Falcons cornerback Dunta Robinson and Philadelphia Eagles receiver DeSean Jackson to the bench with concussions.

headline: Foreclosures: A Paperwork Fiasco
text: After months of horror stories, it seemed that the real estate mess could not get any worse. But now, the nation is in the middle of yet another foreclosure crisis.

headline: At Home as an Exile in Moscow
text: MOSCOW — The cabbie was like thousands of other immigrants here: out in the dead of a Saturday night, ferrying club-hopping Muscovites so he could scrape up some money to send home to relatives in other, poorer former Soviet republics.

headline: Leaked Reports Stir Political Disputes in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD  The release of thousands of classified Iraq war records quickly became part of Iraq’s fraught political terrain on Saturday, with Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki denouncing the leak as a move to derail his bid for a second term.

headline: Name That Freedom
text: So now we know that Christine O’Donnell, the Republican candidate for senator in Delaware, isn’t a constitutional scholar.

headline: SAP Seeks to Muzzle Oracle in Case
text: SAP has asked a California court to impose what amounts to a gag order in the company’s protracted legal battle with Oracle.

headline: WikiLeaks Founder Gets Support in Rebuking U.S. on Whistle-Blowers
text: LONDON  Julian Assange, the WikiLeaks founder, and Daniel Ellsberg, who leaked the Pentagon Papers, lashed out together on Saturday at the Obama administration’s aggressive pursuit of whistle-blowers, including those responsible for the release of secret documents on the Iraq war.

headline: Palestinians Sentenced for Civil Disobedience
text: This month, as a new documentary about a successful campaign of nonviolent, civil disobedience by Palestinian villagers in the West Bank screens in New York and Los Angeles, Israeli military courts have handed out jail terms to two men who led similar protests against the path of Israel’s security barrier near their village.

headline: In Hurricanes’ Wake, but Still Standing
text: CREOLE, La.  They waited five years for a new school at South Cameron High, five years for a weight room, lockers in the hallway and plates in the cafeteria instead of plastic trays.

headline: Thinking of Joao Silva in Afghanistan
text: A superb photographer for The New York Times, Joao Silva, was seriously injured today by a landmine near Arghandab, Afghanistan. Joao was accompanying an American patrol when he stepped on the mine. He has been evacuated and is receiving treatment in Kandahar.

headline: Professional Petitioners Aid Ballot Initiatives
text: CASTLE ROCK, Colo.  At 5-foot-4, with a pot belly and graying beard, Charlie Chavez does not look particularly scary.

headline: On Stump, Obama Takes Sharper Tone
text: SEATTLE  President Obama walked the campaign stage with the same familiar command, to the same music as 2008, same piercing cheers, same “We love you” cries from the crowd and “I love you backs” from the president and the occasional “Yes we can” chant.

headline: In the Mideast, No Politics but God’s
text: BEIRUT — A line was uttered this month by Hassan Nasrallah, the leader of Hezbollah, that drew little notice in between his stentorian asides but said a great deal about politics today for Israelis, Palestinians and the larger Arab world.

headline: Choosing Bearhugs Over Big Hits
text: On Sunday, more eyes than usual will be on the N.F.L. as the league begins to strictly enforce safety initiatives that limit hits to the head, players’ launching themselves into opponents, and gratuitous hits against defenseless players.

headline: The Range of Electronica, Cathedral to Jubilant
text: I bookended Friday night with electronica: two Englishmen, Gold Panda and Jon Hopkins, early and the laptopper Baths late. All three traded in disorientation nearly as much as dance beats, but the early shift was far more decorous.

headline: The British Ax, if Imported to the U.S.
text: With British leaders announcing sharp government cuts, French workers protesting their government’s decision to raise the retirement age, and Republican Congressional candidates promising to unplug the federal A.T.M. the minute they arrive in Washington, austerity is the fall’s dominant political trend.

headline: In Losing the Midterms, There May Be Winning
text: WASHINGTON — Let there be no mistake: President Obama wants the Democrats to win next week’s midterm elections. His voice has gone hoarse telling every audience that from Delaware to Oregon. But let’s also acknowledge this: Although he will not say so, there is at least a plausible argument that he might be better off if they lose.

headline: No F.D.A. Approval for New Diet Pill
text: The Food and Drug Administration has declined to approve what would have been the first new prescription diet pill in more than a decade.

headline: Girardi’s Numbers and Instincts Didn’t Add Up
text: ARLINGTON, Tex.  The baseball axiom that managers are only as good as their players applies to Joe Girardi just as much this year, in the wake of a painful defeat, as it did last season, which ended in a Champagne bath.

headline: A Little Real Estate and Rock ‘n’ Roll
text: Sense of discovery: that’s what people look for in a festival like CMJ (or South by Southwest). But when most acts have already received attention online, it can be hard to walk out of a bar or club feeling the thrill of the find — I liked Dale Earnhardt Jr. Jr., but I didn’t exactly unearth them; they played a Stereogum showcase.

headline: Should You Watch Football?
text: We don’t watch sports because we think it is the very best use of the precious time we are granted in this life. The games entertain us. Distract us from our troubles. We like speed, violence, a hint of threat and danger because those elements raise the stakes and enhance the excitement.

headline: One Weekend Full of Tackles and Injuries
text: Injuries sustained in college and N.F.L. play on Oct. 16 and 17 drew new scrutiny the dangers of football.

headline: Iran Is Said to Give Top Karzai Aide Cash by the Bagful
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  One evening last August, as President Hamid Karzai wrapped up an official visit to Iran, his personal plane sat on the airport tarmac, waiting for a late-running passenger: Iran’s ambassador to Afghanistan.

headline: Equipment Standards Group Considers Changes to Helmet Testing
text: CHATHAM, Mass.  As thousands of college football players crashed and collided on Saturday in hundreds of games before millions of spectators, about 20 experts convened in a quiet Cape Cod hotel meeting room to discuss how some of those impacts might not result in brain injuries, specifically concussions.

text: City Room readers may remember the story of Stephanie Guerra, a professional baby nurse from Hollis, Queens, whose son, Keron Agard, 24, was stabbed in Astoria on Aug. 18, 2008, and died five weeks later, on Sept. 27.

headline: The N.F.L.’s Head Cases
text: AFTER an unusually large number of brain-jarring tackles last week, the National Football League went on the offensive against players. Commissioner Roger Goodell doled out a total of $175,000 in fines to three players and threatened future suspensions for what a league official called “devastating” hits to the head.

headline: Point Guard Becomes a Showcase for Talent
text: When people ask Chris Paul what it is like to play in the N.B.A., his standard response leaves out references to scoring points or fame. Instead, he tells of the nightly challenges his position presents.

text: Chiefs linebacker Mike Vrabel may take a fascinating stat line into retirement — if he ever retires.

text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  If Notre Dame wanted a reminder of how much luster its football program has lost in recent years, it need not have looked any further than across the field at New Meadowlands Stadium on Saturday.

headline: A New Route for an Ex-Receiver
text: Amani Toomer, back arched and chest heaving, inched across the asphalt in halting steps. He cocked his head and grimaced.

headline: Giants’ Replacement Fullback Shines While Wearing More Than One Hat
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Tight end Bear Pascoe has been the Giants’ resident cowboy, a cattle-roping Californian with a taste for country music and an appreciation for the wide-open space on his family’s ranch.

headline: Dick Miles, Record-Setting U.S. Table Tennis Player, Dies at 85
text: Dick Miles, whose powerful forehand and sterling defensive skills made him perhaps the greatest table tennis player the United States has ever produced, died Oct. 12 in Manhattan. He was 85.

headline: Health Care and the Campaign
text: Republican candidates and deep-pocketed special interests are spreading so many distortions and outright lies about health care reform that it is little wonder if voters are anxious and confused.

headline: Soundtrack of Roaring Engines and Angry Words
text: CONCORD, N.C.  The head-splitting sound of 43 mufflerless stock cars circling Charlotte Motor Speedway at 190 miles per hour was partly eased by the protective headphones that Gil Martin wore as he sat atop the pit box of the No. 29 Pennzoil Chevrolet.

headline: Fool Me Twice?
text: In 2004, America’s multinational corporations offered Congress a deal: They would repatriate hundreds of billions of dollars in foreign profits  to invest in new plants and create new jobs at home  in exchange for a break from the 35 percent corporate tax rate imposed on overseas profits when they are brought into the country.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: A Beltran Imitation From Rodriguez
text: The lasting image of Carlos Beltran’s six years as a Met is, of course, the called third strike he took to conclude Game 7 of the National League Championship Series against the St. Louis Cardinals in 2006. Four years later, Beltran has some company.

headline: John & Yoko, & NYC
text: John Lennon could have lived anywhere. He chose New York, and clung to his adopted city with a ferocious love. Yoko Ono, too: “There’s such an incredible romanticism about being refugees,” she said. “We just felt like we returned to our motherland, which is New York, you know.”

headline: A Horse of a Different Color: Green
text: OCEANPORT, N.J.  They are 80 strong, not 80,000, and the object of their affection runs on 4 legs, not 22. But their cheers sound the same.

headline: Fly Anglers Are Drawn to a Toothy Adversary
text: Every few years, a new sport fish emerges as the “it” species for fly fishers, a creature that was previously unknown to fly anglers. The list has recently included taimen, golden dorado and mahseer. Though worthy of angler attention, these quarry require lengthy journeys to faraway lands  Mongolia, Bolivia and India.

headline: Haiti Fears Cholera Will Spread in Capital
text: MEXICO CITY — With the number of dead rising above 200, health officials battling a cholera outbreak in Haiti grew ever more pessimistic Saturday that the disease could be contained to a rural area and braced for a medical disaster in the capital.

headline: One Mess That Can’t Be Papered Over
text: LAWYERS representing delinquent homeowners have been shouting for years about documentation problems in residential mortgages. Now that their complaints have gained traction with investors, attorneys general and some state court officials, the question of consequences looms large.

headline: What Happened to Change We Can Believe In?
text: PRESIDENT Obama, the Rodney Dangerfield of 2010, gets no respect for averting another Great Depression, for saving 3.3 million jobs with stimulus spending, or for salvaging GM and Chrysler from the junkyard. And none of these good deeds, no matter how substantial, will go unpunished if the projected Democratic bloodbath materializes on Election Day. Some are even going unremembered. For Obama, the ultimate indignity is the Times/CBS News poll in September showing that only 8 percent of Americans know that he gave 95 percent of American taxpayers a tax cut.

headline: India’s Smaller Cities Show Off Growing Wealth
text: AURANGABAD, India  For decades this central Indian city was vintage old India: crumbling Mughal-era ruins and ancient Buddhist caves surrounded by endless parched acres from which farmers coaxed cotton.

headline: When Hollywood Gives Hope to Main St.

headline: Now Isn’t the Time to Cut the Deficit
text: THE clamor to cut the budget deficit is deafening. Blue Dog Democrats, Tea Party Republicans and doomsday economists are calling for immediate action. And the demands for austerity coming from abroad are even louder.

headline: China's New Wave: Music Festivals
text: China is experiencing an explosion of music festivals sponsored by local governments. The festivals are seen as a way to draw tourist dollars and youthful hipness to cities.

headline: The Election That Wasn’t
text: In the past two weeks, I’ve taken the Amtrak Acela to the Philadelphia and New York stations. In both places there were signs on the train platforms boasting that new construction work there was being paid for by “the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009,” that is, the $787 billion stimulus. And what was that work? New “lighting” — so now you can see even better just how disgustingly decayed, undersized and outdated are the rail platforms and infrastructure in two of our biggest cities.

headline: Raising Sails for the Fed’s Gales
text: THERE were plenty of worries in the stock market last week  about an unexpected rise in interest rates in China and the latest fallout from the American housing crisis, just for starters.

headline: Cuomo Is Confident, but Warns Upstate Voters of Close Race
text: As Andrew M. Cuomo visited restaurants and universities on a tour of four towns in central New York, the warm fall day — and his comfortable lead in the polls — gave him the appearance of a man at ease. And the crowds seemed confident as well.

headline: Pierced Fans, Stiff Cadres and Hip Rock
text: ZHENJIANG, China — A curious thing happened this month at the Midi Music Festival, China’s oldest and boldest agglomeration of rock, funk, punk and electronica. Performers took musical potshots at the country’s leaders, tattooed college students sold antigovernment T-shirts and an unruly crowd of heavy metal fans giddily torched a Japanese flag that had been emblazoned with expletives.

headline: With Kinect, Microsoft Aims for a Game Changer
text: REDMOND, Wash.

headline: Das Racist Is Still In on the Joke
text: Das Racist is a rap group of its era: hyper-referential, hyper-self-aware, hyper-winking — “stoner jokesters,” Jon Caramanica called them, nurtured by a liberal arts bubble. “But Das Racist’s lack of piety has become an aesthetic of its own,” he wrote in a review last year, “with songs that are as much commentary on hip-hop as rigorous practice of it.”

headline: It’s O.K. to Sleep at Camp
text: MY father was in the Air Force. We lived in Panama for four years and in several states on the East Coast. One of the few schools I attended that wasn’t on a military base was Eastern Wayne High School in Goldsboro, N.C.

headline: Sunday: Risky Business
text: There are three kinds of people. Those who like puns, those who don’t and those who posture disapprovingly but indulge in them nonetheless. I count myself in the third category. Of course, the quality of the puns can sharpen or blur those lines.

headline: What About Afghan Women?
text: KABUL, Afghanistan

headline: After the Wine, a Keepsake
text: Pugliese Vineyards, a low-key fixture on Main Road in Cutchogue, has been synonymous with down-to-earth, moderately priced wines since 1986.

headline: Dominican Tastes With a Family Touch
text: LA COCINA DE MARCIA — Marcia’s Kitchen — is named for one of its owners, Marcia Beltre. But the name does not tell the whole story: Marcia’s mother, Angela Beltre, is in the kitchen as well.

headline: Grandmother’s Recipes, Direct From Afghanistan
text: “FAMILY adds that extra touch.” That simple notion, the bedrock of so many restaurants through the ages, resonates deeply coming from Hamid Rahin of Pamir, a beguiling Afghan restaurant just off the Morristown Green.

headline: 18 Very Different Pieces of Clay
text: IT is massive and raw, its crusty brown surface pockmarked with blisters and crevices. Tim Rowan’s “Untitled,” a troughlike form resting on a metal stand, looks just like what it is: earth. The artwork, over 10 feet long, is made of unprocessed clay dug by the artist in the Raritan Valley of New Jersey, then fired with wood for seven days.

headline: Local, Fresh and in Season
text: Alan Weinberg has never worked a day in his life on a farm. But he appreciates how important farmers are to consumers who want to know who grows their food.

headline: Sleepy Hollow Just Got Scarier
text: SWIRLING mist, eerie wails and a good share of blood and gore are transforming the nighttime grounds of Philipsburg Manor this month. headline: Dispute Over Succession Clouds Megachurch
text: GARDEN GROVE, Calif.  The 10,664 windows did not get washed this year at the Crystal Cathedral, the iconic glass church founded by the Rev. Robert H. Schuller, one of the original religious broadcasters. Volunteers are tending the church’s 40 landscaped acres, now that the gardeners have been laid off. And its renowned Christmas pageant  with live camels and horses, and angels flying overhead on cables  has been canceled for now.

headline: Penn Denies Yale With Two Fourth-Quarter Interceptions

text: MINNEAPOLIS  President Obama wrapped up a four-day campaign swing on Saturday, telling students and the Democratic Party faithful to seize the chance to win a Republican-held governor’s seat here next month.

headline: Reader Comments on my Afghan Women Column
text: My Sunday column from Kabul argues that we do Afghan women no favors by prolonging an unsustainable war in their name. Yes, there’s reason to worry about what will happen if the Taliban gain more influence. And, yes, I’m particularly concerned that fundamentalist values will gain ground even in areas where the Taliban are not formally ruling. But as I write in the column, Afghan women themselves told me that they favor a peace deal with the Taliban because war victimizes them just as much as the Taliban does. And the present course is just not sustainable.

headline: At Auburn, Cheering Replaces Groans
text: AUBURN, Ala.  For seven weeks, the same lacquer was being spread over and over. Auburn wins; quarterback Cam Newton stars. The brush painted the fifth-ranked Tigers as a one-man show. They did not look like a team that could be trusted with such a high national ranking when they relied so much on one player.

headline: Bottle Ban? What Ban? Supervisors May Ask
text: In 2007, Mayor Gavin Newsom of San Francisco banned the use of city money to buy bottled water for municipal employees. For the mayor, it was a point of principle: the local tap water, direct from Yosemite National Park, is among the best anywhere, and in a town where even plastic bags are regulated, water delivered in plastic dispensers appeared to be an unseemly use of resources.

headline: To Get a Clear View, Take the Economists Out to the Ballgame
text: In sports, as in so many walks of life, economics has a way of vindicating its status as the dismal science. That shiny new baseball stadium must be good for the economy, right? Wrong. An appearance by the local team in the World Series, that has to be a boost for businesses, no? No. Isn’t there intangible value in being a “major league” city, and having a winning team? Well, maybe  but the emphasis is on the intangible.

headline: Crosses of Lafayette

headline: Can Democrats Still Win?
text: IN September 1998, after months of coverage of Monica Lewinsky, Kenneth Starr and Bill Clinton’s impeachment, Republicans were confident that they would make historic gains in the midterm elections. Many Democrats agreed, predicting a big loss in the House and one in the Senate, which would give Republicans a filibuster-proof supermajority, their largest since Warren G. Harding.

headline: A Reason to Smile
text: You see a lot of the indie-rock deadpan at CMJ — that look of studious indifference to both the audience and any pleasure from the music. But not from Morning Teleportation, a band from Portland, Ore., whose lead singer, Tiger Merritt, grinned beatifically through its whole set at Public Assembly on Friday, singing choruses like “Why is love so hard to say?”

headline: All Politics Is Olfactory
text: JUST days before New York’s Republican gubernatorial primary, Carl Paladino mailed out thousands of campaign ads impregnated with the smell of rotting garbage. Emblazoned with the message “Something Stinks in Albany” and photos of scandal-tainted New York Democrats like former Gov. Eliot Spitzer and Representative Charles Rangel, the brochure attacked Mr. Paladino’s rival, former Representative Rick Lazio, for being “liberal” and a part of the state’s corrupt political system.

headline: Boot the Blue Dogs
text: IN 2008, Barack Obama’s presidential campaign seemed to rewrite all the rules in electoral politics and herald a new progressive era in America. Democrats assembled a huge Congressional majority and, in the euphoria that followed the historic election, were poised to enact sweeping change. However, despite some notable successes  the stimulus package, health care reform, tighter rules for the financial industry  things have not gone according to plan. Just two years later, Democrats face a bad economy, a skeptical public, a re-energized Republican Party and a coming avalanche of losses in the midterm elections.

headline: Mets Face a Deadline on Keeping Takahashi
text: Because of a relatively obscure major league contract rule, the Mets have less than one week to re-sign the left-handed pitcher Hisanori Takahashi or lose him to another team. If Takahashi is not signed by Oct. 31, he can become a free agent, and if he does, he is prohibited from signing back with the Mets until May 15, virtually assuring that he will join another team.

headline: More on Airport Outlet Policies

headline: Will Credit Card Settlement Bring Fee Relief to Merchants?
text: Last summer, the Senate, while debating what eventually became the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act, took a stab at reining in fees for debit and credit cards. The amendment, proposed by Democratic Senator Dick Durbin of Illinois, would have ended the card networks’ practice of preventing merchants from using incentives to steer customers toward other credit cards and credit card brands. When the bill reached the president’s desk, however, that provision had been replaced by one that allows merchants to offer discounts only for certain forms of payment.

headline: Responsible Recycling: My E-Waste Odyssey
text: Most Americans know that e-waste is supposed to be recycled. Items like cellphones, batteries, televisions, digital clocks, video game systems and broken computers shouldn’t be tossed in the trash because they contain dangerous chemicals and heavy metals that could end up in landfills that way, experts warn.

headline: Advocates Hope Transgender Identity Is Not a Defining One
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Theresa Sparks, a candidate for the San Francisco Board of Supervisors, is running on what some might see as a conservative platform: she is pro-development and anti-loitering, pro-police and anti-grime. She has been endorsed by the mayor, the city’s firefighters’ union and the county deputy sheriff’s association.

headline: Readers Shoot CMJ
text: Times readers submitted their photographs from the CMJ Music Marathon in New York.

headline: ‘Angels in America’ Earns Place in Pantheon
text: “Angels in America,” Tony Kushner’s fever dream about Ronald Reagan and AIDS, love and abandonment, has emerged as the most influential American play of the last two decades. Now about to open in its first New York revival since an acclaimed Broadway run in 1993-94, the play has survived controversy and its own unusual, unruly structure to become a mainstay of the literary canon, produced on college campuses and taught in classrooms with the same reverence as “Death of a Salesman” and “A Streetcar Named Desire.”

headline: Bush to Visit ‘Oprah’ to Promote Book
text: Oprah Winfrey will conduct the second television interview with former President George W. Bush as he embarks on a book tour. The interview will be shown on Nov. 9, the day his book, “Decision Points,” is published by Crown. Mr. Bush’s first sit-down TV talk will be with Matt Lauer of the “Today” show, and will be shown on Nov. 8 in prime time on NBC. Ms. Winfrey was an avid supporter of President Barack Obama during the 2008 campaign.

headline: Ben Vereen to Lead Town Hall’s 90th Season
text: The musical veterans Ben Vereen, Linda Eder and Kelli O’Hara are to be among the performers headlining Town Hall’s 90th anniversary season, the theater announced. Mr. Vereen, right, will perform his one-man tribute to Broadway, Frank Sinatra and Sammy Davis Jr. on Feb. 18, followed by solo concerts by Ms. Eder (May 20) and Ms. O’Hara (June 3). Other season highlights include Don McLean (“American Pie”), joined by the folk-pop singer and songwriter Dar Williams, on March 25; and Dee Dee Bridgewater’s Billie  Holiday show on June 24 (212-840-2824; the-townhall-nyc.org).

headline: Footnotes
text: Pilobolus Dance Theater and the critic and historian Deborah Jowitt are among the winners of the 53rd annual Dance Magazine Awards. The honors, to be handed out at a ceremony next Monday, will also go to Matthew Rushing, a dancer with the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, and Irina Kolpakova, a ballet mistress at American Ballet Theater. ... The Kneehigh Theater Company’s adaptation of Noël Coward’s “Brief Encounter,” playing on Broadway at Studio 54, has been extended four weeks, Playbill reported. The show, based on Coward’s one-act play “Still Life” and featuring original music by Coward, was scheduled to close on Dec. 5 but will now run through Jan. 2. ... “Sondheim! The Birthday Concert,” which celebrated the 80th birthday of Stephen Sondheim at Avery Fisher Hall in March, will be broadcast on PBS television’s “Great Performances” series on Nov. 24. The concert was hosted by David Hyde Pierce and featured appearances by Patti LuPone, Audra McDonald, Mandy Patinkin, Bernadette Peters and Elaine Stritch, among others, accompanied by the New York Philharmonic, with Paul Gemignani conducting.

headline: French Prince Wants Murakami Out of Palace
text: A descendant of the French king Louis XIV has requested a court order to end an exhibition of works by the Japanese artist Takashi Murakami  in the Palace of Versailles, Agence France-Presse reported. Prince Sixte-Henri de Bourbon-Parme said the large, brightly colored pieces, created in the style of Japanese manga comics and scheduled to be on view through Dec. 12 in the palace’s stately salons, above, offend the memory of his ancestors. “We’re not against the modernity of art but against a way of thinking that denatures and does French culture no good,” the prince told the news agency. He was joined in the suit by the Versailles Defense Coordination, which formed in 2008 when the prince’s nephew Prince Charles-Emmanuel de Bourbon-Parme filed a similar suit to try to ban the display of sculptures by the American artist Jeff Koons in the palace. That suit was dismissed by the court and the show was well received by the public.

headline: Top Movie’s Almost Paranormal Feat
text: The low-budget horror film “Paranormal Activity 2” pulled off a rare trick over the weekend: with $41.5 million in ticket sales at the North American box office, easily enough for No. 1  and another $22 million overseas  it was immediately profitable. The movie that hits the black in its first three days is almost nonexistent. Most Hollywood releases, with outsize production budgets, enormous marketing costs and a 50 percent split in revenue with movie theater owners, do not turn a profit for studios until the DVD release. But “Paranormal Activity 2” was produced by Paramount Pictures for just $3 million and given a cheaper-than-usual marketing campaign that relied heavily on Web chatter. Paramount was doing cartwheels on Sunday, partly because it also had the second-place movie: “Jackass 3D” took in about $21.6 million for a two-week total of $87.1 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles ticket statistics. The ensemble action picture “Red” (Summit Entertainment) was third with $15 million for a new total of $43.5 million. Clint Eastwood’s “Hereafter” (Warner Brothers) was fourth in its first wide-release weekend with $12 million. And “The Social Network” (Sony Pictures Entertainment) continued to show strong audience interest in fifth place, selling $7.3 million for a total of about $73 million.

headline: A Zombie Invasion From Across the Atlantic
text: While vampires and werewolves battle to be our favorite scary monsters, a new contender lurches into view. Zombies, already a movie and video-game staple, are infecting television this Halloween season with the arrival of AMC’s new series, “The Walking Dead,” on Sunday (Halloween night) and the unspooling this week of the British mini-series “Dead Set” on IFC.

headline: Stories vs. Statistics
text: Half a century ago the British scientist and novelist C. P. Snow bemoaned the estrangement of what he termed the “two cultures” in modern society — the literary and the scientific. These days, there is some reason to celebrate better communication between these domains, if only because of the increasingly visible salience of scientific ideas. Still a gap remains, and so I’d like here to take an oblique look at a few lesser-known contrasts and divisions between subdomains of the two cultures, specifically those between stories and statistics.

headline: A Wayward Son Checks in With Mother Russia
text: MOSCOW  It was late in the Brezhnev era when a boy named Igor Semyonovich Shteyngart took up writing at the urging of his grandmother, who rewarded him for his labors with bits of cheese. Inspired by a statue of Lenin near his home, he scribbled a fairy tale called “Lenin and His Magical Goose.” Perhaps you will read it someday. The title characters meet, become friends and decide to invade Finland together to set up a glorious Soviet republic there.

headline: A Sound Is Molded to Become an Eclipse
text: Matthias Pintscher’s music whispers far more often than it shouts. But when this imaginative 39-year-old German composer and conductor wants an ensemble to produce a big sound, he is not shy about asking its percussionists to supply a generous helping of thunder, sometimes supported by full-throttle, harmonically dense contributions from the brasses and woodwinds.

headline: Madea Takes a Break, and Tyler Perry Gets Serious
text: LOS ANGELES  Is Tyler Perry capable of highbrow cinema? The studio behind his 10th movie is determined to make audiences and Oscar voters look beyond his track record and answer yes.

headline: Public Housing Repairs Can’t Keep Pace With Need
text: Public housing is falling apart around the country, as federal money has been unable to keep up with the repair needs of buildings more than half a century old.

headline: ’60s Sondheim TV Show Is Now on (Legal) DVD
text: Attention Stephen Sondheim groupies: You’ve lost bragging rights to your bootleg copies of “Evening Primrose.”

headline: Garden State Scandals
text: “The Soprano State: New Jersey’s Culture of Corruption” strikes a lighthearted, if cynical, tone as it reviews some of the worst recent scandals. The documentary presents itself as a nightclub act, with Tony Darrow, who played small parts in “The Sopranos” and “Goodfellas,” narrating from a stage while lounge-lizard music is piped in. But the message of the film, based on the 2008 book of the same name by the longtime Trenton reporters Bob Ingle and Sandy McClure, is relentlessly bleak.

headline: What It Was All About for Alfie, Now a Grandpa
text: Michael Caine’s “Elephant to Hollywood” is an unabashedly old-school celebrity memoir. Its tales sound oft-told because they probably are. Mr. Caine is a charming raconteur, specializing in anecdotes packed with famous names. In these stories all the famous people do their famous-people things, whether it’s Jack Nicholson grinning “with that wolfish Nicholson grin” or John Wayne striding into the lobby of the Beverly Hills Hotel in full cowboy regalia.

headline: Monday: An Exciting Opening Number
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Wham! Boom! Bam! Pow! This Monday puzzle by Jonah Kagan reminds me of the old Batman TV series. The puzzle week STARTS WITH A BANG, and so do each of the theme answers.

headline: Critics’ Choice: New CDs
text: DARIUS RUCKER

headline: Eagles Going Back to Vick
text: Eagles Coach Andy Reid announced after Sunday’s 37-19 loss to the Titans that he was switching quarterbacks — again. Michael Vick will replace Kevin Kolb when the Eagles return from their bye week on Nov. 7.

headline: Bands Dream Globally, Play Locally
text: The sweetest white lie of the CMJ Music Marathon came from the folky songwriter Lia Ices, leading her band at the Lower East Side club Pianos on Thursday night. While half the crowd chatted indifferently, she sang, “For only you I sing, for only you.” Yet Ms. Ices, whose debut album is due in January, was playing CMJ, along with more than 1,000 other groups, for precisely the opposite reason. She was seeking a chance to be heard, sooner or later, by a larger audience.

headline: Looking Back at CMJ 2010

headline: Drug Testing Poses Quandary for Employers

headline: The Shadows of an Airborne Life

headline: After the Spill

Much important work still lies ahead  figuring out how much oil is still out there, cleaning it up, measuring the damage to marine life, compensating victims. And Congress needs to pass an oil-spill bill that will reduce the chances of another drilling debacle.

headline: The Great Bailout Backlash

headline: A.I.A.’s I.P.O. Is Good for Everyone Involved
text: Freedom is at hand at last for the American International Group’s Asian business, A.I.A. The unit’s $30.5 billion initial public offering in Hong Kong priced at the top of the indicated range. Factoring in the extra shares to be sold if early trading goes well, the float will cut the stake held by its beleaguered American parent company to just 33 percent. It is a much needed result for Mark Tucker, A.I.A.’s new boss; A.I.G.; and Goldman Sachs, the I.P.O.’s lead manager.
