text: Just $5.4 billion has been raised by 662 venture capital companies in the third quarter, a significant drop from the $7.7 billion raised in the previous quarter, TechCrunch said, citing figures released by Dow Jones on Monday.

headline: Facebook Shareholder Mail.ru in $876 Million I.P.O.
text: Mail.ru Group, a Russian Internet company with stakes in Facebook and Zynga Game Network, is seeking as much as $876 million in an initial public offering in London, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: Serbia Moves Closer to Joining E.U.
text: LUXEMBOURG — Serbia took a significant step toward membership in the European Union on Monday, despite the union’s suspicions that the country could do more to bring Europe’s most-wanted war crimes suspect to justice.

headline: Are Big Layoffs Coming at Man Group?
text: Is the Man Group, the world’s largest publicly traded hedge fund manager, preparing to hand out a swath of pink slips?

headline: Obama Faces Long ‘To-Do’ List After Election Day
text: President Obama is getting out of Dodge within days of next week’s elections, one way or the other. But his reprieve from Beltway politics will be short-lived.

headline: This Week in Small Business: Some Good News?
text: R.I.P. MR. C Small-business man and hardware shop owner Howard Cunningham died last week.

headline: With a Healthy McFadden, Are the Raiders a Playoff Team?
text: It would be easy to discount Oakland’s 59-14 victory at Denver on Sunday. After all, these are the Raiders, the team that opened the season with a 38-13 loss to Tennessee, and that last week lost to the 49ers (1-6).

headline: Cuban Offers to Bankroll S.E.C. Lawyers to Speed Case
text: Mark Cuban, pictured, is offering to bankroll a team lawyers to help the Securities and Exchange Commission in its review of the agency’s case against him.

headline: Giga Omni Raises $2.5 Million in New Funding
text: Giga Omni Media, parent company of the GigaOm technology-focused blog, among others, has raised a fresh $2.5 million of funding, VentureBeat reports.

headline: OMV Taking Over Turkish Fuel Distributor
text: OMV, the Austrian energy company, said on Monday that it was buying more than half of the Turkish fuel and lubricant distribution company Petrol Ofisi from Dogan Holding for 1 billion euros ($1.4 billion), raising its stake in Petrol to more than 95 percent.

headline: Sam, Janet, and Fiscal Policy
text: One of the common arguments against fiscal policy in the current situation – one that sounds sensible – is that debt is the problem, so how can debt be the solution? Households borrowed too much; now you want the government to borrow even more?

headline: Betfair Books a Strong Gain in Market Debut
text: Betfair Group, a British Internet gambling site, climbed 19 percent in its first day of trading after its London initial public offering raised £211 million ($332 million), Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Catalina Weighs $100 Million Tech Fund
text: Catalina Ventures is weighing a move to raise $100 million for a technology and life sciences fund, which would be the firm’s first institutional fund, peHUB.com reported.

headline: Last Call | Kate Moss for Topshop
text: As far as style role models go, we’ll take Kate Moss over La Gaga any day. Her signature slinky party dresses, leather cigarette pants, downtown tees and fur jackets have become even cooler — and more accessible — since Topshop globalized the supermodel’s iconic style. So when rumors swirled that the Kate Moss for Topshop winter collection would be her last, sentiments went wild. (At least there is still Pete Doherty’s jewelry line.). “When we started the project we didn’t have an end in mind but I’m really proud of all 14 collections,” says Moss. “I’ve learned a lot about the design and development process; experiences that I’d only ever seen informally through being a model.” That’s great, Kate, but what’s in it for us? Well, come Tuesday, lots of sequined dresses and hot pants for the rock chick in Kate and, apparently, all of us, too. Other standout pieces include a tweed cape with a faux fur collar and boho vintage-inspired floral day dresses. Moss’s personal favorite? “If I had to pick one I’d go for the pansy dress!” Here’s an exclusive peek.

headline: Newsweek-Daily Beast: Anatomy of a Failed Deal
text: After talks about a deal to potentially merge Newsweek and The Daily Beast fell apart, it was widely put down to a conflict of personalities between Newsweek’s new owner, Sidney Harman, Barry Diller, owner The Daily Beast, and Tina Brown, the editor who runs the online news magazine.

headline: The Temporary Vegetarian: Raclette
text: Years ago, Terrance Brennan, the chef-owner of Artisanal, and also the chef-owner of Picholine, both in Manhattan, was in Gruyères, Switzerland, and ate his first raclette. The dish is named after a firm cow cheese used in this almost too-simple, but nevertheless hearty, tasty dish of melted cheese on cooked potato slices.

headline: Kenneth Cole-Iconix Merger Talks Stall
text: 9:28 a.m. | Updated Merger talks between Kenneth Cole Productions and the Iconix Brand Group, the licensing company run by Mr. Cole’s brother Neil, have stalled and are unlikely to resume soon, people involved in the talks have told DealBook.

headline: Inflation Bonds Are Sold With Negative Yield for First Time
text: Inflation-protected securities sold at negative yields for the first time ever on Monday as traders anticipate that the Federal Reserve will start a new round of asset purchases.

headline: Gladwell: Who Really Rescued G.M.?
text: “What makes ‘Overhaul’ so unexpectedly fascinating,” Malcolm Gladwell writes in his book review for The New Yorker, is that “it is the product of someone so convinced of the value of his contribution, and of the private-equity model, that he feels no need to hide his condescension.”

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: — Bees beat computers at math, at least with the traveling salesman problem.

headline: Childress Criticizes  Favre’s Decision-Making
text: Vikings Coach Brad Childress used some of his postgame news conference Sunday night to release steam, and he blew much of it in Brett Favre’s direction.

headline: Former Oracle President Phillips Lands C.E.O. Gig at Infor
text: It took Charles E. Phillips Jr., the former co-president of Oracle, all of about six weeks to find a new job.

headline: Afghan Leader Admits His Office Gets Cash from Iran
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  President Hamid Karzai acknowledged on Monday that he regularly receives bags of cash from the Iranian government in payments amounting to millions of dollars, as evidence mounted of a worsening rift between his government and its American and NATO supporters.

headline: Battle Over ‘The Hobbit’ Spurs Rally in New Zealand
text: It will be several months, at least, before audiences are able to see a trailer for “The Hobbit,” the two-part film series that Peter Jackson intends to make from J. R. R. Tolkien‘s fantasy novel. But in the meantime moviegoers can sate themselves with the above promotional reel (which we were pointed to by the good folks at Vulture) announcing a rally to urge Mr. Jackson and the studios behind the “Hobbit” films to keep them in New Zealand.

headline: Now Shopping | Mohawk General Store
text: When Bo and Kevin Carney opened the first Mohawk General Store two years ago in a tiny storefront in the Los Angeles neighborhood of Echo Park, the concept was simple: “stylish essentials … nothing frivolous,” says the elegant, Korean-born Bo. Tell that to the stuffed silk “fox stole” draped across a teak table in the new 1,400-square-foot lifestyle emporium the couple just opened in the city’s Silverlake neighborhood with the European midcentury furniture dealer Amsterdam Modern.

headline: Cuomo Promises to Stand Up to Unions
text: What we’re looking at on this Monday before the Monday before the election:

headline: Morgan Stanley Picks Caterpillar Chairman for Its Board
text: Morgan Stanley said on Monday that it had expanded its board by appointing the departing chairman of Caterpillar, James W. Owens, as a director.

headline: What ‘Angels in America’ Meant to Them, and to You
text: For the film and theater director Mike Nichols the play changed how he thought about characters. For the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright Doug Wright (“I Am My Own Wife”) it established a dividing line for gay-themed theater. For other dramatists like Lisa Kron (“Well”), Tarell Alvin McCraney (“The Brother/Sister Plays”) and Sarah Ruhl (“In the Next Room, or the vibrator play”) it was inspiration. And for academics and artistic directors, it became the last major stage work of the 20th century to wrestle with.

headline: French Protests Ease, but Refineries Are Still Affected
text: PARIS — Amid ongoing fuel shortages and threats of more strikes this week and next, the French government warned Monday that protests against its pension bill were costing the country billions and were damaging its reputation.

headline: Bailed-Out Firms Give to Candidates Who Fought TARP
text: Companies that benefited the most from the Troubled Assets Relief Program have given generously to political candidates this fall – in many cases, to Republicans who opposed the bailout, The Washington Post reports.

headline: Knit Witty
text: Donna Wilson has become the Tim Burton of London’s knitting circle. Back when the designer was a student at the Royal College of Art, she began crafting dolls out of old ‘‘jumpers,’’ the British word for sweaters. The leggy dolls without noses or mouths were picked up by Couverture, a chic lifestyle shop. Today, Wilson’s quirky menagerie includes 30-odd creatures, like the charming hybrid Cyril Squirrel-Fox and Puddle Man (essentially a pool of water with a face), all of which are made from knitted lamb’s wool in Wilson’s East End workshop, not to mention cushions, throws, ottomans, sofas and rugs. Many of these are commissions from and collaborations with SCP, the British home furnishings manufacturer.

headline: Monday Matchup, Giants at Cowboys
text: Giants (4-2) at Cowboys (1-4)Monday, 8:30 p.m.

headline: Arrest in Brooklyn Hair Salon Shootout
text: A suspect in the Saturday shooting at a beauty salon in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, was arrested overnight, the police said.

headline: Muddle Class
text: This weekend, co-vocabularists have generously offered their definitions of middle class.

headline: A Second Pass at Early Voting Totals: Now With Extra Skepticism
text: I’ve gotten a lot of pushback on my post from Sunday night about early voting figures. Michael P. McDonald of The Huffington Post, for instance — whose work I referred to in my article — calls it “fatally flawed” and suggests I have erred by comparing early voting totals in each state to party registration figures. Instead, he thinks, the proper comparison is to early voting figures from past years.

headline: CMJ 2010: Das Racist
text: At this year's CMJ Music Marathon, rap group Das Racist has been steadily gaining popularity with their unconventional style.

headline: Monday Reading: The Airport Wish List
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Mortgage Modifications Slow in September
text: Even as banks, borrowers and regulators battle over how much faulty documentation by lenders should impede foreclosures, fresh evidence came Monday that the housing market remained very wobbly.

headline: Metro-North Wants to Keep Horn-Testing Quiet
text: Memo to the good people of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y.: Next time you ride a Metro-North train, make sure to thank your conductor.

headline: Ladle of Love Food Truck Needs a Place to Sleep
text: It’s brand new, it’s environmentally green (and literally green and white), it cost $92,500, and now it needs a parking space.

headline: Democrat in Rhode Island Tells Obama Off
text: Talk about a not-so-warm welcome for the president of the United States and the leader of your party.

headline: ‘Dexter’ Watch: Bonded by Rage
text: It’s a few weeks into the arrival of Julia Stiles on “Dexter” and we have yet to unpack the meaning of her character’s name. For this I blame myself: I was too busy with my “Mad Men” decoder rings. But now that they have been shelved until the debut of the next season, let’s take a look at what it might signify that her name is Lumen Ann Pierce. Raped and tortured by a gang of psychos led by Boyd Fowler, of the motivational tapes and roadkill-cleanup work, Lumen appeared in the opening moments of Sunday night’s episode doing strange things to raw sugar packets in a diner. Free from Dexter’s captivity, she is unhinged.

headline: On Upper East Side, Parking Laws Meet Parking Customs
text: New Yorkers blessed and cursed with cars have learned that there are few things more frustrating than trying to find street parking. Yet, in front of some of the city’s priciest apartment buildings, often on the Upper East Side, there seems to be an abundance of spaces that drivers are not taking.

headline: 'Riding a Rocket'
text: An architectural preservationist in Buffalo, N.Y., Timothy A. Tielman discusses the rapid rise of Carl P. Paladino to the New York political stage.

headline: Advice for the College Interview: Girls, Dress Discreetly; Boys, Mind Those Hands
text: Something strange happens when teenagers sit down for college admissions interviews.

headline: Seeking Crowd-Sourced Climate Pacts
text: A couple of years ago, the Center for Collective Intelligence (I wonder about the potential for this every day in running a blog) at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology launched the Climate Collaboratorium.

headline: Three First-Time Marathoners Preparing to Take On the World
text: Simon Bairu, 27, will make his marathon debut in New York on Nov. 7. He won the 2005 and ‘06 N.C.A.A. cross-country titles at Wisconsin and holds the Canadian record for 10,000 meters at 27 minutes 23.63 seconds. He ran 1:02:08 in finishing fifth in the Philadelphia half-marathon in September. Bairu, along with Tim Nelson and Shalane Flanagan, are part of the Web series “Rookies Vs. the World,” presented jointly by the New York Road Runners and Kimbia Athletics. New episodes are broadcast every Tuesday and Friday.

headline: Newspaper Circulation Falls Broadly but at Slower Pace
text: Newspapers across the country broadly reported falling circulation from April through September, though the rate of decline slowed from the alarming pace in the same period last year, according to figures released on Monday by the Audit Bureau of Circulations.

headline: After a Crackdown, Few Crunching Hits
text: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.  In the locker room after the Pittsburgh Steelers’ victory Sunday, linebacker James Harrison said that he played the game the way he had been taught since he was 10 years old. Except when he didn’t.

headline: When the Family Needs an Umpire
text: The home care aide didn’t expect her new charge to be particularly cantankerous. After all, she had worked for the elderly woman’s sister for four years, and they’d gotten along well.

headline: Should an 8-Year-Old Watch ‘Glee’?
text: On the spectrum of “we don’t own a television” to “my children can watch whatever they want,” I tend toward the more permissive end. Once my sons reached their early teens, I gave in, deciding to view the ubiquitous sexual innuendo and gender stereotyping, among other things, as fodder for conversation and a means of inoculation against the real world. We regularly watched together, the boys and I, with them slightly mortified that their mother was seeing this inappropriate stuff, and me providing running counterpoint wherever possible.

headline: Ask the Reporters: Iraq War Logs
text: The New York Times reporters who wrote about a trove of classified Iraq war military documents disclosed by Wikileaks last week are answering questions from readers. Please submit a question using the comments form below. We will continue to post selected questions and answers over the next few days. The most recent questions and answers appear at the top of this post.

headline: On Our Radar: Meltdown on Greenland Ice Sheet
text: The Greenland ice sheet melted at a rate that was 25 to 50 percent higher this year than normal, according to Danish research scientists; about 500 gigatons of ice are estimated to have melted this summer. Some scientists express caution on the results but acknowledge that melting has indeed been above average. [Denmark.dk]

headline: We Made It Ourselves | Snap Tonic
text: Steve Grasse is a Jedi distiller. As a Draper-league ad man and branding expert, he is able to convey an idea with a couple of words or a single image. As a creator of alcoholic potables, he ferments unexpected ingredients with logic-defying success. He can’t practice one without the other. When he developed his tattoo-artist-inspired Sailor Jerry line of apparel, he had to include a rum; when William Grant & Sons wanted to produce a premium gin, the company hired Grasse not just to market Hendrick’s but to conceptualize the actual drink as well. (The integral cucumber? That has Grasse’s prints all over it.) And, when he launched a new lifestyle concept and retail shop in 2008, he had to do a spirit tie-in. First there was Root, and now Snap.

headline: Unpopular Science
text: Whether we like it or not, human life is subject to the universal laws of physics.

headline: Off the Menu: The John Dory
text: Not the John Dory redux, but a bigger, more informal space done in shiny black tile and covered with Ken Friedman’s aquatic souvenir shop tchochkes, is set to open in the Ace Hotel on Nov. 1.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Fox 19: Mmmm, beef sticks. Local TV reports Milwaukee plant has recalled 3,000 pounds of glass- and plastic-filled sausage. – Sam Sifton

headline: CommScope Shares Pop Amid Carlyle Deal Talks
text: Shares in CommScope, the telecommunications equipment maker, jumped about 30 percent on Monday after the company confirmed a DealBook report that it was in talks to sell itself to the Carlyle Group.

headline: 'A Pit Bull'
text: Mr. Tielman, an architectural preservationist from Buffalo, N.Y., discusses Carl P. Paladino's management style.

headline: Amish Hackers Tell All
text: Last week, the techies were out in force when Kevin Kelly — a founding editor of Wired and currently the magazine’s “chief maverick” — came to the New York Public Library to talk about his new book, “What Technology Wants.” (See video of the event here.)  There were plenty of smart phones and iPads in the audience, but the thing I was really looking for was some Amish beards. Beards? Yes. As Kelly’s book reveals, he is that rare high-technologist to engage with America’s most famous community of Luddites.

headline: Amish Hackers Tell All
text: Last week, the techies were out in force when Kevin Kelly — a founding editor of Wired and currently the magazine’s “chief maverick” — came to the New York Public Library to talk about his new book, “What Technology Wants.” (See video of the event here.)  There were plenty of smart phones and iPads in the audience, but the thing I was really looking for was some Amish beards. Beards? Yes. As Kelly’s book reveals, he is that rare high-technologist to engage with America’s most famous community of Luddites.

headline: Getting Revenge Against Your Insurance Company
text: Is it possible that one motivation for insurance fraud is to get back at insurance companies that provide poor service?

headline: Are You Throwing to Me?
text: Perhaps it was overshadowed by that other memo the N.F.L. sent to its teams last week  the one politely requesting that players stop trying to kill one another with their helmets  but the league’s teams certainly got this message. It apparently declared Sunday to be National Throw It to the Wrong Team Day. And while the reaction to the anti-maiming directive was mixed, quarterbacks were all too happy to follow these orders, doing everything short of attaching gift cards to the ball.

headline: Stong Management Skills
text: Mark H. Tuohey III, a fried of Carl P. Paladino's from college, discusses Mr. Paladino's management style and people skills.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Q: (Reader)

headline: An Effective Outsider
text: Mr. Tuohey explains why he believes that Mr. Paladino's identity as a political outsider will help him accomplish his goals in office.

headline: Numberplay: Happy Birthday, Bill
text: Last week, we had a pizza puzzle from Peter Winkler. It turned out to be a very tough puzzle, so I’ll leave the discussion over the solutions open for another week and we’ll postpone digging further into Dr. Winkler’s collection. Instead, let’s take a break with some lighter numeric fare about the upcoming birthday of one of the world’s richest men. My partner in this numerical birthday extravaganza is Dr. Aziz Inan, who is a master at creating numeric curiosities involving dates, as he demonstrated in Some Light Number Music and Backdating.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
text: Amy L. Andrews joined Media Networks Inc., Stamford, Conn., in a new post, director for publisher relations, working for MNI and its divisions Targeted Media and MNI MediaConnect. She had most recently been executive marketing director at Redbook, New York, part of the Hearst Magazines division of the Hearst Corporation.

headline: Don’t Park Here. (And Don’t Ask Why.)
text: New Yorkers pride themselves on self-sufficiency and resourcefulness, especially when it comes to securing scarce urban commodities, and the on-street parking spot is a prime example. Our colleague Christine Haughney has an installment of her column, The Appraisal, today about fancy apartment complexes on the Upper East Side that set out signs mounted on brass stands politely asking drivers not to park out front and, at times, use doormen to get the point across in slightly less polite ways.

headline: Our Forecast Calls for Lots of Lakers
text: The great thing about making predictions in October is that no one remembers them in June. Unfortunately, the Internet guarantees these things will live on in perpetuity. Here is how The Times’s basketball writers, Howard Beck and Jonathan Abrams, see the N.B.A. unfolding this season.Howard Beck’s predictions:

headline: Is Energy Efficiency Blue, Red or Both?
text: Recently I wrote about how people in six Kansas towns had been motivated to cut their energy use through intertown competitions. The residents were largely skeptical about the science behind climate change but were moved to act by values like thrift and patriotism. In some cases towns reduced their energy consumption by as much as 5 percent over a year, considered a giant drop in this field.

headline: A Writing Stone: Chapter and Verse
text: For legions of Rolling Stones fans, Keith Richards is not only the heart and soul of the world’s greatest rock ’n’ roll band, he’s also the very avatar of rebellion: the desperado, the buccaneer, the poète maudit, the soul survivor and main offender, the torn and frayed outlaw, and the coolest dude on the planet, named both No. 1 on the rock stars most-likely-to-die list and the one life form (besides the cockroach) capable of surviving nuclear war.

headline: Fernando Alonso Wins in South Korea, Takes Formula One Lead
text: The first-ever Korean Grand Prix, held on Sunday in damp conditions, will be a memorable one. The Formula One race was delayed by heavy rain. It started behind the safety car for 17 laps and finished just before darkness fell. But perhaps more than any of that, the grand prix will be remembered as the day Fernando Alonso outlasted his rivals to take a lead in the championship, a position thought to be unlikely as recently as a month ago.

headline: Thyroid Cancer’s Many Forms
text: The recent Times article “When a Cancer Therapy Puts Others at Risk” describes the unusual problems surrounding radiation therapy for thyroid cancer, which can pose an immediate risk to other people for up to a week.

headline: The Claim: Lying on Your Left Side Eases Heartburn
text: THE FACTS For people with chronic heartburn, restful sleep is no easy feat. Fall asleep in the wrong position, and acid slips into the esophagus, a recipe for agita and insomnia.

headline: New Beastie Boys Album Is a Lot Like Unreleased Beastie Boys Album
text: The bad news for Beastie Boys fans: it looks as though there will be no “Hot Sauce Committee Part 1,” the album that this hip-hop trio planned to release in 2009 — its first since “The Mix-Up,” an all-instrumental record from 2007, and the first with any lyrical content since “To the Five Boroughs” in 2004.

headline: MobileMe Needs a Diet
text: At last week’s “Back to the Mac” presentation, Steve Jobs touted the “green” aspects of Apple‘s latest iteration of the MacBook Air. I have no doubt that the company is seriously committed to the environment; as Apple notes on its Web site, every one of its products meets or exceeds Energy Star standards.

headline: Shop-Class Chic
text: At the London Design Festival in September, I came upon so many homespun, handmade objects and installations that within hours I was feeling guilty for not having made my own shoes. The prevailing aesthetic wasn’t crafty, exactly — and it certainly wasn’t decorative — but it was definitely hand-hewn, mostly in wood, with a less-is-more, whittled-down vibe (and I use the word ‘‘whittled’’ advisedly).

headline: How a Pas5woRd Can Sink Your Company
text: Back in the 1990s fellow science and technology journalist Charles Mann and I wrote a book uncovering the true story of how a lone, young, cognitively impaired hacker with relatively few computer skills managed to perpetrate what was then the most extensive and scariest series of computer break-ins ever — government weapons labs, dam control systems and ATM networks were among the hundreds of networks compromised. At the end of the book, we predicted that no matter how much effort was poured into making the Internet safer, hackers would always be able to have a field day, partly for technical reasons but also because companies and individuals would never get it together to take simple precautions critical to safe computing.

headline: Amid Cholera Outbreak in Haiti, Misery and Hope
text: ST.-MARC, Haiti  Inside the courtyard of St. Nicholas Hospital, beyond the gate with the handwritten sign stating “Diarrhea Emergency Only,” lies a grim but unusually orderly scene at the epicenter of this country’s unexpected cholera epidemic.

headline: What to Do Now to Feel Better at 100
text: Many changes take place in physical abilities as we age. Try as I may, I simply can’t swim as fast at 69 as I did at 39, 49 or even 59. Nor am I as steady on my feet. I can only assume my strength has waned as well  I’m finding bottles and jars harder to open and heavy packages harder to lift and carry.

headline: For Lighter Gnocchi, Turn to Ricotta
text: Gnocchi doesn’t necessarily mean “little flour-and-potato pasta” but — actually — “dumpling.” They can be made with semolina or, in this case, cheese. The version in this week’s Minimalist column is light, easy and delicious.

headline: Hoteliers Look to Shield Themselves From Dishonest Online Reviews
text: The 35 million hotel reviews posted on TripAdvisor reveal everything from snooty staff to filthy toilets, and sometimes the reviewer’s overly picky standards.

headline: Keeping Score: How Good Are the Giants’ Starters?
text: The San Francisco Giants have so far proved the old adage that pitching wins in the postseason. Despite finishing ninth in the National League in offense, they squeaked into the tournament on the back of a vaunted starting rotation of Tim Lincecum, Matt Cain, Jonathan Sánchez and Madison Bumgarner, who combined for a 3.19 earned run average in the regular season.

headline: Ignoramity Triumphant
text: Wow. I guess I lead an intellectually sheltered life. Until I followed a link from Yves Smith, I had been blissfully unaware that the investment airwaves were full of people yelling that Bernanke is debasing the dollar because the dollar has fallen modestly in recent weeks.

headline: Perspectives on Carl Paladino
text: Interviews with the former colleagues, challengers and friends Carl P. Paladino.

headline: Eiland Will Not Return as Yankees’ Pitching Coach
text: Ben Shpigel is covering General Manager Brian Cashman’s news conference following the Yankees’ ouster from the American League Championship Series. He reports, via Twitter, that Cashman will meet with Manager Joe Girardi’s agent on Tuesday to discuss a new contract, and that pitching coach Dave Eiland will not return as the Yankees pitching coach. Check back for more later.

headline: No Quick Broadway Transfer for ‘The Children’s Hour’
text: While the theater producers Sonia Friedman and Scott Landis structured their current revival of “La Bete” to close in the West End on Sept. 4 and move unusually quickly to Broadway, where performances began on Sept. 23, don’t expect the same swift transfer for their coming London production of “The Children’s Hour” by Lillian Hellman, starring Keira Knightley (“Pride and Prejudice”), top left, and Elisabeth Moss (“Mad Men”), bottom left.

headline: Selling New Wine in Millennial Bottles
text: There’s a moment in a classic Warner Brothers cartoon when Bugs Bunny asks, “What’s all the hubbub, bub?” Now along comes a campaign that might encourage the wascally wabbit to inquire, “Where’s all the HobNob, Bob?”

headline: TimesCast | October 25, 2010
text: Afghanistan receives bags of cash from Iran; the California races and using science to save art.

headline: The Bailout and its Discontents
text: My column today defends the moral wisdom of the anti-TARP backlash against the suggestion that we should be happy with the bailout because it isn’t actually going to cost us that much money. I thought this post from Stan Collender opens an interesting window on how voters are responding to the latter argument, and the news that TARP (or at least the Wall Street) might actually turn a profit for the government:

headline: Well-Dressed Men, Pink Panthers and Paris on Hudson
text: Trying to guess at the lives of straphangers while riding the subway is an age-old pastime. It can even bear fruit, as Dvora Meyers writes in The Times, when such profiling leads to correct guesses about which seats may be vacated at which stops.

headline: Taking Harder Stance Toward China, Obama Lines Up Allies
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration, facing a confrontational relationship with China on exchange rates, trade and security issues, is stiffening its approach toward Beijing, seeking allies to confront a newly assertive power that officials now say has little intention of working with the United States.

headline: Food and Drug Administration Recommends Food Safety Managers at Restaurants
text: After conducting a years-long study on food risk factors, the United States Food and Drug Administration has recommended that all restaurants provide on-site, trained and certified food protection managers, according to Nation’s Restaurant News.

headline: Checkered History in Series for Giants
text: For the Giants, the World Series has too often produced more sympathy than success.

headline: Massacre in Tijuana Recalls Worst Era
text: MEXICO CITY  Thirteen people were killed at a drug rehabilitation clinic in Tijuana on Sunday night, a sign that the relative peace there celebrated recently by the president himself might be fracturing. The killings in Tijuana, across the border from San Diego, follow the deaths of 14 young people in Ciudad Juárez, next to El Paso, who were gunned down at a party on Friday night.

headline: New U.S. Standards Take Aim at Truck Emissions and Fuel Economy
text: WASHINGTON  The federal government announced the first national emissions and fuel economy standards for heavy vehicles on Monday, one of a series of regulatory steps that the Obama administration is taking to increase energy efficiency and reduce atmospheric pollution in the absence of Congressional action on climate change.

headline: Deal Averts Trial in Disputed Guantánamo Case
text: WASHINGTON — A former child soldier being held at the military prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, pleaded guilty on Monday to terrorism-related charges, averting the awkward prospect that he would be the first person to stand trial before a military commission under the Obama administration.

headline: In DVR Ratings, Some Shows Find Good News
text: The DVR playback ratings for the third week of the television season arrived Monday and provided much good news for seemingly troubled shows like “The Event” and “Parenthood” on NBC and “Fringe” on Fox, while also sending many successful shows up to ratings well into hit territory.

headline: The Benefits of Left-Side Sleeping
text: Today’s “Really?” column explores how sleeping position affects heartburn pain. Studies show that sleeping on your left side is best.

headline: It Gets Better
text: Internet campaign aimed at homosexual youths who may be feeling alone, or suicidal.

headline: Tasting the Salone del Gusto
text: The Slow Food International founder and president Carlo Petrini has a very exacting definition of globalization. It’s not using Romanian milk to make Italian cheese. His firm retort to anyone who calls that globalization: “tutte balle” (all lies)! His food-focused vision of the much-tossed-around term lies closer to two words interlinked by two symbols: “Food +/= Places.” It’s the circular notion of terroir, of food being rooted to a specific place, and of that place expressing itself through its food. It’s also the theme of the International Salone del Gusto 2010, the eighth edition of Slow Food’s biennial celebration of foods from around the world, which opened on Thursday in Turin concurrently with Terra Madre.

headline: Lustful Opera, Censored, Befuddles Chinese
text: BEIJING  As any artist or performer in China knows, it is impossible to predict what will set off the mercurial culture censors who have sweeping power over the content of film, music, television and print.

headline: Share Your Short-Sale Experiences
text: As banks resume foreclosure proceedings, many hard-pressed homeowners are questioning why banks are making it so difficult to opt for short sales, according to an article “Short Sales Resisted as Foreclosures are Revived” in Monday’s New York Times.

headline: Pizza Without the Dough
text: Lavash is a flatbread, a staple of meals in Iran, Azerbaijan, Armenia and Georgia. Until recently I’d never thought about using it as a pizza crust. It hardly resembles one  it’s much thinner. Still, I’ve found it’s a great way to put together something like a pizza for a quick lunch or dinner. And it’s the easiest pizza you’ll ever make.

headline: How Independent Are Barnes & Noble Directors?
text: Truly independent directors can be hard to spot. The reason is that the conflicts that create doubt as to a director’s independence can be so subtle and hidden. It is easy to know that the spouse of the chief executive is not independent, but what about a best friend from high school? When do relationships, social or otherwise, arise to the level that a conflict is created and director independence is questionable?

headline: The H.P. Slate Is Not Trying to Be an iPad
text: Consumers interested in buying a tablet computer are going to see a lot of devices in the coming months that resemble the iPad. A case in point is Hewlett-Packard’s Slate 500 Tablet PC.

headline: Karzai Rails Against America in Diatribe
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  President Hamid Karzai accused the United States on Monday of exporting killing to Afghanistan by giving contracts to private security companies. It was the latest chapter of a bitter battle between the president and his allies in the war against the Taliban that has taken on an increasingly anti-Western tone.

headline: Emissions Rating for Chevy Volt Doesn’t Consider Electric Driving
text: For people with typical commutes, the coming Chevrolet Volt plug-in hybrid is likely to be driven as an electric car, producing no tailpipe emissions, much of the time. That would make it effectively cleaner than most cars on the road.

headline: Studying Disease in Dogs to Help Humans
text: Cushing’s disease is a rare condition in humans, but common in dogs. As a result, scientists are now hoping that a unique collaboration between veterinarians and human doctors will unlock clues for treating the disease.

headline: McGrady Tries to Recapture Old Form — Again
text: The new Detroit Pistons swingman Tracy McGrady has asserted since the first day of training camp that he’s strong, healthy and ready to play.

headline: Birth Control Pills, 1957
text: Birth control pills  or at least the various attempts to develop them  were mentioned occasionally in The New York Times during the 1950s, but discussion of the possibility of a safe and effective oral contraceptive became heated in the summer of 1957.

headline: Live Election Night Video
text: On Election Night, editors, reporters and columnists from The New York Times discussed race results and offered opinion via live video updates.

headline: No Quick Fix? Developing Problem-Solving Skills
text: Overview | How can real problems be approached and analyzed in ways that lead to practical solutions? What distinguishes effective solutions from ineffective ones? In this lesson, students consider how to work through a practical problem. They identify problems in their school that need fixing, then devise viable solutions to one of those problems, using problem-solving models and drawing on strategies like the social science of behavioral change. They then test some of their proposed solutions in the field and propose them to the school.

headline: A Food Truck Looking for a Place to Rest
text: The Ladle of Love food truck in Central Park runs on an electric engine, uses containers and utensils made of vegetable products, and serves up a mean goat-cheese salad. One thing it lacks is an overnight parking spot. The maximum speed of 25 miles an hour and limited cruising range make Brooklyn, nighttime home of many of Manhattan’s food-vending trucks, a reach. In Manhattan, the owners are having a hard time finding a garage with 10-foot high ceilings. Read the tale of the wandering food truck on Diner’s Journal.

headline: The Improvised Remedies of an Art Healer
text: Eleonora Nagy remembers the first time she got a close look at “Untitled,” a 1966 sculpture by the artist Paul Thek. One of a series of works known as “meat pieces,” it looked like a fresh limb fragment that had gone bad  very bad.

headline: The Caucus: California Races
text: A new poll from the University of Southern California and the Los Angeles Times shows that the Democratic candidates in gubernatorial and Senate races, Jerry Brown and Barbara Boxer, respectively, have the lead over their Republican counterparts, Meg Whitman and Carly Fiorina.

headline: Godard Watch Ends: Director Won’t Attend Honorary Oscars Ceremony
text: In a chaotic universe where all empirical stimuli is subjectively interpreted by imperfect observers, who is to say what does or does not happen? Jean-Luc Godard, for one: Mr. Godard, 79, the irascible filmmaker and a pioneer of the French New Wave movement, will definitely not be attending a special Oscars ceremony on Nov. 13 to pick up an honorary Academy Award, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences said on Monday.

headline: Highlights From Yankees’ News Conferences
text: Highlights of General Manager Brian Cashman and Manager Joe Girardi’s news conferences Monday after the Yankees’ four-games-to-two loss to the Texas Rangers in the American League Championship Series:

headline: Social Media Campaign Takes Aim at Obesity
text: An organization seeking to address the issue of weight gain among Americans has chosen an agency to handle the social media elements of its efforts to reach consumers.

text: When is tap water so good it’s worth fighting for?

headline: TimesCast: Democrats in California
text: In the latest edition of TimesCast, The Times’s Michael D. Shear and Elisabeth Goodridge discuss the results from a recent poll on the Senate and gubernatorial races in California.

headline: House Democrats Fight to Survive in Arizona
text: TUCSON  When it comes to endangered species in Arizona, there are the bonytail chub, the Sonoran pronghorn and, perhaps soon, the Congressional Democrat.

headline: The Morning Skate: Banging Heads and Scratching Ilya
text: CBC’s “Hockey Night in Canada” likes to emphasize the more physical aspects of the N.H.L., from making Don Cherry the show’s centerpiece to their weekly opening, which uses Nickelback’s cover version (with Kid Rock) of Elton John’s “Saturday Night’s Alright For Fighting” under fresh video of fisticuffs and some eye opening plays, like this one from a while ago:

headline: Pelicans in Training
text: Q. How do pelicans learn to dive for fish?

headline: Derailment Snarls Evening Commute Out of Penn Station
text: A partial derailment Monday morning on New Jersey Transit caused no injuries, but it has thrown the evening’s commuting into chaos that cascaded over to the Long Island Rail Road and Amtrak, which share Pennsylvania Station with New Jersey Transit.

headline: Juan Williams and the Partisan Cocoon
text: I have only this to add to the oceans of online ink spilled over NPR’s firing of Juan Williams last week: Whatever you think of the particulars of the case, it’s a shame that the world will have one less pundit whose job requires him to communicate with both public radio listeners and Fox News watchers.

headline: Trying to Follow the Trail of Missing AIDS Patients
text: KISUMU, Kenya  The young woman perched on the edge of the bed in her tiny hut. She was 29 years old, an AIDS widow who supported herself by frying and selling potato fries by the side of the nearby road.

headline: How the King Cobra Maintains Its Reign
text: I can remember the first time I saw one, at the St. Louis Zoo, and the feeling that certain death was just on the other side of the glass. I could not get over the snake’s size  this one was about 12 feet long. I was used to looking at giant snakes in zoos (I always made a beeline for the reptile house), but pythons did not seem so scary to me because they rarely moved. This sleek, agile and very alert snake was a king cobra, the largest venomous snake in the world and an icon to all snake enthusiasts, including this writer.

headline: Power in East Moves to Florida
text: LeBron James took his talents to South Beach, joining Dwyane Wade and Chris Bosh, and the rest of the Eastern Conference shook and reacted to the seismic shift. The move strengthened the Heat and weakened other teams. Some organizations scrambled, reset and readjusted their priorities, while others just complained.

headline: Lakers Best in West, but Watch Out for Thunder
text: It was a noisy summer in the N.B.A., the airwaves jammed with enmity and resentment and interminable psychoanalysis. LeBron James stirred passions and practically swallowed the conversation while everyone fretted over a Miami superteam.

headline: A Plea for More School Counselors
text: Robert Bardwell is director of guidance at Monson High School, a public school in Massachusetts, and an officer of the New England Association for College Admission Counseling.

headline: India: Ambitious Study Indicates Malaria Deaths May Be Underreported Across the World
text: The number of malaria deaths in India far outstrips World Health Organization estimates, according to a study released last week. The authors argue that estimates should be revised upward for the whole world, particularly among adults.

headline: ‘Top Gear’ on ’60 Minutes’
text: Regular readers of this blog are likely to be among the 350 million people in 170 countries who watch “Top Gear” every week — numbers provided by “60 Minutes,” which produced a segment on the British car show on Sunday night.

headline: Breast Cancer Tales: The Inspirational vs. the Actual
text: Before penicillin came along, syphilis was known in medical circles as “the great mimicker,” a stealthy disease able to mangle the human body in virtually all known ways. “Know syphilis and you know medicine,” professors would tell their students.

text: “Having a Sister Makes You Happier”: that was the headline on a recent article about a study finding that adolescents who have a sister are less likely to report such feelings as “I am unhappy, sad or depressed” and “I feel like no one loves me.”

text: Patients rarely suffer serious side effects from endoscopic procedures like colonoscopies, but a new study reports that 1 in 100 experience complications serious enough to send them to the emergency room  a much higher rate than expected.

text: A look at the off-season and training camp before the N.B.A. opens the 2010-11 season on Tuesday with three games, including Miami at Boston and Houston at the Lakers.

headline: Hybrid Model for Nonprofits Hits Snags
text: Since its founding in 2003, the GlobalGiving Foundation has used its Web site to channel more than $30 million to charitable projects like buying seeds for farmers in Zimbabwe and feeding orphaned chimpanzees.

headline: Approach May Matter In Advice On Weight
text: People who are overweight are often counseled by their physicians to lose the extra pounds. But does such advice do any good? A new study suggests that it depends on the way it is offered.

headline: Artifacts | The Baldessari Variations
text: John Baldessari was not the first conceptual artist or appropriationist, but he has to be the funniest. Take his primitive 1971 video, “I Am Making Art,” in which the burly, 6-foot-5 Los Angeleno deadpans the title phrase while improvising mechanical hand and elbow gestures that lie somewhere between sign language for the blind and the body language of a traffic cop. It’s hilarious. And somehow poignant.

headline: Times Square, 3:15 P.M.
text: Lech Walesa, the former president of Poland, speaks to a rally of trade union members.

headline: Encased in Amber, a Trove of New Species
text: An amber excavation in western India has led to the discovery of more than 700 ancient insects, arachnids and crustaceans, and many plant, floral and fungal remains.

headline: Man Says Heinz Stole His Idea for Dippable Ketchup Packets
text: When Heinz came out with dippable/squeezable ketchup packets in February, Diner’s Journal said that the product could be a “game-changer.”

headline: When Hormone Creams Expose Others to Risks
text: Veterinarians around the country are reporting a strange phenomenon: spayed dogs and cats, even some puppies and kittens, are suddenly becoming hormonal.

text: A. O. Scott looks back at Clint Eastwood's 1993 film in which he co-stars with Kevin Costner.

headline: Real-World Steps on Energy and CO2
text: The ripples are still spreading from a recently released game plan for a “post-partisan” approach to expanding humanity’s energy menu without overheating the climate. The plan, aimed at filling the policy gap left by the death of a carbon cap and trading system, focuses on stimulating innovation and diffusion of non-polluting energy technology through direct investment and procurement policies.

headline: The Newest Escape Artist
text: David Blaine, who has shivered inside ice blocks in Times Square and floated inside a water-filled sphere on Oprah Winfrey’s talk show, put the handcuffs on my wrists, talking about Harry Houdini the whole time.

headline: Pandit Criticizes Some Basel III Bank Rules
text: Citigroup‘s chief executive, Vikram S. Pandit, criticized new global capital rules on Monday, saying that while the “reforms are headed in the right direction,” in some cases they “don’t go far enough” or even make the problems that led to the financial crisis worse, Reuters reports.

headline: Above It All: Tracing BP’s Imperious History
text: Not long after the explosion that resulted in one of the largest oil spills in history, in the Gulf of Mexico this spring, the culprit BP committed public-relations gaffes, the most disturbingly memorable of which involved the company’s chief executive at the time, Tony Hayward, proclaiming, “I’d like my life back.”

headline: Taking the Pepsi Franchise to an Ice-Cold Romania
text: I’VE been a frequent business traveler for more than 20 years. I now live in Tel Aviv, but when I was a young executive, I was based in New York. My trips back then were short, mostly to the Midwest and sometimes to the West Coast.

headline: Bankrupt Ultimate Escapes Wins Approval for Sale
text: 6:01 p.m. | Updated Members of Ultimate Escapes, the bankrupt provider of luxury vacations to places like Tahoe and Tuscany, needn’t worry about losing their status.

headline: Joseph Stein, ‘Fiddler on the Roof’ Author, Dies at 98
text: Joseph Stein, the Tony Award-winning author of “Fiddler on the Roof” and more than a dozen other Broadway musicals, died on Sunday in Manhattan. He was 98.

headline: Obama Gets a Caustic Welcome in Rhode Island
text: WOONSOCKET, R.I. – Welcome to Rhode Island, where Democratic politics are so quirky that the party’s nominee for governor welcomed President Obama on Monday by declaring, on live radio, that the president could “take his endorsement and really shove it.”

headline: Now Reading | ‘What Was the Hipster?’
text: “Hipster” is more than a noun — it’s a lifestyle. An overused, albeit elastic, coinage, it can describe everything from vintage T-shirt connoisseurs to anyone who kinda sorta maybe knows Cory Kennedy. And now it’s a subject of highbrow discourse. N+1, the Dumbo-based “journal of politics, literature and culture,” aims to shed new light on the phenomenon with the release of “What Was the Hipster?: A Sociological Investigation” (n+1 Foundation, $10), a pocket-size pop theory text on topics ranging from the aesthetics of party photography to the, ahem, “hipster Other.”

headline: Jazz With a Humorist Urge and a Whiff of Mystery
text: The Respect Sextet stamps ambitious music with a smart-alecky affect, ranging broadly from the antic to the deadpan. Formed not quite a decade ago at the Eastman School of Music, it subscribes to the avant-garde humorist urge that has sustained the Art Ensemble of Chicago, the ICP Orchestra (of Amsterdam) and the Microscopic Septet (of New York). The jazz tradition, as a construct, interests the band. But so do the slippery aspects of electronic and new music, which explained its presence at the Greenwich House Music School on Thursday night, kicking off the 25th season of the North River Music series.

headline: Forces of Darkness, Dressed in T-Shirts and Jeans
text: Dance Theater Workshop audiences tend to be pretty hard-core; it takes a lot for a show to rattle them, especially to the point of walking out midperformance.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘A Perfect World’
text: In this week’s Critics’ Pick, A. O. Scott looks back at Clint Eastwood’s 1993 drama, “A Perfect World.” The film focuses on the relationship between a young boy (T. J. Lowther) and the prison escapee (Kevin Costner) who takes him hostage. Mr. Eastwood plays the police officer in pursuit.

headline: Restaurants’ Best Press: ‘Bill Clinton Ate Here’
text: BILL CLINTON has dined at Bukhara, an upscale restaurant in New Delhi, on just two occasions, but the afterglow of those visits has never worn off. The clientele, it seems, won’t let it.

headline: A Cultural Conversation Through Jazz
text: Chucho Valdés began his late set on Friday night at the Allen Room with a sweeping solo piano introduction to the uptempo Cuban jazz hybrid “Anabis,” such a controlled detonation of music that it kicked through your defenses.

headline: U.S. to Send Visual Artists as Cultural Ambassadors
text: In recent years the State Department has relied on performing artists to act as cultural ambassadors, sending dancers and musicians around the world to show people that America is more than just Hollywood movies, McEverything and two drawn-out wars.

headline: Serving Up Feathered Bait to Attract Ecosystem Data
text: CAPILLA PEAK OBSERVATORY, N.M. — Mandy Weston stood on a ridge in the Manzano Mountains, 9,000 feet above sea level and about 4,000 feet above the Rio Grande Valley, grasping the talons of a juvenile northern harrier in her right hand.

headline: Spears and Spandex: Wagner via World Wide Wrestling
text: Larger-than-life characters, titanic egos, brazen deceit, bloody combat: with such things is Wagner’s grandiose four-opera cycle, “Der Ring des Nibelungen,” concerned. That those characteristics are hardly specific to the Norse mythology of Wagner’s scenario, however, has endowed this lofty 19th-century creation with enduring resonance. Clever directors have long honored the salient points of Wagner’s epic while radically recasting his dramaturgical specifics to make points about contemporary society and its mores.

headline: Claims of Good Faith, and Bad, in Cable Dispute
text: The high-stakes feud between the News Corporation and Cablevision reached the point of filing grievances before the Federal Communications Commission on Monday, with each side trying to prove that it had been bargaining in good faith — while charging that the other side had not.

headline: The Caucus Click: Andrews Air Force Base, Outside Washington
text: Preparing Air Force One for a campaign trip to Providence, R.I.

headline: The Presidential Seal of Approval
text: David Segal writes that despite President Bill Clinton’s fame as a junk-food connoisseur, and his recent health-related conversion to veganism, he is seen around the world as an arbiter of fine dining. A visit from Mr. Clinton seems as a good for business as a star or two from Michelin.

headline: French Unions at Critical Point as Strikes Continue
text: PARIS — The French strikes and demonstrations over a proposed increase in the retirement age have lasted for weeks and attracted wide sympathy in a society whose work force is less than 10 percent unionized. But the proposal will soon become law, setting the stage for confrontations with France’s unions, which continue to starve the country of gasoline, diesel and other petroleum products, and are pressing for demonstrations afterward.

headline: In Yemen, Water Grows Scarcer
text: Increasingly sharp water shortages could cost Yemen 750,000 jobs and slash incomes by as much as 25 percent over the next decade, warns a new report on Yemen, an increasingly troubled Middle Eastern nation.

headline: Light Touch Brings to End a Marathon of Mahler
text: Valery Gergiev and the Mariinsky Orchestra spent the better part of last week working through some of Mahler’s most titanic symphonies  first the Sixth, then the Second, Eighth and Fifth

headline: Difficulties in Defining Errors in Case Against Harvard Researcher
text: The still unresolved case of Marc Hauser, the researcher accused by Harvard of scientific misconduct, points to the painful slowness of the government-university procedure for resolving such charges. It also underscores the difficulty of defining error in a field like animal cognition where inconsistent results are common.

headline: Variety Show, With Arias Thrown In
text: In recent decades Baroque music has been the focus of much debate about authenticity and the importance of historically accurate performances. But in the Baroque era, musicians were far less reverential. In particular, operas known as pasticcios staged in the 17th and 18th centuries were freewheeling hodgepodges, offering fast-paced spectacles of music by several composers, with plot, action and libretto altered at whim. Irrelevant arias might have been thrown into the mix to satisfy the divas on hand.

headline: Using Science to Preserve Art
text: Tuesday's Science Times profiles an art conservator who uses scientific techniques to bring contemporary art back to life.

headline: Practice Gets Group Back to Carnegie
text: The concert the Parker Quartet presented at Weill Recital Hall on Friday was billed as a Carnegie Hall debut, yet anyone with a knowledge of the ensemble’s history might have been struck with a sense of familiarity.

headline: Serving Two Masters: Shariah Law and the Secular State
text: A few weeks ago, the Cardozo School of Law mounted a conference marking the 20th anniversary of Employment Division v. Smith (1990), a case in which the Supreme Court asked what happens when a form of behavior demanded by one’s religion runs up against a generally applicable law — a law not targeted at any particular agenda or point of view — that makes the behavior illegal. (The behavior at issue was the ingestion of peyote at a Native American religious ceremony.) The answer the court gave, with Justice Antonin Scalia writing for the majority, was that the religious believer must yield to the law of the state so long as that law was not passed with the intention of curtailing or regulating his or anyone else’s religious practice. (This is exactly John Locke’s view in his “Letter Concerning Toleration.”)

headline: Testing a Bar Code Technology for Smartphones
text: SHARON BOLTON spotted “those funky tags” — known formally as two-dimensional bar codes — when she took her college-age daughter to catch a train at the Rensselaer rail station near Albany last week.

headline: Return of the Shadow
text: Vikram Pandit, the chief executive of Citigroup, sounded a timely warning today at a New York conference sponsored by The Economist magazine.
