text: Vikram Pandit, the chief executive of Citigroup, sounded a timely warning today at a New York conference sponsored by The Economist magazine.

headline: Texas Is Campaign Issue in California Ads
text: SAN FRANCISCO  In baseball, the San Francisco Giants and the Texas Rangers will meet in the World Series beginning Wednesday. In politics, California and the Lone Star State have been battling for a while.

headline: Silver Lining in F.D.I.C. Deal
Riches May Not Help Papua New Guinea
text: TARI, Papua New Guinea  A founding myth in the Southern Highlands of Papua New Guinea is said to have foretold the arrival of ExxonMobil, the American oil giant that is preparing to extract natural gas here and ship it overseas.

headline: Teenager Known for Hiccups Now Faces a Murder Charge
text: MIAMI  Floridians frequently become famous either for heinous crimes or odd achievements, like building the world’s largest rubber-band ball. Rarely, however, do the two intersect, which is why the Sunshine State marveled on Monday at the fate of Jennifer Mee.

headline: Favre Delivers for NBC, Even if Not for Vikings
text: As Brett Favre led the Minnesota Vikings to a 28-24 loss on Sunday night to the Green Bay Packers, NBC earned a ratings bonanza, easily dominating the night in prime time. Though final audience figures were not available on Monday, preliminary estimates for the game easily exceeded last week’s overnight numbers for “Sunday Night Football,” which drew 19.2 million viewers. NBC said this week’s game posted the third-highest overnight ratings for “Sunday Night Football” on record, just behind a Dallas Cowboys-Washington Redskins game last month that attracted 25.3 million viewers. CBS ranked second over all, its prime-time schedule delayed approximately 15 minutes because of an overrun of its afternoon football coverage. CBS’s “60 Minutes” garnered the network’s most viewers on Sunday, with an audience of roughly 16 million. CBS’s reality competition “The Amazing Race,” and its reality series “Undercover Boss,” followed in the 8 and 9 p.m. hours, drawing audiences between 11 and 12 million viewers each, while “CSI: Miami” ended the night with closer to 10 million. ABC was third with “Desperate Housewives” at 9 (12.2 million) and “Brothers & Sisters” at 10 (8.4 million). Fox finished a distant fourth with reruns of its animated comedies.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,334 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It recently confirmed the deaths of the following Americans:

headline: Making Construction Beautiful in Brooklyn
text: Mauricio Lopez’s “Color Mesh,” one of four designs selected in a recent city competition aimed at beautifying construction sites, had its debut on Monday on a construction fence at Atlantic Yards in Brooklyn, above. The Urbancanvas competition, run by the Department of Buildings and the Department of Cultural Affairs, asked artists to submit designs that could be printed on vinyl or mesh and installed on construction fences, sidewalk sheds and scaffolds. Along with Mr. Lopez, the winning artists were Monika Bravo, Jen Magathan and Corinne Ulmann; each was awarded $7,500. The competition was financed with a $65,000 grant from the Rockefeller Foundation. Developers are to pay for the material and the cost of installing the designs but are allowed to seek sponsorship to offset expenses. While the winners have not been installed anywhere else yet, Robert LiMandri, the department commissioner, said there was interest from two other sites.

headline: Politico, Seeing a Market Need, Adds a Paid News Service
text: To the rapidly growing field of Washington reportage, add one more entrant: Politico Pro.

headline: Former ImClone Chief Acquires Drug Company
text: Samuel D. Waksal, the biotechnology executive whose insider trading landed him and his friend Martha Stewart in prison, is trying to make a comeback.

headline: Latino Immigrants to Sue a Connecticut Police Dept., Asserting Racial Bias
text: When Yadanny García asked police officers in East Haven, Conn., why they were ordering him to the ground, they shocked him three times with a Taser gun, punched him and told him to “go back to your country.”

headline: Navajos Hope to Shift From Coal to Wind and Sun
text: BLUE GAP, Ariz.  For decades, coal has been an economic lifeline for the Navajos, even as mining and power plant emissions dulled the blue skies and sullied the waters of their sprawling reservation.

headline: In Haiti, Rush to Stem the Spread of Cholera
text: The cholera epidemic in Haiti is likely to grow and persist, and will probably reach the Dominican Republic, health officials said on Monday, as they rushed to distribute medical supplies in hopes of keeping ahead of the disease’s spread.

headline: Prison Threat by Killer of Cheshire Family Is Revealed
text: NEW HAVEN  The man convicted of killing three members of a Cheshire family had threatened to kill a prison guard months before his trial began here in September, the jury considering whether to impose the death penalty was told on Monday.

headline: Favre’s Troubles Include Ankle Fractures, and Status Is Uncertain
text: The Minnesota Vikings’ visit to Foxborough, Mass., on Sunday was supposed to revolve around the rather awkward return of receiver Randy Moss to play the New England Patriots, who sent him packing Oct. 6 and whose offense has nonetheless flourished since.

headline: Clinton Battles Repeat of ’94 With Twist on ’08
text: BATTLE CREEK, Mich.  There comes a point about five minutes into Bill Clinton’s standard stump speech when he argues that this campaign is so important that it lured him out of retirement. “I didn’t need to do this,” he said at a stop here over the weekend. “I’m not in politics anymore. I run a big foundation.”

headline: N.C.A.A. Sued Over One-Year Scholarships
text: A former Rice University football player who lost his scholarship for his senior year has filed a class-action lawsuit against the N.C.A.A., arguing that the one-year limit on athletic scholarships amounts to a price-fixing scheme between the association and member universities.

headline: Amazon’s Kindle Sales Are Vague, but Strong
text: Amazon.com is more than happy to shout about the success of its Kindle tablet. But it always does so without disclosing specifics about the number of Kindles actually sold.

headline: Filling the Gap Between Farm and Fair Trade
text: We’ve all seen the ads for fair trade coffee with the beautiful photos of villagers hand picking coffee cherries in exotic regions around the globe. Fair trade is one of those ideas that’s always in the air, but we don’t often consider what it means. What does it really take to connect rural producers in the developing world with consumers in wealthy countries — so that everybody benefits?

headline: An Unlikely Candidacy, Forged by Tragedy
text: If all had gone according to plan, Nicole Paultre Bell, 26, would not be running for City Council to represent a district in southeast Queens. She would be living in Atlanta with her husband, raising their two young daughters, possibly doing some part-time work at a collection agency, as she had in the past, or maybe studying for some kind of degree in health care.

headline: Few Top Women Aides for Paladino or Cuomo
text: Carl P. Paladino has recruited his wife to hit the campaign trail and has put his daughter in a new commercial urging voters to “get to know my dad.” At the same time, Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo has rolled out an advertisement touching on abortion and has ferried his daughters across the state in an RV on a political tour.

headline: Live Analysis: Giants 41, Cowboys 35, Final
text: A 41-35 whipping of the Cowboys on Monday left the Giants looking like perhaps the top team in the National Football Conference. In winning their fourth straight game, the Giants (5-2) claimed sole possession of first place in the N.F.C. East, and they looked the part, despite a sloppy finish that allowed the Cowboys to climb back on the scoreboard.

headline: A Democrat in Idaho Not Hindered by Incumbency
text: MERIDIAN, Idaho  They say this race is an outlier. In one of the most conservative Congressional districts in one of America’s reddest states and amid strong Republican momentum nationwide, a Democrat  and an incumbent at that  may well win.

headline: Help Stop Bullying, U.S. Tells Educators
text: In a 10-page letter to be sent on Tuesday to thousands of school districts and colleges, the Department of Education urges the nation’s educators to ensure that they are complying with their responsibilities to prevent harassment, as laid out in federal laws.

headline: In Bond Frenzy, Investors Bet on Inflation
text: At a time when savers complain that they are earning almost no interest from their bank accounts, some investors on Monday bought United States government bonds that effectively had a negative rate of return.

headline: Shift in Talent Fortifies Elite Teams
text: Three towering figures rise upon a stage, like Roman columns rising from the earth. They are clad all in white, their backs to the audience. Ominous music plays, and smoke shoots skyward.

headline: Police Leader Had Help With Harvard Club Dues
text: Raymond W. Kelly, New York’s police commissioner, can sometimes be found entertaining guests at the Harvard Club, a rarefied spot in Midtown Manhattan whose membership is exclusively for those who have an affiliation with Harvard.

headline: Paladino Wants Tight Budget on Time, or Else
text: Carl P. Paladino promises to sue the federal government to overturn elements of the national health care law, to eliminate state bureaucracies, like the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, that he says are wasting taxpayer money, and to shut down New York’s government if state lawmakers fail to negotiate a budget in a timely fashion.

headline: Democrats Counting on Strength of Obama’s Get-Out-the-Vote Network
text: MAPLE HEIGHTS, Ohio  Democrats have tried improving the political climate, discrediting their Republican opponents and asking Americans for patience in tackling the nation’s challenges, but the party’s best hope of stemming deep losses on Election Day may now rest on loyalty and logistics, not persuasion.

headline: An Unlikely Pairing Bears Fruit in North Korea
text: SEOUL, South Korea  Of all the fantastic tales to come out of North Korea  the country’s leader is injected with the blood of virgin girls, he made 11 holes-in-one during his very first round of golf, each grain of rice he eats is inspected by hand for imperfections, his youngest son and would-be successor has had cosmetic surgery to make him resemble his grandfather  not one of these seems as improbable as the event that took place on Monday, when a science university founded by American evangelical scholars began its first day of classes in Pyongyang, the capital of the secretive Communist state.

headline: Naismith’s Rules of the Game Set to Be Auctioned
text: The first rules of basketball, as set down by Dr. James Naismith, don’t look bad for age 119. The two typewritten pages are yellowed, creased and a bit frayed. A tiny pinhole is visible on one page. Traces of tape that fixed a tear are visible across the top of the other.

headline: With Aging Stars Come Hard Calls
text: The uncomfortable subject of age was front and center Monday when Manager Joe Girardi and General Manager Brian Cashman gave their post-mortems on a season that came crashing down in Texas.

headline: Sylvia Sleigh, Provocative Portraitist and Feminist Artist, Dies at 94
text: Sylvia Sleigh, a British-born artist who put a feminist spin on the portrait genre by painting male nudes in poses that recalled the female subjects of Ingres, Velázquez and Titian, died on Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 94.

headline: Chile Miners Honored by President in Capital
text: SANTIAGO, Chile  They autographed soccer jerseys, received medals and posed with the Phoenix 2 rescue capsule like celebrities. They even battled the government in a friendly soccer match.

headline: Chinese Telecom Giant in Push for U.S. Market
text: SANTA CLARA, Calif.  This spring, an executive from a Chinese telecommunications equipment company made an intriguing job offer to a Silicon Valley software engineer. The Chinese company, Huawei Technologies, wanted to get into the booming market for Internet-based computing, and it had just moved its United States research headquarters here to capture some of the best local talent.

headline: Leo Cullum, New Yorker Cartoonist, Dies at 68
text: Leo Cullum, a cartoonist whose blustering businessmen, clueless doctors, venal lawyers and all-too-human dogs and cats amused readers of The New Yorker for the past 33 years, died on Saturday in Los Angeles. He was 68 and lived in Malibu, Calif.

headline: A Collection of Cullum Cartoons
text: Mr. Cullum, a classic gag cartoonist whose visual absurdities were underlined by captions reeled in from deep left field, published 819 cartoons in The New Yorker.

headline: Iowa on Many Itineraries
text: Are Republican candidates in Iowa suddenly in trouble?

headline: Google Promotes Susan Wojcicki, Advertising Executive
text: Susan Wojcicki, the Google executive who oversees advertising and who also supplied the garage where Google was founded, has been given a promotion.

headline: House Forecast: 8 Days to Go
text: Democratic chances of retaining control of the House are essentially unchanged in today’s FiveThirtyEight forecast. They have a 21 percent chance of doing so, up from 20 percent on Friday; that means Republicans have a 79 percent chance of instead claiming control. The average projection returned a result of 205 Democrats in the House and 230 Republicans, which would reflect a gain of 51 seats for the G.O.P.; this figure is unchanged.

headline: Bloomberg’s Latest on Terms: 3 for Him, but Only 2 for Everyone Else
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg thinks that being able to serve three terms in office is a good idea  just not for anyone else.

headline: A Labor Issue Ensnares ‘The Hobbit’
text: LOS ANGELES  Is Wellywood burning?

headline: Deficit Divisions Likely to Grow After Election
text: WASHINGTON — A midterm campaign that has turned heavily on the issue of the mounting federal debt is likely to yield a government even more split over what to do about it, people in both parties say, with diminished Democrats and reinforced Republicans confronting internal divisions even as they dig in against the other side.

headline: Female Ski Jumpers May Get Bid in 2014
text: Olympic officials announced Monday that they were looking “favorably” at adding women’s ski jumping and other events to the winter program in Sochi, Russia, in 2014, but that they would wait until the sports hold their world championships next year to make their final decision.

headline: In Salon Shootout, an Officer’s Well-Aimed Bullets
text: An off-duty police officer who got into a shootout with an armed robber as the officer was getting her hair done in a beauty salon in Brooklyn on Saturday night shot the gunman’s revolver out of his hands, police officials said on Monday.

headline: For Many, Wars Are Out of Sight, Out of Mind and Out of the Debate
text: Thousands of words were expended Sunday night in the lone debate between Senator Charles E. Schumer and the Republican businessman trying against all odds to defeat him, Jay Townsend. In all the verbiage, neither man found room for two words that you’d think would loom large in a serious discussion of national policy.

headline: Sudan: U.N. Ambassador Faults Arrests
text: The United States ambassador to the United Nations, Susan E. Rice, criticized Sudan on Monday for the “harassment, intimidation and arrests” of at least two Sudanese residents who spoke to Security Council ambassadors touring a camp for the displaced in Darfur this month, calling the arrests “unacceptable.” The Sudanese envoy, Daffa-Alla Elhag Ali Osman, denied that any arrests had occurred. The Security Council is concerned that delayed preparations for the Jan. 9 referendum on independence for Southern Sudan could reignite the fractious nation’s civil conflict.

headline: China: Teachers Sign Petition in Support of Tibetan Language
text: Hundreds of Tibetan schoolteachers signed a petition recently that was sent to the government of Qinghai Province in western China, demanding that schools preserve the use of Tibetan as a main language of instruction. Parts of the petition, which was dated Oct. 15, were put up on a Tibetan blog, www.khabdha.com, on Monday and show that the protests over language policy led by thousands of Tibetan students last week in Qinghai had widespread teacher support. The petition demands that officials follow the Chinese Constitution, including Article Four: “All ethnic groups have the freedom to use and develop their own spoken and written languages and to preserve or reform their own folkways and customs.”

headline: Afghanistan: Dutch Aid Worker and Driver Are Kidnapped on Road
text: A Dutch aid worker and his driver were kidnapped by five armed men on the highway between Takhar and Kunduz Provinces in northern Afghanistan on Monday, a spokesman for Takhar’s governor said. The worker, who was not identified, was with Streams, an organization that helps disabled people in Takhar and was about to close because it lacked funds.

headline: On Legalizing Marijuana
text: The campaign behind the California ballot initiative that would legalize, tax and regulate marijuana has released its first television advertisement, one that seeks to convey a simple message: the current approach is not working.

headline: Minor Parties See Threat in Ballot Quirk
text: Voters in New York cannot vote early, but they can vote often. And because of that, the Conservative and Working Families Parties fear for their very survival after Election Day.

headline: Papua New Guinea Confronts Development
text: ExxonMobil is scheduled to start shipping natural gas through a 450-mile pipeline through the Southern Highlands, the most impoverished region in one of the world’s poorest countries.

headline: An Unorthodox Challenger for an Upstate Senate Seat
text: As political fund-raisers go, this one was short on speeches but long on piano-playing. First, one of the guests, former Senator Alfonse M. D’Amato, tried an amateurish but passable rendition of Debussy’s “Claire de Lune” on a spinet.

headline: Cashman and Girardi Answer for Past Decisions and Yankees’ Future Concerns
text: Still smarting from the Yankees’ performance in a lopsided American League Championship Series, Joe Girardi and Brian Cashman took turns in the Yankee Stadium interview room Monday providing revealing disclosures regarding a pitching staff that crumbled in a six-game loss to Texas.

headline: Gregory Isaacs, Reggae Singer and Songwriter, Dies at 60
text: Gregory Isaacs, reggae’s “Cool Ruler,” whose aching vocals and poignant lyrics about love and loss and ghetto life endeared him to fans of Caribbean music, died on Monday at his home in London. He was 60.

headline: Knicks Add Tequila to Roster of Sponsors
text: The Knicks have signed a marketing agreement with 1800 Silver Tequila, the latest deal between a hard liquor company and an N.B.A. team.

headline: In Alaska Senate Race, Off the Ballot but on the Rise
text: FAIRBANKS, Alaska  The candidate treated like the front-runner in the Alaska Senate race is one not actually on the ballot.

headline: Alex Anderson, Creator of Rocky and Bullwinkle, Dies at 90
text: Alex Anderson, the cartoonist who first drew Rocky the flying squirrel and his buddy, the bumbling moose Bullwinkle, television characters who captivated young baby boomers in the early ’60s, died on Friday in Carmel, Calif. He was 90 and lived in Pebble Beach, Calif.

headline: Sorkin: So What Is Insider Trading?
text: As regulators extend their reach, insider trading is harder to define, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his DealBook column this week.

headline: Tuesday: Event of 10/30/10
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — There is a certain timelessness about typical New York Times crosswords. They eschew topical references for several reasons: there is a long lag between construction and publication, syndicated solvers get the puzzles more than a month after that, and most important, puzzles live long and happy lives well beyond their birth dates. They are collected in books that may be sold many years later.

headline: Stooped and a Bit Slow, but Still Standing Tall
text: Contrary to popular opinion, giants still walk that tired, old corner of the earth called Broadway. Times being what they are, these giants are often penned into cramped quarters, which prevent them from stretching to their full height. But giants of the theater belong to a magnificent species that is fast disappearing. And when one shows up in your neighborhood, you polish your eyeglasses and go for a look.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Constance Reid, Biographer of Mathematicians, Dies at 92
text: Constance Reid, an English teacher who found a second career as a biographer of major 19th- and 20th-century mathematicians, died Oct. 14 at her home in San Francisco. She was 92.

headline: Arizona Democrats on the Defensive
text: In next Tuesday’s election, a number of Democratic members of Congress from Arizona are facing stiff challenges. Voters are listening to both sides at candidate forums and debates.

headline: Thélème Hedge Fund Is Said to Raise Over $700 Million
text: Thélème Partners, a new hedge fund founded by a former Merrill Lynch banker, Patrick Degorce, has raised over $700 million, making it the largest equity hedge fund started since the financial crisis began, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Paladino Says ‘No More Secrets’ in Albany if He’s Governor
text: Nicholas Confessore, a reporter for The New York Times, interviewed the two major candidates for New York governor, Carl P. Paladino and Andrew M. Cuomo, to discuss their approaches to governing. The interview with Mr. Cuomo appeared Monday. Following are edited excerpts from the interview this month with Mr. Paladino; audio excerpts are at nytimes.com/nyregion.

headline: Arizona: Drug Question Holds Up Execution
text: A federal judge has temporarily blocked a convicted murderer’s execution because one of the drugs that would be used is of undisclosed origin. A shortage of the drug, sodium thiopental, has delayed executions in some states; Arizona obtained the drug, but has refused to identify the source, citing state confidentiality laws. Judge Roslyn O. Silver issued a temporary restraining order to stop the execution on Tuesday of Jeffrey Landrigan, saying if the drug came from a source not approved by the Food and Drug Administration, it raises questions of contamination, "efficacy and possible side effects."

headline: G.O.P. Senate Odds Slip on Colorado, West Virginia Polls
text: While Republicans’ position is holding steady in the House — where they are 4:1 favorites to win control of the chamber according to our analysis — their chances of also taking over the Senate declined in today’s forecast. Those chances are now 16 percent, down from 19 percent in our forecast over the weekend.

headline: Not on the Ballot, but Still a Contender in Alaska
text: Lisa Murkowski, the candidate often treated like the front-runner in the Alaska Senate race, happens to be one who is not on the ballot.

headline: Bloggingheads: Jon Stewart’s Power
text: Mark Schmitt, left, of The American Prospect and Timothy Noah of Slate debate the political power of “The Daily Show.”

headline: Governors’ Forecast Moves Toward Democrats in 3 Blue States
text: Democrats have made progress in several states in our latest gubernatorial forecast. Although it remains very probable that Republicans will control the majority of the nation’s governorships after Nov. 2, it is now more likely that Democratic and independent candidates can hold Republicans to victories in 20 to 23 of the 37 contests that will be held on Election Day.

headline: No Second Thoughts
text: When times get tough, it’s really important to believe in yourself. This is something the Democrats have done splendidly this year. The polls have been terrible, and the party may be heading for a historic defeat, but Democrats have done a magnificent job of maintaining their own self-esteem. This is vital, because even if the public doesn’t approve of you, it is important to approve of yourself.

headline: American Songbook Lineup Is Announced
text: Barbara Cook, the longtime interpreter of Stephen Sondheim’s songs; John Doe, the veteran punk rocker; and the mezzo-soprano Stephanie Blythe are among the eclectic mix of performers who will be featured in the 2011 season of Lincoln Center’s American Songbook series, press representatives for Lincoln Center said on Monday. Ms. Cook, who recently appeared in “Sondheim on Sondheim” on Broadway, will open the season, which begins on Jan. 12 at the Allen Room of Frederick P. Rose Hall. Other artists who are to appear in the concert series, which runs through Feb. 20, include the indie-folk band the Low Anthem (Jan. 13); John Doe (Jan. 28); and Ms. Blythe, who will perform songs made popular by Kate Smith (Feb. 16). The lineup also includes Broadway stars like Anika Noni Rose (Feb. 5); Raúl Esparza (Feb. 18) and Kate Baldwin (Feb. 19).

headline: Treasury Hid A.I.G. Loss, Report Says
text: The United States Treasury concealed $40 billion in likely taxpayer losses on the bailout of the American International Group earlier this month, when it abandoned its usual method for valuing investments, according to a report by the special inspector general for the Troubled Asset Relief Program.

headline: The Corrosion of America
text: If you had a leak in your roof or in the kitchen or basement, you’d probably think it a good idea to have it taken care of before matters got worse, and more expensive.

headline: Word of the Day | levitate
text: levitate •\ˈle-və-ˌtat\• verb

headline: The Mortgage Morass
text: The mortgage mess just keeps getting messier. Last week, Bank of America announced that it had performed a “thorough review” of its processes, found nothing amiss and would soon restart 102,000 pending foreclosures. On Sunday, the bank acknowledged that it had in fact found errors in its filings, and would resume foreclosures only in a deliberate manner as new and corrected paperwork was submitted to the courts.

headline: 48th Is Not a Good Place
text: The National Academies, the country’s leading advisory group on science and technology, warned in 2005 that unless the United States improved the quality of math and science education, at all levels, it would continue to lose economic ground to foreign competitors.

headline: Congressional Choices
text: There is no shortage of voter anger out there, and with good reason. But there are races for Congress in New York, and in Connecticut, where rejecting talent and experience makes no sense.

headline: Giants Knock Out Romo and Hold Off Cowboys
text: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Late in the second quarter of a game and a season slipping away from the Dallas Cowboys, the ostentatious video boards hanging over the field  60 yards of enormous, back-to-back heft and clarity  showed a large, shirtless man painted in blue.

headline: Buffett Hires an Outsider to Oversee Investments
text: Warren E. Buffett announced Monday that his company, Berkshire Hathaway, had hired a young hedge fund manager to oversee a “significant portion” of its investment portfolio, adding a new name to the mix of players who are someday expected to take the reins at Berkshire.

headline: Shadows And Fog
text: I’m finding the foreclosure issue difficult to write about; it’s clear that there has been massive malfeasance on the part of the banks (again), but it’s less easy to say what should be done. One thing is clear, however: the main argument being made for turning a blind eye to the situation, and avoiding anything like a temporary freeze on foreclosures, is wrong.

headline: Giants Defeat Cowboys, 41-35.
text: A dangerous Giants offense slid past the Cowboys after quarterback Tony Romo was knocked out of the game with a broken left clavicle.

headline: Maturity Matters
text: A new memo from Goldman Sachs (no link) looks at quantitative easing by treating it as equivalent to a shortening of the maturity of federal debt; among other things, the memo answers the question of where I got it from: work by Jim Hamilton and Cynthia Wu.

headline: Do Investors Expect Too Much From Bernanke?
text: Financial markets seem convinced that quantitative easing will be highly effective at solving at least one problem: inflation running well below the Fed’s 2-percent-or-so target. The chart above shows the difference between interest rates on 5-year inflation-protected bonds (which are now negative) and rates on unprotected bonds; implicitly, the market forecast of inflation over the next five years has risen half a point.

headline: News Quiz | October 26, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: A Roving Sideline Reporter Who Really Roves
text: David Willey is not one to willingly accept a prone position during New York City Marathon weekend, but in 2009 he fought the predicament as long as he could before waving the white flu flag. Some 36 hours before he was to report for duty as an on-course reporter at the race for the third consecutive year, swine flu sucked the broadcast life out of him.

headline: Polartec Said to Seek Buyer
text: Polartec’s parent, Versa Capital Management, is seeking a buyer for the century-old maker of the Polarfleece material, two people with knowledge of the matter told Bloomberg News.

headline: Treasury Hid A.I.G. Loss, Report Says
text: The United States Treasury concealed $40 billion in likely taxpayer losses on the bailout of the American International Group earlier this month, when it abandoned its usual method for valuing investments, according to a report by the special inspector general for the Troubled Asset Relief Program, Mary Williams Walsh reports in The New York Times.

headline: Mortgage Modifications Fell in September
text: Even as banks, borrowers and regulators battle over how much faulty documentation from lenders should impede foreclosures, fresh evidence has arrived that the housing market remained very wobbly, David Streitfeld and Binyamin Appelbaum report in The New York Times.

text: Samuel D. Waksal, the biotechnology executive whose insider trading landed him and his friend Martha Stewart in prison, is trying to make a comeback.

text: A Connecticut hedge fund manager was accused by state and federal regulators on Monday of inflating the value of its holdings, which allowed it to fraudulently collect millions of dollars of undeserved fees, Reuters reports.

headline: UBS Turnaround Advances
text: UBS, the European bank that was hit hardest by the financial crisis, took another step in its turnaround on Tuesday as it reported a third-quarter profit that beat expectations and said the two-year flow of cash out of its private bank had finally stopped, Julia Werdigier reports in The New York Times.

headline: Fannie Halts Foreclosure Work by Florida Firm
text: Fannie Mae, the housing finance giant, has halted mortgage foreclosure work that was previously referred to a Florida law firm now under investigation by state officials, The Wall Street Journal said.

headline: Test Yourself | English, Oct. 26, 2010
text: Test your grammar skills with today’s question, created by Danielle Hoagland and Judith McCaffrey at Grammarlogues from the Times article “An Optimistic Seller of Disaster Plans.”

headline: Bank of America Sues Adviser Starr
text: Bank of America has sued the financial adviser Kenneth Starr, who pleaded guilty to fraud last month, over a $500,000 loan, Reuters reported.

headline: SGX Takeover Of ASX Faces Political Hurdles
text: Singapore Exchange‘s $7.9 billion takeover deal for ASX of Australia faced a new hurdle after prominent political leaders voiced concern about the deal, sending ASX shares down 5.5 percent, Reuters reported.

headline: Chavez to Seize Owens-Illinois Affiliate
text: President Hugo Chavez of Venezuela said on Monday that he was ordering a government takeover of the local unit of the glass manufacturer Owens-Illinois, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: Treasury Sells Negative-Yield Inflation Bonds
text: Inflation-protected securities sold at negative yields for the first time on Monday as traders anticipated that the Federal Reserve would start a new round of asset purchases, Christine Hauser reported in The New York Times.

headline: Joao Silva: ‘Acting Despite Fear’
text: Tuesday, Nov. 16, 6:45 p.m. | Updated

headline: Michelle Obama Deployed in Turnout War
text: Democrats are pulling out all the stops to get their voters to cast ballots early this year. Today, the party’s official apparatus is hoping to convince as many people as possible to change their Twitter icon to an “I voted early” picture.

headline: Foster’s Still Open to Offers for Wine Unit
text: The Australian brewer Foster’s said it had held no further talks with a private equity firm that made a $2.5 billion offer for its wine business in September, Reuters reported.

headline: BankUnited Expected to File for I.P.O. This Week
text: BankUnited, owned by some of the world’s most powerful private equity firms, plans to file for a public offering this week, looking to raise roughly $500 million, Reuters reported, citing two people familiar with the matter.

headline: C.F.T.C. Takes Aim at ‘Runaway Robotic Trades’
text: Computer-generated algorithmic trades have run amok in markets more than once this year, and American regulators should look for ways to hold traders accountable, a top official on the Commodity Futures Trading Commission said on Monday, Reuters reported.

headline: Iran Begins Loading Fuel at Nuclear Reactor
text: TEHRAN  Iran on Tuesday celebrated the start of the process of loading 163 fuel rods into the core of its first nuclear power plant reactor, putting it within months of operation.

headline: U.S. Falls in Annual Corruption Survey
text: PARIS — Perceptions of corruption in the United States have worsened over the past year, knocking it out of the top 20 in global rankings released Tuesday by the watchdog group Transparency International  in Berlin.

headline: Where Would You Like to Get Lost?
text: In the Travel section feature called “Getting Lost,” the travel writer Matt Gross chronicles his experiences with “losing his way all over the globe.” So far, Mr. Gross has gotten lost in Tangier, Morocco, and Ireland. Where would you like to get lost? What do you think you would learn about both the place and yourself?

headline: Dustin Keller’s Guide to Healthy Tailgating
text: When the season starts in August, it just doesn’t feel like football. I know it’s hard to explain, but I think we all know that football feeling in the air. The first few weeks of the season, it still feels like summer. But now that we’re seven weeks in, the air is cooler, the leaves have turned colors, and it just smells and feels like football. I know you know what I mean — when you step outside in the morning and that cool air hits you right away. You just feel like tackling somebody!

headline: Postbank Deal Could Hurt Deutsche Bank’s Profitability

headline: Top Aide to Saddam Hussein Is Sentenced to Death

headline: Buffett Opens Up on Succession Planning
text: Few topics grab investors’ attention than the question of who might succeed Warren E. Buffett as the maestro of Berkshire Hathaway. But on Monday, the Oracle of Omaha himself weighed in on the matter.

text: The Petronas Chemicals Group, the petrochemicals unit of Malaysia’s state oil company, aims to raise between $3.7 billion and $4.2 billion in the Southeast Asian nation’s biggest initial public offering, Bloomberg News reported, citing two people familiar with the matter.

headline: Both Parties Seek Edge in Colorado Senate Race

headline: Does Paul Downs’s Web Site Work?

headline: ‘Mad Men’ for Children (What Would Dr. Edna Say?)

The clever devils at thepoke.co.uk – the satirical British Web site that previously gave us the “Wire”-inspired Monopoly board – have turned their attention to another popular cable series. They’ve designed a series of children’s books that mashes up “Mr. Men,” the adorable, bodyless characters designed by Roger Hargreaves, with “Mad Men,” an AMC period drama you may have read a thing or two about. At their site (which we were pointed to by the good people at The Guardian’s Media Monkey blog), you’ll find covers for books like “Mr. Draper” and “Little Miss Peggy,” and a complete story called “Mr. Sterling Gets Angry.” Enjoy them now before your mom finds out you have an interior life and moves you to a new city.

headline: Now Shopping | Thornwillow at St. Regis

Yet in the century since the property opened its doors, it’s never had a proper shop. That changed last week with the opening of the Thornwillow at St. Regis, an “invisible store” set up in collaboration with the stationer Thornwillow Press, based in Newburgh, N.Y. Founded 25 years ago by Luke Ives Pontifell (at the tender age of 16), the company uses traditional printing techniques to produce a variety of high-end paper goods, including stationery and invitations.

headline: Picking Up the Tab at the Harvard Club
text: Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly has enjoyed an unusual benefit while entertaining guests at the Harvard Club in Midtown Manhattan, an upscale establishment only open to those who, like Mr. Kelly, hold Harvard degrees. Over the past eight years, some or all of Mr. Kelly’s expenses at the club, including dues, drinks and meals, have been paid by the New York City Police Foundation, according to Paul J. Browne, a spokesman for Mr. Kelly. Mr. Browne insisted that the practice was lawful and intended for city business, but that Mr. Kelly may have erred by failing to report the foundation’s payments on his financial disclosure forms by the city’s Conflict of Interest Board. (Also see The Daily News.)

headline: A Date With ‘Density': Lea Thompson on Her ‘Back to the Future’ Experience
text: Think – but not for too long – about the unusual place that Lea Thompson occupies in the iconography of American cinema, all because of the “Back to the Future” movies. As Lorraine (Baines) McFly (Tannen), she is a symbol of 1950s American wholesomeness and the mother-to-be of the time-traveling Marty McFly (played by Michael J. Fox). She is also the hot-to-trot teenager who spurns lovable George McFly (Crispin Glover) for the boy she doesn’t realize is her own offspring. And that’s not even counting the four different future incarnations of the role she plays in “Back to the Future”s I and II, as well as her Old West ancestor, Maggie McFly in Part III.

headline: Arturo O’Farrill to Play in Cuba, His Father’s Homeland
text: The Brooklyn-based pianist and bandleader Arturo O’Farrill announced over the weekend that he would appear at the 26th annual Havana International Plaza Jazz festival, Dec. 16-19. Mr. O’Farrill is the son of Chico O’Farrill, the Cuban-born composer and arranger, who died in 2001. The elder O’Farrill, one of the architects of Afro-Cuban jazz, who collaborated with Charlie Parker, Dizzy Gillespie and others in landmark works of the 1950s like “The Afro-Cuban Jazz Suite” and “The Manteca Suite,” never managed to returned to his homeland after leaving it in 1960. His son, as leader of his father’s old band, the Chico O’Farrill Afro-Cuban Jazz Orchestra, will be playing his father’s music, and more, at the Mella Theater in Havana and in the province of Matanzas. He will also lecture at the Amadeo Roldán conservatory and perform at a children’s class alongside his sons, Zachary and Adam.

headline: Painting at 99, With No Compromises
text: Propelled by a scholarship to the Art Students League, Will Barnet, an aspiring artist with a portfolio heavy on seascapes and family cat portraiture, left Boston for New York City in 1931 with $10 in his pocket. It was summer, it was hot, and besides the Depression-era garbage rotting in the streets, the air was ripe with raucous political protest. He rented a room for a $1 a night, gorged on cheap baked beans at the Automat and started sketching the forlorn and angry faces he saw on every corner. He was 19 and “radicalized” by possibility.

headline: Maker’s Marks
text: ‘‘Hella Jongerius — Misfit,’’ the title of the Dutch designer’s retrospective that opens Nov. 13 at the Museum Boijmans Van Beuningen in Rotterdam, refers not so much to her status in the design world but to the imperfect objects she has long championed. As the exhibition demonstrates, Jongerius has never had trouble finding sympathy for her ideas in the design industry, where companies like Vitra, Ikea and Maharam hired her to introduce beautiful inconsistencies into their sofas, vases and upholstery fabrics. As it turns out, the only people who ever took convincing were the craftspeople themselves. Royal Tichelaar Makkum’s artisans cringed when they were told to fire her 1997 B-Set pottery (above) at too high a temperature, while Nymphenburg’s worried that her 2004 Sketches plates looked half-finished. ‘‘Craft has a tradition of trying to make perfect things,’’ says Louise Schouwenberg, the show’s curator. ‘‘Hella told them to stop trying, because industry can do that better, whereas their appeal is more humane.’’ Jongerius persisted, and these days, evidence of the hand of the maker seems completely natural. The misfits have become the mainstream.

headline: Think Ink
text: Cynics, or perhaps graphic designers, might argue that your average perfume is 99 percent packaging. Maybe more. ‘‘A perfume is an image that you cannot see with your eyes,’’ says Mathias Augustyniak, who, as one half of the design firm M/M (Paris), has worked on scent identities for Balenciaga and Narciso Rodriguez. When he and his partner, Michaël Amzalag, approached Ben Gorham of Byredo Parfums with an idea for a fragrance, they were not following their noses. They gave Gorham three inspirations: a block of solid ink they bought in Korea, a photograph of a Japanese friend who is a calligraphy master and an ‘‘oversized absurd formula’’ that Augustyniak drew with ink on a piece of handmade Korean paper. ‘‘We spoke about ink with Ben, who is properly inked since he’s covered with tattoos, which added a layer of resonance,’’ Amzalag says. The result, M/MINK Eau de Parfum, is represented by a sort of smear campaign — artworks made from existing images, by the photographers Inez van Lamsweerde and Vinoodh Matadin, that Amzalag and Augustyniak obscured with slicks of thick black ink. What the fragrance smells like is even more ambiguous. The artist Wolfgang Tillmans, a friend of the designers, described it to them as ‘‘very manly,’’ while a female friend declared that it reminded her of her grandmother, a comment that left Amzalag wondering if the friend had a manly grandmother. ‘‘To me it feels like a roller coaster ride,’’ he says, ‘‘because it keeps changing once it is on your skin.’’

headline: Losing a Leading Lady While Gaining a New Theatrical Home

Representatives for Ms. LeKae did not immediately reply to a phone message Tuesday. An Arena spokeswoman said that Ms. Gamble was recruited to the show only over the weekend, giving her a few days to prepare for her first performance, on Wednesday, as Laurey, the farm girl courted by the cheery cowboy Curly McClain and brooding hired hand Jud Fry. The role was played on Broadway by Joan Roberts and Christine Andreas, among others, and in the 1955 film version by Shirley Jones.

headline: Keeping Score: Which Players Have Made the Biggest Impact?
text: One of the tenets of sabermetric dogma is that there are no clutch players, only clutch events. Or if there are, the effect is so small as to be meaningless. Over the course of many seasons, you’ll see that almost all of the players perform as well in clutch situations as in normal situations. A particularly rough stretch for a player is probably just a random bad stretch rather than an innate inability to perform under pressure. After all, could you really make it to the major leagues if you couldn’t handle pressure?

headline: Could Bloomberg Make Palin President?
text: As a devout skeptic of both Michael Bloomberg’s presidential ambitions and Sarah Palin’s putative “front-runner” status in the 2012 Republican campaign, I’m naturally completely unconvinced by John Heilemann’s entertainingly bizarre scenario in which Bloomberg runs as an independent in 2012, peels off enough votes and states from Obama to hang the electoral college, and ultimately delivers the White House to Palin. But I’ll confine myself to just one objection. To make his scenario work, Heilemann envisions Bloomberg winning states like New Jersey, New York and Connecticut, behind a combination of moderate Republicans, centrist Democrats and “progressives disappointed with Obama.” In a vacuum, these might be plausible constituencies for Hizzoner — but not in an election where Sarah Palin is the Republican nominee! How many northeastern progressives (or Lincoln Chafee Republicans, for that matter) would contemplate casting a vote for a third-party candidate knowing that it might deliver the White House to the woman they fear and loathe above all others? Not many, I’d say. Nothing would be guaranteed to rally the Obama coalition quite like the specter of a Palin presidency: For months before the election, the drumbeat that “a vote for Bloomberg is a vote for Palin” would be well-nigh deafening, and I’m pretty sure that even a weakened Obama wouldn’t have that much trouble holding serve in that scenario, relegating Bloomberg to exactly the kind of John Anderson-esque performance that would be his most likely fate in any case.

headline: The Bravest, the Finest, the Fastest

A woman told him that a plane had hit one of the World Trade Center towers, and he knew it was a terrorist attack. He continued his run, returning to his starting point at the New York City Fire Academy on Randalls Island. From there he headed downtown, arriving minutes after the second building collapsed.

headline: Glaxo to Pay $750 Million for Sale of Bad Products
text: GlaxoSmithKline, the British drug giant, has agreed to pay $750 million to settle criminal and civil complaints that the company for years knowingly sold contaminated baby ointment and an ineffective antidepressant  the latest in a growing number of whistle-blower lawsuits that drug makers have settled with multimillion-dollar fines.

headline: New York City Board of Elections Chief Fired
text: With Election Day less than a week away, the head of New York City’s embattled Board of Elections was fired on Tuesday after a series of problems with a new computerized voting system and the ballots prepared for the general election.

headline: Introducing Serkan Sarier
text: Serkan Sarier, another promising newcomer to New York’s bustling young designer scene, waited until after all the buzz of the spring collections had died down to introduce his new collection, called Brood. Mr. Sarier held a small presentation in a West Chelsea art gallery Monday evening, showing about a dozen evening dresses in silk taffeta trimmed with zippers and drawstrings,which gave them the look and feel of athletic sportswear, or collapsed parachutes.

headline: Reader Idea | Population Studies With English-Language Learners
text: Here is another in our Great Ideas from Readers series.

headline: Fields Named Knicks Starter
text: Knicks Coach Mike D’Antoni finally chose his fifth starter on Tuesday, and it was not the player that anyone expected a month ago – D’Antoni included.

headline: Rangers’ Gaborik Expects to Start Skating Soon
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Rangers forward Marian Gaborik said Tuesday that he was “happy with the progress” in recovering from the left shoulder separation he sustained in an overtime loss to Toronto on Oct. 15 and that he was on schedule to return to action by mid-November.

headline: Goldman Sells $1.3 Billion in 50-Year Notes
text: In 50 years, Lloyd Blankfein will be 106 years old — and Goldman Sachs‘s new bond issue will mature.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Afghanistan, Haiti and Indonesia.

headline: In Times Square, at Least, Retailing Is Rebounding
text: When the sunglass and sportswear maker Oakley wanted to expand its presence in Manhattan, it leased space last month on a busy corner that was swarming with tourists. To get that space, Oakley is paying $1,375 a square foot — what some luxury retailers paid on Madison Avenue’s choicest blocks before the recession.

headline: Schomburg Center in Harlem Acquires Maya Angelou Archive
text: Maya Angelou’s paper trail includes a rambling, typewritten letter from James Baldwin, dated Nov. 20, 1970, addressed to “Dear, dear Sister” discussing everything from his new book to his feelings about death.

headline: The President Is an Early Voter
text: Michelle Obama, the first lady, is advocating early voting. Her husband has apparently taken her advice.

headline: Commission Approves Historic District in Queens
text: The Landmarks and Preservation Commission celebrated the borough of Queens on Tuesday as it unanimously approved a 210-building historic district in southern Ridgewood and gave landmark status to four buildings in Jamaica: a parish house, a courthouse, a bank building and an office tower.

headline: The Latest From Pino Luongo
text: The location, 420 East 59th Street, has plenty of history. It had been the luxurious Palace, then the first edition of Sandro’s, then Bouterin and, very briefly, it was a Turkish restaurant. Next spring it is to become Morso, a new Italian restaurant from Pino Luongo, the owner and frequent cook at Centolire on the Upper East Side.

headline: On Our Radar: A Panda Baby Boom
text: A record 19 giant pandas have been bred in captivity in China this year, bringing the country’s captive population to around 300, authorities say. The birth of twin female cubs at the Wolong Panda Reserve in Sichuan province last week broke the record of 18 births set in 2006. The giant panda is highly endangered, with only 1,600 thought to remain in the wild. So far, there have been no successful reintroductions of captive-bred pandas to their native habitat. [Sky News]

headline: Foolish Investors Dancing Naked
text: Remember in the late 1990s when everyone was taking cash out of their homes to buy technology stocks?

headline: Ex-Clinton Adviser Raises Millions to Oust Democrats
text: Dick Morris, a Fox News commentator who was an adviser to former President Bill Clinton, has put nearly $1.5 million behind 15 Republican Congressional candidates in the last week, spending more than $1 million on Monday alone.

headline: The Endgame for Alcon and Novartis
text: 10:54 a.m. | Updated It is very likely that we are heading into the endgame in Novartis’s attempt to acquire the remaining 23 percent of the eye care company Alcon that Novartis, the big Swiss drug maker, does not already own. The tea leaves support such a conclusion.

headline: Off the Menu: Carmine Club Cafe
text: Noel Cruz, whose last restaurant venture, Elettaria, with Akhtar Nawab, fell by the wayside, is opening Carmine Club Cafe on Nov. 1. He and his partner, Sam Rivera, have hired Joe Vigorito, formerly at Lupa and dell’Anima, to create a Mediterranean menu for the two-level space that has exposed brick in the ground floor dining room with an open kitchen. Downstairs the menu is the same but it also has a wine cellar.

headline: One Poor Choice in Arming the Afghans, and Its Repercussions
text: The United States military has spent nearly a decade providing weapons to the Afghans it has selected as its allies in the current war. In doing so, it has distributed many tens of thousands of rifles, pistols, machine guns and rocket-propelled grenades.

headline: Shostakovich Quartets as an Intimate Diary
text: When the Pacifica Quartet was appointed quartet in residence at the Metropolitan Museum of Art a year ago, it opted, sensibly, to introduce itself to the Met audience with a season of mixed repertory. But this group has a passion for completeness: its New York performances in recent years have included a Beethoven cycle (in 2007) and the five Elliott Carter quartets (in 2002 and 2008). And now that the introductions are out of the way, it is returning to the immersive programming it prefers. This season is devoted to Shostakovich’s 15 quartets; next season the Pacifica will revisit Beethoven’s works.

headline: The Violent Legacy of a Halloween Prank
text: One Halloween in the Bronx, teenagers threw eggs at a car. The eggs probably cost the boys a few dollars. They cost Karl Jackson his life.

text: Links from around the Web.

headline: Developers’ Effort to Warm a Lobby Leaves Some Cold
text: The developers of a condominium building at 100 11th Avenue in Manhattan got off to a rough start. In excavating the site they hit mud instead of bedrock, which led to long delays; by the time the 54 units were ready for occupancy, the demand for high-end condominiums had softened.

headline: In a Struggle of Wills, Who Is Really the Manipulator?

headline: Stuyvesant Town’s Lenders Take Over Property
text: Lenders formally took control of Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village on Tuesday, ending a four-year odyssey that put the affordable middle-class enclave at the center of both the biggest real estate deal in history and a major financial debacle.

headline: Birth of the Cool | Stella McCartney Kids
text: Perhaps the biggest perk of being a fashion designer is the ability to design not for yourself but for your kids. Just ask Stella McCartney. Not only is she about to bring her fourth child into the world, she’s also about to introduce a new collection specifically for the 12-and-under set. Pieces like cashmere blend pea jackets and floral dresses are designed to be both affordable and timeless, so you don’t have to choose between dressing your child well and sending her to college. And the line even features shrunken versions of pieces from her main collection. Still, McCartney knows that as fashion consumers go, kids are as fickle as anyone.

headline: Art, Fashion, Action | Move at P.S. 1
text: As one of the founders of Visionaire, Cecilia Dean has always encouraged promiscuity between art and fashion. For Move, a two-day performance that opens this weekend at MoMA’s P.S. 1, she teamed up with the writer David Colman to curate a dozen art/fashion mash-ups, including Kalup Linzy and Diane Von Furstenberg, Rob Pruitt and Marc Jacobs, Terence Koh and Italo Zucchelli, Tauba Auerbach and Ohne Titel, Olaf Breuning and Cynthia Rowley, and Brody Condon and Rodarte.

headline: From a Shelter, Parents Fight for a Comatose Son

headline: Once Tough Guy, Now Nurturer
text: “What the hell is happening now?” James Gandolfini asked, not quite smiling, at the start of an interview last week. Mr. Gandolfini is not big on interviews; journalists who mention his most famous role, playing the mob boss Tony Soprano, get swatted away. “I never think about him, ever,” Mr. Gandolfini, 49, said.

headline: E-Mail Spam Falls After Russian Crackdown
text: MOSCOW  You may not have noticed, but since late last month, the world supply of Viagra ads and other e-mail spam has dropped by an estimated one-fifth. With 200 billion spam messages in circulation each day, there is still plenty to go around.

headline: Navajos Come to Grips With Coal Mining
text: For many of the nation’s American Indian tribes, green energy offers a new economic path benefiting from the Obama administration’s emphasis on energy and economic initiatives on reservations. Yet that path is stirring great debate within reservations, exposing how conflicted many Indians feel about coal mining, a huge source of both revenue and environmental degradation.

headline: Job Losses Outweigh Obama’s Successes
text: On the evening of Dec. 3 last year, the Bureau of Labor Statistics sent an advance copy of the next morning’s jobs report to the White House. It’s standard procedure for top White House and Federal Reserve officials to get an early look at the numbers, but there was nothing standard about this particular report.

headline: Graffiti of New York’s Past, Revived and Remade
text: Anyone who has been lost in the last few weeks around the southern reaches of the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn could be excused for experiencing a powerful Koch administration flashback. On the wall of a brick warehouse there, visible from the parking lot of a furniture store, a huge mural unfurls itself, a loving, seemingly spray-by-spray re-creation of one of the more infamous pieces of graffiti ever to ride the subway: a 1980 work by the artist known as Seen that covered the length of a No. 6 train car with the ominous phrase “Hand of Doom.”

headline: Study Finds Street Stops by N.Y. Police Unjustified
text: Tens of thousands of times over six years, the police stopped and questioned people on New York City streets without the legal justification for doing so, a new study says.

headline: North Dakota Incumbent Reintroduces Himself
text: Representative Earl Pomeroy is introducing himself to North Dakota’s voters — and telling them who he is not.

text: COIMBATORE, India  As talk of currency battles rumble through the global economy, India has been a reluctant warrior.

headline: UBS Private Bank, in Reversal, Is Attracting Cash Again
text: LONDON  UBS said on Tuesday that it had reversed a two-year outflow of cash from its private bank in the third quarter, but the shares dropped after the Swiss bank reported that its investment banking division had returned to a quarterly loss.

headline: New Claims of Wrongdoing in Cable Fight
text: In the latest escalation in the battle that has left 3 million viewers without Fox programming, News Corporation Tuesday accused Cablevision of directing subscribers unhappy that they might not be able to see the World Series to illegal Web sites carrying the signals of the Fox network.

headline: Horman Family Pickles Go Retail
text: Nick Horman Jr. took his family pickle business retail. His grandfather, father and uncle all made crisp classic pickles sold in bulk to delis and restaurants, and for private-label packing. But the younger Mr. Horman (at right, with his father), fresh out of college about eight years ago, started peddling the pickles at farmers’ markets and fairs, in plastic containers. Now, Allen Pickle Works in Glen Cove, N.Y., the family company, is packing the pickles in quart jars, which are being sold in stores for the first time. They are cold-cured with whole spices, garlic, peppers and the like. The refrigerated shelf-life is three months (each jar has a date).

headline: Some Halloween Treats to Save for the Grown-Ups
text: Little white-chocolate ghosts filled with gianduja ganache by Larry Burdick are not for dumping into the bags of the Snickers and Reese’s crowd. Save them for the grown-ups to nibble after dinner. Same goes for the sleek black coffin filled with an assortment of Burdick treats, including a few of the ghosts.

headline: A Rustic but Refined Bottle Opener
text: What better way to open that bottle of locally micro-brewed artisanal beer than with this rustic-looking bottle opener? A block of walnut is fitted with a bent nail, with enough of a head and the correct distance to lever up the bottle cap.

headline: With a Double Bill, a Return to Rarities
text: The stars were out in force at Carnegie Hall as the Opera Orchestra of New York opened its 40th-anniversary season with a gala double bill on Monday night. Not so long ago, the chances that this landmark might be reached seemed slim indeed. Facing financial difficulties in 2008, the orchestra suspended its long-running tradition of presenting operatic rarities in full concert performances. Since then, it has maintained a slighter profile with recitals.

headline: Lotus of Siam, a Vegas Hit, Opening in Manhattan
text: LOTUS OF SIAM, a superlative-drenched Thai restaurant in Las Vegas, has been hiding in plain sight in New York for weeks.

headline: Verjuice Makes Sour Grapes a Good Thing
text: LET’S not stereotype power ingredients. They don’t have to be brash  a gentle touch can liven up your cooking just as nicely. And they don’t always have to swirl up from “exotic” cuisines. Even the familiar larder of provincial France can be a source.

headline: Thoughts vs. Actions
text: Christina Romer, whom I mention in this week’s column, was among those White House officials who was most aggressive in arguing for more stimulus.

headline: Judge Tells LimeWire, the File-Trading Service, to Disable Its Software
text: A federal judge in New York issued an injunction on Tuesday that will essentially shut down LimeWire, the big music file-sharing service that has been mired in a four-year legal struggle with the music industry. The company and its founder have already been being found liable for potentially hundreds of millions of dollars in damages.

headline: The Sweet Science of German Rieslings
text: DESPITE endless efforts to explain, simplify and demystify, the riddle of German wines endures. Confronted with the bewildering nomenclature of so many German wine labels, many people simply shake their heads in confusion and give up. Rather than add to the babble, today we concede straight out that understanding German wines is hellishly difficult.

headline: Jazz With Updates on the Past and Eyes on the Future
text: The music of Horace Silver doesn’t exactly beg for reinvention. His compositions  especially those made famous from the mid-1950s through the mid-60s, when he was the high-spirited skipper of hard bop  come prefitted with guideposts and grace notes, an array of breezy embellishments that turn out to be essential. These are songs of brisk efficiency and elegant simplicity. You wouldn’t want to mess any of that up.

headline: A Musician Who Imparts a Glum Kind of Grandeur
text: In her director’s statement for “Strange Powers: Stephin Merritt and the Magnetic Fields,” Gail O’Hara writes that “this one’s for the fans.” Rarely has that been more true. If you respond to the morose grandeur of Mr. Merritt’s music or are drawn to his downtown gay-bard persona — owlish yet waspish — then it’s likely that you’ll be engrossed by this documentary, directed by Ms. O’Hara and Kerthy Fix, which was more than a decade in the making and is sometimes uncomfortably intimate. If not, you might be better off picking up that Keith Richards memoir.

headline: Warhol Board Lawsuit Is Finally Dropped
text: A long-running lawsuit charging the Andy Warhol Foundation and the board that authenticates Warhol’s work with fraud and other misconduct is over, the Web site Artinfo.com reported. Joe Simon-Whelan, a filmmaker who bought a silk-screen Warhol self-portrait in 1989 only to see it later declared inauthentic on two occasions by the board, contended in the suit that the foundation and board had conducted a 20-year conspiracy to inflate the prices for Warhol works by denying the authenticity of a certain number as a way to create artificial scarcity. The board and foundation have denied the accusations. Mr. Simon-Whelan told Artinfo that he had decided to abandon the case because he lacked the money to pursue it. The foundation’s lawyers issued a statement saying that Mr. Simon-Whelan had dropped the suit because “Mr. Simon-Whelan and his lawyers have utterly failed to uncover a single shred of evidence to support” his allegations after more than three years of litigation.

headline: Saudi Border With Yemen Is Still Inviting for Al Qaeda
text: ON THE SAUDI-YEMENI BORDER  The five Yemeni men, all of them rail-thin, clutched their knees as they sat staring across the sand at the narrow road, which separates the Arab world’s poorest country from its richest.

headline: The Caucus Click: Atlanta
text: Georgi Chester of College Park, Ga., cast her ballot during early voting in Atlanta on Tuesday.

headline: When Sweet Wines Belong
text: It may be an old wine industry cliché, but there remains truth in the saying, “Americans talk dry but drink sweet.” That is the reason that the best-selling mass-market chardonnays tend to have a little residual sugar to them, and that Moet & Chandon, the big Champagne house, adds extra sweetness to its White Star Champagne, which is made especially for the American market.

headline: Needing Students, Maine School Hunts in China
text: MILLINOCKET, Me.  Faced with dropping enrollment and revenue, the high school in this remote Maine town has fixed on an unlikely source of salvation: Chinese teenagers.

headline: Carriers of the Torch, in a Chorus of Red Hair
text: LAST June, in the middle of her “Last Girl on Earth” tour, the R & B pop diva Rihanna strutted onto the Rock in Rio stage outside Madrid with the sides of her head shaved and a bowl cut of hair dyed matador red  the color of blood and passion and showmanship. Since then, Rihanna’s red has evolved further, from a voluminous Elmo-red wig while shooting the “What’s My Name” video on the Lower East Side in September to fire-engine-hued extensions during Paris Fashion Week this month.

headline: Versa Is Said to Seek a Buyer for Polarfleece Maker
text: Versa Capital Management, the owner of Polartec, the century-old maker of the Polarfleece material, is seeking a buyer for the company, Bloomberg News reports, citing two people with knowledge of the matter.

headline: Jets’ Jenkins May Be Hobbled, but Vows to Play On
text: Days after knee surgery, Kris Jenkins stopped three times because of a rapidly deflating tire on the drive from New Jersey to Washington to see his agent. Imagine a 6-foot-4-inch, 360-ish-pound nose tackle on crutches, fiddling with an air hose next to his BMW.

text: SAN FRANCISCO  Carly Fiorina, the former Hewlett-Packard chief executive who is the Republican nominee for the Senate from California, was hospitalized Tuesday in Los Angeles with an infection stemming from reconstructive breast surgery she had in July, her campaign said.

headline: Rabbit Ears Redux
text: Since television extended its reach from coast to coast in its early days, the properly equipped baseball fan was not likely to miss the World Series. Those rabbit ears or roof antennas had to be tilted the right way. And the reception might have been snowy. But no dispute between giant news media companies was going to thwart the fan from watching the Series.

headline: Q. and A. With Samira Kawash of Candy Professor
text: In this week’s Dining section, Julia Moskin writes about Samira Kawash, right, who has made a study of the American relationship with candy through history on her blog, Candy Professor. “The big idea behind Candy Professor is that candy carries so much moral and ethical baggage that people view it as fundamentally different — in a bad way — from other kinds of food,” Ms. Moskin writes.

headline: Tonight’s House Forecast: 52-Seat Gain For G.O.P.
text: If Democrats were hoping for a late surge to improve their chances of retaining control of the House, there isn’t any evidence of it yet. Instead, Republicans have generally had the better of the polls in individual House districts released in the past 24 hours.

text: Volunteers at Organizing for America, a phone bank in Manhattan, called voters before Vice President Joseph R. Biden made a visit.

headline: Giants Go From Finished to N.F.C. Front-Runners
text: The Giants returned home for their bye week a confident bunch after demolishing the Dallas Cowboys, the preseason darlings, Monday night and making their case as the best team in the National Football Conference.

headline: A Banner Year for Political Spending
text: With $188 million spent by and for Democrats and $178 million by and for Republicans, this election cycle will be one of the most expensive in Congressional history.

headline: The Last Two Years, in Historical Context
text: For someone judging the Obama administration’s first two years of policy making, the biggest black mark would be the current state of the economy. The administration — along with the Federal Reserve — succeeded in breaking the back of a huge financial crisis. But the administration — and, again, the Fed — also turned too timid this year. That timidity seems all but certain to cost the Democrats next week.

headline: Developers Wage Battle Over a Tower Deemed Ugly
text: From his office at Time Warner Center, the developer Stephen M. Ross looked directly across Columbus Circle to a nearly vacant, financially troubled and, in his view, ugly, 26-story building. This being New York, where real estate is often a blood sport, he decided to do something about it. His firm, Related Companies, bought the $250 million mortgage on the property in September, intending to foreclose on the owner, demolish the building and erect a sleek skyscraper slightly taller than his 750-foot, two-towered Time Warner Center.

headline: Cablevision Asks for F.C.C.-Run Meeting With Fox
text: The president of the Cablevision Corporation has asked the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission to hold a meeting in his office with the top executive from News Corporation in an effort to find a last-minute solution that could solve the fee dispute that threatens to leave 3 million Cablevision subscribers unable to see the World Series, which begins Wednesday night.
