text: By THOMAS KAPLAN

headline: Pre-emptive Charges of Bias in a City-Financed Wage Study
text: Advocates for workers plan to charge on Wednesday that a New York City-financed study is likely to conclude falsely that more harm than good would come from mandating higher minimum wages for employees of companies that receive city subsidizes.

headline: Adviser to Consumer Agency Had Role in Lending
text: WASHINGTON  A senior adviser to Elizabeth Warren, hired to help start the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, is an investor in and, until recently, served as a director of a company that helps to arrange low-documentation loans for consumers with often-spotty credit histories.

headline: Islamophobia and Homophobia
text: As if we needed more evidence of America’s political polarization, last week Juan Williams gave the nation a Rorschach test. Williams said he gets scared when people in “Muslim garb” board a plane he’s on, and he promptly got (a) fired by NPR and (b) rewarded by Fox News with a big contract.

headline: A Feast of Innards Nourishes French Nostalgia
text: LIMOGES, France — While the French may be renowned for their refined culinary tastes, they have another side. It was on full display this month in this city in central France known for its expensive porcelain but with another side of its own.

headline: Gorbachev Says Putin Obstructs Democracy
text: MOSCOW — Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who once supported Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin, is voicing growing frustration with Mr. Putin’s leadership, saying that he had undermined Russia’s fledgling democracy by crippling the opposition forces.

headline: Lincecum and Lee Are Two of a Kind
text: SAN FRANCISCO

headline: Secret Money in Iowa
text: Bruce Braley, a Democrat from northeastern Iowa, has been a popular two-term congressman and seemed likely to have an easy re-election until the huge cash mudslide of 2010. The Republican Party had largely left him alone, but then a secretive group called the American Future Fund began spending hundreds of thousands of dollars on distortion-heavy attack ads.

headline: Former City Resident Is Accused of Trying to Join Terrorists
text: A former Staten Island man who prosecutors said made repeated attempts to join the Taliban and other extremist groups overseas, even though he apparently knew that federal agents were closely watching him, has been charged with making false statements in a terrorism case, the authorities said Tuesday.

headline: Haiti’s Latest Misery
text: The cholera outbreak in Haiti  the first in 50 years  has layered fresh anxiety atop long-standing misery. By Tuesday the disease had sickened more than 3,000 people and killed more than 250. While the authorities have expressed cautious hope that the outbreak might soon stabilize and remain largely confined to the rural Artibonite region, there is still fear that the disease could overwhelm the shattered capital, Port-au-Prince.

headline: Flu Vaccine, Then and Now
text: Last year many Americans, fearful of a new swine flu virus, clamored for vaccines that were often hard to find or even unavailable in their area. This year there should be plenty of vaccine for everyone who wants it.

headline: San Francisco Becomes an October Baseball Town
text: San Francisco

headline: The Movie Isn’t Even Out, But Producer Eyes Stage Version of  ‘The King’s Speech’
text: If the highly anticipated Colin Firth film “The King’s Speech” performs well this awards season, chances are a stage version will come about relatively quickly on Broadway, in London’s West End, or both.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Moose and Squirrel
text: In the Wayback Machine, it’s a very short trip to 1959 and the debut of “Rocky and His Friends” — the cartoon series featuring characters originated by Alex Anderson. Mr. Anderson died Friday at the age of 90 after a life spent mostly in advertising.

headline: In California, an Encounter 2 Candidates Had Avoided
text: LONG BEACH, Calif.  With less than a week until Election Day, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger of California has become a chunk of kryptonite that the candidates to succeed him lob at each other. But even as the candidates, Meg Whitman and Jerry Brown, scrambled to distance themselves from the governor, they shared a stage with him on Tuesday for the first time this election cycle.

headline: Knicks Reach Out, Seeking a Connection to Disillusioned Fans
text: MAYBE, as the saying goes, it is a cliché because it is true. For instance, to prove the veracity of “Hope springs eternal,” consider that the New York Knicks are introducing on Wednesday a campaign to stimulate interest in the team for the 2010-11 season.

headline: Nets’ Top Attraction May Be Prokhorov
text: The Knicks have had a lot of reason to cheer Timofey Mozgov, their new Russian center who had an impressive preseason and figures to play a prominent role on the team this season.

headline: Fed Won’t Join Appeal to Keep Its Loans Secret
text: The Federal Reserve will not join a group of leading commercial banks in asking the Supreme Court to allow the government to withhold details of emergency loans made to financial companies in 2008.

headline: Polls Show Wider Boxer Lead, Narrowing G.O.P. Takeover Path
text: We have been noting for several weeks that, with Republican chances having dwindled from slim to virtually none in a few East Coast Senate contests like Connecticut, Delaware, and the New York special election, their prospects of the party winning a 51st Senate seat on Nov. 2 instead boiled down to winning either California or Washington (while sweeping the other competitive contests). Today, they have gotten bad news in one of those races.

headline: Turning the Taliban Against Al Qaeda
text: FOR the last week there have been widespread news reports that NATO is facilitating talks between the Afghan government and Taliban leaders, even as it routs Taliban forces from their main stronghold in Kandahar. The United States plan seems clear: allow for “preliminary” talks to end the war through a broad-based “reconciliation” process, but don’t get serious about a deal until beefed-up coalition forces have gained the initiative on the battlefield.

headline: Can’t Keep a Bad Idea Down
text: I confess, I find it dispiriting to read the polls and see candidates, mostly Republicans, leading in various midterm races while promoting many of the very same ideas that got us into this mess. Am I hearing right?

headline: Officer in Salon Shootout Is Promoted to Detective
text: The officer who engaged in a shootout with a man who tried to hold up a Brooklyn beauty salon was promoted to detective on Tuesday at City Hall in a ceremony presided over by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly.

headline: Fox TV Blackout Tests Old Giants Fans’ Ingenuity
text: Among old-time baseball fans in New York, rooting for the Giants always required a bit of resilience and resourcefulness. The Giants faithful were outnumbered by Yankees fans, and dwarfed at least in spirit by Dodgers loyalists.

headline: Charges Dropped Against 3 in Bronx Antigay Attacks
text: Citing insufficient evidence, the Bronx district attorney’s office on Tuesday dropped charges against 3 of the 11 young men accused of kidnapping, torturing and sexually assaulting three men who they thought were gay.

headline: Lee’s Wife Is No Fan of Yankee Stadium
text: SAN FRANCISCO — When the millions start piling up at the negotiating table this winter, the behavior of a few rowdy Yankees fans will probably make no difference to Cliff Lee, the Texas Rangers’ ace and a pending free agent. But Lee’s wife, Kristen, was disturbed by the fans at Yankee Stadium during Game 3 of the American League Championship Series last week.

headline: Wednesday: Makes Less Than a Killing
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Bram Stoker’s title character from his 1897 novel simply refuses to die. I guess that’s appropriate. Every generation reinvents him to fit its needs. Teenagers today have a descendant out in twilit Forks, Wash. — a virginal vampire with sparkly skin. Even the thinly veiled eroticism remains.

headline: Four Seven Whiskey, We’ve Got a Problem: A Controller’s Life in a Tailspin
text: A spatter of weird jargon comes thick and fast in the opening minutes of “Spirit Control,” a new play by Beau Willimon that opened on Tuesday at City Center in a Manhattan Theater Club production.

headline: Another Long and Winding Detour
text: Another boomer theme park ride has been installed on Broadway, conveniently just opposite the peppy musical about those crooners from New Jersey. “Rain: A Tribute to the Beatles on Broadway,” a tricked-up cover band concert that opened on Tuesday night at the Neil Simon Theater, gives audiences a chance to sing along, twist and shout, and generally make like swooning teenyboppers from the 1960s as the hits roll by and the endorphins kick in.

headline: In Far Over Their Heads: Life at the Pool’s Bottom
text: There they fester on the floor of that empty swimming pool, four men in Speedos, past their prime. Once they were legion, but they have dwindled to these lucky (or unlucky) few, and their days pass in a blur of sun-bleached sameness. Yet after 20 years, they remain gripped by the same fever of anticipation. They are waiting — hold for it — for Odysseus.

headline: Prosecuting the State’s Business
text: ENVIRONMENTAL CASES Upholding a tradition that goes back to the days when Attorney General Robert Abrams made it his business to clean up the Love Canal toxic waste site, Andrew M. Cuomo has displayed sharp elbows when it comes to environmental protection. He filed lawsuits against the Bush administration’s Environmental Protection Agency over global warming and American Electric Power, the nation’s largest power producer, when emissions from its Midwestern plants were blowing into New York. Just as telling are the less glamorous cases he brought forcing operators of mobile home parks to fix conditions that were imperiling the health of residents.

headline: A Republican Leader Visits a Democratic Stronghold
text: There was an unusual sight in Harlem on Tuesday. A bright red tour bus pulled up outside a restaurant on Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard. The words “Fire Pelosi” were written on the side, and the man who stepped out from the bus was Michael Steele, the chairman of the Republican National Committee.

headline: Recovery Going Well, Rangers’ Gaborik Expects to Start Skating Soon
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Rangers forward Marian Gaborik said Tuesday that he was “happy with the progress” in recovering from the left shoulder separation he sustained in an overtime loss to Toronto on Oct. 15 and that he was on schedule to return to action by mid-November.

headline: A Painter Forges Ahead
text: Will Barnet makes no concessions to age or anything else.

headline: A Volcano Erupts in Indonesia
text: As Indonesian rescue workers sought survivors of a tsunami off Sumatra, Mount Merapi erupted in Java, sending thousands fleeing for their lives.

headline: Candid Talks by Detainee Were Caught on U.S. Tapes
text: Ahmed Khalfan Ghailani, the former Guantánamo detainee now on trial in Federal District Court in Manhattan, has been interrogated repeatedly over the years: by the Central Intelligence Agency, by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and by the Defense Department.

headline: Mixed Views on Cuomo as Attorney General
text: The letter arrived in the New York State attorney general’s office in late 2006  a desperate note from a woman in Yonkers with ovarian cancer. Her health insurer’s reimbursements were so inexplicably low she was drowning in unexpected bills.

headline: F.C.C. Tells Cablevision: Fewer Stunts, More Talks
text: Cablevision Systems on Tuesday tried a new tactic to get the government to intervene in its dispute with the News Corporation, which is threatening to prevent three million homes from seeing the World Series starting Wednesday night. But the effort met with a swift and stinging rebuke from a senior Federal Communications Commission official, who dismissed the move as a stunt.

headline: Expand the Playoff Field? No Thanks
text: SAN FRANCISCO – The last time the World Series was here, in 2002, both teams were wild-card entrants into the postseason. The Angels beat the Giants in a riveting seven-game series, the last World Series to go to the final game. Eight years later, no one seems to care that neither team finished in first place.

headline: Democrats Retain Edge in Campaign Spending
text: Lost in all of the attention paid to the heavy spending by Republican-oriented independent groups in this year’s midterm elections is that Democratic candidates have generally wielded a significant head-to-head financial advantage over their Republican opponents in individual competitive races.

headline: When a Pirate Is the Voice of Chivalry
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Lobbyists Court Potential Stars of House Panels
text: WASHINGTON — Ernst & Young, the global accounting firm, hosted a fund-raising breakfast late last month for Representative Dave Camp that drew so many donors the firm’s lobbyists had to pull extra chairs into their largest conference room.

headline: A Budget Travel Pioneer in a Time When $5 a Day Was Real (Frugal) Money
text: It was the first handwritten letter I’d received in 5 years. Or maybe 10. Signed by John Wilcock, a man I’d never heard of, and postmarked Ojai, Calif., it was waiting for me when I returned from my São Paulo-to-New York summer trip. Mr. Wilcock wrote that he had been an assistant editor at The Times Travel section back in the 1950s, and had written the first editions of “Mexico on $5 a Day,” “Greece on $5 a Day” and “Japan on $5 a Day” for Arthur Frommer in the 1960s.

headline: Mets Could Name Alderson G.M. on Friday
text: The Mets’ top three owners met with Sandy Alderson at Citi Field Tuesday, and all indications continue to point to Alderson being named the team’s next general manager, perhaps as soon as Friday.

headline: Knicks’ Secret Workouts Violated Rules, Report Says
text: On the eve of a promising new season, the Knicks were again confronted with the mayhem of their recent past and the possible misdeeds of the previous administration.

headline: Big Man in Little Odessa
text: The Sunday shoppers at the St. Petersburg Trade and Publishing House hardly noticed the remarkably tall man flipping through compact discs. The old men playing cards by the boardwalk never looked up.

headline: Small Efforts Add Up in Colorado Senate Race
text: COLORADO SPRINGS  The Senate race in Colorado has seen as intense a barrage of television attack ads as any race in the country, tens of millions of dollars worth, numbing voters with the din.

headline: Health Care Vote Puts Democrats on Defensive
text: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. — At the start of their debate here last week, the Republican challenger for Congress, State Senator Robert Hurt, paused only long enough to thank the League of Women Voters before ripping into Representative Tom Perriello for voting for “government-run health care.” Mr. Hurt returned to the topic seven times over the next hour, despite being asked only once.

headline: Bloggingheads: A Witch in the Senate?
text: Michelle Goldberg, left, of The Daily Beast and Jeff Sharlet, author of "C Street," debate Christine O'Donnell's remarks about witchcraft.

headline: Caffeine and Alcohol Drink Is Potent Mix for Young
text: Mixing alcohol and caffeine is hardly a new concept, but a rash of cases involving students and others who landed at hospitals after drinking beverages that combine the two in a single large can has alarmed college and health officials around the country.

headline: A Mix Attractive to Students and Partygoers
text: It has long vexed club-hoppers and partygoers: how do you stay awake while drinking alcohol late into the night?

headline: Corrections
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Toxic Metals Tied to Work in Prisons
text: Inmates and employees at 10 federal prisons were exposed to toxic metals and other hazardous substances while processing electronic waste for recycling, a four-year investigation by the Justice Department’s inspector general found.

headline: Knicks’ Mozgov Tours Russian Enclave in New York
text: The Knicks rookie Timofey Mozgov finds some familiarity in a visit to Brighton Beach.

headline: Phys Ed: Do Cortisone Shots Actually Make Things Worse?
text: In the late 1940s, the steroid cortisone, an anti-inflammatory drug, was first synthesized and hailed as a landmark. It soon became a safe, reliable means to treat the pain and inflammation associated with sports injuries (as well as other conditions). Cortisone shots became one of the preferred treatments for overuse injuries of tendons, like tennis elbow or an aching Achilles, which had been notoriously resistant to treatment. The shots were quite effective, providing rapid relief of pain.

headline: Model Now Has Whitman as Big Underdog in California
text: While there was an interesting set of polls in Senate and U.S. House races today, the polling load was lighter in gubernatorial contests, with most surveys confirming current assumptions about the races.

headline: Word of the Day | fleck
text: fleck •\ˈflek\• noun and verb

headline: 3 Are Wounded in a Shooting on a Lower East Side Street
text: Three people were shot when a gunman, apparently upset over an argument with at least one of his victims, opened fire on a Lower East Side street Tuesday night, the police said.

headline: Alaska Senate Candidate Once Disciplined for Computer Misuse
text: Joe Miller, the Republican Senate candidate from Alaska, was disciplined for using three co-workers’ computers for political purposes and initially lying about it when he worked as a part-time lawyer for the Fairbanks North Star Borough in 2008, personnel records released on Tuesday under a court order showed.

headline: Buyout Keeps Plan Alive for Maryland Nuclear Plant
text: A compromise intended to preserve the possibility of building a nuclear plant in Maryland was announced late Tuesday by Constellation Energy, the Baltimore-based company that had given up on the project, and Électricité de France, which wants to proceed.

headline: Anbar Province, Once a Hotbed of Iraqi Insurgency, Demands a Say on Resources
text: RAMADI, Iraq  As Iraq’s political blocs remain unable to form a national government, lawmakers and residents here in Anbar Province are challenging central control of the natural resources within their territory.

headline: S. Neil Fujita, Innovative Graphic Designer, Dies at 89
text: S. Neil Fujita, a graphic designer who used avant-garde painting and photography to create some of the most striking album covers of the 1950s, and who designed the visually arresting book jackets for “In Cold Blood” and “The Godfather,” died on Saturday in Greenport, on the North Fork of Long Island. He was 89.

headline: Indonesia Struggles After Tsunami and Volcano
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Indonesia moved to count the costs and help survivors on Wednesday after a tsunami and volcanic eruptions struck separate parts of the country, killing at least 340 people and driving tens of thousands from their homes.

headline: Lamont Johnson, Emmy-Winning Director, Dies at 88
text: Lamont Johnson, an Emmy-winning television director known for bringing an understated touch to delicate subjects, died on Sunday at his home in Monterey, Calif. He was 88.

headline: Brazil: Conviction in 2006 Plane Crash Over Amazon
text: An air traffic controller, Jomarcelo Fernandes dos Santos, has been convicted of a crime equivalent to manslaughter and sentenced to 14 months in prison in connection with the crash of a Gol Airlines flight that killed 154 people over the Amazon in 2006, Brazilian news media reported on Tuesday. Four other controllers were acquitted, the reports said. Mr. dos Santos remains free pending appeal. He and the other four controllers were on duty when the Gol Boeing 737-800 collided with a private Legacy jet flown by two pilots from Long Island. The Gol plane crashed into the jungle, killing everyone on board.

headline: Assembly Again Urges U.S. to Lift Cuba Embargo
text: The annual General Assembly resolution calling for the United States to lift its longstanding economic embargo against Cuba passed by the lopsided vote of 187 to 2. Only the United States and Israel opposed the nonbinding measure, the 19th such resolution in a row, while three Pacific island allies of Washington abstained. The Cuban foreign minister, Bruno Rodríguez Parrilla, accused President Obama of promising to change relations with Cuba but falling under the thrall of the exile community in the United States. In response, the United States said that it had expanded trade and other ties with the Caribbean nation but that improved relations hinged on greater domestic freedom.

headline: Arizona: Court Upholds Stay on Execution
text: A federal appeals court on Tuesday upheld a decision blocking the execution of an Arizona inmate because of questions about the quality of one of the drugs that would be used. A three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit upheld the order from Judge Roslyn O. Silver, who demanded information about the origins of the drug, sodium thiopental, in order to know whether there were risks of impurity or efficacy that could cause undue pain and suffering to the inmate, Jeffrey Landrigan. Arizona’s attorney general has stated that the drug came from England, but has not identified the maker or explained how it obtained the drug. Late Tuesday, the full appeals court refused to rehear the case.

headline: Arizona: Citizenship Proof For Voting Is Struck Down
text: A three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit struck down a state law that requires people to provide proof of American citizenship to register to vote, saying the law conflicts with the federal National Voter Registration Act. Nina Perales, national senior counsel for the Mexican American Legal Defense and Educational Fund, said that few illegal immigrants tried to register, but that 30,000 citizens had been rejected for registration under the law, which voters passed in 2004.

headline: Pennsylvania: Governor Bans More Gas Development
text: Gov. Edward G. Rendell signed an order Tuesday effectively banning further natural gas development on state forest land. He said the action was needed in part to prevent unchecked industrialization of public lands in a state that has seen an boom in natural gas development. Roughly 660,000 of the state’s 2.2 million acres of public forest have been leased, according to the state. The moratorium comes just days after a breakdown in negotiations between the governor and State Senate Republicans over a severance tax on natural gas production, favored by Mr. Rendell, a Democrat.

headline: News Quiz | October 27, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Lee’s Wife Is No Fan of Yankee Stadium
text: SAN FRANCISCO  When the millions start piling up at the negotiating table this winter, the behavior of a few rowdy Yankees fans will probably make no difference to Cliff Lee, the Texas Rangers’ ace and a pending free agent. But Lee’s wife, Kristen, was disturbed by the fans at Yankee Stadium during Game 3 of the American League Championship Series last week.

headline: Harvard Man May Be Winner on Winless Bills
text: At 0-6, the Bills are the league’s only winless team. It would be flip to say that they are on the clock for the 2011 draft, but barring a major turnaround, they will be well positioned to select a franchise quarterback. Ryan Fitzpatrick’s play, however, might make them consider other options.

headline: I.B.M. Approves $10 Billion Stock Buyback
text: I.B.M. has approved an additional $10 billion in stock buybacks, representing nearly 6 percent of its outstanding shares, The Associated Press Reports.

headline: Fed Won’t Join Appeal to Keep Emergency Loans Secret
text: The Federal Reserve will not join a group of leading commercial banks in asking the Supreme Court to allow the government to withhold details of emergency loans made to financial companies in 2008, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: BHP Challenge to Potash’s Poison Pill Is Set
text: Saskatchewan’s securities regulator will hear BHP Billiton‘s challenge to Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan‘s shareholder rights plan on Nov. 8 and 9, assuming that the Canadian government allows BHP’s $39 billion bid to proceed.

headline: Creditors Back Dubai World Debt Restructuring
text: The state-owned investment enterprise Dubai World has secured support from all its creditors for a $25 billion debt restructuring plan, a spokesman said on Wednesday, helping it to avoid a drawn-out battle with a special tribunal, Reuters reports.

headline: The Write-In Challenge
text: WHO is Lisa Murkowski? WHO is she running against in the race for United States senator from Alaska?

headline: JPMorgan Said to Face Scrutiny on Silver Trading
text: The American commodity futures regulator is looking into claims by a trader in London that JPMorgan Chase was involved in manipulative silver trading, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing a person close to the situation.

headline: Lee and Lincecum Have Hat Issues
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Rangers pitcher Cliff Lee has gotten a lot of scrutiny for his uniquely worn-out hat, with blotches of rosin on the bill and the back. But his opposite number in Game 1 also wears a studiously worn-in hat.

headline: Daily Lexeme: Pruniferous
text: Today’s word, in association with the cherished Oxford English Dictionary, is

headline: For Myspace, a Redesign to Entice Generation Y
text: SAN FRANCISCO — All but eclipsed by Facebook and Twitter, Myspace is aiming for a comeback.

headline: Ellison Claims Proof of Wrongdoing by New H.P. Chief
text: Oracle‘s chief executive, Larry Ellison, said he can prove that Hewlett-Packard‘s incoming C.E.O. oversaw an SAP scheme to steal Oracle’s software, Reuters reports.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Oct. 27, 2010
text: Test your math skills with today’s question, created by Oana Pascu at Math for America from the Times article “Retired Space Shuttle May Come to Manhattan, After All.”

headline: Deutsche Bank Reports Loss, Citing Takeover Costs
text: Deutsche Bank said on Wednesday that it had lost money in the third quarter as the costs of acquiring Deutsche Postbank, Germany’s largest retail bank, added to the effects of a slump in stock trading, Jack Ewing of The New York Times report.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: –Female founders, influencers and deal makers on the New York Scene.

headline: Is ASX Bid Too Much for SGX to Handle?
text: Magnus Bocker, who stitched together eight European stock exchanges and sold them in a bidding war, is running into a wall with shareholders and politicians over his plan to acquire Australia’s main exchange, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: E.D.F. Buys Constellation’s Stake in Nuclear Venture
text: Électricité de France and Constellation Energy have announced a deal under which E.D.F. would buy out Constellation’s share of what had been a joint venture, UniStar Nuclear Energy, for $140 million.

headline: JPMorgan’s Highbridge to Buy Gávea of Brazil
text: JP Morgan Chase said on Wednesday that it would acquire a controlling stake in Gávea Investimentos, a $6 billion hedge fund founded by Arminio Fraga, former head of the central bank of Brazil.

headline: Consumer Protection Agency Adviser Had Role in Soured Loans
text: A senior adviser to Elizabeth Warren, pictured, hired to help start the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, is an investor in and, until recently, served as a director of a company that helps to arrange low-documentation loans for consumers with often-spotty credit histories.

headline: A Street Photographer’s Nimble Tread
text: Neal Boenzi is the Fred Astaire of photojournalism — a master of his craft who was classy enough to make it all look so easy. Though he retired years ago (he’ll turn 85 on Nov. 15), those of us who were his colleagues can still picture his seemingly effortless footwork.

headline: European Union Adopts Hedge Fund Rules
text: After drawn-out negotiations, the European Union has agreed  to new rules for hedge funds, having gained the approval of the European Parliament to regulate more thoroughly the 2 trillion euro ($2.8 trillion) industry.

headline: What Would You Risk Your Life For?
text: Joao Silva, a photographer for The New York Times who has photographed wars in numerous countries, was seriously wounded recently while covering the conflict in Afghanistan. What drives people like Mr. Silva to risk their lives to report the news? What are you so committed to that you would take considerable risks, including putting yourself in harm’s way?

headline: SGX-ASX Merger Seen as Threat to Hong Kong Exchange
text: A merger between Singapore Exchange and ASX will make it harder for Hong Kong to win offerings by commodity companies and achieve an expansion plan announced this year, the chairman of the Hong Kong exchange said.

headline: Mecox Lane’s Stock Surges 57% in Trading Debut
text: Shares of Mecox Lane soared in their first day of trading on Wednesday.

headline: C.F.T.C. Proposes New Tools to Stop Fraud
text: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission has laid out a proposal that would give it greater power to combat traders who seek to manipulate prices or defraud investors.

headline: Facebook’s Ad Sales Chief Is Leaving
text: Facebook‘s head of advertising sales is leaving the social networking company.

headline: U.S. Companies Hoarding Almost $1 Trillion in Cash
text: American companies are hoarding almost $1 trillion in cash, but are unlikely to spend on expanding their businesses and hiring new employees because of continuing uncertainty about the strength of the economy, Moody’s Investors Service says.

headline: Measuring the Futility of Favre
text: Brian Burke, a former Navy pilot who has taken up the less dangerous hobby of N.F.L. statistical analysis, operates Advanced NFL Stats. A longer version of this post is at his site.

headline: Shaking It Up at Paris’s Cocktail Bars
text: From New York to Copenhagen to London, cocktail culture is on the ascent, with creative throw-back bars popping up around some dedicated enthusiasts. And Paris is no exception. Here are just a few of the specialist bars in Paris serving unusual concoctions.

headline: Assessing the Power of One at the Polls
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

headline: Early Word: Expectations
text: In Wednesday’s Times:

headline: Korea Finance May Form Private Equity Fund for Hynix
text: The Korea Finance Corporation, the country’s state-run financier, said it might purchase temporary control of Hynix Semiconductor by forming a private equity fund should creditors fail to find a capable buyer for Hynix, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Jets Not Sold on N.F.L.’s Approach to Limit Concussions
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Jets linebacker Bart Scott is never one to be slow of tongue, but even he was left speechless, even if only for a moment.

headline: Obama to Appear on ‘Daily Show’
text: President Obama will make the fusion of politics and comedy official tonight by becoming the first president to appear on Comedy Central’s “Daily Show” just days before crucial midterm elections that could reshape his presidency.

headline: Hedge Funds Pass Previous High-Water Mark
text: Hedge funds have surpassed their previous high-water marks in the third quarter, recouping the losses sustained during the financial crisis, according to a report from Credit Suisse.

headline: Has the Seed Investment Bubble Burst?
text: New data released by the University of New Hampshire’s Center for Venture Research found that angel investors put much less money into start-up deals during the first half of 2010 than they did in 2009, a direct refutation of the widely held notion in Silicon Valley that seed valuations had been rising.

headline: Expensive Ways to Save Money
text: One of the keys to making money is to keep your costs down. Sometimes, in the effort to save money, a company can be the victim of unintended consequences. You “save” some money by putting off machine maintenance, and a machine breaks down and stops production. You “save” some money by changing insurance companies, and you find out after you make a claim why the new company is cheaper. You “save” money by not doing safety training in your factory, and someone gets hurt doing something the wrong way.

headline: Cloudera Raises $25 Million for Hadoop Development
text: From VentureBeat:

headline: Flowers Wins Approval to Buy N.J. Bank
text: J. Christopher Flowers has won approval to buy a two-branch bank in New Jersey in a rare bank takeover by a private equity fund manager that may revive a debate about such investors’ role in the banking system, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Nail Polish Maker OPI May Fetch $1 Billion in Auction
text: OPI Products, the popular nail polish company known for its quirky color names, is in advanced talks to sell itself to a beauty care company or private equity firm for as much as $1 billion, Bloomberg News reported, citing four people with knowledge of the matter.

headline: Google Said Near $2 Billion Deal for N.Y.C. Building
text: Google is nearing a deal to buy an office building at 111 Eighth Ave. in Manhattan for a price close to $2 billion, The New York Post reported.

headline: Lovie Smith’s Missing Challenge
text: Brian Burke, a former Navy pilot who has taken up the less dangerous hobby of N.F.L. statistical analysis, operates Advanced NFL Stats. A longer version of this post is at his site.

headline: Aid Request Snags Korea Talks
text: SEOUL, South Korea  A request by North Korea on Tuesday for huge shipments of fertilizer and half a million tons of rice has derailed talks about further reunions of Korean families who were separated by the Korean War.

headline: ‘Hobbit’ Movies Will Stay in New Zealand
text: New Zealand’s claim to be the cinematic home of Middle-earth is in jeopardy no longer: on Wednesday, government officials there reached a deal to keep a two-film adaption of J. R. R. Tolkien‘s fantasy novel “The Hobbit,” to be produced and directed by Peter Jackson, in their country, Jonathan Hutchison reports for The New York Times.

headline: 5-2 Starts Are Common for Giants, but Where Do They Finish?

The Giants are 5-2 for the sixth time in seven seasons under Coach Tom Coughlin. Giants finishes after 5-2 starts under Coughlin have ranged from winning the Super Bowl in 2007 to the total collapse in 2004, when their record was 6-10.

headline: Global Warming and the ‘Tyranny of Boredom’
text: My discussion of the newsroom “tyrannies” that impede effective media coverage of human-driven climate change elicited a provocative response from Randy Olson, the marine biologist turned filmmaker and communication coach for scientists. I’ve long described what I call tyrannies in talks to journalists and students — including the tyrannies of (limited) time and space, balance, the lure of the “front-page thought” and conflict, the need need for a “news peg” (a reason for a story to run today, not next month, next year or never).

headline: James Cameron Announces ‘Avatar’ Sequels
text: LOS ANGELES — It’s official: James Cameron is going back to Pandora not just for his next film, but also for his next two. Mr. Cameron, the filmmaker behind the 3-D blockbuster “Avatar,” joined 20th Century Fox in announcing that he would make “Avatar 2” and “Avatar 3” as his next two movies, with the first of the sequels scheduled for release in December 2014, and the second for December of the following year. That assures a lot of fantasy-filled Decembers, as Peter Jackson has already scheduled a pair of “Hobbit” films for Warner Brothers and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer in that month in the years 2012 and 2013. “Avatar” was released on Dec. 18 of last year and became the highest-grossing film in history, with almost $2.8 billion in worldwide ticket sales. Mr. Cameron and the top Fox film executives, Jim Gianopulos and Tom Rothman, jointly said they aimed to begin production next year on the first sequel. The film is not yet officially titled, they said.

headline: Over Tutu’s Objections, South African Opera Company Says It Will Tour Israel

headline: Space Craft
text: As a set designer, Gary Card is used to pouring his creativity into a wildly elaborate mise-en-scène, only to see the whole thing dismantled or destroyed once the project is finished. So when the creative director John Skelton and his partner, Dan Mitchell, approached him to design the interiors of LN-CC, a new concept store (think meticulously curated avant-garde fashion, rare books and vintage vinyl) in the scrappy east London neighborhood of Dalston, Card jumped at the chance to create something permanent. He used his surrealist sensibility to transform the space, a former boxing gym, into a hipster fun house. To enter the store, visitors navigate Card’s ‘‘deconstructed forest,’’ only to find themselves in the belly of a beast — a wooden tunnel that resembles a crudely assembled whale skeleton. The rest of the 6,000-square foot-space is divided into individual rooms, like a gallery hung with mannequins (above) and a library lined with asymmetrical shelving. ‘‘Every room needed a distinct atmosphere, tone and temperature,’’ Card says. ‘‘The idea was to move from organic to industrial, from warm to cold. And always keep it open to change.’’ The main attraction is the private club space, with its sound system by the legendary sound guru Mickey Boyle. For Card’s sake, we hope the parties don’t get too out of hand.

headline: Latest Poll Shows Cuomo Ahead by 20 Points
text: With six days to go before the election, Andrew M. Cuomo leads Carl P. Paladino in the race for governor by 20 percentage points, 55 percent to 35 percent, according to a Quinnipiac University poll of likely voters conducted last week and released Wednesday morning.

headline: The Worst Economist in the World, 10/27/10
text: In my first WEITW post, I went after the claim that quantitative easing, by weakening the dollar, could actually hurt recovery — because, you see, a weaker dollar leads to higher commodity prices. As I tried to explain, a weaker dollar is also a stronger euro (and other currencies), so what raises prices in terms of one currency lowers them in terms of others, and the whole thing makes no sense.

headline: Face Values | Inge Grognard’s Radical Chic
text: The 1980s were a time of general excess, especially in fashion. But the emergence of a band of Belgian designers dedicated to a radically deconstructed vision of dress signaled a mucking out its Augean stables. Out with pouf skirts, in with sweaters made of old socks! Abetting this brave new look were the makeup artist Inge Grognard and her photographer husband, Ronald Stoops. Working on magazine shoots and runway shows for Dries Van Noten, Dirk Bikkembergs, Walter Van Beirendonck, Dirk Van Saene and perhaps most famously, Martin Margiela, the couple created some of the most arresting images of the ’90s. The couple’s long-awaited first book, “Inge Grognard Ronald Stoops (Ludion),” out at the end of the month, gathers their favorite images in one coffee-table-ready volume. The Moment recently caught up with Grognard via phone from her home in Antwerp — Stoops and the designer An Vandervorst could be heard chatting in the background — to talk about how fashion has changed since the ’80s, her definition of beauty and the problem with red lipstick.

The song is the epiphany Seurat experiences, allowing him to complete his painting even as he realizes his model and lover has left him for another:

headline: Do You Need a Recruiter to Hire a No. 2?
text: In a case study we’ve just published, Adriana Gardella writes about Fikes Products, a 30-employee company that sells janitorial supplies and services to restaurants, retailers, and other businesses. Mark Sims, the owner, wanted to hire a strong No. 2 person and also fill four additional slots. But he didn’t trust his own hiring abilities and he was reluctant to spend the money for a recruiter. Ultimately, he did decide to use a recruiter.

headline: In Writings of Obama, a Philosophy Is Unearthed
text: When the Harvard historian James T. Kloppenberg decided to write about the influences that shaped President Obama’s view of the world, he interviewed the president’s former professors and classmates, combed through his books, essays, and speeches, and even read every article published during the three years Mr. Obama was involved with the Harvard Law Review (“a superb cure for insomnia,” Mr. Kloppenberg said). What he did not do was speak to President Obama.

headline: Leaked Reports Prompt Questions About Civilian Casualties
text: The whistle-blowing organization WikiLeaks posted 77,000 secret field reports this summer, covering six years of the war in Afghanistan, and many of the reports shed new light on civilian deaths. The British newspaper The Guardian, which was one of several publications — The New York Times was another — that printed articles about the leaked field reports, followed up with a Freedom of Information request to the British Ministry of Defense, seeking more information about the civilian deaths.

headline: Moncler, Where the Parkas Need a Bouncer

Two young people went into the store last week, dressed unflamboyantly, carrying sheaves of résumés probably meant for every boutique south of Union Square. One got an impromptu (informational?) interview on the spot. None of the on-duty salespeople seemed ruffled by the intrusion. Maybe they were a bit relieved.

headline: Take My Bulgarian Joke Book. Please.
text: GABROVO, Bulgaria — The sign leading into town, faded but still readable in Bulgarian, was as I remembered it. “Welcome and good riddance,” it said. Gabrovians, like Borscht Belt comedians or Delaware Republicans, pride themselves on their sense of humor. Before the Wall fell, this hard-luck but endearing city at the foot of the central Balkans was regarded as the Communist capital of humor.

headline: For Charity, a Cross-Country Trip on 2 Wheels

Looking like an 1960s Italian movie star in a gray pinstripe suit and black Dior oxfords, Mr. Levy waltzed right in  he’s on the permanent guest list  and emerged on the 18th floor, where a hostess whisked him to a corner table marked “reserved” that offered stellar views of the Empire State Building.

headline: Friday Is the Day to Introduce Alderson as Mets General Manager
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The Mets are planning a news conference for Friday to introduce Sandy Alderson as their new general manager. The team made the decision to hire Alderson on Tuesday after he met with the Mets’ three-headed ownership group. They then notified the runner-up candidate, Josh Byrnes, of the news later in the day, according to a person who has spoken with one of the people involved in the decision.

headline: Kennedy Center ‘Follies’ Gets Its Phyllis

Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, executives there announced on Wednesday.

headline: Legislative Approval Final for French Pension Bill
text: PARIS  The lower house of France’s parliament, the National Assembly, gave final approval on Wednesday to a bill that raises the minimum retirement age from 60 to 62 and the age for a full pension from 65 to 67.

headline: The Opening of Ferrari World Is Delayed
text: Ferrari World, the extravagant 40-acre theme park on Yas Island in Abu Dhabi, is at long last complete and was scheduled to open to the public on Wednesday night. But according to the site Emirates 24/7, the opening has been postponed because of the death on Wednesday of Sheikh Saqr bin Mohammed al-Qasimi, the ruler of Ras al Khaymah, one of the seven members of the United Arab Emirates.

headline: Looking Back and Looking Ahead: Week 8 in Fantasy

headline: Dubai Faces Environmental Problems After Growth
text: DUBAI  Dubai’s skyline is the most sparkling in the Middle East. But down on the ground, the environmental problems of a quickly erected city built on sand look a lot less alluring.

headline: Lin-Manuel Miranda to Close Out Broadway Run of ‘In the Heights’
text: After a Broadway run of more than two and a half years that included four Tony Awards and a Grammy, the hit musical “In the Heights” will close on Jan. 9. “It’s the right time,” one of the producers, Kevin McCollum, said Wednesday, citing the implacable economics of Broadway. “If we ran into another year, it wouldn’t make sense.”

headline: For Democrats, Losing the House Is Not Inevitable. (Just Very Likely.)
text: Pretty much every time that we issue a House forecast — like last night, for instance, when we projected that Republicans’ gains were most likely to be on the order of 52 seats — we point out that the forecast has a lot of uncertainty in it.

headline: Velour Still Has Some Juice
text: WHEN we last heard from Juicy Couture, the maker of velour tracksuits that all but defined the California casual sportswear look of the last decade, things were not looking so good. Retailers began scaling back their orders after its founders, Gela Nash-Taylor and Pamela Skaist-Levy, announced in January that they were reducing their involvement in the company to “non-operating creative consulting” roles.

headline: 36 Hours in Venice
text: WITH its picture-perfect canals and waterside palazzi, Venice is a romantic idyll. No wonder 18 million tourists pile onto the floating city each year. But what is surprising is that the embattled residents still manage to carve out a hometown for themselves — a pastiche of in-the-know restaurants, underground bars, quiet piazzas and calmer, outlying islands. And that’s not counting all the cultural offerings that Venetians take full advantage of. The cool art scene now goes beyond the Biennale. And instead of sinking, architectural icons have re-emerged as new landmarks.

headline: The Hurdles to Suing Outside Advisers for Fraud

headline: It’s a Trad, Trad, Trad World

Combining the Hickey Freeman heritage with Opening Ceremony’s youthful aesthetic, the retweaked classics include slim-line pants ($300) and suit jackets ($1,395) available in hound’s-tooth, herringbone, pinstripes and tweeds.

headline: Ideas in Motion: Illustrating Basic Science Concepts

In this lesson, students explore different ways of representing topics in science. They address whether entertainment can also be educational, and write their own comic strips that explain science concepts.

headline: Basketball Heads to Bahamas Resort

The resort is spending about half a million dollars to convert its conference center — usually host to big-name pop concerts featuring the likes of Rihanna and the Jonas Brothers — to create a temporary 4,200-seat arena with live broadcasting capabilities.

headline: Variations on the Vegetable Fritter
text: It is no secret that I possess a deep love for deep-fried food. The carrot and zucchini fritter recipe that I wrote about will work beautifully for any kind of vegetable: onions, sweet potatoes, shredded winter squash and pretty much anything so long as it’s cut up into little pieces for uniform frying. In fact, fritters are a great way to use up the bounty of seasonal vegetables you may be getting in your C.S.A. box (broccoli, broccoli, broccoli; turnips, turnips, turnips). Fritters demand to be dipped, says I, but you can also use them as a base for a thick spread of hummus, baba ganoush or chutney. And, when the temperature starts dropping, I love them on a plate with beef stew ladled on top.

She is the coordinator for the Foundry Photojournalism Workshop, a nonprofit program for emerging photojournalists. Amanda Rivkin’s conversation with Ms. Luce has been edited.

text: With opening night (and performances for the critics) fast approaching, the creators of the new Broadway musical “Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown” added several changes for Tuesday night’s audience, most noticeably a new number at the top of the show that had been the Act II opener.

headline: Seeking Sylvia Plath, in Her Own Words and Someone Else’s

headline: Allowing Children, of All Ages, to Choose
text: Unlike Ilie Ruby, Caitlin Hamilton Summie is not an adoptive mother. She has lived every moment of her son’s and daughter’s lives in tandem with them. And yet she wonders, as Ruby does, where the lines are between where she ends and her children begin. And it makes her wonder how her own parents managed to so regularly hold their tongues.

headline: Prosecutors Defend Wiretaps in Galleon Case
text: Federal prosecutors filed a brief on Wednesday asking a judge to deny Raj Rajaratnam’s request to exclude thousands of wiretapped conversations from his upcoming insider-trading trial.

headline: Shea, Billy Joel and a Lot of Brenda and Eddies
text: Most years, the World Series makes Mets fans wistful. With rare exception, the team will have played its last game weeks earlier, often in dispiriting fashion. The falling leaves and chillier weather are reminders that spring training — and hope for a fresh start — are months away.

headline: TNT’s Heat-Celtics Game Viewed by 7.4 Million
text: TNT’s heavily promoted opening night game between the Miami Heat and the Boston Celtics on Tuesday night attracted 7.4 million viewers, the most for a regular-season N.B.A. game on cable. It surpassed the 7.27 million for a Bulls-Lakers game in February 1996.

headline: The Whitney Gears Up for Downtown
text: CHANGE was in the air at the Whitney Museum of American Art’s annual gala on Tuesday night, where the topic of conversation was the board’s recent vote to break ground on a space in the meatpacking district.

headline: Which Team Has World Series-Winning Characteristics?
text: Carlton Chin, a fund manager, and Jay Granat, psychotherapist, are authors of “Who Will Win the Big Game? A Psychological & Mathematical Method.” They have previously written about the N.B.A. finals, the N.F.L. playoffs, and the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament.

headline: Even the Undead Play Chess
text: Street chess hustlers are famous for taking on all challengers, but they never know who might show up and want to play a game. Tuesday, during a promotion in Union Square in Manhattan for a new AMC series, “The Walking Dead,” one of the zombies evidently found something more diverting to do than eating brains.

headline: Fielder’s Choice: Gloves of the World Series
text: The game of baseball requires you to keep your eye on the ball, but the fielder’s mitt deserves our attention too. Photographs by Dan Winters for The New York Times Magazine showcase some of the mitts used in the World Series from 1910 to 2000. Examine the details of the gloves used by Babe Ruth, Joe DiMaggio, Brooks Robinson and others.  Explore more.

headline: Late-Night Double Feature: The ‘Rocky Horror Glee Show’ Reconsidered
text: Apparently “The Rocky Horror Glee Show” – an innocent episode of “Glee” in which a squad of high-school students tries to stage a simple musical about an oversexed transvestite from outer space and the two virgins he seduces in his castle of hedonistic delights – was a rather tender subject, provoking all kinds of responses around the Web. So: another slice, anyone? In this IM conversation, Dave Itzkoff, a culture reporter for The New York Times who writes about “Glee” for ArtsBeat, and Rebecca Milzoff, a reporter for New York magazine who writes about “Glee” for Vulture.com, discussed their reactions to the episode and their histories as “Rocky Horror” fans. It was a chat they would remember. For a very. Long. Time.

headline: Price of Justice for Stanford: Cheaper Lawyers
text: Yet again, the jailed Texas financier R. Allen Stanford is getting a new set of lawyers. This time, price definitely came into play in the legal defense of Mr. Stanford, who is accused of of swindling investors out of $7 billion in a Ponzi scheme.

text: Photos from Tuesday night’s gala at the Whitney.

headline: Carly Fiorina Released from Hospital
text: Carly Fiorina, the Republican candidate for Senate in California, was released from the hospital on Wednesday, a day after she was admitted for an infection related to breast cancer treatment.

headline: A Sideways Strategy for a Flawed Chess Board
text: On a recent Saturday, Jean Manas and his son, Mateos Haile-Manas, were playing chess on one of the three public tables on the East River promenade, a raised platform on the Upper East Side between the water and the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive. There were plenty of distractions — the strong October wind, the traffic hurtling by — but another factor was affecting their game more: They were forced to play sideways.

headline: Thrashers Don’t See Race, Just Opportunity
text: The Atlanta Thrashers are trying something new in their struggle to draw fans. But if they keep playing the way they did Wednesday night at Madison Square Garden, where they snapped the Rangers’ three-game winning streak with a wild 6-4 victory, their job could be a lot easier.

headline: Animal Cruelty Caught on Camera
text: A New York City Housing Authority security camera mounted inside an elevator captured a man violently yanking the leash of a small dog in an Upper Manhattan apartment building.

headline: Strides Made Toward Early Diagnosing of Pancreatic Cancer
text: Researchers have made significant progress in understanding the biology of pancreatic tumors, suggesting that there may be ways of identifying the usually fatal cancer at a much earlier and more treatable stage.

headline: The Dance of the Mean Girls
text: The students of the Constance Billard School for Girls, the fictional alma mater of the catfighters on “Gossip Girl,” have been known to perch on the steps of the Met as they go about their undermining ways. But in a coming episode of the television series, a crosstown arts institution is muscling in.

headline: A Collection’s First E-Sale
text: CAMEL, fake fur and men’s wear are represented in a capsule collection culled from Club Monaco by Kate Ciepluch, the fashion director for the online retailer Shopbop. Shopbop.com Winter shorts have replaced last year’s mini and can be worn with ribbed opaque tights for work and with bare legs and heels at night. At left are Jacqueline shorts ($119) and wool thigh-highs ($24); the Hannah coat ($295); Samarie top ($89); and Audrey leather shoulder bag ($249). Customers can view the whole collection at Clubmonaco.com.

headline: A Classic Shoe, Restyled
text: THE first offering from New Balance for the J. Crew collection, the 1400, is named for a style number originally released in 1994. The unisex suede shoe comes in two colors, navy and what is called “classic pine,” a dark moss green (left, $130), and was manufactured in New Balance’s factory in Skowhegen, Me. Available via the J. Crew catalog, online at jcrew.com and at select stores, including J. Crew’s Men Shop at 1040 Madison Avenue (79th Street); (212) 453-2677.

headline: For the Boots of Fall, Fur Rules
text: FOUR QUESTIONS FOR BETTY WANG, right, senior buyer for designer shoes at Saks Fifth Avenue.

headline: A Pop-Up Showcase
text: PROJECT No. 8, which has two stores on the Lower East Side and an outpost at the Ace Hotel, is extending its clothing-rather-than-fashion message to a temporary satellite store on Duane Street, starting today. The temporary boutique, which will be open until mid-February, will showcase designers like the London-based Zowie Broach and Brian Kirkby, who began by showing their collaborations in galleries before starting their label Boudicca. (At left is one of their dresses, $1,725). Project No. 8 is popping up in Paris on Thanksgiving weekend. 186 Duane Street (Greenwich Street); (212) 966-3904, projectno8.com.

headline: Courier Replaces Patrick McEnroe as U.S. Davis Cup Captain
text: Back when Jim Courier was playing Davis Cup matches in the 1990s, Patrick McEnroe remembered thinking that he would make a good captain one day. That is what happened Wednesday, when the United States Tennis Association named him to the job to replace McEnroe, who stepped down after 10 years.

headline: Android App Forwards Private Text Messages

headline: Tennis, Anyone?
text: In yet another East-meets-West mash-up, the California-based K-Swiss has created a capsule collection with Brendon Babenzien, the creative director of the downtown skate shop Supreme. The first output from the collaboration, California Tennis, a limited-edition line of T-shirts, polos and perfectly worn-in collegiate sweatshirts, pays homage to 1970s courtside style. Inspired by “Tennis Girl,” the saucy Martin Elliott poster image, the tops in the collection have a bicoastal ease to them and are as appropriate with a pair of swim trunks as they are with skinny black jeans. The pieces are available starting Nov. 1 on beams.co.jp, with prices ranging from about $75 for a T-shirt screen-printed with the Elliott image to about $270 for a windbreaker. For a preview of the line, check out Jake Davis’s video, above.

headline: Hustlers and Lovers Endure the Civil War Era
text: The hive of activity on the tiny Irish Repertory stage in the opening of “Banished Children of Eve” includes a Fulton Street fishmonger cleaning the catch, a tottering drunk, a Yankee sharpening his dagger, an actress applying makeup, a maid scrubbing stairs, an urchin rattling a tambourine and a Bowery barker inviting audiences to step up for a minstrel show. All this is accompanied by a sad piano scratching out the popular melody of “Beautiful Dreamer.”

headline: Video Shows Man Abusing Dog in Harlem Elevator
text: Updated, Oct. 29 | A man abusing a dog in a housing-project elevator in Harlem was caught on videotape, the police said.

headline: The Juice Cleanse: A Strange and Green Journey
text: A MONTH ago I went on a juice cleanse. You know what it cleans out of you best? The will to live.
