headline: Limber Up Your Sluggish PC
text: As we get older, most of us tend to put on weight. We bulk up in all the wrong places. Over the years we ingest a lot of things that are bad for us. We may still suffer the effects of long-gone viruses. Our gait slows, and we’re not as sharp as we used to be.

headline: In Ontario, Sailing the Lake of the Woods
text: “ARE you claustrophobic?” my friend Leif Larsen wanted to know.

headline: Old World but Oil Rich in Azerbaijan
text: TO the north of Baku Boulevard, the namesake promenade that separates the capital of Azerbaijan from its Caspian Sea waterfront, stands the Maiden Tower. The eight-story stone structure, which dates back to at least the 12th century, is thought to have once been a lookout against invading armies. Today, it is the centerpiece of the walled Old City in Baku. The 15th-century buildings within those walls are made of a honey-hued sandstone and, since 2003, have been painstakingly restored, leaving behind a movie-set veneer. A maze of winding lanes runs throughout, and tucked inside is the unadorned Palace of the Shirvanshahs, the seat of Azerbaijan’s ruling dynasty during the Middle Ages. Today, carpet merchants, hawking their wares, sing out the usual chorus of “Hello!” and “Where are you from?”

headline: Hotel Review: The Hotel Monaco in Baltimore
text: THE BASICS

headline: Restaurant Review: Rino in Paris
text: Restaurant-mad Parisians love to hunt, so it’s no surprise that the February opening of Rino, on a hip little street behind the Bastille in the 11th Arrondissement, instantly became hot local news.

headline: Mumbai Seizes Its Next Moment
text: ON a recent Sunday, crowds of mostly Indian day-trippers milled around the monumental basalt arch of the Gateway of India at Mumbai’s harbor, along with the usual contingent of snack vendors, balloon salesmen and roving photographers who snap tourist portraits for a few rupees.

headline: In Northern Vietnam, a Region of Beauty and Ethnic Traditions
text: MY first glimpse of the place that some call Shangri-La came on a brisk spring afternoon as we were careening along a narrow road hemmed in by sheer limestone walls. Our driver made a hairpin turn and all at once the landscape erupted into a sweep of dazzling slopes, serrated ridges and hanging valleys. In the pocket of a mountain pass called Heaven’s Gate, Hoang Tuan Anh, who also served as our guide, stopped his pickup truck so we could gaze at the vista of radiant sky that had opened up before us. This was only the beginning, Mr. Anh said, as we resumed our upward drive. “We will go as high as the clouds!”

headline: Baltimore’s Harbor East Adds to Its Allure
text: AGAINST a backdrop of squat row houses and tall industrial buildings on a dim corner in Baltimore, laughter, soft music and the intoxicating smell of oven-roasted burgers drift out to the sidewalk. The sounds and smells are spilling over from new restaurants and bars in Harbor East, a burgeoning neighborhood that has undergone an extensive transformation in recent years.

headline: Motor City District Regains Its Luster
text: Despite the decline of the auto industry, Detroit’s Grand Circus Park district, long a hot spot with its opulent movie palaces and clubs, boasts a spruced up park and thriving restaurant scene.

headline: A Jet Set Emerges in Baku, Azerbaijan
text: Gucci and sushi take their place in an ancient civilization.

headline: Vietnam, Above the Clouds
text: In Vietnam’s north, ethnic minorities thrive in a region of slopes and cliffs that is just being discovered by visitors.

headline: At Goodman Theater, Glitter and Be Gloomy
text: CHICAGO  With this city’s airwaves choked with finger-pointing political ads, its favorite son fighting for the future of his presidency and its leading newspaper shell-shocked from executive turmoil, it would be pretty hard for Chicagoans to argue that they are living in the best of all possible worlds. So the moment is peculiarly ripe for the Goodman Theater’s revival of the 1956 musical “Candide,” adapted from Voltaire’s cackling satire deriding the folly of unthinking optimism in the face of man’s  and nature’s  brutalities.

headline: Chess 101: How to Set Up the Board
text: One of the first things people learn about chess is that the near right-hand corner on each side should be a White square. Evidently, not everyone at the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation, which is responsible for maintaining the city’s chess and checkers tables, knows that rule. City Room has a post on Wednesday about several tables on the East River promenade, on the Upper East Side, that were stenciled incorrectly, so that the near right-hand corner squares were Black.

headline: Mobile Travel Guides Can Help, but Trust Books
text: As with so many smartphone apps, it is tempting to look at the current spate of mobile travel guides and proclaim the end of their paper counterparts as we know them.

headline: Strong Arms, Fast Hands, Supple Spines and, of Course, Clowns
text: Fast, funny, filled with feats and fancy footwork, “Dance On!,” the colorful 33rd edition of the Big Apple Circus, is winning applause that pays tribute to the rich array of talent in its familiar single ring and behind the scenes under its little big top.

headline: Meet the ‘Ladle of Love’
text: The Diner’s Journal blog introduces readers to an electric-powered food truck in Central Park that bills itself as New York City’s “most environmentally friendly mobile noshing vehicle.”

headline: The Caucus Click: Port Clinton, Ohio
text: Listening to candidates during a pancake breakfast at the Port Clinton Elks Club.

headline: Calling a Ghost Town Home
text: The writer Antonya Nelson and her husband own several pieces of property in an old southern Colorado mining town that is mostly abandoned.

headline: Living in a Ghost Town
text: I OWN a ghost town. Well, not all of it. My husband, Robert, and I first bought the three town blocks at the intersection of Main Street and First Avenue, where the old post office sits, five years ago, but that’s hardly the whole place. Later, we bought an abandoned mine on the local stream, and then the spot where the town entrance sign sits, and also the graveyard. But I don’t think we’re actually majority owners, yet.

headline: Of Birds and Insects (and a Coral Snake)
text: Saturday, Oct. 23

headline: Nostrums: Caution Urged on Cholesterol-Lowering Supplement
text: Americans trying to avoid cholesterol-lowering drugs are spending tens of millions of dollars each year on Chinese red yeast rice, a supplement found to lower LDL, or “bad,” cholesterol.

headline: Philharmonic Renews Effort to Visit Cuba
text: If they cannot go as tourists, put ’em to work.

headline: Pop-Up Window Shopping
text: Another day, another pop-up store. Fortunately, the latest shopkeepers to hang out a temporary shingle are Elizabeth Beer and Brian Janusiak, the married duo behind the eclectic boutique Project No. 8. Says Beer of the company’s latest venture, a 100-square-foot former gallery in TriBeCa: “We heard about this space on Duane Street, which has always been one of our favorite blocks in the city, and thought it would allow us to do a series of mini-shows featuring several designers at a time.” In addition to Kostas Murkudis, the Berlin-trained designer who hosted an intimate presentation at the unopened store during New York Fashion Week, the location will feature a constantly rotating selection from labels like Natalia Brilli, Boudicca and Christian Wijnants, as well as pieces from the house label, Various Projects. The TriBeCa space will be open through Valentine’s Day 2011, and Beer and Janusiak are opening another pop-up store in Paris next month.

headline: Telling Your Children Too Much
text: Speaking of oversharing, Stephanie Thompson certainly shares openly in The Brooklyn Paper last week. She is thinking of divorcing her husband, and in an essay last week she dissects her reasons — and her children’s reactions to the increasing tension in the house.

headline: Food Association Plans a Package-Front Label Showing Nutritional Data
text: Responding to pressure from federal regulators, a major food manufacturers organization said Wednesday that it would develop a labeling system for the front of food packages that would highlight the nutritional content of foods, including things like calories, unhealthy fats and sodium that many consumers want to limit.

headline: Agitated Rhythms and Other European Motions
text: Under the artistic direction of Benoit-Swan Pouffer, Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet has become a repository of work by European choreographers that strives to epitomize that embarrassing phrase in dance: cutting edge. While a good portion of its repertory subsists on a certain manic jitteriness, there is little daring about it. Contrived and derivative  iterations of William Forsythe are still going strong  its new crop of dances have traveled quite a distance from the company’s previous nuanced productions of works like Ohad Naharin’s “Decadance” and Jill Johnson’s “Copier.”

headline: A Nano-Solution to Energy ‘Vampires’
text: Vampire power, the electricity consumed by devices that are plugged in but not in use, costs American homeowners some $4 billion every year and accounts for 5 to 10 percent of all residential energy use, according to estimates from the Department of Energy. Studies in Europe have found similar amounts of energy waste in residences and businesses.

headline: A Crooner Serenades His Loyal Friends
text: Everyone is familiar with the AIDS charity anthem, “That’s What Friends Are For,” sung by an all-star coalition, Dionne and Friends, that became a No. 1 single in 1986. But how many remember another song with the same title, written by Paul Williams, that was a minor 1972 hit for B. J. Thomas?

headline: Online Video Takes Another Small Step, but Giant Leap Remains Elusive
text: The battle for the living room? Oh, it’s on, all right.

headline: ‘American Idol’ Owner CKX Ends Buyout Talks
text: “American Idol” is not heading into the hands of private equity after all.

headline: Sheriff Won’t Run for Chicago Mayor
text: Rahm Emanuel’s showdown with the sheriff has been averted. The Cook County sheriff, Tom Dart, who posed the strongest potential competition to Mr. Emanuel’s bid for Chicago mayor, announced he would not seek the office on Wednesday.

headline: A Vanishing and a Chance to Do Penance
text: Dennis Lehane’s 1998 “Gone, Baby, Gone” was a taut, exposition-packed novel about the apparent kidnapping of a 4-year-old girl. It was part of Mr. Lehane’s top-notch series about a pair of lovebird private investigators, Patrick Kenzie and Angie Gennaro. But the whole weight of its story fell onto Patrick’s shoulders.

headline: Big Picture in Schumann Vignettes
text: Andras Schiff has become the piano world’s long-distance runner. Even when his recital programs are the standard two hours  and given his penchant for hefty encores, they are typically longer  they have grand ambitions that make them almost heroic. Lately they have been installments in a Beethoven cycle, played in chronological order over two seasons at Carnegie Hall, and a Haydn program offered as part of a campaign to restore Haydn’s sonatas to the active repertory.

headline: A Visit to Harry Reid's Hometown
text: The Times's Adam Nagourney visited Searchlight, Nev., the hometown of Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid and suddenly, the center of the political universe.

headline: Letters
text: Female Candidates’ Look

headline: Angle Turns Corner in Nevada, but G.O.P. Senate Odds Drop
text: Sharron Angle, the Republican candidate in Nevada, has been improving her position in our forecast in recent days, and for the first time since the spring has better than a three-in-four chance to win her race against Harry Reid, according to the FiveThirtyEight model.

headline: Letter: In Wine Country
text: To the Editor: In “Overnighter: California Farmland, Known for Its Drinks” (Oct. 17), Freda Moon captured the flavor and essence of the Anderson Valley: “hills shrouded in straw with green vineyards creeping up their sides ... a fierce, rural independence.”

headline: Letter: Amazon Revelations
text: To the Editor: Andy Isaacson’s “Amazon Awakening” (Oct. 17) article on the Ecuadorean Amazon was fascinating and moving. Nearly every sentence or paragraph was dense with sensory detail and revelation. This is exactly the kind of insightful writing that has been missing from travel pages of late, which seem to focus on the latest luxury destinations  nourishing neither the wallet nor the traveler. Ideally, we travel to adventure outside of our safety zones, to learn about other cultures, to question our countries and ourselves and to better find our place in the world.

headline: The Caucus
text: The Times's Megan Liberman and Nate Silver discuss FiveThirtyEight's forecast for next week's midterm elections, and what the results may mean to both political parties.

headline: Breeders’ Cup Overflows, Led by Zenyatta
text: Zenyatta is a perfect 19-0. The mare might even be invincible. She beat the boys in this race last year. There is a long line of accomplished contenders, however, intent on making her earn her immortality in the $5 million Breeders’ Cup Classic. They are salty bunch, seven Grade I winners, that include a colt named Blame, who has lost only once this year; Gio Ponti, last year’s reigning champion older male horse; and Espoir City, one of Japan’s most highly regarded runners.

headline: Bobbing for a Lost Apple
text: The drum of horror holds her sound,Which will not let me sleep,When ghastly breezes float around,And hidden goblins creep.—George Moses Horton,“The Fearful Traveler in the Haunted Castle”

headline: TimesCast: Next Week’s Forecast
text: In the latest edition of TimesCast, The Times’s Megan Liberman and Nate Silver discuss what could happen to the political makeup of Congress when voters head to the polls next Tuesday.

headline: Students Feel Peer Pressure to Donate
text: Nonprofits have long used the honor roll, a list of benefactors prominently displayed, to inspire others to make gifts.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
text: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Oct. 21 through 26 with 1,173 adults throughout the United States, including 1,073 who said they were registered to vote.

headline: A Phone of Promise, With Flaws
text: What on earth is Microsoft doing, bringing out its iPhone competitor now, in 2010?

headline: Obama Coalition Is Fraying, Poll Finds
text: Critical parts of the coalition that delivered President Obama to the White House in 2008 and gave Democrats control of Congress in 2006 are switching their allegiance to the Republicans in the final phase of the midterm Congressional elections, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: Obama, Jon Stewart and Change
text: President Obama took his campaign get-out-the-vote blitz to “The Daily Show” on Wednesday, telling the host, Jon Stewart, that he never promised transformational change overnight.

headline: A First Look at ‘The Rent Is Too Damn High,’ the Album
text: Tuesday is a very big day for Jimmy McMillan. Not only will Mr. McMillan, the candidate on the Rent Is Too Damn High ticket, learn whether he is the next governor of the state of New York, but it is also the release date of his newest album.

headline: In Utah, a Clash Over Slashing Government
text: Mike Lee, the Republican candidate for United States Senate in Utah, has caused a late-race stir by suggesting that the federal government may need an immediate 40 percent cut in spending to get the budget deficit under control.

headline: For the First Time, ‘The Daily Show’ Hosts a Sitting President
text: President Obama on Wednesday became the first sitting president to appear on “The Daily Show,” the news satire show on Comedy Central. On The Caucus, Sheryl Gay Stolberg recaps Jon Stewart’s interview of the president:

headline: Gloves of the World Series
text: Keep your eyes on the ball, but the mitt deserves our attention too.

headline: For World Series, Cablevision Steers Customers Online
text: 8:02 p.m. | Updated  The first game of the World Series was blacked out in three million homes serviced by Cablevision on Wednesday night, because of a continuing dispute between the cable company and Fox, which is broadcasting the championship series.

headline: Fla. House Candidate Faces More Questions
text: MIAMI — Politics is bloodsport in the heavily Cuban congressional district that includes Miami, and Republican David Rivera is looking pretty banged up.

headline: Levinsohn Replaces Schneider at Yahoo
text: Yahoo, which has seen a steady stream of its executives depart, has hired Ross Levinsohn, a former executive with Fox Interactive Media, to lead its operations in the Americas.

headline: In Paris, a Threadbare Home From the 1800s
text: A couple fell in love with a house in the 14th Arrondissement that had once been a haberdashery.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Adoring Your Computer
text: Whether you realize it or not, you may be relating to your computer as if it were human. On this week’s New York Times Tech Talk podcast, Bettina Edelstein chats with Clifford Nass, a Stanford University professor who studies the interaction of people and technology. He has found that the connections we have with computers and other electronic devices are fundamentally social. Professor  Nass’s new book, with Corina Yen, is called “The Man Who Lied to His Laptop: What Machines Teach Us About Human Relationships.”

headline: Bold ‘Trovatore,’ Inspired by Goya
text: Many singers have classically beautiful voices that appeal to almost everyone. There are also excellent singers whose voices may not be generically beautiful but whose vocal artistry is exceptional. Two such — the soprano Patricia Racette and the baritone Zeljko Lucic — were in the cast on Tuesday night when the director David McVicar’s production of Verdi’s “Trovatore,” introduced in the 2008-9 season, returned to the repertory at the Metropolitan Opera. It’s a starkly effective, boldly updated staging, with images inspired by Goya sketches of civil war.

headline: TPG Giddy Over Rangers-Giants World Series
text: Truth be told, this DealBook reporter is having a tough time getting excited over a World Series between two teams not from the Bronx. Anecdotal evidence suggests that the interest across Wall Street is also pretty low.

headline: 10 Writers Receive Whiting Awards Honor
text: The Whiting Writers’ Awards are usually given to people who are not yet known even in literary circles. But the recipients are young and talented, and often go on to fame and acclaim, as did winners from years past like Jonathan Franzen, Sarah Ruhl, Colson Whitehead and Michael Cunningham. The 2010 recipients, who were to be announced at a ceremony in Manhattan on Wednesday night, are three fiction writers, three nonfiction writers, three poets and one playwright. The prizes are administered by the Mrs. Giles Whiting Foundation, established in 1963 by Flora E. Whiting. The winning fiction writers are Michael Dahlie (“A Gentleman’s Guide to Graceful Living”); Rattawut Lapcharoensap (“Sightseeing”); and Lydia Peelle, author of a collection of stories, “Reasons for and Advantages of Breathing.” The nonfiction winners are Elif Batuman (“The Possessed”); Amy Leach, who is writing a book of essays about animals, plants and stars; and Said Sayrafiezadeh, author of the memoir “When Skateboards Will Be Free.” The poets are Matt Donovan (“Vellum”); Jane Springer (“Dear Blackbird”); and L. B. Thompson, whose chapbook is “Tendered Notes.” The playwright is David Adjmi, whose “Stunning” had its premiere at the Lincoln Center Theater. The prizes have been given annually since 1985, with a cash award of $50,000 each.

headline: Shopping With Lindsey Adelman
text: An industrial designer shopped for reading lamps, perfect for this time of year, when days are getting shorter.

headline: Reading Lamps
text: L INDSEY ADELMAN, a New York industrial designer with a special interest in light fixtures, creates elaborate chandeliers of blown glass bubbles that fundamentally change the feel of a room. “I like the idea of transforming a space in a dramatic way through lighting,” she said, noting that much of her work is “about creating a mood and beauty, and people looking great at your dinner party.”

headline: Footnote
text: The Cleveland Orchestra has received a promise of $20 million to help provide discount and free tickets to children and young adults. The Maltz Family Foundation made the pledge, which will go toward a $60 million endowment to finance what the orchestra is calling a Center for Future Audiences.

headline: Sales on Artemide Lamps and More
text: During Richard Schultz’s first warehouse sale, Nov. 5 and 6, limited quantities of the designer’s pieces will be marked way down; items can be reserved in advance, by phone or e-mail, with a deposit during the presale, beginning on Nov. 1 (the Topiary bench, regularly $2,550, will be $500; the 1966 Collection dining set, which includes a table and eight chairs, regularly $17,140, will be $2,500); 806 Gravel Pike, Palm, Pa.; (215) 679-2222, richardschultz.com.

headline: New Doors by Dror Benshetrit, David Rockwell and Robert A. M. Stern
text: Doors rarely get the kind of attention that furnishings do, something Lualdi, an Italian manufacturer, is trying to change. “It’s like having a very nice painting — they contribute to the environment,” said Alberto Lualdi, the president of the company. “Why not consider a door as a piece of furniture, and an element for decoration?” To prove the point, Lualdi is introducing three doors created by American designers, catering to different tastes.

headline: Sustainable Furnishings in Philadelphia
text: When Jaime and Isaac Salm, the brothers who run Mio, a design firm specializing in sustainable home furnishings, moved their studio into an old fortune cookie factory in Philadelphia, passers-by didn’t know what to make of it. “People would walk in off the street, wanting to know who we were,” Jaime Salm said. “They didn’t really get it.” Now that the first Mio store has opened in that space, though, they probably will.

headline: A High-Design Retreat on a Newfoundland Island
text: The Long Studio is the first of six modern artists’ residences to be built in what some might consider an unlikely location — on Fogo, a 91-square-mile island off the coast of Newfoundland. Designed by Todd Saunders, a Newfoundland-born architect based in Norway, and financed by the Shorefast Foundation, a local charity, the studios will range from 200 to 2,000 square feet. “They’re very expressive forms that reflect the Newfoundland architecture — they’re on stilts like a lot of the houses on the coast,” Mr. Saunders said. “For the locals, it’s strange and familiar at the same time.”

headline: Marital Issues Buried in the Sofa
text: IT all came down to a coffee table.

headline: ‘Nordic Models + Common Ground’ Opening at Scandinavia House
text: “Nordic Models + Common Ground: Art and Design Unfolded,” an exhibition of 41 objects, including furniture, architectural models, photos, lighting and textiles by 35 Nordic designers, will open on Friday at Scandinavia House in Midtown Manhattan.

headline: Eddie Ross on Shopping at Flea Markets
text: Eddie Ross has been trolling flea markets for years, first on his own and later as an editor at Martha Stewart Living and House Beautiful, where he wrote a column about flea markets.

headline: Simplifying Their Garden
text: In the gardens at Page Dickey’s home in North Salem, N.Y., where perennials are being replaced with shrubs and ground covers.

text: PARIS

headline: ‘NCIS’ Is Back on Top
text: Tuesday’s episode of “NCIS” attracted that crime show’s largest audience since January as CBS dominated the night. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 19.9 million viewers tuned in to the CBS series at 8 p.m., easily outperforming all other programming and helping to elevate the rest of the network’s schedule. A “Dancing With the Stars” elimination episode at 9 (15.5 million) helped lift ABC to second place. Fox’s “Rocky Horror” episode of “Glee” ranked second in the 8 p.m. hour with 11.5 million viewers while topping the night’s ratings among viewers 18 to 49. Fox ranked third over all, and NBC was fourth.

headline: A Reassured F.T.C. Ends Google Street View Inquiry
text: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  The Federal Trade Commission announced Wednesday that it had ended its investigation of Google’s collection of Internet users’ personal communications by the company’s Street View cars.

headline: Seeing Opportunity in Health Care
text: IN another demonstration of the increasing importance of health and wellness advertising to Madison Avenue, a leading agency is forming a unit that will specialize in marketing to health care professionals like doctors and managed care organizations.

headline: He Takes Advantage, Then Takes a Title, Too
text: The World Bridge Federation puts a lot of effort into junior events. At the championships in Philadelphia this month there was the inaugural young women’s team championship, as well as two team and two individual events, one each for players under 27 and under 22.

headline: Meningitis Booster Urged for Teenagers
text: ATLANTA  Federal vaccine advisers recommended on Wednesday that 16-year-olds be given a booster dose of a vaccine against meningococcal meningitis and that people ages 11 to 64 get a booster to protect against whooping cough, diphtheria and tetanus.

headline: Wells Fargo to Amend About 55,000 Foreclosures
text: After several weeks of insisting its foreclosure processes were sound, Wells Fargo & Company said on Wednesday that it planned to correct and resubmit up to 55,000 improperly filed documents by mid-November.

headline: Chandler Said He Did Not Take Part in Improper Workouts With Knicks
text: TORONTO — Knicks forward Wilson Chandler said Wednesday that he never took part in improper workouts with the team before he was drafted in 2007.

headline: From a Rally to a Phone Bank
text: President Obama‘s political organization is seeking to capitalize on Saturday’s Rally to Restore Sanity and March to Keep Fear Alive by convening volunteers for a phone bank at the Democratic Party‘s national headquarters once the events, headlined by Comedy Central hosts Stephen Colbert and Jon Stewart, is over.

text: 7:52 p.m. | Updated

text: HOHENWALD, Tenn.  They’re fighting like elephants.

headline: New Jersey Governor Says He Won’t Budge on Scrapped Rail Tunnel
text: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey put a final stop on Wednesday to the most expensive public-works project in the country: a proposed rail tunnel under the Hudson River that could have doubled commuter-train service to Manhattan.

headline: Marijuana Web Names Snapped Up, in Case of Legalization
text: SAN FRANCISCO — It was just about a year ago that Kevin Faler came up with his get-rich-quick marijuana scheme. No, he does not plan to sell the drug, even if Californians vote next week to become the first state in the nation to fully legalize it. He intends to sell the Internet real estate that could one day lead to marijuana Web sites.

headline: Obama Set to Offer Stricter Nuclear Deal to Iran
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration and its European allies are preparing a new offer for negotiations with Iran on its nuclear program, senior administration officials say, but the conditions on Tehran would be even more onerous than a deal that the country’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, rejected last year.

headline: Eva Ibbotson, Children’s Book Author, Dies at 85
text: Eva Ibbotson, an English writer for children whose comic novels of enchantment  which rumble with wizards, ghosts, ghouls and mustached elderly aunts  anticipated the work of J.K. Rowling, died last week at her home in Newcastle upon Tyne. She was 85.

headline: Gulfstream Orders Suggest Recovery in Business Jets
text: General Dynamics said Wednesday that its Gulfstream unit received orders for more business jets in the third quarter than in any comparable period since mid-2008, another indication of recovery in the market for corporate planes.

headline: Storm Spreads Its Problems From the Midwest to the East Coast
text: CHICAGO  A major storm that slammed the Midwest continued to cause problems on Wednesday as thunderstorms and strong winds reached the East Coast.

headline: Homeowners Facing Foreclosure Demand Recourse
text: Ricky Rought paid cash to the Deutsche Bank National Trust Company for a four-room cabin in Michigan with the intention of fixing it up for his daughter. Instead, the bank tried to foreclose on the property and the locks were changed, court records show.

headline: M.T.A. Board Raises Bridge and Tunnel Tolls
text: Drivers who pay cash to traverse many of the region’s major tunnels and bridges will pay significantly more by the end of this year, while E-ZPass users will see more modest increases, as the Metropolitan Transportation Authority on Wednesday approved the final stage of this year’s big toll and fare increases.

headline: Tax Shortfalls Spur New Fear on Europe’s Recovery Bid

headline: Childhood Abuse Is Cited for a Convicted Killer of 3
text: NEW HAVEN  The man convicted of killing three people in Cheshire, Conn., grew up in a “very dysfunctional” family, with a violent father and an alcohol-abusing mother and was sexually abused as a child, jurors who will decide whether to sentence him to death were told on Wednesday.

headline: Goat vs. Man
text: OLYMPIC NATIONAL PARK, Wash. — You come to this pork chop of land in the Far West, even with the first lashing storm of the season, on the off-chance of seeing something as nimble as a 300-pound, snow-white mountain goat in all its bewhiskered hauteur.

headline: Harry Reid's Home Town
text: Scenes from Searchlight, Nev., where residents are divided about the Senate Majority Leader.

headline: Even in His Hometown, Reid Is Source of Anguish
text: SEARCHLIGHT, Nev. — This shrinking town in the desert has endured its indignities over the years. It has been referred to as a ghost town, a description that galls the 800 or so people who still call it home. It was once famous for its brothels, a reputation that, though hard to quarrel with, is not exactly something to brag about.

headline: In Spain, Homes Are Taken but Debt Stays
text: MADRID — Manolo Marbán, 59, is still living in his house in Toledo and going to work in the small pink-and-aqua pet grooming shop he bought here in 2006, when he got swept up in Spain’s giddy real estate boom.

headline: Handling of Abuse in Chilean Church Questioned
text: SANTIAGO, Chile  In April of last year, the Rev. Juan Esteban Morales, the head of a Roman Catholic parish here, visited Dr. James Hamilton at his clinic to make an unusual request: that he stop pursuing an annulment to his marriage.

headline: Lazard Lives On After Wasserstein
text: Bruce Wasserstein left behind a healthy Lazard. During his nearly decade-long tenure, he whipped into shape a firm that had been mired in internecine warfare.

headline: If They Only Knew What Was in the Cards
text: SAN FRANCISCO  It was 5 a.m. in the casino at the Ritz-Carlton beside the balmy beaches of San Juan, P.R. Two ballplayers sat at the blackjack table and laughed at what they thought was their amazing good fortune. The cards were smiling upon them that morning in June, and both players walked away with a few extra dollars in their already well-filled pockets.

headline: Ignoring the Planet Won’t Fix It
text: It’s hardly surprising that a study released the other day by a scientist with the National Center for Atmospheric Research didn’t register on any political radar screens, amid Kentucky foot stomps, dead wrestlers, $2 billion in campaign spending and the pitched battles for control of Congress.

headline: Plan to Tighten Control on Trades
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission is poised to ban brokers from letting clients make unsupervised trades on stock exchanges, reflecting its concern that a rogue transaction could upset markets.

headline: In Icy Tip of Afghanistan, War Seems Remote
text: BOZAI GUMBAZ, Afghanistan — As the pickup truck bounced toward a remote village deep in northeastern Afghanistan, the young woman was told by her companions that she could toss her burqa aside.

headline: A Well-Dressed Dry Cleaner, Just Like Dad
text: John-Claude Hallak knows the proper way to press trousers, coax a spot from a wedding gown, or restore a carpet to its original glory. He is a second-generation dry cleaner; his parents, Joseph and Marie-Louise, opened Hallak Cleaners on the Upper East Side in 1966. (His mother, widowed in 1992, is the president.) Mr. Hallak, 54, who has a master’s degree in economics from Rutgers University, joined the company in 1982; he and his younger brother, Joseph, 49, are both vice presidents. He lives in Basking Ridge, N.J., with his wife, Michelle, and their 16-year-old twin sons.

headline: Nakamura Poised to Defend Title at Cap d’Agde
text: After setting a blistering pace in the preliminary rounds of the elite French tournament, America’s top player has qualified for the quarterfinals.

headline: Names of the Dead

headline: Recalling a New York Character, in Fiction and Real Life
text: Tom Wolfe said Burton B. Roberts, the model for a cranky character in Mr. Wolfe’s 1987 best-seller “The Bonfire of the Vanities,” “had such a huge impact on my life, it’s hard to know where to start.”

headline: Clinton Rallies for Cuomo
text: Bill Clinton spoke at a rally for Andrew M. Cuomo in the gym of a downtown Brooklyn college.

headline: And Now, a Word About Candidates’ Parenting Skills
text: For weeks, voters in Connecticut have gotten to know two Republican candidates, Linda E. McMahon, who is running for the Senate, and Thomas C. Foley, the party’s nominee for governor, thanks to their relentless television advertising.

headline: New Federal Rules Set on Career Colleges
text: After receiving 90,000 public comments, and making 82 changes, the Department of Education will release its final rules Thursday to require career colleges to disclose graduation and job placement rates, end misleading recruiting practices and ensure that only eligible students or programs receive federal student aid.

headline: Weather Watch in San Francisco
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Rain has delayed or postponed a game in three of the last four World Series, a trend that could be continued Thursday for Game 2.

headline: Balloon Boy’s Father Tries a New Gimmick
text: DENVER  Having tried to convince a worried nation that his 6-year-old son had drifted across Colorado in a makeshift balloon, Richard Heene is now trying to convince the world that everyone needs his latest invention: a wooden back scratcher.

headline: Paladino’s Handling of Aunt’s House Involved a Curious Chain of Transactions
text: In 1992, when Alzheimer’s disease had begun stealing the faculties of his Aunt Anna, the widow of his beloved Uncle Pasquale, Carl P. Paladino was appointed to safeguard her affairs. Mr. Paladino had significant credentials to serve as his aunt’s financial guardian: he was an established real estate developer and lawyer, someone who would become rich enough to bankroll his own campaign for governor.

headline: Lottery Numbers
The Age of Alzheimer’s
text: OUR government is ignoring what is likely to become the single greatest threat to the health of Americans: Alzheimer’s disease, an illness that is 100 percent incurable and 100 percent fatal. It attacks rich and poor, white-collar and blue, and women and men, without regard to party. A degenerative disease, it steadily robs its victims of memory, judgment and dignity, leaves them unable to care for themselves and destroys their brain and their identity — often depleting their caregivers and families both emotionally and financially.

headline: Favre Holds Out Hope of Playing With Injury
text: EDEN PRAIRIE, Minn.  Minnesota Vikings quarterback Brett Favre normally wears nondescript sneakers to his midweek news conference. On Wednesday, he limped in with his battered left ankle in a walking boot.

headline: Changeups Aren’t Part of Washington’s Repertory
text: San Francisco

headline: PolitiFact: Truth Is Out There, Barely
text: A well-known political fact-checking group has pored over the 2010 election and come up with a rating for the year: “barely true.”

headline: Lessons Learned. Already.
text: It is not too soon to consider what we’ve learned from the 2010 elections.

headline: End the War on Pot
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Fact-Checking Group Finds Campaign Year ‘Barely True’
text: Brian Stelter of The New York Times has word on The Caucus blog on how PolitiFact, a fact-checking operation at The St. Petersburg Times, has pored over the 2010 election campaign and come up with a rating for the year: “barely true.”

headline: Remember Renewable Energy?
text: Global warming, energy independence and good 21st-century jobs are three compelling reasons why Washington must do a lot more to promote renewable energy. Congress seemed to get it in 2005 when it directed the Interior Department to approve enough wind, solar and other projects on public land to produce 10,000 megawatts by 2015  enough to heat, cool and light five million homes. Not much has happened since.

headline: Boiling Point in Kentucky
text: The Kentucky Senate race has been particularly childish and nasty  even by this year’s dispiritingly low standards. So we suppose we should not have been surprised when a county coordinator for Rand Paul, the Republican candidate, stomped on a MoveOn activist outside Monday night’s debate in Lexington. The politicians need to cool it and they need to urge their supporters to cool it.

headline: Thursday: Halloween Riddle
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Do you love puns? If not, it’s perfectly appropriate in this Halloween puzzle to shout “BOO.”

headline: At the Polls, With Fingers Crossed
text: The list of failures by New York City’s inept Board of Elections just keeps growing. The primary election was chaotic, with long waits and workers who had not been trained to use the new optical scanner voting machines. Then the board was late sending absentee ballots to military personnel. Incredibly, we are now hearing that the instructions on next week’s ballots include a glaring error: they tell voters to fill in the circle above or next to a candidate’s name instead of below.

headline: Sport and Spectacle: The Gladiators of Football
text: To the Editor:

headline: Alderson Set to Get to Work on Mets
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Sandy Alderson was in the Dominican Republic on Wednesday, attending to his duties for Major League Baseball in its efforts to clean up the player procurement process. But he has already begun working on his next assignment, which may be equally as challenging  resurrecting the Mets.

headline: Stoudemire Era Begins With Vim, Vigor and a Win
text: TORONTO  Amar’e Stoudemire never tried to mask his happy fervor. He skipped around the court. He winked at a young fan. He sprinted into timeouts.

headline: The Courts and the Mandate
text: Health care reform is being challenged in the courts by 21 state governments, as well as by private groups and individuals. They contend Congress has no constitutional authority to require virtually everyone to carry health insurance starting in 2014 or pay a penalty.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Karzai Delays Order to Ban Private Security Companies
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Under intense pressure, the government of President Hamid Karzai announced Wednesday that it would extend, if briefly, a contentious deadline for banning most private security companies in Afghanistan.

headline: Liability and Evidence-Based Standards in Medicine
text: To the Editor:

headline: AARP To Sponsor Gordon’s Car
text: Jeff Gordon, 39, a four-time champion in Nascar’s top series, said he had picked up the AARP Foundation and its Drive to End Hunger campaign as his main sponsor for 22 Sprint Cup races each over the next three years. A cause has never been the main sponsor for a top stock-car racing team. Gordon’s Chevrolet has been mainly sponsored by DuPont since he broke into the top series in 1992, but DuPont has reduced its commitment. AARP plans to use its sponsorship to raise awareness of hunger in the United States, especially among older people.

headline: Attacks (Again) Punctuate Illinois Senate Forum
text: CHICAGO – Well, it’s official now. With but a few days left until the vote, the race to fill the Senate seat vacated by President Obama – one of the nastiest and most bitterly fought races around — is right on the verge of turning positive. Or at least Alexi Giannoulias, the Democratic Party candidate who wants this seat from Illinois, announced during a candidate forum on Wednesday night that he is “going positive” for what is left of the campaign.

headline: In Texas, a Front-Runner’s National Twist
text: BEAUMONT, Tex.  Gov. Rick Perry waded into a crowded room at Rao’s Bakery recently, full of conservatives and Tea Party members, and delivered his pitch with a sunny twang: Texas has one of the strongest economies in the country right now, and his small-government, low-tax policies are the reason.

headline: Energized Base Tilts Rightward in Maine
text: SANFORD, Me.  For a while this fall, Paul LePage, the Republican running for governor, appeared too combative to win in this low-key state.

headline: A Campaign of Few Details, but Questions Keep Coming
text: NAPLES, Fla.  The question for Rick Scott at last week’s debate had been asked countless times: Why was he qualified to be Florida’s governor when his tenure as a chief executive of Columbia/HCA led to $1.7 billion in fines for defrauding the government? Was he involved, or too out of touch to know what was going on?

headline: Nets Win Opener Over Pistons but Admit It’s Still Early
text: NEWARK  The Nets accomplished a feat Wednesday night that took 3 coaches, 19 games and 38 days at the start of last season.

headline: Governor Forecast Update: Live, Automated Polls Split on Tancredo Chances
text: Perhaps this year’s most intriguing gubernatorial contest is in Colorado, which had once looked safe for the Democratic nominee, Mayor John Hickenlooper of Denver. A series of recent polls, however, have shown sharp gains by Tom Tancredo, the former Republican Congressman, who is running on the ticket of the American Constitution Party.

headline: Activist Tells of Torture in North Korea Prison
text: SEOUL, South Korea  An evangelical activist from Arizona, imprisoned by North Korea last year after he illegally entered the country on Christmas Day, appeared Wednesday on South Korean television and spoke for the first time about his treatment by his captors.

headline: Coming Off Heavy Workload, Sabathia Will Have Surgery
text: SAN FRANCISCO — C.C. Sabathia threw 3,903 pitches in 2010, and perhaps just as many in spring training, while warming up and between starts.

headline: Gunmen Kill 15 in Mexico; Gang Link Seen
text: MEXICO CITY  At least 15 young people, several of them in treatment for drug addiction, were shot and killed Wednesday at a car wash in western Mexico, the third mass shooting with apparent connections to organized crime in less than a week.

headline: Charges Dropped Against Fourth Man in Bronx Antigay Attacks
text: The Bronx district attorney’s office announced on Wednesday that it was dropping charges against a teenager accused of taking part in the antigay attacks in an abandoned apartment building this month.

headline: Photo Replay: Oct. 27, 2010
text: A view of the day in sports, from a handball court in Russia to a soggy soccer pitch in northern Spain.

headline: Final: World Series Game 1 – Giants 11, Rangers 7
text: The Texas Rangers’ Cliff Lee, one of the most dominant postseason pitchers in recent memory, faced Tim Lincecum, a two-time National League Cy Young Award winner, in the most-hyped playoff pitching matchup since, well, last week, when Lincecum started for the San Francisco Giants against Roy Halladay of the Philadelphia Phillies.

headline: Kenya: Foreign Minister Resigns
text: Foreign Minister Moses Wetangula abruptly stepped down on Wednesday amid allegations that his ministry had stolen millions of dollars in a dubious land deal in Japan. Mr. Wetangula, a close ally of President Mwai Kibaki, is accused of trying to cover up a transaction in which Kenya overpaid by millions of dollars for land in Tokyo for a new embassy. Mr. Wetangula said that he was resigning “to give room for the investigation,” which involves other questionable embassy deals, and that he was confident that he would be cleared and would return to the cabinet. The government, which has long turned a blind eye to corruption, seems to be cracking down on it. In the past month, the mayor of Nairobi was arrested on corruption charges, and the agriculture minister was suspended and ordered to stand trial on corruption allegations.

headline: Yankees Turn Down Contract Options
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The Yankees began their off-season makeover by declining 2011 contract options for Nick Johnson, Kerry Wood and Lance Berkman, as expected.

headline: Stores Push Black Friday Into October
text: Attention bargain shoppers! It is October  and Black Friday specials are here.

headline: As College Fees Climb, Aid Does Too
text: As their state financing dwindled, four-year public universities increased their published tuition and fees almost 8 percent this year, to an average of $7,605, according to the College Board’s annual reports. When room and board are included, the average in-state student at a public university now pays $16,140 a year.

headline: Tuition Rises, But So Does Financial Aid
text: The average cost of tuition and fees for four-year, public universities, many of them grappling with budget cuts, rose almost 8 percent this year, to $7,605, according to my colleague Tamar Lewin’s reading of the College Board’s annual Trends in College Pricing report. When room and board are factored in, Ms. Lewin writes of the just-released report, the average in-state student at a public university will pay $16,140 this year.

headline: Charmed Giants Take a Big First Step
text: SAN FRANCISCO  A gray-haired Juan Marichal stood beside the 300-game winner Gaylord Perry. Willie McCovey steadied himself against a walker as Orlando Cepeda offered support. Watching from the stands at AT&T Park was Barry Bonds. Few teams have as many living legends as the Giants, who somehow have not won a World Series title in 56 years. It was never Marichal’s turn, or McCovey’s or Bonds’s. Baseball is funny like that.

headline: Quake Was Both Aftershock and Foretaste
text: Since the devastating Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami in 2004, I’ve been reporting on the potent seismic activity along the Sunda Fault, a dangerous seam in the seabed off the coast of Sumatra. All along, a critical source has been Kerry Sieh, who recently moved from the California Institute of Technology to the Earth Observatory of Singapore and has spent a couple of decades doing field work in the region.

headline: China Wrests Supercomputer Title From U.S.
text: A Chinese scientific research center has built the fastest supercomputer ever made, replacing the United States as maker of the swiftest machine, and giving China bragging rights as a technology superpower.

headline: Richard T. Gill, Economist and Opera Singer, Dies at 82
text: Richard T. Gill, in all statistical probability the only Harvard economist to sing 86 performances with the Metropolitan Opera, died on Monday in Providence, R.I. He was 82.

headline: Statutory Realignment at Tribune Company
text: Not long after Sam Zell, the real estate mogul, took over the Tribune Company, he installed a sculpture in the headquarters  lobby titled “Bureaucratic Shuffle,” a six-legged man going in circles and nowhere fast. But what was intended as a commentary on the existing culture at Tribune Towers came to be seen as a metaphor for the new management after the company tipped over into bankruptcy and a new, non-linear approach to management failed to gain traction.

headline: Numbers Diminish at Protests in France
text: MARSEILLE, France  Several hundred thousand people demonstrated again on Thursday to protest changes in France’s retirement age, but the numbers were down significantly from previous national days of protest, and it appeared that President Nicolas Sarkozy and his government had won an important victory.

text: After several weeks of insisting its foreclosure processes were sound, Wells Fargo said Wednesday that it planned to correct and resubmit up to 55,000 improperly filed documents by mid-November, Eric Dash reports in The New York Times.

headline: The TV Watch: Access and the Plight of the Political Comedian
text: The country long ago stopped wondering whether a president demeans his office by appearing on a late-night comedy show. The more immediate question posed by President Obama’s appearance on “The Daily Show With Jon Stewart” on Wednesday is whether a political satirist loses credibility when hobnobbing with a sitting president.

headline: Sunday at the Bar With Chef Joe
text: Friday night was crowded. Chef Joe was dismayed. Guests were opting for the comfort food. Not that his clam chowder or chicken with salsa verde or pasta with clams are anything like comfort food — one woman complained that the salad, with goat’s milk blue cheese dressing, was so fresh that the crunching sound in her head gave her a headache — it’s just that Chef Joe was considering the possibility that the naysayers and doubters had been correct: Southfork Kitchen might have to stick to the basics and let the big city boys play with esoteric embellishments and international condiments.

headline: Fed’s Bond Program Labeled a ‘Ponzi Scheme’
text: Two top asset managers, Bill Gross, the co-founder of Pacific Investment Management Company, and Jeremy Grantham, the chief investment strategist at Grantham Mayo Van Otterloo & Company, have lambasted the Federal Reserve, with Mr. Grantham calling its loose monetary policy “ruinous,” and Mr. Gross labeling its renewed asset purchases “somewhat of a Ponzi scheme,” Reuters reported.

headline: Anglo Irish Bondholders to Fight Ireland’s Offer
text: A group of investors holding the junior debt of Anglo Irish Bank have vowed to oppose the offer made by the Irish government last week to pay them a fraction of the face value of the bonds.

headline: Tiger Asia Gets S.E.C. Subpoena, Report Says

headline: Sanofi Posts Strong Profit and Defends Genzyme Bid
text: Sanofi-Aventis, after reporting strong third-quarter earnings on Thursday, reiterated that it believed its $18.5 billion hostile takeover bid for the American biotechnology firm Genzyme represented good value.

headline: Elements Slow Aid in Indonesia, and New Eruption Raises Fears
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Indonesian rescue workers struggled against rough weather and difficult terrain to reach tsunami victims on Thursday as the death toll continued to rise from the natural disasters that hit the archipelago nation this week on two separate fronts and just 24 hours apart.

headline: I.C.B.C. Buys 60% of AXA’s Chinese Joint Venture
text: The Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, the bank with the highest market value, agreed to buy a 60 percent stake in the AXA Group’s Chinese insurance venture in its latest foray outside banking, Bloomberg News reported.

text: A main indicator of consumer and business sentiment in Europe rose more than expected on Thursday, while a public bank that finances private enterprise in ex-Communist countries raised its growth forecasts.

headline: Using Every Bit of the Beet
text: One of the grand things about beets and some other root vegetables is that they lend themselves to a meatless version of everything-but-the-oink eating. It frustrates me to see people asking the market vendor to hack off the greens when they buy a bunch of beets: now, in the latter part of the season, the substantial leafy tops can provide as much to eat as a bunch of, say, Swiss chard, which is a form of beet.

headline: Exxon Profit Soars 55% as Oil Prices Rebound

headline: On Our Radar: Record Salmon Run in British Columbia
text: British Columbia’s Fraser River has seen a record run of sockeye salmon as an estimated 34 million fish have returned to the river this year, far above last year’s total of 1.5 million. One hypothesis is that the increase may be linked to the eruption of Alaska’s Kasatochi volcano in 2008; ash from the volcano may have created a massive algae bloom in Pacific waters where adolescent salmon reside, creating a veritable fish food buffet. If the connection is valid, this year’s record spawn may only be a one-off event, however, scientists said. [The Globe and Mail]

headline: Fake ‘Mad Men’ Character Gets Real Book
text: Just so it is clear in everyone’s minds: the 1960s were real. John Slattery is real. Roger Sterling, the character he plays on “Mad Men,” is not real, and the subplot from the past season of that AMC period drama in which he seeks to publish a memoir of his business advice was fiction. Having said all that, the book in question is real.

headline: Seeing Things | Studio Visit: Anna Sew Hoy
text: The artist Anna Sew Hoy most often works with fabric and clay, materials usually associated with craft and handiwork, and yet the sculptures she makes are more tough than homespun. Sew Hoy began working with clay in a figure sculpting class in high school, long before she knew she wanted to be an artist, and she is interested in exploring, and playing with, its material properties. She builds her pieces from solid blocks of clay that she takes great pleasure in slapping and smacking to create the off-kilter shapes she prefers. Faceted orbs, large looped pieces that she calls buckles and textured ceramic pieces with holes that recall a hair-covered face with only the eyes showing (think Cousin Itt from the Addams Family) are some of the forms she’s been working with recently.

headline: Gorbachev: Afghan Victory Is ‘Impossible’
text: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the former Soviet leader who oversaw the withdrawal of Russian troops from Afghanistan two decades ago, has warned NATO that victory in Afghanistan is “impossible”.

headline: The N.B.A.’s Oligarch and His Power Games
text: The Prokhorov Effect“Pretend you are putting a gun against my back,” said the Russian billionaire. We were standing in a small training room on the third floor of his house outside Moscow. Suddenly he pivoted, and any ideas I had of sprinting off with his wallet went poof. His loaded foot was poised to crush my knee. You had to wonder, Did he really need the full security detail that followed his chauffeured Mercedes around Moscow in a Land Rover?

headline: Recipe Redux: Grapefruit Fluff, 1941
text: The 1940s were a good time for drinking; eating, however, could be a dicey affair. Grapefruit fluff, published in The Times in 1941, was like a shining beacon in the sea of dull food. When looking for recipe inspiration in the paper’s archives, I moved right on by the date icebox pudding made with evaporated milk and the fruit turnovers that called for canned fruit. (A footnote, which only further proves my point: the original recipe had the uninspiring name “Grapefruit Dessert.” I changed this to fluff, for reasons you’ll understand when you make it.)

headline: Common Ground

headline: Ballet Leader to Leave Over Flemish Official’s Plan
text: A Flemish culture minister’s plan to put the Royal Flanders Ballet and Flemish Opera under the same management has prompted the dance troupe’s artistic director, Kathryn Bennetts, to submit her resignation, citing the loss of independence. She said she would leave when her contract ends in two years.

headline: Beards, Wigs and Panda Heads: It’s Giants Baseball
text: SAN FRANCISCO  The fall colors here are worth a long look, and on Wednesday, AT&T Park provided a spectacular viewing spot. Without traveling farther than an infield grounder, one could see a young redhead tugging at his fake black beard, an adult dressed in orange from his top hat to his spats, a man with a gray ponytail wearing a tie-dyed Giants T-shirt, and people of all ages and persuasions wearing white panda caps.

headline: Evercore Has Robust Quarter
text: Evercore Partners, the boutique investment bank, reported a 33 percent rise in third-quarter earnings on Thursday, buoyed by higher fees for advising on mergers.

headline: Low-Profile Banker, Meet High-Profile Car
text: The name is Yeaggy, Harry Yeaggy, and he’s now the proud new owner of what may be the world’s most famous car.

headline: Some Pre-Election Perspective
text: I don’t agree with everything in Will Wilkinson’s explanation of why the midterms don’t actually matter all that much, but it’s still a useful corrective to the vast effort currently underway to persuade you that this election (like the election before it, and the election before that) is a world-historical hinge moment, and that nothing in American life matters more than how many seats the Republicans gain or don’t gain next Tuesday:

headline: Smitten With a Cocktail Called Frisco
text: “Are you familiar with the Frisco?” I asked a bartender at Rye House, near Union Square, who in turn asked me to repeat myself, then had me spell the two syllables I had twice uttered. Still he was baffled. He took out his iPhone and sought to Google his way to illumination. But the recipe he found didn’t match my rough memory and sense of what a Frisco should be: a bracing blast of whiskey, tempered to a very particular degree by undercurrents of an opulent sweetness. The drink he made disappointed me.

headline: The View From France: Assessing the Europeans
text: Your attention please. We interrupt this Zenyatta-fest with a bulletin from Europe, where another distaff superstar is packing her bags for America, with a string of top-class companions in tow. Goldikova leads the challenge from across the pond in what the Racing Post is referring to as the Equine Ryder Cup. The Breeders’ Cup is starting to catch on over here, and now that the organizers have offered to pay the travel costs, you can look for more and more top horses to make the trip.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: The Wall Street Journal: Roxbury Russett. Cornish Gilliflower. Ralls Genet. They are heritage apples, some going back to colonial times, and they are undergoing a renaissance. – Glenn Collins

headline: The Insider | El Guincho
text: The Insider profiles emerging tastemakers in the fields of fashion, design, food, travel and the arts. Here the Spanish musician El Guincho (real name: Pablo Díaz-Reixa) shares his essentials. El Guincho is currently on tour in Europe promoting his latest album, “Pop Negro,” a chaotic mix of Afro beat, tropicalia and dub.

headline: Rehearsal Video of 'Amer'
text: A rehearsal video of the film "Amer," with the co-director Hélène Cattet standing in for the lead role.

headline: With Basketball Season on the Horizon, A.C.C. Endures Football Schedule
text: It has been one of those autumns in the Atlantic Coast Conference that prompts the pleas for the quick arrival of basketball, which is still considered the strong suit of the A.C.C. There has been scandal (North Carolina) and disappointment (Miami) and little national buzz about the conference’s football teams.

headline: A Scene From 'Amer'
text: A scene from the film "Amer," an homage to Italian giallo horror films.

headline: Finding a Way Around the Press?
text: 4:14 p.m. | Updated The first question is in, and it’s pretty much of a softball. Mr. Gibbs chose to answer the question “What is the purpose of the India trip.” That gave him a chance to talk about the president’s upcoming trip to Asia, including the economic summits he will attend. (As a bonus, he also answered a question about whether the president’s Secret Service code-name is now “dude,” since that’s how Jon Stewart referred to him on his show. It’s not, Mr. Gibbs said. It’s still “Renegade.”) But instead of answering the question at the podium, Mr. Gibbs recorded it on video from a webcam in the White House.

headline: The ‘Terminator’ Team Reunites for the Environment
text: The director James Cameron and the actor-turned-governor Arnold Schwarzenegger, who worked on the “Terminator” films together, have teamed up again, but this time to shoot a political ad urging Californians to vote against Proposition 23, a ballot initiative that would put California’s Global Warming Act of 2006 on hold.

text: Does Carlyle Group have a grand telecoms strategy?

headline: Night Watch: Analyzing Obama’s ‘Daily Show’ Appearance
text: Keith Olbermann presented a closing argument of sorts for Democrats on MSNBC on Wednesday night, in the form of one of his longest “special comments” ever. (He’s been reading the commentaries on-air for four years.)

headline: Plane Sequence From 'Monsters'
text: A sequence from the film "Monsters" where characters find a plane in the river. (Magnet Releasing)

headline: Governors Association Complains Again About Fox News
text: A newly amended complaint by the Democratic Governors Association, filed this week before the Ohio Elections Commission, asserts that “Fox News used corporate funds to make a prohibited contribution of $169,389 in violation of Ohio law when it provided one minute and 30 seconds of free political advertising to John Kasich’s campaign on August 18, 2010.”

headline: An Accidental King Finds His Voice

headline: Crossing Delancey
text: Even hipsters have to grow up — or, in this case, move farther downtown. A fixture on Ludlow Street since 1992, TG170, Terri Gillis’s quirky-cool clothing store, has moved down the street into more streamlined digs designed by the architect Philip Otto. More Chelsea gallery than boho hangout, the store remains true to its curatorial spirit, with artwork by Rich Jacobs and Mike Mills interspersed with Gillis’s collection of concrete garden animals, and signage by the graphic designer Chris Rubino. On the racks: indie labels like Corell & Corell, Hazel Brown, Mociun and Hengst.TG170, at 77 Ludlow Street; (212) 995-8660, or tg170.com.

headline: Inside a Trauma Ward in Iraq
text: In 2007, a surgical team tried to save the lives of three wounded Marines.

headline: China Is Said to Resume Shipping Rare Earth Minerals
text: BAOTOU, China  The Chinese government on Thursday abruptly ended its unannounced export embargo on crucial rare earth minerals to the United States, Europe and Japan, four industry officials said.

headline: Opposites Attract as Paula Abdul Takes on ‘American Idol’
text: Paula Abdul‘s new dance show, “Live to Dance,” will be scheduled against her former singing show, “American Idol.”

headline: Giants Fans Don’t Stop Believin’
text: There were more than a few fans dressed in panda suits for Game 1 and a stunning number of jet-black beards in the stands as the World Series opened in San Francisco. And perhaps one guy dressed as Cliff Lee. That couldn’t possibly have been the Texas ace on the mound for four and two-thirds innings, could it?

headline: A Hundred Ways to Be a Frog
