headline: The Legality of Buying Knockoffs
text: In a recent Bucks post, “How to Bargain at Markets,” I shared some of the tips my business school classmates and I learned while bargaining for knockoffs and counterfeit goods on a class trip to China.

headline: Keeping Score: What Does a Blowout in Game 1 Mean?
text: Game 1 of the World Series was anything but the taut, well-pitched contest we had been sold during the run-up to the World Series. The Giants especially were quick to shed their label as a no-hit, pitching-centered team. From Sept. 1 through the National League Championship Series, the Giants had played 39 games and had scored five or more runs only 10 times. In contrast, the Rangers had done it 20 times. But the Giants pitched so well over that stretch that they won 26 and lost 13 of those games, so their anemic offense hasn’t really hurt them.

headline: Poetry Pairing | Oct. 28, 2010
text: In our weekly “Poetry Pairing” series, we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poem’s themes. Each poem is introduced briefly by Ted Kooser, a former United States poet laureate.

headline: Theory by Olivier Theyskens
text: The clothes, under the label Theyskens’ Theory, reflect Mr. Theyskens’s signature drainpipe style, but also look like Theory’s urban wardrobe.

headline: Blumenthal and McMahon Take Campaigns to Main Street
text: Richard Blumenthal had two members of Congress in tow Tuesday afternoon as he swept into El Jibaro barber shop on New Haven’s main Latino commercial strip. Severiano Burgos took a break from cutting a customer’s hair. In the final weeks before Election Day, Mr. Burgos has gotten used to these visits from politicians.

headline: Olivier Theyskens and Theory: Q & A
text: After introducing his first capsule collection for Theory in September, the designer Olivier Theyskens broadened his relationship with the contemporary sportswear powerhouse this week by signing on as its artistic director. In his new role, Mr. Theyskens, formerly the designer of the luxury labels Rochas and Nina Ricci, will oversee the design of men’s, women’s and accessories collections that now have sales of more than $500 million annually. (Istvan Francer, who was the design director of the women’s Theory collection, is expected to move to another role within Theory’s parent company, Fast Retailing.)

headline: Times Popcast: Taylor Swift, Dierks Bentley and Wrapping CMJ
text: Country music is the focus this week on Popcast, the music podcast of The Times.

headline: Airgas’s Strategic Blink
text: The plight of the three independent Airgas directors selected by Air Products and Chemicals is fascinating.

headline: Labor Law Is Broken, Economist Says
text: In a new paper, Richard B. Freeman, a labor economist at Harvard, said he had some “harsh and impolitic” news for the National Labor Relations Act on its 75th anniversary. He declared that the law “has become an anachronism irrelevant for most workers and firms.”

headline: S.C. Write-In Candidate Says He’s ‘Not a Total Moron’
text: Karl Fornes has chosen a pretty direct slogan for his write-in campaign for Senate in South Carolina: “He’s not a total moron.”

headline: Amid Criticism of the M.T.A., a Show of Support
text: The Republican outsider says it should be abolished. The Democratic insider says no one is in charge of it.

headline: Cuomo’s Running Mate Fills Quiet but Scrappy Role
text: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y.  The 6-foot-5-inch, 225-pound man behind Andrew M. Cuomo emerged from a black Chevrolet here to a crowd of puzzled looks. He stood to the side, gazing at the ground and fiddling with his sleeves as Mr. Cuomo basked in the attention of cameras.

headline: Pee-wee’s Comeback
text: Images of from the career of Paul Reubens.

headline: Candy-Colored Bow-Tied Redemption
text: THE Pied Piper was nowhere to be heard, and Santa Claus wouldn’t be coming to town for a few more weeks, but something irresistible had drawn a small crowd to the West Fourth Street basketball courts in Greenwich Village on a recent Thursday morning. Huddled in groups of two and three, a few dozen men and women in their 20s and 30s glanced at one another and at their smartphones, rereading the Twitter and Foursquare messages that directed them here, waiting for something to happen.

headline: Cliff Lee’s Off Night
text: The one thing we thought we knew about baseball this year was, it’s the year of the pitcher. And in the year of the pitcher, Texas’s Cliff Lee was king. Unbeatable. Teams might as well not even try. So, naturally, the score of Game 1 of the World Series is 11-7 and Lee gets shelled. Next they’ll be telling us there is no Santa Claus and playing Powerball is not, in fact, a good retirement strategy.

headline: The Morning Line: In Racing’s Galaxy, Zenyatta Stands Out
text: Bennett Liebman is the executive director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School.

headline: Ristretto | AeroPress
text: This morning I made coffee with an AeroPress, a device that reminds me of a horse syringe without the needle. At its most basic, it works like a French press crossed with a Melitta filter: you put coffee grounds and hot water in one plastic cylinder, then plunge it into a cup or kettle with the other. It’s inexpensive (about $30), easy to use and even if it has no mechanical charisma — it looks like it was pieced together with parts from a Habitrail set — it’s actually a carefully engineered tool that addresses some of the more obsessive issues concerning extraction, grind and temperature.

headline: In 2010 Campaign, War is Rarely Mentioned
text: WASHINGTON  The wars in Afghanistan and Iraq have dominated American foreign policy for the past nine years, but debate about them is all but absent from this year’s midterm election campaigns.

headline: Death and Memory
text: When I tell stories about Iraq, the ones people react to are always the stories of violence. This is strange for me. As a public affairs officer in 2007 and 2008, I never saw combat, only its aftermath. I saw women and children wounded or dying in trauma centers. Ruins left by explosives in towns and cities across Anbar province. I saw surgeons who could do no more because the body they were trying to repair was too badly destroyed. I stood in formations as the bodies were taken away.

headline: Q&A: Portugal for the Holidays
text: My wife and I are planning to travel to Portugal for a three-week trip that will include Christmas and New Year’s. We would appreciate suggestions as to how we might best enjoy these holidays while we are there. We also wonder if any regions of the country have particularly distinctive celebrations.

headline: TimesCast | October 28 2010
text: Illinois Senate barbs; the latest New York Times/CBS poll and award-worthy political ads in New York region.

headline: HBO Announces End of ‘Big Love’
text: For years, Bill Henrickson and his three wives on the HBO drama “Big Love” have skated on some precarious ice — at least until they changed what was a perfectly good opening-credit sequence for that series — but they won’t be able to keep it up for much longer. On Thursday, HBO said the coming season of “Big Love,” which stars Bill Paxton as a Utah polygamist, and Jeanne Tripplehorn, Chloë Sevigny and Ginnifer Goodwin as his wives, will be the show’s last.

headline: Somali Islamists Kill Two Girls Branded Spies
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia  Somalia’s most powerful Islamist insurgents, the Shabab, executed two teenage girls on Wednesday after deciding they were spies, setting off fears among residents, officials and witnesses said.

headline: Binghamton Coach Gets $1.2 Million to Resign
text: The tumultuous tenure of Kevin Broadus, the coach who oversaw the Binghamton basketball program’s first N.C.A.A. tournament berth and also its subsequent implosion, has ended.

headline: Courage, Recognized: The Infantry and Joao Silva
text: During a few frantic minutes late in 2006, Joao Silva, a photographer for The New York Times, made a series of photographs of a Marine sergeant, Jesse E. Leach, retrieving from the line of fire a radio operator, Lance Cpl. Juan Valdez-Castillo, who had just been shot by a sniper on a foot patrol in Karma, Iraq.

headline: Senator Gillibrand Has New York Home on the Market
text: SENATOR Kirsten E. Gillibrand of New York, who filled the seat vacated by Hillary Rodham Clinton when she became secretary of state, is running for a full term in a special election next month against Joseph J. DioGuardi, a Republican and former congressman. And perhaps anticipating an extended stay in Washington, Ms. Gillibrand, a Democrat, has been trying to sell her five-bedroom home on 13 acres in Hudson, N.Y.

headline: In Marseille, Bipartisan Calls for Strikes to End
text: MARSEILLE — The strikes and protests against a seemingly inevitable pension change may be waning here, as elsewhere in France, but much of the port remains blocked, nearly 11,000 tons of uncollected trash remain piled in the streets, and residents remain embarrassed and exasperated, if somewhat unsurprised.

headline: Theater Talkback: Better Off Off Broadway?
text: Broadway or death. The reigning wisdom of theater producers these days is that if a play is ever going to grow up – that is, be taken seriously, receive lots of attention and, above all, make money – it can do so only on Broadway. I know that there are incontrovertible economic reasons for this theory. (Off-Broadway shows are highly unlikely ever to turn a profit.) And I suppose that as a New York theater lover, I should be grateful that the neon imprimatur of Broadway still holds a hypnotic glamor for people around the world.

headline: Panel Says Firms Knew of Cement Flaws Before Spill
text: WASHINGTON  Halliburton officials knew weeks before the fatal explosion of the BP well in the Gulf of Mexico that the cement mixture they planned to use to seal the bottom of the well was unstable but still went ahead with the job, the presidential commission investigating the accident said on Thursday.

headline: Linda Somers Smith, 49 and Still Among the Elite, Is Taking Your Questions
text: 10:15 p.m. |Update: Somers Smith’s Responses

headline: Yankees, Girardi Agree on Contract
text: The Yankees acted quickly to retain Manager Joe Girardi, rewarding him with a three-year, $9 million contract. The framework of the deal is in place, but because the Yankees did not want to make the announcement on the day of a World Series game, the new deal will not be announced until Friday. Girardi’s three-year, $7.8 million contract is set to expire on Sunday, but there was little doubt that he would return. General Manager Brian Cashman, minutes after the Yankees’ season ended last Friday night in Texas, said he absolutely expected Girardi to come back, a sentiment echoed Monday at their post-mortem news conferences at Yankee Stadium.

headline: Halliburton and BP Knew of Cement Flaws
text: The chief investigator of the presidential commission investigating the gulf oil spill says that Halliburton and BP knew of flaws in the cement used to seal the oil well weeks before the spill. Here is his letter to the full commission.

headline: But Judge, Who Knew the Rangers Would Advance?
text: 9:47 p.m. | Updated with comments from Cook

headline: What We’re Reading: Pot Domains, and Throwing Pies at Bees
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: Leaked: Obama Mentor’s Blunt Advice on Court Choices
text: In May 2009, after Justice David Souter announced his retirement from the Supreme Court, Laurence H. Tribe, the prominent Harvard Law professor, wrote a two-page letter to President Obama that bluntly laid out his views about several justices and potential nominees.

headline: Reader Rejoinders
text: An occasional assemblage of overheard or underappreciated words – generously emailed by co-vocabularists.

headline: Babylon on Hudson?
text: As if it weren’t bad enough for the city to see itself caricatured in political ads around the country, Animal New York dredges up a video from one of the many fretfully conspiratorial corners of YouTube that dares to ask the following question: Is New York actually the affluent and wicked city known as the mystery Babylon?

headline: Let There Be Light, and Elegance
text: “Elegance is refusal,” Diana Vreeland declared. But not always. She would have had a tough time selling that line of logic to the financier and elegance addict J. P. Morgan, a notable nonrefuser in practically every area, including art. He bought porcelains by the pound, drawings by the ream, bucketsful of Near Eastern cylinder seals and box upon box of rare books, chucking the junk and keeping the gems. Such was his way.

headline: Hispanics Cite Bias in Survey
text: More than 6 in 10 Latinos in the United States say discrimination is a “major problem” for them, a significant increase in the last three years, according to a survey of Latino attitudes by the Pew Hispanic Center, a nonpartisan research group.

headline: The Paul Reubens Show: Meet the Man Behind Pee-wee Herman
text: The sign on the marquee at the Stephen Sondheim Theater may read “The Pee-wee Herman Show,” but the man at the center of it, and behind more than 30 years of fascination with that antic, perpetually adolescent character, is the actor and comedian Paul Reubens. The popularity of Pee-wee Herman, at the Groundlings and in his original stage show, led Mr. Reubens to portray him in hit movies like “Pee-wee’s Big Adventure,” and on a Saturday morning television series, “Pee-wee’s Playhouse.” Two sex scandals could have cost Mr. Reubens his career, or made it unthinkable that he could plausibly portray the childlike Pee-wee — instead, he successfully revived “The Pee-wee Herman Show” earlier this year in Los Angeles and is now about to open it on Broadway.

headline: Indonesia’s Largest Mosque Is on Obama’s Itinerary
text: President Obama will mix childhood reflections with Muslim outreach when he travels to Indonesia, the world’s largest Muslim nation, next month. White House officials said Thursday that his visit would include a stop at Istiqlal Mosque, the nation’s largest, and a major address in Jakarta, where he lived for four years as a boy and remains hugely popular.

headline: City Considering 47 Schools For Closing
text: It’s school closing season: Let the battles begin.

headline: Cavaliers Owner Proclaims ‘No Regrets’
text: Dan Gilbert, the owner of the Cleveland Cavaliers, said Wednesday he has no regrets about l’affaire LeBron James.

headline: G.M. to Pare Down Debt Before I.P.O.
text: 4:30 p.m. | Updated Susanne Craig of The New York Times discusses the General Motors financial makeover in a video on the jump. And Nick Bunkley of The Times has more details about G.M.’s plans.

headline: Graduate Pays Back Cornell With $80 Million Gift
text: Cornell University must surely be pleased that one of its graduates, David R. Atkinson, made a fortune on Wall Street. Mr. Atkinson, Class of 1960 and a retired money manager, and his wife, Patricia, are giving the university $80 million — the largest individual gift that it has ever received.

headline: A Love Letter to a Camera
text: Dear Canon S95,

headline: Taking Genetic History to the Grave
text: Has the death of a loved one left you wondering about your own genetic risk for cancer?

headline: The Morgan, Restored
text: The 1906 McKim building at the Morgan Library & Museum will reopen on Saturday after a $4.5 million restoration.

headline: Responding to Reader Comments on Password Security
text: In response to my recent post on password security, a number of readers put up comments that provided other suggestions for good password security, put password security in a different perspective, or just emoted about this sometimes frustrating issue. Thanks to all for taking the trouble. Here are my responses to some of them:

headline: High Jobless Rates Persist Among Blacks and Hispanics
text: Since the depths of the recession, unemployment has been persistently high for blacks and Hispanics in New York City, while it has declined among whites and Asians, according to an analysis released on Thursday by the city’s comptroller, John C. Liu.

headline: New DNA Tests Aimed at Reducing Colon Cancer
text: Two new DNA-based tests, one of them described at a meeting in Philadelphia on Thursday, hold the promise of detecting early  and sharply reducing  colon cancer, a disease that afflicts 150,000 people a year in the United States and costs an estimated $14 billion to treat.

headline: Print vs. Digital: Analyzing and Designing Book Apps for Works of Literature
text: Overview | How has digital technology changed the way we read? How might e-books and book applications enhance our reading experiences? In this lesson, students consider the ways that new ways of reading have changed the nature of reading and design book apps for literature they have read in print. They then reflect on and compare the experiences of reading in print and in digital formats.

headline: Robert Duffy on the Stump
text: Mr. Duffy introduces Andrew M. Cuomo at a campaign stop at a steak house in Batavia, N.Y. as part of a tour of Western New York on Monday.

headline: 4 Nations With Child Soldiers Keep U.S. Aid
text: WASHINGTON — In 2009, the government of Chad conscripted refugee children for unlawful use as guards and combatants in its desert battles against rebel forces; the army of the Democratic Republic of Congo forced children to carry ammunition and supplies through the jungle, and some died under their weight; hundreds of boys and girls were forced into the army of southern Sudan, despite a commitment to release them; and in Yemen, children as young as 14 make up perhaps half the ranks of both the government’s forces and the rebels opposing them.

headline: Streetscapes | J.P. Morgan's Library
text: The library of 1906 was also a place where the financier retreated to smoke cigars, play solitaire and on one occasion, to save New York.

headline: Le Toux Among Most Valuable, but He’s Not on the List
text: There is an old baseball story that loosely informs a soccer story in Major League Soccer this season.

headline: Gebrselassie Racing Marathon Course, Not Clock
text: Having won world championships or set world records from the metric mile to the marathon, Haile Gebrselassie of Ethiopia is considered by many the greatest distance runner of this or any generation.

headline: The Architect Charles McKim, Designer of the Morgan Library
text: THIS weekend the Morgan Library and Museum marks the opening of its refurbished centerpiece, J. P. Morgan’s severe, jewel-like library of 1906, one of the signature works of the architect Charles McKim. And on Tuesday Knopf released “Triumvirate: McKim, Mead & White: Art, Architecture, Scandal, and Class in America’s Gilded Age," by Mosette Broderick. This 581-page history serves as the only modern work to examine the career of the reflective, often depressed McKim, perennially in the shadow of his flamboyant and equally troubled partner, Stanford White.

headline: Brooklyn Condo in Historic ‘Graham Home for Old Ladies’ Is for Sale
text: AS the city’s housing market soared over the last decade, many abandoned buildings and old factories were developed into condominiums. Few of those conversions, however, have as rich a history as the condo at 320 Washington Avenue in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, which was built in 1851 as the home of the Brooklyn Society for the Relief of Respectable Aged Indigent Females.

headline: Money Transfer Site Attracts Venture Capital
text: PeerTransfer, a Web service based in Boston that specializes in international money transfers and payments, said Thursday that it had secured a first round of venture financing worth $1.1 million.

headline: Verizon Deal Ends Inquiry Over Fees
text: WASHINGTON — Verizon Wireless, the nation’s largest mobile phone carrier, will pay $25 million to end an investigation into complaints that it had charged 15 million cellphone customers unauthorized data fees over the last three years, the Federal Communications Commission announced Thursday.

headline: How to Save a Third of Your Income
text: In her new book, “Generation Earn: The Young Professional’s Guide to Spending, Investing, and Giving Back” (Ten Speed Press), the author Kimberly Palmer recommends that young adults try to save at least a quarter of their annual income.

headline: Reviving Haitian Revelry in Greenwich Village
text: BARRYTOWN, N.Y. — Didier Civil stood in the center of the dilapidated barn, surrounded by skeletons, horse heads and other costumes that will form part of Sunday’s Halloween parade through Greenwich Village. He wrapped a piece of white lace around the colossal head of Gran Brigitte, a Haitian voodoo spirit of the dead. When she is complete, the papier-mâché Brigitte will stand 18 feet tall. Swathed in a purple robe and headscarf, she will join her husband, Baron Samedi, at the front of the parade.

headline: Dressing Up for Halloween, and Election Night Beers
text: Everybody has a dark side, and the Miser can think of no better time than Halloween weekend to help you explore it.

headline: Two Sides of 'Amer'
text: A scene from the rehearsal video for the film “Amer,” then the same scene as it appears in the completed film.

headline: Candy of All Stripes, in Stores in New York City
text: YOU’RE never too old to dress up for Halloween, but after about 13, if you turn up at an unsuspecting someone’s door looking for candy, you could end up in the back of a squad car.

headline: ‘Shrinking’ the Climate Problem
text: I’ve written here before about the substantial part of the climate challenge that isn’t out in the world of greenhouse gases and coal furnaces, but within the human mind.

headline: Senator Gillibrand’s Hudson Valley House on the Market
text: Our colleague Sarah Kershaw has the lowdown on Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand’s Hudson Valley home up for sale: a five-bedroom, four-and-a-half bath house on 13 acres in Hudson, N.Y. The listing over at Halstead Property notes the property’s “spectacular Hudson River views” and “delightful guest cottage.”

headline: New York High School Students Will Get Chance to See ‘Scottsboro Boys’ for Free
text: In a rare move, the Theater Development Fund — a nonprofit group that runs Broadway’s TKTS discount booth and an array of arts education programs — has bought all of the seats to two performances of a Broadway show for nearly 1,800 New York City high school students to attend.

headline: The Success of Political Nostaglia: Answers From Matt Bai
text: In his “Political Times” column on Wednesday, Matt Bai wrote that “we may see the election of several venerable politicians to offices they held before, including some who haven’t governed since the days when ‘apple’ and ‘blackberry’ referred primarily to fruit.”

headline: New DNA Tests Aim at Reducing Cancer
text: Nicholas Wade of The New York Times reports on two new DNA-related tests in an article recently posted on our Web site. The tests, he notes, “one of them described at a meeting in Philadelphia on Thursday, hold the promise of detecting early — and sharply reducing — colon cancer, a disease that afflicts 150,000 people a year in the United States and costs an estimated $14 billion to treat.”

headline: G.M. Moves to Clean Up Its Books Before I.P.O.
text: DETROIT  Preparing for its highly anticipated public offering next month, General Motors said on Thursday that it would repurchase $2.1 billion in preferred stock held by the federal government, contribute at least $6 billion to its pension plans and pay down debt to a health care fund for union retirees.

headline: Mets Get More Time to Negotiate With Takahashi
text: The Mets and the new agent for Hisanori Takahashi have received permission from Major League Baseball and the Players Association to push back the deadline for signing him, probably for about another week, although the exact date has not been determined.

headline: Do Dogs Like to Dress Up for Halloween?
text: Like many pet owners, I have, on occasion, dressed up my dog. One Halloween, Fluffy was a pink princess. Another time, she was Batman.

headline: Inquiry Puts Halliburton in a Familiar Hot Seat

headline: The Morning Skate: Coaches Challenges? MacLean in Trouble? Rangers Reverting?
text: During the second intermission of the Islanders-Montreal game, TSN’s Darren Dreger reported that he had surveyed N.H.L. coaches on whether they’d like to see a challenge system instituted in the league, much like the N.F.L.’s, where head coaches can request a review of an official’s decision. (video and here on his blog).

headline: Coffeehouse Cool Amid the Stroller Scene
text: MY mother never let me have Pop-Tarts  breakfast shouldn’t involve frosting, was the theory  but she would approve of the version sold at Ted & Honey, a snug cafe on Clinton Street next to Cobble Hill Park in Brooklyn.

headline: Neighborhood Joint | Ted & Honey
text: Ted & Honey, a cafe next to Cobble Hill Park in Brooklyn, has become something of a neighborhood institution since it opened in 2008.

headline: Condé Nast Moves One Executive Out, Another Up

headline: City Plans to Push Repairs for Set of Bronx Buildings
text: The city will begin aggressively cataloging violations in ten decrepit Bronx buildings, make emergency repairs and issue liens if not repaid, officials said on Thursday, in the hopes of forcing the firm controlling the portfolio to fix the buildings and usher them into responsible new ownership.

headline: Now Riding | Hermès and Yamaha
text: Hermès is more synonymous with horse riding than with motorcycling. But the haute leather goods house has once again collaborated with Yamaha, having upholstered the new VMAX Concept Bike in buffalo leather. (Hermès and Yamaha worked together on a similar project 15 years ago.) The waterproof matte leather is available in black and chocolate, and is a sleek complement to the bike’s brushed aluminum fixtures. A matching helmet is also available, upon request. The price tag for the bike is approximately $62,000 and delivery takes from one to four months, but — hey — it’s quicker than a waiting-list Kelly bag.

headline: Name This Face

Giuliani unveiled Tuesday at City Hall turns into a veritable celebrity Rorschach, bringing to mind any number of actors, politicians and cartoon notables (as well as, of course, Mr. Giuliani himself, who sat for the portrait artist Everett Raymond Kinstler in 2006).

headline: Fields Study | ‘Strange Powers’
text: Tonight, at Other Music, the ever-brooding Stephin Merritt will be manning the turntables for the opening of “All Our Friends Are In New York,” a photo exhibit of which he and his band, the Magnetic Fields, are the principal subjects. About the night’s musical program, Merritt told The Moment, “I suppose I’ll be playing the bubblegum and psychedelic music that I generally play. Maybe with an Octoberish slant — if I show up and there are skeletons hanging over the place.” The exhibit itself, which is on view through Nov. 14, is tied to the release of “Strange Powers: Stephin Merritt and the Magnetic Fields,” a documentary, 10 years in the making, which Mike Hale reviewed this week in the New York Times. The exhibit features candid photos of the band, including one of Merritt taking a smoke break on the fire escape at Spin Magazine, where he once moonlighted as a proofreader. Asked what he thinks of music journalists today — he’s a critical darling who in 2006 was the butt of some very bad press — Merritt said: “I think that working for a magazine is the highest possible calling and that all rock journalists are saints that are governing the country.” Yes, Merritt can be sharply sarcastic, and also blunt, as in his appraisal of the documentary itself: “It’s boring — it’s just me and my friends, talking about me.”

headline: Cold Case Files
text: Ian Frazier’s “Great Plains,” published in 1989, was a tour de force of travel writing: a 25,000-mile jaunt from the Dakotas to Texas that stripped away the region’s seemingly bland facade. From Sitting Bull to Bonnie and Clyde to the Clutter family, whose murder was chronicled in Truman Capote’s “In Cold Blood,” Frazier revisited American archetypes, and in some cases reinvented them. Later, in “On the Rez,” he drew on his 20-year friendship with Le War Lance, a beer-swilling Oglala Sioux, to describe life at the Pine Ridge Reservation in South Dakota. In both books, Frazier’s skillful storytelling, acute powers of observation and wry voice captured the soul of the American West.

headline: The Boys With the Band
text: The fledgling men’s-wear label Tuesday Night Band Practice was born out of harmonic convergence. The founding foursome — Robin Graves and Mark Murder, who are from Britain, and Ben Bones and Dan Danger, who hail from Australia — first met up in Bali over weekly jam sessions and started turning out illustration-heavy, verse-inflected T-shirts. (Graves is an illustrator by trade with a penchant for songwriting.) But as they soon discovered, making music is one thing and making clothes is another entirely. Bones and Danger splintered off. “It’s a similar situation with bands,” Graves said. “People have certain directions and visions, and mine and Mark’s are both coming from U.K. We’re very art-directioned, and when you’ve got your ideas, you can work quite rapidly and leave other people behind.”

headline: Award-Worthy Political Ads

headline: Making Music Like a Pro. Sort of.
text: Music-minded Mac users have GarageBand, which is bundled on all new Macs, to create and edit music. Windows computers, by comparison, don’t include music-creation software, and that has left some users singing the blues. Unaccompanied.

headline: Voters Are Encouraged to Report Any Problems With Machines
text: The city’s new electronic voting machines, are definitely, definitely going to work fine on Election Day, but just in case, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg urged New Yorkers to call 311 and to use Twitter to report any and all problems they observe at voting sites.

headline: Solar Power Projects Face Potential Hurdles
text: NIPTON, Calif.  The long-promised solar building boom in the desert Southwest is finally under way. Here in the Mojave Desert, a dice throw away from the Nevada border, giant road graders and a small army of laborers began turning the dirt for BrightSource Energy’s $2 billion Ivanpah project, the first large-scale solar thermal power plant to be built in the United States in two decades.

headline: Coffeehouse Cool Amid the Stroller Scene
text: My mother never let me have Pop-Tarts — breakfast shouldn’t involve frosting, was the theory — but she would approve of the version sold at Ted & Honey, a snug cafe on Clinton Street next to Cobble Hill Park in Brooklyn.

headline: Soaring Above India’s Poverty, a 27-Story Home
text: MUMBAI  The newest and most exclusive residential tower for this city’s superrich is a cantilevered sheath of steel and glass soaring 27 floors into the sky. The parking garage fills six levels. Three helipads are on the roof. There are terraces upon terraces, airborne swimming pools and hanging gardens in a Blade Runner-meets-Babylon edifice overlooking India’s most dynamic city.

headline: A Tidy Home, Cluttered With Weighty Emotions
text: Grieving parents have become such a movie staple that the theme is now a demonstrable cliché. Such grief isn’t new in movies, but the preponderance of these stories — recent examples include “The Lovely Bones,” “Creation,” “Antichrist,” “I’ve Loved You So Long” and the forthcoming “Rabbit Hole” — suggests that filmmakers believe that there’s something compelling about the agony of others. To this strange canon add “Welcome to the Rileys,” about a middle-aged couple and the young stripper who comes between them with platform heels and the kind of sad eyes you used to see on the side of milk cartons.

headline: ‘Grant Wood’
text: Sometime in the late 1930s, Grant Wood confided to his sister that he had a double. Mistaken for the artist by Wood's lifelong friends and even his Aunt Jeanette, this shadowy figure had appeared as far away as Omaha and as uncomfortably close as the painter's home in Iowa City. The story of Wood's doppelgänger appears only briefly in his sister Nan's memoirs — the reference is casual, the mystery left unsolved — yet it raises related questions about the impression Wood made on those who knew him best, and reveals, to use Nan's words, one of the many "strange by-products" of her brother's fame. Typically more amused than alarmed by his own celebrity, Wood confessed that in this instance "the matter makes me feel a little queer."

headline: Streetscapes | Charles McKim
text: The reopening of the J.P. Morgan library, and a new book, cast a spotlight on the architect Charles McKim.

headline: Gothic American
text: “American Gothic” has been described as the most reproduced painting in this country, which is not necessarily high praise. What artist would be elated to hear that one of his paintings had been appropriated in an advertising campaign for General Mills country cornflakes, or ­Coors beer? For most of his life, Grant Wood endured the scorn of leading art critics, who failed to recognize his refinement. He was known for one painting only, that image of a pale, homely farming pair posed in front of their white house, looking as if their dog just died.

headline: Ogled and Threatened on a Journey to Womanhood
text: Sex, death and schlock: Hélène Cattet and Bruno Forzani’s “Amer” (the French word for bitter) is a surreal cinematic tone poem that pays slavering homage to Italian giallo horror films of the 1970s. Its three parts, which dissolve into one another, observe a female protagonist, Ana, played by three actresses — in childhood, adolescence and adulthood. The movie has almost no dialogue, and its cheesy soundtrack (some of it borrowed from vintage giallo films) is punctuated with aural shocks and effects, including heavy-breathing gasps.

headline: The Eye of Mrs. Vreeland
text: With “Balenciaga: Spanish Master” opening in mid-November at the Queen Sofia Spanish Institute in Manhattan, a new edition of Diana Vreeland’s “Allure” seems strangely well-timed. The first edition appeared in 1980, when Vreeland was special consultant to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where she organized costume shows of Balenciaga and Yves Saint Laurent, among other legends. She worked on “Allure” with Christopher Hemphill, a process that took three years as Vreeland sought the elusive quality of personality in images of celebrities and models, in their gestures and sometimes violent expressions — a special condition for pictures of Maria Callas — and Mr. Hemphill did his best to oblige her. He recorded their conversations as they went along.

headline: The Fall Auction Season
text: Before the big sales, the auction houses will be filled with multimillion-dollar masterpieces and are open to everyone, not just the art elite.

headline: Other People’s Children
text: My 6-year-old daughter’s best friend has a very physical younger brother, who often hits and pushes. Their mother has difficulty handling him. Recently, as we were walking down a flight of stairs, he pushed my daughter, almost causing her to fall. The mother told him meekly to stop. When he pushed her again, I grabbed him by the arm and yelled, “No pushing on the steps!” He cried. They left, and the mother has been unfriendly since. My wife thinks I should apologize, but I don’t. Verdict?

headline: Auction Houses as Museums: Art on Display Presale
text: THE New York City Marathon isn’t the only race this town is bracing for. The beginning of November is also the start of the fall auction season, that twice-yearly endurance test when collectors and dealers from all over the world arrive here with comfortable (though fashionable) shoes to see and perhaps buy a painting, a drawing or a sculpture at the important Impressionist, Modern and contemporary art auctions.

headline: Lions Gate Sues Icahn Over MGM Deal
text: Lions Gate Entertainment is still angry at the billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn, even if they now agree that the movie studio should merge with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.

headline: Photo of the Week
text: An Indian woman gets her hand decorated with henna paste as part of “Karwa Chauth” festivities, in Allahabad, India.

headline: The Opulence of the Underworld
text: As visually sumptuous as it is dramatically inert, “Persephone,” a multimedia production from the Ridge Theater at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, at least presents a lush feast of imagery for the eye to savor. At its bewitching best the production evokes a French neoclassical painting that has magically bloomed into three dimensions.

headline: Tourism to Mexico Is Up
text: Undeterred by travel warnings and frightening headlines about safety in Mexico, an increasing number of international tourists are flying to the country, according to the Mexico Tourism Board. The number of international tourists who flew to Mexico from January to August increased 19 percent over the same period last year, according to the board, and most were from the United States. More than four million American citizens flew to Mexico, an increase of 15 percent over the same period last year, and about 61 percent of international tourists to Mexico are Americans.

headline: The Caucus Click: Basehor, Kan.
text: At Recordnews Presort, Mailing & Printing, political campaign material to be mailed to voters in Kansas and Missouri runs through a heating process after addresses are printed.

headline: Governor’s Aide Steps In for Ousted Environment Chief
text: Gov. David A. Paterson is replacing a Pete with a Peter. On Thursday he announced that his deputy secretary for the environment, Peter M. Iwanowicz, was taking over as acting commissioner of the state Department of Environmental Conservation after the dismissal of Alexander B. Grannis, better known as Pete.

headline: The Whitney’s Good Old Friend Is Joined by Some of His
text: It’s Edward Hopper time again at the Whitney Museum of American Art. A little more than four years ago the museum’s 75th-anniversary celebration, “Full House,” devoted an entire floor to his work.

headline: Period Rooms Take on a Modern Gloss
text: They have their charms, but the 18th-century period rooms at the Metropolitan Museum of Art are not the first place visitors are likely to go. Stocked with antiques that barriers prevent you from studying up close and dimly lighted in the interest of historical authenticity, they may be invaluable for decorative-arts wonks, but they can’t compete for popularity with the Impressionist and Ancient Egyptian galleries.

headline: On Fortepiano, the Subtle Intimacy of Schumann
text: With Andras Schiff’s extraordinary Schumann recital at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday still echoing in a listener’s memory, the tenor Mark Padmore and the fortepianist Kristian Bezuidenhout offered a very different view of the composer on Wednesday evening at Zankel Hall.

headline: Forget a Playoff and Focus on Scheduling
text: College football fans across the country have been trying to make sense of the Bowl Championship Series standings since they first came out two weeks ago. Itʼs like trying to understand Les Miles’ clock management.

headline: Potash Shares Fall on Worries About BHP Deal
text: OTTAWA  Investors seem to be growing nervous about the future of the Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan.

headline: ‘Robopolls’ Significantly More Favorable to Republicans Than Traditional Surveys
text: I mentioned in passing in last night’s post that surveys that use automated scripts rather than live interviewers — what are sometimes called ‘robopolls’ — have shown more Republican-leaning results this year. Given how sensitive forecasts can be to fairly minor variations in the polling, it is worth going into more detail on this.

headline: The Undead Are Undaunted and Unruly
text: The one good thing about the walking dead is that they don’t drive.

headline: Dude, Can I Have My Parody Back?
text: The country long ago stopped wondering whether a president demeans his office by appearing on a late-night comedy show. The more immediate question posed by President Obama’s appearance on “The Daily Show With Jon Stewart” on Wednesday is whether a political satirist loses credibility when hobnobbing with a sitting president.

headline: Bill Clinton Tried to Get Meek to Drop Out
text: Former President Bill Clinton last week tried to convince Kendrick Meek, the Democratic candidate for Senate in Florida, to drop out of the race – but Mr. Meek changed his mind at the last minute, a spokesman for Mr. Clinton said Thursday evening.

headline: Tension and a Stern, Deep-Focus Note on Bass
text: Michael Formanek played the first notes at the Jazz Standard on Wednesday night, his double bass clamped in a bear hug. The notes came fast and hit squarely, with articulate force. Mr. Formanek was flanked by several partners  the alto saxophonist Tim Berne, the pianist Craig Taborn, the drummer Gerald Cleaver  but for the moment it was just his roomy, rubbery tone filling the air, preceding the formation of a theme.

headline: A Very Zen Robust Emptiness, Set to a Work by Cage Inspired by Thoreau
text: Most choreographers find a style and stick with it, but in the case of the French choreographer Angelin Preljocaj, you’re never exactly sure what you’re going to get. There are the twists on classics (his “Roméo et Juliette” is set in a police state) as well as the dances that are as overwrought as they are overworked (“Paysage Après la Bataille,” or “Landscape After the Battle,” which pitted Marcel Duchamp against Joseph Conrad).

headline: A Family’s Misery, a Composer’s Moment
text: It has been hard for supporters of New York City Opera to see this essential company humbled by administrative and financial crises in recent years. But George Steel, City Opera’s tireless general manager and artistic director, has argued that it is more important now than ever for the institution to have a clear mission and to do adventurous work.

headline: Creating 'Monsters'
text: Gareth Edwards, the director of "Monsters," discusses how he also built the special effects for the film on his computer. The film is now on DVD.

headline: Betrayed by a Mafia Underboss
text: Salvatore Vitale, a former underboss of the Bonanno crime family, helped put away 51 organized-crime figures through his testimony as a government witness, 38 of them for murders.

headline: Assistance Trickles to Indonesian Islands
text: Indonesian rescue workers struggled to reach tsunami victims on Thursday as the death toll continued to rise from the natural disasters that hit the archipelago nation this week.

headline: A Flawed Cement Recipe
text: After a well is drilled, engineers pump cement in to seal the gap between the drill hole and the pipe, preventing oil and gas from the reservoir from escaping to the surface. Recent tests showed that the cement mixture used in the Macondo well was unstable.

headline: Potential Titian Buyers Get an Advance Look
text: Although images of Titian’s “Sacra Conversazione: The Madonna and Child With Saints Luke and Catherine of Alexandria” appear in much of the literature on that Renaissance master, the painting has not left the walls of its Swiss home for more than 30 years. The last time it made a public appearance was in 1978 at an exhibition in Geneva.

headline: Worries Grow About BHP Deal for Potash
text: Investors seem to be growing nervous about the future of the Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan, The New York Times reports.

headline: In Trilogy’s Finale, Tough Girl Rages Against Villains of Society
text: Lisbeth Salander can finally wipe the blood off her face. After being repeatedly beaten and raped, tied up like a pig being prepped for the knife and shot one, two, three times (in one go), the little woman with the large tattoo can sit back in her cool digs and enjoy a much deserved smoke. It’s been a long time coming, literally, what with seven hours of art house pulp craziness — Nazis and child molesters, an evil psychiatrist and a prostitution ring — which, among other things, proves that women in trouble never go out of style.

headline: A Luxe Designer, Restored to Glory
text: Joseph Urban, the Vienna-born architect and interior and set designer, was so renowned in the 1930s that when he was dying of cancer at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York, he checked in as Mr. John Smith to keep away gossipers and stalkers.

headline: Blagojevich Defenders Looking For Help
text: As they hunker down for a long winter sorting through the evidence from former Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich’s first trial, members of a thinned-out defense team are hoping that free help is on the way.

headline: Judicial Retention Vote Could Change Course of Politics for Decade
text: It’s fitting that a $150-a-head fund-raiser for Thomas Kilbride last week was in the basement of a Loop restaurant and that most of the attendees can’t even vote for him.

headline: Preckwinkle Promotes Her Independence as Some Question It
text: It is a longstanding practice for Cook County’s Democratic Party heavyweights to dismiss would-be reformers as weaklings and phonies.

headline: City’s Skyscraper Title Is Going, Going ...
text: Chicago is facing another Second City moment: It soon will not be able to boast about having the tallest building in America.

headline: A Detective Who Solves Crimes for a Living, and as a Pastime
text: In the newest edition of his “Biographical Dictionary of Film” David Thomson writes that the French filmmaker Claude Chabrol “could go on forever, the last great pro.” The book had already gone to press when Chabroldied, at 80, on Sept. 12, but the posthumous American release of his last film, “Inspector Bellamy,” seems, if anything, to support Mr. Thomson’s judgment. The ease and professionalism that distinguished this prolific director’s later work is very much in evidence, as is an insouciant attitude, at once resigned and dismissive, toward mortality. The first thing you see is a graveyard, and the first sound you hear is whistling.

headline: Giants, Rangers Win
text: Despite somewhat lackluster ratings for Game 1 of the World Series between the San Francisco Giants and the Texas Rangers, Fox’s coverage, amid its dispute with Cablevision, led the night in prime time on Wednesday. Final audience figures for the game were not immediately available, but Nielsen’s preliminary estimates for the broadcast were considerably below those for last year’s first game between the New York Yankees and the Philadelphia Phillies, which drew 19.5 million viewers, and closer to Fox’s Game 1 ratings in 2008 (14.6 million), when the Phillies played the Tampa Bay Rays. CBS trailed Fox to rank second over all, garnering 11.6 million at 8 p.m. for “Survivor: Nicaragua” followed by “Criminal Minds” at 9 (13.9 million) and “The Defenders” at 10 (9.9 million). ABC was third with Halloween-themed episodes of its comedy lineup including “The Middle” (9.4 million) and “Modern Family” (13.1 million), both of which attracted their largest audiences ever. NBC finished fourth with reruns from 9 to 11 following “Undercovers” at 8 (5.4 million).

headline: Vow Against Attack Ads Resonates in Colorado
text: IDAHO SPRINGS, Colo.  In his appearances around the state, the No. 1 applause line for John Hickenlooper, the Democratic candidate for Colorado’s governor, comes when he talks about running a positive campaign.

headline: In Sharp Rise, 47 City Schools May Close Over Performance

headline: The Tricky Business of Halloween Sunday

Just the last day of October.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Churchill During the War, Armed With Inspiration
text: “Winston Churchill: Walking With Destiny” is a handsomely produced, television-scale documentary with a split personality. Over all it’s a glowing biography of Churchill the wartime prime minister, with sonorous (and nearly constant) narration by Ben Kingsley, extracts from the famous speeches and periodic emotional crescendos — Dunkirk, the Battle of Britain, the Blitz — marked by surging strings and crashing cymbals. No mention here of the undeniably great leader’s imperialist dark side.

Seduced at 16 by a smitten uncle-in-law (Dermot Mulroney), Jolene (Jessica Chastain), a survivor of sequential foster-home abuse, embarks on a 10-year search for stability and happiness.

headline: Senate Update: Washington Is the New Florida
text: Back during the 2008 presidential campaign, we coined a term called tipping-point states. A tipping-point state was one that might potentially put Barack Obama (or John McCain) over the top to his 270th electoral vote, thereby winning him the presidency. States like Colorado, Virginia, Florida and Ohio were ranked highly by this metric.

The film mostly eschews the pumped-up emotionalism of Hindi movies and very nearly dispenses with Hindi too. (English is mostly spoken here, with smatterings of French, Tamil and, yes, Hindi.)

headline: Details Emerge on Man Charged in Plot on Subway
text: Farooque Ahmed, who was accused of trying to help men he believed to be militants plot bombings at subway stations in the Washington-area, told an undercover F.B.I. agent that he had used firearms, and practiced at a shooting range, according to an affidavit filed in federal court on Thursday as part of a search warrant. Mr. Ahmed, a 34-year-old naturalized American citizen of Pakistani origin who lives in Ashburn, Va., was arrested in a sting operation on Wednesday. He also told the agent that he planned to go fight Americans in Afghanistan and Pakistan, after traveling to Saudi Arabia for the hajj, a Muslim pilgrimage. Federal agents began tracking Mr. Ahmed in January, after he and a friend spoke of their interest in carrying out jihad.

headline: The Latest Gulf Outrage

headline: Serbia: Reward for Capture of Mladic Increased
text: Days after the European Union urged Serbia to increase its efforts to capture Ratko Mladic, left, the fugitive accused of masterminding the massacre at Srebrenica in 1995, officials there increased the reward for information leading to his capture. The government said in a statement on Thursday that it had raised the reward to $14 million from $1.4 million. “Serbia is determined to get rid of that burden,” Verica Kalanovic, the nation’s infrastructure minister, said, according to Reuters.

headline: The Quiet of War
text: To most people, the word “war” is likely to conjure dramatic images of combat. Soldiers ducking for cover. Helicopters swooping low. Medics treating the critically wounded. But for deployed troops, life at war is also filled with many quieter moments. Mundane, perhaps; but those moments may carry powerful memories, bitter and fond. They may evoke a vivid sense of place. They may even define a deployment in some intensely personal way.

headline: Other Ace Puts the Giants in Command

headline: Polls Track Governors’ Races
text: A Field Poll out Thursday on the California governor’s race shows Jerry Brown, the Democrat, with a 10-point lead among likely voters over Meg Whitman, the Republican and former eBay executive. That marks a significant change from the last Field Poll, in September, which found the two candidates tied. Mr. Brown is helped in the latest poll by support among independents, women and Latinos. The poll was conducted Oct. 14 to 26 among 1,092 likely voters, and has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.

headline: Pacino Wants to Be Fair to Shakespeare
text: SOME stars get their names above the title. Others’ appear in lights on the marquee. Then there’s Al Pacino. A giant photo of his weary-looking face in the new production of “The Merchant of Venice” towers above West 44th Street, high above signs for “Phantom of the Opera” and “American Idiot.” The Public Theater production of "Merchant," staged by Daniel Sullivan at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, received glowing reviews last summer, but this simple, unadorned portrait explains why the show is transferring to Broadway at the Broadhurst Theater: star power, pure and simple. And, sure enough, ticket sales have already been brisk.

headline: How the Horror Can Serve the Hilarity
text: NEAR the close of “The Coward,” Nick Jones’s play set amid the dueling culture of 18th-century England, most of the characters lie prostrate on the stage. Dead or dying, they whimper and groan as they smear the set with blood. A father takes a tender farewell of his son. Two lovers bid adieu. One noblewoman declares poignantly: “If I die, I die for something larger. For honor.” Then she uses a handkerchief to dab at the viscera spilling from the front of her dress.

headline: By Any Means Necessary: Gawker and the O’Donnell Post
text: We get it. It’s a dirty, terrible world out there and anything and everyone is fair game. So when some guy was willing to trash Christine O’Donnell, the Republican candidate for United States Senate in Delaware, for the small money Gawker paid for the scoop, it was just one more step down the road to clickable perdition. Except even as she was being fed into the digital wood chipper, various other parties on the Web began to step back and wonder why a pretty average night between seemingly normal people was being pathologized.

headline: Samurai Shopper | Decades Dance
text: Few shopping outposts in America possess the pampered-poodle patina of Decades, a vintage shop on Melrose Avenue that dresses Hollywood’s fish-lipped set in mint-condition, 20th-century couture. DecadesTwo, established in 1999 as “a 21st Century designer consignment shop” — not to be confused with the designer-purgatory pit stop Century 21 — was the sequel. And last week, DecadesTwo, “the first internationally branded luxury consignment business with sales surpassing $5 million” (whew), introduced DecadesTwo.1, an e-commerce Web site for those who prefer to rock vintage boots that are not made for walking without risking a single blister.

headline: Combat Duty, Close to Home
text: Returning from an assignment in Brooklyn on Nov. 5, 1988, the photographer Ángel Franco had a message for his editors on the picture desk of The New York Times. He added it to the caption notes on the back of the 8-by-10 contact sheets with the day’s take: “Important. Please do not show faces. Puts our source in danger. Life and death situation. For both of us.” Our colleagues at Lens remind us with a gallery of photos from the 1960s through the 1980s that “When Drugs Ruled New York Streets,” a picture assignment could be a tricky — and risky — business.

headline: Nudge the Vote
text: Over the past few days, thousands of Democratic-leaning voters nationwide — including the young people, minorities and unmarried women who were a crucial part of Barack Obama’s 2008 coalition and whom the party is desperate to rouse again on Tuesday — received a message in their mailboxes that effectively said: we’re keeping an eye on you. The mailers are the handiwork of Hal Malchow, a political consultant who is acting on a theory that first intrigued him four years ago. Before the 2006 Michigan gubernatorial primary, three political scientists isolated a group of voters and mailed them copies of their voting histories, listing the elections in which they participated and those they missed. Included were their neighbors’ voting histories, too, along with a warning: after the polls closed, everyone would get an updated set.

headline: Be Alert to Protect Yourself Against Medicare Fraud
text: THIS month, more than 40 members of what is said to be an Armenian-American crime syndicate were arrested and charged in an extensive Medicare fraud. Prosecutors say the suspects stole the identities of doctors and thousands of patients, using them at more than 100 bogus health clinics in 25 states to bill Medicare for more than $100 million.

headline: The New Momism
text: They make for strange bedfellows, Sarah Palin, leading her pack of “mama grizzlies,” and Michelle Obama, now touring the country on behalf of beleaguered, largely female Democratic candidates as the self-described “mom in chief.” The former beauty-pageant flutist dead set on undoing health care reform and the working-class Harvard law grad intent on consolidating her husband’s legislative triumphs couldn’t be further apart in their political goals or in their personal histories. But each is doing the mom thing — big time — tapping a vein of sentiment and belief, practicing a special form of political sympathetic magic, hoping clearly that by invoking the image, inveighing the glorious beloved power of all that’s maternal, they will warm and rally the hearts of voters enough to get them to the polls and determine the outcome of the midterm elections.

headline: Letters: What Does He Do Now?
text: Peter Baker, in his insightful appraisal of the president, quotes Governor Rendell of Pennsylvania as grading him “D-plus or C-minus on communication.” Alas, this may be true. But it is very odd indeed, given that a major factor in Obama’s election was his extraordinary ability to communicate. Here, many of us thought when he was elected, was an ace of eloquence. Since then, it appears he has neglected the legendary bully pulpit to his great disadvantage. Perhaps in the next two years he ought to take a page from F.D.R.’s notebook and begin a series of regular “fireside chats” on television to speak directly to the American people.

headline: Letter: The Sound of Spirit
text: I am a great admirer of Arvo Pärt’s music in spite of the mystic Christianity surrounding it. To my ears, Pärt is about architecture and spatial ordering rather than theology. But whatever it takes him to compose his beautiful sounds is his business and fine with me. Religion has already poisoned the well of politics; it would be a shame for it to do the same for our understanding of music.

headline: Letters: The Medium
text: If the implications of the e-book trend hadn’t already given me pause (and they had), Virginia Heffernan’s recent column about the Kindle feature that highlights text found notable by other readers would have iced the job. I’ve never been enamored of reading used books marked up by their former owners, and here now, it seems, is the e-version of that bugbear. Despite a user’s ability to disable the intrusive feature, many will not. As a result, they will encounter text produced not by its author but by a vast community of the opinionated. Is this, then, the future of e-literature and — perish the thought — of all literature? A world where, to access the “virgin text,” readers must disable features and fight the temptation to read a book littered with the signposts of what others have found noteworthy? Is too much freedom, in the publishing industry and elsewhere, not necessarily a good thing? As an author, should I feel that my work — punctuated with underlined phrases I chose deliberately not to emphasize — has been bowdlerized or enhanced?

headline: Is the Move to Hybrids Hyped?
text: How popular will electric and hybrid cars be in 10 years? Depends on whom you ask.

headline: London Underground | The Pleasure Seekers
text: “Hedonism is not just about all-night partying, it is the pursuit of pleasure in everyday life,” Fleur Britten tells me as we sip our herbal teas in the sun outside the hipster/gay hangout Dalston Superstore. As the editor of “A Hedonist’s Guide to London,” Britten has made it her job to know how to enjoy living in that city, and is taking me on a design tour of some of her favorite hangouts.

headline: Letters: The Old World

headline: Letter: Little Brother Is Watching
text: I was disturbed and disheartened to see Walter Kirn, in an otherwise discerning essay on our loss of privacy, describe the behavior of Tyler Clementi’s roommate (taping an intimate encounter and putting it online) as “prankish” and “silly juvenile troublemaking.” We are not talking about an 8-year-old here; we are talking about a college student, someone surely old enough to be expected to make reasonable judgments about what might be upsetting or painful to another person, and then refrain from acting purely on impulse. Just because the technology is there doesn’t excuse a person from using it indiscriminately.

headline: Real-Life Golden Girls

headline: Letter: The Traditionalist
text: Arthur Lubow’s article fails to mention perhaps the greatest influence on Robert A. M. Stern: the ultraluxury apartment buildings like 1040 Fifth Avenue and 740 Park Avenue designed by Rosario Candela, with the latter structure developed in 1929 by James T. Lee, maternal grandfather of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis. Candela’s high-end apartments sported abundant bathrooms (even for servants), innovative floor plans including multiplexing, graceful spiral staircases, private terraces (the effective response to set-back requirements) and many wood-burning fireplaces. The sweeping chimney stack of 1040 is the direct antecedent for Stern’s 15 Central Park West. A careful study of Candela’s work reveals a genius eclipsed by the Depression yet brought to life again by Stern.

headline: Frightful Medicare Scams
text: Medicare scams cost taxpayers billions of dollars every year and cause vexing problems for patients seeking legitimate care, reports Walecia Konrad in today’s Patient Money column.

headline: Inside Outsider
text: As a presidential historian and emeritus professor at Northwestern, you’re well aware that the Democrats are facing the likelihood of an electoral setback this Tuesday. Yet President Obama continues to be the object of scathing criticism among Democrats, including yourself. Why won’t you give him credit for getting things done?  He gets things done in a very crippled way. The health care plan and the finance plan — he made so many bargains along the way.

headline: End-of-Life Duty
text: At 65 years old, I am facing a final diagnosis for lung cancer and the prospect of a 15 percent survival rate. If this is confirmed, would it be ethical to put myself through painful long-term treatment and to have the people who love me endure this? At my age, is it ethical to consume the health care dollars involved? What is the tipping point to elect aggressive care? Thirty percent? Sixty percent? G.M., JACKSON HEIGHTS

headline: Microscopic Microeconomics
text: In the last decade or so, the American economy has been undone by a series of bubbles. First there was the dot-com boom, in which start-ups without business models were suddenly worth billions of dollars. Then after a brief recession, we began speculating about real estate, so that Las Vegas tract homes tripled in value before they even had roofs. The latest suspect for a bubble is gold, which has doubled in price over the past three years.

headline: The Cancer Sleeper Cell

headline: Good News, Bad News
text: When the Gap unveiled a new logo earlier this month, the reaction was swift, intense and very, very negative. In fact, some people detested the look so much it actually inspired them: somebody set up a Twitter account (@GapLogo) that purported to speak in the unpopular design’s voice, and someone else built a site called CrapLogo.me that made it easy to convert any short text into an imitation of the brand’s new style. The Gap tried to pivot off the negative buzz by asking the online hate mob for advice, in a sort of “crowd sourcing” gimmick, but that didn’t go over well, either. In just four days, the company capitulated and announced that it would not change its logo after all.

headline: Funeral for a Friend
text: I started to distrust telephones the instant they stopped working. I can’t pinpoint when that was — the first time I “dropped” a call, or someone said, “I’m losing you” — and I don’t know why the telephone, the analog landline telephone, was never formally mourned. I do remember clearly what life was like when telephones worked.

headline: 'The Larry Sanders Show'
text: A clip from the enormously influential, deeply neurotic HBO comedy that starred Garry Shandling as the anguished talk-show host and Sharon Stone as his guest.

headline: Survey Forecasts Reliability of 2011 Cars
text: GENERAL MOTORS has made such significant improvements in its products that Chevrolet, Buick, Cadillac and GMC are now ranked as more reliable brands than Mercedes-Benz, BMW and Audi, according to a survey released last week by Consumer Reports.

headline: Video: Undefeated, but for How Long?
text: Missouri, Michigan State and Oregon are all undefeated, but all face tough opponents in the coming weeks. Connor Ennis and Paul Myerberg break it all down on this week’s edition of the Pregame Huddle.

headline: TimesCast | October 29, 2010
text: The Florida race; what the GDP numbers mean and why people like scary movies.

headline: Keeping Both Spouses in the Financial Picture
text: NO one likes to be left out. But when it comes to financial matters, excluding one spouse from the decision making can, at the least, lead to unease but, at the worst, cause distrust.

headline: Oh No! New Museum to Take Down Distinctive Outdoor Sculpture
text: An exuberant, colorful exhortation on a drab stretch of the Bowery in downtown Manhattan will not greet pedestrians strolling by the New Museum of Contemporary Art for much longer. On Friday the museum said that this weekend it will take down “Hell, Yes!,” a sculpture by the Swiss artist Ugo Rondinone that spells those words in rainbow-colored letters on its second-floor ledge, and begin preparations to replace it with a new work by Isa Genzken called “Rose II.” “Hell, Yes!” was unveiled on the museum’s facade when its new building at 235 Bowery was opened in December 2007, and the sculpture became so closely associated with the institution that it was acquired by trustees and donated to the museum. Though nothing could replace it in our hearts, we’ll try to keep an open mind about “Rose II,” a 28-foot-tall depiction of a flower that is expected to be fully installed by the end of November. The museum said it would put “Hell, Yes!” in a new location, but did not yet know where or when this would take place.

headline: Carlsen Wins Pearl Spring With a Round to Spare
text: With a win in the penultimate round, Magnus Carlsen has already clinched first place, defending the title he won last year.

headline: Immigration Reform? Really?
text: Richard Wolffe has the scoop on how the White House plans to take the fight to the Republicans in a brave new post-midterm world:

headline: A Shifting at the Top of Columbia Pictures
text: LOS ANGELES—There’s been some moving and shaking among the movers and shakers at Columbia Pictures. Matt Tolmach, who had been jointly overseeing Columbia Pictures in a co-presidency with his fellow executive Doug Belgrad, is leaving the executive team for a choice assignment as one of the producers of the next “Spider-Man” film. Mr. Belgrad becomes Columbia’s sole president, while Hannah Minghella was named production president of Columbia. Ms. Minghella was previously the production president of Sony Pictures Animation. Michael Lynton remains the chairman and chief executive of Sony Pictures Entertainment, which includes Columbia, and Amy Pascal remains the co-chairwoman of Sony Pictures. “I couldn’t be happier for or prouder of Matt, Doug and Hannah,” Ms. Pascal said in a statement on Friday.

headline: Asked & Answered | Alex Gartenfeld and Haley Mellin
text: It’s perhaps the biggest thing to hit New Jersey since the Situation. At least as far as the art world is concerned. On Oct. 24, the New Jersey Museum of Contemporary Art opened with an exhibition curated by two wunderkinder of the downtown scene: Alex Gartenfeld, 23, the online editor of Interview and Art in America, as well as the curator of the West Street Gallery; and Haley Mellin, a 30-year-old artist whose curatorial work has included shows at Palais de Tokyo in Paris and Rental Gallery in New York. The theme? Made in America. Gartenfeld and Mellin bring more than a fresh perspective; their deep connections in the art community brought out a glittering roster to the kickoff, including Aurel Schmidt, Ryan McGinley and Rita Ackermann. T caught up with the dynamic duo via e-mail to find out how they are keeping all of the balls in the air and what they learned about the Garden State.

headline: Super Bowl Ad Slots Sell Out Early
text: In another sign of the strong demand among advertisers for commercial time during so-called big TV events, Fox Broadcasting has sold all the spots it plans to run in Super Bowl XLV on Feb. 6.

headline: Russia Joins Drug Raid in Afghanistan, Marking Advance in Relations With U.S.
text: MOSCOW  Russian counternarcotics agents took part in an operation to eradicate several drug laboratories in Afghanistan this week, joining Afghan and American antidrug forces in what officials here said Friday marked an advance in relations between Moscow and Washington.

headline: When to Ask Parents for a Business Investment
text: In a recent Your Money column, “Underwriting a Child’s Business Poses Pitfalls for Parents,” Ron Lieber offered advice for parents considering investing in their child’s business.

text: This week: A conversation with Ian Frazier about his “Travels in Siberia”; Deborah Soloman discusses a new biography of the artist Grant Wood; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive) //

headline: Inside the List
text: PERSIAN PERPLEX: Joel C. Rosenberg first crashed the hardcover fiction best-seller list in 2002 with “The Last Jihad,” a thriller, written before the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, that begins with a hijacked airplane dive-bombing the president’s motorcade and ends with American nukes raining down on Iraq.

headline: Choosing Between Life and Limb
text: HERE’S a not very promising idea for a movie: A young man goes hiking alone, gets his arm stuck under a boulder in a crack in the ground and after five days, during which nothing much happens except a few hallucinations, extricates himself by performing a self-amputation.

headline: The Ethics of the War Logs: Debating the Pros and Cons of WikiLeaks
text: Overview | What is WikiLeaks, and why did it distribute hundreds of thousands of secret United States government documents about the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq? What ethical questions arise from the work of WikiLeaks? In this lesson, students answer these and related questions as they read primary documents and news analyses from and about WikiLeaks’s war logs in preparation for a class debate over whether WikiLeaks is a champion of freedom of information or an instigator of trouble.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: DRIVING ON THE RIM,  by Thomas McGuane (Knopf, $26.95.) The rambling plot of McGuane’s novel is held together by its pleasurable, acutely observed episodes, and by the sardonic Montana doctor at its center, sympathetic in his dissociated journey.

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE MUSEUM OF INNOCENCE,  by Orhan Pamuk. Translated by Maureen Freely (Vintage International, $15.95.) A privileged Istanbul resident becomes “the anthropologist of my own experience” to describe his lifelong obsession with a shopgirl, his distant cousin. He begins to collect mementos of their affair — a hair clip, a cup, cigarette butts — and a character named Orhan Pamuk plays a significant role in the story. Questions of class and of East and West, raised by the narrator’s position as a wealthy Turk, make this, as Pamuk writes, “not simply a story of lovers, but of the entire realm, that is, of Istanbul.”

headline: Paladino Still Believes Gillibrand Is Schumer’s ‘Little Girl’
text: ALBANY — Carl P. Paladino meant what he said.

headline: World Cup Votes to Proceed Despite Corruption Allegations
text: FIFA President Sepp Blatter offered a rare sign of vulnerability Friday when he acknowledged it was a mistake to decide the hosts for the 2018 and 2022 World Cup tournaments at the same time. Still, the votes will proceed on Dec. 2 as scheduled, despite allegations of corruption.

headline: The Candidate Is Not My Type
text: DURING the 2008 presidential campaign, Barack Obama’s choice of Gotham  an elegant 21st-century font  for his campaign signage was praised by graphic designers for its modernity and implicit message of change. Critics derided John McCain’s font, Optima, which was developed in the 1950s, and recalled the printing on a remedy for gastric distress.

text: For the easiest pizza you’ll ever make, try lavash, a thin flatbread that makes a great substitute for traditional pizza dough. Martha Rose Shulman explains:

text: IF early retirement brings happiness, France should be the happiest place in the world.
