headline: Drop the Weapons
text: Since the detonation of nuclear weapons over Japan, American presidents haven’t learned to love the bomb, but rather have worried about it. In 1946, the Truman administration presented the United Nations with the Baruch Plan for international control of nuclear weapons, which Stalin, working on his own bomb, rejected. Four decades later, Ronald Reagan almost signed a deal with Mikhail Gorbachev to eliminate nuclear weapons, but this time missile defense proved an insuperable stumbling block. Now that President Obama and senior statesmen like George Shultz and Henry Kissinger have endorsed the abolition of nuclear weapons, the issue has assumed a fresh ­prominence.

headline: Dream Sequence
text: This absorbing novel — the first from the distinguished Spanish author to be translated into English — is full of mild sensations. Mild humor (bacalao soaked for dinner in the toilet tank) gives way to mild horror (a woman bends over another’s baby with “the posture of certain all-consuming insects”), which in turn yields to mild philosophizing (on the “admiration that denizens of the rural world feel for folding things”). At times, the mildness turns to provocation, as when the main character, a simple yet baffling woman named María Antonia Etxarri, watches a troop of soldiers and has “a feeling that one of those soldiers, if not more than one, was going to rape her.” The placidity with which she faces this prospect is galvanic. But de Lope’s languid sentences, artfully translated by John Cullen, continue to unfurl, and you find yourself sinking back into the narrative as if it were quicksand.

headline: Nation-Building
text: On Sept. 17, 1787, the convention that had been sitting in Philadelphia for four months to design a new form of government for the United States adjourned, offering its handiwork to the nation. Almost a year later, on Sept. 13, 1788, Congress declared that the Constitution had been duly ratified, and prescribed the rules for the first presidential election the following year. Pauline Maier’s delightful and engrossing book shows how America got from the first date to the second — and ultimately to today, since we still live with the same document, however modified.

headline: Sailing Alone
text: I grew up loving Joshua Slocum’s “Sailing Alone Around the World.” It was “Walden” without the training wheels. Whereas Thoreau made so much of his precious solitude in a shack only a couple of miles from his home in Concord, Slocum actually put himself at risk. In his 50s, pistol-whipped by fate, he set out in a largely self-built 36-foot sailboat and somehow managed to circumnavigate the earth. He might have been without a crew, but he was hardly alone; he had the magical Spray for a companion: a vessel that could literally steer herself for hundreds of miles at a time while he reclined contentedly in his book-lined cabin eating salt cod and reading “Don Quixote.” For a landlocked teenager who had both nautical and literary ambitions, Slocum was almost too good to be true.

headline: Arms and the Man
text: The Soviet Union did not often make a product superior to the American alternative. Nobody in his right mind would have chosen to drive a pokey Lada over a speedy Corvette or even a stolid Packard. One of the few exceptions was in the military sphere, where the Soviets devoted a disproportionate share of their resources. In the long run, their greatest engineering triumph may not have been the construction of an atomic bomb in 1949 (based on stolen Western secrets) or the lofting of the first satellite into orbit (1957) or even the first man in space (1961). Far more enduring, if more low tech, was the development of the world’s most ubiquitous firearm: the AK‑47, or as it is often called, after its designer, the Kalashnikov.

headline: Abnormal Psychology
text: “God on the Rocks” is so charming a novel that you don’t want to give away a single one of the many twists of its plot. As its central character might ask: “Why can’t she just — not?” But Jane Gardam must be shared. She’s a find who’s just beginning to be found, at least on our side of the Atlantic (thanks to the novels “Old Filth” and “The Man in the Wooden Hat”), although more than 20 of her books have been published in England and she has won numerous prizes. Now at last comes the American publication of her early novel “God on the Rocks,” which was a finalist for the Booker Prize back in 1978.

headline: State Court to Exchange Guidance With a Foreign One
text: The concept is novel and, as far as New York State’s chief judge can tell, unprecedented: a state court agreeing with a court system in another country to provide each other with legal guidance.

headline: Trick or Treat on the Street
text: By ERIC DASHWhat might be a scarier sight on Wall Street than Elizabeth Warren in a mortgage modification center? More ghastly than a Goldman Sachs C.D.O.? Packed with more skeletons than Citigroup’s balance sheet?

headline: Discussing Finances as a Couple
text: In his Wealth Matters column this week, Paul Sullivan discusses an issue that’s often not discussed by couples — their finances. In particular, he writes that one partner is often making all the financial decisions, leaving the other in a difficult position if he or she ends up managing the family’s money at the worst possible time: after death, disability or divorce.

headline: What It Takes to Buy a House in Foreclosure
text: ATLANTA  As in any economic downturn, the wave of home foreclosures has attracted voracious opportunists  investors among them who are buying, fixing and then renting the places out.

headline: In the Beginning
text: Lucy Bergmann sits in front of a little fire in the South of France, thinking of Wordsworth, the Bedouins and the ancient document — an alternative rendering of the Book of Genesis — that her friend Pierre has just read aloud. She is about to express her admiration for pantheism when a gang of intruders bursts into the room, one brandishing a gun. The reader, desperate to be spared Lucy’s musings on religion, thinks: not a moment too soon. “I suppose you’ve come for the manuscript?” Pierre asks the men. “And for your pendant, Lucy,” one of them demands. Ah, yes, the pendant — a USB flash drive that Lucy wears around her neck containing evidence, discovered by her late husband, of extraterrestrial life.

headline: Finding His Voice, the Slow, Steady Way
text: IF we have heard it once, we have heard it a hundred times: The opera singer who hopes to last must learn to say no. The American tenor Brandon Jovanovich, at 40, has not always had that luxury.

headline: Coal Industry Spending to Sway Next Congress
text: WASHINGTON  The coal industry, facing a host of new health and safety regulations, is spending millions of dollars in lobbying and campaign donations this year to influence the makeup of the next Congress in hopes of derailing what one industry official called an Obama administration “regulatory jihad.”

headline: Tough Love
text: Bruce Machart’s impressive first novel, “The Wake of Forgiveness,” opens with a scene of a pioneer woman dying in childbirth on a homestead on the South Texas plains. Her husband, a Czech farmer named Vaclav Skala, carries her body into a hayloft so his three older boys do not wake to find their mother dead, then burns the gore-spattered mattress upon which his fourth son was born and stares into the flames to avoid looking at his hands, “stained with the blood of the only woman he’d ever been fond of.”

headline: Athens Marathon Is a Siren Call Hard to Ignore
text: Not much in this world can celebrate a 2,500th anniversary. And certainly not much in the way of sporting events.

headline: Weekend Competition: Terrifying Titles
text: This Halloween weekend, Schott’s Vocab is soliciting shuddersome, spooky and spine-chilling re-workings of book titles.

headline: ‘Speed Limits’ Exhibition at the Wolfsonian-F.I.U. Museum in Miami Beach
text: A new exhibition at the Wolfsonian-Florida International University, the museum in Miami Beach devoted to design, propaganda and the decorative arts, looks at a century of the modern idea of speed — and its limits.

headline: Paul Kolton, Who Led the American Stock Exchange, Dies at 87
text: Paul Kolton, who became the first full-time paid chairman of the American Stock Exchange without ever having worked as a stockbroker, died on Wednesday in Stamford, Conn., where he lived. He was 87.

headline: Keeping Them Company at the End
text: IT was the second time in two days that Harriet had called me. The first time she had simply wanted some advice. Her husband, Sid, had a rare degenerative neurological disorder called progressive supranuclear palsy. At 81, he could not move and could barely communicate, and he was running a fever.

headline: Scientists Spar With Defender of Palm Oil and Pulp Firms
text: 8:18 a.m. | Updated

headline: Bits Pics: Video Calls From the Top of the World
text: In 1924 George Mallory was asked why he wanted to climb Mount Everest, the world’s highest peak. Mr. Mallory, a quick-witted and seasoned English mountaineer, responded: “Because it’s there.”

headline: Halliburton Rejects Blame for BP Cement Job
text: WASHINGTON  Halliburton, whose failed cement job on the BP well in the Gulf of Mexico was identified as a contributing factor to the deadly blowout by a presidential investigative panel on Thursday, is defending its work and assigning the blame for the accident to BP.

headline: The Long, Winding Road to a Foreclosure Purchase
text: In this weekend’s Your Money column, I tell the epic tale of Jennifer Kuzara, who spent about 1,000 hours finding, buying and fixing up a foreclosed home in Atlanta.

headline: Defending the Right to Long Hair
text: An essay by Dominique Browning last Sunday about her decision to keep her hair long in her mid-50s (“Flying a Long Flag of Rebellion”) drew an unusually large response from readers, with more than 1,200 comments posted on the Web site of The New York Times. Here is a sampling.

headline: Stuff Nightmares Are Made Of
text: There’s nothing quite as creepy as a creepy drawing: almost real, but just wrong enough to suggest it’s wearing only the torn-off skin of reality. Charles Burns’s comics are fluid, smooth and as solidly built as a vintage TV set, but they shudder with the chill of the uncanny. His slim graphic novel X’ED OUT (Pantheon, $19.95) filters William S. Burroughs’s body-loathing and disjunction through the iconography of Hergé’s “Tintin” comics. (Hergéphiles will notice a string of allusions, beginning with the front cover’s visual paraphrase of “The Shooting Star.”)

headline: Clinton Is Urged to Confront Vietnam on Human Rights
text: BANGKOK  The Vietnamese government has arrested or convicted a half-dozen dissidents and bloggers in the days before a visit to Hanoi by Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton, according to the United States Embassy and human rights groups.

headline: Motherless Child
text: FX Antoine, the 39-year-old narrator of Susan Straight’s latest novel, is an accomplished travel writer who’s reluctant to speak about her own hometown. If you’ve driven to Palm Springs, she bluntly tells someone in Los Angeles, “you passed Rio Seco.” This fictional working-class town figures in many of Straight’s novels, and Antoine’s mixed-race family settled in its orange groves after fleeing Louisiana, where their women were hunted by a white rapist.

headline: Hot Plates | Israel’s Creative Cooking
text: The creative streak coursing through many a Tel Aviv kitchen has spilled over to Jaffa, its ancient and often aesthetically unruly sister. Fittingly for a place that has served as a port since the Bronze Age, one of the new entrants sits in a retrofitted relic by the water: Container (Warehouse 2, Jaffa Port; 011-972-3-683-6321; entrees about $20 to $27) makes its home inside a hangar that dates from the 1920s, when Jaffa was part of the British Mandate of Palestine. The space fuses Red Hook grit with Levantine glam, incorporating a sweeping, 45-seat horseshoe-shaped bar under a warehouse-high ceiling that affords nice views of both the oversize wood oven in the open kitchen and the rotating exhibits on the walls. Adding to the mix is a three-times-a-week D.J. set.

headline: Harlem Troupe Prepares for Act II
text: HOW long can a company remain on hiatus until it disappears for good? In 2004 Dance Theater of Harlem, facing debt of about $2.3 million, was forced to shutter its 44-member professional company. Months turned into years, and it seemed as if the vibrant group, formed in 1969 by Arthur Mitchell and Karel Shook after the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., would end up a footnote to dance history.

headline: Majoring in Violin With a Minor in Piano
text: FOR a demonstration of comprehensive musicianship and instrumental mastery, few artists have topped the performance that the German violinist Julia Fischer gave at the Alte Oper in Frankfurt on Jan. 1, 2008.

headline: In Concert: Home-Grown New York Water Music
text: In one composition, the gurgles and pops picked up by a microphone placed 10 feet deep in the Gowanus Canal duet with a double bass. In another, heavily processed trickles from the Red Hook waterfront and ambient noise from the Coney Island Boardwalk pulsate behind an echo-y marimba.

headline: He Doesn’t Comp (Much)
text: IT was Thursday night at the Lambs Club, and Geoffrey Zakarian, the chef, stood in the center of the kitchen, peering into an iPhone app called Total Control, which was streaming live video from his security cameras. Mr. Zakarian’s attention to detail, it seems, is rivaled only by his gusto for control.

headline: Hockey’s Most Decorated
text: Some of the most famous hockey masks of a bygone era.

headline: Meet Todd Combs (the Teenager)
text: 5:03 p.m. | Updated The mysterious Todd Combs is faceless no more.

text: Mary Halvorson Quintet

headline: On Hard-Times TV, Dumpster Diving and Résumé Rehab
text: CINDERELLA’S fairy godmother arrived bearing a magic wand by which she produced the ball gown, pumpkin coach and glass slippers that made possible a gala night on the town.

headline: Eddy Hellebuyck Comes Clean
text: Athletes have been seeking an edge through the use of performance-enhancing substances for decades. But a sustained, systematic and widespread effort to combat cheating in sports has been around only since the International Olympic Committee created the World Anti-Doping Agency in 1999. Since then, a number of sports, including some that are not under the purview of WADA, have taken meaningful steps to tighten their testing procedures and have imposed stern punishment.

headline: Another Spiritual Seduction
text: METAL has traditionally been a genre in which definitions matter. It’s all deep, dark and dire, but evolves through its subgenres: death metal (torrid); black metal (cold); doom metal (lumbering); grindcore (frantic); and onward into smaller divisions. But some of the best new metal comes from widening the rules and deepening the sound.

headline: Especially for the Inner Ear
text: TWO new CDs  a live recording of “A Crimson Grail,” Rhys Chatham’s mammoth meditation for 200 electric guitars, 16 electric basses and percussion; and “Treasure State,” a collaboration between the instrumentalist-composers of So Percussion and the electronica group Matmos  draw in varying degrees on the notion that sound trumps content as the most crucial element of a composition. This is a time-honored idea in a particular corner of the avant-garde where conventional elements like melody, rhythm, harmonic movement and phrase structure are regarded as less fascinating than timbre, texture, duration, volume and intensity, particularly when these qualities change slowly, if at all.

headline: Week in Pictures, Oct. 29
text: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region.

headline: Habitats: A Roomy Park Slope Apartment
text: William and Lucille Harris moved into a roomy Park Slope apartment after World War II. Three children and about 60 years later, they are still there.

headline: ‘Milo’: Works by Bridge, Britten, Turnage
text: A WEB of musical connections among several generations of teachers, pupils and friends inspired this disc of works by three British composers, vividly interpreted by two other Britons, the cellist Guy Johnston and the pianist Kathryn Stott.

headline: The Election Will Be Tweeted (and Retweeted)

headline: Warp Speed for Risky Solar Ventures
text: In an article in Friday’s paper, I write about the solar thermal power plant building boom now under way in California’s Mojave Desert. The looming expiration of crucial federal financial support for the multibillion-dollar projects, though, could turn the boom to bust.

headline: Gas Station Worker Shot Dead Over Candy Bar
text: The police are searching for a man who shot and killed a gas station attendant after a dispute over a candy bar in the Bronx Thursday.

headline: Reviewing the 2011 Honda Odyssey
text: In Sunday’s Automobiles section, Cheryl Jensen reviews the updated Honda Odyssey, the best-selling minivan in the United States for the last two years. As Ms. Jensen notes, several automakers have cut minivans out of their lineups — partly, one suspects, because consumers have begun buying more crossover vehicles. Of the Odyssey, she writes:

headline: The Caucus: Florida Senate Race
text: Former President Bill Clinton last week almost succeeded in persuading Kendrick B. Meek, the Democratic nominee for the Senate in Florida, to drop out of the three-way race.

headline: Garry and Larry and Jeffrey and Hank
text: HISTORY has been doubly unkind to “The Larry Sanders Show,” the enormously influential, deeply neurotic HBO comedy that starred Garry Shandling as the anguished talk-show host of its title and Jeffrey Tambor as his bombastic but insecure sidekick, Hank Kingsley. First, the series ended its six-season run in 1998, before its cinematic, laugh-track-averse style (and its meta-fictional show-within-a-show) became the norm. Then, for years, only a handful of its episodes were available on home video. At least one of those wrongs will soon be righted. On Tuesday “The Larry Sanders Show: The Complete Series” will be released as a 17-DVD boxed set by Shout! Factory.

headline: Oligarchs and Absinthe Shots
text: The elevator doors opened to a phalanx of black-clad waiters offering champagne flutes, white wine, and water with lime. The Hudson River stretched out before the full-story windows. The Empire State building loomed close enough to touch from the 14th floor balcony. And in every corner — by the raw salmon bar, the grand staircase and the willowy model looking past her hefty suitor — the conversation was in Russian.

headline: Arts & Leisure Preview: Pee-wee Herman, Al Pacino, Garry Shandling and More

text: The Times’s Megan Liberman and Frank Bruni discuss the recent revelations that former President Bill Clinton unsuccessfully urged Kendrick B. Meek, the Democratic candidate for Florida’s Senate seat, to drop out of the three-way race last week.

headline: Artifacts | The Amazing Collapsible Family Muscle Car
text: Bikini-clad babes have been fixtures of auto shows since the “Mad Men” era, when cars became objects of desire for a predominantly male audience. Women like cars too, of course, and they go for the stylish ones even more. But they aren’t known for tinkering under the hood.

text: Photographs from Pakistan, Iran and China.

text: A look at some of the visual development paintings for the 3-D animated comedy "Megamind."

headline: Analyzing the Heat by the Numbers
text: Rob Mahoney is an obsessive student of professional basketball, dedicated to the minutiae, the overarching themes and everything in between. You can read more of his work at TheTwoManGame.com, HardwoodParoxysm.com and ProBasketballTalk.com.

headline: The Dark Art of Statistical Deception
text: Will sprinters one day break the sound barrier? Do Olympic athletes win more medals if they wear red? And can a simple formula predict happiness?

headline: Conjuring Tati’s Spirit With Animation
text: IN the spring of 2003 the animator Sylvain Chomet found himself on a train from Paris to the south of France, where his new film, “The Triplets of Belleville,” was to be shown at the Cannes Film Festival. “I had something like five hours to kill,” Mr. Chomet said recently on the phone from Paris, so he took out a script he had put off reading for years.

headline: Week 9 College Football Matchups
text: Let’s say this right now: It’s hard to go undefeated in college football. After about the third or fourth week of the season, we all start to worry about what happens if all these teams go undefeated. Then teams start losing. That’s the way it works. Suddenly, every week is like a playoff. Missouri and Michigan State are essentially playing playoff games on Saturday. Oregon as well. All those teams are on the road against ranked conference opponents with a lot to prove. A loss would knock any of them out of the national title conversation (some further out than others).  This is why I am not in favor of a playoff system. (Soapbox alert.) Not that I like the B.C.S., but I do not like the idea of a playoff.

headline: Big Cats, Tapirs and a Mysterious Bat
text: Wednesday, Oct. 27

headline: Pontiac, 84, Dies of Indifference
text: DETROIT — Pontiac, the brand that invented the muscle car under its flamboyant engineer John Z. DeLorean, helped Burt Reynolds elude Sheriff Justice in “Smokey and the Bandit” and taught baby boomers to salivate over horsepower, but produced mostly forgettable cars for their children, will endure a lonely death on Sunday after about 40 million in sales.

headline: Awareness: Blood Pressure Check With That Haircut?
text: Barber shops often serve as a pipeline for health information in African-American communities. Now, a study reports a striking success: when barbers checked their male patrons’ blood pressure on every visit, the men were far more likely to see a doctor and get high blood pressure under control. (There was also a financial incentive: a free haircut for those who returned with a prescription.)

headline: U.S. Nuclear Plants Get the Iraq Treatment
text: The International Atomic Energy Agency, perhaps best known to Americans for inspecting nuclear sites in Iraq, has spent the last two weeks in the United States. Rather than Tuwaitha, the notorious facility south of Baghdad, it has been passing time in Limerick Township, Pa., and Lower Alloways Creek, N.J. And in general, it liked what it saw, said Jukka Laaksonen, director general of Finland’s nuclear safety authority and the head of the delegation.

headline: Risks: Smokers Found More Prone to Dementia
text: Middle-aged smokers are far more likely than nonsmokers to develop dementia later in life, and heavy smokers  those who go through more than two packs a day  are at more than double the risk, a new study reports.

headline: On ‘Project Runway,’ a Final Plot Twist
text: WELL, I was wrong.

headline: The Morning Line: We Hardly Knew You, Super Saver

headline: Evil May Prevail, but Then What’s a Villain to Do?
text: WHEN it comes to superhero movies, today’s audiences come loaded with certain expectations: an emotional origin story, a menacing villain and the dynamic triumph of good over evil. The filmmakers behind the 3-D animated comedy “Megamind,” who have feasted on a steady diet of these movies over the years, embrace the genre’s staples in their creation but still manage to find an original twist: Their film is not based on a prior comic strip and it puts a superhero’s archenemy front and center.

headline: Finders, Keepers
text: A PHOTOGRAPH of an Army cadet pilot hangs on a wall in the apartment in Park Slope, Brooklyn, where William and Lucille Harris have lived nearly their entire married life. He wears a bomber jacket, goggles pushed up over his hair and a milewide smile. The fledgling pilot must have been a heartbreaker; not surprisingly, an insurance company clerk a decade his junior fell hard for him a few years after he returned from World War II.

headline: Profiteroles to Dazzle, Made at Home
text: BECAUSE profiteroles are served with a degree of fanfare in restaurants, you might not think of making them at home. Which is a shame; they’re easy and quite a bit of fun, even for a novice. I know this because I made them as a novice, with a recipe much like this one, and I experienced success, elation and praise.

headline: The Great Unwashed
text: A DAILY shower is a deeply ingrained American habit. Most people would no sooner disclose they had not showered in days than admit infidelity. But Jenefer Palmer, 55, of Malibu, Calif., cheerfully acknowledged recently that she doesn’t shower or shampoo daily and doesn’t use deodorant. Ever.

headline: The States Take on Foreclosures
text: Have you noticed that the lead dogs investigating the mortgage foreclosure mess are not any federal prosecutors or national bank regulators, but rather the state attorneys general? I sure have. I can’t think of a more encouraging development.

text: With an air of authority, the former Marine Sandy Alderson officially took over stewardship of the Mets’ baseball operations Friday by promising to develop a team that strives for the highest standard.

headline: Awkward Test for Scott if He Wins in Florida
text: If his bid to be Florida’s next governor is successful, Rick Scott could find himself in the awkward position of choosing his own inquisitor. New documents show that complaints into a chain of clinics he ran have been referred to the state health department, whose head is appointed by the governor.

text: FORK & VINE in Glen Head epitomizes the current trend in small plates and wine bars. The long, sleek restaurant, which opened in June, also adds full-size entrees to the mix. There’s something for everyone, and nearly all of it works well.

headline: Ruing Oakland’s Use of Steroids
text: Sandy Alderson, the Mets’ new general manager, presided over the Oakland Athletics as president and G.M. in the late 1980s, when that team was considered an incubator for the use of steroids in baseball. After the former Athletics slugger Jose Canseco wrote a book detailing his and teammate Mark McGwire’s use of performance-enhancing drugs, Alderson was interviewed by Congress and former Senator George Mitchell for a report on the subject.

headline: Abraham Lincoln and Sojourner Truth
text: Writing corrections is seldom a proud chore, but it is often eye-opening and, dare I say, educational. In an Oct. 3 review of Eric Foner’s book “The Fiery Trial: Abraham Lincoln and American Slavery,” we incorrectly described an enigmatic portrait of Lincoln and Sojourner Truth examining a Bible. (By the way, our reviewers are not responsible for captions, and the reviewer in this case, David S. Reynolds, a distinguished professor at the CUNY Graduate Center, kindly helped steer us to the truth.) The portrait, a painting by Franklin C. Courter (1854-1947), is a wonderful piece of Americana and well deserves more generous treatment.

headline: Despite an Illness, a Special Theater Role
text: As the Christmas party number, “Turkey Lurkey Time,” got cooking at a recent performance of Broadway’s “Promises, Promises,” the evening’s sign-language interpreter, Alan Champion, rose from his front-row seat and faced his deaf and hard-of-hearing audience from the right of the stage. Fifteen feet behind him were three dancers vamping onstage as ’60s-era secretaries, twirling as they sang about a “mistletoey Christmas.”

headline: Doughnuts and Cider: Wonders of Autumn
text: FRESH apple cider is one of autumn’s great glories, from the first bracing batches, made with early-ripening types like McIntosh and Jonamac, to the last sweet blends, made with late-hanging Winesaps, Yellow Russets and Idareds. Right now, we’re in the thick of cider season, which begins around the time children start planning their Halloween costumes and ends between Thanksgiving and Christmas.

text: When Meredith Monk performed her “Click Song No. 1” on Thursday, it sounded as if she was accompanied by an array of percussion. They accompanied Linda Ronstadt on two of her albums, and Beck on one of his. They even had a cameo role in the film “Sex and the City.”

text: “I’m going to make you shake,” Karl Hyde sang as Underworld started its set at the Roseland Ballroom on Wednesday night, over a four-on-the-floor beat and pumping keyboard chords aimed straight at dancers. He was in motion himself, moving across the stage with angled elbows and twitching hips like a jumpy stick figure. “The rhythm, the rhythm, the rhythm, the rhythm,” went the next song, “Always Loved a Film.”

text: SAN FRANCISCO  For years, AOL has tried and largely failed to make its main Web site a bigger hit with Internet users. The number of visitors to the site has eroded, as has the company’s overall revenue.

headline: Smiling Skeletons, With Lives to Lead and Issues to Raise
text: THEIR limbs crisscrossed at wild angles, their mouths puckered around toothless gums, their eyes deep black pools  the grinning skeletons in Nicolás De Jesús’s etchings are busy. Some are riding the subway, some are meeting in a cafe or attending an art opening, and others, throngs of them, are gathered to partake in Día de los Muertos, the Mexican celebration of the Day of the Dead.

text: It became the most successful world-music album in history, but “Buena Vista Social Club” happened by accident.

headline: Was It the Music Marathon or Fashion Week?
text: AFTER last year’s CMJ Music Marathon, the annual five-day festival sponsored by the College Music Journal, all anyone could talk about were the barely 20-year-old British youngsters who make up The xx. And while their haunting, minimalist debut album placed them on everyone’s best “Best Of” lists, from Rolling Stone to Pitchfork, their matching sartorial style  black on black on black  may have left an even greater impression.

headline: Split Personalities and a Double Motive
text: THE musical “Jekyll and Hyde,” about a 19th-century London doctor who develops a split personality, explores the idea of duality. A new production of it also has a dual nature, according to its executive producer, Beverly J. Bell.

headline: After a Leap, a Strong Defense by Poland
text: The World Young Ladies Championship for the Rona Cup in Philadelphia this month had a disappointing entry of four teams. Not surprisingly, because the Polish Bridge Federation runs many training sessions during the year, the 48-board final was won by Poland, Ewa Agnieszka Grabowska, Natalia Sakowska, Magdalena Holeksa, Joanna Taczewska, Danuta Kazmucha and Justyna Zmuda. They defeated France by 131 international match points to 97.

headline: When Is Gambling an Addiction?
text: When is gambling an entertaining pastime, and when does it become a compulsive addiction? Is stock trading a form of gambling addiction? How common is compulsive gambling, and is there a gambling gene? These are among the questions recently posed by readers of the Consults blog in “Ask an Expert About Gambling Addiction.”

headline: From Avant-Garde to Resurgent Realism
text: There’s a loud, rowdy conversation going on at the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art in Hartford, but you won’t hear any words. You will sense the energy, though, as the drawings, pastels and watercolors of “American Moderns on Paper” argue and cajole and campaign for form over color, or imagination over reality. You will feel the winds of the dawning 20th century pushing artists outward into teeming urban streets and bellowing factories and pulling them inward toward the bizarre landscape of dreams and the virgin territory of abstraction.

headline: A Traveling Storyteller Weary of the Awfulness of War
text: Among the oldest tales in Western culture, “The Iliad” is attributed to Homer, but this ancient saga of the tragic last days of Troy likely was developed through earlier versions told by many other bards.

headline: Fear of Profit
text: Almost 20 years ago, when I was reporting on the then-emerging field of microfinance (now a $25 billion industry), I discovered that different people would often look at the same set of facts and come to opposite conclusions about whether they revealed something positive or negative. At the time, most of the funding for microloans came from foreign aid and philanthropy, and no lenders had yet turned profits. For some business-minded people, this was awful. It demonstrated that microfinance was an illegitimate kind of banking, worse ─ a form of charity. For those who were socially concerned, it was a saving grace. If microfinance ever became highly profitable, they feared, it would attract the wrong kind of people ─ profit-seekers ─ who would ultimately abandon the poor.

headline: Georgia Democrat Proves He’s Not Pelosi
text: Representative Jim Marshall, a Georgia Democrat, has come up with a new prop to distance himself from Speaker Nancy Pelosi: his driver’s license.

headline: McDonald’s Workers Are Told Whom to Vote for
text: WASHINGTON  When workers in a McDonald’s restaurant in Canton, Ohio, opened their paychecks this month, they found a pamphlet urging them to vote for the Republican candidates for governor, Senate and Congress, or possibly face financial repercussions.

headline: Gunman Has Grievance With Marines, F.B.I. Says

headline: Disarray in Service of Deconstruction

headline: G.O.P. House Projection Steady at Plus-53 Seats
text: FiveThirtyEight’s House projection is unchanged over the past 48 hours. Over the course of its simulation runs, our model found Republicans gaining an average of 53 seats, which would bring them to 232 total. Democrats are given a 16 percent chance of holding the House, down slightly from 17 percent on Wednesday.

headline: Detroit Reins In an Annual Halloween Revelry
text: DETROIT  The arts community here is abuzz over the potential dismantling of the site of Theatre Bizarre, an 11-year-old party and macabre neighborhood carnival that is part Ringling Brothers, part “Dawn of the Dead,” and features makeshift rides, punk rock bands, over-the-top costumes, a haunted house, burlesque sideshows and other performances, some of them involving fire.

headline: A Carl Paladino Volunteer Shares the Anger

headline: Volunteer for Andrew Cuomo Is Calm Under Fire
text: THE phone calls roll into Andrew M. Cuomo’s campaign headquarters all day long, each one a tinder box: Why do no African-Americans live in Westchester? How dare Mr. Cuomo take his daughters to a gay pride parade? Does Mr. Cuomo know that hydrofracking will destroy upstate New York, and what is his position?

headline: No Halloween at Hedge Fund Haven
text: By PETER LATTMAN

headline: World Series Ratings Are Scary but Sufficient
text: Game 2 of the World Series posted ratings that were mediocre but likely enough to have lifted Fox to No. 1 on Thursday. Final figures for the live baseball game were not immediately available on Friday, but Nielsen’s preliminary estimates show the broadcast attracted slightly fewer viewers than Wednesday’s opening game, which garnered 15 million viewers. The estimates indicate that Fox probably led the night narrowly ahead of CBS, which drew strong ratings for its crime shows “CSI” (14.1 million) and “The Mentalist” (14.6 million) as well as its sitcoms. ABC was third, beginning the night with its annual special “It’s the Great Pumpkin, Charlie Brown” (7 million), followed by “Grey’s Anatomy” (10.7 million) and “Private Practice” (7.8 million). NBC was fourth despite solid ratings for the network’s Halloween special “Scared Shrekless” at 8 (8.2 million).

headline: Footnote
text: Ethan Stiefel, a principal dancer with American Ballet Theater, will become artistic director of the Royal New Zealand Ballet, the New Zealand company said on Friday. Mr. Stiefel takes over in September.

headline: Jon Stewart on the Hustings
text: UPDATED: The reviews are in! Summaries at the bottom of this post.

headline: Bondholders Approve MGM Bankruptcy
text: Bondholders of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer have approved a long-awaited restructuring plan, clearing the way for a bankruptcy filing that would eliminate some $4 billion in debt and put the studio under the management of the Hollywood executives Gary Barber and Roger Birnbaum, The New York Times reports.

headline: Becoming Han Solo
text: In Brooklyn, New York, a nearly paralyzed boy, who cannot talk, uses an iPad to tell his mother what he wants to be for Halloween.

headline: For Red Bulls, Renovation Started at Top
text: HARRISON, N.J.  The Red Bulls’ playoff opener in California on Saturday night could not be farther from the club’s sparkling new home or more distant from last season’s stunning debacle.

headline: The New Face of the G.O.P.? Grizzled Veterans
text: WASHINGTON  Christine O’Donnell, the Tea Party favorite and Republican Senate nominee from Delaware, is trailing badly in the polls, but her every utterance seems to win national attention. Meanwhile, John Hoeven, the three-term governor of North Dakota, remains largely unknown even though he is virtually certain to win a Senate seat next week  not to mention that he was recently named a finalist for the American Mustache Institute’s Mustached American of the Year award.

headline: Bruce Springsteen: 'Save My Love'
text: The song is from an upcoming album called "The Promise," which contains tracks from the recording sessions for his 1978 release "Darkness on the Edge of Town."

headline: Suicide Bomber Kills 25 at Cafe in Iraq’s Diyala Province
text: BAGHDAD — A suicide bomber struck a crowded cafe in one of Iraq’s most restive provinces on Friday night, killing 25 people in the deadliest attack here in more than a month.

headline: Missouri Dynasties Go Head to Head in a Senate Race
text: COLUMBIA, Mo. — The names on the ballot here are so well known that it is hard to believe that there are any undecided voters, especially after the assault of months of campaign commercials. But at a homecoming parade last weekend, the candidates were out nevertheless, flashing those familiar brands as they trolled for the undecided vote, estimated at 2 percent.

headline: After China’s Rare Earth Embargo, a New Calculus
text: BAOTOU, China  When Japanese mineral traders learned in late September that China was blocking shipments of a vital commodity, the word came not from a government announcement but from dock workers in Shanghai.

headline: U.S. Hears Echo of Japan’s Woes
text: TOKYO  In the annals of economic policy blunders, the one in which Hiroshi Kato played a hand in early 1997 ranks among the biggest in recent Japanese history.

headline: Nikki Haley No Longer a Sure Winner in S. Carolina
text: BEAUFORT, S.C.  She tours the state in a 34-person bus, has had her face on the cover of Newsweek and received endorsements from Sarah Palin and Mitt Romney.

headline: IPad Opens World to a Disabled Boy
text: OWEN CAIN depends on a respirator and struggles to make even the slightest movements  he has had a debilitating motor-neuron disease since infancy.

headline: Heat Begins Meeting Forecasts in a Rout of the Magic
text: MIAMI  The basketball changed hands in seconds, from Chris Bosh to LeBron James to Dwyane Wade. By the time Wade crashed it into the rim, the lucky piece of leather spent time with 17 All-Star selections, 2 N.B.A. most valuable players, 2 scoring champions and a finals M.V.P.

headline: DealBook Debate: Are Foreclosure Ills Overblown?
text: The New York Times’s Joe Nocera and Andrew Ross Sorkin discuss the role of banks in foreclosures in this DealBook Debate video. Document problems in the foreclosure process have raised questions about the culpability of banks. Aside from legal concerns raised by this issue, there also may be a wider impact on the economy.

headline: 'Memento Mickey'
text: A short Halloween film by Jeff Scher.

headline: Europe Plans System to Handle Debt Crises
text: BRUSSELS  European Union leaders decided Friday to create a permanent rescue system to handle sovereign debt crises like the one that threatened Greece this spring, but argued openly over whether private investors should share the burden of future bailouts.

headline: A Saint, and an Inquiry Into the Sins of His Brothers
text: MONTREAL  At least 50,000 Quebecers are expected to gather Saturday for something most rarely do: attend a religious service.

headline: A Hidden Minefield at Pregnancy Centers
text: I had barely finished signing in at the Expectant Mother Care counseling center in Downtown Brooklyn when a staff member ushered me into a darkened room for a sonogram. As we both watched the flickering image of what looked more or less like a tadpole, she called my attention to every anatomical detail, from eyes and nose to hands and toes. Staring at the little bugger wriggling around inside me, a tear slid out of my eye.

headline: ESPN to Make Decision on Miller and Morgan
text: Jon Miller and Joe Morgan’s fates as ESPN’s announcers on “Sunday Night Baseball” will be decided soon after the end of the World Series, which they are calling on ESPN Radio.

headline: Drug For Neurological Disorders Cleared By F.D.A.
text: Avanir Pharmaceuticals won approval for a drug that curbs bouts of uncontrolled laughing or crying in patients with neurological disorders, regulators said. The medicine, Nuedexta, is the first approved to treat patients with multiple sclerosis or Lou Gehrig’s disease who develop symptoms known as pseudobulbar affect that causes loss of emotional control, the Food and Drug Administration said. Avanir, which has no other products on the market, said it planned to begin selling the drug in the first three months of 2011. Shares of Avanir, which is based in Aliso Viejo, Calif., more than doubled in after hours trading to $5.17.

headline: Obama Campaigns for Perriello in Virginia
text: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. — Representative Tom Perriello squeaked his way into Congress two years ago with a 727-vote victory over his Republican opponent — after a recount. Friday night, with his political future hanging by a thread, President Obama tried to come to his rescue. It was payback, in part, for the Democratic congressman’s support of the president’s landmark health bill.

headline: Family First, Baseball a Close Second
text: Neal Shapiro believes in “the power of television to make people smarter” and the power of baseball to forge family bonds. He offers himself as proof of both. Mr. Shapiro, 52, is the president and chief executive of WNET.org, parent company of the public television stations Channel 13 and Channel 21 (WLIW). Before joining WNET in 2007, he was the president of NBC News and executive producer of “Dateline NBC.” He lives on the Upper West Side with his wife, Juju Chang, 45, a “Good Morning America” news anchor, and their three sons, Jared, 10; Travis, 7; and Mason, who turns 3 on Monday.

headline: City Views: Gardens, Postcards and History
text: GARDENS are hardly the first thing that comes to mind when you think about New York (after all, it’s New Jersey’s 19th-century vegetable farms  not New York’s  that inspired the nickname Garden State). But in “New York City Gardens” (Hirmer Verlag, $49.90), Veronika Hofer and Betsy Pinover Schiff offer up a visually inviting respite from the city of steel, glass, concrete and asphalt. They celebrate the city’s luxuriant public and private spaces  including one real estate company’s office terrace, which required 98 tons of planters, dirt, trees and material delivered over six months.

headline: Support for Paladino From a Few Florida Neighbors
text: BOCA RATON, Fla.  One would think that after almost 25 years of owning a condominium here, Carl P. Paladino would be able to rely on a little support from his neighbors in his underdog quest to be New York’s next governor.

headline: Bill Clinton’s Role in Florida Senate Race Seems to Cost Democrat Some Black Votes
text: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.  Former President Bill Clinton’s political bank shot appears to have hit its mark with many black Democrats who were lined up at the polls here Friday.

headline: Yemen Emerges as Base for Qaeda Attacks on U.S.
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Not long ago, most Americans had scarcely heard of Yemen, the arid, Texas-size country in the southern corner of the Arabian peninsula.

headline: Where Financiers and Families Gather
text: With the long-promised notion of the financial district as a 24-hour neighborhood coming ever closer to reality, this Irish-inflected brasserie, open about three weeks, is already generating buzz. Under Donal Crosbie, the executive chef, who has worked in first-class kitchens like Spago and Danube, the menu at Bailey offers updated versions of classics that include coq au vin, bangers and mash and a lobster roll. In a nod to the area’s growing family population, there is also a children’s menu that comes with free ice cream. With dark wood floors, red leather banquettes and big plate-glass windows overlooking the corner of William and Pine Streets, the restaurant offers breakfast, lunch and dinner. At midday on Wednesday, there were three business associates out for a quasi-social gathering.

headline: Explosives in Cargo Renew Debate on Screening
text: The discovery of two explosive devices shipped by cargo planes has reignited a long-running debate about how thoroughly cargo needs to be screened on its way into the United States.

headline: Juror Dismissed in Sentencing on 3 Murders
text: NEW HAVEN  A juror on the panel deciding whether to impose the death penalty in the home-invasion murders of a mother and her two daughters in Cheshire, Conn., was dismissed on Friday after making a derogatory comment in court about the defense.

headline: A Surge in Democratic Spending
text: Groups aligned with Democratic candidates have unleashed a last-minute paroxysm of spending in competitive House races in the final days of the campaign that has them outpacing Republicans, reversing the trend of the past few months, according to an analysis of campaign finance data by The New York Times.

headline: Driver in Crash That Led to Tougher Law Is Sentenced
text: A drunken driver was sentenced to 4 to 12 years in prison on Friday for killing an 11-year-old girl.

text: Caroline Sarah Donohue and Alexi E. Mantsios were married Saturday afternoon. The Rev. Michael J. Sheehan, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Stonington Lighthouse Museum in Stonington, Conn.

text: Kristen Elizabeth Cole and Gregory Martin Gaul were married Saturday in Rio Verde, Ariz. The Rev. Lloyd D. Powers, a Lutheran minister, officiated at the Rio Verde Community Church.

headline: Christin Cho and Andrew Hires
text: Christin Kyungsik Cho and Samuel Andrew Hires were married Saturday afternoon in Los Angeles, Calif. The Rev. Dennis McCarty, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated at the Bel-Air Bay Club, an event space.

text: Stacey Elizabeth McKeever and Charles Joseph Fogelman were married Saturday evening at reBar, a restaurant and event space in Brooklyn. Andy Grotelueschen, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

text: Amelia Katherine Seewann and Vladimir Brankov are to be married Sunday afternoon by the Rev. Anthony P. SooHoo at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

text: Molly Beauchamp Fahner and Robert Benn Calhoun III were married Saturday evening at the Fourth Presbyterian Church in Chicago. The Rev. Sarah Johnson, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

headline: Joan Giambalvo, Milton Hutson
text: Joan Elizabeth Giambalvo and Dr. J. Milton Hutson were married Saturday at the Riverside Church in New York. The Rev. Linda Tarry-Chard, a United Church of Christ minister, officiated.

headline: A Final Bid to Pretty Up an Ugly Senate Race
text: CHICAGO  Something remarkable has happened in the Senate race here: Gentle, gauzy ads  with no scary music, no sarcastic narrators, no actual meanness at all  are turning up.

headline: Mob Killer and Defector Receives Time Served, and Will Live in Hiding
text: By his own account, Salvatore Vitale took part in 11 murders during his 30 years with the Bonanno crime family. But Mr. Vitale, a former underboss who became perhaps the most significant Mafia defector in nearly two decades, will not have to serve any more than the seven years he has already spent in prison.

headline: Climbing High, at No Small Risk, to Capture the View
text: Around 4 a.m., Luis D. Rosado began making his descent from the huge History Channel billboard in the South Bronx, 10 good shots of the city at night digitally stored on his camera. He climbed down from his perch about 100 feet in the air, made his way through the vacant building below and, before stepping out, peered through a hole in scaffolding he had climbed a few hours earlier.

headline: A Polish-American Paper’s Final Edition
text: After 51 years and countless articles about Polish parades, banquets in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, and, especially, polka, The Polish American World confronted readers with an editorial recently that was as sad as it was inevitable.

headline: 2 Linked to Suicide Case Withdraw From Rutgers
text: The two Rutgers students charged with invading the privacy of a fellow freshman who killed himself after his romantic encounter with another man was streamed on the Internet have withdrawn from the university, their lawyers said on Friday.

headline: On the Street | It's Halloween
text: Earlier this month, the Anime Festival and Comic Con combined to fill the Javits Center, and many of the visitors were costumed as their favorite comic-book subjects.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: Comedy

headline: Lebanon: International Tribunal Says Hezbollah Tried to Obstruct Justice in Prime Minister’s Killing
text: The international tribunal investigating the 2005 killing of the former Lebanese prime minister, Rafik Hariri, left, issued a statement on Friday saying that calls to boycott cooperation with the tribunal constituted “a deliberate attempt to obstruct justice.” The statement came a day after the leader of Hezbollah, Hassan Nasrallah, called on the Lebanese not to assist the tribunal, which he has labeled a political tool of Israel and the United States. Hezbollah is waging a public campaign against the investigation amid reports that the tribunal is set to issue indictments of Hezbollah members.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Confidence in Abundance, Despite an E.R.A. of Infinity
text: ARLINGTON, Tex.  When the Texas Rangers’ clubhouse opened for reporters after Game 2 of the World Series in San Francisco on Thursday, the only player talking was Derek Holland. Five minutes after the home clubhouse opened Friday, before a workout at Rangers Ballpark, Holland was back at his locker, ready for more.

headline: The Rangers’ Clean and Sober Batting Champion
text: SAN FRANCISCO  If anybody is equipped to lead a team back from a two-games-to-none deficit in the World Series, it is Texas Rangers outfielder Josh Hamilton, who has climbed out of a deeper and darker abyss.

headline: Malnourished 4-Year-Old Girl’s Death Is Ruled a Homicide
text: A 4-year-old Brooklyn girl who weighed 18 pounds when she was found dead last month had toxic levels of antihistamines in her system, the city’s chief medical examiner’s office said on Friday in ruling the death a homicide.

headline: Reflecting on a Lawsuit Against a 4-Year-Old
text: That children under the age of 5 make it through the day, more often than not, without grievous bodily injury is something of a miracle, one of the many that present themselves to people once they become parents. But even young children have an instinct for self-preservation, which is why I find it even more mystifying how rarely those creatures  stick-wielding, stone-chucking, body-flinging  actually harm others.

headline: Trick or Treat! It’s Little Ron Washington!
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. – One of the tough things about covering the World Series these days (O.K., the only drawback) is that you have to miss your kids’ Halloween parades. But I’m pretty sure the costume “Texas Rangers Manager” is not too popular back in the New York area — especially after the Rangers eliminated the Yankees from the playoffs.

headline: Going to Extremes to Give Others the Creeps
text: Few theatrical productions, if any, offer a prize to audience members who have wet themselves. At Blood Manor, an elaborate haunted house on West 27th Street between 10th and 11th Avenues in Chelsea, a handful of spectators claim a souvenir T-shirt for that reason each season. On Thursday night, the actors, students and even a supermarket clerk who make up the spectacle’s macabre cast seemed intent on terrifying people into winning that prize.

headline: Ruling Sought on Suit Over 9/11 DNA Software
text: A federal judge in Manhattan has been asked to determine if a lawsuit can proceed that accuses the New York City Medical Examiner’s Office of stealing the secrets behind a computer program used to identify the remains of 9/11 victims.

headline: In Wake of Inquiry, Selig Resets Precedent
text: In the final weeks of the 2008 season, Commissioner Bud Selig was forced to confront a troubling situation: a valuable relief pitcher on a team contending for the postseason had tested positive for a performance-enhancing drug.

headline: Mary Emma Allison, Who Inspired Charitable Ghouls, Dies at 93
text: Six decades ago, on a fall afternoon, a young woman caught sight of a children’s parade. She followed the children, in bright native dress, as they wended their way through the streets of the town. They entered a store, with the woman behind them, and inside the store she encountered a cow. She followed the cow, and she came to a booth.

headline: Bedbugs? There’s an App for That.
text: Bedbugs are as likely to settle in luxury hotels as youth hostels. So, travelers may wonder, is there a way to figure out whether a hotel (or theater or restaurant) is infested? Well, now there’s an app for that.

headline: U.N. Sets Goals to Reduce the Extinction Rate
text: UNITED NATIONS  After years of wrangling, most United Nations member states agreed early on Saturday in Japan to set significant new goals to reverse the extinction of plant and animal species. As part of the accord, they also agreed that rich and poor nations would share profits from pharmaceutical or other products derived from genetic material.

headline: Artist Puts Hercules, and Himself, on Pedestals
text: BERLIN

headline: In Nevada, a Battle for Every Vote
text: Will the tea party wave swamp Harry Reid's organization? The answer lies in the hard-hit suburbs of Las Vegas.

headline: Alderson Ascension May Not Please All
text: Three weeks shy of his 63rd birthday, Sandy Alderson would appear to be at the perfect stage of life for the task of running a Mets organization that has been simultaneously  and sorely  lacking in youthful discipline and adult erudition.

headline: Gaza: Palestinian Islamic Jihad Vows Resistance
text: Tens of thousands of supporters of Palestinian Islamic Jihad gathered Friday to mark their movement’s 23rd anniversary and chant “Death to America and Israel” and slogans supporting armed resistance. “The motto of every honorable one should remain that Israel must be eliminated from life,” said Abdullah Shallah, the top Islamic Jihad leader, addressing the event by telephone from Damascus. Mr. Shallah attacked the Palestinian Authority in the West Bank for continuing peace talks with Israel. Any negotiated settlement to the conflict is “forbidden religiously and politically,” Mohammed al-Hendi, another Islamic Jihad leader based in Gaza, said at the rally. Islamic Jihad, which is heavily supported by Iran, is the third largest Palestinian faction, an ally and sometime rival of the ruling Hamas party in Gaza.

headline: France: Oil Workers Vote to End Their Walkouts
text: Workers voted Friday to end walkouts Friday at major French oil terminals and six of the country’s 12 refineries, after as many as 33 consecutive days on strike. The walkouts, most of which were in protest of President Nicolas Sarkozy’s proposed increase in the national retirement age, have caused gasoline shortages across the country and cost France’s oil industry several hundreds of millions of dollars, according to the French Union of Petroleum Industries. Gasoline shortages were expected to all but end this weekend, officials said, and refining operations were to begin again in the coming days. France’s lower house of Parliament gave final approval to the pension reform on Wednesday, and it is expected to become law in mid-November.

headline: Uncertain Return for Giants’ Kiwanuka
text: When the Giants placed Mathias Kiwanuka on injured reserve Thursday with a herniated disk in his neck, General Manager Jerry Reese and Coach Tom Coughlin each expressed hope that Kiwanuka would be healthy in 2011.

headline: Corrections
text: NATIONAL

headline: Baghdad’s Shiite Heart Beats Freely as War Ebbs
text: BAGHDAD  Is it too early to declare a Sadr City Spring?

headline: Sports Broadcasts Return as Fox and Dish End Dispute
text: Dish Network and the News Corporation’s Fox Networks unit announced a distribution agreement on Friday restoring Fox’s regional sports networks in Dish households after a four-week blackout.

headline: In Nevada, It’s Hold Nose and Cast Vote
text: HENDERSON, Nev.  The knock on the front door elicited the annoyed yapping of an unseen dog, followed by the appearance of a gray-haired man busily eating chips from a bag. His callers were two union workers, canvassing the neighborhood on behalf of Democrats, especially Senator Harry Reid.

headline: For Unsung Islander, Tough Jobs Are a Staple
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  Not long after he joined the Islanders, Zenon Konopka decided the team needed a new goal song. Their song was being used by other teams after a score, plus his teammates thought it was boring. The Islanders needed to start over, in more ways than one.

headline: Confidence in Abundance, Despite an E.R.A. of Infinity
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — When the Texas Rangers’ clubhouse opened for reporters after Game 2 of the World Series in San Francisco on Thursday, the only player talking was Derek Holland. Five minutes after the home clubhouse opened Friday, before a workout at Rangers Ballpark, Holland was back at his locker, ready for more.

headline: Anne Erdmann Solves the Saturday Crossword
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — I’ve been wanting to interview Anne Erdmann for a long time. She’s a fascinating person and one of the fastest solvers on the planet.

headline: Back on Board, Girardi Acknowledges Hurdles
text: The Yankees’ season came crashing down a week ago, but Brian Cashman, the general manager, has not wasted time working on next year’s squad.

headline: U.S. Says Genes Should Not Be Eligible for Patents
text: Reversing a longstanding policy, the federal government said on Friday that human and other genes should not be eligible for patents because they are part of nature. The new position could have a huge impact on medicine and on the biotechnology industry.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Girardi’s New Deal Carries Challenge of Handling Aging Stars
text: The Yankees’ season came crashing down a week ago, but Brian Cashman, the general manager, has not wasted time working on next year’s squad.

headline: Cost Cuts Help Merck to Avert Revenue Losses
text: The drug maker Merck reported third-quarter profit on Friday that rose more than analysts had estimated, as reduced costs helped overcome revenue losses from drugs facing generic competition.

headline: Rangers Stay With Lineup
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — With the Giants starting Jonathan Sanchez in Game 3, Rangers Manager Ron Washington said he would go with his usual lineup against a left-hander.

headline: Knicks Lose, but They Don’t Go Down Quietly
text: BOSTON  With two minutes left on the clock Friday night, the Knicks faced an 11-point deficit and a familiar fate: an unsightly loss to the Boston Celtics.

headline: Nevada’s Bleak Landscape
text: In these last frantic days of an extremely tight and unpleasant campaign, two candidates are united by the same problem: the voters of Nevada do not particularly like either of them.

headline: Trying a Home Remedy
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — C.J. Wilson loves to cook, read and surf. He plays guitar, practices martial arts and races cars. Wilson is also an expert in finger care, thanks to the occupational hazards of his day job, pitching for the Rangers. Over the last year, Wilson has developed a comprehensive routine to manage a blister on his left middle finger, which opened and started bleeding during the seventh inning of Game 2, knocking him out with the Rangers trailing San Francisco, 1-0.

headline: Pontiac: Cars and Culture
text: Pontiac brought Americans the Bonneville, GTO, Firebird and other venerable nameplates.

headline: How to Keep Agents Off the Field
text: THIS college football season, the play on the field has often been overshadowed by the steady reports of players being held out of competition while their contacts with agents are investigated. The confessions of one former agent, Josh Luchs, who told Sports Illustrated that he had given money to at least 30 college players, gave a sense of the depth of the problem. I’m all too aware of the damage done by agents who tamper with student-athletes: the football program at the University of Southern California, where I was a player and later athletic director, now faces a two-year bowl ban and three years of N.C.A.A. probation for violations stemming from such tampering.

headline: A New Attitude in Sadr City

headline: Senate Update: California May Be Out of Reach for G.O.P.
text: A new poll from Field Research, highest-rated polling firm in our database, gives Barbara Boxer an 8-point lead, 49 to 41, over her Republican challenger, Carly Fiorina. While Ms. Fiorina’s chances had already been on the decline — California has been very widely polled, and most of the surveys have shown Ms. Boxer holding a lead in the mid-single digits — the new poll on Friday harms her odds somewhat further. Given the robustness of the polling (and how close we now are to Election Day), our model gives Ms. Fiorina just a 4 percent chance of making a comeback, down from 7 percent on Thursday.

headline: Nos. 41 and 43 on the Roster
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. —The former presidents George H.W. Bush and George W. Bush will throw out the ceremonial first pitches before Game 4 of the World Series on Sunday. The Hall of Fame pitcher Nolan Ryan, the Rangers president, will do it before Game 3 on Friday.

headline: Sharp Changes in Maine, Oregon Governor Forecasts
text: I noted on Thursday that our forecasting model — even though it had shown an increase in Republican Paul LePage’s chances to be the next governor of Maine — still seemed to be underestimating him, given that the Democrat Elizabeth Mitchell was rapidly losing support to independent Eliot Cutler and that neither she nor Mr. Cutler were good bets to achieve the roughly 40 percent of the vote that Mr. LePage seems bound to achieve.

headline: Rebuilding Our Aging Water Systems

headline: Enough Game-Playing
text: Israeli-Palestinian peace talks have been suspended for four weeks, about as long as they were on. The more protracted the impasse, the harder it will be for the parties to get back to the negotiating table. More delay only plays into the hands of extremists.

headline: The Shame of New York
text: The whole notion of the rule of law, critical to a democracy, is sabotaged when the guardians of the law  in this case the officers of the New York City Police Department  are permitted to violate the law with impunity.

headline: The Noise About Public Radio
text: NPR’s ham-handed firing of Juan Williams, one of its senior news analysts, after he made foolish and hurtful remarks about Muslims on the Fox News Channel has emboldened conservative Republican leaders in Congress to demand  once again  an end to federal support for all public broadcasting.

headline: Name That Candidate
text: The end of an election season is always thick with regrets. Do you think Meg Whitman is contemplating all the other things she could have done with $141 million? Does the Republican candidate for the United States Senate in West Virginia kick himself for allowing his wife to establish a voting residence in Florida?

headline: Judges and Money
text: This fall’s round of state judicial elections is setting records of the wrong kind. Extravagant spending by interest groups out to influence judicial decisions and snarling television and radio attack ads have long become routine. This year, the virus has spread to retention elections, in which states ask for a yes-or-no vote on whether to grant sitting justices another term.

headline: Voting on the Fine Print
text: Add this to the challenges for New York City’s voters on Tuesday: On the back of the ballot, in excruciatingly fine print, are two yes-or-no questions about changing the city’s charter.

headline: Ehud Netzer, Archeologist Who Unearthed Herod’s Tomb, Dies at 76
text: JERUSALEM — Ehud Netzer, one of Israel’s best-known archeologists who unearthed King Herod’s tomb near Bethlehem three years ago, died on Thursday after being injured in a fall at the site. He was 76.

headline: Photo Replay: Oct. 29
text: From the women’s volleyball world championships to the N.B.A.’s courts, scenes from the day in sports.

headline: Weekly Pick ‘Em: The End Is In Sight
text: There’s still a long way to go in the regular season, but not that long. For Michigan State and Missouri — both unbeaten and among the biggest surprises in college football — Saturday could be a day of reckoning. Both face stern tests on the road (with the Spartans at Iowa and the Tigers at Nebraska). But if they get past this weekend, both will be favored in their remaining games, not counting a potential Big 12 title game for Missouri. Of course, they both have to get past Saturday.

headline: For Campaign Workers, It’s Their Busy Season
text: For all the artifice and attack ads, political campaigns still rely on dedicated workers who set aside their lives, sometimes without pay, to drive the elderly to the polls, to network with wealthy donors, to pipe up on their behalf in remote precincts — to believe, sometimes when few others do.

headline: Despite Money, Medals and Records, Gebrselassie Remains Motivated
text: Haile Gebrselassie of Ethiopia has no chance of lowering his world record on the tough, undulating course at the New York City Marathon, but that does not mean he is finished, even at age 37, with attempting to limbo under his current mark of 2 hours 3 minutes 59 seconds.

headline: A Dark Transformation to Strains of ‘Swan Lake’
text: “WHEN I started thinking about ‘Swan Lake,’ ” said Darren Aronofsky, whose new film, “Black Swan,” is about a young dancer wrestling with the demanding lead role in that ballet, “a dancer, I think Julie Kent, said to me that the story is really about a girl who gets caught by an evil magician who turns her into a swan during the day and a half-swan, half-human at night. It popped into my head, ‘Oh, a were-swan.’ And I realized I was making a werewolf movie.”

headline: Rex Ryan on the Cablevision-Fox Dispute

headline: U.S. Hunts for More Suspicious Packages
text: WASHINGTON  Two packages containing explosives, shipped from Yemen and addressed to synagogues in Chicago, were intercepted in Britain and Dubai, setting off a broad terrorism scare on Friday that included the scrambling of fighter jets to accompany a passenger flight as it landed safely in New York. On Friday, President Obama said the explosives represented a “credible terrorist threat” to the United States while Janet Napolitano, secretary of the Homeland Security, said on Saturday morning that the plot “has the hallmarks of Al Qaeda.”The discovery of the explosives packed in toner cartridges for computer printers, based on a tip from Saudi intelligence officials, began an urgent hunt for other suspicious packages in the United States and other countries.

headline: The Moral Equivalent of Stagflation
text: Martin Fackler and Steve Lohr have a good article this morning on parallels between the United States and Japan; regular readers know that I’ve been on this for more than two years. And the possibility of such a parallel was the main theme of the original version of The Return of Depression Economics, which I wrote way back in 1999. Domo arigato, Bernanke-san.

headline: Did Obama Really Cut Small-Business Taxes 16 Times?
text: On Monday, President Obama visited yet another small business, American Cord & Webbing, which manufactures hardware for outdoor gear in Woonsocket, R.I. He was there to talk about his two principal accomplishments on behalf of small businesses — easier access to loans and tax relief. He told the audience, and the assembled reporters: “We’ve now passed, with the help of these outstanding members of Congress, 16 different tax cuts for America’s small businesses over the last couple years.”

headline: Q&A With John Elway
text: John Elway, the former Denver Broncos quarterback who won two of the five Super Bowls he played in, was enshrined into Pro Football’s Hall of Fame in 2004. Elway, 50, owns two steakhouses in Denver and three auto dealerships in California. He is also helping to promote the Topps Gridiron Giveaway, in which collectors can win vintage Topps football cards and memorabilia.

headline: U.S. Sees Complexity of Bombs as Link to Al Qaeda
text: WASHINGTON  The powerful bombs concealed inside cargo packages and destined for the United States were expertly constructed and unusually sophisticated, American officials said Saturday, further evidence that Al Qaeda’s affiliate in Yemen is steadily improving its abilities to strike on American soil.

headline: A Big Bet on Natural Gas
text: Exxon Mobil is the biggest publicly traded company in the world, but its stock price has been lagging over the last year chiefly because a lot of people wonder why it’s making such a big bet on natural gas.

text: Matt Carothers is the host of “:58 Flat” and “Blinkers Off” on TVG, as well being one its regular analysts. He started playing the horses long before the law allows.

text: It is laughter devoid of inner joy, and weeping without sorrow.

text: The imbroglio over which European nation, or nations, will host the 2018 World Cup is turning into a shouting match between England and Russia, two of the top bidders.

headline: U.S. Works to Ease China-Japan Conflict
text: HANOI, Vietnam  With tensions between China and Japan spilling out at an East Asian summit meeting here, the United States is trying to defuse an escalating diplomatic row over their competing claims to a cluster of small islands in the East China Sea.

headline: Accounting Identities
text: Peter Dorman has a good post on the meaning of deficit misses in Europe, This Is What Accounting Identities Look Like. It meshes with the way I’ve been trying to explain our mess lately; so let me go back to Sam and Janet — that is, to how to think about the role of debt in our problems.

headline: Koreans Reunite at a Red Cross Gathering
text: SEOUL, South Korea  Hundreds of South Koreans, separated from family members in North Korea for more than half a century, were reunited with their relatives on Saturday as a Red Cross gathering got under way at the Diamond Mountain resort in the North.

headline: Urban Forager | Tomato-Pumpkin Mash-Up on a Tree
text: This time of year, persimmon trees across the five boroughs are abundant with fruit. The day that I visited the Brooklyn Botanic Garden to take a look at their very healthy-looking Diospyros virginiana, which the recent hailstorm had stripped of many of its leaves, the tree was filled with tiny, intact, mango-colored clusters of persimmons.

headline: Serenade Rings Out for a Favorite of Giants Fans
text: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Wearing his ever-present smile, Juan Uribe plopped into a chair in the Giants’ clubhouse Friday night, stretched his wrists and reached for a ballpoint pen. Awaiting his signature were 252 baseballs, roughly one for every clutch hit or sparkling defensive play that has elevated him to the status of folk hero in San Francisco over the last three weeks.

headline: Toeing Line, Not Rubber, and Fulfilling Expectations
text: ARLINGTON, Tex.  As he watched Game 3 of the World Series on Saturday from his home in Jonesboro, Ark., Tommy Raffo recognized the pivotal at-bat by Mitch Moreland of the Texas Rangers. He had seen it before.

headline: For-Profit Schools, Tested Again
text: LAST week was challenging for the Apollo Group, the big for-profit education company that runs the University of Phoenix, Western International University and other institutions. One reason is that the Obama administration instituted new rules barring pay-for-enrollment deals among student recruiters at for-profit colleges  a development that is likely to cause significantly lower enrollment levels at Apollo and its peers.

headline: Finding Her Way a Step at a Time
text: FLAGSTAFF, Ariz.  Alicia Shay occasionally finds herself across town, crying in front of the house that she and her husband once shared on Ponderosa Parkway. She cannot bring herself to pull their two favorite George Strait compact discs out of the changer in the Ford pickup. They have been in there for years.

headline: Putting Himself Up for Re-Election (by His Staff)
text: This interview with Arkadi Kuhlmann, chairman and president of ING Direct USA, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Aggressive Compulsive: Harrison Walks Alone
text: PITTSBURGH  He finally learned the complex Pittsburgh Steelers defense a few years ago with the help of two wristbands, base defenses scribbled on one, Dick LeBeau’s myriad blitzes on the other. But when the N.F.L. told linebacker James Harrison 12 days ago that the way he thought he had always tackled was wrong, he reacted not with the studied determination it took for him to make it to the league, but with the ferocity that has propelled him to the elite of defensive players.

text: My father, Michael, was a former volleyball player who competed in the 1964 Olympics in Tokyo. He worked for the 1984 Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee .

text: TO understand the thinking behind Chris Lindland’s company, Betabrand, you need to keep three seemingly disparate ideas in your head at the same time: 1) It’s a challenge for Web-only businesses to sell clothing. 2) Most people want to be witty. 3) Some shoppers go crazy for limited-edition goods. (Think Beanie Babies.)

headline: Tea Party Kingmaker Becomes Power Unto Himself
text: On election night last year, South Carolina’s freshman senator, Jim DeMint, convened a conference call with 4,000 supporters to declare the next battle: conservatives had to rally behind Marco Rubio, a relative unknown who was trailing the establishment candidate in the Republican Senate primary in Florida.

headline: China’s Fast Rise Leads Neighbors to Join Forces

text: DO one assigned task on your computer. It shouldn’t take you more than two seconds. Repeat 14,399 times. Congratulations! Your eight-hour work day is complete.
